<h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="A">A</a></font></h1>
<p></p><dl><dt><a name="aacr1"><b><em>AACR</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#anglo"><b>A</b>nglo-<b>A</b>merican <b>C</b>ataloging <b>R</b>ules</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aacr2"><b><em>AACR2</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#anglo"><b>A</b>nglo-<b>A</b>merican <b>C</b>ataloging <b>R</b>ules</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aacr2e"><b><em>AACR2-e</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#anglo"><b>A</b>nglo-<b>A</b>merican <b>C</b>ataloging <b>R</b>ules</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aacr2r"><b><em>AACR2R</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#anglo"><b>A</b>nglo-<b>A</b>merican <b>C</b>ataloging <b>R</b>ules</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aahsl1"><b>AAHSL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aahsl"><b>A</b>ssociation of <b>A</b>cademic <b>H</b>ealth <b>S</b>ciences <b>L</b>ibraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aall1"><b>AALL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aall"><b>A</b>merican <b>A</b>ssociation of <b>L</b>aw <b>L</b>ibraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aap1"><b>AAP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aap"><b>A</b>ssociation of <b>A</b>merican <b>P</b>ublishers</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aas1"><b>AAS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aas"><b>A</b>merican <b>A</b>ntiquarian <b>S</b>ociety</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aasl1"><b>AASL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aasl"><b>A</b>merican <b>A</b>ssociation of <b>S</b>chool <b>L</b>ibrarians</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aaup1"><b>AAUP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aaup"><b>A</b>merican <b>A</b>ssociation of <b>U</b>niversity <b>P</b>rofessors</a> and <a href="#aaupress"><b>A</b>ssociation of <b>A</b>merican <b>U</b>niversity <b>P</b>resses</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aba1"><b>ABA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aba"><b>A</b>merican <b>B</b>ooksellers <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abaa1"><b>ABAA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#abaa"><b>A</b>ntiquarian <b>B</b>ooksellers <b>A</b>ssociation of <b>A</b>merica</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abbookmans"><b><em>AB Bookman's Weekly</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#tradejournal">trade publication</a> used mainly by <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s to locate <a href="#rarebook">rare</a>, <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>, and difficult to find <a href="#title">titles</a>, <b><em>AB Bookman's Weekly</em></b> began as a section of <em><a href="#publishersweekly">Publisher's Weekly</a></em> under the title <em>Antiquarian Bookman</em>.  In 1948 it became an independent <a href="#weekly">weekly</a> of the same title <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>. <a href="#publication">Publication</a> under the current title began in 1967. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abbreviation"><b>abbreviation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened form of a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> used for brevity in place of the whole, consisting of the first <a href="#letter">letter</a>, or the first few letters, followed by a <a href="#period">period</a> (<a href="#fullstop">full stop</a>), for example, <b>assoc.</b> for <em>association</em> or <b>P.O.</b> for <em>post office</em>.  Some <a href="#term">term</a>s have more than one abbreviation (<b>v.</b> or <b>vol.</b> for <em>volume</em>).  Abbreviated <em>abbr</em>.
<p>
Also used as an umbrella <a href="#term">term</a> for any shortened form of a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, not an <a href="#acronym">acronym</a>, <a href="#initialism">initialism</a>, or <a href="#contraction">contraction</a>, for example, the postal code <b>CT</b> for Connecticut.  The rules governing the use of abbreviations in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> <a href="#entry">entries</a> are given in <em>Appendix B</em> of <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abcbook"><b>ABC book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#abecedarium">abecedarium</a> and <a href="#alphabetbook">alphabet book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abecedarium"><b>abecedarium</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> containing the <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> and basic rules of spelling and grammar, used in Europe as a <a href="#primer">primer</a> before the invention of the <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a>.  Early <a href="#printing">printed</a> examples (sometimes in the form of a <a href="#broadsheet">broadsheet</a>) displayed the alphabet in <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> and <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> letters in both <a href="#roman">roman</a> and <a href="#gothic">gothic</a> <a href="#type">type</a>, with separate lists of vowels, dipthongs, and consonants.  By 1700, some ABC books included children's <a href="#nurseryrhyme">rhyme</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>abecedary</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#hornbook">horn book</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abecedarius"><b>abecedarius</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#acrostic">acrostic</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aberrantcopy"><b>aberrant copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> containing obvious <a href="#printing">printing</a> and/or <a href="#bindingerror">binding error</a>s which are more serious than minor defects.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abf1"><b>ABF</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#abf"><b>A</b>ssociation des <b>b</b>ibliothecaires <b>f</b>rancais</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aboutness"><b>aboutness</b></a>
</dt><dd>The totality of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s explicitly or implicitly addressed in the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a>, including but not limited to the meaning(s) of the <a href="#title">title</a>, the stated and unstated intentions of the <a href="#author">author</a>, and the ways in which the <a href="#information">information</a> may be used by <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.  Levels of <a href="#specificity">specificity</a> must be considered in ascertaining the subject(s) of a <a href="#work">work</a>.  In the case of the hypothetical <a href="#title">title</a> <b><em>The Japanese Teamwork Approach to Improving High School Effectiveness</em></b>, is the work about:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd>1.  education?
</dd><dd>2.  educational effectiveness?
</dd><dd>3.  high school effectiveness?
</dd><dd>4.  teamwork?
</dd><dd>5.  a Japanese approach to teamwork?</dd></dl>
<p>
As a general rule, <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s and <a href="#index">index</a>ers assign the most specific <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s that describe the significant <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  In a <a href="#postcoordinate">post-coordinate</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> system such as the one used in <em><a href="#eric">ERIC</a></em>, the <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s
"Educational effectiveness," "High schools," "Japan," and "Teamwork"
would probably be assigned to the example given above, but in a <a href="#precoordinate">pre-coordinate</a> system, such as the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject heading</a>s list, the appropriate <a href="#heading">heading</a>s might be "High schools--Japan," "Teacher effectiveness--Japan," and "Teaching teams--Japan."  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#summarization">summarization</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abovethefold"><b>above the fold</b></a>
</dt><dd>The half of a <a href="#broadsheet">broadsheet</a> <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> that appears above the horizontal fold.  <a href="#article">Article</a>s <a href="#printing">printed</a> near the top have greater prominence because most <a href="#language">language</a>s are read from top to bottom of <a href="#page">page</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abridged"><b>abridged</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adc"><b>Abridged Decimal Classification (ADC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened version of <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> developed for use in small <a href="#library">libraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abridgment"><b>abridgment</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened version or <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a written <a href="#work">work</a>, which preserves the overall meaning and manner of presentation of the <a href="#original">original</a> but omits the less important passages of <a href="#text">text</a>, and usually the <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#note">note</a>s,  and <a href="#appendix">appendices</a>.  Often prepared by a person other than the original <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#editor">editor</a>, an <em>abridged edition</em> is generally intended for <a href="#reader">reader</a>s unlikely to purchase the <a href="#unabridged">unabridged</a> version because of its length, complexity, or <a href="#listprice">price</a> (<em>example</em>: <b><em>The New Shorter Oxford English Dictionary</em></b>).  Also spelled <em>abridgement</em>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>abr</em>.  Synonymous with <em>condensation</em>.  Compare with <a href="#simplifiededition">simplified edition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>, <a href="#brief">brief</a>, <a href="#digest">digest</a>, <a href="#epitome">epitome</a>, <a href="#summary">summary</a>, and <a href="#synopsis">synopsis</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="absenteeism"><b>absenteeism</b></a>
</dt><dd>The failure of an employee to report for work, usually due to
illness, accident, family responsibilities, or personal business. A
persistently high rate of absenteeism may be a sign of low morale among
the <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#burnout">burnout</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="absolutehumidity"><b>absolute humidity</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#humidity">humidity</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="absorbency"><b>absorbency</b></a>
</dt><dd>The capacity of <a href="#paper">paper</a> to absorb and retain moisture, which varies with type of paper, and is of particular importance in <a href="#printing">printing</a> processes that use liquid <a href="#ink">ink</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#waterdamaged">water-damaged</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="absorption"><b>absorption</b></a>
</dt><dd>The assimilation of one <a href="#serial">serial</a> by another.  The <a href="#note">note</a> <em>Absorbed:</em> followed by the <a href="#title">title</a> of the assimilated serial is added to the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing the assimilating <a href="#publication">publication</a>, and the corresponding note <em>Absorbed by:</em> giving the title of the assimilating serial is added to the record for the assimilated publication.  Compare with <a href="#merger">merger</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abstract"><b>abstract</b></a>       
</dt><dd>A brief, objective summary of the essential <a href="#content">content</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#article">article</a>, speech, <a href="#report">report</a>, <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a>, or other <a href="#work">work</a>, which presents the main points in the same order as the <a href="#original">original</a>, but has no independent literary value.  An abstract can be <a href="#indicativeabstract">indicative</a>, <a href="#infoabstract">informative</a>, <a href="#criticalabstract">critical</a>, or written from a particular point of view (slanted).  In a scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a> article, the abstract follows the <a href="#title">title</a> and the name(s) of the <a href="#author">author</a>(s), and precedes the <a href="#text">text</a>.  In an <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, the abstract accompanies the <a href="#citation">citation</a>.  Compare with <a href="#summary">summary</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#authorabstract">author abstract</a> and <a href="#abstractingjournal">abstracting journal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abstracting"><b>abstracting</b></a>
</dt><dd>The preparation of a brief, objective statement (<a href="#abstract">abstract</a>) of the <a href="#content">content</a> of a written <a href="#work">work</a>, to enable the <a href="#research">research</a>er to quickly determine whether reading the entire <a href="#text">text</a> might satisfy the specific <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>.  Abstracting is usually limited to the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of a specific <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or group of related disciplines, and is performed by an individual or commercial entity, such as an <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>, that provides abstracts regularly to a list of <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abstractingjournal"><b>abstracting journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#journal">journal</a> that specializes in providing <a href="#summary">summaries</a> (called <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>s) of <a href="#article">article</a>s and other <a href="#document">document</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> within the scope of a specific academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or <a href="#field">field</a> of study (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Peace Research Abstracts Journal</em></b>).  Compare with <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abstractingservice"><b>abstracting service</b></a>    
</dt><dd>A commercial <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> service that provides both a <a href="#citation">citation</a> and a brief <a href="#summary">summary</a> or <a href="#abstract">abstract</a> of the <a href="#content">content</a> of each <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#index">index</a>ed (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="#isa">Information Science Abstracts</a></em>).  Numbered consecutively in order of addition, <a href="#entry">entries</a> are <a href="#issue">issue</a>d <a href="#serial">serially</a> in <a href="#printing">print</a>, usually in <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> or <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>s, or in a regularly <a href="#updated">updated</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> available by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>.  Abstracting services can be <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> or <a href="#selective">selective</a> within a specific academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or subdiscipline.  Compare with <a href="#abstractingjournal">abstracting journal</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="academicfreedom"><b>academic freedom</b></a>
</dt><dd>The principle that faculty members employed at institutions of higher education (including <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s with <a href="#facultystatus">faculty status</a>) should remain free to express their views and teach in the manner of their own choosing, without interference from <a href="#administration">administration</a>, government, or outside organizations which may have an axe to grind. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="academiclib"><b>academic library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> that is an integral part of a college, university, or other institution of post-secondary education, <a href="#libadmin">administered</a> to meet the <a href="#information">information</a> and <a href="#research">research</a> needs of its students, faculty, and staff.  In the United States, the professional <a href="#libassociation">association</a> for academic libraries and <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s is the <a href="#acrl">Association of College and Research Libraries</a> (ACRL).  <a href="http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/libweb/Academic_main.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>Libweb</em></b> list of academic libraries in the United States.  Compare with <a href="#researchlib">research library</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#collegelibrary">college library</a>, <a href="#departmentallib">departmental library</a>, <a href="#gradlib">graduate library</a>, <a href="#undergradlib">undergraduate library</a>, and <a href="#universitylib">university library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="academicpress"><b>academic press</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#universitypress">university press</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acadstatus"><b>academic status</b></a>
</dt><dd>Recognition given by an institution of higher education that the <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s in its employ are considered members of the teaching or <a href="#research">research</a> staff, but are <em>not</em> entitled to <a href="#rank">rank</a>s, <a href="#title">title</a>s, rights, and <a href="#benefits">benefits</a> equivalent to those of faculty.  Compare with <a href="#facultystatus">faculty status</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acanthus"><b>acanthus</b></a>
</dt><dd>A representation of the elegant leaf-form of <em>Acanthus spinosus</em>,
a species of herbaceous plant native to the Mediterranean region, used
by the ancient Greeks to ornament Corinthian capitals, and as a
decorative <a href="#motif">motif</a> in the <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a>s and <a href="#border">border</a>s of medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, where it is often found painted in a unrealistic colors (red, yellow, purple, blue).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acceptableuse"><b>acceptable use policy</b></a>
</dt><dd>Guidelines established by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> concerning the manner in which its computer systems and equipment may be used, for example, most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> forbid the use of public <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>s for commercial or unlawful activities.  In most libraries, a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a>
of acceptable use policy is posted near the workstations to which the
restrictions apply. Some libraries also make the statement available on
their <a href="#website">Web site</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="access"><b>access</b></a>
</dt><dd>The right of entry to a <a href="#library">library</a> or its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  All <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> and most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> in the United States are open to the general public, but access to certain areas such as <a href="#closedstacks">closed stacks</a>, <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s, and <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>
may be restricted. In a more general sense, the right or opportunity to
use a resource which may not be openly and freely available to
everyone. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#accessibility">accessibility</a>.
<p>
In computing, the privilege of using a computer system or <a href="#online">online</a> resource, usually controlled by the issuance of <a href="#accesscode">access code</a>s to <a href="#authorization">authorized</a> users.  In a more general sense, the ability of a user to reach <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#storage">stored</a> on a computer or computer system.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accesscode"><b>access code</b></a>
</dt><dd>An identification code, such as a <a href="#username">username</a>, <a href="#password">password</a>, or <a href="#pin">PIN</a> which a user must enter correctly to gain <a href="#access">access</a> to a computer system or <a href="#network">network</a>.  In most <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> systems, access codes are tightly controlled to exclude un<a href="#authorization">authorized</a> users.  Synonymous with <em>authorization code</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accessibility"><b>accessibility</b></a>
</dt><dd>The ease with which a person may enter a <a href="#library">library</a>, gain <a href="#access">access</a> to its <a href="#online">online</a> systems, use its resources, and obtain needed <a href="#information">information</a> regardless of its <a href="#format">format</a>.  In a more general sense, the quality of being able to be located and used by someone.  
<p>
In <a href="#isar">information storage and retrieval</a>, the manner in which a computer system retrieves <a href="#record">record</a>s from a <a href="#file">file</a>, which usually depends on the method of their arrangement in or on the <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accession"><b>accession</b></a>
</dt><dd>To <a href="#record">record</a> in an <a href="#accessionrecord">accession list</a> that a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> has been added to a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  Also refers to the <a href="#document">document</a> added.  The process of making additions is known as <em>accessions</em>.  The opposite of <a href="#deaccession">deaccession</a>.  Compare with <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#accessionnumber">accession number</a>. 
<p>
In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the formal act of accepting and <a href="#documentation">documenting</a> the receipt of <a href="#records">records</a> taken into <a href="#custody">custody</a>, part of the process of establishing physical and intellectual control over them.  In the case of donated items, a <a href="#deedofgift">deed of gift</a> may be required to transfer legal title.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accessionlist"><b>accession list</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#accessionrecord">accession record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accessionnumber"><b>accession number</b></a>
</dt><dd>A unique <a href="#number">number</a> assigned to a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> in the order in which it is added to a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, recorded in an <a href="#accessionrecord">accession record</a> maintained by the <a href="#technicalservices">technical services</a> department.  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a>
assign accession numbers in continuous numerical sequence, but some use
a code system to indicate type of material and/or year of <a href="#accession">accession</a>, in addition to order of accession.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#lccn">Library of Congress Control Number</a> and <a href="#oclccontrol">OCLC control number</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accessionorder"><b>accession order</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> of <a href="#book">book</a>s or other <a href="#document">document</a>s on shelves in the <a href="#chronological">chronological</a> and numerical order of their <em>addition</em> to a specific category or <a href="#class">class</a>, as opposed to an arrangement based entirely on a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accessionrecord"><b>accession record</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>s added to a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> in the order of their addition.  Normally such a list includes the <a href="#accessionnumber">accession number</a>, brief bibliographic identification, <a href="#source">source</a>, and <a href="#price">price</a> paid for each item.  Synonymous with <em>accession catalog</em>, <em>accession register</em>, and <em>accession list</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accesspoint"><b>access point</b></a>
</dt><dd>A unit of <a href="#information">information</a> in a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> under which a person may <a href="#search">search</a> for and identify <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s listed in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>.  Access points have traditionally included the <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a>, <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a>, <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s, <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> or <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>, and codes such as the <a href="#standardnumber">standard number</a>, but with <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> almost any portion of the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> (name of <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, type of material, etc.) can be used as an access point.  In the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record, most access points are found the following <a href="#field">field</a>s, with XX in the range of 00-99:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>1XX</b> - Main entries
</dd><dd><b>4XX</b> - <a href="#seriesstatement">Series statement</a>s
</dd><dd><b>6XX</b> - Subject headings
</dd><dd><b>7XX</b> - Added entries other than subject or <a href="#series">series</a> 
</dd><dd><b>8XX</b> - Series added entries</dd></dl>
<p>
In a more general sense, any unique <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a> that serves as a point of entry to an organized <a href="#file">file</a> of information.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accesspolicy"><b>access policy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal written statement issued by the person(s) or body responsible for managing <a href="#archives">archives</a> or <a href="#specialcollections">special collection</a>s, specifying which <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> are available for <a href="#access">access</a> and by whom, including any conditions or restrictions on use, usually posted or distributed in some manner to users. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accessservices"><b>access services</b></a>
</dt><dd>The provision of <a href="#access">access</a> to a <a href="#library">library</a>'s resources and <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, which includes the <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> (general circulation, <a href="#reserves">reserves</a>, <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>, <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery</a>), <a href="#reshelving">reshelving</a>, <a href="#stackmaintenance">stack maintenance</a>, and <a href="#security">security</a>.  Large libraries employ an <em>access services librarian</em> to manage these activities.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accesstime"><b>access time</b></a>
</dt><dd>The amount of time it takes a computer system to provide <a href="#storage">stored</a> <a href="#data">data</a> to a person who <a href="#logon">logs on</a> and follows correct procedures for retrieval.  Access time may be slower during periods of <a href="#peakuse">peak use</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accompanying"><b>accompanying material</b></a>
</dt><dd>Related material <a href="#issue">issue</a>d with an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, for example, a <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, <a href="#slide">slide</a> set, answer <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#teachersmanual">teacher's manual</a>, <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>, or <a href="#portfolio">portfolio</a> of <a href="#print">print</a>s or <a href="#plate">plate</a>s intended by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to be used and stored with it, often in a pocket inside the <a href="#cover">cover</a> or loose inside the <a href="#container">container</a>.  When such an item is <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a>, the presence of accompanying material is indicated in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accordion"><b>accordion fold</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#concertina">concertina</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accountability"><b>accountability</b></a>
</dt><dd>The extent to which persons in government and the workplace
are held answerable for their conduct in office, and for the quality of
their performance of assigned duties, particularly when incompetence,
dereliction, or malfeasance is at issue. <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#performanceeval">performance evaluation</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accreditation"><b>accreditation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The regular evaluation process by which an educational or
service organization establishes that its program of study or services,
or the institution as a whole, meets certain pre-existing <a href="#standards">standards</a> of quality.  In the United States, institutions of higher learning are evaluated by regional accrediting bodies, and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> are evaluated as part of the institutional accreditation process.  The formal evaluation of individual competence is called <a href="#certification">certification</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#accredited">accedited library school</a> and <a href="#credential">credential</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accredited"><b>accredited library school</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the United States, a <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> offering a degree program regularly evaluated by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> and found to meet established <a href="#standards">standards</a> of quality, as opposed to an <em>approved library school</em> offering a program recognized or certified by a state board or educational <a href="#agency">agency</a> as meeting its standards.  Some approved <a href="#library">library</a> schools are also ALA-<a href="#accreditation">accredited</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="accuracy"><b>accuracy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The quality of correctness as to fact and precision as to detail in <a href="#information">information</a> resources and in the delivery of information services.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, it is essential that the resources used by <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s to provide <a href="#refservices">reference service</a> be free of error.  Accuracy is also an important criterion in judging the reliability of information provided on the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  The accuracy of a statement can be verified by checking other sources that provide the same information.  The opposite of <em>inaccuracy</em> (the quality of being incorrect or mistaken).    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acidfree"><b>acid-free</b></a>
</dt><dd>Materials with a <a href="#ph">pH</a> value of 7.0 (neutral) or higher (<a href="#alkaline">alkaline</a>), preferred in <a href="#printing">printing</a> and <a href="#binding">binding</a> to prevent <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> caused by <a href="#acidpaper">acid</a> over time.  Acid-free <a href="#paper">paper</a>s are often <a href="#buffering">buffered</a> to counteract acids that may develop with age as a result of bleaching and <a href="#sizing">sizing</a>, or be introduced through <a href="#acidmigration">acid migration</a> or atmospheric pollution.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acidic"><b>acidic</b></a>
</dt><dd>Substances which have a <a href="#ph">pH</a> value less than 7.0 (neutral).  The main source of <a href="#acidpaper">acid in paper</a> products is <a href="#lignin">lignin</a> contained in wood used for <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>.  Because acid causes the <a href="#paper">paper</a> and <a href="#board">board</a> used in <a href="#printing">printing</a> and <a href="#binding">binding</a> to <a href="#deterioration">deteriorate</a> over time, lignin is removed in all but the lowest-grade papers.  A <a href="#buffering">buffer</a> such as calcium carbonate or magnesium carbonate may be added in <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a> to neutralize acids that develop or are introduced in paper after it is manufactured.  The opposite of <a href="#alkaline">alkaline</a>.  Compare with <a href="#acidfree">acid-free</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acidmigration"><b>acid migration</b></a>
</dt><dd>The movement of acid from a material containing acid to one that is less <a href="#acidic">acidic</a>, <a href="#ph">pH</a> neutral, or <a href="#alkaline">alkaline</a>.  The process can occur through direct contact or vapor transfer.  One of the most common problems in <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> is the migration of acid from the <a href="#board">board</a>s, <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s, or paper <a href="#cover">cover</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> to the less acidic paper of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> (or vice versa).  Acid can also migrate from <a href="#bookplate">bookplate</a>s, <a href="#insert">insert</a>s, <a href="#tissue">tissue</a>s used in <a href="#interleaving">interleaving</a>, and <a href="#label">label</a>s that are not <a href="#acidfree">acid-free</a>.  The result may be <a href="#yellowing">discoloration</a> and eventual em<a href="#brittle">brittle</a>ment.  The process can be arrested by removing the contaminating material and subjecting the <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>(s) or <a href="#volume">volume</a> to <a href="#deacidification">deacidification</a>.  Synonymous with <em>acid transfer</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bufferedpaper">buffered paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acidpaper"><b>acid paper</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#paper">Paper</a> that has a <a href="#ph">pH</a> value less than 7.0 (neutral).  The primary source of acid in paper is <a href="#lignin">lignin</a>, an organic substance contained in untreated wood <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>, but acid can also develop from the addition of certain types of <a href="#sizing">sizing</a> or from residual chlorine used in bleaching.  It can also be introduced by <a href="#acidmigration">acid migration</a> or atmospheric pollution (sulphur dioxide).  Because <a href="#acidic">acidity</a> weakens the <a href="#cellulose">cellulose</a> in plant fiber, it can cause paper, <a href="#board">board</a>, and <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> to <a href="#yellowing">yellow</a> and become <a href="#brittle">brittle</a> over time, making it an important factor in the <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> of <a href="#printing">printed</a> materials.  To ensure <a href="#durability">durability</a>, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s are encouraged to use <a href="#acidfree">acid-free</a> <a href="#permanentpaper">permanent paper</a> in printing <a href="#tradeedition">trade book</a>s.  <a href="#buffering">Buffering</a>
helps neutralize acids that develop after manufacture. Acid can be
removed from fiber-based materials by means of an expensive process
called <a href="#deacidification">deacidification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acidtransfer"><b>acid transfer</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#acidmigration">acid migration</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acknowledgments"><b>acknowledgments</b></a>
</dt><dd>The section of the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#author">author</a> gives formal recognition to the contributions others have made to the <a href="#work">work</a>.  The acknowledgments usually follow the <a href="#preface">preface</a> or <a href="#foreword">foreword</a> and precede the <a href="#introduction">introduction</a>.  Some authors include their acknowledgments in the preface.  Also spelled <em>acknowledgements</em>.  Compare with <a href="#dedication">dedication</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acquisitionnumber"><b>acquisition number</b></a>
</dt><dd>A unique <a href="#number">number</a> used by the <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> department of a <a href="#library">library</a> to identify a specific <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> on a <a href="#purchaseorder">purchase order</a>.  Some libraries use a <a href="#standardnumber">standard number</a> such as the <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a> (International Standard Book Number) or <a href="#issn">ISSN</a> (International Standard Serial Number) as the acquisition number.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acquisitions"><b>acquisitions</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of <a href="#selection">selecting</a>, ordering, and receiving <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> for <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s by purchase, <a href="#exchange">exchange</a>, or <a href="#gift">gift</a>, which may include <a href="#budget">budget</a>ing and negotiating with outside <a href="#agency">agencies</a>, such as <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>s, and <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s, to obtain resources to meet the needs of the institution's <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>, in the most economical and expeditious manner.  
<p>
Also refers to the department within a library responsible for
selecting, ordering, and receiving new materials, and for maintaining
accurate <a href="#records">records</a> of such transactions, usually managed by an <em>acquisitions librarian</em>.  In small libraries, the acquisitions <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> may also be responsible for <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>, but in most <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>
this responsibility is shared by all the librarians who have an
interest in collection building, usually on the basis of their
expertise and <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#accession">accessions</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#alcts">ALCTS</a>.
</p><p>
For a more detailed description of the responsibilities entailed in acquisitions, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> by Liz Chapman in the <b><em>International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science</em></b> (1997) <a href="#editor">edited</a> by John Feather and Paul Sturges.  <a href="http://acqweb.library.vanderbilt.edu/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of <b>AcqWeb</b>, an <a href="#online">online</a> resource for acquisitions and collection development librarians. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acrl1"><b>ACRL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#acrl"><b>A</b>ssociation of <b>C</b>ollege and <b>R</b>esearch <b>L</b>ibraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acrobat"><b><em>Acrobat</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#adobeacrobat">Adobe Acrobat</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acronym"><b>acronym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A new name or word (<a href="#neologism">neologism</a>) that is pronounceable and hence memorable, coined from the first or first few <a href="#letter">letter</a>s or parts of a <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> or compound <a href="#term">term</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>ERIC</b> for <b>E</b>ducational <b>R</b>esources <b>I</b>nformation <b>C</b>enter).  Compare with <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> and <a href="#initialism">initialism</a>.  
<p>
<a href="http://dir.yahoo.com/Reference/Acronyms_and_Abbreviations/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of <a href="#online">online</a> acronym and abbreviation finders.    
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acrostic"><b>acrostic</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#poetry">verse</a> or list of words composed in such a way that certain <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of each line (usually the first and/or last), when read in order of appearance, spell a word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, or sentence.  An <em>abecedarius</em> is an acrostic in which the pattern consists of the letters of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> in traditional order.  An acrostic can be <em>single</em>, <em>double</em>, or <em>triple</em>, depending on how many words in each line are composed in this way.  As a matter of policy, <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> and <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <a href="#editor">editor</a>s routinely check verses for acrostics prior to <a href="#publication">publication</a> to avoid embarrassment.  The following well-known example is an <em>all around</em> acrostic in Latin:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>R O T A S
</b></dd><dd><b>O P E R A
</b></dd><dd><b>T E N E T
</b></dd><dd><b>A R E P O
</b></dd><dd><b>S A T O R</b></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="act"><b>act</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of the major divisions in the action of a <a href="#play">play</a>,
usually marked by the dropping of the curtain, followed by an
intermission. In modern drama, most plays are divided into three acts
which may be further subdivided into <em>scenes</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#oneactplay">one-act play</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a piece of legislation (a <a href="#bill">bill</a>) after it has been passed into law (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="#dmca">Digital Millennium Copyright Act of 1998</a></em>).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="actadiurna"><b><em>Acta Diurna</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#daily">daily</a> <a href="#gazette">gazette</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a>
in ancient Rome from the period of the late Republic onward, devoted
primarily to matters of state (official events, public speeches, legal
proceedings, public building projects, major military actions) and
announcements of births, marriages, and deaths. It also contained news
of unusual occurrences (earthquakes, strange accidents, portents) and <a href="#information">information</a> about the private lives of prominent persons (scandals, divorces, lawsuits).  
<p>
The <a href="#text">text</a> was posted on public buildings and <a href="#copy">copies</a> were made for wealthy Romans living in the city and provinces, or away temporarily on public business.  The <em>actuarii</em>
responsible for gathering the news were sometimes misled by persons
intent on manipulating commodity markets and political events for
personal gain. Surviving fragments, preserved in the writings of
Petronius, read very much like a modern <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="actingedition"><b>acting edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#play">play</a>
intended for the use of actors and others directly involved in theater
production, which includes fuller stage directions (entrances, exits,
stage properties, etc.) than one intended for reading, usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#limpbinding">limp</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s and <a href="#listprice">price</a>d lower than other editions of the same <a href="#work">work</a>.  Compare with <a href="#script">script</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="activerecords"><b>active records</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#records">Records</a> required by an <a href="#agency">agency</a>
or individual to function effectively on a daily basis, usually kept
close at hand, organized in a manner that renders them readily <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a>.  Synonymous with <em>current records</em>.  The opposite of <a href="#inactiverecords">inactive records</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#intermediaterecords">intermediate records</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="activerelation"><b>active relation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ada1"><b><em>ADA</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#ada"><b>A</b>mericans with <b>D</b>isabilities <b>A</b>ct</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adaptation"><b>adaptation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> that has been <a href="#editing">edit</a>ed or <a href="#rewrite">rewritten</a>, in part or in its entirety, for a new use, <a href="#audience">audience</a>, or purpose.  Also, a work converted to another literary form or artistic <a href="#medium">medium</a> to serve a different or related purpose, while retaining as much of the action, <a href="#character">character</a>s, <a href="#language">language</a>, and tone of the <a href="#original">original</a> as possible, for example, a <a href="#novel">novel</a> adapted for performance on the stage, a <a href="#play">play</a> adapted for the <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> screen, or an <a href="#engraving">engraving</a> based on a painting.  Under <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, adaptations of <a href="#text">text</a>s are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under the name of the <em>adapter</em>, or under the <a href="#title">title</a> if the adapter is unknown, with a <a href="#nametitleadded">name-title added entry</a> for the <a href="#original">original</a> work.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>adapt</em>.
<p>
In music, a work which is a distinct alteration of another <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> (<em>example</em>:  a free <a href="#transcribe">transcription</a>), or that <a href="#paraphrase">paraphrase</a>s parts of various works or imitates the style of another <a href="#composer">composer</a>, or is somehow based on another musical work (<em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adc1"><b>ADC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#adc"><b>A</b>bridged <b>D</b>ecimal <b>C</b>lassification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="addedcopy"><b>added copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> already owned by a <a href="#library">library</a>, added to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> usually when <a href="#demand">demand</a> warrants.  Compare with <a href="#duplicate">duplicate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="addededition"><b>added edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> added to a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, which is not the same as editions of the same <a href="#title">title</a> already owned by the <a href="#library">library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="addedentry"><b>added entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> other than the <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a>, usually one that adds a <a href="#heading">heading</a> for a <a href="#jointauthor">joint author</a>, <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>, <a href="#translation">translator</a>, <a href="#series">series</a>, or <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  Synonymous with <em>secondary entry</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nametitleadded">name-title added entry</a> and <a href="#tracings">tracings</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="addedtitlepage"><b>added title page</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> preceding or following the one that the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> uses as the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a> in creating the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  It can be more general (a <a href="#seriestitlepage">series title page</a>) or of equivalent generality (a title page in a different <a href="#language">language</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="addendum"><b>addendum</b></a>
</dt><dd>Brief <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a>, less extensive than a <a href="#supplement">supplement</a> or <a href="#appendix">appendix</a>, included in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> after the <a href="#work">work</a> has been <a href="#typesetting">typeset</a> because it is considered essential to the meaning or completeness of the <a href="#text">text</a>, usually printed separately on a slip of <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#tippedin">tipped in</a> at the beginning or end of the text.  Plural: <em>addenda</em>.  Compare with <a href="#errata">errata</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="addnote"><b>add note</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief note in the <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a>s instructing the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> to append to a given <a href="#basenumber">base number</a> one or more <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s found elsewhere in the <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> in order to <a href="#numberbuilding">build</a> a <a href="#classnumber">class number</a>.  For example, the instruction to "add to base number <b>027.1</b> (<a href="#privatelib">private</a> and family libraries) <a href="#notation">notation</a> from 1-9 from <a href="#table">Table</a> 2, e.g., family libraries in the United Kingdom <b>027.141</b>."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="address"><b>address</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, a <a href="#character">character</a> or set of characters used to identify a specific location in main <a href="#memory">memory</a> or <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> <a href="#storage">storage</a>, usually for the purpose of <a href="#access">access</a>ing stored <a href="#data">data</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adhesive"><b>adhesive</b></a>
</dt><dd>A substance applied to a material to make it stick to another
surface by chemical or mechanical action. Gummed adhesives require
moisture to be effective. Solid at room temperatures, <a href="#hotmelt">hot-melt</a> adhesives liquify when heated and set up quickly as they cool.  Some types of adhesive are <a href="#pressuresensitive">pressure-sensitive</a>.  Adhesives of various kinds are used extensively in <a href="#binding">binding</a> and <a href="#technical">technical processing</a> in <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  In <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>, adhesives are often selected for their <a href="#reversibility">reversibility</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive binding</a>, <a href="#glair">glair</a>, <a href="#glue">glue</a>, <a href="#paste">paste</a>, and <a href="#polyvinylacetate">polyvinyl acetate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adhesivebinding"><b>adhesive binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic <a href="#term">term</a> for <a href="#binding">binding</a> methods in which the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> are held together by a strong <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> applied directly to the <a href="#back">back</a> of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a>, usually done after the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> is <a href="#milling">milled</a>, but sometimes after the <a href="#section">section</a>s are <a href="#sewing">sewn</a>.  The most commonly used adhesives are animal <a href="#glue">glue</a>s, <a href="#hotmelt">hot-melt</a>s, and <a href="#polyvinylacetate">polyvinyl acetate</a> (PVA).  Synonymous with <em>threadless binding</em> and <em>unsewn binding</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doublefan">double-fan adhesive binding</a>, <a href="#notchedbinding">notched binding</a>, <a href="#otabind">Otabind</a>, and <a href="#perfectbinding">perfect binding</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adhoc"><b><em>ad hoc</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for "to this," used to indicate that something was
created or exists for the particular purpose in view at the moment.
Also refers to something organized for a specific purpose, for example,
an <em>ad hoc committee</em> elected or appointed to address a
specific issue or handle an unanticipated contingency, usually
dissolved once the need has been met.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adjacency"><b>adjacency</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#proximity">proximity</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adjunct"><b>adjunct</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> employed <a href="#parttime">part-time</a> in an <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a> at an institution that grants librarians <a href="#facultystatus">faculty status</a>.  Synonymous with <em>part-time faculty</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adjustableshelving"><b>adjustable shelving</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#fixedshelving">fixed shelving</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adloc"><b><em>ad loc.</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin phrase <em>ad locum</em> meaning "at the place [cited]".
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="administration"><b>administration</b></a>
</dt><dd>The range of activities normally associated with the management of a <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>, organization, or institution, such as a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>.  Also refers collectively to the persons responsible for such activity, from <a href="#librarydirector">director</a> to secretary.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#libadmin">library administration</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adminhistory"><b>administrative history</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the part of a <a href="#findingaid">finding aid</a> that provides pertinent <a href="#information">information</a> concerning the <a href="#records">records</a> it lists and describes, such as the history and organizational structure of the <a href="#agency">agency</a>
(or group of related agencies) that generated them, or significant
details in the life and career of the individual or family with which
they are associated, usually in the form of a <a href="#biography">biographical</a> <a href="#note">note</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adminvalue"><b>administrative value</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adobeacrobat"><b><em>Adobe Acrobat</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#document">document</a> exchange <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> created by Adobe Systems which allows <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s created on one <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#platform">platform</a> (<a href="#dos">DOS</a>, <a href="#windows">Windows</a>, <a href="#macintosh">Macintosh</a>, etc.) to be displayed and <a href="#printing">printed</a> on another without loss of <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#formatting">formatting</a>.  This capability is particularly important in communication over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> which interconnects computers of all types and sizes.  Adobe Systems sells the <a href="#software">software</a> required to create or <a href="#dataconversion">convert</a> documents to its <a href="#pdf">Portable Document Format</a>, but does not charge users for the software needed to read PDF documents.  The <b><em>Acrobat Reader</em></b> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> can be <a href="#download">download</a>ed directly from the company <a href="#website">Web site</a> at:  <a href="http://www.adobe.com/support/downloads/main.html">www.adobe.com</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#plugin">plug-in</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adult"><b>adult</b></a>
</dt><dd>A fully grown, mentally competent person of sufficient age to be considered capable of making mature decisions and held legally <a href="#accountability">accountable</a> for the consequences of his (or her) actions.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> operate on the assumption that adult <a href="#patron">patron</a>s
are capable of deciding independently what they wish to read and
borrow. Although it is the responsibility of the parent to supervise
the actions of a child, it is appropriate for <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s to provide guidance to children in the selection of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> suitable to their age level and interests, if asked to do so. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#readersadvisory">readers' advisory</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adulteducation"><b>adult education</b></a>
</dt><dd>Courses designed specifically for <a href="#adult">adult</a>s who have spent their lives outside the system of formal higher education.  Because <a href="#nontraditional">nontraditional student</a>s often lack the <a href="#library">library</a> skills of students who follow a traditional course of study, they may require more assistance at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a> and a more basic level of <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adultlearner"><b>adult learner</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person older than traditional college age, who pursues an
independent, organized course of study, usually without the benefit of
formal instruction at an established educational institution. When
enrolled as a <a href="#nontraditional">nontraditional student</a> at a college or university, such a person may require <a href="#refservices">reference services</a> and <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a> at a more basic level than traditional students.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adultliteracy"><b>adult literacy</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#literacy">literacy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adultservices"><b>adult services</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#libmaterials">Materials</a>, services, and programs intended to meet the needs of the <a href="#adult">adult</a> users of a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>, as opposed to those designed for <a href="#childrensservices">children</a> and <a href="#yaservices">young adult</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#readersadvisory">readers' advisory</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="advancecopy"><b>advance copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> bound in advance of the normal <a href="#pressrun">press run</a> to enable the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to check that all is in order before <a href="#binding">binding</a> of the <a href="#edition">edition</a> proceeds.  Advance copies are also sent to <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, <a href="#bookclub">book club</a> selection committees, and <a href="#review">review</a>ers before the announced <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, sometimes <a href="#unbound">unbound</a> or in a binding other than the <a href="#publishersbinding">publisher's binding</a>, often with a review slip <a href="#laidin">laid in</a>.  Copies sent unbound are known as <em>advance sheets</em>.  Synonymous with <em>early copy</em>.  Compare with <a href="#readingcopy">reading copy</a> and <a href="#reviewcopy">review copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="advanceonroyalty"><b>advance on royalty</b></a>
</dt><dd>An amount paid to the <a href="#author">author</a>(s) of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> prior to its <a href="#publication">publication</a> against the <a href="#royalties">royalties</a> it is expected to earn, usually offered as an inducement to sign a <a href="#bookcontract">book contract</a> with the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  Synonymous with <em>author's advance</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#publishersagreement">publisher's agreement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="advanceorder"><b>advance order</b></a>
</dt><dd>An order placed for a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> prior to its <a href="#publicationdate">date of publication</a>, usually in response to <a href="#prepublication">prepublication</a> promotion.  The number of <a href="#copy">copies</a> ordered in advance may assist the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> in determining the size of the first <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the <a href="#listprice">price</a>, and how much to spend on advertising.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="advancesheet"><b>advance sheet</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#advancecopy">advance copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="advertorial"><b>advertorial</b></a>
</dt><dd>Advertising <a href="#text">text</a> written in <a href="#editorial">editorial</a> style and <a href="#format">format</a>.  To avoid confusion, most <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s add the word "Advertisement" to the <a href="#runninghead">running head</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="adverts"><b>adverts</b></a>
</dt><dd>Advertisements <a href="#binding">bound</a> into a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually at the end of the <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>ads</em> or <em>advrts</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="advocacy"><b>advocacy</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#libraryadvocate">library advocate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aerialmap"><b>aerial map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> of the earth, or of another planetary body, composed of one or more <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s taken from a position above its surface, usually from a passing aircraft, satellite, or space vehicle.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#photomosaic">photomosaic</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="affiliate"><b>affiliate</b></a>
</dt><dd>A separately <a href="#administration">administered</a> organization closely connected with another by formal agreement, for example, the various organizations affiliated with the <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/affiliates/affiliates_home.html">American Library Association</a> (ALA).  Also refers to the process of forming such a link.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#affiliatedlibrary">affiliated library</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="affiliatedlibrary"><b>affiliated library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> which is, by formal agreement, part of a larger <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> but <a href="#libadmin">administered</a> independently by its own <a href="#board">board</a> or management structure.  <a href="#medicallib">Medical</a> and <a href="#lawlibrary">law libraries</a> at large universities often fall into this category.  Compare with <a href="#branchlibrary">branch library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="affirmative"><b>affirmative action</b></a>
</dt><dd>An active effort, begun in the late 1960's, to enhance
opportunities in the United States for minority groups and women,
through federal regulations and programs intended to counteract <a href="#bias">bias</a>
and discrimination in government employment and contracting, and in
admissions to state-supported educational institutions. Most publicly
supported <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the U.S. are affirmative
action employers. The legality of affirmative action has been called
into question by individuals and political groups who believe that
legislating equality discourages initiative and results in reverse
discrimination. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#diversity">diversity</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="againstthegrain"><b>against the grain</b></a>
</dt><dd>A popular expression meaning "contrary to natural inclination" originally used in the <a href="#printing">printing</a> trade to refer to machine-made <a href="#paper">paper</a> folded across the <a href="#grain">grain</a> of its fibers.  In <a href="#book">book</a> production, <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s are printed with the grain running from top to bottom of the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, allowing them to flex easily lengthwise after they are <a href="#binding">bound</a>.  When folded <em>with</em> the grain, paper tears easily and cleanly along the fold.  When folded <em>across</em> the grain, it cracks and leaves a ragged edge when torn. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="atg"><b><em>Against the Grain (ATG)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> providing news about <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>s, and <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agent</a>s, with <a href="#report">report</a>s on the issues, <a href="#literature">literature</a>, and people affecting books and journals.  <a href="http://www.against-the-grain.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>ATG</em></b> homepage. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="agency"><b>agency</b></a>
</dt><dd>For <a href="#archives">archival</a> purposes, any commercial enterprise, organization, institution, or other <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a> that creates and manages <a href="#records">records</a>
of its business, activities, or affairs. In very large organizations,
subordinate units (sections, departments, offices) may function as
separate agencies. In a more general sense, any person (agent) or
organization that has the authority to perform a specific function, for
example, the <a href="#neh">National Endowment for the Humanities</a> (NEH).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="agenda"><b>agenda</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of <a href="#topic">topic</a>s or issues to be
discussed at a meeting, sometimes solicited from prospective attendees
in advance by the person who calls or chairs the meeting. It is
customary to distribute the agenda before the meeting begins, to allow
attendees time to prepare. A <em>hidden agenda</em> is a goal or
intention consciously or unconsciously concealed, usually to gain the
advantage of surprise, a tactic that often backfires when unsuspecting
persons discover that they have been manipulated. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="agent"><b>agent</b></a>
</dt><dd>An individual or company that acts as middle-man between a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> and a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> in the purchase of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, for example, a <a href="#subscripagency">subscription service</a> such as <a href="#ebsco">EBSCO</a> or <a href="#faxon">FAXON</a> that manages <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s for client libraries.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#literaryagent">literary agent</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aggregator"><b>aggregator</b></a>
</dt><dd>A bibliographic service that provides <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#access">access</a> to the <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> of <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> by different <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s.  Because aggregator <a href="#database">database</a>s can be very large, tracking their <a href="#coverage">coverage</a> is not an easy task for <a href="#serial">serial</a>s <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s.  A task group of the <a href="#pcc">Program for Cooperative Cataloging</a> (PCC) is working on <a href="#standards">standards</a> for analytic <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>s for <a href="#serial">serial</a>s <a href="#title">title</a>s available electronically from aggregator services.  Currently, the top three <a href="#journal">journal</a> aggregators in the United States are <a href="#ebsco">EBSCO</a>, <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>, and <a href="#proquest">ProQuest</a>.
Recently, EBSCO has been building market share by offering higher
up-front payments to secure exclusivity from the publishers of certain
journals. The effects of this competitive practice on <a href="#library">libraries</a> and the <a href="#enduser">end-user</a> are as yet unclear. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ai"><b>AI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#artificial"><b>a</b>rtificial <b>i</b>ntelligence</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aiga1"><b>AIGA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aiga"><b>A</b>merican <b>I</b>nstitute of <b>G</b>raphic <b>A</b>rts</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aiip1"><b>AIIP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aiip"><b>A</b>ssociation of <b>I</b>ndependent <b>I</b>nformation <b>P</b>rofessionals</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aila1"><b>AILA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aila"><b>A</b>merican <b>I</b>ndian <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aisle"><b>aisle</b></a>
</dt><dd>The space left unoccupied between two parallel <a href="#bookcase">bookcase</a>s or shelf <a href="#range">range</a>s, or at right angles to a bank of ranges, to allow <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#patron">patron</a>s and <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> to <a href="#access">access</a> the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a>.  Minimum aisle width is 36 inches in libraries open to the public in the United States.  Some types of <a href="#compactshelving">compact shelving</a> allow staff or users to shift movable ranges, usually along tracks in the floor, opening aisles as needed.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#crossaisle">cross aisle</a> and <a href="#rangeaisle">range aisle</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ajl1"><b>AJL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ajl"><b>A</b>ssociation of <b>J</b>ewish <b>L</b>ibraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aka"><b>a.k.a.</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of "also known as."  <b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#allonym">allonym</a>, <a href="#eponym">eponym</a>, <a href="#penname">pen name</a>, and <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="al"><b><em>AL</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#americanlibraries"><b>A</b>merican <b>L</b>ibraries</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ala1"><b>ALA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ala"><b>A</b>merican <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alaallied"><b>ALA Allied Professional Organization (APA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A separate adjunct organization operating under bylaws approved by the governing Council of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>
at the 2002 Midwinter Meeting, which allows the ALA to conduct
activities prohibited under its current 501(c)(3) tax status. In the
planning stages since 1996, the <b>APA</b> will be able to offer postgraduate specialty certification, advocate for pay equity, and address other issues related to the <a href="#professionalism">professional</a> status of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, as a 501(c)(6) entity.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/hrdr/ala_apa.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ALA/APA</b> homepage.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alaapa"><b>ALA/APA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#alaallied"><b>ALA</b> <b>A</b>llied <b>P</b>rofessional <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alacharacterset"><b>ALA character set</b></a>
</dt><dd>The set of <a href="#character">character</a>s defined by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> for use in the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>, including the characters of the Latin <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>, special characters, <a href="#diacriticalmark">diacritics</a>, 14 <a href="#superscript">superscript</a> characters, 14 <a href="#subscript">subscript</a> characters, and 3 Greek <a href="#letter">letter</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alacodeethics"><b><em>ALA Code of Ethics</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#codeofethics">code of ethics</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alaeditions"><b>ALA Editions</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1886, the Publishing Section of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> first evolved into ALA Books and Pamphlets, and then into <b>ALA Editions</b> in 1993.  Its roster of <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>s includes <em>Reference Books for Libraries</em> (1902), <em>Books for College Libraries</em> (1967), <em>Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</em> (1967), and the <em>Intellectual Freedom Manual</em> (1974).  Income from annual sales of over 100,000 <a href="#copy">copies</a> of <a href="#title">title</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <b>ALA Editions</b> supports ALA's other programs.  <a href="#publication">Publication</a>s currently available from <b>ALA Editions</b> are listed in its <a href="#tradecatalog">trade catalog</a>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/editions/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of <b>ALA Editions</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alafiling"><b><em>ALA Filing Rules</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of guidelines for determining the order in which <a href="#entry">entries</a> are to be filed in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, originally <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> in 1942 under the <a href="#title">title</a> <em>A.L.A. Rules for Filing Catalog Cards</em>.  Revised in 1967 to correspond with <em>Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</em>, the <a href="#filingrule">filing rule</a>s were expanded and published under the <a href="#currency">current</a> title in 1980 to cover any form of bibliographic display (<a href="#print">print</a>, <a href="#microform">microform</a>, <a href="#digital">digital</a>, etc.) and any <a href="#catalogcode">catalog code</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alagraphics"><b>ALA Graphics</b></a>
</dt><dd>A marketing section of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> that sells <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, <a href="#bookplate">bookplate</a>s, <a href="#bookmark">bookmark</a>s, T-shirts, and other <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> materials designed to promote <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#literacy">literacy</a>, and reading.  ALA graphics can be ordered from a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or electronically from the <a href="http://alastore.ala.org/">ALA Online Store</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="album"><b>album</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">bound</a> or <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> <a href="#book">book</a> containing <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#page">page</a>s for <a href="#mounted">mounting</a> stamps, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#poetry">poem</a>s, <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s, <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s, or other <a href="#memorabilia">memorabilia</a>, or for collecting <a href="#autograph">autograph</a>s.  Also, a book containing a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#picture">picture</a>s, with or without accompanying <a href="#text">text</a>.  Also refers to a book of <a href="#sleeve">sleeve</a>s designed to hold <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>s, usually enclosed in an <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> <a href="#pasteboard">pasteboard</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> with a list of the <a href="#contents">contents</a> and descriptive notes <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the inside.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alcove"><b>alcove</b></a>
</dt><dd>A semi-private recessed area within a <a href="#library">library</a>, formed when two <a href="#freestanding">free-standing shelving</a> units are placed at right angles to one or more units of <a href="#wallshelving">wall shelving</a>, usually large enough to provide <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> on the shelves and to accommodate a small number of <a href="#reader">reader</a>s,
seated at desks or around a study table. The architect Sir Christopher
Wren is credited with originating this style of seating in his design
of the library at Trinity College, Cambridge in 1676. Synonymous with <em>cell</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#carrel">carrel</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alcts1"><b>ALCTS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#alcts"><b>A</b>ssociation for <b>L</b>ibrary <b>C</b>ollections and <b>T</b>echnical <b>S</b>ervices</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alexandrian"><b>Alexandrian Library</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded by Ptolemy I in about 300 BC, the great <a href="#library">library</a>
at Alexandria in Egypt became the most important center of Hellenistic
culture in antiquity. At its peak, it contained over 500,000 <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, mostly <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a> <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>s, some of which were <a href="#translation">translated</a> into Greek from other <a href="#language">language</a>s.  The <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> was <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>ed in the "Pinakes" of Callimachus which included the <a href="#author">author</a>'s name and a <a href="#summary">summary</a> of the <a href="#content">content</a> of each <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.
The main library was part of a museum that functioned as an academy,
attracting scholars from all parts of the Mediterranean world. A
smaller library was established in the Temple of Serapis by Ptolemy III
in about 235 BC. <p>
Although the main library was damaged in 47 BC during the siege by
Julius Caesar, both libraries flourished under the Romans until the
civil war that occurred in the late 3rd century AD under the Emperor
Aurelian. The smaller library was destroyed in 391 AD by edict of the
Byzantine Emperor Theodosius. In 1987, UNESCO embarked on a project in
cooperation with the government of Egypt to revive the Library at
Alexandria as a center of culture, science, and academic <a href="#research">research</a>.  <a href="http://www.unesco.org/webworld/alexandria_new/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#website">Web site</a> of the <b>Bibliotheca Alexandrina</b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pergamum">Pergamum</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="algorithm"><b>algorithm</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <em>finite</em> sequence of unambiguous steps or
instructions, designed to solve a complex problem or accomplish a
specific task in a way that produces at least one output, for example,
a formula used to <a href="#encryption">encrypt</a> <a href="#data">data</a>.  Algorithms can be expressed in <a href="#naturallang">natural language</a> (<em>example</em>: a culinary recipe or the instructions for assembling an item shipped in pieces), in a <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ic language such as that used in mathematical logic, or in a <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a>ming language.  One measure of proficiency in programming is the ability to create <em>elegant</em> algorithms that achieve the desired result in a minimum number of ingenious steps.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#automaticindexing">automatic indexing</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alhhs1"><b>ALHHS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#alhhs"><b>A</b>rchivists and <b>L</b>ibrarians in the <b>H</b>istory of the <b>H</b>ealth <b>S</b>ciences</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alias"><b>alias</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened form of an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> address that allows a computer user to type a brief identifier (<em>example</em>: <b>susan</b>) to send a message to a person whose full e-mail address is much longer (<b>susanmiller@library.myuniversity.edu</b>).  Compare with <a href="#macro">macro</a>.
<p>
Also, an assumed name, especially one adopted by a person engaged in
illegal activity to avoid detection and possible prosecution. Compare
with <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alibris"><b>Alibris</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial company that specializes in supplying <a href="#rarebook">rare</a>, <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>, and hard-to-find <a href="#book">book</a>s to <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s, <a href="#library">libraries</a>, and retail customers through a worldwide network of <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s and distribution capabilities.  <a href="http://www.alibris.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Alibris</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
