<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alignment"><b>alignment</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typography">typography</a>, the arrangement of <a href="#character">character</a>s in a line of <a href="#type">type</a> in such a way that the tops and bottoms form a straight line across the <a href="#page">page</a>, parallel with other lines.  Also, the <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> of type in lines that are even at both right and left <a href="#margin">margin</a>s.  Compare in this sense with <a href="#justification">justification</a>.  
<p>
In a more general sense, the lining up of type or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a> in relation to any common horizontal or vertical line for <a href="#printing">printing</a> on a page.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alise1"><b>ALISE</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#alise"><b>A</b>ssociation  for <b>L</b>ibrary and <b>I</b>nformation <b>S</b>cience <b>E</b>ducation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alkaline"><b>alkaline</b></a>
</dt><dd>Substances with a <a href="#ph">pH</a> exceeding 7.0 (neutral), for example, calcium carbonate or magnesium carbonate added to <a href="#paper">paper</a> in manufacture as a reserve or <a href="#buffering">buffer</a> to neutralize any <a href="#acidic">acid</a>s that might develop with age.  Alkaline substances are also used in the <a href="#deacidification">deacidification</a> of materials made from <a href="#acidpaper">acid paper</a> or <a href="#board">board</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allacross"><b>all across</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#allalong">all along</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allalong"><b>all along</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> method used in <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a> in which each <a href="#section">section</a> of the <a href="#textblock">text-block</a>  is sewn separately to cords or <a href="#tapes">tapes</a>, from <a href="#kettle">kettle stitch</a> to kettle stitch inside the <a href="#backfold">fold</a>.  For the sake of economy or to reduce <a href="#swell">swell</a>, sections may be hand sewn <a href="#twoon">two on</a>.  Synonymous with <em> all across</em> and <em>all on</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allegory"><b>allegory</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> that can be interpreted literally, but which also has at least one <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ic
meaning, usually expressing or elucidating an abstract idea or moral
principle. Also, a form of extended metaphor used primarily in <a href="#work">work</a>s of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#poetry">poetry</a> in which an event, idea, thing, or person stands for itself and simultaneously for something else.  A <em>dream allegory</em> is a medieval poem or story about a dream that has allegorical significance, for example, King Rene's <b><em>Book of Love</em></b> (<em>Le Cueur d'Amours Espris</em>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#beastepic">beast epic</a>, <a href="#fable">fable</a>, <a href="#moralityplay">morality play</a>, and <a href="#parable">parable</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allfirsts"><b>all firsts</b></a>
</dt><dd>An expression used in the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> and in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> to indicate that all the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in a group of <a href="#publication">publication</a>s are known to be <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allied"><b>Allied Professional Association</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#alaallied"><b>ALA</b> <b>A</b>llied <b>P</b>rofessional <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allocation"><b>allocation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A quantity of time, money, materials, or other resources
reserved by an organization for a specific purpose, usually to meet a
need essential to realizing its <a href="#goal">goal</a>s and <a href="#objective">objective</a>s.  In most <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s, funds are <em>allocated</em> in accordance with an <a href="#annual">annual</a> or <a href="#biennial">biennial</a> <a href="#budget">budget</a> determined by the availability of funds.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allon"><b>all on</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#allalong">all along</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allonym"><b>allonym</b></a>
</dt><dd>The name of a person known to have existed, assumed as a <a href="#penname">pen name</a> by another writer, as opposed to a <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>al <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a>.
For example, the name "Publius" for the Roman tribune Publius Clodius
Pulcher, used by Alexander Hamilton, John Jay, and James Madison in
writing <em>The Federalist</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allover"><b>all over</b></a>
</dt><dd>A style of  <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the whole of both sides (front <em>and</em> back <a href="#cover">cover</a>s) are decorated, in contrast to design on the front cover only, on the centers and/or <a href="#corner">corner</a>s, or on the <a href="#border">border</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allpublished"><b>all published</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#note">note</a> in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> describing a <a href="#publication">publication</a> originally proposed in more than one <a href="#part">part</a> or <a href="#volume">volume</a> but never completed, usually because it was discontinued by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  Similarly, a note describing all the <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> for which publication <a href="#ceased">ceased</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allrag"><b>all-rag</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ragpaper">rag paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allrights"><b>all rights reserved</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> in or on a <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>, usually on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, giving formal notice that all <a href="#rights">rights</a> granted under existing <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law are retained by the copyright holder and that legal action may be taken against <a href="#infringement">infringement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allthrough"><b>all through</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#letterbyletter">letter-by-letter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="allusion"><b>allusion</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief figurative or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ic reference in a literary <a href="#text">text</a>, usually made indirectly to a familiar person, place, thing, or event outside the text, or to another <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> or passage in it.  Allusions are sometimes <a href="#indexing">indexed</a> and <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#collection">collection</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Allusions--Cultural, Literary, Biblical, and Historical: A Thematic Dictionary</em></b>
by Laurence Urdang and Frederick Ruffner). In a more general sense, any
implied indication, indirect reference, or casual mention, as opposed
to an explicit reference.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="almanac"><b>almanac</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, a <a href="#book">book</a> introduced by the Moors to Spain, listing the days, weeks, and months of the year and providing <a href="#information">information</a> about festivals, holidays, astronomical phenomena, etc.  In modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, an <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#compendium">compendium</a> of practical dates, facts, and statistics, <a href="#currency">current</a> and/or <a href="#retrospective">retrospective</a>, often arranged in <a href="#table">table</a>s to facilitate comparison.  Almanacs can be general (<em>example</em>: <b><em>World Almanac and Book of Facts</em></b>) or related to a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> or academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> (<b><em>Almanac of American Politics</em></b>).  <a href="http://www.infoplease.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> version of the <b><em>Information Please</em></b> almanac.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alphabet"><b>alphabet</b></a>
</dt><dd>The complete <a href="#set">set</a> of <a href="#character">character</a>s used to write or indicate the speech sounds of a <a href="#language">language</a>, usually arranged in traditional order.  The roman alphabet used in writing the English language contains 26 <a href="#letter">letter</a>s (5 vowels and 21 consonants), each with an <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> and <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> form.  The roman alphabets used to write other languages may contain fewer or additional <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, with <a href="#diacriticalmark">diacritical mark</a>s used to indicate specific sounds.  <a href="http://www.wam.umd.edu/%7Erfradkin/alphapage.html">Click here</a> to find out more about the <em>Evolution of Alphabets</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> and <a href="#exotics">exotics</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alphabetbook"><b>alphabet book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a> for preschool children with <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s designed to teach the <a href="#letter">letter</a>s and sequence of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> by showing on each <a href="#page">page</a> or <a href="#doublespread">double spread</a>, one or more objects, animals, etc., belonging to a <a href="#class">class</a> whose name begins with the letter displayed (<b>a</b> for <b>apple</b>, etc.).  Compare with <a href="#countingbook">counting book</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#abecedarium">abecedarium</a> and <a href="#hornbook">horn book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alphabetical"><b>alphabetical</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the customary order of the <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> of a <a href="#language">language</a>.  <a href="#alphabetization">Alphabetizing</a> can be <a href="#letterbyletter">letter-by-letter</a>, ignoring <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a> and divisions between words, or <a href="#wordbyword">word-by-word</a>, with <a href="#entry">entries</a> beginning with the same word alphabetized by the next word, and so on.  The terms in this <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> are listed alphabetically letter-by-letter.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alphabetization"><b>alphabetization</b></a>
</dt><dd>Arranging <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s or <a href="#entry">entries</a> in the conventional order of the <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> of a <a href="#language">language</a>, usually by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or other <a href="#heading">heading</a>.  The most frequently used methods are <a href="#letterbyletter">letter-by-letter</a> or <a href="#wordbyword">word-by-word</a>, as illustrated by the following examples:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><p>
</p><table>
<tbody><tr align="left"><td width="200"><b><em>Letter-by-Letter</em></b></td><td width="100"><b><em>Word-by-Word</em></b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="200">New</td><td width="100">New</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="200">Newel</td><td width="100">New Haven</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="200">Newfoundland</td><td width="100">New moon</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="200">New Haven</td><td width="100">New York</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="200">New moon</td><td width="100">Newel</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="200">Newport</td><td width="100">Newfoundland</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="200">Newt</td><td width="100">Newport</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="200">New York</td><td width="100">Newt</td></tr>
</tbody></table></dd></dl>
<p>
For a brief discussion of the history of alphabetization, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> on "Alphabetization Rules" by Geoffrey Martin in the <b><em>International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science</em></b> (Routledge: 1997). 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alphameric"><b>alphameric</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alphanumeric"><b>alphanumeric</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#contraction">contraction</a> of <em>alphabetic-numeric</em>, referring to a <a href="#character">character</a> <a href="#set">set</a> containing <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s, and/or special characters.  The <a href="#accesscode">access code</a>s used in computer systems are often alphanumeric (<em>example</em>:  the <a href="#username">username</a> <b>smith003</b>).  Synonymous with <em>alphameric</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="anscr"><b>Alpha-Numeric System for Classification of Recordings (ANSCR)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A scheme for classifying <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>s of all types, based on a set of 23 major <a href="#subject">subject</a> categories represented by <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the Latin <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>M</b> for popular music), with some categories subdivided and represented by double letters (<b>MJ</b> for jazz).  To the alphabetic category is added a three- or four-letter code representing type of sub<a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> (by <a href="#title">title</a> of <a href="#work">work</a>; name of <a href="#composer">composer</a>, <a href="#performer">performer</a>, or <a href="#author">author</a>; name of skill, <a href="#language">language</a>, or sound; etc.).  The third part of the <a href="#classification">classification</a> number is composed of the first letter of each of the first three <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> in the title of the work or <a href="#album">album</a>, or a <a href="#number">number</a>
if the work is known by form and numbered. The fourth part is composed
of a letter representing the name of an individual closely associated
with the performance on the recording, followed by the last two digits
of the commercial recording number:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>ES</b>
</dd><dd><b>BEET</b>
</dd><dd><b>5</b>
</dd><dd><b>O 98</b></dd></dl>
<p>
In the preceding example, <b>ES</b> indicates that the recorded work is orchestral and of symphonic form, <b>BEET</b> that it was composed by Ludwig Van Beethoven, <b>5</b> that it is his fifth symphony, and <b>O 98</b> that the performance was conducted by Eugene Ormandy and that the last two digits of the Columbia record number are 98.
</p><p>
<b>ANSCR</b> is used mainly by <a href="#library">libraries</a> holding large numbers of sound recordings.  Libraries with smaller <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s generally use <a href="#accessionnumber">accession number</a> or some other "home-grown" <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> to organize sound recordings.  Pronounced "answer."
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alphatest"><b>alpha test</b></a>
</dt><dd>The first full-scale test of a newly designed computer <a href="#software">software</a> system or <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> <a href="#device">device</a>, or of substantially revised software or hardware that has undergone a major <a href="#upgrade">upgrade</a>, usually conducted in a laboratory environment.  Compare with <a href="#betatest">beta test</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alsc1"><b>ALSC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#alsc"><b>A</b>ssociation for <b>L</b>ibrary <b>S</b>ervice to <b>C</b>hildren</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alta1"><b>ALTA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#alta"><b>A</b>ssociation for <b>L</b>ibrary <b>T</b>rustees and <b>A</b>dvocates</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alternativepress"><b>alternative press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small, politically progressive <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> not controlled by the handful of giant multinational corporations that dominate the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> industry worldwide.  Alternative press <a href="#publication">publication</a>s often address important social issues and publish innovative and experimental <a href="#work">work</a>s largely ignored or covered superficially in the mainstream <a href="#press">press</a>.  For the past thirty years, the <a href="http://www.altpress.org/">Alternative Press Center</a> (APC), an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#srrt">Social Responsibilities Round Table</a> (SRRT) of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, has provided <a href="#access">access</a> to such publications through <b><em>Alternative Press Index</em></b>, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of large <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alternativetitle"><b>alternative title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The second part of a <a href="#title">title</a> consisting of two parts, each of which is a title in itself, connected by the word "or" or its equivalent in another <a href="#language">language</a> (<em>example</em>: <b><em>The Female Quixote, or, the Adventures of Arabella</em></b>).  Compare with <a href="#subtitle">subtitle</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ambientconditions"><b>ambient conditions</b></a>
</dt><dd>The prevailing characteristics of the environment within the room or building in which <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> are stored or used, including temperature, <a href="#humidity">humidity</a>, natural and artificial light, dust, etc., important considerations for long-term <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ambientlight"><b>ambient light</b></a>
</dt><dd>The level of illumination in an enclosed space, from natural or artificial sources, an important consideration in the <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> that <a href="#deterioration">deteriorate</a> when exposed to light (especially the <a href="#ultraviolet">ultraviolet</a> in direct sunlight).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ameliafrances"><b>Amelia Frances Howard-Gibbon Illustrator's Award</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a> established in 1971, presented <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly for the best <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in Canada during the preceding year.  The <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a> must be a citizen or permanent resident of Canada and the <a href="#text">text</a>
must be worthy of the illustrations. The award is sponsored by the
National Book Service and administered by the Canadian Association of
Children's <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s.  <a href="http://www.acs.ucalgary.ca/%7Edkbrown/awards.html">Click here</a> to see a list of past award winners.  Compare with <a href="#clabook">CLA Book of the Year for Children</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#caldecott">Caldecott Medal</a> and <a href="#greenaway">Greenaway Medal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="americana"><b>Americana</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> and by <a href="#bookcollecting">collector</a>s to refer to <a href="#book">book</a>s and other materials written about the Americas (North, South, and Central America), not necessarily <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the Americas or written by <a href="#author">author</a>s from the Americas.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> that own extensive or valuable <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of Americana often store them in <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#-ana">-ana or -iana</a> and <a href="#aas">American Antiquarian Society</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aas"><b>American Antiquarian Society (AAS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An independent national <a href="#researchlib">research library</a> founded in 1812 in Worcester, Massachusetts to <a href="#documentation">document</a> the history of the American people from the colonial period through the Civil War and Reconstruction.  The <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of the <b>AAS</b> include <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#broadside">broadside</a>s, <a href="#juvenile">juvenile literature</a>, music, <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> arts, <a href="#genealogy">genealogy</a>, and local history.  <a href="http://www.americanantiquarian.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>AAS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aall"><b>American Association of Law Libraries (AALL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1906, <b>AALL</b> has a membership of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and related <a href="#information">information</a> professionals who serve the legal profession in bar <a href="#association">association</a>s, courts, law schools, law societies, private law firms, businesses, and government.  <b>AALL</b> seeks to promote and enhance the value of <a href="#lawlibrary">law libraries</a> to the legal community and general public, fosters the profession of law <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>, and provides leadership in the field of legal information.  An <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>AALL</b> has <a href="#publishing">published</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em>Law Library Journal</em> since 1908.  <a href="http://www.aallnet.org/index.asp">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>AALLNET</b> <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aasl"><b>American Association of School Librarians (AASL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1951, <b>AASL</b> is a division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> with a membership of elementary and secondary <a href="#schoollibrary">school library</a> <a href="#mediaspecialist">media specialist</a>s and others interested in the improvement and extension of services for <a href="#childrensservices">children</a> and <a href="#yaservices">young adult</a>s.  <b>AASL</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/aasl/SLMR/index.html">School Library Media Research</a></em> and its <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> companion <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/aasl/kqweb/index.html">Knowledge Quest</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/aasl/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>AASL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aaup"><b>American Association of University Professors (AAUP)</b></a>
</dt><dd></dd><dd>A professional <a href="#association">association</a> founded in 1915 to represent college and university faculty, the <b>AAUP</b> is also open to administrators, graduate students, and the general public.  The organization is dedicated to defending <a href="#academicfreedom">academic freedom</a> and <a href="#tenure">tenure</a>, advocating collegial <a href="#governance">governance</a>,
developing policies to ensure due process in the workplace, and
providing statistics and analysis of trends in academic employment. <a href="#libraryfaculty">Library faculty</a> members at colleges and universities in the United States who are members of the <b>AAUP</b> may be covered by a <a href="#collectivebargaining">collective bargaining agreement</a> negotiated by their chapter.  <a href="http://www.aaup.org/">Click</a> here to connect to the <b>AAUP</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aba"><b>American Booksellers Association (ABA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1900, the <b>ABA</b> is the oldest <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a> of independent <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s with store front locations in the United States. Its <a href="#mission">mission</a> is to meet the needs of its members through advocacy, education, <a href="#research">research</a>, and the dissemination of <a href="#information">information</a>.  The <b>ABA</b> actively supports fee speech, <a href="#literacy">literacy</a>, and programs that encourage children to read.  The organization also <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> an <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#handbook">handbook</a> for <a href="#book">book</a> buyers and maintains the <a href="http://www.bookweb.org/">BookWeb.org</a> <a href="#website">site</a> on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abtd"><b><em>American Book Trade Directory (ABTD)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publishing">Published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, the <b><em>ABTD</em></b> provides basic <a href="#directory">directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> on <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>s, <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>s, and <a href="#antiquarian">antiquarian</a>s in the United States and Canada, listed geographically by state/province and <a href="#index">index</a>ed by name and type of store, as well as information about <a href="#bookauction">auction</a>eers of literary property, appraisers of <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s, book exporters and importers, and national and regional <a href="#association">association</a>s involved in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="americanfolklife"><b>American Folklife Center</b></a>
</dt><dd>Created by Congress in 1976, the <b>American Folklife Center</b> is an <a href="#govtagency">agency</a> within the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>, dedicated to <a href="#preservation">preserving</a> and presenting the American folk tradition.  It incorporates the Archive of Folk Culture, established in 1928 as a <a href="#repository">repository</a> of American folk music.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/folklife/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>American Folklife Center</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aila"><b>American Indian Library Association (AILA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1979, <b>AILA</b> is an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> with a membership of individuals and institutions committed to promoting the development, maintenance, and improvement of <a href="#library">library</a> services and <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s for Native Americans, particularly cultural and <a href="#information">information</a> resources needed on reservations and in communities of Native Americans and Native Alaskans.  <b>AILA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em>AILA Newsletter</em>.  <a href="http://www.nativeculture.com/lisamitten/aila.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>AILA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aiga"><b>American Institute of Graphic Arts (AIGA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1914 in New York, <b>AIGA</b> is a nonprofit organization that fosters excellence in <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> design as an academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, communication <a href="#medium">medium</a>, business tool, and cultural force by providing a forum for design professionals to exchange ideas and <a href="#information">information</a>, participate in <a href="#research">research</a> and critical analysis, and enhance education and ethical practice.  <b>AIGA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> <em>Trace: AIGA Journal of Design</em> in three <a href="#issue">issue</a>s per year.  <a href="http://www.aiga.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>AIGA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="americanize"><b>americanize</b></a>
</dt><dd>To convert to American English the style and spelling of a <a href="#work">work</a> written in (or <a href="#translation">translated</a> into) British English.  Compare with <a href="#briticize">briticize</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="americanlibraries"><b><em>American Libraries (AL)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A professional <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> for <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#publishing">published</a> since 1907 by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b><em>AL</em></b> provides news and announcements, analysis of trends, <a href="#feature">feature</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s, job postings, and advertising by library-related businesses in eleven <a href="#issue">issue</a>s per year.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/alonline/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> version of <b><em>AL</em></b>.  For <a href="#review">review</a>s of <a href="#book">book</a>s and other categories of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> <a href="#libcollec">collected</a> by <a href="#library">libraries</a>, see <em><a href="#booklist">Booklist</a></em>, also published by the ALA. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ala"><b>American Library Association (ALA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The leading professional <a href="#association">association</a> of <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> and <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s in the United States, the <b>ALA</b> was founded in Philadelphia in October, 1876 by a group of <a href="#library">library</a> leaders (90 men and 13 women) that included <a href="#deweymelvil">Melvil Dewey</a>.  An "association of associations," the <b>ALA</b> is organized in divisions, each with its own officers, budget, and programs, and is closely tied to over 50 state and regional <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>s.  The Association also sponsors <a href="#roundtable">round table</a>s on specific issues and topics, and is <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a>d with other independent library-related organizations.  Its <a href="#imprint">imprint</a> is <a href="#alaeditions">ALA Editions</a>.  The most widely read <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the <b>ALA</b> are the <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> <em><a href="#americanlibraries">American Libraries</a></em> and the <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a> <em><a href="#booklist">Booklist</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/library/alaperiodicals.html">Click here</a> to see a complete list of <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a>s, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, and <a href="#journal">journal</a>s published by the various branches the <b>ALA</b>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ALA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#alaallied">ALA Allied Professional Association</a>, <a href="#abf">Association des bibliothecaires francais</a>, <a href="#canadianla">Canadian Library Association</a>, and <a href="#la">Library Association</a> (UK).
<p>
<b>ALA</b> divisions:
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><a href="#aasl">American Association of School Librarians (AASL)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#alcts">Association for Library Collections and Technical Services (ALCTS)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#alsc">Association for Library Service to Children (ALSC)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#alta">Association for Library Trustees and Advocates (ALTA)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#acrl">Association of College and Research Libraries (ACRL)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#ascla">Association of Specialized and Cooperative Library Agencies (ASCLA)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#lama">Library Administration and Management Association (LAMA)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#lita">Library and Information Technology Association (LITA)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#pla">Public Library Association (PLA)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#rusa">Reference and User Services Association (RUSA)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#yalsa">Young Adult Library Services Association (YALSA)</a></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ald"><b><em>American Library Directory (ALD)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a>s of most <a href="#library">libraries</a>, providing <a href="#directory">directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> (name, location, phone and <a href="#facsimiletrans">FAX</a> number(s), department heads, <a href="#budget">budget</a>, <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> size, <a href="#specialcollections">special collection</a>s, electronic resources, <a href="#network">network</a> participation, etc.) for over 30,000 <a href="#academiclib">academic</a>, <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a>, <a href="#researchlib">research</a>, county, provincial, <a href="#regionallib">regional</a>, <a href="#medicallib">medical</a>, <a href="#lawlibrary">law</a>, and other <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a> in the United States, Canada, and Mexico. <b><em>ALD</em></b> also includes separate sections listing library <a href="#network">network</a>s and <a href="#consortium">consortia</a>, <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s, libraries for persons with special needs, and <a href="#statelibrary">state</a> and <a href="#federallibrary">federal library</a> <a href="#govtagency">agencies</a>.  It also contains an <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly arranged <em>Personnel Index</em> of all the individuals named in the <a href="#entry">entries</a> for libraries, library systems, and library consortia, with contact information.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ansi"><b>American National Standards Institute (ANSI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonprofit national <a href="#clearinghouse">clearinghouse</a> founded in 1918 to facilitate <a href="#standardization">standardization</a> by voluntary consensus in the United States in both the public and private sectors, and to coordinate and administer <a href="#standards">standards</a> of all types.  <b>ANSI</b> membership includes over 1,400 companies, organizations, <a href="#govtagency">government agencies</a>, and other institutions.  The U.S. is represented by <b>ANSI</b> in the <a href="#iso">International Organization for Standardization</a> (ISO).  Standards for <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a> are developed by the <a href="#niso"> National Information Standards Organization</a> (NISO), a nonprofit <a href="#association">association</a> accredited by <b>ANSI</b>.  <a href="http://www.ansi.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ANSI</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="apha"><b>American Printing History Association (APHA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1974, <b>APHA</b> encourages study and <a href="#research">research</a> in <a href="#printing">printing</a> history and related arts and skills, including <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, <a href="#type">type</a> founding, <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, and <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>.  From its headquarters in New York City, <b>APHA</b> publishes the <em>APHA Newsletter</em> and the <a href="#biannual">biannual</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em><a href="http://www.printinghistory.org/htm/journal/index.htm">Printing History</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.printinghistory.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>APHA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arba"><b><em>American Reference Books Annual (ARBA)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#lu">Libraries Unlimited</a>, <b><em>ARBA</em></b> provides <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#coverage">coverage</a> of English-<a href="#language">language</a> <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s and <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>s published in the United States and Canada during the previous year, presenting <a href="#review">review</a>s in a <a href="#classified">classified</a> arrangement, <a href="#index">index</a>ed by <a href="#author">author</a>/<a href="#title">title</a> and <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  Reviews are usually 100-300 words long, written by scholars, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, and <a href="#libraryeducation">library educators</a> who are asked to examine new <a href="#work">work</a>s and provide well-<a href="#documentation">documented</a> critical comments (positive <em>and</em> negative).  All reviews are <a href="#signed">signed</a>.  <b><em>ARBA</em></b> is shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of large <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="asist"><b>American Society for Information Science and Technology (ASIST)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>ASIST</b> is a non-profit <a href="#association">association</a> established in 1937 to provide opportunities for professionals in the <a href="#infoscience">information science</a> <a href="#field">field</a> to communicate across the <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s of <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a>, computer science, linguistics, mathematics, and the physical sciences. <a href="http://www.asis.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ASIST</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
<b>ASIST</b> publications:
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em><a href="http://www.asis.org/Publications/ARIST/">ARIST: Annual Review of Information Science and Technology</a></em> 
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.asis.org/Bulletin/index.html">Bulletin of the American Society of Information Science and Technology</a></em> 
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.asis.org/Publications/JASIS/jasis.html">Journal of the American Society for Information Science and Technology</a></em></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="asi"><b>American Society of Indexers (ASI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1968, <b>ASI</b> is an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> that seeks to promote <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>ing, and <a href="#database">database</a> construction.  Its members are professional indexers, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#editor">editor</a>s, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, and organizations that employ indexers.  <b>ASI</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>The Indexer</em> and the <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#bulletin">bulletin</a> <em>Key Words</em>.  <a href="http://www.asindexing.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ASI</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ascii1"><b>American Standard Code for Information Interchange</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ascii">ASCII</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ada"><b><em>Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Legislation passed by Congress in 1990 guaranteeing right of <a href="#access">access</a>
to public facilities and resources to persons with physical
disabilities and prohibiting discrimination against them in employment.
The <b><em>ADA</em></b> has had a profound effect on the delivery of <a href="#library">library</a> services in the United States, from  architectural planning (ramps, elevators, automatic door-openers, <a href="#signage">signage</a> in <a href="#braille">Braille</a>, etc.) to the design and placement of furniture, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, and shelving, and even the design of computer <a href="#interface">interface</a>s.  To learn more, <a href="http://www.adata.org/">click here</a> or see the <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> <b><em>How Libraries Must Comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)</em></b> by Donald Foos and Nancy Pack (Oryx: 1992).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="atla"><b>American Theological Library Association (ATLA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1947, <b>ATLA</b> is an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> with an ecumenical membership that includes theological <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, persons interested in theological <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>,
and theological institutions dedicated to providing programs, products,
and services in support of theological and religious studies <a href="#library">libraries</a> and librarians. <b>ATLA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em>ATLA Newsletter</em>.  <a href="http://www.atla.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ATLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aol"><b>America Online (AOL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The largest <a href="#internetservice">Internet service provider</a> in the world, <b>America Online</b> was founded as Quantum Computer Services in 1985, reached one million <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s in 1994, purchased its closest rival CompuServe in 1997, and merged with Time Warner in 2001.  Known by the <a href="#initialism">initialism</a> <b>AOL</b>, the company offers <a href="#email">e-mail</a>, a <a href="#chat">chat</a> <a href="#directory">directory</a>, a <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> and <a href="#subject">subject</a> directory of <a href="#website">Web site</a>s, <a href="#online">online</a> shopping, and <a href="#information">information</a> and entertainment services, in addition to providing <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#access">access</a> to businesses and individuals, usually for a monthly <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  <a href="http://www.aol.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>AOL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="amia1"><b>AMIA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#amia"><b>A</b>ssociation of <b>M</b>oving <b>I</b>mage <b>A</b>rchivists</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="amnesty"><b>amnesty</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#grace">grace period</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ampersand"><b>ampersand</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> <b>&amp;</b> derived from a fusion of the <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the Latin word <em>et</em>, meaning "and."  Under <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, when the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> contains an ampersand (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Notes &amp; Queries</em></b>), it is <a href="#transcribe">transcribe</a>d in the <a href="#titleand">title and statement of responsibility</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> exactly as it appears on the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a>, and an <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> is made under the <a href="#title">title</a> with "and" spelled out.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="-ana"><b>-ana, -iana</b></a>
</dt><dd>A suffix added to the name of a person, place, or institution to signify the body of related <a href="#literature">literature</a>, <a href="#information">information</a>, <a href="#memorabilia">memorabilia</a>, etc., that has accumulated over time (<em>examples</em>:  Conradiana, <a href="#americana">Americana</a>, <a href="#librariana">librariana</a>).  In <a href="#library">libraries</a> such <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> are usually housed in <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#localcollec">local collection</a> and <a href="#regionalbook">regional book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="analects"><b>analects</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek <em>analekta</em> meaning "things gathered up."  A collection or "gleaning" of miscellaneous literary <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>s or fragments (<em>example</em>:  the teachings of Confucius).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="analog"><b>analog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A representation of an object, physical condition, or process,
that closely replicates the original, reflecting any variations in its
state. In technology, analog devices are designed to monitor conditions
such as sound, movement, or temperature, and convert the resulting
measurements into electrical signals or mechanical patterns
representing the fluctuations of the actual phenomenon (<em>example</em>:  sounds recorded on a <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>).  Analog <a href="#data">data</a> is <a href="#encoding">encoded</a>
in signals that are continuous over a range or interval of values, for
example, data transmitted over a telephone line which must be <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> by a device called a <a href="#modem">modem</a> into the discrete values of <a href="#digital">digital</a> code in order to be processed by a digital computer.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="analyticalbibliog"><b>analytical bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>The comparative and historical study of <a href="#book">book</a>s as physical objects, including the methods and techniques of book production and their influence on <a href="#text">text</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>critical bibliography</em>.  Analytical <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> has three main branches:
<p> 
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b><em>Historical bibliography</em></b> - the history of books and their methods of production 
</dd><dd><b><em>Textual bibliography</em></b> - the relationship between the text as conceived by the <a href="#author">author</a> and the text as <a href="#publishing">published</a>
</dd><dd><b><em>Descriptive bibliography</em></b> - the close description of the physical characteristics of books</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="analyticalentry"><b>analytical entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> for a part of a <a href="#work">work</a> (<a href="#chapter">chapter</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a>) or for an entire work (<a href="#shortstory">story</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>, <a href="#essay">essay</a>, or <a href="#poetry">poem</a>) contained in an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, such as an <a href="#anthology">anthology</a> or <a href="#collection">collection</a>, for which a <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> entry is made.  Analytical entries are made under the <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, and <a href="#subject">subject</a>
of the part, and include a reference to the title of the work
containing the part. Because preparation of analytical entries is
time-consuming, the level of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> provided in a catalog depends on the administrative policy of the library and its assessment of local needs.  Synonymous with <em>analytics</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#analyticalnote">analytical note</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="analyticalnote"><b>analytical note</b></a>
</dt><dd>The statement in an <a href="#analyticalentry">analytical entry</a> indicating the relationship of the <a href="#work">work</a>, or part of a work, to the more comprehensive work of which it is a part, for example, the <a href="#title">title</a> of an <a href="#anthology">anthology</a> containing a <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>, <a href="#essay">essay</a>, or <a href="#poetry">poem</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="analyticclass"><b>analytic classification</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical classification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="analytics"><b>analytics</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#analyticalentry">analytical entry</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ancillarymap"><b>ancillary map</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#insetmap">inset map</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="and"><b>AND</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#logicalproduct">logical product</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="anglo"><b><em>Anglo-American Cataloging Rules (AACR)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A detailed set of <a href="#standardization">standardized</a> rules for <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> various types of <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> which had its origin in <em>Catalog Rules: Author and Title Entries</em> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1908 under the auspices of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> and the <a href="#la">Library Association</a> (UK), and the <em>A.L.A. Cataloging Rules for Author and Title Entries</em> (1949), with its companion <a href="#volume">volume</a> <em>Rules for Descriptive Cataloging in the Library of Congress</em>.  Cooperation between the ALA, the Library Association, and the <a href="#canadianla">Canadian Library Association</a> resumed with the joint <a href="#publication">publication</a> in 1967 of <b><em>Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</em></b>, which is divided into two parts:  rules for creating the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> of any type, and rules governing the choice and <a href="#formofentry">form of entry</a> of <a href="#heading">heading</a>s (<a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s) in the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  
<p>
A second <a href="#edition">edition</a> (<b><em>AACR2</em></b>) was published in 1978 and revised in 1988 (<b><em>AACR2R</em></b>) to reflect changes in <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#format">format</a>s.  The 1998 revision includes changes and corrections authorized by the <a href="http://www.nlc-bnc.ca/jsc/">Joint Steering Committee (JSC)</a> for revision of <b><em>AACR</em></b> since 1988, including amendments authorized through 1997.  Additional amendments were issued in 1999 and 2001.  <b><em>AACR2-e</em></b> is a <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> version <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#alaeditions">ALA Editions</a> that includes all amendments through 2001.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#paris">Paris Principles</a> and <a href="#catalogcode">catalog code</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="animated"><b>animated graphics</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> design technique in which a sequence of related still images, such as <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a> drawings or <a href="#diagram">diagram</a>s, is displayed in such rapid succession that the illusion of continuous motion is created on a computer screen.  <a href="#animation">Animated</a> graphics require less <a href="#bandwidth">bandwidth</a> than <a href="#fullmotion">full-motion video</a> when transmitted over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> (and also less <a href="#memory">memory</a>), so they can be <a href="#download">download</a>ed more quickly when a <a href="#website">Web site</a> containing them is selected by the viewer.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="animation"><b>animation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The illusion of continuous motion created on <a href="#film">film</a> by <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ing a sequence of drawings, still <a href="#picture">picture</a>s, or <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a> <a href="#cel">cel</a>s,
each representing a slight change from the preceding one, and viewing
them in rapid succession. Developed into an art form by <em>animators</em> in the studios of Walt Disney, the technique continues to provide pleasure to audiences worldwide.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#animated">animated graphics</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="annals"><b>annals</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> in which the <a href="#transactions">transactions</a> of a <a href="#society">society</a> or organization, or events and developments in a specific <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or <a href="#field">field</a> of study are recorded (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> since 1890).  In a more general sense, a list of events recorded in <a href="#chronological">chronological</a> order. <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#chronicle">chronicle</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="annex"><b>annex</b></a>
</dt><dd>An addition to an existing <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#archive">archive</a>,
or a nearby facility used as an addition to the main building, usually
of smaller size. A library annex is sometimes used to store low-<a href="#usage">use</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in <a href="#closedstacks">closed stacks</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="annotate"><b>annotate</b></a>
</dt><dd>To add <a href="#note">note</a>s to a written <a href="#document">document</a> to explain, comment on, or evaluate its <a href="#content">content</a>, as in an <a href="#annotatededition">annotated edition</a>.  Also, to add brief notes, called <a href="#annotation">annotation</a>s, to the <a href="#entry">entries</a> in a <a href="#annotatedbib">bibliography</a> or <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> to describe, explain, or evaluate the sources listed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="annotatedbib"><b>annotated bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> in which a brief explanatory or evaluative <a href="#note">note</a> is added to each reference or <a href="#citation">citation</a>.  An <a href="#annotation">annotation</a> can be helpful to the <a href="#research">research</a>er in evaluating whether the <a href="#source">source</a> is <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> to a given <a href="#topic">topic</a> or line of inquiry.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="annotatededition"><b>annotated edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> that includes comments written by the <a href="#author">author</a> or another <em>annotator</em>, which are explanatory or supplemental rather than evaluative.  Compare with <a href="#criticaledition">critical edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="annotation"><b>annotation</b></a>     
</dt><dd>A brief <a href="#note">note</a>, usually no longer than two or three sentences, added after a <a href="#citation">citation</a> in a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> to describe or explain the <a href="#content">content</a> or message of the <a href="#work">work</a> cited, or to comment on it.
<p> 
<em>Example</em>:
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>Bradbury, Malcolm, ed. <em>The Atlas of Literature</em>. London: De Agostini Editions, 1997.</b>
<dl><dt></dt><dd>A heavily-<a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> international thematic history of the relationship between geography and <a href="#literature">literature</a>, from the Middle Ages and Renaissance to the post-Cold War era.  Includes references for <a href="#furtherreading">further reading</a> and a list of places to visit by country.
</dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
In a more general sense, any brief explanatory or descriptive comment added to a <a href="#document">document</a>, <a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> <a href="#entry">entry</a>, etc.  In a <a href="#criticalannotation">critical annotation</a>, the commentary is evaluative.  Also refers to the process of <a href="#annotate">annotating</a> a document or an entry in a bibliography or <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="annual"><b>annual</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d once a year, every year, as in an <a href="#annualreport">annual report</a> or <a href="#annualreview">annual review</a>.  Also refers to a form of literary <a href="#anthology">anthology</a> popular during the 19th century, usually <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> with <a href="#engraving">engraving</a>s.  According to Geoffrey Glaister (<b><em>Encyclopedia of the Book</em></b>, Oak Knoll: 1996), this type of <a href="#book">book</a> was intended mainly for female <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.  
<p>
In modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> in any <a href="#format">format</a>, issued once a year.  Compare with <a href="#yearbook">yearbook</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#biennial">biennial</a>, <a href="#triennial">triennial</a>, <a href="#quadrennial">quadrennial</a>, <a href="#quinquennial">quinquennial</a>, <a href="#sexennial">sexennial</a>, <a href="#septennial">septennial</a>, and <a href="#decennial">decennial</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="annualreport"><b>annual report</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually less than one hundred <a href="#page">page</a>s
in length, submitted each year by the officers of a publicly held
company to its board of directors (or other governing body) and <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#softcover">softcover</a>
for distribution to current and prospective shareholders, describing
the firm's activities during the preceding fiscal year and its current
financial position. Some corporations make their annual reports
available <a href="#online">online</a>.  In <a href="#businesslibrary">business libraries</a>, annual reports are usually retained in a <a href="#companyfile">company file</a> for a fixed <a href="#number">number</a> of years and subsequently <a href="#discard">discard</a>ed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="annualreview"><b>annual review</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> that surveys the most important <a href="#work">work</a>s of original <a href="#research">research</a> and creative thought <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a specific <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or subdiscipline during a given <a href="#calendar">calendar</a> year (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="#arist">Annual Review of Information Science and Technology</a></em>).  In most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, <a href="#annual">annual</a> reviews are placed on <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>.  In the workplace, an inspection or personnel evaluation conducted once a year.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arist"><b><em>Annual Review of Information Science and Technology (ARIST)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issued</a> once a year by the <a href="#asist">American Society for Information Science and Technology</a> (ASIST) and Information Today, <b><em>ARIST</em></b> provides scholarly <a href="#review">review</a>s of <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#topic">topic</a>s in <a href="#infoscience">information science</a> and technology, as substantiated by the <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#literature">literature</a> of the <a href="#field">field</a>.  <a href="#publication">Publication</a> of <b><em>ARIST</em></b>
began in 1966 with the financial support of the National Science
Foundation. Because the field is broad and dynamic, no single topic is
treated on an <a href="#annual">annual</a> basis.  The reviews are critical in the sense of presenting the <a href="#contributor">contributor</a>'s opinion concerning activities, developments, and trends within the <a href="#subject">subject</a> area reviewed.  Each <a href="#volume">volume</a> includes a <a href="#cumulativeindex">cumulative</a> <a href="#keywords">keyword</a> and <a href="#author">author</a> <a href="#index">index</a> to the entire <a href="#series">series</a>.  <a href="#indexing">Indexing</a> and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting</a> of <b><em>ARIST</em></b> is provided in <em><a href="#lisa">Library and Information Science Abstracts</a></em>, <em><a href="#librarylit">Library Literature &amp; Information Science</a></em>, and <em><a href="#eric">ERIC</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="anonymous"><b>anonymous</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> in which the <a href="#author">author</a>'s name does not appear and cannot be traced with certainty in <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a>, or any other reliable <a href="#source">source</a>.  Of <a href="#unknownauth">unknown authorship</a>.  For an entertaining introduction to the methods used to detect the identities of writers of anonymous works, please see <b><em>Author Unknown: On the Trail of Anonymous</em></b> by Don Foster (New York: Henry Holt, 2000).  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>anon</em>.  Compare with <a href="#apocryphal">apocryphal</a> and <a href="#spurious">spurious work</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="anonymousftp"><b>anonymous FTP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ftp">FTP</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="anscr1"><b>ANSCR</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#anscr"><b>A</b>lpha-<b>N</b>umeric <b>S</b>ystem for <b>C</b>lassification of <b>R</b>ecordings</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ansi1"><b>ANSI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ansi"><b>A</b>merican <b>N</b>ational <b>S</b>tandards <b>I</b>nstitute</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="anthology"><b>anthology</b></a>      
</dt><dd>A <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#extract">extract</a>s or complete <a href="#work">work</a>s by various <a href="#author">author</a>s, selected by an <a href="#editor">editor</a> for <a href="#publication">publication</a> in a single <a href="#volume">volume</a> or multi-volume <a href="#set">set</a>.  Anthologies are often limited to a specific literary <a href="#form">form</a> or <a href="#genre">genre</a> (<a href="#shortstory">short stories</a>, <a href="#poetry">poetry</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>s) or to a national <a href="#literature">literature</a>, theme, time period, or category of author.  The works <em>anthologized</em> are listed in the <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a> by <a href="#title">title</a> in the order of their appearance in the <a href="#text">text</a>.  In the <a href="#cardcatalog">card catalog</a>, <a href="#analyticalentry">analytical entries</a> are prepared for works <a href="#publishing">published</a> in anthologies.  In the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>, the individual works contained in an anthology are listed in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> in a <a href="#contentsnote">contents note</a> <a href="#searchable">searchable</a> by <a href="#keywords">keyword(s)</a> in most <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> <a href="#software">software</a>.  Compare with <a href="#compilation">compilation</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#garland">garland</a> and <a href="#miscellany">miscellany</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="antiphonary"><b>antiphonary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#liturgicalwork">liturgical work</a> containing hymns, psalms, or <a href="#verse">verse</a>s chanted or sung responsively by the choir in a worship service.  Also, a <a href="#book">book</a> containing the choral <a href="#part">part</a>s of the Divine Office (canonical hours) of the Catholic Church. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="antiquarianbook"><b>antiquarian book</b></a>
</dt><dd>An old <a href="#outofprint">out-of-print</a> <a href="#usedbook">used book</a>, more valuable than most second-hand <a href="#book">book</a>s because of its <a href="#rarity">rarity</a> and/or <a href="#condition">condition</a>, usually sold by an <a href="#antiquarian">antiquarian bookseller</a>.  Very rare and valuable old books are sold at <a href="#bookauction">auction</a>.  <a href="#priceguide">Price guide</a>s are available for <a href="#appraisal">appraising</a> old books.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#abbookmans">AB Bookman's Weekly</a></em> and <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="antiquarian"><b>antiquarian bookseller</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> who deals in old, <a href="#rarebook">rare</a>, <a href="#finebook">fine</a>, <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>, and <a href="#usedbook">secondhand</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#abaa">ABAA</a>, <em><a href="#abbookmans">AB Bookman's Weekly</a></em>, <a href="#alibris">Alibris</a>, and <a href="#oakknoll">Oak Knoll</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abaa"><b>Antiquarian Booksellers Association of America (ABAA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1949, the <b>ABAA</b> encourages interest in <a href="#finebook">fine</a> and <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian book</a>s and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s (and other <a href="#rarity">rare</a> or valuable <a href="#printing">printed</a> materials), promotes ethical <a href="#standards">standards</a> and <a href="#professionalism">professionalism</a> in the antiquarian <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, encourages <a href="#bookcollecting">collecting</a> and <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, advances technical and general <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> useful to the trade, sponsors <a href="#bookfair">book fair</a>s, and facilitates collegial relations among <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, scholars, and <a href="#bookcollecting">collector</a>s.  <a href="http://www.abaa.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ABAA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ilab">International League of Antiquarian Booksellers</a>.<p>
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="antique"><b>antique</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, the unpolished <a href="#matte">matte</a> <a href="#finish">finish</a> produced when uncoated <a href="#paper">paper</a> is <em>not</em> processed through a <a href="#calender">calender</a>ing machine.  <a href="#eggshell">Eggshell</a> is a smooth, slightly pitted antique finish.  Also refers to a contemporary <a href="#calf">calf</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a> designed to imitate an older binding.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="antiquebinding"><b>antique binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A modern <a href="#binding">binding</a> done in the style of an earlier period, with no intent to mislead prospective buyers as to its actual age.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="antivirus"><b>anti-virus software</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a> designed to periodically check the <a href="#harddisk">hard drive</a> of a computer (or all the computers attached to a <a href="#network">network</a>) for the presence of man-made computer <a href="#virus">virus</a>es and eliminate them if found.  The anti-virus <a href="#software">software</a> used on computer <a href="#network">network</a>s usually includes an <a href="#update">update</a> feature that automatically <a href="#download">download</a>s profiles of newly-created viruses soon after they are detected.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="antonym"><b>antonym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> which is the <em>opposite</em> in meaning of another <a href="#term">term</a>.  <a href="#dictionary">Dictionaries</a> of antonyms are available in the <a href="#refstacks">reference section</a> of larger <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  In some <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>s, one of the terms in a pair of opposites may be selected to represent both, with a <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a> made from the other.  The opposite of <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aol1"><b>AOL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aol"><b>A</b>merica <b>O</b>n<b>l</b>ine</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="apa"><b>APA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#alaallied">ALA <b>A</b>llied <b>P</b>rofessional <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="apala1"><b>APALA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#apala"><b>A</b>sian-<b>P</b>acific <b>A</b>merican <b>L</b>ibrarians <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="apastyle"><b>APA style</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#guide">guide</a> for typing <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a>s in the social sciences, developed by the <b>A</b>merican <b>P</b>sychological <b>A</b>ssociation, which includes the proper <a href="#format">format</a> for typing <a href="#note">note</a>s and <a href="#bibliography">bibliographic</a> <a href="#citation">citation</a>s.  APA style is described fully in the most recent <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the <b><em>Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association</em></b>, available in the <a href="#refstacks">reference section</a> of most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>.  <a href="http://dir.yahoo.com/Social_Science/Linguistics_and_Human_Languages/Languages/Specific_Languages/English/Grammar__Usage__and_Style/Style_Guides/APA_Style/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of APA style guides.  Compare with <a href="#mlastyle">MLA style</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicstyle">electronic style</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aperturecard"><b>aperture card</b></a>
</dt><dd>A card containing one or more small windows in which individual <a href="#frame">frame</a>s cut from a strip of <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> are <a href="#mounted">mounted</a>.  This <a href="#format">format</a> allows microfilm images to be used independently and provides a convenient surface for <a href="#record">record</a>ing pertinent <a href="#information">information</a> about each frame.  Synonymous with <em>image card</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="apha1"><b>APHA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#apha"><b>A</b>merican <b>P</b>rinting <b>H</b>istory <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aphorism"><b>aphorism</b></a>
</dt><dd>A very concise sentence or statement ("nugget") that
expresses, in a pointedly memorable way, a universally recognized truth
or principle. A maxim (<em>example</em>: "Well begun is half done.").  Aphorisms <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#collection">collection</a>s are usually shelved in the <a href="#refstacks">reference section</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Oxford Book of Aphorisms</em></b>). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="apocryphal"><b>apocryphal</b></a>
</dt><dd>Writings which scholars consider to be of dubious <a href="#authorship">authorship</a> or <a href="#authenticity">authenticity</a> (not genuine), for example, the 14-15 <a href="#book">book</a>s of the Greek <a href="#translation">translation</a>s of the Old Testament (Septuagint), known as the <em>Apocrypha</em>, accepted as <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> by the Roman Catholic and Greek Orthodox churches, but rejected in Judaism and not considered <a href="#canon">canon</a>ical in Protestantism.  Compare with <a href="#anonymous">anonymous</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#spurious">spurious work</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="apostil"><b>apostil</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#margin">margin</a>al <a href="#note">note</a> or <a href="#annotation">annotation</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>.  Also spelled <em>apostille</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="appendix"><b>appendix</b></a>
</dt><dd>A part of a written <a href="#work">work</a>, not essential to the completeness of the <a href="#text">text</a>, containing complementary  <a href="#information">information</a> such as statistical <a href="#table">table</a>s or explanatory material too long to be included in the text, or in <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s or <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>s.  An appendix differs from an <a href="#addendum">addendum</a> in having been planned in advance as an integral part of the <a href="#publication">publication</a>, rather than conceived after <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a> occurs.  <em>Appendices</em> usually appear in the <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>, following the text and preceding the <a href="#note">note</a>s, <a href="#glossary">glossary</a>, <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, and <a href="#index">index</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>app</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="applet"><b>applet</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> written in the <a href="#java">Java</a> <a href="#proglang">programming language</a> developed by Sun Microsystems for distribution over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  Applets run on any Java-enabled <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> independent of <a href="#platform">platform</a> (<a href="#windows">Windows</a>, <a href="#macintosh">Macintosh</a>, <a href="#unix">UNIX</a>, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="applicant"><b>applicant</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who has made a formal request to be considered for employment, usually by filling out an <a href="#application">application</a> form or by sending a <a href="#resume">resume</a> or <em><a href="#cv">curriculum vitae</a></em> with <a href="#coverletter">cover letter</a> to a prospective employer in response to a job posting.  Compare with <a href="#candidate">candidate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="application"><b>application</b></a>
</dt><dd>Computer <a href="#software">software</a> that allows the user to process <a href="#data">data</a> or perform calculations necessary to achieve a desired result, as opposed to the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> designed to control the computer's <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> and run all other <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s.  Common <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> applications include <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a>, <a href="#spreadsheet">spreadsheet</a>, <a href="#email">e-mail</a>, presentation <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s, <a href="#desktop">desktop publishing</a>, <a href="#dbmanagement">database management system</a>s, and <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#multitasking">multitasking</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a formal request to be considered for employment, usually made by filling out a form or by submitting a <a href="#resume">resume</a> or <em><a href="#cv">curriculum vitae</a></em> with <a href="#coverletter">cover letter</a> in response to a job posting.  Each <a href="#library">library</a> develops its own application procedure, unless it is part of a larger organization that uses a standardized procedure.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="appm"><b><em>APPM</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><em><b>A</b>rchives, <b>P</b>ersonal <b>P</b>apers, and <b>M</b>anuscripts</em>, a <a href="#standard">standard</a> for the description of archival materials based on <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, accepted by most <a href="#archives">archives</a> in the United States.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="appraisal"><b>appraisal</b></a>
</dt><dd>The monetary valuation of <a href="#gift">gift</a>s, usually done at the request of an <a href="#archives">archives</a>, <a href="#library">library</a>, or museum, by a professional <em>appraiser</em> familiar with the market for the type of item(s) donated.  Also refers to the process of evaluating <a href="#records">records</a> to determine whether they are to be archived indefinitely, retained for a shorter period, or <a href="#disposition">disposed</a> of in some other way (sold, donated, <a href="#destruction">destroyed</a>, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="approvalplan"><b>approval plan</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal arrangement in which a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#jobber">wholesaler</a> agrees to <a href="#selection">select</a> and supply, subject to <a href="#returns">return</a> privileges specified in advance, <a href="#publication">publication</a>s exactly as <a href="#issue">issue</a>d which fit a <a href="#library">library</a>'s pre-established <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> <a href="#profile">profile</a>.  Approval profiles usually specify <a href="#subject">subject</a> areas, levels of <a href="#specialization">specialization</a> or reading difficulty, <a href="#series">series</a>, <a href="#format">format</a>s, <a href="#price">price</a> ranges, <a href="#language">language</a>s, etc.  Some plans provide advance <a href="#notificationslip">notification slip</a>s instead of sending the actual physical <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  Compare with <a href="#blanketorder">blanket order</a> and <a href="#booklease">book lease plan</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="approvals"><b>approvals</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#newbook">New book</a>s sent automatically by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#jobber">wholesaler</a> in accordance with a pre-established <a href="#profile">profile</a> of the <a href="#library">library</a>'s needs, rather than ordered <a href="#title">title</a>-by-title by the <a href="#selection">selectors</a> responsible for <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>.  Approvals not <a href="#returns">returned</a> within an agreed upon time are understood to have been accepted by the library.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="approvalshelf"><b>approval shelf</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shelf or shelves, usually located in or near the <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> department of a <a href="#library">library</a>, where <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s ordered on <a href="#approvalplan">approval</a> are stored pending examination by the <a href="#selection">selectors</a> responsible for deciding whether they are to be added to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> or returned to the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#jobber">wholesaler</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="approved"><b>approved library school</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the United States, a <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> that offers a program recognized or certified by a state board or educational <a href="#agency">agency</a> as meeting its <a href="#standards">standards</a> of quality and <a href="#professionalism">professionalism</a>.  Some approved library schools are also <a href="#ala">ALA</a>-<a href="#accreditation">accredited</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="approximatewhole"><b>approximate the whole</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a <a href="#work">work</a> which is nearly coextensive with the <a href="#subject">subject</a>(s) represented by a <a href="#class">class</a> in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, or which covers more than half the <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#heading">heading</a>, or which covers representative examples from three or more <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a>s of the class.  The <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> is permitted to add <a href="#standardsubdivision">standard subdivision</a>s to a work that approximates the whole of a subject (adapted from <em>DDC</em>).  Compare with <a href="#standingroom">standing room</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arabesque"><b>arabesque</b></a>
</dt><dd>An elaborate Islamic-style design consisting of intricately
interlaced lines which may include flowers and foliage, or geometric
patterns, stamped as a decoration on the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or used by a <a href="#printer">printer</a> to <a href="#printersornament">ornament</a> a <a href="#text">text</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arabicnumeral"><b>arabic numeral</b></a>
