</dt><dd>One of the ten digits (<b>0</b> <b>1</b> <b>2</b> <b>3</b> <b>4</b> <b>5</b> <b>6</b> <b>7</b> <b>8</b> <b>9</b>) developed in India in the 6th century to indicate <a href="#number">number</a>
in a system of place value based on ten. Arabic numerals were adopted
by the Arabs around 900 AD, who introduced them in Europe via Spain
about 100 years later, where they replaced <a href="#romannumeral">roman numeral</a>s.  Colonization introduced them to the rest of the world.
<p>
The <a href="#notation">notation</a> used in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> is composed entirely of arabic <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s.  They are also used in <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a> notation to indicate <a href="#subclass">subclass</a>es, following the <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> used to represent <a href="#mainclass">main class</a>es and divisions.  In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#pagination">pagination</a> is in arabic numerals, except for the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> in <a href="#book">book</a>s which is done in roman numerals.  Arabic numerals are also used to indicate the sequence of <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s and <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>s.  Under <em><a href="#alafiling">ALA Filing Rules</a></em>, <a href="#heading">heading</a>s and <a href="#title">title</a>s
that begin with arabic numerals (including dates) precede those
beginning with letters of the alphabet, arranged according to value
from lowest to highest. </p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arba1"><b><em>ARBA</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#arba"><b>A</b>merican <b>R</b>eference <b>B</b>ooks <b>A</b>nnual</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archetypalnovel"><b>archetypal novel</b></a>
</dt><dd>Early <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>al <a href="#tale">tale</a>s and <a href="#romance">romance</a>s considered to be precursors of the <a href="#novel">novel</a> in its modern form (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Tale of Genji</em></b> by Lady Shikibu Murasaki).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="architecturalbinding"><b>architectural binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of ornamental <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> popular during the 16th century in which the front <a href="#cover">cover</a> was decorated with architectural columns on either side, supporting an arch or lintel across the top, beneath which the <a href="#title">title</a> is displayed on a <a href="#panel">panel</a>, the style of the cover bearing no relation to the <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cathedral">cathedral binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="architecturaldrawing"><b>architectural drawing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A drawing or <a href="#sketch">sketch</a> of a proposed
construction project, done by an architect or architectural firm. A
full set of drawings, showing all phases of the construction process,
includes the specifications used by contractors for bidding, purchase
of materials and equipment, etc. Synonymous with <a href="#blueprint">blueprint</a>, a term derived from the process used to duplicate them which produces a white image on a blue ground.  Compare with <a href="#architecturalrendering">architectural rendering</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="architecturalrendering"><b>architectural rendering</b></a>
</dt><dd>A pictorial representation of a building or other structure,
usually from an angle showing the front or main entrance, created by
the architect or an architectural firm to give an accurate, if somewhat
idealized, impression of how the structure will appear after it is
constructed. Sometimes used in <a href="#fundraising">fund-raising</a> to promote <a href="#capitalexp">capital project</a>s, such as the <a href="#newconstruc">construction</a> of a new <a href="#library">library</a> facility or the <a href="#renovation">renovation</a> and/or <a href="#expansion">expansion</a> of an existing one.  Compare with <a href="#architecturaldrawing">architectural drawing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="architecturelib"><b>architecture library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A specialized <a href="#library">library</a> associated with a graduate school of architecture or a large architectural firm, containing <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s on architecture and architectural engineering, building codes and <a href="#standards">standards</a>, <a href="#architecturaldrawing">architectural drawing</a>s and <a href="#architecturalrendering">rendering</a>s, <a href="#index">index</a>es and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s, <a href="#database">database</a>s, and other <a href="#refbook">reference materials</a> for <a href="#research">research</a> in architecture and related <a href="#field">field</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archivalcopy"><b>archival copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a> specifically created or designated for <a href="#archives">archival</a>
storage by the company, government, organization, or institution that
wishes to preserve it, usually for legal, evidential, or historical
purposes. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#archivalquality">archival quality</a> and <a href="#presphotocopy">preservation photocopy</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archivaldatabase"><b>archival database</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organized <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#records">records</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, containing <a href="#information">information</a>
to be retained for an indefinite period of time, usually for future
reference, for example, the messages received and distributed by an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> <a href="#mailinglist">discussion list</a>, or the <a href="#refquestion">reference question</a>s received by an <a href="#electronicref">electronic reference</a> service, including the answers provided. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archivaljournal"><b>archival journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> mainly for <a href="#archives">archival</a> purposes, as opposed to one intended for distribution to retailers and individual <a href="#subscription">subscriber</a>s, usually priced for the <a href="#librarymarket">library market</a> with little or no attempt to market it to a wider <a href="#audience">audience</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archivalpaper"><b>archival paper</b></a>
</dt><dd>A grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a> that is <a href="#permanentpaper">permanent</a> and highly <a href="#durability">durable</a>, particularly with respect to fading and physical <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> caused by <a href="#acidic">acidity</a>, used for <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> of <a href="#archivalquality">archival quality</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ragpaper">rag paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archivalquality"><b>archival quality</b></a>
</dt><dd>The physical properties of <a href="#records">records</a> in all <a href="#medium">media</a> (<a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#microform">microform</a>, <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a> or <a href="#disk">disk</a>, <a href="#opticaldisk">optical disk</a>, etc.) which make them suitable for permanent storage in <a href="#archives">archives</a>.  Items <a href="#printing">printed</a> on paper must have a <a href="#ph">pH</a> of 7 or higher and be free of other contaminates (chemicals, <a href="#mildew">mildew</a>, etc.).  Synonymous with <em>archival standard</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#archivalpaper">archival paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archivalvalue"><b>archival value</b></a>
</dt><dd>The decision, following <a href="#appraisal">appraisal</a> by a knowledgeable expert (or experts), that a <a href="#document">document</a>, <a href="#record">record</a>, or group of <a href="#records">records</a> is worth <a href="#preservation">preserving</a>, permanently or for an indefinite period.  Records are retained for their:
<p>
</p></dd><dt></dt><dl><dd><b><em>Administrative value</em></b> - utility in the conduct of current or future administrative affairs
</dd><dd><b><em>Evidential value</em></b> - capacity of records to furnish proof of facts concerning their <a href="#creator">creator</a> or the events/activities to which they pertain 
</dd><dd><b><em>Fiscal value</em></b> - utility in the conduct of financial business or fiscal accounting 
</dd><dd><b><em>Historical value</em></b> - capacity to document past events, providing information about the lives and activities of persons involved in them 
</dd><dd><b><em>Informational value</em></b> - usefulness for <a href="#reference">reference</a> and <a href="#research">research</a>
</dd><dd><b><em>Intrinsic value</em></b> - inherent worth of a document based on its <a href="#content">content</a>, cultural significance, antiquity, past uses, etc.
</dd><dd><b><em>Legal value</em></b> - utility in the conduct of future legal proceedings, or as evidence of past legal decisions 
</dd><dd><b><em>Monetary value</em></b> - worth in the market place, based on appraisal by a person experienced in making such judgments
</dd></dl><p>  
</p><dd>Compare with <a href="#artifactual">artifactual value</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#primaryvalues">primary values</a> and <a href="#secondaryvalues">secondary values</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archive"><b>archive</b></a>
</dt><dd>The building, facility, or area that houses an <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#collection">collection</a> (the term <a href="#repository">repository</a> is preferred by most <a href="#archivist">archivist</a>s).  Also, to place <a href="#document">document</a>s in storage, usually to <a href="#preservation">preserve</a> them as an historical, <a href="#information">information</a>al, legal, or evidential <a href="#record">record</a>, permanently or for a finite or indefinite period of time.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archives"><b>archives</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organized <a href="#collection">collection</a> of the <a href="#noncurrent">noncurrent</a> <a href="#records">records</a> of the activities of a business, government, organization, institution, or other <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a>, or the <a href="#personalpapers">personal papers</a> of one or more individuals, families, or groups, <a href="#retention">retained</a>
permanently (or for a designated or indeterminate period of time) by
their originator or a successor for their permanent historical, <a href="#information">information</a>al, evidential, legal, administrative, or monetary value, usually in a <a href="#repository">repository</a> managed and maintained by a trained <a href="#archivist">archivist</a>.  Also refers to the office or organization responsible for <a href="#appraisal">appraising</a>, selecting, <a href="#preservation">preserving</a>, and providing <a href="#access">access</a> to archival materials.  
<p>
Archives can be classified in three broad categories:  <a href="#govarchives">government archives</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#nara">National Archives and Records Administration</a>), <a href="#inhousearchives">in-house archives</a> maintained by a parent institution, and <a href="#collectingarchives">collecting archives</a> (<a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#filmarchives">film archives</a>, <a href="#genealogy">genealogical</a> archives, <a href="#soundarchives">sound archives</a>, <a href="#personalarchives">personal archives</a>, etc.).  Compare with <a href="#archive">archive</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#archivalcopy">archival copy</a>, <a href="#archivaldatabase">archival database</a>, <a href="#archivalpaper">archival paper</a>, <a href="#archivalquality">archival quality</a>, <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>, <a href="#digitalarchives">digital archives</a>, and <a href="#saa">Society of American Archivists</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archivesbox"><b>archives box</b></a>
</dt><dd>A container of standard size with a hinged or lift-off lid, used to store and facilitate the handling of <a href="#archives">archival</a> materials, usually constructed of <a href="#acidfree">acid-</a> and <a href="#lignin">lignin</a>-free cardboard held together without <a href="#glue">glue</a> or metal staples.  Boxes made of inert <a href="#polypropylene">polypropylene</a> plastic are also used for this purpose.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#boxlist">box list</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archivespolicy"><b>archives policy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal written statement defining the authority under which an <a href="#archives">archives</a> operates, the scope of its activities (<a href="#mission">mission</a>, <a href="#objective">objective</a>s, conditions/restrictions, etc.), and the range of services it provides.  Compare with <a href="#accesspolicy">access policy</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="archivist"><b>archivist</b></a>
</dt><dd>The person responsible for managing and maintaining an <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, usually a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> with special training in archival practices and methods, including the identification and <a href="#appraisal">appraisal</a> of <a href="#records">records</a> of <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>, <a href="#authentication">authentication</a>, <a href="#accession">accession</a>ing, description/<a href="#documentation">documentation</a>, facilitation of <a href="#access">access</a> and use, <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> and <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>, and <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ion and <a href="#publication">publication</a> to benefit scholarship and satisfy public interest.  Archivists are organized in the <a href="#saa">Society of American Archivists</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alhhs"><b>Archivists and Librarians in the History of the Health Sciences (ALHHS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#association">association</a> of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#archivist">archivist</a>s, and other specialists actively engaged in the <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a> of the history of the health sciences, dedicated to the exchange of <a href="#information">information</a> and to improving <a href="#standards">standards</a> of service.  <a href="http://www.alhhs.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ALHHS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="area"><b>area</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of the major portions of description comprising the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> created to represent a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>.  Each area ia reserved for <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s of a specific category (or categories).  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the <a href="#standard">standard</a> areas of a <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> are:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><a href="#titleand">Title and statement of responsibility</a> (<a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#field">field</a> 245)
</dd><dd><a href="#editionarea">Edition</a> (MARC field 250)
</dd><dd><a href="#materialspecific">Material specific details</a> (MARC field 254 for music, 255 for <a href="#cartographic">cartographic material</a>, and 362 for <a href="#serial">serial</a>s)
</dd><dd><a href="#publicationarea">Publication, distribution, etc.</a> (MARC field 260)
</dd><dd><a href="#physicaldescrip">Physical description</a> (MARC field 300)
</dd><dd><a href="#seriesarea">Series</a> (MARC fields 4XX)
</dd><dd><a href="#notearea">Note</a> (MARC fields 5XX)
</dd><dd><a href="#standardnumberandterms">Standard number and terms of availability</a> (MARC field 020 or 022)</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="areastudy"><b>area study</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> that provides factual <a href="#information">information</a>
about a specific region of the world (Africa, Asia, Europe, Latin
America, the Middle East, etc.), including a description of its
physical and social geography, economy, history, governments, and
cultures, and which may also contain pertinent statistical and <a href="#directory">directory</a> information.  Area studies are often <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#serial">serial</a>ly (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Far East and Australia</em></b> in the <a href="#series">series</a>  <em>Regional Surveys of the World</em>, published <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by Europa).  Compare with <a href="#countrystudy">country study</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="argot"><b>argot</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#idiom">idiom</a>atic <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a>
of a group or class of people, or of the members of a specific
occupation or profession, particularly those who are on the margins of
conventional society. <a href="#dictionary">Dictionaries</a> of argot are available in the <a href="#refstacks">reference section</a> of larger <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  Compare with <a href="#slang">slang</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#jargon">jargon</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ariadne"><b><em>Ariadne</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#electronicjournal">electronic journal</a> for academic <a href="#infoscience">information science</a> professionals, reporting on issues and developments in <a href="#information">information</a> service and information <a href="#network">network</a>ing worldwide.  <a href="#publishing">Published</a> <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> by <a href="http://www.ukoln.ac.uk/">UKOLN</a>, <b><em>Ariadne</em></b> is aimed at keeping the practitioner informed of <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#digitallibrary">digital library</a> initiatives.  <a href="http://www.ariadne.ac.uk/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>Ariadne</em></b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ariel"><b><em>Ariel</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#document">document</a> transmission system developed by the <a href="#rlg">Research Libraries Group</a> (RLG) which provides rapid, inexpensive, high-quality document delivery over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> by integrating <a href="#scanner">scanning</a>, sending, receiving, and <a href="#printing">printing</a> functions.  The user can send <a href="#text">text</a> and gray-scale images (<a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, etc.) in letter, legal, and other sizes to another <b><em>Ariel</em></b> <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>, to an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> account used by an <b><em>Ariel</em></b> machine, or to anyone who uses <a href="#mime">MIME</a>-compliant e-mail <a href="#software">software</a> and a multipage <a href="#tiff">TIFF</a> viewer.  The system is used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> to facilitate <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> and <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery service</a>.  <a href="http://www.rlg.org/ariel/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the RLG <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> for <b><em>Ariel</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arist1"><b><em>ARIST</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#arist"><b>A</b>nnual <b>R</b>eview of <b>I</b>nformation <b>S</b>cience and <b>T</b>echnology</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aristonym"><b>aristonym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#surname">surname</a> used as, or derived from, a formal <a href="#title">title</a> of nobility (<em>example</em>:  <b>Thomas Harold Andre Le Duc</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arl1"><b>ARL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#arl"><b>A</b>ssociation of <b>R</b>esearch <b>L</b>ibraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arlisna1"><b>ARLIS/NA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#arlisna"><b>Ar</b>t <b>Li</b>braries <b>S</b>ociety/<b>N</b>orth <b>A</b>merica</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arma1"><b>ARMA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#arma">Association for Information Management Professionals</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="armarian"><b>armarian</b></a>
</dt><dd>The person charged with keeping the <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and <a href="#book">book</a>s owned by a medieval monastery in good order and repair, also responsible for maintaining an <a href="#accuracy">accurate</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> of the <a href="#library">library</a>'s contents.  It was also the armarian's duty to keep the <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>s and <a href="#illuminate">illuminator</a>s in the <a href="#scriptorium">scriptorium</a> well-supplied with <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>, pens, <a href="#ink">ink</a>, pigments, gold and silver <a href="#leaf">leaf</a>, and other materials needed to <a href="#copy">copy</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustrate</a>, and <a href="#binding">bind</a> books by hand.  Synonymous with <em>armarius</em>.  Compare with <a href="#armarium">armarium</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="armarium"><b>armarium</b></a>
</dt><dd>A wooden cupboard or free-standing piece of furniture with shelves and doors, first used to store <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>s, and eventually <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and <a href="#book">book</a>s.  Known to have existed during the Roman Empire, <em>armaria</em> were used in medieval monasteries until the end of the Renaissance.  Compare with <a href="#armarian">armarian</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#capsa">capsa</a> and <a href="#scriptorium">scriptorium</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="armorial"><b>armorial binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">binding</a>, usually in <a href="#leather">leather</a>, decorated with a coat-of-arms or other heraldic device to indicate the royal or noble lineage of its original owner.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arpanet"><b>ARPAnet</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>A</b>dvanced <b>R</b>esearch <b>P</b>rojects <b>A</b>gency <b>net</b>work, the first computer <a href="#network">network</a> to use <a href="#packet">packet switching</a>.  Funded by the U.S. Advanced Research Projects Agency in 1969, <b>ARPAnet</b> linked <a href="#research">research</a>
computers on two University of California campuses with the Stanford
Research Institute and the University of Utah. In 1983, with more than
300 computers connected, its <a href="#protocol">protocol</a>s were changed to <a href="#tcpip">TCP/IP</a> and it became known as the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  In 1987, when the National Science Foundation (NSF) began to develop a high-speed <a href="#opticalfiber">fiber-optic</a> <a href="#backbone">backbone</a> to connect <a href="#supercomputer">supercomputer</a> centers, intermediate networks of regional <b>ARPAnet</b> sites began connecting to the backbone.  In 1995, commercial <a href="#internetservice">Internet service provider</a>s assumed control of the major backbones in the United States.  Traffic over the "Net" continues to expand.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arrangement"><b>arrangement</b></a>
</dt><dd>A portion of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a>, or an entire <a href="#work">work</a>, rewritten for a <a href="#mediumofperf">medium of performance</a> or market other than the one for which the <a href="#original">original</a> was intended (synonymous in this sense with <em>transcription</em>); or a simplified or amplified version of a musical <a href="#composition">composition</a>, written for the same medium.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, an arrangement is, as a general rule, <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under the name of the <a href="#composer">composer</a>, with an <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> under the name of the <a href="#arranger">arranger</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the process of putting <a href="#records">records</a> into order, following accepted archival principles, with special attention given to their <a href="#provenance">provenance</a> and <a href="#originalorder">original order</a>.  If, upon careful scrutiny, the original order is found to be completely random, the <a href="#archivist">archivist</a> may, after carefully <a href="#documentation">documenting</a> the original sequence, substitute an impartial arrangement that is more convenient to use. 
</p><p>
In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, the process of putting in systematic and consistent order the <a href="#heading">heading</a>s under which <a href="#entry">entries</a> are listed.  The sequence can be <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>, numerical, or <a href="#classifiedindex">classified</a> in some manner.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arranger"><b>arranger</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who transforms an entire <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a>, or a major portion of a such a <a href="#work">work</a>, to a <a href="#mediumofperf">medium of performance</a> other than the one intended by the original <a href="#composer">composer</a>,
or who extends or simplifies a work in the same medium, retaining a
substantial amount of the original musical structure. Under <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, an <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> is, as a general rule, <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under the name of the composer, with an <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> under the name of the arranger.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="array"><b>array</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>arredare</em> meaning "to arrange in order."  In an <a href="#index">index</a> or <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">term</a>s, a display of <a href="#entry">entries</a>, <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s, etc., in an orderly sequence.  In <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a>, a set of mutually exclusive and <a href="#exhaustivity">exhaustive</a> coordinate <a href="#subclass">subclass</a>es dividing a <a href="#class">class</a> by a single <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>, for example, the array "<a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>," "<a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a>," "<a href="#magazine">magazine</a>," and "<a href="#journal">journal</a>" dividing the class "<a href="#periodical">periodical</a>" by form.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arrears"><b>arrears</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#library">Library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in need of <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>,
which have accumulated to the point of requiring a special effort to
process, usually the result of heavy ordering, receipt of a large <a href="#gift">gift</a>, or insufficient personnel to maintain normal <a href="#workflow">workflow</a>.  Synonymous in this sense with <a href="#backlog">backlog</a>.  Also refers to the state of being behind in the payment of <a href="#salary">salaries</a>, <a href="#wages">wages</a>, <a href="#invoice">invoice</a>s, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arsc1"><b>ARSC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#arsc"><b>A</b>ssociation for <b>R</b>ecorded <b>S</b>ound <b>C</b>ollections</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="art"><b>art</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general term used in <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> and <a href="#printing">printing</a> for the <a href="#illustration">illustrative</a> matter in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, for which no <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> of <a href="#type">type</a> is required, including any hand <a href="#lettering">lettering</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>s of drawings, <a href="#print">print</a>s, and paintings, etc.  Compare with <a href="#artwork">artwork</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="artbook"><b>art book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#volume">volume</a>, usually of relatively large size, containing high-quality <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>s of <a href="#work">work</a>s of visual art (paintings, drawings, <a href="#print">print</a>s, etc.) or <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s of sculpture, architecture, or other three-dimensional works of art, usually with accompanying <a href="#text">text</a>.  In an <a href="#exhibitcatalog">exhibit catalog</a>, the text may be minimal.  Because art books are expensive to produce, they are sometimes <a href="#copublishing">co-published</a> to achieve economies of scale.  Compare with <a href="#coffee">coffee table book</a>.
<p>
Also refers to books created as a form of visual and/or tactile artistic expression (see <b><em>Structure of the Visual Book</em></b> by Scott McCarney and Keith A. Smith).  Art books created for <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ion may be <a href="#oneofakind">one-of-a-kind</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bookart">book art</a> and <a href="#foldedbook">folded book</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="article"><b>article</b></a>
</dt><dd>A self-contained <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> <a href="#prose">prose</a> <a href="#composition">composition</a> on a fairly narrow <a href="#topic">topic</a> or <a href="#subject">subject</a>, written by one or more <a href="#author">author</a>s and <a href="#publishing">published</a> under a separate <a href="#title">title</a> in a <a href="#collection">collection</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> containing other <a href="#work">work</a>s of the same <a href="#form">form</a>.  The length of a periodical article is often an indication of the type of <a href="#publication">publication</a>--<a href="#magazine">magazine</a> articles are usually less than five pages long, articles published in scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a>s longer than five pages.  Periodical articles are <a href="#indexing">indexed</a>, usually by <a href="#author">author</a> and <a href="#subject">subject</a>, in <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s, called <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s when available on computer.  Compare with <a href="#editorial">editorial</a> and <a href="#essay">essay</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#coverstory">cover story</a> and <a href="#feature">feature</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to the words <em>a</em>, <em>an</em>, or <em>the</em>, or their equivalent in another <a href="#language">language</a>, used as adjectives preceding a noun, <em>the</em> being the definite article, and <em>a</em> and <em>an</em> indefinite articles.  In <a href="#library">library</a> filing, an initial article is ignored at the beginning of a <a href="#heading">heading</a>.  An initial article is also ignored at the beginning of a <a href="#title">title</a> in a <a href="#search">search</a> of an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> by title.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="artifact"><b>artifact</b></a>
</dt><dd>An object made or modified by the work of one or more persons (<a href="#replica">replica</a>s excluded), as distinct from a natural object called a <a href="#specimen">specimen</a> when collected.  Objects created for their aesthetic value are considered <a href="#work">work</a>s of art.  The value of an item to collectors as a physical object is usually reduced by any modification.  Also spelled <em>artefact</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#realia">realia</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="artifactual"><b>artifactual value</b></a>
</dt><dd>The worth of a thing as a physical object, for example, a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> that has little value in the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> market, but is important to <a href="#text">text</a>ual scholars because of its <a href="#typography">typographic</a> <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>s, or to book historians because of its unusual <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Normally, any modification of such an object reduces its value.  Compare with <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="artificialdigit"><b>artificial digit</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, a <a href="#letter">letter</a> or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> used optionally as a substitute for the <a href="#arabicnumeral">numeral</a>s 0-9 to give various <a href="#language">language</a>s, <a href="#literature">literature</a>s, religions, cultures, and ethnic groups a more prominent location or shorter <a href="#notation">notation</a> (adapted from <em>DDC</em>).  For example, under <a href="#class">class</a>es 810-890 (Literature of specific languages), Option B to "give preferred treatment by placing before <b>810</b> through use of a letter or other symbol, e.g., literature of Arabic language <b>8A0</b>, for which the <a href="#basenumber">base number</a> is <b>8A</b>."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="artificial"><b>artificial intelligence (AI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Mechanical and electronic devices and <a href="#application">application</a>s designed to closely mimic the human ability to learn, reason, and make decisions.  <b>AI</b> is used in <a href="#voicerecognition">voice recognition</a> technology, <a href="#expertsystem">expert system</a>s, <a href="#naturallang">natural language</a> and foreign <a href="#language">language</a> processing, and robotics.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="artificiallang"><b>artificial language</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#language">language</a> constructed from a pre-established set of rules.  Its <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a> can be a <a href="#subset">subset</a> of a <a href="#naturallang">natural language</a>, as in a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, or composed of <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s, as in a language used in <a href="#computerprogram">programming computers</a>.  Synonymous with <em>synthetic language</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="artificialleather"><b>artificial leather</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#imitationleather">imitation leather</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arlisna"><b>Art Libraries Society/North America (ARLIS/NA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1972, <b>ARLIS</b> is an organization of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, institutions, and individuals with an interest in art <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a> and the <a href="#curator">curator</a>ship of visual art resources in <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, museums, galleries, art institutes, and <a href="#publisher">publishing house</a>s.  An <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>ARLIS</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em><a href="http://www.arlisna.org/index__838.html">ARLIS/NA Update</a></em> five times a year.  <a href="http://www.arlisna.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ARLIS/NA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#artlibrary">art library</a>.
<p>   
</p></dd><dt><a name="artlibrary"><b>art library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> charged with <a href="#acquisitions">acquiring</a>, organizing, <a href="#preservation">preserving</a>, and providing <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#information">information</a> and resources in the diverse fields constituting the visual arts (architecture, drawing, <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> design, painting, photography, sculpture, etc.).  An art library usually functions as a unit within a larger <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> or <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>, or as a <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a> maintained by a <a href="#hostorg">host organization</a> such as a gallery, museum, art institute, or <a href="#publisher">publishing house</a>.
The first modern art library in the United States was founded in 1871
by the San Francisco Art Association (now the San Francisco Art
Institute). <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#artbook">art book</a> and <a href="#arlisna">Art Libraries Society/North America</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="artoriginal"><b>art original</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#work">work</a> of art created by an artist in two or three dimensions, as distinct from a <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> of such a work.  The term is not applied to <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s and art <a href="#print">print</a>s which can be produced in multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a> by a person other than the artist.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="artprint"><b>art print</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See </em></b>:  <a href="#print">print</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="artwork"><b>artwork</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general term used in <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> and <a href="#printing">printing</a> to refer to <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> <a href="#original">original</a>s in any <a href="#medium">medium</a>, as opposed to <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>s of art originals.  Such <a href="#work">work</a>s may have artistic and monetary value independent of the <a href="#publication">publication</a> for which they were created.  Compare with <a href="#art">art</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ascender"><b>ascender</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typography">typography</a> and <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, the stroke of a <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a> that extends above the highest point of an <a href="#xheight">x-height</a> letter (<b>a</b>, <b>c</b>, <b>e</b>, <b>m</b>, etc.).  The letters of the Latin <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> with ascenders are: <b>b</b>, <b>d</b>, <b>f</b>, <b>h</b>, <b>k</b>, <b>l</b>, and <b>t</b>.  The <em>ascender line</em> is an imaginary horizontal line connecting the tops of ascender letters, often, but not necessarily, the same as the <a href="#capline">cap line</a>.  Compare with <a href="#descender">descender</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#primaryletter">primary letter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ascii"><b>ASCII</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <b>A</b>merican <b>S</b>tandard <b>C</b>ode for <b>I</b>nformation <b>I</b>nterchange (pronounced "askee"), the <a href="#binary">binary</a> code built into most <a href="#minicomputer">minicomputer</a>s and all <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a>s to represent <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> and <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s, and special <a href="#character">character</a>s in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  Each <b>ASCII</b> character consists of seven <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#bit">bit</a>s and one <a href="#paritybit">parity bit</a> for error checking.  
<p>
Designed to facilitate information exchange between nonstandard <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a> and <a href="#communications">communications</a> equipment, <b>ASCII</b> is recognized by the <a href="#ansi">American National Standards Institute</a> (ANSI).  Also refers to <a href="#text">text</a> that has been <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> to <b>ASCII</b> code.  Unlike text containing special <a href="#formatting">formatting</a>, <b>ASCII</b> can be <a href="#import">import</a>ed and <a href="#export">export</a>ed by most <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s without conversion, and requires no special <a href="#software">software</a> for display and <a href="#printing">printing</a>. <em>ASCII text</em> is also called <a href="#vanillatext">vanilla text</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ascla1"><b>ASCLA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ascla"><b>A</b>ssociation of <b>S</b>pecialized and <b>C</b>ooperative <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>gencies</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="asi1"><b>ASI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#asi"><b>A</b>merican <b>S</b>ociety of <b>I</b>ndexers</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="apala"><b>Asian/Pacific American Librarians Association (APALA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1980, <b>APALA</b> is an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> with a membership consisting of of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and <a href="#information">information</a> specialists of Asian Pacific (APA) descent employed in the Unites States, and other interested persons.  <b>APALA</b> provides a forum for the discussion of issues and ideas of interest to APA librarians, supports and encourages <a href="#library">library</a> services to APA communities, establishes scholarships for APA <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> students, <a href="#recruitment">recruits</a> and <a href="#mentor">mentor</a>s APA <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a> professionals, and fosters cooperation with other organizations with similar interests.  <b>APALA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em><a href="http://www.uic.edu/depts/lib/projects/resources/apala/letter">APALA Newsletter</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.uic.edu/depts/lib/projects/resources/apala/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>APALA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="asissued"><b>as issued</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> to indicate the <a href="#condition">condition</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> that exists in the same unaltered form in which it was first <a href="#publishing">published</a>, as opposed to one that has been <a href="#rebinding">rebound</a>, <a href="#technical">processed</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a>, <a href="#damaged">damaged</a>, etc.  Compare with <a href="#doctored">doctored</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="asist1"><b>ASIST</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#asist"><b>A</b>merican <b>S</b>ociety for <b>I</b>nformation <b>S</b>cience and <b>T</b>echnology</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="askeric"><b><em>AskERIC</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Initiated in 1996 as a project of the <a href="#eric">ERIC</a> <a href="#clearinghouse">Clearinghouse</a> on <a href="#information">Information</a> &amp; Technology, <b><em>AskERIC</em></b> is an <a href="#email">e-mail</a>-based <a href="#refservices">reference</a> and <a href="#inforeferral">referral</a> system that provides answers to questions, assistance, and referral services to K-12 educators via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  <b><em>AskERIC</em></b> also provides news of interest to educators and a growing <a href="#virtuallibrary">virtual libary</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> resources at its <a href="#website">Web site</a>, including lesson plans, <em>ERIC Digests</em> in full-text, completed ERIC <a href="#search">search</a>es on <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#topic">topic</a>s in education, resource <a href="#guide">guide</a>s, answers to <a href="#faq">FAQ</a>s, and the <a href="#archives">archives</a> of education-related electronic <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>s.  <a href="http://www.askeric.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>AskERIC</em></b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="askjake"><b><em>AskJake</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a> designed to identify the <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s (<a href="#aggregator">aggregator</a>s) that contain <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s or provide <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting</a> for a given <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#title">title</a>.  The <b><em>AskJake</em></b> development site is currently <a href="#host">host</a>ed by Simon Fraser University Library.  <a href="http://mercury.lib.sfu.ca/%7Etholbroo/sfujake/search.cgi">Click here</a> connect to <b><em>AskJake</em></b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#metadata">metadata</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aslib1"><b>Aslib</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#aslib">Association for Information Management</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="asnew"><b>as new</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#mint">mint</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aspect"><b>aspect</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, an approach to a <a href="#subject">subject</a> from a <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> other than the one in which the subject is <a href="#classification">classified</a>, for example, the <em>economic</em> or <em>sociological</em> aspects of health care delivery.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="assessment"><b>assessment</b></a>
</dt><dd>Quantitative and qualitative measurement of the degree to which a <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s,
services, and programs meet the needs of its users, usually undertaken
with the aim of improving performance. Assessment is accomplished by
various methods, including direct observation, analysis of <a href="#feedback">feedback</a> obtained through interviews, <a href="#usersurvey">user survey</a>s, testing, etc.  When conducted by the library, rather than an outside <a href="#agency">agency</a>, the process is known as <em>self-assessment</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#qualityofservice">quality of service</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="assignedindexing"><b>assigned indexing</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#assignmentindexing">assignment indexing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="assignmentindexing"><b>assignment indexing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> in which a human indexer selects one or more <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s from a list of <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a> to represent the <a href="#subject">subject</a>(s) of a <a href="#work">work</a>.  The indexing <a href="#term">term</a>s need not appear in the <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#text">text</a> of the <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#index">index</a>ed.  Synonymous with <em>assigned indexing</em>.  Compare with <a href="#derivativeindexing">derivative indexing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="association"><b>association</b></a>
</dt><dd>The group of persons who have joined a formal organization
devoted to pursuing a common interest or purpose, usually by paying an
annual membership <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  Professional associations, such as the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, are dedicated to promoting the interests of a specific profession and its practitioners.  The most <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#directory">directory</a> of such organizations is the <em><a href="#encyassoc">Encyclopedia of Associations</a></em> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States.  <a href="http://www.lib.uwaterloo.ca/society/subjects_soc.html">Click here</a> to connect to an <a href="#online">online</a> directory of scholarly <a href="#society">societies</a> in North America, maintained by the University of Waterloo Library.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>ass.</em>, <em>assn.</em>, and <em>assoc.</em>  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#libassociation">library association</a> and <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="assoccopy"><b>association copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, which has a special association with the <a href="#author">author</a>, with a person closely connected to the author or its <a href="#content">content</a>, with a well-known individual other than the author, or with a particular <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, as indicated by an <a href="#autograph">autograph</a>, <a href="#bookplate">bookplate</a>, <a href="#dedication">dedication</a>, <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>, <a href="#marginalia">marginalia</a>, special <a href="#binding">binding</a>, or other physical characteristic.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="abf"><b>Association des bibliothecaires francais (ABF)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1906, L'<b>ABF</b> is the oldest and largest <a href="#association">association</a> of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s in France, with approximately 3,500 members.  L'<b>ABF</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em><a href="http://www.abf.asso.fr/publications/bulletin/">Bulletin d'informations</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.abf.asso.fr/">Click here</a> to connect to L'<b>ABF</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aslib"><b>Association for Information Management (Aslib)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1924, <b>Aslib</b> is a nonprofit organization with
an international membership consisting of over 2,000 private and public
companies and organizations in 70 countries, which have an interest in
the efficient management of <a href="#information">information</a> resources.  Divided into 14 special interest groups covering approximately 60 <a href="#sic">SIC</a> areas, <b>Aslib</b> specializes in advising organizations, from small companies to large corporations and <a href="#govtagency">government agencies</a>, on issues and problems related to <a href="#infomanagement">information management</a>.  <a href="http://www.aslib.co.uk/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Aslib</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>  
<b>Aslib</b> publications: 
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b><em>Journal of Documentation</em></b> (<a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a>)
</dd><dd><b><em>Managing Information</em></b> (10 <a href="#issue">issue</a>s per year)
</dd><dd><b><em>Online and CD Notes</em></b> (10 issues per year) 
</dd><dd><b><em>Performance Measurement and Metrics</em></b> (3 issues per year)
</dd><dd><b><em>Program:  Electronic Library and Information Systems</em></b> (<a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a>)  
</dd><dd><b><em>Records Management Journal</em></b> (3 issues per year)</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arma"><b>Association for Information Management Professionals (ARMA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonprofit international <a href="#association">association</a> serving over 10,000 <a href="#infomanagement">information management</a> professionals in the U.S., Canada, and over 30 other countries, including <a href="#recordsmanagement">records manager</a>s, MIS and ADP professionals, imaging specialists, <a href="#archivist">archivist</a>s, hospital and legal administrators, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, and educators, <b>ARMA</b> provides education, <a href="#research">research</a>, and networking opportunities enabling its members to maximize the value of <a href="#records">records</a>, <a href="#information">information</a>, and <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> as corporate assets.  Formerly known as the Association of Records Managers and Administrators, <b>ARMA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <em><a href="http://www.arma.org/publications/journal/journal_about.cfm">Information Management Journal</a></em> and the <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em><a href="http://www.arma.org/publications/infopro/online.cfm">InfoPro Online</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.arma.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ARMA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alise"><b>Association for Library and Information Science Education (ALISE)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1915, <b>ALISE</b> is an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, dedicated to promoting excellence in <a href="#research">research</a>, teaching, and service in <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>
education. Its members are graduate schools offering degree programs in
library and information science, and their faculties. <b>ALISE</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em>Journal of Education for Library and Information Science (JELIS)</em>.  <a href="http://www.alise.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ALISE</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alcts"><b>Association for Library Collections and Technical Services (ALCTS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> since in 1957, <b>ALCTS</b> has a membership consisting of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and other persons interested in the <a href="#acquisitions">acquisition</a>, identification, <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a>, <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>, and <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/alcts/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ALCTS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
<b>ALCTS</b> publications:
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alcts/publications/an2/index.html">ALCTS Network News (AN2)</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alcts/alcts_news/">ALCTS Online Newsletter</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alcts/lrts/">Library Resources &amp; Technical Services</a></em></dd></dl> 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alsc"><b>Association for Library Service to Children (ALSC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> since in 1900, <b>ALSC</b> has a membership consisting of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and persons interested in improving the quality of <a href="#childrensservices">services for children</a> in all types of <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  <b>ALSC</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>Children and Libraries</em>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/alsc/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ALSC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="alta"><b>Association for Library Trustees and Advocates (ALTA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A recently formed division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>ALTA</b> has a membership consisting of <a href="#librarytrustee">library trustee</a>s and persons interested in promoting outstanding <a href="#library">library</a> service through educational programs that develop excellence in trusteeship and actions that advocate <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#information">information</a> for all.   <a href="http://www.ala.org/alta/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ALTA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#folusa">FOLUSA</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arsc"><b>Association for Recorded Sound Collections (ARSC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1966, with headquarters in Annapolis, Maryland, <b>ARSC</b> has a membership consisting of persons in the <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>ing and <a href="#soundrecording">recording</a> industry, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#archivist">archivist</a>s, <a href="#curator">curator</a>s, private collectors, and institutions such as museums, <a href="#nationallib">national libraries</a>, and foundations.  <b>ARSC</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> <em>ARSC Journal</em> and the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em>ARSC Newsletter</em>.  <a href="http://www.arsc-audio.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ARSC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aahsl"><b>Association of Academic Health Sciences Libraries (AAHSL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1977, <b>AAHSL</b> is an organization of the <a href="#librarydirector">director</a>s of <a href="#medicallib">medical libraries</a> at over 140 <a href="#accreditation">accredited</a>
medical schools in the U.S. and Canada belonging to the Association of
American Medical Colleges. Its goal is to promote excellence in
academic health science <a href="#library">libraries</a> and assure that health practitioners acquire the <a href="#infoliteracy">information skills</a> necessary for quality health care delivery, education, and <a href="#research">research</a>. <a href="http://www.aahsl.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>AAHSL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aap"><b>Association of American Publishers (AAP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The principal <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a> of the <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> industry in the United States, <b>AAP</b> was created in 1970 by the merger of the American Book <a href="#publisher">Publisher</a>s Council (ABPC) and the American Educational Publishers Institute (AEPI).  Directed by standing committees, <b>AAP</b> is currently focused on a variety of core issues, such as <a href="#intellectualproperty">intellectual property</a>; new technology and <a href="#telecommunications">telecommunications</a>; <a href="#firstamendment">First Amendment</a> rights, <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>, and <a href="#libel">libel</a>; international freedom to publish; funding for education and <a href="#library">libraries</a>; postal rates and regulations; and tax and trade policy.  <a href="http://www.publishers.org/index.htm">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>AAP</b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#aaupress">Association of American University Presses</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aaupress"><b>Association of American University Presses (AAUP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1937, <b>AAUP</b> is a <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a> representing over 120 scholarly <a href="#press">press</a>es, large and small, associated for the most part with colleges and universities in the United States and Canada.  Its members <a href="#publishing">publish</a> in a wide range of <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s, including the arts and humanities, social sciences, and science and technology.  Some also publish <a href="#book">book</a>s of <a href="#regionalbook">regional interest</a>, others include <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#poetry">poetry</a> in their <a href="#list">list</a>s.  Through its programs, <b>AAUP</b> seeks to further the interests of scholarly publishing by monitoring legislation affecting <a href="#universitypress">university press</a>es, <a href="#fundraising">fund-raising</a> for projects beneficial to scholarly <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, and helping its members market their <a href="#publication">publication</a>s and train personnel effectively.  <a href="http://aaupnet.org/">Click</a> here to connect to the <b>AAUP</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#aap">Association of American Publishers</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="acrl"><b>Association of College and Research Libraries (ACRL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> since 1889, <b>ACRL</b> has a membership of academic and <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s committed to improving <a href="#qualityofservice">quality of service</a> in <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, promoting the career and <a href="#profdevel">professional development</a> of academic and research librarians, and supporting the programs of academic and <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/acrl/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ACRL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
<b>ACRL</b> publications: 
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em><a href="http://www.ala.org/acrl/c&amp;rl.html">College &amp; Research Libraries (C&amp;RL)</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.ala.org/acrl/c&amp;rlnew2.html">College &amp; Research Libraries News (C&amp;RL News)</a></em></dd></dl> 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="aiip"><b>Association of Independent Information Professionals (AIIP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1987, <b>AIIP</b> is an organization of entrepreneurs owning professional firms that provide <a href="#information">information</a>-related services, including <a href="#online">online</a> and manual <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a> and <a href="#research">research</a>, <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery</a>, <a href="#database">database</a> design, <a href="#library">library</a> support, <a href="#consultant">consulting</a>, writing, and <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>. <a href="http://www.aiip.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>AIIP</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#informationbroker">information broker</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ajl"><b>Association of Jewish Libraries (AJL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1965 with headquarters in New York City, <b>AJL</b> seeks to advance the interests of Jewish <a href="#library">libraries</a> and promote <a href="#publication">publication</a>s of Jewish <a href="#bibliography">bibliographical</a> interest.  <b>AJL</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>Judaica Librarianship</em> and the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em>AJL Newsletter</em>.  <a href="http://aleph.lib.ohio-state.edu/www/ajl.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>AJL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="amia"><b>Association of Moving Image Archivists (AMIA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonprofit professional <a href="#association">association</a> devoted to advancing the <a href="#field">field</a> of moving image <a href="#archives">archiving</a> by encouraging cooperation among the individuals and organizations concerned with the collection, <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ion, and use of moving image materials, <b>AMIA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em><a href="http://www.amianet.org/08_Publications/Publications.html">AMIA Newsletter</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.amianet.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>AMIA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="armaold"><b>Association of Records Managers and Administrators (ARMA)</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#arma">Association for Information Management Professionals</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="arl"><b>Association of Research Libraries (ARL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1932, <b>ARL</b> is an organization of large <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a>
dedicated to influencing major decisions affecting the future of
research libraries and their ability to serve effectively the needs of
students, faculty, and the <a href="#research">research</a> community,
by articulating concerns, forming coalitions, suggesting policy, and
supporting innovations and improvements in operations. An <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>ARL</b> provides <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> <a href="#database">database</a>s, training and consultation in management and program development, <a href="#directory">directories</a>, and statistics on its membership.  <a href="http://arl.cni.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ARL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ascla"><b>Association of Specialized and Cooperative Library Agencies (ASCLA)</b></a> 
</dt><dd>A division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> representing <a href="#statelibrary">state library</a> <a href="#govtagency">agencies</a>, specialized library agencies, independent <a href="#library">libraries</a>, and multi-type library cooperatives.  <b>ASCLA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/ascla/interface.html/">Interface</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/ascla/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ASCLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="avsl"><b>Association of Vision Science Librarians (AVSL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An international <a href="#association">association</a> of <a href="#information">information</a> professionals employed at educational institutions, eye clinics and hospitals, and private companies whose <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s and services include the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of vision, <b>AVSL</b> is a special interest group of both the Association of Schools and Colleges of Optometry and the <a href="#medicallibassoc">Medical Library Association</a>.  The organization <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> <a href="#standards">standards</a> and guideliness for vision science libraries, a <a href="#unionlist">union list</a> of vision-related <a href="#serial">serial</a>s, and a <a href="#corecollection">core list</a> <a href="#audiovisual">audiovisual</a> collection.  <a href="http://spectacle.berkeley.edu/%7Elibrary/AVSL.HTM">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>AVSL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="associative"><b>associative relation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a> in which two words or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s are conceptually connected, sometimes within a specific <a href="#context">context</a>, but are not related <a href="#hierarchicrelation">hierarchically</a>  (<em>example</em>:  "Library extension" and "Library outreach").  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#relatedterm">related term</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="asterisk"><b>asterisk</b></a>
</dt><dd>A special <a href="#character">character</a> in the shape of a star (<b>*</b>) produced on a standard <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> by pressing the <b>Shift+8</b> keys.  The asterisk is used as a <a href="#refmark">reference mark</a> in <a href="#printing">printing</a> to indicate a <a href="#footnote">footnote</a> or other reference on the same <a href="#page">page</a>.  A series of asterisks is sometimes used in <a href="#text">text</a> to indicate <a href="#ellipsis">ellipsis</a>, for example, to suggest an <a href="#unprintable">unprintable</a> word (D***).  In most <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, the asterisk is used as the end <a href="#truncation">truncation</a> symbol in <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> <a href="#search">search</a>es.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="astronomicalmap"><b>astronomical map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> of the planets, stars, galaxies, or other heavenly bodies, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> against a dark ground.  Synonymous with <em>star map</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="asynchronous"><b>asynchronous</b></a>
</dt><dd>Occurring at different times.  In <a href="#communications">communications</a>, a response that is delayed due to the nature of the transmission <a href="#medium">medium</a>.  The opposite of <em>synchronous</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#realtime">real time</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="asyndetic"><b>asyndetic</b></a>
</dt><dd>Lacking <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#syndetic">syndetic structure</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="atg1"><b><em>ATG</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#atg"><b>A</b>gainst <b>t</b>he <b>G</b>rain</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="athenaeum"><b>athenaeum</b></a>
</dt><dd>The temple of Athena, goddess of <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>
and learning, where scholars and writers met in the city of Athens in
ancient Greece to exchange ideas. In early 19th century New England,
the name was applied to certain <a href="#proprietarylib">proprietary libraries</a>, <a href="#readingroom">reading room</a>s, and buildings containing <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  The <a href="http://www.redwoodlibrary.org/">Redwood Library &amp; Athenaeum</a> in Newport, Rhode Island is the oldest surviving library of this kind in the United States.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="atla1"><b>ATLA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#atla"><b>A</b>merican <b>T</b>heological <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="atlas"><b>atlas</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">bound</a> or <a href="#boxed">boxed</a> <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#map">map</a>s, usually related in <a href="#subject">subject</a> or theme, with an <a href="#index">index</a> of <a href="#geographicname">place name</a>s (<a href="#gazetteer">gazetteer</a>) usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the end.  The first bound collection of maps is known to have been <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in Europe in the mid-16th century.  In most atlases, the maps are printed in uniform style and <a href="#format">format</a>, on a fairly consistent <a href="#scale">scale</a>.  An atlas may be issued as an independent <a href="#publication">publication</a> or as <a href="#accompanying">accompanying material</a>, with or without descriptive <a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#plate">plate</a>s, <a href="#chart">chart</a>s, etc.  Some have a special focus (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Times Atlas of World Exploration</em></b>), others are intended for a specific use (<a href="#roadatlas">road atlas</a>es).  In a <a href="#library">library</a>, large atlases may be stored in a specially designed <a href="#atlascase">atlas case</a>.  <a href="http://www.nationalatlas.gov/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> <b><em>National Atlas of the United States</em></b>, available at the <a href="http://www.usgs.gov/">U.S. Geological Survey</a> <a href="#website">Web site</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#historicalatlas">historical atlas</a>, <a href="#thematicatlas">thematic atlas</a>, and <a href="#worldatlas">world atlas</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="atlascase"><b>atlas case</b></a>
</dt><dd>A free-standing piece of display furniture used mainly in <a href="#library">libraries</a>, usually about waist-high with a sloping top and a <a href="#bookstop">book stop</a> along the front edge for displaying an open <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>.  Most <a href="#atlas">atlas</a> cases are made of wood, with several <a href="#depth">deep</a>, wide, closely-spaced shelves for storing <a href="#oversize">oversize</a> <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s.  Some designs have sliding shelves to facilitate use.  Compare with <a href="#dictionarystand">dictionary stand</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="atlasfolio"><b>atlas folio</b></a>
</dt><dd>The largest widely used <a href="#folio">folio</a>, usually about 16 x 25 inches in size, used mainly for large <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>es.  Compare with <a href="#elephantfolio">elephant folio</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="attachment"><b>attachment</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#file">file</a> of any type linked to an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> message in such a way that the two are transmitted together to the designated <a href="#internetaddress">address</a>.  Non<a href="#text">text</a> attachments, such as <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s and <a href="#database">database</a> files, may require special <a href="#encoding">encoding</a> and decoding <a href="#software">software</a>.  Particular care should be taken when opening attachments as they are sometimes used to transmit computer <a href="#virus">virus</a>es.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="attribute"><b>attribute</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#classification">classification</a>, one of the distinguishing <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>s of a <a href="#class">class</a>, identified as a means of differentiating it from other classes.  As defined in <em><a href="#frbr">FRBR</a></em> (<em>Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records</em>), one of a set of characteristics enabling users of <a href="#information">information</a> to formulate <a href="#query">queries</a> and evaluate responses when <a href="#search">search</a>ing for information about a specific <a href="#entity">entity</a>.
Attributes can be inherent in the entity (physical characteristics,
labeling information, etc.) or imputed by an external agent (assigned
identifiers, <a href="#context">context</a>ual information, etc.). 
<p>
For example, the logical attributes of a creative <a href="#work">work</a> include its <a href="#title">title</a>, form, date of creation, intended <a href="#audience">audience</a>,
etc. As a general rule, a given instance of an entity exhibits a single
value for each attribute, but multiple values are possible (<em>example</em>:  a work <a href="#publishing">published</a> under more than one title) or a value may change over time (date of publication for a <a href="#serial">serial</a>).  Nor is it necessary for every instance of an entity to exhibit <em>all</em> its attributes--some may be appropriate to a specific subtype of the entity, for example, the attribute "<a href="#coordinate">coordinate</a>s" applicable only to <a href="#cartographic">cartographic materials</a>.   
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="attributed"><b>attributed</b></a>
</dt><dd>A creative <a href="#work">work</a> ascribed to a known person or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a>, usually on the basis of reliable supporting evidence.  Degree of certainty concerning <a href="#authorship">authorship</a> depends on the strength of the existing evidence, for example, some scholars believe the <a href="#play">play</a>s and <a href="#sonnet">sonnet</a>s
of William Shakespeare to be the work of another Elizabethan writer,
but the available evidence is insufficient to resolve this dispute.
When evidence of authorship is inconclusive, a work is said to be of <a href="#unknownauth">unknown authorship</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="attributedauthor"><b>attributed author</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person believed to have written or created a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#anonymous">anonymous</a>ly or which is of <a href="#doubtful">doubtful authorship</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Second Maiden's Tragedy</em></b>
attributed to the 17th century writer Thomas Middleton). Attribution is
usually based on supporting evidence, but uncertainty may arise when
the evidence is meager or conflicting (<b><em>The Two Noble Kinsmen</em></b> ascribed to John Fletcher but sometimes erroneously attributed to William Shakespeare).  In the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, attributed <a href="#authorship">authorship</a> is indicated in the <a href="#notearea">note area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  Synonymous with <em>supposed author</em>.  Compare with <a href="#suppositious">suppositious author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="auctiongallery"><b>auction gallery</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bookauction">book auction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="audience"><b>audience</b></a>
</dt><dd>The people who actually read a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> or attend an artistic performance or exhibition, not necessarily the same as the <a href="#targetaudience">target audience</a> for whom the <a href="#work">work</a> is intended by the <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#creator">creator</a>, or by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#producer">producer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="audiobook"><b>audiobook</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bookontape">book-on-tape</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="audiocassette"><b>audiocassette</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a> permanently enclosed in a hard plastic case containing two take-up <a href="#reel">reel</a>s to which the ends of the tape are attached for <a href="#playback">playback</a> and rewinding.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> that allow audiocassettes to <a href="#circulation">circulate</a> usually place them in a section reserved for <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>s, arranged by <a href="#composer">composer</a>, <a href="#performer">performer</a>, <a href="#genre">genre</a>, or some other means of <a href="#classification">classification</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the <a href="#term">term</a> "sound cassette" is used in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing an audiocassette, with "<a href="#analog">analog</a>" given as <a href="#typerecording">type of recording</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="audiodisc"><b>audiodisc</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="audiorecording"><b>audiorecording</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic term for any <a href="#medium">medium</a> on which sounds are recorded for mechanical or electronic <a href="#playback">playback</a>, including <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>s (vinyl), <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a>, and <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>.  Synonymous with <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="audiotape"><b>audiotape</b></a>
</dt><dd>A continuous strip of thin <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a> on which sounds can be recorded as electrical signals, and converted back into sound with the proper <a href="#playback">playback</a> equipment.  The most common size in <a href="#library">libraries</a> is 1/4-inch wide, stored on <a href="#audiocassette">audiocassette</a>.  Synonymous with <em>tape recording</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#audiorecording">audiorecording</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="audiovisual"><b>audiovisual</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> in a <a href="#medium">medium</a> that combines sound and visual images, for example, a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> or <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a> with a <a href="#soundtrack">sound track</a>, or a <a href="#slide">slide</a> presentation synchronized with <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a>.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> for products and services provided by the audiovisual industry is available in <b><em>AV Market Place</em></b> (<em>AVMP</em>), <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.  Also spelled <em>audio-visual</em>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>a-v</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#media">media</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="audit"><b>audit</b></a>
</dt><dd>An official examination of the accounts or <a href="#records">records</a>
of an individual, company, organization, or institution to determine if
they are correct. Also, to conduct such an examination, usually on a
