regular basis. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#securityaudit">security audit</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authentication"><b>authentication</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#online">online</a> systems, the procedure for verifying the integrity of a transmitted message.  Also, a <a href="#security">security</a> procedure designed to verify that the <a href="#authorization">authorization</a> code entered by a user to gain <a href="#access">access</a> to a <a href="#network">network</a> or system is valid.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#username">username</a>, <a href="#password">password</a>, and <a href="#pin">PIN</a>.   
<p>
In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the process of verifying, usually through careful investigation and <a href="#research">research</a>, whether a <a href="#document">document</a> or its <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> is what it appears or claims to be.  Compare with <a href="#certification">certification</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authenticity"><b>authenticity</b></a>
</dt><dd>The quality in a thing of being what it is claimed to be (valid, real, genuine, etc.), verified in <a href="#archives">archives</a> and <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a> through an investigative process known as <a href="#authentication">authentication</a>, essential in <a href="#appraisal">appraising</a> the value of an item.  <b><em>See also</em></b> <a href="#forgery">forgery</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="author"><b>author</b></a>
</dt><dd>The person responsible for producing a written <a href="#work">work</a> (<a href="#essay">essay</a>, <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>, <a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>, <a href="#poetry">poem</a>, <a href="#screenplay">screenplay</a>, <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>, etc.), whose name is <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, or given elsewhere in or on a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or other item, and in whose name the work is <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>ed.  A work may have two or more <a href="#jointauthor">joint author</a>s.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#term">term</a> is used in its broadest sense to include <a href="#editor">editor</a>, <a href="#compiler">compiler</a>, <a href="#composer">composer</a>, <a href="#creator">creator</a>, etc.  Compare with <a href="#personalauthor">personal author</a> and <a href="#corporateauthor">corporate author</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#authorship">authorship</a>, <a href="#attributedauthor">attributed author</a>, and <a href="#suppositious">suppositious author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorabstract"><b>author abstract</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief summary, called an <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>, written by the person responsible for creating the <a href="#work">work</a> summarized, as opposed to one written by someone other than the <a href="#author">author</a>, usually a professional <em>abstractor</em> or <a href="#index">index</a>er.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authoraffiliation"><b>author affiliation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The name of the organization with which the <a href="#author">author</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> is formally connected, usually given in <a href="#book">book</a>s on the back <a href="#flap">flap</a> of the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> or on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, and in <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s in a <a href="#note">note</a> at the <a href="#foot">foot</a> of the first <a href="#page">page</a>, sometimes with the writer's <a href="#positiontitle">position title</a> and contact <a href="#information">information</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorbib"><b>author bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> of <a href="#work">work</a>s written by or about a specific <a href="#author">author</a>, which can vary in detail and extent from an un<a href="#annotation">annotated</a> list of selected <a href="#title">title</a>s to a <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a>, in-depth <a href="#descriptivebib">descriptive bibliography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorentry"><b>author entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, or <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> under the authorized <a href="#heading">heading</a> for the first-named <a href="#author">author</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, whether it be a <a href="#personalname">person</a> or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a>.  In most <a href="#library">library</a> catalogs, the author entry is the <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorindex"><b>author index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> <a href="#index">index</a> in which the <a href="#heading">heading</a>s are the names of the individuals and <a href="#corporatebody">corporate bodies</a> responsible for creating the <a href="#work">work</a>s indexed.  <a href="#author">Author</a> <a href="#entry">entries</a> may be combined with the <a href="#subjectindex">subject index</a> or <a href="#titleindex">title index</a>, rather than listed separately.  Compare with <a href="#nameindex">name index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorinterview"><b>author interview</b></a>
</dt><dd>A conversation in which a writer is questioned about his/her life and work by an <em>interviewer</em> who intends to <a href="#publishing">publish</a> the results <a href="#verbatim">verbatim</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, or incorporate them into a radio or television <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>, in their entirety or <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>ed.  Also refers to the <a href="#article">article</a> or program based on such an interview.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authoritative"><b>authoritative</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#source">source</a> that is official.  Also, a <a href="#work">work</a> known to be reliable because its authority or <a href="#authenticity">authenticity</a> has been widely recognized by experts in the <a href="#field">field</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authority"><b>authority</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> and experience qualifying a person to write or speak as an expert on a given <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  In the academic community, authority is based on credentials, previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s on the subject, institutional affiliation, awards, <a href="#imprint">imprint</a>, <a href="#review">review</a>s, patterns of <a href="#citation">citation</a>, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authoritycontrol"><b>authority control</b></a>
</dt><dd>The procedures by which consistency of <a href="#formofentry">form</a> is maintained in the <a href="#heading">heading</a>s (names, <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a>s, <a href="#seriestitle">series title</a>s, and <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a>s) used in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s, through the application of an <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> list called an <a href="#authorityfile">authority file</a> to new <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s as they are added to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  Authority control is available from commercial service providers.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorityfile"><b>authority file</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> forms of the <a href="#heading">heading</a>s used in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s, maintained to ensure that the headings are applied consistently as new <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s are added to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  Separate authority files are usually maintained for <a href="#nameauthority">name</a>s, <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a>s, <a href="#seriestitle">series title</a>s, and <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a>s.  All the references made to and from a given heading are also included in the authority file. 
<b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorityrecord"><b>authority record</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> or <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#record">record</a> of the decision made concerning the <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> form of a name (<a href="#personalname">personal</a> or <a href="#corporatename">corporate</a>), <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a>, <a href="#seriestitle">series title</a>, or <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a> used as a <a href="#heading">heading</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s, listed in an <a href="#authorityfile">authority file</a> governing the application of headings to new <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s as they are added to the <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>.  An authority record may also contain <em>See from</em> and <em>See also from</em> records, as well as notes concerning the application of the authorized form.  <a href="http://authorities.loc.gov/">Click here</a> to connect to <em>Library of Congress Authorities</em>, a <a href="#searchable">searchable</a> <a href="#database">database</a> of <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority</a> headings. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authoritywork"><b>authority work</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of deciding which form of a name, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#seriestitle">series title</a>, or <a href="#subject">subject</a> will be used as the authorized <a href="#heading">heading</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s, including the establishment of appropriate references to the heading, and its relationship to other headings in the <a href="#authorityfile">authority file</a>. 
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>:  <b>Shaw Bernard</b>, with references from <b>Shaw G. B.</b> and <b>Shaw George Bernard</b>.</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorization"><b>authorization</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, a <a href="#username">username</a>, <a href="#password">password</a>, <a href="#pin">PIN</a>, or other <a href="#accesscode">access code</a> issued to a person who is allowed <a href="#access">access</a> to a specific electronic resource, <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>, <a href="#network">network</a>, or other computer system, which the user must enter correctly in order to <a href="#logon">log on</a>.  Authorization codes are usually subject to periodic renewal.  A single <a href="#authentication">authentication</a> may have multiple authorizations.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorizedbiog"><b>authorized biography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#biography">biography</a> written with the explicit consent and sometimes the cooperation of its <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or the subject's family if the <em>biographee</em> is deceased.  Authorized biographies are more likely to be scrutinized by <a href="#review">review</a>ers for <a href="#bias">bias</a> because the <em>biographer</em> may have been expected to overlook or downplay embarrassing events or unflattering qualities in exchange for <a href="#access">access</a> to first-hand <a href="#information">information</a> and confidential <a href="#source">source</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#unauthorizedbiog">unauthorized biography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorizededition"><b>authorized edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d with the explicit sanction of the <a href="#author">author</a> or holder of <a href="#copyright">rights</a> in the <a href="#work">work</a> or, in the case of a <a href="#biography">biography</a>, by the person who is its <a href="#subject">subject</a> or the subject's family if the <em>biographee</em> is deceased.  The opposite of <a href="#unauthorized">unauthorized edition</a>.  Compare with <a href="#definitive">definitive edition</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authormark"><b>author mark</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#letter">Letter</a>s, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s, or other <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s representing the last name of an <a href="#author">author</a>, added by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> to the <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> to distinguish an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> from others of the same <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> (<em>example</em>:  the <a href="#cuttersanborn">Cutter-Sanborn</a> <a href="#cutternumber">number</a> <b>D548</b> to identify <a href="#work">work</a>s by Charles Dickens).  When a <a href="#workmark">work mark</a> is added to the author mark, the result is known as the <a href="#booknumber">book number</a> (<b>D548d</b> for <em>David Copperfield</em>).  Synonymous with <em>author number</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorportrait"><b>author portrait</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#plate">plate</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a>, bearing a <a href="#fullpage">full-page</a> image of the <a href="#author">author</a>, usually a <a href="#photograph">photograph</a> or a <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> of a painting, drawing, or <a href="#engraving">engraving</a>, <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> preceding the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  Common in books <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the 19th and early 20th centuries, most show just the head and shoulders, with the author's name and source of <a href="#portrait">portrait</a> given in a <a href="#caption">caption</a>.  In medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, the authors of the gospels were sometimes depicted in a drawing or <a href="#miniature">miniature</a> accompanying the <a href="#text">text</a> of their <a href="#work">work</a>.  In modern book production, a small portrait photograph of the author is usually printed on the back <a href="#flap">flap</a> of the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorsadvance"><b>author's advance</b></a>
</dt><dd>An amount paid by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to the <a href="#author">author</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> before the completed <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> is submitted for <a href="#publication">publication</a>, established by contractual <a href="#publishersagreement">agreement</a> between the two parties, usually refundable if the work is not completed.  Synonymous with <em>advance on royalty</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#royalties">royalties</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorscontract"><b>author's contract</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#publishersagreement">publishers' agreement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorscopy"><b>author's copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of six or more <a href="#complimentary">complimentary copies</a> of a <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a> normally provided to the <a href="#author">author</a> free-of-charge by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> at the time of first <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  Faculty members sometimes donate complimentary <a href="#copy">copies</a> of their <a href="#work">work</a>s to the <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a> at the college or university with which they are affiliated.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorsedition"><b>author's edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of all the <a href="#unpublished">unpublished</a> and previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s of an <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in one or more <a href="#uniformedition">uniform</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a>s, usually bearing a <a href="#collectivetitle">collective title</a> or some other indication on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> that all known works are included.  Synonymous with <em>complete works</em> and <em>uniform edition</em>.  Compare with <a href="#collectededition">collected edition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#definitive">definitive edition</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to an edition published with the author's consent (<a href="#authorizededition">authorized edition</a>). 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorseditor"><b>author's editor</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#editor">editor</a> familiar with the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> industry, employed by a university or <a href="#research">research</a> institution to assist faculty and researchers in preparing their <a href="#work">work</a> for <a href="#publication">publication</a>, and to help them negotiate the intricacies of the publishing process, as distinct from an editor employed by a <a href="#publisher">publishing company</a> to help prepare a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> for <a href="#printing">printing</a> once it has been accepted for publication.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorship"><b>authorship</b></a>
</dt><dd>The origin of a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, <a href="#book">book</a>, or other written <a href="#work">work</a>, with reference to its <a href="#author">author</a>(s).
In a more general sense, the source of an idea or creative work in any
form, with reference to its creator or originator, for example, the <a href="#composer">composer</a> of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a>.  When authorship of an <a href="#anonymous">anonymous</a> work cannot be determined with reasonable certainty, it is said to be of <a href="#unknownauth">unknown authorship</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#diffuse">diffuse authorship</a>, <a href="#doubtful">doubtful authorship</a>, <a href="#mixed">mixed responsibility</a>, <a href="#shared">shared responsibility</a>, and <a href="#spurious">spurious work</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authortour"><b>author tour</b></a>
</dt><dd>A tightly-scheduled trip, usually arranged by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of a new <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a>, in which the <a href="#author">author</a> (or a well-known <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>) agrees to help promote sales by participating in <a href="#booksigning">book signing</a>s, <a href="#authorinterview">author interview</a>s, <a href="#booktalk">book talk</a>s, etc., usually at <a href="#tradebookstore">trade bookstore</a>s and through the mass <a href="#media">media</a>.
Travel expenses are paid by the publisher, but the writer is usually
not compensated for his or her time. Author tours are announced in the <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> <em><a href="#publishersweekly">Publishers Weekly</a></em>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="authorware"><b>authorware</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#courseware">courseware</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="autobiography"><b>autobiography</b></a>
</dt><dd>An account of a person's life written by its <a href="#subject">subject</a>, usually in the form of a continuous <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> of events considered by the <a href="#author">author</a>
to be the most important or interesting, selected from those he or she
is willing to reveal. The first fully-developed autobiography, the <b><em>Confessions</em></b> of St. Augustine, was written in the 4th century A.D.  Some autobiographies are largely <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>al (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Confessions</em></b> of Jean-Jacques Rousseau).  Contemporary autobiographies of famous people are often written with the assistance of a <a href="#ghostwriter">ghost writer</a>.  An autobiography differs from a <a href="#diary">diary</a> or <a href="#journal">journal</a> in being written for others, rather than for purely private reasons.  Compare with <a href="#biography">biography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="autograph"><b>autograph</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> written entirely in the <a href="#author">author</a>'s own handwriting.  Also refers to a person's own <a href="#signature">signature</a>.  Compare with <a href="#holograph">holograph</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#autographedcopy">autographed copy</a> and <a href="#autographededit">autographed edition</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="autographedcopy"><b>autographed copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#signature">signed</a> by the <a href="#author">author</a>.  Autographed copies may be of considerable value to <a href="#bookcollecting">collector</a>s if the author is very well-known and signed copies <a href="#rarity">rare</a>.  Compare with <a href="#inscribed">inscribed copy</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="autographededit"><b>autographed edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> in which all the <a href="#copy">copies</a> are personally <a href="#signature">signed</a> by the <a href="#author">author</a>, possible only in relatively small editions.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="automatedcheckout"><b>automated checkout</b></a>
</dt><dd>Some computerized <a href="#circulation">circulation system</a>s allow <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to <a href="#checkedout">check out</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> on their own, without the assistance of <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a>, usually by means of <a href="#barcode">barcode</a>s on the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> and on the patron's <a href="#librarycard">library card</a>.  Automated checkout is part of a trend toward <a href="#selfservice">self-service</a> in <a href="#library">library</a> operations.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="automaticindexing"><b>automatic indexing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of computerized <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> in which an <a href="#algorithm">algorithm</a> is used to extract words or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s representing <a href="#subject">subject</a>s from the <a href="#title">title</a> and/or <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, for use as <a href="#heading">heading</a>s under which <a href="#entry">entries</a> are made in an <a href="#index">index</a>.  Compare with <a href="#machineaided">machine-aided indexing</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#derivativeindexing">derivative indexing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="autonym"><b>autonym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person's own name.  Also refers to a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> under the real name of its <a href="#author">author</a>, rather than under a <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a> or <a href="#allonym">allonym</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="auxiliaryschedule"><b>auxiliary schedule</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a>, a separate list of <a href="#class">class</a>es (with their <a href="#notation">notation</a>s) which serve only to subdivide the classes listed in the <a href="#mainschedule">main schedule</a>s, for example, the <a href="#standardsubdivision">standard subdivision</a>s listed in Table 1 of <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="available"><b>available</b></a>
</dt><dd>An indication in an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> of the <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> that can be found on the shelf ready to be <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>.  In a more general sense, any item that can be seen, used, or obtained by a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#patron">patron</a>, including <a href="#refbook">reference materials</a> and items in <a href="#specialcollections">special collection</a>s for which <a href="#access">access</a> may be subject to certain <a href="#restricted">restriction</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#outofcirculation">out of circulation</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="averageprice"><b>average price</b></a>
</dt><dd>The sum of the prices of individual items within a specific
category (or a representative sample), divided by the number of items
selected for the purpose of calculation. In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#acquisitions">acquisition</a>s, average price per <a href="#title">title</a> is used to compute the annual rate of inflation in the cost of various types of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, an important consideration in <a href="#budget">budget</a>ing and the <a href="#allocation">allocation</a> of funds.  The average price of <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#serial">serial</a>s sold in the United States is broken down by <a href="#subject">subject</a> in the <b><em>Bowker Annual Library and Book Trade Almanac</em></b>, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of larger libraries.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#price">price</a> and <a href="#listprice">list price</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="avsl1"><b>AVSL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#avsl"><b>A</b>ssociation of <b>V</b>ision <b>S</b>cience <b>L</b>ibrarians</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="axonometricmap"><b>axonometric map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A very detailed, large-<a href="#scale">scale</a> <a href="#map">map</a> of a city, in which the buildings and other structures are shown in perspective, usually on an incline.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>
<center>
| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> 
| <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a> | <a href="#F">F</a> 
| <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> 
| <a href="#JK">JK</a> | <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> 
| <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a> | <a href="#P">P</a> 
| <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> 
| <a href="#T">T</a> | <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> 
| <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="B">B</a></font></h1>

<p></p><dl><dt><a name="back"><b>back</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> or <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#gathering">gathered</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a>, to which the <a href="#lining">lining</a> is applied.  The back may be <a href="#flatback">flat</a>, but more often it is given a convex curve in a binding procedure called <a href="#rounding">rounding</a>.  A flexible or <a href="#hollowback">hollow back</a> is preferable because it allows a <a href="#volume">volume</a> to <a href="#openability">open</a> flat.  Compare with <a href="#backstrip">backstrip</a> and <a href="#spine">spine</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#tightback">tight back</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backbone"><b>backbone</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a>, the portion of a physical <a href="#network">network</a>
that covers the longest distance and handles the heaviest traffic. To
operate at the highest possible transmission speed, it must be
constructed of cable that provides maximum <a href="#bandwidth">bandwidth</a>.  On the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, regional networks are connected to the <a href="#opticalfiber">fiber-optic</a> backbone, smaller networks are connected to regional networks, and so on down the line.
<p>
Synonymous in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> with <a href="#spine">spine</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backdate"><b>backdate</b></a>
</dt><dd>To make a <a href="#document">document</a> or transaction effective from a date earlier than its actual date, for example, a <a href="#book">book</a> order given a prior date with the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s permission, to allow the purchaser to qualify for an <a href="#expirationdate">expired</a> <a href="#discount">discount</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backfile"><b>back file</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> which precede the <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>, usually <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a>s or converted to <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> or <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> to conserve space.  In the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>, the extent of the back file is indicated in the <a href="#holdingsnote">holdings note</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#holdings">holdings</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backfold"><b>back fold</b></a>
</dt><dd>The fold along which a <a href="#signature">signature</a> is <a href="#gathering">gathered</a> to form the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, left <a href="#uncut">uncut</a> in <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>s but <a href="#trimmed">trimmed</a> in <a href="#perfectbinding">perfect binding</a> to allow the <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> to bond more securely.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backing"><b>backing</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the process of shaping a <a href="#shoulder">shoulder</a> on each side of the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> after <a href="#rounding">rounding</a>, before <a href="#lining">lining</a> is applied to the <a href="#back">back</a>.  In <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a>, a backing hammer is used to bend the backs of the <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s from the center of the text block toward the front and back, forming two ridges against which the <a href="#board">board</a>s of the <a href="#cover">cover</a> will fit.  By folding the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> over each other close to the binding edge, backing also helps maintain the rounded shape of the <a href="#spine">spine</a>, preventing the leaves from working their way forward as the <a href="#volume">volume</a> is used.  The process also enhances the <a href="#openability">openability</a> of a volume by creating a slight crease in each leaf near the spine.  In <a href="#publishersbinding">edition binding</a> and <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a>, backing is done by machine.
<p>
Also, a <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> in which an additional layer is applied to an item to provide support, usually on the reverse side of a weakened <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>.  Also refers to the material added in this type of reinforcement.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backissue"><b>back issue</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> that precedes the <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>.  Back issues are usually retained in a <a href="#backfile">back file</a> which may be stored in a different location in the periodicals section of a <a href="#library">library</a>, sometimes converted to a more compact <a href="#format">format</a>, such as <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> or <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>.  In the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>, the extent of the back file is indicated in the <a href="#holdingsnote">holdings note</a>.  Synonymous with <em>back number</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backlining"><b>back-lining</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lining">lining</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backlist"><b>backlist</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#publication">publication</a>s on a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s active <a href="#list">list</a> which are no longer <a href="#newbook">new</a>, having been <a href="#publishing">published</a> prior to the <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#season">season</a>.  Kept <a href="#instock">in stock</a> to meet future <a href="#demand">demand</a>, backlist <a href="#title">title</a>s are often the most profitable part of a publisher's list.  Also spelled <em>back-list</em>.  Compare with <a href="#frontlist">frontlist</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#inprint">in print</a>, <a href="#outofstock">out of stock</a>, and <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backlog"><b>backlog</b></a>
</dt><dd>An accumulation of work that remains to be done, often the cause of delays and bottlenecks in <a href="#workflow">workflow</a>.  A <em>cataloging backlog</em> may result when <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ing is insufficient to meet the demands of <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, for example, when a substantial <a href="#gift">gift</a> is received within a short period of time.  Synonymous in this sense with <a href="#arrears">arrears</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backmatter"><b>back matter</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#page">page</a>s following the <a href="#text">text</a> at the end of a <a href="#book">book</a>, on which the <a href="#appendix">appendices</a>, <a href="#note">note</a>s, <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a>, list of <a href="#contributor">contributor</a>s, <a href="#index">indices</a>, <a href="#imprint">imprint</a>, and any <a href="#adverts">advertising</a> normally appear.  In scholarly <a href="#work">work</a>s, the back matter may be considerable.  Back matter is <a href="#pagination">paginated</a> in <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s continuously with the text.  <a href="#blank">Blank</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> may be included at the end to make up a full <a href="#section">section</a>.  Synonymous with <em>end matter</em>, <em>postliminary matter</em>, and <em>subsidiaries</em>.  Compare with <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#partsofabook">parts of a book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backnumber"><b>back number</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#backissue">back issue</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backorder"><b>back order (BO)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An order for <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> that could not be filled when originally placed because at least one of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s requested was not <a href="#instock">in stock</a> or as yet <a href="#unpublished">unpublished</a>.  Back orders are held <a href="#openorder">open</a> for future delivery, usually for a designated period of time, after which they are <a href="#oc">canceled</a>.  Synonymous in the U.K. with <em>dues</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#reorder">reorder</a> and <a href="#shortshipment">short shipment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backslanted"><b>backslanted</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> or handwriting that inclines to the left of center.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backslash"><b>backslash</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#character">character</a> consisting of a straight line slanting diagonally from upper left to lower right, used mainly in <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a>ming notation and to separate <a href="#directory">directory</a> and <a href="#file">file</a> names in <a href="#dos">DOS</a> and <a href="#windows">Windows</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>c:\bib\bib.txt</b> referring to the <b>bib.txt</b> file in the <b>bib</b> <a href="#folder">folder</a> stored on the <b>c:\</b> <a href="#diskdrive">disk drive</a>).  Also spelled <em>back slash</em>.  Synonymous with <em>reverse solidus</em>.  Compare with <a href="#slash">slash</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backstrip"><b>backstrip</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the central portion of the covering material, extending from the front <a href="#joint">joint</a> to the back joint over the <a href="#inlay">inlay</a> separating the <a href="#board">board</a>s, stamped with the <a href="#title">title</a> and <a href="#author">author</a>'s name in most <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  Sometimes used synonymously with <a href="#spine">spine</a>.  Compare with <a href="#back">back</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#lining">lining</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="backup"><b>backup</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a>, to make a second <a href="#copy">copy</a> of an important <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>
in case the original is lost, damaged, or destroyed. Also refers to
computer files, equipment, and procedures created and maintained
specifically for use in the event of loss or failure of normal systems.
In a more general sense, any strategy designed to be implemented if a
preferred method or system fails. <p>
Also, to <a href="#printing">print</a> the reverse side of a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> that has already been printed on one side.  Also spelled <em>back up</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="baker&amp;taylor"><b>Baker &amp; Taylor</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#jobber">jobber</a> in the business of supplying <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>s, and music materials to retailers and <a href="#library">libraries</a>, usually at a <a href="#discount">discount</a>, and of providing value-added and customized services to meet the needs of libraries of all types.  <b>B&amp;T</b> products and services are listed and described in its <a href="#tradecatalog">trade catalog</a>s.  <a href="http://www.btol.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>B&amp;T</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="balance"><b>balance</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#budget">budget</a>ing, to keep expenditures in line with income, usually for the duration of a fixed accounting period.  In <a href="#printing">printing</a> and <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> design, to arrange <a href="#text">text</a> and <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s on a <a href="#page">page</a> in a configuration that is aesthetically pleasing. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="balanced"><b>balanced</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> containing <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> that present the full range of opinion on controversial issues and sensitive <a href="#topic">topic</a>s, for example, the "for" and "against" positions on legalized abortion, or <a href="#religiousbook">religious book</a>s representing various faiths.  Although it is an elusive goal, balance is particularly important in <a href="#collecdevel">developing</a> <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> collections which must meet the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s and reflect the reading tastes of a wide range of <a href="#patron">patron</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ballad"><b>ballad</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, an orally transmitted <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>
song composed in an impersonal style for public performance, often sung
to a traditional tune that served as a musical accompaniment to a
dance. Most ballads tell a popular story of tragic romance or personal
catastrophe in short stanzas with a refrain, usually in the form of a <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> with action.  Repetition over an extended period of time tends to produce variants.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>folk ballad</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#saga">saga</a>. 
<p>
Beginning in 16th century Britain, <a href="#broadside">broadside</a> ballads about contemporary issues and events were <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a single <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>
and sold in the streets to be sung to well-known popular tunes. In the
late 18th century, a new literary form developed in which long <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#poetry">poem</a>s were written in deliberate imitation of earlier popular ballads (<em>example</em>: Coleridge's <b><em>Rime of the Ancient Mariner</em></b>).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="balloon"><b>balloon</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>s, <a href="#comicbook">comic book</a>s, and <a href="#graphicnovel">graphic novel</a>s, a space encircled by a line drawn from the mouth of one of the <a href="#character">character</a>s, containing <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> or the character's unspoken thoughts.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bands"><b>bands</b></a>
</dt><dd>In older <a href="#handbinding">hand-bound</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s, the <a href="#section">section</a>s were <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> to cords of flax or hemp, spaced at regular intervals across the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a>, producing a series of parallel ridges in the material covering the <a href="#spine">spine</a>, unless <a href="#sunkbands">sunk</a> by the <a href="#binder">binder</a> into grooves sawn across the <a href="#back">back</a> (the term refers to both the cords and the ridges).  Bands replaced the <a href="#leather">leather</a> thongs originally used to <a href="#binding">bind</a> books in <a href="#codex">codex</a> form.  In modern <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, bands have been replaced by <a href="#tapes">tapes</a> in quality bindings, or omitted entirely in most <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#raisedbands">raised bands</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bandwidth"><b>bandwidth</b></a>
</dt><dd>The maximum carrying capacity of a line in an electronic <a href="#communications">communications</a> <a href="#network">network</a>.  For <a href="#digital">digital</a> devices, bandwidth is measured measured in <a href="#bit">bit</a>s or <a href="#byte">byte</a>s per second; for <a href="#analog">analog</a> devices, in <a href="#megahertz">Hertz</a> (cycles per second).  Bandwidth determines the amount of <a href="#data">data</a> that can be transmitted in a fixed amount of time.  During periods of <a href="#peakuse">peak use</a>, it may also determine speed of transmission, particularly for large <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s (<a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s, audio, video, etc.).  On the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, the <a href="#opticalfiber">fiber-optic</a> <a href="#backbone">backbone</a> has greatest bandwidth.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#t1">T1</a> and <a href="#t3">T3</a>. 
<p>
In <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>ing, the width of the band of
frequencies or wave-lengths assigned (usually by licensing agreement)
to a radio or television station for its exclusive use. </p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="banned"><b>banned book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a>, the <a href="#publication">publication</a> and/or sale of which has been prohibited or <a href="#suppressed">suppressed</a> by ecclesiastical or secular authority because its <a href="#content">content</a> is considered objectionable or dangerous, usually for political reasons (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Grapes of Wrath</em></b>) or social reasons (<b><em>Leaves of Grass</em></b>).  <a href="#bannedbooksweek">Banned Books Week</a> has been celebrated annually in the United States since 1981.  Lists of banned books are available in the <a href="#refstacks">reference section</a> of most large <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  Compare with <a href="#expurgated">expurgated edition</a>.  <a href="http://digital.library.upenn.edu/books/banned-books.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <em>Banned Books Online</em> <a href="#website">Web site</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>, <a href="#challenge">challenge</a>, <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>, and <em><a href="#indexlibrorum">Index Librorum Prohibitorum</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bannedbooksweek"><b>Banned Books Week</b></a>
</dt><dd>An annual event observed in the United States since 1981 during the last week of September, <b>Banned Books Week</b> is sponsored by the <a href="#aba">American Booksellers Association</a>, American Booksellers Foundation for Free Expression, <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <a href="#aap">Association of American Publishers</a>, American Society of Journalists and Authors, and National Association of College Stores, and endorsed by the <a href="#centerforthebook">Center for the Book</a> at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> and <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s throughout the country celebrate the <a href="#ftrs">freedom to read</a> by displaying recently <a href="#banned">banned book</a>s and <a href="#book">book</a>s that have been banned throughout history.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/bbooks/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to <b>Banned Books Week</b> on the ALA <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="banner"><b>banner</b></a>
</dt><dd>A narrow band of <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> promotional material displayed on a <a href="#website">Web site</a> that has leased or sold space on its page(s) to a commercial advertiser.  Also, a narrow strip <a href="#logo">logo</a> across the top or bottom of a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>, identifying the <a href="#host">host</a> organization or suggesting the <a href="#content">content</a> of the site. 
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> <a href="#headline">headline</a> of one or two lines, large enough to extend across an entire <a href="#page">page</a> or most of a page.  Compare with <a href="#skyline">skyline</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="barcode"><b>barcode</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#label">label</a> containing <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#encoding">encoded</a> in vertical lines of equal length but variable thickness, which can be read into an attached computer by an optical <a href="#scanner">scanner</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a> barcodes are used to identify <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> for <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> and <a href="#inventory">inventory</a>, and to link the <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>'s <a href="#librarycard">library card</a> to the appropriate <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a> in automated <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s.  Also spelled <em>bar code</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#automatedcheckout">automated checkout</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bargraph"><b>bar graph</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#histogram">histogram</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="baseline"><b>base line</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typography">typography</a>, the imaginary horizontal line connecting the bottoms of <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a>s lacking <a href="#descender">descender</a>s, used to measure the intervals between lines of <a href="#type">type</a>.  The line connecting the tops of letters lacking <a href="#ascender">ascender</a>s is called the <a href="#meanline">mean line</a>.  Also spelled <em>baseline</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="basemap"><b>base map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#topographic">topographic map</a>, usually on a <a href="#scale">scale</a> of 1:10,000 to 1:50,000, used as the basis for other <a href="#map">map</a>s.  In the United States, the base map is the 1:24,000 7.5-minute topographic <a href="#quadrangle">quadrangle</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#toposeries">series</a> by the <a href="http://www.usgs.gov/">U.S. Geological Survey</a>, popularly known as the <em>quad</em>.  Synonymous with <em>mother map</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="basenumber"><b>base number</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> in the <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a>s to which other <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s are appended (<em>example</em>:  <b>020</b> representing the <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>s) to which a <a href="#decimalpoint">decimal</a> fraction can be added to indicate a <a href="#subclass">subclass</a> (<b>.5</b> for an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> that is a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>).  Compare with <a href="#baseofnotation">base of notation</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#addnote">add note</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="baseofnotation"><b>base of notation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The set of <a href="#character">character</a>s or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s used in the <a href="#notation">notation</a> of a given <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>.  In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s <b>0-9</b> are used (<a href="#decimalpoint">decimal</a> notation).  In <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a>, the <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the English <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> are used (alphabetic notation), minus the letters <b>O</b> and <b>I</b> which are easily mistaken for the <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s zero and one.  As a general rule, the shorter the base, the longer the notation representing a given <a href="#class">class</a> is likely to be.  Compare with <a href="#basenumber">base number</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bastardtitle"><b>bastard title</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#halftitle">half title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="batchprocessing"><b>batch processing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of <a href="#records">records</a> accumulated so that they can be processed together, rather than one-by-one, used mainly in automated <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> and <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> to increase efficiency and reduce costs.  Synonymous with <em>batchload processing</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bathymetricmap"><b>bathymetric map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#topographic">topographic map</a> showing the depth and features of the sea floor, including coastal zones (bays and estuaries), usually by means of <a href="#contourmap">contour line</a>s called <em>isobaths</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="battledore"><b>battledore</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of school <a href="#primer">primer</a> used in the late 18th century, made of folded <a href="#paper">paper</a> varnished on the inside, resembling a <a href="#hornbook">horn book</a> when opened, but sometimes lacking a handle. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="baud"><b>baud</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, a unit of telegraph signaling speed (one Morse
code dot per second) proposed in 1927 at the International Telegraph
Conference and named after the French engineer Jean-Maurice-Emile
Baudot (1845-1903) who designed the first teleprinter. <p>
In <a href="#telecommunications">telecommunications</a>, a unit of measurement indicating the number of <em>signaling elements</em> (changes of voltage or frequency) transmitted per second over a communication channel, at slower speeds synonymous with <em><a href="#bit">bit</a>s per second (bps)</em>.  At higher speeds, more than one bit may be <a href="#encoding">encoded</a> per second, for example, a speed of 4,800 baud may transmit 9,600 bits per second.  For this reason, <em>bps</em> has replaced the term <em>baud</em> as a measure of <a href="#data">data</a> transmission speed.  The <em>baud rate</em> of a <a href="#modem">modem</a> is one of the factors determining the speed of an <a href="#internet">Internet</a> connection in <a href="#dialaccess">dial-up access</a>.  Pronounced <em>bawd</em>.  Plural:  <em>baud</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bbc1"><b>BBC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bbc"><b>B</b>ritish <b>B</b>roadcasting <b>C</b>orporation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bbs1"><b>BBS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bbs"><b>b</b>ulletin <b>b</b>oard <b>s</b>ystem</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bcala1"><b>BCALA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bcala"><b>B</b>lack <b>C</b>aucus of the <b>A</b>merican <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bea1"><b>BEA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bea"><b>B</b>ook<b>E</b>xpo <b>A</b>merica</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="beastepic"><b>beast epic</b></a>
</dt><dd>A series of stories popular during the Middle Ages in which the <a href="#character">character</a>s are animals with human qualities, usually written in the form of an <a href="#allegory">allegory</a> <a href="#satire">satirizing</a> the Catholic Church, the royal court, or some other powerful person, group, or institution (<em>example</em>:  Pierre de Saint-Cloud's 12th century <b><em>Roman de Renart</em></b>).  A more recent example is George Orwell's <b><em>Animal Farm</em></b> (1945), written in the same tradition.  Compare with <a href="#bestiary">bestiary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="beginningreader"><b>beginning reader</b></a>
</dt><dd>A heavily <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> <a href="#work">work</a> of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> or <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> designed specifically for young children learning to read, in which the <a href="#text">text</a> is brief, the <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a> and grammar simplified, and the <a href="#typesize">type size</a> large, shelved in the <a href="#juvenile">juvenile collection</a> in <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Harry and the Lady Next Door</em></b> by Gene Zion).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="belleslettres"><b>belles lettres</b></a>
</dt><dd>A French phrase meaning "beautiful letters," referring to polite, refined <a href="#literature">literature</a> (<a href="#poetry">poetry</a>, <a href="#essay">essay</a>s, <a href="#play">drama</a>, orations, <a href="#letters">letters</a>, literary <a href="#criticism">criticism</a>, etc.) and to the aesthetics of literary studies.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="benchmark"><b>benchmark</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> borrowed from surveying to indicate the superior quality of a product or service recognized as a <a href="#standards">standard</a>
or point of reference in comparisons made by other producers or
providers intent on improving their performance. In computing, a
measure of the performance of a <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> or <a href="#software">software</a> component.  Also spelled <em>bench mark</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="benefits"><b>benefits</b></a>
</dt><dd>Compensation to which an employee is entitled in addition to <a href="#salary">salary</a> or <a href="#wages">wages</a>, such as health and dental insurance, pension or <a href="#retirement">retirement</a> contributions, free tuition, etc., usually specified in the contract or <a href="#collectivebargaining">collective bargaining agreement</a> governing terms of employment.  Persons employed <a href="#parttime">part-time</a> are usually not entitled to full benefits.  Synonymous with <em>fringes</em>.  Compare with <a href="#perk">perk</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="berne"><b><em>Berne Convention</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#internationalcopyright">international copyright</a> agreement creating an <em>International Union for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works</em>
signed in Berne, Switzerland in 1886, ratified in 1887 by several
European countries and their colonies, and revised periodically. By
1974, there were 64 signatories. The United States joined in 1988. To
receive <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> protection under the <b><em>Berne Convention</em></b>, first <a href="#publication">publication</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> must occur in a member country.  Works <a href="#publishing">published</a> in nonsignatory nations receive protection if published simultaneously in a signatory nation.  Protection is for the <a href="#author">author</a>'s lifetime plus fifty years.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#universalcopyright">Universal Copyright Convention</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bernerslee"><b>Berners-Lee, Tim </b></a>
</dt><dd>The inventor of the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>, Tim Berners-Lee graduated from Oxford University in physics and worked in the <a href="#telecommunications">telecommunications</a>
industry in England before he was granted a fellowship in 1984 at CERN,
a high-energy physics lab in Geneva. In 1989, he proposed that CERN
fund the development of a <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#data">data</a>
system and spent the next five years facilitating the design of what
quickly became a global electronic communications system. In 1994,
Berners-Lee moved to the Laboratory for Computer Science at MIT where
he continued to develop Web tools and <a href="#standards">standards</a>.  Although Berners-Lee has received awards for his work, he elected <em>not</em> to <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> or profit from his invention because he wanted the Web to remain widely <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a>.
He has been quoted as saying, "....you can have an idea...and it can
happen. It means that dreamers all over the world should take note and
not stop."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bestbooks"><b>best books</b></a>
</dt><dd>A selection of recently <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s considered by <a href="#review">review</a>ers to be superior in the <a href="#field">field</a> or the type of <a href="#publication">publication</a> they represent.  Most <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>s publish <a href="#annual">annual</a> lists of highly recommended <a href="#title">title</a>s in the various categories reviewed (<a href="#refbook">reference</a>, <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>, <a href="#yabook">young adult</a>, <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>s, etc.).  Recommended lists are also published in book form (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Best Books for Beginning Readers</em></b> by Thomas G. Gunning) for use in <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>.  Compare with <a href="#bestseller">bestseller</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bestiary"><b>bestiary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#literature">literature</a> popular during the Middle Ages, containing <a href="#myth">myth</a>s and <a href="#folklore">folklore</a> about exotic animals, real or imaginary, in which <a href="#text">text</a> and <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s were employed to teach both natural history and Christian morals through the use of <a href="#allegory">allegory</a>.  Compare with <a href="#beastepic">beast epic</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bestpractice"><b>best practice</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the application of theory to real-life situations, any
procedure which, when properly applied, consistently yields superior
results, and is therefore used as a reference point in evaluating the
effectiveness of alternative methods of accomplishing the same task.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bestseller"><b>bestseller</b></a>
</dt><dd>A highly <a href="#publicity">publicized</a> <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a> currently in such high <a href="#demand">demand</a> in <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s and <a href="#library">libraries</a> that large <a href="#number">number</a>s of <a href="#copy">copies</a> are sold and <a href="#circulation">circulated</a>.  Major <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s and <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>s often <a href="#publishing">publish</a> ranked lists of bestsellers in <a href="#adult">adult</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> (and sometimes in <a href="#juvenile">children's literature</a>) based on sales volume over a given period of time (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/books/bestseller/index.html">The New York Times Best-Seller Lists</a></em>).  The <em>Bowker Annual Library and Book Trade Almanac</em> usually includes an <a href="#essay">essay</a> analyzing the previous year's bestsellers.  <a href="http://dir.yahoo.com/Arts/Humanities/Literature/Bestseller_Lists/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of <a href="#online">online</a> bestseller lists.  Also spelled <em>best-seller</em>.  Compare with <a href="#classic">classic</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bestseller1"><b>best-seller</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bestseller">bestseller</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="betaphimu"><b>Beta Phi Mu</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded at the University of Illinois in 1948, <b>Beta Phi Mu</b> is an international <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a> honor <a href="#society">society</a> established to recognize outstanding scholarship and to sponsor professional and scholarly projects in <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>.  Membership is open to graduates of <a href="#ala">ALA</a>-<a href="#accreditation">accredited</a> <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a>s who have completed the requirements leading to a fifth year or advanced degree (<a href="#mls">M.L.S.</a> or <a href="#mlis">M.L.I.S.</a>) with a scholastic average of at least 3.75 and in the top 25 percent of their class.  An <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>Beta Phi Mu</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> a <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> national <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a>.  <a href="http://www.beta-phi-mu.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Beta Phi Mu</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="betatest"><b>beta test</b></a>
</dt><dd>A full-scale test of a new <a href="#software">software</a> or <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> system involving actual users under normal operating conditions in the field, usually preceded by <a href="#alphatest">alpha test</a>ing in a laboratory environment.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="beveledboards"><b>beveled boards</b></a>
</dt><dd>A technique used in <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a> in which the upper surface of the edges of heavy <a href="#board">board</a>s are cut at a sloping angle, instead of the usual 90-degrees, to give the <a href="#cover">cover</a> a more elegant appearance or in conscious imitation of an earlier style.  Also spelled <em>bevelled boards</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bevelededge">beveled edge</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bevelededge"><b>beveled edge</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any edge tapered at less than a 90-degree angle to make the
transition from upper to lower surface more gradual than in a
right-angle cut. <a href="#beveledboards">Beveled boards</a> are sometimes used in <a href="#handbinding">hand</a> <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>.  The edges of <a href="#mat">mat</a>s used in framing are normally beveled at a 60-degree angle. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bi1"><b>BI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#bi"><b>b</b>ibliographic <b>i</b>nstruction</a>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biannual"><b>biannual</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d twice each year.  Also refers to a <a href="#publication">publication</a> issued twice a year.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bias"><b>bias</b></a>
</dt><dd>Judgment unfairly influenced by subjective opinion when the
situation calls for reliance on objective fact. Bias exists even in <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s (compare the <a href="#entry">entries</a> for "Holocaust" and "Inquisition" in the <b><em>Encyclopedia Judaica</em></b>, <b><em>Encyclopedia of Religion</em></b>, and <b><em>New Catholic Encyclopedia</em></b>).  In publicly supported <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States, bias in employment practices is prohibited by law.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#affirmative">affirmative action</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibelot"><b>bibelot</b></a>
</dt><dd>A French term for a small decorative object of exceptional beauty, <a href="#rarity">rarity</a>, or curiosity.  In <a href="#literature">literature</a>, a <a href="#book">book</a> of unusually small size, elegantly designed, and crafted from the finest materials.  Also known as a <em>thumb book</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biblepaper"><b>bible paper</b></a>
</dt><dd>A strong, thin, <a href="#opacity">opaque</a> <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> made from new cotton or linen <a href="#ragpaper">rag</a>s, or from flax fiber, used to reduce the <a href="#bulk">bulk</a> of large <a href="#volume">volume</a>s such as <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a>, <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s, bibles, and prayer books that would otherwise be too thick to be easily handled.  Sometimes used synonymously with <em>India paper</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biblestyle"><b>Bible style</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general <a href="#term">term</a> for any <a href="#flexiblebinding">flexible</a> <a href="#leather">leather</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a> that has rounded <a href="#corner">corner</a>s, especially one of dark color.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliapaup"><b><em>Biblia Pauperum</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for "Bible of the Poor," a <a href="#blockbook">block book</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in large numbers beginning in about 1450, consisting mainly of <a href="#picture">picture</a>s with explanatory <a href="#text">text</a> in Latin or German providing lessons from the <a href="#scripture">Scripture</a>s.  According to Jean Peters (<b><em>The Bookman's Glossary</em></b>, Bowker: 1975), this form of <a href="#book">book</a> was not <a href="#superseded">superseded</a> by the invention of <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>, but continued to be produced into the early part of the 16th century.  Extremely <a href="#rarity">rare</a>, fewer than two dozen examples are known to survive.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biblio"><b>biblio-</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek word <em>biblion</em> meaning "book," used in combination to form a host of <a href="#term">term</a>s pertaining to <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#library">libraries</a> (<a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, <a href="#bibliomania">bibliomania</a>, <a href="#bibliophile">bibliophile</a>, <a href="#bibliophobia">bibliophobia</a>, <a href="#bibliotherapy">bibliotherapy</a>, etc.).  In interactions with <a href="#patron">patron</a>s, most <a href="#publicservices">public services</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s avoid the "B-words" because the general public is not familiar with the technical <a href="#terminology">terminology</a> of <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliocaper"><b>bibliocaper</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> coined by George Eberhart (<b><em>The Whole Library Handbook</em></b>, ALA: 2000) to refer to an odd or wacky event, harebrained prank, or bizarre petty crime involving <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, library <a href="#patron">patron</a>s, or <a href="#book">book</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biblioclast"><b>biblioclast</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who destroys or <a href="#mutilation">mutilates</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s, for one reason or another.  Fortunately for <a href="#bibliophile">bibliophile</a>s, this form of aberrant behavior occurs infrequently.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliogony"><b>bibliogony</b></a>
</dt><dd>Of or relating to the production of <a href="#book">book</a>s in all their forms.  Synonymous with <em>bibliogenesis</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliographee"><b>bibliographee</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person concerning whom a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> is <a href="#compilation">compiled</a>, as in a list of references at the end of a biographical <a href="#essay">essay</a> or <a href="#book">book</a>-length <a href="#biography">biography</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#biobibliography">biobibliography</a>.
<p> 
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliographer"><b>bibliographer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who describes and lists <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, with particular attention to such characteristics as <a href="#authorship">authorship</a>, <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, <a href="#edition">edition</a>, <a href="#typography">typography</a>, etc.  The result of this endeavor is a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>.  A person who limits such efforts to a specific <a href="#field">field</a> or <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> is a <em>subject bibliographer</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bsa">Bibliographical Society of America</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bsa"><b>Bibliographical Society of America (BSA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Organized in 1904, the <b>BSA</b> promotes <a href="#bibliography">bibliographical</a> <a href="#research">research</a> and <a href="#issue">issue</a>s <a href="#publication">publication</a>s on bibliographical <a href="#topic">topic</a>s.  Membership is open to all who have an interest in bibliographical problems and projects, including <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s.  The <b>BSA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>Papers of the Bibliographical Society of America</em>.  <a href="http://www.bibsocamer.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>BSA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibcontrol"><b>bibliographic control</b></a>
</dt><dd>A broad <a href="#term">term</a> encompassing all the activities involved in creating, organizing, managing, and maintaining the <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s representing the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s held in a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, or the sources listed in an <a href="#index">index</a> or <a href="#database">database</a>, to facilitate <a href="#access">access</a> to the <a href="#information">information</a> contained in them.  Bibliographic control includes the <a href="#standardization">standardization</a> of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> and <a href="#subject">subject</a> access by means of uniform <a href="#catalogcode">catalog code</a>, <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>s, and preferred <a href="#heading">heading</a>s; the creation and maintenance of <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, <a href="#unionlist">union list</a>s, and <a href="#findingaid">finding aid</a>s; and the provision of physical access to the items in the collection.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibdatabase"><b>bibliographic database</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#file">file</a> consisting of electronic <a href="#entry">entries</a> called <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s, each containing a uniform <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a> of a specific <a href="#document">document</a> or <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>, usually <a href="#inforetrieval">retrievable</a> by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> (<a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>), or <a href="#keywords">keyword(s)</a>.  Some bibliographic <a href="#database">database</a>s are general in <a href="#scope">scope</a> and <a href="#coverage">coverage</a>, others provide <a href="#access">access</a> to the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of a specific <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or group of disciplines.  An increasing number provide the <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> of at least a portion of the <a href="#source">source</a>s indexed.  Most bibliographic databases are <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a>, available by <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a> from <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s, or directly from the indexing and abstracting services that create them.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibdescrip"><b>bibliographic description</b></a>
</dt><dd>In a general sense, all the elements of <a href="#data">data</a> necessary to conclusively identify a specific <a href="#document">document</a>, presented in some form of <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>.  
<p>
In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the detailed description of a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a specific <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, intended to identify and distinguish it from other works by the same <a href="#author">author</a>, of the same <a href="#title">title</a>, or on the same <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the bibliographic record representing an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> includes the following standard <a href="#area">area</a>s of description:  <a href="#titleand">title and statement of responsibility</a> (author, <a href="#editor">editor</a>, <a href="#composer">composer</a>, etc.), <a href="#editionarea">edition</a>, <a href="#materialspecific">material specific details</a>, details of <a href="#publicationarea">publication and distribution</a>, <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a>, <a href="#seriesarea">series</a>, <a href="#notearea">notes</a>, and <a href="#standardnumberandterms">standard number and terms of availability</a> (<a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>, <a href="#issn">ISSN</a>, <a href="#price">price</a>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a> and <a href="#levelofdescrip">level of description</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibessay"><b>bibliographic essay</b></a>
</dt><dd>A critical <a href="#essay">essay</a> in which the <a href="#bibliographer">bibliographer</a> identifies and evaluates the core <a href="#literature">literature</a> of a sub<a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or <a href="#field">field</a> of study, providing guidance to students, <a href="#research">research</a>ers, and <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s (<em>example</em>:  the bibliographic essay <a href="#publishing">published</a> at the beginning of each <a href="#issue">issue</a> of the <a href="#reviewpub">review journal</a> <em><a href="#choice">CHOICE</a></em>).  Compare with <a href="#litreview">literature review</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibformat"><b>bibliographic format</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#standardization">standardized</a> sequence and manner of presentation of the <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s constituting the full <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a specific <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> or <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> system.  The <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> <a href="#format">format</a> has become the <a href="#standard">standard</a> for <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s in many countries of the world. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bi"><b>bibliographic instruction (BI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Instructional programs designed to teach <a href="#library">library</a> users how to locate the <a href="#information">information</a> they need quickly and effectively.  <b>BI</b> usually covers the library's system of organizing <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, the structure of the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of the <a href="#field">field</a>, <a href="#research">research</a> methodologies appropriate to the <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, and specific resources and <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a>s (<a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, <a href="#index">index</a>ing and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, etc.).  
<p>
In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, bibliographic instruction is usually <a href="#courserelated">course-related</a> or <a href="#courseintegrated">course-integrated</a>.  Libraries which have a computer-equipped <a href="#instructionlab">instruction lab</a> are in a position to include <a href="#handson">hands-on</a> practice in the use of <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s, electronic <a href="#database">database</a>s, and <a href="#internet">Internet</a> resources. Instruction sessions are usually taught by an <em>instructional services <a href="#librarian">librarian</a></em> with specialized training and experience in pedagogical methods.  Synonymous with <em>library instruction</em> and <em>library orientation</em>.   Compare with <a href="#usereducation">user education</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:   <a href="#lifelong">lifelong learning</a>, <a href="#oneshot">one-shot</a>, <a href="#lirt">LIRT</a>, and <a href="#loex">LOEX</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibitem"><b>bibliographic item</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, a <a href="#document">document</a> or set of documents in any physical <a href="#format">format</a> (<a href="#printing">print</a> or <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a>), given a single <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> based on the fact of having been <a href="#publishing">published</a>, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d, released, or otherwise treated as a single entity.
<p>
As defined in <em><a href="#frbr">FRBR</a></em> (<em>Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records</em>), a single concrete <a href="#exemplar">exemplar</a> of a <a href="#manifestation">manifestation</a> of an <a href="#expression">expression</a> of an intellectual or artistic <a href="#work">work</a>, in most cases a single physical object, such as a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of an <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a single-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>.  All the items constituting a manifestation normally contain the same intellectual/artistic <a href="#content">content</a> and are identical in physical form, but variations can occur subsequent to production, as in the case of a monograph <a href="#rebinding">rebound</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a>.  In some cases an item consists of more than one physical object, for example, a <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a> released on more than one <a href="#videocassette">cassette</a> or a <a href="#multivolumework">multivolume</a> <a href="#set">set</a> of <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibrecord"><b>bibliographic record</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#entry">entry</a> representing a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, containing all the <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s necessary for a full <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a>, presented in a specific <a href="#bibformat">bibliographic format</a>.
