In modern <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the standard format is <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> (<em>example</em>:   the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record), but prior to the use of computers, the traditional format was the <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a>.  Compare with <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>, <a href="#checkinrecord">check-in record</a>, <a href="#itemrecord">item record</a>, and <a href="#orderrecord">order record</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#briefrecord">brief record</a>, <a href="#fullrecord">full record</a>, <a href="#encodinglevel">encoding level</a>, and <a href="#recordstructure">record structure</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibretrieval"><b>bibliographic retrieval</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process in which a user <a href="#query">queries</a> a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, usually by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> (<a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>), or <a href="#keywords">keyword(s)</a>, and receives a list of <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s representing <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s that satisfy the parameters of the <a href="#search">search</a>.  Most commercial <a href="#database">database</a>s allow the searcher to use techniques such as <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic, <a href="#truncation">truncation</a>, and <a href="#proximity">proximity</a> to refine <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>s.  <em><b>See also</b></em>:  <a href="#precision">precision</a>, <a href="#recall">recall</a>, and <a href="#searchstrategy">search strategy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibservice"><b>bibliographic service center</b></a>
</dt><dd>A regional broker in the business of handling <a href="#access">access</a>, communication, training, billing, and other services for <a href="#library">libraries</a> located within a given geographic area which are connected to an <a href="#online">online</a> bibliographic <a href="#network">network</a>, for example, <a href="http://www.nelinet.net/">Nelinet</a> which provides access to and support for <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> and a variety of <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s to libraries in the northeastern U.S.  Compare with <a href="#bibutility">bibliographic utility</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibutility"><b>bibliographic utility</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization that provides <a href="#access">access</a> to and support for <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s directly to member <a href="#library">libraries</a> or through a <a href="#network">network</a> of regional <a href="#bibservice">bibliographic service center</a>s, usually via a <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> <a href="#interface">interface</a>.  The largest bibliographic utility in the United States is <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliography"><b>bibliography</b></a>   
</dt><dd>Strictly speaking, a systematic list or <a href="#enumerative">enumeration</a> of written <a href="#work">work</a>s by a specific <a href="#author">author</a> or on a given <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or which share one or more common characteristics (<a href="#language">language</a>, form, period, <a href="#placeofpublication">place of publication</a>, etc.).  When a bibliography is about a person, the subject is called the <a href="#bibliographee">bibliographee</a>.  A bibliography may be <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> or <a href="#selective">selective</a>.  Long bibliographies may be <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#serialbib">serial</a>ly or in <a href="#book">book</a> form.  The person responsible for <a href="#compile">compiling</a> a bibliography is the <a href="#bibliographer">bibliographer</a>.  Bibliographies are <a href="#index">index</a>ed by subject in <b><em>Bibliographic Index: A Cumulative Bibliography of Bibliographies</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#hwwilson">H. W. Wilson</a>.  Compare with <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#discography">discography</a>, <a href="#filmography">filmography</a>, and <a href="#bsa">Bibliographical Society of America</a>.  
<p>
In the context of scholarly <a href="#publication">publication</a>, a list of references to <a href="#source">source</a>s <a href="#cite">cite</a>d in the <a href="#text">text</a> of an <a href="#article">article</a> or book, or suggested by the author for <a href="#furtherreading">further reading</a>, usually given at the end of the work.  <a href="#stylemanual">Style manual</a>s describing <a href="#citation">citation</a> format for the various <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s (<a href="#apastyle">APA</a>, <a href="#mlastyle">MLA</a>, etc.) are available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> and <a href="#online">online</a> via the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>.  
</p><p>
Also refers to the art and practice of describing books, with particular reference to their <a href="#authorship">authorship</a>, <a href="#publication">publication</a>, physical form, and literary <a href="#content">content</a>. <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#analyticalbibliog">analytical bibliography</a>, <a href="#annotatedbib">annotated bibliography</a>, <a href="#biobibliography">biobibliography</a>, <a href="#currentbib">current bibliography</a>, <a href="#nationalbib">national bibliography</a>, <a href="#periodbib">period bibliography</a>, <a href="#retrobib">retrospective bibliography</a>, and <a href="#selectivebibliography">selective bibliography</a>, 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biblioholism"><b>biblioholism</b></a>
</dt><dd>An addiction to <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#bookcollecting">book collecting</a>, a lesser affliction than <a href="#bibliomania">bibliomania</a>, but more intense than <a href="#bibliophile">bibliophily</a>.  A term coined by Tom Raabe which appears in the <a href="#title">title</a> of his book <b><em>Biblioholism:  The Literary Addiction</em></b> (Fulcrum Pub., 1991).  Raabe provides a 25-point quiz for self-diagnosis.    Compare with <a href="#bibliolatry">bibliolatry</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biblioklept"><b>biblioklept</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thief who steals <a href="#book">book</a>s.  A <em>bibliokleptomaniac</em> is a person suffering from a compulsion to steal books.  When <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s are targeted, biblioklepts are considered <a href="#problempatron">problem patron</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bibliomania">bibliomania</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliolatry"><b>bibliolatry</b></a>
</dt><dd>Excessive reverence for <a href="#book">book</a>s, carried to the point of emotional dependence on them.  A person who is an habitual <a href="#bookworm">bookworm</a> may be at risk of becoming a <em>bibliolater</em>.  Compare with <a href="#bibliophile">bibliophile</a> and <a href="#biblioholism">biblioholism</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to excessive devotion to a <a href="#literal">literal</a> interpretation of the <em>Bible</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliology"><b>bibliology</b></a>
</dt><dd>The historical and scientific study and description of <a href="#book">book</a>s as physical objects, from their origins in human society to the present, including <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> of the processes and materials (booklore) involved in making them.  Compare with <a href="#codicology">codicology</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliomancy"><b>bibliomancy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The art of divination through the use of <a href="#book">book</a>s or <a href="#verse">verse</a>s of the <em>Bible</em> or some other <a href="#sacredtext">sacred text</a>.  Also, the practice of opening the <em>Bible</em>, or a book of verses or <a href="#aphorism">aphorism</a>s such as the <em>I Ching</em>, without previously marking the <a href="#page">page</a>, to discover meaning or significance in the passage found.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliomania"><b>bibliomania</b></a>
</dt><dd>An obsession or mania for collecting and possessing <a href="#book">book</a>s, especially <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s and <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  In the <b><em>International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science</em></b> (Routledge: 1997), the origin of the term is attributed to Thomas Frognall Dibdin (1776-1845), a writer and <a href="#bibliographer">bibliographer</a> who helped establish <a href="#bookcollecting">book collecting</a> as a popular pursuit among English aristocracy of the 19th century.  
<p>
Some <em>bibliomaniacs</em> are driven by apparent obsession to become <a href="#biblioklept">biblioklept</a>s.
In a recent case, Stephen C. Blumberg was convicted on four felony
counts, sentenced to five years and eleven months in prison, and fined
$200,000 after a collection of 21,000 rare books was found in his home
in Iowa, stolen over a period of years from approximately 140 <a href="#library">libraries</a>
in the United States and Canada. The fact that Mr. Blumberg had a very
comfortable independent income from family trusts suggests that his
larceny was motivated by the desire to possess rather than profit from
his illegal activities. Compare with <a href="#bibliophile">bibliophile</a> and <a href="#biblioholism">biblioholism</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliometrics"><b>bibliometrics</b></a>
</dt><dd>The use of mathematical and statistical methods to study and identify patterns in the <a href="#usage">usage</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> and services within a <a href="#library">library</a>, or to analyze the historical development of a specific body of <a href="#literature">literature</a>, especially its <a href="#authorship">authorship</a>, <a href="#publication">publication</a>, and use.  Prior to the mid-20th century, the quantitative study of <a href="#bibliography">bibliographic</a> <a href="#data">data</a> and usage was known as <em>statistical bibliography</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#citationanalysis">citation analysis</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliopegy"><b>bibliopegy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The fine art of <a href="#bookbinding">binding</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s by hand, performed by a <em>bibliopegist</em> (bookbinder).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliophilately"><b>bibliophilately</b></a>
</dt><dd>The collection and study of <a href="#library">library</a>-related postage stamps, usually as a hobby (see "Bibliophilately Revisited" by Larry Nix in the February 2000 <a href="#issue">issue</a> of <em><a href="#americanlibraries">American Libraries</a></em>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliophile"><b>bibliophile</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who loves and treasures <a href="#book">book</a>s (especially their physical form), and is sufficiently knowledgeable to be able to distinguish <a href="#edition">edition</a>s by their characteristics and qualities.  Most bibliophiles are <a href="#bookcollecting">book collector</a>s.  The opposite of <a href="#bibliophobia">bibliophobe</a>.  Synonymous with <em>booklover</em> and <em>bibliophilist</em>.  Compare with <a href="#biblioholism">biblioholism</a> and <a href="#bibliomania">bibliomania</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliophilist"><b>bibliophilist</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bibliophile">bibliophile</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliophobia"><b>bibliophobia</b></a>
</dt><dd>An irrational fear or dread of <a href="#book">book</a>s, so intense that the afflicted person, known as a <em>bibliophobe</em>, avoids them whenever possible.  The opposite of <a href="#bibliophile">bibliophily</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliopole"><b>bibliopole</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>, especially one who deals in <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s and <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#antiquarian">antiquarian bookseller</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliotaph"><b>bibliotaph</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who hoards <a href="#book">book</a>s and hides them from others, even to the extent of keeping them under lock and key.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliotheca"><b>bibliotheca</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek <em>biblion</em> ("book") and <em>theke</em> ("to place").  A <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#book">book</a>s.  Also refers to a list or <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> of books, especially one prepared by a <a href="#bibliographer">bibliographer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bnfrance"><b>Bibliotheque nationale de France (BnF)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#nationallib">national library</a> of France, located in Paris.  The history of the <b>BnF</b> spans five centuries.  King Charles V ("The Wise") made the initial <a href="#gift">gift</a> of his <a href="#privatelib">private library</a> in 1368, but continuity in <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> did not begin until the reign of Louis XI (1461-1483).  Francis I established the legal <a href="#depository">depository</a> in 1537, and the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> was first <a href="#classification">classified</a>
in 1670 by Nicolas Clement. During the French Revolution, the royal
library was proclaimed a national library. After the rise of Napoleon
Bonparte in 1799, it became an imperial library until the Republic was
re-established in 1870. The creation of a Master <a href="#catalog">Catalog</a> of <a href="#printing">Printed</a> <a href="#book">Book</a>s was initiated in 1874 by Leopold Delisle, a medievalist who served as administrator general of the <a href="#library">library</a> from 1874 until 1905. 
<p>
In 1994, the Bibliotheque Nationale (BN) and the newly built Bibliotheque de France (BDF) merged to form a single entity, the <b>Bibliotheque nationale de France</b>,
one of the leading libraries in the world. The collections have been
brought together in two locations, the "Site Richelieu" and the "Site
Francois Mitterand." The latter welcomes both scholars (2,000 seats)
and the general public (1,700 seats). <a href="http://www.bnf.fr/site_bnf_eng/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>BnF</b>.  The <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> currently <a href="#host">host</a>s the <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> <em><a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/exhibits/bnf/bnf0001.html">Creating French Culture: Treasures from the Bibliotheque Nationale de France</a></em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bibliotherapy"><b>bibliotherapy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The use of <a href="#book">book</a>s selected on the basis of <a href="#content">content</a>
in a planned reading program designed to facilitate the recovery of
patients suffering from mental illness or emotional disturbance.
Ideally, the process occurs in three phases: personal identification of
the <a href="#reader">reader</a> with a particular <a href="#character">character</a> in the recommended <a href="#work">work</a>, resulting in psychological catharsis, which leads to rational insight concerning the <a href="#relevance">relevance</a> of the solution suggested in the <a href="#text">text</a> to the reader's own experience.  Assistance of a trained psychotherapist is advised.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#readersadvisory">readers' advisory</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biennial"><b>biennial</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d every two years.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> issued every two years.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#annual">annual</a>, <a href="#triennial">triennial</a>, <a href="#quadrennial">quadrennial</a>, <a href="#quinquennial">quinquennial</a>, <a href="#sexennial">sexennial</a>, <a href="#septennial">septennial</a>, and <a href="#decennial">decennial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bifolium"><b>bifolium</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a pair of <a href="#conjointleaves">conjoint leaves</a> (as opposed to a single <a href="#leaf">leaf</a>), forming four <a href="#page">page</a>s when folded.  Plural:  <em>bifolia</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bildungsroman"><b>Bildungsroman</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the German word <em>Bildung</em> (meaning education, culture) and the French word <em>roman</em> (novel).  A <a href="#novel">novel</a> in which the <a href="#author">author</a>
traces the maturation of the hero or heroine, from the subjectivity of
childhood and early adolescence through the development of objective
self-awareness (<em>examples</em>:  <b><em>The Magic Mountain</em></b> by Thomas Mann and <b><em>The Tin Drum</em></b> by Gunter Grass).  Compare with <a href="#kunstlerroman">Kuntslerroman</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bilingualedition"><b>bilingual edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in two <a href="#language">language</a>s, usually because both languages are spoken in the country in which the <a href="#work">work</a> was <a href="#publishing">published</a> (<em>example</em>:  English and French in Canada) or because the work was <a href="#copublishing">co-published</a> in countries with different national languages.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bill"><b>bill</b></a>
</dt><dd>A law proposed during a formal session of a legislative body.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, bills and <a href="#draft">draft</a>s of legislation are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under the <a href="#heading">heading</a> for the appropriate legislative body.
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>:
<dl><dt></dt><dd><b>A bill to give the consent of Congress to the
removal by the legislature of the State of Washington of the
restrictions upon the power of alienation of their lands by the
Puyallup Indians : 52d Congress, 1st session, S.2306</b>
</dd><dd><em><a href="#mainentry">Main entry</a> is under the heading for the Senate of the United States.</em></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
Also refers to a written statement of the amount owed for goods or
services rendered, sent by the seller to the purchaser in expectation
of prompt payment. In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, the term <a href="#invoice">invoice</a> is preferred.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="billed"><b>billed</b></a>
</dt><dd>A code used in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s and <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s to indicate the <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> unavailable due to loss or damage, for which a previous <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> has been charged an amount usually based on the cost of <a href="#replacement">replacement</a>.  Most libraries make an effort to replace <a href="#lost">lost</a> and <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> items, even if the <a href="#patron">patron</a> fails to pay the bill, provided <a href="#demand">demand</a> exists and a reasonably priced <a href="#edition">edition</a> is still <a href="#inprint">in print</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bimonthly"><b>bimonthly</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d in alternate months (six times per year).  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> issued every other month.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="binary"><b>binary</b></a>
</dt><dd>Literally, <em>two</em>.  <a href="#data">Data</a> used as <a href="#input">input</a> in a <a href="#digital">digital</a> computer must be <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> into code made up of the digits <b>0</b> and <b>1</b>, called <a href="#bit">bit</a>s.  <em>Binary code</em> is transmitted as a series of electrical pulses (<b>0</b> bits at low voltage and <b>1</b> bits at higher voltage), <a href="#storage">stored</a> as <a href="#memory">memory</a> cells.  When data <a href="#file">file</a>s in digital <a href="#format">format</a> are displayed as <a href="#output">output</a>, the binary signals are translated back into <a href="#character">character</a>s or images.  In <em>binary notation</em>, value is indicated by the position of the two digits:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>0 0 0 0</b> position
</dd><dd><b>8 4 2 1</b> value</dd></dl>
<p>
Thus the decimal number <b>15</b> is expressed in binary as <b>1111</b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ascii">ASCII</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bind"><b>bind</b></a>
</dt><dd>To fasten the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> together and enclose them in a protective <a href="#cover">cover</a>, a process known as <a href="#binding">binding</a>, originally done <a href="#handbinding">by hand</a>, but in modern book production, almost entirely by machine.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="binder"><b>binder</b></a>
</dt><dd>A removable <a href="#cover">cover</a> used for filing and storing <a href="#loose">loose</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, and <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s.  Commercially-made binders used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> to protect <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>s of <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s usually have a transparent front cover to facilitate <a href="#browse">browsing</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a person trained in the art and craft of <a href="#binding">binding</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, usually employed in a <a href="#bindery">bindery</a>.  Also used synonymously with <em>bindery</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#libbinder">library binder</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bindersboard"><b>binder's board</b></a>
</dt><dd>A stiff, sturdy <a href="#board">board</a> made from <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>ed fiber derived from rope, wood, or recycled <a href="#paper">paper</a>, used since the early 18th century to give rigidity to the <a href="#cover">cover</a>s of <a href="#book">book</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>, and preferred in <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a>.  Modern high-quality binder's board is single-<a href="#ply">ply</a>, made by pressing pulp between heavy rollers to achieve the desired thickness and smoothness.  Synonymous in the U.K. with <em>millboard</em>.  Compare with <a href="#pasteboard">pasteboard</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="binderstitle"><b>binder's title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> stamped or <a href="#lettered">lettered</a> on the <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#volume">volume</a> by the <a href="#binding">binder</a>, as distinct from the <a href="#covertitle">cover title</a> on the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#edition">edition</a> or the title <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  Compare with <a href="#sidetitle">side title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bindery"><b>bindery</b></a>
</dt><dd>An establishment that performs one or more of the various types of <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Some large <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s have an <a href="#inhouse">in-house</a> bindery usually associated with <a href="#centralizedproc">centralized</a> <a href="#technical">technical processing</a>.  In smaller libraries, <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in need of binding or <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a> (<a href="#backissue">back issue</a>s of <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, etc.) are sent to a commercial bindery.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#libbinder">library binder</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="binding"><b>binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>The outside covering on a <a href="#volume">volume</a> of <a href="#printing">printed</a> or <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>.  Books <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> are bound in <a href="#board">board</a>s covered in <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> or some other <a href="#durability">durable</a> material.  <a href="#leather">Leather</a> was used to bind <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and <a href="#incunabula">incunabula</a>, but is now used mainly in <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a>.  <a href="#book">Book</a>s bound in <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s are called <a href="#paperback">paperback</a>s.  Also refers to the <em>process</em> of fastening the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> or <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> together by <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> or <a href="#stitching">stitching</a>, or by applying <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> to the <a href="#back">back</a>, and then attaching a cover by hand or by machine under the supervision of a skilled <em>binder</em>.  In large <a href="#library">libraries</a>, binding may be done <a href="#inhouse">in-house</a>.  Smaller libraries usually send <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> to a commercial <a href="#bindery">bindery</a>.  In any case, most libraries follow an established <a href="#bindingpolicy">binding policy</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>bdg</em>.  
<p>
<b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive binding</a>, <a href="#antiquebinding">antique binding</a>,  <a href="#architecturalbinding">architectural binding</a>, <a href="#casebinding">case binding</a>, <a href="#cathedral">cathedral binding</a>, <a href="#cloisonne">cloisonne</a>, <a href="#conservationbinding">conservation binding</a>, <a href="#cottagebinding">cottage binding</a>, <a href="#custombinding">custom binding</a>, <a href="#easelbinding">easel binding</a>, <a href="#extendedbinding">extended binding</a>, <a href="#flexiblebinding">flexible binding</a>, <a href="#flushbinding">flush binding</a>, <a href="#imitationbinding">imitation binding</a>, <a href="#jewelledbinding">jewelled binding</a>, <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a>, <a href="#limpbinding">limp binding</a>, <a href="#mechanical">mechanical binding</a>, <a href="#papiermache">papier mache binding</a>, <a href="#prelibrary">prelibrary binding</a>, <a href="#publishersbinding">publisher's binding</a>, <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>, <a href="#reinforced">reinforced binding</a>, and <a href="#relievobinding">relievo binding</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bindingcopy"><b>binding copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A worn <a href="#book">book</a> in such poor <a href="#condition">condition</a> that it needs to be rebound, provided it is worth the expense of <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bindingedge"><b>binding edge</b></a>
</dt><dd>The edge at which the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> are attached to one another, usually by <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> the folded and <a href="#gathering">gathered</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s together and gluing them to a <a href="#lining">lining</a>, or by <a href="#trimming">trimming</a> away the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a> and applying strong <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> to the <a href="#loose">loose</a> leaves.  The three outer edges of a book are the <a href="#head">head</a>, <a href="#foot">foot</a> or tail, and <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a>.  Compare with <a href="#spine">spine</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bindingerror"><b>binding error</b></a>
</dt><dd>A mistake made in <a href="#binding">binding</a> a <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  Common errors include the incorrect folding of <a href="#signature">signature</a>s; <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> or an entire <a href="#section">section</a> omitted, <a href="#gathering">gathered</a> in incorrect sequence, or bound in upside down; application of the wrong <a href="#cover">cover</a> to the <a href="#body">body</a> of the <a href="#book">book</a>; etc.  Under most circumstances, the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> will replace such <a href="#copy">copies</a> at no charge.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#aberrantcopy">aberrant copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bindingmargin"><b>binding margin</b></a>
</dt><dd>The unprinted space between the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#page">page</a> and the area that bears <a href="#print">print</a>.  The width of the inner <a href="#margin">margin</a> often determines whether <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a> is possible.  Synonymous with <em>back</em>, <em>gutter</em>, and <em>inside margin</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bindingpolicy"><b>binding policy</b></a>
</dt><dd>Guidelines established by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> concerning the manner in which <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> not purchased in permanent <a href="#binding">binding</a> are to be bound.  <a href="#cataloging">Cataloged</a> <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>s are usually bound (except for <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> and <a href="#spiralbinding">spiral bound</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>), <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s may be placed in pamphlet covers, and <a href="#serial">serial</a>s permanently retained are usually bound unless converted <a href="#microform">microform</a>.  Large library systems sometimes have an <a href="#inhouse">in-house</a> <a href="#bindery">bindery</a>, but most small and medium-size libraries use a commercial bindery.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bindingslip"><b>binding slip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of written instructions sent by a <a href="#library">library</a> to the <a href="#bindery">bindery</a> with each <a href="#volume">volume</a> or <a href="#set">set</a> of volumes, giving the <a href="#specifications">specifications</a> by which the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is to be <a href="#binding">bound</a>.  A form in multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a> allows the library to maintain a <a href="#record">record</a> of the instructions given.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biobibliography"><b>biobibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of <a href="#work">work</a>s written by and about an <a href="#author">author</a>, including <a href="#biography">biographical</a> sources devoted to the author's life and work.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biogdictionary"><b>biographical dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single-<a href="#volume">volume</a> reference <a href="#work">work</a> or <a href="#set">set</a> of <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s containing <a href="#biography">biographical</a> <a href="#essay">essay</a>s about the lives of actual people, sometimes limited to <em>biographees</em> who are deceased.  Biographical dictionaries may be general (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Webster's Biographical Dictionary</em></b>), <a href="#subject">subject</a>-specific (<b><em>Biographical Dictionary of the History of Technology</em></b>), or limited to persons of a specific nationality (<b><em>American National Biography</em></b>), race (<b><em>Contemporary Black Biography</em></b>), <a href="#field">field</a> or profession (<b><em>International Dictionary of Anthropologists</em></b>), or period or gender (<b><em>Biographical Dictionary of Ancient Greek and Roman Women</em></b>).  Some are <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#serial">serial</a>ly (<b><em>Current Biography Yearbook</em></b>).  Compare with <a href="#collectivebiography">collective biography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biography"><b>biography</b></a>      
</dt><dd>A carefully <a href="#research">research</a>ed, relatively full <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> account of the life of a specific person or closely related group of people, written by another.  The <em>biographer</em> selects the most interesting and important events with the intention of elucidating the character and personality of the <em>biographee</em>, and placing the <a href="#subject">subject</a>'s life in social, cultural, and historical context.  
<p>
The literary form was pioneered by the Roman historians Plutarch,
Tacitus, and Suetonius. English literary biography began with James
Boswell's <b><em>Life of Samuel Johnson</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1791.  Modern biographers tend to be objective in approach, but <a href="#classics">classical</a> and medieval biographers often wrote to confirm a <a href="#thesis">thesis</a> or illustrate a moral principle.  An <a href="#authorizedbiog">authorized biography</a>, written with the consent and sometimes the cooperation of its subject, may be less critical than an <a href="#unauthorizedbiog">unauthorized biography</a>.  Biographical <a href="#work">work</a>s are <a href="#index">index</a>ed <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly in <b><em>Biography Index</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#hwwilson">H. W. Wilson</a> and in <b><em>Biography and Genealogy Master Index</em></b> published by the <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>.    
</p><p>
Also refers to the branch of <a href="#literature">literature</a> and history in which the lives of actual people are described and analyzed.  Compare with <a href="#autobiography">autobiography</a> and <a href="#memoirs">memoirs</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>biog</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#biobibliography">biobibliography</a>, <a href="#biogdictionary">biographical dictionary</a>, <a href="#collectivebiography">collective biography</a>, and <a href="#hagiography">hagiography</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bip1"><b><em>BIP</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#bip"><b>B</b>ooks <b>I</b>n <b>P</b>rint</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="birthdeath"><b>birth and death dates</b></a>
</dt><dd>The dates on which a person was born and died.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, birth and death dates are given immediately following the name in a <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#heading">heading</a>,
to distinguish the person from others of the same name. If the person
is still living, the birth date is given, followed by a <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a>, and the death date is added later.  If the birth or death date is unknown, the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> <em>c.</em> (<em><a href="#circa">circa</a></em>) is used before the estimated date to mean "approximately."  Birth and death dates are also included in the <a href="#entry">entries</a> in <a href="#biography">biographical</a> <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#falsedate">false date</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="birthday"><b>birthday book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#book">book</a> popular during the Victorian period in which a <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> from a <a href="#work">work</a> by a well-known writer (usually a poet) is given for each day of the year, with <a href="#blank">blank</a> space for <a href="#autograph">autograph</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bit"><b>bit</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#contraction">contraction</a> of <em><b>bi</b>nary digi<b>t</b></em>, either of the two values (0 and 1) used in the <a href="#binary">binary</a> number system and as the smallest unit of <a href="#storage">storage</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> computers.  In <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a>s, <a href="#data">data</a> is stored and processed in 8-bit units called <a href="#byte">byte</a>s.  In <a href="#ascii">ASCII</a> code, each <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a> <a href="#character">character</a> is represented by a unique sequence of seven bits.  Although bits are used to measure digital transmission speed (<em>bit rate</em>), the capacity of <a href="#storage">storage</a> (<a href="#disk">disk</a>s, <a href="#file">file</a>s, <a href="#database">database</a>s, etc.) is measured in bytes. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bitmap"><b>bitmap</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#digital">digital</a> representation composed of dots arranged in rows and columns, each represented by a single <a href="#bit">bit</a> of <a href="#data">data</a> that determines the value of a <a href="#pixel">pixel</a> in a monochrome image on a computer screen.  In a gray scale or color image, each dot is composed of a <a href="#set">set</a> of bits that determine the individual values of a group of pixels which <em>in combination</em>
create the visual impression of a specific shade or hue. The greater
the number of bits per dot, the wider the range of possible shades or
hues. <p>
The number of dots per square inch (density) determines the <a href="#resolution">resolution</a>
of a bitmapped image. Resolution may also be expressed as the number of
rows multiplied by the number of columns in the map. When <a href="#document">document</a>s are <a href="#scanner">scanned</a> into a computer, the image on the <a href="#page">page</a> is automatically <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> into a bitmapped image that can be viewed on a <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>.  Also spelled <em>bit map</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#digitalimaging">digital imaging</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="biweekly"><b>biweekly</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d twice each month.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> issued twice a month.  Synonymous with <a href="#semimonthly">semimonthly</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bcala"><b>Black Caucus of the American Library Association (BCALA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1970, <b>BCALA</b> has a membership of black <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and black persons interested in promoting <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a> and encouraging active participation by African-Americans in <a href="#libassociation">library association</a>s and at all levels of the profession.  <b>BCALA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <em>BCALA Newsletter</em>.  <a href="http://www.bcala.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>BCALA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blackface"><b>black face</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#boldface">boldface</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blackletter"><b>black letter</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#gothic">gothic</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blackwell"><b>Blackwell</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial company that supplies <a href="#book">book</a>s and bibliographic support products and systems to <a href="#academiclib">academic</a>, <a href="#researchlib">research</a>, and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> worldwide.  <a href="http://www.blackwell.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Blackwell</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blank"><b>blank</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> intentionally left unprinted in a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually preceding the <a href="#halftitle">half-title</a> and/or following the <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>.  Also refers to any <a href="#page">page</a> or <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> (or other writing surface) that does not bear written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a>.  Compare with <a href="#whitespace">white space</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blankbook"><b>blankbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> consisting of clean or <a href="#rule">rule</a>d <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> for writing or making entries, with <a href="#printing">printing</a> limited to <a href="#page">page</a> <a href="#heading">heading</a>s and/or divisions.  Examples include <a href="#diary">diaries</a>, <a href="#album">album</a>s, <a href="#scrapbook">scrapbook</a>s, account books, exercise books, etc.  Because the <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#record">record</a>ed in official blankbooks may be of permanent value, good quality <a href="#paper">paper</a> and <a href="#durability">durable</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>s are commonly used.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blanketorder"><b>blanket order</b></a>
</dt><dd>An agreement in which a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#dealer">dealer</a> supplies to a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> one <a href="#copy">copy</a> of each <a href="#title">title</a> as <a href="#issue">issue</a>d, on the basis of a <a href="#profile">profile</a> established in advance by the purchaser.  Blanket order plans are used mainly by large <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> to reduce the amount of time required for <a href="#selection">selection</a> and <a href="#acquisitions">acquisition</a>, and to speed the process of getting new titles into <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>.  Unlike <a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a>s, most blanket order plans do not allow <a href="#returns">returns</a>.  One of the best-known examples in the United States is the <a href="#greenawayplan">Greenaway Plan</a>.  Synonymous with <em>gathering plan</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#booklease">book lease plan</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blanking"><b>blanking</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, the application of a heated <a href="#blocking">brass stamp</a> to the <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> to create a glossy impression to serve as a base for <a href="#lettering">lettering</a> or for a stamped decoration. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bleed"><b>bleed</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, to run an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> off the <a href="#trimmed">trimmed</a> edge of the <a href="#page">page</a> without leaving space for a <a href="#margin">margin</a>.
A page can bleed in more than one direction depending on how many edges
are touched by the image printed on it. Also refers to <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#cropped">cropped</a> too closely in <a href="#binding">binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blind"><b>blind</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a procedure done without further embellishment, for example, <a href="#tooling">tooling</a> stamped on a <a href="#leatherbound">leather binding</a> without the addition of <a href="#ink">ink</a> or <a href="#goldleaf">gold leaf</a> to highlight the design.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#blindpage">blind page</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a person whose vision is severely <a href="#visuallyimpaired">impaired</a>, eligible to receive <a href="#library">library</a> services through the <a href="#nls">National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped (NLS)</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blindfolio"><b>blind folio</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> in a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#book">book</a>, included in the <a href="#foliation">foliation</a> but not given a <a href="#folio">folio</a> number.  Compare with <a href="#blindpage">blind page</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blindpage"><b>blind page</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually the <a href="#halftitle">half-title</a>, <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, <a href="#dedication">dedication</a>, or a <a href="#blank">blank</a> page, included in the <a href="#pagination">pagination</a> but not given a <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>.  Compare with <a href="#blindfolio">blind folio</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blindreference"><b>blind reference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a> in an <a href="#index">index</a> or <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, directing the <a href="#reader">reader</a> to a <a href="#heading">heading</a> that does <em>not</em> exist in the same index or catalog. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blockbook"><b>block book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#book">book</a> containing <a href="#text">text</a> alone, or text with <a href="#picture">picture</a>s, <a href="#printing">printed</a> entirely from <a href="#woodcut">woodcut</a>s on only one side of each <a href="#leaf">leaf</a>.  Block books originated in Europe during the 15th century at the same time as printing from <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a> and may have been an inexpensive alternative to books produced on a <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a>.  The best known example is the <em><a href="#bibliapaup">Biblia Pauperum</a></em> (<em>Bible of the Poor</em>) printed in large quantities during the second half of the 15th century.  Fewer than two dozen <a href="#copy">copies</a> are known to have survived.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#xylography">xylography</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blockbuster"><b>blockbuster</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#slang">slang</a> <a href="#term">term</a> for a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> for which the sale of a very large <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#copy">copies</a> is virtually guaranteed, usually due to the reputation or popularity of the <a href="#author">author</a> (Mary Higgins Clark, Stephen King, Danielle Steel, etc.).  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> often order such <a href="#title">title</a>s in multiple copies to satisfy initial <a href="#demand">demand</a>.  Also refers to the willingness of <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s to repeatedly sign such authors and promote their <a href="#work">work</a>s, sometimes to the neglect of writers of lesser fame whose works deserve to be read.  Synonymous with <em>megabook</em>.  Compare with <a href="#bestseller">bestseller</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blocked"><b>blocked</b></a>
</dt><dd>The status of the <a href="#borroweraccount">borrower account</a> of a <a href="#patron">patron</a> who is barred from <a href="#checkedout">checking out</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> from the <a href="#library">library</a>, usually because <a href="#fines">fines</a> for <a href="#overdue">overdue</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s remain unpaid.  Most electronic <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s are designed to automatically block a <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a> under conditions prescribed by the library.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blocking"><b>blocking</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of impressing <a href="#letter">letter</a>s or a decorative design on the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> in <a href="#ink">ink</a>, metal foil/<a href="#goldleaf">leaf</a>, or <a href="#blind">blind</a>, using an <a href="#engraving">engraved</a> <a href="#plate">plate</a> called a <em>brass</em> (binder's die) mounted on a <em>blocking press</em>.  Synonymous in the U.S. with <em>stamping</em>.
<p>
Also refers to the tendency of the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>
to stick together, forming a solid block after they have been exposed
to water, a problem that can be mitigated by standing the wet <a href="#bibitem">item</a> on end with the leaves fanned open to allow them to air dry.  Leaves of <a href="#coated">coated</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> can be difficult to separate without damaging the <a href="#printing">printed</a> surface, especially after drying has commenced.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blockletter"><b>block letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#letter">letter</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> in a <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> that has strokes of equal width and <a href="#boldface">boldness</a>, straight and without <a href="#serif">serif</a>s, a style used for <a href="#legibility">legibility</a> in <a href="#headline">headline</a>s, but considered less legible for printing <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a>.  Synonymous with <em>sans-serif</em>.  Compare with <a href="#monoline">monoline</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blockquotation"><b>block quotation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blowback"><b>blowback</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#hardcopy">hard copy</a> <a href="#enlargement">enlargement</a> of an image on <a href="#microform">microform</a>.  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> provide <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a> machines for enlarging and making <a href="#copy">copies</a> of <a href="#document">document</a>s available on <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> or <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>.  Also spelled <em>blow back</em>.  Compare with <a href="#blowup">blowup</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blowup"><b>blowup</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>y, an <a href="#enlargement">enlargement</a> usually made from a copy <a href="#negative">negative</a> taken of a smaller <a href="#print">print</a> (the procedure is demonstrated in the 1966 <a href="#featurefilm">feature film</a> "Blowup" <a href="#director">directed</a> by Michelangelo Antonioni).  In <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>, any <a href="#copy">copy</a> made on a <a href="#scale">scale</a> larger than the <a href="#original">original</a>.  In the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, a greatly enlarged image of a <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, or <a href="#specimenpage">specimen page</a>, used in marketing.  Also spelled <em>blow up</em>.  Compare with <a href="#blowback">blowback</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bluebook"><b>blue book</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the United States, the popular name for a <a href="#manual">manual</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by a state government, listing the names of elected and appointed officials and providing <a href="#information">information</a> about government structure, <a href="#govtagency">agencies</a>, voting districts, elections, etc., usually <a href="#binding">bound</a> in blue <a href="#cover">cover</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#redbook">red book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bluepencil"><b>blue pencil</b></a>
</dt><dd>To mark corrections in a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#typescript">typescript</a> during the <a href="#editing">editing</a> process, derived from the color of pencil traditionally used by <a href="#editor">editor</a>s.  The term has also been applied to the editing of <a href="#text">text</a> by a <a href="#censorship">censor</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blueprint"><b>blueprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic <a href="#copy">copy</a> of the detailed plans for constructing a building or other structure, originally <a href="#printing">printed</a> in white against a blue ground.  Blueprints are usually produced in <a href="#set">set</a>s, one for each floor for each phase of construction (plumbing, electrical, HVAC, etc.).  They are <a href="#libcollec">collected</a> by <a href="#architecturelib">architecture libraries</a> and by <a href="#archives">archives</a> and <a href="#specialcollections">special collection</a>s for construction projects of historical significance.  Blueprints are used by <a href="#library">libraries</a> in planning and overseeing the <a href="#renovation">renovation</a>, <a href="#expansion">expansion</a>, and <a href="#newconstruc">new construction</a> of facilities.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#architecturaldrawing">architectural drawing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="blurb"><b>blurb</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s description and recommendation of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the front <a href="#flap">flap</a> of the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>, portions of which may be used in advertisements <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> <a href="#tradejournal">journal</a>s and <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>s, and in the <a href="#publisherscatalog">publisher's catalog</a>.  Brief <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>s from favorable <a href="#review">review</a>s are usually printed on the back of the dust jacket.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#puff">puff</a> and <a href="#teaser">teaser</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bnf"><b>BnF</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bnfrance"><b>B</b>ibliotheque <b>n</b>ationale de <b>F</b>rance</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bo"><b>BO</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#backorder"><b>b</b>ack <b>o</b>rder</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="board"><b>board</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general term for the sheet of rigid material forming one side of the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> bound in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>.  In early <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, wood was used for this purpose (usually seasoned oak), but by the 15th century <a href="#pasteboard">pasteboard</a> had been introduced.  In modern <a href="#binding">binding</a>s, the cover is usually made of <a href="#bindersboard">binder's board</a> or of <a href="#strawboard">strawboard</a>, <a href="#chipboard">chip board</a>, or <a href="#pasteboard">pasteboard</a> in less expensive <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, all made from various fibrous materials, <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>ed or laminated and then pressed into large flat <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s cut to size in <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  The lay term is <em>cardboard</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fiberboard">fiberboard</a> and <a href="#pressboard">pressboard</a>.
<p>
In computers, the flat piece of plastic or fiberglass designed to hold <a href="#chip">microchip</a>s and other computer <a href="#hardware">hardware</a>.  The main circuit board in most systems is called the <em>motherboard</em> and all the component chips that plug into the main board are called <em>cards</em> or <em>boards</em>. 
</p><p>
Also refers to a group of prominent persons, elected or appointed to serve as <a href="#librarytrustee">trustee</a>s responsible for overseeing the policies and major management decisions of an organization or institution, such as a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#editorialboard">editorial board</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="boardbook"><b>board book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#durability">durable</a> <a href="#book">book</a> of small size designed for very young children, consisting of a few unnumbered <a href="#page">page</a>s made of <a href="#pasteboard">pasteboard</a> covered in <a href="#glossy">glossy</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> with colorful <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s and little if any <a href="#text">text</a>.  Board books are often <a href="#alphabetbook">alphabet book</a>s or <a href="#countingbook">counting book</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bodleian"><b>Bodleian Library</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#library">library</a> of Oxford University in
England. The original medieval library was severely damaged in 1542,
then refounded in 1598 by Sir Thomas Bodley, a former diplomat. Its
combination of buildings, constructed between 1490 and 1970, and its
vast <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> make it unique among the world's great libraries.  Its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s are particularly strong in English <a href="#literature">literature</a>, history, and <a href="#typography">typography</a>.  The Bodleian has been a <a href="#copyrightdepository">copyright depository</a> library since 1662.  <a href="http://www.bodley.ox.ac.uk/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the Bodleian Library.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#britishlib">British Library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="body"><b>body</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the main portion of a <a href="#book">book</a>, beginning with the first <a href="#page">page</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a> and including any <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s and <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, but excluding the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> and <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>.  In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the <a href="#bookblock">block</a> of <a href="#section">section</a>s <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> or glued together in preparation for attachment to the <a href="#case">case</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  
<p>
In an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> message, the <a href="#text">text</a> of the message, as opposed to the <a href="#header">header</a> (<a href="#emailaddress">e-mail address</a> of sender, address(es) of recipient(s), <a href="#subject">subject</a> of message) and any <a href="#footer">footer</a>.
</p><p>
In <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a>, the small rectangular unit of cast metal bearing a single raised <a href="#character">character</a> on one end (the <a href="#face">face</a>) from which an <a href="#impression">impression</a> is taken in <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a> <a href="#printing">printing</a>.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>shank</em>.
</p><p>
Also refers to a group of people with an official function.  <a href="#library">Library</a> <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s recognize:  <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a>, <a href="#relatedbody">related body</a>, or <a href="#subordinatebody">subordinate body</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bodymatter"><b>body matter</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> to be <a href="#printing">printed</a>, as distinct from any <a href="#displaymatter">display matter</a> (<a href="#heading">heading</a>s, <a href="#printersornament">ornament</a>s, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bodytype"><b>body type</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#texttype">text type</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bold"><b>bold</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#boldface">boldface</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="boldface"><b>boldface</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> conspicuous for being <b>thicker</b> and <b>darker</b> but not larger than the medium <a href="#weight">weight</a> <a href="#type">type</a> of the same <a href="#font">font</a>, used mainly for contrast or emphasis, and for <a href="#heading">heading</a>s.  The words <em>thicker</em> and <em>darker</em> in the preceding sentence are in boldface.  Variations include <em>semi-bold</em>, <em>extra-bold</em>, and <em>ultra-bold</em>.  Also spelled <em>bold face</em>.  Synonymous with <em>bold</em> and <em>black face</em>.  Compare with <a href="#lightface">lightface</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bolt"><b>bolt</b></a>
</dt><dd>The folded edge of a single <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> at the <a href="#head">head</a>, <a href="#tail">tail</a>, or <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of the <a href="#bookblock">block</a> in an <a href="#uncut">uncut</a> or unopened <a href="#book">book</a>, known respectively as the <em>head-bolt</em>, <em>tail-bolt</em>, or <em>fore-edge bolt</em>.  In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, the fourth edge, called the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a>, is <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> and glued to the other folded and <a href="#gathering">gathered</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s to form the <a href="#back">back</a> of a book.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bondmeasure"><b>bond measure</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#librarybond">library bond</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="book"><b>book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A collection of <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>, cloth, or other material (written, <a href="#printing">printed</a>, or <a href="#blank">blank</a>) fastened together along one edge, with or without a protective <a href="#case">case</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  Also refers to a literary <a href="#work">work</a> or one of its <a href="#volume">volume</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>.
<p>
To qualify for the special parcel post rate known in the United States as <a href="#mediarate">media rate</a>, a <a href="#publication">publication</a> must consist of 24 or more <a href="#page">page</a>s, at least 22 of which bear <a href="#printing">printing</a> consisting primarily of reading material or scholarly <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, with advertising limited to <a href="#bookannouncement">book announcement</a>s.  UNESCO defines a book as a non<a href="#periodical">periodical</a> literary publication consisting of 49 or more pages, covers excluded.  The <a href="#ansi">ANSI</a> <a href="#standards">standard</a> includes publications of less than 49 pages which have <a href="#hardcover">hard cover</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#artbook">art book</a>, <a href="#boardbook">board book</a>, <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>, <a href="#coffee">coffee table book</a>, <a href="#giftbook">gift book</a>, <a href="#licensedbook">licensed book</a>, <a href="#managedbook">managed book</a>, <a href="#newbook">new book</a>, <a href="#packagedbook">packaged book</a>, <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>, <a href="#premiumbook">premium book</a>, <a href="#professionalbook">professional book</a>, <a href="#promobook">promotional book</a>, <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>, <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>, <a href="#religiousbook">religious book</a>, and <a href="#reprintbook">reprint book</a>.
</p><p>
Also, a major division of a longer <a href="#work">work</a> (usually of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>) which is further subdivided into <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>s.  Usually <a href="#number">number</a>ed, such a division may or may not have its own <a href="#title">title</a>.  Also refers to one of the divisions of the Christian <b><em>Bible</em></b>, the first being <em>Genesis</em>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookannouncement"><b>book announcement</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief statement by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> announcing the availability of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> or <a href="#backlist">backlist</a>ed <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#publishing">published</a> as an advertisement in <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> <a href="#tradejournal">journal</a> or <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>, or in an advertising section included in another <a href="#book">book</a> published under the same <a href="#imprint">imprint</a>.  A book announcement usually includes the title of the <a href="#work">work</a>, the name of the <a href="#author">author</a>(s) or <a href="#editor">editor</a>(s), <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>, projected <a href="#publicationdate">date of publication</a>, <a href="#listprice">list price</a>, and <a href="#prepubprice">prepublication price</a> if offered.  It may also include a <a href="#blurb">blurb</a> or brief <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>s from favorable <a href="#review">review</a>s, and a <a href="#picture">picture</a> of the front <a href="#cover">cover</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookart"><b>book art</b></a>
</dt><dd>The form of art expressed through the <a href="#medium">medium</a> of the <a href="#book">book</a>.  The artist's input extends beyond <a href="#authorship">authorship</a> and <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, making the physical appearance of the book as an object a manifestation of creativity in and of itself.  In some <a href="#artbook">art book</a>s, the traditional <a href="#format">format</a> of the book is not altered (<em>example</em>:  an illustrated <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#poetry">poems</a> in which the words and images are <a href="#embossed">embossed</a> rather than <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#page">page</a>s).  In other <a href="#work">work</a>s, the artist experiments with format, even to the extent of challenging the concept of reading (<em>example</em>:  a book with the <a href="#cover">cover</a>s and <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> consisting entirely of double-sided mirrors).  Some <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s specialize in this art form (Ron King's Circle Press).  The <a href="http://www.nal.vam.ac.uk/">National Art Library</a> at the Victoria and Albert Museum of decorative and applied arts in London <a href="#holdings">holds</a> an extensive <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of books on the history of this form of artistic experimentation.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookarts"><b>book arts</b></a>
</dt><dd>The skills and techniques used in creating <a href="#finebook">fine book</a>s and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, including <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, <a href="#illuminated">illumination</a> and <a href="#rubric">rubric</a>ation, <a href="#typography">typography</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, <a href="#printing">printing</a>, and <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>.  <a href="http://www.yahoo.com/Arts/Design_Arts/Book_Arts/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of <a href="#website">Web site</a>s related to the <a href="#book">book</a> arts.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cba">Center for Book Arts</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookauction"><b>book auction</b></a>
</dt><dd>A public or private sale at which <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s and <a href="#usedbook">used book</a>s are sold to the highest bidder, usually on commission.  A firm specializing in such sales is known as a <em>book auction house</em>.  Extremely <a href="#rarity">rare</a> and valuable <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s are usually sold by international auction houses such as <a href="http://www.christies.com/">Christie's</a> and <a href="http://www.sothebys.com/">Sotheby's</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookaward"><b>book award</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookband"><b>book band</b></a>
</dt><dd>A strip of <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> (usually colored) placed around the <a href="#dustjacket">jacketed</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> to call attention to a special characteristic, such as availability at a reduced price, receipt of an <a href="#literaryaward">award</a>, or special <a href="#loanstatus">loan status</a> (<a href="#reserves">reserve</a> or <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookbin"><b>bookbin</b></a>
</dt><dd>A wheeled box for transporting <a href="#book">book</a>s, sometimes with a bottom equipped with a spring mechanism to allow the space inside to fill gradually as books and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> are returned to a <a href="#bookdrop">book drop</a> built into the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> or wall of a <a href="#library">library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookbinding"><b>bookbinding</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of fastening the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> together and enclosing them in a protective <a href="#cover">cover</a>, formerly done by <a href="#handbinding">hand</a> but now largely mechanized.  <a href="http://www.cs.uiowa.edu/%7Ejones/book/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#website">Web site</a> <em>Bookbinding, A Tutorial</em> maintained by Douglas W. Jones.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#casebinding">case binding</a> and <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookblock"><b>book block</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> or <a href="#gluingoff">glued</a> together, plus the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s and any other materials added by the <a href="#binder">binder</a>, before the <a href="#cover">cover</a> is applied.  Compare with <a href="#textblock">text block</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookburning"><b>book burning</b></a>
</dt><dd>The intentional destruction by fire of <a href="#book">book</a>s considered objectionable or dangerous, usually by a religious or secular authority, as in the mass burning of book considered <a href="#politcorrect">politically incorrect</a> by the Nazi Party in pre-World War II Germany, or by a mob, usually in the frenzy of political revolt.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#censorship">censorship</a> and <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookcard"><b>book card</b></a>
</dt><dd>A piece of stiff card stock of <a href="#standard">standard</a> size (three inches wide and five inches high), with space at the top for the <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>, name of <a href="#author">author</a>, and <a href="#title">title</a> of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, and <a href="#blank">blank</a> lines below for recording the <a href="#duedate">due date</a> and the <a href="#librarycard">library card</a> number or name of the <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>, used in manual <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s to maintain a card <a href="#file">file</a> of items currently <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>.  The book card is reinserted in the <a href="#bookpocket">book pocket</a> inside each item at check-in.  Some libraries use color-coded book cards to indicate type of material or applicable <a href="#loanrule">loan rule</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#datedueslip">date due slip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookcase"><b>bookcase</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of two or more single- or double-sided shelves in a rigid frame, used to store <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>s, and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, bookcases are usually made of wood or metal with <a href="#fixedshelving">fixed</a> or adjustable shelves.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="book catalog"><b>book catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> in the form of a <a href="#binding">bound</a> or <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> <a href="#book">book</a>, whether handwritten, <a href="#printing">printed</a>, or computer-generated, practical only for small <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookcloth"><b>book cloth</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookclub"><b>book club</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial company that sells <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s and <a href="#backlist">backlist</a>ed <a href="#title">title</a>s by mail to <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s who agree to purchase a minimum number of titles per year at <a href="#discount">discount</a>
prices, usually from main, alternate, or special selections offered on
a monthly basis which may be rejected or returned by the subscriber. To
attract new subscribers, an <a href="#introductoryoffer">introductory offer</a>
of free or heavily discounted titles may be offered in exchange for a
minimum purchase commitment. Some book clubs offer books of general
interest, others <a href="#specialization">specialize</a> by <a href="#genre">genre</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#mystery">mystery</a>), <a href="#subject">subject</a> (gardening), or academic <a href="#field">field</a> or <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> (history).  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> for book clubs is available in <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>, a <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> available in most <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#bookclubedition">book club edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookclubedition"><b>book club edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> offered for sale mail-order by a <a href="#bookclub">book club</a>.  <a href="#copy">Copies</a> may be purchased by the club from the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s stock (usually at a <a href="#discount">discount</a>) or specially <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>ed for club distribution.  An edition produced solely for distribution to book club <a href="#subscription">subscriber</a>s can usually be distinguished from the <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a> of the same <a href="#title">title</a> by the inferior quality of the <a href="#paper">paper</a> and <a href="#binding">binding</a>, and by the absence of a <a href="#listprice">price</a> on the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>bc</em> or <em>bce</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookcollecting"><b>book collecting</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of acquiring a collection of <a href="#book">book</a>s based on their <a href="#content">content</a>, history, antiquity, <a href="#rarity">rarity</a>,
beauty, monetary value, or other characteristics. A person who
systematically acquires books for the pleasure of owning them, as an
investment, or with the intention of bequeathing them to a <a href="#library">library</a> or other institution is known as a <em>book collector</em>.  <a href="http://www.rarebooks.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the International Book Collector's Association (IBCA).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bibliomania">bibliomania</a>, <a href="#bibliophile">bibliophile</a>, and <a href="#privatelib">private library</a>.
<p>
For a brief but fascinating <a href="#essay">essay</a> on the history of book collecting, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> for the <a href="#term">term</a> in <b><em>A Dictionary of Book History</em></b> by John Feather (Oxford University Press: 1986).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookcontract"><b>book contract</b></a>
</dt><dd>A legally binding written agreement between a writer and <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> in which the <a href="#author">author</a> grants the publisher the <a href="#rights">rights</a> to a specific <a href="#work">work</a> in exchange for compensation (usually <a href="#royalties">royalties</a> as a percentage of net sales on <a href="#copy">copies</a> sold) and a commitment to <a href="#publishing">publish</a> the work in specified form within a designated period of time.  Synonymous with <a href="#publishersagreement">publisher's agreement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookcradle"><b>book cradle</b></a>
</dt><dd>A low stand or rack, made of wood, metal, or plastic, designed to display an open <a href="#book">book</a>, usually as part of an <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookculture"><b>book culture</b></a>
</dt><dd>The habits, skills, institutions, etc., of a given people concerning <a href="#book">book</a>s in all forms, including their manufacture (<a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, <a href="#printing">printing</a>, and <a href="#binding">binding</a>), marketing and promotion, <a href="#bookseller">bookselling</a> and <a href="#bookcollecting">collecting</a>, <a href="#bookclub">book club</a>s and <a href="#readinggroup">reading group</a>s, <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> and <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>, activities of <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#archives">archives</a>, and the writing, <a href="#illustration">illustrating</a>, <a href="#review">review</a>ing,
and reading of books. In the United States, the persistence of book
culture is evident in the presence of small cafes intended for <a href="#reader">reader</a>s on the premises of large <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s, and in the success of companies that manufacture and sell giftware, decorative items, and accessories for readers.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookdrop"><b>book drop</b></a>
</dt><dd>A slot, chute, bin, or box to which <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s borrowed from a <a href="#library">library</a> may be returned, especially during <a href="#libraryhours">hours</a> when the facility is closed.  Book drops may be free-standing (usually outside the walls of the library) or built into the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> or an exterior wall.  <a href="#security">Security</a>
is an important consideration in the design of an after-hours book
drop. Libraries have suffered damage from hazardous materials deposited
in book drops by malicious persons.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookend"><b>bookend</b></a>
</dt><dd>An L- or inverted T-shaped movable piece of wood, metal, tough plastic, or other rigid material, placed at the end of a row of <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>s,
etc., to keep them upright on a shelf. Bookends manufactured as gift
items may be covered in leather, carved in wood or fine stone, or cast
in metal and given a decorative finish. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bea"><b>BookExpo America (BEA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The largest <a href="#bookfair">book fair</a> in the United States, <b>BEA</b> is an exhibition of <a href="#book">book</a>s in all <a href="#format">format</a>s (plus retail <a href="#multimedia">multimedia</a>), a forum for educating persons involved in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, and a center for negotiating <a href="#copyright">rights</a> to intellectual property.  Formerly known as the <em>ABA Convention and Trade Exhibit</em>, <b>BEA</b> is held in a different city in the United States each year.  <a href="http://www.bookexpoamerica.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>BEA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookfair"><b>book fair</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#booktrade">trade</a> <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ion, usually held <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly, at which <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s and <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>s display their products in spaces called <em>booths</em> leased for that purpose.  The first international book fair was held in France at Lyon during the late medieval period.  The <a href="#frankfurt">Frankfurt Book Fair</a> began in the 1490s and is still the chief market place for publishers who wish to sell <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>s, <a href="#translation">translation</a> <a href="#rights">rights</a>, and other privileges to overseas buyers.
