Also refers to a non-trade exhibition of books and the <a href="#bookarts">book arts</a>, which may include presentations by <a href="#author">author</a>s, <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>s, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, <a href="#binder">binder</a>s, etc.  <a href="http://www.lights.com/publisher/bookfairs.html">Click here</a> to connect to a list of <a href="#link">link</a>s to book fair/festival <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>s maintained by Peter Scott of the University of Saskatchewan Library and <a href="http://www.yahoo.com/Arts/Humanities/Literature/Events/Books/Book_Fairs/">here</a> to connect to the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of book fairs.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bea">BookExpo America</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookformat"><b>book format</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#booksize">book size</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookhand"><b>book hand</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal style of handwriting used by <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>s to prepare <a href="#book">book</a>s before the invention of the <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a>, distinct from the <a href="#cursive">cursive</a> hand used for writing <a href="#letters">letters</a> and other informal <a href="#document">document</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#courthand">court hand</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#gothic">gothic</a> and <a href="#uncial">uncial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookhistory"><b>book history</b></a>
</dt><dd>The study of the origins and development of written <a href="#work">work</a>s, from the <a href="#cuneiform">cuneiform</a> <a href="#claytablet">clay tablet</a>s and <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a> <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>s of antiquity, through the <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and <a href="#incunabula">incunabula</a> of the Middle Ages, to modern <a href="#printing">printing</a> and <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>.  Synonymous with <em>history of the book</em>.  <a href="http://www.xs4all.nl/%7Eknops/timetab.html">Click here</a> to see an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#chronology">chronology</a> of <a href="#book">book</a> history.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#apha">American Printing History Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookish"><b>bookish</b></a>
</dt><dd>Pertaining to a <a href="#book">book</a>, or to books and
reading in general, usually in the literary sense. Also refers to a
person who is fond of reading books or excessively studious. As a term
of disparagement, any person whose <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> of life is acquired largely by reading books, rather than from actual experience.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookjacket"><b>book jacket</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booklabel"><b>book label</b></a>
</dt><dd>A card, strip, etc., smaller than a <a href="#bookplate">bookplate</a>, usually made of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, affixed to the inside of a <a href="#book">book</a>, in most cases to indicate <a href="#ownershipmark">ownership</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booklease"><b>book lease plan</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> plan offered by some <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>s which allows a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> to lease an agreed upon number of popular <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s, usually for a fixed monthly fee.  After a prescribed period of time, or a decline in <a href="#demand">demand</a>, titles are <a href="#returns">returned</a> for credit toward <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s usually selected from a monthly list provided by the jobber (<em>example</em>:  McNaughton Plan).  Because leased books arrive fully <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> and <a href="#technical">processed</a> for <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>, some <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> rely on leasing plans for high-demand items.  Leasing is also used in <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> with limited space for a permanent <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of popular fiction and nonfiction.  Synonymous with <em>rental plan</em>.  Compare with <a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a> and <a href="#blanketorder">blanket order</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booklet"><b>booklet</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booklice"><b>book lice</b></a>
</dt><dd>A species of minute (1/16-inch) soft-bodied, wingless insect (<em>Liposcelis divinatorius</em>) of worldwide distribution, which damages old <a href="#book">book</a>s by feeding on the <a href="#glue">glue</a> and <a href="#paste">paste</a> in their <a href="#binding">binding</a>s.
Book lice also consume mold, cereal products, and the bodies dead
insects, which makes them a menace to botanical and zoological museum <a href="#specimen">specimen</a>s.  Keeping relative <a href="#humidity">humidity</a> low helps to control them in <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> spaces.  Book lice also fall prey to <a href="#bookscorpion">book scorpion</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#bookworm">bookworm</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booklift"><b>book lift</b></a>
</dt><dd>A fixed mechanical device similar to a dumb waiter, designed for transporting <a href="#book">book</a>s from one floor or <a href="#stacks">stack</a> level to another in a <a href="#library">library</a>, without having to use a stairway or full-size elevator.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booklight"><b>book light</b></a>
</dt><dd>A very small electric light designed to attach, usually by means of a clip, to the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> for reading in a dark place (airplane seat, bed, tent, etc.) without disturbing others.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booklist"><b><em>Booklist</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> for <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> since 1905 by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b><em>Booklist</em></b> <a href="#review">review</a>s nearly 4,000 <a href="#book">book</a>s for <a href="#adult">adult</a>s in 22 <a href="#issue">issue</a>s per year, plus 2,500 <a href="#title">title</a>s for <a href="#childrensbook">children</a> and <a href="#youngadult">young adult</a>s, 1,000 <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> titles, and approximately 500 <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s and electronic resources in <em><a href="#rbb">Reference Books Bulletin</a></em>, a separate <a href="#section">section</a> at the end of each issue.  <b><em>Booklist</em></b> also includes <a href="#feature">feature</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#authorinterview">author interview</a>s, <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a>, and regular <a href="#column">column</a>s.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/booklist/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> version of <b><em>Booklist</em></b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em> and <em><a href="#choice">CHOICE</a></em>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bklist"><b>book list</b></a>
</dt><dd>A selected list of <a href="#book">book</a>s, usually on a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a> or in a particular <a href="#genre">genre</a>, arranged in some kind of order (by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>, theme, etc.), which may include brief descriptive <a href="#annotation">annotation</a>s, used mainly in <a href="#readersadvisory">readers' advisory</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booklouse"><b>book louse</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#booklice">book lice</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booklover"><b>booklover</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bibliophile">bibliophile</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookman"><b>bookman</b></a>
</dt><dd>A man in the business of <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, making, or selling <a href="#book">book</a>s.  Also, a man of literary or scholarly inclination who is familiar with books. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookmark"><b>bookmark</b></a>
</dt><dd>A narrow strip of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, leather, ribbon, or other thin, flexible material placed between the <a href="#page">page</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> to mark a place.  Hand-crafted decorative bookmarks are sometimes given as gifts.  In older and more expensive <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, a piece of narrow ribbon longer than the length of the pages is sometimes <a href="#glue">glue</a>d to the top of the <a href="#spine">spine</a> to serve as a bookmark.  A ribbon used in this way is called a <em>register</em>.
<p>
In computing, to mark a <a href="#document">document</a> or a specific location in a document for subsequent retrieval.  Most <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> <a href="#software">software</a> includes a "bookmark" <a href="#option">option</a> that allows an <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a> (<a href="#url">URL</a>) to be archived, enabling the user to revisit the <a href="#website">site</a> without having to retype the address or repeat the original <a href="#search">search</a> from scratch. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookmobile"><b>bookmobile</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large motorized van equipped with shelves to accommodate a small <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> and a desk for a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or <a href="#paraprofessional">paraprofessional</a> member of the <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a>, serving as a traveling <a href="#branchlibrary">branch library</a> in neighborhoods and communities too remote to be easily served by the nearest <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>.  Synonymous with <em>mobile library</em> (UK).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#rurallibrary">rural library</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booknumber"><b>book number</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portion of the <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> following the <a href="#class">class</a> <a href="#notation">notation</a>, added to identify a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a> within its class.  A book number is composed of an <a href="#authormark">author mark</a> appended by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> to subarrange <a href="#work">work</a>s of the same class by name of <a href="#author">author</a>, followed by a <a href="#workmark">work mark</a> added to subarrange works of the same author by <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#edition">edition</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>H5371m</b> in the <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal</a> <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> <b>993.101 H5371m</b> assigned to the title <b><em>The Maoris</em></b>, written by Charles Higham).  Synonymous with <em>book mark</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookofhours"><b>Book of Hours</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> of common prayers for the Catholic
laity, to be said at seven appointed hours in each day, introduced
during the 11th century in England and France, and used in Europe until
the 16th century. Some medieval examples are magnificently <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a>.  <a href="http://www.ibiblio.org/wm/rh/">Click here</a> to view <a href="#page">page</a>s from the <b><em>Les tres riches heures du Duc de Berry</em></b>, courtesy of the <b><em>WebMuseum</em></b> <a href="#website">site</a> maintained by The Louvre in Paris.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookontape"><b>book-on-tape</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> read aloud and recorded on <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a>, usually by a professional actor or <a href="#reader">reader</a>, or in some cases by the <a href="#author">author</a>.
Originally, books were produced on tape for the visually impaired, but
the market has expanded to include joggers and walkers who like to
listen as they exercise, individuals who must spend long hours in
travel, persons who are <a href="#literacy">illiterate</a> or dyslexic, and others who would rather listen than read.  Synonymous with <em>audiobook</em>, <em>recorded book</em>, <em>spoken audio</em>, and <em>talking book</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookpaper"><b>book paper</b></a>
</dt><dd>A grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a> suitable for <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, etc., as opposed to various other grades (<a href="#newsprint">newsprint</a>, tissue paper, wallpaper, wrapping paper, etc.).   Book papers vary in content, color, <a href="#finish">finish</a>, <a href="#opacity">opacity</a>, weight, and <a href="#permanence">permanence</a>.  For books which are to be retained indefinitely in the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s prefer <a href="#permanentpaper">permanent paper</a>s, <a href="#acidfree">acid-free</a> and of high <a href="#ragpaper">rag</a> content.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookplate"><b>bookplate</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#label">label</a> or similar device affixed to a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually on the inside of the front <a href="#cover">cover</a> or on the front <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>, providing a space to record the name of the owner.  Decorative bookplates are a category gift item sold <a href="#blank">blank</a> or with the name of the recipient custom-<a href="#printing">printed</a> in the space allowed for the name, sometimes following the Latin phrase <em><a href="#exlibris">ex libris</a></em>.  
<p>
The earliest known examples appeared in Germany a few years after the invention of <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>.
They often expressed gratitude to the donor from the person who
received the book as a gift (a practice still followed in some <a href="#library">libraries</a> that receive books as <a href="#gift">gift</a>s).
Bookplate design as an art form began with Albrecht Durer in the early
16th century. Heraldic bookplates usually bore a coat of arms and/or
family motto. Professional mottos and designs commemorating important
historical events were also popular, but the mottos on modern
bookplates usually praise books or scholarly pursuits. The <a href="#nypl">New York Public Library</a> and Yale University Library own substantial <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of historically significant bookplates.  Compare with <a href="#booklabel">book label</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookpocket"><b>book pocket</b></a>
</dt><dd>A three-inch wide strip of stiff <a href="#paper">paper</a> with a small pocket folded and glued across the bottom third of its height to hold a <a href="#bookcard">book card</a>, affixed to <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#holdings">held</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a> that does not have an automated <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>.  Available ungummed or with a self-<a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> back, plain or with a <a href="#datedueslip">date due slip</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the top, pockets are affixed to the inside <a href="#cover">cover</a> or <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a> in <a href="#book">book</a>s, or to some other part in <a href="#nonbook">nonbook</a> items.  To enable <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> to match card to item at check-in, the front of the pocket and the top of the corresponding card are marked with the <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>, name of <a href="#author">author</a>, and <a href="#title">title</a> of item. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookpress"><b>book press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A mechanical device consisting of two thick composite boards
with a long screw at each of the four corners, used like a sandwich to
apply pressure to a <a href="#book">book</a>, to ensure that <a href="#glue">glue</a>d or <a href="#paste">paste</a>d surfaces adhere properly in <a href="#binding">binding</a>, <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>, and <a href="#repairing">repairing</a>.
In heavy-duty models, the boards are positioned on a base between two
sturdy metal uprights to which a horizontal bar is attached, with a
single large screw for increasing the downward pressure of the bar.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookprize"><b>book prize</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookproposal"><b>book proposal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A plan for a prospective <a href="#book">book</a>, submitted by the <a href="#author">author</a> (or the author's <a href="#literaryagent">literary agent</a>) to a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> for consideration, sometimes at the publisher's invitation.  A book proposal usually includes:  tentative <a href="#title">title</a>, brief discussion of <a href="#scope">scope</a> and purpose of <a href="#work">work</a>, intended <a href="#audience">audience</a> and market, <a href="#outline">outline</a> or <a href="#summary">summary</a> of <a href="#content">content</a>, list of proposed <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>s or <a href="#entry">entries</a>, analysis of competing works, approximate length, form of <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, proposed schedule, and sometimes a sample of the <a href="#text">text</a>, accompanied by a <a href="#coverletter">cover letter</a>.  Book proposals are also used by academic faculty in applying for sabbatic leave.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bookcontract">book contract</a> and <a href="#rejectionslip">rejection slip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookrate"><b>book rate</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#mediarate">media rate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookrepair"><b>book repair</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#repairing">repairing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookrest"><b>bookrest</b></a>
</dt><dd>A portable device similar to the music rest on a piano, designed to be placed on a desk or table to hold a <a href="#book">book</a>
at an angle convenient for reading. Bookrests are also available in
metal for attachment to indoor exercise machines, and in the form of a
soft cushion for laptop use or bedtime reading.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookreturn"><b>book return</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#bookdrop">book drop</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookreview"><b>book review</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#review">review</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booksale"><b>book sale</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#library">Libraries</a> often dispose of <a href="#discard">discard</a>ed <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> and unused <a href="#gift">gift</a>s at an annual or ongoing public sale, sometimes organized by a <a href="#friends">Friends of the Library</a> group which uses the proceeds to benefit the library.  Library book sales are a good place to find <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s and bargains.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booksbymail"><b>books-by-mail</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#circulation">Circulation</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> via the postal system to registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s who request <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s by telephone or post, usually from a mail-order <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, a service provided by <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> serving rural areas and <a href="#homebound">homebound</a> <a href="#patron">patron</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#bookmobile">bookmobile</a> and <a href="#directdelivery">direct delivery</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookscorpion"><b>book scorpion</b></a>
</dt><dd>A species of small (1/8 to 1/4-inch) stingless arachnid (<em>Chelifer cancroides</em>), also known as the <em>false scorpion</em>, which diets on tiny insects such as <a href="#booklice">book lice</a> that damage <a href="#book">book</a>s by feeding on <a href="#paper">paper</a> and <a href="#binding">binding</a>s.
<p>

</p></dd><dt><a name="bookscout"><b>book scout</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person in the business of scouring obscure or remote <a href="#bookstore">bookshop</a>s, second-hand stores, and <a href="#booksale">book sale</a>s in search of <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#edition">edition</a>s desired by <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, private <a href="#bookcollecting">collector</a>s, and <a href="#antiquarian">antiquarian bookseller</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#scout">scout</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookseller"><b>bookseller</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person in the business of selling <a href="#book">book</a>s and related materials to the retail trade at the full <a href="#net">net</a> <a href="#publishedprice">published price</a>, especially one who owns a <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>.  Also refers to anyone in the business of selling <a href="#usedbook">used book</a>s.  In the United States, the <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a> of the bookselling industry is the <a href="#aba">American Booksellers Association</a> whose <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> <a href="http://www.bookweb.org/">BookWeb.org</a> includes a <a href="#searchable">searchable</a> <a href="http://www.bookweb.org/bookstores/">Bookstore Directory</a>.  <a href="#information">Information</a> about book retailers in the United States and Canada is also available in the <em><a href="#abtd">American Book Trade Directory</a></em>, <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.  Compare with <a href="#dealer">dealer</a> and <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookshop"><b>bookshop</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booksigning"><b>book signing</b></a>
</dt><dd>An event scheduled at a retail <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a> or <a href="#library">library</a> at which the <a href="#author">author</a> and/or <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a> of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> is available to <a href="#autograph">autograph</a> <a href="#copy">copies</a> of his or her <a href="#work">work</a>(s), sometimes scheduled in conjunction with a <a href="#booktalk">book talk</a> or a reading from the <a href="#text">text</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#autographedcopy">autographed copy</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bip"><b><em>Books in Print (BIP)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><em><b>B</b>ooks <b>I</b>n <b>P</b>rint</em>, a multi-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#set">set</a> in which <a href="#book">book</a>s <a href="#currency">currently</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> or <a href="#distributor">distributed</a> in the United States are listed by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, and <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  <a href="#entry">Entries</a> include <a href="#information">information</a> useful to <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s such as <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#listprice">price</a>, <a href="#edition">edition</a>, <a href="#binding">binding</a> type, and <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>.  Published <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, <b><em>BIP</em></b> includes a <a href="#directory">directory</a> of publishers in a separate volume.  It is <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>ed by <em><a href="#forthcomingbooks">Forthcoming Books</a></em>.  Bowker also publishes <em><a href="#cbip">Children's Books in Print</a></em> and <em><a href="#elhitextbooks">El-Hi Textbooks &amp; Serials in Print</a></em> on an annual basis.  In some <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <b><em>BIP</em></b> is available <a href="#online">online</a>.  <b><em>International Books in Print</em></b> is published by K. G. Saur and <a href="#distributor">distributed</a> in the United States by the <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booksize"><b>book size</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#height">height</a> and <a href="#width">width</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually measured in inches or centimeters from <a href="#head">head</a> to <a href="#tail">tail</a> and from <a href="#spine">spine</a> to <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of the <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  Historically, the size of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> book was determined by the <a href="#number">number</a> of times a full <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> measuring approximately 19 x 25 inches was folded, once to form <a href="#signature">signature</a>s of two <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> (four <a href="#page">page</a>s) known as <a href="#folio">folio</a>, twice to form four leaves (eight pages) known as <a href="#quarto">quarto</a>, three times to form eight leaves (sixteen pages) known as <a href="#octavo">octavo</a>, to form twelve leaves (twenty-four pages) known as <a href="#duodecimo">duodecimo</a>, four times to form sixteen leaves (thirty-two pages) known as <a href="#sextodecimo">sextodecimo</a>, etc.  
<p>
In modern book production, the size of an <a href="#edition">edition</a> depends on the size of the unfolded sheet used in printing.  In the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s, the historical dimensions are is still used, but in modern book production, size is based on the height and width of the <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Slight differences exist between American and British practice in the <a href="#standardization">standardization</a> of book sizes.  American sizes are given below.  Synonymous with <em>book format</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#exactsize">exact size</a>.
</p><p>
</p><center><table>
<tbody><tr align="left"><td width="300"><b><em>Name</em></b></td><td width="200"><b><em>Height &amp; Width</em></b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Thirty-sixmo</td><td width="200">4 x 3 1/3 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Medium Thirty-twomo</td><td width="200">4 3/4 x 3 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Medium Twenty-fourmo</td><td width="200">5 1/2 x 3 5/8 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Medium Eighteenmo</td><td width="200">6 2/3 x 4 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Medium Sixteenmo</td><td width="200">6 3/4 x 4 1/2 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Cap Octavo</td><td width="200">7 x 7 1/4 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Duodecimo</td><td width="200">7 1/2 x 4 1/2 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Crown Octavo</td><td width="200">7 1/2 x 5 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Post Octavo</td><td width="200">7 1/2 x 5 1/2 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Medium Duodecimo</td><td width="200">7 2/3 x 5 1/8 inches</td></tr>
