<tr align="left"><td width="300">Royal Octavo</td><td width="200">10 x 6 1/2 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Super Royal Octavo</td><td width="200">10 1/2 x 7 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Imperial Quarto</td><td width="200">11 x 15 inches</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="300">Imperial Octavo</td><td width="200">11 1/2 x 8 1/4 inches</td></tr>
</tbody></table></center>  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookstall"><b>bookstall</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small open-air retail <a href="#book">book</a> outlet,
usually found in airports and railway stations, and at fairs and
markets. In France, quay-side bookstalls have been an important part of
Parisian culture for centuries. Compare with <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookstamp"><b>book stamp</b></a>
</dt><dd>A wood, metal, or rubber stamp used to make an <a href="#ink">ink</a>ed <a href="#impression">impression</a> on the <a href="#cover">cover</a>, edge, <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>, or <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> as a <a href="#ownershipmark">mark of ownership</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookstock"><b>book stock</b></a>
</dt><dd>The total <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#book">book</a>s in a <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, subject to growth through <a href="#acquisitions">acquisition</a> and to diminution through <a href="#lost">loss</a>, <a href="#damaged">damage</a>, <a href="#theft">theft</a>, <a href="#weeding">weeding</a>, etc.  Synonymous with <em>book collection</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#inventory">inventory</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookstop"><b>book stop</b></a>
</dt><dd>A narrow ridge or ledge along the lower edge of the sloping top of a <a href="#dictionarystand">dictionary stand</a>, <a href="#atlascase">atlas case</a>, or <a href="#lectern">lectern</a>, allowing an open <a href="#book">book</a> or sheaf of <a href="#paper">paper</a>s to rest at an angle convenient for reading without sliding off.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookstore"><b>bookstore</b></a>
</dt><dd>An enclosed store devoted to the retail sale of <a href="#book">book</a>s, usually in both <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> and <a href="#softcover">softcover</a>.  Some bookstores <a href="#specialization">specialize</a> in <a href="#usedbook">used book</a>s, <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s, <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>s, or materials on a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> or in a particular <a href="#genre">genre</a> (<a href="#sciencefiction">science fiction</a>, <a href="#comicbook">comic</a>s, etc.).  Large <a href="#tradebookstore">trade bookstore</a>s may also sell <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s and <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#calendar">calendar</a>s, greeting cards, <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#media">media</a> (<a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>s, <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>s, <a href="#audiocassette">audiocassette</a>s, <a href="#compactdisc">CD</a>s, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>s),
and reading paraphernalia. Bookstore chains have outlets in most large
cities in the United States, offering nearly identical stock (<a href="http://www.barnesandnoble.com/">Barnes &amp; Noble</a> and <a href="http://www.bordersstores.com/index.jsp">Borders Books &amp; Music</a>).  <a href="#collegebookstore">College bookstore</a>s sell mainly <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s and <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>s for the use of students.  <a href="#information">Information</a> on book retailers in the United States and Canada is available in the <a href="#annual">annual</a> <em><a href="#abtd">American Book Trade Directory</a></em>, <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.  Synonymous with <em>bookshop</em>.  Compare with <a href="#bookstall">bookstall</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booktalk"><b>book talk</b></a>
</dt><dd>An event, usually scheduled in a <a href="#library">library</a>, <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>, or educational institution, at which the <a href="#author">author</a>, a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>, or other interested person discusses a <a href="#book">book</a> and reads <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>s from it to encourage <a href="#readership">readership</a> and promote reading in general.  Also spelled <em>booktalk</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#booksigning">book signing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booktrade"><b>book trade</b></a>
</dt><dd>The operations and arrangements that exist in a specific country for the manufacture, distribution, and sale of <a href="#book">book</a>s to the public, including <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s and their <a href="#association">association</a>s, <a href="#printer">printer</a>s and <a href="#bindery">binder</a>s, retail <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s and their <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a>s, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>s and <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>s, and the generally accepted practices, <a href="#standards">standards</a>, and codes governing their activities.  Statistics on the U.S. book trade can be found in <b><em>The Bowker Annual Library and Book Trade Almanac</em></b>, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most larger <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> can be found in the <a href="#annual">annual</a> <em><a href="#abtd">American Book Trade Directory</a></em>, also <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booktradejournal"><b>book trade journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, and others engaged in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> for the purpose of <a href="#bookannouncement">announcing</a> and promoting newly <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s.  Book <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a>s also include trade news, <a href="#bestseller">bestseller</a> lists, <a href="#authorinterview">author interview</a>s, <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#review">review</a>s, feature <a href="#article">article</a>s, regular <a href="#column">column</a>s, analysis of current trends and issues, and <a href="#information">information</a> about book production/distribution, <a href="#bookfair">book fair</a>s, and <a href="#booksigning">book signing</a>s.  In the United States, the leading book trade journals are <em><a href="http://publishersweekly.reviewsnews.com/">Publisher's Weekly</a></em> and BookWeb.org's <em><a href="http://www.bookweb.org/news/">Industry Newsroom</a></em> from the <a href="#aba">American Booksellers Association</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="booktruck"><b>book truck</b></a>
</dt><dd>A wheeled metal or wooden cart with two or three shelves, used by a <a href="#page">page</a> or other <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> member for transporting <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> from one area of the <a href="#library">library</a> to another.  Book trucks are available from library <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#reshelvingcart">reshelving cart</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookweek"><b>Book Week</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#childrensbookweek">Children's Book Week</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bookworm"><b>bookworm</b></a>
</dt><dd>The larval form of a moth or beetle that damages <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#printing">printed</a> materials by boring small holes through <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> and <a href="#binding">binding</a>s, creating a highly undesirable <a href="#condition">condition</a> called <a href="#worming">worming</a>.  Also spelled <em>book-worm</em>.  Compare with <a href="#booklice">book lice</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fumigation">fumigation</a>.
<p>
Also, a <a href="#slang">slang</a> expression used as a term of
disparagement for someone who prefers reading over most other
activities, and can usually be found with his or her nose in a book.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="boolean"><b>Boolean</b></a>        
</dt><dd>A system of logic developed by the English mathematician George Boole (1815-1864) which allows the user to combine words or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s representing significant concepts in a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> <a href="#search">search</a> of an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>.  Three logical commands (sometimes called "operators") are available in most <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a>: 
<p>
</p></dd><dd>The <b>OR</b> command is used to <em>expand</em> <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a> by including <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>s and <a href="#relatedterm">related term</a>s in the <a href="#query">query</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#logicalsum">logical sum</a>.
<p> 
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Search statement:</em>  <b>violence or conflict or aggression</b></dd></dl>
<p>    
</p></dd><dd>The <b>AND</b> command is used to <em>narrow</em> search results.  Each time another concept is added using "and" the search becomes more <a href="#specificity">specific</a>.  In some <a href="#online">online</a> catalogs and databases, the "and" command is <em>implicit</em> (no need to type it in a keywords <a href="#search">search</a>).  In other <a href="#interface">interface</a>s, <a href="#term">term</a>s will be searched as a phrase if not separated by "and."  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#logicalproduct">logical product</a>.
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Search statement</em>:  <b>violence and television and children</b></dd></dl>  
<p>     
</p></dd><dd>The <b>NOT</b> command is used to <em>exclude</em> unwanted <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s from search results.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#logicaldifference">logical difference</a>.
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Search statement</em>:  <b>television not cartoon*</b></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dd>When two <em>different</em> Boolean commands are used in the same <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>, <a href="#parenthesis">parentheses</a> must be included to indicate the sequence in which they are to be executed (<a href="#syntax">syntax</a>).  This technique is called <a href="#nesting">nesting</a>.
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Search statement</em>:  <b>television and (violence or aggression) and children</b></dd></dl> 
<p>
</p></dd><dd>For a detailed discussion of Boolean logic, please see the entry by Gwyneth Tseng in the <b><em>International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science</em></b> (Routledge: 1997).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#proximity">proximity</a>, <a href="#truncation">truncation</a>, and <a href="#venn">Venn diagram</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="boot"><b>boot</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, a <a href="#slang">slang</a> <a href="#term">term</a> borrowed from the expression "to pull oneself up by one's <a href="#bootstrap">bootstrap</a>s" meaning to start a computer, causing the <a href="#file">file</a>s in its <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> to automatically begin executing.  <a href="#application">Application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s are "loaded" rather than "booted."  Synonymous with <em>boot up</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#coldboot">cold boot</a> and <a href="#reboot">reboot</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bootleg"><b>bootleg</b></a>
</dt><dd>A product illegally imported or sold.  In the case of commercially published <a href="#compactdisc">CD</a>s, computer <a href="#software">software</a>, <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>s, <a href="#book">book</a>s, and other <a href="#intellectualproperty">intellectual property</a>, a <a href="#copy">copy</a> made for sale in violation of existing <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pirated">pirated edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bootstrap"><b>bootstrap</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> that causes the first piece of <a href="#software">software</a> installed on a computer (usually the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>) to load when the power is switched on, enabling the <a href="#centralproc">CPU</a> to begin executing instructions.  The word <em>bootstrap</em>
originally referred to a strap or tab attached to the back of the ankle
of a boot to help the wearer pull it on, hence the expression "to pull
oneself up by one's bootstraps." In computing, it has spawned <a href="#boot">boot</a>, <a href="#coldboot">cold boot</a>, <a href="#reboot">reboot</a>, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="border"><b>border</b></a>
</dt><dd>Continuous ornamentation running parallel with the edges of a <a href="#page">page</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, or around a block of <a href="#text">text</a> or an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>.  A border can consist of one or more unbroken <a href="#rule">rule</a>s, plain or embellished, or units of geometric or organic design arranged in an unbroken repeating pattern.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fullpageborder">full-page border</a> and <a href="#historiatedborder">historiated border</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="borndigital"><b>born digital</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#slang">slang</a> <a href="#term">term</a> for a <a href="#work">work</a> created from scratch in electronic form, for example, a <a href="#hypermedia">hypermedia</a> <a href="#thesis">thesis</a> or <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a>, or an <a href="#electronicjournal">electronic journal</a> that has no <a href="#print">print</a> counterpart.  <a href="#digitalpreservation">Preservation</a> dilemmas are posed by the rapid obsolescence of <a href="#digital">digital</a> equipment and <a href="#format">format</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="borrower"><b>borrower</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who <a href="#checkedout">checks out</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> from a <a href="#library">library</a>.  Most libraries require users to <a href="#register">register</a> to receive the <a href="#borrowingprivileges">borrowing privileges</a> associated with a <a href="#librarycard">library card</a>.  Some form of identification is usually required of new applicants.  Not all library <a href="#patron">patron</a>s are registered borrowers--in most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> and publicly supported <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> in the United States, unregistered persons may use <a href="#refcollection">reference materials</a> and <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in the <a href="#circulating">circulating collection</a>
without removing them from library premises. The library privileges to
which a borrower is entitled are indicated by the individual's <a href="#borrowerstatus">borrower status</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="borroweraccount"><b>borrower account</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#patron">patron</a>'s ongoing transactions with a <a href="#library">library</a>, including <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s currently <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>, <a href="#overdue">overdue</a>s, unpaid <a href="#fines">fines</a>, <a href="#hold">hold</a>s, etc.  <a href="#librarystaff">Library staff</a> can check the status of an individual's account by examining the <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a>.  Most automated <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s are designed to protect the <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>'s <a href="#confidentiality">confidentiality</a> by deleting transaction history as soon as items are returned and fines paid.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="borrowerstatus"><b>borrower status</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#borrowingprivileges">borrowing privileges</a> to which a registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> is entitled, determined by borrower type as indicated in the <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a>.  Each <a href="#library">library</a> establishes its own list of borrower categories to reflect local conditions.  In <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, all registered users generally enjoy the same privileges, but in <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, certain privileges, such as length of <a href="#loanperiod">loan period</a>, may not be the same for faculty and students.  In <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>, privileges may depend on a person's rank in the parent organization.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="borrowinglibrary"><b>borrowing library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> or institution that requests and receives <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> from another library, usually on <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>.  Compare with <a href="#lendinglibrary">lending library</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#netborrower">net borrower</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="borrowing"><b>borrowing period</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#loanperiod">loan period</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="borrowingprivileges"><b>borrowing privileges</b></a>
</dt><dd>The rights to which a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> is entitled, usually established by registering to receive a <a href="#librarycard">library card</a>.  Such privileges normally include the right to <a href="#checkedout">check out</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> from the <a href="#circulating">circulating collection</a> for a designated period of time, <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>, use of <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>, etc.  They may be suspended if <a href="#fines">fines</a> remain unpaid.  In most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, all registered users enjoy the same privileges, but in <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, certain privileges, such as length of <a href="#loanperiod">loan period</a>, may be different for faculty than for students.  In <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>, borrowing privileges may depend on a person's rank in the parent organization.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="boss"><b>boss</b></a>
</dt><dd>A plain or embellished metal knob or raised cleat firmly attached to the outside of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>, usually at the center and/or <a href="#corner">corner</a>s.  Bosses were used in medieval <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> for decorative effect and to protect against wear.  Compare with <a href="#shoe">shoe</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bounced"><b>bounced</b></a>
</dt><dd>An undeliverable <a href="#email">e-mail</a> message returned to the sender's mailbox, usually because the recipient's <a href="#emailaddress">e-mail address</a> was incorrectly typed, the user unknown to the mail <a href="#server">server</a>, or the e-mail box full.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="boundasis"><b>bound as is</b></a>
</dt><dd>An incomplete or defective <a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> in the <a href="#condition">condition</a> in which it is received by the <a href="#binder">binder</a>, usually in compliance with specific instructions from the <a href="#library">library</a> as indicated on the <a href="#bindingslip">binding slip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="btsb"><b>Bound To Stay Bound (BTSB)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1920 as a family-owned business, <b>BTSB</b> is the leading <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> of <a href="#prelibrary">prelibrary bound</a> <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>s to <a href="#schoollibrary">school</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> in the United States, providing a list of 18,000 <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#media">media</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s.  For heavily used <a href="#title">title</a>s, <a href="#library">libraries</a> rely on <b>BTSB</b> because the <a href="#binding">binding</a>s are so sturdy that the <a href="#page">page</a>s usually wear out first.  <a href="http://www.btsb.com/btsb.asp">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>BTSB</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bowdlerize"><b>bowdlerize</b></a>
</dt><dd>To change the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>
by altering or deleting words or entire passages considered
objectionable. Derived from the name of the Reverend Thomas Bowdler
(1754-1825) who <a href="#publishing">published</a> an <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a>s
of Shakespeare in the early 19th century from which passages considered
"unfit to be read by a gentleman in the presence of ladies" were
omitted. He produced a similar edition of the <em>Old Testament</em>.  Chaucer's <b><em>Canterbury Tales</em></b> and Jonathan Swift's <b><em>Gulliver's Travels</em></b> have received the same kind of <a href="#treatment">treatment</a>.  Synonymous with <em>expurgate</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#censorship">censorship</a> and <a href="#unexpurgated">unexpurgated</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bowker"><b>Bowker</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bowkerrr">Bowker, Richard Rogers</a> and <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bowkerrr"><b>Bowker, Richard Rogers (1848-1933)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A literary <a href="#editor">editor</a> who in 1876 founded, with Frederick Leypoldt and Melvil Dewey, the <a href="#publication">publication</a> <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em>.  In the same year, he helped found the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> and with Leypoldt began <a href="#publication">publication</a> of <em>American Catalogue</em>, a <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#index">index</a> of <a href="#book">book</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the United States.  In 1879, he purchased <em><a href="#publishersweekly">Publishers Weekly</a></em> which Leypoldt had created in 1873, assuming editorial control of the <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a>
after Leypoldt's death in 1884. During this period, Bowker also helped
found a liberal movement within the Republican Party known as the
"Mugwumps" which was instrumental in preventing the nomination of
Ulysess S. Grant for a third term. In 1880, he traveled to England to
start the British <a href="#edition">edition</a> of <em>Harper's Magazine</em>.  
<p>
Bowker is also known for his interest in international <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law and his success as a businessman.  In 1911, he consolidated his business and publishing interests in the <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker Co.</a> which continues to be a leading <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s on <a href="#library">libraries</a>
and the publishing industry. Bowker remained an active member of the
ALA throughout his life, but refused its presidency three times because
he felt the position should be held by a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>.
He finally accepted the title Honorary President when he was in his
seventies. Although he eventually lost his sight, he published <a href="#essay">essay</a>s on <em>The Arts of Life</em> and two <a href="#volume">volume</a>s of <a href="#verse">verse</a> in his later years. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="box"><b>box</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a square or oblong area within a larger area of <a href="#type">type</a>, or between two <a href="#column">column</a>s, delineated by <a href="#rule">rule</a>s or white spaces that set apart the <a href="#text">text</a> and/or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> contained in it.  Also refers to a square or rectangular <a href="#border">border</a> of one or more parallel <a href="#rule">rule</a>s, printed around a block of type, sometimes with embellishment at the corners.  Type <a href="#matter">matter</a> set apart in this manner is said to be <em>boxed-in</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="boxed"><b>boxed</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#set">set</a> of <a href="#book">book</a>s or other <a href="#document">document</a>s stored in a close-fitting box-shaped container, usually to keep the <a href="#volume">volume</a>s together and provide protection, but sometimes for decorative effect.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#slipcase">slipcase</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="boxed-in"><b>boxed-in</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#box">box</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="boxlist"><b>box list</b></a>
</dt><dd>An initial list of the contents of an <a href="#archivesbox">archives box</a>, usually made at the time the materials are packed for <a href="#transfer">transfer</a>, identifying the contents and giving a date range if applicable, used for control and <a href="#access">access</a> until a more complete <a href="#inventory">inventory</a> can be undertaken.  Synonymous with <em>consignment list</em> and <em>container list</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bracing"><b>bracing</b></a>
</dt><dd>Heavy metal rods attached in the form of a large <b>X</b> to the uprights across the back of a <a href="#section">section</a> of single-sided shelving, or down the middle of a double-sided section of <a href="#freestanding">free-standing shelving</a>, for the purpose of reducing lengthwise sway.  Metal braces are also attached to sections in parallel <a href="#range">range</a>s, over the <a href="#aisle">aisle</a>s, to reduce side-to-side sway, particularly in geographic areas prone to earthquake. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bracketedinterp"><b>bracketed interpolation</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#bibdescrip">Description</a> added to a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> inside <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s [ ] to indicate <a href="#information">information</a> that has been provided by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>, usually because it is not available in or on the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> itself, for example, [15] p. indicating that an <a href="#unpaginated">unpaginated</a> <a href="#work">work</a> is fifteen <a href="#page">page</a>s long.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="braille"><b>Braille</b></a>
</dt><dd>A tactile system of <a href="#embossed">embossed</a> <a href="#print">print</a> invented in 1829 by the blind Parisian, Louis Braille, in which the letters of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> are represented by combinations of six raised dots arranged in columns three dots high and two dots wide, to enable <a href="#visuallyimpaired">visually impaired</a> persons to read by touch.  The most widely used tactile <a href="#medium">medium</a> in the world, Braille is used by <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States for <a href="#signage">signage</a> and <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> for <a href="#reader">reader</a>s who have significant visual impairments.  The form of Braille used in mathematics is called <em>Nemeth code</em>.  The <em><a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/nls/bbr/index.html">Braille Book Review</a></em> is available <a href="#online">online</a> from the <a href="#nls">National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped</a> (NLS).  <a href="http://www.nyise.org/braille.htm">Click here</a> to learn more about Braille.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="branchlibrary"><b>branch library</b></a>
</dt><dd>An auxiliary service outlet in a <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, housed in a facility separate from the <a href="#centrallib">central library</a>, which has at least a basic <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, a regular <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>, and established <a href="#hours">hours</a>, with a <a href="#budget">budget</a> and policies determined by the central library.  A branch library is usually managed by a <em>branch librarian</em> who may have responsibility for more than one branch.  In a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> system, new branches may be sited on the basis of a comprehensive plan for the entire city, county, region, or <a href="#librarydistrict">library district</a> served by the system.  Compare with <a href="#affiliatedlibrary">affiliated library</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#bookmobile">bookmobile</a> and <a href="#booksbymail">books-by-mail</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="brandname"><b>brand name</b></a>
</dt><dd>The part of the name or <a href="#logo">logo</a> associated with a specific product or service, which can be vocalized, usually <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, words, and/or <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s identifying and distinguishing it from varieties of the same product or service marketed by competing companies (<em>example</em>:  Coca-Cola versus Pepsi-Cola).  When registered with the U.S. <a href="#patent">Patent</a> and Trademark Office, a brand or part of a brand is known as a <a href="#trademark">trademark</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="brass"><b>brass</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#blocking">blocking</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="breach"><b>breach of contract</b></a>
</dt><dd>Failure to keep the terms of an agreement or <a href="#contract">contract</a>.  Some employment contracts include penalties for breach of certain provisions, such as length of notice required at time of <a href="#resignation">resignation</a>, but enforcement is usually at the discretion of the employer.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bookcontract">book contract</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="break"><b>break</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#gap">gap</a> and <a href="#nongapbreak">nongap break</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="breviary"><b>breviary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#liturgicalwork">liturgical work</a> containing
daily divine Offices (prayers) said by clergy of the Roman Catholic and
Eastern Orthodox Churches at the canonical Hours of the day. Hand <a href="#copy">copied</a> breviaries of the medieval period were often beautifully <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> (<em>example</em>:  the 15th century <em><a href="http://www.bnf.fr/enluminures/manuscrits/aman11.htm">Breviary of Martin of Aragon</a></em> in the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of the <a href="#bnfrance">Bibliotheque nationale de France</a> in Paris).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="brief"><b>brief</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#outline">outline</a> of the evidence and
arguments supporting one side of an argument. In a more general sense,
any concise statement in written form. In law, a <a href="#summary">summary</a> statement of the main points of an oral or written argument presented in court.  Also refers to a <a href="#letter">letter</a> of authority, especially one sent by the Pope to the members of a Roman Catholic religious community.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="briefrecord"><b>brief record</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> display of a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> in an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>, omitting <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s contained in some of the less essential <a href="#field">field</a>s and <a href="#subfield">subfield</a>s, in contrast to the <a href="#fullrecord">full record</a> providing a complete <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  In most <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, <a href="#search">search</a> results can be displayed in both <a href="#format">format</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="brightcopy"><b>bright copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of an older <a href="#book">book</a> that is as fresh and new as the day it was <a href="#publishing">published</a>, a <a href="#condition">condition</a> likely to command a higher price in the market for <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> and <a href="#usedbook">used book</a>s than a copy of the same <a href="#edition">edition</a> showing signs of wear.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mint">mint</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="briticize"><b>briticize</b></a>
</dt><dd>To convert to British English the style and spelling of a <a href="#work">work</a> written in (or <a href="#translation">translated</a> into) American English.  Compare with <a href="#americanize">americanize</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bbc"><b>British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An independent <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>ing service
that began daily "wireless" transmission in 1922, supported by
individual licenses sold at ten shillings apiece. By the end of the
1930s, the number of licenses had increased to nearly nine million and
the <b>BBC</b> had become a major patron of the arts.  In 1936, the <b>BBC Television Service</b> was launched, only be to be closed down during World War II, but the <b>BBC</b> emerged from the war with an enhanced reputation for the quality of its news broadcasts.  
<p>
Today, individuals and businesses in Britain that use or install
equipment to receive or record television programming are required to
pay an annual license <a href="#fee">fee</a> in support of the <b>BBC</b>, which is run by a 12-member Board of Directors appointed by the Queen in Council to monitor performance <a href="#standards">standards</a> and appoint a Director-General and upper-level management.  Many of the television programs and series shown on <a href="http://www.pbs.org/">PBS</a> in the United States are co-produced with or acquired from the <b>BBC</b>.  <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>BBC</b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pubtv">public television</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="britishlib"><b>British Library</b></a>
</dt><dd>Located mainly in London, <b>The British Library</b> is the <a href="#nationallib">national library</a>
of the United Kingdom (UK), created in 1973 by an act of Parliament
which merged the British Museum Library, the National Central Library,
the National Lending Library for Science and Technology, and the
British National Bibliography. <a href="http://www.bl.uk/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of <b>The British Library</b>. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bodleian">Bodleian Library</a>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="brittle"><b>brittle</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of being easily broken or shattered.  In time, <a href="#acidpaper">acid paper</a>s turn <a href="#yellowing">yellow</a> and become brittle, tearing easily and even crumbling under normal use.  For <a href="#paper">paper</a>, the standard test of brittleness is whether the corner of a <a href="#page">page</a> can withstand <a href="#twodoublefold">folding</a> in each direction twice.  <a href="#encapsulation">Encapsulation</a> is used to preserve individual <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s, but is not practical for entire <a href="#volume">volume</a>s.  <a href="#digital">Digital</a> <a href="#reformat">reformat</a>ting is replacing conversion to <a href="#microform">microform</a>s in the <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> of <em>embrittled</em> <a href="#book">book</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="broadcast"><b>broadcast</b></a>
</dt><dd>Simultaneous transmission to all who own the equipment required to receive a signal communicating <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#content">content</a>
(radio and television) or to those who have paid for a specific type of
communication service (cable television). Compare with <a href="#multicast">multicast</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a radio or television program or announcement once it has been transmitted to its <a href="#audience">audience</a>.  In the most general sense, to make any message widely known.  The opposite of <a href="#narrowcast">narrowcast</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="broadclassification"><b>broad classification</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> in which the main <a href="#class">class</a>es are not extensively <a href="#subdivision">subdivided</a>, for use in small <a href="#library">libraries</a> that do not require <a href="#closeclassification">close classification</a> to organize their <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s effectively.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="broaderterm"><b>broader term (BT or B)</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>s, a <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> that includes another <a href="#term">term</a> as a <a href="#subclass">subclass</a> (<em>example</em>:  "Libraries" listed as a broader term under "School libraries").  In some <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> systems, a subject heading or descriptor may have more than one broader term (<em>example</em>:  "Documentation" and "Library science" under "Cataloging").  Compare with <a href="#narrowerterm">narrower term</a> (NT) and <a href="#relatedterm">related term</a> (RT).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="broadsheet"><b>broadsheet</b></a>
</dt><dd>A long, narrow unfolded <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a>
on one or both sides, used mainly for advertising purposes and formerly
to disseminate religious or political views. Sometimes used
synonymously with <a href="#broadside">broadside</a>.  Also refers to a full-size <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, as opposed to a <a href="#tabloid">tabloid</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="broadside"><b>broadside</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, a large <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a>
across one side only, intended to be read unfolded or posted, bearing a
royal proclamation or official notice, but later used to disseminate
news or political views. Also used in the 16th century England to
distribute <a href="#ballad">ballad</a>s and other <a href="#poetry">poem</a>s.  Sometimes used synonymously with <a href="#broadsheet">broadsheet</a>.  <a href="http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/rbpehtml/pehome.html">Click here</a> to view <a href="#online">online</a> an <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of broadsides, courtesy of the <em><a href="http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/ammemhome.html">American Memory</a></em> project at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  
<p>
In modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, a large sheet printed on one or both sides, folded down the center for mailing.  Sometimes restricted to a sheet on which the <a href="#text">text</a> is printed from side to side across the fold.  Also refers to the substance of the <a href="#matter">matter</a> printed in such a <a href="#format">format</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="brochure"><b>brochure</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the French word <em>brocher</em> (to stitch).  An independent non<a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> consisting of a few <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of <a href="#printing">printed</a> material <a href="#saddle">stitched</a> together, but not <a href="#binding">bound</a>, usually <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s.  Considered <a href="#ephemera">ephemera</a> in most <a href="#library">libraries</a>, brochures are not <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> separately unless they are of historical interest, or <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by a <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a> and <a href="#selection">selected</a> for inclusion in a <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  Used synonymously with <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="brodart"><b>Brodart</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial company that <a href="#supplier">supplies</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s, furniture, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a>, and automation services to <a href="#library">libraries</a> of all kinds, largely through its <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#tradecatalog">trade catalog</a>.  <a href="http://www.brodart.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Brodart</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#demco">DEMCO</a> and <a href="#highsmith">Highsmith</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="brokenlink"><b>broken link</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#link">link</a> in an <a href="#html">HTML</a> <a href="#document">document</a> which is not functioning properly, usually because the link <a href="#url">address</a> is incorrect or the <a href="#website">Web site</a> is no longer available or has been moved to another <a href="#server">server</a> with no forwarding address provided.  When a broken link is selected in a <a href="#www">Web</a> <a href="#document">document</a>, an error message appears on the screen.  The tendency of links in a <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#document">document</a> to become nonfunctional over time is known colloquially as <em>link rot</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="brokenup"><b>broken up</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> disassembled to enable its parts (usually <a href="#plate">plate</a>s or other <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s) to be sold separately.  <a href="#copy">Copies</a> of the <em><a href="#gutenbergbible">Gutenberg Bible</a></em> have been broken up and the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> can be sold separately.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="browsability"><b>browsability</b></a>
</dt><dd>The ease with which a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, or other list of resources can be <a href="#search">search</a>ed in a casual, unsystematic manner.  A <a href="#printing">printed</a> index is often more <em>browsable</em> than its <a href="#online">online</a> counterpart because the <a href="#page">page</a> <a href="#format">format</a> makes it easy for the user to scan a list of <a href="#heading">heading</a>s to find related <a href="#information">information</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#serendipity">serendipity</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="browse"><b>browse</b></a>
</dt><dd>To look through a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, or other <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a> in a casual <a href="#search">search</a> for <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s of interest, without clearly defined intentions.  To facilitate browsing, libraries assign similar <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>s to items on the same <a href="#subject">subject</a>, which groups them together on the shelf.
<p>
In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, a search directed by the user in a dynamic but casual way.  A clearly formulated <a href="#query">query</a> may determine the initial point of entry into an index or <a href="#database">database</a>, but searches that begin systematically often give way to an exploratory approach as new <a href="#terminology">terminology</a> is revealed in the results retrieved.  Some <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s consider <a href="#printing">printed</a> indexes to be more <a href="#browsability">browsable</a> than electronic databases because <a href="#page">page</a> <a href="#format">format</a> allows the user to scan with ease the <a href="#heading">heading</a>s and <a href="#entry">entries</a> that precede and follow the initial <a href="#accesspoint">point of access</a>.  
</p><p>
Also, to search for <a href="#information">information</a> available on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a> in a casual, <a href="#serendipity">serendipitous</a> manner.  <a href="#hypertext">Hypertext</a> is designed to facilitate <a href="#online">online</a> browsing  by providing embedded <a href="#link">link</a>s to related <a href="#document">document</a>s and electronic resources (this online <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> is an example).  Compare with <a href="#surf">surf</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="browser"><b>browser</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who <a href="#search">search</a>es a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#collection">collection</a>, <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, or other list of resources in a casual, unsystematic manner.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#serendipity">serendipity</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a type of <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#software">software</a> called a <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>, designed to facilitate searching for <a href="#information">information</a> available on the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="browsercache"><b>browser cache</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portion of <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> <a href="#memory">memory</a> reserved by <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> <a href="#software">software</a> for storing the <a href="#contents">contents</a> of <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s previously visited by the user, reducing the amount of time required to revisit a page using the same machine.  Clicking on "<a href="#reload">Reload</a>" or "Refresh" in the <a href="#toolbar">toolbar</a> of a browser will cause the Web page displayed on the screen to be retrieved from its original remote <a href="#url">address</a>, rather than from the <a href="#cache">cache</a>.  Most browsers allow the user to specify the length of time <a href="#searchhistory">search history</a> will be retained before it is automatically <a href="#delete">delete</a>d.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bsa1"><b>BSA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bsa"><b>B</b>ibliographical <b>S</b>ociety of <b>A</b>merica</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bt"><b>BT (or B)</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#broaderterm"><b>b</b>roader <b>t</b>erm</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="btsb1"><b>BTSB</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#btsb"><b>B</b>ound <b>T</b>o <b>S</b>tay <b>B</b>ound</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="buckram"><b>buckram</b></a>
</dt><dd>A strong, <a href="#durability">durable</a> <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> consisting of a heavy woven base in cotton, linen, or jute filled with starch or impregnated with pyroxylin, used to <a href="#cover">cover</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a>s for which heavy use is anticipated (<a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es, children's <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>s, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="budget"><b>budget</b></a>
</dt><dd>The total amount of funds available to meet a <a href="#library">library</a>'s expenditures over a fixed period of time (usually one or two years).  In most budgets, funds are <a href="#allocation">allocated</a> by category of expenditure, called <em>lines</em>.  In chronically <a href="#underfunded">under-funded</a> libraries and <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s, <em>budgeting</em> can be a major source of frustration for <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and <a href="#libadmin">library administration</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#lineitem">line-item budget</a>, <a href="#operatingbudget">operating budget</a>, and <a href="#zbb">zero-base budget</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="buffer"><b>buffer</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, temporary <a href="#storage">storage</a> (usually <a href="#ram">RAM</a>) used for <a href="#data">data</a>
while it is being processed, or for special purposes such as the
transfer of data between two system components which have different
operating speeds, for example, a <a href="#printer">printer</a> and a <a href="#centralproc">CPU</a> capable of processing data more quickly than <a href="#output">output</a> can be printed.  A buffer may be a section of <a href="#memory">memory</a> reserved for a specific processing function, or a portion of general memory allocated and deallocated as needed.    
<p>
In <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, a substance or mixture of substances added to <a href="#paper">paper</a> stock during manufacture to control the <a href="#acidpaper">acidity</a> or <a href="#alkaline">alkalinity</a> of the product.  In <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, a substance or mixture used to maintain the acidity or alkalinity of paper (or of a solution) at an optimum level.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bufferedpaper"><b>buffered paper</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#printing">Printing</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> to which an <a href="#alkaline">alkaline</a> substance, such as calcium carbonate or magnesium carbonate, is added in manufacture to neutralize any <a href="#acidic">acid</a> produced internally as a result of aging, or introduced by <a href="#acidmigration">acid migration</a> or exposure to atmospheric pollution.  <em>Non-buffered</em> paper is required for certain types of <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic <a href="#print">print</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="buffering"><b>buffering</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, the addition of an <a href="#alkaline">alkaline</a> substance such as calcium carbonate or magnesium carbonate to the <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>ed fiber to neutralize any <a href="#ph">acid</a> that may develop as paper ages, or be introduced through <a href="#acidmigration">acid migration</a> or exposure to atmospheric pollution.  Extent of buffering is indicated as a percentage of the paper <a href="#weight">weight</a>, usually no more than 2-3%.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bug"><b>bug</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, a <a href="#slang">slang</a> <a href="#term">term</a> for a persistent error in <a href="#software">software</a> or <a href="#hardware">hardware</a>.  Once it has been located, a software bug can be corrected by altering the <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>, a process known as <em>debugging</em>.  To correct a hardware bug, it is usually necessary to reconfigure circuitry.  Compare with <a href="#glitch">glitch</a>.
<p>
Also refers to an electronic eavesdropping device installed in a
telephone receiver, or in some other hidden location, usually for the
purpose of <a href="#espionage">espionage</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bulk"><b>bulk</b></a>
</dt><dd>The thickness of a <a href="#book">book</a> without its <a href="#cover">cover</a>, normally less after <a href="#binding">binding</a> than in its <a href="#unbound">unbound</a> state.  Also, the thickness of a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> in relation to its weight, as measured in thousandths of an inch.  The thickness of <a href="#printing">printing</a> papers is also measured in <a href="#page">page</a>s-per-inch.  <a href="#publisher">Publisher</a>s sometimes "bulk" a short <a href="#text">text</a> by printing it on thick, low-density paper.  <a href="#indiapaper">India paper</a> and <a href="#biblepaper">bible paper</a> are used to <em>reduce</em> the bulk of a large <a href="#volume">volume</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bulklending"><b>bulk lending</b></a>
</dt><dd>The lending of a large volume of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> by one <a href="#library">library</a> to another, usually for a period of time longer than the normal <a href="#checkout">borrowing period</a>.  <a href="#book">Book</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#largeprint">large print</a> and <a href="#bookontape">books-on-tape</a> are sometimes loaned in bulk to the <a href="#branchlibrary">branch libraries</a> within a <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, or even outside the system.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bull"><b>bull</b></a> 
</dt><dd>Narrowly speaking, a <a href="#document">document</a>, <a href="#letter">letter</a>, edict, or decree <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by the Pope, to which his official seal (<em>Bulla</em>) is affixed.  Also refers to any statement of belief or doctrine, whether ecclesiastical or not. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bullet"><b>bullet</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a>, and <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> design, a small <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>al element, usually in the shape of a:
<p></p><ul>
<li>small circle,
</li><li>large dot,
</li><li>square, 
</li><li>diamond,
</li><li>or other shape
<p></p></li></ul>used to emphasize a part of a <a href="#text">text</a> or to itemize an unnumbered list.  Such a list is said to be <em>bulleted</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bulletin"><b>bulletin</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, usually in the form of a <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by a <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>, <a href="#society">society</a>, or other institution, containing announcements, news, and <a href="#information">information</a> of <a href="#currency">current</a> interest, usually more substantial than a <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a>.  In a more general sense, any brief <a href="#report">report</a> on the latest developments in an ongoing process or situation, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#print">print</a> or <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>bull</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bulletinboard">bulletin board</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bulletinboard"><b>bulletin board</b></a>
</dt><dd>A flat notice board, usually attached to a wall near the entrance to a <a href="#library">library</a>, used to display announcements of forthcoming events, <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>s removed from <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s recently added to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, <a href="#readinglist">reading list</a>s, comments and suggestions from library users (sometimes with responses from the <a href="#libadmin">library administration</a>), and other <a href="#information">information</a> pertinent to library operations.  Some libraries use a <a href="#kiosk">kiosk</a> for this purpose.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bbs">bulletin board system</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bbs"><b>bulletin board system (BBS) </b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#online">online</a> messaging system and
discussion forum that allows users to post notices and comments to
members of an interest group connected to the same <a href="#network">network</a>.  A <b>BBS</b> is similar in function to a <a href="#website">Web site</a>, but lacks <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s and has its own telephone number which the user must dial with the aid of a communications <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>.  Bulletin board systems have been largely <a href="#superseded">superseded</a> in the United States by the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>, but are still used in parts of the world which lack direct <a href="#access">access</a> to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  Compare with <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bumped"><b>bumped</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#binding">binding</a> that has at least one <a href="#corner">corner</a> bent, compressed, or rounded by forceful contact with a hard surface, such as the floor in a fall from a bookshelf. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bureau"><b>bureau</b></a>
</dt><dd>An office or department within an organization or <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>, responsible for collecting and disseminating <a href="#information">information</a>, usually on a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a>, in a particular <a href="#field">field</a>, or of a certain type, for example, demographic information in the case of the U.S. <a href="#census">Census</a> Bureau.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="burlesque"><b>burlesque</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Italian word <em>burla</em> meaning "mockery."  A crude form of <a href="#satire">satire</a> in which the style of a <a href="#work">work</a>, or of an entire <a href="#genre">genre</a>, is ridiculed by trivializing a serious <a href="#subject">subject</a>
or dignifying a trivial one, usually in the form of a stage
performance. The purpose is to amuse and entertain, rather than to
inform. Compare with <a href="#parody">parody</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="burnish"><b>burnish</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, to polish the colored or <a href="#giltedges">gilt edges</a> of a <a href="#volume">volume</a> with a smooth hard tool, such as an agate, until the surface gleams elegantly in the light.  Left unburnished, a gilt edge is <em>antique</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="burnout"><b>burnout</b></a>
</dt><dd>A serious and sometimes irreversible decline in <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> morale due to chronic overwork, which may result in increased <a href="#absenteeism">absenteeism</a>, <a href="#backlog">backlog</a>s, high <a href="#turnover">turnover</a>, and deterioration in <a href="#qualityofservice">quality of service</a>.  Also spelled <em>burn-out</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="businesslibrary"><b>business library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#branchlibrary">branch</a> of a metropolitan <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> which serves the specialized <a href="#information">information</a>
needs of persons engaged in business, usually located in or near the
commercial or financial district. Also, a separately administered <a href="#library">library</a>
associated with the business department of a college or university,
administered to serve the curriculum needs of the business faculty and
the information needs of students enrolled in courses in business,
management, accounting, and related <a href="#field">field</a>s.  The <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> usually includes <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, and <a href="#refbook">reference material</a>s on business, as well as company <a href="#report">report</a>s, economic and business statistics, business-related <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es and <a href="#database">database</a>s, etc., managed by a <em>business librarian</em>.  Compare with <a href="#corporationlib">corporation library</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="buyingguide"><b>buying guide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> intended for professional <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, providing <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> guidance on the purchase of a specific type of resource (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Purchasing an Encyclopedia:  Twelve Points to Consider</em></b> published by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>
in 1996). Buying guides usually begin with a discussion of evaluation
techniques, then provide detailed analysis of possible selections,
usually broken down by type of <a href="#work">work</a>.  The relative strengths/weaknesses of available alternatives may be presented in <a href="#table">tabular</a> <a href="#format">format</a> to facilitate comparison.  Also used synonymously with <a href="#consumerguide">consumer guide</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="bword"><b>B-word</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#biblio">biblio-</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="byline"><b>byline</b></a>
</dt><dd>A line of <a href="#type">type</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the beginning or end of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> or <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <a href="#article">article</a> to indicate its <a href="#authorship">authorship</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dateline">date line</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="byte"><b>byte</b></a>
</dt><dd>The common unit of computer <a href="#storage">storage</a> used in <a href="#digital">digital</a> computers of all types and sizes, composed of eight <a href="#binary">binary</a> digits called <a href="#bit">bit</a>s.  <a href="#hardware">Hardware</a> specifications for computers (<a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a>s to <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a>s) are indicated in bytes.  Each unique sequence of eight bits can <a href="#encoding">encode</a> a single <a href="#character">character</a>, for a total of 256 possible characters.  In <a href="#ascii">ASCII text</a>, the characters are <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a>.  Disagreement exists about the origin of the term.  It may be an <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of <em><b>b</b>inar<b>y</b> <b>t</b>abl<b>e</b></em> or <em><b>b</b>inar<b>y</b> <b>te</b>rm</em>, or derived from the expression "by eights."  
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>1 byte</b> = 8 bits
</dd><dd><b>1 kilobyte (K)</b> = 1,024 bytes
</dd><dd><b>1 megabyte (MB)</b> = 1,024 kilobytes or approximately one million bytes
</dd><dd><b>1 gigabyte (GB)</b> = 1,024 megabytes or approximately one billion bytes</dd></dl>
<p>
<a href="#text">Text</a> and image <a href="#file">file</a>s are usually measured in kilobytes, portable storage and <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> files in megabytes, and <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a> capacity in gigabytes.
</p></dd></dl>
<p>

</p><hr>
<center>| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> | <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a>

| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> 
| <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="C">C</a></font></h1>

<p></p><dl><dt><a name="cache"><b>cache</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small section of dedicated high-speed <a href="#memory">memory</a> built into a <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> to improve system performance by providing temporary <a href="#storage">storage</a> for blocks of <a href="#data">data</a>
and instructions which would otherwise be retrieved from slower memory.
As a general rule, the larger the cache, the greater the enhancement of
performance and speed. Pronounced "cash." <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#browsercache">browser cache</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cadastralmap"><b>cadastral map</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin word <em>capitastrum</em> meaning "<a href="#register">register</a> of the poll tax."  A <a href="#map">map</a> showing boundaries and subdivisions, made to <a href="#record">record</a> ownership and rights in land, and to describe and establish the value of property, usually for the purpose of tax assessment.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cala1"><b>CALA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cala"><b>C</b>hinese <b>A</b>merican <b>L</b>ibrarians <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="caldecott"><b>Caldecott Medal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a> given <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly since 1938 under the auspices of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> to the <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a> of the most distinguished children's <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the United States during the preceding year.  The medal is donated by the family of Frederic G. Melcher.  <a href="http://www.acs.ucalgary.ca/%7Edkbrown/awards.html">Click here</a> to view a list of Caldecott Medal winners.  Compare with <a href="#newbery">Newbery Medal</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ameliafrances">Amelia Frances Howard-Gibbon Illustrator's Award</a> and <a href="#greenaway">Greenaway Medal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="calendar"><b>calendar</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the days in a year, usually arranged by month and
within each month by week, sometimes indicating the dates of important
events such as national and religious holidays. Also, an <a href="#almanac">almanac</a> listing days of the year which are of special significance to a particular culture or political entity.  Compare with <a href="#chronology">chronology</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#calendaryear">calendar year</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a list of the <a href="#document">document</a>s included in an <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#collection">collection</a> (<a href="#roll">roll</a>s, <a href="#charter">charter</a>s, state <a href="#papers">papers</a>, etc.), usually <a href="#annotation">annotated</a> to indicate the date, <a href="#contents">contents</a>, and other characteristics of each <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="calendaryear"><b>calendar year</b></a>
</dt><dd>The one-year period beginning on January 1 and ending on December 31.  Most <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s run for a single <a href="#calendar">calendar</a> year, although an incentive may be offered to subscribe or <a href="#renew">renew</a> for two or more years.  Compare with <a href="#pubyear">publication year</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#subscripcycle">subscription cycle</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="calender"><b>calender</b></a>
</dt><dd>The part of a <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a> machine consisting of a series of rollers designed to smooth <a href="#paper">paper</a> after drying, reducing its permeability to moisture by closing the pores in its surface.  In <em>calendering</em>, the degree of smoothness depends on the amount of pressure applied by the rollers.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="calf"><b>calf</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#leather">leather</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>
made from the skin of a calf usually no more than a few weeks old. The
smooth, unblemished surface of calf made it the preferred material in
England for <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a> <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>s, but not on the Continent where <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s were usually sold in <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s to be bound at the discretion of the purchaser.  Calf bindings can be dyed any color and decorated in various ways (<a href="#marbling">marbled</a>, <a href="#mottledcalf">mottled</a>, speckled, stained, <a href="#tooling">tooled</a>, etc.).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#oozeleather">ooze leather</a> and <a href="#rough">rough</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="calligraphy"><b>calligraphy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The art of elegant handwriting.  A highly skilled penman is a <em>calligrapher</em>.  The term also refers to handwritten <a href="#character">character</a>s, words, <a href="#page">page</a>s, and even entire <a href="#document">document</a>s
which meet the aesthetic requirements of highly skilled penmanship. In
Far Eastern cultures, calligraphy is done with a pointed brush held in
a vertical position. In Western and Islamic cultures, it is done with a
reed, quill, or nib pen held at an angle to the writing surface. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bookhand">book hand</a> and <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="callnumber"><b>call number</b></a>
</dt><dd>A unique code <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a <a href="#label">label</a> affixed to the outside of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, usually the lower <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>, also handwritten or printed on a label inside the item.  Assigned by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>, the call number is also displayed in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing the item in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, to identify the <a href="#work">work</a>, indicate its <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#classification">classification</a>, and give its <a href="#locator">location</a> on the shelf relative to other items of similar classification. 
<p>
A call number is composed of the <a href="#notation">notation</a> identifying the <a href="#class">class</a> assigned to the item, followed by an <a href="#authormark">author mark</a> to distinguish the work from others of the same class, followed by a <a href="#workmark">work mark</a> distinguishing the <a href="#title">title</a> from other works of the same class by the same <a href="#author">author</a>, and sometimes other <a href="#information">information</a> such as <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a>, <a href="#copynumber">copy number</a>, and <a href="#locationsymbol">location symbol</a>.
</p><p>
In <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a> (LCC), used by most <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> in the United States, class notation begins with <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the English <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> (<em>example:</em>  <b>PN 2035.H336 1991</b>).  In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> (DDC), used by most <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#schoollibrary">school libraries</a> in the United States, class notation consists of <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s (<em>example:</em> <b>480.0924 W3</b>).  U.S. federal <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> are assigned <a href="#sudocs">SuDocs</a> numbers (<em>example</em>:  <b>L 2.2:M 76</b>).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="callslip"><b>call slip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief form that must be filled out by a registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> to request an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> from the <a href="#closedstacks">closed stacks</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>, usually retrieved by hand by a <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> member called a <a href="#page">page</a>, although automated and semi-automated systems are used in some large libraries.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cameo"><b>cameo</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> used for special effect in which the normal method of <a href="#printing">printing</a> is reversed, the <a href="#character">character</a>s appearing in white against a solid or shaded background, instead of in black against a light background.  Compare with <a href="#outlineletter">outline letter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cameobinding"><b>cameo binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A style of <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> popular in Italy from about 1500-1560 in which the centers of the <a href="#board">board</a>s forming the <a href="#cover">cover</a> are <a href="#cameostamp">stamped</a> in relief in imitation of a coin or medallion.  The decoration may be left <a href="#blind">blind</a>, or embellished with <a href="#ink">ink</a>, silver, or <a href="#goldleaf">gold leaf</a>.  Synonymous with <em><a href="#plaquette">plaquette</a> binding</em>.  Compare with <a href="#centerpiece">centerpiece</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cameostamp"><b>cameo stamp</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, a metal tool of oval shape, <a href="#engraving">engraved</a> with a design, usually in the form of a <a href="#picture">picture</a>, used from the 11th to 16th century in <a href="#blind">blind</a> <a href="#tooling">tooling</a> to make an <a href="#impression">impression</a> resembling cameo jewelry on the side of a <a href="#leatherbound">leather-bound</a> <a href="#book">book</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cameobinding">cameo binding</a>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cameramicrofilm"><b>camera microfilm</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#reprography">reprography</a>, an image of an <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#sourcedocument">source document</a>, made with a camera on high-quality <a href="#film">film</a>, usually retained by the producer for the purpose of making <a href="#archives">archival</a> or distribution <a href="#copy">copies</a>.  Synonymous with <em>first <a href="#generation">generation</a></em> and <em><a href="#masternegative">master negative</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cameraready"><b>camera-ready copy (CRC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#copy">copy</a> typed using <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#software">software</a>, or produced by some other means, which has been fully <a href="#editing">edited</a> and is ready to be <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ed for <a href="#plate">plate</a>making without having to be <a href="#typesetting">typeset</a>.  Synonymous with <em>camera copy</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="canadianbooksellers"><b>Canadian Booksellers Association (CBA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonprofit national <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a>
devoted to promoting the current and future interests of the
bookselling industry in Canada and to meeting the needs of Canadian <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s.  Its members include over 1200 <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s and over 350 <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s across Canada.  <b>CBA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> <em>Canadian Bookseller</em> in nine <a href="#issue">issue</a>s per year.  <a href="http://www.cbabook.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CBA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="canadianla"><b>Canadian Library Association(CLA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1946, <b>CLA</b> has a membership of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and other persons involved or interested in <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>, and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a> in Canada.  An <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>CLA</b> sponsors a national <a href="#libconference">conference</a> held at a different location in Canada each year.  <b>CLA</b> is also <a href="#copublishing">co-publisher</a> with the ALA and the <a href="#la">Library Association</a> (UK) of <em><a href="#anglo">Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.cla.ca/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cpc"><b>Canadian Publishers' Council (CPC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1910, <b>CPC</b> is a <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a> representing the interests of Canadian <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s of English-<a href="#language">language</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#media">media</a> for schools, colleges and universities, professional and <a href="#refbook">reference</a> markets, and the retail and <a href="#library">library</a> sectors.  Located in Toronto, <b>CPC</b> also represents the Canadian <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> industry internationally and maintains a liaison with the <a href="#aap">Association of American Publishers</a>.  <a href="http://www.pubcouncil.ca/home.htm">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CPC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cancel"><b>cancel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A new <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> or leaves <a href="#printing">printed</a> to replace part of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> when changes are required in the <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, usually before <a href="#binding">binding</a> but after the <a href="#work">work</a> has <a href="#gonetopress">gone to press</a>,
more common in the 17th and 18th centuries than today because as
printing developed, the frequency of printing errors declined.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cancellationperiod"><b>cancellation period</b></a>
</dt><dd>The period of time a <a href="#library">library</a> allows a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, or other <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> for <a href="#shipping">shipment</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#bibitem">item</a> before the order is automatically <a href="#canceled">canceled</a>, usually 90-180 days.  The item may subsequently be reordered from the same vendor, or a different source.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="canceled"><b>canceled</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a regular order, <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>, or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> terminated for some reason by the <a href="#library">library</a> or the seller.  A nonserial <a href="#bibitem">item</a> may be <a href="#reorder">reorder</a>ed if it is still available.  Library <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> of a canceled <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#title">title</a> are <a href="#note">note</a>d in the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> in a <a href="#closedentry">closed entry</a>.  <a href="#serialcancel">Serial cancellation</a>s have increased in recent years, particularly in <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, due to the rising cost of <a href="#print">print</a> subscriptions and the availability of <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> in periodical <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#discontinued">discontinued</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="candidate"><b>candidate</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person whose <a href="#application">application</a> for employment has been accepted and who is being seriously considered for a <a href="#position">position</a>.
Also refers to a person taking an examination, running for an elected
office, considered for an award or degree, or destined for a particular
purpose or fate. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#shortlist">short list</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="canon"><b>canon</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#literature">literature</a>, the accepted list of <a href="#work">work</a>s by a given <a href="#author">author</a>, considered by scholars to be <a href="#authenticity">authentic</a>, for example, the thirty-seven <a href="#play">play</a>s of William Shakespeare.  Also refers to the approved list of works included in the Christian <b><em>Bible</em></b>.  In the most general sense, a criterion or <a href="#standard">standard</a> of judgment applied for the purpose of evaluation.  Compare with <a href="#apocryphal">apocryphal</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#canonicalorder">canonical order</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="canonicalorder"><b>canonical order</b></a>
</dt><dd>The arrangement of <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, parts, divisions, or items in an order established by law or tradition, the classic example being the sequence of the <a href="#book">book</a>s of the Christian <b><em>Bible</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="canto"><b>canto</b></a>
