</dt><dd>A major subdivision of a long <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> or <a href="#epic">epic</a> <a href="#poetry">poem</a>, serving the same function as a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> in a <a href="#novel">novel</a>.  Cantos are traditionally <a href="#number">number</a>ed in <a href="#romannumeral">roman numeral</a>s.  Examples of <a href="#work">work</a>s divided in this way are Dante's <b><em>Divina Commedia</em></b>, Spenser's <b><em>Faerie Queene</em></b>, and Byron's <b><em>Don Juan</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="capitalexp"><b>capital expenditure</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#budget">budget</a>ing, an <a href="#allocation">allocation</a> made on a one-time basis, usually for the construction of <a href="#newconstruc">new facilities</a>, the <a href="#renovation">renovation</a> or <a href="#expansion">expansion</a> existing facilities, or a major <a href="#upgrade">upgrade</a> of automation equipment or systems, as opposed to the <a href="#operatingbudget">operating budget</a> allocated <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly or <a href="#biennial">biennial</a>ly to meet ongoing expenses incurred in running a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="capitalimprovement"><b>capital improvement</b></a>
</dt><dd>The acquisition of a long-term asset, such as a <a href="#newconstruc">new</a> or <a href="#renovation">renovated</a> facility, initial <a href="#bookstock">book stock</a>, or new <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, furnishings, or vehicle(s), funded on a one-time basis from a <a href="#budget">budget</a> for <a href="#capitalexp">capital expenditure</a>s, as distinct from the ongoing purchase of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, payment of <a href="#salary">salaries</a> and <a href="#wages">wages</a>, routine repair and replacement of existing equipment and furnishings, and regular maintenance of facilities, funded from the <a href="#operatingbudget">operating budget</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="capitalization"><b>capitalization</b></a>
</dt><dd>The writing or <a href="#printing">printing</a> of a <a href="#letter">letter</a>, word, or words in <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a>, rather than <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a>.  Also refers to the conventions in a <a href="#language">language</a>
with respect to words written or printed with certain letters in
uppercase. For example, in English the first letter of the first word
of a paragraph, and of each of the parts of a <a href="#propername">proper name</a>, is normally <em>capitalized</em> (unless you are a cockroach and not heavy enough to depress the "Caps" key).  The general rules governing capitalization in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> <a href="#entry">entries</a> can be found in <em>Appendix A</em> of <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="capitalletter"><b>capital letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large <a href="#letter">letter</a> of the roman <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> (<b>A</b>, <b>B</b>, <b>C</b>, etc.) which prior to the 4th century A.D. consisted of capitals only.  The name is derived from the lapidary Roman <a href="#letterform">letterform</a>s incised with a chisel at the top (<em>capital</em>) of architectural columns and on other stone monuments.  Also, any letter written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> in a form larger and usually different from that of the corresponding small letter.  Abbreviated <em>cap</em>.  Synonymous with <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a>.  Compare with <a href="#majuscule">majuscule</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#capitalization">capitalization</a>, <a href="#capline">cap line</a>, <a href="#rusticcapital">rustic capital</a>, <a href="#smallcapital">small capital</a>, and <a href="#squarecapital">square capital</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="capline"><b>cap line</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typography">typography</a>, the imaginary horizontal line connecting the tops of the <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of a <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#font">font</a>, often, but not necessarily, the same as the <a href="#ascender">ascender</a> line.  Compare with <a href="#meanline">mean line</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#baseline">base line</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="caps"><b>caps</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="capsa"><b>capsa</b></a>
</dt><dd>A box of cylindrical shape used in ancient <a href="#library">libraries</a> to store <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>s in an upright position.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#scrinium">scrinium</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="caption"><b>caption</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin word for "capture" or "seizure."  A brief <a href="#title">title</a>, explanation, or description appearing immediately above, beneath, or adjacent to an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> or <a href="#photograph">photograph</a> on a <a href="#page">page</a>, sometimes indicating the source of the image.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>cut line</em> or <a href="#legend">legend</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#heading">heading</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the beginning of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or other section of a <a href="#book">book</a>, and to the <a href="#headline">headline</a> at the beginning of the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#article">article</a>, or section of it.  
</p><p>
In <a href="#microform">microform</a>s, a <a href="#title">title</a> or brief line of description in a <a href="#typesize">type size</a> large enough to enable the viewer to identify the <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ed <a href="#document">document</a> without the aid of magnification.  In <a href="#film">film</a>s and <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>s, a line of text at the bottom of a <a href="#frame">frame</a> or sequence of frames, identifying or explaining the <a href="#content">content</a>.  A continuously moving line of text at the bottom of television screen is called a <em>crawl</em>.  Compare with <a href="#subtitle">subtitle</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#closedcaption">closed caption</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="captiontitle"><b>caption title</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#title">title</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the beginning of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>, <a href="#section">section</a>, or other major division of a <a href="#book">book</a>, or at the beginning of the first <a href="#page">page</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a>, which, in the absence of a <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, is sometimes used as the title of the whole in creating the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  The <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> usually adds "caption title" as a <a href="#note">note</a> in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> to indicate its source.  In a musical <a href="#score">score</a>, the title that appears immediately above the opening bars may be used as the <a href="#caption">caption</a> title.  Synonymous with <em>head title</em>.  Compare with <a href="#dropdowntitle">drop-down title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cardcatalog"><b>card catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>, <a href="#printing">printed</a>, typed, or handwritten on <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a>s, each representing a single <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> in the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  Catalog cards are normally filed in a single <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> sequence (<a href="#dictionarycatalog">dictionary catalog</a>), or in separate sections by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, and <a href="#subject">subject</a> (<a href="#dividedcatalog">divided catalog</a>),
in the long narrow drawers of a specially designed filing cabinet,
usually constructed of wood. Most large and medium-sized libraries in
the United States have <a href="#retrocon">converted</a> their card catalogs to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> format.  Also spelled <em>card catalogue</em>.  Compare with <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="caricature"><b>caricature</b></a>
</dt><dd>A deliberately distorted <a href="#picture">picture</a> of a
person, or imitation of a performance or literary style, achieved by
grossly exaggerating certain features or mannerisms peculiar to the
object of <a href="#satire">satire</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a> and <a href="#lampoon">lampoon</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="carnegielibrary"><b>Carnegie library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> facility constructed wholly or in part with <a href="#grant">grant</a>
funds provided by the American steel magnate and philanthropist Andrew
Carnegie (1835-1919) who, in his later years, devoted his considerable
wealth to the promotion of libraries and world peace. Between 1881 and
1917, over 2,500 Carnegie libraries were built around the world, the
majority in the United States, United Kingdom, and Canada. The
libraries of many small towns in the United States still occupy
facilities built with Carnegie funds. <a href="http://www.andrewcarnegie.cc/">Click here</a> to learn more about the Carnegie library formula.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#carnegiemedal">Carnegie Medal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="carnegiemedal"><b>Carnegie Medal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a> presented <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly since 1936 by the <a href="#la">Library Association</a> of the United Kingdom to the <a href="#author">author</a> of the most outstanding English-<a href="#language">language</a> <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a>
in the U.K. during the preceding year. The prize is named after the
American steel magnate and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie (1835-1919)
who devoted the last years of his life to the advancement of <a href="#library">libraries</a> and world peace.  <a href="http://www.acs.ucalgary.ca/%7Edkbrown/awards.html">Click here</a> to view a list of Carnegie Medal winners.  Compare with <a href="#greenaway">Greenaway Medal</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#clabook">CLA Book of the Year for Children</a> and <a href="#newbery">Newbery Medal</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="carolingian"><b>Carolingian minuscule</b></a>
</dt><dd>The first <a href="#script">script</a> to introduce small <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, Carolingian <a href="#minuscule">minuscule</a>
was developed in the late 8th century by Alcuin of York, Abbot of St.
Martin's at Tours, in response to Charlemagne's desire for a standard <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> in which <a href="#book">book</a>s of the Catholic Church could be <a href="#copy">copied</a> throughout his realm.  It quickly became the dominant <a href="#bookhand">book hand</a> in Europe where it was used through the 11th century and adopted in England following the Norman Conquest.  Its <a href="#letterform">letterform</a>s are wide and curved, with <a href="#ligature">ligature</a>s sparingly used, each letter written separately.  Carolingian style <a href="#standardization">standardized</a> the practice of beginning each sentence with a single <a href="#majuscule">majuscule</a> and completing it in minuscules, and formed the basis for the <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> letterforms developed after the invention of <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>.  Synonymous with <em>Caroline minuscule</em>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="carousel"><b>carousel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A detachable, circular slotted container, usually made of plastic, in which dozens of <a href="#slide">slide</a>s
can be queued for sequential viewing on a specially-designed slide
projector. Although carousels are bulky, they can also be used to store
slides when not in use. Compare with <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="carrel"><b>carrel</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally a small stall or pew in a medieval cloister
containing a desk for reading, writing, and semi-private study. In
modern <a href="#library">libraries</a>, a small room or <a href="#alcove">alcove</a> in the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a>
designed for individual study. Also refers to a free-standing desk (or
two desks face-to-face) with low partitions at back and sides to
provide some degree of privacy, with a shelf across the back facing the
<a href="#reader">reader</a>.  Newer study carrels have built-in illumination and may be wired to provide <a href="#network">network</a> <a href="#access">access</a> for <a href="#patron">patron</a>s using <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cartobibliography"><b>cartobibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of references to <a href="#map">map</a>s and/or <a href="#work">work</a>s about maps, arranged in some kind of order, with or without <a href="#annotation">annotation</a>s.  Also, the branch of <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> pertaining to maps and mapping.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cartographic">cartographic material</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cartogram"><b>cartogram</b></a>
</dt><dd>A simplified <a href="#map">map</a> in which the size, outline, or location of geographic features is altered or exaggerated to <a href="#illustration">illustrate</a> <a href="#diagram">diagram</a>matically a principal concept or set of statistical <a href="#data">data</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cartographic"><b>cartographic material</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any representation of part or all of the surface of the earth or any other celestial body (real or imaginary) on any <a href="#scale">scale</a>, including two- and three-dimensional <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>es, <a href="#globe">globe</a>s, aeronautical and navigational <a href="#chart">chart</a>s, <a href="#aerialmap">aerial photograph</a>s, <a href="#section">section</a>s, <a href="#cartogram">cartogram</a>s, bird's-eye views, etc.  In the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing a cartographic <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, the nature of the material is <a href="#bibdescrip">described</a> in the <a href="#materialspecific">material specific details</a> <a href="#area">area</a> (MSD).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cartography">cartography</a> and <a href="#maplibrary">map library</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cartography"><b>cartography</b></a>
</dt><dd>The art and craft of making <a href="#map">map</a>s and other <a href="#cartographic">cartographic material</a>s.  A person who makes or produces maps is a <em>cartographer</em>.  Synonymous with <em>mapmaking</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cartobibliography">cartobibliography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cartoon"><b>cartoon</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ic or representational drawing in one or more <a href="#panel">panel</a>s, intended to <a href="#caricature">caricature</a> a person or institution, or <a href="#satire">satirize</a> in a witty and imaginative way an action or situation of current popular interest.  Usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> or <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, cartoons may be <a href="#caption">caption</a>ed or use <a href="#balloon">balloon</a>s to convey <a href="#monologue">monologue</a> or <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a>.  Political cartoons usually appear on or near the <a href="#editorial">editorial page</a> of a newspaper.  Successful <em>cartoonists</em> are often <a href="#syndicate">syndicate</a>d.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/exhibits/oliphant/">Click here</a> to see an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> of political cartoons by Pat Oliphant on the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> <a href="#website">Web site</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#comicbook">comic book</a> and <a href="#lampoon">lampoon</a>.
<p>
Also refers to an <a href="#animation">animated</a> <a href="#film">film</a> created by <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ing a series of drawings done as individual <a href="#cel">cel</a>s, and then <a href="#editing">editing</a> the images into a sequence of <a href="#frame">frame</a>s which, when viewed in rapid succession, create the illusion of continuous motion.  
</p><p>
In art, a full-sized drawing done on <a href="#paper">paper</a> as a preliminary <a href="#draft">draft</a>,
to be transferred to a large working surface, sometimes in sections, a
technique used in creating large frescoes, tapestries, and stained
glass windows.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cartouche"><b>cartouche</b></a>
</dt><dd>An ornamental <a href="#frame">frame</a> in the form of a <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>, drawn or <a href="#printing">printed</a> in the corner of a <a href="#map">map</a> around an <a href="#inscription">inscription</a> giving the map's <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#subject">subject</a>, name of <a href="#cartography">cartographer</a>, <a href="#scale">scale</a>, and other descriptive <a href="#information">information</a>.  In older maps, the cartouche often includes decorative elements.  Sometimes seen on older <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="case"><b>case</b></a>
</dt><dd>In machine <a href="#binding">binding</a>, a <a href="#cover">cover</a> made completely before it is attached to the <a href="#body">body</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, consisting of two <a href="#board">board</a>s and a <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#inlay">inlay</a> covered in book <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> or some other protective material.  The <a href="#publishersbinding">edition</a> <a href="#binder">binder</a> submits a <em>specimen case</em> to the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> for approval showing the size, boards, covering, <a href="#lettering">lettering</a>, and <a href="#squares">squares</a>.  The process of attaching the case to the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> by <a href="#pastingdown">pasting down</a> the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s is called <em>casing-in</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#casebinding">case binding</a> and <a href="#recased">recased</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a container used by a <a href="#typesetting">typesetter</a> to hold <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>.  The words <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> and <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> are derived from the relative positions of the compartments used to store the two kinds of <a href="#type">type</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="casebinding"><b>case binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> in which a hard <a href="#cover">cover</a>, called a <a href="#case">case</a>, consisting of two <a href="#board">board</a>s and an <a href="#inlay">inlay</a> covered in <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>, <a href="#leather">leather</a>, or <a href="#paper">paper</a>, is manufactured separately from the <a href="#book">book</a> and subsequently attached to it.  The process of attaching the case to the <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> and <a href="#gluingoff">glued</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s by <a href="#pastingdown">pasting</a> the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s to the boards is called <em>casing-in</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#recased">recased</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="casebook"><b>casebook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> containing <a href="#records">records</a> or descriptions of actual cases that have occurred in a professional <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>
(law, medicine, psychology, sociology, social work, counseling, etc.),
selected to illustrate important principles and concepts, for the use
of students as a <a href="#textbook">textbook</a> and practitioners for <a href="#refbook">reference</a>.  Compare with <a href="#casestudy">case study</a> 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cased"><b>cased</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#casebinding">case binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="casesensitive"><b>case-sensitive</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer system or <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> in which <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> letters (<b>A</b>, <b>B</b>, <b>C</b>...) and <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> letters (<b>a</b>, <b>b</b>, <b>c</b>...) are <em>not</em> interchangeable as <a href="#input">input</a> (<b>JAVA</b> versus <b>java</b>). On the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, <a href="#www">Web</a> addresses (<a href="#url">URL</a>s) are case-sensitive, but <a href="#email">e-mail</a> <a href="#internetaddress">address</a>es and <a href="#filename">filename</a>s usually are not.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="casestudy"><b>case study</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the social and medical sciences, analysis of the behavior
of one individual in a population, or a single event in a series, based
on close observation over a period of time. A case study may be <a href="#publishing">published</a> as an <a href="#article">article</a> in a <a href="#journal">journal</a>, as an <a href="#essay">essay</a> in a <a href="#collection">collection</a>, or in <a href="#book">book</a> form.  In <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s that permit the user to <a href="#limiting">limit</a> retrieval by type of publication, case studies may be one of the <a href="#option">option</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>PsycINFO</em></b>).  Compare with <a href="#casebook">casebook</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="casingin"><b>casing-in</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#casebinding">case binding</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catalog"><b>catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> list of the <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in a given <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, arranged in systematic order to facilitate <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a> (usually <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, and/or <a href="#subject">subject</a>).  In most modern <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the <a href="#cardcatalog">card catalog</a> has been <a href="#retrocon">converted</a> to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s and is available <a href="#online">online</a>.  The purpose of a library catalog, as stated by Charles C. Cutter in <b><em>Rules for a Dictionary Catalog</em></b> (1904) later modified by Bohdan S. Wynar in <b><em>Introduction to Cataloging and Classification</em></b> (<em>Seventh ed., 1985</em>), is to offer the user a variety of approaches or <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s to the <a href="#information">information</a> contained in the collection:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>Objects:</b>
<dl><dt></dt><dd>1)  To enable a person to find any work, whether <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#printing">print</a> or in <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, when one of the following is known:
<dl><dt></dt><dd>a)  The author
</dd><dd>b)  The title
</dd><dd>c)  The subject</dd></dl>
</dd><dd>2)  To show what the library has
<dl><dt></dt><dd>d)  By a given author
</dd><dd>e)  On a given and related subjects
</dd><dd>f)  In a given kind of <a href="#literature">literature</a></dd></dl>
</dd><dd>3)  To assist in the choice of a work
<dl><dt></dt><dd>g)  As to the bibliographic <a href="#edition">edition</a>
</dd><dd>h)  As to its character (<a href="#literarywork">literary</a> or <a href="#topic">topic</a>al).</dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl> 
<p>
The preparation of <a href="#entry">entries</a> for a library catalog (called <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>) is performed by a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> known as a <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>.  British spelling is <em>catalogue</em>.  Compare with <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> and <a href="#index">index</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#classifiedcatalog">classified catalog</a>, <a href="#dictionarycatalog">dictionary catalog</a>, <a href="#dividedcatalog">divided catalog</a>, and <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>. 
</p><p>
In a more general sense, any list of materials systematically prepared for a specific purpose, such as a <a href="#publisherscatalog">publisher's catalog</a>, <a href="#exhibitcatalog">exhibition catalog</a>, or <a href="#film">film</a> rental catalog.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catalogcard"><b>catalog card</b></a>
</dt><dd>In manual <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> systems, a <a href="#paper">paper</a> card used to make a handwritten, typed, or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#cardcatalog">card catalog</a>, usually of <a href="#standard">standard</a> size (7.5 cm high and 12.5 cm wide), plain or <a href="#rule">rule</a>d.  With the <a href="#retrocon">conversion</a> of paper <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s to <a href="#machinereadable">machine readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a> and the use of <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s, <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> cards have fallen into disuse.  British spelling is <em>catalogue card</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catalogcode"><b>catalog code</b></a>
</dt><dd>A detailed set of rules for preparing <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s to represent <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s added to a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, established to maintain consistency within the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> and between the catalogs of <a href="#library">libraries</a> using the same code.  In the United States, Great Britain, and Canada, libraries use the <em><a href="#anglo">Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</a></em> developed jointly by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <a href="#la">Library Association</a> (UK), and <a href="#canadianla">Canadian Library Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cataloger"><b>cataloger</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> primarily responsible for preparing <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s to represent the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#acquisitions">acquired</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a>, including <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, <a href="#subjectanalysis">subject analysis</a>, and <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a>.  Also refers to the librarian responsible for supervising a <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> department.  British spelling is <em>cataloguer</em>.  Synonymous with <em>catalog librarian</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:   <a href="#alcts">Association for Library Collections and Technical Services</a> and <em><a href="#catalogersdesktop">Cataloger's Desktop</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catalogersdesktop"><b><em>Cataloger's Desktop</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publishing">Published</a> on a single <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, <b><em>Cataloger's Desktop</em></b> is a product of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> that provides basic <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> <a href="#documentation">documentation</a> (including <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#format">format</a>s), the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress Subject Headings</a> list, <a href="#cuttersanborn">Cutter table</a>, and much more, based on the 1998 revision of <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, including all Amendments.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/cds/cdroms1.html">Click here</a> to learn more about <b><em>Cataloger's Desktop</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cataloging"><b>cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of creating <a href="#entry">entries</a> for a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, this usually includes <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, <a href="#subjectanalysis">subject analysis</a>, assignment of <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> <a href="#notation">notation</a>, and all the activities involved in physically preparing the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> for the shelf, tasks usually performed under the supervision of a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> trained as a <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>.  British spelling is <em>cataloguing</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#catagency">cataloging agency</a>, <a href="#cip">cataloging-in-publication</a>, <a href="#centralizedcat">centralized cataloging</a>, <a href="#collectivecat">collective cataloging</a>, <a href="#cooperativecat">cooperative cataloging</a>, <a href="#copycataloging">copy cataloging</a>, <a href="#descripcatalog">descriptive cataloging</a>, <a href="#encodinglevel">encoding level</a>, and <a href="#recataloging">recataloging</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catagency"><b>cataloging agency</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> or other institution that provides <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> <a href="#data">data</a> in the form of new <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s
and modifications of existing records, for the use of other libraries.
In the United States, the leading source of cataloging data is the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  In the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record, the identity of the cataloging <a href="#agency">agency</a> is indicated by its three-letter <a href="#oclcsymbol">OCLC symbol</a> in the <a href="#catsource">cataloging source</a> <a href="#field">field</a> (<em>example</em>: <b>DLC</b> for Library of Congress). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cds"><b>Cataloging Distribution Service (CDS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#govtagency">agency</a> within the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> that develops and markets, on a <a href="#costrecovery">cost-recovery</a> basis, bibliographic products and services that provide <a href="#access">access</a> to its resources for <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States, the American public, and the international <a href="#information">information</a> community.  To accomplish its <a href="#goal">goal</a>s, the <b>CDS</b> employs <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s,
product developers, systems analysts, programmers, operators,
marketers, shippers, customer service representatives, accountants, and
production staff. <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/cds/cdsintro.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CDS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cip"><b>cataloging-in-publication (CIP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#prepublication">prepublication</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> program in which participating <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s complete a <a href="#standardization">standardized</a> <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> and submit it with the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> or entire <a href="#text">text</a> of <a href="#newbook">new book</a> (usually still in <a href="#galley">galleys</a>) to the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> for use in assigning an <a href="#lccn">LCCN</a> and preparing a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> which is sent back to the publisher within ten days to be <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  The Library of Congress distributes <b>CIP</b> records to large libraries, <a href="#bibutility">bibliographic utilities</a>, and book vendors on a weekly basis to facilitate <a href="#book">book</a> processing.  If incomplete, the initial record may be amended by the Library of Congress after the <a href="#usco">U.S. Copyright Office</a> receives the <a href="#depositcopy">deposit copy</a> of the <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>.  The CIP Program began at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> in 1971 and is used throughout the world.  British spelling is <em>cataloguing-in-publication</em>.  <a href="http://cip.loc.gov/cip/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CIP</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cataloginglevel"><b>cataloging level</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#encodinglevel">encoding level</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catsource"><b>cataloging source</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#field">Field</a> (040) of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record, reserved for the three-<a href="#letter">letter</a> <a href="#oclcsymbol">OCLC symbol</a> representing the <a href="#catagency">cataloging agency</a> that created, transcribed, or modified the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>DLC</b> for <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>).  If English is not the <a href="#language">language</a> of the <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> agency, the 040 field may also contain <a href="#information">information</a> about the language in which the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is cataloged.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catalogrecord"><b>catalog record</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the manual <a href="#cardcatalog">card catalog</a>, all the <a href="#information">information</a> given on a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a>, including a <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a> of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, the <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a>, any <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a> and <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s, <a href="#note">note</a>s, and the <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>.  In the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>, the screen display that represents most fully a specific <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, including <a href="#element">element</a>s of description and <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s taken from the complete <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, as well as information about the <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> of the local library or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> (<a href="#copy">copies</a>, <a href="#locationsymbol">location</a>, call number, <a href="#circstatus">status</a>, etc.) taken from the <a href="#itemrecord">item record</a>s attached to the bibliographic record.  British spelling is <em>catalogue record</em>.  Compare with <a href="#entry">entry</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catchletters"><b>catch letters</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sequence of <a href="#letter">letter</a>s (usually three) <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the top of a <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>, <a href="#gazetteer">gazetteer</a>, or similar <a href="#work">work</a>, which duplicate the first few letters of the first or last word on the <a href="#page">page</a>.  Those printed on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> indicate the first letters of the <em>first</em> word on the page; those on the <a href="#recto">recto</a>, the first letters of the <em>last</em> word on the page.  In some <a href="#work">work</a>s, the letters appear in two groups separated by a <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a>, representing the first <em>and</em> last words on the page.  Compare with <a href="#catchword">catchword</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catchstitch"><b>catch stitch</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#kettle">kettle stitch</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catchtitle"><b>catch title</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#catchwordtitle">catchword title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catchword"><b>catchword</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word or part of a word <a href="#printing">printed</a> in <a href="#boldface">boldface</a> or <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> at the top of a <a href="#column">column</a> or <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> or <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>, which repeats the first and/or last <a href="#heading">heading</a> appearing in the column or on the page.  Synonymous with <em>guideword</em>.  Compare in this sense with <a href="#catchletters">catch letters</a>.  
<p>
In medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s,
a word or part of a word given below the last line on a page, which
repeats the first word on the following page to enable the <a href="#binding">binder</a> to assemble the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> in correct sequence.  
</p><p>
Also refers to a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> repeated so frequently that it has become a motto or slogan.  Compare in this sense with <a href="#cliche">cliche</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catchwordtitle"><b>catchword title</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#partialtitle">partial title</a> composed of an easily remembered word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> likely to be used as a <a href="#heading">heading</a> or <a href="#keywords">keyword</a> in a <a href="#search">search</a> of the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, sometimes the same as a <a href="#subtitle">subtitle</a> or the <a href="#alternativetitle">alternative title</a>.  Synonymous with <em>catch title</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cathedral"><b>cathedral binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> or <a href="#leather">leather</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>
decorated with architectural motifs of the Gothic period, sometimes
even including a rose window, popular in France and England from about
1815 to 1840 when interest in Gothic art underwent a revival.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cla"><b>Catholic Library Association (CLA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1921, <b>CLA</b> has a membership of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, teachers, and <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s involved with Catholic <a href="#library">libraries</a> and the writing, <a href="#publication">publication</a>, and distribution of Catholic <a href="#literature">literature</a>.  <b>CLA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em>Catholic Library World</em>.  <a href="http://www.cathla.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="catme"><b><em>CatME</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#oclc">OCLC</a>'s <em><b>Cat</b>aloging <b>M</b>icro <b>E</b>nhancer</em>, <a href="#software">software</a> that enables <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s to <a href="#search">search</a> the <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> and <em>OCLC Authority File</em> <a href="#interactive">interactive</a>ly <a href="#online">online</a>, edit <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic</a> and <a href="#authorityrecord">authority record</a>s <a href="#offline">offline</a>, and send <a href="#update">update</a>s to OCLC in <a href="#batchprocessing">batches</a> to increase <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> efficiency and reduce costs.  <a href="http://www.oclc.org/catme/">Click here</a> to learn more about <b><em>CatME</em></b>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="caucus"><b>caucus</b></a>
</dt><dd>An interest group within a political faction or party,
legislative body, or organization, formed (sometimes spontaneously) to
address an immediate need for action on a given issue or series of
related issues, usually by formulating policy, supporting candidates
for political office, drafting campaign strategy, lobbying, etc. (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#bcala">Black Caucus of the ALA</a>). Compare with <a href="#taskforce">task force</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="causalrelation"><b>causal relation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="caxton"><b>Caxton, William, c. 1422?-1491</b></a>
</dt><dd>England's first <a href="#printer">printer</a>, <b>Caxton</b> learned the trade relatively late in life while living in Cologne and Bruges.  He brought the first <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a> to England and installed it in the Chapter House at Westminster Abbey, <a href="#issue">issuing</a> the first <a href="#publicationdate">dated</a> <a href="#book">book</a> known to have been <a href="#printing">printed</a> in England (probably his <em>The Dictes and Sayings of the Philosophers</em>) in 1477.  By the time he died in 1491, his press had issued approximately one hundred <a href="#work">work</a>s, including <a href="#folio">folio</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s of Chaucer's <em>Canterbury Tales</em> (1478) and Mallory's <em>Morte D'Arthur</em> (1485) which he sold to English <a href="#reader">reader</a>s in <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#copy">copies</a>.  He was an expert <a href="#editor">editor</a> and <a href="#translation">translated</a> into English many of the works he printed.  For a succinct, informative <a href="#essay">essay</a> on the life and work of <b>William Caxton</b>, see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> under his name in Geoffrey Glaister's <b><em>Encyclopedia of the Book</em></b> (Oak Knoll: 1996). <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#gutenberg">Gutenberg, Johann</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cba1"><b>CBA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#canadianbooksellers"><b>C</b>anadian <b>B</b>ooksellers <b>A</b>ssociation</a> and <a href="#cba"><b>C</b>enter for <b>B</b>ook <b>A</b>rts</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cbc1"><b>CBC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cbc"><b>C</b>hildren's <b>B</b>ook <b>C</b>ouncil</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cbip1"><b>CBIP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cbip"><b>C</b>hildren's <b>B</b>ooks <b>i</b>n <b>P</b>rint</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cc"><b>CC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#closedcaption"><b>c</b>losed <b>c</b>aption</a> and <a href="#commoncarrier"><b>c</b>ommon <b>c</b>arrier</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ccc1"><b>CCC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ccc"><b>C</b>opyright <b>C</b>learance <b>C</b>enter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cctv"><b>CCTV</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#closedcircuit"><b>c</b>losed <b>c</b>ircuit <b>t</b>ele<b>v</b>ision</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cd"><b>CD</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#compactdisc"><b>c</b>ompact <b>d</b>isc</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cdrom"><b>CD-ROM</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>C</b>ompact <b>D</b>isc-<b>R</b>ead <b>O</b>nly <b>M</b>emory (pronounced "see dee rom"), a small plastic <a href="#opticaldisk">optical disk</a> similar to an audio <a href="#compactdisc">compact disk</a>, measuring 4.72 inches (12 centimeters) in diameter, used as a <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> and for storing <a href="#information">information</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  Stamped by the producer on the metallic surface, the <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#encoding">encoded</a> on a CD-ROM can be <a href="#search">search</a>ed and displayed on a computer screen, but not changed or erased.  The <a href="#disc">disc</a> is read by a small laser beam inside a <a href="#device">device</a> called a <a href="#cdromdrive">CD-ROM drive</a>.  
<p>
Each disc has the capacity to store 650 <a href="#byte">megabyte</a>s of data, the equivalent of 250,000-300,000 <a href="#page">page</a>s of <a href="#text">text</a> or approximately 1,000 <a href="#book">book</a>s of average length.  CD-ROMs can be used to  store <a href="#soundtrack">sound track</a>s, still or moving images, and computer <a href="#file">file</a>s, as well as text.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, CD-ROMs are used primarily as a <a href="#storage">storage</a> medium for <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s and <a href="#fulltext">full text</a> resources, mostly <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a>, <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s and other <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#worm">WORM</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#cdromdrive">CD-ROM drive</a>, <a href="#cdromtower">CD-ROM tower</a>, and <a href="#cdromnetwork">CD-ROM network</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cdromchanger"><b>CD-ROM changer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> <a href="#device">device</a> designed to store a small number of <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>s or <a href="#disc">disc</a> modules, with carousels and robot arms to move one disc at a time to an optical or magnetic reader, and back to its <a href="#storage">storage</a> location.  Colloquially known as a <em>jukebox</em>.  Compare with <a href="#cdromdrive">CD-ROM drive</a> and <a href="#cdromtower">CD-ROM tower</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cdromdrive"><b>CD-ROM drive</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> component designed to read <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#record">record</a>ed on a <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> <a href="#disc">disc</a>, originally an external <a href="#device">device</a>, but built into most newer <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a>s.  CD-ROM drives can also be used to play audio <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>s when attached to a sound card via cable.  Compare with <a href="#cdromchanger">CD-ROM changer</a> and <a href="#cdromtower">CD-ROM tower</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cdromlan"><b>CD-ROM LAN</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cdromnetwork">CD-ROM network</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cdromnetwork"><b>CD-ROM network</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#clientserver">client-server</a> system that makes multiple <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> <a href="#disc">disc</a>s stored in a <a href="#cdromtower">CD-ROM tower</a> <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> to users <a href="#authorization">authorized</a> to <a href="#logon">log on</a> to a computer <a href="#network">network</a>.  Most <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s available on CD-ROM require special <a href="#licensing">licensing</a> for network access.  Synonymous with CD-ROM <a href="#localarea">LAN</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cdromtower"><b>CD-ROM tower</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> <a href="#device">device</a> designed to store a large number of <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> <a href="#disc">disc</a>s, usually connected to a <a href="#server">server</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>med to handle <a href="#cdromnetwork">network</a> <a href="#access">access</a>.  Compare with <a href="#cdromdrive">CD-ROM drive</a> and <a href="#cdromchanger">CD-ROM changer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cds1"><b>CDS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cds"><b>C</b>ataloging <b>D</b>istribution <b>S</b>ervice</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ceased"><b>ceased publication</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> no longer <a href="#publishing">published</a>.  <a href="#publication">Publication</a> may start up again under the same <a href="#title">title</a> or an altered title.  Also said of a <a href="#work">work</a> published in more than one <a href="#volume">volume</a>, which was never completed.  <a href="#library">Library</a> <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> are indicated in a <a href="#closedentry">closed entry</a>.  Compare with <a href="#canceled">canceled</a> and <a href="#discontinued">discontinued</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#cessation">cessation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cel"><b>cel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thin <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of transparent material of <a href="#standards">standard</a> size (usually acetate), having the same proportions as a <a href="#frame">frame</a> of <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> <a href="#film">film</a>, on which is drawn or painted a single image in a sequence of <a href="#animation">animation</a>.  <a href="#original">Original</a> cels from early animated films may have independent value as <a href="#work">work</a>s of art.  Also refers to a transparent sheet used as an overlay against an opaque background, as in <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s on anatomy to show in layers the various systems of the human body (circulatory, nervous, skeletal, etc.). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cell"><b>cell</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#alcove">alcove</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cellulose"><b>cellulose</b></a>
</dt><dd>The fibrous vegetable material used in <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, derived primarily from wood pulp, but formerly from cotton or linen <a href="#ragpaper">rag</a>s.  The cellulose in <a href="#paper">paper</a> and <a href="#board">board</a> made from wood pulp is weakened over time by the presence of <a href="#acidic">acid</a> unless <a href="#lignin">lignin</a> is removed in manufacture and an <a href="#alkaline">alkaline</a> <a href="#buffer">buffer</a> added.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cellulosenitrate"><b>cellulose nitrate film</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nitratefilm">nitrate film</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="censorship"><b>censorship</b></a>
</dt><dd>Prohibition of the production, distribution, circulation, or display of a <a href="#work">work</a>
by a governing authority on grounds that it contains objectionable or
dangerous material. The person who decides what is to be prohibited is
called a <em>censor</em>. Commonly used methods include decree and
confiscation, legislation, repressive taxation, and licensing to grant
or restrict the right to <a href="#publishing">publish</a>.  
<p>
The <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/ethics.html">ALA Code of Ethics</a></em> places an ethical responsibility on its members to resist censorship of <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> and programs in any form, and to support <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and other <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> who put their careers at risk by defending <a href="#library">library</a> policies against censorship.  Compare with <a href="#suppressed">suppressed</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#banned">banned book</a>, <a href="#bookburning">book burning</a>, <a href="#challenge">challenge</a>, <a href="#comstock">Comstock</a>, <a href="#expurgated">expurgated</a>, <a href="#filtering">filtering</a>, <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>, and <em><a href="#indexlibrorum">Index Librorum Prohibitorum</a></em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="census"><b>census</b></a>
</dt><dd>An official count and statistical analysis of the population
of a given geographic entity (city, county, state, province, country,
etc.) taken at a particular point in time. The earliest known census of
taxpaying households was recorded in China in the 3rd century B.C. More
complete enumerations were conducted for military and tax purposes in
ancient Rome by special magistrates called <em>censors</em>. The
development of the modern census began in Europe in the 17th century
and today includes questions concerning age, gender, ethnicity, income,
housing, etc., formulated to generate <a href="#data">data</a> used in
social planning, political redistricting, business marketing, etc. In
most countries, participation in the census is compulsory and the <a href="#information">information</a> collected on individual households and businesses is <a href="#confidentiality">confidential</a>.  
<p>
In the United States, the national census is conducted every tenth year by the <a href="http://www.census.gov/">U.S. Census Bureau</a> which reports the detailed results in statistical form by state.  Census <a href="#data">data</a> is available in the <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of larger <a href="#library">libraries</a> and online at:  <a href="http://www.census.gov/">www.census.gov</a>.  <a href="#summary">Summary</a> <a href="#table">table</a>s are <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the <em><a href="http://www.census.gov/statab/www/">Statistical Abstract of the United States</a></em>, prepared <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly since 1879 by the Bureau of Statistics (Dept. of U.S. Treasury), available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most libraries in the United States.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#censustract">census tract</a>.   
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="censustract"><b>census tract</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of many small geographic areas into which a state or country is divided for the purpose of gathering and reporting <a href="#census">census</a> <a href="#data">data</a>.  In the United States, the average tract contains 4,000 residents or approximately 1,200 households.  Census tract outline <a href="#map">map</a>s are available from the <a href="http://www.census.gov/">U.S. Census Bureau</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cba"><b>Center for Book Arts (CBA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1974, <b>CBA</b> is a non-profit organization with
headquarters in New York City, dedicated to preserving the traditional
craft of bookmaking and encouraging contemporary interpretations of the
<a href="#book">book</a> as an art object, through <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ions, lectures, <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, and services to artists, including courses, <a href="#workshop">workshop</a>s, and seminars on all aspects of the <a href="#bookarts">book arts</a>.  <a href="http://www.centerforbookarts.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CBA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crl"><b>Center for Research Libraries (CRL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1949, <b>CRL</b>'s members are large <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> that seek to improve <a href="#access">access</a> to scholarly <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  <b>CRL</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> a <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> and serves as a <a href="#depository">depository</a> for infrequently used <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> which its members may use cooperatively.  <a href="http://wwwcrl.uchicago.edu/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CRL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="centerforthebook"><b>Center for the Book</b></a>
</dt><dd>An educational <a href="#outreach">outreach</a> program established in 1977 by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> to stimulate public interest in and awareness of <a href="#book">book</a>s, reading, and <a href="#library">libraries</a>, and to encourage the study of books and the <a href="#printing">printed</a> word.  The <b>Center</b>
is a public-private partnership between the Library of Congress, 35
affiliated state centers, and over 50 national and civic groups. <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/loc/cfbook/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>Center for the Book</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="centerpiece"><b>centerpiece</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> of the late 16th and early 17th centuries, an ornamental design such as an <a href="#arabesque">arabesque</a>, stamped on the center of the front and/or back <a href="#cover">cover</a>, usually accompanied by matching <a href="#cornerpiece">cornerpiece</a>s.  Also refers to a piece of <a href="#embossed">embossed</a> or <a href="#engraving">engraved</a> metal attached to the center of the front cover of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  Also spelled <em>centrepiece</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cameobinding">cameo binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="centralizedcat"><b>centralized cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd>The preparation of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s for <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> by a central <a href="#catagency">cataloging agency</a> which distributes them in <a href="#printing">printed</a> and/or <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> form to participating libraries, usually for a modest <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  Also refers to the <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> for an entire <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> at one of its facilities, usually the <a href="#centrallib">central library</a>, to achieve uniformity and economies of scale.  Also spelled <em>centralized cataloguing</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="centralizedproc"><b>centralized processing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The practice of concentrating in a single location all the functions involved in preparing <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> for <a href="#library">library</a> use, as opposed to <a href="#technical">technical processing</a> carried out at multiple locations within a library or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>.  Centralization allows processing methods to be <a href="#standardization">standardized</a>, but increased efficiency may be offset by the cost of distributing materials to the units where they will be used.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="centrallib"><b>central library</b></a>
</dt><dd>The administrative center of a <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, where system-wide management decisions are made, <a href="#centralizedproc">centralized</a> <a href="#technical">technical processing</a> is conducted, and principal <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s are located.  Synonymous with <em>main library</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#branchlibrary">branch library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="centralproc"><b>central processing unit (CPU)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> component of a computer that houses the circuitry for <a href="#storage">storing</a> and processing <a href="#data">data</a> according to instructions contained in the <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s installed on it, including the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>, <a href="#utility">utilities</a> to run <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> <a href="#device">device</a>s, and <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#software">software</a>.  Generally speaking, the more <a href="#memory">memory</a> and <a href="#harddisk">disk</a> <a href="#storage">storage</a> a CPU has, the more processing it can handle within a given amount of time, and the faster it can accomplish a task.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cerf"><b>cerf</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#kerf">kerf</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="certificate"><b>certificate of issue</b></a>
</dt><dd>In a <a href="#limitededition">limited edition</a>, the statement in each <a href="#copy">copy</a> giving the total <a href="#number">number</a> of copies <a href="#printing">printed</a> and the <a href="#numberedcopy">copy number</a>.  In an <a href="#autographededit">autographed edition</a>, the certificate may also bear the <a href="#signature">signature</a> of the <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#editor">editor</a>, or <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="certification"><b>certification</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the formal act of attesting to the official identity and nature of an <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#document">document</a> or its <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>.  Compare with <a href="#authentication">authentication</a>.
<p>
Also, the process by which a <a href="#govtagency">state agency</a>, or a nongovernmental <a href="#agency">agency</a>
or organization authorized by a state government, evaluates the
qualifications of an individual, organization, or institution to
perform a specific service or function, for the purpose of granting a
credential. Compare with <a href="#accreditation">accreditation</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#approved">approved library school</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cessation"><b>cessation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#serial">serial</a> or <a href="#annual">annual</a> that has <a href="#ceased">ceased publication</a>.  Cessations are listed <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#title">title</a> in a separate section of <em><a href="#ulrichs">Ulrich's International Periodicals Directory</a></em> <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, and in <em><a href="#serialsdirectory">The Serials Directory</a></em> published by <a href="#ebsco">EBSCO</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> of a serial that has ceased <a href="#publication">publication</a> are indicated in a <a href="#closedentry">closed entry</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>v. 1-26, 1950-76</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cf"><b><em>cf.</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin <em>confer</em> meaning "compare."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cgi"><b>CGI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#commongateway"><b>C</b>ommon <b>G</b>ateway <b>I</b>nterface</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="challenge"><b>challenge</b></a>
</dt><dd>A complaint lodged by a <a href="#library">library</a> user acting as an individual or representing a group, concerning the inclusion of a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a> (or items) in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, usually followed by a demand that the <a href="#libmaterials">material</a> be removed.  Library programs may also be targeted.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> are challenged far more frequently than other types of <a href="#library">libraries</a> because they are supported by public funds and must provide resources and services for a highly diverse <a href="#clientele">clientele</a> ("this library has something to offend everyone").  An unambiguously worded <a href="#collecdevelpolicy">collection development policy</a> is a <a href="#library">library</a>'s best defense against such objections.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#banned">banned book</a>, <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>, and <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="changedtitle"><b>changed title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> that has undergone a change of <a href="#title">title</a> from the one under which it was previously <a href="#publishing">published</a>.  Title changes occur most frequently in <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, compounding the work of <a href="#serial">serial</a>s <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and complicating <a href="#access">access</a> for users.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a <a href="#note">note</a> (<em>Continues:</em>) is included in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing the new title, and a similar note (<em>Continued by:</em>) is added to the record for the previously published title.  Synonymous with <em>title change</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#retitlededition">retitled edition</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="channel"><b>channel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A pathway along which <a href="#data">data</a> is transmitted electronically from one computer, <a href="#terminal">terminal</a>, or <a href="#device">device</a> to another.  The <a href="#term">term</a> also refers to the physical <a href="#medium">medium</a> carrying the signal (<a href="#opticalfiber">optical fiber</a>, <a href="#coaxial">coaxial cable</a>, etc.) and to the properties that distinguish a specific channel from others.  In data <a href="#storage">storage</a>, a <a href="#track">track</a> on a specific storage medium (<a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a>, magnetic <a href="#disk">disk</a>, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>, etc.) on which electrical signals are recorded.    
<p>
In <a href="#communications">communications</a>, a band of <a href="#frequency">frequencies</a> assigned by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to a radio or television transmitting station for its exclusive use.
</p><p>
Also refers to the <a href="#blank">blank</a> space dividing <a href="#column">column</a>s of <a href="#text">text</a> written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a <a href="#page">page</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chapbook"><b>chapbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Anglo-Saxon root <em>ceap</em>.  A small inexpensive <a href="#paperback">paperbound</a> <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a> containing a popular <a href="#legend">legend</a>, <a href="#tale">tale</a>, <a href="#poetry">poem</a>, or <a href="#ballad">ballad</a>, or a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#prose">prose</a> or <a href="#verse">verse</a>, hawked in the streets of London from the 16th to the 18th century by traveling peddlers called <em>chapmen</em>.  The <a href="#content">content</a>
was usually sensational (abduction, murder, witchcraft etc.),
educational (travel), or moral. Chapbooks were typically of small size
(6 x 4 inches), containing up to 24 <a href="#page">page</a>s <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> with <a href="#woodcut">woodcut</a>s, usually with a decorated <a href="#covertitle">cover title</a>.  Also refers to a modern <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a> of the same type.  Also spelled <em>chap-book</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chapter"><b>chapter</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of two ore more major divisions of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#work">work</a>, each complete in itself, but related in theme or <a href="#plot">plot</a> to the division preceding and/or following it.  In works of <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>, chapters are usually given a <a href="#chaptertitle">chapter title</a>, but in works of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> they may simply be <a href="#number">number</a>ed, usually in <a href="#romannumeral">roman numeral</a>s.  Chapters are listed in order of appearance by title and/or number in the <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a> in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> of a book.  Compare with <a href="#canto">canto</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#chapterdrop">chapter drop</a>, <a href="#chapterheading">chapter heading</a>, and <a href="#runonchapter">run on chapter</a>.
<p>
Also, one of over 50 independent state and regional <a href="#libassociation">library association</a>s closely affiliated with the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  Each has a separate budget and <a href="#dues">dues</a> structure, elects its own officers, and sponsors an <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#conference">conference</a>.
The 53 state chapters are each represented in the ALA's governing
assembly by an elected chapter councilor. The ALA also has student
chapters in over 25 states. Within the ALA, chapter interests are
represented by the Chapter Relations Committee and the <a href="http://www.ala.org/cro/">Chapter Relations Office</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chapterdrop"><b>chapter drop</b></a>
</dt><dd>The position below the <a href="#chapterheading">chapter heading</a> at which the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> begins--lower than on succeeding <a href="#page">page</a>s of the text and, in most <a href="#book">book</a>s, the same for all chapters.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chapterheading"><b>chapter heading</b></a>
</dt><dd>A display <a href="#heading">heading</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, usually consisting of a <a href="#romannumeral">roman numeral</a> indicating the <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> <a href="#number">number</a>, followed by the <a href="#chaptertitle">chapter title</a>, written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the first <a href="#page">page</a> of the chapter in <a href="#uniformstyle">uniform style</a> and position above the first paragraph of the <a href="#text">text</a>.  Set in a <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#typesize">size</a> larger than the text and <a href="#runninghead">running head</a>s, chapter headings are sometimes embellished with an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> or <a href="#headpiece">head-piece</a> in older <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#chapterdrop">chapter drop</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chaptertitle"><b>chapter title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> that appears at the beginning of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually bearing some relation to the <a href="#content">content</a> of the division of the <a href="#work">work</a>.  Chapters may simply be <a href="#number">number</a>ed (usually in <a href="#romannumeral">roman numeral</a>s), or given a number and a title.  They are listed in order of appearance by number and/or title in the <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a> in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#chapterheading">chapter heading</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="character"><b>character</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any mark, sign, or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> conventionally used in writing or <a href="#printing">printing</a>, including <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s, <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a> marks, and <a href="#refmark">reference mark</a>s.  In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, the smallest unit used in the <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> of <a href="#heading">heading</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#loancharacter">loan character</a> and <a href="#nonsorting">nonsorting character</a>.  
<p>
In <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a>, a sequence of eight <a href="#binary">binary</a> digits (one <a href="#byte">byte</a>) representing a letter of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>, numeral, punctuation mark, or other symbol. 
</p><p>  
Also, a <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>al person in a <a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>, <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>, or other <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>.  A <em>character study</em> is a <a href="#work">work</a> in which the primary theme is the inner development of a person or group of persons (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Hamlet</em></b>).  In <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject headings</a>, "Characters" is a <a href="#standardsubdivision">standard subdivision</a> used in <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#heading">heading</a>s for writers of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, particularly <a href="#playwright">playwright</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b>Shakespeare, William, 1546-1616 - Characters - Falstaff</b>).  Well-known characters may be given a separate heading, followed by a <a href="#parenthetical">parenthetical qualifier</a>, as in <b>Jeeves (Fictitious character)</b>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="characteristic"><b>characteristic</b></a>
</dt><dd>An attribute, property, or quality that forms the basis for dividing a <a href="#class">class</a> into clearly differentiated <a href="#subclass">subclass</a>es, for example, the characteristic "period" dividing the class "European <a href="#literature">literature</a>"
into the subclasses "classical," "medieval," "renaissance," "modern,"
and "contemporary," as opposed to the characteristic "form" dividing
the same class into "<a href="#play">drama</a>," "<a href="#essay">essay</a>," "<a href="#novel">novel</a>," "<a href="#poetry">poetry</a>," "<a href="#shortstory">short story</a>," etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="charactermasking"><b>character masking</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#truncation">truncation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="characterset"><b>character set</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s in a specific <a href="#font">font</a>, used for <a href="#printing">printing</a> and/or electronic display.  <a href="#character">Character</a> <a href="#set">set</a>s for <a href="#language">language</a>s written in the roman <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> usually contain 256 symbols of which the first 128 are the same.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ascii">ASCII</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="charge"><b>charge</b></a>
</dt><dd>To record the loan of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> from the <a href="#circulating">circulating collection</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> to a <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>.  In modern libraries, this task involves the use of a computer.  Also refers to the library's <a href="#record">record</a> of such a transaction, including the identity of the borrower, the <a href="#title">title</a> and <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> of the item, and its <a href="#duedate">due date</a>.  Compare with <a href="#discharge">discharge</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#itemrecord">item record</a> and <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a>. 
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#fee">fee</a> or payment required of a library <a href="#patron">patron</a>, usually for the use of nontraditional services, such as <a href="#rentalcollec">rental collection</a>s and certain methods of <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chart"><b>chart</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> designed to meet the requirements of navigation, or one showing meteorological phenomena or heavenly bodies.  A <em>nautical chart</em> indicates soundings, currents, coastlines, and other important maritime features.  An <em>aeronautical chart</em> shows features of interest to aircraft pilots.  Also refers to an opaque <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> on which <a href="#data">data</a> are displayed in the form of <a href="#graph">graph</a>s or <a href="#table">table</a>s, or by other <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> techniques.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#flipchart">flip chart</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="charter"><b>charter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A legal <a href="#document">document</a> recording the franchise or granting of specific rights to an individual or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a> by a governmental authority such as a legislature or sovereign (<em>example</em>:  the Charter of the United Nations).  The <a href="#text">text</a>s of important charters are usually available in the <a href="#govdocs">government document</a>s or <a href="#refstacks">reference section</a> of large <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  The <a href="#original">original</a>s are preserved by the institutions that own them, usually in <a href="#archives">archives</a> or <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cilip"><b>Chartered Institute of Library and Information Professionals (CILIP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A new professional <a href="#association">association</a> formed in April 2002 by the unification of the Institute of Information Scientists (IIS) and the <a href="#la">Library Association</a> (UK).  <a href="http://www.cilip.org.uk/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CILIP</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> which includes <a href="#information">information</a> about the <a href="#mission">mission</a>, <a href="#goal">goal</a>s, and action plan of this new organization.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chase"><b>chase</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a>, the portable rectangular metal frame in which assembled <a href="#type">type</a> and <a href="#displaymatter">display matter</a>, <a href="#composition">composed</a> into <a href="#page">page</a>s, is firmly <a href="#lockedup">locked</a> into position.  The resulting <a href="#forme">forme</a> is then ready to be transferred to the bed of the <a href="#printingpress">press</a> for <a href="#printing">printing</a>.  The expression <em>in chase</em> means "ready for printing."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chasededges"><b>chased edges</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small wavy or crimped repeating pattern impressed as decoration on the <a href="#giltedges">gilt edges</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, using heated <a href="#finishing">finishing</a> tools called gauffering irons, popular in 16th and 17th century ornamental <a href="#binding">binding</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>gauffering</em> and <em>goffered edges</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chat"><b>chat</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#realtime">real time</a> computer conferencing capability between two or more users of a <a href="#network">network</a> (<a href="#localarea">LAN</a>, <a href="#widearea">WAN</a>, <a href="#internet">Internet</a>) by means of a <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> rather than voice transmission.  Most <a href="#internetservice">Internet service provider</a>s offer a <em>chat room</em> to their <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#lurk">lurk</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="checkdigit"><b>check digit</b></a>
</dt><dd>A digit added to a sequence of digits, related arithmetically to the sequence in such a way that <a href="#input">input</a> errors can be automatically detected whenever the sequence is entered as <a href="#data">data</a> into a computer (<em>example</em>:  last digit of the <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="checkedout"><b>checked out</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> that has been <a href="#charge">charged</a> to a <a href="#borroweraccount">borrower account</a> and is not due back in the <a href="#library">library</a> until the end of the <a href="#loanperiod">loan period</a>.  In the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>, the <a href="#duedate">due date</a> is usually displayed as a status code in the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> to indicate that the item is currently not available for <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>.  Synonymous with <em>on loan</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#overdue">overdue</a>, <a href="#recall">recall</a>, and <a href="#renew">renew</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="checkinrecord"><b>check-in record</b></a>
</dt><dd>A separate record attached to the full <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, in which the receipt by the <a href="#library">library</a> of individual <a href="#issue">issue</a>s or <a href="#part">part</a>s is entered, usually by an assistant working in the serials department. Most <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s
allow users to view the check-in record to determine if a specific
issue has arrived. The check-in record may also indicate whether an
issue is <a href="#missing">missing</a>, <a href="#claim">claim</a>ed, or at the <a href="#bindery">bindery</a>.  Compare with <a href="#itemrecord">item record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="checklist"><b>checklist</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> list of <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, or other <a href="#document">document</a>s, which provides the minimum amount of <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a> or <a href="#annotation">annotation</a> necessary to identify each <a href="#work">work</a>--briefer than a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>.  Also, the log kept by a <a href="#library">library</a> to record the receipt of each <a href="#number">number</a> of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, or <a href="#part">part</a> of a <a href="#workinprogress">work in progress</a>.
