Also refers to a list of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s required, or procedures to be followed, such as the steps in a library's <a href="#opening">opening</a> or <a href="#closing">closing</a> routine.  Also spelled <em>check-list</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="checkout"><b>checkout period</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#loanperiod">loan period</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chefdoeuvre"><b>chef-d'oeuvre</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#magnumopus">magnum opus</a> and <a href="#masterpiece">masterpiece</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chemise"><b>chemise</b></a>
</dt><dd>A loose <a href="#leather">leather</a> or cloth <a href="#cover">cover</a> designed with pockets to fit over the wooden <a href="#board">board</a>s of a <a href="#handbinding">hand-bound</a> <a href="#book">book</a>, sometimes secured to the boards with <a href="#boss">boss</a>es, used in Europe from the 12th to 15th century as a substitute for full <a href="#binding">binding</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cio"><b>Chief Information Officer (CIO)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> of the person in a commercial company or nonprofit organization who is responsible for managing the flow of official <a href="#information">information</a>, including computing and any <a href="#library">library</a> services--a relatively new <a href="#position">position</a> in companies and organizations that recognize the need for such a management function. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chiefsource"><b>chief source of information</b></a>
</dt><dd>The source of bibliographic <a href="#data">data</a> preferred by <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s in preparing the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, usually the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> or a substitute, for example, the <a href="#titleframe">title frame</a> at the beginning of a <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a> or <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, or the <a href="#titlescreen">title screen</a> of a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#suppliedtitle">supplied title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chiffonsilk"><b>chiffon silk</b></a>
</dt><dd>Extra-thin but strong silk tissue used to <a href="#mending">mend</a> or strengthen a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#paper">paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="childrensbook"><b>children's book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> written and <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> specifically for children up to the age of 12-13.  Included in this category are juvenile <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>, <a href="#boardbook">board book</a>s, <a href="#nurseryrhyme">nursery rhyme</a>s, <a href="#alphabetbook">alphabet book</a>s, <a href="#countingbook">counting book</a>s, <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>s, <a href="#easybook">easy book</a>s, <a href="#beginningreader">beginning reader</a>s, <a href="#picturestorybook">picture storybook</a>s, and <a href="#storybook">storybook</a>s.  Children's books are shelved in the <a href="#juvenile">juvenile collection</a> of most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> and in the <a href="#curriculumroom">curriculum room</a> in most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>.  Currently available children's <a href="#title">title</a>s are <a href="#index">index</a>ed in <em><a href="#cbip">Children's Books in Print</a></em> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.  <a href="http://www.sc.edu/library/spcoll/kidlit/kidlit/kidlit.html">Click here</a> to view a sample of 19th century children's books.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#childrensaward">children's book award</a>, <a href="#childrenslit">children's literature</a>, and <a href="#cbc">Children's Book Council</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="childrensaward"><b>children's book award</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a> or prize given to the <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#illustration">illustrator</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> specifically for children.  In the United States, the two best-known awards are the <a href="#caldecott">Caldecott Medal</a> and the <a href="#newbery">Newbery Medal</a>.  <a href="http://www.acs.ucalgary.ca/%7Edkbrown/awards.html">Click here</a> to connect to an international list of <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a> awards.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ameliafrances">Amelia Frances Howard-Gibbon Illustrator's ward</a>, <a href="#carnegiemedal">Carnegie Medal</a>, <a href="#clabook">CLA Book of the Year for Children</a>, and <a href="#greenaway">Greenaway Medal</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cbc"><b>Children's Book Council (CBC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1945, the <b>CBC</b> is a nonprofit <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a> dedicated to encouraging <a href="#literacy">literacy</a> and the use and enjoyment of <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>s.  Its membership includes <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s and packagers of children's <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a>s, and producers of <a href="#book">book</a>-related <a href="#multimedia">multimedia</a> for children.  The <b>CBC</b> sponsors <a href="#childrensbookweek">Children's Book Week</a>, celebrated in schools, <a href="#library">libraries</a>, and <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s throughout the United States each November, and <b>Young People's Poetry Week</b> celebrated in April in conjunction with National <a href="#poetry">Poetry</a> Month.  <a href="http://www.cbcbooks.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CBC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cbip"><b><em>Children's Books in Print</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, and <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a> <a href="#index">index</a> to currently available <a href="#childrensbook">books for children</a> and <a href="#youngadult">young adult</a>s, <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.  The separately published <b><em>Subject Guide to Children's Books in Print</em></b> includes indexes by <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">wholesaler</a>, and <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#elhitextbooks">El-Hi Textbooks &amp; Serials in Print</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="childrensbookweek"><b>Children's Book Week</b></a>
</dt><dd>Sponsored since 1919 by the <a href="#cbc">Children's Book Council</a>, <b>Children's Book Week</b> is a local and national celebration held each November in which <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, and educators schedule <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>s, <a href="#readathon">read-a-thon</a>s, <a href="#storyhour">story hour</a>s,
swap sessions, contests, book raffles, an other activities to stimulate
interest in books and reading among young people. Synonymous with <em>Book Week</em>.  <a href="http://www.cbcbooks.org/html/book_week.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Children's Book Week</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="childrenscollec"><b>children's collection</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#juvenile">juvenile collection</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cipa"><b><em>Children's Internet Protection Act of 1999 (CIPA)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Legislation passed by Congress in 1999 that makes discounted <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#access">access</a> and internal connection services for schools and <a href="#library">libraries</a> under the <a href="#erate">E-rate</a> provisions of the <em>1996 Telecommunications Reform Act</em> contingent on <a href="#certification">certification</a> that certain "Internet safety policies" have been put in place, most notably technology that <a href="#filter">filter</a>s and blocks access to visual depictions considered <a href="#obscenity">obscene</a> or harmful to minors.  Implemented by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), <b><em>CIPA</em></b> was strongly opposed by the education/library lobby and civil liberties groups, and remains controversial.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/hunterappendix6.html">Click here</a> to read the <a href="#text">text</a> of the <b><em>Children's Internet Protection Act</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="childrenslibrarian"><b>children's librarian</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> who specializes in <a href="#childrensservices">services</a> and <a href="#juvenile">collection</a>s for children up to the age of 12-13.  Most children's librarians have extensive knowledge of <a href="#childrenslit">children's literature</a> and are trained in the art of <a href="#storytelling">storytelling</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="childrenslit"><b>children's literature</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#literarywork">Literary work</a>s created specifically for children, as distinct from <a href="#work">work</a>s written for <a href="#adult">adult</a>s and <a href="#youngadult">young adult</a>s, including <a href="#poetry">poetry</a> and <a href="#prose">prose</a>, <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>.  Children's <a href="#literature">literature</a> began with the oral transmission of <a href="#nurseryrhyme">nursery rhyme</a>s, songs, poems, <a href="#fairytale">fairy tale</a>s, and stories.  During the early 17th century, the <a href="#hornbook">horn book</a> came into widespread use in Britain and the American colonies, but it was not until the late 17th century with the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of the popular <em>Tales of Mother Goose</em> by Charles Perrault (1628-1703) that written literature for children emerged as a separate genre.  
<p>
By the mid-18th century, the British writer, <a href="#printer">printer</a>, and <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> John Newbery (1713-1767) perceived that a market existed for <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>s and began <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> works intended to be morally instructional (<em>Little Goody Two-Shoes</em>).
Not until the 19th century did children's literature break away from
didacticism, first with the publication of the fairy tales of Hans
Christian Anderson (1805-1875) and the brothers Grimm, and later with
Edward Lear's <em>Book of Nonsense</em> (1846),  <em>Alice's Adventures in Wonderland</em> (1865) and the <a href="#sequel">sequel</a> <em>Through the Looking Glass</em> (1871).  
</p><p>
The illustrations in most early children's books were <a href="#printing">printed</a> in black and white, but by the 1860's the English printer Edmund Evans (1826-1905) began <a href="#issue">issuing</a> <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>s
in color, illustrated by artists such as Walter Crane (1845-1915), Kate
Greenaway (1846-1901), and Randolph Caldecott (1846-1886). The
publication of the children's <a href="#classic">classic</a>s <em>Little Women</em> by Louisa May Alcott in 1868 and <em>The Adventures of Tom Sawyer</em> by Mark Twain in 1876 marked the beginning of realism in juvenile <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>.  Today, children's literature has earned a place in the hearts of millions of <a href="#reader">reader</a>s, and a worldwide market exists for <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s for children of all ages.  
</p><p>
Recently published children's books are <a href="#review">review</a>ed in <em><a href="#booklist">Booklist</a></em>, <em><a href="http://www.lis.uiuc.edu/puboff/bccb/">The Bulletin of the Center for Children's Books</a></em>, <em><a href="http://www.hbook.com/mag.shtml">Horn Book Magazine</a></em>, <em><a href="http://www.press.jhu.edu/press/journals/titles/uni.html">The Lion and the Unicorn</a></em>, and <em>School Library Journal</em>, and reviews are <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>ed in <em><a href="#chlitreview">Children's Literature Review</a></em>, a <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> published by the <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>.  <a href="http://www.sc.edu/library/spcoll/kidlit/kidlit/kidlit.html">Click here</a> to view a sample of 19th century children's literature.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#childrensaward">children's book award</a> and <a href="#juvenile">juvenile collection</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chlitreview"><b><em>Children's Literature Review (CLR)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> since 1976 by the <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>, providing <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>s from <a href="#review">review</a>s, <a href="#criticism">criticism</a>, and <a href="#commentary">commentary</a> on <a href="#book">book</a>s for <a href="#childrensbook">children</a> and <a href="#youngadult">young adult</a>s, arranged <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by name of <a href="#author">author</a>, with <a href="#cumulativeindex">cumulative</a> author and <a href="#title">title</a> <a href="#index">index</a>es at the end of each <a href="#volume">volume</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="childrensroom"><b>children's room</b></a>
</dt><dd>The area in a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> or one of its <a href="#branchlibrary">branch</a>es, reserved for <a href="#juvenile">collection</a>s and <a href="#childrensservices">services</a> intended specifically for children up to the age of 12-13, usually <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ed by at least one <a href="#childrenslibrarian">children's librarian</a>
and furnished to accommodate persons of small stature. Some children's
rooms include a comfortable corner or alcove designed for group <a href="#storytelling">storytelling</a>, <a href="#puppetry">puppetry</a>, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="childrensservices"><b>children's services</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#library">Library</a> services intended for children up to the age of 12-13, including <a href="#juvenile">juvenile collection</a> <a href="#collecdevel">development</a>, <a href="#lapsitservices">lapsit services</a>, <a href="#storytelling">storytelling</a>, assistance with <a href="#homeworkcenter">homework</a> assignments, and <a href="#summerreading">summer reading program</a>s, usually provided by a <a href="#childrenslibrarian">children's librarian</a> in the <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a> of a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>.  Compare with <a href="#adultservices">adult services</a> and <a href="#yaservices">young adult services</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#alsc">Association for Library Services to Children</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cala"><b>Chinese American Librarians Association (CALA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1983, <b>CALA</b> seeks to promote better communication between Chinese American <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s employed in the United States, and serves as a forum for discussion of the problems of its members.  An <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>CALA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> <em>Journal of Library and Information Science</em> in English and Chinese, the <em>CALA Newsletter</em> in three <a href="#issue">issue</a>s per year, and the <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> <em>CALA E-Journal</em>.  <a href="http://www.cala-web.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CALA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chinesestyle"><b>Chinese style</b></a>
</dt><dd>In China and Japan, the evolution of the <a href="#book">book</a> proceeded as in the West, from <a href="#scroll">scroll</a> to <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> enclosed in a <a href="#cover">cover</a>, but by a different route.  Instead of <a href="#binding">binding</a> separately cut leaves in <a href="#codex">codex</a> form, a continuous roll of writing material was accordion-pleated, creating a series of folded leaves left <a href="#uncut">uncut</a> at the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> with writing (and later <a href="#printing">printing</a>) on one side only.  Also known as <em>Japanese style</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doubleleaf">double leaf</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chip"><b>chip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened form of <em>microchip</em>, a high-speed
miniaturized integrated circuit, etched in a semiconducting material
(usually silicon) on the surface of a tiny, wafer-thin piece of metal,
for use as <a href="#centralproc">microprocessor</a> and <a href="#memory">memory</a>
in computers and other electronic equipment. The design of increasingly
powerful microchips has been the driving force behind the <a href="#infotech">information technology</a> revolution that began in the second half of the 20th century.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ram">RAM</a> and <a href="#rom">ROM</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chipboard"><b>chip board</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thin, cheap, low-density <a href="#board">board</a> manufactured from recycled <a href="#paper">paper</a> and other <a href="#cellulose">cellulose</a> fibers.  Although chip board is sometimes used in <a href="#casebinding">case binding</a>, <a href="#bindersboard">binder's board</a> is preferred in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#tradebook">trade</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  Also spelled <em>chipboard</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chipped"><b>chipped</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> that has small pieces missing from the edges of its <a href="#cover">cover</a>, <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>, or <a href="#page">page</a>s, not as prized in the market for <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian book</a>s as a <a href="#copy">copy</a> in <a href="#mint">mint</a> condition.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="choice"><b><em>CHOICE:  Current Reviews for Academic Libraries</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a> founded in 1964 by the <a href="#acrl">Association of College and Research Libraries</a> (ACRL) and <a href="#publishing">published</a> in eleven <a href="#issue">issue</a>s/year, <b><em>CHOICE</em></b> provides <a href="#review">review</a>s of 6,000-7,000 English-<a href="#language">language</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#website">Web site</a>s, and other resources per year, focusing on <a href="#title">title</a>s of interest to the <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and teaching faculty responsible for <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> in <a href="#collegelibrary">college</a> and <a href="#universitylib">university libraries</a>.  Arranged by <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, <b><em>CHOICE</em></b> reviews are prepared by academic <a href="#reviewer">reviewer</a>s from completed books, not <a href="#galley">galley proof</a>s.  Each issue also includes an <a href="#editorial">editorial</a>, a <a href="#bibliography">bibliographic</a> <a href="#essay">essay</a>, and at least one <a href="#feature">feature</a> <a href="#article">article</a>, with separate <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, and <a href="#topic">topic</a> <a href="#index">index</a>es at the end.  <b><em>Reviews on Cards (ROC)</em></b> contains the same set of reviews as the <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, each printed on heavy-duty 4.25" x 5.5" paper stock to facilitate routing to individual <a href="#selection">selector</a>s.  <b><em>CHOICE</em></b> is also available <a href="#online">online</a> by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> under the title <b><em>Choice Reviews.online</em></b>.    <a href="http://www.ala.org/acrl/choice/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>CHOICE</em></b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="choropleth"><b>choropleth map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> on which color, shading, or some other <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>
technique is used to show the density or frequency of a variable (e.g.,
mortality, population, precipitation) in each of several areas, based
on the average <a href="#number">number</a> of occurrences per unit of area.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#isogram">isogram</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chorusscore"><b>chorus score</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#score">score</a> of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> originally written for solo voice and chorus, which shows only the choral <a href="#part">part</a>s and any accompaniment <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> for keyboard instrument.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chrestomathy"><b>chrestomathy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#collection">collection</a> of choice passages from the <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s of an <a href="#author">author</a> (or authors), especially one <a href="#compilation">compiled</a> as a sample of literary <a href="#specimen">specimen</a>s as an aid in the study of a <a href="#language">language</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="christianfiction"><b>Christian fiction</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#novel">Novel</a>s and <a href="#shortstory">stories</a> in which Christian religious belief is a major (sometimes predominant) element in the development of <a href="#plot">plot</a>, theme, and <a href="#character">character</a>.  The market for Christian <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> has expanded considerably in the United States in recent years.  <a href="#newbook">New</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s are regularly <a href="#review">review</a>ed in <em><a href="#booklist">Booklist</a></em> and <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#religiousbook">religious book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chromolithography"><b>chromolithography</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lithography">lithography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chronicle"><b>chronicle</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, a detailed <a href="#chronological">chronological</a> <a href="#record">record</a>
of contemporary events, usually written over an extended period of
time, with no pretense of literary style and little or no
interpretation or analysis. The first extant example is the <em>Anglo-Saxon Chronicle</em>
which begun in the 9th century during the reign of King Alfred, which
covered the history of England from 60 BC to the 12th century. In
modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, a list of events described and recorded in the order in which they occurred.  The <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> is fuller and more connected than in <a href="#annals">annals</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chronicleplay"><b>chronicle play</b></a>
</dt><dd>A drama based on material from the <a href="#chronicle">chronicle</a> histories of England, for example, those written by Hall and Holinshead.  Popular during the Elizabethan period, chronicle <a href="#play">play</a>s were at first loosely structured, but evolved into sophisticated <a href="#character">character</a> studies, exemplified by the history plays of William Shakespeare.  A more recent example of a history play is <b><em>A Man for All Seasons</em></b> by Robert Bolt (1960).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chronological"><b>chronological</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> of <a href="#data">data</a>, <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s, <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s, <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, <a href="#entry">entries</a>, etc., according to their relation in time, from earliest to latest.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>s, the <a href="#periodsubdivision">period subdivision</a>s added to <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s are listed in chronological order (<em>example</em>:  Antiquity--Medieval--Renaissance--then by century from the 15th to 20th).  The opposite of <a href="#reversechron">reverse chronological</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chronology"><b>chronology</b></a>     
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or section of a book that lists
events and their dates in the order of their occurrence. Most
chronologies are limited to a specific period (<em>example</em>:  Roman Empire), event (World War II), or theme (women's history).  Book-length chronologies are usually shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Day by Day: The Sixties</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1983 by Facts on File).  Compare with <a href="#calendar">calendar</a>.  <a href="http://www.xs4all.nl/%7Eknops/timetab.html">Click here</a> to see an example of an <a href="#online">online</a> chronology of <a href="#bookhistory">book history</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="chrysography"><b>chrysography</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek words <em>chrys</em> ("gold") and <em>graphia</em> ("writing").  The art and craft of writing <a href="#letter">letter</a>s in <a href="#goldleaf">gold</a>, as practiced by the skilled <a href="#copy">copyist</a>s who produced medieval <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s.  Also refers to writing done in gold letters.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cilip1"><b>CILIP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cilip"><b>C</b>hartered <b>I</b>nstitute of <b>L</b>ibrary and <b>I</b>nformation <b>P</b>rofessionals</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cinefilm"><b>cinefilm</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cinema"><b>cinema</b></a>
</dt><dd>A broad <a href="#term">term</a> encompassing the <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> industry and distribution system, the <a href="#film">film</a>s
produced, and the art form they represent. It is also used in Europe
and the UK to refer to the theater in which motion pictures are
publicly shown.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cio1"><b>CIO</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cio"><b>C</b>hief <b>I</b>nformation <b>O</b>fficer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cip1"><b>CIP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cip"><b>c</b>ataloging-<b>i</b>n-<b>p</b>ublication</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cipa1"><b><em>CIPA</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#cipa"><b>C</b>hildren's <b>I</b>nternet <b>P</b>rotection <b>A</b>ct of 1999</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cipher"><b>cipher</b></a>
</dt><dd>The initials of a <a href="#personalname">personal name</a>, written or arranged in ornamental form of such complexity and/or artistry as to form a private mark or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>.  Compare with <a href="#cryptonym">cryptonym</a>.  
<p>
In a more general sense, secret writing or code intended to be understood (<em>deciphered</em>) only by those who know the key to it.  In <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a>, an <a href="#encryption">encrypted</a> <a href="#character">character</a> that can only be decrypted with a key.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circa"><b>circa</b></a>
</dt><dd>A Latin word meaning "about," used to indicate lack of
certainty but reasonable probability concerning a date, for example,
the approximate <a href="#birthdeath">birth and/or death date(s)</a> of a person for whom official <a href="#records">records</a> are lacking.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>c.</em> or <em>ca.</em>
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>: <b><em>c</em>. 1922</b> (<em>about 1922</em>)</dd></dl> 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circular"><b>circular</b></a>
</dt><dd>An advertisement, announcement, or directive, usually in the form of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a> or <a href="#leaflet">leaflet</a>, distributed to a large circle of people at the same time and intended to be passed on to others to whom its <a href="#content">content</a> might be of interest. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circbook"><b>circulating book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> that can be <a href="#charge">charge</a>d to a <a href="#borroweraccount">borrower account</a> for use inside or outside the <a href="#library">library</a> facility, as opposed to one <a href="#restricted">restricted</a> to <a href="#libraryuseonly">library use only</a>.  Compare with <a href="#noncirculating">noncirculating</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circulating"><b>circulating collection</b></a> 
</dt><dd><a href="#book">Book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> which may be <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> by registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s for use inside or outside the <a href="#library">library</a>.  In most <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> in the United States, <a href="#circulation">circulating</a> materials are shelved in <a href="#openstacks">open stacks</a> to facilitate <a href="#browse">browsing</a>.  Compare with <a href="#noncirculating">noncirculating</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circulatinglib"><b>circulating library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> containing <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>
that can be borrowed by persons authorized to do so, usually for a
fixed period of time, after which prompt return is expected. The idea
of a <a href="#subscriptionlib">subscription library</a> to <a href="#circulation">circulate</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and other <a href="#book">book</a>s of general interest was first conceived and implemented by London <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s in the 17th century.  By the Victorian period, this type of library was sufficiently widespread to provide a market for the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of quality fiction in Britain. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circulation"><b>circulation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of checking <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in and out of a <a href="#library">library</a>.  Also refers to the total <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> by library <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s
during a designated period of time, and to the number of times a given
item is checked out during a fixed period of time, usually one year. In
<a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, low circulation is an important criterion for <a href="#weeding">weeding</a> items from the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  Books for which circulation is anticipated to be high may be ordered in multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a> to satisfy <a href="#demand">demand</a>, or given a more <a href="#durability">durable</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a> to withstand heavy use.  Some <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s provide <a href="#circstats">circulation statistics</a> by <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> and material type, for use in <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>.  Circulation is a fundamental to <a href="#accessservices">access services</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>circ</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#automatedcheckout">automated checkout</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the number of <a href="#copy">copies</a> distributed of each <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, including <a href="#complimentary">complimentary copies</a>, single-copy retail sales, and copies sent to paid <a href="#subscription">subscriber</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#totalcirc">total circulation</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circanalysis"><b>circulation analysis</b></a>
</dt><dd>Close examination of <a href="#circstats">statistics</a> <a href="#compile">compile</a>d on the <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a>, usually broken down by <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a>, material type, category of <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>, time of year, etc., to determine patterns of <a href="#usage">usage</a>, an important tool in <a href="#budget">budget</a>ing, <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>, <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ing, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circulationdesk"><b>circulation desk</b></a>   
</dt><dd>The <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a> at which <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> are checked in and out of a <a href="#library">library</a>, usually a long <a href="#counter">counter</a> located near the entrance or <a href="#exit">exit</a>, which may include a built-in <a href="#bookdrop">book drop</a> for returning borrowed materials.  In small and medium-sized libraries, <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s on <a href="#hold">hold</a> or <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> are usually available at the circulation desk, which is normally <a href="#librarystaff">staffed</a> by one or more persons trained to operate the <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a> and handle <a href="#patron">patron</a> <a href="#borroweraccount">account</a>s. 
Synonymous with <em>loan desk</em>.  Compare with <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circulationrecord"><b>circulation record</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circstats"><b>circulation statistics</b></a>
</dt><dd>A count maintained of the <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> from a <a href="#library">library</a>
during a given period (usually a year), or the number of times a
specific item is checked out during a given period, usually broken down
by type of material and/or <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a>.  <a href="#circulation">Circulation</a> statistics can be kept by hand, but most automated <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s provide detailed statistical reports by day, week, month, and year, which can be <a href="#circanalysis">analyzed</a> to determine <a href="#usage">usage</a> patterns, an important aid in <a href="#budget">budget</a>ing, <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>, <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ing, etc.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#inhouseuse">in-house use</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circstatus"><b>circulation status</b></a>
</dt><dd>The conditions under which a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> is available for use.  An item may be <a href="#onorder">on order</a>, <a href="#inprocess">in process</a>, at the <a href="#binding">bindery</a>, for <a href="#libraryuseonly">library use only</a>, <a href="#available">available</a> to be <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>, on loan until a certain <a href="#duedate">due date</a>, <a href="#recently">recently returned</a>, <a href="#missing">missing</a>, <a href="#lost">lost</a>, or <a href="#billed">billed</a>.  Compare with <a href="#loanstatus">loan status</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="circulationsystem"><b>circulation system</b></a>
</dt><dd>The methods used to record the loan of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s from a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> by linking <a href="#data">data</a> in the <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a> to the <a href="#itemrecord">item record</a> for each item loaned.  An effective circulation system provides the means of identifying items on loan to a specific <a href="#patron">patron</a> (including those which are <a href="#overdue">overdue</a>) and enables <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> to place <a href="#hold">hold</a>s, <a href="#recall">recall</a> items needed before the <a href="#duedate">due date</a>, and notify <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s when items are overdue.  An <em>automated</em> circulation system is capable of generating <a href="#circstats">circulation statistics</a> for planning and reporting purposes.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>circ system</em>.  Synonymous with <em>charging system</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#automatedcheckout">automated checkout</a>, <a href="#barcode">barcode</a>, and <a href="#librarycard">library card</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="citation"><b>citation</b></a>       
</dt><dd>In the literary sense, any written or spoken reference to an authority or precedent, or to the <a href="#verbatim">verbatim</a> words of another speaker or writer.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#usage">usage</a>, a written <a href="#reference">reference</a> to a specific <a href="#work">work</a> or portion of a work (<a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#article">article</a>, <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a>, <a href="#report">report</a>, musical <a href="#composition">composition</a>, etc.) by a particular <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#editor">editor</a>, <a href="#composer">composer</a>, etc., which clearly identifies the <a href="#document">document</a> in which the work is to be found.  The frequency with which a work is <a href="#cite">cite</a>d is sometimes considered a measure of its importance in the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of the <a href="#field">field</a>.  Citation <a href="#format">format</a> varies from one <a href="#field">field</a> of study to another but includes at a minimum author, <a href="#title">title</a>, and <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>.  An <em>incomplete</em> citation can make a source difficult if not impossible to locate.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>cite</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#citationindex">citation index</a> and <a href="#selfcitation">self-citation</a>.  
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Examples</em>:
<dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Book</em>:  
<dl><dt></dt><dd><b>Chappell, Warren.  <em>A Short History of the Printed Word</em>.  Boston:  Nonpareil Books, 1970.</b></dd></dl>
</dd><dd><em>Periodical article</em>:  
<dl><dt></dt><dd><b>Dow, Ronald F.  "Editorial Gatekeepers Confronted by the Electronic Journal."  <em>College &amp; Research Libraries</em> 61 (2000): 146-154.</b></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
Citation <a href="#stylemanual">style manual</a>s are available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>.  <a href="http://dir.yahoo.com/Social_Science/Linguistics_and_Human_Languages/Languages/Specific_Languages/English/Grammar__Usage__and_Style/Style_Guides/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of <a href="#online">online</a> style <a href="#guide">guide</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#apastyle">APA style</a>, <a href="#mlastyle">MLA style</a>, and <a href="#electronicstyle">electronic style</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="citationanalysis"><b>citation analysis</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibliometrics">bibliometric</a> technique in which <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#cite">cite</a>d in <a href="#publication">publication</a>s are examined to determine patterns of <a href="#scholarlycommunication">scholarly communication</a>, for example, the comparative importance of <a href="#book">book</a>s versus <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, or of <a href="#currency">current</a> versus <a href="#retrospective">retrospective</a> <a href="#source">source</a>s, in one or more academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="citationchasing"><b>citation chasing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A legitimate <a href="#research">research</a> technique in which the <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a> of <a href="#work">work</a>s already located in a <a href="#litsearch">literature search</a> are examined ("mined") for additional <a href="#source">source</a>s containing further <a href="#information">information</a> on the <a href="#topic">topic</a>.  The process can be facilitated by using a <a href="#citationindex">citation index</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="citationindex"><b>citation index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A three-part <a href="#index">index</a> in which <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#cite">cite</a>d during a specific year are listed <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by name of <a href="#author">author</a> <a href="#cite">cite</a>d, followed by the names of the citing authors (<a href="#source">source</a>s) in a "Citation Index."  Full <a href="#bibliography">bibliographic</a> <a href="#information">information</a> for the citing author is given in a "Source Index."  Also provided is a "Subject Index," usually listing <a href="#article">article</a>s by significant words in the <a href="#title">title</a>.  <a href="#research">Research</a>ers can use this tool to trace interconnections among authors citing <a href="#paper">paper</a>s on the same <a href="#topic">topic</a>, and to determine the frequency with which a specific work is cited by others, an indication of its importance in the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of the <a href="#field">field</a>.  
<p>
<a href="#citation">Citation</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> originated in 1961 when Eugene Garfield, Columbia University graduate in chemistry and <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a>, and founder of the fledgling <a href="http://www.isinet.com/isi/">Institute for Scientific Information</a> (ISI), received an NIH <a href="#grant">grant</a> to produce the experimental <em>Genetics Citation Index</em> which evolved into the <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <b><em>Science Citation Index</em></b>.  ISI subsequently <a href="#publishing">published</a> <b><em>Social Sciences Citation Index</em></b> beginning in 1972 and <b><em>Arts &amp; Humanities Citation Index</em></b> from 1978.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#citationchasing">citation chasing</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="citationorder"><b>citation order</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the order in which the <a href="#facet">facet</a>s or <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>s of a <a href="#class">class</a> are to be combined in <a href="#numberbuilding">number building</a>.  For example, juvenile court procedure in the United States is expressed in a <a href="#notation">notation</a> built or synthesized from four facets: <b>345/.73/081/0269</b>.  The citation order for the <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> of law (<b>34</b>) is branch of the law (criminal <b>5</b>), jurisdiction (United States <b>73</b>), topic in the branch of law (juvenile court <b>081</b>), and <a href="#standardsubdivision">standard subdivision</a> (<b>0269</b> for procedure).  Instructions for citation order are provided in the <a href="#classificationschedule">Schedule</a>s.  When number building is not permitted or possible, an <a href="#precedence">order of precedence</a> with respect to the choice of facets or characteristics is provided (<em>DDC</em>). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="citationstyle"><b>citation style</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#citation">citation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cite"><b>cite</b></a>
</dt><dd>To <a href="#quotation">quote</a> or refer to an authority
outside oneself, usually in support of a point or conclusion, or by way
of explanation or example. In scholarly <a href="#publication">publication</a>, the <a href="#source">source</a> of such a reference is indicated in a <a href="#footnote">footnote</a> or <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>.  Also used as a shortened form of the <a href="#term">term</a> <a href="#citation">citation</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="citydirectory"><b>city directory</b></a>
</dt><dd>A three-way <a href="#directory">directory</a> that lists the residents and businesses located in a specific town or city <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by name, with street address and telephone number included in each <a href="#entry">entry</a>.
In a second section, name(s) and addresses are listed by phone number,
and in a third section, names and phone numbers are listed by street
address. <a href="#publishing">Published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly and sold by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>, current city directories often include zip code and <a href="#censustract">census tract</a> locators for use in marketing.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, they are usually shelved in <a href="#readyreference">ready reference</a> or in the <a href="#refstacks">reference stacks</a>.  Synonymous with <em>cross reference directory</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="citymap"><b>city map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a>, larger in <a href="#scale">scale</a> than a <a href="#roadmap">road map</a>, showing in considerable detail the streets, public transportation lines, hospitals, schools, <a href="#publiclibrary">libraries</a>, museums, parks, and other major institutions and landmarks within the boundaries of a city. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cjk"><b>CJK</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> that refers to materials <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the Chinese, Japanese, and Korean <a href="#language">language</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cla1"><b>CLA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#canadianla"><b>C</b>anadian <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a> and <a href="#cla"><b>C</b>atholic <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clabook"><b>CLA Book of the Year for Children</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a> established in 1947 and presented <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly under the auspices of the <a href="#canadianla">Canadian Library Association</a> to the <a href="#author">author</a> of the most outstanding <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a> of creative writing (<a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, <a href="#poetry">poetry</a>, retelling of traditional <a href="#literature">literature</a>, etc.) <a href="#publishing">published</a> in Canada during the preceding year.  The author must be a citizen or permanent resident of Canada.  <a href="http://www.acs.ucalgary.ca/%7Edkbrown/awards.html">Click here</a> to see a list of past award winners.  Compare with <a href="#ameliafrances">Amelia Frances Howard-Gibbon Illustrator's Award</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#carnegiemedal">Carnegie Medal</a> and <a href="#newbery">Newbery Medal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="claim"><b>claim</b></a>
</dt><dd>A notice from a <a href="#library">library</a> informing the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agency</a> that a specific <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> on <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>, or <a href="#bibitem">item</a> on <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>,
has not been received within a reasonable time, with a request that a
replacement copy be sent. Claimed items are noted in the <a href="#checkinrecord">check-in record</a> attached to the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> created to represent the <a href="#publication">publication</a> in the library <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clasp"><b>clasp</b></a>
</dt><dd>A hinged catch made of ornamented metal, ivory, or bone, attached to the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of the <a href="#board">board</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a>, used from the 14th to the early 17th century to keep the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> pressed firmly together and to prevent the <a href="#cover">cover</a> from <a href="#warping">warping</a>.  Today, clasps are used mainly on personal <a href="#diary">diaries</a> and <a href="#album">album</a>s, and may include a lock to prevent the <a href="#volume">volume</a> from being opened by someone other than the person who holds the key. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="class"><b>class</b></a>
</dt><dd>A grouping of objects or concepts based on one or more <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>s, <a href="#attribute">attribute</a>s,
properties, qualities, etc., which they have in common, for the purpose
of classifying them according to an established system. In <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>s, the members of a class (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#book">book</a>s) are divided into more specific <a href="#subclass">subclass</a>es (<a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>s), sub-subclasses (<a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>s), and so on.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mainclass">main class</a>.
<p>
In human resources management, a group of <a href="#position">position</a>s within an organization, for which the <a href="#qualification">qualification</a>s, duties, responsibilities, evaluation procedures, etc., are comparable and which share the same scale of <a href="#rank">rank</a> and pay.  In <a href="#library">library</a> employment, positions are typically classified as follows:  <a href="#librarydirector">library director</a>, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>, library technician, library technical assistant, and clerical assistant.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classic"><b>classic</b></a>
</dt><dd>A widely read <a href="#work">work</a> recognized as outstanding in its <a href="#field">field</a>.  Such a work remains <a href="#inprint">in print</a> long after initial <a href="#publication">publication</a>; is <a href="#translation">translated</a>, <a href="#adaptation">adapted</a>, and <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in multiple <a href="#edition">edition</a>s; and continues to be the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of <a href="#criticism">criticism</a>, <a href="#commentary">commentary</a>, study, and analysis (<em>example</em>: <b><em>The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn</em></b> by Mark Twain).  Also refers to a <a href="#featurefilm">feature film</a> (Chaplin's <b><em>The Gold Rush</em></b>) or <a href="#documentary">documentary</a> (Robert Flaherty's <b><em>Nanook of the North</em></b>) that has withstood the test of time.  Compare with <a href="#classics">classics</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classics"><b>classics</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the non-Christian <a href="#work">work</a>s written in the Greek and Latin <a href="#language">language</a>s prior to 600 AD (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Republic</em></b> of Plato).  In a broader sense, outstanding <a href="#book">book</a>s on any <a href="#subject">subject</a>, <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> or <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>, written for <a href="#adult">adult</a>s or <a href="#childrensbook">children</a>.  Compare with <a href="#classic">classic</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classification"><b>classification</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of dividing objects or concepts into logically hierarchical <a href="#class">class</a>es, <a href="#subclass">subclass</a>es, and sub-subclasses based on the <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>s they have in common and those that distinguish them.  Also used as a shortened form of the term <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> or classification scheme.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#crossclass">cross-classification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classificationschedule"><b>classification schedule</b></a>
</dt><dd>The names assigned to the <a href="#class">class</a>es in a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, listed in the order of their <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ic <a href="#notation">notation</a>.  In a <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical classification</a> system, the arrangement of the schedule(s) indicates levels of specificity.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#auxiliaryschedule">auxiliary schedule</a>, <a href="#mainschedule">main schedule</a>, <a href="#relativeindex">relative index</a>, and <a href="#schedulereduction">schedule reduction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classificationscheme"><b>classification scheme</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="csna"><b>Classification Society of North American (CSNA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonprofit <a href="#interdisciplinary">interdisciplinary</a> organization devoted to promoting the scientific study of <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> and clustering, and to the dissemination of scientific and educational <a href="#information">information</a> related to its <a href="#field">field</a>s of interest.  The <b>CSNA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#biannual">biannual</a> <em><a href="http://www.pitt.edu/%7Ecsna/joc.html">Journal of Classification</a></em> and the <em><a href="http://osler.wustl.edu/%7Eshannon/csna/news.index.html">CSNA Newsletter</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.pitt.edu/%7Ecsna/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CSNA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ifcs">International Federation of Classification Societies</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classificationsys"><b>classification system</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of <a href="#class">class</a>es <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> according to a set of pre-established principles, for the purpose of organizing <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in a <a href="#collection">collection</a>, or <a href="#entry">entries</a> in an <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, or <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, into groups based on their similarities and differences, to facilitate <a href="#access">access</a> and <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a>.  In the United States, most <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s are classified by <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  Classification systems can be <a href="#enumerativeclass">enumerative</a> or <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a>, <a href="#broadclassification">broad</a> or <a href="#closeclassification">close</a>.  In the United States, most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> use <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, but <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> prefer <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#notation">notation</a>, <a href="#colonclassification">Colon Classification</a>, and <a href="#csna">Classification Society of North America</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classified"><b>classified</b></a>
</dt><dd>The status of a <a href="#document">document</a> to which <a href="#access">access</a> is restricted to a few <a href="#authorization">authorized</a> individuals within a military or <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>, <a href="#research">research</a> institution, private corporation, or other organization, usually because it contains highly sensitive <a href="#information">information</a> which might be misused by unauthorized persons.  When secrecy is no longer required, the document may be <a href="#declassified">declassified</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#needtoknow">need to know</a> and <em><a href="#foia">Freedom of Information Act (FOIA)</a></em>.
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#refbook">reference</a> tool (<a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>, <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>, etc.) organized according to a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, usually by <a href="#subject">subject</a> or some other <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> based on <a href="#content">content</a>, as opposed to a strictly <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> or numerical listing of <a href="#entry">entries</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classifiedcatalog"><b>classified catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> in which the <a href="#entry">entries</a> are filed according to a pre-established <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, with <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s entered under as many <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s as apply to the <a href="#content">content</a> of each <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  An <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> <a href="#subjectindex">subject index</a> facilitates the use of a <a href="#classified">classified</a> catalog, which is usually maintained alongside an <a href="#author">author</a> and/or <a href="#title">title</a> catalog.  Compare with <a href="#dictionarycatalog">dictionary catalog</a> and <a href="#dividedcatalog">divided catalog</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classifiedindex"><b>classified index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#index">index</a> in which <a href="#entry">entries</a> are arranged under <a href="#heading">heading</a>s and <a href="#subheading">subheading</a>s indicating <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> divisions and subdivisions within <a href="#class">class</a>es based on the <a href="#subject">subject</a> matter indexed, rather than in <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> or numerical sequence.  To use such an index effectively, a <a href="#subjectindex">subject index</a> is required.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classnumber"><b>class number</b></a>
</dt><dd>The specific <a href="#notation">notation</a> used in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> to identify a <a href="#class">class</a>, for example, <b>943.085</b> assigned to <a href="#work">work</a>s on the history of the Weimar Republic in Germany.  In <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a>, the corresponding notation is <b>DD237</b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#basenumber">base number</a>, <a href="#discontinuednumber">discontinued number</a>, <a href="#interdiscipnumber">interdisciplinary number</a>, and <a href="#numberbuilding">number building</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classroomcollec"><b>classroom collection</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small semi-permanent <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> selected by a <a href="#schoollibrary">school library</a> or <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a> for the general classroom use use of an instructor and the students enrolled in a course (or courses).  Compare with <a href="#classroomlibrary">classroom library</a> and <a href="#classroomloan">classroom loan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classroomlibrary"><b>classroom library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>
located permanently in a school classroom for the use of instructor and
students in support of the general curriculum. Such a collection may
include <a href="#refbook">reference materials</a> such as a <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>, <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a>, <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>, general <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>, etc.   Compare with <a href="#classroomcollec">classroom collection</a> and <a href="#classroomloan">classroom loan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="classroomloan"><b>classroom loan</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> on temporary loan from a <a href="#schoollibrary">school library</a> or <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a>
to a classroom, for the use of instructor and students, usually in
support of a specific project or curriculum unit. Compare with <a href="#classroomcollec">classroom collection</a> and <a href="#classroomloan">classroom loan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="claytablet"><b>clay tablet</b></a>
</dt><dd>The earliest known <a href="#book">book</a>s were <a href="#inscription">inscribed</a> on small, thin, wet slabs of clay, using a thin, sharp instrument called a <a href="#stylus">stylus</a> to incise the wedge-shaped <a href="#cuneiform">cuneiform</a> <a href="#character">character</a>s of the written <a href="#language">language</a>s
of ancient Mesopotamia. The finished tablets were sun-dried or
kiln-fired, then enclosed in a protective outer shell of dried or fired
clay inscribed with a <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#abstract">abstract</a> of the <a href="#contents">contents</a>.  Although clay tablets were too heavy to be portable in large numbers and too small to <a href="#record">record</a> long <a href="#text">text</a>s effectively, they were much more <a href="#durability">durable</a> than the <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a> <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>s that <a href="#superseded">superseded</a> them.  <a href="http://special.lib.umn.edu/rare/cuneiform/">Click here</a> to learn more about clay tablets.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clearinghouse"><b>clearinghouse</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization or unit within an organization that functions
as a central agency for collecting, organizing, storing, and
disseminating <a href="#document">document</a>s, usually within a specific academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or <a href="#field">field</a>.  A clearinghouse may also assist the <a href="#research">research</a> process by maintaining <a href="#records">records</a> of <a href="#information">information</a> resources for referral (<em>examples</em>: <a href="#eric">ERIC</a> and <a href="#loex">LOEX</a>).  Also spelled <em>clearing house</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cliche"><b>cliche</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the French word <em>clicher</em> meaning "to stereotype."  A word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>,
or expression so overused that it has lost its impact and, to some
degree, its original meaning. Considered unimaginative, cliches are
avoided by serious writers and speakers, except in <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> when the <a href="#author">author</a> wishes to make a point about the mentality of the speaker.  <a href="#dictionary">Dictionaries</a> of cliches are available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of larger <a href="#library">libraries</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#literature">literature</a>, an overused <a href="#plot">plot</a> element or <a href="#character">character</a> type whose lack of originality detracts from the quality of the <a href="#work">work</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clickanddrag"><b>click-and-drag</b></a>
</dt><dd>To change the position of an <a href="#icon">icon</a>, <a href="#filename">filename</a>, <a href="#window">window</a>, or other movable element on a computer screen by clicking on it with a pointing <a href="#device">device</a>, such as a <a href="#mouse">mouse</a>, and then holding down on the button to shift the element to another location on the <a href="#monitor">screen</a>.  The technique can be used to reposition <a href="#window">window</a>s on a <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> <a href="#desktop">desktop</a>, move computer <a href="#file">file</a>s from one <a href="#directory">directory</a> or subdirectory to another in <a href="#storage">storage</a>, and organize <a href="#bookmark">bookmark</a>ed <a href="#website">Web site</a>s in <a href="#folder">folder</a>s in most <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>s.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="client"><b>client</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who uses the services of a professionally trained
expert, or of a professional organization or institution, usually in
exchange for payment of a <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s employed in <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> usually refer to the people they serve as users or <a href="#patron">patron</a>s because <a href="#library">libraries</a> have traditionally provided most services without charge.  <a href="#informationbroker">Information broker</a>s who operate on a fee-for-service basis can be more appropriately said to serve "clients."    
<p>
Also refers to a computer connected to a <a href="#network">network</a> such as the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, equipped with <a href="#software">software</a> enabling the user to <a href="#access">access</a> resources available on another computer, called a <a href="#server">server</a>, connected to the same network. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#clientserver">client-server</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clientele"><b>clientele</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the persons who use a <a href="#library">library</a>'s services and <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s on a regular or irregular basis, usually those who live in the <a href="#librarydistrict">district</a> that funds it operations or are members of the institution it serves.  Successful <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> depends on the <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>'s <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> of the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s and preferences of the library's clientele.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#usersurvey">user survey</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clientserver"><b>client-server</b></a>
</dt><dd>Wide-area (<a href="#widearea">WAN</a>) or local-area <a href="#network">network</a> (<a href="#localarea">LAN</a>) architecture that makes it possible for a <a href="#client">client</a> computer (usually a <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a> <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>) to <a href="#download">download</a> <a href="#information">information</a> or processing from a <a href="#server">server</a> machine, as opposed to a system that uses <a href="#dedicated">dedicated</a> <a href="#terminal">terminal</a>s connected to a <a href="#minicomputer">minicomputer</a> or <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a>.  The size and speed of computer required as a server (<a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a>, minicomputer, or mainframe) depends on the nature of the <a href="#application">application</a>s to be installed and the amount of anticipated use.  Also refers to the <a href="#software">software</a> used to establish the connection between a client and server.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#osi">Open Systems Interconnection</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clipboard"><b>clipboard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small amount of computer <a href="#memory">memory</a> reserved as a temporary <a href="#storage">storage</a> place in the exchange of <a href="#data">data</a> between <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#application">application</a>s.  In <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a>, this is normally accomplished by selecting the <a href="#option">option</a> to "cut" or "copy" from one <a href="#document">document</a> and "paste" into another.  Data transferred to the clipboard is lost when another cut/copy operation commences, unless <a href="#save">save</a>d as a separate <a href="#file">file</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clipping"><b>clipping</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#page">page</a>, piece of a page, or pages cut or torn from a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually from a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> or <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, by a person who wishes to save an <a href="#article">article</a>, <a href="#editorial">editorial</a>, <a href="#letter">letter to the editor</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>, <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>, etc.  Large collections of clippings are usually stored in a <em>clipping file</em>, <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> by <a href="#subject">subject</a> or some other method of <a href="#classification">classification</a>.   Synonymous with <em>cutting</em>.  Compare with <a href="#tearsheet">tear sheet</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#clippingservice">clipping service</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clippingservice"><b>clipping service</b></a>
</dt><dd>A service, usually performed in a <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a>, in which news announcements, <a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, and other items of interest to the <a href="#hostorg">host organization</a> are <a href="#clipping">clipped</a> from <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s
and news services on a daily or weekly basis, to be forwarded to
appropriate personnel within the organization, based on pre-established
<a href="#interestprofile">interest profile</a>s.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> for clipping services is available in the <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>.  Synonymous with <em>clipping bureau</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clir1"><b>CLIR</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#clir"><b>C</b>ouncil on <b>L</b>ibrary and <b>I</b>nformation <b>R</b>esources</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cloisonne"><b>cloisonne</b></a>
</dt><dd>An elegant style of <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>
produced by Italian and Greek craftsmen of the 11th century in which an
ornamental design in narrow metal strips was soldered onto a metal
plate, and the open spaces between the strips filled with enamel in
various colors, to form the outer surface of the cover. Books <a href="#binding">bound</a> in this style are usually very valuable, especially if they are in good <a href="#condition">condition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closeclassification"><b>close classification</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> in which the main <a href="#class">class</a>es and divisions are minutely <a href="#subdivision">subdivided</a>, allowing very specific <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>s of each <a href="#subject">subject</a> to be differentiated.  The opposite of <a href="#broadclassification">broad classification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closedcaption"><b>closed caption (CC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A continuous moving line of <a href="#text">text</a> (called a <em>crawl</em>) along the bottom of the screen in a television <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>, giving the <a href="#narration">narration</a> or <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a>,
and noting any non-speech vocalizations (laughter, screams, dogs
barking, etc.) or sound effects (music, applause, doorbells, etc.).
Used mainly for the hearing-impaired and in bilingual programming, <em>closed captioning</em> is visible only with the aid of a special decoder.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> <em>closed captioned</em> is entered in the <a href="#notearea">note area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> to identify an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> that includes the feature.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closedcatalog"><b>closed catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> to which new <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s
are no longer added, or in which additions are restricted to certain
categories, although existing records continue to be removed as they
are revised, corrected, and/or converted to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  After <a href="#retrocon">retrospective conversion</a> is completed, a closed catalog is usually removed from public <a href="#access">access</a> and eventually discarded.  Compare with <a href="#frozencatalog">frozen catalog</a> and <a href="#opencatalog">open catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closedcircuit"><b>closed circuit television (CCTV) </b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#videotape">video</a> system used internally in some large <a href="#library">libraries</a>, for conferencing and to monitor traffic for <a href="#security">security</a> purposes.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closedendindex"><b>closed-end index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#index">index</a> covering one or more <a href="#document">document</a>s or <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, <a href="#compile">compile</a>d all at one time (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Canadian Feature Film Index, 1913-1985</em></b>).  Compare with <a href="#openendindex">open-end index</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#singleindex">single index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closedentry"><b>closed entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#notearea">note</a> in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for a <a href="#serial">serial</a> or <a href="#continuation">continuation</a>, giving the complete <a href="#information">information</a> for all the <a href="#part">part</a>s or <a href="#volume">volume</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a>, or in the <a href="#holdingsnote">holdings note</a> in the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> for such a <a href="#title">title</a>, indicating all the parts or volumes <a href="#holdings">held</a> by a the <a href="#library">library</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>v. 1-10, 1936-46</b>), as distinct from the <a href="#openentry">open entry</a> for an <em>ongoing</em> serial <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> or <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>v.1- ,1936- </b>).  For <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, a closed entry usually indicates that the subscription was <a href="#canceled">canceled</a> or the <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#ceased">ceased</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closedfile"><b>closed file</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#document">document</a>s in which additions or changes are unlikely to occur, or a <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#record">record</a>s to which <a href="#access">access</a> is <a href="#restricted">restricted</a> or denied, except under special circumstances.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closedreserve"><b>closed reserve</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#bibitem">item</a> on <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> which may be <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> by a <a href="#register">register</a>ed <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>, but may not be removed from <a href="#library">library</a> premises.  Also, a reserve <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> shelved in a <a href="#closedstacks">closed stack</a> from which requested items must be retrieved by a member of the <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a>.  Compare with <a href="#openreserve">open reserve</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closedstacks"><b>closed stacks</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shelving area in a <a href="#library">library</a> to which only to members of the <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> have <a href="#access">access</a>, established to protect the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> or conserve space by using <a href="#aisle">aisle</a>s narrower than the <a href="#standard">standard</a> width in <a href="#openstacks">open stacks</a>.  <a href="#libmaterials">Materials</a> are retrieved from closed <a href="#stacks">stacks</a> by staff members upon request.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#callslip">call slip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closeout"><b>close out</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#title">title</a> offered for retail sale at a significantly reduced price because the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> is allowing it to go <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>.  A rebate may be offered by the publisher to the <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> for <a href="#copy">copies</a> that do not sell. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closescore"><b>close score</b></a>
</dt><dd>A vocal music <a href="#score">score</a> in which all the <a href="#part">part</a>s are given on a minimum <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#stave">stave</a>s, usually two, as in a hymn.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closetdrama"><b>closet drama</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#play">play</a> written to be read rather than performed on the stage, for example, the dramatic <a href="#work">work</a>s of the French <a href="#poetry">poet</a> Alfred de Musset.  Also refers to a drama originally intended for performance, which survives as a work of <a href="#literature">literature</a> but is rarely if ever performed (Byron's <b><em>Manfred</em></b>).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="closing"><b>closing</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the procedures followed by the <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> when the facility closes at the end of a day, such as informing <a href="#patron">patron</a>s that it is time to leave, checking the premises to be certain all users have vacated, <a href="#logoff">logging off</a> computer systems, turning off lights and <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, locking doors, switching on pre-recorded phone messages, activating <a href="#security">security</a> alarms, etc.  Size and design of facility determine the length of time and <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> required to close.  In very large facilities, a <a href="#checklist">checklist</a> may be followed for each floor, and one or more <a href="#securityguard">security guard</a>s may assist in clearing the building.  Compare with <a href="#opening">opening</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#libraryclosure">library closure</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cloth"><b>cloth</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic <a href="#term">term</a> for any woven material used since the early 19th century to <a href="#cover">cover</a> the  <a href="#board">board</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a>, as opposed to the <a href="#leather">leather</a>, <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> used in earlier <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, or the <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s used today.  Dyed book cloth used in <a href="#publishersbinding">edition binding</a>
is woven from cotton or linen, filled with starch sizing, or coated or
impregnated with some other compound, then pressed under heat. Because
the covers of cloth-bound <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>s are not designed to withstand heavy use, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s add an attractively designed paper <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> for protection (and marketing purposes).  <a href="#volume">Volume</a>s that must withstand heavy use are often given a <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a> in a heavier, more <a href="#durability">durable</a> material such as <a href="#buckram">buckram</a>.  The term is also used in publishers' <a href="#tradecatalog">catalog</a>s to distinguish the <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> from the <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>.  Synonymous with <em>clothbound</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#halfcloth">half cloth</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clothboard"><b>cloth board</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#flannelboard">flannel board</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clothbook"><b>cloth book</b></a>
