</dt><dd>A small, <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> entirely on sturdy woven fabric and given a flexible <a href="#binding">binding</a> for toddlers who have not yet developed sufficient manual dexterity to turn <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#page">page</a>s
without tearing them. To withstand drooling, the cloth pages may be
treated with a moisture-resistant substance. In the 19th century, this
type of <a href="#toybook">toy book</a> was called a <em>rag book</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clothbound"><b>cloth-bound</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clothjoint"><b>cloth joint</b></a>
</dt><dd>A strip of cloth used to reinforce the inside of the front and back <a href="#joint">joint</a>s in some <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a>s, and in very large, thick, or heavy <a href="#book">book</a>s.  In  <a href="#volume">volume</a>s of normal size and thickness, the unreinforced joints are usually formed on the inside by the fold in each <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clr1"><b>CLR</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#chlitreview"><b>C</b>hildren's <b>L</b>iterature <b>R</b>eview</a></em> and <a href="#clir"><b>C</b>ouncil on <b>L</b>ibrary and <b>I</b>nformation <b>R</b>esources (CLIR)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clubline"><b>club line</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single <a href="#indention">indented</a> line at the beginning of a paragraph when it appears at the <a href="#foot">foot</a> of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#column">column</a> or <a href="#page">page</a> of <a href="#text">text</a>, considered awkward by skilled <a href="#typesetting">typesetter</a>s and avoided whenever possible.  Compare with <a href="#orphan">orphan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cni1"><b>CNI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cni"><b>C</b>oalition for <b>N</b>etworked <b>I</b>nformation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cni"><b>Coalition for Networked Information (CNI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1990, <b>CNI</b> is a nonprofit organization with headquarters in Washington D.C., dedicated to supporting the future of <a href="#network">network</a>ed <a href="#infotech">information technology</a> for the advancement of <a href="#scholarlycommunication">scholarly communication</a> and the enhancement of intellectual productivity.  Sponsored by the <a href="#arl">Association of Research Libraries</a> (ARL) and <a href="http://www.educause.edu/">EDUCAUSE</a>, <b>CNI</b>'s membership includes 200 institutions representing higher education, <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a>, information technology, <a href="#library">libraries</a>, and library-related activities.  <a href="http://www.cni.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CNI</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coated"><b>coated</b></a>
</dt><dd>The smooth surface of <a href="#paper">paper</a>s to which a thin layer of mineral, wax, resin, plastic, or <a href="#emulsion">emulsion</a> has been applied, either in the <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a> machine prior to drying and <a href="#finish">finish</a>ing,
or by a separate coating machine after manufacture (some papers are
double-coated using both methods). Coated papers are used to <a href="#printing">print</a> <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, wall <a href="#calendar">calendar</a>s, <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>s, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> and <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s, and other materials in which detailed visual elements predominate (<a href="#artbook">art book</a>s, <a href="#exhibitcatalog">exhibit catalog</a>s, <a href="#coffee">coffee table book</a>s, etc.).  The finish can be <a href="#glossy">glossy</a> or dull.  Also known as <em>art papers</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coauthor"><b>coauthor</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#jointauthor">joint author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coaxial"><b>coaxial cable</b></a>
</dt><dd>A high-capacity metal cable consisting of four layers: a solid
or stranded wire encased in insulation, shielded by braided wire
covered in plastic insulation. Various types of coaxial cable are used
extensively in cable television transmission and computer <a href="#network">network</a>s because "coax" can carry more <a href="#data">data</a> and is less susceptible to interference than the <a href="#twistedpair">twisted pair</a> wire used in older telephone systems.  Compare with <a href="#opticalfiber">optical fiber</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cocked"><b>cocked</b></a>
</dt><dd>A serious <a href="#binding">binding</a> defect in which the <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> is angled or twisted in a way that prevents the <a href="#board">board</a>s from lining up evenly with each other.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#shelfcocked">shelf-cocked</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cockedup"><b>cocked-up initial</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#raisedcapital">raised capital</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cockle"><b>cockle</b></a>
</dt><dd>A slightly puckered <a href="#finish">finish</a> produced naturally or artificially when <a href="#paper">paper</a> shrinks unevenly as it is dried under little or no tension, as in the production of <a href="#onionskin">onionskin</a>.  The <a href="#board">board</a>s and paper in a finished <a href="#book">book</a> may cockle if heat is applied following exposure to excessive moisture.  The <a href="#condition">condition</a> can be prevented by controlling temperature and relative <a href="#humidity">humidity</a> in storage.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cockled"><b>cockled</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> or <a href="#board">board</a>s appear puckered, wavy, wrinkled, or curled, usually due to excessive heat and/or <a href="#humidity">humidity</a> in drying.  In a book <a href="#cover">cover</a>, the condition can result from the incorrect use of <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> (too much or the wrong kind).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coda"><b>coda</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin word <em>cauda</em> meaning "tail."  An independent passage added at the end of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> or literary <a href="#composition">composition</a> to bring the <a href="#piece">piece</a> to a graceful conclusion by drawing preceding motifs and themes together in a satisfying <a href="#resolution">resolution</a>.  The last <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> of a <a href="#biography">biography</a>, the last <a href="#essay">essay</a> in a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of essays, or the last story in a <a href="#book">book</a> of <a href="#shortstory">short stories</a> is sometimes written as a coda to tie the other parts together.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coden"><b>CODEN</b></a>
</dt><dd>A system of <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a> codes developed by the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) to uniquely and permanently identify sci-tech <a href="#serial">serial</a> and <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>ic <a href="#publication">publication</a>s.  Responsibility for administering the system was transferred to Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) in 1975.  The <b>CODEN</b> is used in electronic <a href="#information">information</a> systems to process <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic</a> <a href="#data">data</a> because it is more concise than the full <a href="#title">title</a> and less ambiguous than an <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> title.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="codeofethics"><b>code of ethics</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of <a href="#standards">standards</a> governing the conduct and judgment of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a>, and other <a href="#information">information</a> professionals in their work.  The <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/ethics.html">ALA Code of Ethics</a></em> sets standards for equitable <a href="#access">access</a>, <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>, <a href="#confidentiality">confidentiality</a>, respect for <a href="#intellectualproperty">intellectual property</a> <a href="#rights">rights</a>, excellence, <a href="#accuracy">accuracy</a>, integrity, impartiality, courtesy, and respect for colleagues and library <a href="#patron">patron</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="codex"><b>codex</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, an ancient <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> written with a <a href="#stylus">stylus</a> on hinged wax-covered tablets made of metal, wood, or ivory, called <em>codices</em>.  Later, a manuscript written on <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s of  <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>, or <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a>, fastened at one side to allow the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> to open like a <a href="#book">book</a>.  This <a href="#format">format</a> was used for law books in ancient Rome, and for devotional <a href="#work">work</a>s and the <a href="#classics">classics</a> during the Middle Ages.  According to <b><em>Harrod's Librarians' Glossary</em></b>, the oldest Greek <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> codex known to exist (the <b><em>Codex Sinaiticus</em></b>) has been in the possession of the <a href="#britishlib">British Library</a> since 1933.  Also refers to the form of the modern book, consisting of individual leaves of writing material <a href="#binding">bound</a> together along one <a href="#bindingedge">edge</a> and enclosed in a protective <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pugillaria">pugillaria</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="codicology"><b>codicology</b></a>
</dt><dd>The study of the physical characteristics of <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s.  By identifying the <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>s and workshops that produced them, <em>codicologists</em>
are able to establish interrelationships among manuscripts, which
assist scholars in detecting alterations (accidental and intentional)
in <a href="#classics">classical</a> and medieval <a href="#text">text</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#bibliology">bibliology</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="codification"><b>codification</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of creating systematic rules to govern a specific activity, such as the <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> of <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic material</a>s.  In the United States, Britain, and Canada, the joint efforts of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, the <a href="#la">Library Association</a> (UK), and the <a href="#canadianla">Canadian Library Association</a> have produced <em><a href="#anglo">Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</a></em> which apply to <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> in various <a href="#format">format</a>s (<a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#cartographic">cartographic material</a>s, music, <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>s, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s and <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> materials, computer <a href="#file">file</a>s, three-dimensional <a href="#artifact">artifact</a>s and <a href="#realia">realia</a>, <a href="#microform">microform</a>s, and <a href="#serial">serial</a>s).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coedition"><b>co-edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> for which two or more <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s share responsibility, for example, <b><em>The Great Libraries:  From Antiquity to the Renaissance</em></b>, <a href="#publishing">published</a>
in 2000 by Oak Knoll Press and The British Library. In most cases, the
original publisher grants the exclusive right to market and <a href="#distributor">distribute</a> the <a href="#publication">publication</a> within a specific sales territory to one or more other publishers (see <a href="#copublishing">co-publishing</a>).  The <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a co-edition may bear the <a href="#imprint">imprint</a> of the originator, of one of the companies granted distribution rights, or of all the co-publishers.  Compare with <a href="#exportedition">export edition</a> and <a href="#jointpub">joint publication</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#jointimprint">joint imprint</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coextensive"><b>coextensive entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>The principle in <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> that the <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> assigned to a <a href="#work">work</a> should encompass <em>all</em> the significant concepts covered in the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> (and no more).  Thus a <a href="#book">book</a>
about painters and poets would require the heading "Painters and
poets," rather than separate headings for "Painters" and "Poets."
Coextensive indexing is attempted in the <a href="#preserved">PRECIS</a> system.  Also spelled <em>co-extensive entry</em>.  Compare with <a href="#specificentry">specific entry</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coextensiveheading"><b>coextensive heading</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> that indicates all or most of the <a href="#subject">subject</a>s of a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>, for example, the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject heading</a> <b>United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Participation, African American--Juvenile literature</b> assigned to the <a href="#juvenile">juvenile</a> <a href="#book">book</a> <em>Black, Blue &amp; Gray:  African Americans in the Civil War</em> (Simon &amp; Schuster: 1998).  Also spelled <em>co-extensive heading</em>.  Compare with <a href="#postcoordinate">post-coordinate indexing</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#exhaustivity">exhaustivity</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coffee"><b>coffee table book</b></a>
</dt><dd>An expensive <a href="#book">book</a> on a popular <a href="#subject">subject</a>, usually <a href="#oversize">oversize</a> and lavishly illustrated, with the <a href="#text">text</a> clearly subordinate to the <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s.  Designed primarily for display and casual <a href="#browse">browsing</a> rather than <a href="#cover">cover</a>-to-cover reading, coffee table books are often marketed on the decorative appeal of their colorful <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>s.  In <a href="#tradebookstore">trade bookstore</a>s, they may be sold at a deep <a href="#discount">discount</a>, especially at Christmas to attract gift buyers.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> may add them to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> when received as <a href="#gift">gift</a>s, provided <a href="#demand">demand</a> exists for the <a href="#subject">subject</a> and their <a href="#condition">condition</a> is good.  <a href="#academiclib">Academic library</a> <a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a>s generally exclude them.  Compare with <a href="#tablebook">table book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cognitivestyle"><b>cognitive style</b></a>
</dt><dd>The manner in which an individual habitually organizes a
problem-solving or learning experience, especially whether the person
prefers <a href="#content">content</a> that is already structured (lecture-style) or is more likely to impose his/her own structure on the material (<a href="#handson">hands-on</a> approach).  Differences in learning style have important implications for the delivery of <a href="#refservices">reference services</a> and <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>, and for the design of <a href="#onlinetutorial">online tutorial</a>s and <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coilbinding"><b>coil binding</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#spiralbinding">spiral binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coldboot"><b>cold boot</b></a>
</dt><dd>To restart a computer by turning the power off and turning it back on again, causing the <a href="#file">file</a>s in its <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>
to be re-executed. This procedure is sometimes helpful in getting a
computer "unstuck" when it locks up unexpectedly during processing and <a href="#reboot">reboot</a>ing fails to get it going again, but the user should be aware that powering down will result in loss of un<a href="#save">save</a>d <a href="#data">data</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coldcrack"><b>cold-crack</b></a>
</dt><dd>The tendency of the <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> on the <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#perfectbinding">perfect-bound</a> <a href="#book">book</a> to split at very low temperatures, reducing the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> to a pile of <a href="#loose">loose</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>.  The inability of <a href="#hotmelt">hot-melt</a> adhesives to withstand cold temperatures makes them unsuitable for use in <a href="#binding">binding</a>s marketed in countries like Finland and Russia where winter temperatures can be severe.  The problem is eliminated in <a href="#otabind">Otabind</a> <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive binding</a> which uses slower drying, cold-resistant <a href="#polyvinylacetate">polyvinyl acetate</a> (PVA) adhesive.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collaborator"><b>collaborator</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who works closely with one or more associates in producing a <a href="#work">work</a> to which all who participate make the same kind of contribution (<a href="#shared">shared responsibility</a>) or different contributions (<a href="#mixed">mixed responsibility</a>), for example, <a href="#essay">essay</a>s written by different <a href="#author">author</a>s for <a href="#publication">publication</a> in a <a href="#collection">collection</a>, or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s for a <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a> in which the <a href="#text">text</a> is written by a person other than the <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#jointauthor">joint author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collate"><b>collate</b></a>
</dt><dd>To determine, usually by close examination of <a href="#signature">signature</a>s, <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, and other characteristics, if a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> is complete and perfect, or to compare it with descriptions of <a href="#idealcopy">ideal copies</a> found in <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a> for the same purpose.  Also, to compare two <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#page">page</a>-by-page and line-by-line, to establish whether they are identical copies or <a href="#variant">variant</a>s of the same <a href="#text">text</a>.  
<p>
Also, to check a book before <a href="#binding">binding</a> to be sure that it is complete and that the <a href="#section">section</a>s are <a href="#gathering">gathered</a> in correct sequence, a task is made easier by <em>collating marks</em> <a href="#printing">printed</a> along the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a> to make misplaced sections easier to spot.  The marks are concealed after the <a href="#lining">lining</a> has been applied to the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a>.  
</p><p>
Also, to merge two or more ordered sets of <a href="#document">document</a>s, <a href="#records">records</a>, <a href="#page">page</a>s, or <a href="#data">data</a> into a single desired sequence.  High-end <a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a>s usually have collating capability.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collatingmark"><b>collating mark</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#collate">collate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collation"><b>collation</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a <a href="#synonym">synonym</a> for the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> area of a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, which has fallen into disuse.  
<p>
In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, a list of the <a href="#signature">signature</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a>, indicating the number of <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> in each.  Also, the process of checking the physical <a href="#makeup">make-up</a> of a book for completeness before binding, particularly the presence of all <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#plate">plate</a>s, and <a href="#map">map</a>s not <a href="#printing">printed</a> with the <a href="#text">text</a>.   
</p><p>
In <a href="#analyticalbibliog">analytical bibliography</a>, the comparison of two <a href="#text">text</a>s of the same <a href="#work">work</a> to determine which is the first <a href="#edition">edition</a> or the definitive text.  
</p><p>
Also refers to the merger of two ordered sets of <a href="#document">document</a>s, <a href="#records">records</a>, <a href="#page">page</a>s, or <a href="#data">data</a> into a single desired sequence.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectededition"><b>collected edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s of an <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in a single <a href="#volume">volume</a> or <a href="#uniformedition">uniform</a> <a href="#set">set</a> of volumes, usually under a <a href="#collectivetitle">collective title</a>.  Compare with <a href="#authorsedition">author's edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectedwork"><b>collected work</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#collection">collection</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectedworks"><b>collected works</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#authorsedition">author's edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectible"><b>collectible</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any class of things, usually old or <a href="#rarity">rare</a> but lacking intrinsic value, which people accumulate as a hobby or in the expectation that the value will rise (<a href="#autograph">autograph</a>s, <a href="#comicbook">comic book</a>s, <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>s, etc.).  Also used as an adjective to describe something sought by collectors, for example, <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>s and <a href="#incunabula">incunabula</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectingarchives"><b>collecting archives</b></a>
</dt><dd>An independent organization, or unit within a larger organization or institution, responsible for building a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#records">records</a> and <a href="#document">document</a>s from a variety of sources, in keeping with the <a href="#mission">mission</a> of the parent institution, for example, a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> <a href="#repository">repository</a> in the <a href="#library">library</a> of a major university.  <a href="#archives">Archives</a> of this type may provide <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#access">access</a> to a portion of their resources (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.loc.gov/exhibits/declara/declara1.html">Declaring Independence: Drafting the Documents</a></em> <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>) or be completely electronic (<em><a href="http://www.rootsweb.com/%7Eusgenweb/">USGenWeb Archives</a></em> <a href="#host">host</a>ed by RootsWeb).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#personalarchives">personal archives</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collection"><b>collection</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, three or more independent <a href="#work">work</a>s or long <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>s from works by the <em>same</em> <a href="#author">author</a>, or two or more independent works or excerpts from works by <em>different</em> authors, not written for the same <a href="#publication">publication</a> or occasion, <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a single <a href="#volume">volume</a> or <a href="#uniformedition">uniform</a> <a href="#set">set</a> of volumes, for example, a <a href="#book">book</a> of <a href="#essay">essay</a>s written by one or more essayists.  Selected for publication by an <a href="#editor">editor</a>, the works are listed in order of appearance in the <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a> in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>.  Synonymous with <em>collected work</em>.  Compare with <a href="#anthology">anthology</a> and <a href="#compilation">compilation</a>.  <em><strong>See also</strong></em>:  <a href="#analyticalentry">analytical entry</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a number of <a href="#document">document</a>s (<a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#report">report</a>s, <a href="#records">records</a>, etc.), assembled in a single location by one or more persons, or by a corporate entity, and <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> in some kind of systematic order to facilitate <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collecagency"><b>collection agency</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial enterprise that specializes in collecting
past-due bills from people who owe them, usually by informing the
person that their credit record will suffer unless prompt payment is
received. Most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> enter into a contractual agreement with such an <a href="#agency">agency</a> to handle the collection of unpaid bills for <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#lost">lost</a>, <a href="#damaged">damaged</a>, or long <a href="#overdue">overdue</a>.  Academic institutions have the option of withholding grades or diploma from a student until <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#fines">fines</a> are paid.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collecassess"><b>collection assessment</b></a>
</dt><dd>The systematic evaluation of the quality of a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> to determine the extent to which it meets the <a href="#library">library</a>'s service <a href="#goal">goal</a>s and <a href="#objective">objective</a>s and the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of its <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>.  Deficiencies are addressed through <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>.  Synonymous with <em>collection evaluation</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collecdevel"><b>collection development</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of planning and building a useful and <a href="#balanced">balanced</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> over a period of years, based on an ongoing <a href="#collecassess">assessment</a> of the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of the <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>, analysis of <a href="#usage">usage</a> statistics, and demographic <a href="#projection">projection</a>s, normally constrained by <a href="#budget">budget</a>ary limitations.  Collection development includes the formulation of <a href="#selectioncriteria">selection criteria</a>, planning for <a href="#resourcesharing">resource sharing</a>, and <a href="#replacement">replacement</a> of <a href="#lost">lost</a> and <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> <a href="#bibitem">items</a>, as well as routine <a href="#selection">selection</a> and <a href="#deselection">deselection</a> decisions. 
<p>
Large libraries and <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s may use an <a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a> or <a href="#blanketorder">blanket order plan</a>
to develop their collections. In small and medium-sized libraries,
collection development responsibilities are normally shared by all the <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, based on their interests and <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>s, usually under the overall guidance of a written <a href="#collecdevelpolicy">collection development policy</a>.  Compare with <a href="#collecmanagement">collection management</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collecdevelpolicy"><b>collection development policy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal written statement of the principles guiding a <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#selection">selection</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, including the <a href="#selectioncriteria">criteria</a> used in making selection and <a href="#deselection">deselection</a> decisions (<a href="#field">field</a>s covered, degrees of <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>, levels of difficulty, <a href="#language">language</a>s, <a href="#format">format</a>s, <a href="#balanced">balance</a>, etc.) and policies concerning <a href="#gift">gift</a>s and <a href="#exchange">exchange</a>s.  An unambiguously worded <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> policy can be very helpful in responding to <a href="#challenge">challenge</a>s from <a href="#pressuregroup">pressure group</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="colleceval"><b>collection evaluation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#collecassess">collection assessment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectionlevel"><b>collection level cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#encodinglevel">encoding level</a> used to <a href="#bibcontrol">control</a> <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s (<a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, <a href="#ephemera">ephemera</a>, etc.) which are unrelated bibliographically and do not warrant the expense of <a href="#fulllevel">full level</a> or even <a href="#minimallevel">minimal level cataloging</a>, but have <a href="#research">research</a> value and can be <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> as a single <a href="#bibitem">item</a> under a <a href="#collectivetitle">collective title</a> because they share at least one unifying <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a> (<a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#issue">issuing</a> body, <a href="#language">language</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>, <a href="#genre">genre</a>, etc.).  Synonymous with <em>collective cataloging</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collecmaint"><b>collection maintenance</b></a>
</dt><dd>Measures taken on a routine basis or as needed to <a href="#preservation">preserve</a> the <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> in usable <a href="#condition">condition</a>, including <a href="#mending">mending</a>, <a href="#repairing">repairing</a>, <a href="#binding">binding</a>, <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>, and <a href="#reformat">reformat</a>ting, usually the responsibility of the <a href="#technical">technical processing</a> and <a href="#serial">serials</a> departments.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collecmanagement"><b>collection management</b></a>
</dt><dd>The application of quantitative techniques, such as statistical and cost-benefit analysis, to the process of <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>, usually limited to large <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s.  In a more general sense, the activity of planning and supervising the growth and <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> of a library's <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, based on an <a href="#collecassess">assessment</a> of existing strengths and weaknesses, and an estimate of future needs.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectivebargaining"><b>collective bargaining agreement</b></a>
</dt><dd>A legally binding <a href="#contract">contract</a> signed on behalf of <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> organized in a <em>collective bargaining unit</em>, by elected representatives authorized to negotiate terms of employment with management, including <a href="#salary">salaries</a> and <a href="#wages">wages</a>, <a href="#benefits">benefits</a>, job responsibilities, evaluation for <a href="#promotion">promotion</a> and <a href="#tenure">tenure</a>, <a href="#grievance">grievance</a> procedures, etc.  <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s employed at colleges and universities which grant librarians <a href="#facultystatus">faculty status</a> may be members of the same bargaining unit as the teaching faculty.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#compulsoryarbit">compulsory arbitration</a> and <a href="#aaup">American Association of University Professors</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectivebargunit"><b>collective bargaining unit</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#collectivebargaining">collective bargaining agreement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectivebiography"><b>collective biography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> in one or more <a href="#volume">volume</a>s
containing separate accounts of the lives of two or more individuals
who lived within a specific time period, distinguished themselves in
the same <a href="#field">field</a> or activity, or have some other characteristic in common (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Ordinary Women, Extraordinary Lives:  Women in American History</em></b> edited by Kriste Lindenmeyer).  Written by one or more <a href="#biography">biographers</a>, the <a href="#essay">essay</a>s in a collective <a href="#biography">biography</a> are usually longer than the <a href="#entry">entries</a> in a <a href="#biogdictionary">biographical dictionary</a>, and may include a <a href="#biobibliography">biobibliography</a> or list of references for <a href="#furtherreading">further reading</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectivecat"><b>collective cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#collectionlevel">collection level cataloging</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectivename"><b>collective name</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#corporatename">corporate name</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collectivetitle"><b>collective title</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> of a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> containing several <a href="#work">work</a>s by one or more <a href="#author">author</a>s, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in a single <a href="#volume">volume</a> or <a href="#uniformedition">uniform</a> <a href="#set">set</a> of volumes, each with its own <a href="#title">title</a> distinct from that of the whole.  Also refers to the title assigned by a <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> to a group of <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> <a href="#collectionlevel">cataloged collectively</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collegebookstore"><b>college bookstore</b></a>
</dt><dd>A retail outlet operated in association with a college or university, selling new and second-hand <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s and <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>s used by professors as assigned reading in their courses.  College bookstores also sell <a href="#poprefbook">popular reference book</a>s, school supplies, greeting cards, college <a href="#memorabilia">memorabilia</a>, <a href="#genintmag">general interest magazine</a>s, <a href="#bestseller">bestseller</a>s, and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> <a href="#tradebook">trade</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s
of interest to the student market. They can be owned and managed by the
institution served, operated by an independent contractor, or run as a
cooperative. Compare with <a href="#tradebookstore">trade bookstore</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collegecatalog"><b>college catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#coursecatalog">course catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collegedictionary"><b>college dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#deskdictionary">desk dictionary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collegelibrary"><b>college library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a>
maintained by an independent four-year college, or by one of several
colleges within a larger university, for the use of students and
faculty. Compare with <a href="#undergradlib">undergraduate library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="collocation"><b>collocation</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the process of bringing together all the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s representing <a href="#work">work</a>s by the same <a href="#author">author</a>, of variant <a href="#title">title</a>s, of different <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, of the same <a href="#series">series</a>, or on closely related <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a>s, by assigning the same <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a> to facilitate <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a>.  For example, the preparation of <a href="#entry">entries</a> under a <a href="#heading">heading</a> for the <a href="#predominantname">predominant name</a> of an author who wrote under one or more <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a>s.  Collocation often requires the use of <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s to direct the user to the authorized form of the name, title, <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>, etc.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#classification">classification</a>, the <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> of the subdivisions of a <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> in a manner that places <a href="#class">class</a>es and <a href="#subclass">subclass</a>es of equal rank together, and shows the degree to which they are logically removed from the <a href="#mainclass">main class</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="colloquy"><b>colloquy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> written in the form of a conversation or <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Aelfric's Colloquy</em></b>).  Plural:  <em>colloquies</em>.  
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#libconference">conference</a> in the
form of a seminar, with several speakers participating in a discussion
that is conversational in style and tone. Synonymous in this sense with
<em>colloquium</em>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="colonclassification"><b>Colon Classification</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> in which <a href="#subject">subject</a>s are analyzed into <a href="#facet">facet</a>s based on their uses and relations, and then represented by <a href="#syntheticclass">synthetic</a>ally constructed <a href="#class">class</a>es with the parts separated by the colon (<b>:</b>).  Developed by <a href="#ranganathan">S. R. Ranganathan</a> in the 1930s, Colon Classification is used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> in India and in <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> throughout the world.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="colophon"><b>colophon</b></a>
</dt><dd>A Greek word meaning "finishing touch."  A statement given at the end of the <a href="#text">text</a> of an early <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, indicating the <a href="#title">title</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a>, name of <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>, and place of copying.  The colophon may also include an expression of gratitude to the patron or client who commissioned the <a href="#copy">copy</a>,
and a warning against unauthorized copying. Early printed colophons
followed the manuscript tradition, giving the name and emblem (<a href="#imprint">imprint</a>) of the <a href="#printer">printer</a>, date of printing, number of copies printed, and sometimes an apology to the <a href="#reader">reader</a> for any errors in the text.  Synonymous with <a href="#explicit">explicit</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#impensis">impensis</a></em>.  
<p>
In modern <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a statement printed at the end of the text, or on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, giving the name of the printer, <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>, grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, materials used in <a href="#binding">binding</a>, and sometimes the names of those responsible for producing the <a href="#edition">edition</a>.  Also refers to a printing <a href="#device">device</a>, usually an emblem, used to represent a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s imprint.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="colorplate"><b>color plate</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> in color, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> separately from the <a href="#text">text</a> on a different grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a> and <a href="#binding">bound</a> with others in one or more sections of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  Also spelled <em>colorplate</em>.  Compare with <a href="#duotone">duotone</a> and <a href="#monochromeplate">monochrome plate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="colorsupplement"><b>color supplement</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> in color to be <a href="#issue">issue</a>d with a Sunday <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The New York Times Magazine</em></b>).  Also refers to a <a href="#section">section</a> of <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s printed in color for <a href="#insert">insert</a>ion in the center of a magazine or <a href="#book">book</a>, whether removable or not.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="colporteur"><b>colporteur</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the French words <em>col</em> (neck) and <em>porter</em> (to carry).  A peddler of <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s and <a href="#book">book</a>s <a href="#printing">printed</a> in inexpensive <a href="#edition">edition</a>, (<a href="#almanac">almanac</a>s, <a href="#primer">primer</a>s,
Bibles, etc.), who traveled around the countryside of Europe, carrying
his wares in a box or basket attached to a neck strap as he hawked them
in the streets and door-to-door. In Britain, itinerant salesmen were
sometimes employed by religious societies to sell or distribute
religious <a href="#tract">tract</a>s on foot.  <em>Colportage</em> flourished from the late 15th century, when printed <a href="#work">work</a>s
first became available, until the end of the 18th century despite
unsuccessful efforts by the French government to suppress the trade
because it helped spread the revolutionary new ideas that eventually
led to reformation and revolution. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="column"><b>column</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of two or more vertical sections of written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#text">text</a> separated from each other by a <a href="#rule">rule</a>d line or <a href="#blank">blank</a> space, as in ancient <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>s, <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, and <a href="#language">language</a> <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a>.  The length of a newspaper <a href="#article">article</a> is expressed in <a href="#columninch">column inch</a>es.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>col</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doublecolumn">double column</a>. 
<p>
Also refers to an <a href="#essay">essay</a> providing <a href="#commentary">commentary</a> on a <a href="#currency">current</a> issue, sometimes from a political point of view (left, right, or center), usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on or near the <a href="#editorial">editorial page</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, or in a <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> or <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> (<em>example</em>:  Carol Tenopir's <em>Online Databases</em> column in <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em>).  National political <a href="#columnist">columnist</a>s are often <a href="#syndicate">syndicate</a>d.  Compare with <a href="#editorial">editorial</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="columninch"><b>column inch</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> and <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the unit of measurement in which the length of an <a href="#article">article</a> or size of a paid advertisement is expressed, equivalent to the width of a <a href="#column">column</a> of <a href="#type">type</a> multiplied by one inch of depth.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="columnist"><b>columnist</b></a>
</dt><dd>A journalist who writes regular <a href="#commentary">commentary</a> on <a href="#currency">current</a> issues for <a href="#publication">publication</a> in a <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> or <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>,
or in more than one newspaper, usually from a political position left
or right of center, or expressing an original point of view on a matter
of interest to <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.  National political columnists are often <a href="#syndicate">syndicated</a>.  Also refers to a specialist in a particular <a href="#field">field</a> or on a given <a href="#subject">subject</a> who writes regular commentary for a <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> or <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> (<em>example</em>:  Roy Tennant who writes the <em>Digital Libraries</em> <a href="#column">column</a> in <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="com1"><b>COM</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#com"><b>c</b>omputer <b>o</b>utput <b>m</b>icroform</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="combbinding"><b>comb binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#mechanical">mechanical binding</a> in which a row of interconnected curved plastic teeth is inserted into slots punched along the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> to hold them together, used for binding <a href="#calendar">calendar</a>s, <a href="#labmanual">lab manual</a>s, instruction <a href="#manual">manual</a>s, and <a href="#workbook">workbook</a>s which must <a href="#openability">open</a> flat to be used conveniently.  If the plastic <a href="#spine">spine</a> is wide enough, the <a href="#title">title</a> may be <a href="#printing">printed</a> on it.  Compare with <a href="#spiralbinding">spiral binding</a> and <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="comcatalog"><b>comcatalog</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#comc">computer-output microform catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="comedy"><b>comedy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A dramatic <a href="#work">work</a> in which an amusing event, or series of events with a happy ending, is presented for the enjoyment of the <a href="#audience">audience</a> or <a href="#reader">reader</a>.  Comic effect is usually achieved by emphasizing incongruity of <a href="#character">character</a> in <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a>
and/or action. When such an effect is achieved with subtle insight, the
result is "high" comedy, as distinct from "low" comedy which appeals to
cruder perceptions. The earliest surviving examples of classical comedy
are the eleven plays of Aristophanes, thought to have been written and
performed in Athens in the 5th century B.C. Compare with <a href="#farce">farce</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#tragedy">tragedy</a> and <a href="#tragicomedy">tragicomedy</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="comicbook"><b>comic book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#pamphlet">booklet</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> in color on <a href="#paper">paper</a> made from wood pulp, containing one or more stories told <a href="#picture">pictorially</a> in a continuous strip of <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a> <a href="#panel">panel</a>s, with any <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> or <a href="#monologue">monologue</a> enclosed in <a href="#balloon">balloon</a>s or given in <a href="#caption">caption</a>s.  An extended form of the comic strip seen in daily <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, comic books are often <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#series">series</a> classified by <a href="#genre">genre</a> (adventure, <a href="#fantasy">fantasy</a>, <a href="#romance">romance</a>, <a href="#sciencefiction">science fiction</a>, etc.).  They are <a href="#acquisitions">acquired</a> by <a href="#library">libraries</a> for <a href="#specialcollections">special collection</a>s on popular culture, and  are of considerable interest to private <a href="#collectible">collector</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#graphicnovel">graphic novel</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="commanddriven"><b>command-driven</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#interface">interface</a> in which the user must type a command statement or <a href="#query">query</a> to achieve the desired result, usually faster than a <a href="#menudriven">menu-driven</a> interface, but not as <a href="#userfriendly">user-friendly</a> for <a href="#novice">novice</a>s who must invest time and effort in learning the system's command language.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="commentary"><b>commentary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A critical or explanatory <a href="#note">note</a> or collection of notes on a sacred or <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>, accompanying the <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#issue">issue</a>d separately, usually written by a person (or persons) other than the <a href="#author">author</a>.  Commentaries are usually devoted to major <a href="#work">work</a>s that have been the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of considerable interpretation (<b><em>Bhagavad-Gita</em></b>, <b><em>Bible</em></b>, <b><em>Koran</em></b>, etc.).  Also refers to an historical <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> written largely from personal experience (<b><em>Seven Commentaries on the Gallic War</em></b> by Julius Caesar).  Synonymous in this sense with <a href="#memoirs">memoirs</a>.
In a more general sense, a series of remarks or observations, made by
someone with authority to speak and be heard on the subject, for
example, a <a href="#journalism">journalist</a> writing a <a href="#column">column</a> on a political or social issue. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="commercialjournal"><b>commercial journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a> or <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> <a href="#publisher">published</a> by a for-profit company (<em>example</em>:  Elsevier), as opposed to a journal published by a <a href="#universitypress">university press</a> or nonprofit organization, such as a scholarly <a href="#society">society</a> or professional <a href="#association">association</a>.  Relentless price increases have become an important issue for <a href="#library">libraries</a> that <a href="#subscription">subscribe</a> to commercially published journals.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="commercialpublisher"><b>commercial publisher</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> in the business of producing and selling <a href="#book">book</a>s and/or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s for profit, as opposed to a <a href="#universitypress">university press</a> or the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> arm of a scholarly <a href="#society">society</a>, professional <a href="#association">association</a>, or other nonprofit organization that operates on a <a href="#costrecovery">cost-recovery</a> basis.  The <a href="#term">term</a> includes <a href="#tradepublisher">trade publisher</a>s and <a href="#popularpress">popular press</a>es.
In commercial publishing, the decision to publish is influenced by
sales potential, sometimes at the expense of originality and quality.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="comtv"><b>commercial television</b></a>
</dt><dd>Television <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> stations for
which profit is the prime concern. In the selection of programming,
commercial stations rely heavily on ratings because their advertisers
are motivated by the desire to reach the widest possible viewing <a href="#audience">audience</a>.  Compare with <a href="#pubtv">public television</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="commoncarrier"><b>common carrier (CC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> service,
such as a telephone or cable company, that provides wire and/or
microwave services to businesses and the general public, usually at
rates regulated by federal, state, or local government.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="commongateway"><b>Common Gateway Interface (CGI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A program <a href="#interface">interface</a> installed on a <a href="#webserver">Web server</a>, that allows <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s to be <a href="#link">link</a>ed to <a href="#database">database</a>s and other <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s in such a way that <a href="#input">input</a> can be entered via the Web page and sent to a <a href="#dbmanagement">database management system</a> for <a href="#search">search</a>ing.  Results are sent back by the DBMS and presented to the user in <a href="#html">HTML</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="commonplace"><b>commonplace book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> with <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#page">page</a>s in which passages in <a href="#prose">prose</a> or <a href="#verse">verse</a> are recorded irregularly by its owner as ideas for future exploration or contemplation, sometimes arranged by <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  The writer may note only his own thoughts and ideas, or <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>
those of other writers or speakers. Commonplace books kept by persons
of stature, such as Ralph Waldo Emerson and Thomas Jefferson, have been
deemed worthy of <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  Although interest in this form of literary expression has waned, it is still used by poets (<em>example</em>: <b><em>A Certain World</em></b> by W. H. Auden).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#diary">diary</a> and <a href="#journal">journal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="communications"><b>communications</b></a>
</dt><dd>The transfer of <a href="#information">information</a> from one physical location to another by electronic means.  The <a href="#term">term</a> <em><a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a></em> refers to both <a href="#analog">analog</a> and <a href="#digital">digital</a> communications, including the transmission of voice and <a href="#videotape">video</a>.  <em>Data communications</em> refers to digital communications only, occurring via <a href="#modem">modem</a> over a telephone line, by direct cable to another <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a> equipped with <a href="#file">file</a> transfer <a href="#software">software</a>, from a remote <a href="#terminal">terminal</a> connected to a <a href="#minicomputer">minicomputer</a> or <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a>, from one <a href="#node">node</a> to another on a <a href="#localarea">local area network</a> (LAN), or between <a href="#clientserver">client</a> and <a href="#server">server</a> in a <a href="#network">network</a> environment.  A <em>communications device</em> is a piece of <a href="#hardware">hardware</a>, such as a <a href="#modem">modem</a>, cable, or <a href="#port">port</a>, designed to facilitate <a href="#data">data</a> transmission.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compactdisc"><b>compact disc (CD)</b></a>        
</dt><dd>A <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#audiorecording">audiorecording</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> introduced in 1982, capable of storing up to 74 minutes of high-fidelity <a href="#stereophonic">stereophonic</a> sound in a single spiral <a href="#track">track</a> on one side of a 4.75-inch <a href="#disc">disc</a>, similar to the track on a <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>.  Designed to be read by a laser beam and decoded inside a device called a <em>CD player</em>, compact discs not only provide clearer sound than phonograph records and <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a>, but are capable of recording a much wider range of volume.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>,
CDs are usually shelved separately, often in specially designed display
cases. Some libraries provide listening equipment on the premises. In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the <a href="#term">term</a> "sound disc" is used in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing a compact disc, with "<a href="#digital">digital</a>" given as <a href="#typerecording">type of recording</a>. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#opticaldisk">optical disk</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compactedition"><b>compact edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> in which the physical size of a long <a href="#work">work</a> is reduced, usually by altering the <a href="#format">format</a> without changing the <a href="#content">content</a>, for example, <b><em>The Compact Oxford English Dictionary</em></b> (second edition) <a href="#reproduction">reproduced</a> <a href="#micrographics">micrographically</a> and <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in a <a href="#slipcase">slipcase</a> with a microprint reader.  Compare with <a href="#conciseedition">concise edition</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compactshelving"><b>compact shelving</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#library">Library</a> shelving designed to maximize the storage capacity of a given space by incorporating movable elements such as shelf <a href="#range">range</a>s
on tracks. Because it is considerably heavier than normal shelving when
filled, compact shelving requires more structural support, an important
design consideration in the construction of a new library facility. <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#compactstorage">compact storage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compactstorage"><b>compact storage</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> shelving area, often reserved for low-use <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, in which narrow <a href="#aisle">aisle</a>s, higher than normal shelves, and/or <a href="#compactshelving">compact shelving</a>
is employed to maximize storage capacity. The building must be
structurally capable of supporting the additional weight. Compact
shelving with movable parts may be subject to electrical or mechanical
failure.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="companyfile"><b>company file</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#information">information</a> about one or more commercial enterprises, usually maintained by a <a href="#corporationlib">corporation</a> or <a href="#businesslibrary">business library</a> for the use of employees, business students, investors, career counselors, job seekers, etc.  <a href="#annualreport">Annual report</a>s, SEC filings, <a href="#tradecatalog">trade catalog</a>s, <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of <a href="#houseorgan">house organ</a>s, news <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, etc., are usually organized <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by name of firm.  Synonymous with <em>corporation file</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="companylibrary"><b>company library</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#corporationlib">corporation library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="comparativelib"><b>comparative librarianship</b></a>
</dt><dd>The study and analysis of similarities and differences in <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>
as practiced in different countries, to identify or clarify underlying
principles, expand awareness of successful practices, facilitate
cooperation, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="comparativetable"><b>comparative table</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> list of selected <a href="#topic">topic</a>s in a complete or extensive <a href="#revision">revision</a> of <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, giving the <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> in the current <a href="#edition">edition</a> and the corresponding number used in the preceding edition.  In most cases, only numbers for comprehensive <a href="#work">work</a>s are given.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#equivalencetable">equivalence table</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compatibility"><b>compatibility</b></a>
</dt><dd>The ability of computer <a href="#software">software</a> to run on <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> other than that for which it was originally designed.  Compatibility can be <em>upward</em> (or <em>forward</em>) in <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s capable of running on newer, more powerful machines, or <em>downward</em> (<em>backward</em>) in programs that will run on older, less powerful machines.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compendium"><b>compendium</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> that presents in condensed form the main points of a longer work, prepared by a person other than the original <a href="#author">author</a>.  Also, a work that <a href="#treatment">treats</a> a broad <a href="#subject">subject</a> or entire <a href="#field">field</a> of <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> briefly and concisely, sometimes in the form of an <a href="#outline">outline</a>.  Used synonymously with <a href="#digest">digest</a> and <a href="#epitome">epitome</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="competencies"><b>competencies</b></a>
</dt><dd>The capabilities expected of a person hired to perform a
specific job, or upon successful completion of a course of study or
training. In <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>, the <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>, skills, and experience necessary to effectively handle <a href="#professionalism">professional</a> responsibilities, usually within a <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>, expressed inclusively rather than as a set of minimum <a href="#standards">standards</a>.  For an example, please see the <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alsc/competencies.html">ALSC Competencies</a></em> for <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s serving children in <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compilation"><b>compilation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> assembled from the works of various <a href="#author">author</a>s, or the various works of a <em>single</em> author, into an ordered whole by a person other than the original author, without <a href="#editor">editor</a>ial alteration of the original <a href="#text">text</a>.  Laws, rules, procedures, regulations, and technical <a href="#data">data</a> are particularly <a href="#subject">subject</a> to compilation.  The person who puts such a work together is a <a href="#compiler">compiler</a>.  In a broader sense, any <a href="#book">book</a>
or other written work assembled, sometimes over an extended period of
time, from materials gathered from a variety of sources, for example, a
<a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> or <a href="#index">index</a>.  Compare with <a href="#anthology">anthology</a> and <a href="#collection">collection</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compile"><b>compile</b></a>
</dt><dd>To gather and put together pieces of <a href="#information">information</a> or materials from various sources in an orderly structured whole, as in the creation of a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> or <a href="#index">index</a>.  The person who assembles such a <a href="#work">work</a> is the <a href="#compiler">compiler</a> and the resulting work is called a <a href="#compilation">compilation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compiler"><b>compiler</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who selects and assembles written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> material from the <a href="#work">work</a>s of various persons or bodies, or the various works of a <em>single</em> person or body, into a ordered whole, without editorial alteration of the original <a href="#text">text</a>.  The resulting <a href="#document">document</a> is called a <a href="#compilation">compilation</a>.  When the compiler's name is indicated in or on the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a>, it is entered in the <a href="#statementof">statement of responsibility</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> that represents the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  Compare with <a href="#editor">editor</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="completeness"><b>completeness</b></a>
</dt><dd>An indication of how much of the <a href="#publishing">published</a> run of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#title">title</a> is <a href="#holdings">held</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a>, usually given in the <a href="#holdingsnote">holdings note</a> as:  <em>complete</em> (95-100% held), <em>incomplete</em> (50-94% held), or <em>scattered</em> (less than 50% held).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="completeworks"><b>complete works</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#authorsedition">author's edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="complimentary"><b>complimentary copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> sent without charge to an instructor for consideration as a <a href="#textbook">textbook</a> for students enrolled in courses on the <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  Faculty members sometimes <a href="#gift">donate</a> complimentary copies to the <a href="#library">library</a> at the institution with which they are affiliated.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>inspection copy</em>.  In a more general sense, any copy of a book or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> given away by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to promote sales, including <a href="#authorscopy">author's copies</a>, <a href="#deskcopy">desk copies</a>, and <a href="#reviewcopy">review copies</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="composer"><b>composer</b></a>
</dt><dd>The original creator of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> in any form, entered as <a href="#author">author</a> in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> created to represent the <a href="#work">work</a> in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  Compare with <a href="#arranger">arranger</a> and <a href="#performer">performer</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compositevolume"><b>composite volume</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a> containing two or more <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s, for example, a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#brochure">brochure</a>s or music <a href="#score">score</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compositework"><b>composite work</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#work">work</a> produced as the result of a collaboration between two or more <a href="#author">author</a>s or <a href="#composer">composer</a>s in which the contribution of each is a separate and distinct part of a planned whole (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#festschrift">Festschrift</a>).  Compare with <a href="#jointauthor">joint author</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#shared">shared responsibility</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="composition"><b>composition</b></a>
</dt><dd>The putting together of words to express an idea, sentiment, <a href="#thesis">thesis</a>, analysis, or conclusion, as in a <a href="#work">work</a> of <a href="#poetry">poetry</a> or <a href="#prose">prose</a>, or in the form of a writing exercise assigned as school work.  In a musical composition, the message is expressed in musical <a href="#notation">notation</a>.  Also refers to the <a href="#piece">piece</a> of writing or music that is the result of such activity.  
<p>
In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the process of preparing <a href="#copy">copy</a>, assembling <a href="#type">type</a>, and <a href="#makeup">making up</a> type and <a href="#displaymatter">display matter</a> into <a href="#page">page</a>s.  In <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a>, these tasks are accomplished by the <a href="#compositor">compositor</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compositor"><b>compositor</b></a>
</dt><dd>The worker responsible for <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> (<em>composing</em>) the <a href="#type">type</a> used to <a href="#printing">print</a> a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  In <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a>, the compositor holds the <em>composing stick</em> in his left hand and removes the individual elements of type, called <em>sorts</em>, each bearing an individual <a href="#letter">letter</a> or other <a href="#character">character</a>, from the <em>case</em> with his right hand, assembling each line in sequence until the stick is full and ready to be transferred to a tray called a <a href="#galley">galley</a>.  The compositor is also responsible for <a href="#makeup">making up</a> the galleys into <a href="#page">page</a>s, a process that includes inserting <a href="#displaymatter">display matter</a>, dividing the matter into page lengths, adding <a href="#runninghead">running head</a>s, <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s, <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s, etc., and imposing the pages in a frame called a <a href="#chase">chase</a> which, when <a href="#lockedup">locked up</a>, constitutes a <a href="#forme">forme</a> ready to be placed on the bed of the <a href="#printingpress">press</a> for printing.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compoundname"><b>compound name</b></a>
</dt><dd>A name formed by joining two or more <a href="#propername">proper name</a>s with a <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>Marie-Louise</b>), conjunction (<b>Simon &amp; Schuster</b>), or preposition (<b>Alcuin of York</b>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#compoundsurname">compound surname</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compoundsubject"><b>compound subject heading</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> consisting of two or more words that together represent a single concept (<em>examples</em>:
"Bibliotherapy for children," "Book reviewing," "Library catalogs") or
two closely related concepts ("Libraries and adult education"). In some
cases <a href="#semanticfactoring">semantic factoring</a> yields <a href="#falsedrop">false drop</a>s (School + Library --&gt; Library school / School library). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compoundsurname"><b>compound surname</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#surname">surname</a> composed of two or more <a href="#propername">proper name</a>s, usually joined by a <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a>, conjunction, or preposition.  Under <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, compound surnames are entered under the element preferred by the person, with <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s from the other elements (<em>example</em>:  <b>Lloyd George, David, 1863-1945</b> with a reference from <b>George, David Lloyd</b>, his correct paternal surname).  Hyphenated surnames are entered under the first element (<b>Bourke-White, Margaret, 1904-1971</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="comprehensive"><b>comprehensive</b></a>
</dt><dd>All-inclusive or all-encompassing.  An <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, or other work of <a href="#refbook">reference</a>, <a href="#compile">compile</a>d with the stated goal of covering all possible aspects of a <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or all the <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#literature">literature</a> on a subject or in a <a href="#field">field</a> or <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>.  In <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, an attempt to list of <em>all</em> the <a href="#work">work</a>s that meet the criteria for inclusion established by the <a href="#bibliographer">bibliographer</a> as to <a href="#author">author</a>, subject, <a href="#publication">publication</a> type, <a href="#currency">currency</a>, etc.  The opposite of <a href="#selective">selective</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="comptime"><b>comp time</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#flextime">flextime</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compulsoryarbit"><b>compulsory arbitration</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process in which representatives organized labor and
management, having reached an impasse in contract negotiations, submit
their differences to a legally designated <em>arbitrator</em> or <em>arbitration board</em>
authorized to hear arguments from both sides on unresolved issues and
reach a final binding decision. Both sides are required to accept the
outcome. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#collectivebargaining">collective bargaining agreement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="compulsoryretire"><b>compulsory retirement</b></a>
</dt><dd>Mandatory retirement at a fixed age, usually established by
the employer and stipulated in its personnel policy. Compulsory
retirement is a controversial legal issue in the United States.
Organizations that have no mandatory retirement age may offer periodic
retirement incentives to long-time employees, aimed at reducing <a href="#payroll">payroll</a> costs. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="computerfile"><b>computer file</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#data">Data</a> or <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s <a href="#encoding">encoded</a> in <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a> for processing by a computer.  Data <a href="#file">file</a>s <a href="#storage">stored</a> on a computer are usually organized by topic or other characteristic in <a href="#directory">directories</a> and subdirectories.  Synonymous with <em>machine-readable data file</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="computerliteracy"><b>computer literacy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The skills required to <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> <a href="#information">information</a> efficiently and communicate effectively using computer <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> and <a href="#software">software</a>,
based on a conceptual understanding of computer technology and how it
can be used to accomplish specific tasks, including an awareness of its
inherent limitations, as well as its advantages. Because most hardware
and software is progressively <a href="#upgrade">upgrade</a>d, an ongoing effort is required of the user to remain computer literate.  Compare with <a href="#infoliteracy">information literacy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="com"><b>computer output microform (COM)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Computer <a href="#output">output</a> produced directly on <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> or <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> without ever having been <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  A <a href="#device">device</a> called a <em>COM recorder</em> <a href="#dataconversion">converts</a> <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#data">data</a> into a form that can be read by the human eye before recording it on film.  <b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#comc">computer output microform catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="comc"><b>computer output microform catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> produced directly on <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> or <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> from a <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s, using a special recording <a href="#device">device</a> called a <em>COM recorder</em>.  <em>Comcatalog</em>s are more compact than <a href="#cardcatalog">card catalog</a>s, but a <a href="#microform">microform</a> <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a> machine is required to display and <a href="#printing">print</a> individual <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>s.  Prior to the development of <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s, this <a href="#format">format</a> was preferred for state, regional, and <a href="#consortium">consortial</a> <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="computerprogram"><b>computer program</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of instructions written in a <a href="#proglang">programming language</a> to enable a computer to <a href="#dataprocessing">process data</a>, perform operations, and solve logical problems.  Synonymous with <a href="#software">software</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#application">application</a> and <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="comstock"><b>Comstock, Anthony, 1844-1915</b></a>
</dt><dd>An American reformer with a high school education who in 1873,
after serving in the Union army during the Civil War, founded the New
York Society for the Suppression of Vice and devoted the rest of his
life to waging an aggressive crusade against <a href="#pornography">pornography</a>,
abortion, gambling, swindling, medical quackery, and other activities
he considered morally offensive. Comstock used his influence to
persuade Congress to pass what became known as the "Comstock laws"
empowering the U.S. Postal Service to exclude from the mail <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s which he considered indecent or <a href="#obscenity">obscene</a>, including <a href="#information">information</a> about contraception.  After Comstock publicly attacked the first American production of George Bernard Shaw's <a href="#play">play</a> <em>Mrs. Warren's Profession</em>, the British <a href="#playwright">playwright</a> dubbed his rigid views and repressive methods "comstockery," turning his name into a public <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> of <a href="#censorship">censorship</a> based on prudery.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="comstockery"><b>comstockery</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#comstock">Comstock, Anthony</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="concatenate"><b>concatenate</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>con</em> ("together") and <em>catenare</em> ("to chain").  To join two or more <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#field">field</a>s within a <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> to create a single field.  In a more general sense, to link items together in a series, for example, several related <a href="#essay">essay</a>s or long <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>s for <a href="#publication">publication</a> in a <a href="#collection">collection</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="concertina"><b>concertina</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> in which the <a href="#spine">spine</a> is continuous with the front and back <a href="#cover">cover</a>s, but folded in narrow accordion-style pleats to which the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> or <a href="#folio">folio</a>s are attached along the peaks or valleys of the folds.  Compare with <a href="#zigzag">zig-zag book</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a method of folding <a href="#paper">paper</a> in which each successive fold is parallel with, but in the opposite direction to, the preceding one.  Synonymous with <em>accordion fold</em>, <em>fan fold</em>, and <em>z-fold</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#chinesestyle">Chinese style</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conciseedition"><b>concise edition</b></a>
