</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> in which the <a href="#content">content</a> of a longer <a href="#work">work</a> is stated in the fewest possible words, sometimes aimed at beginners in the <a href="#field">field</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Concise AACR2</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#alaeditions">ALA Editions</a>).  In the concise edition of a <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>, infrequently used words and <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s in the full edition are omitted, and long <a href="#definition">definition</a>s may be shortened.  In a concise <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>, the <a href="#text">text</a> is shortened and less important <a href="#entry">entries</a> may be dropped entirely.  The adjective "concise" is sometimes used in the <a href="#title">title</a>s of works <em>not</em> based on a longer work, to indicate that the content is expressed succinctly.  Compare with <a href="#compactedition">compact edition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="concordance"><b>concordance</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly arranged <a href="#index">index</a> of the principal words or selected words in a <a href="#text">text</a>, or in the <a href="#work">work</a>s of an <a href="#author">author</a>, giving the precise location of each word in the text, with a brief indication of its <a href="#context">context</a>.  A <em>glossarial concordance</em> includes a brief <a href="#definition">definition</a> of each <a href="#term">term</a>.  Concordances are usually devoted to very well-known works, such as the <em>Bible</em>, or to the works of a major writer (Chaucer, Shakespeare, etc.).  Compare with <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="condensation"><b>condensation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="condensed"><b>condensed</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> narrower in proportion to its height than the normal version of the same style, used in <a href="#printing">printing</a> to fit more <a href="#text">text</a> than normal in a <a href="#column">column</a> or on a <a href="#page">page</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#expanded">expanded</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="condensedbook"><b>condensed book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single <a href="#volume">volume</a>, usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> in inexpensive <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>, containing <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>s or long <a href="#extract">extract</a>s from several <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s, usually of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>.  In the United States, the <em>Reader's Digest Condensed <a href="#bookclub">Book Club</a></em> is a prolific distributor of condensed books.  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> specify in their <a href="#collecdevelpolicy">collection development policy</a> that works are to be purchased in <a href="#unabridged">unabridged</a> form. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="condensedscore"><b>condensed score</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#score">score</a> of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> composed for orchestra or band in which the principal <a href="#part">part</a>s, usually given by type of instrument (woodwind, brass, strings, percussion), are reduced to a minimum number of <a href="#stave">stave</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="condition"><b>condition</b></a>
</dt><dd>The physical state of existence of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#document">document</a> at a particular point in time, designated in the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> and <a href="#usedbook">used</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> by a two-part code (<em>example</em>: VG/G) in which the first part (VG) indicates the condition of the book itself and the second part (G) the condition of its <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>.  A <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a> or <a href="#dash">dash</a> following the slash indicates that the dust jacket is missing.  Antiquarian book <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>s grade condition as follows:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>As New</b>/<b>Mint</b> - in the same flawless condition as when <a href="#publishing">published</a> (no defects, missing <a href="#page">page</a>s, or <a href="#ownershipmark">ownership mark</a>s); dust jacket in perfect condition (no chips, marks, or tears).
</dd><dd><b>Fine (F or FN)</b> - nearly new, but not as crisp and clean as <a href="#mint">mint</a>; small defects in dust jacket are noted.
</dd><dd><b>Very Good (VG)</b> - shows some signs of wear, but has no tears in <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#binding">binding</a>; defects are noted.
</dd><dd><b>Good (G)</b> - an obviously worn book in which all the pages or <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> are present; defects must be noted.
</dd><dd><b>Fair</b> - worn but all pages present; may lack <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s, <a href="#halftitle">half-title</a>, etc.; binding and jacket also show signs of wear; defects must be noted.
</dd><dd><b>Poor</b> - <a href="#text">text</a> complete, but so worn that it can be sold only as a <a href="#readingcopy">reading copy</a>; missing parts must be noted.</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dd><b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#asissued">as issued</a>, <a href="#brittle">brittle</a>, <a href="#chipped">chipped</a>, <a href="#cracked">cracked</a>, <a href="#damaged">damaged</a>, <a href="#doctored">doctored</a>, <a href="#dogeared">dog-eared</a>, <a href="#foxing">foxing</a>, <a href="#mildew">mildew</a>, <a href="#rubbed">rubbed</a>, <a href="#shaken">shaken</a>, <a href="#sunned">sunned</a>, <a href="#waf">w.a.f.</a>, <a href="#warping">warping</a>, <a href="#waterdamaged">water-damaged</a>, and <a href="#worming">worming</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conference"><b>conference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal meeting of a group of individuals, or representatives
of several bodies, to provide the opportunity for discussion or
consultation on <a href="#topic">topic</a>s of mutual interest.  When <a href="#publishing">published</a> colelctively, the <a href="#paper">paper</a>s presented at such a meeting are called <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>conf</em>.  Compare with <a href="#workshop">workshop</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#conferencename">conference name</a>, <a href="#libconference">library conference</a>, and <a href="#preconference">preconference</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a formal meeting of the representatives constituting the legislative or governing authority of a <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a>, usually for the purpose of discussing and acting on issues of importance to the organization.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conferencename"><b>conference name</b></a>
</dt><dd>The official name of a meeting, <a href="#conference">conference</a>, <a href="#workshop">workshop</a>, <a href="#symposium">symposium</a>, <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ion, exposition, festival, athletic contest, scientific expedition, etc., used as the <a href="#corporatename">corporate name</a> <a href="#heading">heading</a> in <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> any <a href="#publication">publication</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in its name.  Form of heading is subject to <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="confproc"><b>conference proceedings</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="confidentiality"><b>confidentiality</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the delivery of <a href="#library">library</a> services, the right of <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to have the nature of their <a href="#research">research</a> and library transactions remain <a href="#privacy">private</a>.  Under the guidance of the <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/ethics.html">ALA Code of Ethics</a></em>, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> members are encouraged to "protect each library user's right to privacy and confidentiality with respect to <a href="#information">information</a> sought or received and resources consulted, borrowed, acquired or transmitted."  For this reason, automated <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s are designed to delete from the <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a> all indication that a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a> has been borrowed once it has been returned to the library, and to limit <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#borroweraccount">borrower account</a>s to <a href="#authorization">authorized</a> personnel.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#lap">Library Awareness Program</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="configuration"><b>configuration</b></a>
</dt><dd>The physical arrangement and functional relationships of the
various components of a computer system, usually established to meet
the needs and preferences of its users. The term <em>configurability</em>
has been coined to refer to the ease with which a computer system can
be modified or customized to meet changing needs and requirements.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conjointleaves"><b>conjoint leaves</b></a>
</dt><dd>Two <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> formed by one piece of <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>, or <a href="#paper">paper</a>, usually folded lengthwise down the center.  In a <a href="#book">book</a>, they may be <a href="#binding">bound</a> into a <a href="#section">section</a> in such a way that they are not adjacent in the resulting sequence of leaves, but when traced through the <a href="#back">back</a> of the <a href="#volume">volume</a> are found to be of a single piece, for example, in a 16-page <a href="#signature">signature</a>, <a href="#page">page</a>s 3-4 (leaf 2) would be the <em>conjugate</em> of pages 13-14 (leaf 7) and vice versa.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conjugate"><b>conjugate</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#conjointleaves">conjoint leaves</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="connecttime"><b>connect time</b></a>
</dt><dd>The length of time a user is <a href="#logon">logged on</a> to a remote computer <a href="#network">network</a> or system.  Some <a href="#internetservice">Internet service provider</a>s began by charging <a href="#subscription">subscriber</a>s on the basis of connect time, but most ISPs now provide unlimited <a href="#access">access</a> for a fixed monthly <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  Connect time is still used by some <a href="#database">database</a> <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s as the basis for billing (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#dialog">DIALOG</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conser"><b>CONSER</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <b>C</b>ooperative <b>ON</b>line <b>SER</b>ials, a cooperative <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#serial">serial</a>s <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> program that began in the early 1970s as a project to <a href="#retrocon">convert</a> manual serials cataloging to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  Since then it has evolved into a program for creating and maintaining high quality <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s for serial <a href="#publication">publication</a>s.  <b>CONSER</b> also establishes <a href="#standards">standards</a> for serials.  
<p>
Residing within the <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> Online Union Catalog, the <b>CONSER</b> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> is maintained by program members, which include the <a href="#nationallib">national libraries</a> of the United States and Canada, and their respective <a href="#issn">ISSN</a> centers; selected <a href="#academiclib">academic</a>, U.S. <a href="#federallibrary">federal</a>, and <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>; participants in the U.S. Newspaper Program (USNP); and selected <a href="#libassociation">library association</a>s, <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agencies</a>, and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting and indexing services</a>.  <b>CONSER</b> is a component of the <a href="#pcc">Program for Cooperative Cataloging</a> (PCC).  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/acq/conser/homepage.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CONSER</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conservation"><b>conservation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The use of physical or chemical methods to ensure the survival of <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#book">book</a>s, and other <a href="#document">document</a>s, for example, the storage of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> under controlled environmental conditions or the <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> of <a href="#mildew">mildew</a>-infected <a href="#paper">paper</a> with a chemical inhibitor.  Non-invasive techniques are preferred as a means of <a href="#preservation">preserving</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in their original <a href="#condition">condition</a>.  In a more general sense, any measures taken to protect <a href="#archives">archival</a> or <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s from damage or <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a>, including initial examination, <a href="#documentation">documentation</a>, <a href="#treatment">treatment</a>, and preventive care supported by <a href="#research">research</a>.  A person educated, trained, and experienced in such procedures is a <em>conservator</em>.  <a href="http://palimpsest.stanford.edu/">Click here</a> connect to <em>CoOL (Conservation Online):  Resources for Conservation Professionals</em>, a project of the Preservation Department of the Stanford University Libraries.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#conservationbinding">conservation binding</a> and <a href="#conservationcenter">conservation center</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conservationbinding"><b>conservation binding</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#binding">Binding</a> or <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a> intended to ensure the long-term survival of a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#book">book</a> while maintaining the integrity of its original form, as opposed to binding or rebinding for appearance or <a href="#durability">durability</a> regardless of the implications for <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conservationcenter"><b>conservation center</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization that <a href="#specialization">specializes</a> in the protection and rehabilitation of <a href="#printing">printed</a> and <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic materials, especially <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> or <a href="#deterioration">deteriorating</a> items.  Conservation centers support the enhancement of <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> programs in <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#archives">archives</a>, museums, and other historical and cultural organizations.  Some <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> centers also provide disaster assistance (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.nedcc.org/">Northeast Document Conservation Center</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conservator"><b>conservator</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="consignmentlist"><b>consignment list</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#boxlist">box list</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="consistency"><b>consistency</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, the degree of similarity between the <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s assigned to the same <a href="#bibitem">item</a> or <a href="#document">document</a> by different <a href="#index">index</a>ers, or at different times by the same indexer.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="consolidated"><b>consolidated shipment</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, a batch of materials sent by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, or other <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> to a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> which includes both recently ordered <a href="#title">title</a>s and <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s on <a href="#backorder">back order</a>, combined to reduce <a href="#shipping">shipping</a> costs.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="consolidation"><b>consolidation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The merger of two or more separately administered <a href="#library">libraries</a>,
or organizational units within a library, into one unit under a single
administration, usually for reasons of efficiency and/or economy, or to
improve <a href="#qualityofservice">quality of service</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="consortium"><b>consortium</b></a>
</dt><dd>An association of independent <a href="#library">libraries</a> and/or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s established by formal agreement, usually for the purpose of <a href="#resourcesharing">resource sharing</a>.  Membership may be restricted to a specific geographic region, type of library (<a href="#publiclibrary">public</a>, <a href="#academiclib">academic</a>, <a href="#speciallibrary">special</a>), or <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>.  One of the leading examples in the United States is <a href="http://www.ohiolink.edu/">OhioLINK</a> which includes Ohio's <a href="#collegelibrary">college</a> and <a href="#universitylib">university libraries</a> and the Ohio <a href="#statelibrary">State Library</a>.  Plural:  <em>consortia</em>.  Compare with <a href="#network">network</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conspectus"><b>conspectus</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#survey">survey</a> of a <a href="#topic">topic</a> or body of <a href="#literature">literature</a> that takes a general or <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> view of the <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  Also, a <a href="#summary">summary</a> or <a href="#digest">digest</a> that retains the basic pattern or structure of a larger <a href="#work">work</a>, but condenses the <a href="#content">content</a> considerably.
<p>
In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, a method of uniform <a href="#collecassess">collection assessment</a> developed in North America in 1979 to facilitate <a href="#resourcesharing">resource sharing</a>.
The system uses codes to survey strengths, levels of difficulty,
linguistic and geographical coverage, etc., recorded on worksheets in <a href="#subject">subject</a> areas based on <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a>.  In 1982, the <a href="#rlg">Research Libraries Group</a> initiated the RLG Conspectus Online to provide electronic <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#data">data</a> on the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> in the United States.  The system was subsequently adopted by the <a href="#arl">Association of Research Libraries</a> for its North American Collection Inventory Project (NCIP).  It has also been adapted by the <a href="#nationallib">National Library</a>
of Canada and is used in the UK, Australia, and some European
countries. In the 1990s, after the Western Library Network (WLN)
developed <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a> <a href="#software">software</a> that enables <a href="#library">libraries</a> to develop and maintain local collection assessment <a href="#database">database</a>s, use of RLG Conspectus Online dwindled and the <a href="#file">file</a>s were removed from <em><a href="#rlin">RLIN</a></em> in 1997.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/acq/devpol/cpc.html">Click here</a> to view the collecting levels of the RLG Conspectus, used in <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> policy statements to define the extent of its collections.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="constituency"><b>constituency</b></a>
</dt><dd>The persons represented by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> when it seeks funding for daily <a href="#operatingbudget">operations</a>, new programs, and <a href="#capitalexp">capital improvement</a>s, and when it lobbies for legislation favorable to its interests.  Successful <a href="#libadmin">library administration</a> depends on winning the approval of the library's <em>external</em> constituency (voters, users, supporters, etc.) through <a href="#qualityofservice">quality of service</a>, <a href="#publicrelations">public relations</a>, and community <a href="#outreach">outreach</a> programs.  A library also has an <em>internal</em> constituency consisting of its employees and management.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#libraryadvocate">library advocate</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="consultant"><b>consultant</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person with <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> and experience in a <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#field">field</a>, hired by a <a href="#library">library</a>
or other institution to analyze a problem and provide professional or
technical advice concerning possible solutions, especially when the
required level of expertise is not available within the organization or
the opinion of an outsider is desirable. A consultant may also
participate in the planning and implementation phase of a recommended
change.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="consumerguide"><b>consumer guide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> containing practical <a href="#information">information</a>
and advice for prospective purchasers concerning the quality of
products and services available in the market place. Some consumer
guides are <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#serial">serial</a>ly (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Consumer Reports Buying Guide</em></b>).  High-<a href="#demand">demand</a> consumer guides may be shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>, sometimes in <a href="#readyreference">ready reference</a>.  Used synonymously with <a href="#buyingguide">buying guide</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="container"><b>container</b></a>
</dt><dd>A box or holder used for storing a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>, group of items, or part of an item (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#pullcase">pull-case</a>, <a href="#slipcase">slipcase</a>, or <a href="#solander">solander</a>).  Physically separable from its <a href="#contents">contents</a>, a container can be open or lidded.
Compare with <a href="#physicalcarrier">physical carrier</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conte"><b>conte</b></a>
</dt><dd>The French term for a <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#tale">tale</a> or <a href="#shortstory">short story</a> of the medieval period, originally dealing with events of an imaginative nature (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Guigemar</em></b> by Marie de France, as distinct from her <a href="#lai">lai</a>s).  In modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, the <a href="#term">term</a> is associated with any brief story of a few <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#page">page</a>s, regardless of <a href="#genre">genre</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#shortshort">short short story</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contemporary"><b>contemporary</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> and <a href="#usedbook">used</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> within the most recent decade.  Also refers to a <a href="#book">book</a> in which all the parts (particularly the <a href="#binding">binding</a>) were created at the time the <a href="#edition">edition</a> was <a href="#printing">printed</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="content"><b>content</b></a>
</dt><dd>The essential matter or substance of a written <a href="#work">work</a> or discourse, as opposed to its form or style.  In a more general sense, <em>all</em> the ideas, <a href="#topic">topic</a>s, facts, or statements contained in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other written work.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>subject matter</em>. Also refers to the matter which is the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of a course of study.  Compare with <a href="#contents">contents</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#contentanalysis">content analysis</a> and <a href="#editorialcontent">editorial content</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contentanalysis"><b>content analysis</b></a>
</dt><dd>Close analysis of the explicit and implicit message of a <a href="#work">work</a> or body of communicated <a href="#information">information</a> through classification and evaluation of the important concepts, <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s, and themes it addresses, to determine its meaning and account for the effect it has on its <a href="#audience">audience</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contentdesignator"><b>content designator</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#character">Character</a>s used as <a href="#tag">tag</a>s, <a href="#indicator">indicator</a>s, and <a href="#subfieldcode">subfield code</a>s in a <a href="#machinereadable">machine readable</a> <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> to identify or provide additional <a href="#information">information</a> about the <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s of which it is composed.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#parallelcontent">parallel content</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contents"><b>contents</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the divisions, <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>s, <a href="#article">article</a>s, or individual <a href="#work">work</a>s contained in a <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually listed with <a href="#locator">locator</a>s (<a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s) in order of appearance in the <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a> in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> of a book, or on a <a href="#page">page</a> near the front of an <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a periodical.  Compare with <a href="#content">content</a>.
<p>
Also refers to all the items physically contained in a <a href="#archivesbox">box</a>, <a href="#binder">binder</a>, case, or holder designed for <a href="#loose">loose</a> materials, for example, a <a href="#pamphletfile">pamphlet file</a> or <a href="#portfolio">portfolio</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contentsnote"><b>contents note</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#note">note</a> in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for a <a href="#book">book</a>, listing its major divisions (books, <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>s, etc.) or the <a href="#work">work</a>s contained in it (<a href="#essay">essay</a>s, interviews, <a href="#shortstory">short stories</a>, <a href="#poetry">poems</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>s, etc.), usually by <a href="#title">title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="context"><b>context</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the most general sense, the entire situation, background, or environment <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> to an event, action, statement, <a href="#work">work</a>, etc.  In a literary sense, the parts of a sentence, paragraph, or <a href="#text">text</a> that occur just before and after a specific word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, or passage and determine its precise meaning.  <a href="#quotation">Quoting</a> <em>out of context</em> may give a misleading impression of the intentions of the original speaker or <a href="#author">author</a>.  Context is included in certain types of <a href="#keywords">keyword</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> (<em>see</em>:  <a href="#kwac">KWAC</a>, <a href="#kwic">KWIC</a>, and <a href="#kwoc">KWOC</a>).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contextsensitive"><b>context-sensitive</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, an <a href="#interface">interface</a> designed to provide assistance to the user at the point when help is needed, as opposed to a <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> that provides a general <a href="#helpscreen">help screen</a> which the user must first locate and then navigate to find instructions or advice concerning a specific problem.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#wizard">wizard</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contingencyfund"><b>contingency fund</b></a>
</dt><dd>A special fund set aside in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#budget">budget</a> to cover unanticipated expenditures and emergencies.  Contingency funds are commonly included in budgets for major <a href="#capitalimprovement">capital improvement</a>s to allow for possible cost overruns.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contingencyplan"><b>contingency plan</b></a>
</dt><dd>An alternative plan of action prepared in advance to be put
into effect should it become impossible to implement normal
arrangements, or when certain predetermined conditions arise. An
example might be the decision of a <a href="#library">library</a> to cut spending on <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>s rather than <a href="#canceled">cancel</a> <a href="#serial">serial</a>s <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s in the event of an unexpected <a href="#budget">budget</a> cut.  Compare with <a href="#disasterplan">disaster plan</a> and <a href="#emergencyplan">emergency plan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="continuation"><b>continuation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or other uncompleted <a href="#work">work</a> continued by another writer, usually after the death of the original <a href="#author">author</a>.  Compare with <a href="#sequel">sequel</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#posthumous">posthumous</a>.
<p>
Also, a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d as a <a href="#supplement">supplement</a> to one previously <a href="#publishing">published</a>, or a <a href="#part">part</a> issued in continuance of a <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>ic <a href="#set">set</a> or <a href="#series">series</a>.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> normally place such <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> on <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>.  In the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> for such a <a href="#publication">publication</a>, a <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> are indicated in an <a href="#openentry">open entry</a> for a publication that is ongoing, or in a <a href="#closedentry">closed entry</a> for one that has <a href="#ceased">ceased</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="continuationorder"><b>continuation order</b></a>
</dt><dd>An order placed by a <a href="#library">library</a> with an <a href="#agent">agent</a> or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to automatically supply until further notice each succeeding <a href="#issue">issue</a>, <a href="#volume">volume</a>, or <a href="#part">part</a> of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> or <a href="#series">series</a> as <a href="#publishing">published</a>.  If a continuation order does not specify a maximum <a href="#listprice">price</a>, it is assumed that the <a href="#item">item</a> may be <a href="#shipping">shipped</a> regardless of price.  Some <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s offer a <a href="#discount">discount</a> on continuation orders (usually 5-10%).  <a href="#annual">Annual</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Literary Market Place</em></b>), <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#set">set</a>s (<b><em>Dictionary of Literary Biography</em></b>), and <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>s <a href="#revisededition">revised</a> and <a href="#reissue">reissue</a>d in frequent <a href="#edition">edition</a>s (<a href="#travelguide">travel guide</a>s) are often purchased in this way.  A special <a href="#orderrecord">order record</a> is created and maintained to track the receipt of such items.  Synonymous with <em>standing order</em>.  Compare with <a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#openentry">open entry</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="continuationdiscount"><b>continuation order discount</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#discount">discount</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="continuinged"><b>continuing education</b></a>
</dt><dd>Formal instruction for persons who have completed an academic
degree, moved into the workplace, and wish to keep up with changes and
innovations in their <a href="#field">field</a>.  For <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, continuing education opportunities include courses offered <a href="#distancelearning">online</a> or traditionally through a <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a>, training provided by commercial <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s, and <a href="#workshop">workshop</a>s sponsored by <a href="#bibservice">bibliographic service center</a>s and <a href="#libassociation">library association</a>s, as well as independent study.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="continuouspagination"><b>continuous pagination</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#pagenumber">Number</a>ing the <a href="#page">page</a>s of two or more <a href="#volume">volume</a>s or <a href="#part">part</a>s of a <a href="#set">set</a>, or the <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> comprising a volume, in a single unbroken sequence, beginning with number one.  Compare with <a href="#separately">separately paginated</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#journalpagination">journal pagination</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="continuousrevision"><b>continuous revision</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of <a href="#update">updating</a> a <a href="#textbook">textbook</a> or <a href="#refbook">reference work</a> by revising a portion of the <a href="#text">text</a> and/or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s with each <a href="#printing">printing</a>, as opposed to updating the entire <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a> all at once and <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> the result as a <a href="#revisededition">revised edition</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contourmap"><b>contour map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#topographic">topographic map</a> that indicates relief by continuous lines, traditionally shown in brown <a href="#ink">ink</a>,
connecting points of equal elevation, with or without shading. The
number of feet represented by the intervals between contour lines
varies with the <a href="#scale">scale</a> of the <a href="#map">map</a>.  A topographic map of the sea floor is called a <a href="#bathymetricmap">bathymetric map</a>.  Compare with <a href="#reliefmap">relief map</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contract"><b>contract</b></a>
</dt><dd>A legally binding written agreement between an employer and 1) an individual <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or other member of the <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a>, or 2) librarians and/or staff organized in a <a href="#collectivebargaining">collective bargaining</a> unit for the purpose of negotiating terms of employment (<a href="#salary">salaries</a> and <a href="#wages">wages</a>, duties and responsibilities, <a href="#promotion">promotion</a> and <a href="#tenure">tenure</a>, vacation and sick leave, <a href="#benefits">benefits</a>, etc.) usually for a specified period of time.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bookcontract">book contract</a> and <a href="#breach">breach of contract</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contraction"><b>contraction</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened form of a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> used for brevity in place of the whole, formed by the omission of one or more <a href="#letter">letter</a>s or sounds, usually replaced by a <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a> (<b>e-mail</b> for <em>electronic mail</em>) or an apostrophe (<b>isn't</b> for <em>is not</em>).  Compare with <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> and <a href="#elision">elision</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contraries"><b>contraries</b></a>
</dt><dd>Impurities in the <a href="#ragpaper">rag</a>, waste <a href="#paper">paper</a>,
or other fibrous material from which paper is made, usually bits of
wool, feathers, or twine, or hard materials such as metal staples,
bone, or plastic which must be removed in the <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a> process to maintain quality of product.  Contraries occasionally show as blemishes in a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#finish">finish</a>ed paper. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contrast"><b>contrast</b></a>
</dt><dd>The degree of difference between the high and low tonal values in a <a href="#print">print</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>, or image on <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> <a href="#film">film</a>, <a href="#videotape">video</a>, or television, maximum contrast being black and white with no intermediate gray tones. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="contributor"><b>contributor</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of several persons, each of whom writes one or more <a href="#signed">signed</a> or <a href="#unsigned">unsigned</a> portions of a <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, or other <a href="#editor">edited</a> <a href="#work">work</a>.  A <em>contribution</em> may consist of an <a href="#article">article</a> or <a href="#column">column</a> in a <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> or <a href="#journal">journal</a>, an <a href="#essay">essay</a> in a <a href="#collection">collection</a>, a <a href="#poetry">poem</a> or <a href="#shortstory">story</a> in an <a href="#anthology">anthology</a>, an <a href="#entry">entry</a> in an <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>, or one or more <a href="#term">term</a>s and <a href="#definition">definition</a>s in a <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> or <a href="#glossary">glossary</a>.  Contributors are usually listed by name in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> or <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a> of a book, on one <a href="#page">page</a> of a periodical, or in the last <a href="#volume">volume</a> of a <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#set">set</a>, <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by name or in the order in which their work appears.  Compare with <a href="#jointauthor">joint author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="controlkey"><b>control key</b></a>
</dt><dd>A key located in the lower left-hand corner of a standard computer <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>, usually labeled <b>Ctrl</b> or <b>Ctl</b>, which can be used simultaneously with one or more other keys to give a specific command, for example, <b>Ctrl+Alt+Del</b> to <a href="#reboot">reboot</a> the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="controlledaccess"><b>controlled access</b></a>
</dt><dd>Entry into a <a href="#library">library</a>, or use of a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, which is limited to <a href="#register">register</a>ed members of the library's <a href="#usergroup">user group</a> or some other category of user specifically granted <a href="#access">access</a>.
The libraries of large private universities may extend access to all or
part of their collections only to registered students, faculty, and
staff. Use of <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a> may be limited to authorized <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a>, except by appointment.  Compare with <a href="#restricted">restricted access</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#closedstacks">closed stacks</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="controlled"><b>controlled vocabulary</b></a>
</dt><dd>An established list of <a href="#preferredterm">preferred term</a>s from which a <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> or indexer must select when assigning <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, to indicate the <a href="#content">content</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or in an <a href="#index">index</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>.  <a href="#synonym">Synonym</a>s are included as <a href="#leadinvocabulary">lead-in vocabulary</a>, with instructions to <em><a href="#see">see</a></em> or <a href="#use">USE</a> the authorized <a href="#heading">heading</a>.
<p>
For example, if the authorized subject heading for <a href="#work">work</a>s about dogs is "Dogs" then all <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s about dogs will be assigned the heading "Dogs," including a work <a href="#title">title</a>d <b><em>All About Canines</em></b>.  A <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a> to the heading "Dogs" will be made from the <a href="#term">term</a> "Canines" to ensure that anyone looking for <a href="#information">information</a> about dogs under "Canines" will be directed to the correct heading.  <a href="#authoritycontrol">Controlled</a> <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a> is usually listed <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly in a subject headings list or <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of indexing terms.  The process of creating and maintaining a list of preferred <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">terms</a> is called <a href="#vocabcontrol">vocabulary control</a>.  Synonymous with <em>controlled terms</em>.  Compare with <a href="#freetextsearch">free-text search</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conventionalname"><b>conventional name</b></a>
</dt><dd>A name, distinct from the real or official name by which a thing, place, or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a> has become known, for example, "Wall Street" for the New York Stock Exchange.  Compare with <a href="#nickname">nickname</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conventionaltitle"><b>conventional title</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conventiondiscount"><b>convention discount</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#discount">discount</a> given on orders placed at a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> booth during a <a href="#conference">conference</a> or convention, usually 10-20%, with 15% the norm.  <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s sometimes <a href="#compile">compile</a> lists of selected <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s prior to attending a major <a href="#libconference">library conference</a>, to be prepared to take advantage of the anticipated discount.  At the end of the conference, <a href="#displaycopy">display copies</a> may be sold at an even deeper discount, especially if the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>s are no longer in perfect <a href="#condition">condition</a>.  Synonymous with <em>show discount</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="conventionissue"><b>convention issue</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> devoted to a forthcoming <a href="#libconference">conference</a> or convention, providing a brief description of the program, <a href="#information">information</a> about <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>s, registration procedures, advice about travel and accommodations, and whom to contact for more details.  Follow-up <a href="#article">article</a>s usually appear in the issue immediately following the event.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cookbook"><b>cookbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#howto">how-to</a> <a href="#book">book</a>
that gives instructions for preparing food, including recipes for
specific dishes, notes about tools and ingredients, weights and
measures, and sometimes <a href="#directory">directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> for culinary suppliers.  Most cookbooks are <a href="#specialization">specialized</a>, focusing on a particular cuisine, type of dish, or category of food.  Cookbooks for beginners often include color <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, but those intended by the <a href="#author">author</a> to be <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> are usually sparsely illustrated.  Most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> include a diverse selection of cookbooks in the <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> section.  Synonymous with <em>recipe book</em>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cookie"><b>cookie</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small string of <a href="#data">data</a> created by a <a href="#webserver">Web server</a>, transmitted to a computer connected to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> and stored in the cookie file of its <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>.  Originally intended to reduce the amount of time required for <a href="#website">Web site</a> registration by retrieving from the user's hard drive <a href="#input">input</a>
provided in a previous visit, cookies can also be used to determine
what a user viewed on previous visits, and on visits to other Web
sites. Potential invasiveness has made cookies the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of debate over <a href="#privacy">privacy</a>.  Web browser <a href="#software">software</a> can be set to allow the user to accept or reject a cookie at the time it is offered, or to reject <em>all</em> cookies automatically.  "Cookie manager" software provides a wider range of <a href="#option">option</a>s.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cooperativecat"><b>cooperative cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd>An arrangement in which a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> agrees to follow established <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> practices and work in automated systems or utilities that facilitate the creation of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic</a> and <a href="#authorityrecord">authority record</a>s
in a form that can be shared with other libraries. In North America,
cooperative cataloging is facilitated by the uniform cataloging
practices established under <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2R</a></em>.  <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> is the <a href="#bibutility">bibliographic utility</a> used for cooperative cataloging in the United States.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nucmc">NUCMC</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corc"><b>Cooperative Online Resource Catalog (CORC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#www">Web</a>-based <a href="#metadata">metadata</a> system designed to facilitate <a href="#access">access</a> to electronic resources, <b>CORC</b> provides a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s for electronic resources, an <a href="#authorityfile">authority file</a>, a <a href="#pathfinder">pathfinder</a> <a href="#database">database</a>, and an enhanced version of <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> called <em><a href="#webdewey">WebDewey</a></em>.  Based on technology developed at <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a>, the <b>CORC</b> <a href="#toolkit">toolkit</a> supports flexible automated bibliographic record creation, <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>, <a href="#url">URL</a> maintenance, <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> assignment, and pathfinder creation.  <a href="http://www.oclc.org/corc/">Click here</a> to learn more about <b>CORC</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coordinate"><b>coordinate</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of a <a href="#number">number</a> of quantities used to indicate the position of a point, line, or plane with reference to a fixed system, such as a <a href="#grid">grid</a>.  On <a href="#map">map</a>s and <a href="#chart">chart</a>s of the surface of the earth and other heavenly bodies, the quantities are usually degrees, minutes, and seconds of <em>longitude</em> and <em>latitude</em>, or angles of declination and ascension.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coordinateindexing"><b>coordinate indexing</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#postcoordinate">post-coordinate indexing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copublishing"><b>co-publishing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The simultaneous <a href="#publication">publication</a> of an <a href="#edition">edition</a> by two or more <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s,
usually in different countries, to achieve economies of scale when the
home market is not sufficient to guarantee a reasonable profit.
Typically, a <a href="#work">work</a> is <a href="#printing">printed</a> in the country of the originating publisher and then supplied to a publisher in another country with a <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> bearing the <a href="#imprint">imprint</a> of the second publisher (or both).  Subsequent printings may occur independently or cooperatively.  In <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the result may be separate editions for each country or a <a href="#bilingualedition">bilingual edition</a> marketed in both countries.  Compare with <a href="#exportedition">export edition</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copy"><b>copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>To make a <a href="#duplicate">duplicate</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a> or other <a href="#work">work</a>, by hand or any other process.  Many <a href="#earlybook">early book</a>s were produced in only one copy.  In medieval Europe, devotional <a href="#work">work</a>s and the <a href="#classics">classics</a> were laboriously hand-copied by monks and <em>copyists</em> known as <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>s.  Modern methods rely on <a href="#printing">printing</a> and <a href="#reprography">reprography</a>.  In <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a>, to reproduce <a href="#data">data</a> from one <a href="#file">file</a>, location, or <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> to another without alteration. 
<p>
Also refers to a single specimen of a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or printed <a href="#document">document</a>.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> sometimes purchase heavily-used <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in multiple copies.  <a href="#copynumber">Copy number</a> is indicated in the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> and at the end of the <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>, beginning with the second copy.  In <a href="#limitededition">limited edition</a>s, the total number of copies printed and the number of each copy are recorded in the <a href="#certificate">certificate of issue</a>, usually on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> preceding the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#aberrantcopy">aberrant copy</a>, <a href="#assoccopy">association copy</a>, <a href="#complimentary">complimentary copy</a>, <a href="#deskcopy">desk copy</a>, and <a href="#distribcopy">distribution copy</a>.
</p><p>
In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, <a href="#matter">matter</a> that is to be <a href="#typesetting">typeset</a> in preparation for printing, or incorporated as <a href="#text">text</a> into a <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> document.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#faircopy">fair copy</a> and <a href="#printerscopy">printer's copy</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copycard"><b>copy card</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small plastic debit card available for purchase from a vending machine or at the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>, which can be used in <a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a>s and <a href="#microform">microform</a> <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a> machines instead of cash to pay for <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#copy">copies</a> of <a href="#document">document</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copycataloging"><b>copy cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd>Adaptation of a pre-existing <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> (usually found in <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a>, <em><a href="#rlin">RLIN</a></em>, <a href="#nuc">NUC</a>, or another <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>) to fit the characteristics of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> on hand, with modifications to correct obvious errors and minor adjustments to reflect locally accepted <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> practice, as opposed to creating a completely new record from scratch.  Synonymous with <em>derived cataloging</em>.  Compare with <a href="#originalcataloging">original cataloging</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copyeditor"><b>copy editor</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person employed by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to meticulously <a href="#editing">edit</a> and mark up an <a href="#author">author</a>'s <a href="#typescript">typescript</a> in preparation for <a href="#printing">printing</a>, usually in accordance with <a href="#housestyle">house style</a> as to spelling, <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a>, <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a>, grammar, <a href="#syntax">syntax</a>, <a href="#usage">usage</a>, <a href="#citation">citation</a> style, etc.  A good <a href="#copy">copy</a> <a href="#editor">editor</a> also checks the <a href="#accuracy">accuracy</a> of facts, <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s, and citations, and is alert to possibilities of <a href="#libel">libel</a>, <a href="#plagiarism">plagiarism</a>, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copyist"><b>copyist</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copynumber"><b>copy number</b></a>
</dt><dd>When multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a> of the same <a href="#edition">edition</a> are added to a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> <a href="#number">number</a>s each copy sequentially, beginning with the second.  In the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> for the edition, each copy is listed separately in the <a href="#holdings">holdings</a>, with the copy <a href="#number">number</a> given at the end of the <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> following the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> <em>cop.</em>  It is also <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the end of the call number on the <a href="#spinelabel">spine label</a> attached to the outside of the physical <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copyright"><b>copyright</b></a>      
</dt><dd>The exclusive legal <a href="#rights">rights</a> granted by a government to an <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#editor">editor</a>, <a href="#compiler">compiler</a>, <a href="#composer">composer</a>, <a href="#playwright">playwright</a>, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, or <a href="#distributor">distributor</a> to <a href="#publishing">publish</a>, produce, sell, or distribute <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#literarywork">literary</a>, musical, dramatic, artistic, or other <a href="#work">work</a>, within certain limitations (<a href="#fairuse">fair use</a>).  Copyright law also governs the right to prepare <a href="#derivativework">derivative work</a>s, <a href="#reproduction">reproduce</a> a work or portions of it, and display or perform a work in public.  
<p>
Such rights may be transferred or sold to others and do not necessarily
pass with ownership of the work itself. Copyright protects a work in
the specific form in which it is created, not the idea, theme, or
concept expressed in the work, which other writers are free to
interpret in a different way. A work never copyrighted or no longer
protected by copyright is said to be in the <a href="#publicdomain">public domain</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#copyrightcompliance">copyright compliance</a>, <a href="#copyrightdate">copyright date</a>, <a href="#copyrightdepository">copyright depository</a>, <a href="#infringement">infringement</a>, <a href="#intellectualproperty">intellectual property</a>, <a href="#internationalcopyright">international copyright</a>, and <a href="#pirated">pirated edition</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dd>In 1710, the first copyright law in England gave
protection to the author for fourteen years, renewable for a second
period of equal length. In the United States, the first federal
copyright law was passed in 1790. Copyright is controlled by Congress
and administered by the <a href="#usco">U.S. Copyright Office</a> of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  International copyright is governed by the <em><a href="#berne">Berne Convention</a></em> and the <em><a href="#universalcopyright">Universal Copyright Convention</a></em>.
<p>
Notice of copyright usually appears on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> in the form of a "c" inside a small circle or the word "Copyright" followed by the year of <a href="#publication">publication</a>, the name of the owner of copyright, and the <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> "<a href="#allrights">all rights reserved</a>."  Because copyright law is highly complex, accurate interpretation often requires the advice of a legal specialist. <a href="http://fairuse.stanford.edu/">Click here</a> for more information about <b><em>Copyright &amp; Fair Use</em></b> in the United States.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ccc">Copyright Clearance Center</a>, <em><a href="#dmca">Digital Millennium Copyright Act</a></em>, and <a href="#icic">International Copyright Information Centre</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ccc"><b>Copyright Clearance Center, Inc. (CCC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The largest licenser of <a href="#xerography">photocopy</a> <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> <a href="#rights">rights</a> in the world, <b>CCC</b> was established in 1978 by a group of <a href="#author">author</a>s, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, and users of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>ed material in an effort to facilitate <a href="#copyrightcompliance">compliance</a> with U.S. copyright law. <b>CCC</b> manages the rights to over 1.75 million <a href="#work">work</a>s and represents approximately 9,600 <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s and hundreds of thousands of individual <a href="#author">author</a>s and creators.  <a href="http://www.copyright.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CCC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fairuse">fair use</a> and <a href="#icic">International Copyright Information Centre</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copyrightcompliance"><b>copyright compliance</b></a>
</dt><dd>The responsibility of a <a href="#library">library</a> to ensure that its <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> requests, <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, instruction <a href="#guide">guide</a>s, <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s, etc., conform to existing <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law.  In the <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> interlibrary loan system, the codes <em>ccg</em> ("conforms to copyright guidelines") and <em>ccl</em> ("conforms to copyright law") are used by the <a href="#borrowinglibrary">borrowing library</a> to inform the <a href="#lendinglibrary">lending library</a> that a request is compliant.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ccc">Copyright Clearance Center</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copyrightdate"><b>copyright date</b></a>
</dt><dd>The year in which a specific <a href="#work">work</a> was granted <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> protection, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>,
sometimes following the letter "c" with a circle around it. If more
than one copyright date is given, the earliest is the date of the <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>, which is the same as the date of first <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  Subsequent dates indicate revisions in the <a href="#text">text</a> of an extent requiring renewal of copyright.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copyrightdepository"><b>copyright depository</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> designated by law or custom to receive and preserve a specified <a href="#number">number</a> of free <a href="#copy">copies</a> of <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> under national <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law.  In the United States, the copyright <a href="#depository">depository</a> is the <a href="#usco">U.S. Copyright Office</a> at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  In Great Britain it is the <a href="#bodleian">Bodleian</a>.  In Canada, copyright law is administered by the <a href="http://strategis.ic.gc.ca/sc_mrksv/cipo/welcome/welcom-e.html">Canadian Intellectual Property Office</a> (CIPO).  Synonymous with <em>copyright library</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copyrightfee"><b>copyright fee</b></a>
</dt><dd>The payment required by a national <a href="#copyrightdepository">copyright depository</a> to register <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> of a creative <a href="#work">work</a>, which must be submitted with the completed application form and a <a href="#depositcopy">deposit copy</a> of the work.  Also refers to the <a href="#fee">fee</a> that must be paid to the holder of copyright, in exchange for the <a href="#rights">right</a> to use all or part of a work in a manner <em>not</em> defined under U.S. copyright law as <a href="#fairuse">fair use</a>, for example, the right to include a <a href="#poetry">poem</a> or <a href="#shortstory">short story</a> in an <a href="#anthology">anthology</a>, or an <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a> or <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> in a <a href="#publishing">published</a> work.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#permission">permission</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copyright office"><b>Copyright Office</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#usco">U.S. Copyright Office</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="copyrightpiracy"><b>copyright piracy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The systematic unauthorized <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> or use without <a href="#permission">permission</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> protected under <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law, usually for the purpose of profiting from such activity.  This type of egregious <a href="#infringement">infringement</a>
is subject to legal action by the copyright owner(s) in countries that
have accepted international copyright agreements, but in countries
which have not, the holder of <a href="#intellectualproperty">intellectual property</a> rights may have little recourse.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pirated">pirated edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corc1"><b>CORC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#corc"><b>C</b>ooperative <b>O</b>nline <b>R</b>esource <b>C</b>atalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corecollection"><b>core collection</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> representative of the basic <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of a <a href="#library">library</a>'s primary <a href="#usergroup">user group</a>.  In <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, core collections are <a href="#selection">selected</a> in anticipation of popular <a href="#demand">demand</a> and maintained on the basis of <a href="#usage">usage</a>.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, selection is based on curriculum need and collections are maintained to meet the <a href="#research">research</a> interests of students and faculty.  Also refers to an initial collection developed for a new library, usually with the aid of <a href="#standardlist">standard list</a>s and other selection aids (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Books for College Libraries:  A Core Collection...</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corecurriculum"><b>core curriculum</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#curriculum">curriculum</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corejournal"><b>core journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a> that reports original <a href="#research">research</a> of such significance to the academic community that the <a href="#publication">publication</a> is considered indispensable to students, teachers, and <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s in the <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or subdiscipline.  For this reason, it is included in the <a href="#serial">serial</a>s <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> supporting curriculum and research in the <a href="#field">field</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>American Historical Review</em></b> in American history).  Compare with <em>primary journal</em>. 
<p>
In <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> so essential to meeting the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of a wide range of users that it is included in most general serials collections (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Scientific American</em></b>).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corelevel"><b>core level cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#encodinglevel">encoding level</a> developed for use in the <a href="#pcc">Program for Cooperative Cataloging</a> (PCC), which allows the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> to create <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s containing fewer <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s than in <a href="#fulllevel">full level cataloging</a>, but more than in <a href="#minimallevel">minimal level cataloging</a>.  <a href="#field">Field</a>s of <a href="#fixedfield">fixed length</a> are fully coded, but a list of exceptions applies to certain fields of <a href="#variablefield">variable length</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corelist"><b>core list</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the <a href="#bestbooks">best books</a>, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, etc., on a <a href="#subject">subject</a> or in a <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, usually <a href="#compile">compile</a>d as a <a href="#selection">selection</a> aid for <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s whose responsibilities include <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Core List of Best Books and Journals in Education</em></b> by Nancy O'Brien and Emily Fabiano).  Although useful when first <a href="#publishing">published</a>, such lists become <a href="#outdated">outdated</a> within a few years.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#corecollection">core collection</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corner"><b>corner</b></a>
</dt><dd>The juncture of two edges of the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  Corners can be rounded, square, or <a href="#miter">mitered</a>, and are sometimes covered in contrasting material, such as <a href="#leather">leather</a> or heavier <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>, for protection and decorative effect.  To make <em>library corners</em>, the <a href="#turnin">turn-in</a> is folded; on <em>Dutch corners</em>, it is cut.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#boss">boss</a> and <a href="#cornerpiece">cornerpiece</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cornerpiece"><b>cornerpiece</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> of the late 16th and early 17th centuries, an ornamental design such as an <a href="#arabesque">arabesque</a>, stamped on the <a href="#corner">corner</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>, usually with a matching <a href="#centerpiece">centerpiece</a>.  Also refers to decorative metal corners attached to the <a href="#binding">binding</a> of a book.  In modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, a temporary guard made of metal or some other hard material, attached to the corners of a book to protect against damage in <a href="#shipping">shipping</a>.  Compare with <a href="#boss">boss</a> and <a href="#shoe">shoe</a>.
<p>
Also refers to an ornament or flourish <a href="#printing">printed</a> or drawn by hand at the corner of a <a href="#border">border</a> around a portion of <a href="#printing">printed</a> or handwritten <a href="#text">text</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corpora"><b>corpora</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#initialletter">Initial</a> <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a>s inserted by a <a href="#rubric">rubric</a>ator in <a href="#blank">blank</a> spaces left for that purpose by the <a href="#scribe">copyist</a> in a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or by the <a href="#printer">printer</a> in an early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corporateauthor"><b>corporate author</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a> such as an <a href="#association">association</a>, company, <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>, institution, or nonprofit organization in whose name a <a href="#publication">publication</a> is <a href="#issue">issue</a>d.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the <a href="#officialname">official name</a> or title of such a <a href="#body">body</a> is used as the <a href="#corporatename">corporate name</a> in <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> publications issued in its name (<em>example</em>:  American Library Association).  Compare with <a href="#personalauthor">personal author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corporatebody"><b>corporate body</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial enterprise, <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>, <a href="#association">association</a>, nonprofit organization, institution, or group of individuals identified by a <a href="#corporatename">collective name</a>, which has the capacity to act as a single entity, including territorial authorities and groups constituted as meetings, <a href="#conference">conference</a>s, congresses, expeditions, <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ions, etc., whether operating or defunct.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the <a href="#officialname">official name</a> or title of such a <a href="#body">body</a> is used as the <a href="#corporatename">corporate name</a> in <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in its name.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#relatedbody">related body</a> and <a href="#subordinatebody">subordinate body</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corporatename"><b>corporate name</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#officialname">official name</a> by which a <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a> such as an <a href="#association">association</a>, commercial enterprise, <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>, institution, or organization is identified, used by <a href="#library">libraries</a> in <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in its name (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>).  <a href="#formofentry">Form of entry</a> is subject to <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>.  Synonymous with <em>collective name</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#geographicname">geographic name</a> and <a href="#personalname">personal name</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corporationlib"><b>corporation library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a> established and maintained as a unit within an incorporated company or organization, to meet the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of its employees and facilitate the achievement of its <a href="#mission">mission</a> and <a href="#goal">goal</a>s.  Some corporation libraries also serve as the <a href="#repository">repository</a> for the official <a href="#records">records</a> of the organization.  For internal <a href="#security">security</a> reasons, most corporation libraries are closed to the public except by special appointment.  Synonymous with <em>company library</em>.  Compare with <a href="#businesslibrary">business library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="correctional"><b>correctional library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a>
maintained inside the walls of a prison or other correctional
institution for the use of inmates and staff, usually managed by a <em>prison librarian</em> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://bop.library.net/">Federal Bureau of Prisons Library</a>).  The <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> usually includes general interest <a href="#title">title</a>s for recreational reading, educational and vocational materials, and legal resources.  Synonymous with <em>prison library</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="correspondence"><b>correspondence</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#letters">Letters</a> or recorded messages exchanged between two or more people, usually <a href="#archives">archived</a> with the <a href="#personalpapers">personal papers</a> of the <em>correspondents</em>.  Often used in preparing <a href="#biography">biographical</a> and historical <a href="#work">work</a>s, correspondence may be <a href="#publishing">published</a> separately or with other papers.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, <a href="#collection">collected</a> correspondence is <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under the name that appears first on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, with an <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> for each of the other correspondents and for the <a href="#editor">editor</a> or <a href="#compiler">compiler</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corrigenda"><b>corrigenda</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#errata">errata</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="corruptedtext"><b>corrupted text</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#text">text</a> in which words or passages have
been added, deleted, or altered to suggest a meaning other than the one
intended by the original <a href="#author">author</a>.  In medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, this was sometimes the result of accidental <a href="#copy">copy</a>ing errors, but in modern texts tampering may be done by an individual or organization for other purposes, such as <a href="#propaganda">propaganda</a> or <a href="#publicrelations">public relation</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#censorship">censorship</a> and <a href="#expurgated">expurgated</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="costeffective"><b>cost-effective</b></a>
</dt><dd>A decision or practice that reduces expenditure in relation to
the amount of resources invested (time, money, materials, etc.).
Monetary savings can be difficult to determine when costs are
intangible, intermittent, or incurred over an extended period of time.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="costrecovery"><b>cost-recovery</b></a>
</dt><dd>A product or service offered at a price that allows the vendor
or provider to cover the costs incurred without generating a profit,
for example, <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery service</a> in most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cottagebinding"><b>cottage binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A style of decorative <a href="#leather">leather</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a> popular in England during the 17th century in which the center <a href="#panel">panel</a> is surrounded by designs <a href="#tooling">tooled</a> to resemble the gables of a building, with the style of binding bearing no relation to the <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a>.  Synonymous with <em>cottage style</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cottagestyle"><b>cottage style</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cottagebinding">cottage binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clir"><b>Council on Library and Information Resources (CLIR)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally named the Council on Library Resources, <b>CLIR</b> is an independent foundation that supports initiatives in <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> awareness, <a href="#digitallibrary">digital libraries</a>, <a href="#information">information</a> economics, resources for scholarship, and international developments in <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>.  <b>CLIR</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em><a href="http://www.clir.org/pubs/issues/issues.html">CLIR Issues</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.clir.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CLIR</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="clr"><b>Council on Library Resources (CLR)</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#clir"><b>C</b>ouncil on <b>L</b>ibrary and <b>I</b>nformation <b>R</b>esources</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="counter"><b>counter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A long cabinet top, shelf top, or other horizontal work
surface of sufficient height to accommodate a person standing in front
of it who wishes to transact business with the person standing or
sitting behind it. In most <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> is a long counter near the entrance to the building.  In the <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a> of a library, countertops (and furniture) are usually lower than normal to accommodate persons of small stature.
<p>
Also, an automatic feature built into the <a href="#html">HTML</a> code of a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>, or into the <a href="#software">software</a> running some other type of <a href="#online">online</a> resource, that allows the number of visits or uses to be counted for statistical purposes. 
</p><p>
In <a href="#typography">typography</a>, the space enclosed by the strokes of a unit of <a href="#type">type</a>, for example, the center of the "p" or the space between the vertical strokes of the "h."
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="countermark"><b>countermark</b></a>
</dt><dd>A smaller, secondary <a href="#watermark">watermark</a> on <a href="#antique">antique</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a>s, usually located in the center or lower center of the half-<a href="#sheet">sheet</a> opposite the watermark, indicating the name of the <a href="#papermaking">papermaker</a> and sometimes the date and place of hand manufacture.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="countersunk"><b>countersunk</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a depression stamped or impressed on the surface of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> to display a <a href="#label">label</a>, <a href="#inlay">inlay</a>, or decoration.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="countingbook"><b>counting book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a> designed to teach preschool children to count (usually from one to ten or twelve) by providing <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s in which the <a href="#number">number</a> of objects displayed on each <a href="#page">page</a> or <a href="#doublespread">double spread</a> corresponds to the <a href="#numeral">numeral</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> with them.  Compare with <a href="#alphabetbook">alphabet book</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#hornbook">horn book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="countrycode"><b>country code</b></a>
</dt><dd>The last portion of an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> or <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a> outside the United States, consisting of two <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>ic <a href="#character">character</a>s indicating the country in which the <a href="#host">host</a> computer is located (<em>examples</em>:  <b>.ca</b> for Canada and <b>.uk</b> for Great Britain).  Some <a href="#www">Web</a> <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>s allow the user to specify country code in a <a href="#query">query</a>.  <a href="http://www.bcpl.net/%7Ejspath/isocodes-table.html">Click here</a> to view a worldwide list of <a href="#iso">ISO</a> two-<a href="#letter">letter</a> country codes.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="countrystudy"><b>country study</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> that provides factual <a href="#information">information</a>
about a specific nation, including its history, geography, demography,
society and culture(s), economy, government and politics, etc., with
