statistical information sometimes given in an <a href="#appendix">appendix</a>.  Country studies often include at least one <a href="#map">map</a> and may be <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#series">series</a>, for example, the <a href="http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/cshome.html">Country Studies/Area Handbook Program</a> sponsored by the U.S. Department of the Army and <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by the Federal <a href="#research">Research</a> Division of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  Compare with <a href="#areastudy">area study</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="courier"><b>courier</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person or service hired by a <a href="#library">library</a> to retrieve <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> on request from an <a href="#offsitestorage">off-site storage</a> facility, or to transport materials from one library to another within a <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> or <a href="#consortium">consortium</a>, as opposed to relying on the postal service or a commercial delivery service.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coursecatalog"><b>course catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> list, usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly,
of all the courses taught at a school, college, or university during a
given academic year, usually arranged by department and course number,
with brief descriptions of course <a href="#content">content</a> and a list of instructors and their <a href="#credential">credential</a>s
at the end. Institutions offering both undergraduate and graduate
programs may publish separate catalogs. Course catalogs for educational
institutions in the United States and around the world are available <a href="#online">online</a> in <em>CollegeSource</em>, a <a href="#searchable">searchable</a> <a href="#database">database</a> provided by the <a href="http://www.collegecatalogs.org/home.asp">Career Guidance Foundation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="courseintegrated"><b>course-integrated</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#bi">Bibliographic instruction</a> designed to complement the <a href="#content">content</a> of a specific course of study, integral to completing the library <a href="#research">research</a> component embedded in the course.  Compare with <a href="#courserelated">course-related</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="courserelated"><b>course-related</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#bi">Bibliographic instruction</a> designed to
support the needs and objectives of a specific course of study, but not
essential to the completeness of the course. Compare with <a href="#courseintegrated">course-integrated</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="courseware"><b>courseware</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#application">application</a> designed to assist teachers and <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s in creating <a href="#www">Web</a>-based courses and <a href="#onlinetutorial">online tutorial</a>s.  Courseware requires little knowledge of <a href="#html">HTML</a> and may include presentation management <a href="#software">software</a>, the ability to include <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s and <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a>/<a href="#videorecording">video</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s, <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#chat">chat</a> and <a href="#thread">thread</a>ed discussions, auto-marked quizzes, course <a href="#calendar">calendar</a>ing, and grading (<em>examples</em>: <b><em>Blackboard</em></b> and <b><em>WebCT</em></b>).  Synonymous with <em>authorware</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="courtesybook"><b>courtesy book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A literary <a href="#genre">genre</a> popular during the
Renaissance, devoted to the detailed description of the code of
personal conduct, training, and view of life expected of a gentleman,
soldier, and courtier by the society in which he lived (<em>example</em>:  Castiglioni's <b><em>The Courtier</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="courthand"><b>court hand</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#cursive">cursive</a> style of writing used by <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>s from about 1100 AD until the end of the 16th century in <a href="#copy">copy</a>ing <a href="#charter">charter</a>s, legal <a href="#records">records</a>, and other official <a href="#document">document</a>s, in contrast to the <a href="#bookhand">book hand</a> used for copying <a href="#literarywork">literary</a> and devotional <a href="#work">work</a>s in <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> form.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="courtlibrary"><b>court library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large <a href="#privatelib">private library</a> housed in a monumental building, similar to the <a href="#library">libraries</a>
known to have existed in ancient Rome, financed by a wealthy nobleman,
aristocratic family, or high-ranking church dignitary of the Italian
Renaissance, whose love of <a href="#book">book</a>s manifested itself in <a href="#bookcollecting">collecting</a>.  An expression of the humanist revival of interest in <a href="#classics">classical</a> culture, court libraries were open for use by outsiders at the discretion of the owner and, according to Konstantinos Staikos (<em>The Great Libraries: From Antiquity to the Renaissance</em>, Oak Knoll/British Library, 2000), some even functioned as lending libraries for educated <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cover"><b>cover</b></a>
</dt><dd>The outer protective material attached to the <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, consisting in <a href="#book">book</a>s of two panels (front and back), each attached to the <a href="#inlay">inlay</a> over the <a href="#spine">spine</a> along a flexible <a href="#joint">joint</a>.  Books bound in <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>, or <a href="#leather">leather</a> over <a href="#board">boards</a> are said to be <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>.  The cover of a <a href="#casebinding">machine-bound</a> book is called a <a href="#case">case</a>.  Books bound in flexible <a href="#coverpaper">paper cover</a>s are called <a href="#paperback">paperback</a>s.  <a href="#periodical">Periodical</a>s are almost always <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#softcover">softcover</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#allover">all over</a>, <a href="#coversboundin">covers bound in</a>, <a href="#extendedbinding">extended binding</a>, <a href="#flushbinding">flush binding</a>, <a href="#fullbinding">full binding</a>, <a href="#halfbinding">half binding</a>, <a href="#quarterbinding">quarter binding</a>, and <a href="#threequarter">three-quarter binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coverage"><b>coverage</b></a>
</dt><dd>The extent of a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> (or section of a collection), or of a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>, <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>, <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, or other <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a>, usually indicated by the <a href="#number">number</a> and types of <a href="#publication">publication</a>s indexed, and a publication <a href="#daterange">date range</a>.  The range of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s or <a href="#field">field</a>s indexed determines the <a href="#scope">scope</a> of such a resource.
<p>
Also refers to the amount of attention (time, space, number of commentators, etc.) given a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a> in the <a href="#media">media</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coverletter"><b>cover letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#letter">letter</a> of introduction, usually no longer than one <a href="#page">page</a>, sent with a <a href="#resume">resume</a> or <em><a href="#cv">curriculum vitae</a></em> when applying for employment.  A good cover letter usually indicates that the <a href="#applicant">applicant</a> meets all the <a href="#qualification">qualification</a>s listed in the job posting, and expresses an interest in being considered for the <a href="#position">position</a>.  In a more general sense, a brief letter of explanation sent with a <a href="#document">document</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coverpaper"><b>cover paper</b></a>
</dt><dd>The heavier grades of <a href="#paper">paper</a> used for the outer <a href="#cover">cover</a> of <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, <a href="#tradecatalog">trade catalog</a>s, and <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s, manufactured in a range of colors and <a href="#finish">finish</a>es.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coversboundin"><b>covers bound in</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> to describe a <a href="#volume">volume</a> in which the original <a href="#cover">cover</a>s are enclosed in a later <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  This usually occurs in <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a> when the <a href="#bindery">bindery</a> decides to retain the original covers as <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s or <a href="#flyleaf">flyleaves</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="coverstory"><b>cover story</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#article">article</a> in a <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> or <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> that corresponds to the <a href="#headline">headline</a> and <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> on the <a href="#cover">cover</a>, usually longer and more extensively illustrated than other <a href="#feature">feature</a> articles in the same <a href="#issue">issue</a>.  Some <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s are designed to indicate whether an article is a cover story.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="covertitle"><b>cover title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> or impressed on the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#asissued">as issued</a> by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> (in <a href="#book">book</a>s usually on the <a href="#spine">spine</a>), which may be a shortened form of the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a>.  Compare with <a href="#binderstitle">binder's title</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#sidetitle">side title</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cpc1"><b>CPC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cpc"><b>C</b>anadian <b>P</b>ublishers' <b>C</b>ouncil</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cpu"><b>CPU</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#centralproc"><b>c</b>entral <b>p</b>rocessing <b>u</b>nit</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cracked"><b>cracked</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> that has developed one or more long, narrow breaks in the <a href="#cover">cover</a> or down the length of the <a href="#spine">spine</a>.  The usual method of rehabilitation is <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#coldcrack">cold-crack</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cracker"><b>cracker</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#slang">slang</a> <a href="#term">term</a> for a person who tries to gain access to a supposedly <a href="#security">secure</a> computer system without proper <a href="#authorization">authorization</a>, usually with malicious or criminal intent.  Compare with <a href="#hacker">hacker</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#security">security</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crash"><b>crash</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a narrow strip of thin, loosely woven, starched muslin attached with <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> to the <a href="#back">back</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> after the <a href="#section">section</a>s have been <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> to help hold them together.  In some <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, a strip of <a href="#kraftpaper">kraft paper</a> is applied to the layer of fabric as a second <a href="#lining">lining</a> for added strength.  Synonymous with <em>gauze</em>, <em>mull</em>, and <em>super</em> (in United States).
<p>
In computing, a <a href="#slang">slang</a> term for the unanticipated breakdown of a system, usually caused by <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> failure, a serious <a href="#software">software</a> defect, or a <a href="#network">network</a> error.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dump">dump</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crawler"><b>crawler</b></a>
</dt><dd>A robot <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> that searches "intelligently" for <a href="#information">information</a> on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>, for example, one that looks for new <a href="#document">document</a>s and <a href="#website">Web site</a>s by following <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#link">link</a>s from one <a href="#server">server</a> to another, <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> the <a href="#file">file</a>s it finds according to pre-established criteria.  Crawlers used to fetch <a href="#url">URL</a>s listed as <a href="#entry">entries</a> by Web <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>s are designed to adhere to standard rules of politeness by asking each <a href="#server">server</a> which files may not be <a href="#index">index</a>ed, observing <a href="#firewall">firewall</a>s, and allowing an interval of time to pass between requests to avoid tying up the server.  Synonymous with <em>spider</em> and <em>webcrawler</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="CRC"><b>CRC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cameraready"><b>c</b>amera-<b>r</b>eady <b>c</b>opy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="creasing"><b>creasing</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, the process of impressing a dull <a href="#rule">rule</a> or disk on a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> or <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>
to create an indentation along the line where a fold is to be made. By
compressing the fibers, creasing produces a cleaner fold and increases
the number of times the sheet can flex before it detaches at the fold.
Compare with <a href="#scoring">scoring</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="creator"><b>creator</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the individual or <a href="#agency">agency</a> responsible for creating, receiving, accumulating, or otherwise producing <a href="#records">records</a> or <a href="#document">document</a>s for which some form of <a href="#disposition">disposition</a> must be made once their <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a> has been <a href="#appraisal">appraised</a>.  Also refers to the person responsible for producing an <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#work">work</a> of visual art.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="credential"><b>credential</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#letter">letter</a>, certificate, degree, or other <a href="#document">document</a>
certifying that a person, organization, or institution is qualified to
fill a specific position, offer a service, or exercise authority in a
given <a href="#field">field</a>.  For <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s in the United States, the most desirable credential is the <a href="#mls">M.L.S.</a> or <a href="#mlis">M.L.I.S.</a> degree from an <a href="#ala">ALA</a>-<a href="#accredited">accredited library school</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="credenza"><b>credenza</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, a sideboard from which a lord's food was tested for poison ("credence").  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, a furnishing that doubles as a bookshelf and study table, having two or three <a href="#tier">tier</a>s of shelves under a flat surface low enough to accommodate a person standing or seated on a high stool or chair.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="credit"><b>credit</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any <a href="#text">text</a>ual statement at the beginning or end of a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>, or television program, identifying by name the <a href="#director">director</a>, <a href="#producer">producer</a>, <a href="#screenwriter">screenwriter</a>, <a href="#performer">performer</a>s, <a href="#narration">narrator</a>, and other persons responsible for creating the <a href="#work">work</a>,
usually with musical accompaniment. In filmmaking, considerable
artistic attention is devoted to the style in which credits are
presented, to set the tone for what is to follow (or add a final
touch).
<p>
Also refers to an amount <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>'s monthly statement, or on a separate <em>credit memo</em>, usually following a minus sign, indicating that it has been deducted from the total amount owed, for <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#returns">returned</a> or <a href="#prepayment">prepaid</a> but not <a href="#shipping">shipped</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="creditline"><b>credit line</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief statement giving the name of the <a href="#author">author</a>, artist, <a href="#agency">agency</a>, or <a href="#publication">publication</a> that is the source of a <a href="#picture">picture</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>, or <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> used in an <a href="#article">article</a> or <a href="#book">book</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> immediately below the <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> or <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>, or at the end of the <a href="#caption">caption</a>.  Credit lines are sometimes <a href="#printing">printed</a> together in a separate section in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> or <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a> of a book, or in a paragraph on a separate <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crime"><b>crime in the library</b></a>
</dt><dd>Because many <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United
States and other countries are open to the public, they are not immune
to the disruption caused by unlawful behavior, including <a href="#theft">theft</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> and <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, verbal abuse and assault on <a href="#patron">patron</a>s and <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>, indecent exposure, drug use and sale by patrons and staff, <a href="#mutilation">mutiliation</a> of materials, <a href="#vandalism">vandalism</a>
of equipment and facilities, arson, and more recently, computer crimes.
Statistics indicate that crime is increasing in libraries, placing an
additional burden on library <a href="#budget">budget</a>s to provide adequate <a href="#security">security</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#problempatron">problem patron</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="criticalabstract"><b>critical abstract</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abstract">abstract</a> that includes a brief evaluation of the <a href="#content">content</a> and/or style of presentation of the <a href="#work">work</a> abstracted, usually written by a <a href="#subjectspecialist">subject specialist</a>.  Compare with <a href="#indicativeabstract">indicative abstract</a> and <a href="#infoabstract">informative abstract</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="criticalannotation"><b>critical annotation</b></a>
</dt><dd>In a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> or list of references, an <a href="#annotation">annotation</a> that includes a brief evaluation of the <a href="#source">source</a> <a href="#citation">cited</a>, as opposed to one in which the <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a> is described, explained, or summarized.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="criticalbibliog"><b>critical bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#analyticalbibliog">analytical bibliography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="criticaledition"><b>critical edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> based on scholarly <a href="#research">research</a> and close examination of earlier <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#text">text</a>s, <a href="#document">document</a>s, <a href="#letters">letters</a>, etc., which sometimes includes analysis and <a href="#commentary">commentary</a> by one or more qualified scholars who have studied and interpreted its meaning and significance.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="criticalthinking"><b>critical thinking</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#research">research</a> and scholarship, the skill required to develop effective and efficient <a href="#searchstrategy">search strategies</a>, assess the <a href="#relevance">relevance</a> and <a href="#accuracy">accuracy</a> of <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieved</a>, evaluate the <a href="#authority">authority</a> of the person(s) or organization producing information <a href="#content">content</a>, and analyze the assumptions, evidence, and logical arguments presented in relevant <a href="#source">source</a>s.  Critical thinking is essential in evaluating <a href="#information">information</a> available <a href="#online">online</a> because the process of <a href="#peerreviewed">peer-review</a> that exists in <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> has yet to be stablished in <a href="#electronicpub">electronic publishing</a>.  For this reason, <a href="#bi">instruction librarian</a>s have focused an increasing amount of attention on teaching critical thinking skills in recent years.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="criticism"><b>criticism</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek word <em>kritikos</em> meaning "judge."  The thoughtful analysis, interpretation, and evaluation of an artistic or <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>, in which the primary considerations are its essential nature ("message"), the intentions of the artist or <a href="#author">author</a>, the effect of the <a href="#work">work</a> on its <a href="#audience">audience</a>, its relationship to works of similar style or <a href="#content">content</a>,
its influence on subsequent works, and its implications for critical
theory. Literary criticism is considered to have originated with the
ancient Greeks (Aristotle's <b><em>Poetics</em></b>).  Modern criticism is classified by school or type, depending on the approach taken by the <em>critic</em>.  
<p>
In the performing arts, initial critical response may determine the
success or demise of a production, though a work which fails on first
exposure may receive wider acclaim if revived. In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, works rejected by critics and <a href="#reader">reader</a>s when first published sometimes become <a href="#classic">classic</a>s with the passage of time.  Unlike <a href="#review">review</a>s, which appear during the months immediately following first <a href="#publication">publication</a>, serious criticism of an enduring literary work may continue indefinitely.  Compare with <a href="#explication">explication</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="critique"><b>critique</b></a>
</dt><dd>A critical examination of a <a href="#topic">topic</a>, idea,
thing, or situation by a person intent on determining its essential
nature, its strengths and/or limitations, and the degree to which it
conforms to accepted <a href="#standards">standards</a> or prevailing beliefs or assumptions.  Sometimes used synonymously with <a href="#review">review</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crl1"><b>CRL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#crl"><b>C</b>enter for <b>R</b>esearch <b>L</b>ibraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cropped"><b>cropped</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#photograph">photograph</a> or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> from which a portion of the top, bottom, or sides has been eliminated in the process of <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> to omit unnecessary detail or make its proportions fit the space available in the <a href="#layout">layout</a> of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#page">page</a>.  Also refers to a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#trimming">trimmed</a> to such an extent that the <a href="#text">text</a> is cut into, causing it to <a href="#bleed">bleed</a>.  Compare with <a href="#shaved">shaved</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crossaisle"><b>cross aisle</b></a>
</dt><dd>A corridor or passageway that intersects at a 90-degree angle the <a href="#range">range</a>s and <a href="#rangeaisle">range aisle</a>s in the <a href="#stacks">stack</a> area of a <a href="#library">library</a>, allowing <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> and <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to move from one range to another without walking to the end of the range. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crosscheck"><b>cross-check</b></a>
</dt><dd>To verify the results of an investigation by using an alternative <a href="#source">source</a> or method.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#research">research</a>,
facts are usually confirmed or disconfirmed by consulting a second
(independent) source. When conflicting evidence or opinion is found, a
third or fourth source may be required to resolve the discrepancy.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crossclass"><b>cross-classification</b></a>
</dt><dd>The inclusion of a <a href="#subclass">subclass</a> under more than one <a href="#class">class</a> in a <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, for example, the <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> "Library bonds" under the <a href="#broaderterm">broader term</a>s "Library finance" and "Municipal bonds" in the list of <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress Subject Headings</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crossgrain"><b>cross-grain</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> in which the <a href="#grain">grain</a> of the <a href="#paper">paper</a> runs perpendicular to the <a href="#spine">spine</a>, instead of parallel to it, reducing its <a href="#openability">openability</a> and making the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> more difficult to turn.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crossindex"><b>cross-index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#index">index</a> that covers the <a href="#contents">contents</a> of more than one <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>, such as a group of related <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s.  The <a href="#author">author</a> and <a href="#title">title</a> indexes to the various parts of the <a href="#gale">Gale</a> <b><em>Literary Criticism Series</em></b> are a good example. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crossref"><b>cross-reference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A reference from one <a href="#heading">heading</a> to another in the same <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, or <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>.  The most common are <em><a href="#see">see</a></em> references instructing the user to look elsewhere for the <a href="#preferredterm">preferred</a> form of the heading, and <em><a href="#seealso">see also</a></em> references directing the user to <a href="#relatedterm">related heading</a>s under which additional <a href="#information">information</a> may be found.  A <a href="#work">work</a> containing cross-references is said to have <a href="#syndetic">syndetic structure</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>x-ref</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#blindreference">blind reference</a>, <a href="#explanatoryref">explanatory reference</a>, and <a href="#omnibusref">omnibus reference</a>.
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Examples</em>:
<dl><dt></dt><dd>Librarianship
<dl><dt></dt><dd><em>See</em> Library science</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dd>Library catalogs
<dl><dt></dt><dd><em>See also</em> Cataloging</dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crossrefdirec"><b>cross reference directory</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#citydirectory">city directory</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="crosswalk"><b>crosswalk</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#table">table</a> that enables <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>s to operate across <a href="#database">database</a>s with dissimilar <a href="#record">record</a> <a href="#format">format</a>s, by mapping the relationships between <a href="#metadata">metadata</a> elements.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#interoperability">interoperability</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cryptography"><b>cryptography</b></a>
</dt><dd>Writing in <a href="#cipher">cipher</a>, usually for the purpose of concealment.  Also refers to the study and decoding of such writing.  In computing, the <a href="#dataconversion">conversion</a> of <a href="#data">data</a> into a code that can be deciphered only by those who have the key, usually to ensure <a href="#confidentiality">confidentiality</a> when it is transmitted over a publicly accessible <a href="#network">network</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#encryption">encryption</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cryptonym"><b>cryptonym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A secret name, for example, a name written in code or <a href="#cipher">cipher</a>, or in the form of an anagram.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cryptography">cryptography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="csna1"><b>CSNA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#csna"><b>C</b>lassification <b>S</b>ociety of <b>N</b>orth <b>A</b>merica</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cubook"><b>cubook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A unit of volume used to measure <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#stackcapacity">stack capacity</a>, equal to 1/100 of a <a href="#standard">standard</a> <a href="#section">section</a> of shelving (3 feet wide by 7 1/2 feet high), the amount of space needed to shelve a <a href="#book">book</a> of average <a href="#height">height</a> and <a href="#depth">depth</a> (thickness), assuming 10% of the length of each shelf remains unoccupied.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cuirbouilli"><b>cuir bouilli</b></a>
</dt><dd>A French term meaning "boiled skin."  An early form of <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> in which the <a href="#leather">leather</a> used in the <a href="#cover">cover</a>
was soaked in scalding water, then hammered or molded on a die to
create a design in relief, usually incorporating motifs popular in the
medieval <a href="#bookarts">book arts</a> (vines, leaves, flowers, birds, mythical beasts, etc.).  When the skin dried, it became so hard that <a href="#board">board</a>s were unnecessary.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cumdach"><b>cumdach</b></a>
</dt><dd>An Irish word for a rectangular box made of bronze, brass, or
wood, usually ornamented in elaborate style with gold, silver, and
precious stones, used to store and protect medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>book shrine</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cumlicentia"><b><em>cum licentia</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#cumprivilegio">cum privilegio</a></em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cumprivilegio"><b><em>cum privilegio</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A Latin <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> meaning "with permission," <a href="#printing">printed</a> in old <a href="#book">book</a>s to notify <a href="#reader">reader</a>s that the <a href="#work">work</a> was <a href="#publishing">published</a> with the approval of existing secular or ecclesiastical authorities.  The Roman Catholic Church still requires <em><a href="#imprimatur">imprimatur</a></em> and <em><a href="#nihilobstat">nihil obstat</a></em> in books representing its official teachings.  Synonymous with <em>cum licentia</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cumulativeindex"><b>cumulative index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#index">index</a> designed to save the user's time by combining in a single sequence the <a href="#entry">entries</a> listed in two or more previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> indexes, for example, the ten-year indexes to <b><em>Current Biography Yearbook</em></b>.  Most <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es are <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> or <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>s, <em>cumulated</em> at the end of the <a href="#pubyear">publication year</a> in one or more <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a>s.  In a more general sense, any index that combines in a single sequence entries for previously published volumes of a <a href="#book">book</a> or periodical. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cuneiform"><b>cuneiform</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>cuneus</em> (wedge) and <em>forma</em> (shape or form), referring to the <a href="#pictograph">pictograph</a>ic <a href="#character">character</a>s used in ancient Akkadian, Assyrian, Babylonian, Persian, and Sumerian <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>s from about 4,000 to 100 BC, each of which consisted of an arrangement of wedge-shaped marks incised in a wet <a href="#claytablet">clay tablet</a> using a sharp, pointed implement called a <a href="#stylus">stylus</a>.  If a <a href="#text">text</a> was long enough to be continued on more than one tablet, each tablet was <a href="#number">number</a>ed and incised with a <a href="#catchword">catchword</a> at its <a href="#foot">foot</a> to link it to the next.  The last tablet usually ended with a <a href="#colophon">colophon</a>.  <a href="http://special.lib.umn.edu/rare/cuneiform/">Click here</a> to learn more about cuneiform.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="curator"><b>curator</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person responsible for the development, care, organization, and supervision of a museum, gallery, or other <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> space and all the objects stored or displayed in it.  Also, a person in charge of a <a href="#specialcollections">special collection</a>, trained to assist users in locating and interpreting its <a href="#holdings">holdings</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="curiosa"><b>curiosa</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#book">Book</a>s or <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s that are highly unusual in <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#treatment">treatment</a>, usually somewhat indecent by conventional standards.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#erotica">erotica</a> and <a href="#pornography">pornography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="currency"><b>currency</b></a>
</dt><dd>The quality of being in progress, recent, or up-to-date.  In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, the extent to which the <a href="#content">content</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a> or <a href="#source">source</a> reflects the existing state of <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> about the <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  In the <a href="#research">research</a> process , the importance of currency varies, depending on the <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>.  In medicine and the sciences, <a href="#information">information</a> can become <a href="#outdated">outdated</a> in less than five years, but in the arts and humanities, materials decades old may be just as useful as more recent <a href="#information">information</a>.  
<p>
Because <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s are <a href="#issue">issue</a>d at <a href="#regular">regular</a> intervals, they provide more current information than <a href="#book">book</a>s, which must be <a href="#update">update</a>d in <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>s and <a href="#revisededition">revised edition</a>s.  Some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s allow the user to limit <a href="#search">search</a> results by <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> to retrieve only recently published materials.  The opposite of <a href="#noncurrent">noncurrent</a> and <a href="#outdated">outdated</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#currentawareness">current awareness service</a>, <a href="#currentbib">current bibliography</a>, <a href="#currentcontents">current contents</a>, and <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>.
</p><p>
In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, newly acquired <a href="#records">records</a> usually remain current for a designated period of time, after which their status is changed to <a href="#semicurrent">semicurrent</a> and they are moved to a temporary <a href="#holdingarea">holding area</a> to await final <a href="#disposition">disposition</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="currentawareness"><b>current awareness service</b></a>
</dt><dd>A service or <a href="#publication">publication</a> designed to alert scholars, <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s, <a href="#reader">reader</a>s, customers, or employees to recently <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#literature">literature</a> in their <a href="#field">field</a>(s) of <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>, usually available in <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a> serving companies, organizations, and institutions in which <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#information">information</a> is essential.  Such services can be tailored to fit the <a href="#interestprofile">interest profile</a> of a specific individual or group.  Some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s include a "preferred searches" <a href="#option">option</a> that allows the <a href="#library">library</a> user to archive <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>s and re-execute them as needed.  Synonymous with <em><b>s</b>elective <b>d</b>issemination of <b>i</b>nformation</em> (SDI).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#currentcontents">current contents</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="currentbib"><b>current bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> that includes only references to recently <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#source">source</a>s on a <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or in a specific <a href="#field">field</a> or <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Annual Bulletin of Historical Literature</em></b> published by the Historical Association, London).  The opposite of <a href="#retrobib">retrospective bibliography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="currentcontents"><b>current contents</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> that <a href="#reproduction">reproduces</a> the <a href="#tableofcontents">tables of contents</a> of the leading scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a>s in an academic <a href="#field">field</a> or <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, to assist <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s in keeping abreast of the most recently <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#literature">literature</a> in their areas of interest or <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>, usually published <a href="#weekly">weekly</a> or <a href="#monthly">monthly</a>.  Because <a href="#currency">currency</a> is the <em>raison d'etre</em> of this type of <a href="#publication">publication</a>, <a href="#library">libraries</a> may limit <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s to the most recent 3-5 years.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#currentawareness">current awareness service</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="currentissue"><b>current issue</b></a>
</dt><dd>The latest <a href="#number">number</a> of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, bearing the most recent <a href="#issuedate">issue date</a>.  In some <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>s are displayed with the front <a href="#cover">cover</a> facing forward on sloping shelves or on a <a href="#periodicalstand">periodical stand</a> to facilitate <a href="#browse">browsing</a>.  <a href="#backfile">Back file</a>s are typically stored in a different location, sometimes on <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> or <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> to conserve space.  Synonymous with <em>current number</em>.  Compare with <a href="#backissue">back issue</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#firstissue">first issue</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="currentnumber"><b>current number</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="curriculum"><b>curriculum</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the required and elective <a href="#subject">subject</a>s/courses taught at a school or institution of higher learning, usually listed by department and course number in an <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#coursecatalog">course catalog</a>.   Courses required of all students for graduation constitute the <em>core curriculum</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="curriculumguide"><b>curriculum guide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written plan covering one or more facets of <a href="#curriculum">curriculum</a> and instruction (<a href="#goal">goal</a>s and <a href="#objective">objective</a>s,
teaching strategies, learning activities, specific resources,
evaluation and assessment techniques) for use within an instructional
unit as small as a classroom or as large as a school district or state.
Curriculum guides are <a href="#indexing">indexed</a> and <a href="#abstracting">abstracted</a> as <a href="#document">document</a>s in <em><a href="#eric">ERIC</a></em>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="curriculumlab"><b>curriculum lab</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#curriculumroom">curriculum room</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="curriculumroom"><strong>curriculum room</strong></a>     
</dt><dd>A room or designated area within an <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a> containing <a href="#curriculum">curriculum</a>-related materials such as <a href="#kit">kit</a>s, <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s, <a href="#workbook">workbook</a>s, educational <a href="#software">software</a>, and <a href="#childrensbook">juvenile</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>, for the use of students enrolled in teacher education courses. Synonymous with <em>curriculum lab</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cv"><b><em>curriculum vitae</em> (<em>c.v.</em>)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief <a href="#summary">summary</a> of a person's professional career, including basic <a href="#biography">biographical</a> <a href="#information">information</a>, degrees and post-graduate education, honors and awards, employment history, <a href="#publication">publication</a>s and presentations, memberships, service, etc., for use in employment (hiring, <a href="#tenure">tenure</a>, <a href="#promotion">promotion</a>, etc.).  Compare with <a href="#resume">resume</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cursive"><b>cursive</b></a>
</dt><dd>A right-sloping style of handwriting also known as <em>running script</em>, in which the <a href="#letter">letter</a>s within words are connected, having been written continuously without lifting pen or pencil from <a href="#paper">paper</a> or other writing surface. Used in humanist <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and papal <a href="#document">document</a>s of the Renaissance, and for writing <a href="#letters">letters</a>.  In <a href="#printing">printing</a> and <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a>, any <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> that has the appearance of handwriting.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#courthand">court hand</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cursor"><b>cursor</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small illuminated point, vertical bar, underline, or other <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> on a computer screen which can be positioned by the user via a <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>, <a href="#mouse">mouse</a>, or other control <a href="#device">device</a> to indicate where a new <a href="#character">character</a> will appear when typed as <a href="#input">input</a>, or a new operation is to occur when initiated by the user.  In <a href="#windows">Windows</a> and other <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a>s, the cursor may change shape when moved from one <a href="#window">window</a> or <a href="#dialogbox">dialog box</a> to another, turning into an I-beam for <a href="#text">text</a>-<a href="#editing">editing</a>, an arrow or finger for selecting an <a href="#option">option</a> from a <a href="#menu">menu</a> or <a href="#toolbar">toolbar</a>, an hour-glass while an operation is in progress, or a small pen in <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s.  In many <a href="#application">application</a>s, the symbol <blink>blinks</blink> steadily to make it easier to locate on the screen.  Synonymous with <em>pointer</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#prompt">prompt</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="custodian"><b>custodian</b></a>
</dt><dd>The person responsible for the care and protection of something of value.  Over the past one hundred years, the model of <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a> has evolved from <em>custodianship</em> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in physical form, to one in which the <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> is seen as a mediator of <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#information">information</a> in a wide range of <a href="#format">format</a>s, including electronic resources.  However, custodianship remains a high priority in <a href="#archives">archival</a> and <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="custody"><b>custody</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the official guardianship of <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#papers">papers</a>, <a href="#records">records</a>, and other <a href="#document">document</a>s, based on physical possession, with or without legal title or the right to control <a href="#access">access</a> or <a href="#disposition">disposition</a>.  The person responsible for such care is their <a href="#custodian">custodian</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="custombinding"><b>custom binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> to the specifications of its owner or a <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>, or in accordance with special instructions from the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, rather than the general instructions for the <a href="#edition">edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cut"><b>cut</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> (<a href="#caption">caption</a>ed or uncaptioned) with the <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#page">page</a>, as opposed to a <a href="#plate">plate</a> printed on a separate <a href="#leaf">leaf</a>, usually of different quality <a href="#paper">paper</a>, to be added to the <a href="#publication">publication</a> in <a href="#binding">binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cutandpaste"><b>cut-and-paste</b></a>
</dt><dd>A feature built into most <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a>s that allows the user to move an element displayed on the computer screen, such as a portion of <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>, from one location to another within the same <a href="#document">document</a>, from one document to another, or even from one <a href="#application">application</a> to another, usually by <a href="#highlight">highlight</a>ing the element to be moved, selecting "cut" or "copy" under the "edit" <a href="#option">option</a> in a <a href="#toolbar">toolbar</a>, and then using the option to "paste" after positioning the <a href="#cursor">cursor</a> at the point to which the element is to be moved.  The element cut or copied is transferred to a temporary <a href="#storage">storage</a> area called a <a href="#clipboard">clipboard</a> until the next cut-and-paste operation is initiated.  Most <a href="#software">software</a> includes an "undo" option that allows the user to reverse the operation if a mistake is made.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cutflush"><b>cut flush</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> that has edges perfectly even with the edges of the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, the result of having been cut after it was attached to the <a href="#section">section</a>s.  Most <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> books are cut flush in <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Synonymous with <em>flush boards</em> and <em>trimmed flush</em>.  Compare with <a href="#squares">squares</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cutinnote"><b>cut-in note</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#sidenote">side note</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> wholly or partially inside the edge of a paragraph of <a href="#text">text</a>, instead of in the <a href="#margin">margin</a>, usually in a <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> heavier and smaller in <a href="#typesize">size</a> than the <a href="#texttype">text type</a>.  Synonymous with <em>cut-in side note</em>, <em>in-cut note</em>, and <em>let-in note</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cutline"><b>cut line</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#caption">caption</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cutternumber"><b>Cutter number</b></a>
</dt><dd>A system of <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a> <a href="#authormark">author mark</a>s developed by Charles A. Cutter to enable <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>s of the same <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> to be subarranged <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#author">author</a>'s last name.  A Cutter number consists of one to three <a href="#letter">letter</a>s from the name, followed by one or more <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s from the <a href="#cuttersanborn">Cutter-Sanborn Table</a> added to the end of the <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> by a <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>.  Synonymous with <em>Cutter author mark</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#workmark">workmark</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cuttersanborn"><b>Cutter-Sanborn Table</b></a>
</dt><dd>In 1880, Charles A. Cutter first circulated a two-figure <a href="#table">table</a> designed to assist <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s in adding <a href="#authormark">author mark</a>s to <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>s, as a means of differentiating <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s of the same <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> by author.  The Cutter Table was subsequently extended by Kate A. Sanborn to allow three <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s to be assigned, following the initial <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the <a href="#author">author</a>'s last name. <a href="http://nvl.nist.gov/pub/ois/rlip/catacq/lccutter.htm">Click here</a> to view the <em>LC Cutter Table</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cutternumber">Cutter number</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cuttertable"><b>Cutter Table</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cuttersanborn">Cutter-Sanborn Table</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cutting"><b>cutting</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cv1"><b><em>c.v.</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#cv">curriculum vitae</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cybercafe"><b>cybercafe</b></a>
</dt><dd>A high-tech coffee house equipped with <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a>s
for the use of its customers. Cybercafes originated in New York City in
the 1990's and have since spread throughout the world. Some large <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> have installed them on their premises to give students a place to relax and read their <a href="#email">e-mail</a>.  Synonymous with <em>Internet cafe</em> and <em>netcafe</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cybernetics"><b>cybernetics</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek word <em>kybernetes</em> meaning "helmsman."  A branch of science developed by Norbert Wiener in the 1940's that utilizes the concept of <a href="#feedback">feedback</a>
in comparing human and machine processes, particularly mental
processes, to understand their similarities and differences, with the
ultimate goal of creating machines capable of imitating human behavior
and intelligence. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#artificial">artificial intelligence</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cyberporn"><b>cyberporn</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#neologism">neologism</a> coined from the terms "<a href="#cyberspace">cyberspace</a>" and "<a href="#pornography">pornography</a>" to refer to sexually explicit materials available electronically over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  Cyberporn is of particular concern to parents who would like to see their children become <a href="#computerliteracy">computer literate</a>, but hesitate to expose them to <a href="#adult">adult</a> influences prematurely.  <a href="#filter">Filter</a>ing <a href="#software">software</a> designed to block <a href="#access">access</a> to adult material remains controversial.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>, <em><a href="#cipa">Children's Internet Protection Act (CIPA)</a></em>, and <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cyberspace"><b>cyberspace</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#neologism">neologism</a> coined by the writer William Gibson in his <a href="#sciencefiction">science fiction</a> <a href="#novel">novel</a> <b><em>Neuromancer</em></b> (1984) to refer to the virtual world of <a href="#digital">digital</a> communication, in which human beings interact with one another electronically via computer <a href="#network">network</a>s, instead of face-to-face.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cybrarian"><b>cybrarian</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened form of <em><b>cyb</b>erlib<b>rarian</b></em>, coined from the <a href="#term">term</a>s "<a href="#cyberspace">cyberspace</a>" and "<a href="#librarian">librarian</a>" to refer to a librarian whose work routinely involves <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a> and dissemination via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, and the use of other <a href="#online">online</a> resources.  Despite its catchy sound, the appellation has <em>not</em> been widely adopted within the <a href="#library">library</a> profession.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cycle"><b>cycle</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s (<a href="#poetry">poem</a>s, <a href="#play">play</a>s, <a href="#shortstory">stories</a>, <a href="#novel">novel</a>s) that share a unifying theme, for example, the Yoknapatawpha stories of William Faulkner.  An <em>epic cycle</em> is a group of individual <a href="#epic">epic</a>s or <a href="#ballad">ballad</a>s joined, usually by a process of accretion, to form a whole, as in the <b><em>Iliad</em></b> of Homer or the <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>s comprising the Arthurian legend. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cyclopedia"><b>cyclopedia</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="cyrillic"><b>Cyrillic</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> used in Russia and countries formerly part of the Soviet Union, Cyrillic evolved from the Greek <a href="#uncial">uncial</a> alphabet.  Formalized during the 9th or 10th century, it contains <a href="#character">character</a>s not included in the Latin alphabet, which represent sounds peculiar to the Slavic <a href="#language">language</a>s.  Cyrillic <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>s of 43 <a href="#letter">letter</a>s were introduced in the 18th century, based on the civil <a href="#script">script</a>
established by Peter the Great in 1710. In 1918, the alphabet was
reduced to its present 32 letters as a result of reforms introduced
after the Russian Revolution. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#romanization">romanization</a> and <a href="#transliteration">transliteration</a>.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>
<center>| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> | <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a>
| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> 
| <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="D">D</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="daemon"><b>daemon</b></a>
</dt><dd>The Greek word for "guardian spirit."  In computing, an auxiliary <a href="#operatingsys">systems program</a>
initiated at startup and executed in the background that performs a
specific task when needed, for example, running a scheduler to start
another process automatically at a pre-established time, checking
incoming <a href="#email">e-mail</a> messages for addresses that
cannot be found, or notifying the sender that a message could not be
delivered. Pronounced "demon." <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dagger"><b>dagger</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#character">character</a> in the shape of a vertical stroke crossed above its mid-point, used in <a href="#text">text</a> as a second-order <a href="#refmark">reference mark</a> following use of the <a href="#asterisk">asterisk</a>.  When it appears before a <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> in the English <a href="#language">language</a>, the dagger indicates that the individual is deceased.  Also called an <em>obelisk</em> or <em>long cross</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doubledagger">double dagger</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="daguerreotype"><b>daguerreotype</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#daguerrotype">daguerrotype</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="daguerrotype"><b>daguerrotype</b></a>
</dt><dd>Historically, the first <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic
process that actually worked, producing a positive image directly on a
highly polished, silvered copper plate sensitized with iodide vapor. By
exposing the plate to light in a <em>camera obscura</em>, an image was
captured in the photosensitive layer of silver iodide which could be
developed through the application of mercury vapor. Made public in
1839, the process was named after its French inventor, the painter of <a href="#diorama">diorama</a>s
Louis Jacques Mande Daguerre, who relied heavily on earlier experiments
by Joseph Nicephore Niepce. Easily scratched and tarnished,
daguerrotypes were normally protected by a metal mat and a sheet of
glass. Early examples are valued by collectors because each one is
unique, not having been made from a <a href="#negative">negative</a>.  Also spelled <em>daguerreotype</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#tintype">tintype</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dai1"><b><em>DAI</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#dai"><b>D</b>issertation <b>A</b>bstracts <b>I</b>nternational</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="daily"><b>daily</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d on a daily basis, with the possible exception of Sundays.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> issued daily, especially a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="damaged"><b>damaged</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#bibitem">item</a> returned to the <a href="#library">library</a> in such poor <a href="#condition">condition</a> that it cannot be placed back on the shelf for <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>, for example, a water-soaked or pet-chewed <a href="#book">book</a>.  The <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> is normally charged the cost of <a href="#repairing">repair</a> or <a href="#replacement">replacement</a>.  New items received from the <a href="#shipping">shipper</a> in damaged condition are returned by the library to the seller for <a href="#credit">credit</a> or replacement.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dana"><b>Dana, John Cotton, 1856-1929</b></a>
</dt><dd>A public <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> for over forty years, John Cotton Dana began his career in 1889 as head of the Denver <a href="#publiclibrary">Public Library</a>,
moved to the City Library of Springfield in 1898, and ended his career
at the Free Public Library in Newark, New Jersey. A leader in the <a href="#library">library</a> profession, he served as president of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> from 1895-96, as a member of its council from 1896-1902, and as president of the <a href="#sla">Special Libraries Association</a> from 1909-10, an organization he helped establish.  His philosophical approach to <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a> is best expressed in his <a href="#book">book</a> <em>Suggestions</em>, <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1921 by F. W. Faxon.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dandyroll"><b>dandy roll</b></a>
</dt><dd>The cylinder that exerts pressure in mechanized <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, smoothing the surface and creating designs such as the <a href="#watermark">watermark</a>, <a href="#countermark">countermark</a>, and the lines characteristic of <a href="#laidpaper">laid</a> and <a href="#wovepaper">wove paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dartmouthmedal"><b>Dartmouth Medal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a> presented <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly since 1974 by the <a href="#rusa">Reference and User Services Association</a> (RUSA), a division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, to the most outstanding <a href="#refbook">reference work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> during the preceding <a href="#calendaryear">calender year</a>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/rusa/awards/awd_dartmouth.html">Click here</a> to see a list of Dartmouth Medal recipients.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dash"><b>dash</b></a>
</dt><dd>A short length of horizontal <a href="#rule">rule</a> used for <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a>, to separate <a href="#text">text</a>, and for decorative effect.  In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, dashes vary in length from the two-em (longest) to the <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a> (shortest).  In typing, a dash is made by striking the hyphen key twice in succession (--).  In <a href="#descripcatalog">descriptive cataloging</a>, the dash is given a <a href="#spacing">space</a> on either side, but when used in <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s to indicate <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a>, no spaces are included.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="data"><b>data</b></a>
</dt><dd>The plural of the Latin word <em>datum</em> meaning "what is
given," often used as a singular collective noun. Facts, figures, or
instructions presented in a form that can be comprehended, interpreted,
and communicated by a human being, or <a href="#dataprocessing">processed</a> by a computer.  Compare with <a href="#information">information</a> and <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#metadata">metadata</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="databank"><b>data bank</b></a>
</dt><dd>Sometimes used <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>ously with <a href="#database">database</a>, the <a href="#term">term</a> applies more specifically to a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of nonbibliographic <a href="#data">data</a>, usually numeric (<em>example</em>:  the <em><a href="http://climate.envsci.rutgers.edu/soil_moisture/">Global Soil Moisture Data Bank</a></em> available <a href="#online">online</a> from the Department of Environmental Studies at Rutgers University).  Large data banks containing <a href="#information">information</a> about individuals (social security numbers, credit history, health records, etc.) have become the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of controversy as the rapid development of high-speed <a href="#infotech">information technology</a> poses new threats to personal <a href="#privacy">privacy</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="database"><b>database</b></a>  
</dt><dd>A large, regularly <a href="#update">update</a>d <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#digitization">digitized</a> <a href="#information">information</a> (bibliographic references, <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>s, <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s, <a href="#directory">directory</a> <a href="#entry">entries</a>, images, statistics, etc.) related to a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#field">field</a>, consisting of <a href="#record">record</a>s of uniform <a href="#format">format</a> organized for ease and speed of <a href="#search">search</a> and <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a>, and managed with the aid of <a href="#dbmanagement">database management system</a> (DBMS) <a href="#software">software</a>.  <a href="#content">Content</a> is created by the database producer (<em>example</em>:  American Psychological Association) which usually <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> a <a href="#print">print</a> version (<em>Psychological Abstracts</em>) and leases the content to a database <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#ebsco">EBSCO</a> or <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a>) that provides electronic <a href="#access">access</a> to the <a href="#data">data</a> after it has been <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> form (<em>PsycINFO</em>), usually on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> or <a href="#online">online</a> via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> using <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a>.  
<p>
Most databases used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> are <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es, <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s, and <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#refbook">reference</a> resources leased <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly under <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a>s that limit access to registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s and <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>db</em>.  Compare with <a href="#databank">data bank</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> and <a href="#metadatabase">metadatabase</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dbmanagement"><b>database management system (DBMS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#application">application</a> designed to control the <a href="#storage">storage</a>, <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a>, <a href="#security">security</a>, integrity, and reporting of <a href="#data">data</a> in the form of uniform <a href="#record">record</a>s organized in a large <a href="#searchable">searchable</a> <a href="#file">file</a> called a <a href="#database">database</a>.  The range of available <b>DBMS</b> <a href="#software">software</a> extends from simple systems intended for <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a>s to highly complex systems designed to run on <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a>s.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="datacompression"><b>data compression</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of reducing the amount of <a href="#memory">memory</a> required to <a href="#storage">store</a> <a href="#data">data</a> on a computer by <a href="#encoding">encoding</a> it and minimizing <a href="#redundancy">redundancy</a>.
Compressed data requires less transmission time, but more computation
time to restore it to its original form for processing. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#jpeg">JPEG</a> and <a href="#zip">zip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dataconversion"><b>data conversion</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of translating <a href="#data">data</a> from one form to another, usually from human-readable to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a> or vice versa, from one <a href="#filetype">file type</a> to another, or from one recording <a href="#medium">medium</a> to another (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#film">film</a> to <a href="#videotape">videotape</a> or <a href="#videodisc">videodisc</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dataprocessing"><b>data processing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The systematic performance of a single operation or sequence of operations by one or more <a href="#centralproc">central processing unit</a>s on <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, to achieve the result for which the <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a> that controls the processing was written, for example, the compilation of <a href="#circstats">circulation statistics</a> from records of <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> transactions occurring in a <a href="#library">library</a> over a given period of time.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="datedueslip"><b>date due slip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A card or slip of <a href="#paper">paper</a> inserted in an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> <a href="#charge">charge</a>d from a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, or a small <a href="#printing">printed</a> form attached to the inside of the front or back <a href="#cover">cover</a> (or to one of the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s), on which is <a href="#rubberstamp">stamp</a>ed the date the item is <a href="#duedate">due</a> back in the <a href="#library">library</a>.  Date due slips are sometimes removed by <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s in an attempt to avoid <a href="#overdue">overdue</a> <a href="#fines">fines</a>, but automated <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s have put an end to this strategy.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dateline"><b>date line</b></a>
</dt><dd>The line <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the beginning of a story in a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> or <a href="#article">article</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, indicating the date and place of origin of news that is not local.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#byline">byline</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="daterange"><b>date range</b></a>
</dt><dd>An interval of time marked by a beginning and ending date.  Some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s allow the user to <a href="#limiting">limit</a> a <a href="#search">search</a> to a specific range of <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>s.  A year followed by a <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a> (1946- ) limits <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a> to <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the year specified or any succeeding year, a year preceded by a hyphen ( -1945) limits retrieval to <a href="#source">source</a>s
published up to and including the year specified, and a year followed
by a hyphen and a subsequent year (1939-1945) limits retrieval to
sources published in those or any intervening years.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dbms"><b>DBMS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dbmanagement"><b>d</b>ata<b>b</b>ase <b>m</b>anagement <b>s</b>ystem</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dbv1"><b>DBV</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dbv">German Library Association (<b>D</b>eutscher <b>B</b>ibliotheksverband e. <b>V</b>.)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dcmi"><b>DCMI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dublincore">Dublin Core (DC)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ddc"><b>DDC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dewey"><b>D</b>ewey <b>D</b>ecimal <b>C</b>lassification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dds"><b>DDS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#docdeliv"><b>d</b>ocument <b>d</b>elivery <b>s</b>ervice</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deaccession"><b>deaccession</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of deleting from an <a href="#accessionrecord">accession record</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> which are to be removed from a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>.  Also refers to any <a href="#bibitem">item</a> so removed.  The opposite of <a href="#accession">accession</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the process of removing <a href="#records">records</a> or documents from official <a href="#custody">custody</a>, undertaken after careful consideration, usually as the result of a decision to <a href="#transfer">transfer</a> the material to another <a href="#custodian">custodian</a>, or because the legal owner desires its return or the material is found upon re<a href="#appraisal">appraisal</a> to be of doubtful <a href="#authenticity">authenticity</a> or to be inappropriate for the <a href="#collection">collection</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deacidification"><b>deacidification</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general <a href="#term">term</a> for a variety of costly <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> processes that chemically reduce the <a href="#acidpaper">acid</a> content of <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s to a <a href="#ph">pH</a> of 7.0 (neutral) or higher, usually undertaken at a professional <a href="#conservationcenter">conservation center</a> to prevent further <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a>.  An <a href="#alkaline">alkaline</a> <a href="#buffer">buffer</a> may be deposited in deacidification to neutralize any acids that develop in the future.  <a href="#brittle">Brittle</a>ness is not reversed by deacidification.  <em>Mass deacidification</em> is the shipment of a quantity of <a href="#document">document</a>s to a center for processing in small batches, rather than individually.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dealer"><b>dealer</b></a>
</dt><dd>An individual or commercial company in the business of buying and selling <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s, <a href="#usedbook">used book</a>s, and/or <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s for resale to <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#bookcollecting">collector</a>s, and other <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#antiquarian">antiquarian bookseller</a> and <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#priceguide">price guide</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="decennial"><b>decennial</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d every ten years (<em>example</em>:  U.S. Census).  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> issued every ten years.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#annual">annual</a>, <a href="#biennial">biennial</a>, <a href="#triennial">triennial</a>, <a href="#quadrennial">quadrennial</a>, <a href="#quinquennial">quinquennial</a>, <a href="#sexennial">sexennial</a>, and <a href="#septennial">septennial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="decimalpoint"><b>decimal point</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#period">period</a> used in the numeric portion of <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a> <a href="#notation">notation</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>DK 265.9</b>) and following the third <a href="#numeral">numeral</a> of a <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> (<b>947.084</b>) to indicate that succeeding numerals are to be treated as a decimal fraction.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deckle"><b>deckle edge</b></a>
</dt><dd>The uneven or feathered edge of a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of handmade <a href="#paper">paper</a>,
created by the flow of liquified fibrous stock between the frame
(deckle) and sieve of the mould used in manufacture. The same effect is
achieved in machine-made paper by exposing the edge to a jet of air or
water. In quality <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, deckle edges are considered tasteful, but since <a href="#book">book</a>s tend to collect dust when stored on an open shelf, and rough edges are difficult to clean, this feature is not practical.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="declassified"><b>declassified</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#document">document</a> no longer protected against unauthorized disclosure because the <a href="#security">security</a> classification assigned to maintain <a href="#confidentiality">confidentiality</a> has been officially changed or canceled.  The opposite of <a href="#classified">classified</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dedicated"><b>dedicated</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing and <a href="#communications">communications</a>, a <a href="#device">device</a> or channel reserved for a specific use.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, dedicated <a href="#server">server</a>s are used to run the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> and provide <a href="#access">access</a> to the library's <a href="#website">Web site</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dedicatedline">dedicated line</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dedicatedline"><b>dedicated line</b></a>
</dt><dd>A direct pathway to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> or some other computer <a href="#network">network</a> via a separate <a href="#telecommunications">telecommunications</a> channel not shared with multiple users as in <a href="#dialaccess">dial-up access</a>, but available around the clock to a specific user or group of users, for a designated purpose.  When <a href="#access">access</a>ed through a <a href="#commoncarrier">common carrier</a>, the channel is called a <em>leased line</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dedication"><b>dedication</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief note in which the creator of a <a href="#work">work</a> addresses it to one or more persons, usually a colleague, <a href="#mentor">mentor</a>, or family member, as a sign of honor, appreciation, or affection.  In <a href="#book">book</a>s, the <a href="#author">author</a>'s dedication appears in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#recto">recto</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> following the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  Compare with <a href="#acknowledgments">acknowledgments</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dedicationcopy"><b>dedication copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#work">work</a> inscribed by the <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#editor">editor</a>, or <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a> to the person or persons to whom the <a href="#work">work</a> is <a href="#dedication">dedicated</a>.  In the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, a dedication copy may be of considerably greater value than a copy with no <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deduping"><b>deduping</b></a>
</dt><dd>Removal of all but one occurrence of a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> from a <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> records, one of the initial steps in processing a <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>.  Deduping is a <a href="#batchprocessing">batch process</a> that prevents confusion in the minds of users, conserves computer <a href="#storage">storage</a>, and allows reliable <a href="#usage">usage</a> statistics to be collected.  <a href="#duplicaterecord">Duplicate record</a>s are not uncommon because the "cancel holdings" command in <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <a href="#software">software</a> does not delete a record from the <a href="#library">library</a>'s OCLC tapes.
