Synonymous with <em>duplicate removal</em> and <em>duplicate resolution</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deedofgift"><b>deed of gift</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#signature">signed</a> <a href="#document">document</a> stating the terms of agreement under which legal title to real or personal property, such as a <a href="#gift">gift</a> to a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#archives">archives</a>,
is transferred, voluntarily and without recompense, by the donor to the
recipient institution, with or without conditions specifying <a href="#access">access</a>, use, <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="default"><b>default</b></a>
</dt><dd>A value, <a href="#option">option</a>, or setting automatically selected in a <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> or <a href="#software">software</a> system in the absence of specific instructions from the user.  The default setting may be displayed on the <a href="#data">data</a> entry screen to allow the user to see what action will be taken if no <a href="#input">input</a> is provided. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="definition"><b>definition</b></a>
</dt><dd>One meaning of a word, expressed clearly and concisely.
Because some words have more than one meaning, a word may have more
than one definition. In <a href="#lexicography">lexicography</a>, a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> is defined by first specifying the <a href="#class">class</a> (genus) to which its referent belongs, then indicating the <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>s that distinguish the referent from others of the same class.  Definitions are listed in <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a> and <a href="#glossary">glossaries</a>, and are also provided in some <a href="#concordance">concordance</a>s and <a href="#thesaurus">thesauri</a>.
In most dictionaries, the modern definition of a word is given first
and the oldest last, but there are notable exceptions to this rule. <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>def</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#headword">headword</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the distinctness of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> or <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic image.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="definitive"><b>definitive edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the complete <a href="#text">text</a> of an <a href="#author">author</a>'s <a href="#work">work</a> or works, usually <a href="#editing">edit</a>ed and <a href="#publishing">published</a> after the person's death in a form considered final and <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a>.  Also refers to the text of an <a href="#anonymous">anonymous</a> work considered by scholars or other experts to be closest to the <a href="#original">original</a> version.  Compare with <a href="#authorizededition">authorized edition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#criticaledition">critical edition</a> and <a href="#variantedition">variant edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dehumidify"><b>dehumidify</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#humidity">humidity</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="delete"><b>delete</b></a>
</dt><dd>To remove, erase, or omit a <a href="#character">character</a>, word, or passage from a <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#document">document</a>.  In computing, to erase a character, word, passage, or entire <a href="#file">file</a> from <a href="#memory">memory</a>, usually by pressing the "Backspace" key on a <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>, or by <a href="#highlight">highlight</a>ing text and pressing the "Delete" key or selecting the "Delete" <a href="#option">option</a> from a <a href="#menu">menu</a> or <a href="#toolbar">toolbar</a>.  Some <a href="#software">software</a> systems allow the user to "Undo" a deletion while the <a href="#application">application</a> remains open.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="delimiter"><b>delimiter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A symbol used in a <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> as the first <a href="#character">character</a> of a two-character <a href="#subfieldcode">subfield code</a> to indicate the beginning of a <a href="#subfield">subfield</a>, separating one <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a> from another within a <a href="#field">field</a>.  <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> uses the <a href="#doubledagger">double dagger</a> as a delimiter; the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> uses the <b>$</b> (dollar) sign.  In a more general sense, any character or sequence of characters used in an electronic <a href="#database">database</a> to separate discrete elements of data within a field (or fields) contained in a <a href="#record">record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deluxeedit"><b>deluxe edition</b></a> 
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on better quality <a href="#paper">paper</a> than the standard <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>, sometimes from specially cast <a href="#type">type</a>, usually <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#leather">leather</a> or some other material of fine quality.  Deluxe editions may also be larger in <a href="#booksize">size</a>, more lavishly <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a>, and <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#limitededition">limited edition</a>.  Also spelled <em>de luxe edition</em>.  Synonymous with <em>fine edition</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#giltedges">gilt edges</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="demand"><b>demand</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#number">number</a> of people who need or request a product or service.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <em>high-demand</em> <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s may be ordered in multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a> or placed on <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> to ensure <a href="#access">access</a>.  In <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, low-demand items in the <a href="#circulating">circulating collection</a> may be candidates for <a href="#weeding">weeding</a>.  Demand for library services usually peaks at different times during the day, week, month, and year.  <a href="#transactionlog">Transaction log</a>s can be helpful in tracking and anticipating patterns of <a href="#usage">usage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="demandpublishing"><b>demand publishing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial service that supplies single <a href="#copy">copies</a> of <a href="#rarebook">rare</a> or <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s in response to individual demand, usually by <a href="#photocopier">photocopying</a> prints made from a <a href="#microform">microform</a> <a href="#master">master</a>, for example, <em>Dissertation Express</em> from Bell &amp; Howell.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="demco"><b>DEMCO</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial company that provides furniture, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, and <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a> for the <a href="#library">library</a>, school, office, and home.  <b>DEMCO</b> also provides <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscripagency">subscription services</a>.  <a href="http://www.demco.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>DEMCO</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#brodart">Brodart</a> and <a href="#highsmith">Highsmith</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="departmentallib"><b>departmental library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a> that serves the <a href="#information">information</a> and <a href="#research">research</a>
needs of the faculty members of a department within an institution of
higher learning, usually a large university. Departmental <a href="#library">libraries</a> are also used by students enrolled in courses in the <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>(s) taught by the department, especially graduate students.  If <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> are funded through the department, <a href="#selection">selection</a> is usually the responsibility of the teaching faculty in collaboration with the departmental <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dependentwork"><b>dependent work</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a <a href="#work">work</a> that is contingent in some way on a previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> work by another <a href="#author">author</a>.  Included in this category are:  <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>s, <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a>s, <a href="#commentary">commentaries</a>, <a href="#continuation">continuation</a>s, <a href="#dramatization">dramatization</a>s, <a href="#sequel">sequel</a>s, <a href="#revisededition">revised edition</a>s, and <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>related work</em>.  Compare with <a href="#derivativework">derivative work</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deposit"><b>deposit</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any addition to <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#holdings">holdings</a>, usually a <a href="#transfer">transfer</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> from some other location or <a href="#agency">agency</a>, but the term also applies to materials on loan for a period of fixed or indefinite duration.  The <em>depositor</em> usually retains legal ownership and responsibility, except in the case of <a href="#gift">gift</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#depositcopy">deposit copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="depositcopy"><b>deposit copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A  <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a new <a href="#publication">publication</a> sent without charge to a <a href="#copyrightdepository">copyright depository</a> or other designated <a href="#library">library</a> by the <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> in <a href="#copyrightcompliance">compliance</a> with national <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law.  In the United States, the deposit copy is sent with the completed copyright application form and <a href="#copyrightfee">copyright fee</a> to the <a href="http://www.loc.gov/copyright/">U.S. Copyright Office</a> of the <a href="http://www.loc.gov/">Library of Congress</a> in Washington, D.C.  Synonymous with <em>statutory copy</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="depository"><b>depository library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> legally designated to receive without charge all or a portion of the <a href="#govdocs">government document</a>s provided by the U.S. Government Printing Office (<a href="#gpo">GPO</a>) and other federal agencies to the Superintendent of Documents for distribution under the <a href="#fdlp">Federal Depository Library Program</a> (FDLP).  Some federal depositories also collect <a href="#publication">publication</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by state <a href="#govtagency">government agencies</a>.  Federal <a href="#document">document</a>s are usually classified and shelved by <a href="#sudocs">SuDocs number</a>.  Compare with <a href="#repository">repository</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="depth"><b>depth</b></a>
</dt><dd>The thickness of a <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a> at its thickest point included (usually at the <a href="#spine">spine</a>) with the <a href="#cover">cover</a>s included.  Average depth determines how many <a href="#volume">volume</a>s will fit on a shelf of given length.  Also refers to the <a href="#width">width</a> of a book shelf from front to back.  Most <a href="#library">library</a> shelving is 10 or 12 inches deep.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#height">height</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="depthindexing"><b>depth indexing</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> system that attempts to extract <em>all</em> the concepts covered in a <a href="#work">work</a>, including any subtopics, as opposed to <em>summarization</em>, in which a work is <a href="#index">index</a>ed only under its dominant <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  <a href="#library">Library</a> <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s have traditionally looked for the single concept that best describes the entire <a href="#content">content</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, leaving depth indexing to commercial services that index parts of items (<a href="#article">article</a>s in <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>s, <a href="#essay">essay</a>s in <a href="#collection">collection</a>s, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="derivativeindexing"><b>derivative indexing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> in which a human indexer or computer extracts from the <a href="#title">title</a> and/or <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a> one or more words or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s to represent <a href="#subject">subject</a>(s) of the <a href="#work">work</a>, for use as <a href="#heading">heading</a>s under which <a href="#entry">entries</a> are made.  Synonymous with <em>derived indexing</em> and <em>extractive indexing</em>.  Compare with <a href="#assignmentindexing">assignment indexing</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#automaticindexing">automatic indexing</a> and <a href="#machineaided">machine-aided indexing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="derivativework"><b>derivative work</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> based on another work, which transforms the <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#original">original</a> in a significant way (<a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>, <a href="#adaptation">adaptation</a>, <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a>, <a href="#revisededition">revision</a>, <a href="#translation">translation</a>, etc.).  Under U.S. <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law, the <a href="#rights">rights</a> to produce derivative works are retained by the copyright holder.  Compare with <a href="#dependentwork">dependent work</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="derivedcataloging"><b>derived cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#copycataloging">copy cataloging</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="derivedindexing"><b>derived indexing</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#derivativeindexing">derivative indexing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="descender"><b>descender</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typography">typography</a> and <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, the stroke of a <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> letter that extends below the lowest point of an <a href="#xheight">x-height</a> letter (<b>a</b>, <b>c</b>, <b>e</b>, <b>m</b>, etc.).  The letters of the roman <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> which have descenders are:  <b>g</b>, <b>j</b>, <b>p</b>, <b>q</b>, and <b>y</b>.  The <em>descender line</em> is an imaginary horizontal line connecting the bottoms of descender letters, not to be confused with the <a href="#baseline">baseline</a>.  Compare with <a href="#ascender">ascender</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#primaryletter">primary letter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="descriptivebib"><b>descriptive bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>The close study and description of the physical and bibliographic characteristics of <a href="#book">book</a>s and other materials, including detailed <a href="#information">information</a> about <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#publicationdate">date</a> and <a href="#placeofpublication">place of publication</a>, <a href="#format">format</a>, <a href="#pagination">pagination</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#binding">binding</a>, etc., as opposed to an examination of their <a href="#content">content</a>.  Also, a <a href="#work">work</a> that is the result of such study. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="descripcatalog"><b>descriptive cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd>The part of the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> process concerned with identifying and describing the physical and bibliographic characteristics of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, and with determining the name(s) and <a href="#title">title</a>(s) to be used as <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s in the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, but not with the assignment of <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a> and <a href="#formheading">form heading</a>s.  In the United States, Great Britain, and Canada, descriptive cataloging is governed by <em><a href="#anglo">Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</a></em> (<b><em>AACR2</em></b>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a> and <a href="#subjectanalysis">subject analysis</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="descriptor"><b>descriptor</b></a>     
</dt><dd>In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, a <a href="#preferredterm">preferred term</a>, <a href="#notation">notation</a>, or sequence of <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s assigned as an <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a> in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing a <a href="#document">document</a>, to indicate one of the <a href="#subject">subject</a>s of its <a href="#text">text</a> (<a href="#synonym">synonym</a>ous in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> with the <a href="#term">term</a> <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>).  In <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, descriptors appear in the DE or SUBJECT <a href="#field">field</a> of the record.  <a href="#major">Major</a> descriptors are distinguished from <a href="#minor">minor</a> descriptors by a special <a href="#character">character</a>, usually the <a href="#asterisk">asterisk</a>.  Some indexing and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s, such as <em><a href="#eric">ERIC</a></em> and <em>Psychological Abstracts</em>, provide a list of authorized indexing terms in the form of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> or <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a>.  Compare with <a href="#identifier">identifier</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#aboutness">aboutness</a> and <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deselection"><b>deselection</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#serial">serial</a>s, the process of identifying <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s for <a href="#canceled">cancellation</a>, usually in response to <a href="#subscripprice">subscription price</a> increases and <a href="#budget">budget</a>ary constraints.  In <a href="#book">book</a> and <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, the process of identifying <a href="#title">title</a>s for <a href="#weeding">weeding</a>, usually on the basis of <a href="#currency">currency</a>, <a href="#usage">usage</a>, and <a href="#condition">condition</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#selection">selection</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="desensitization"><b>desensitization</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of deactivating the <a href="#magneticstrip">magnetic strip</a> affixed to a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> to prevent the <a href="#securitysystem">security alarm</a> from sounding when the <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> exits the <a href="#library">library</a>, a step performed by <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> when the item is <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>, using a <a href="#device">device</a> called a <em>desensitizer</em>.  A different machine is required to desensitize magnetic <a href="#media">media</a> (<a href="#audiocassette">audiocassette</a>s, <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>s, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="desiccant"><b>desiccant</b></a>
</dt><dd>A drying agent such as silica gel used in museums and <a href="#library">libraries</a> to remove water vapor from an enclosed space when control of relative <a href="#humidity">humidity</a> is an important factor in the <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> of <a href="#specimen">specimen</a>s, <a href="#document">document</a>s, and other materials in storage or on <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>.  Because desiccants release moisture when heated, they can usually be reused.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="desiderata"><b>desiderata</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> needed and wanted by a <a href="#library">library</a>, to be purchased when <a href="#budget">budget</a> permits or a cash donation is received.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>waiting list</em> and <em>want list</em>.  Also refers to a list of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s or <a href="#topic">topic</a>s on which a writer or <a href="#researcher">researcher</a> requires <a href="#information">information</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deskcopy"><b>desk copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> or recently <a href="#revisededition">revised edition</a>, provided  without charge by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>
as an instructor's copy when additional copies are ordered by a college
or university bookstore for students enrolled in a course of study. A <a href="#complimentary">complimentary copy</a> may become a desk copy once an instructor decides to assign the <a href="#work">work</a> as required reading.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deskdictionary"><b>desk dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> of approximately 150,000 words, intended for use by an individual sitting at a desk or in a workspace  (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Webster's New World Dictionary of the American Language</em></b>).  <a href="#entry">Entries</a> usually indicate <a href="#orthography">orthography</a>, <a href="#syllabication">syllabication</a>, pronunciation, <a href="#etymology">etymology</a>, and <a href="#definition">definition</a>.  <a href="#synonym">Synonym</a>s, <a href="#antonym">antonym</a>s, and brief <a href="#biography">biographical</a> and <a href="#gazetteer">gazetteer</a> <a href="#information">information</a> are included in some <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>college dictionary</em>.  <a href="http://www.m-w.com/dictionary.htm">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> version of <b><em>Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary and Thesaurus</em></b>.  Compare with <a href="#pocketdictionary">pocket dictionary</a> and <a href="#unabridgeddict">unabridged dictionary</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deskschedule"><b>desk schedule</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the hours during which <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and other <a href="#publicservices">public services</a> <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> are regularly assigned to assist users at the <a href="#circulation">circulation desk</a>, <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>, <a href="#informationdesk">information desk</a>, or other public <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a>, usually prepared by the staff member responsible for supervising the operations performed at the location.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#rotation">rotation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="desktopcomputer"><b>desktop computer</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="desktop"><b>desktop publishing (DTP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The use of <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> and <a href="#software">software</a> for <a href="#page">page</a> <a href="#layout">layout</a>, <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> design, and <a href="#printing">printing</a> to produce professional quality <a href="#cameraready">camera-ready copy</a> for commercial <a href="#printing">printing</a> at a fraction of the cost of using the services of a commercial <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  Used extensively to produce in-house <a href="#brochure">brochure</a>s, <a href="#flier">flier</a>s, <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a>s, <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, etc., <b>DTP</b> requires desktop publishing <a href="#software">software</a> and a high-speed <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a> equipped with a large <a href="#monitor">monitor</a> and high-resolution <a href="#laserprinter">laser printer</a> to produce <a href="#text">text</a> and graphics in <a href="#wysiwyg">WYSIWYG</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#selfpublishing">self-publishing</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="destruction"><b>destruction</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the process of physically doing away with <a href="#records">records</a> that are no longer of <a href="#archivalvalue">value</a>, but remain too sensitive to be simply discarded as trash.  For <a href="#paper">paper</a> records, the most common methods are shredding and <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>ing.  Incineration is used for records in all other <a href="#format">format</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="detective"><b>detective fiction</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#novel">novel</a> or <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>
in which the details of a crime (or suspected crime) are uncovered by
an amateur or professional sleuth who looks for clues and interprets
them, sometimes using ingenious methods, to solve the mystery of <em>who-done-it</em>.  The modern detective story began with Edgar Allan Poe's <b><em>Murders in the Rue Morgue</em></b> and has since become a popular <a href="#subgenre">subgenre</a> of <a href="#mystery">mystery</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>.  Some detective stories qualify as <a href="#historicalfiction">historical fiction</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#chronicle">chronicle</a>s of Brother Cadfael by Ellis Peters).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#suspense">suspense</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deterioration"><b>deterioration</b></a>
</dt><dd>Damage that occurs to an item by physical, chemical, or
biological means after it has been produced, usually over a period of
time. Examples include <a href="#binding">binding</a>s weakened by <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a>s that dry out and crack, <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a>s em<a href="#brittle">brittle</a>d by <a href="#acidpaper">acid</a>, and paper <a href="#document">document</a>s discolored by the growth of <a href="#mildew">mildew</a> under damp conditions.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#inherentvice">inherent vice</a> and <a href="#stabilization">stabilization</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deutscherbib"><b>Deutscher Bibliogtheksverband e. V.</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dbv">German Library Association (DBV)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="device"><b>device</b></a>
</dt><dd>An ornament or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> used in <a href="#printing">printing</a>, such as the <a href="#northpointer">north pointer</a> used on <a href="#map">map</a>s to indicate compass orientation.  Also refers to an insignia used as a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s identifying mark, for example, the small design of a house stamped on the <a href="#spine">spine</a> and printed on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of <a href="#book">book</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> by Random House.  Synonymous in this sense with <a href="#colophon">colophon</a>.
<p>
Also refers to any electronic or electromagnetic machine or <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> component.  Computer <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a>s (<a href="#printer">printer</a>, <a href="#scanner">scanner</a>, <a href="#diskdrive">disk drive</a>s, etc.) require a <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> <a href="#routine">routine</a> called a <em>device <a href="#driver">driver</a></em> to connect to the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dewey"><b>Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> system for <a href="#classification">classifying</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> by <a href="#subject">subject</a>, first <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1876 by the <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> and educator <a href="#deweymelvil">Melvil Dewey</a> who divided human <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> into ten <a href="#mainclass">main class</a>es, each of which is divided into ten <a href="#division">division</a>s, and so on.  In Dewey Decimal <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>s, <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s and <a href="#decimalpoint">decimal</a> fractions are used in the class <a href="#notation">notation</a> (<em>example:</em> <b>996.9</b>).  An <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a> <a href="#booknumber">book number</a> is added to subarrange <a href="#work">work</a>s of the same classification by <a href="#author">author</a>, and by <a href="#title">title</a> and <a href="#edition">edition</a> (<b>996.9 B3262h</b>).
<p>
Developed and <a href="#updated">updated</a> continuously for the past 125 years, most recently by a 10-member international Editorial Policy Committee (EPC), <b>DDC</b> is the most widely used <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> in the world.  According to <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a>, it has been <a href="#translation">translated</a> into 30 <a href="#language">language</a>s and is used by 200,000 <a href="#library">libraries</a> in 135 countries.  The <a href="#nationalbib">national bibliographies</a> of 60 countries are organized according to <b>DDC</b>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dd>In the United States, <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#schoollibrary">school libraries</a> use <b>DDC</b>, but most <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> use <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a> because it is more <a href="#hospitality">hospitable</a>.  <a href="#adc">Abridged Decimal Classification</a> is available for use in small libraries, and OCLC has developed <em><a href="#webdewey">WebDewey</a></em> for classifying <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s and other electronic resources.  <a href="http://www.oclc.org/dewey/index.htm">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>DDC</b> <a href="#website">Web site</a> maintained by OCLC.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#universaldecimal">Universal Decimal Classification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="deweymelvil"><b>Dewey, Melvil, 1851-1931</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of the founders of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, Melvil Dewey served as <a href="#editor">editor</a> of <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em> from 1876 to 1881, <a href="#publishing">published</a> the <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> system in 1876, and served as <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> at Columbia University from 1883 to 1888 where he founded the first professional <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> in 1887.  He became the <a href="#librarydirector">director</a> of the New York <a href="#statelibrary">State Library</a> in Albany in 1888, taking the library school with him.  Dewey was also a spokesman for <a href="#professionalism">professionalism</a> in <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>, for <a href="#libraryeducation">library education</a>, and for equality of opportunity for women in the profession.  A dynamic man, he also advocated <a href="#standardization">standardization</a> of library education, methods, tools, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, and <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="diacriticalmark"><b>diacritical mark</b></a>
</dt><dd>A mark written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> above or below an <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>ic <a href="#character">character</a>, to indicate a change in its pronunciation, for example, the <em>cedilla</em> used in French under the letter <em>c</em> when it is pronounced like <em>ts</em> or <em>s</em>, instead of <em>k</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="diagnostics"><b>diagnostics</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#software">Software</a> designed to automatically test <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> components (<a href="#disk">disk</a>s, <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>, <a href="#memory">memory</a>,
etc.) whenever a computer session begins, to determine if they are
functioning properly. If a component fails on startup, a warning
message appears on the screen.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="diagram"><b>diagram</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#figure">figure</a>, <a href="#chart">chart</a>, or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> design intended to explain or <a href="#illustration">illustrate</a> a principle, concept, or set of statistical <a href="#data">data</a>.  Also, a drawing, <a href="#sketch">sketch</a>, or <a href="#plan">plan</a>
that shows the steps in a process, or the relationship of the parts of
an object or structure to the whole, usually simplified for the sake of
clarity. A diagram is usually accompanied by a line or two of
explanation, or by explanatory <a href="#text">text</a> in the <a href="#document">document</a> in which it appears.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dialog"><b>DIALOG</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> that provides <a href="#persearch">per-search</a> <a href="#access">access</a> to a wide selection of <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#database">database</a>s via a <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> <a href="#interface">interface</a>.  Established in 1972, <b>DIALOG</b> led the market for many years in online <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, and remains strong in business, science, and technology.  The company also provides technical support for <a href="#internet">Internet</a> users and e-commerce.  In most <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <b>DIALOG</b> <a href="#search">search</a>es are <a href="#mediated">mediated</a> by a specially trained <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> to keep costs down.  <a href="http://www.dialog.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>DIALOG</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dialogbox"><b>dialog box</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small square or rectangular area that opens in a <a href="#gui">graphical user interface</a> in response to a selection made by the user, usually providing additional <a href="#information">information</a> or listing other <a href="#option">option</a>s and/or settings available at that point in the <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>.  A dialog box differs from a <a href="#window">window</a> in being neither movable nor <a href="#resized">resizable</a>.  Some <a href="#application">application</a>s
are designed to open a dialog box automatically when certain operations
are selected, but this feature can usually be set "off" when not
desired.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dialogue"><b>dialogue</b></a>
</dt><dd>Conversation, real or imagined, between two or more persons,
especially the exchange of ideas and opinions between individuals who
do not share the same point of view. Also refers to a written <a href="#work">work</a> in the form of a conversation between two or more people, or to the portions of a work of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> (<a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>, etc.) consisting of words spoken by the <a href="#character">character</a>s, as opposed to passages of <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> or description.  In the <a href="#text">text</a> of a narrative work, dialogue is set apart by the use of <a href="#quotation">quotation mark</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#monologue">monologue</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dialaccess"><b>dial-up access</b></a>
</dt><dd>Connection to a <a href="#network">network</a>, <a href="#online">online</a> service, or computer system from a <a href="#terminal">terminal</a> or <a href="#workstation">workstation</a> via a telephone line, usually in exchange for payment of a monthly <a href="#fee">fee</a> to a <a href="#internetservice">service provider</a>, as opposed to <a href="#access">access</a> via a <a href="#dedicatedline">dedicated line</a>.  Dial-up access requires a <a href="#modem">modem</a> to convert the <a href="#digital">digital</a> signals produced by a computer into the analog signals used in voice transmission, and vice versa.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="diary"><b>diary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A private written <a href="#record">record</a> of day-to-day thoughts, feelings, and experiences, kept by a person who does not expect them to be <a href="#publishing">published</a>.  Also refers to the <a href="#blankbook">blankbook</a> or <a href="#notebook">notebook</a> in which such experiences are recorded.  Diaries are sometimes <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#posthumous">posthumous</a>ly and some have become famous <a href="#literarywork">literary</a> and historical <a href="#work">work</a>s, for example, the <b><em>Diary of Samuel Pepys</em></b> and more recently that of Anne Frank.  Compare with <a href="#journal">journal</a> and <a href="#memoirs">memoirs</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a small <a href="#notebook">notebook</a> in which the consecutive dates of the year are listed, with <a href="#blank">blank</a> space for scheduling appointments, meetings, important deadlines, etc.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dictionary"><b>dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single-<a href="#volume">volume</a> or multi-volume <a href="#refbook">reference work</a> containing brief explanatory <a href="#entry">entries</a> for <a href="#term">term</a>s and <a href="#topic">topic</a>s related to a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#field">field</a> of inquiry, usually arranged  <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Dictionary of Neuropsychology</em></b>).  The entries in a dictionary are usually shorter than those contained in an <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a> on the same subject, but it is not uncommon for the word "dictionary" to be used in the <a href="#title">title</a> of works that should more appropriately be called encyclopedias (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Dictionary of the Middle Ages</em></b> in 13 <a href="#volume">volume</a>s).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#biogdictionary">biographical dictionary</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#work">work</a> listing the words of a <a href="#language">language</a> in alphabetical order, with <a href="#orthography">orthography</a>, <a href="#syllabication">syllabication</a>, pronunciation, <a href="#etymology">etymology</a>, and <a href="#definition">definition</a>(s).  Some dictionaries also include <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>s, <a href="#antonym">antonym</a>s, and brief <a href="#biography">biographical</a> and <a href="#gazetteer">gazetteer</a> <a href="#information">information</a>.  An <a href="#unabridgeddict">unabridged dictionary</a> is <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> in the number of words and definitions included (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Webster's Third New International Dictionary</em></b>).  An <a href="#abridgment">abridged</a> dictionary provides a more limited selection of terms and less information in each entry (<b><em>Webster's New College Dictionary</em></b>).  In a <a href="#visualdictionary">visual dictionary</a>, the terms are  <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#deskdictionary">desk dictionary</a> and <a href="#pocketdictionary">pocket dictionary</a>.  
</p><p>
Dictionaries are known to have developed from Latin <a href="#glossary">glossaries</a> as early as the 13th century.  Dictionaries of the English language, limited to difficult words, were first <a href="#compilation">compiled</a> in the 17th century.  The most famous is the <em><a href="#oed">Oxford English Dictionary</a></em> (1989), conceived in Britain in 1857 by the Philological Society.  Some English dictionaries are limited to a <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> vocabulary (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Dictionary of American Slang</em></b>).  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, at least one large <a href="#printing">printed</a> dictionary is usually displayed open on a <a href="#dictionarystand">dictionary stand</a>.  Smaller portable <a href="#edition">edition</a>s are shelved in the <a href="#refstacks">reference section</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>dict</em>.  Compare with <a href="#concordance">concordance</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#languagedictionary">language dictionary</a>, <a href="#polyglotdictionary">polyglot dictionary</a>, and <a href="#rhymingdictionary">rhyming dictionary</a>. 
</p><p>
This <a href="#website">Web site</a> is an example of an <em>electronic dictionary</em>.  <a href="http://www.m-w.com/dictionary.htm">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> version of <b><em>Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary and Thesaurus</em></b>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dictionarycatalog"><b>dictionary catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, widely used in the United States before the <a href="#retrocon">conversion</a> of the <a href="#cardcatalog">card catalog</a> to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> form, in which all the <a href="#entry">entries</a> (<a href="#mainentry">main</a>, <a href="#addedentry">added</a>, <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a>) and <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s are interfiled in a single <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetic</a> sequence, as opposed to one <a href="#dividedcatalog">divided</a> into separate sections by type of entry (<a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, subject).  Compare with <a href="#classifiedcatalog">classified catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dictionarystand"><b>dictionary stand</b></a>
</dt><dd>A free-standing piece of display furniture usually made of wood, at least waist-high with a sloping top and a <a href="#bookstop">book stop</a>, used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> to display an open <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> or other large <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>.  A dictionary stand is narrower than an <a href="#atlascase">atlas case</a> and may contain shelves for storing other <a href="#volume">volume</a>s.  Small revolving table-top models are also available from library <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="differential"><b>differential pricing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The controversial practice of charging <a href="#library">libraries</a> a substantially higher <a href="#subscripprice">price</a> for <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s than the amount an individual <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a> is required to pay, which some <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s claim is justified because a library <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> makes the <a href="#publication">publication</a> available to more <a href="#reader">reader</a>s, an effect known in the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> trade as <a href="#passalong">pass-along</a>.
Also refers to the practice in Europe of charging North American
subscribers a rate substantially higher than normal, presumably because
they can afford to pay more. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="diffuse"><b>diffuse authorship</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> created by four or more persons or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate bodies</a> in which no single individual or body can be identified as the primary <a href="#author">author</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, such works are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under the <a href="#title">title</a>, with an <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> for the first-named person or body.  Under <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, if three or fewer persons or bodies are primarily responsible for a work, the <a href="#mainheading">main entry</a> is under the <a href="#heading">heading</a> for first-named author, with added entries for the other principal authors.  Compare with <a href="#unknownauth">unknown authorship</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mixed">mixed responsibility</a> and <a href="#shared">shared responsibility</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digest"><b>digest</b></a>
</dt><dd>An orderly, <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a> or condensation of a written <a href="#work">work</a> (legal, scientific, historical, or <a href="#literarywork">literary</a>), broader in <a href="#scope">scope</a> than a <a href="#synopsis">synopsis</a>, usually prepared by a person other than the <a href="#author">author</a> of the <a href="#original">original</a>.  <a href="#heading">Heading</a>s and <a href="#subheading">subheading</a>s may be added to facilitate reference.  Also refers to a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> or <a href="#index">index</a> containing <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>s or condensations of works from various sources, usually arranged in some kind of order (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Book Review Digest</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digital"><b>digital</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#data">Data</a> recorded or transmitted as discrete, discontinuous voltage pulses represented by the <a href="#binary">binary</a> digits 0 and 1, called <a href="#bit">bit</a>s.  In <a href="#digitization">digitized</a> <a href="#text">text</a>, each <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a> <a href="#character">character</a> is represented by a specific eight-bit sequence called a <a href="#byte">byte</a>.  The computers used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> transmit data in digital <a href="#format">format</a>.  Compare with <a href="#analog">analog</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#borndigital">born digital</a>.
<p>
The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used in a general sense to refer to the wave of <a href="#infotech">information technology</a> generated by the invention of the <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> in the second half of the 20th century, as in the expression "<a href="#digitaldivide">digital divide</a>" and "<a href="#digitallibrary">digital library</a>."
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digitalarchives"><b>digital archives</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#archives">Archival</a> materials that have been <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, usually for the sake of <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> or to make them more <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> to users.  A prime example is <em><a href="http://memory.loc.gov/">American Memory</a></em>, a project undertaken by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> to make <a href="#digitalcollec">digital collection</a>s of <a href="#primarysource">primary source</a>s on the history and culture of the United States available over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digitalcollec"><b>digital collection</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a> for <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, or to provide <a href="#access">access</a> electronically (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://etext.virginia.edu/jefferson/">Thomas Jefferson Digital Archive</a></em>, a project of the Electronic Text Center, University of Virginia Library).  In the United States, the <a href="#dlf">Digital Library Federation</a> is developing <a href="#standards">standards</a> and <a href="#bestpractice">best practice</a>s for <a href="#digital">digital</a> collections and <a href="#network">network</a> access.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digitaldivide"><b>digital divide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> coined by former Assistant Secretary of Commerce for <a href="#telecommunication">Telecommunication</a> and Communication, Larry Irving, Jr., to focus public awareness on the gap in <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#information">information</a> resources and services between those with the means to purchase the computer <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> and <a href="#software">software</a> necessary to connect to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, and low-income families and communities that cannot afford <a href="#network">network</a> access.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> are helping to bridge the gap between information "haves" and "have-nots" with the assistance of substantial <a href="#grant">grant</a>s from industry leaders such as Microsoft's Bill Gates.  The <a href="#erate">E-rate</a> established by the <em>Telecommunications Act of 1996 (TCA)</em> has helped schools, <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, and rural health care institutions bridge the gap.  <em><a href="http://www.digitaldividenetwork.org/">Digital Divide Network</a></em> is a <a href="#website">Web site</a> devoted to the issue.  Synonymous with <em>information gap</em>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digitalimaging"><b>digital imaging</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#field">field</a> within computer science covering all aspects of the capture, <a href="#storage">storage</a>, manipulation, transmission, and display of images in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, including digital <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>y, <a href="#scanner">scanning</a>, and <a href="#bitmap">bitmap</a>ped <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, images of <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s are created for <a href="#elecreserves">electronic reserve</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s and <a href="#digitalarchives">digital archives</a>.  They are also available in <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s and reference resources.  <a href="http://images.library.uiuc.edu/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em>Digital Imaging &amp; Media Technology Initiative</em> at the University of Illinois Library.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dli"><b>Digitial Libraries Initiative (DLI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A multi-<a href="#govtagency">agency</a> <a href="#interdisciplinary">interdisciplinary</a> <a href="#research">research</a> program of the National Science Foundation (NSF), that provides <a href="#grant">grant</a>s to facilitate the creation of large <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> bases, develop the <a href="#infotech">information technology</a> to <a href="#access">access</a> them effectively, and improve their <a href="#usability">usability</a> in a wide range of contexts.  <a href="http://www.dli2.nsf.gov/projects.html">Click here</a> to see a list of <b>DLI</b>-funded projects.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digitallibrary"><b>digital library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> in which a significant proportion of the resources are available in <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, rather than in <a href="#printing">print</a> or on <a href="#microform">microform</a>.  In libraries, the process of <a href="#digitization">digitization</a> began with the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, moved to <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s, then to <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s and large <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s, and finally <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>d-lib</em>.  Compare with <a href="#virtuallibrary">virtual library</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dlf">Digital Library Federation</a> and <a href="http://www.dlib.org/">D-Lib Forum</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dlf"><b>Digital Library Federation (DLF)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#consortium">consortium</a> of major <a href="#library">libraries</a> and library-related <a href="#agency">agencies</a> dedicated to promoting the use of electronic technologies to extend <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s and services, <b>DLF</b> is committed to identifying <a href="#standards">standards</a> and <a href="#bestpractice">best practice</a>s for <a href="#digitalcollec">digital collection</a>s and <a href="#network">network</a> <a href="#access">access</a>, coordinating <a href="#research">research</a>-and-development in the use of <a href="#infotech">information technology</a>
by libraries, and assisting in the initiation of projects/services that
individual libraries lack the means to develop on their own. <a href="http://www.diglib.org/dlfhomepage.htm">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>DLF</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digitalmedia"><b>digital media</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#multimedia">multimedia</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dmca"><b><em>Digital Millennium Copyright Act of 1998 (DMCA)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Legislation passed by Congress and signed into law in October,
1998 to prepare the United States for the ratification of international
<a href="#treaty">treaties</a> protecting rights to <a href="#intellectualproperty">intellectual property</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> form, drafted in 1996 at a <a href="#conference">conference</a> of the <a href="#wipo">World Intellectual Property Organization</a> (WIPO).  The <a href="#bill">bill</a> was supported by the <a href="#software">software</a> and entertainment industries, and opposed by the <a href="#library">library</a>, <a href="#research">research</a>, and education communities.  <a href="http://www.educause.edu/issues/dmca.html">Click here</a> to learn more about the <b><em>DMCA</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digitalpreservation"><b>digital preservation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of maintaining, in a <a href="#condition">condition</a> suitable for use, materials produced in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>s.  Problems of physical <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> are compounded by the obsolescence of computer equipment, <a href="#software">software</a>, and <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">media</a>.  Also refers to the practice of <a href="#digitization">digitizing</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> originally produced in nondigital formats (<a href="#print">print</a>, <a href="#film">film</a>, etc.) to prevent permanent loss due to <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> of the physical <a href="#medium">medium</a>.  Synonymous with <em>e-preservation</em> and <em>electronic preservation</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dataconversion">data conversion</a> and <a href="#digitalarchives">digital archives</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digitalref"><b>digital reference</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicref">electronic reference</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digitalthesis"><b>digital thesis</b></a>
</dt><dd>A master's <a href="#thesis">thesis</a> or Ph.D. <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a> created in electronic form ("<a href="#borndigital">born digital</a>").  Most universities require a <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#microform">microform</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> for <a href="#archives">archival</a> purposes, but for some <a href="#hypermedia">hypermedia</a> theses, a <a href="#print">print</a> version may not be an accurate representation of the original (or even possible).  <a href="#digitalpreservation">Preservation</a> dilemmas posed by the rapid obsolescence of <a href="#digital">digital</a> equipment and <a href="#format">format</a>s underscore the need for <a href="#standards">standards</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digitalvideodisc"><b>digital videodisc</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="digitization"><b>digitization</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of converting <a href="#data">data</a> to <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a> for <a href="#dataprocessing">processing</a> by a computer.  In <a href="#information">information</a> systems, digitization usually refers to the <a href="#dataconversion">conversion</a> of <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#text">text</a> or images (<a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, etc.) into digital signals using some kind of <a href="#scanner">scanning device</a> that enables the result to be displayed on a computer screen.  In <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a>, digitization refers to the conversion of continuous <a href="#analog">analog</a> signals into pulsating digital signals.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dimenovel"><b>dime novel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#melodrama">melodrama</a>tic <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>al <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> of adventure, romance, and action, <a href="#publishing">published</a> in inexpensive <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> in the United States during the second half of the 19th century, sold mainly at news stands for 10-25 cents a <a href="#copy">copy</a>.  The term originated with the <em>Dime <a href="#novel">Novel</a> <a href="#library">Library</a></em> introduced in 1860 by Beadle and Adams of New York.  Hundreds of thousands of <a href="#title">title</a>s, written according to formula, were <a href="#issue">issue</a>d before this form of <a href="#pulpfiction">pulp fiction</a> waned in the early 20th century.  Among of the most popular was <b><em>Buffalo Bill, King of the Border Men</em></b> (1869) by E. Z. C. Judson, writing under the <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a> Ned Buntline.  His other works included <em>Bigfoot Wallace, the Giant Hero of the Border</em> (1891) and <em>The Red Warrior, or, Stella DeLorme's Comanche Lover: A Romance of Savage Chivalry</em> (1869).  The influence of this <a href="#genre">genre</a> on popular culture is studied by literary historians.  Compare with <a href="#pennydreadful">penny dreadful</a> and <a href="#yellowback">yellowback</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dimensions"><b>dimensions</b></a>
</dt><dd>The actual physical size of a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>, given in centimeters the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> unless some other unit of measurement is more appropriate.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#height">height</a> and <a href="#width">width</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="diorama"><b>diorama</b></a>
</dt><dd>A museum <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> or display on any <a href="#scale">scale</a>
in which inanimate objects and life-like figures representing animate
beings are carefully placed in front of a background scene drawn or
painted in perspective on a flat or curved surface to create the
illusion of greater depth of field than actually exists. Special
lighting and <a href="#soundrecording">recorded sound</a> effects are sometimes added to make the impression more realistic.  Small portable examples are made for traveling exhibits.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="diptych"><b>diptych</b></a>
</dt><dd>A portable hinged tablet consisting of two pieces of wood,
ivory, or metal covered with wax on the inside surface, on which the
ancient Greeks and Romans wrote with a <a href="#stylus">stylus</a>.  Also, a <a href="#picture">picture</a> or design painted or carved on the inside surfaces of two hinged tablets.  In medieval Europe, three tablets called a <em>triptych</em> were also used for the same purpose, hinged in such a way that the outer tablets folded over the center panel.  Compare with <a href="#pugillaria">pugillaria</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="directdelivery"><b>direct delivery</b></a>
</dt><dd>Putting <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> directly into the hands of the <a href="#patron">patron</a> who requests them, without requiring a trip to the <a href="#library">library</a> to pick them up, for example, through a <a href="#booksbymail">books-by-mail</a> program.  Direct delivery is practical for <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a> located on the premises of the <a href="#hostorg">host organization</a>.  It is also used by <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> on a limited scale to serve <a href="#homebound">homebound</a> users. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="directedition"><b>direct edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> for which the <a href="#author">author</a> provides the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> with <a href="#cameraready">camera-ready copy</a> produced on a computer with the aid of <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#software">software</a>.  Used mainly for <a href="#work">work</a>s that cannot be produced economically from <a href="#type">type</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="directentry"><b>direct entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>The principle in <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> that a concept describing the <a href="#content">content</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> should be entered under the <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> that names it, rather than as a <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a> of a <a href="#broaderterm">broader term</a>, thus a <a href="#book">book</a> about "academic libraries" would be assigned the heading <b>Academic libraries</b>, not <b>Libraries--Academic</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="directional"><b>directional</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a question that can be answered at the <a href="#informationdesk">information desk</a> or <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a> by directing the <a href="#patron">patron</a> to the location of specific resources, services, or facilities within the <a href="#library">library</a>, as opposed to a question requiring substantive <a href="#information">information</a>, <a href="#bi">instruction</a> in the use of library resources, or <a href="#inforeferral">referral</a> to an outside <a href="#agency">agency</a> or authority.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#signage">signage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="director"><b>director</b></a>
</dt><dd>The person who has overall responsibility for directing the performance of a <a href="#work">work</a> written for stage or screen.  The director's name appears in the <a href="#credit">credit</a>s at the beginning or end of a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>, or television program, and is indicated in the <a href="#notearea">note area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> created to represent the work in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  Compare with <a href="#producer">producer</a>, and <a href="#screenplay">screenwriter</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#librarydirector">library director</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="directorder"><b>direct order</b></a>
</dt><dd>An order for <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> placed by an <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> directly with the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, rather than through a <a href="#jobber">jobber</a> or <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agency</a>.
The percentage of orders placed in this manner has declined as
wholesalers and subscription agents have positioned themselves to offer
economies of scale to their customers and provide services that add
value. Some publishers no longer accept direct orders and sell only to
wholesalers (<em>example</em>:  <b>Random House</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="directory"><b>directory</b></a>      
</dt><dd>A list of people, companies, institutions, organizations, etc., in <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> or <a href="#classified">classified</a> order, providing contact <a href="#information">information</a> (names, addresses, phone/<a href="#facsimiletrans">FAX</a> numbers, etc.) and other pertinent details (affiliations, <a href="#conference">conference</a>s, <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, membership, etc.) in brief <a href="#format">format</a>, often <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#serial">serial</a>ly (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="#ald">American Library Directory</a></em>).  In most <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#currency">current</a> directories are shelved in <a href="#readyreference">ready reference</a> or in the <a href="#refstacks">reference stacks</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#citydirectory">city directory</a>, <a href="#telephonedirectory">telephone directory</a>, and <a href="#tradedirectory">trade directory</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#storage">storage</a> and retrieval, a catalog of the <a href="#file">file</a>s stored on the <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a> of a computer, or on some other storage <a href="#medium">medium</a>, usually organized for ease of <a href="#access">access</a> in a hierarchical tree of <em>subdirectories</em>.  The topmost directory is called the <em>root directory</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ftp">FTP</a>.  
</p><p>
In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the portion of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record following the <a href="#leader">leader</a>, which serves as an <a href="#index">index</a> to the <a href="#tag">tag</a>s included in the record, normally hidden from view of <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> and <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> user.  Constructed by the cataloging <a href="#software">software</a> from the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> at the time the record is created, the directory indicates the tag, length, and starting location of each <a href="#variablefield">variable field</a>.  Whenever a change is made in the record, the directory is automatically reconstructed.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dirtyproof"><b>dirty proof</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#proof">proof</a> of <a href="#typesetting">typeset</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> containing many errors, or one returned to the <a href="#printer">printer</a> heavily corrected.  A <em>clean proof</em> contains no errors or corrections.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="disasterplan"><b>disaster plan</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of written procedures prepared in advance by the <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> to deal with an unexpected occurrence that has the potential to cause injury to personnel or damage to equipment, <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, and/or facilities sufficient to warrant temporary suspension of services (flood, fire, earthquake, etc.).  In <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#recordsmanagement">records management</a>, securing <a href="#vitalrecords">vital record</a>s
in the event of disaster is one of the highest priorities. An effective
disaster plan begins with a thorough risk assessment to identify the
areas most susceptible to various kinds of damage and evaluate measures
that can be taken in advance to ensure <a href="#disasterpreparedness">preparedness</a>.  Both an initial action plan and a recovery plan should be included.  Compare with <a href="#contingencyplan">contingency plan</a> and <a href="#emergencyplan">emergency plan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="disasterpreparedness"><b>disaster preparedness</b></a>
</dt><dd>Steps taken by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#archives">archives</a> to prepare for serious damage to facilities, <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s,
and/or personnel in the event of a major occurrence such as a fire,
flood, or earthquake, including preventive measures, formulation of an
effective <a href="#disasterplan">disaster plan</a>, maintenance of adequate insurance, etc.  <a href="http://palimpsest.stanford.edu/bytopic/disasters/">Click here</a> to connect to the disaster preparedness section of the <em>Conservation OnLine (CoOL)</em> <a href="#website">Web site</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="disbound"><b>disbound</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> from which a previous <a href="#binding">binding</a> has been removed, usually in preparation for <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>, part of the process called <a href="#pulling">pulling</a>.  Compare with <a href="#unbound">unbound</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="disc"><b>disc</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic <a href="#term">term</a> for a direct-access magnetic <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> that is <a href="#readonly">read-only</a>, as distinct from <a href="#rewritable">rewritable</a>, including audio <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>s, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>s, <a href="#videodisc">videodisc</a>s, etc.  Compare with <a href="#disk">disk</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="discard"><b>discard</b></a>
</dt><dd>To officially <a href="#withdrawal">withdraw</a> an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> from a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> for disposal, a process that includes removing from the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> all references to it.  Also refers to any item withdrawn for disposal, usually stamped "discard" to avoid confusion.  <a href="#libmaterials">Materials</a> are usually withdrawn when they become <a href="#outdated">outdated</a>, cease to <a href="#circulation">circulate</a>, wear out, or are <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> beyond <a href="#repairing">repair</a>.  When shelf space is limited, <a href="#duplicate">duplicate</a>s may be discarded to make room for new <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>.  Withdrawn items may be <a href="#exchange">exchange</a>d or given as <a href="#gift">gift</a>s to other <a href="#library">libraries</a>, but the most common method of disposal is in a <a href="#booksale">book sale</a>.  Unsold items may be given to a thrift store or thrown away as trash, depending on the policy of the library.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#weeding">weeding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="discharge"><b>discharge</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>, to cancel the <a href="#record">record</a> of a loan upon return of the borrowed <a href="#bibitem">item</a> and payment of any <a href="#overdue">overdue</a> <a href="#fines">fine</a>.  Compare with <a href="#charge">charge</a>. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="discipline"><b>discipline</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organized branch of human <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>, developed through study and <a href="#research">research</a>
or creative endeavor, and which constitutes a division of the
curriculum taught at institutions of higher learning. A discipline may
be divided into subdisciplines, for example, <em>biology</em> and <em>zoology</em> within the <em>biological sciences</em>.  In western scholarship, the disciplines are traditionally organized as follows:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b><em>Arts and humanities</em></b>: archaeology,
classical studies, communication, folklore, history, language and
literature, performing arts (dance, film, music, theater), philosophy,
religion and theology, visual arts
</dd><dd><b><em>Social sciences</em></b>: anthropology, criminology
and criminal justice, economics, international relations, law,
political science, psychiatry, psychology, public administration,
social work, sociology, urban studies, women's studies </dd><dd><b><em>Sciences</em></b>:  astronomy, biology, chemistry, computer science, earth sciences, mathematics, medicine and health, physics</dd></dl>    
<p>
In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the <a href="#class">class</a>es representing <a href="#subject">subject</a> areas are <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> by discipline (<em>example</em>  <b>150</b> for Psychology).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="disclaimer"><b>disclaimer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A legal notice posted on a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>, appended to an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> message, given on a product, or provided with a service, informing the <a href="#reader">reader</a> or consumer that the <a href="#host">host</a> or producer does not guarantee and cannot be held responsible for all aspects of its <a href="#content">content</a> or performance. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="discography"><b>discography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list or <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> of <a href="#audiotape">audiorecording</a>s, usually of <a href="#work">work</a>s by a specific <a href="#composer">composer</a> or <a href="#performer">performer</a>, of a certain style or <a href="#genre">genre</a>, or of a specific time period.  Each <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a discography provides some or all of the following descriptive elements:  <a href="#title">title</a> of work, name of composer and performer(s), date of recording, name of <a href="#manufacturer">manufacturer</a>, manufacturer's catalog number, and <a href="#releasedate">release date</a>.  Also refers to the systematic <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> of audiorecordings, and to the study of <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a> as a <a href="#medium">medium</a> of expression.  The person who <a href="#compile">compile</a>s such a catalog is called a <em>discographer</em>.  Compare with <a href="#filmography">filmography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="discontinued"><b>discontinued</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> for which a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> or <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a> has ended.  In the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> for the <a href="#title">title</a>, the library's <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> are indicated in a <a href="#closedentry">closed entry</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#canceled">canceled</a> and <a href="#ceased">ceased publication</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="discontinuednumber"><b>discontinued number</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> from an earlier <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, which is no longer used, indicated at the appropriate location in the <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a> by a note to "class in" a more general number. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#schedulereduction">schedule reduction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="discount"><b>discount</b></a>
</dt><dd>A percentage deducted from the price of any product or service, for example, the reduction in the rate paid for <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> services by schools and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> under the federal <a href="#erate">E-rate</a> program.  In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, a percentage deducted from the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#listprice">list price</a> for an item, as an inducement to purchase.  In <a href="#book">book</a> sales, the discount system includes:  
<p>
</p><dl><dt>
</dt><dd><b><em>Cash discount</em></b> - usually 1-2%, offered by publishers  to <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s in exchange for payment within 10 days of the end of the billing month
</dd><dd><b><em>Continuation order discount</em></b> - for automatic shipment of <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> as <a href="#serial">serial</a>s (usually 5%)
</dd><dd><b><em>Convention discount</em></b> - on orders placed at a publisher's <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> during a <a href="#libconference">conference</a> or convention (usually 15%)
</dd><dd><b><em>Library discount</em></b> - on purchases by <a href="#library">libraries</a> and related institutions (usually 5-10%)
</dd><dd><b><em>Long discount</em></b> - standard discount given on <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a>s (usually 40%)
</dd><dd><b><em>Prepayment discount</em></b> - for payment with the order (usually 5% or free <a href="#shipping">shipping</a>) 
</dd><dd><b><em>Prepublication discount</em></b> - on orders placed prior to the <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> to encourage advance sales
</dd><dd><b><em>Quantity discount</em></b> - on purchases of a required number of <a href="#copy">copies</a> or <a href="#title">title</a>s
</dd><dd><b><em>Trade discount</em></b> - given by publishers to <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>s and retail outlets
</dd><dd><b><em>Short discount</em></b> - on professional books and  <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s sold directly to individuals, and sometimes on <a href="#specialorder">special order</a>s
</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="discourse"><b>discourse analysis</b></a>
</dt><dd>Linguistic analysis of segments of spoken or written <a href="#language">language</a>
which are longer than one sentence and form a unit having recognizable
structure, for the purpose of identifying regularities in the
occurrence of phonological, grammatical, and <a href="#semantics">semantic</a>
elements. In computer science, the results of discourse analysis have
been applied to the study of human/computer interaction, for example,
in the development of <a href="#voicerecognition">voice recognition</a> systems.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="discussionlist"><b>discussion list</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="disintermediation"><b>disintermediation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Elimination of the mediator or "middle man."  In the delivery of <a href="#information">information</a> services, the need for professional assistance is minimized in <a href="#userfriendly">user-friendly</a> systems designed to facilitate <a href="#endusersearch">end-user search</a>ing.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mediated">mediated search</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="disk"><b>disk</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic term for a direct-access magnetic <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> which is <a href="#rewritable">rewritable</a>, as opposed to <a href="#readonly">read-only</a>, including <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>s, <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a>s, and <a href="#zipdisk">Zip disk</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>magnetic disk</em>.  Compare with <a href="#disc">disc</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="diskdrive"><b>disk drive</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, a generic term for the <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> component that physically manipulates a specific type of magnetic <a href="#disk">disk</a> (<a href="#harddisk">hard</a>, <a href="#floppydisk">floppy</a>, <a href="#worm">WORM</a>, <a href="#zipdisk">Zip</a>), allowing the user to read <a href="#data">data</a> from and write data to it.  Disk drives can be internal or external.  Also spelled <em>disc drive</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="diskette"><b>diskette</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="displaycase"><b>display case</b></a>
</dt><dd>A box or set of shelves enclosed in glass or plexiglass to allow <a href="#book">book</a>s and other items to remain protected while on <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>.
A display case can be free-standing, wall-mounted, or built-in. Modern
