designs are usually lockable. Cases used for perishable museum <a href="#specimen">specimen</a>s may be climate-controlled to prevent <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a>.  Synonymous with <em>exhibit case</em>.  Compare with <a href="#displayrack">display rack</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="displaycopy"><b>display copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> put on view, usually in a <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a> or as part of <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> at a <a href="#libconference">conference</a> or convention.  At the end of the event, display copies are sometimes sold to conference participants at a <a href="#discount">discount</a>, especially if their <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>s are no longer in new <a href="#condition">condition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="displaymatter"><b>display matter</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a> that is not part of the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, including <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, <a href="#caption">caption</a>s, <a href="#printersornament">printer's ornament</a>s, etc.  To distinguish it from <a href="#bodymatter">body matter</a>, textual display matter is <a href="#typesetting">set</a> in <a href="#displaytype">type</a> of a different <a href="#typesize">size</a> and/or <a href="#font">font</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="displayrack"><b>display rack</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> furnishing in metal, wood, or plastic, designed to display <a href="#printing">printed</a> material, such as <a href="#brochure">brochure</a>s, announcements, instructional handouts, <a href="#readinglist">reading list</a>s, etc., face-forward to encourage users to <a href="#browse">browse</a> and select what they need.  Sold by library <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s,
display racks are available in wall-mounted and free-standing designs,
from small counter-top models to large floor units. Compare with <a href="#displaycase">display case</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="displaytype"><b>display type</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#typesize">Type size</a>s larger than 14-<a href="#point">point</a>, used mainly for <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, <a href="#title">title</a>s, <a href="#banner">banner</a>s, and other display purposes, in contrast to the smaller <a href="#texttype">text type</a> used to <a href="#printing">print</a> the <a href="#bodymatter">body</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a>, and even smaller <a href="#extracttype">extract type</a> used for <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s, <a href="#note">note</a>s, etc.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fancytype">fancy type</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="disposal"><b>disposal</b></a>
</dt><dd>In U.S. government <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the <a href="#destruction">destruction</a> of <a href="#noncurrent">noncurrent</a> <a href="#records">records</a> that are no longer needed.  Also used synonymously with <a href="#disposition">disposition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="disposition"><b>disposition</b></a>
</dt><dd>The manner in which the <a href="#noncurrent">noncurrent</a> <a href="#records">records</a> of an <a href="#agency">agency</a> or individual are handled once their utility has been <a href="#appraisal">appraised</a>, whether stored (temporarily or permanently) in a <a href="#repository">repository</a> in their original <a href="#format">format</a>, <a href="#reproduction">reproduced</a> and stored on <a href="#microform">microform</a>, sold, donated, or <a href="#destruction">destroyed</a>.  Compare with <a href="#disposal">disposal</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dispositionschedule">disposition schedule</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dispositionschedule"><b>disposition schedule</b></a>
</dt><dd>A systematic list of <a href="#document">document</a>s used by an <a href="#archivist">archivist</a> to determine: 1) which of the recurring <a href="#records">records</a> of an <a href="#agency">agency</a> or individual will be retained, 2) the period of time for which they will be held, 3) where they will be housed during the <a href="#retentionperiod">retention period</a> (<a href="#archives">archives</a> or <a href="#intermediatestorage">intermediate storage</a>), and 4) any other decisions concerning their <a href="#disposition">disposition</a>, based on their utility and <a href="#archivalvalue">value</a> to the organization.  Synonymous with <em>retention schedule</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#sentencing">sentencing</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dissertation"><b>dissertation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A lengthy, formal written <a href="#treatise">treatise</a> or thesis, especially an account of scholarly investigation or <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#research">research</a> on a specialized <a href="#topic">topic</a>,
submitted to a university in partial fulfillment of the requirements
for a Ph.D. degree. Dissertations submitted at universities in the
United States, Canada, Great Britain, and other European countries are <a href="#indexing">indexed</a> and <a href="#abstracting">abstracted</a> in <em><a href="#dai">Dissertation Abstracts International</a></em> (<em>DAI</em>) available in <a href="#print">print</a>, on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, and <a href="#online">online</a> from Bell &amp; Howell.  In most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, <a href="#copy">copies</a> of dissertations may be requested on <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> or ordered via <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>diss</em>.  Compare with <a href="#thesis">thesis</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dai"><b><em>Dissertation Abstracts International (DAI)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A service of Bell &amp; Howell that provides <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> and <a href="#abstracting">abstracting</a> of Ph.D. <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a>s and master's <a href="#thesis">theses</a> in all academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s,
submitted at universities in the United States, Canada, Great Britain,
and other European countries since 1861 (dissertations <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>ed since 1980, theses since 1988).  <b><em>DAI</em></b> is available in <a href="#print">print</a>, on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, and as an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> directly from Bell &amp; Howell or via <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#firstsearch">FirstSearch</a></em> (<a href="#update">update</a>d <a href="#monthly">monthly</a>).  <a href="#print">Print</a> <a href="#copy">copies</a> of dissertations can be obtained from <em>Dissertation Express</em> (Bell&amp; Howell) upon payment of a fixed <a href="#fee">fee</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="distanceeducation"><b>distance education</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#distancelearning">distance learning</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="distancelearning"><b>distance learning</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of instruction and learning designed to overcome
barriers of time and space by allowing students to study in their own
homes or at local facilities, often at their own convenience, using
materials available electronically or by mail. Communication with the
instructor is normally by telephone or <a href="#email">e-mail</a>.  <a href="#telecommunication">Telecommunication</a> <a href="#network">network</a>s and <a href="#teleconference">teleconferencing</a> have facilitated distance learning.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> are working to support distance learning by providing <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>s, <a href="#elecreserves">electronic reserves</a>, electronic <a href="#refdesk">reference service</a>, <a href="#onlinetutorial">online tutorial</a>s, and electronic <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery service</a>.  <a href="http://distancelearn.about.com/">Click here</a> to learn more about distance learning.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#continuinged">continuing education</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="distinctivetitle"><b>distinctive title</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#title">title</a> that is unique to a specific <a href="#work">work</a>.  Distinctiveness of title is important in registering <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, and makes the <a href="#entry">entry</a> for a <a href="#document">document</a> easier to retrieve from a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or other <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a> in a <a href="#search">search</a> by title.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="distribcopy"><b>distribution copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#reprography">reprography</a>, a <a href="#microform">microform</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> from which additional copies of equal <a href="#legibility">legibility</a> can be <a href="#reproduction">reproduced</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="distribimprint"><b>distribution imprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>The statement <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> giving the official name(s) of the <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>(s) from which <a href="#copy">copies</a> can be obtained, as distinct from the <a href="#imprint">imprint</a> of the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> that <a href="#issue">issue</a>d the <a href="#edition">edition</a>, or the <a href="#printer">printer</a> responsible for <a href="#printing">printing</a> the <a href="#edition">edition</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="distributionlist"><b>distribution list</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#email">e-mail</a> <a href="#software">software</a>, a feature that allows the user to establish a list of <a href="#emailaddress">e-mail address</a>es
under a common name, enabling messages to be sent simultaneously to
everyone on the list when addressed to the list name. Although the <a href="#term">term</a> is sometimes used synonymously with <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>, the latter generally supports a much larger group, requiring special software for automatic maintenance (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#listserv">LISTSERV</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="distributionrights"><b>distribution rights</b></a>
</dt><dd>Legal arrangements made by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to transfer to another company or person the exclusive <a href="#rights">right</a> to market a <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually within a designated geographic area.  In <a href="#book">book</a>s, distribution rights are usually indicated in the <a href="#distribimprint">distribution imprint</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="distributor"><b>distributor</b></a>
</dt><dd>An agent or <a href="#agency">agency</a> that owns the exclusive or shared <a href="#rights">rights</a> to market a <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>, usually within a designated geographic area.  In domestic publishing, the distributor is usually, but not always, the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  Foreign publications are often distributed by a domestic publishing company under an agreement with the original publisher.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>distr</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#distribimprint">distribution imprint</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="diversity"><b>diversity</b></a>
</dt><dd>Inclusiveness with regard to variation in age, gender, sexual
orientation, religious belief, and ethnic, racial, and cultural
background within a given population. In the United States, <a href="#library">libraries</a> strive to achieve diversity in <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> admissions, hiring, <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>, services, and programs.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#affirmative">affirmative action</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dividedcatalog"><b>divided catalog </b></a>
</dt><dd>In the 1930s, when it became apparent that <a href="#dictionarycatalog">dictionary catalog</a>s were becoming cumbersome, large <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States began dividing their <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s into two sections, one for <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#entry">entries</a> and the other for <a href="#mainentry">main</a> and <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a> other than subject (<a href="#author">author</a>s, <a href="#title">title</a>s, <a href="#series">series</a>, etc.).  Eventually, some libraries divided their catalogs into <em>three</em>
sections (author, title, and subject). Divided catalogs have the
disadvantage of requiring that the user know in advance which type of
entry is required (entries for <a href="#work">work</a>s written <em>by</em> a specific author are filed separately from works written <em>about</em>
the same person), but once the initial determination is made, the user
is spared the time and effort of looking through entries which are not
of the type desired. Synonymous with <em>split catalog</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#classifiedcatalog">classified catalog</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dividelike"><b>divide-like note</b></a>
</dt><dd>A note added to a <a href="#heading">heading</a> in a <a href="#classificationschedule">classification schedule</a> to inform the user that the heading is <a href="#subdivision">subdivide</a>d in the same way as another heading in the same schedule. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="division"><b>division</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the first level of <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a> of the ten <a href="#mainclass">main class</a>es, usually representing a <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or subdiscipline, indicated by the first two digits in the <a href="#notation">notation</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>94</b> in <b>940</b>
for European history). There are one hundred divisions in DDC (10 x
10). The next level of subdivision, indicated by a third digit other
than zero, is called a <a href="#section">section</a> (<b>944</b> for <a href="#work">work</a>s on the history of France).  <a href="http://www.oclc.org/dewey/about/hundreds.htm">Click here</a> to see a <a href="#table">table</a> of the divisions in DDC.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="divisionaltitle"><b>divisional title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#recto">recto</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> preceding the first <a href="#page">page</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a> of a major division of a <a href="#book">book</a>, sometimes with the number of the division (if they are numbered).  The <a href="#verso">verso</a> is normally left <a href="#blank">blank</a>.  Synonymous with <em>part title</em> and <em>section title</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dlf1"><b>DLF</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dlf"><b>D</b>igital <b>L</b>ibrary <b>F</b>ederation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dli1"><b>DLI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dli"><b>D</b>igital <b>L</b>ibraries <b>I</b>nitiative</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dmca1"><b>DMCA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#dmca"><b>D</b>igital <b>M</b>illennium <b>C</b>opyright <b>A</b>ct</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dns"><b>DNS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#domainnamesystem"><b>D</b>omain <b>N</b>ame <b>S</b>ystem</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dockingstation"><b>docking station</b></a>
</dt><dd>A piece of computer <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> that enables a <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>
to function as a desktop computer by providing a single large plug and
socket that duplicates the individual cable connections to <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>, <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>, <a href="#mouse">mouse</a>, and <a href="#printer">printer</a>.  Some docking stations include built-in <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a>s such as audio speakers and <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> drive, and a <a href="#network">network</a> <a href="#interface">interface</a> card to allow the user to connect to a <a href="#localarea">local area network</a>.  Because no <a href="#standard">standard</a> exists for docking stations, <a href="#compatibility">compatibility</a> with the specific type of laptop is an important consideration in making a purchase decision.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doctored"><b>doctored</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> that has been altered from its original <a href="#condition">condition</a>, usually as a consequence of <a href="#mending">mending</a>, <a href="#repairing">repairs</a>, <a href="#restoration">restoration</a>, or the addition or removal of parts.  Compare with <a href="#asissued">as issued</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#madeupcopy">made-up copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="docudrama"><b>docudrama</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened form of the <a href="#term">term</a> <em>documentary drama</em>, a dramatization of events that actually happened, usually produced for <a href="#film">film</a> or television.  Although some elements may be <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>alized, a serious attempt is made to be historically accurate (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Edward Hopper, the Silent Witness</em></b>, a film by Wolfgang Hastert).  Compare with <a href="#documentary">documentary</a> and <a href="#featurefilm">feature film</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="document"><b>document</b></a>
</dt><dd>A physical entity consisting of any substance on which is <a href="#record">record</a>ed all or a portion of one or more <a href="#work">work</a>s, in the words of <a href="#mcluhan">Marshall McLuhan</a>, the "<a href="#medium">medium</a>" in which a "message" (<a href="#information">information</a>) is communicated.  Document <a href="#format">format</a>s range from <a href="#print">print</a> (<a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, <a href="#report">report</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#chart">chart</a>s, <a href="#print">print</a>s, etc.) to <a href="#microform">microform</a> and <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#media">media</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>doc.</em>  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery service</a>, <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a>, and <a href="#internaldocument">internal document</a>.
<p>
Also, any form <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#paper">paper</a>, once it has been filled in, especially one that has legal significance or is supplied by a <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a> (<em>example</em>:  an application for <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> protection). 
</p><p>
Also refers to a <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#file">file</a> (<a href="#filetype">file type</a> <b>.doc</b>) or any file created on a <a href="#macintosh">Macintosh</a> computer.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="documentary"><b>documentary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> that records actual events or depicts social conditions without <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>alization, often through the use of historical <a href="#footage">footage</a> and still <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, usually accompanied by a <a href="#narration">narration</a>
dramatically structured to highlight important individuals who
participated in the action. The term was coined by the Scottish
film-maker John Grierson in the late 1920's to describe the cinematic <a href="#work">work</a>s of Robert Flaherty, the first person to produce films of social commentary depicting actual people in real-life situations (<em>example</em>: <b><em>Louisiana Story</em></b>).  Compare with <a href="#docudrama">docudrama</a> and <a href="#featurefilm">feature film</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="documentation"><b>documentation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The acquisition, organization, storage, retrieval, and distribution of specialized <a href="#document">document</a>s, especially of a legal, technical, or scientific nature.  Also refers to a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of documents pertaining to a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a>, especially when used to substantiate a point of fact.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doccenter">documentation center</a>.
<p>
In scholarly <a href="#publication">publication</a>, the practice of <a href="#citation">citing</a> the <a href="#source">source</a> of a direct <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> or <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>, an idea that is not original, or factual <a href="#information">information</a>, to support a <a href="#thesis">thesis</a> or argument, and/or avoid <a href="#plagiarism">plagiarism</a> or <a href="#infringement">infringement</a> of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, particularly important in the writing of history and <a href="#biography">biography</a>.  
</p><p>
In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the process of writing and organizing descriptions of <a href="#records">records</a> for reference purposes and to facilitate the development of <a href="#findingaid">finding aid</a>s for users.
</p><p>
In <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a>, detailed descriptive <a href="#information">information</a> required to develop, operate, and maintain <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s
and systems. In a more general sense, a systematic written description
of any procedure (or set of procedures and/or policies), including the
history of its application within a specific <a href="#context">context</a>.
</p><p>
In France, a <a href="#term">term</a> used in nearly the same sense as <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doccenter"><b>documentation center</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization or <a href="#agency">agency</a> that specializes in receiving, processing, <a href="#preservation">preserving</a>, <a href="#abstracting">abstracting</a>, and <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, usually within a scholarly <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or <a href="#field">field</a> of <a href="#research">research</a> and study (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#eric">ERIC</a>).  Documentation centers also <a href="#issue">issue</a> <a href="#bulletin">bulletin</a>s on the progress of such work for distribution to interested parties and may also prepare <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a> on special <a href="#topic">topic</a>s, make <a href="#copy">copies</a> or <a href="#translation">translation</a>s, and engage in bibliographic research.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="documentcamera"><b>document camera</b></a>
</dt><dd>A table-top device used in <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a> and other visual presentations to project <a href="#text">text</a> and/or images from an opaque surface or <a href="#transparency">transparency</a> onto a large screen using an <a href="#lcd">LCD</a> projector.  Document cameras have superseded <a href="#overheadprojector">overhead projector</a>s in well-equipped <a href="#library">libraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="docdeliv"><b>document delivery service (DDS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The provision of <a href="#publishing">published</a> or <a href="#unpublished">unpublished</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s in <a href="#hardcopy">hard copy</a>, <a href="#microform">microform</a>, or <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, usually for a fixed <a href="#fee">fee</a> upon request.  In most <a href="#library">libraries</a>, document delivery service is provided by the <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> office on a <a href="#costrecovery">cost-recovery</a> basis.  The <a href="#patron">patron</a> is usually required to <a href="#pickuplocation">pick-up</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> material at the library, but electronic <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> may be forwarded via <a href="#email">e-mail</a>.  Also refers to the physical or electronic delivery of documents from a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> to the residence or place of business of a library user, upon request.  <a href="http://www.docdel.net/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em>DocDel.net</em> <a href="#website">Web site</a> provided by Instant Information Systems.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#edocdeliv">electronic document delivery</a> and <em><a href="#ariel">Ariel</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="documenttrail"><b>document trail</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#authentication">authenticated</a> sources of <a href="#information">information</a> about a <a href="#topic">topic</a>, <a href="#record">record</a>ed in any <a href="#medium">medium</a>, traced backward in time to determine conclusively the origins of an existing state of affairs, a technique used in <a href="#archives">archives</a> to establish <a href="#provenance"> provenance</a> and in news reporting to uncover the details of a story.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dogeared"><b>dog-eared</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> that shows definite signs of wear, especially <a href="#page">page</a>s that have been folded down at a corner to mark a place.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doggerel"><b>doggerel</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#verse">Versification</a> that is loose, irregular, crude, and/or superficial due to the writer's ineptitude, or by intention, usually for <a href="#comedy">comic</a> effect, as in John Skelton's <em>Colin Clout</em>:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd>For though my rhyme be ragged,
</dd><dd>Tattered and jagged,
</dd><dd>Rudely rain-beaten,
</dd><dd>Rusty and moth-eaten,
</dd><dd>If ye take well therewith,
</dd><dd>It hath in it some pith.</dd></dl>
<p>
Also spelled <em>doggrel</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="domain"><b>domain</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> and <a href="#software">software</a> resources controlled by a single computer system.  In a <a href="#localarea">local area network</a> (LAN), all the <a href="#clientserver">client</a>s, <a href="#server">server</a>s, and <a href="#device">device</a>s under the control of a single <a href="#security">security</a> <a href="#database">database</a>, administered under a common set of rules and procedures.  On the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, all the clients, servers, and devices sharing a common portion of the <a href="#ipaddress">IP address</a>, the highest level domain being the category of <a href="#host">host</a>, indicated in the United States by the three-letter suffix at the end of the <a href="#domainname">domain name</a>.  In <a href="#dbmanagement">database management</a>, all the possible values of the <a href="#data">data</a> contained in a specific <a href="#field">field</a> present in every <a href="#record">record</a> in a <a href="#file">file</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, the range or extent within which <a href="#document">document</a>s or <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s are selected for inclusion in a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, or <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  When the domain is one or more tangible <a href="#collection">collection</a>s, the result is a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  In an indexing and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>, the domain is usually the <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#literature">literature</a> of an academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Sociological Abstracts</em></b>) or group of related disciplines (<b><em>Child Development Abstracts and Bibliography</em></b>).  In a <a href="#nationalbib">national bibliography</a>, the domain is the published output of an entire country.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#scope">scope</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="domainname"><b>domain name</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#internetaddress">address</a> identifying a specific site on the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  In the United States, domain names usually consist of three parts separated by the <a href="#period">period</a> (<a href="#fullstop">full stop</a>).  In the address <b>www.thisuniversity.edu</b>, the first part (<b>www</b>) indicates the <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> or language used in <a href="#access">access</a>ing the address, the second part (<b>thisuniversity</b>) represents the name of the institution or organization <a href="#host">host</a>ing the site, and the last part (<b>edu</b>) is a high-level domain code indicating the category of entity serving as <a href="#network">network</a> host.  In the United States, there are currently <em>six</em> three-letter top-level domain codes:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>.com</b> - commercial enterprise
</dd><dd><b>.edu</b> - educational institution
</dd><dd><b>.gov</b> - government agency
</dd><dd><b>.mil</b> - military installation
</dd><dd><b>.net</b> - network
</dd><dd><b>.org</b> - nonprofit organization</dd></dl>  
<p>
</p></dd><dd>In other countries, the high-level domain code precedes a two-<a href="#letter">letter</a> <a href="#countrycode">country code</a>, for example, in the <a href="#url">URL</a> <b>www.bbc.co.uk</b>, the code <b>.uk</b> indicates that the commercial <a href="#website">site</a> is hosted in the United Kingdom.  Other top-level domain codes have been proposed to <a href="http://www.icann.org/">ICANN</a>,
the technical coordination body authorized to assign identifiers that
must be globally unique for the Internet to function. For more <a href="#information">information</a> on the assignment of domain names, see <em><a href="http://www.icannwatch.org/">ICANN Watch</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="domainnamesystem"><b>Domain Name System (DNS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#table">table</a> used to translate numerical <a href="#ipaddress">IP address</a>es (<em>example</em>: <b>123.456.78.9</b>) into the <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a> <a href="#domainname">domain name</a> addresses (<b>www.thisuniversity.edu</b>) familiar to Internet users, and vice versa.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="donation"><b>donation</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, a voluntary <a href="#deposit">deposit</a> of <a href="#records">records</a> by a person or organization, in which both legal title and physical <a href="#custody">custody</a> are formally <a href="#transfer">transfer</a>red by the <em>donor</em>.  Compare with <a href="#gift">gift</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#donorfile">donor file</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="donorfile"><b>donor file</b></a>
</dt><dd>A systematic <a href="#record">record</a> of the names of persons and/or organizations that have donated <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> to a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#archives">archives</a>.   A well-maintained donor file should <a href="#documentation">document</a> any restrictions on the <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, use, or <a href="#disposition">disposition</a> of donated <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s or <a href="#file">file</a>s, and provide current contact <a href="#information">information</a>.  In a <a href="#weeding">weeding</a> project, it is wise to check <a href="#discard">discard</a>s against such a file to ascertain if a prior agreement was made with the donor concerning final disposition.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doorstop"><b>door stop</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#library">Library</a> <a href="#slang">slang</a> for
a piece of equipment so obsolete that it cannot be given away. Such
items are usually consigned to a storage room in the basement until <a href="#renovation">renovation</a> or a <a href="#moving">move</a> into a new facility makes disposal unavoidable. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dos"><b>DOS</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <b>D</b>isk <b>O</b>perating <b>S</b>ystem (pronounced "dahss"), the first <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> for IBM-<a href="#compatibility">compatible</a> <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a>s,
developed for IBM in a version called PC-DOS by Bill Gates' fledgling
company Microsoft. Gates subsequently marketed the Microsoft version
(MS-DOS) which became the underlying control <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> for early versions of <a href="#windows">Windows</a>.  Windows NT and later versions of Windows are not dependent on DOS, although they are capable of supporting DOS <a href="#application">application</a>s.  Because it is non<a href="#graphic">graphic</a>al, line-oriented, and <a href="#commanddriven">command-driven</a>, the DOS <a href="#interface">interface</a> is not as <a href="#userfriendly">user-friendly</a> as Windows.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dosados"><b>dos-a-dos</b></a>
</dt><dd>An English term for a type of <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which two <a href="#book">book</a>s are bound back-to-back, sharing the back <a href="#cover">cover</a>, with the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a>s of one aligned with the <a href="#spine">spine</a>
of the other, so that they open in opposite directions. Popular during
the 17th century, this style was used to bind in a single <a href="#volume">volume</a> the <em>New Testament</em> with the <em>Prayer Book and Psalms</em>.  Compare with <a href="#tetebeche">tete-beche</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dot"><b>dot</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#fullstop">full stop</a> used to divide the elements of an <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dotcom"><b>dot.com</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial enterprise that does all or a substantial portion of its business over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.amazon.com/">Amazon.com</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doublecolumn"><b>double column</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> in which the <a href="#text">text</a> is <a href="#typesetting">set</a> to half the width of a <a href="#page">page</a>, usually with a <a href="#blank">blank</a> space or <a href="#rule">rule</a> dividing the two <a href="#column">column</a>s, a <a href="#format">format</a> commonly used in <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a>, <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s, and other large-<a href="#format">format</a> <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doubledagger"><b>double dagger</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#character">character</a> in the shape of a vertical stroke crossed twice, above and below the mid-point, used as the third-order <a href="#refmark">reference mark</a>, following the use of the <a href="#asterisk">asterisk</a> and the <a href="#dagger">dagger</a>.  The double dagger is also known as a <em>double obelisk</em> or <em>diesis</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doublefan"><b>double-fan adhesive binding </b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive binding</a> in which the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> is <a href="#milling">milled</a> and splayed, first in one direction while a slow-drying <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a>
is applied, and then in the opposite direction as a second application
is made, allowing the adhesive to penetrate no more than 1/32 inch
between the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, so that each leaf is <a href="#tippedin">tipped</a> to the next.  The method is not practical for <a href="#book">book</a>s with a text block more than two inches thick.  The strength of fan adhesive <a href="#binding">binding</a> can be enhanced by <a href="#notchedbinding">notching</a> the binding edge, but this technique has the disadvantage of restricting <a href="#openability">openability</a>.  Compare with <a href="#perfectbinding">perfect binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doublefold"><b>double fold</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#doubleleaf">double leaf</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doubleleaf"><b>double leaf</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> twice the page size in a <a href="#book">book</a>, folded in half at the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> or top edge, with the fold <a href="#uncut">uncut</a> and no <a href="#printing">printing</a> inside the fold.  When such a leaf is un<a href="#number">number</a>ed, it is counted as two pages.  In the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, the total number of pages is recorded as in the following example:  <b>[32] pp. (on double leaves)</b>.  Synonymous with <em>double fold</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#chinesestyle">Chinese style</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doublenumeration"><b>double numeration</b></a>
</dt><dd>A system of enumeration, used mainly in <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s, law books, and technical <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, in which <em>two</em> numbers are assigned, usually separated by a period, <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a>, or other <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>, the first being the number of the <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or other major division of the <a href="#work">work</a>, and the second indicating a section of the <a href="#text">text</a> or one of several <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#graph">graph</a>s, <a href="#chart">chart</a>s, etc., <a href="#number">number</a>ed in the sequence in which they appear within the division.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doubleplate"><b>double plate</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> that extends across facing <a href="#page">page</a>s in an open <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a double-size <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> folded down the center and <a href="#binding">bound</a> at the fold.  A <a href="#caption">caption</a> may be printed on the preceding or following page.  Compare with  <a href="#doublespread">double spread</a> and <a href="#faceup">face up</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#plate">plate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doubleshelving"><b>double shelving</b></a>
</dt><dd>Storing <a href="#book">book</a>s two rows to a shelf, one behind the other, a shelving method used in <a href="#library">libraries</a>
only when space is severely limited. Shelves must be at least ten
inches deep for this alternative to work. The method can potentially
double <a href="#shelfcapacity">shelf capacity</a>, but it reduces <a href="#browsability">browsability</a> and makes <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> more difficult to locate and <a href="#reshelving">reshelve</a>.  These drawbacks can be minimized by installing <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> <a href="#signage">signage</a> or limiting its use to <a href="#series">series</a>, such as legal case law, or to the <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s of <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s and <a href="#report">report</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#flatshelving">flat shelving</a>, <a href="#foreedgeshelving">fore-edge shelving</a>, and <a href="#shelvingbysize">shelving by size</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doublespread"><b>double spread</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#text">Text</a> and/or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> across facing <a href="#page">page</a>s in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, as if on a single page, usually for visual effect.  Compare with <a href="#doubleplate">double plate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doublure"><b>doublure</b></a>
</dt><dd>An ornamental lining of silk, satin, <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>, <a href="#leather">leather</a>, or some other material of fine quality, affixed to the inside <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, especially in <a href="#leatherbound">leather-bound</a> <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a>s.  In older books, the doublure was often elegantly decorated.  Synonymous with <em>ornamental endpaper</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#marbling">marbling</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="doubtful"><b>doubtful authorship</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> for which <a href="#authorship">authorship</a> has <em>not</em>
been conclusively established, which is ascribed to one or more persons
on the basis of incomplete or unconvincing evidence. Some scholars
believe the works of William Shakespeare to have been written by
another <a href="#author">author</a>, but the evidence in support of this contention is inconclusive.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="download"><b>download</b></a>  
</dt><dd>To <a href="#copy">copy</a> one or more <a href="#file">file</a>s from a <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a> computer to a <a href="#terminal">terminal</a>, from a <a href="#network">network</a> <a href="#server">server</a> to a <a href="#client">client</a> computer, or from the <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a> of any computer to another <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, downloading bibliographic <a href="#data">data</a> to <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a> is a low-cost alternative to <a href="#printing">printing</a> the <a href="#output">output</a> of an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#search">search</a>, and users are generally encouraged to do so.  The opposite of <a href="#upload">upload</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="downtime"><b>down time</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any period during which a computer or system is out of operation, usually due to <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> or <a href="#software">software</a> failure or regular maintenance.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the amount of time a public access <a href="#workstation">workstation</a> or system is "down" is a measure of its reliability and can directly affect <a href="#qualityofservice">quality of service</a>,
particularly during periods of <a href="#peakuse">peak use</a>.  Also spelled <em>downtime</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="draft"><b>draft</b></a>
</dt><dd>A handwritten, typed, or <a href="#printing">printed</a> version of a <a href="#document">document</a>,
not intended to be final, which is subject to future modification,
correction, revision, etc., sometimes by a person or persons other than
the original <a href="#author">author</a>.  A <em>rough draft</em> usually provides only a preliminary or sketchy version of the <a href="#work">work</a> or plan.  The last version of a work that has seen multiple revisions is the <em>final draft</em>.  To avoid misunderstanding, a document not yet completed should be clearly marked "Draft."  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bill">bill</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="drama"><b>drama</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#play">play</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dramatization"><b>dramatization</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#adaptation">adaptation</a> of a nondramatic <a href="#work">work</a> of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> or <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> for performance on stage or screen, usually by a person other than the original <a href="#author">author</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a dramatization is entered under the name of the <a href="#playwright">playwright</a>, with <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a> under the author and <a href="#title">title</a> of the work on which it is based.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#novelization">novelization</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="driver"><b>driver</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> <a href="#routine">routine</a> specifically designed to link a <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> <a href="#device">device</a> to the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> of a computer, allowing it to perform the functions requested by <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#software">software</a>.  Some drivers, such as the <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> driver, are included in the operating system, but when a new piece of <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> is added to a computer (<a href="#printer">printer</a>, <a href="#scanner">scanner</a>, <a href="#diskdrive">disk drive</a>, etc.), the appropriate driver must usually be installed on the <a href="#centralproc">CPU</a> so that the operating system can call upon it to run the device.  Also called a <em>device driver</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="drop"><b>drop</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> outlet in a <a href="#library">library</a> or other facility, usually consisting of a voice jack and at least one <a href="#data">data</a> jack to allow users to connect to a computer <a href="#network">network</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dropcap"><b>drop cap</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dropinitial">drop initial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dropdowntitle"><b>drop-down title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The shortened version of the <a href="#title">title</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the first <a href="#page">page</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a>, usually the same as the <a href="#runningtitle">running title</a>.  Compare with <a href="#captiontitle">caption title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dropinitial"><b>drop initial</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large decorated or undecorated <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a> in a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#work">work</a>, aligned horizontally with the tops of succeeding <a href="#letter">letter</a>s in the same line, but extending below the line into a space left by <a href="#indention">indenting</a> the next line (or lines).  Drop initials are used mainly at the beginning of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or other major division of a work.  Synonymous with <em>drop cap</em>.  Compare with <a href="#raisedcapital">raised capital</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dropship"><b>drop shipment</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publication">Publication</a>s ordered from a <a href="#jobber">jobber</a> by the <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> department of a <a href="#library">library</a>, sent by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> directly to the library at the request of the jobber, usually to reduce <a href="#shipping">shipping</a> costs when the jobber does not have the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#instock">in stock</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dtp"><b>DTP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#desktop"><b>d</b>esk<b>t</b>op <b>p</b>ublishing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dublincore"><b>Dublin Core (DC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of <a href="#metadata">metadata</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s designed to facilitate the description of <a href="#document">document</a>-like resources in a <a href="#network">network</a>ed environment.  <b>Dublin Core</b> is the result of an international cross-<a href="#discipline">disciplinary</a>
consensus achieved through the ongoing efforts of the Dublin Core
Metadata Initiative (DCMI). It has the potential to provide a
foundation for <a href="#standardization">standardizing</a> <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of <a href="#information">information</a> resources available via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  <a href="http://dublincore.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the DCMI <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="duedate"><b>due date</b></a>       
</dt><dd>The date of the last day of the <a href="#loanperiod">loan period</a>, <a href="#rubberstamp">stamp</a>ed or written by a <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> member on the <a href="#datedueslip">date due slip</a> affixed to an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> when it is <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> at the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a>.  <a href="#fines">Fines</a> may be charged for <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> returned after the due date if they are not <a href="#renew">renew</a>ed.  In the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>, the due date may be displayed to indicate the <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> of an item currently checked out.  Synonymous with <em>date due</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#overdue">overdue</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dues"><b>dues</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#title">Title</a>s ordered from a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> that cannot be supplied until additional stock arrives from the <a href="#printer">printer</a>, usually <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s for which stock has not been received or <a href="#backlist">backlist</a>ed titles in the process of being <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>ed.  Such <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s are usually <a href="#backorder">back order</a>ed.
<p>
Also refers to the annual <a href="#fee">fee</a> that a member of a professional organization, such as the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, must pay to keep his or her membership <a href="#currency">current</a>.
Some organizations offer a sliding scale allowing each member to pay an
amount corresponding to length of service or level of participation,
with students and recent graduates paying the least.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dumbterminal"><b>dumb terminal</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#terminal">terminal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dummy"><b>dummy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single prototype of a <a href="#book">book</a>, made up of the same number of <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> (usually <a href="#blank">blank</a>) of the same grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a> as the final product, <a href="#trimming">trimmed</a> and <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> but usually <a href="#unbound">unbound</a>, to give the <a href="#binding">binder</a> an idea of <a href="#bulk">bulk</a> and <a href="#page">page</a> size, and to assist the <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> designer in planning the <a href="#layout">layout</a> of the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the complete layout of every page of a <a href="#printing">print</a> job, including <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>, <a href="#typesize">type size</a>, and the position of <a href="#textblock">text block</a>, <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#caption">caption</a>s, etc.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#shelfdummy">shelf dummy</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dump"><b>dump</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer operation that copies raw <a href="#data">data</a> from one location to another in a system, usually with little or no <a href="#format">format</a>ting, for example, the transfer of the contents of <a href="#memory">memory</a> to a <a href="#printer">printer</a> or computer screen to display the status of a <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> at the moment it <a href="#crash">crash</a>ed, useful in diagnosing the nature of a problem. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="duodecimo"><b>duodecimo (12mo)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a>, approximately 8 inches in <a href="#height">height</a>, made by folding a full <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of book <a href="#paper">paper</a> to form <a href="#signature">signature</a>s of twelve <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> (twenty-four <a href="#page">page</a>s).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#folio">folio</a>, <a href="#quarto">quarto</a>, <a href="#octavo">octavo</a>, and <a href="#sextodecimo">sextodecimo</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="duotone"><b>duotone</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> in which the image, originally done in black-and-white, is <a href="#printing">printed</a>
in two colors, usually black and either dark blue or dark green.
Duotone allows tint to be applied to an image at considerably less
expense than <a href="#fullcolor">full-color printing</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#halftone">halftone</a> and <a href="#monochromeplate">monochrome plate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="duplex"><b>duplex</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#communications">communications</a>, a channel capable of transmitting signals in both directions (sending and receiving) at the same time. In computer <a href="#network">network</a>s, this is usually achieved by using paired wires or by dividing <a href="#bandwidth">bandwidth</a> into two frequencies.  A <em>half-duplex</em> connection is capable of transmitting signals alternately but not simultaneously in either direction (<em>example</em>:  two-way radio).  Synonymous with <em>full-duplex</em>.  Compare with <a href="#simplex">simplex</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#printer">printer</a> attached to a computer or computer <a href="#network">network</a>, which has the capability to <a href="#printing">print</a> both sides of a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, a means of conserving paper in <a href="#library">libraries</a> that allow <a href="#printing">printing</a> from public access <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>s.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="duplicate"><b>duplicate</b></a>
</dt><dd>An additional <a href="#copy">copy</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> already in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, which is not needed.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> often order high-<a href="#demand">demand</a> items in multiple copies, then <a href="#weeding">weed</a> duplicates as they cease to <a href="#circulation">circulate</a>.  Compare with <a href="#addedcopy">added copy</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#reprography">reprography</a>, an exact <a href="#copy">copy</a> of an <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#document">document</a>
(either positive or negative) which can be used in place of the
original. Also refers to the process of making single or multiple
copies of an original document.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="duplicatepaging"><b>duplicate paging</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#pagenumber">number</a>ing of <a href="#page">page</a>s in duplicate, usually on facing pages, used mainly in <a href="#book">book</a>s containing <a href="#paralleltexts">parallel texts</a>, for example, a <a href="#text">text</a> in <a href="#translation">translation</a> and the same text in the original <a href="#language">language</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="duplicaterecord"><b>duplicate record</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> that occurs more than once on a <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  In <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s, this usually occurs when a record is used more than once in <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> procedures.  When a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> is created or <a href="#updated">updated</a>, duplicate records are removed in a <a href="#batchprocessing">batch process</a> known as <a href="#deduping">deduping</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="durability"><b>durability</b></a>
</dt><dd>The degree to which a material retains its physical integrity
when subjected to stress, for example, heavy use in the case of some <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a>.  A <em>durable</em> material, such as the <a href="#buckram">buckram</a> used as a covering in some <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a>s, will generally last a relatively long time under conditions of normal use.  The opposite of <em>fragile</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="durablepaper"><b>durable paper</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#permanentpaper">permanent paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dustcover"><b>dust cover</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dustjacket"><b>dust jacket</b></a>
</dt><dd>The removable <a href="#paper">paper</a> wrapper on the outside of a <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#book">book</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> in color and given a <a href="#glossy">glossy</a> <a href="#finish">finish</a> to market the <a href="#work">work</a> to retail customers and protect it from wear and tear.  The front of the dust jacket bears the <a href="#title">title</a>, the <a href="#author">author</a>'s full name, and a <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> design.  The title also appears on the <a href="#spine">spine</a> of the jacket, with the author's last name and the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s name or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>.  In most <a href="#tradebook">trade title</a>s, a promotional <a href="#blurb">blurb</a> written by the publisher appears on the inside <a href="#flap">flap</a>.  The back flap usually provides brief <a href="#biography">biographical</a> <a href="#information">information</a> about the author, which may include a small <a href="#portrait">portrait</a> <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>.  The <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a> is printed on the back of the dust jacket, usually in the lower right-hand corner, following brief <a href="#quotation">quote</a>s from positive <a href="#review">review</a>s of the <a href="#work">work</a>.  <a href="#textbook">Textbook</a>s, <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s, and sci-tech books are usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> without a dust jacket.
<p>
The first protective paper jacket was provided by a publisher in
England in 1833. Since then, dust jacket design has become a highly
skilled form of graphic art and a significant factor in the cost of
book production. In <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>s, the design used on the dust jacket is usually done by the <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>dj</em>.  Synonymous with <em>book jacket</em> and <em>dust cover</em>.  Compare with <a href="#wrapper">wrapper</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#sleeve">sleeve</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dvd"><b>DVD</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialism">initialism</a> that stands for <em><b>d</b>igital <b>v</b>ideo<b>d</b>isc</em>, a type of <a href="#opticaldisk">optical disk</a> of the same size as a <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>,
but with significantly greater recording capacity, partly because it is
double-sided. DVD is expected to supersede video CDs, laserdiscs, and <a href="#videotape">videotape</a> as the preferred <a href="#medium">medium</a> for <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s for home use.  DVD players can also read most CD <a href="#media">media</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dwarfbook"><b>dwarf book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bibelot">bibelot</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dwell"><b>dwell</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#tooling">tooling</a>, the length of time the heated <a href="#finishing">finishing</a> tool is in contact with the <a href="#leather">leather</a> or <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> surface being decorated.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dynamicmap"><b>dynamic map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> on which flow lines and/or arrows of
varying width are used to indicate the direction and amount of movement
(migration), action (military maneuvers), or change in conditions
(weather). Synonymous with <em>flow map</em>.
</dd></dl>
<p>

</p><hr>

| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="E">E</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="ead1"><b>EAD</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ead"><b>E</b>ncoded <b>A</b>rchival <b>D</b>escription</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ear"><b>ear</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small decorative design <a href="#printing">printed</a> on either side of the <a href="#title">title</a> in the <a href="#flag">flag</a> at the <a href="#head">head</a> of the <a href="#frontpage">front page</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>.  Also refers to a small projection found on the upper right-hand edge of the <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> "g" in some <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="earlybook"><b>early book</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#book">Book</a>s produced during the earliest periods in which human activities were <a href="#record">record</a>ed--on <a href="#claytablet">clay tablet</a>s in Mesopotamia, on <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a> <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>s in ancient Egypt, on tree bark or palm leaves in Asia, etc.--usually to record sacred prayers and rituals, traditional <a href="#saga">saga</a>s and <a href="#epic">epic</a>s,
lists of dynastic succession, laws and legal decisions, property
ownership and taxation, magical incantations, astronomical observations
and astrological predictions, important medical <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>, etc.  Due to the amount of labor required, early books were usually produced in single <a href="#copy">copies</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="earlycopy"><b>early copy</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#advancecopy">advance copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="easel"><b>easel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A metal, wood, or plastic rack or stand on a tripod base, designed to allow an open <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> to be <a href="#displaycopy">display</a>ed face-out as part of an <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> or presentation.  Large models are used to display <a href="#flipchart">flip chart</a>s in presentations.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="easelbinding"><b>easel binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#combbinding">comb</a> or <a href="#spiralbinding">spiral</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a> designed with rigid <a href="#extendedbinding">extended</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s that can be folded back to form the base of a triangle, allowing the <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#notebook">notebook</a> to stand upright when opened, with the <a href="#spine">spine</a> across the top.  The <a href="#text">text</a> is <a href="#printing">printed</a> parallel with the spine, and the <a href="#page">page</a>s are turned up and over, instead of from side to side. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="easybook"><b>easy book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A heavily <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> <a href="#book">book</a> with limited <a href="#text">text</a>, written to appeal to the interests and reading ability of <a href="#childrensbook">children</a> from preschool to third grade, usually shelved in a separate section of a <a href="#schoollibrary">school library</a> or <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a> in a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ebook"><b>e-book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicbook">electronic book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ebsco"><b>EBSCO</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial company that provides <a href="#subscripagency">subscription management services</a>, <a href="#electronicjournal">electronic journal</a> <a href="#access">access</a>, <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic</a> and <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#database">database</a>s, and an online <a href="#book">book</a> ordering service to <a href="#library">libraries</a> and related institutions.  <b>EBSCO</b> is currently one of the three leading <a href="#aggregator">aggregator</a>s of journals available in electronic <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a>.  <a href="http://www-us.ebsco.com/home/default.asp">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>EBSCO</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a> and <a href="#proquest">ProQuest</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="eclogue"><b>eclogue</b></a>
</dt><dd>A short pastoral <a href="#poetry">poem</a>, or part of a longer one, traditionally in the form of a <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> between a pair of shepherds, for example, Spenser's <em>The Shepheard's Calendar</em> (1579).  The <a href="#term">term</a> lost its pastoral connotation in the 18th century and now refers to a poem in which a serious theme is developed through a <a href="#monologue">monologue</a> or dialogue, as in <em>Rosalind and Helen</em> (1819) by Percy Bysshe Shelley.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ecollection"><b>e-collection</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#electroniccollec">electronic collection</a>.
<p> 
</p></dd><dt><a name="econference"><b>e-conference</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="edited"><b>edited</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single <a href="#work">work</a>, or two or more shorter works by the same or different <a href="#author">author</a>s, prepared for <a href="#publication">publication</a> by a person other than the author, whose name usually appears as <a href="#editor">editor</a> on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  In the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, the editor's name is given in the <a href="#titleand">title and statement of responsibility</a> <a href="#area">area</a> (<a href="#field">field</a> 245 of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>) following the phrase "edited by."  For works with more than one editor, the names are listed in order of appearance on the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a>, followed by the word "editors." 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="editing"><b>editing</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the process of revising and preparing for <a href="#publication">publication</a> material submitted by an <a href="#author">author</a> in <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#typescript">typescript</a> form, usually performed by one or more <a href="#editor">editor</a>s.  Also refers to the work of gathering together and preparing for publication in a single <a href="#volume">volume</a> or <a href="#uniformstyle">uniform</a> <a href="#set">set</a> of volumes the previously published <a href="#work">work</a>s of one or more authors, usually done by someone else.   
<p>
In <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a>, the revision of a <a href="#document">document</a>, such as a <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, usually by selecting from an <em>edit</em> <a href="#menu">menu</a> an <a href="#option">option</a> to <em>cut</em>, <em>copy</em>, <em>paste</em>, or <em>delete</em> portions of <a href="#text">text</a>, or by <a href="#reformat">reformat</a>ting the text in some manner.
</p><p>
Film editing is the process of selecting from the total amount of <a href="#footage">footage</a> shot those portions which are to be included in a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, then splicing them together in a sequence of scenes that tells a story (<a href="#featurefilm">feature film</a>) or conveys factual <a href="#information">information</a> about the <a href="#subject">subject</a> (<a href="#documentary">documentary</a>).  A similar process occurs in <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a> and <a href="#videotape">videotape</a> production.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="edition"><b>edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a single <a href="#typography">typographical</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, <a href="#printing">printed</a> from the same <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a>, and <a href="#issue">issue</a>d at one time by the same <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, or at intervals without alteration.  An edition may consist of several <a href="#impression">impression</a>s in which the <a href="#text">text</a> and other <a href="#matter">matter</a> is not substantially changed.  In older <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, the terms <em>impression</em> and <em>edition</em> are virtually synonymous since type was broken up for reuse after the first printing.  In the case of <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s, all the copies produced from the same <a href="#master">master</a> copy and issued by the same entity.  In a more general sense, the <a href="#format">format</a> (particularly the size and shape) in which a <a href="#work">work</a> is published.    
<p>
Some <a href="#book">book</a>s, especially <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s and <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s, are revised and republished.  Unless the publisher stipulates that a work is a <a href="#revisededition">revised edition</a> or <a href="#expandededition">expanded edition</a>, the first revision is known as the <em>second edition</em>.  Subsequent revisions are numbered in the order in which they are published.  The latest edition is the most <a href="#currency">current</a>, but older editions may contain useful <a href="#information">information</a>
deleted from later ones. Also refers to a work published in a specific
form for a particular market or purpose, for example, a <a href="#bookclubedition">book club edition</a>, <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a>, <a href="#exportedition">export edition</a>, <a href="#libraryedition">library edition</a>, <a href="#limitededition">limited edition</a>, <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>, or <a href="#specialedition">special edition</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the edition is indicated by ordinal <a href="#number">number</a> and/or description in the <a href="#editionarea">edition area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>ed.</em>  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#coedition">co-edition</a>. 
</p><p>
In <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> publishing, one of two
or more printings issued on the same day, for example, the "Early
Edition" or the "Late Edition." In radio and television, a program <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> at a particular time of day ("Morning Edition").  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="editionarea"><b>edition area</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#area">area</a> of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> in which <a href="#information">information</a> pertaining to the <a href="#edition">edition</a> is entered, usually by ordinal number (<em>15th ed.</em>) and/or description (<em>Rev. ed.</em>), including the <a href="#editionstatement">edition statement</a> and statements of responsibility relating to the edition.  In the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> these <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s are given in <a href="#field">field</a> 250. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="editionbinding"><b>edition binding</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#publishersbinding">publisher's binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="editionstatement"><b>edition statement</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the portion of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> in which the <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a> is indicated by ordinal number (<em>7th ed.</em>) and/or description (<em>Rev. ed.</em>) as found on the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, using standard <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a>s found in <em>Appendix B</em> of <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>.
If an item lacks an edition statement, but is known to include
important changes from previous editions, a brief statement in the <a href="#language">language</a> and <a href="#script">script</a> of the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> is provided by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> in <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s.  In the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record, the edition statement is given in <a href="#subfield">subfield</a> <em>a</em> of <a href="#field">field</a> 250.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="editor"><b>editor</b></a>         
</dt><dd>A person who prepares for <a href="#publication">publication</a> the <a href="#work">work</a>(s) of one or more <a href="#author">author</a>s.  An editor may be responsible for selecting material included in a <a href="#collection">collection</a> or for preparing <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> for the <a href="#printer">printer</a>, including <a href="#annotation">annotation</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a>, verification of the <a href="#accuracy">accuracy</a> of facts and bibliographic <a href="#citation">citation</a>s, polishing grammar and style, organizing <a href="#frontmatter">front</a> and <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>, etc.  <a href="#periodical">Periodical</a>s and large <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s often have a <em>general editor</em> or <em>editor-in-chief</em> who supervises the work of an editorial staff.  Compare with <a href="#compiler">compiler</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#authorseditor">author's editor</a>. 
<p>
In large publishing houses, the editing process may be divided into separate functions, each performed by a different person:
</p><p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b><em>Acquisition editor</em></b> - scouts and evaluates new works for recommendation to the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> 
</dd><dd><b><em>Manuscript editor</em></b> - assists the <a href="#author">author</a> in developing and organizing the work
</dd><dd><b><em>Copy editor</em></b> - perfects details of grammar and style, checks the accuracy of facts, <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s, citations, etc.
</dd><dd><b><em>Managing editor</em></b> - coordinates resources required for <a href="#publication">publication</a> and develops the <a href="#publicschedule">publication schedule</a>
</dd><dd><b><em>Production editor</em></b> - oversees the transition from editorial process to production (<a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#binding">binding</a>, distribution)</dd></dl>
<p>
Also refers to the individual in charge of the <a href="#content">content</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, or <a href="#journal">journal</a>, and in some cases its <a href="#publication">publication</a>, whose name is given in the <a href="#masthead">masthead</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#editorial">editorial</a>, <a href="#editorialboard">editorial board</a>, and <a href="#letter">letter to the editor</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="editorial"><b>editorial</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief <a href="#essay">essay</a> expressing clearly and unequivocally, and sometimes with artful persuasiveness, the opinion or position of the chief <a href="#editor">editor</a>(s) of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> or <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> with respect to a <a href="#currency">current</a> political, social, cultural, or professional issue.  Editorials appear on the <em>editorial page</em> of a newspaper, usually at the end of the news <a href="#section">section</a>.  The editorial page may also include <a href="#column">column</a>s written by syndicated <a href="#columnist">columnist</a>s, <a href="#lettereditor">letters to the editor</a>, and political <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>s.  In a <a href="#newsmagazine">news magazine</a>, editorials and columns usually appear at the beginning before the <a href="#feature">feature</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s, or sometimes on the last page(s).  Compare with <a href="#advertorial">advertorial</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#journalofcomment">journal of commentary</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="editorialboard"><b>editorial board</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of people responsible for controlling the <a href="#editorialcontent">editorial content</a> and overseeing the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, whose names are usually given in the <a href="#masthead">masthead</a>.  In <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the editorial <a href="#board">board</a> establishes the overall editorial policy and tone to be followed by staff writers, selects <a href="#columnist">columnist</a>s, and decides which <a href="#letter">letters to the editor</a> will be <a href="#publishing">published</a>.  In <a href="#journal">journal</a> publishing, the board usually controls the evaluation and selection of <a href="#article">article</a>s submitted by independent scholars for publication.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="editorialcontent"><b>editorial content</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portions of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> containing <a href="#content">content</a> controlled by the <a href="#editor">editor</a>(s) or <a href="#editorialboard">editorial board</a> (<a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#column">column</a>s, <a href="#editorial">editorial</a>s, <a href="#letter">letters to the editor</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, political <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>s, etc.), as opposed to the space devoted to advertisements, notices and announcements, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="editorialize"><b>editorialize</b></a>
</dt><dd>To put forth an opinion or position on a <a href="#subject">subject</a>, usually with intent to persuade the listener or <a href="#reader">reader</a>
to adopt or at least consider the point of view of the speaker or
writer. Also, to inject personal opinions or comments into an otherwise
objective discussion or account, a technique used in <a href="#essay">essay</a>s, <a href="#editorial">editorial</a>s, <a href="#column">column</a>s, <a href="#letter">letters to the editor</a>, and other forms of persuasive writing, but considered inappropriate in scholarly <a href="#publication">publication</a> and in <a href="#work">work</a>s of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="editorialpage"><b>editorial page</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#editorial">editorial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="educationalvideo"><b>educational videotape</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#videotape">videotape</a> designed and marketed to schools and <a href="#library">libraries</a> as a teaching tool, sometimes for use in conjunction with a specific curriculum unit.  Educational videos tend to be <a href="#listprice">price</a>d higher than <a href="#featurefilm">feature film</a>s and mass market <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> videos.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="eg"><b>e.g.</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin phrase <em>exempli gratia</em> meaning "for the sake of example."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="eggshell"><b>eggshell</b></a>
