</dt><dd>A smooth, slightly pitted <a href="#finish">finish</a> given to un<a href="#coated">coated</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#board">board</a>, which produces a soft non<a href="#glossy">glossy</a> surface resembling the shell of a bird's egg.  Most <a href="#antique">antique</a> papers have this type of finish. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="eighteenth"><b><em>Eighteenth Century Short-Title Catalogue</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#estc">English Short-Title Catalogue (ESTC)</a></em>.
<p> 
</p></dd><dt><a name="ejournal"><b>e-journal</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>see</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicjournal">electronic journal</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="electronicbook"><b>electronic book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> composed or typed on a computer, or <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> from <a href="#printing">print</a> to <a href="#digital">digital</a> (<a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a>) <a href="#format">format</a> by <a href="#scanner">scanning</a> or some other process, for display on a computer screen.  Although the first <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#novel">novel</a> was <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1987 (<em>Afternoon, A Story</em> by Michael Joyce), <em>e-books</em> did not capture public attention until the <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> of Stephen King's <a href="#novella">novella</a> <em>Riding the Bullet</em> in March, 2000.  Within 24 hours, the <a href="#text">text</a> had been <a href="#download">download</a>ed by 400,000 computer users.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="electroniccollec"><b>electronic collection</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#library">Library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, including <a href="#electronicmagazine">e-zine</a>s, <a href="#electronicjournal">e-journal</a>s, <a href="#electronicbook">e-book</a>s, <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#online">online</a> and on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, online <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic</a> and <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#database">database</a>s, and other <a href="#www">Web</a>-based resources.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="electronicconference"><b>electronic conference</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="elecdiscuss"><b>electronic discussion list</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="edocdeliv"><b>electronic document delivery</b></a>
</dt><dd>The transfer of <a href="#information">information</a> traditionally recorded in a physical <a href="#medium">medium</a> (<a href="#print">print</a>, <a href="#videotape">videotape</a>, <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>, etc.) to the user electronically, usually via <a href="#email">e-mail</a> or the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> employ <a href="#digital">digital</a> technology to deliver the information contained in <a href="#document">document</a>s and <a href="#file">file</a>s placed on <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> and requested via <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="electronicjournal"><b>electronic journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#website">Web site</a> <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>ally modeled on an existing <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://libraryjournal.reviewsnews.com/">Library Journal</a></em>), or which provides <a href="#access">access</a> to an <a href="#online">online</a> journal that has no print counterpart (<em><a href="http://ejde.math.swt.edu/">Electronic Journal of Differential Equations</a></em>).  The rapidly rising cost of print journal <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s has led many <a href="#library">libraries</a> to explore electronic alternatives.  <a href="http://www.library.ubc.ca/ejour/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>Ejournal SiteGuide MetaSource</em></b> maintained by the University of British Columbia Library.  Synonymous with <em>e-journal</em>.  Compare with <a href="#electronicmagazine">electronic magazine</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="electronicmagazine"><b>electronic magazine</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#website">Web site</a> <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>ally modeled on an existing <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.newyorker.com/">The New Yorker</a></em>) or which provides <a href="#access">access</a> to an <a href="#online">online</a> magazine that has no print counterpart (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://slate.msn.com/">Slate</a></em>).  <a href="http://www.newsdirectory.com/">Click here</a> to connect to a <a href="#directory">directory</a> of magazines available on the Web.  Synonymous with <em>e-zine</em>, <em>e-magazine</em> and <em>Webzine</em>.  Compare with <a href="#electronicjournal">electronic journal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="electronicmail"><b>electronic mail</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#email">e-mail</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="electronicnewsletter"><b>electronic newsletter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#online">online</a>, usually via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, with or without a <a href="#print">print</a> counterpart (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.lita.org/newslett/index.html">LITA Newsletter</a></em>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="elecpreservation"><b>electronic preservation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#digitalpreservation">digital preservation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="electronicpub"><b>electronic publishing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#publication">publication</a> of <a href="#electronicbook">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s (<a href="#electronicjournal">e-journal</a>s, <a href="#electronicmagazine">e-zine</a>s, etc.), <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, and other <a href="#information">information</a> resources in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, usually on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> or <a href="#online">online</a> via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, for in-house users, <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s, and/or retail customers, with or without a <a href="#print">print</a> counterpart (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.press.umich.edu/jep/">Journal of Electronic Publishing</a></em>).  Synonymous in this sense with <em>e-publishing</em>.  Also used synonymously with <a href="#desktop">desktop publishing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="electronicrecords"><b>electronic records</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#bibrecord">Bibliographic</a> or <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#records">records</a> stored on a <a href="#medium">medium</a>, such as <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a>/<a href="#disk">disk</a> or <a href="#opticaldisk">optical disk</a>, that requires computer equipment for <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a> and <a href="#dataprocessing">processing</a>.  Compare with <a href="#machinerecords">machine-readable records</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="electronicref"><b>electronic reference</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#refservices">Reference services</a> requested over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, usually via <a href="#email">e-mail</a>, <a href="#instantmessaging">instant messaging</a> ("<a href="#chat">chat</a>"), or <a href="#www">Web</a>-based submission forms, answered by the reference department of a <a href="#library">library</a>, independently or through a collective system such as <em><a href="http://www.questionpoint.org/">QuestionPoint</a></em> maintained by the participating members of the <a href="http://www.loc.gov/rr/digiref/">Global Reference Network</a>.  Synonymous with <em>digital reference</em> and <em>online reference</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="elecreserves"><b>electronic reserves</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#bibitem">Item</a>s placed on <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> which an <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a> makes available <a href="#online">online</a> to be read on a computer screen, <a href="#download">download</a>ed to <a href="#floppydisk">diskette</a>, or <a href="#printing">printed</a> as needed.  <a href="#permission">Permission</a> may be required to use <a href="#work">work</a>s not in the <a href="#publicdomain">public domain</a>.  <a href="#software">Software</a> for electronic reserves systems is available from commercial <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b>ERes</b> from Docutek Information Systems).  <a href="http://www.mville.edu/Administration/staff/Jeff_Rosedale/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the Electronic Reserves Clearinghouse.  Synonymous with <em>e-reserves</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="electronicstyle"><b>electronic style</b></a>
</dt><dd>Accepted <a href="#format">format</a> for <a href="#citation">citing</a> (in <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s, <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>s, and <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a>) <a href="#information">information</a> available in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>s, such as computer <a href="#software">software</a>, <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>s and <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a> from <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, messages posted to <a href="#newsgroup">newsgroup</a>s and <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>s, and <a href="#document">document</a>s available on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>.  <a href="http://dir.yahoo.com/Social_Science/Linguistics_and_Human_Languages/Languages/Specific_Languages/English/Grammar__Usage__and_Style/Citation/Internet_Citation/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of electronic style <a href="#guide">guide</a>s.  
<p>
The most recent <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s of the <em><a href="#apastyle">Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association</a></em> and the <em><a href="#mlastyle">MLA Handbook for Writers of Research Papers</a></em> also include sections on citing electronic resources.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="etd"><b>electronic theses and dissertations (ETD)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Master's <a href="#thesis">theses</a> and Ph.D. <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a>s submitted in <a href="#digital">digital</a> form rather than on <a href="#paper">paper</a>, as opposed to those submitted in <a href="#hardcopy">hard-copy</a> and subsequently <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, usually by <a href="#scanner">scanning</a>.  Forty universities in the United States and over one hundred institutions worldwide currently participate in the <a href="http://www.ndltd.org/">Networked Digital Library of Theses and Dissertations</a> (NDLTD), an initiative to require that <em>all</em> theses and dissertations be submitted in electronic format.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="elegy"><b>elegy</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#classics">classical</a> <a href="#literature">literature</a>, a <a href="#lyric">lyric</a> <a href="#poetry">poem</a> <a href="#composition">composed</a> in couplets of alternating hexameter and pentameter lines, a form known as <em>elegiac meter</em>.  In English literature through the 17th century, a song or poem of melancholy or solemn contemplation.  In contemporary <a href="#usage">usage</a>, a formal poem lamenting the death of a particular person (example:  <em>In Memory of W. B. Yeats</em> by W. H. Auden) or the phenomenon of mortality in general (example:  <em>Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard</em> by Thomas Gray).  Compare with <a href="#eulogy">eulogy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="element"><b>element</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a discrete unit of <a href="#data">data</a> constituting part of an <a href="#area">area</a> of <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a> within the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> created to represent an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, for example, the <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> in the <a href="#editionstatement">edition statement</a> or the <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#page">page</a>s or <a href="#plate">plate</a>s in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a>.  Also refers to a unit of <a href="#information">information</a> within a <a href="#field">field</a> of a record in a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, for example, the <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a> in the <a href="#source">source</a> field of an entry representing a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#article">article</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="elephantfolio"><b>elephant folio</b></a>
</dt><dd>In nonspecialty <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, a large <a href="#folio">folio</a> usually about 14 x 23 inches in size.  The term <em>double-elephant</em> refers to the very large <a href="#paper">paper</a> size used to <a href="#printing">print</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s such as <em>Birds of America</em> by John James Audubon.  Compare with <a href="#atlasfolio">atlas folio</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="elhibook"><b>elhi book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A term used in the educational <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> in the United States to refer to a <a href="#textbook">textbook</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> specifically for <b>el</b>ementary and <b>hi</b>gh-school students, usually <a href="#revision">revised</a> and <a href="#updated">updated</a> regularly by <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s anxious to retain market share.  In a more general sense, <em>any</em> book published for elementary and/or high school age <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.  Also spelled <em>el-hi</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#elhitextbooks">El-Hi Textbooks &amp; Serials in Print</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="elhi"><b>el-hi book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#elhibook">elhi book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="elhitextbooks"><b><em>El-Hi Textbooks &amp; Serials in Print</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a> in which <a href="#elhibook">elhi</a> <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s <a href="#currency">currently</a> <a href="#inprint">in print</a> are <a href="#indexing">indexed</a>, by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, and a <a href="#classifiedindex">classified</a> list of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s.  A separate index is provided for textbooks published in <a href="#series">series</a>.  Elhi serials are indexed by subject and title.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#cbip">Children's Books in Print</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="elision"><b>elision</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>elisio</em> meaning "a striking out."  The omission of a vowel or silent consonant at the beginning or in the middle of a word (<em>example</em>:  <b>you've</b> for <em>you have</em> or <b>ne'er</b> for <em>never</em>), or the omission of a vowel, consonant, or syllable in the pronunciation of a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>. In <a href="#orthography">orthography</a>, the omission is indicated by an apostrophe.  Compare with <a href="#contraction">contraction</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ellipsis">ellipsis</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ellipsis"><b>ellipsis</b></a>
</dt><dd> The use of <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s [ ] or three <a href="#fullpoint">full point</a>s ... or a series of <a href="#asterisk">asterisk</a>s **** in handwritten or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#text">text</a>
to indicate the omission or suppression of a word or words (four points
if the omission ends a sentence). Often used to reduce the length of a <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> without altering its meaning or significance.  Compare with <a href="#elision">elision</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="emagazine"><b>e-magazine</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicmagazine">electronic magazine</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="email"><b>e-mail</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of <em><b>e</b>lectronic <b>mail</b></em>, an <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> that allows computer users to exchange messages and <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s in <a href="#realtime">real time</a> with other users, locally and across <a href="#network">network</a>s.  E-mail requires a <em>messaging system</em> to allow users to store and forward messages, and a <em>mail program</em> with an <a href="#interface">interface</a> for sending and receiving.  Users can send messages to a single recipient at a specific <a href="#emailaddress">e-mail address</a> or <a href="#multicast">multicast</a> to a distribution list or <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a> without creating a <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> until <a href="#hardcopy">hard copy</a>
is desired. Faster and more reliable than the postal service, e-mail
can also be more convenient than telephone communication, but it has
raised issues of <a href="#security">security</a> and <a href="#privacy">privacy</a>.  Commonly used e-mail <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s:  <b><em>Lotus Notes</em></b>, <b><em>Eudora</em></b>, <b><em>Sendmail</em></b>, <b><em>Critical Path</em></b>.  Most <a href="#internetservice">Internet service provider</a>s offer an e-mail <a href="#option">option</a> to their <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s.  Also spelled <em>email</em>.  Compare with <a href="#facsimiletrans">FAX</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#attachment">attachment</a>, <a href="#body">body</a>, <a href="#header">header</a>, <a href="#footer">footer</a>, <a href="#encryption">encryption</a>, and <a href="#smtp">SMTP</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="emailaddress"><b>e-mail address</b></a>
</dt><dd>A string of <a href="#character">character</a>s used to route messages from one computer to another over a <a href="#network">network</a> governed by the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> for <a href="#email">electronic mail</a> (<a href="#smtp">SMTP</a>).
<p>
E-mail addresses follow a <a href="#standard">standard</a> <a href="#format">format</a> containing <em>no</em> <a href="#spacing">space</a>s:
</p><p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>United States</em>: <b>username@domainname.domaincode</b> </dd><dd><em>Other countries</em>:  <b>username@domainname.countrycode</b> 
<p>
</p></dd><dd><em>Examples</em>:
<dl><dt></dt><dd><b>smithj@myuniversity.edu</b>
</dd><dd><b>duboisf@universite.fr</b></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
<a href="http://www.yahoo.com/Reference/Phone_Numbers_and_Addresses/Email_Addresses/">Click here</a> to view the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of e-mail <a href="#directory">directories</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="embargo"><b>embargo</b></a>
</dt><dd>The period during which the <a href="#article">article</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> are not available in <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> from a <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#aggregator">aggregator</a>, usually the most recent 1-3 years.  Journal <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s have established such periods to prevent <a href="#library">libraries</a> from <a href="#canceled">canceling</a> <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s.  In most periodical <a href="#database">database</a>s, this restriction applies only to a small proportion of the <a href="#title">title</a>s <a href="#indexing">indexed</a>, but in <em><a href="#jstor">JSTOR</a></em> the journals are 100% embargoed.  Not to be confused with an <a href="#exclusive">exclusive</a> agreement between a journal publisher and an aggregator.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="emblembook"><b>emblem book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> <a href="#book">book</a>, popular in the 16th and 17th centuries, containing a collection of <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ic <a href="#engraving">engraving</a>s or <a href="#woodcut">woodcut</a>s called <em>emblems</em>, each expressing a moral principle, accompanied by an <a href="#epigram">epigram</a>, motto, <a href="#proverb">proverb</a>, or brief explanation in <a href="#prose">prose</a> or <a href="#verse">verse</a>.  <b><em>Harrod's Librarians' Glossary</em></b> includes in this category books in which the <a href="#text">text</a> of verses is arranged in symbolic designs, e.g. crosses.  The form was revived by the poet William Blake in <b><em>Gates of Paradise</em></b>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="embossed"><b>embossed</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a> and <a href="#binding">binding</a>, design or <a href="#lettering">lettering</a> raised in relief above the surface of a <a href="#page">page</a> or <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>, produced mechanically with stamping dies.  Embossing is used on <a href="#artbook">art book</a>s, elegant greeting cards, and other decorative items.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="embrittlement"><b>embrittlement</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#brittle">brittle</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="emendation"><b>emendation</b></a>
</dt><dd>An alteration or correction that removes an error or flaw from a <a href="#text">text</a> found to have been <a href="#corruptedtext">corrupted</a> in transmission, restoring it to a state believed to be closer to the <a href="#original">original</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="emergencyplan"><b>emergency plan</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of guidelines or steps prepared in advance to help the <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> deal with unusual occurrences that may temporarily disrupt normal operations (assaults, bomb threats, <a href="#security">security</a> violations, etc.), but are not usually disastrous.  Compare with <a href="#contingencyplan">contingency plan</a> and <a href="#disasterplan">disaster plan</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="emmy"><b>Emmy Award</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of several awards given annually in the United States by the <a href="http://www.emmys.tv/">Academy of Television Arts and Sciences</a> for outstanding programming in news and <a href="#documentary">documentaries</a>, sports, and daytime television.  <a href="http://www.emmyonline.org/">Click here</a> to see a list of the most recent <b>Emmy Award</b> winners.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="emoticon"><b>emoticon</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the <a href="#term">term</a> <em><b>emot</b>ional <b>icon</b></em>.  <b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#smiley">smiley</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="employeehandbook"><b>employee handbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#manual">manual</a>, often <a href="#printing">printed</a> in <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a>
form, describing the rights, responsibilities, privileges, rules,
expectations, etc., associated with employment in a company,
organization, <a href="#agency">agency</a>, or institution, usually distributed to employees at the time they are hired.  At academic institutions that grant <a href="#facultystatus">faculty status</a> to <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, the faculty <a href="#handbook">handbook</a> usually serves this function and may also cover <a href="#governance">governance</a>.  Compare with <a href="#proceduremanual">procedure manual</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="emulation"><b>emulation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process by which a <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a> or <a href="#device">device</a> designed to allow one system to imitate another accomplishes that task.  <em>Terminal emulation</em> <a href="#software">software</a> allows a <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a> user to <a href="#logon">log on</a> to a <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a> as if it were the type of <a href="#terminal">terminal</a> normally used for that purpose.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="emulsion"><b>emulsion</b></a>
</dt><dd>A stable colloidal suspension of one immiscible liquid in another.  In <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>y, the light-sensitive coating on a plate or base of plastic <a href="#film">film</a>
consisting of very fine silver halide crystals dispersed in a gelatin
medium. Considered a scientific art, the making of photographic
emulsions often involves trade secrets jealously guarded by commercial
film manufacturers.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="encapsulation"><b>encapsulation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of enclosing a flat <a href="#document">document</a> in a thin <a href="#polyester">polyester</a> envelope, the edges of which are sealed to protect it from damage, used in <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> and <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> to provide support for large, fragile <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s such as <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#chart">chart</a>s, <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, etc., while allowing them to remain visible on both sides.  The procedure does not alter the <a href="#condition">condition</a> of the document by adhering it to the film, as does <a href="#lamination">lamination</a>.
The sheet can easily be removed by slitting one or more sides of the
envelope. Although encapsulation protects the item from impurities in
the atmosphere, it does not retard processes of <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> inherent in the object.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="enchiridion"><b>enchiridion</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek word for <a href="#handbook">handbook</a>, a <a href="#volume">volume</a> of a size that can be easily carried in a person's hand.  In the Christian religious tradition, a <a href="#manual">manual</a> of devotions (<em>example</em>:  Saint Augustine's <b><em>Enchiridion on Faith, Hope, and Love</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ead"><b>Encoded Archival Description (EAD)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The EAD Document Type Definition (DTD) is a non<a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> <a href="#standard">standard</a> for <a href="#encoding">encoding</a> in <a href="#sgml">Standard Generalized Markup Language</a> (SGML) the <a href="#findingaid">finding aid</a>s (<a href="#register">register</a>s, inventories, <a href="#index">index</a>es, etc.) used in <a href="#archives">archives</a>, <a href="#library">libraries</a>, museums, and other <a href="#repository">repositories</a> of <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and <a href="#primarysource">primary source</a>s, to facilitate use of their <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>.  <b>EAD</b> was developed in 1993 on the initiative of the UC Berkeley Library and is maintained by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>, in partnership with the <a href="#saa">Society of American Archivists</a>.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/ead/">Click here</a> to learn more about <b>EAD</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="encoding"><b>encoding</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, the process of converting a message or <a href="#data">data</a> into electronic signals that can be <a href="#dataprocessing">processed</a> by a computer or transmitted over a <a href="#communications">communications</a> channel.  The opposite of <em>decoding</em>.  Compare with <a href="#encryption">encryption</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="encodinglevel"><b>encoding level</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of several modes of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> recognized by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> as appropriate, depending on a <a href="#library">library</a>'s resources and needs, and the amount of <a href="#bibdescrip">descriptive</a> detail available to the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>.  The levels are:  <a href="#fulllevel">full level</a>, <a href="#corelevel">core level</a>, <a href="#minimallevel">minimal level</a>, <a href="#collectionlevel">collection level</a>, and <a href="#copycataloging">copy cataloging</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="encryption"><b>encryption</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of <a href="#dataconversion">converting</a> the <a href="#data">data</a> contained in a message into a secret code prior to transmission via public <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> channels, to make it unreadable to all but the <a href="#authorization">authorized</a> recipient(s).  Encryption is a <a href="#security">security</a> measure taken to protect <a href="#confidentiality">confidential</a> <a href="#information">information</a>, such as credit card <a href="#number">number</a>s used in <a href="#online">online</a> business transactions, and to ensure that only those who have paid for a <a href="#feebased">fee-based service</a> obtain it.  The opposite of <em>decryption</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="encumbrance"><b>encumbrance</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, an amount charged against a <a href="#budget">budget</a>ary fund to cover a prior commitment to purchase <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, services, or <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a>, removed once full payment is made or the order is canceled.  Encumbrances are tracked to prevent over-expenditure.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="encyclopedia"><b>encyclopedia</b></a>   
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#number">number</a>ed <a href="#set">set</a> of books containing <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> <a href="#summary">summary</a> <a href="#information">information</a> about a variety of <a href="#topic">topic</a>s in the form of short <a href="#essay">essay</a>s, usually arranged <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#headword">headword</a> or <a href="#classified">classified</a> in some manner.  An entry may be <a href="#signed">signed</a> or <a href="#unsigned">unsigned</a>, with or without <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> or a list of references for <a href="#furtherreading">further reading</a>.  Headwords and <a href="#text">text</a> are usually <a href="#revision">revised</a> periodically for <a href="#publication">publication</a> in a new <a href="#edition">edition</a>.  In a <a href="#multivolumework">multivolume</a> encyclopedia, any <a href="#index">index</a>es are usually located at the end of the last <a href="#volume">volume</a>.  Encyclopedias may be general (<em>example</em>: <b><em>Encyclopedia Americana</em></b>) or <a href="#specialization">specialized</a>, usually by <a href="#subjectencyclopedia">subject</a> (<b><em>Encyclopedia of Bad Taste</em></b>) or <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> (<b><em>Encyclopedia of Social Work</em></b>).  In <a href="#electronicpub">electronic publishing</a>, encyclopedias were one of the first <a href="#format">format</a>s to include <a href="#multimedia">multimedia</a> and <a href="#interactive">interactive</a> elements (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Grolier Multimedia Encyclopedia Online</em></b>).  Also spelled <em>encyclopaedia</em>.  Synonymous with <em>cyclopedia</em>.  Compare with <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="encyassoc"><b><em>Encyclopedia of Associations</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>, providing detailed <a href="#directory">directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> on over 22,000 nonprofit American membership organizations of national scope.  Each <a href="#entry">entry</a> typically includes the organization's <a href="#officialname">official name</a>, address, and phone/FAX numbers; the primary official's name and <a href="#title">title</a>; founding date, purpose,  and activities; size of membership and <a href="#dues">dues</a>; national and international <a href="#conference">conference</a>s; and <a href="#publication">publication</a>s.  Each <a href="#edition">edition</a> includes an <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly arranged <a href="#nameindex">name index</a> and <a href="#keywords">keyword</a> <a href="#index">index</a>, and a separate <a href="#volume">volume</a> containing <a href="#geographicindex">geographic</a> and executive indexes.  Companion volumes are available from the same <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> for international organizations and regional, state, and local organizations.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="endangered"><b>endangered</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#archives">archives</a>, a category of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, or group of items, whose continued existence is threatened, usually by <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> or the obsolescence of equipment required to read the <a href="#format">format</a>.  <a href="#preservation">Preservation</a> may require <a href="#dataconversion">conversion</a> to a format of greater <a href="#permanence">permanence</a>.  Synonymous with <em>at risk</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="endbands"><b>endbands</b></a>
</dt><dd>A collective <a href="#term">term</a> for the <a href="#headband">headband</a> and tailband at the top and bottom of the <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> which has a <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="endmatter"><b>end matter</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="endnote"><b>endnote</b></a>
</dt><dd>A statement <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the end of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or <a href="#book">book</a> to explain a point in the <a href="#text">text</a>, indicate the basis of an assertion, or <a href="#cite">cite</a> the <a href="#source">source</a> of factual <a href="#information">information</a> or a <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>.   Like <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s, endnotes are <a href="#number">number</a>ed, usually in <a href="#superscript">superscript</a>, and listed in the sequence in which they appear in the text.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="endowment"><b>endowment</b></a>
</dt><dd>A permanent fund accumulated by an institution over an
extended period of time, consisting of gifts and bequests invested to
provide an ongoing return, all or a portion of which is expended,
sometimes for purposes specified by the donor(s), leaving the principal
intact to generate further income. A <a href="#library">library</a> may be separately endowed or share in the endowment of its parent institution.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fundraising">fund-raising</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="endpanel"><b>end panel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single- or double-faced flat piece of wood, steel, or other rigid material securely attached to the end of a <a href="#range">range</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> shelving, usually extending from floor to top of unit to cover the shelf ends facing an <a href="#aisle">aisle</a>
or open area. End panels also help provide structural rigidity to
shelving, important in regions prone to earthquake. The panels may be
painted or covered with material that aesthetically enhances the
library's decor. End panels in wood may be custom-made to match library
furnishings.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="endpaper"><b>endpaper</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of thick, strong <a href="#paper">paper</a> folded down the center, one half of which is <a href="#pastingdown">pasted down</a> to the inside of the front or back <a href="#board">board</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, the other half forming the first (or last) <a href="#leaf">leaf</a>, called the <a href="#flyleaf">flyleaf</a>.  Each fold becomes a <a href="#hinge">hinge</a> joining the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> to the <a href="#cover">cover</a>
and allowing the boards to swing open and closed. Colored endpapers are
often selected to complement the material used to cover the boards and <a href="#inlay">inlay</a> along the <a href="#spine">spine</a>.  For extra strength, some books have <em>double endpapers</em>.  In older books, the endpapers were often decorated (see <a href="#marbling">marbling</a>).  In modern book production, <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#genealogy">genealogies</a>, <a href="#table">table</a>s, or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s are sometimes <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the endpapers.  Also spelled <em>end-paper</em>.  Synonymous with <em>endleaf</em> or <em>endsheet</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doublure">doublure</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="enduser"><b>end-user</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, the person or persons for whom a <a href="#mediated">mediated</a> <a href="#litsearch">literature search</a> is conducted and to whom the results are delivered.  In a more general sense, the person for whom <em>any</em> <a href="#search">search</a> requiring the use of <a href="#library">library</a> resources or other <a href="#information">information</a> services is performed. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="endusersearch"><b>end-user search</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, a <a href="#litsearch">literature search</a> conducted by the person who actually intends to use the results, as opposed to a <a href="#mediated">mediated search</a> conducted by a trained specialist on behalf of the user.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="enewsletter"><b>e-newsletter</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicnewsletter">electronic newsletter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="estc"><b><em>English Short-Title Catalogue (ESTC)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A project begun by the <a href="#britishlib">British Library</a> in 1977 under the <a href="#title">title</a> <em>Eighteenth Century Short-Title Catalogue</em> to <a href="#compile">compile</a> a <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#record">record</a> of the <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, and other <a href="#printing">printed</a> material <a href="#publishing">published</a> in Great Britain and its colonies, and printed in the English <a href="#language">language</a> anywhere else in the world from 1701 to 1800.  The <a href="#changedtitle">title change</a>d to <b><em>English Short-Title Catalogue</em></b> after the decision was made to include <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>s and <a href="#serial">serial</a>s printed prior to 1701.  In the United States, work completed by the <a href="#rlg">Research Libraries Group</a> (RLG) on the <b><em>ESTC</em></b> is available in <em><a href="#rlin">RLIN</a></em>.  Plans are underway to <a href="#digitalimaging">digitize image</a>s of sample <a href="#publication">publication</a>s from the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of various <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="engraving"><b>engraving</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> or <a href="#print">print</a> made from a design incised with a sharp, pointed tool called a <em>burin</em> or <em>graver</em> on the surface of a metal <a href="#plate">plate</a> or hardwood block, in a process known as <a href="#intaglio">intaglio</a>.  The lines are <a href="#ink">ink</a>ed and an <a href="#impression">impression</a> made by pressing a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> or some other <a href="#printing">printing</a> surface against the plate.  Compare with <a href="#etching">etching</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#stippleengraving">stipple engraving</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="enlargededition"><b>enlarged edition</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#expandededition">expanded edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="enlargement"><b>enlargement</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> or <a href="#copy">copy</a> produced on a larger <a href="#scale">scale</a> than the <a href="#original">original</a>.  Some <a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a>s have the capacity to enlarge an original.  The opposite of <a href="#reduction">reduction</a>.  Synonymous, in <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>y, with <a href="#blowup">blowup</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ensemblework"><b>ensemble work</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> <a href="#composer">composed</a> for more than one voice and/or instrument singing or playing together, for example, soprano and piano, or a string quartet.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="entity"><b>entity</b></a>
</dt><dd>As defined in <em><a href="#frbr">FRBR</a></em> (<em>Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records</em>), one of the key objects of interest to users of <a href="#information">information</a> within a given domain of "things" described by bibliographic <a href="#data">data</a>.  In <em>FRBR</em>, entities are divided into three groups:  1) the products of intellectual or artistic endeavor (<a href="#work">work</a>, <a href="#expression">expression</a>, <a href="#manifestation">manifestation</a>, and <a href="#bibitem">item</a>); 2) the individual(s) or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate bodies</a> responsible for creating intellectual/artistic <a href="#content">content</a>, for producing or disseminating the content in physical form, or for maintaining custody of the products; and 3) the <a href="#subject">subject</a>s of intellectual or artistic expression (concept, object, event, place).  Each type of entity has a defining set of <a href="#attribute">attribute</a>s, for example, the attributes of a "work" include the <a href="#title">title</a>, form, date of work, intended <a href="#audience">audience</a>, etc.  The nature of the link between entities is their <a href="#relationship">relationship</a>, for example, an expression may be an "adaptation of" a pre-existing work.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="entrancelevel"><b>entrance-level</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#entrylevel">entry-level</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="entry"><b>entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single <a href="#catalogrecord">record</a> in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog"> catalog</a>, representing an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in one of its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a> and <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a>.  Also, a <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> in a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> representing a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#indexing">indexed</a> and/or <a href="#abstracting">abstracted</a>.    
<p>
Also refers to a reference in a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#index">index</a>, or to all the <a href="#information">information</a> given under a <a href="#headword">headword</a> in a <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>, or under a <a href="#heading">heading</a> in a <a href="#refbook">reference work</a> such as an <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a> or <a href="#handbook">handbook</a>.  
</p><p>
In a more general sense, any <a href="#accesspoint">point of access</a> to a <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s or other <a href="#data">data</a> (name of <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a> of <a href="#work">work</a>, <a href="#seriestitle">series title</a>, assigned <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>) under which a record representing a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a> may be <a href="#search">search</a>ed and identified, manually or electronically.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="entrylevel"><b>entry-level</b></a>
</dt><dd>Employment at the lowest grade in a system of classified <a href="#position">position</a>s, suitable for <a href="#candidate">candidate</a>s who are beginning their careers and lack experience.  <a href="#promotion">Promotion</a>
usually depends on a vacancy occurring at a higher grade or
classification, rather than on the development of the initial position
into one requiring greater skill or responsibility. Synonymous with <em>entrance-level</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="entryword"><b>entry word</b></a>
</dt><dd>The word under which a <a href="#catalogrecord">record</a> in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, or <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> is <a href="#file">file</a>d and <a href="#search">search</a>ed, usually the first word of the <a href="#heading">heading</a> (initial <a href="#article">article</a>s excluded).  In retrieving <a href="#information">information</a> from an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, the order of <a href="#term">term</a>s typed as <a href="#input">input</a> may determine the success or failure of a search by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>, or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>, but in a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> search, word order should not affect results if <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic is used correctly.  Synonymous with <em>filing word</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="enumerative"><b>enumerative</b></a>
</dt><dd>A naming or counting of items, one by one, as in a list, in any amount of detail, but without systematic <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#enumerativeclass">enumerative classification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="enumerativeclass"><b>enumerative classification</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> in which an attempt is made to designate <em>all</em> the <a href="#subject">subject</a>s required, without organizing them in logical hierarchy (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#lcc">Library of Congress Classification</a>).  Compare with <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical classification</a> and <a href="#syntheticclass">synthetic classification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="environcontrol"><b>environmental control</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> and <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, creating and maintaining hospitable storage conditions is the most effective strategy for promoting the longevity of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>.  <a href="#deterioration">Deterioration</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#leather">leather</a>, <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>, plastic, etc., can be dramatically reduced by controlling temperature, relative <a href="#humidity">humidity</a>, light, and air quality in storage.  Monitoring devices should be installed to ensure that <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> remain cool and dry.  Low illumination, ventilation that removes atmospheric pollutants, and effective <a href="#pestmanagement">pest management</a> are also essential.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ephemera"><b>ephemera</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#printing">Printed</a> materials of everyday life,
generally considered to have little or no permanent value, usually
because they are produced in large quantities or in disposable <a href="#format">format</a>s.  The category includes <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, <a href="#leaflet">leaflet</a>s, <a href="#flier">flier</a>s, performance <a href="#programnotes">program</a>s, <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, <a href="#postcard">postcard</a>s, greeting cards, menus, <a href="#comicbook">comic book</a>s, <a href="#paper">paper</a> toys, etc.  Ephemeral items are sometimes retained and <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ed for their <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> qualities or for their association with a specific person, event, or activity.  When collected by <a href="#library">libraries</a>, they are usually stored in <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>.  Also refers to material of brief <a href="#currency">currency</a>, which has reference value or sufficient literary or historical importance to merit permanent <a href="#archives">archival</a> storage, for example, academic <a href="#coursecatalog">course catalog</a>s and schedules, <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a>s, etc.  <a href="http://www.ephemerasociety.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of The Ephemera Society of America.  Compare with <a href="#grayliterature">gray literature</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epic"><b>epic</b></a>
</dt><dd>A lengthy <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#poetry">poem</a> in which the <a href="#language">language</a>, <a href="#character">character</a>s, and action are heroic and exalted in style.  Most epics have a comparatively simple <a href="#plot">plot</a>,
a theme (or themes) reflecting the universal human condition, a hero of
superhuman mental and physical capacity who is nonetheless fatally
flawed, a <a href="#setting">setting</a> imaginary or remote in time
and place, with supernatural forces playing a decisive role in the
action, upon which may depend the fate of an entire society or people.
Epics are usually closely tied to the <a href="#legend">legend</a>s, oral traditions, and history of a specific culture (<b><em>Iliad</em></b> and <b><em>Odyssey</em></b> of Homer, <b><em>Beowulf</em></b>, etc.).  Literary epics, such as the <b><em>Aeneid</em></b> of Virgil and <b><em>Paradise Lost</em></b> by John Milton, are consciously modeled on traditional examples.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epigram"><b>epigram</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the classical period, an <a href="#inscription">inscription</a> or <a href="#epitaph">epitaph</a>, but in modern <a href="#usage">usage</a> a tersely witty, often antithetical saying, ingeniously composed in <a href="#prose">prose</a> or <a href="#verse">verse</a>,
delivered with aplomb to make a point in a manner calculated to enhance
one's reputation in the company of people who value feats of
intellectual and literary virtuosity. The <a href="#satire">satirical</a>
form, established in ancient Rome by Martial, was cultivated in England
from the late 16th to the early 20th century. An example by Hilaire
Belloc:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b><em>ON OLD LADY POLTAGRUE, A PUBLIC PERIL</em></b>
<br><em>The Devil, having nothing else to do,
<br>Went off to tempt my Lady Poltagrue.
<br>My Lady, tempted by a private whim,
<br>To his extreme annoyance, tempted him.</em></dd></dl>  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epigraph"><b>epigraph</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> or motto included in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually following the <a href="#dedication">dedication</a>, or at the beginning of each <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>, expressing an idea or theme the <a href="#author">author</a> intends to develop more fully in the <a href="#text">text</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epilogue"><b>epilogue</b></a>
</dt><dd>A part added as a conclusion at the close of a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>, for example, the statement of the moral at the end of a <a href="#fable">fable</a>.  The <a href="#term">term</a> also refers to the final section of a speech, also called the <em>peroration</em>, and to a brief speech delivered at the end of a dramatic performance, requesting the approval of <a href="#audience">audience</a> and <a href="#criticism">critic</a>s.  Compare in this sense with <a href="#prologue">prologue</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="episodic"><b>episodic</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> consisting of a <a href="#number">number</a> of more or less self-contained but loosely connected incidents (<em>episodes</em>) strung together by the <a href="#author">author</a> to form a <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Idylls of the King</em></b> (1859) by Alfred, Lord Tennyson).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epistemology"><b>epistemology</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek <em>episteme</em> (knowledge) and <em>logos</em> (theory), the branch of philosophy devoted to the theoretical study of the nature, methods, and validity of human <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>, including the relationship between the knower (subject), the known (object), and the process of knowing.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epistle"><b>epistle</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#composition">composition</a> in <a href="#poetry">poetry</a> or <a href="#prose">prose</a>, written in the form of a <a href="#letters">letter</a> so elegant in style that it is considered a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> worthy of <a href="#publication">publication</a> (<em>example</em>:  the epistles or Cicero, Horace, and Pliny).  Also refers to one of the letters of the <em>New Testament</em> of the Christian Bible.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epistolarynovel"><b>epistolary novel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#novel">novel</a> that reached its greatest popularity during the 18th century, in which the <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> is developed by the <a href="#author">author</a> in a series of <a href="#letters">letters</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Clarissa</em></b> by Samuel Richardson).  Sometimes a novelist begins a <a href="#work">work</a> in epistolary style, then switches to conventional narrative (<b><em>Busman's Honeymoon</em></b> by Dorothy L. Sayers).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epitaph"><b>epitaph</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek <em>epi</em> ("upon") and <em>taphos</em> ("tomb"), a brief valedictory <a href="#verse">verse</a> on the life and death of a person (or persons), composed as an <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>
on a grave marker, sometimes by the deceased before death. Epitaphs are
usually complimentary, but may be humorous or ironic. One of the most
famous was written by Simonides of Ceos (556-468 BC) commemorating the
300 warriors who died at Thermopylae:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b><em>Go, tell the Lacedaimonians, passer-by,<br>
That here obedient to their laws we lie.</em></b></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epithet"><b>epithet</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek word <em>epitheton</em>, meaning "something added."  A descriptive name or <a href="#title">title</a> expressing an important quality or attribute, usually added to distinguish a person (William <em>the Conqueror</em>), epoch (Age of <em>Enlightenment</em>), or thing (<em>John Knox</em> cap) from others of the same name or <a href="#class">class</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the epithet follows the <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> in the <a href="#heading">heading</a> under which the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is cataloged.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epitome"><b>epitome</b></a>
</dt><dd>A statement of the essence of a <a href="#subject">subject</a>, in the briefest possible form.  Also refers to a very brief but accurate written statement of the main points of a <a href="#work">work</a>, usually prepared by a person other than the <a href="#author">author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="eponym"><b>eponym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single name under which several <a href="#author">author</a>s are <a href="#publishing">published</a>.  Also, the name of a person or <a href="#character">character</a> so closely associated with a quality, process, or activity that the name is used in signifying it (<em>Herculean</em>, <em>pasteurization</em>, <em>Platonic</em>, <em>Romeo</em>).
<p>
Also refers to a person who gives, or is reputed to have given, his or her name to an institution, structure, place, etc. (<em>Guggenheim Museums</em>), or to a distinguishing title derived from the name of a person, designating a people, place, thing, or period (<em>Periclean</em> Athens, <em>Carolingian</em> <a href="#minuscule">minuscule</a>, <em>Elizabethan</em> drama). 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epreservation"><b>e-preservation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened form of <em>electronic preservation</em>.  <b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#digitalpreservation">digitial preservation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="epublishing"><b>e-publishing</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicpub">electronic publishing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="equivalencetable"><b>equivalence table</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list in numerical order of the <a href="#class">class</a>es altered in a complete <a href="#revision">revision</a> of <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, giving the <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> in the preceding <a href="#edition">edition</a> and its equivalent in the <a href="#currency">current</a> edition.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#comparativetable">comparative table</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="erate"><b>E-rate</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of <em><b>e</b>ducation <b>rate</b></em>.  A federal program established under the <em>Telecommunications Act of 1996 (TCA)</em> and implemented in 1998, with oversight by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), <b>E-rate</b> allows schools, <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, and rural health care institutions to apply for substantial <a href="#discount">discount</a>s on rates paid for <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> services, including <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#access">access</a>, <a href="#communications">communications</a>
equipment, and internal wiring. The program is funded by the Universal
Service surcharge on telephone bills and administered by the Universal
Service Administrative Company (USAC) in Washington D.C. Although it
has been hampered by a byzantine application process and subjected to <a href="#filtering">filtering</a> requirements under the <em><a href="#cipa">Children's Internet Protection Act of 1999</a> (CIPA)</em>, the program has helped many schools and <a href="#library">libraries</a> build technological <a href="#infrastructure">infrastructure</a>, particularly in low-income areas.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="eref"><b>e-reference</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicref">electronic reference</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="eres"><b>ERes</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#elecreserves">electronic reserves</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ereserves"><b>e-reserves</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#elecreserves">electronic reserves</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ergonomics"><b>ergonomics</b></a>
</dt><dd>The systematic study of the relationship between people and
the environment in which they work, serving as the basis for the design
and arrangement of equipment, furnishings, and workspaces with the aim
of increasing productivity and avoiding negative effects on safety,
health, comfort, and efficiency. Synonymous with <em>human engineering</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="eric"><b>ERIC</b></a>           
</dt><dd>The <b>E</b>ducational <b>R</b>esources <b>I</b>nformation <b>C</b>enter is a national <a href="#information">information</a> system consisting of a group of federally-funded <a href="#clearinghouse">clearinghouse</a>s administered by the <a href="#nle">National Library of Education</a> (NLE), that <a href="#index">index</a>es and <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>s <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s and <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#report">report</a>s in education and related <a href="#field">field</a>s, and <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the results in the <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s <b><em>CIJE</em></b> (<em>Current Index to Journals in Education</em>) and <b><em>RIE</em></b> (<em>Resources in Education</em>), and in the <b><em>ERIC</em></b> <a href="#database">database</a> available <a href="#online">online</a> or on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> in most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> supporting education curriculum in the United States.
<p>
<a href="#bibitem">Item</a>s indexed in <b><em>ERIC</em></b> are assigned at least one <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> from the <b><em>Thesaurus of ERIC Descriptors</em></b> and a six-digit <em>EJ number</em> for journal articles, or a six-digit <em>ED number</em> for research reports (<a href="#document">document</a>s).  Available on <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>, <a href="#ericdocument">ERIC document</a>s are <a href="#file">file</a>d by ED number in microfiche cabinets usually located in the <a href="#microform">microform</a>s section of the <a href="#library">library</a>.  A <a href="#readerprinter">reader/printer</a> machine is required to <a href="#enlargement">enlarge</a> and make <a href="#copy">copies</a> of documents on microfiche.  ERIC documents are also available <a href="#online">online</a> from the <a href="http://www.edrs.com/">ERIC Document Reproduction Service</a> (EDRS).  <a href="http://www.eric.ed.gov/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <em>ERIC Clearinghouses</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#askeric">AskERIC</a></em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ericdocument"><b>ERIC document (ED)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a> or <a href="#unpublished">unpublished</a> <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#report">report</a> on a <a href="#topic">topic</a> in education or a related <a href="#field">field</a>, available on <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> and <a href="#online">online</a> by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> from the <a href="http://www.edrs.com/">ERIC Document Reproduction Service</a> (EDRS).  <a href="#access">Access</a> to ERIC <a href="#document">document</a>s is provided by most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> in the United States that support curriculum in education.  ERIC microfiche is <a href="#file">file</a>d by six-digit <em>ED number</em> in microfiche cabinets usually located in the <a href="#microform">microform</a>s section of the <a href="#library">library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="erotica"><b>erotica</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#work">Work</a>s containing sexual <a href="#content">content</a> calculated to stimulate the passions of the <a href="#reader">reader</a>, but which also have some artistic value and integrity (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Fanny Hill, or, Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure</em></b> by John Cleland).  Examples are usually found in <a href="#privatelib">private collection</a>s and in the <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a> of <a href="#library">libraries</a> that <a href="#specialization">specialize</a> in the history of <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>.  Compare with <a href="#curiosa">curiosa</a> and <a href="#pornography">pornography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="errata"><b>errata</b></a>
</dt><dd>The plural of <em>erratum</em>.  Errors discovered after a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> has <a href="#gonetopress">gone to press</a> but before it is distributed, brought to the <a href="#reader">reader</a>'s attention by the insertion of a list of corrections, separately <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a small piece of <a href="#paper">paper</a> known as an <em>errata slip</em>, usually <a href="#tippedin">tipped in</a> at the beginning of the <a href="#text">text</a> or in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>.  Synonymous with <em>corrigenda</em>.  Compare with <a href="#pastein">paste-in</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ert1"><b>ERT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ert"><b>E</b>xhibits <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="es"><b>ES</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#expertsystem"><b>e</b>xpert <b>s</b>ystem</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="escapekey"><b>escape key</b></a>
</dt><dd>A key located in the upper left-hand corner of a standard computer <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>, usually labeled <b>Esc</b>, which allows the user to go backward one step in a sequence of operations, terminating the current operation.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="escapistliterature"><b>escapist literature</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#fiction">Fiction</a> written as light entertainment, intended mainly to divert the mind of the <a href="#reader">reader</a> into a world of imagination and fantasy.  Popular <a href="#genre">genre</a>s include <a href="#romance">romance</a>, <a href="#sciencefiction">science fiction</a>, <a href="#thriller">thriller</a>s, etc.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="esl"><b>ESL</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of "<b>E</b>nglish as a <b>S</b>econd <b>L</b>anguage," a branch of English <a href="#language">language</a> study and teaching.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="esparto"><b>esparto</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#paper">paper</a> named after a coarse, short-fibered grass grown in the Mediterranean region which, when mixed with chemical wood <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>, produces the <a href="#bulk">bulk</a> and smooth <a href="#finish">finish</a> suitable for <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#finebook">fine</a> quality <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#plate">plate</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="espionage"><b>espionage</b></a>
</dt><dd>The practice of spying or using spies (or listening devices) to systematically collect strategic <a href="#information">information</a>
which the government of a country or the management of a commercial
entity would prefer to keep secret. When such information is used in
military planning and decision-making, it is called "intelligence."
Because some <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> in the United States provide public <a href="#access">access</a> to scientific and technical information that could be used by an aggressor, their policies have been scrutinized (<em>see</em> <a href="#lap">Library Awareness Program</a>). 
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#subgenre">subgenre</a> of <a href="#mystery">mystery</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, devoted to tales of spies and spying (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Reilly: The Ace of Spies</em></b>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#suspense">suspense</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="essay"><b>essay</b></a>
</dt><dd>A short <a href="#prose">prose</a> literary <a href="#composition">composition</a> addressed to the general <a href="#reader">reader</a>, usually dealing thoughtfully and in some depth with a single theme, seen from the personal point of view of the <em>essayist</em> who does not necessarily attempt the systematic or <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> analysis one would expect in a <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a> or <a href="#treatise">treatise</a>.  There are no limitations on style or <a href="#content">content</a>--essays can be formal or informal, descriptive, <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>, persuasive, humorous, <a href="#satire">satirical</a>, historical, <a href="#biography">biographical</a>, <a href="#autobiography">autobiographical</a>, or <a href="#criticism">critical</a>.
In some cases, essays that appear on the surface to be straightforward
can have a deeper, more philosophical meaning. Essays <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#collection">collection</a>s and <a href="#festschrift">Festschriften</a> are <a href="#index">index</a>ed in <b><em>Essay and General Literature Index</em></b> published by <a href="#hwwilson">H. W. Wilson</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="estc1"><b><em>ESTC</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#estc"><b>E</b>nglish <b>S</b>hort-<b>T</b>itle <b>C</b>atalogue</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="estimatedprice"><b>estimated price</b></a>
</dt><dd>The price that the <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> department of a <a href="#library">library</a> anticipates will be charged when an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> or <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> is ordered from a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>, or <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agency</a>.  The price actually paid may be higher or lower due to a <a href="#discount">discount</a>, <a href="#shipping">shipping</a> charges, etc.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#listprice">list price</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="estray"><b>estray</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the legal term for a <a href="#record">record</a> or <a href="#document">document</a> no longer in the possession of its original <a href="#creator">creator</a> or legitimate <a href="#custody">custodian</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="etal"><b><em>et al.</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin phrase <em>et alii</em>, meaning "and other people" used in <a href="#bibliography">bibliographic</a> <a href="#citation">citation</a>s after the first of more than three <a href="#collaborator">collaborator</a>s, instead of listing all the names.  Also, an abbreviation of <em>et alibi</em> ("and elsewhere") and <em> et alia</em> ("and other things").
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="etc"><b><em>etc.</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin phrase <em>et cetera</em> meaning "and the rest" or "and so forth," used to shorten a list.  Also abbreviated <em>&amp;c</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="etching"><b>etching</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> or <a href="#print">print</a> made from a metal or glass <a href="#plate">plate</a>
on which a design is made with a needle or other pointed tool through a
layer of wax, varnish, or other resistant material (the <em>etching-ground</em>).
When subjected to an acid bath, areas of the surface exposed by the
action of the needle are eaten away, becoming design elements that can
be <a href="#ink">ink</a>ed to produce an <a href="#impression">impression</a> on <a href="#paper">paper</a> in <a href="#intaglio">intaglio</a> <a href="#printing">printing</a>.  Compare with <a href="#engraving">engraving</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="etd1"><b>ETD</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#etd"><b>e</b>lectronic <b>t</b>heses and <b>d</b>issertations</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ethernet"><b>Ethernet</b></a>
</dt><dd>Conceived at Xerox PARC in 1976 and developed in cooperation with Intel and DEC, Ethernet has become the industry <a href="#standard">standard</a> for <a href="#network">network</a> architecture.  It is the most widely installed <a href="#localarea">local area network</a> (LAN) technology in the world, connecting <a href="#node">node</a>s over <a href="#twistedpair">twisted pair</a>, <a href="#coaxial">coaxial</a>, or <a href="#opticalfiber">fiber optic</a> cable.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#packet">packet switching</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ethics"><b>ethics</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#codeofethics">code of ethics</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="etseq"><b><em>et seq.</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin phrase <em>et sequens</em> meaning "and the following one."  Plural:  <em>et seqq.</em> ("and those that follow").
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="etymology"><b>etymology</b></a>
</dt><dd>The origins of a word, traced back as far as possible in time, usually by the methods of comparative linguistics.  Some <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#languagedictionary">language dictionaries</a> are devoted specifically to etymology (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Barnhart Dictionary of Etymology</em></b>).  The most <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> is the <em><a href="#oed"><b>O</b>xford <b>E</b>nglish <b>D</b>ictionary</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="eulogy"><b>eulogy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written or spoken <a href="#composition">composition</a> in praise of someone or something, especially a person who is deceased (<em>example</em>:  Ben Jonson's eulogy on Shakespeare).  Compare with <a href="#elegy">elegy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="evidentialvalue"><b>evidential value</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exactsize"><b>exact size</b></a>
</dt><dd>The actual size of the <a href="#binding">binding</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, as measured in inches or centimeters, independent of the dimensions of the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> or any other size designation.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, exact size is given in centimeters in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>.  Synonymous with <em>absolute size</em>.  Compare with <a href="#booksize">book size</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="example"><b>example</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a> and the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, a specific <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a given <a href="#edition">edition</a>, no different in any respect from other copies of the same edition.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="excerpt"><b>excerpt</b></a>
</dt><dd>A lengthy <a href="#verbatim">verbatim</a> selection taken from a speech or written <a href="#work">work</a>, usually longer than a <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>.  <a href="#reprint">Reprint</a>ing an excerpt without <a href="#permission">permission</a> may be an <a href="#infringement">infringement</a> of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>.  Excerpts are sometimes <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the form of a <a href="#digest">digest</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Book Review Digest</em></b>).  Compare with <a href="#extract">extract</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exchange"><b>exchange</b></a>
</dt><dd>An arrangement in which a <a href="#library">library</a> sends <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s it owns to another library and receives in return items owned by the other library, or sends <a href="#duplicate">duplicate</a> <a href="#copy">copies</a> to another library and receives duplicate <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in return.  Also refers to any <a href="#publication">publication</a> given or received in this manner.  Compare with <a href="#gift">gift</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exclusive"><b>exclusive</b></a>
</dt><dd>An agreement in which a <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> agrees to make the <a href="#content">content</a> of one or more of its <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#serialtitle">title</a>s available in <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> from a <em>single</em> journal <a href="#aggregator">aggregator</a>, as opposed to multiple aggregators, a practice that has become the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of debate among <a href="#serial">serial</a>s <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s.  Not to be confused with the <a href="#term">term</a> <a href="#embargo">embargo</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exegesis"><b>exegesis</b></a>
</dt><dd>Scholarly explanation or interpretation of a word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, sentence, or passage in a written work, based on close study and <a href="#criticism">critical</a> analysis of the <a href="#text">text</a>, especially to clarify an obscure point in the <em>Bible</em> or some other <a href="#sacredtext">sacred work</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#scholium">scholium</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exemplar"><b>exemplar</b></a>
</dt><dd>In medieval <a href="#book">book</a> production, an officially approved <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a scholastic <a href="#text">text</a>, made by hand by a <a href="#stationer">stationer</a> on the authority of a university.  Prior to the invention of the <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a>, university students used such copies as <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s
in their studies. In a more general sense, someone or something that
serves as a model, type, specimen, instance, or example of a quality,
category, or group.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exemplum"><b>exemplum</b></a>
</dt><dd>A story or anecdote told to illustrate a moral point, especially in the <a href="#context">context</a> of a sermon given by a medieval preacher.  An exemplum differs from a <a href="#parable">parable</a>
in having the moral stated at the beginning, rather than at the end. It
is also presumed to be based on actual events. Plural: <em>exempla</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exhaustive"><b>exhaustive</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#search">search</a> of an <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, or <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> with the aim of identifying <em>all</em> the <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s or <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> to the <a href="#topic">topic</a>.  An exhaustive <a href="#litsearch">literature search</a>, using all the <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a>s at the scholar's disposal, is one of the first steps in a major <a href="#research">research</a> project.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exhaustivity"><b>exhaustivity</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> and <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, a measure of the level of detail in which the <a href="#content">content</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a> is described in <a href="#subjectanalysis">subject analysis</a>, expressed as the average number of <a href="#term">term</a>s extracted from the <a href="#title">title</a> and <a href="#text">text</a>, or the average number of <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s selected from an authorized list, assigned in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, to facilitate <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a> by <a href="#subject">subject</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exhibit"><b>exhibit</b></a>
</dt><dd>A physical object placed on display in a museum, gallery, or
other public place, usually because of its historical, cultural, or
scientific importance, or its aesthetic qualities, extraordinary
characteristics, or monetary value. <a href="#library">Libraries</a> typically exhibit <a href="#rarebook">rare</a> and valuable <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, personal <a href="#papers">papers</a>, and <a href="#memorabilia">memorabilia</a> associated with <a href="#authorship">authorship</a>, <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, <a href="#bookhistory">book history</a>, and reading.  Exhibits may be permanent or rotated periodically, depending on the availability of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> suitable for display and the policy of the library.
