Also refers to the event during which such objects are displayed.  <a href="http://www.loc.gov/exhibits/">Click here</a> to connect to a list of <a href="#online">online</a> exhibits sponsored by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  Synonymous with <em>exhibition</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#displaycase">display case</a> and <a href="#exhibitcatalog">exhibit catalog</a>.
<p>
Also, a booth or table at which a book <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, or <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>, or a library <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> or <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>, displays its products and services at a <a href="#libconference">conference</a> to attract prospective customers.  Companies and organizations that lease exhibit space are called <em>exhibitors</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#displaycopy">display copy</a> and <a href="#ert">Exhibits Round Table</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exhibitcase"><b>exhibit case</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#displaycase">display case</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exhibitcatalog"><b>exhibit catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#artbook">art book</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hard</a> or <a href="#softcover">softcover</a>, containing <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>s of the <a href="#work">work</a>s of art displayed in an <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ion or series of exhibitions held at a museum or gallery.  The <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s are usually <a href="#number">number</a>ed and may be arranged in the order in which the items are exhibited, with or without prices.  Accompanying <a href="#text">text</a> may be minimal.  Exhibit catalogs are often <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by <a href="#museumpublisher">museum publisher</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>exhibition catalog</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ert"><b>Exhibits Round Table (ERT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A permanent <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>ERT</b> provides a venue for cooperation between the Association and exhibitors, with the aim of making <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>s an effective part of state, regional, and national <a href="#libconference">library conference</a>s.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/rtables/ert/">Click here </a> to connect to the <b>ERT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exit"><b>exit</b></a>
</dt><dd>A door or set of doors through which <a href="#patron">patron</a>s are permitted to leave a <a href="#library">library</a> facility under normal conditions, usually located near the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> and equipped with a <a href="#securitysystem">security alarm</a> to detect unauthorized removal of <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a>.  In the United States, special <em>emergency exit</em>s are required by law in libraries open to the public.  
<p>
Also, to end a session using a computer <a href="#application">application</a> by closing the <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>.  The procedure for ending a session on the computer itself is called <a href="#logoff">logging off</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exitinterview"><b>exit interview</b></a>
</dt><dd>An interview conducted by a personnel director, or some other
person designated by management, at the time an employee leaves
employment (voluntarily or involuntarily), usually to determine the
reason(s) for leaving, in particular whether separation is the result
of grievances that might have been resolved or prevented. For retirees,
the interview also provides a final opportunity to discuss with the
employer matters concerning pension, health insurance, etc. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exlibrary"><b>ex-library copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> once owned by a <a href="#library">library</a> and subsequently acquired by a <a href="#dealer">dealer</a> in <a href="#usedbook">used book</a>s, usually identified by an <a href="#ownershipmark">ownership mark</a>, <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a>, or <a href="#spinelabel">spine label</a>.  An ex-library copy may also show signs of heavy use.  <a href="#condition">Condition</a> may reduce its value to collectors.  If not <a href="#rubberstamp">stamp</a>ed "<a href="#discard">discard</a>," the <a href="#volume">volume</a> may still belong to the library.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>ex-lib</em> or <em>x-lib</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exlibris"><b><em>ex libris</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A Latin phrase meaning, "From the books of..." <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a <a href="#bookplate">bookplate</a> followed by a blank space for the owner's name.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>ex lib.</em> 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exotics"><b>exotics</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#printing">printing</a> trade, a general term for non-Latin <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>s (Arabic, Chinese, Cyrillic, Hebrew, Japanese, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="expanded"><b>expanded</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> wider in proportion to its height than the normal version of the same style.  The opposite of <a href="#condensed">condensed</a>.  Synonymous with <em>extended</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="expandededition"><b>expanded edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>A previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a> enlarged by the addition of a significant amount of new material, sometimes in the form of at least one <a href="#supplement">supplement</a> or <a href="#appendix">appendix</a>, with little or no revision of the existing <a href="#text">text</a>.  Compare with <a href="#revisededition">revised edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="expansion"><b>expansion</b></a>
</dt><dd>Enlargement of the space available in an existing <a href="#library">library</a>
facility. The amount of floor space in a library is usually increased
by moving non-library functions such as a computer lab or offices to
other facilities, or by adding a new wing or floor to the existing
structure. Some libraries are designed with a knock-out wall and sited
on property large enough to accommodate future expansion. In libraries
critically short of space, a new addition may dwarf the original
structure. Major library expansions are reported <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly in <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em> and in the <b><em>Bowker Annual Library and Book Trade Almanac</em></b>.  Compare with <a href="#renovation">renovation</a> and <a href="#newconstruc">new construction</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the development of an existing <a href="#class">class</a> or <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a> in the <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a>s or <a href="#table">table</a>s of the <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, usually to accommodate advances in the <a href="#literature">literature</a> on the <a href="#subject">subject</a> which require more specific <a href="#notation">notation</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="expertsystem"><b>expert system (ES)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#application">application</a> or system based on <a href="#artificial">artificial intelligence</a>,
designed to replicate the ability of a human expert to solve a problem
or perform a specific task or sequence of tasks, for example, financial
analysis and forecasting. Expert systems require a knowledge base, a
facts base, and a rules base. In the plural, the <a href="#term">term</a> refers to the science of creating such systems.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="expertuser"><b>expert user</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person with sufficient <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> and experience to be able to use a <a href="#library">library</a> or computer system effectively and efficiently, with only occasional assistance.  The opposite of <a href="#novice">novice</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="expirationdate"><b>expiration date</b></a>
</dt><dd>The date on which delivery of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> ceases if <a href="#subscripprice">payment</a> is not received from the <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a> in response to a final <a href="#renewalnotice">renewal notice</a>.  Also, the date after which a <a href="#library">library</a> is no longer eligible to receive a <a href="#prepubprice">prepublication price</a>, special <a href="#discount">discount</a>, or other promotional incentive for ordering an item.  Also, the date after which a <a href="#librarycard">library card</a>, <a href="#password">password</a>, membership, <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#licensing">license</a>, <a href="#document">document</a>, etc., is no longer valid.  Synonymous with <em>expiry date</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="explanatoryref"><b>explanatory reference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a> provided in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#index">index</a> when more <a href="#information">information</a> is required than is normally given in a <em><a href="#see">see</a></em> or <em><a href="#seealso">see also</a></em> reference.
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dl><dt><em>For example</em>:
</dt><dl><dt></dt><dd>Klama, John
<dl><dt></dt><dd>The <a href="#pseudonym">joint pseudonym</a> of John Durant, Peter Klopfer, and Susan Oyama.</dd></dl>
</dd><dd>For separate <a href="#work">work</a>s entered under each name see
<dl><dt></dt><dd>Durant, John
</dd><dd>Klopfer, Peter
</dd><dd>Oyama, Susan</dd></dl></dd></dl></dl></dl> 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="explication"><b>explication</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#criticism">critical analysis</a> requiring close examination of the <a href="#language">language</a>, style, <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ism, and structure of a <a href="#literarywork">literary</a> <a href="#text">text</a>, intended to provide a clear and detailed exposition of its meaning and significance.  Examples can be found in the literary <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <b><em>The Explicator</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="explicit"><b>explicit</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin phrase <em>Explicitus est liber</em> meaning "it is unrolled to the end" originally used to signify the end of a <a href="#text">text</a> written on a continuous <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a> or <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> <a href="#scroll">scroll</a> or <a href="#volumen">volumen</a>.  The expression continued to be used in <a href="#codex">codex</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s to indicate the end of the <a href="#work">work</a> or the conclusion of one of its major divisions.  The explicit sometimes included the <a href="#author">author</a>'s name and <a href="#title">title</a> of work, but more often the <a href="#placeofpublication">place</a> and <a href="#publicationdate">date of publication</a>, and name of <a href="#printer">printer</a>.  Compare with <a href="#incipit">incipit</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#colophon">colophon</a> and <a href="#finis">finis</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="export"><b>export</b></a>
</dt><dd>To send <a href="#data">data</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a> from one <a href="#application">application</a> or computer system to another, usually by means of a specific command, for example, <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s retrieved from an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> to an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> <a href="#emailaddress">address</a> or <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> (usually <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>).  The export process may require the <a href="#dataconversion">conversion</a> of <a href="#data">data</a> into a format <a href="#compatibility">compatible</a>
with the receiving application or system. Most applications have the
capacity to convert a variety of popular formats. The opposite of <a href="#import">import</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="exportedition"><b>export edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> prepared by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> specifically for <a href="#distributor">distribution</a> and sale in another country (or countries).  Compare with <a href="#coedition">co-edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="expression"><b>expression</b></a>
</dt><dd>As defined in <em><a href="#frbr">FRBR</a></em> (<em>Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records</em>), the form in which a creative <a href="#work">work</a> is realized, for example, a single <a href="#variant">variant</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> (Shakespeare's <b><em>Hamlet</em></b>), or a <a href="#composer">composer</a>'s <a href="#score">score</a> or a specific performance of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> (original Broadway production of <b><em>West Side Story</em></b>).  Any alteration of the intellectual or artistic <a href="#content">content</a> of a work (<a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>, <a href="#adaptation">adaptation</a>, <a href="#revision">revision</a>, <a href="#translation">translation</a>, etc.) produces a new expression.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is abstract in the sense of excluding aspects of physical form not essential to the intellectual/artistic content, such as the <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>, <a href="#typesize">type size</a>, and <a href="#page">page</a> <a href="#layout">layout</a> used in <a href="#printing">printing</a> the words and sentences of a written work.  Compare with <a href="#manifestation">manifestation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="expressivenotation"><b>expressive notation</b></a>
</dt><dd>In some <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>s, the structure of the <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s, and/or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s used to indicate the <a href="#class">class</a>es is designed to show the <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> position or <a href="#facet">facet</a>s of each class and <a href="#subclass">subclass</a>.  For example, in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the successive <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a>s of a class are indicated by <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s and <a href="#decimalpoint">decimal</a> fractions.  In the DDC <a href="#notation">notation</a> <b>782.42</b>, assigned to the <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#title">title</a>d <em>Broadway Love Songs</em>, <b>700</b> indicates that the <a href="#work">work</a> is about a <a href="#topic">topic</a> in the <em>the arts</em>, <b>780</b> that it concerns <em>music</em>, <b>782</b> <em>vocal music</em>, and the decimal fraction <b>.42</b> <em>songs</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="expurgated"><b>expurgated</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#edition">edition</a> from which portions have been deleted ("purged") usually to satisfy moral or political objections, an alternative to <a href="#banned">banning</a> the <a href="#work">work</a> completely from <a href="#publication">publication</a> or <a href="#distributor">distribution</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#unexpurgated">unexpurgated</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#bowdlerize">bowdlerize</a> and <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extended"><b>extended</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#expanded">expanded</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extendedbinding"><b>extended binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the front and back <a href="#cover">cover</a>s extend beyond the <a href="#trimmed">trimmed</a> edges of the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> it encloses.  Compare with <a href="#flushbinding">flush binding</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#squares">squares</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extendedcover"><b>extended cover</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#extendedbinding">extended binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extendedoffer"><b>extended offer</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, an <a href="#introductoryoffer">introductory offer</a> or <a href="#prepubprice">prepublication price</a> continued beyond the originally announced <a href="#expirationdate">expiration date</a>, usually in response to strong <a href="#demand">demand</a>.  Sometimes a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> <a href="#reissue">reissue</a>s an entire sale <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> with an extended expiration date. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="xml"><b>Extensible Markup Language (XML)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#subset">subset</a> of the <a href="#sgml">SGML</a> language in which <a href="#tag">tag</a>s, similar to those used in <a href="#html">HTML</a>, define the kind of <a href="#information">information</a> contained in a <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a> (<em>i.e.</em>, product number, price, etc.), rather than how it is displayed.  "Extensible" means that in <b>XML</b> tags are not limited and predefined as they are in HTML, but must be created and defined by the person producing the <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>.  <b>XML</b> can be used with HTML in the same <a href="#www">Web</a> <a href="#document">document</a>.  The most elaborate <b>XML</b> vocabularies are those developed to support business-to-business transactions.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extension"><b>extension</b></a>
</dt><dd>A three- or four-<a href="#character">character</a> code added to a <a href="#filename">filename</a> following a <a href="#period">period</a> (full stop) to indicate <a href="#filetype">file type</a>, for example, <b>.txt</b> to indicate a <a href="#file">file</a> in plain <a href="#ascii">ASCII</a> <a href="#text">text</a>, <b>.doc</b> for a <a href="#document">document</a> file created in MS-Word, or <b>.html</b> for a file in <a href="#html">HTML</a> script.  For a more complete list of extensions, see <em><a href="http://whatis.techtarget.com/fileFormatA/0,289933,sid9,00.html">Every File Format in the World</a></em> from <b>whatis?com</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extent"><b>extent</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> <a href="#term">term</a> for the length of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> expressed as the total <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#page">page</a>s.  <a href="#typesize">Type size</a> and width of <a href="#margin">margin</a>s can be manipulated by the <a href="#typography">typographer</a> to make a <a href="#work">work</a> appear longer or shorter than it actually is.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, number of pages is given in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>.  In a more general sense, the length of any <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>, <a href="#print">print</a> or <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#extentofitem">extent of item</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extentofitem"><b>extent of item</b></a>
</dt><dd>The first <a href="#element">element</a> in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> (<a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#field">field</a> 300) of a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, giving in <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s the number of physical units of which the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is comprised, the <a href="#specificmaterial">specific material designation</a>, and any other details of <a href="#extent">extent</a>, such as <a href="#playingtime">playing time</a> in the case of <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>s, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, and <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="externaldecoder"><b>external decoder</b></a>
</dt><dd>An electronic <a href="#device">device</a> that connects one or more <a href="#barcode">barcode</a> <a href="#scanner">scanner</a>s by cable to a computer or computer system, and translates <a href="#input">input</a> from the scanner into <a href="#digital">digital</a> signals that can be processed by the computer.  Some barcode scanners come with a built-in decoder.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extract"><b>extract</b></a>
</dt><dd>One or more lengthy <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s from a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#work">work</a>, set within the main <a href="#text">text</a> of another work, usually <a href="#indention">indented</a> and sometimes <a href="#printing">printed</a> in distinguishing <a href="#type">type</a>.  When printed in the same <a href="#typesize">type size</a> as the text and without indention, an extract is enclosed in <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> marks, and preceded and followed by a <a href="#blank">blank</a>
line. In a more general sense, any piece taken from one work and used
in another, sometimes to represent the whole, as in a scene from a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> used in a <a href="#trailer">trailer</a>.  Compare with <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extracttype"><b>extract type</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#note">note</a>s and lengthy <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s or <a href="#extract">extract</a>s are distinguished from the <a href="#body">body</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a> by <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> them in a smaller <a href="#typesize">size</a> of the same <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>.  Compare with <a href="#texttype">text type</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#displaytype">display type</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extraillustrated"><b>extra-illustrated</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#volume">volume</a> into which additional <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> and sometimes <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a> has been <a href="#insert">insert</a>ed, not part of the <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#asissued">as issued</a>.  Synonymous with <em>privately illustrated</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#grangerized">grangerized</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extranet"><b>extranet</b></a>
</dt><dd>A private computer <a href="#network">network</a> designed to serve the employees of a company or members of an organization (as in an <a href="#intranet">intranet</a>), and also to provide various levels of <a href="#accessibility">accessibility</a> to selected persons <em>outside</em>
the organization (business partners, customers, clients, etc.), but not
the general public. When transmission occurs over public <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> channels (the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>), the system is <a href="#password">password</a>ed to exclude un<a href="#authorization">authorized</a> users.  Services may be <a href="#feebased">fee-based</a> or offered at no charge.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="extrapolation"><b>extrapolation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The addition of one or more new <a href="#subject">subject</a>s at the end of an <a href="#array">array</a> in a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, based on a shared <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a> or characteristics.  Compare with <a href="#interpolation">interpolation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ezine"><b>e-zine</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicmagazine">electronic magazine</a>.  
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>

| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="F">F</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="fable"><b>fable</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#fiction">fictitious</a> story which uses animal <a href="#character">character</a>s to express or teach a moral lesson (example:  <b><em>Animal Farm</em></b> by George Orwell).  Compare with <a href="#bestiary">bestiary</a>.   <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#allegory">allegory</a> and <a href="#parable">parable</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fabliau"><b>fabliau</b></a>
</dt><dd>In medieval <a href="#literature">literature</a> written in
old French, a humorous metrical story told in eight-syllable lines that
relates incidents of ordinary life in a realistic style, and at the
same time conveys a moral message. <em>Fabliaux</em> often <a href="#satire">satirize</a>
the faults of clergymen or other prominent persons, or the foibles of
ordinary people. They can be broadly humorous, as in some of Chaucer's <b><em>Canterbury Tales</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="face"><b>face</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the outside of the front <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the raised surface of a unit of metal <a href="#type">type</a>, from which the <a href="#impression">impression</a> of a single <a href="#character">character</a> is taken in <a href="#printing">printing</a>.  Also used as an <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the unbroken front of a single-sided <a href="#bookcase">bookcase</a> or shelving unit, or one side of a double-sided bookcase or shelving unit, or <a href="#range">range</a> of double-sided units.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="faceout"><b>face out</b></a>
</dt><dd>Placement of a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> on end with the front <a href="#cover">cover</a> forward, usually to attract <a href="#browser">browser</a>s to a <a href="#library">library</a> display or <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>, or to encourage sales in a retail outlet.  In some libraries, <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s are displayed on sloping shelves designed to allow the front covers to face forward.  Compare with <a href="#spineout">spine-out</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facet"><b>facet</b></a>
</dt><dd>The entire set of <a href="#class">subclass</a>es generated when a <a href="#class">class</a> representing a <a href="#subject">subject</a> in a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> is divided according to a single <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>.  The number of subclasses depends on the specific characteristic applied.  In his <em><a href="#colonclassification">Colon Classification</a></em>, <a href="#ranganathan">S. R. Ranganathan</a> identified five categories of facet recognizable in any <a href="#class">class</a>:  personality, matter, energy, space, and time.  In a more general sense, any one of several distinct aspects of a subject.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facetanalysis"><b>facet analysis</b></a>
</dt><dd>Examination of the various aspects of a <a href="#subject">subject</a> to identify the basic <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>s by which it can be divided into <a href="#class">subclass</a>es, the first step in developing a <a href="#facetedclassification">faceted</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facetedclassification"><b>faceted classification</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> developed through <a href="#facetanalysis">analysis</a> of the fundamental <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>s of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s, by which they can be divided into <a href="#class">subclass</a>es. <a href="#ranganathan">S. R. Ranganathan</a> identified five basic characteristics in his <em><a href="#colonclassification">Colon Classification</a></em>:  personality, matter, energy, space, and time.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facetedinitial"><b>faceted initial</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a> in an <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, drawn to appear as if cut like a gemstone into a number of flat geometric surfaces.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facetednotation"><b>faceted notation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#notation">notation</a> in which the <a href="#facet">facet</a>s of a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> are indicated by <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s, for example, the colon in <a href="#ranganathan">S. R. Ranganathan</a>'s <em>Colon Classification</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facetia"><b>facetiae</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#jestbook">jestbook</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="faceup"><b>face up</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the position of a <a href="#fullpage">full-page</a> <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> printed on the <a href="#recto">recto</a> of a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> so that it appears on the right-hand side of the <a href="#opening">opening</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  Compare with <a href="#doublespread">double spread</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facilitator"><b>facilitator</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who makes it easier for others to do their work and accomplish their <a href="#goal">goal</a>s.  Ideally, a <a href="#librarydirector">library director</a> should facilitate the work of <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>
under his or her supervision. Also refers to a person with exceptional
communication skills, selected to lead the discussion at a <a href="#conference">conference</a> or <a href="#workshop">workshop</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facsimile"><b>facsimile</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> or <a href="#copy">copy</a> intended to simulate as closely as possible the physical appearance of a previous <a href="#work">work</a>.  A facsimile of a handwritten or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#document">document</a> is an exact <a href="#replica">replica</a> of the <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#text">text</a>, without <a href="#reduction">reduction</a> or <a href="#enlargement">enlargement</a>.  A <em>facsimile edition</em> duplicates as closely as possible the appearance and <a href="#content">content</a> of the original <a href="#edition">edition</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>facsim</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#facsimilebinding">facsimile binding</a> and <a href="#facsimilecatalog">facsimile catalog</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facsimilebinding"><b>facsimile binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">binding</a> intended to duplicate as closely as possible the binding on a previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the same <a href="#work">work</a>, or an earlier style of binding typical of the period in which the work was first <a href="#publishing">published</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facsimilecatalog"><b>facsimile catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> that includes in each <a href="#entry">entry</a> a small <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> of the <a href="#picture">picture</a>, <a href="#slide">slide</a>, <a href="#map">map</a>, or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> it represents, usually affixed to or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#catalogcard">card</a>s larger than standard size, or on <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s of heavy <a href="#paper">paper</a> filed in a <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> or other type of <a href="#binder">binder</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facsimileedition"><b>facsimile edition</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#facsimile">facsimile</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facsimilereprint"><b>facsimile reprint</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#typefacsimile">type facsimile</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facsimiletrans"><b>facsimile transmission (FAX)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The transfer, over telephone lines, of <a href="#text">text</a> and/or images <a href="#printing">printed</a> or handwritten on a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, producing <a href="#output">output</a> that is an exact <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> of the <a href="#original">original</a>.  The method requires a <em>FAX machine</em> at the each location (sending and receiving), consisting of a <a href="#scanner">scanner</a>, <a href="#printer">printer</a>, and <a href="#modem">modem</a> with a <a href="#dedicatedline">dedicated line</a> and FAX number.  Transmission speed depends on the <a href="#standard">standard</a> of the sending machine, with Group 3 (9600 <a href="#bit">bit</a>s per second) the most common.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="factotum"><b>factotum</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printersornament">printer's ornament</a> in wood or metal, designed with a space in the center, into which a unit of <a href="#type">type</a> bearing any <a href="#letter">letter</a> of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> can be inserted to <a href="#printing">print</a> a large <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a> at the beginning of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>.  In early <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <em>factotum initials</em> were usually decorated.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="facultystatus"><b>faculty status</b></a>
</dt><dd>Official recognition by a college or university that the <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s in its employ are considered members of the <a href="#libraryfaculty">faculty</a>, with <a href="#rank">rank</a>s, <a href="#title">title</a>s, rights, and <a href="#benefits">benefits</a> equivalent to those of teaching faculty, including <a href="#tenure">tenure</a>, <a href="#promotion">promotion</a>, and the right to participate in <a href="#governance">governance</a>.  Compare with <a href="#acadstatus">academic status</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="faflrt1"><b>FAFLRT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#faflrt"><b>F</b>ederal and <b>A</b>rmed <b>F</b>orces <b>L</b>ibraries <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="faircopy"><b>fair copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the final version of the <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#typescript">typescript</a> of an <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#work">work</a>, containing few mistakes and no corrections, having been carefully prepared from the final <a href="#draft">draft</a> by the <a href="#author">author</a>, or by a <a href="#copyeditor">copy editor</a>, for the use of the <a href="#printer">printer</a>.  Synonymous with <em>clean copy</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fairuse"><b>fair use</b></a>
</dt><dd>Conditions under which <a href="#copy">copy</a>ing a <a href="#work">work</a>, or a portion of it, does <em>not</em> constitute <a href="#infringement">infringement</a> of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, including copying for purposes of <a href="#criticism">criticism</a>, comment, news reporting, teaching, scholarship, and <a href="#research">research</a>.  <a href="http://fairuse.stanford.edu/">Click here</a> for more <a href="#information">information</a> about <b><em>Copyright &amp; Fair Use</em></b>, provided by the Stanford University Libraries.
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em><b>U.S. Copyright Act:  Fair Use</b>
</em><p>
<em><b>Title 17. Chapter 1. Section 107.</b> Limitations on exclusive rights:  Fair use
</em></p><p>
<em>Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 106 and 106A, the fair
use of a copyrighted work, including such use by reproduction in copies
or phonorecords or by any other means specified by that section, for
purposes such as criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching
(including multiple copies for classroom use), scholarship, or
research, is not an infringement of copyright. In determining whether
the use made of a work in any particular case is fair use the factors
to be considered shall include:
</em></p><p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>(1) the purpose and character of the use,
including whether such use is of a commercial nature or is for
nonprofit educational purposes;
</em></dd><dd><em>(2)  the nature of the copyrighted work;
</em></dd><dd><em>(3)  the amount and substantiality of the portion used in relation to the copyrighted work as a whole; and
</em></dd><dd><em>(4)  the effect of the use upon the potential market for or value of the copyrighted work.</em></dd></dl><em>  
</em><p>
<em>The fact that a work is unpublished shall not itself bar a finding
of fair use if such finding is made upon consideration of all the above
factors.</em></p></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fairytale"><b>fairy tale</b></a>
</dt><dd>A fanciful story, written for or told to children, usually
containing at least one supernatural element (magic, dragons, elves,
ghosts, hobgoblins, witches, etc.) affecting adults and children,
animals, and/or inanimate objects. Most fairy <a href="#tale">tale</a>s are based on the traditional <a href="#folklore">folklore</a> of a specific culture.  Some are didactic (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Three Little Pigs</em></b>).  Often <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> <a href="#collection">collection</a>s, fairy tales are usually shelved in the <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a> of a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> or in the <a href="#curriculumroom">curriculum room</a> of an <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a>.  Compare with <a href="#folktale">folktale</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="falsebands"><b>false bands</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#raisedbands">raised bands</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="falsedate"><b>false date</b></a>
</dt><dd>A date such as a <a href="#birthdeath">birth or death date</a> or <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> given incorrectly, whether intentionally or inadvertently.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the correct date is <a href="#interpolation">interpolated</a> in <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s following the incorrect date in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>1950 [1952]</b>) .
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="falsedrop"><b>false drop</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> retrieved in a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> <a href="#search">search</a>, which is unrelated to the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the search, usually because it meets the <a href="#syntax">syntactic</a> requirements of the <a href="#query">query</a>, but not its <a href="#semantics">semantic</a> requirements.  False drops generally occur when meaning is contingent on the order of <a href="#searchterm">search term</a>s (library + school retrieves "library school" and "school library") or when a <a href="#term">term</a> used in a <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a> has more than one meaning.  For example, a search on the keyword "aids" will retrieve records for <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s about HIV infection, and also items about <em>hearing aids</em>, <em>teaching aids</em>, <em>band-aids</em>, etc.  To avoid this problem, a <a href="#parenthetical">qualifier</a> such as "disease" must be added to the <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a> to make retrieval more <a href="#precision">precise</a>.  Synonymous with <em>false combination</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#semanticfactoring">semantic factoring</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="falseimprint"><b>false imprint</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#fictitiousimprint">fictitious imprint</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="family"><b>family</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#typefamily">type family</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="familyname"><b>family name</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#surname">surname</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fan"><b>fan</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> at only one point, usually one of the four <a href="#corner">corner</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fancytype"><b>fancy type</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a general term for decorative <a href="#type">type</a> in any <a href="#typesize">size</a>, used mainly for <a href="#displaytype">display</a> purposes (ornamental <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s, <a href="#chapterheading">chapter heading</a>s, etc.). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fantasy"><b>fantasy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A highly imaginative <a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>, <a href="#poetry">poem</a>,
etc., in which the action occurs in an unreal and nonexistant time
and/or place outside the realm of possibility. Examples include <b><em>Alice's Adventures in Wonderland</em></b> and <b><em>Through the Looking Glass</em></b> by Lewis Carroll and <b><em>The Hobbit</em></b> and <b><em>The Lord of the Rings</em></b> by J. R. R. Tolkien.  Also refers to <a href="#genre">genre</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> in which the writer's imagination is not constrained by the limitations of conventional reality.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#sciencefiction">science fiction</a> and <a href="#utopia">utopia</a>n literature.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="faq"><b>FAQ</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>F</b>requently <b>A</b>sked <b>Q</b>uestions, a <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#file">file</a> available <a href="#online">online</a> or in <a href="#print">print</a>, containing answers to commonly asked questions about a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a>, that serves as a mini-help file for inexperienced users of a computer system or <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>.  Usually maintained by one or more persons who have an active interest in the <a href="#subject">subject</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="farce"><b>farce</b></a>
</dt><dd>A light, boisterous form of <a href="#comedy">comedy</a> in which the <a href="#character">character</a>s
are exaggerated stereotypes, the action improbable to the point of
being ludicrous, and the verbal and visual humor lacking in subtlety (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Charley's Aunt</em></b> by Brandon Thomas).  Farce bears the same relationship to "high" comedy as <a href="#melodrama">melodrama</a> to <a href="#tragedy">tragedy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="farrago"><b>farrago</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#literature">literature</a>, an unorganized mixture ("hodgepodge") of humorous <a href="#prose">prose</a> and light <a href="#verse">verse</a>.  Also used in the <a href="#context">context</a> of vaudeville and musical theater to indicate a disjointed medley of tunes, dramatic skits, and <a href="#comedy">comedy</a> routines.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fascicle"><b>fascicle</b></a>
</dt><dd>For convenience in <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> or <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is sometimes <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#number">number</a>ed or unnumbered <a href="#installment">installment</a>s, each of which is incomplete and does not necessarily coincide with any formal division of the <a href="#work">work</a>.  Usually issued in <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#wrapper">wrapper</a>s, fascicles may eventually be bound together in correct sequence to form a complete <a href="#volume">volume</a> or uniform <a href="#set">set</a> of volumes (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Middle English Dictionary</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the University of Michigan Press).  They differ from <a href="#part">part</a>s in being temporary rather than permanent.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>fasc.</em>  Synonymous with <em>fascicule</em> and <em>fasciculus</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fascicule"><b>fascicule</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#fascicle">fascicle</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fatface"><b>fat face</b></a>
</dt><dd>A novelty <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> in which the degree of contrast between the thick and thin strokes of each <a href="#character">character</a> is highly exaggerated. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fatmatter"><b>fat matter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printer">printer</a>'s term for <a href="#copy">copy</a> that does not take long to <a href="#typesetting">set</a> because it contains a high proportion of <a href="#whitespace">white space</a>, for example, extended passages of <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> in a <a href="#work">work</a> of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#leanmatter">lean matter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fax"><b>FAX</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#facsimiletrans">facsimile transmission</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="faxon"><b>FAXON</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial company that provides <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> management services to <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#information">information</a> centers.  <a href="http://www.faxon.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>FAXON</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agency</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fdlp1"><b>FDLP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#fdlp"><b>F</b>ederal <b>D</b>epository <b>L</b>ibrary <b>P</b>rogram</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="feasibilitystudy"><b>feasibility study</b></a>
</dt><dd>A preliminary investigation and report on a proposed policy,
project, or plan to ascertain if it can be successfully carried out,
for example, to determine if a <a href="#library">library</a> building can be constructed on a particular site.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="feature"><b>feature</b></a>
</dt><dd>A comparatively long <a href="#article">article</a> in a <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> or <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, given special emphasis by the <a href="#editor">editor</a>(s) or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, as opposed to a short article, regular <a href="#column">column</a>, or <a href="#editorial">editorial</a>.  In magazines, the article <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> on the front <a href="#cover">cover</a> is called the <a href="#coverstory">cover story</a>.  Other feature stories in the same <a href="#issue">issue</a> may also be noted on the front cover, usually by <a href="#subject">subject</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="featurefilm"><b>feature film</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> in which the <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> and <a href="#character">character</a>s are largely <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>al, although the <a href="#plot">plot</a> may be derived from a true story.  Feature <a href="#film">film</a>s vary in length, but most are at least 90 minutes long.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> that <a href="#circulationdesk">circulate</a> feature films usually make them available on <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a> or <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>.  Compare with <a href="#documentary">documentary</a> and <a href="#shortfilm">short film</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#director">director</a>, <a href="#performer">performer</a>, and <a href="#credit">credit</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="faflrt"><b>Federal and Armed Forces Libraries Round Table (FAFLRT)</b></a> 
</dt><dd>A <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>FAFLRT</b> is dedicated to promoting <a href="#library">library</a> and <a href="#information">information</a>
services and the LIS profession within the U.S. federal
government/military community, to encouraging appropriate utilization
of federal and military library and information facilities and
resources, and to stimulating <a href="#research">research</a> and development related to the planning, development, and operation of <a href="#federallibrary">federal</a> and <a href="#militarylibrary">military libraries</a>.  <b>FAFLRT</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/rtables/faflrt/">Federal and Armed Forces Libraries</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/rtables/flrt/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>FAFLRT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fdlp"><b>Federal Depository Library Program (FDLP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established by Congress as part of the Printing Act of 1895 to assure that the American public has <a href="#access">access</a> to federal government <a href="#information">information</a>, <b>FDLP</b> provides <a href="#copy">copies</a> of federal <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> without charge to designated <a href="#depository">depository libraries</a>
in the United States (and its territories) which provide unrestricted
access and professional assistance at no charge to the user. There are
currently about 1,350 depository <a href="#library">libraries</a>, some receiving less than the full complement of available <a href="#publication">publication</a>s.  The <b>FDLP</b> also funds free <a href="#online">online</a> public access to government information via <em><a href="#gpoaccess">GPO Access</a></em>.  The Public Printer and <a href="#superintendent">Superintendent of Documents</a> are advised on policy matters concerning the <b>FDLP</b> by the Depository Library Council (DLC) established in 1972.  <a href="http://www.access.gpo.gov/su_docs/fdlp/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>FDLP</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="federallibrary"><b>federal library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> owned and operated by the federal government of the United States, usually containing a <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> pertaining to the field(s) it is mandated to cover.  The largest are the  <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>, the <a href="#nlm">National Library of Medicine</a>, the <a href="#nle">National Library of Education</a>, and the <a href="#nal">National Agricultural Library</a>.  The Federal Library and Information Center Committee (FLICC) of the Library of Congress has provided the <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/flicc/">FEDLINK</a> guide to federal libraries since 1965.  Federal <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s are organized in the <a href="#faflrt">Federal and Armed Forces Libraries Round Table</a> (FAFLRT) of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flicc"><b>Federal Library and Information Center Committee (FLICC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Created in 1965 as the Federal Library Committee, <b>FLICC</b> is composed of the directors of the four <a href="#nationallib">national libraries</a> (<a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>, <a href="#nlm">National Library of Medicine</a>, <a href="#nle">National Library of Education</a>, and <a href="#nal">National Agriculture Library</a>) and representatives of cabinet-level executive departments and federal <a href="#govtagency">agencies</a> with major <a href="#library">library</a> programs, chaired by the <a href="#librariancongress">Librarian of Congress</a>.  
<p>
The <a href="#mission">mission</a> of <b>FLICC</b> is to enhance utilization of <a href="#federallibrary">federal library</a> and <a href="#information">information</a> center resources and facilities through <a href="#profdevel">professional development</a>, <a href="#publicity">publicity</a>, and coordination.  <b>FLICC</b>
is also responsible for recommending policies, programs, and procedures
to federal agencies concerning libraries and information resources, and
for providing guidance and direction for the Federal Library and
Information Network (<a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/flicc/">FEDLINK</a>), the purchasing, training, and <a href="#resourcesharing">resource sharing</a> <a href="#consortium">consortium</a> of federal libraries and information centers.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/flicc/mmabout.html">Click here</a> to learn more about the <b>FLICC</b> and <b>FEDLINK</b>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fedlink"><b>FEDLINK</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#flicc"><b>F</b>ederal <b>L</b>ibrary and <b>I</b>nformation <b>C</b>enter <b>C</b>ommittee</a> (FLICC).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fee"><b>fee</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sum of money paid for a service. The amount may be fixed,
depending on type of service, or variable depending on the amount of
time required to perform the service. In some <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery service</a> is a <a href="#feebased">fee-based</a>.  Fees may also charged for the use of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in <a href="#rentalcollec">rental collection</a>s, but for the most part libraries in the United States are committed to offering basic services at no charge to their <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>.  Persons who live outside a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>'s service area, or who are not faculty or students entitled to use the resources and services of an <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a>, may be charged a fee for limited <a href="#borrowingprivileges">borrowing privileges</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#copyrightfee">copyright fee</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="feebased"><b>fee-based service</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#information">information</a> service provided by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#informationbroker">information broker</a> in exchange for monetary payment.  In most <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> in the United States, <a href="#fee">fee</a>-based services are limited to <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery</a> and <a href="#rentalcollec">rental collection</a>s, provided on a <a href="#costrecovery">cost-recovery</a> basis.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="feedback"><b>feedback</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, <a href="#output">output</a> put back into the same system as <a href="#input">input</a> to achieve a degree of self-regulation.  In <a href="#library">library</a> operations, the views (solicited or unsolicited) of the users of a resource or service concerning its <a href="#qualityofservice">quality</a> and/or usefulness, whether positive or negative.  Libraries rely on <a href="#usersurvey">user survey</a>s and the <a href="#suggestionbox">suggestion box</a> to obtain feedback from <a href="#patron">patron</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="feint"><b>feint</b></a>
</dt><dd>Parallel horizontal lines drawn lightly with a ruler or <a href="#printing">printed</a> in light-colored <a href="#ink">ink</a> across a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> or <a href="#page">page</a>, as in an account <a href="#book">book</a> to keep entries separate, or in a medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> to guide the hand of the <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="feltboard"><b>feltboard </b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#flannelboard">flannel board</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ftf"><b>Feminist Task Force (FTF)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1970 as a <a href="#taskforce">task force</a> of the <a href="#srrt">Social Responsibilities Round Table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Libraries Association</a>, <b>FTF</b> focuses on women's issues, including sexism in <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>.  <b>FTF</b> hosts an electronic <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a> and <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em><a href="http://www.wtamu.edu/wil/">Women in Libraries</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.lib.wayne.edu/ftf/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>FTF</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ferrotype"><b>ferrotype</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#tintype">tintype</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="festschrift"><b>Festschrift</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the German words <em>Fest</em> ("festival") and <em>Schrift</em> ("writing").  A memorial <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually in the form of a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#essay">essay</a>s or speeches by distinguished persons, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in honor of a scholarly person or <a href="#society">society</a>, sometimes on the occasion of an anniversary, birthday, or retirement celebration.  The <a href="#subject">subject</a> or theme encompassing the collected <a href="#work">work</a>s is usually related to the <a href="#field">field</a> in which the person (or organization) achieved distinction.  The <a href="#contributor">contributor</a>s are often friends, colleagues, and former students of the person (or entity) honored.  Plural:  <em>Festschriften</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fiaf1"><b>FIAF</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#fiaf">International Federation of Film Archives</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fiberboard"><b>fiberboard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A very rigid form of paperboard made from heavily pressed sheets of <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>ed vegetable fiber, laminated together.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fibercontent"><b>fiber content</b></a>
</dt><dd>A statement of the various kinds of fiber present in a material manufactured from fiber (<a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#board">board</a>, <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>, <a href="#thread">thread</a>), usually expressed in percentages to indicate relative proportions, important <a href="#information">information</a> because type of fiber affects the properties of a product, for example, its color, chemical stability, strength, and <a href="#durability">durability</a>.  Synonymous with <em>fiber composition</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fiberoptics"><b>fiber optics</b></a>
</dt><dd>The high-speed transmission of <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#encoding">encoded</a> in pulses of laser light via cable constructed of <a href="#opticalfiber">optical fiber</a>, a technology that revolutionized the <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> industry in the late 20th century, making it possible to interconnect computers large and small in a worldwide <a href="#network">network</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fiche"><b>fiche</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>.
<p>

</p></dd><dt><a name="fiction"><b>fiction</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>fictio</em> meaning to "make" or "counterfeit."  <a href="#literarywork">Literary work</a>s in <a href="#prose">prose</a>, portraying <a href="#character">character</a>s and events created in the imagination of the writer, intended to entertain and vicariously expand the <a href="#reader">reader</a>'s experience of life.  In <a href="#historicalfiction">historical fiction</a>, <a href="#character">character</a>s and events usually bear some relationship to what actually happened, but any <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> is reconstructed or imagined by the  <a href="#author">author</a>.
All fiction is fictitious in the sense of being invented, but good
fiction remains "true to life." In the Western tradition, the
traditional forms of literary fiction include the <a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#novelette">novelette</a>, and <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>.  Compare with <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#genre">genre</a>, <a href="#popularfiction">popular fiction</a>, and <a href="#pulpfiction">pulp fiction</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dd>In <a href="#library">libraries</a> that use <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a>, fiction is shelved in the P's, the section for <a href="#language">language</a> and <a href="#literature">literature</a>, subdivided by language.  To locate a specific <a href="#work">work</a> of fiction in the <a href="#stacks"> stacks</a>, the <a href="#patron">patron</a> must first look up the LC <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> in the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  In libraries that use <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, long fiction is shelved separately from <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>, <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by last name of <a href="#author">author</a>, to facilitate <a href="#browse">browsing</a>.  In some <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, <a href="#genre">genre</a> fiction is shelved separately from general fiction, usually by category (<a href="#mystery">mystery</a>, <a href="#sciencefiction">science fiction</a>, etc.), sometimes indicated by a <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> <a href="#label">label</a> on the <a href="#spine">spine</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fictitiousimprint"><b>fictitious imprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#imprint">imprint</a> that has no real existence, usually invented to evade legal or other restrictions, avoid charges of <a href="#copyrightpiracy">copyright piracy</a>, or conceal the identity of the <a href="#author">author</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the real imprint, when known, is given following the fictitious one as an <a href="#interpolation">interpolation</a> inside <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s [] in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  Synonymous with <em>false imprint</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="field"><b>field</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a relative location of <a href="#fixedfield">fixed</a> or <a href="#variablefield">variable</a> length in a <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>, reserved for a specific <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a> or group of elements that constitute a single logical category of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, for example, the <a href="#area">area</a> of <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> reserved for <a href="#information">information</a> about the physical characteristics of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  In the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record, each field is indicated by a three-digit <a href="#tag">tag</a>, but in the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog</a> display, textual <a href="#fieldlabel">field label</a>s are provided to assist users in identifying the various categories of description.  
<p>
<a href="#repeatable">Repeatable</a> fields (R) may appear more than once in the same record, for example, there is no restriction on the number of topical <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s (MARC field 650) that may be assigned to a <a href="#work">work</a>.  <a href="#nonrepeatable">Nonrepeatable</a> (NR) fields can be used only once and may be mutually exclusive, for example, the <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a> (field 100) and <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a> main entry (field 130).  Fields for <a href="#area">area</a>s of description containing more than one data element are divided into <a href="#subfield">subfield</a>s.  Only about ten percent of available MARC fields are used in most <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s.  The other ninety percent are used infrequently.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#directory">directory</a>, <a href="#leader">leader</a>, <a href="#variablecontrol">variable control field</a>, and <a href="#variabledata">variable data field</a>.  
</p><p>
In a more general sense, a logical unit of data which, together with other units, comprises a record in a <a href="#database">database</a> or other system of <a href="#recordkeeping">recordkeeping</a>, for example, the name, address, or phone number field of each <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a> in a library's <a href="#patron">patron</a> database.
</p><p>
In <a href="#research">research</a>, a <a href="#subject">subject</a>
or group of related subjects studied in depth, for example,
"anthropometry" in the subdiscipline "physical anthropology" within the
<a href="#discipline">discipline</a> of anthropology.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fieldguide"><b>field guide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#handbook">handbook</a> designed to help readers identify and learn about the flora and/or fauna of a specific geographic area, often <a href="#publishing">published</a> as part of a <a href="#series">series</a>.  The <a href="#content">content</a> of a field guide is usually arranged according to biological <a href="#classification">classification</a>, with each <a href="#entry">entry</a>
describing a single species (or group of closely related species).
Entries typically include the Latin species name, descriptive <a href="#text">text</a>, at least one <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> to facilitate identification, and one or more <a href="#map">map</a>s showing geographic distribution.  Field guides are shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> or the <a href="#circulating">circulating</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, depending on local <a href="#library">library</a> policy. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fieldlabel"><b>field label</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> or descriptive word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> appearing in the <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> display in an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, usually in <a href="#italic">italic</a>s or distinguished <a href="#typography">typographically</a> in some other way, aligned with the left-hand <a href="#margin">margin</a> to indicate the category of <a href="#data">data</a> that follows, for example, <em>Source</em> used in <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#database">database</a>s to indicate the <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a>, <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, and <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s of the <a href="#article">article</a> <a href="#indexing">indexed</a>.  In the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record, a numeric <a href="#tag">tag</a> is used instead of a textual <a href="#label">label</a> to indicate a specific <a href="#field">field</a> of the record. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fieldwork"><b>fieldwork</b></a>
</dt><dd>The gathering of <a href="#information">information</a> or scientific <a href="#data">data</a> about a <a href="#subject">subject</a>
through observation, interviewing, and other methods of direct
investigation, usually conducted in a location closely associated with
the <a href="#topic">topic</a>, as opposed to <a href="#research">research</a>ing the subject in <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, conducting experiments in a laboratory setting, administering mail <a href="#survey">survey</a>s, etc.
<p>
In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the process of locating, identifying, and securing materials for an archival <a href="#collection">collection</a>, including any negotiations required to acquire <a href="#custody">custody</a> if the materials have monetary value.  Also spelled <em> field work</em>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="figure"><b>figure</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#illustration">Illustrative</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> <em>with</em> the <a href="#text">text</a>, rather than separately in the form of <a href="#plate">plate</a>s.  Figures are usually fairly simple <a href="#linedrawing">line drawing</a>s, numbered consecutively in <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s in order of appearance to facilitate reference.  Figures not individually <a href="#caption">caption</a>ed may be listed with captions on a separate <a href="#page">page</a>, usually in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>fig</em>.  Also, synonymous in printing with <em>numeral</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="figureinitial"><b>figure initial</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a> in an <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, elaborately decorated with colorful images of animals, humans, or imaginary beings.  Compare with <a href="#historiated">historiated initial</a> and <a href="#inhabited">inhabited initial</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#foliateinitial">foliate initial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="figspeech"><b>figure of speech</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of expression employed mainly in rhetoric and literary
writing, in which words or entire sentences are used in a way that
deviates from conventional order or literal meaning, to achieve an
unusual or unexpected <a href="#poetry">poetic</a> or aesthetic effect.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#metaphor">metaphor</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="file"><b>file</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#document">document</a>s, usually related in some way, stored together and <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> in a systematic order.  In computing, a collection of structured <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s <a href="#storage">stored</a> as a single entity, or a collection of <a href="#record">record</a>s related by source and/or purpose, stored on a magnetic <a href="#medium">medium</a> (<a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>, <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a>, <a href="#zipdisk">Zip disk</a>, etc.).  <a href="#filetype">File type</a>, indicated by an <a href="#extension">extension</a> on the end of the <a href="#filename">filename</a>, depends on the code in which the data is written (<em>example</em>:  <b>.html</b> for <a href="#html">HTML</a> script). 
<p>
In manual <a href="#data">data</a> systems, the contents of a <a href="#manila">manila</a> file <a href="#folder">folder</a>
or other physical container used to organize documents, usually of a
size and shape designed to fit inside the drawer of a standard-size
filing cabinet or other storage space. Also refers to a collection of <a href="#information">information</a> about a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> or person, for example, a <em>personnel file</em> kept by an employer.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filecopy"><b>file copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a>, <a href="#report">report</a>, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#article">article</a>, etc., kept on <a href="#file">file</a>, usually with related items, for reference or future use.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filename"><b>filename</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief name assigned by a programmer or computer user to a <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a> to identify it for future retrieval.  Filenames usually provide a clue to the <a href="#content">content</a> of the file (<em>example</em>:  <b>resume.txt</b> or <b>home.html</b>).  The three- or four-<a href="#letter">letter</a> <a href="#extension">extension</a> added to the end of a filename indicates <a href="#filetype">file type</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>.txt</b> for a file in <a href="#ascii">ASCII</a> or <b>.html</b> for a file in <a href="#html">Hypertext Markup Language</a>).  Also spelled <em>file name</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filenm"><b>file name</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#filename">filename</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fileserver"><b>file server</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#server">server</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filetype"><b>file type</b></a>
</dt><dd>In electronic <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a>, the type of code in which a <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a> is written, indicated by a three- or four-<a href="#letter">letter</a> <a href="#extension">extension</a> at the end of the <a href="#filename">filename</a> (<em>example</em>: <b>dictionary.html</b> for a file in <a href="#html">HTML</a> script).  Synonymous with <em>file format</em>.  Common file types and their extensions:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><p>
</p><table>
<tbody><tr align="left"><td width="200"><b><em>File Type</em></b></td><td width="100"><b><em>Extension</em></b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400">Plain <a href="#ascii">ASCII</a> <a href="#text">text</a></td><td width="100"><b>.txt</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><a href="#document">Document</a> in <a href="#html">Hypertext Markup Language</a></td><td width="100"><b>.htm</b> or <b>.html</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400">Document in <a href="#sgml">Standard Generalized Markup Language</a></td><td width="100"><b>.sgml</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400">Document in <a href="#xml">Extensible Markup Language</a></td><td width="100"><b>.xml</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><a href="#gif">GIF</a> image</td><td width="100"><b>.gif</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><a href="#jpeg">JPEG</a> image</td><td width="100"><b>.jpg</b> or <b>.jpeg</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><a href="#tiff">TIFF</a> image</td><td width="100"><b>.tif</b> or <b>.tiff</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><a href="#bitmap">Bitmap</a></td><td width="100"><b>.bmp</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400">PostScript file</td><td width="100"><b>.ps</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400">AIFF sound file</td><td width="100"><b>.aif</b> or <b>.aiff</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400">AU sound file</td><td width="100"><b>.au</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400">WAV sound file</td><td width="100"><b>.wav</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400">QuickTime movie</td><td width="100"><b>.mov</b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><a href="#mpeg">MPEG</a> movie</td><td width="100"><b>.mpg</b> or <b>.mpeg</b></td></tr>
</tbody></table></dd></dl>
<p>
For a more complete list of file <a href="#format">format</a>s, see <em><a href="http://whatis.techtarget.com/fileFormatA/0,289933,sid9,00.html">Every File Format in the World</a></em> from <b>Whatis.com</b>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filigree"><b>filigree</b></a>
</dt><dd>An elegant style of decoration used in <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and fine <a href="#printing">printing</a>, in which an <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a> or <a href="#border">border</a> is edged with a delicate tracery of curved lines resembling lacework.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filigreeletter"><b>filigree letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a> in a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>, given a decorative outline or background of delicately interlaced lines resembling lacework.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filingrule"><b>filing rule</b></a>
</dt><dd>A guide established to determinine how a specific type of decision is to be made concerning the order in which <a href="#entry">entries</a> are <a href="#file">file</a>d in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  <a href="#publishing">Published</a> in 1942, the first <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the <em>A.L.A. Rules for Filing Catalog Cards</em> was revised in 1967 to correlate with <em><a href="#anglo">Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</a></em>.  New <em><a href="#alafiling">ALA Filing Rules</a></em> published in 1980 apply to all bibliographic display <a href="#format">format</a>s (<a href="#print">print</a>, <a href="#microform">microform</a>, <a href="#digital">digital</a>, etc.).  Under the current guidelines, filing is <a href="#character">character</a>-by-character to the end of each word, and word-by-word to the end of each filing element.  <a href="#numeral">Numeral</a>s precede <a href="#letter">letter</a>s and letters of the English <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> precede those of nonroman alphabets.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filingtitle"><b>filing title</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filingword"><b>filing word</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#entryword">entry word</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filler"><b>filler</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#blank">Blank</a> unnumbered <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> added at the end of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> to increase its <a href="#bulk">bulk</a> when <a href="#binding">bound</a>, known in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> as <em>padding</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fillet"><b>fillet</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a fine band or line impressed on the sides and/or <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> for decorative effect.  Also refers to the rolling tool used, when heated, to apply such lines.  A <em>French fillet</em> consists of three unevenly-spaced lines to which <a href="#goldleaf">gilding</a> is added.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fillrate"><b>fill rate</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, the percentage of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> ordered which is actually <a href="#shipping">shipped</a> by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, or other <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> over a fixed period of time.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#canceled">canceled</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="film"><b>film</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thin strip or sheet of flexible, transparent or translucent material (usually plastic) coated with a light-sensitive <a href="#emulsion">emulsion</a> which, when exposed to light, can be used to develop <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic images.  The instability and flammability of the cellulose <a href="#nitratefilm">nitrate</a> used as a film base prior to 1950 has created a <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> imperative of massive proportions.  To prevent <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a>, older films must be <a href="#copy">copied</a> onto a more permanent base such as acetate or polyester, a time-consuming and expensive process.  
<p>
Also refers to commercial and educational <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s in widths of 8, 16, 35, or 70 millimeters, including <a href="#documentary">documentaries</a>, <a href="#featurefilm">feature film</a>s, and <a href="#shortfilm">short film</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#filmarchives">film archives</a>, <a href="#filmlibrary">film library</a>, <a href="#filmography">filmography</a>, <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>, <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a>, <a href="#fiaf">International Federation of Film Archives</a>, and <a href="#nfr">National Film Registry</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filmarchives"><b>film archives</b></a>
