</dt><dd>An organization or unit within a larger organization or institution responsible for maintaining a permanent <a href="#film">film</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, usually of <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, <a href="#documentary">documentaries</a>, <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>s, and associated materials.  Environmental control is essential in film <a href="#archives">archives</a> to prevent <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> of the <a href="#medium">medium</a>.  The <a href="http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/">UCLA Film &amp; Television Archive</a>
maintains the largest university-held moving-image collection in the
world. For an international list of film archives, see the <a href="#directory">directory</a> of the <a href="http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/fiaf/english/dir.html">International Federation of Film Archives</a> (FIAF).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nfpf">National Film Preservation Foundation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filmclip"><b>film clip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A short piece of <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> <a href="#footage">footage</a> taken from a longer <a href="#work">work</a>, usually for promotional use or for <a href="#review">review</a> purposes, to give viewers a brief impression of the whole.  Compare with <a href="#trailer">trailer</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#videoclip">video clip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filmlibrary"><b>film library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a> containing a <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of 8, 16, 35, or 70 mm <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>s, and <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> related to <a href="#film">film</a>-making and film studies, <a href="#classificationsys">classified</a> for ease of <a href="#access">access</a> and retrieval.  <a href="#borrowingprivileges">Borrowing privileges</a> may be restricted to registered members or <a href="#subscription">subscriber</a>s required to pay a <a href="#rentalcollec">rental</a> <a href="#fee">fee</a> per <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#filmarchives">film archives</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filmography"><b>filmography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, usually limited to <a href="#work">work</a>s by a specific <a href="#director">director</a> or <a href="#performer">performer</a>, in a particular <a href="#genre">genre</a>, of a specific time period or country, or on a given <a href="#subject">subject</a>, usually listed <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#chronological">chronological</a>ly by <a href="#releasedate">release date</a>.  The <a href="#entry">entries</a> in a filmography include some or all of the following elements of <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a>:  <a href="#producer">producer</a>, <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>, <a href="#director">director</a>, cast, release date, <a href="#runningtime">running time</a>, <a href="#language">language</a>, color or black-and-white, etc.  Compare with <a href="#discography">discography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filmslip"><b>filmslip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A very short <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a> <a href="#mounted">mounted</a> like a <a href="#slide">slide</a> in a rigid holder, instead of stored in a short flexible roll.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filmstrip"><b>filmstrip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A length of 35 mm or 16 mm black-and-white or color <a href="#film">film</a> consisting of a sequence of related still images, with or without <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#caption">caption</a>s, intended to be projected one at a time at slow speed using a <em>filmstrip projector</em>.  Filmstrips are of variable length, usually no longer than fifty <a href="#frame">frame</a>s.  Some include a signal that automatically advances the projector in synchrony with a recorded <a href="#narration">narration</a>.  Compare with <a href="#filmslip">filmslip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filmstripprojector"><b>filmstrip projector</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filter"><b>filter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#computerprogram"> computer program</a> designed to allow only selected <a href="#data">data</a> to pass through to the user, for example, an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> system that alerts the recipient to selected incoming messages, or <a href="#software">software</a> that blocks <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#website">Web site</a>s
containing certain types of content, usually violent or sexually
explicit material considered unsuitable for young children. In the
United States, <a href="#filtering">filtering</a> has become the focus of a national debate over <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a> and <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/filtersandfiltering.html">Click here</a> to learn more about filters and filtering from the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#vchip">V-chip</a> and <em><a href="#cipa">Children's Internet Protection Act</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="filtering"><b>filtering</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, the use of specially designed <a href="#software">software</a> to prevent the user of a specific computer, <a href="#network">network</a>, or system from viewing certain types of <a href="#content">content</a> by blocking <a href="#access">access</a>.  <a href="#filter">Filter</a>s
are used primarily to prevent children from viewing violent and/or
sexually explicit material, and by employers to prevent employees from
engaging in nonwork-related activities on the job. In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the passage by Congress of the <em><a href="#cipa">Children's Internet Protection Act</a></em> has made filtering a controversial issue.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/filtersandfiltering.html">Click here</a> to learn more about filters and filtering from the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a> and <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="findingaid"><b>finding aid</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publishing">published</a> or <a href="#unpublished">unpublished</a> <a href="#guide">guide</a>, <a href="#inventory">inventory</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#register">register</a>, <a href="#calendar">calendar</a>, list, or other system for retrieving <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#primarysource">primary source</a> materials, providing more detailed description of each item than is customary in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>.  Finding aids also exist in <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#format">format</a>s (<a href="#ascii">ASCII</a>, <a href="#html">HTML</a>, etc.).  In partnership with the <a href="#saa">Society of American Archivists</a>, the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> maintains a <a href="#standard">standard</a> known as <a href="#ead">Encoded Archival Description</a> (EAD) for <a href="#encoding">encoding</a> archival finding aids in <a href="#sgml">Standard Generalized Markup Language</a> (SGML).  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/rr/ead/eadhome.html">Click here</a> to connect to a list of <a href="#online">online</a> finding aids for the Library of Congress <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="findinglist"><b>finding list</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of a <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> in which each <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is represented by a very brief <a href="#entry">entry</a> containing incomplete <a href="#bibliography">bibliographic</a> <a href="#information">information</a> (usually just the <a href="#author">author</a>'s name, the <a href="#title">title</a>, and its location within the <a href="#library">library</a>).  Compare with <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="findings"><b>findings</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#information">Information</a> or evidence uncovered as a result of systematic <a href="#research">research</a> or investigation.  Also, the conclusions of an official inquiry or <a href="#hearings">hearing</a> on a particular <a href="#topic">topic</a> or issue, usually presented in the form of a <a href="#report">report</a> which may be preserved as a legal <a href="#document">document</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="findingtool"><b>finding tool</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general <a href="#term">term</a> for a resource designed to be used in a <a href="#library">library</a> to locate sources of <a href="#information">information</a>, usually in a <a href="#search">search</a> by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or <a href="#keywords">keywords</a>.  The category includes <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>es, <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, etc.  The corresponding term in <a href="#archives">archives</a> is <em>finding aid</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="finebook"><b>fine book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> of exceptional quality with respect to its design, <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, and <a href="#binding">binding</a>, often a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a>.  Very fine books are usually sold by <a href="#antiquarian">antiquarian bookseller</a>s and at <a href="#bookauction">book auction</a>s.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> preserve them in <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>.  Compare with <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="finecopy"><b>fine copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#usedbook">used book</a> trade, a <a href="#copy">copy</a> in clean, crisp <a href="#condition">condition</a> that surpasses "good" but falls short of <a href="#mint">mint</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fineedition"><b>fine edition</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="finefree"><b>fine-free period</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#grace">grace period</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fineprint"><b>fine print</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#information">Information</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> in very small <a href="#type">type</a>, usually at the end of a <a href="#document">document</a> or in an inconspicuous place within it, containing details of which the <a href="#reader">reader</a> must be informed, but to which the source or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> may not wish to call attention.  Failure to read fine print can have serious consequences for the person <a href="#signed">signing</a> a legal document.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mousetype">mouse type</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fines"><b>fines</b></a>
</dt><dd>To encourage <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s to return <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> promptly, most <a href="#library">libraries</a> charge a small amount for each day that a <a href="#circulating">circulating</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is kept past its <a href="#duedate">due date</a>.  The amount may vary depending on the <a href="#format">format</a> of the material <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>.  <a href="#overdue">Overdue</a> fines for items on <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> may be charged by the hour.  Fines can be avoided by <a href="#renew">renew</a>ing items on or before the due date.  Most automated <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s are <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>med to <a href="#blocked">block</a> a <a href="#borroweraccount">borrower account</a> if unpaid fines accumulate beyond a certain amount.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#grace">grace period</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fingerprint"><b>fingerprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>A unique identifier constructed according to formula, used in <a href="#analyticalbibliog">historical bibliography</a> to identify <a href="#copy">copies</a> of early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s as belonging to a specific <a href="#edition">edition</a> or <a href="#issue">issue</a>.  Fingerprint formulas are usually in two parts:  the year in which the edition appeared plus <a href="#booksize">size of book</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>157504</b> for a <a href="#quarto">quarto</a> edition of the year 1575), followed by three groups of <a href="#character">character</a>s transcribed from the line of <a href="#text">text</a> immediately above the <a href="#signature">signature</a> marks printed at the <a href="#foot">foot</a> of certain <a href="#page">page</a>s in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>, main text, and <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a> to assist the <a href="#binder">binder</a> in assembling the <a href="#gathering">gathering</a>s in correct sequence.  Even when a text is <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>ed exactly as it appeared in a preceding edition, the signature marks added after the text is <a href="#compositor">composed</a> rarely fall in the same place, creating a variance that can be used for identification.  Synonymous with <em>signature position</em>.  
<p>
For more <a href="#information">information</a>, please see <b><em>Fingerprints = Empreintes = Impronte</em></b>
(Paris: Institut de Recherche et d'Histoire des Textes, 1984) and the
critique by Ben J. P. Salemans of the technique in the June, 1994 issue
of the <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>Computers and the Humanities</em>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="finis"><b>finis</b></a>
</dt><dd>A French word <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the end of an old <a href="#book">book</a>, or appearing at the end of an early <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, meaning "the end" or "conclusion."  Compare with <a href="#explicit">explicit</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="finish"><b>finish</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general <a href="#term">term</a> for the texture of the surface of a grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, determined by the materials and techniques used in manufacture (fiber content, <a href="#sizing">sizing</a>, <a href="#calender">calender</a>ing, <a href="#coated">coating</a>, drying, etc.).  The terms used to describe finish are descriptive:  <a href="#antique">antique</a>, <a href="#cockle">cockle</a>, <a href="#eggshell">eggshell</a>, <a href="#glossy">glossy</a>, <a href="#matte">matte</a>, <a href="#stipple">stipple</a>, etc.   
<p>
In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, to apply <a href="#lettering">lettering</a> and/or ornamentation to the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> in a process known as <a href="#finishing">finishing</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="finishing"><b>finishing</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a>, the process of applying <a href="#lettering">lettering</a> and/or decorative elements to a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> by <a href="#tooling">tooling</a>, <a href="#inlay">inlay</a>ing, or <a href="#onlay">onlay</a>ing, done by a person known as a <em>finisher</em>.  Also, a general term for the final steps in the processing of <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a> once it has been <a href="#printing">printed</a>, including cutting, folding, machine <a href="#binding">binding</a>, stamping, <a href="#lamination">laminating</a>, application of the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firewall"><b>firewall</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#dedicated">dedicated</a> computer that functions as a <a href="#security">security</a> boundary, blocking traffic from one part of a <a href="#network">network</a> to another, usually the transmission of <a href="#data">data</a> from a larger network to a <a href="#localarea">local area network</a>.  Firewalls are installed to restrict <a href="#access">access</a> to private computer <a href="#network">network</a>(s) and <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s, by screening incoming traffic and denying access to un<a href="#authorization">authorized</a> users.  They also help prevent <a href="#confidentiality">confidential</a> <a href="#information">information</a> from passing out.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firmorder"><b>firm order</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, an order placed with a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, or <a href="#dealer">dealer</a> that specifies a maximum price and time limit for delivery, not to be exceeded without prior approval of the ordering <a href="#library">library</a>.  Firm orders are placed for <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> requested by the individual <a href="#selection">selector</a>s responsible for <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>.  Compare with <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstamendment"><b>First Amendment</b></a>
</dt><dd>Amendment I to the <em>United States Constitution</em>,
ratified in 1791, which guarantees freedom of speech: "Congress shall
make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the
free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the
press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to
petition the government for a redress of grievances." The <em><a href="#ftrs">Freedom to Read Statement</a></em> and the <em><a href="#lbor">Library Bill of Rights</a></em> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> are based on this constitutional protection.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstamerican"><b>first American edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>The first <a href="#edition">edition</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the United States of a <a href="#work">work</a> previously published in another country.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstappearance"><b>first appearance</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> to mean:  1) an <a href="#author">author</a>'s initial appearance in <a href="#print">print</a>; 2) the first time a given <a href="#work">work</a> by an author appears in print, especially a short work (<a href="#essay">essay</a>, <a href="#poetry">poem</a>, or <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>); or 3) the first <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> of a <a href="#subject">subject</a> to be <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#book">book</a> form.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#firstbook">first book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstbook"><b>first book</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the first appearance in <a href="#print">print</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>-length <a href="#work">work</a> written entirely by the <a href="#author">author</a>.  The initial books of many well-known writers remain relatively obscure (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Fanshawe: A Tale</em></b> by Nathaniel Hawthorne).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstedition"><b>first edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#copy">copies</a> of the <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> and <a href="#issue">issue</a>d at the same time, before any other printings.  Subsequent printings from the same set of <a href="#type">type</a> are considered new <a href="#impression">impression</a>s but are still part of the first edition.  The <em>second edition</em> is printed from a new <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> of type or includes significant changes in <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#format">format</a>.  Also refers to an individual copy of a <a href="#work">work</a> printed from the initial setting of type.  In the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, first editions are usually more valuable than later editions.  Synonymous with <em>princeps edition</em> and <em>edito princeps</em>.  Compare with <a href="#reprint">reprint</a> and <a href="#revisededition">revised edition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#allfirsts">all firsts</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the first printing of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> on a specific date, when two or more editions are <a href="#issue">issue</a>d each day.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstfolio"><b>first folio</b></a>
</dt><dd>The common name for the first <a href="#collection">collected</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> of Shakespeare's dramatic <a href="#work">work</a>s.  <a href="#publishing">Published</a> in 1623, it is one of the most famous and valuable <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s in the world.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#folger">Folger Library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstimpression"><b>first impression</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> made at the first <a href="#printing">printing</a>, before any alterations in the <a href="#text">text</a>.  Subsequent <a href="#impression">impression</a>s made from the same <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> of <a href="#type">type</a> soon after the first are <a href="#number">number</a>ed sequentially and may contain slight changes to correct errors detected after the first printing.  Compare with <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstissue"><b>first issue</b></a>
</dt><dd>The first installment of a newly <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> (<a href="#issuenumber">issue number</a> one of <a href="#volumenumber">volume</a> one).  Also refers to the first installment received by a <a href="#library">library</a> in response to a new periodical <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>, not necessarily the first issue published.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a> and <a href="#backissue">back issue</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstline"><b>first-line index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#index">index</a> in which the opening lines of <a href="#poetry">poems</a> (songs, hymns, etc.) are listed in <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> order, each <a href="#entry">entry</a> giving the <a href="#title">title</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a> and the name of the poet, usually shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>.  In <b><em>The Columbia Granger's Index to Poetry in Anthologies</em></b>, poems are indexed by first-line, last-line, and title in a single alphabetical sequence.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstname"><b>first name</b></a>
</dt><dd>The first of one or more <a href="#givenname">given name</a>s or Christian names, as distinct from the <a href="#surname">surname</a> identifying members of the same family.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#heading">heading</a>s
for persons known by their initials begin with the surname, followed by
a comma, then the initials, followed by the full given names (<em>example</em>:  <b>Eliot, T. S. Thomas Stearns</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstoftwo"><b>first-of-two</b></a>
</dt><dd>The instruction in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> that <a href="#work">work</a>s found to be about two mutually exclusive <a href="#subject">subject</a>s are given the <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> that appears first in the <a href="#schedule">schedule</a>s, whether the subjects are close in the list of <a href="#class">class</a>es or widely separated.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ruleofthree">rule of three</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstpublished"><b>first published edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d for sale to the general public after it has been distributed to a restricted <a href="#audience">audience</a>, for example, a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> <a href="#release">release</a>d for public viewing after it has been <a href="#preview">preview</a>ed by a limited audience usually selected by the <a href="#producer">producer</a> and <a href="#director">director</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firsts"><b>firsts</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="firstsearch"><b><em>FirstSearch (FS)</em></b></a>    
</dt><dd>A service of <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> that provides <a href="#access">access</a> to over fifty <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s in a wide range of <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s via a <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> <a href="#interface">interface</a>, on a <a href="#persearch">per search</a> or <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> basis, by <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a>.  Some of the <a href="#database">database</a>s in <b><em>FirstSearch</em></b> include <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a>.  <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em>, the largest <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a> in the world, is available in <b><em>FS</em></b>.  <a href="http://www.oclc.org/firstsearch/">Click here</a> to learn more about <b><em>OCLC FirstSearch</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fiscalvalue"><b>fiscal value</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fiscalyear"><b>fiscal year</b></a>
</dt><dd>A period of twelve months, not necessarily coincident with the calendar year, used by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> for financial accounting purposes.  In the United States, most <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>
that depend on public funding use a fiscal year beginning on July 1 and
ending on June 30. Academic libraries at privately funded colleges and
universities may use a fiscal year that coincides with the academic
calendar. In <a href="#federallibrary">federally libraries</a>, the fiscal year may begin on October 1 and end on September 30.  In <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>, the fiscal year usually corresponds with that of the parent organization.  Synonymous with <em>accounting year</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fist"><b>fist</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#printer">Printer</a>'s <a href="#slang">slang</a> for a <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> in the form of a closed hand with the index finger extended, used to draw attention to something on a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#page">page</a>, and in <a href="#signage">signage</a> to indicate direction.  Also called a <em>digit</em> or <em>hand</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fivelaws"><b><em>Five Laws of Library Science</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ranganathan">Ranganathan, S. R.</a>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fixedfield"><b>fixed field</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#field">field</a> in the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> containing a fixed number of <a href="#character">character</a>s, for example, the 24-character <a href="#leader">leader</a> or the 005, 007, and 009 fields, as opposed to a field of <a href="#variablefield">variable length</a>.  Because the function of each character in a fixed field is defined by its relative position, <a href="#subfieldcode">subfield code</a>s are not required to distinguish <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s.  <a href="#cataloging">Cataloging</a> <a href="#software">software</a> usually provides <a href="#prompt">prompt</a>s or <a href="#window">window</a>s to assist <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s in entering data in fixed fields. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fixedlength"><b>fixed length data elements</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#field">Field</a> <b>008</b> of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>, containing 40 <a href="#character">character</a>s used to <a href="#encoding">encode</a> <a href="#information">information</a> that allows records meeting certain criteria to be identified and <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a>, for example, <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in <a href="#largeprint">large print</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a specific <a href="#language">language</a> or country, or intended for a <a href="#childrensbook">juvenile</a> <a href="#audience">audience</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fixedlocation"><b>fixed location</b></a>
</dt><dd>A specific physical location to which an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> is permanently assigned, for example, a <a href="#dictionarystand">dictionary stand</a> on which a large <a href="#languagedictionary">dictionary</a> is displayed or an <a href="#atlascase">atlas case</a> in which several large <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>es are stored for ease of <a href="#access">access</a>.  In medieval <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#manuscriptbook">manuscript book</a>s were sometimes chained to a shelf, table, or <a href="#carrel">carrel</a> to prevent removal.  In most modern libraries, items have a <em>relative location</em> determined by the <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> <a href="#notation">notation</a> assigned in <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, their actual physical position on the shelf changing as other items are acquired or <a href="#withdrawal">withdrawn</a>, or when the collection is <a href="#shifting">shifted</a>.  Synonymous with <em>absolute location</em>). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fixedshelving"><b>fixed shelving</b></a>
</dt><dd>Shelving in which each shelf is permanently attached to the uprights in a <a href="#range">range</a>, or to the vertical side of a <a href="#bookcase">bookcase</a>, as opposed to <em>adjustable shelving</em> in which the shelves are detachable and can easily be moved up or down to accommodate <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> of variable height. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flag"><b>flag</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> exactly as <a href="#printing">printed</a> across the top of the <a href="#frontpage">front page</a>, including any design elements on either side, called <a href="#ear">ear</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>nameplate</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#masthead">masthead</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a long, narrow strip cut with the <a href="#grain">grain</a> from a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of stiff <a href="#paper">paper</a> or thin <a href="#pasteboard">pasteboard</a>, inserted in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> to alert <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> to the existence of special characteristics, status, or instructions, usually in <a href="#technical">technical processing</a> or shelving.  The strips may be color-coded to communicate specific <a href="#information">information</a> to the person doing the processing or shelving.  <a href="#acidfree">Acid-free</a> paper or board should be used for this purpose.   
</p><p>
In <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a>, a special <a href="#character">character</a> used to mark the occurrence of a condition specified in advance.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flame"><b>flame</b></a>
</dt><dd>To communicate via <a href="#email">e-mail</a> in an angry, sarcastic, or critical tone.  A protracted dispute in a <a href="#newsgroup">newsgroup</a> or <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a> discussion is known as a <em>flame war</em>.  Such disputes are usually mediated or terminated by the other participants or by the moderator.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#netiquette">netiquette</a> and <a href="#shouting">shouting</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flannelboard"><b>flannel board</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large square or rectangular board covered in felt, used in <a href="#storytelling">storytelling</a> and instruction to display <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s,
and shapes cut from fabric or some other textured material that sticks
to the felt surface when the board is held in an upright position.
Synonymous with <em>feltboard</em> and <em>cloth board</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flap"><b>flap</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of the two ends of the <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> wrapped around the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>.  The <a href="#listprice">list price</a> and the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s promotional <a href="#blurb">blurb</a> are usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the front flap.  The back flap provides brief <a href="#biography">biographical</a> <a href="#information">information</a> about the <a href="#author">author</a> and/or <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>, usually with a small <a href="#portrait">portrait</a> <a href="#photograph">photograph</a> of each person.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flashcard"><b>flash card</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small stiff, opaque card bearing a <a href="#letter">letter</a>, word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>, <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>, <a href="#picture">picture</a>, or combination of <a href="#character">character</a>s and images, for rapid display in mnemonic drill and recognition training, usually part of a <a href="#set">set</a>.  Flash cards are also used in presentations to provide visual cues to the audience.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> that include flash cards in their <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s usually make them available in the <a href="#curriculumroom">curriculum room</a> or <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flatback"><b>flat back</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the <a href="#back">back</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> is not <a href="#rounding">rounded</a> or <a href="#backing">backed</a> after <a href="#gluingoff">gluing</a>, leaving the front and back <a href="#cover">cover</a>s to meet the <a href="#spine">spine</a> at a right angle.  Synonymous with <em>square back</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#hollowback">hollow back</a> and <a href="#tightback">tight back</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flatpanel"><b>flat panel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> <a href="#device">device</a> in the form of a thin, flat screen that uses <a href="#lcd">LCD</a> or plasma technology, rather than a cathode ray tube, to display <a href="#output">output</a>.  In <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>s, the flat panel folds down to cover the <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flatshelving"><b>flat shelving</b></a>
</dt><dd>Storing <a href="#book">book</a>s stacked flat on the shelf, one on top of another with the lower edges (<a href="#tail">tail</a>s) facing outward, used mainly for large <a href="#set">set</a>s and <a href="#series">series</a> such as law books.  The <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a> may be written large on the lower edge to facilitate retrieval.  This method of shelving can increase <a href="#shelfcapacity">shelf capacity</a> by as much as 28%, but it makes <a href="#browse">browsing</a> more difficult because the <a href="#spine">spine</a>s are not visible.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doubleshelving">double shelving</a>, <a href="#foreedgeshelving">fore-edge shelving</a>, and <a href="#shelvingbysize">shelving by size</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fleuron"><b>fleuron</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#printersflower">printer's flower</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flexcover"><b>flex-cover</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#flexiblebinding">flexible binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flexiblebinding"><b>flexible binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> or <a href="#leather">leather</a> covered <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> in a material that bends easily, rather than the rigid <a href="#board">board</a>s used in most <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>flex-cover</em>.  Compare with <a href="#limpbinding">limp binding</a> and <a href="#softcover">softcover</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#biblestyle">Bible style</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flextime"><b>flextime</b></a>
</dt><dd>Time worked in excess of the maximum <a href="#number">number</a>
of hours per day, week, or month specified under the terms governing
employment, for which the employee is granted time off at a later date.
Synonymous with <em>comp time</em>.  Compare with <a href="#overtime">overtime</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flicc1"><b>FLICC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#flicc"><b>F</b>ederal <b>L</b>ibrary and <b>I</b>nformation <b>C</b>enter <b>C</b>ommittee</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flickerbook"><b>flicker book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#toybook">toy book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> during the 19th century, containing a sequence of closely-related <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>-style <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s designed to give the impression of animation when the <a href="#page">page</a>s are fanned from <a href="#cover">cover</a> to cover, similar to the visual effect created by the rapid projection of <a href="#frame">frame</a>s in a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flier"><b>flier</b></a>
</dt><dd>An inexpensive, widely distributed <a href="#handbill">handbill</a> or <a href="#circular">circular</a> of small size (usually 8 1/2 x 11 inches), used flat or folded for advertising and announcements.  Also spelled <em>flyer</em>.  Synonymous in the U.K. with <em>leaflet</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ephemera">ephemera</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flipchart"><b>flip chart</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large-sized pad of <a href="#paper">paper</a> designed to be mounted on an <a href="#easel">easel</a>, to display <a href="#information">information</a> in <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> or <a href="#table">tabular</a> <a href="#format">format</a> during a presentation.  As the session proceeds, <a href="#page">page</a>s can either be torn off or turned over the top.  Unlike <a href="#slide">slide</a> projection or presentation <a href="#software">software</a>, a flip <a href="#chart">chart</a> allows the presenter to manipulate <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#content">content</a> manually as it is presented, sometimes in response to <a href="#feedback">feedback</a> from the <a href="#audience">audience</a>.  <a href="#transparency">Transparencies</a> are visible to a larger audience but require <a href="#overheadprojector">overhead projection</a> equipment.  Also spelled <em>flipchart</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="floorplan"><b>floor plan</b></a>
</dt><dd>A drawing of the layout of a <a href="#library">library</a> building, showing the location of <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, services, and facilities on each floor, helpful to first-time users, sometimes displayed on the library's <a href="#website">Web site</a> with <a href="#link">link</a>s to descriptive <a href="#text">text</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="floppy"><b>floppy</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="floppydisk"><b>floppy disk</b></a>
</dt><dd>A 3 1/2-inch external metallic <a href="#disk">disk</a> encased in a rigid plastic envelope, designed for use in a <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a> as a portable <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> for <a href="#data">data</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  The most commonly used sizes are 720<a href="#byte">K</a> (double-density) and 1.44<a href="#byte">MB</a> (high-density).  Before 1987, most PCs used flexible 5 1/4-inch <em>floppies</em>.  To conserve <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#library">library</a> users are encouraged to <a href="#save">save</a> the results of a <a href="#search">search</a> of an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> to floppy disk (or <a href="#export">export</a> <a href="#output">output</a> to an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> account), instead of <a href="#printing">printing</a> it.  In <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a>s, the floppy <a href="#diskdrive">disk drive</a> is the <b>a:/</b> drive.  Synonymous with <em>diskette</em>.  Compare with <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="floret"><b>floret</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#printersflower">printer's flower</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flourish"><b>flourish</b></a>
</dt><dd>A decorative tail or ornamental extension on a <a href="#swashletter">swash letter</a>, usually in the form of one or more curves, used in older <a href="#signature">signature</a>s as a mark of distinction and to render <a href="#forgery">forgery</a> more difficult.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#paraph">paraph</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flowchart"><b>flowchart</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#diagram">diagram</a> showing the complete series of steps in a process, such as a <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a>, or the sequence in which the components of a system function, usually in the form of <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s
of various shapes, each representing a specific type of operation or
component, connected by directional lines indicating movement.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flowmap"><b>flow map</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dynamicmap">dynamic map</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flush"><b>flush</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a line of <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#alignment">aligned</a> along a right or left <a href="#margin">margin</a> without <a href="#indention">indention</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flushbinding"><b>flush binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the <a href="#cover">cover</a>s are <a href="#trimming">trimmed</a> even with the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> after having been attached to the <a href="#section">section</a>s.  Most <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s have <em>flush covers</em>.  Compare with <a href="#extendedbinding">extended binding</a>.  <b><em>See aso</em></b>:  <a href="#cutflush">cut flush</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flushcover"><b>flush cover</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#flushbinding">flush binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flyer"><b>flyer</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#flier">flier</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flyleaf"><b>flyleaf</b></a>
</dt><dd>The half of an <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a> not <a href="#pastedown">pasted</a> to the inside of one of the <a href="#board">board</a>s of the <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  The term is also used for one or more <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> at the beginning of a <a href="#book">book</a> following the front free endpaper, or at the end preceding the back free endpaper, when the <a href="#text">text</a> does not fill the last few <a href="#page">page</a>s.  The purpose of the flyleaves is to protect the first and last leaves of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> from damage.  Also spelled <em>fly leaf</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="flytitle"><b>fly-title</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#title">title</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on an otherwise <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> indicating the beginning of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or other major division of a <a href="#book">book</a>, such as an <a href="#essay">essay</a> in a <a href="#collection">collection</a>, or a <a href="#shortstory">story</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>, or <a href="#poetry">poem</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in an <a href="#anthology">anthology</a>.  In England, a <a href="#synonym">synonym</a> for <a href="#halftitle">half title</a> or <em>bastard title</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fogindex"><b>fog index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A numeric formula used in <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> to gauge the degree of readability (clarity) of a piece of writing, based on average sentence length and <a href="#number">number</a>
of words of three or more syllables per sentence. The higher the index
number, the less intelligible the writing, an important consideration
in judging the sales potential of a <a href="#work">work</a>. The
measure is imprecise because it does not take into consideration the
writer's style, which may break long sentences into phrases and make
difficult words easier to comprehend from the <a href="#context">context</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foia1"><b><em>FOIA</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#foia"><b>F</b>reedom <b>o</b>f <b>I</b>nformation <b>A</b>ct</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fol"><b>FOL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#friends"><b>F</b>riends <b>o</b>f the <b>L</b>ibrary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fold"><b>fold</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bolt">bolt</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foldedbook"><b>folded book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A novelty <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#format">format</a> consisting of one long strip of <a href="#paper">paper</a> folded accordion-style, with one or both ends attached to separate rigid <a href="#cover">cover</a>s, and no <a href="#back">back</a>.  Used for <a href="#picture">pictorial</a>
display of wide-angle panoramas, particularly in China. More complex
folded books have been created by contemporary artists for whom the
book is a form of visual art (see <a href="#artbook">art book</a>).  Synonymous with <em>folding book</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="folder"><b>folder</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> consisting of a single <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> folded, usually down the center, into two or more <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, not cut or <a href="#saddle">stitched</a>.  Examples include performance programs, restaurant menus, etc.  Also refers to a sheet of heavy paper such as <a href="#manila">manila</a>, folded once, sometimes with a flap across the bottom and a projecting tab for <a href="#label">label</a>ing, used to file <a href="#loose">loose</a> papers.  Standard sizes in the U.S. are 9 x 11 3/4 and 9 x 17 3/4 inches.
<p>
In <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#application">application</a>s, a heading created by the user under which <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s, <a href="#email">e-mail</a> messages, <a href="#website">Web</a> <a href="#bookmark">bookmark</a>s, and other <a href="#information">information</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a> can be filed and <a href="#storage">stored</a> for future <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foldout"><b>fold-out</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#throwout">throw-out</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foldsewn"><b>fold sewn</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the <a href="#gathering">gathered</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s are attached to each other by <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> through the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a>, with a <a href="#kettle">kettle stitch</a> linking adjacent sections at the end of each pass of the <a href="#thread">thread</a>.  Hand fold sewing can be <a href="#allalong">all along</a>, <a href="#twoon">two on</a>, or <a href="#twoon">three on</a>.  Compare with <a href="#sidesewing">side sewing</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="folger"><b>Folger Shakespeare Library</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1932, the <b>Folger Library</b> in Washington D.C. is an independent <a href="#research">research</a> center for Shakespeare scholars containing the largest <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#printing">printed</a> materials in the world on "The Bard" and his <a href="#work">work</a>s.  The <b>Folger</b> also collects research materials on British civilization and culture of the Renaissance, including <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s.  A substantial <a href="#gift">gift</a> from the <a href="#privatelib">private library</a> of Henry and Emily Folger forms the nucleus of the collection.  The Folgers also established an <a href="#endowment">endowment</a> in support of the <a href="#library">library</a>, administered by the Trustees of Amherst College.  The library includes a small theater in which Shakespeare's <a href="#play">play</a>s are publicly performed.  <a href="#poetry">Poetry</a> readings and concerts of early music are also scheduled.  The <b>Folger Library</b> is housed in a building listed in the National Register of Historic Places.  <a href="http://www.folger.edu/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Folger</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foliateinitial"><b>foliate initial</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a> in an <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> embellished with a design consisting of vines, leaves, fruit, flowers, and/or other foliage.  Compare with <a href="#figureinitial">figure initial</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#historiated">historiated initial</a>, <a href="#inhabited">inhabited initial</a>, and <a href="#rusticcapital">rustic capital</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foliation"><b>foliation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The precursor of <a href="#pagination">pagination</a> in which the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, rather than the individual <a href="#page">page</a>s, of a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a> were <a href="#number">number</a>ed consecutively on the <a href="#recto">recto</a> only, usually in <a href="#romannumeral">roman numeral</a>s following the word "<a href="#folio">Folio</a>" or the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> <em>F.</em>, <em>f.</em>, <em>fo.</em>, or <em>fol.</em>  Foliation in <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s was introduced in Italy during the late 15th century.  Pagination in arabic <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s
began about one hundred years later, but did not become widespread
until the 18th century. Also refers to the total number of leaves in a
manuscript or book, <a href="#number">number</a>ed or unnumbered.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#blindfolio">blind folio</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="folio"><b>folio</b></a>
</dt><dd>The Latin word for "leaf," <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> <em>F.</em>, <em>f.</em>, <em>fo.</em>, or <em>fol.</em>  The <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> of a book or <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> <a href="#number">number</a>ed at the top or bottom on the <a href="#recto">recto</a> only, said to be <a href="#foliation">foliated</a> rather than <a href="#pagination">paginated</a>.  The term also refers to a <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> in its full, unfolded size, and to a single sheet of a writer's manuscript or <a href="#typescript">typescript</a> with writing or printed <a href="#matter">matter</a> on one side only. 
<p>
Also refers to the size of <a href="#book">book</a>, approximately 15 inches in <a href="#height">height</a>, made by folding a full sheet of book paper in half once to form <a href="#signature">signature</a>s of two <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> (four <a href="#page">page</a>s).  The precise size of each leaf in a folio <a href="#edition">edition</a> depends on the size of the original sheet.  Some early editions are known by the number of leaves in their <a href="#section">section</a>s, as in the <a href="#firstfolio">first folio</a> edition of Shakespeare's plays.  Compare with  <a href="#quarto">quarto</a>, <a href="#octavo">octavo</a>, <a href="#duodecimo">duodecimo</a>, and <a href="#sextodecimo">sextodecimo</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="folionumber"><b>folio number</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#foliation">foliation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="folklore"><b>folklore</b></a>
</dt><dd>A collective <a href="#term">term</a> applied since the mid-19th century to the traditions, beliefs, <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>s,
etc., passed from one generation to the next within a community by word
of mouth, without being written down. Folklore includes <a href="#legend">legend</a>s, <a href="#folktale">folktale</a>s, songs, <a href="#nurseryrhyme">nursery rhyme</a>s, <a href="#riddle">riddle</a>s, superstitions, <a href="#proverb">proverb</a>s,
customs, and forms of dance and drama performed at traditional
celebrations. Because folklore flourishes in communities with a low <a href="#literacy">literacy</a> rate, it is disappearing in many parts of the world.  <a href="#dictionary">Dictionaries</a> of folklore are available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most large <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  Compare with <a href="#myth">myth</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="folktale"><b>folktale</b></a>
</dt><dd>A short <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> rooted in the oral
tradition of a particular culture, which may include improbable or
supernatural elements. The category includes a range of forms, from <a href="#fairytale">fairy tale</a> to <a href="#myth">myth</a>.  Some have historical roots (<em>example</em>: John Henry), others are purely imaginative (Pecos Bill).  Folktales are usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#collection">collection</a>s.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, they are shelved in either the <a href="#adult">adult</a> or <a href="#juvenile">juvenile collection</a>, depending on <a href="#readinglevel">reading level</a> and <a href="#format">format</a>.  Also spelled <em>folk tale</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="followthrough"><b>follow through</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#letterbyletter">letter-by-letter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="folusa1"><b>FOLUSA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#folusa"><b>F</b>riends <b>o</b>f <b>L</b>ibraries <b>USA</b></a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="font"><b>font</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the French word <em>fondre</em> meaning "to cast."  In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, all the <a href="#character">character</a>s of a specific <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> in a given <a href="#typesize">size</a>, including <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> and <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a>, <a href="#smallcapital">small capital</a>s, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s, <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a> marks, <a href="#refmark">reference mark</a>s, and any special characters, as opposed to a <a href="#typefamily">type family</a> that includes different variations and sizes of the same type style  (<a href="#roman">roman</a>, <a href="#italic">italic</a>, <a href="#boldface">boldface</a>, etc.).  In <a href="#book">book</a>s, the <a href="#text">text</a> is <a href="#typesetting">set</a> in a single font, with any long <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s and <a href="#note">note</a>s in a smaller size of the same font.  Older spelling: <em>fount</em>.
<p>
In computers, fonts come built into the <a href="#printer">printer</a>, usually in the form of exchangeable plug-in cartridges or as "soft" fonts residing on the computer's <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a> or on a hard disk built into the printer.  By embedding fonts in a <a href="#document">document</a> before it is transmitted, document exchange <a href="#software">software</a> such as <em><a href="#adobeacrobat">Adobe Acrobat</a></em> allows <a href="#text">text</a> to be displayed and printed in its original form without having to install fonts on the receiving machine.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foolscap"><b>foolscap</b></a>
</dt><dd>Formerly, a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> of <a href="#standard">standard</a> size, which varied from 13 x 15 to 13 1/2 x 17 inches, producing two <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of roughly 13 x 8 inches when folded once down the center.  The word is derived from the <a href="#watermark">watermark</a> traditionally used by <a href="#papermaking">papermaker</a>s, showing the distinctive multi-pointed cap with bells worn by medieval jesters.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>fcap</em> or <em>fcp</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foot"><b>foot</b></a>
</dt><dd>The bottom edge of a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  The opposite of <em>head</em>. Synonymous with <em>tail</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="footage"><b>footage</b></a>
</dt><dd>A length or quantity expressed in feet, for example, the <a href="#number">number</a> of running feet in a segment of <a href="#film">film</a> joined to other segments in <a href="#editing">editing</a> to create a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="footer"><b>footer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A line or lines at the bottom of a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>, giving the name of the person (or persons) responsible for creating and maintaining the <a href="#website">site</a>, and its <a href="#host">host</a>.  The footer may also include the date of last <a href="#update">update</a>, a <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> notice, and a contact <a href="#link">link</a> or <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a>.  Also refers to the lines at the bottom of an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> message indicating the name, <a href="#title">title</a>, and affiliation of the sender, and any contact <a href="#information">information</a>, as distinct from the <a href="#header">header</a> at the beginning of the message and the <a href="#body">body</a> containing the <a href="#text">text</a>.  Also used synonymously in <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s with <a href="#runningfoot">running foot</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="footline"><b>footline</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#runningfoot">running foot</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="footnote"><b>footnote</b></a>       
</dt><dd>A brief note at the bottom of a <a href="#page">page</a> explaining or expanding upon a point in the <a href="#text">text</a>, or indicating the source of a <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> or idea attributed by the <a href="#author">author</a> to another person.  Footnotes are indicated in the text by an <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a> in <a href="#superscript">superscript</a>, or a <a href="#refmark">reference mark</a>, and are usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> in a smaller <a href="#typesize">size</a> of the <a href="#font">font</a> used for the text.  When <a href="#number">number</a>ed, the sequence usually starts with 1 at the beginning of each <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>, but may occasionally start with 1 at the beginning of each page.  Compare with <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#marginalia">marginalia</a>.  
<p>
In a more general sense, any afterthought or minor but related comment
on, or confirmation of, a primary statement, in writing or in speech. </p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="footprint"><b>footprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>The amount of surface area on a desktop or table required to accommodate a computer or <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> device, less for a <a href="#laptop">laptop</a> than for a conventional <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a>, an important consideration in designing and equipping <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#instructionlab">instruction lab</a>s.
<p>
Also refers to the geographic area in which the signal transmitted by a <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> satellite can be received. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foreedge"><b>fore-edge</b></a>
</dt><dd>The outer edge of a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> in a <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, or of the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> or its <a href="#cover">cover</a>, opposite the <a href="#spine">spine</a> or <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a>, the others being the <a href="#head">head</a> and <a href="#tail">tail</a>.  Synonymous with <em>front edge</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#foreedgepainting">fore-edge painting</a> and <a href="#foreedgetitle">fore-edge title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foreedgepainting"><b>fore-edge painting</b></a>
</dt><dd>The practice of painting a <a href="#picture">picture</a> on the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of a medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> with its <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> closed.  In late 18th and early 19th century England, the technique was refined to make the picture visible only when the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a> were slightly fanned.  In <em>double fore-edge painting</em>, two different images can be seen by fanning the leaves first in one direction, then in the other.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foreedgeshelving"><b>fore-edge shelving</b></a>
</dt><dd>Storing <a href="#book">book</a>s with their <a href="#spine">spine</a>s parallel with the surface of the shelf, rather than perpendicular to it.  To prevent the force of gravity from causing the <a href="#bookblock">book block</a> to pull away from the <a href="#case">case</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a>, the spine should rest on the shelf with the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> up.  This method preserves <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> sequence and adds at least two shelves to a standard 90-inch high <a href="#section">section</a> when space is limited, but makes <a href="#browse">browsing</a> and locating a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a> difficult because the spines are not visible.  For this reason, it is usually restricted to portions of the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> that are not heavily used.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doubleshelving">double shelving</a>, <a href="#flatshelving">flat shelving</a>, and <a href="#shelvingbysize">shelving by size</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foreedgetitle"><b>fore-edge title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> hand-<a href="#lettering">lettered</a> on the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of a <a href="#volume">volume</a>, to facilitate identification when it was standard practice to shelve <a href="#book">book</a>s fore-edge out.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foreignbook"><b>foreign book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> to refer to a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> outside the United States.  Certain <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s specialize in supplying <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s with <a href="#title">title</a>s published in specific countries (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.chinabooks.com/">China Books &amp; Periodicals, Inc.</a> of San Francisco).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foreignsub"><b>foreign subsidiary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> wholly or partially owned by a company that has its headquarters in another country (<em>example</em>:  <b>Random House</b> owned by Bertelsmann AG of Germany).  The trend toward globalization of corporate ownership has profoundly affected the <a href="#media">media</a>, including <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="forename"><b>forename</b></a>
</dt><dd>A name preceding a person's <a href="#surname">surname</a> (family name), given at birth to distinguish him or her from others of the same family or clan.  Synonymous with <em>given name</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#firstname">first name</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="forenameentry"><b>forename entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#entry">entry</a> made in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> under a person's given name (<a href="#forename">forename</a>).  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, this practice is reserved for names that do not include a <a href="#surname">surname</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>Plato</b>), names that include a <a href="#patronymic">patronymic</a> (<b>Isaac ben Aaron</b>), and names of royal persons (<b>Eleanor</b>, <em>of Aquitaine</em>).  Any word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> commonly associated with the name in <a href="#work">work</a>s by the person, or in reference sources, such as place of origin, domicile, occupation, etc., is added following a comma (<b>Ezekiel</b>, <em>Biblical Prophet</em>). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foreword"><b>foreword</b></a>
</dt><dd>Introductory remarks preceding the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, usually written by a person other than the <a href="#author">author</a>.  When written by the author, introductory remarks constitute the <a href="#preface">preface</a>.  The foreword differs from the preface in remaining unchanged from one <a href="#edition">edition</a> to the next.  In the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, the foreword or preface usually follows the <a href="#dedication">dedication</a> and precedes the <a href="#introduction">introduction</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>fwd</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="forgery"><b>forgery</b></a>
</dt><dd>The deliberate counterfeit or imitation of a <a href="#signature">signature</a>, or fabrication or alteration of a <a href="#document">document</a> or other <a href="#work">work</a>, with intent to deceive or harm the interests of another person or persons.  The creation of fake <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>s of <a href="#rarebook">rare</a> and valuable <a href="#book">book</a>s
is considered forgery. In most countries, the act of forgery, or the
sale of a forged work with intent to deceive, is a crime. Also refers
to that which is forged. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#authenticity">authenticity</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="form"><b>form</b></a>
</dt><dd>A term used in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> to refer to the manner in which the <a href="#text">text</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> is arranged (<a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>, <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>, <a href="#directory">directory</a>, <a href="#anthology">anthology</a>), the <a href="#genre">genre</a> in which a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> is written (<a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#poetry">poetry</a>, drama, etc.), or the structure of a musical <a href="#composition">composition</a> (concerto, symphony, opera, etc.).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#formheading">form heading</a> and <a href="#formsubdivision">form subdivision</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="format"><b>format</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general indication of the size of a <a href="#book">book</a>, based on the number of times the <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s are folded in <a href="#binding">binding</a> (<a href="#folio">folio</a>, <a href="#quarto">quarto</a>, <a href="#octavo">octavo</a>, <a href="#duodecimo">duodecimo</a>, <a href="#sextodecimo">sextodecimo</a>, etc.).
<p>
Also refers to the overall physical presentation of a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>.  For <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, format includes size, proportions, quality of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, <a href="#layout">layout</a>, and style of <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Synonymous in American <a href="#usage">usage</a> with <em>get up</em> (books).  In a more general sense, the physical <a href="#medium">medium</a> in which <a href="#information">information</a> is <a href="#record">record</a>ed, including <a href="#print">print</a> and <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#reformat">reformat</a>. 
</p><p>
In <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a>, the manner in which <a href="#data">data</a> is arranged in a medium of <a href="#input">input</a>, <a href="#output">output</a>, or <a href="#storage">storage</a>, including the code and instructions determining the arrangement (see <a href="#filetype">file type</a>).  Also, to prepare a <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a> for the recording of data (most floppies are sold preformatted), and to arrange <a href="#text">text</a> on a computer screen in the form in which it will be printed on <a href="#paper">paper</a> (<a href="#font">font</a>, <a href="#margin">margin</a>s, <a href="#alignment">alignment</a>, <a href="#typesize">type size</a>, <a href="#italic">italic</a>, <a href="#boldface">boldface</a>, etc.).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="formatintegration"><b>format integration</b></a>
</dt><dd>The concept in <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> that the same <a href="#field">field</a>s, <a href="#subfield">subfield</a>s, and <a href="#contentdesignator">content designator</a>s (<a href="#tag">tag</a>s, <a href="#indicator">indicator</a>s, and <a href="#subfieldcode">subfield code</a>s) should be used in <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, independent of <a href="#format">format</a> whenever possible, to record <a href="#data">data</a> of the same kind, instead of using a different set of codes for each type of <a href="#libmaterials">material</a>.  For example, in the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>, the 245 field contains the <a href="#title">title</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a>, whether the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> happens to be a <a href="#book">book</a>, music <a href="#score">score</a>, <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="formatting"><b>formatting</b></a>
</dt><dd>The appearance of <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#text">text</a>, including <a href="#font">font</a>, <a href="#typesize">type size</a>, <a href="#alignment">alignment</a>, <a href="#boldface">boldface</a>, <a href="#italic">italic</a>, underlining, etc.  In <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#software">software</a>, <a href="#option">option</a>s allow the user to specify formatting.  In <a href="#html">HTML</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s, the same effects are achieved through the use of fixed <a href="#tag">tag</a>s embedded in the text.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="forme"><b>forme</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a>, assembled <a href="#type">type</a> and <a href="#displaymatter">display matter</a> that has been <a href="#makeup">made up</a> into <a href="#page">page</a>s, imposed in a <a href="#chase">chase</a>, and firmly <a href="#lockedup">locked up</a> for transfer to the bed of the <a href="#printingpress">press</a> for <a href="#printing">printing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="formheading"><b>form heading</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, an <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a> added to a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, consisting of a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> that indicates type of <a href="#composition">composition</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>Children's poetry</b>) or <a href="#format">format</a> of <a href="#bibitem">item</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>Astronomy charts, diagrams, etc.</b>).  Compare with <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#formsubdivision">form subdivision</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="formofcomp"><b>form of composition</b></a>
</dt><dd>The structural form or shape in which a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> is composed, given in the <a href="#notearea">note area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> if it is not apparent from the <a href="#title">title</a> or other parts of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> (concerto, fantasia, fugue, nocturne, prelude, rondo, sonata, variations, etc.).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="formofentry"><b>form of entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>The specific words and spelling used to create the <a href="#heading">heading</a>s that serve as <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#index">index</a>, governed by rules concerning singular and plural forms, verb tense, syntax, <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a>, etc.  In most <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> and <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> systems, form of <a href="#entry">entry</a> for names (<a href="#personalname">personal</a> and <a href="#corporatename">corporate</a>), <a href="#title">title</a>s, and <a href="#subject">subject</a>s is also subject to <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="formsubdivision"><b>form subdivision</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> added to a <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> to divide <a href="#work">work</a>s on the same <a href="#subject">subject</a> by type of <a href="#composition">composition</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>Chaucer Geoffrey D 1400--Biography</b>) or <a href="#format">format</a> (<b>Psychology--Encyclopedias</b>).  In a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, a similar subdivision of a <a href="#class">class</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#formheading">form heading</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="forthcoming"><b>forthcoming</b></a>
</dt><dd>Soon to be <a href="#publishing">published</a>.  Usually refers to new <a href="#title">title</a>s included in a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#frontlist">frontlist</a> for the next <a href="#season">season</a>.  <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a> publishes a <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#author">author</a> and <a href="#title">title</a> <a href="#index">index</a> of <em><a href="#forthcomingbooks">Forthcoming Books</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="forthcomingbooks"><b><em>Forthcoming Books</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#author">author</a> and <a href="#title">title</a> list of <a href="#book">book</a>s to be <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the United States within the next five months, and books published since the most recent <a href="#edition">edition</a> of <em><a href="#bip">Books in Print</a></em>.  Published in <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, <b><em>Forthcoming Books</em></b> lists approximately 200,000 titles <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly.  <a href="#entry">Entries</a> include name of <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, month and <a href="#publicationdate">year of publication</a>, <a href="#listprice">price</a>, and <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foxing"><b>foxing</b></a>
</dt><dd>Reddish-brown or yellowish spots resembling freckles on the <a href="#paper">paper</a> of old <a href="#document">document</a>s (<a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#print">print</a>s, etc.), a <a href="#condition">condition</a> probably caused by fungus and/or a chemical reaction under <a href="#humidity">humid</a>
conditions, particularly common in paper made by machine during the
late 18th and 19th centuries. Although the cause (or causes) are not
fully understood, the fact that foxing often begins near the edge of a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> or <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>
and spreads inward suggests that exposure to the atmosphere may play an
important role. In some types of documents, foxing can be reduced or
eliminated by a technique called <a href="#washing">washing</a>, but <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>ists proceed with caution because some methods can cause further damage.  Synonymous with <em>foxmarks</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fps"><b>fps</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of "<a href="#frame"><b>f</b>rame</a>s <b>p</b>er <b>s</b>econd."  <b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#projectionspeed">projection speed</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frame"><b>frame</b></a>
</dt><dd>A separately <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>able area in the <a href="#window">window</a> of a computer <a href="#application">application</a> or in a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> that has been divided into more than one scrollable area.  
<p>
In <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>s, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, and <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s,
one of the individual still images arranged in sequence to tell a story
or create the illusion of movement when projected in rapid succession. <a href="#projectionspeed">Projection speed</a> is measured in <em>fps</em> (frames per second).  <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s use the frame (or frames) bearing the <a href="#title">title</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a> as the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a> in <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> such an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  Also refers to a single subdivision of the <a href="#grid">grid</a> on a sheet of <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>, or one of the units comprising a length of <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a>.
</p><p>
In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, an ornamental rectangle impressed in the surface of the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> some distance from the edges.  Compare in this sense with <a href="#border">border</a>.  Also refers to a rigid border of wood, metal, plastic, cardboard, etc., used to <a href="#mounted">mount</a> a <a href="#picture">picture</a>, <a href="#print">print</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>, <a href="#slide">slide</a>, etc. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frankfurt"><b>Frankfurt Book Fair</b></a>
</dt><dd>The largest and one of the oldest <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> <a href="#bookfair">fair</a>s in the world, held annually in Frankfurt, Germany in October, providing an opportunity for <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s to <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> their <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, negotiate international sales <a href="#rights">rights</a>, make arrangements for <a href="#copublishing">co-published</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, etc.  <a href="http://www.frankfurt-book-fair.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Frankfurt Book Fair</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frayed"><b>frayed</b></a>
