</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> on which the threads along at least one edge have broken and pulled loose due to abrasion, exposing the <a href="#board">board</a> underneath.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frbr1"><b><em>FRBR</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#frbr"><b>F</b>unctional <b>R</b>equirements for <b>B</b>ibliographic <b>R</b>ecords</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="freedom"><b>freedom of information</b></a>
</dt><dd>The statutory right of public <a href="#access">access</a> to official <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#compile">compile</a>d and maintained by federal government agencies, embodied in the <em><a href="#foia">Freedom of Information Act (FOIA)</a></em> passed by the U.S. Congress in 1966 and subsequently enacted in most European and UK countries.  Under <b><em>FOIA</em></b>, applicants who request in writing specific information must be supplied with <a href="#copy">copies</a> of the requested <a href="#document">document</a>s or <a href="#records">records</a>
within a designated period of time. Disclosure of information that
might prove harmful to national defense, foreign relations, law
enforcement, commercial activities of third parties, or personal <a href="#privacy">privacy</a> is exempted.  Compare with <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#informationlaw">information law</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="foia"><b><em>Freedom of Information Act (FOIA)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Passed by Congress in 1966, <b><em>FOIA</em></b> guarantees right of <a href="#access">access</a> to un<a href="#classified">classified</a> government <a href="#information">information</a> to any American who submits a written request to see <a href="#copy">copies</a> of specific <a href="#records">records</a> or <a href="#document">document</a>s.
The Act exempts from disclosure information that might prove harmful to
national defense, foreign relations, law enforcement, commercial
interests of third parties, or personal privacy. The intent behind <b><em>FOIA</em></b>
is to make government more transparent and accountable to citizens, and
to prevent secrecy from being used for illegitimate purposes. Similar
legislation has been enacted in most European and UK countries. <b><em>FOIA</em></b>
applies only to federal agencies and does not create right of access to
records held by Congress, the courts, or state or local government
agencies (each state has enacted its own access laws). <a href="http://www.usdoj.gov/04foia/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the official <b><em>FOIA</em></b> <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> maintained by the U.S. Department of Justice.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ftrf"><b>Freedom to Read Foundation (FTRF)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A non-profit organization founded in 1969 by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> in support of the <a href="#firstamendment">First Amendment</a> right of all Americans to read and hear the ideas of others without government interference.  The <b>FTRF</b> also fosters <a href="#library">libraries</a> in which the individual's First Amendment rights can be fulfilled, and supports the right of libraries and <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s to include in their <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s any <a href="#work">work</a> that can be legally purchased in the United States, despite objections from individuals and groups with an axe to grind.  <a href="http://www.ftrf.org/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>FTRF</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>, <a href="#ifrt">Intellectual Freedom Round Table</a>, and <em><a href="#lbor">Library Bill of Rights</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ftrs"><b><em>Freedom to Read Statement</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal declaration originally issued in May, 1953 by the Westchester Conference of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> and the American Book Publishers Council (now the <a href="#aap">Association of American Publishers</a>) which affirms the <a href="#firstamendment">First Amendment</a>
right of every American to choose without interference whatever he or
she wishes to read. The Statement was adopted by the ALA and the ABPC
in June, 1953 and revised in 1972 and 1991 by the ALA Council and the
AAP Freedom to Read Committee. <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/freeread.html">Click here</a> to read the entire <a href="#text">text</a> of the statement as <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/">Office for Intellectual Freedom</a> of the ALA.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ftrf">Freedom to Read Foundation</a> and <em><a href="#lbor">Library Bill of Rights</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="freehand"><b>free hand</b></a>
</dt><dd>Handwriting of any period that does not follow established rules with respect to <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a>, <a href="#contraction">contraction</a>, <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a>, <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> and <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a>, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="freelance"><b>freelance</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of self-employment in which a person, acting as an
independent contractor, markets and sells a specific product, skill, or
service to more than one employer (usually by the project) for a fixed <a href="#fee">fee</a> that may be payable in advance.  In the <a href="#information">information</a> sector, this mode of operation is commonly used by <a href="#literaryagent">literary agent</a>s, <a href="#informationbroker">information broker</a>s, <a href="#journalism">journalist</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ers, <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>s, and even <a href="#editor">editor</a>s.  Freelancers often work from home, rather than from a commercial address.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="freeresource"><b>free resource</b></a>
</dt><dd>A source of reliable <a href="#information">information</a> that can be obtained without charge (<em>example</em>:  telephone <a href="#directory">directories</a>).  Prior to the emergence of the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, government, business, and nonprofit organizations provided most of the free information available to <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and <a href="#library">library</a> users.  Today, information is available at no charge from a considerably wider range of sources via the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>, but the user must exercise <a href="#criticalthinking">discrimination</a> in assessing <a href="#accuracy">accuracy</a> and <a href="#authority">authority</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="freespeech"><b>free speech</b></a>
</dt><dd>Freedom under the <a href="#firstamendment">First Amendment</a> to the U.S. Constitution to write or say whatever one wishes without fear of <a href="#censorship">censorship</a> or prosecution, within certain limitations (<a href="#libel">libel</a>, <a href="#libel">slander</a>, etc.).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="freestanding"><b>free-standing shelving</b></a>
</dt><dd>Shelving designed to stand on its own, away from a wall or
other support. Most free-standing shelving is double-sided and
available in <a href="#section">section</a>s to allow the assembly of <a href="#range">range</a>s of variable length.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States, minimum <a href="#aisle">aisle</a> width between ranges is 36 inches.  Building safety codes in earthquake-prone areas may require special <a href="#bracing">bracing</a> to stabilize free-standing shelving.  Compare with <a href="#wallshelving">wall shelving</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#compactshelving">compact shelving</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="freetextsearch"><b>free-text search</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#search">search</a> of a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> in which <a href="#naturallang">natural language</a> words and <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s appearing in the <a href="#text">text</a> of the <a href="#document">document</a>s <a href="#indexing">indexed</a>, or in their <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>s, are used as <a href="#searchterm">search term</a>s, rather than terms selected from a list of <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a> (authorized <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s).  Compare with <a href="#fulltextsearch">full-text search</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#keywords">keyword(s)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="freeware"><b>freeware</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> coined in the 1980s to refer to <a href="#software">software</a> available at no cost, usually distributed over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> by the developer who retains <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>.  Compare with <a href="#shareware">shareware</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="freeze"><b>freeze</b></a>
</dt><dd>A cessation in the hiring of new personnel or the payment of funds, usually necessitated by <a href="#budget">budget</a>ary constraints.  In most cases, normal operations resume after the cause of the problem is resolved.  
<p>
Also, to stop the action and display a single <a href="#frame">frame</a> in <a href="#film">film</a>, television, or <a href="#videorecording">video</a> production, a technique used for dramatic effect.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frenchfold"><b>french fold</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#printing">printed</a> on one side and folded twice, first down its length and then at a right angle to the initial fold, to form a single <a href="#section">section</a> with the unprinted side folded in and the <a href="#bolt">bolt</a>s left uncut to form four <a href="#page">page</a>s, as in wedding invitations and greeting cards. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frequency"><b>frequency</b></a>
</dt><dd>The interval at which a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> or other <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> is <a href="#issue">issue</a>d (<a href="#daily">daily</a>, <a href="#semiweekly">semiweekly</a>, <a href="#weekly">weekly</a>, <a href="#semimonthly">semimonthly</a>, <a href="#monthly">monthly</a>, <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a>, <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a>, <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a>ly, <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly, <a href="#irregular">irregular</a>ly, etc.).  Scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a>s are usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> quarterly, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s weekly or monthly, and <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s daily or weekly.  Frequency and changes of frequency are indicated in the <a href="#notearea">note area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of a serial.
<p>
In statistics, the number of times a unit of measurement occurs within a <a href="#class">class</a>
or during a specified period of time. In electronics, the number of
repetitions of the period of an alternating current (signal), expressed
in <em>hertz</em> (cycles per second).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#megahertz">MegaHertz</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="folusa"><b>Friends of Libraries USA (FOLUSA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1979, with headquarters in Philadelphia, <b>FOLUSA</b> is an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> with a membership consisting of <a href="#friends">Friends of the Library</a> groups, <a href="#library">libraries</a>, clubs, <a href="#association">association</a>s, corporations, and individuals interested in promoting quality <a href="#library">library</a> service to all residents of the United States.  <a href="http://www.folusa.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>FOLUSA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="friends"><b>Friends of the Library (FOL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization whose members share an interest in supporting a particular <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> through <a href="#fundraising">fund-raising</a> and promotional activities.  In some libraries, the <b>Friends</b> group operates a small gift shop or conducts an annual <a href="#booksale">book sale</a>, using the proceeds to support library programs and services.  <b>Friends</b> members often serve as <a href="#volunteer">volunteer</a>s in the library, performing a variety of tasks from <a href="#mending">mending</a> to <a href="#storytelling">storytelling</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#folusa">FOLUSA</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fringes"><b>fringes</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#benefits">benefits</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frontis"><b>frontis</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#frontispiece">frontispiece</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frontispiece"><b>frontispiece</b></a>   
</dt><dd>An unnumbered, <a href="#unpaginated">unpaged</a> <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> immediately preceding the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> or first <a href="#page">page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>front</em>.  Compare with <a href="#headpiece">headpiece</a> and <a href="#tailpiece">tailpiece</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frontlist"><b>frontlist</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#list">list</a> of all the <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s published (or about to be published) during the most recent <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> season or cycle, usually heavily promoted by sales staff.  The most important <a href="#title">title</a>s in the frontlist are called <em>leaders</em>.  Also spelled <em>front-list</em>.  Compare with <a href="#backlist">backlist</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frontmatter"><b>front matter</b></a>  
</dt><dd>The parts of a <a href="#book">book</a> that precede the first <a href="#page">page</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a>.  They include, in customary but not immutable order, the <a href="#halftitle">half title</a>, <a href="#seriestitle">series title</a> or <a href="#frontispiece">frontispiece</a>, <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, <a href="#imprint">imprint</a> and <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> notice, <a href="#dedication">dedication</a>, <a href="#epigraph">epigraph</a>, <a href="#preface">preface</a>/<a href="#foreword">foreword</a>, <a href="#acknowledgments">acknowledgments</a>, <a href="#contributor">contributor</a>s, <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a>, list of <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, list of <a href="#table">table</a>s, list of <a href="#contributor">contributor</a>s, <a href="#introduction">introduction</a>, list of <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a>s, <a href="#translation">translator</a>'s note, and <a href="#errata">errata</a> or corrigenda.  Front matter is usually <a href="#pagination">paginated</a> in <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#romannumeral">roman numeral</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>preliminary matter</em>, <em>preliminaries</em>, and <em>prelims</em>.  Compare with <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#partsofabook">parts of a book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frontpage"><b>front page</b></a>
</dt><dd>The first <a href="#page">page</a> of the first <a href="#section">section</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, bearing the <a href="#flag">flag</a> and <a href="#headline">headline</a>s of the major news stories of the day.  Compare with <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frozencatalog"><b>frozen catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> to which no new <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s are added and from which no existing records are removed, even when revisions or corrections are made, or existing records <a href="#retrocon">converted</a> to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  Compare with <a href="#closedcatalog">closed catalog</a> and <a href="#opencatalog">open catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fte1"><b>FTE</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#fte"><b>f</b>ull-<b>t</b>ime <b>e</b>quivalent</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ftf1"><b>FTF</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ftf"><b>F</b>eminist <b>T</b>ask <b>F</b>orce</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ftp"><b>FTP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>F</b>ile <b>T</b>ransfer <b>P</b>rotocol, the <a href="#tcpip">TCP/IP</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> that allows <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s to be <a href="#copy">copied</a> directly from one computer to another over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> regardless of <a href="#platform">platform</a>, without having to <a href="#attachment">attach</a> them as in <a href="#email">e-mail</a>.  A computer that functions as a file <a href="#server">server</a>, <a href="#storage">storing</a> files available to other computers, is called an <em>FTP site</em>.  If no <a href="#username">username</a> or <a href="#password">password</a> is required for <a href="#access">access</a>, such a computer is an <em>anonymous FTP site</em>--its files may be <a href="#download">download</a>ed by anyone with access to the Internet.  Although still widely available, anonymous FTP has been supplanted by the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a> as the most popular mode of disseminating <a href="#information">information</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fugitive"><b>fugitive material</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publication">Publication</a>s such as <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, performance and <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>
programs, and duplicated material produced in small quantities, which
are of immediate, local, or transitory interest and therefore difficult
for <a href="#library">libraries</a> to <a href="#libcollec">collect</a> and <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#ephemera">ephemera</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fulfillmentyear"><b>fulfillment year</b></a>
</dt><dd>The period of time during which the <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s who have paid for an <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> are entitled to receive <a href="#issue">issue</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#subscripcycle">subscription cycle</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#renewal">renewal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fullbinding"><b>full binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A style of <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> in which the <a href="#spine">spine</a> and <a href="#board">board</a>s are covered in material entirely of one kind, originally <a href="#leather">leather</a>, but in modern <a href="#binding">binding</a> usually some kind of <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>.  Compare with <a href="#quarterbinding">quarter binding</a>, <a href="#halfbinding">half binding</a>, and <a href="#threequarter">three-quarter binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fullcolor"><b>full-color printing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of reproducing in <a href="#printing">print</a> an infinite range of colors by controlling the overprinting of three colors of <a href="#ink">ink</a> (yellow, magenta, and cyan), with black added to create gradations of light and dark.  The term <em>color separation</em> refers to the process by which a full-color <a href="#original">original</a> is <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ed through colored filters or scanned by a color sensing machine to separate the colors and allow <a href="#negative">negative</a>s to be produced that define the area to be <a href="#printing">printed</a> with each color of ink.  Compare with <a href="#duotone">duotone</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fullduplex"><b>full-duplex</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#duplex">duplex</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fulllevel"><b>full level cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd>The most complete form of general <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, applied to <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> not designated for one of the other <a href="#encodinglevel">encoding level</a>s, producing a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> that contains the fullest set of <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s, including a complete <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a <a href="#recordstructure">record structure</a>d to facilitate descriptive and <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#access">access</a>.  Compare with <a href="#corelevel">core level cataloging</a> and <a href="#minimallevel">minimal level cataloging</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fullmeasure"><b>full measure</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#type">type</a> extending across the entire width of a line in a <a href="#column">column</a> or on a <a href="#page">page</a>, without <a href="#indention">indention</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fullmotion"><b>full-motion video</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#videorecording">Video</a> transmission in which the image changes at the rate of 30 <a href="#frame">frame</a>s per second (fps).  <a href="#motionpicture">Motion picture</a>s run at 24 fps.  Video that has been <a href="#digitization">digitized</a> and <a href="#storage">stored</a> on computer can be displayed at varying frame rates depending on the speed of the computer.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fullpage"><b>full-page</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in <a href="#printing">printing</a> to refer to an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, <a href="#plate">plate</a>, or <a href="#map">map</a> that fills an entire <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, with or without <a href="#margin">margin</a>s and <a href="#caption">caption</a>.  Also refers to an <a href="#article">article</a> that fills all the available space on one page of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fullpageborder"><b>full-page border</b></a>
</dt><dd>Continuous ornamentation, plain or simple, extending around the perimeter of a <a href="#page">page</a> on all four sides.  A three-quarter <a href="#border">border</a> extends around three of the four sides.  In medieval <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, a decorative band surrounding a <a href="#miniature">miniature</a> or portion of <a href="#text">text</a>
on all four sides, usually covering the surface of the page in a dense
carpet of multicolored vines, leaves, flowers, birds, and animals,
except for very narrow <a href="#margin">margin</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fullpoint"><b>full point</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printer">printer</a>'s term for the <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a> mark used to indicate the end of an ordinary sentence, and as a mark of <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a>.  Synonymous with <a href="#period">period</a> and <a href="#fullstop">full stop</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fullrecord"><b>full record</b></a>
</dt><dd>The most complete display of <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s contained in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> created to represent an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, including all the <a href="#field">field</a>s and <a href="#subfield">subfield</a>s needed to identify and describe the item, as opposed to a <a href="#briefrecord">brief record</a> in which only a portion of the available <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> is shown.  Most <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s provide both <a href="#format">format</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fullscore"><b>full score</b></a>
</dt><dd>A music <a href="#score">score</a> in which each of the <a href="#part">part</a>s is written on a separate <a href="#stave">stave</a>, usually for the use of the conductor.  For orchestral and choral <a href="#work">work</a>s, this usually requires a large <a href="#page">page</a>
size. From top to bottom, the standard arrangement of instrumental
parts in a full score is: woodwinds, brass, percussion, and strings,
with any solo part in a concerto appearing above the violins. Voice
parts, arranged in descending order of vocal register, are placed above
the string section, with any solo parts given above the chorus. Only
the largest <a href="#musiclibrary">music libraries</a> collect this type of score.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fullstop"><b>full stop</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#period">period</a>, a <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a> mark used in <a href="#text">text</a> to indicate the end of a sentence, and in <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s to separate <a href="#element">element</a>s of <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a>.  When used to divide the parts of an <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a>, it is called a <a href="#dot">dot</a>.  Synonymous with <a href="#fullpoint">full point</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fulltext"><b>full-text</b></a>
</dt><dd>An electronic resource that provides the entire <a href="#text">text</a> of a single <a href="#work">work</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Britannica Online</em></b>) or a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> that provides the entire text of a significant proportion of the works  <a href="#index">index</a>ed in it, in addition to the <a href="#citation">citation</a> and (in most cases) an <a href="#abstract">abstract</a> of each work (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="#jstor">JSTOR</a></em>).  Also spelled <em>fulltext</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fulltextsearch"><b>full-text search</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#search">search</a> of a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> in which every word of the <a href="#text">text</a> of each <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> or <a href="#document">document</a> is searched and the <a href="#entry">entry</a> <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a> if the <a href="#term">term</a>s included in the <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a> are present.  Most <a href="#www">Web</a> <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>s are designed to perform <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> searches.  This can pose a problem for the user when a <a href="#searchterm">search term</a> has more than one meaning, causing <a href="#relevance">irrelevant</a> <a href="#information">information</a> (<a href="#falsedrop">false drop</a>s) to be retrieved.  For example, in a medical <a href="#database">database</a>, the <a href="#query">query</a> "treatment of AIDS" might retrieve entries for sources on the role of "hearing-aids in geriatric treatment" (the <a href="#stopword">stopword</a> "of" is ignored in the query).  Compare with <a href="#freetextsearch">free-text search</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fulltime"><b>full-time</b></a>
</dt><dd>Employment for the number of working hours considered normal for a given <a href="#position">position</a>, in the United States no more than forty hours per week without payment of <a href="#overtime">overtime</a>.  Full-time employees are usually entitled to full <a href="#benefits">benefits</a>.  At some academic institutions, the ratio of full-time to <a href="#parttime">part-time</a> (<a href="#adjunct">adjunct</a>) faculty, including <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, is governed by a <a href="#collectivebargaining">collective bargaining agreement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fte"><b>full-time equivalent (FTE)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A measure of the total <a href="#number">number</a> of
students, undergraduate and graduate, enrolled for the number of credit
hours considered by an institution of higher learning to be a full
schedule, sometimes used by <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s to determine <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> rates charged on a sliding scale for <a href="#access">access</a> to electronic resources such as <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s.  In the United States, there is no national <a href="#standard">standard</a> for computing <b>FTE</b>--each
institution has devised its own formula. A typical example: FTE = total
number of undergraduate credit hours divided by 15, plus total number
of graduate credit hours divided by 12. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fumigation"><b>fumigation</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>, the process of exposing items made of <a href="#paper">paper</a> and other materials to a toxic vapor within an airtight container to eliminate insects, <a href="#mildew">mildew</a>, <a href="#mold">mold</a>,
and other organisms that damage collections. When an infestation is
extensive, fumigation of the area(s) in which the affected items are
stored may also be necessary.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="functionality"><b>functionality</b></a>
</dt><dd>Features built into a search <a href="#interface">interface</a> that determine the ease with which users may formulate <a href="#query">queries</a> and obtain results.  Well-designed <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a> enables the user to:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><li>Identify the <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>(s) most appropriate to the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the <a href="#search">search</a>
</li><li>Search more than one database simultaneously
</li><li>Remove <a href="#duplicate">duplicate</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s from results when searching multiple databases
</li><li>View a <a href="#currency">current</a> list of the <a href="#publication">publication</a>s <a href="#index">index</a>ed in each database
</li><li>Choose a search mode based on proficiency (basic or advanced)
</li><li><a href="#access">Access</a> well-organized <a href="#context">context</a>ual <a href="#helpscreen">help</a> at each stage of the <a href="#search">search</a> process
</li><li>View an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> or use <a href="#vocabmap">vocabulary mapping</a> to identify appropriate <a href="#searchterm">search term</a>s
</li><li><a href="#limiting">Limit</a> search results by <a href="#relevance">relevance</a>, <a href="#materialtype">material type</a>, <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, <a href="#language">language</a>, institutional <a href="#holdings">holdings</a>, latest <a href="#update">update</a>, <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a>, etc.
</li><li><a href="#sorting">Sort</a> results by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, publication date, etc. 
</li><li>View search terms highlighted in results
</li><li>Select/deselect records as <a href="#output">output</a> 
</li><li>View and <a href="#save">save</a> <a href="#searchhistory">search history</a>
</li><li>Save results independent of <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>
</li><li><a href="#printing">Print</a>, <a href="#email">email</a>, and <a href="#download">download</a> results in a range of <a href="#format">format</a>s</li></dd></dl>  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="frbr"><b><em>Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records (FRBR)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of fundamental elements forming the theoretical basis for <a href="#catalogrecord">record</a>s created by <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s to represent <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>.  <b><em>FRBR</em></b> was developed by an <a href="#ifla">IFLA</a> study group in response to a <a href="#resolution">resolution</a>
passed at the 1990 Stockholm Seminar on Bibliographic Records calling
for a clear delineation of the functions performed by the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> with respect to <a href="#medium">media</a>, applications, and user needs.  <b><em>FRBR</em></b> addresses not only <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, but also <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s, organizing elements (<a href="#classification">classification</a>), and <a href="#annotation">annotation</a>s.  
<p>
In the years following the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of <em>International Bibliographic Description for Monographic Publications</em> (1971), major changes occurred in the environment in which <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> principles and <a href="#standards">standards</a> operate, such as the expansion of automated systems, the development of large-scale <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s by national <a href="#catagency">cataloging agencies</a>, and the emergence of <a href="#network">network</a>ed <a href="#access">access</a> to electronic <a href="#information">information</a> and new forms of <a href="#electronicpub">electronic publishing</a>, which have increased the pressure on catalogers to reduce costs by doing more <a href="#minimallevel">minimal level cataloging</a>.  These changes necessitated a comprehensive re-examination of cataloging theory.  
</p><p>
In the user-focused study that produced <b><em>FRBR</em></b>, no <em>a priori</em> assumptions were made about the nature of the bibliographic record.  The study group used <em>entity analysis</em>, a technique for constructing conceptual models of relational <a href="#database">database</a>s, to generate a model based on three basic elements:  the <a href="#entity">entities</a> of interest to users of bibliographic records, the <a href="#attribute">attribute</a>s of each entity, and the <a href="#relationship">relationship</a>s between entities.  <a href="http://www.ifla.org/VII/s13/frbr/frbr.htm">Click here</a> to read the final <a href="#report">report</a> of the IFLA Study Group on <b><em>FRBR</em></b>, approved by the Standing Committee of the IFLA Section on Cataloging in 1997 and <a href="#publishing">published</a> by K. G. Saur Munchen in 1998. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="functionky"><b>function key</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of twelve keys numbered F1-F12 from left to right across the top row of  a standard <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a> <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> to allow the user to execute a specific task or <a href="#routine">routine</a> in a <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a> by pressing the appropriate key.  The program-specific function associated with each key in the program is explained in the <a href="#documentation">documentation</a> provided with the <a href="#software">software</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fundraising"><b>fund-raising</b></a>
</dt><dd>Programs and activities intended to encourage benefactors to contribute a portion of their wealth to a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, in support of <a href="#capitalexp">capital project</a>s and <a href="#operatingbudget">operating expenditure</a>s.  Some <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> and large <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> have an <a href="#endowment">endowment</a> fund to which potential benefactors are encouraged to contribute.  <a href="#lsta">LSTA</a> <a href="#grantinaid">grants-in-aid</a> often require the local community to provide <a href="#matchinggrant">matching funds</a>.  Also spelled <em>fundraising</em>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="furtherreading"><b>further reading</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> of sources provided by the <a href="#author">author</a> for the benefit of <a href="#reader">reader</a>s who wish to extend their knowledge of the <a href="#subject">subject</a>(s) treated in the <a href="#work">work</a> to which it is appended, distinct from a list of works <a href="#cite">cite</a>d, a common feature of introductory works used as <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s at the undergraduate level.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fuzzylogic"><b>fuzzy logic</b></a>
</dt><dd>The branch of logic that recognizes a possible range of
intermediate values between the logical extremes of true and false,
similar to the way the human mind evaluates complex situations. Because
fuzzy logic allows degrees of uncertainty and imprecision to be
expressed in the representation of <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>, it has proved useful in <a href="#artificial">artificial intelligence</a> and the design of <a href="#expertsystem">expert system</a>s.  In <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#software">software</a>, it has been incorporated into some <a href="#spellchecker">spell checker</a>s to suggest to the user the most likely substitutions for a misspelled word.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>
<center>| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> | <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a>
| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="G">G</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="gale"><b>Gale Group</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of major <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#serial">serial</a>s (<em>Contemporary Authors</em>, <em><a href="#encyassoc">Encyclopedia of Associations</a></em>, <em>Market Share Reporter</em>, etc.), in <a href="#print">print</a> and <a href="#online">online</a>, for <a href="#library">libraries</a>, educational institutions, and businesses worldwide.  <b>Gale</b> is also one of the three leading <a href="#aggregator">aggregator</a>s of <a href="#journal">journal</a>s in electronic <a href="#format">format</a>, providing online <a href="#access">access</a> to a range of <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic</a> and <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#database">database</a>s.  <a href="http://www.galegroup.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Gale</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ebsco">EBSCO</a> and <a href="#proquest">ProQuest</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="galley"><b>galley</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a long narrow tray open at one end, into which assembled lines of <a href="#type">type</a> are transferred by the <a href="#compositor">compositor</a> from a manual composing <a href="#stick">stick</a>, or from a <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a> machine, to await <a href="#makeup">make-up</a> into <a href="#page">page</a>s.
Galleys were originally about 10 x 6 inches in size and made of wood,
but in the early 19th century, metal trays came into use and their
length was extended to about 22 inches to accommodate several pages of
type. Also used as a shortened form of <a href="#galleyproof">galley proof</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="galleyproof"><b>galley proof</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#impression">impression</a> taken from <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#composition">composed</a> in long columns, arranged in trays called <a href="#galley">galley</a>s, before it has been <a href="#makeup">made up</a> into <a href="#page">page</a>s, to allow the <a href="#author">author</a> and <a href="#proofreading">proofreader</a> to inspect the <a href="#text">text</a> and make any corrections before the <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#gonetopress">goes to press</a>.  Although galley <a href="#proof">proof</a>s usually do <em>not</em> include <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s and <a href="#index">index</a>es, <a href="#review">review</a>s may be written from them.  Synonymous with <em>galleys</em> and <em>slip proof</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="galleys"><b>galleys</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#galleyproof">galley proof</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="game"><b>game</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of materials designed for play according to an established set of rules, usually housed in a <a href="#container">container</a> to keep the pieces together.  Educational games are usually stored in the <a href="#curriculumroom">curriculum room</a> or <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>.  Compare with <a href="#kit">kit</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gap"><b>gap</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> representing a <a href="#serial">serial</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a>, an indication that <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d are missing from the sequence <a href="#holdings">held</a> by the library.  This happens when a <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> is <a href="#canceled">canceled</a> and later resumed, or when issues or <a href="#volume">volume</a>s are <a href="#lost">lost</a> due to <a href="#damaged">damage</a> or <a href="#theft">theft</a>.  Most libraries make an effort to fill gaps in <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> subscriptions with <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> or <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> if <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> is not available.  Compare with <a href="#nongapbreak">nongap break</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="garland"><b>garland</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#anthology">anthology</a> containing a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#prose">prose</a> <a href="#extract">extract</a>s or short literary <a href="#composition">composition</a>s, usually <a href="#ballad">ballad</a>s or <a href="#poetry">poems</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>A Little Garland of Celtic Verse</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1905 by T. B. Mosher). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gatecount"><b>gate count</b></a>
</dt><dd>The number of times a counting device, attached to or located near the <a href="#securitygate">security gate</a> at the entrance to or <a href="#exit">exit</a> from a <a href="#library">library</a>, is activated during a designated period of time (day, week, or month).  Gate counts provide statistical <a href="#information">information</a> on traffic patterns which can be helpful in establishing library <a href="#hours">hours</a> and anticipating <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ing needs.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gatefold"><b>gatefold</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, <a href="#map">map</a>, or other <a href="#insert">insert</a>, larger than the <a href="#volume">volume</a> in which it is <a href="#binding">bound</a>, which must be unfolded horizontally to the left or right to be fully viewed.  Also, a method of folding a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> into three sections in which the two ends are folded toward each other over the center, like a <a href="#diptych">triptych</a>, used in advertising, performance programs, restaurant menus, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gateway"><b>gateway</b></a>
</dt><dd>Computer <a href="#software">software</a> that allows a user to <a href="#access">access</a> <a href="#data">data</a> stored on a <a href="#host">host</a> computer via a <a href="#network">network</a>.  Also refers to the <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> <a href="#device">device</a> that interconnects two separate networks, providing a pathway for the transfer of data and any <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> conversion required, for example, between the messaging protocols of two different <a href="#email">e-mail</a> systems.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gathering"><b>gathering</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, the process of assembling and arranging in correct sequence the folded <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> prior to <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> them through the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a>, or before <a href="#milling">milling</a> the clamped back folds and <a href="#gluingoff">gluing</a> the sections to the <a href="#cover">cover</a> in <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive binding</a>.  Sometimes used synonymously with <a href="#signature">signature</a> and <a href="#quire">quire</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gauffering"><b>gauffering</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#chasededges">chased edges</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gauze"><b>gauze</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#crash">crash</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glbtrt"><b>Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, and Transgendered Round Table (GLBTRT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1970 as the Task Force on Gay Liberation of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>GLBTRT</b> is a permanent <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> that serves as an advocate for gays, lesbians, and bisexuals employed in <a href="#library">libraries</a>, and for the inclusion of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> on gay, lesbian, and bisexual issues in <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s.  <b>GLBTRT</b> hosts the electronic <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a> GLBTRT-L, sponsors <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a>s in <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>, and <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em>GLBTRT Newsletter</em>.  <a href="http://calvin.usc.edu/%7Etrimmer/ala_hp.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>GLBTRT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#lambda">Lambda Book Report</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gaylord"><b>Gaylord</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#supplier">supplier</a> that provides office and <a href="#librarysupplies">library supplies</a>, furniture, <a href="#securitysystem">security system</a>s, and automation <a href="#software">software</a> to <a href="#library">libraries</a>, schools, and other educational institutions largely through its <a href="#tradecatalog">trade catalog</a>.  <a href="http://www.gaylord.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Gaylord</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gazette"><b>gazette</b></a>
</dt><dd>A news <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> in which <a href="#currency">current</a> events, legal notices, public appointments, etc., are <a href="#record">record</a>ed on a regular basis.  Formerly, a <a href="#journal">journal</a> devoted to current news.  Also, a journal officially <a href="#issue">issue</a>d
by a government, particularly in Great Britain. The word is derived
from the name of an Italian coin that was equivalent at one point in
time to the price of a news sheet. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gazetteer"><b>gazetteer</b></a>      
</dt><dd>A <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a> <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> of <a href="#geographicname">geographic name</a>s that gives the location of each <a href="#entry">entry</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Columbia Gazetteer of the World</em></b>).  Also, an <a href="#index">index</a> of the names of the places and geographic features shown in an <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> in a separate section following the <a href="#map">map</a>s, with locations indicated by <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a> or map number and <a href="#grid">grid</a> <a href="#coordinate">coordinate</a>s.  Some <a href="#book">book</a>-length gazetteers include basic <a href="#information">information</a> about major geographic features such as rivers, lakes, mountains, cities, etc.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>gaz</em>.  <a href="http://www.census.gov/cgi-bin/gazetteer">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> <b><em>U.S. Gazetteer</em></b> provided by the U.S. <a href="#census">Census</a> Bureau.  
<p>
Also refers to person who writes or <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> a <a href="#gazette">gazette</a>.    
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="genealogicaltable"><b>genealogical table</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#diagram">diagram</a>, usually in the form of an
inverted tree, with branches showing the lineage of a person or group
of persons who share a common ancestor, sometimes <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s of <a href="#biography">biographical</a> or historical <a href="#work">work</a>s, particularly those concerning the reigns of sovereigns or the lives of <a href="#title">title</a>d nobility.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="genealogy"><b>genealogy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The study of the descent from a common ancestor (or ancestors)
of a specific individual, family, or group of persons. Genealogical <a href="#research">research</a> often requires the use of <a href="#archives">archival</a> materials.  Genealogical resources are increasingly available in <a href="#digital">digital</a> form (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.rootsweb.com/%7Eusgenweb/">US GenWeb Archives</a>).  
<p>
Also refers to an enumeration of ancestors and their descendants in
natural order of succession, usually in the form of a "family tree." In
<a href="#work">work</a>s of history and <a href="#biography">biography</a>, <a href="#genealogicaltable">genealogical table</a>s are sometimes <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s or at the beginning of the <a href="#text">text</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ngs">National Genealogical Society</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="generalencyclopedia"><b>general encyclopedia</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a> that provides basic <a href="#information">information</a> on a broad range of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s, but treats no single subject in depth (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Encyclopedia Americana</em></b>), as distinct from a <a href="#subjectencyclopedia">subject encyclopedia</a> that provides greater depth of coverage within a limited <a href="#scope">scope</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Encyclopedia of 20th Century American Humor</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="generalia"><b>generalia</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#work">Work</a>s that cannot be assigned to a particular <a href="#class">class</a> on the basis of <a href="#subject">subject</a>, theme, or <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> because their non<a href="#specialization">specialized</a> or diverse nature defies specific <a href="#classification">classification</a>, for example, general <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s and world <a href="#almanac">almanac</a>s.  In <a href="#library">library</a> classification and <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, a separate category is reserved for general works, usually appearing at the beginning of the <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a> or list.  Synonymous with <em>generalities</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="genintmag"><b>general interest magazine</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> of interest to a wide <a href="#audience">audience</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Reader's Digest</em></b>).  Most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> make an effort to <a href="#subscription">subscribe</a> to the most popular general interest magazines, but are more selective in subscribing to <a href="#specintmag">special interest magazine</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#newsmagazine">news magazine</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gmd"><b>general material designation (GMD)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An optional <a href="#term">term</a> added in <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s to the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of a <a href="#nonbook">nonbook</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> following the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> to indicate type of material, for example, [videorecording].  Separate lists of general material designations are provided in <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em> for British and North American <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  In some categories, the British list is more general (<em>object</em> includes <a href="#diorama">diorama</a>, <a href="#game">game</a>, <a href="#microscopeslide">microscope slide</a>, <a href="#model">model</a>, and <a href="#realia">realia</a>).  The <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> does <em>not</em> to include the GMD in <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s for <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, music, and <a href="#text">text</a>.  Compare with <a href="#materialtype">material type</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#specificmaterial">specific material designation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="generation"><b>generation</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#reprography">reprography</a>, the degree to which a <a href="#copy">copy</a> is removed from the <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#document">document</a>.  In <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a>, the <a href="#masternegative">master negative</a> developed from <a href="#film">film</a> taken of the original image is <em>first-generation</em>, <a href="#printmaster">print master</a>s made from the <a href="#master">master</a> <a href="#negative">negative</a> are <em>second-generation</em>, and <a href="#servicecopy">service copies</a> made from a print master for use in <a href="#library">libraries</a> are <em>third-generation</em>.  Sharpness of image usually declines with each succeeding generation.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="genericrelation"><b>generic relation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="genre"><b>genre</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type, class, or style of <a href="#literature">literature</a>, music, <a href="#film">film</a>, or art.  Genre <a href="#criticism">criticism</a> originated with Aristotle who divided literature into three basic categories:  dramatic, <a href="#epic">epic</a>, and lyric.  In <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, genre are based on form (<a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>, etc.), theme (<a href="#christianfiction">Christian</a>, <a href="#fantasy">fantasy</a>, <a href="#horror">horror</a>, <a href="#mystery">mystery</a>, <a href="#romance">romance</a>, <a href="#sciencefiction">science fiction</a>, <a href="#western">western</a>, etc.), or <a href="#format">format</a> (<a href="#graphicnovel">graphic novel</a>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#subgenre">subgenre</a>.
<p>
Also, a painting in which the <a href="#subject">subject</a> is a person (as in a <a href="#portrait">portrait</a>),
an object (as in a still-life), or a scene from daily life, rather than
a theme derived from history, mythology, imagination, etc. By
extension, a <em>genre piece</em> is a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> that has as its subject people and incidents from everyday life.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="geographicindex"><b>geographic index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#index">index</a> in which the <a href="#entry">entries</a>
are listed by their geographic location (city, state, country, etc.).
Also refers to an index that lists the geographic locations mentioned
in the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a>.  Synonymous with <em>place index</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#gazetteer">gazetteer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gis"><b>geographic information system (GIS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer-based system (<a href="#hardware">hardware</a> <em>and</em> <a href="#software">software</a>) designed to facilitate the mathematical manipulation and analysis of spatially distributed <a href="#data">data</a>
(geographic phenomena, geologic resources, etc.), which provides an
automated link between the data and its location in space, usually in
relation to a system of coordinates. The data can be on any <a href="#scale">scale</a>, from microscopic to global.  A <b>GIS</b> differs from a <a href="#map">map</a> in being a <a href="#digital">digital</a>, rather than an <a href="#analog">analog</a>,
representation. Each spatial feature is stored as a separate layer of
data which can be easily altered using techniques of quantitative
analysis. A map can be <a href="#input">input</a> or <a href="#output">output</a> in a <b>GIS</b>, but the output may also be one or more data sets.  In the plural, the <a href="#term">term</a> refers to the <a href="#field">field</a> within the earth sciences, which is devoted to the study of computer-based systems for analyzing spatial data.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="geographicname"><b>geographic name</b></a>
</dt><dd>The name most commonly used to identify a specific geographic location, feature, or area, preferred by <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s in establishing the correct <a href="#formofentry">form of entry</a>, not necessarily the same as the <a href="#politicalname">political name</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>France</b> instead of Republique francaise).  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/geogname.html">Click here</a> to connect to <em>Geographic Names and the World Wide Web</em>, a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> <a href="#host">host</a>ed by the <a href="#cataloging">Cataloging</a> Policy and Support Office of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  Synonymous with <em>place name</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#corporatename">corporate name</a>, <a href="#personalname">personal name</a>, and <em><a href="#tgn">Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names</a></em>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="geographic"><b>geographic subdivision</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a>, the <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a> of a <a href="#class">class</a> by geographic location (region, country, state, city, etc.).  For example, in <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a> the subdivision of the class <b>P</b> (<a href="#literature">literature</a>) into <b>PR</b> (English literature), <b>PS</b> (American literature), etc.  Also, the extension of an existing <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> by the addition of a <a href="#subheading">subheading</a> indicating the place or geographic unit to which it applies (<em>example</em>:  <b>School violence--United States</b>).  In the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject headings</a> list, the option to subdivide geographically is indicated by the note <em>(May Subd Geog)</em> or <em>(Not Subd Geog)</em>).  Synonymous with <em>local subdivision</em> and <em>place subdivision</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="geologicalsurvey"><b>geological survey</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization that prepares and <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#chart">chart</a>s, and other <a href="#cartographic">cartographic material</a> concerning the geography of a specific nation and its territories, usually with government approval or sponsorship (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.usgs.gov/">U.S. Geological Survey</a>).  In <a href="#library">libraries</a> without a separate map section, <a href="#publication">publication</a>s of the USGS may be shelved in the <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="geologicmap"><b>geologic map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> that shows the distribution of the
different types of rock and sediment lying beneath the surface of a
specific region, usually by means of color, shading, and/or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s.  Major fault lines, mineral deposits, fossils, and the age of rock formations may also be indicated.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="dbv"><b>German Library Association (DBV)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1949 with headquarters in Berlin, the <b>Deutscher Bibliotheksverband e. V.</b> promotes <a href="#library">library</a> services and professional <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a> in Germany, and <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>Bibliotheksdienst</em>.  <a href="http://www.bibliotheksverband.de/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>DBV</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tgn"><b><em>Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names (TGN)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#searchable">searchable</a> <a href="#database">database</a> of <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a>, containing over one million names and other details concerning places, maintained on the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> by the Getty Research Institute in Los Angeles, California.  Although the terms are not <a href="#link">link</a>ed to <a href="#map">map</a>s, longitude and latitude are given in each <a href="#entry">entry</a>, with the place name's position in a hierarchy of <a href="#geographicname">geographic name</a>s.  <a href="http://www.getty.edu/research/tools/vocabulary/tgn/">Click here</a> to connect to <b><em>TGN</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ghost"><b>ghost</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> or <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a work <a href="#record">record</a>ed in <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a>, <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, or other <a href="#source">source</a>s, of whose actual existence there is no conclusive evidence.  Synonymous with <em>bibliographical ghost</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ghostwriter"><b>ghost writer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who writes or prepares a <a href="#work">work</a> for, and in the name of, another person who may be famous but is usually not a writer by profession.  <a href="#autobiography">Autobiographies</a> and <a href="#memoirs">memoirs</a> are often written in this way.  A ghost writer is normally paid for his or her services, and may or may not be listed on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> as <a href="#jointauthor">joint author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gif"><b>GIF</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <b>G</b>raphics <b>I</b>nterchange <b>F</b>ormat, one of the two most commonly used <a href="#file">file</a> <a href="#format">format</a>s for storing <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> images displayed on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a> (the other being <a href="#jpeg">JPEG</a>).  An <a href="#algorithm">algorithm</a> developed by <a href="http://www.unisys.com/unisys/lzw/">Unisys</a>, <b>GIF</b> is protected by <a href="#patent">patent</a>, but in practice the company has not required users to obtain a <a href="#licensing">license</a>.  The most recent version of <b>GIF</b> supports color, animation, and <a href="#datacompression">data compression</a>.  Pronounced <em>jiff</em> or <em>giff</em> (with a hard <em>g</em>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gift"><b>gift</b></a>
</dt><dd>One or more <a href="#book">book</a>s or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s donated to a <a href="#library">library</a>, usually by an individual, but sometimes by a group, organization, estate, or other library.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, <a href="#deskcopy">desk copies</a> and <a href="#reviewcopy">review copies</a>
are sometimes received as gifts from members of the teaching faculty.
Donated items are usually evaluated in accordance with the library's <a href="#collecdevelpolicy">collection development policy</a>, and either added to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> or disposed of, usually in a <a href="#booksale">book sale</a> or <a href="#exchange">exchange</a> with another library.  Compare with <a href="#donation">donation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="giftbook"><b>gift book</b></a>
</dt><dd>An elaborately <a href="#printing">printed</a>, expensively <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a>, ornately <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#book">book</a> of <a href="#poetry">poetry</a> or <a href="#prose">prose</a>, usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly, popular as a gift item during the early part of the 19th century.  Also known as a <em>keepsake</em>.  In modern usage, a book purchased as a gift for another person (or persons).  <a href="#coffee">Coffee table book</a>s are often purchased for this purpose.  Also spelled <em>giftbook</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gigabyte"><b>gigabyte (GB)</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#byte">byte</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gigo"><b>GIGO</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, an <a href="#initialism">initialism</a> that stands for "garbage in, garbage out," a <a href="#slang">slang</a> expression for the axiom that the quality of <a href="#output">output</a> a user receives from a computer is directly proportional to the quality of the <a href="#input">input</a> submitted.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="giltedges"><b>gilt edges</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a>s, <a href="#goldleaf">gold leaf</a> is sometimes applied to the <a href="#head">head</a>, <a href="#tail">tail</a>, and/or <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of each <a href="#copy">copy</a>, then <a href="#burnish">burnish</a>ed to create an especially luxurious appearance.   In the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> "ge" means <em>gilt edges</em>, "aeg" means <em>all edges gilt</em>, "gt" means <em>gilt top</em>, and "teg" means <em>top edge gilt</em>.  Left unburnished, a gilt edge is called <em>antique</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gis1"><b>GIS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#gis"><b>g</b>eographic <b>i</b>nformation <b>s</b>ystem</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="givenname"><b>given name</b></a>
</dt><dd>One or more names chosen for a person, usually by the parents at birth or christening (<em>example</em>:  <b>Emily</b>), sometimes the same as that of a living relative or ancestor, but distinct from the <a href="#surname">surname</a> identifying members of the same family (<em>example</em>:  <b>Dickinson</b>).  Given names can be <a href="#compoundname">compound</a> (<em>example</em>: <b>Marie-Louise</b>).  Compare with <a href="#firstname">first name</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glair"><b>glair</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> preparation made from egg whites, used in <a href="#giltedges">edge gilding</a> and <a href="#tooling">tooling</a> to permanently fix silver and <a href="#goldleaf">gold leaf</a>.
Glair is usually purchased dry as albumen and mixed with water or
vinegar prior to use. It melts with the application of heat and sets up
quickly as soon as the hot <a href="#finishing">finishing</a> tool is removed, securing the leaf firmly to the surface.  Also spelled <em>glaire</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glaire"><b>glaire</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#glair">glair</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glassine"><b>glassine</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of thin, dense, translucent glazed <a href="#paper">paper</a> sometimes used to protect the <a href="#cover">cover</a>s of <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s.
Also used for panels in window-envelopes and as wrapping material
because it is resistant to the passage of air, water, grease, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glbtrt1"><b>GLBTRT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#glbtrt"><b>G</b>ay, <b>L</b>esbian, <b>B</b>isexual, and <b>T</b>ransgendered <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glitch"><b>glitch</b></a>
</dt><dd>A malfunction in the <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> of a computer system, usually temporary or random, sometimes difficult to distinguish from a <a href="#bug">bug</a> in the <a href="#software">software</a>.  In a more general sense, any unanticipated problem that brings a process to a halt.  Also spelled <em>glytch</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="globe"><b>globe</b></a>
</dt><dd>A representation of the surface of the earth, or of another
celestial body, on a relatively permanent spherical object. A globe is
usually more accurate than a <a href="#map">map</a> because it is free
of the distortion inherent in a two-dimensional representation of a
three-dimensional object. Globes are made of heavy <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#papiermache">papier-mache</a>,
cardboard, plastic, metal, or glass, mounted on a full- or
half-meridian axel, in a free cradle, or with gyroscopic support.
Expensive models may be illuminated and/or animated for special effect.
In the United States, the most common sizes are 12 inches and 16 inches
in diameter.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gloss"><b>gloss</b></a>
</dt><dd>In old <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, an explanation, <a href="#definition">definition</a>, or interpretation of a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, sometimes in a more familiar <a href="#language">language</a>, written on a <a href="#margin">margin</a>, above the line of <a href="#text">text</a> to which it refers, or in a special <a href="#appendix">appendix</a> called a <a href="#glossary">glossary</a>, <a href="#compile">compile</a>d by a person known as a <em>glossator</em>, <em>glossographer</em>, or <em>glossarist</em>.  In modern <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a note on the left- or right-hand margin is called a <a href="#sidenote">side note</a> and is usually set in a <a href="#typesize">type size</a> smaller than that of the text to which it refers.  Compare with <a href="#interlinear">interlinear</a> matter.
<p>
Also refers to a deliberately misleading interpretation.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glossarial"><b>glossarial concordance</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#concordance">concordance</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glossarialindex"><b>glossarial index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#index">index</a> at the end of a <a href="#book">book</a> (or <a href="#set">set</a> of books) that includes in each <a href="#entry">entry</a> a <a href="#definition">definition</a> or description of the <a href="#term">term</a> indexed, as well as the <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>(s) referenced.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glossary"><b>glossary</b></a>       
</dt><dd>An <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> list of the <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#term">term</a>s related to a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#field">field</a> of study, with brief <a href="#definition">definition</a>s, often appearing at the end of a <a href="#book">book</a> or at the beginning of a long <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a technical <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>.  Long glossaries may be <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a>, for example, <b><em>The ALA Glossary of Library and Information Science</em></b> (1983).  Compare with <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>, <a href="#lexicon">lexicon</a>, and <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#gloss">gloss</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a list of equivalent <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>s in more than one <a href="#language">language</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glossink"><b>gloss ink</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#printing">Printing</a> <a href="#ink">ink</a> that appears shiny even when dry because it contains a higher than normal proportion of <a href="#varnish">varnish</a>, used mainly in display work.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glossy"><b>glossy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#finish">finish</a> in which the surface of <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#board">board</a> is given a smooth, shiny coat of <a href="#varnish">varnish</a> to enhance the appearance of visual material (<a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, etc.).  Most <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s are <a href="#printing">printed</a> on glossy paper to attract <a href="#readership">readership</a>, as are <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>s to heighten the sales appeal of <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s.  In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the term also refers to a photograph printed on smooth, shiny paper, the format preferred by <a href="#printer">printer</a>s in <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> work.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glue"><b>glue</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> made from protein
derived from the collagen in animal by-products (bone, hooves, hides,
etc.) boiled to form a brownish gelatin that can be thinned with water.
Most glues are not suitable for use in <a href="#binding">binding</a> because they become <a href="#brittle">brittle</a> with age.  Compare with <a href="#paste">paste</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gluingoff"><b>gluing off</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the application of <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> to the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, after the <a href="#section">section</a>s have been <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> and before the steps called <a href="#rounding">rounding</a> and <a href="#backing">backing</a>.  The <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> is forced between the sections to help hold them together.  Compare with <a href="#pastingdown">pasting down</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="glyphic"><b>glyphic</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> derived from a carved or chiseled form, rather than from a <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphic</a> hand.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gmd1"><b>GMD</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#gmd"><b>g</b>eneral <b>m</b>aterial <b>d</b>esignation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gnawed"><b>gnawed</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> that shows signs of having been chewed by an animal on at least one edge or <a href="#corner">corner</a>, a <a href="#condition">condition</a> that reduces its value considerably in the <a href="#usedbook">used book</a> market, and makes it a candidate for <a href="#weeding">weeding</a> in <a href="#library">libraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="goal"><b>goal</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#strategicplanning">strategic planning</a>, a general direction or aim that an organization commits iself to attaining, in order to further its <a href="#mission">mission</a>.
Goals are usually expressed in abstract terms, with no time-limit for
realization. The specific means by which they are to be attained is
also left open. Compare with <a href="#objective">objective</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="goatskin"><b>goatskin</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#leather">Leather</a> made from the skin of a goat, used extensively in <a href="#handbinding">hand</a> <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>.  Older <a href="#book">book</a>s <a href="#binding">bound</a> in fine-quality goatskin, known in the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> as <a href="#morocco">morocco</a>, can be very valuable.  The names of the various types of goatskin reflect their place of origin (<a href="#levant">Levant</a>, Niger, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="godort1"><b>GODORT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#godort"><b>GO</b>vernment <b>DO</b>cuments <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gofferededges"><b>goffered edges</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#chasededges">chased edges</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="goldfoil"><b>gold foil</b></a>
</dt><dd>An inexpensive substitute for <a href="#goldleaf">gold leaf</a>, made by spraying a thin deposit of gold or a look-alike substitute onto an <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> backing, used extensively to decorate <a href="#publishersbinding">edition binding</a>s and <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a>s, and also in <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a> when economy is desired.  Syonymous with <em>blocking foil</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="goldleaf"><b>gold leaf</b></a>
</dt><dd>Gold beaten by hand or mechanical means into very thin sheets, used in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> to embellish <a href="#lettering">lettering</a>, <a href="#tooling">tooling</a>, and the <a href="#giltedges">edges</a> of the <a href="#section">section</a>s.  The gold leaf used in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>
is sold in sheets 3 1/2 inch square, made from an alloy of 23 carat
gold, and 1 carat silver and copper, beaten to a thinness of
1/200,000-1/250,000 of an inch. Silver is used less often for the same
purpose. Compare with <a href="#goldfoil">gold foil</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#burnish">burnish</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gonetopress"><b>gone to press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in <a href="#printing">printing</a> to indicate that the process of preparing the final <a href="#plate">plate</a>s for a <a href="#work">work</a> has commenced.  Subsequent changes or corrections must be added as <a href="#errata">errata</a> after printing is completed.  In <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the corresponding term is <em>gone to bed</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gopher"><b>Gopher</b></a>
</dt><dd>Before the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a> was developed, <a href="#file">file</a>s and resources available on the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> were <a href="#access">access</a>ed by means of a hierarchical <a href="#menu">menu</a> system installed on a <em>Gopher server</em> (named after the mascot of the University of Minnesota where the <a href="#software">software</a> was developed).  Although they have fallen into disuse since the introduction of graphical <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>s, Gopher <a href="#server">server</a>s have two advantages over Web <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>s:  they list Internet resources of <em>all</em> types (<a href="#ftp">FTP</a> files, Usenet <a href="#newsgroup">newsgroup</a>s, etc.), not just <a href="#website">Web site</a>s, and they present resources in a logical hierarchy of <a href="#directory">directories</a> created by a human being, rather than relying on an automated Web <a href="#crawler">crawler</a> ("spider") to locate <a href="#information">information</a>.  The tools developed for searching Gopher file directories are named <b><em>Veronica</em></b> and <b><em>Jughead</em></b>.  Gopher <a href="#internetaddress">address</a>es begin with the prefix <b>gopher://</b>.  <a href="gopher://gopher.tc.umn.edu/11/Other%20Gopher%20and%20Information%20Servers">Click here</a> to connect to a list of Gopher servers maintained by the University of Minnesota. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gothic"><b>gothic</b></a>
</dt><dd>A style of dark, angular <a href="#script">script</a> executed with a broad-nib pen, widely used as a <a href="#bookhand">book hand</a> in northern Europe during the late medieval period and adapted as a <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> in early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s, particularly Bibles and other devotional <a href="#work">work</a>s.  Also refers to any modern typeface resembling gothic script, characterized by compressed <a href="#letterform">letterform</a>s, broad main strokes, fine hair strokes, regular verticals, uniform <a href="#counter">counter</a>s, diagonal couplings, and a lack of curves.
