The first <a href="#book">book</a> printed in Europe from <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a> (the <em><a href="#gutenbergbible">Gutenberg Bible</a></em>) was <a href="#typesetting">set</a> in gothic <a href="#type">type</a>.  Synonymous with <em>black letter</em> and <em>lettre de forme</em>.  Compare with <a href="#roman">roman</a> and <a href="#whiteletter">white letter</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#rotunda">rotunda</a> and <a href="#textura">textura</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gothicnovel"><b>gothic novel</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, a type of <a href="#novel">novel</a> in which a medieval castle formed the <a href="#setting">setting</a> for a <a href="#plot">plot</a> with chillingly sinister overtones, intended to evoke irrational fear in the heart of the <a href="#reader">reader</a>.  Horace Walpole's <b><em>Castle of Otranto, A Gothic Story</em></b> (1764) established this <a href="#genre">genre</a>.  In modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, a <a href="#subgenre">subgenre</a> of <a href="#romance">romance</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>,
popular during the 18th and early 19th centuries, in which the setting
is dark and gloomy, the action grotesque or violent, the <a href="#character">character</a>s strange or malevolent, the plot mysterious, and the mood often one of decadence or degeneration (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Wuthering Heights</em></b> by Emily Bronte).  Synonymous with <em>roman noir</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mystery">mystery</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gouge"><b>gouge</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nick or hole made accidentally in the <a href="#cover">cover</a> or <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  Also refers to a <a href="#finishing">finishing</a> tool used in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> to make curved lines on a book cover.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="governance"><b>governance</b></a>
</dt><dd>The arrangements by which the faculty and administration of an
academic institution control and direct institutional affairs (bylaws,
elective offices, committees, etc.). In some <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, participation in governance may be a factor in <a href="#tenure">tenure</a> and <a href="#promotion">promotion</a> decisions affecting <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s who have <a href="#facultystatus">faculty status</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="govtagency"><b>government agency</b></a>
</dt><dd>A unit of government authorized by law or regulation to
perform a specific function, for example, the U.S. Government Printing
Office (<a href="#gpo">GPO</a>) authorized to collect, <a href="#publishing">publish</a>, and <a href="#distributor">distribute</a> <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> to the American public.  Each agency of the U.S. federal government normally maintains its own <a href="#records">records</a>, which may or may not be publicly <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> depending on whether its activities are exempted from public disclosure under the <em><a href="#freedom">Freedom of Information Act (FOIA)</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="govarchives"><b>government archives</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a> authorized by legislation to provide centralized <a href="#archives">archival</a>
services for all, or a portion of, the agencies or units that
administer a country's government (legislative, executive, and
judicial). For the federal government of the United States, that agency
is the <a href="#nara">National Archives and Records Administration</a> (NARA).  Each of the 50 U.S. state governments maintains its own state archives, sometimes as a unit of the <a href="#statelibrary">state library</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="govdocs"><b>government documents</b></a>     
</dt><dd><a href="#publication">Publication</a>s of the U.S. federal government, including <a href="#hearings">hearings</a>, <a href="#bill">bill</a>s, <a href="#resolution">resolution</a>s, <a href="#charter">charter</a>s, statutes, <a href="#report">report</a>s, <a href="#treaty">treaties</a>, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s (<em>example</em>: <b><em>Monthly Labor Review</em></b>), and statistics (U.S. <a href="#census">Census</a>). In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, federal <a href="#document">document</a>s are usually shelved in a separate section by <a href="#sudocs">SuDocs number</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#depository">depository library</a>, <a href="#gpo">GPO</a>, and <a href="#godort">GODORT</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="godort"><b>Government Documents Round Table (GODORT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A permanent <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> within the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>GODORT</b> has a membership of <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and others who have an interest in government <a href="#document">document</a>s <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s and <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>.  <b>GODORT</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>DttP: Documents to the People</em>.  <a href="http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/GODORT/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>GODORT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="govtlibrary"><b>government library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> maintained by a unit of government at the local, state, or federal level, containing <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s for the use of its staff.  Some government libraries have a wider mandate that includes <a href="#accessibility">accessibility</a> to the general public (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.si.edu/info/libraries_archives.htm">Smithsonian Libraries &amp; Archives</a>).  Government <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s are organized in the <a href="#godort">Government Documents Round Table</a> (GODORT) of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#federallibrary">federal library</a>, <a href="#militarylibrary">military library</a>, <a href="#nationallib">national library</a>, and <a href="#statelibrary">state library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gpo"><b>GPO</b></a>            
</dt><dd>The U.S. <b>G</b>overnment <b>P</b>rinting <b>O</b>ffice, the <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a> responsible for collecting, <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, and distributing federal government <a href="#information">information</a>.  The <b>GPO</b> publishes a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#index">index</a> to <a href="#govdocs">government document</a>s under the <a href="#title">title</a> <b><em>Monthly Catalog of U.S. Government Publications</em></b>.  Its <a href="#online">online</a> equivalent is <em><a href="#gpoaccess">GPO Access</a></em>, funded by the <a href="#fdlp">Federal Depository Library Program</a>.  The British counterpart is <a href="#hmso">Her Majesty's Stationery Office</a>.  <a href="http://www.gpo.gov/">Click here</a> to learn more about <b>GPO</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gpoaccess"><b><em>GPO Access</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A service of the <a href="#gpo">U.S. Government Printing Office</a> that provides free electronic <a href="#access">access</a> to over 1,500 <a href="#database">database</a>s of government <a href="#information">information</a>, including the <em>Federal Register</em>, <em>Code of Federal Regulations</em>, and <em>Congressional Record</em>.  <b><em>GPO Access</em></b> is funded by the <a href="#fdlp">Federal Depository Library Program</a> under the Government Printing Electronic Information Enhancement Act of 1993 (Public Law 103-40).  <a href="http://www.access.gpo.gov/su_docs/index.html">Click here</a> to learn more about <b><em>GPO Access</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="grace"><b>grace period</b></a>
</dt><dd>A designated period of time following the <a href="#duedate">due date</a> during which a <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> may <a href="#renew">renew</a> an <a href="#overdue">overdue</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> or return it to the <a href="#library">library</a> without incurring a <a href="#fines">fine</a>.  To encourage the return of long overdue <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>,
some libraries also set aside one day (or several days) each year
during which overdue items may be returned without penalty. Not all
libraries provide a grace period. Synonymous with <em>amnesty period</em> and <em>fine-free period</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gradlib"><b>graduate library</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a> at a university that maintains separate <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s (and usually facilities) for <a href="#undergradlib">undergraduates</a> and graduate students, containing the major <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ed and equipped to meet the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of graduate students and faculty.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="grain"><b>grain</b></a>
</dt><dd>In a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of machine-made <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#board">board</a>, the direction in which most of the fibers lie, determined by forward movement of the <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a> machine in manufacture.  <a href="#book">Book</a>s are <a href="#printing">printed</a> with the grain parallel to the <a href="#spine">spine</a> because paper bends more readily with the grain than against it.  One way to determine the grain in a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of paper is to do a <em>tear test</em>--paper
tears more cleanly with the grain than across it. There is little or no
grain in a sheet of handmade paper. Woven material used as covering
material in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> also has grain--as a general rule, the warp threads run parallel to the spine.  Grain in <a href="#leather">leather</a> depends on the direction in which the hairs lay before removal, indicated by tiny puncture marks on the surface.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#againstthegrain">against the grain</a> and <a href="#crossgrain">cross-grain</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gramophone"><b>gramophone record</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="grangerized"><b>grangerized</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> into which <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#letters">letters</a>, and/or other <a href="#matter">matter</a> is <a href="#insert">insert</a>ed after <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  The practice began in 1769, when James Granger (1723-1776) <a href="#publishing">published</a> <b><em>A Biographical History of England</em></b> containing <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> for the insertion of <a href="#portrait">portrait</a> <a href="#engraving">engraving</a>s after <a href="#printing">printing</a>.  Synonymous with <em>privately illustrated</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#extraillustrated">extra-illustrated</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="grant"><b>grant</b></a>
</dt><dd>Funds received from a private foundation (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#clir">Council on Library and Information Resources</a>) or government sponsored organization (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#neh">National Endowment for the Humanities</a>)
by an individual, group, or institution, in support of a worthy project
or cause. In most cases, the recipient must compete for such funds by
submitting a <a href="#proposal">proposal</a>.  The art of obtaining grants is called <a href="#grantsmanship">grantsmanship</a>.  Guides for proposal writing are available in <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> and large <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.  <a href="#information">Information</a> on funding sources can be found in the <b><em>Annual Register of Grant Support</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a> and <b><em>The Foundation Directory</em></b> published <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by The Foundation Center.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#matchinggrant">matching grant</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="grantinaid"><b>grant-in-aid</b></a>
</dt><dd>Funds received by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> from a state or federal <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>
in support of regular operations, or a special project or program, as
opposed to funds derived from the community or district served. In most
cases, the library must apply in a competitive process by submitting a <a href="#proposal">proposal</a> (<em>example</em>:  certain <a href="#lsta">LSTA</a> funds).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="grantsmanship"><b>grantsmanship</b></a>
</dt><dd>The art of successfully obtaining and administering <a href="#grant">grant</a>s and <a href="#grantinaid">grants-in-aid</a>, including the ability to recognize when an idea is fundable, locate funding sources, <a href="#research">research</a> the <a href="#information">information</a> necessary to fill out the application, establish a realistic timetable, write the <a href="#proposal">proposal</a>,
and manage the grant process once funding is approved. When grant
funding is a high priority, a college or university usually employs a
trained and experienced <em>grants administrator</em> to help teaching faculty and <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s negotiate the process.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="granularity"><b>granularity</b></a>
</dt><dd>The level of <a href="#bibdescrip">descriptive</a> detail in a <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> created to represent a <a href="#document">document</a> or <a href="#information">information</a> resource for the purpose of <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a>, for example, whether the <a href="#recordstructure">record structure</a> in a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> allows the <a href="#author">author</a>'s name to be parsed into <a href="#givenname">given name</a> and <a href="#surname">surname</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="graph"><b>graph</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#diagram">diagram</a> that shows 1) quantity in
relation to a whole (pie graph), 2) the distribution of separate values
of a variable in relation to another (scatter graph), or 3) change in
the value of a variable in relation to another, for example, the change
in the <a href="#averageprice">average price</a> of a <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#serial">subscription</a> over time (coordinate graph, <a href="#histogram">histogram</a>, etc.).   
<p>
The suffix <b>-graph</b>, derived from the Greek word <em>graphos</em> ("writing"), refers to something written, as in <em><a href="#autograph">autograph</a></em> or <em><a href="#monograph">monograph</a></em>, or something that writes or records, as in <em><a href="#photograph">photograph</a></em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="graphic"><b>graphic</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any two-dimensional non<a href="#text">text</a>ual, still representation.  Graphics can be opaque (<a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#diagram">diagram</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#chart">chart</a>s, <a href="#graph">graph</a>s, etc.) or designed to be viewed or projected with the aid of optical equipment (<a href="#slide">slide</a>s, <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>s, etc.).  <a href="#magazine">Magazine</a>s and <a href="#artbook">art book</a>s usually contain a high proportion of graphic material.  The graphic design of the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> is important in marketing <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s.  Computer graphics are created with the aid of graphic design <a href="#software">software</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#animated">animated graphics</a>, <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface (GUI)</a>, <a href="#thumbnail">thumbnail</a>, and <a href="#aiga">American Institute of Graphic Design</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> that appears to have been drawn, rather than derived from a <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphic</a> hand or lapidary precursor.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="graphicnovel"><b>graphic novel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> coined by Will Eisner to describe his semi-<a href="#autobiography">autobiographical</a> <a href="#novel">novel</a> <b><em>A Contract with God</em></b> (1978), written and <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> in <a href="#comicbook">comic book</a> style, the first <a href="#work">work</a> in a new <a href="#genre">genre</a> that presents an extended <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> as a continuous sequence of <a href="#picture">pictorial</a> images <a href="#printing">printed</a> in color and arranged in <a href="#panel">panel</a>-to-panel <a href="#format">format</a>, with <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> enclosed in <a href="#balloon">balloon</a>s.  A precursor can be found in the <em>picture story</em> <a href="#album">album</a>s
of the 19th century Swiss writer Rodolphe Topffer, who also wrote
novels in conventional form. This new literary form is viewed with
suspicion by traditionalists who regard it as a marketing ploy aimed at
attracting <a href="#adult">adult</a> <a href="#reader">reader</a>s to comic books by removing the stigma attached to them.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="graphicaluser"><b>graphical user interface (GUI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#interface">interface</a> that allows the user to provide <a href="#input">input</a> and receive <a href="#output">output</a> interactively by manipulating <a href="#menubar">menu bar</a>s, <a href="#icon">icon</a>s, and movable, resizable <a href="#window">window</a>s by means of a <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> or pointing device such as a <a href="#mouse">mouse</a>.  GUIs are used in <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>s and in most <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a>, <a href="#spreadsheet">spreadsheet</a>, and <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s <a href="#application">application</a>s.  The quality of a GUI depends on its <a href="#functionality">functionality</a> and <a href="#usability">usability</a>.  Pronounced "gooey."  Synonymous with <em>graphic user interface</em> and <a href="#wimps">WIMPS</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#macintosh">Macintosh</a> and <a href="#windows">Windows</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="graticule"><b>graticule</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#grid">grid</a> composed of horizontal and vertical lines <a href="#printing">printed</a> over an image, such as a <a href="#map">map</a>, to assist the viewer in locating specific features.  In an <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>, the grids are usually keyed to a <a href="#gazetteer">gazetteer</a> of place names giving <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a> and grid coordinates for each <a href="#entry">entry</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="grayliterature"><b>gray literature</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#printing">Printed</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s such as <a href="#report">report</a>s, <a href="#internaldocument">internal document</a>s, PhD <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a>s, master's <a href="#thesis">theses</a>, and <a href="#conference">conference</a> <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a>, not usually available through regular market channels because they were never commercially <a href="#publishing">published</a>, <a href="#list">list</a>ed, or priced.  Alternative methods of supply and <a href="#bibcontrol">bibliographic control</a> have evolved in response to the need of <a href="#library">libraries</a> to <a href="#preservation">preserve</a> and provide <a href="#access">access</a> to such material.  In the United States, the gray literature of science and technology is <a href="#index">index</a>ed in the <a href="#ntis">NTIS</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>.  Theses and dissertations are <a href="#indexing">indexed</a> and <a href="#abstracting">abstracted</a> in <em><a href="#dai">Dissertation Abstracts International</a></em> and are available in <a href="#hardcopy">hard copy</a> via <em>Dissertation Express</em>.  Also spelled <em>grey literature</em>.  Compare with <a href="#ephemera">ephemera</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#semipublished">semipublished</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="grayscale"><b>gray scale</b></a>
</dt><dd>Variations in the density of black, arranged in sequence (usually from 10% to 90%) for use in <a href="#printing">printing</a> and <a href="#film">film</a> developing.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="greenaway"><b>Greenaway Medal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a> presented annually since 1956 by the <a href="#la">Library Association</a> (UK) to the artist judged to have produced the most distinguished <a href="#work">work</a> in the <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> of <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the United Kingdom during the preceding <a href="#calendaryear">calendar year</a>.  <a href="http://www.acs.ucalgary.ca/%7Edkbrown/awards.html">Click here</a> to view a list of Greenaway Medal winners.  Compare with <a href="#carnegiemedal">Carnegie Medal</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ameliafrances">Amelia Frances Howard-Gibbon Illustrator's Award</a> and <a href="#caldecott">Caldecott Medal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="greenawayplan"><b>Greenaway Plan</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#blanketorder">blanket order</a> plan in which a large <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> agrees to receive from a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> for a nominal price one <a href="#advancecopy">advance copy</a> of all the <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a>s it <a href="#publishing">publishes</a>, to encourage <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s to order <a href="#selection">selected</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s in advance of <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  The publisher relies on the probability that enough titles will be ordered in multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a>
to cover its costs. The plan is named after Emerson Greenaway, the
librarian at the Philadelphia Free Library who conceived the idea in
1958.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="greenpaper"><b>green paper</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in green <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s
by a ministry or department of the British government to elicit public
comment and debate on a proposed new policy (or change in an existing
one). The practice began in 1967. Compare with <a href="#whitepaper">white paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="greyliterature"><b>grey literature</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#grayliterature">gray literature</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="grid"><b>grid</b></a>
</dt><dd>Two sets of parallel lines intersecting at right angles, usually at regular intervals, which when superimposed on a <a href="#map">map</a> or other two-dimensional surface, can be used to locate specific points by means of <a href="#coordinate">coordinate</a>s, usually a sequence of <a href="#number">number</a>s or <a href="#letter">letter</a>s <a href="#printing">printed</a> across the top and/or bottom <a href="#margin">margin</a>, with a second sequence along one or both sides.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="grievance"><b>grievance</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the workplace, a formal complaint concerning a specific
action or policy, set of circumstances, or persistent condition,
addressed by an employee or group of employees to management, to a
special committee established to hear grievances, or to some other
appropriate authority, to protest its unfairness and request a remedy.
Most organizations have an established procedure for filing grievances
and negotiating their settlement. In <a href="#library">library</a> employment governed by <a href="#collectivebargaining">collective bargaining agreement</a>, the grievance procedure and conditions under which it applies may be explicitly stated in the <a href="#contract">contract</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="groupware"><b>groupware</b></a>
</dt><dd>Computer <a href="#software">software</a> designed to support more than one user connected to a <a href="#localarea">LAN</a>,
usually colleagues working together on related tasks whose offices are
not in the same location. Although groupware is an evolving concept,
most products include a messaging system, <a href="#document">document</a> sharing and management software, a <a href="#calendar">calendar</a>ing
and scheduling system for coordinating meetings and tracking the
progress of group projects, electronic conferencing, and an <a href="#electronicnewsletter">electronic newsletter</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Lotus Notes</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="guard"><b>guard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A flexible strip of cloth or strong <a href="#paper">paper</a> inserted along the inner <a href="#margin">margin</a> between two <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> prior to <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a>, used to <a href="#mounted">mount</a> a <a href="#plate">plate</a> or <a href="#insert">insert</a> too stiff to turn like a normal <a href="#page">page</a>.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>hinge</em>.  Also, a strip of paper or other material added to reinforce a <a href="#signature">signature</a> in a book.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#securityguard">security guard</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gui"><b>GUI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#graphicaluser"><b>g</b>raphical <b>u</b>ser <b>i</b>nterface</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="guide"><b>guide</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#information">Information</a> provided by a <a href="#library">library</a>, usually in the form of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#handout">handout</a> or <a href="#leaflet">leaflet</a>, that 1) explains how to use a library service (<a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>, <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>, etc.); 2) describes important resources on a <a href="#subject">subject</a> (<b>World War II</b>), in a <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> (<b>history</b>), or of a specific form (<a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a>, <a href="#biography">biography</a>, etc.); or 3) explains how to accomplish something (<a href="#compile">compile</a> an <a href="#annotatedbib">annotated bibliography</a>, <a href="#cite">cite</a> <a href="#source">source</a>s in a particular <a href="#bibliography">bibliographical</a> style, etc.). 
<p>
In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, a type of <a href="#findingaid">finding aid</a> that provides a <a href="#summary">summary</a> or general description of the contents of an archival <a href="#collection">collection</a>, or that describes archival <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> related to a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a>, geographic area, period in history, etc., or of a certain type of material (<a href="#diary">diaries</a>, <a href="#letters">letters</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, etc.).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="guidebook"><b>guidebook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#handbook">handbook</a> that provides useful current <a href="#information">information</a>
for travellers to a city, state, region, country, or other geographic
area, or for visitors to a museum, park, historical site, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="guideword"><b>guideword</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#catchword">catchword</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="guillemets"><b><em>guillemets</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>French <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> marks <a href="#printing">printed</a> &lt;&lt; like this &gt;&gt;, also seen in some German <a href="#text">text</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>duck-foot quotes</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="guillotine"><b>guillotine</b></a>
</dt><dd>A power-driven or hand-operated machine with a long, sharp-edged blade, used in <a href="#binding">binding</a> to cut and <a href="#trimming">trim</a> large numbers of flat or folded <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s to the desired dimensions.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gutenbergbible"><b><em>Gutenberg Bible</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>The earliest known <a href="#book">book</a> to have been produced from <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>, probably <a href="#printing">printed</a> between 1450 and 1455 at Mainz, Germany by <a href="#gutenberg">Johann Gutenberg</a> and his associate Peter Schoffer, with the financial assistance of a merchant named Johann Fust.  Also known as the <b><em>Mazarin Bible</em></b> because a <a href="#copy">copy</a> was found by a French <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> in the <a href="#privatelib">private library</a> of the <a href="#bibliophile">bibliophile</a> Cardinal Mazarin (1602-1661) one hundred years after his death.  It is a Latin bible printed in black <a href="#ink">ink</a> in <a href="#gothic">gothic</a> <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#typesetting">set</a> in two 42-line <a href="#column">column</a>s per <a href="#page">page</a>.  Of approximately 180 copies printed, only forty-eight copies are known to have survived, which makes them very <a href="#rarity">rare</a> and valuable.  Twelve are printed on <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> and thirty-six on <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  The <a href="#britishlib">British Library</a> owns two copies, and the <a href="#bnfrance">Bibliotheque nationale de France</a> one.  In the United States, there are thirteen copies, one each at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>, the <a href="#nypl">New York Public Library</a>, the <a href="#huntingtonlibrary">Huntington Library</a> in California, and <a href="#library">libraries</a> at Harvard, Princeton, and Yale.  The <a href="#pierpont">Pierpont Morgan Library</a> in New York City owns three copies.  <a href="http://prodigi.bl.uk/gutenbg/">Click here</a> to see <a href="#digitalimaging">digital images</a> of the beautifully <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> copies in the British Library <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#incunabula">incunabula</a>.     
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gutenberg"><b>Gutenberg, Johann, c. 1399-1468</b></a>
</dt><dd>A goldsmith by trade, Johann Gensfleisch zum Gutenberg is credited with the invention <a href="#printing">printing</a> from <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>, probably at Mainz in Germany.  His first printed <a href="#work">work</a> was a 42-line <a href="#gutenbergbible">Bible</a> <a href="#typesetting">set</a> in <a href="#gothic">gothic</a> <a href="#type">type</a> probably printed no later than 1456.  Uncertainty regarding Gutenberg's accomplishment arises from the lack of <a href="#record">record</a>ed <a href="#information">information</a> about his life and the fact that no extant work bears his name, nor have any of his presses survived.  The <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a>
spread rapidly to the Netherlands, Italy, France, and England, becoming
well-established in Europe by the 1480's. The Gutenberg Museum was
established in Mainz in 1900 as a center for the study of Gutenberg's
life and work, and early history of <a href="#typography">typography</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gutter"><b>gutter</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#blank">blank</a> space formed by the inner <a href="#margin">margin</a>s of facing <a href="#page">page</a>s in an open <a href="#book">book</a>, from the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> to the area that bears <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a>.  The width of the gutter is an important factor in determining whether a book can be <a href="#rebinding">rebound</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gutterpress"><b>gutter press</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#tabloid">Tabloid</a> <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s and <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s that <a href="#publishing">publish</a> salacious gossip, usually of a personal nature concerning the lives of prominent people.  Synonymous with <a href="#yellowpress">yellow press</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="gutting"><b>gutting</b></a>
</dt><dd>The practice, abhorred by <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, of <a href="#review">review</a>ing a <a href="#book">book</a>, not by critically evaluating its strengths and/or weaknesses, but by revealing the main lines of its <a href="#plot">plot</a>, ruining the experience of first-time <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.  Also refers to the practice in <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> of carefully <a href="#quotation">quoting</a> out of <a href="#context">context</a>, in the <a href="#blurb">blurb</a> on the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>
and in advertising, only the most complimentary passages from reviews
which, in their entirety, expressed mixed or even negative opinions of
the <a href="#work">work</a>.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>
<center>| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> | <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a>
| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="H">H</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="hachure"><b>hachure</b></a>
</dt><dd>A series of short lines drawn or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a land <a href="#map">map</a>
to indicate gradient: long thin, widely-spaced lines indicating a
moderate grade and short, thick, closely-spaced lines a steep grade,
with direction of slope indicated by direction of line. <em>Hachuring</em> is common on maps produced by the National Geographic Society and the U.S. Forest Service.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hacker"><b>hacker</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#slang">slang</a> <a href="#term">term</a> for a person with extensive <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> of computers and computing, who uses his skills to <a href="#access">access</a> supposedly <a href="#security">secure</a>
computer systems for the intellectual challenge such activities
provide. The best hackers take pride in leaving no "tracks" to reveal
their presence. Compare with <a href="#cracker">cracker</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#security">security</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hagiography"><b>hagiography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#biography">biography</a>, widespread during the Middle Ages and Renaissance, in which the life described is that of a saint.  Also refers to a <a href="#book">book</a> containing such writing, often a <a href="#collectivebiography">collective biography</a> covering the lives of two or more saints.  An <a href="#author">author</a> who writes about the lives (and <a href="#legend">legend</a>s) of saints is a <em>hagiographer</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="halfbinding"><b>half-binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A style of <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> in which the <a href="#spine">spine</a> and <a href="#corner">corner</a>s are covered in a different material than the sides, usually selected for greater <a href="#durability">durability</a>.  Compare with <a href="#fullbinding">full binding</a>, <a href="#quarterbinding">quarter binding</a>, and <a href="#threequarter">three-quarter binding</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#halfcloth">half cloth</a> and <a href="#halfleather">half leather</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="halfcloth"><b>half cloth</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> in a <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> <a href="#spine">spine</a> and <a href="#paper">paper</a>-covered <a href="#board">board</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>half linen</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="halfduplex"><b>half-duplex</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#duplex">duplex</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="halfleather"><b>half leather</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> with <a href="#spine">spine</a> and <a href="#corner">corner</a>s covered in <a href="#leather">leather</a> and the rest of the <a href="#binding">binding</a> in <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>.  Compare with <a href="#quarterleather">quarter leather</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="halftitle"><b>half-title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> as <a href="#printing">printed</a>, in full or in brief, on the <a href="#recto">recto</a> of a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> preceding the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, usually in a smaller <a href="#typesize">size</a> of the <a href="#font">font</a> used to print the title on the title page.  In books <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#series">series</a>, the <a href="#seriestitlepage">series title page</a> often appears on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the leaf bearing the half-title.  
<p>
The use of half-titles dates from the 17th century and may have evolved from the practice of including a <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> to protect the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> from wear.  In modern printing, the half-title helps the <a href="#printer">printer</a> identify the <a href="#work">work</a> to which the first <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> belongs.  In some <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, the half-title also appears on the recto of a leaf separating the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> from the first <a href="#page">page</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a>.  Also spelled <em>half title</em>.  Synonymous with <em>bastard title</em> and <em>fly-title</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="halftone"><b>halftone</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#art">Art</a> made ready for <a href="#printing">printing</a> by <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ing
the image through the fine, diagonally crossed lines of a screen made
of glass or film, converting it into a field of tiny graded dots that
reproduce by optical illusion the tonal values of the <a href="#original">original</a>.  Halftone screens range from 50-200 <a href="#rule">ruling</a>s per inch.  The finer the screen, the greater the range of tonal values.  Printing <a href="#paper">paper</a>s with a smooth <a href="#finish">finish</a> require a finer screen than coarse papers.  Also refers to a <a href="#print">print</a> made by this process.  Also spelled <em>half-tone</em>.  Compare with <a href="#lineart">line art</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="halfuncial"><b>half uncial</b></a>
</dt><dd>The stage in the development of Latin <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphic</a> <a href="#letterform">letterform</a>s at which <a href="#cursive">cursive</a> characteristics and <a href="#ligature">ligature</a>s were added to the <a href="#uncial">uncial</a> style, and <a href="#ascender">ascender</a>s and <a href="#descender">descender</a>s introduced.  A transitional phase on the path to Roman <a href="#minuscule">minuscule</a>s, half-uncial <a href="#script">script</a> was used as a <a href="#bookhand">book hand</a> in Europe from the 7th to the 9th century.  Synonymous with <em>semi-uncial</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#carolingian">Carolingian minuscule</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="halfyearly"><b>half yearly</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="handbill"><b>handbill</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small notice or advertisement <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a single unfolded <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>, intended for distribution by hand, but also used as a <a href="#poster">poster</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#broadside">broadside</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="handbinding"><b>hand-binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>The art and craft of <a href="#binding">binding</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s by hand without the aid of mechanization.  Medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and early <a href="#printing">printed</a> books were hand-bound in wooden <a href="#board">board</a>s <a href="#cover">cover</a>ed in <a href="#leather">leather</a>.  Today, <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>s are <a href="#casebinding">case bound</a> and hand-binding is limited to <a href="#finebook">fine book</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="handbook"><b>handbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#refbook">reference book</a> of compact size that provides concise factual <a href="#information">information</a> on a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a>, organized systematically for quick and easy access.  Statistical information is often <a href="#publishing">published</a> in handbook form (<em>example</em>:  <em><strong>Statistical Handbook on the American Family</strong></em>).  Some handbooks are published <a href="#serial">serial</a>ly (<b><em>CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics</em></b>).  Synonymous with <a href="#vademecum">vade mecum</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#manual">manual</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="handheld"><b>handheld computer</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#pda">personal digital assistant (PDA)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="handout"><b>handout</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>,
or group of sheets, usually stapled together at one corner, intended
for distribution during an oral presentation or instruction session to
give the attendees a record of <a href="#content">content</a> covered (<a href="#summary">summary</a>, <a href="#outline">outline</a>, <a href="#hardcopy">hard copy</a> of <em>PowerPoint</em> <a href="#slide">slide</a>s, etc.) or provide supplementary or complementary <a href="#information">information</a> (supporting <a href="#data">data</a>, examples, suggestions for <a href="#furtherreading">further reading</a>, contact information, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="handson"><b>hands-on</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bi">library instruction</a> session or one-on-one <a href="#refquestion">reference transaction</a> in which the student or <a href="#patron">patron</a> has the opportunity to practice, usually at a computer <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>, <a href="#research">research</a> techniques demonstrated by the instructor or <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hang"><b>hang</b></a>
</dt><dd>Having a computer freeze during a session so that it does not respond to user <a href="#input">input</a>, usually with no indication of the probable cause.  <a href="#download">Download</a>ing a very large <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a> can create the appearance of a <em>hang-up</em>.  Closing the <a href="#application">application</a> or <a href="#reboot">reboot</a>ing will usually get the system unstuck, but un<a href="#save">save</a>d data will be lost in the process.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hangingindention"><b>hanging indention</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#indention">indention</a> in which the opening line is <a href="#flush">flush</a> with the left-hand <a href="#margin">margin</a> and subsequent lines are indented one or more <a href="#spacing">spaces</a>.  Used in typed and <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a>s and in some styles of <a href="#bibliography">bibliographic</a> <a href="#entry">entry</a>.  Hanging indention is used for the terms and <a href="#definition">definition</a>s in this <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hardcopy"><b>hard copy</b></a>       
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a> or <a href="#record">record</a> that exists in <a href="#machinerecords">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a> (<a href="#digital">digital</a>, <a href="#microform">microform</a>, etc.).  Also used in a more general sense to refer to printed <a href="#matter">matter</a>, as opposed to its <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> equivalent.  Compare with <a href="#printout">printout</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hardcover"><b>hardcover</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> in an inflexible <a href="#board">board</a> <a href="#case">case</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a>, usually covered in <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>, <a href="#paper">paper</a>, plastic, <a href="#leather">leather</a>, or some other <a href="#durability">durable</a> material, as distinct from a book bound in a cover made of flexible material.  In modern <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, a new <a href="#tradebook">trade title</a> is usually <a href="#issue">issue</a>d first in hardcover, then in a <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> after sales in hardcover decline.  Synonymous with <em>cloth bound</em>, <em>hardback</em>, and <em>hard bound</em>.  Compare with <a href="#softcover">softcover</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="harddisk"><b>hard disk</b></a>
</dt><dd>A magnetic <a href="#medium">medium</a> capable of <a href="#storage">storing</a> a large quantity of <a href="#data">data</a>, which resides permanently within a computer, as opposed to a portable disk (<a href="#floppydisk">floppy</a>, <a href="#zipdisk">Zip</a>, etc.) that can be inserted in a <a href="#diskdrive">disk drive</a> by the user whenever a data <a href="#file">file</a> needs to be opened or <a href="#save">save</a>d, and removed once the operation is completed.  In <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a>s, the hard disk is usually the <b>c:/</b> drive.  In <a href="#network">network</a>ed systems, users may also have <a href="#access">access</a> to a portion of the <em>hard drive</em> on a shared <a href="#server">server</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hardware"><b>hardware</b></a>
</dt><dd>Mechanical, electrical, electronic, or other physical
equipment and machinery associated with a computer system, or necessary
for the <a href="#playback">playback</a> or projection of <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#media">media</a>.  Basic <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> hardware includes a <a href="#centralproc">central processing unit</a> (CPU), <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>, and <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>.  The <em><a href="http://www.techweb.com/encyclopedia/">TechEncyclopedia</a></em> describes the distinction between hardware and <a href="#software">software</a> as the difference between "storage and transmission" and "logic and language."  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hardwired"><b>hardwired</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> that originally referred to a computer <a href="#device">device</a> containing unalterable circuitry designed to perform a specific task, as opposed to circuits that are <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>mable or controlled by a switch.  However, the meaning has broadened to include constants built into computer <a href="#software">software</a>.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>hard-coded</em>.  In a more general sense, <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> or software that cannot be modified.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hash"><b>hash</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#hashmark">hashmark</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hashmark"><b>hashmark</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> <b>#</b> used to represent
the word "number" in lists and street addresses, in touch-tone
telephone systems that allow the caller to key <a href="#input">input</a>, in <a href="#www">Web</a> addresses (<a href="#url">URL</a>s) to create a <a href="#link">link</a> to another location in the same <a href="#document">document</a>, etc.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>hash</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="head"><b>head</b></a>
</dt><dd>The top edge of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  Also refers to the <a href="#margin">margin</a> at the top of a <a href="#page">page</a>, as opposed to the margin at the <a href="#tail">tail</a> or <a href="#foot">foot</a> of the page.  Also, a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> used as a brief <a href="#headline">headline</a> in a book or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="headband"><b>headband</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a band of woven cotton or silk, sometimes colored or multi-colored, <a href="#gluingoff">glued</a> or <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> to the <a href="#back">back</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> at the <a href="#head">head</a>, to protect the end of the <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s and take the strain off the covering material at the top of the <a href="#spine">spine</a> when the <a href="#volume">volume</a> is pulled from the shelf.  The corresponding band at the lower end of the spine is called the <em>tailband</em>.  Collectively, the headband and tailband are known as <em>endbands</em>.  
<p>
Originally, the headband and tailband were a part of the sewing of a
book, holding the sections together securely, but because they
prevented the edges of the sections from being <a href="#trimming">trimmed</a> after sewing, their primary function was transferred to the <a href="#kettle">kettle stitch</a>, and endbands began to be glued on with the <a href="#lining">lining</a>.  In early <a href="#binding">binding</a>s and <a href="#finebook">fine binding</a>, embroidered headbands also serve a decorative purpose.  Compare with <a href="#headcap">headcap</a>.  
</p><p>
Also refers to a decorative band <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the top of a <a href="#page">page</a> or at the beginning of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> in older books.  Synonymous in this sense with <a href="#headpiece">headpiece</a> and <em>head ornament</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="headcap"><b>headcap</b></a>
</dt><dd>The thickened edge at the upper end of the <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#leatherbound">leather-bound</a> <a href="#book">book</a>, created by inserting a piece of cord inside the turned-in end of the covering material after the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> has been attached to the <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  The same edge at the lower end of the spine is called the <em>tailcap</em>.  Compare with <a href="#headband">headband</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="header"><b>header</b></a>
</dt><dd>The lines at the beginning of an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> message that display the <a href="#emailaddress">e-mail address</a> and (in some mail systems) the name of the sender (To:) and recipient (From:), any delivery options (CC:), and the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of communication (Subj:), as opposed to the <a href="#footer">footer</a> at the end of the message and the <a href="#body">body</a> containing the <a href="#text">text</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="heading"><b>heading</b></a>
</dt><dd>The name of a person, <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a>, or geographic location; the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>; or an authorized <a href="#content">content</a> descriptor (<a href="#subject">subject heading</a>), used as an <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a> in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#index">index</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, <a href="#formheading">form heading</a>s are also used.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, <a href="#formofentry">form of entry</a> is subject to <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mainheading">main heading</a> and <a href="#subheading">subheading</a>.
<p>  
Also, a line of <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a separate line at the beginning of a section of <a href="#text">text</a> in a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or other division of a <a href="#work">work</a>, indicating the following content in a few descriptive words, usually distinguished from the text <a href="#typography">typographically</a> (<a href="#boldface">boldface</a>, larger <a href="#typesize">type size</a>, <a href="#italic">italic</a>).  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="headline"><b>headline</b></a>
</dt><dd>A few words <a href="#printing">printed</a> in large <a href="#displaytype">display type</a> across the top of the <a href="#frontpage">front page</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> to give prominence to the most important news story of the day, or above the <a href="#text">text</a> of one of the other <a href="#article">article</a>s in the newspaper to give the <a href="#reader">reader</a> a sense of its <a href="#content">content</a>.  Headlines are carefully worded to capture the reader's interest.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#banner">banner</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a uniform line of <a href="#type">type</a> printed at the top of the <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a>, giving the <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a> and <a href="#runningtitle">running title</a>, usually on the <a href="#verso">verso</a>, or the <a href="#chaptertitle">chapter title</a> or <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the chapter or page, usually on the <a href="#recto">recto</a>.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>page head</em> and <em>running head</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="headnote"><b>headnote</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief explanatory note <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the beginning of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>, <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>, <a href="#poetry">poem</a>, or other <a href="#work">work</a>, to serve as a <a href="#preface">preface</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="headpiece"><b>headpiece</b></a>
</dt><dd>A decoration <a href="#printing">printed</a> in the <a href="#blank">blank</a> space at the beginning of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or other division of a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually a <a href="#printersornament">printer's ornament</a> or a small <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> done by a professional <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>.  Also spelled <em>head-piece</em>.  Synonymous with <a href="#headband">headband</a> and <em>head ornament</em>.  Compare with <a href="#tailpiece">tailpiece</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#sinkage">sinkage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="headword"><b>headword</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> used as a <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a> in a <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> or <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> in <a href="#boldface">boldface</a> or some other distinctive <a href="#type">type</a> at the beginning of a <a href="#definition">definition</a> or other <a href="#entry">entry</a>.  In most dictionaries, headwords are arranged in a single <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> sequence.  In <a href="#classified">classified</a> <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s, headwords may be listed alphabetically within each section, usually with a <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#keywords">keyword</a> <a href="#index">index</a> to the entire <a href="#work">work</a> at the end of the last <a href="#volume">volume</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="healthscilib"><b>health science library</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#medicallib">medical library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hearings"><b>hearings</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publication">Publication</a>s of the U.S. federal government containing the <a href="#transcript">transcript</a>s of testimony given before Congressional committees and subcommittees, usually available in the <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> section of a <a href="#library">library</a>.  Congressional hearings are also available <a href="#online">online</a> via <em><a href="http://www.access.gpo.gov/congress/cong017.html">GPO Access</a></em>.  Not all hearings are <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the <a href="#gpo">U.S. Government Printing Office</a>.  In a more general sense, the <a href="#printing">printed</a>
transcript of testimony given before any government committee or
executive body authorized to hold investigative or fact-finding
proceedings. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#freedom">freedom of information </a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="height"><b>height</b></a>
</dt><dd>The dimension of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> from <a href="#head">head</a> to <a href="#tail">tail</a>, usually greater than its <a href="#width">width</a>, the exception being <a href="#volume">volume</a>s <a href="#square">square</a> or <a href="#oblong">oblong</a> in shape.  In the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the height of a book is given in centimeters in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  In many libraries, books over a certain height are <a href="#spinelabel">label</a>ed <a href="#oversize">oversize</a>
and shelved in a separate section. Also refers to the vertical
dimension of a unit of single- or double-faced shelving. Most
commercially-made library shelving is sold in units 42, 60, 72, or 84
inches high. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#depth">depth</a> and <a href="#shelfheight">shelf height</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="helpline"><b>help line</b></a>
</dt><dd>A telephone number that a person may call to receive
assistance of a certain kind, for example, instructions or advice on
how to use a specific type of computer <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> or <a href="#software">software</a>.  Some help lines are more helpful than others.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#helpscreen">help screen</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="helpscreen"><b>help screen</b></a>
</dt><dd>The screen or sequence of screens in an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, or other <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>, providing instructions to users who need assistance in learning how to use the system.  In well-designed <a href="#software">software</a>, the help screens are <a href="#contextsensitive">context-sensitive</a>.  Compare with <a href="#wizard">wizard</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#tutorial">tutorial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hmso"><b>Her Majesty's Stationery Office (HMSO)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a> in the United Kingdom responsible for <a href="#printing">printing</a> official <a href="#govdocs">government</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, and for regulating and <a href="#licensing">licensing</a> the use of all <a href="#information">information</a> produced by the government, the British equivalent of the <a href="#gpo">U.S. Government Printing Office</a>.  <a href="http://www.hmso.gov.uk/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>HMSO</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hermeneutics"><b>hermeneutics</b></a>
</dt><dd>The study of the art and science of interpretation and understanding, as opposed to the practice of exposition.  The <a href="#term">term</a> originally applied to Biblical <a href="#exegesis">exegesis</a>, but was subsequently extended to secular <a href="#text">text</a>s.  In the 19th century, literary theorists recognized the paradox that understanding a <a href="#work">work</a> as a whole requires <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>
of its parts, but understanding the parts presupposes at least some
knowledge of the whole. In the 20th century, as objectivity gave way to
subjectivity in literary theory, interpretation was found to be rooted
in culture and history, turning the meaning of a text into the history
of its interpretations.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="heuristic"><b>heuristic</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek word <em>heuriskein</em> meaning "to discover."
A course of action or method of problem-solving in which progress
toward the best possible outcome or solution is continuously evaluated
through trial and error. Both positive and negative results are
incorporated as <a href="#feedback">feedback</a> into the discovery process, allowing procedure to be adjusted as the best next step is determined.  <a href="#library">Library</a> <a href="#research">research</a> is usually a heuristic process.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hickie"><b>hickie</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#printer">Printer</a>'s <a href="#slang">slang</a> for an unintended spot or defect on a printed <a href="#page">page</a>, usually caused by a speck of dust, lint, or dried ink on the <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#plate">plate</a> or <a href="#negative">negative</a>.  Also spelled <em>hickey</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hiddenagenda"><b>hidden agenda</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#agenda">agenda</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hierarchicalclass"><b>hierarchical classification</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> in which the <a href="#class">class</a>es are <a href="#subdivision">subdivided</a> on the principle of logical subordination, from the most general <a href="#subject">subject</a>s to the most specific.  Hierarchical classification can be <a href="#broadclassification">broad</a> or <a href="#closeclassification">close</a>.  <a href="http://www.oclc.org/dewey/about/about_the_ddc.htm#hierarchy">Click here</a> to see the hierarchy in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>.  Synonymous with <em>analytic classification</em>.  Compare with <a href="#enumerativeclass">enumerative classification</a> and <a href="#syntheticclass">synthetic classification</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#treestructure">tree structure</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hierarchicalforce"><b>hierarchical force</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>s based on logical subordination, such as <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the basic principle that the <a href="#attribute">attribute</a>s of a <a href="#class">class</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>) identified in the <a href="#heading">heading</a> assigned to represent it and in certain explanatory <a href="#note">note</a>s, apply to all its <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a>s (<em>examples</em>:  <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, <a href="#journal">journal</a>) and to all other classes to which reference is made in the notes.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hierarchicrelation"><b>hierarchic relation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a> between two terms in which the concept represented by one is a <a href="#subclass">subclass</a> of the concept represented by the other (<em>example</em>:  Library books / Books). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hierarchy"><b>hierarchy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> of <a href="#class">class</a>es in a <a href="#classification">classification system</a>, from the most general to the most <a href="#specificity">specific</a>.  In a <a href="#classificationschedule">classification schedule</a>, hierarchy is usually indicated by <a href="#indention">indention</a>, as in the following example from <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd>700 The Arts
<dl><dt></dt><dd>720 Architecture
<dl><dt></dt><dd>725 Public structures
<dl><dt></dt><dd>725.1 Government buildings
<dl><dt></dt><dd>725.11 Legislative buildings</dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
In an <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>, logical hierarchy is indicated in the list of <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s by the codes <a href="#broaderterm">BT</a> (broader term) or <a href="#narrowerterm">NT</a> (narrower term).  In a more general sense, the arrangement of a set of <a href="#term">term</a>s or items by degree of specificity according to a given <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>,
for example, the sequence United States - New England - Massachusetts -
Boston - Beacon Street, according to geographic location. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#treestructure">tree structure</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hieroglyphics"><b>hieroglyphics</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek <em>hieros</em> ("sacred" or "powerful") and <em>glyphikos</em> ("carving").  A writing system in which <a href="#picture">picture</a>s or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s, rather than <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of a phonetic <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>, are used to represent words, syllables, and sounds.  The ancient Egyptians wrote in <em>hieroglyphs</em> that were not deciphered until the discovery of the Rosetta Stone in 1799.  <a href="http://www.greatscott.com/hiero/">Click here</a> to learn more about Egyptian hieroglyphs.  Also refers to a form of written expression that is difficult to read or understand.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hieronym"><b>hieronym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#familyname">surname</a> based on a sacred name (<em>example</em>: <b>Perse Saint John</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="highdemand"><b>high-demand</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#demand">demand</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="highfidelity"><b>high fidelity</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any method of <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a> that minimizes distortion by reproducing such a wide range of audible <a href="#frequency">frequencies</a> that the result is very faithful to the <a href="#original">original</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="highlevel"><b>high-level domain</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#domainname">domain name</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="highlight"><b>highlight</b></a>
</dt><dd>To use a broad-tipped pen to mark in light-colored <a href="#ink">ink</a> a section of <a href="#text">text</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#document">document</a>, usually for future reference.  College <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s donated to <a href="#library">libraries</a> are often heavily highlighted.  In a similar fashion, the "edit" <a href="#option">option</a> in some computer <a href="#application">application</a>s allows the user to mark in a shaded or contrasting background portions of electronic text to be cut or <a href="#copy">copied</a>.
In a more general sense, to give prominence to the part of a whole that
is the most outstanding, interesting, pertinent, useful, etc. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="highlighting"><b>highlighting</b></a>
</dt><dd>Words, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s, or passages of <a href="#text">text</a> marked in a <a href="#book">book</a>
with a broad-tipped, brightly colored pen for future study. The
presence of highlighting diminishes the value of a book for resale,
particularly for <a href="#bookcollecting">collector</a>s.  As a general rule, donated <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> containing highlighting are added to a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> only in exceptional cases.  Compare with <a href="#underlining">underlining</a>.
<p>
Highlighting is also used in some computer <a href="#application">application</a>s to <a href="#editing">edit</a> <a href="#text">text</a> by positioning the <a href="#cursor">cursor</a>
at the beginning of a word, phrase, or entire passage, holding down on
the mouse button, and dragging the cursor to the end of the desired
portion of text. </p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="highriskcollec"><b>high-risk collection</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#archives">archival</a> or <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> for which the likelihood of <a href="#vandalism">vandalism</a> or <a href="#theft">theft</a> is higher than normal due to its exceptional value (<a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s) or unusual <a href="#content">content</a> (<a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>).  Tighter <a href="#security">security</a> precautions are taken, especially when such <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s are placed on <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="highsmith"><b>Highsmith Inc.</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial company in the business of providing <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a>, and furnishings to <a href="#library">libraries</a> and schools, marketed through its <a href="#tradecatalog">trade catalog</a>.  <a href="http://www.highsmith.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Highsmith</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#brodart">Brodart</a> and <a href="#demco">DEMCO</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="highspeed"><b>high-speed</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, equipment that functions at a higher than normal speed, usually purchased at a premium.  Also refers to a fast <a href="#internet">Internet</a> connection (compare <a href="#t3">T3</a> with <a href="#t1">T1</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hinge"><b>hinge</b></a>
</dt><dd>A narrow strip of muslin or <a href="#paper">paper</a>, attached with <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> along the line dividing the two halves of an <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a> to reinforce the flexible <a href="#joint">joint</a> along which the <a href="#body">body</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> is attached to the <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  In <a href="#volume">volume</a>s lacking this reinforcement, the hinge is formed by adhering the covering material (<a href="#leather">leather</a>, <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>, <a href="#paper">paper</a>, etc.) directly to the fold in the endpaper.
<p>
Also refers to a narrow cloth or paper stub inserted along the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> between the <a href="#page">page</a>s of a book to allow a <a href="#map">map</a> or added <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> to flex easily when the volume is opened.  Synonymous in this sense with <a href="#guard">guard</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="histogram"><b>histogram</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#graph">graph</a> representing quantitative <a href="#data">data</a>
in a series of vertical or horizontal bars or lines drawn from a base
line. The position of each bar (or line) along the base indicates the
class or value of one variable, with the length of the bar (or line)
indicating the corresponding value of a second variable. A third
variable can be added if the bars are displayed in groups and
distinguished graphically, by color, shading, etc. Synonymous with <em>bar graph</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="historiatedborder"><b>historiated border</b></a>
</dt><dd>An ornamental band around a <a href="#miniature">miniature</a> or portion of <a href="#text">text</a> on the <a href="#page">page</a> of an <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, decorated with figures of animals and/or human beings, sometimes in a scene <a href="#illustration">illustrating</a> the accompanying text.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fullpageborder">full-page border</a> and <a href="#historiated">historiated initial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="historiated"><b>historiated initial</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a> in an <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, decorated with animal and/or human figures. sometimes in a scene that <a href="#illustration">illustrates</a> the accompanying <a href="#text">text</a>.  Compare with <a href="#figureinitial">figure initial</a> and <a href="#inhabited">inhabited initial</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#historiatedborder">historiated border</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="historicalatlas"><b>historical atlas</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> of <a href="#map">map</a>s showing
the progressive changes that have occurred over a given period of time
in a geographic area or in the development of a spatial phenomenon (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Historical Atlas of United States Congressional Districts, 1789-1983</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="historicalbib"><b>historical bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>The branch of <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> devoted to the study of the history and methods of <a href="#book">book</a> production, including hand-<a href="#copy">copy</a>ing, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, <a href="#binding">binding</a>, and <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>.  Historical bibliography has merged with the <a href="#field">field</a> of <a href="#bookhistory">book history</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="historicalfiction"><b>historical fiction</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> in the form of a <a href="#novel">novel</a>, set in a specific period of history or based on an event or sequence of events that actually happened.  The <a href="#character">character</a>s may be completely <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>al,
but if they are known to have existed, their feelings, words, and
actions are reconstructed and to some degree imagined by the <a href="#author">author</a>.  The presence of <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> in an historical <a href="#work">work</a> is usually a clue that the account is fictionalized.  Sir Walter Scott established the <a href="#genre">genre</a> in 1814 with the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of <b><em>Waverly</em></b>, a novel of life in the Scottish borderlands, followed by several more historical <a href="#romance">romance</a>s, including <b><em>Ivanhoe</em></b> (1819).    Compare with  <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="historicalsociety"><b>historical society</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonprofit organization devoted to preserving the historical <a href="#record">record</a> of a state or municipality (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.ohs.org/homepage.html">Oregon</a>), place (<a href="http://www.vineyard.net/org/mvhs/">Martha's Vineyard</a>), institution (<a href="http://www.supremecourthistory.org/">U.S. Supreme Court</a>), people (<a href="http://www.hhs-newpaltz.org/">Huguenots</a>), activity (<a href="http://www.seahistory.org/public_html/frame.htm">Seafaring</a>), or thing (<a href="http://www.organsociety.org/html/site/site_frame.html">Pipe organs</a>).  Well-established historical <a href="#society">societies</a> often support a public museum, maintain an <a href="#archive">archive</a> or <a href="#library">library</a> for the use of members, and may <a href="#publishing">publish</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and other materials related to their sphere of interest.  <a href="http://www.theaha.org/affiliates/">Click here</a> to connect to a <a href="#directory">directory</a> of the affiliates of the American Historical Association (AHA).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="historicalvalue"><b>historical value</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="history"><b>history</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#searchhistory">search history</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="historynote"><b>history note</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief note in an <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">term</a>s, giving the date the <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> was added to the list of <a href="#preferredterm">preferred term</a>s, and indicating any changes that have occurred in its meaning, <a href="#scopenote">scope</a>, relationships to other terms, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="historyofbook"><b>history of the book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bookhistory">book history</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="historyplay"><b>history play</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#chronicleplay">chronicle play</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hit"><b>hit</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, a <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> retrieved from a <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> that matches the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a> expressed in the <a href="#query">query</a>.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is sometimes used loosely to refer to a record that satisfies the <a href="#syntax">syntactic</a> requirements of the query without necessarily meeting its <a href="#semantics">semantic</a> requirements (a <a href="#falsedrop">false drop</a>), but this is an imprecise use of the term.  <em>Hit rate</em> is the percentage of all the records retrieved in a <a href="#search">search</a> that are <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> to the query.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#precision">precision</a> and <a href="#recall">recall</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hits"><b>hits</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, the number of <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s retrieved from a <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> that are <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> to the <a href="#query">query</a>.  In some databases, the number of hits is indicated <em>before</em> records are displayed, to enable the user to modify the <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a> before viewing <a href="#search">search</a> results.  Compare with <a href="#falsedrop">false drop</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#precision">precision</a> and <a href="#recall">recall</a>.
<p>
On the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, the number of times a particular site is visited during a designated period of time, which can be recorded by an automatic <a href="#counter">counter</a> supported by the <a href="#software">software</a> running the site.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hmso1"><b>HMSO</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#hmso"><b>H</b>er <b>M</b>ajesty's <b>S</b>tationery <b>O</b>ffice</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hold"><b>hold</b></a>           
</dt><dd>When a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is currently on loan, most <a href="#library">libraries</a> permit another <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> to place a "hold" on it by contacting the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a>.  The <a href="#patron">patron</a> who has the item <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> will not be permitted to <a href="#renew">renew</a> it, and the person placing the "hold" will be entitled to check it out after it has been returned.  Some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s include a feature that allows the user to place an item on hold without <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> assistance.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="holdingarea"><b>holding area</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, a location specifically designated for the temporary storage of <a href="#semicurrent">semicurrent</a> <a href="#records">records</a> and materials, usually less <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> than the space allocated for <a href="#currency">current</a> records.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="holdings"><b>holdings</b></a>
