</dt><dd>The total stock of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, <a href="#print">print</a> and <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a>, owned by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, usually listed in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  Synonymous in this sense with <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to all the <a href="#copy">copies</a>, <a href="#volume">volume</a>s, <a href="#issue">issue</a>s, or <a href="#part">part</a>s of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> owned by a library, indicated in a <a href="#holdingsnote">holdings note</a> in the <a href="#catalogrecord">record</a> that represents the item in the catalog.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#openentry">open entry</a> and <a href="#closedentry">closed entry</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="holdingsdisplay"><b>holdings display</b></a>
</dt><dd>In a <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a>, a list of all the <a href="#library">libraries</a> and other participating institutions that own a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  In the <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>, the three-letter <a href="#oclcsymbol">OCLC symbol</a>s attached to the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for an item, representing the institutions that own at least one <a href="#copy">copy</a>, used in <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> to generate <a href="#lenderstring">lender string</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="holdingsnote"><b>holdings note</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#note">note</a> added to the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> for an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, indicating the <a href="#copy">copies</a>, <a href="#volume">volume</a>s, <a href="#issue">issue</a>s, or <a href="#part">part</a>s <a href="#holdings">held</a> by the <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> in an <a href="#openentry">open</a> or <a href="#closedentry">closed entry</a>, usually with <a href="#information">information</a> concerning the location of the item.  For <a href="#serial">serial</a>s, separate notes may be provided for <a href="#print">print</a> and <a href="#microform">microform</a> <a href="#holdings">holdings</a>.  Compare with <a href="#numericalphabetic">numeric and/or alphabetic, chronological, or other designation</a> <a href="#area">area</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="holdingsrate"><b>holdings rate</b></a>
</dt><dd>The percentage of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s requested by the users of a <a href="#library">library</a> that are in its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  In most libraries, items not held locally may be borrowed on <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> (ILL) or obtained via <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery service</a> (DDS). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hollow"><b>hollow</b></a>
</dt><dd>The open space between the <a href="#cover">cover</a> and the <a href="#back">back</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#section">section</a>s are not <a href="#gluingoff">glued</a> directly to the cover.  A <a href="#hollowback">hollow back</a> allows a book to <a href="#openability">open flat</a> and stay open without damaging the <a href="#spine">spine</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hollowback"><b>hollow back</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the <a href="#cover">cover</a> is <em>not</em> <a href="#gluingoff">glued</a> to the <a href="#back">back</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, leaving an open space that allows the binding to flex easily when the <a href="#volume">volume</a> is <a href="#openability">opened</a>, without <a href="#cracked">cracking</a> the <a href="#spine">spine</a>.  Most <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>s are bound with a <a href="#hollow">hollow</a> back.  Synonymous with <em>loose-back</em> and <em>open back</em>.  Compare with <a href="#tightback">tight back</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="holograph"><b>holograph</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#document">document</a> written entirely in the handwriting of the person (or persons) to whom it is <a href="#attributed">attributed</a>.  A holographic <a href="#reprint">reprint</a> is a <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>
of such a document, made by mechanical means. Also refers to a
three-dimensional image of an object recorded on photosensitive <a href="#film">film</a> by the pattern of interference made by a split laser beam, in a process called <em>holography</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="homebound"><b>homebound</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person unable to leave home to come to the <a href="#library">library</a>, usually for reasons of disability or ill health.  To reach homebound <a href="#patron">patron</a>s, <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> have developed <a href="#libraryextension">extension</a> services such as <a href="#booksbymail">books-by-mail</a>, <a href="#bookmobile">bookmobile</a>s, and <a href="#directdelivery">direct delivery</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="homepage"><b>homepage</b></a>
</dt><dd>The first or main page of a <a href="#website">site</a> on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>, displayed whenever a user <a href="#logon">logs on</a> to a <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> and opens the site <a href="#internetaddress">address</a> (<a href="#url">URL</a>).  The <a href="#filename">filename</a> at the end of a homepage address is often <em>home.html</em>, <em>index.html</em>, <em>main.html</em>, or something similar.  A well-designed homepage gives the <a href="#title">title</a> of the site, name of <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#host">host</a>, date of last <a href="#update">update</a>, notice of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a>, and <a href="#link">link</a>s to <a href="#subpage">subpage</a>s providing more detailed <a href="#information">information</a> about the site, usually the best starting point when navigating the site for the first time.  Also spelled <em>home page</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="homeworkcenter"><b>homework center</b></a>
</dt><dd>A space set aside in a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>, usually with established <a href="#hours">hours</a> and assigned <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> trained to provide clearly defined services to students in need of assistance with their homework assignments. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="homily"><b>homily</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sermon that explains a point in the Christian <em>Bible</em>,
usually accompanied by instructions for the congregation hearing it. In
a more general sense, any tendentious, moralizing speech or lecture.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="homograph"><b>homograph</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word spelled the same as one or more other words, but different in meaning and sometimes in origin, for example, <em>current</em> (ocean) and <em>current</em> (up-to-date), but not <em>currant</em> (the fruit).  Every effort is made to avoid homographs in <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, but when necessary, a <a href="#parenthetical">parenthetical qualifier</a> is added to the <a href="#heading">heading</a>, as in the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress Subject Heading</a> <b>Mice (Computers)</b>.  Compare with <a href="#homonym">homonym</a> and <a href="#homophone">homophone</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="homonym"><b>homonym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word pronounced the same as one or more other words, but
different in meaning and origin (and usually in spelling), for example,
<b><em>plate</em></b> (<a href="#illustration">illustration</a>) and <b><em>plait</em></b> (braid or pleat).  The word "plate" is also a <a href="#homograph">homograph</a>:  <b><em>plate</em></b> (food dish).  Synonymous with <a href="#homophone">homophone</a>.  Compare with <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="homophone"><b>homophone</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word pronounced the same as one or more others, which has a different spelling, meaning, and derivation (<b><em>toad</em></b>, <b><em>toed</em></b>, and <b><em>towed</em></b>).  Synonymous with <a href="#homonym">homonym</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="honorifictitle"><b>honorific title</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal <a href="#title">title</a> conferred on a person by a recognized authority as a mark of honor, rank, nobility, or royalty (<em>example</em>:  <b>Cardinal</b> Richelieu).  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, an honorific title is included in a <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#heading">heading</a> only when commonly used in referring to the person.  In such cases, the title follows the <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> and precedes the <a href="#birthdeath">birth and death dates</a> (<b>Newton, Isaac, Sir, 1642-1727</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hornbook1"><b>hornbook</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#hornbook">horn book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hornbook"><b>horn book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of child's <a href="#primer">primer</a> used in England and America from the 15th to the 18th century, consisting of a sheet of <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> or <a href="#paper">paper</a> bearing the <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>, usually the first ten <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s, basic spelling rules, the Lord's Prayer, and sometimes a hand-colored <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>,
protected by a thin, transparent sheet of cattle horn, mounted on an
oblong bat of wood or leather with a projecting handle by which it
could be fastened to a child's girdle. Its paddle shape suggests that
it may have been used in playing the game <em>shuttlecock</em>.  The term is used in the <a href="#title">title</a> of <em><a href="#hornbookmagazine">Horn Book Magazine</a></em>, a <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a> devoted to <a href="#childrenslit">children's literature</a>.  Also spelled <em>hornbook</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#abecedarium">abecedarium</a> and <a href="#battledore">battledore</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hornbookmagazine"><b><em>Horn Book Magazine</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publishing">Published</a> since 1924, <b><em>Horn Book Magazine</em></b> provides <a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#authorinterview">author interview</a>s, <a href="#editorial">editorial</a>s, <a href="#column">column</a>s, and lengthy <a href="#review">review</a>s of <a href="#childrensbook">children's books</a> in each <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>.  The <a href="#title">title</a> is derived from the name of an educational toy, called a <a href="#hornbook">horn book</a>, used by young children from about the 15th to the 18th century.  <a href="http://www.hbook.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> version of <b><em>Horn Book</em></b>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="horror"><b>horror</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#subgenre">subgenre</a> of <a href="#gothicnovel">gothic</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> in which supernatural events, macabre effects, and obsessive introspection are combined with chilling <a href="#suspense">suspense</a> to produce in the <a href="#reader">reader</a> a sensation of fear and revulsion.  Early <a href="#literarywork">literary</a> examples are Mary Shelley's <a href="#novel">novel</a> <b><em>Frankenstein</em></b> (1818), the <a href="#shortstory">short story</a> "The Fall of the House of Usher" (1839) by Edgar Allan Poe, and <b><em>Dracula</em></b> (1897) by Bram Stoker.  In <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, the earliest examples are <b><em>The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari</em></b> (1919) <a href="#director">directed</a> by Robert Wiene and <b><em>Nosferatu</em></b> (1922) by F. W. Murnau, two <a href="#classic">classic</a>s of German expressionism.  More recent examples include Alfred Hitchcock's <b><em>Psycho</em></b> (1960) and episodes of Rod Serling's television series <b><em>The Twilight Zone</em></b>.  Compare with <a href="#thriller">thriller</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="horstexte"><b><em>hors texte</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A French phrase meaning "outside the text," referring to <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s not <a href="#printing">printed</a> with the <a href="#text">text</a>, such as <a href="#plate">plate</a>s.  They are usually numbered in <a href="#romannumeral">roman numeral</a>s to distinguish them from illustrations printed <em>with</em> the text, which are numbered in <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s or referenced by <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hospitality"><b>hospitality</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#classification">classification</a>, the property that allows new <a href="#class">class</a>es to be added to a system of <a href="#notation">notation</a> as needed, without requiring the alteration of previously established <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a>s.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hospitallib"><b>hospital library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#medicallib">medical library</a> maintained within the walls of a hospital, containing a <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#print">print</a> and <a href="#online">online</a> resources on medicine and allied health, to serve the <a href="#infoneed">information</a> and <a href="#research">research</a> needs of doctors, nurses, patients, and staff, usually managed by a medical <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="host"><b>host</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer that serves as a source of <a href="#data">data</a> for other <a href="#terminal">terminal</a>s or computers, for example, a central computer providing <a href="#file">file</a>s to terminals connected directly to it, or a <a href="#network">network</a> <a href="#server">server</a> <a href="#access">access</a>ed by <a href="#client">client</a> machines.  Also refers to the organization or institution that provides the <a href="#server">server</a> on which a <a href="#website">Web site</a> is installed, usually indicated in its <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hostorg"><b>host organization</b></a>
</dt><dd>The organization in which a <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a> functions as an administrative unit, for example, a museum that maintains a <a href="#museumlib">library</a> on its premises for the use of <a href="#curator">curator</a>s, <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s, and members, or a corporation that maintains a library for the use of employees in their work.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hotmelt"><b>hot-melt</b></a>
</dt><dd>A tough, flexible chemical <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> used in commercial <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>.  Solid at room temperatures, hot-melt adhesive liquifies under high heat.  In <a href="#perfectbinding">perfect binding</a>, it is applied to the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> in a <a href="#oneshot">single shot</a> at temperatures of 135-175 degrees C.  Unlike the adhesives used in <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>s
which take time to dry, hot-melt adhesive sets up in seconds as it
cools, significantly reducing production costs. Unfortunately, it has a
clamping effect which reduces <a href="#openability">openability</a>, and it is not resistant to <a href="#coldcrack">cold-crack</a> which makes it unsuitable for bindings marketed in countries where winter temperatures are severe.  Also spelled <em>hotmelt</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#otabind">Otabind</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hotspot"><b>hot spot</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#icon">icon</a> of any size, or portion of a larger image displayed on a computer screen, that functions as a live <a href="#link">link</a> to another <a href="#file">file</a> or <a href="#document">document</a> available on the same or a different <a href="#server">server</a>.  When it is clicked with a pointing device such as a <a href="#mouse">mouse</a>, a coded instruction is executed to <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> and display the linked material.  Also refers to the precise <a href="#pixel">pixel</a>s within a clickable icon or image which are sensitive to selection by the user.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hours"><b>hours</b></a>
</dt><dd>The times during a day, week, and year that a <a href="#library">library</a> is open to its users, usually posted near the front entrance and available by phone or via the library's <a href="#website">Web site</a>,
including any days the library is not open, usually holidays. A
library's hours are determined by the needs of its users and by <a href="#budget">budget</a>ary
constraints. Also refers to the times during which a specific service
is available from a library, which may be shorter (or longer) than the
hours the facility is open.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="housekeeping"><b>housekeeping</b></a>
</dt><dd>Routine chores that must be performed methodically in a <a href="#library">library</a>
to maintain manual or automated systems in good order, usually
delegated to a trained assistant, for example, the task of checking in <a href="#serial">serial</a> parts in a timely manner to make them available to users and identify missing <a href="#issue">issue</a>s that need to to be <a href="#claim">claim</a>ed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="houseorgan"><b>house organ</b></a>

</dt><dd>A <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d
by a commercial or industrial organization for distribution internally
to its employees and/or externally to its customers, not intended for
wider <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  Synonymous with <em>house journal</em>.  Compare with <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="housestyle"><b>house style</b></a>
</dt><dd>The uniform <a href="#standards">standards</a> of a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#printer">printer</a>, company, or organization with reference to writing style (grammar, <a href="#syntax">syntax</a>, <a href="#usage">usage</a>, <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a>, etc.) and presentation (spelling, <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a>, <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a>/<a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a>, <a href="#citation">citation</a> format, etc.) to be followed, in the absence of contrary instructions, in <a href="#publication">publication</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in its name, usually explained in a <a href="#stylesheet">style sheet</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="howto"><b>how-to publication</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>, or <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a> that provides practical <a href="#information">information</a>
and advice about how to accomplish a task, acquire a skill, or achieve
a desired result, usually in the form of step-by-step instructions
accompanied by <a href="#diagram">diagram</a>s (<em>example</em>:  home improvement and auto repair <a href="#manual">manual</a>s).  How-to <a href="#title">title</a>s are available in <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, shelved by <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> in the <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> section.  Compare with <a href="#selfhelp">self-help publication</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="html1"><b>HTML</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#html"><b>H</b>yper<b>T</b>ext <b>M</b>arkup <b>L</b>anguage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="htmleditor"><b>HTML editor</b></a>
</dt><dd>Computer <a href="#software">software</a> designed to facilitate the creation of <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s by relieving the designer of the necessity of typing the required <a href="#html">HTML</a> code from scratch (<em>examples</em>:  <b><em>Dreamweaver</em></b>, <b><em>FrontPage</em></b>, and <b><em>Netscape Composer</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="http"><b>http://</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>H</b>yper<b>T</b>ext <b>T</b>ransfer <b>P</b>rotocol, the <a href="#communications">communications</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> used in <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> <a href="#software">software</a> to establish the connection between a <a href="#client">client</a> computer and a remote <a href="#webserver">Web server</a>, making it possible for <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s in <a href="#html">HTML</a> <a href="#format">format</a> to be transmitted over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> from the <a href="#server">server</a> to the client machine on which the browser is installed.  Most <a href="#www">Web</a> browsers are designed to <a href="#default">default</a> to the <a href="#prefix">prefix</a> <b>http://</b> whenever a user enters a Web address (<a href="#url">URL</a>) without the prefix.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="humanistic"><b>humanistic script</b></a>
</dt><dd>In 15th century Europe, the renaissance of interest in classical art and culture had a profound effect on <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, producing a <a href="#script">script</a> that abandoned many characteristics of <a href="#gothic">gothic</a> <a href="#letterform">letterform</a>s and embraced some of features of the earlier <a href="#carolingian">Carolingian</a> <a href="#script">script</a>, but in a more compressed form.  Appearing concurrently with the invention of <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>, <em>scrittura umanistica</em> was quickly adapted by <a href="#type">type</a> founders, particularly the <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a>s which are very close to the forms used in modern <a href="#printing">printing</a>.  According to Warren Chappell in <b><em>A Short History of the Printed Word</em></b> (1970), chancery script, from which <a href="#italic">italic</a> developed, was a direct descendant of <em>scrittura umanistica</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="humanresources"><b>human resources</b></a>
</dt><dd>A collective term for all the people employed by a company, <a href="#agency">agency</a>,
organization, or institution. Also, the administrative department
responsible for matters pertaining to employment (hiring, evaluation, <a href="#promotion">promotion</a>, termination, etc.).  Large independent <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s
usually have their own human resources office. Libraries that function
as a unit within a larger organization may rely on the parent
organization for such services. Synonymous with <em>personnel</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="humidify"><b>humidify</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#humidity">humidity</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="humidity"><b>humidity</b></a>
</dt><dd>The amount of water vapor held in air.  <em>Absolute humidity</em> is the weight (mass) of water vapor in a given volume of air, usually expressed as grams of water per cubic meter of air.  <em>Relative humidity</em>
is the ratio of the amount of water vapor present in a given volume of
air to the amount required to reach saturation (condensation into
droplets) at the same temperature, expressed as a percentage. Relative
humidity varies with temperature and air pressure--warm air can hold
more water vapor than cooler air. Forty percent relative humidity is
considered ideal for permanent storage of <a href="#library">library</a> and <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> made from <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  <a href="#mold">Mold</a> can become a serious problem when relative humidity exceeds 70%. 
<p>
To <em>humidify</em> is to put moisture into the atmosphere, usually done with a device called a <em>humidifier</em> to prevent paper <a href="#document">document</a>s from becoming <a href="#brittle">brittle</a>.  <em>Dehumidification</em> takes moisture out of the atmosphere.  It is done with <a href="#desiccant">desiccant</a>s or a <em>dehumidifier</em> to prevent <a href="#mildew">mildew</a>, <a href="#warping">warping</a>, etc.  Measured by an instrument called a <a href="#hygrometer">hygrometer</a>, humidity is carefully controlled in areas where archival and <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a> are stored and used. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="huntingtonlibrary"><b>Huntington Library</b></a>
</dt><dd>Located in San Marino, California, the <b>Huntington Library</b> is one of the world's leading <a href="#library">libraries</a> of <a href="#americana">Americana</a> and English <a href="#literature">literature</a>, surpassed only by the <a href="#britishlib">British Library</a> and the <a href="#bodleian">Bodleian</a>.  Its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s include over five million <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s, <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s, and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> on Anglo-American history, literature and the arts, the history of science, and maritime history.  The library includes a <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> center, <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ion hall, art collection, and botanical gardens.  <a href="http://www.huntington.org/LibraryDiv/LibraryHome.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>Huntington Library</b>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hwwilson"><b>H. W. Wilson</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial company that began <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a>s for <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s (especially <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es) long before library <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a>s were automated.  Most of its <a href="#publication">publication</a>s are now available on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> and <a href="#online">online</a>.  Some of its <a href="#bibdatabase"> bibliographic database</a>s include <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a>.  <a href="http://www.hwwilson.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>H. W. Wilson</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hybridjournal"><b>hybrid journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> that functions as both a <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> and a <a href="#journal">journal</a> by including features typical of both.  A prime example is <b><em>Analytical Chemistry</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the American Chemical Society, which includes a magazine section in the front of each <a href="#issue">issue</a>, followed by a longer section of <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s with its own <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a> and separate <a href="#journalpagination">pagination</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hydrologicmap"><b>hydrologic map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> showing the drainage of surface
waters (streams, rivers, etc.) and other features related to hydrology
in a geographic area (lakes, reservoirs, glaciers, ground water,
springs, wetlands, water quality, etc.). <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hygrometer"><b>hygrometer</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any one of several meteorological instruments designed to measure atmospheric <a href="#humidity">humidity</a>.  Hygrometers are used to monitor conditions in facilities such as <a href="#library">libraries</a> and museums that house materials easily <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> by water vapor (<a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#specimen">specimen</a>s, <a href="#film">film</a>, etc.).  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hype"><b>hype</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of <em>hyperbole</em>.  <a href="#publisher">Publisher</a>'s <a href="#slang">slang</a> for advertising <a href="#copy">copy</a> written in an exaggerated style to attract attention to a new <a href="#publication">publication</a>, not intended to be taken literally by prospective customers.  Objective <a href="#review">review</a>s are the best antidote.  Compare with <a href="#puff">puff</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hyperlink"><b>hyperlink</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See </em></b>: <a href="#link">link</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hypermedia"><b>hypermedia</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#document">document</a> in which <a href="#text">text</a> is combined with <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s, <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a>, <a href="#animated">animation</a>, and/or <a href="#fullmotion">full-motion video</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.nationalgeographic.com/channel/">National Geographic Channel</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hyperonym"><b>hyperonym</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#broaderterm">broader term</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hypertext"><b>hypertext</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of presenting <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#information">information</a> that allows related <a href="#file">file</a>s and elements of <a href="#data">data</a> to be interlinked, rather than viewed in linear sequence.  <a href="#text">Text</a> <a href="#link">link</a>s and <a href="#icon">icon</a>s embedded in a <a href="#document">document</a> written in <a href="#html">HTML</a> script allow <a href="#information">information</a> to be <a href="#browse">browse</a>d
in nonlinear, associative fashion similar to the way the human mind
functions, by selecting with a pointing device or using a computer <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>.  Hypertext is the basic organizing principle of the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>.  This <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>, with its web of interconnected hyperlinks, is an example of such a <a href="#document">document</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#hypermedia">hypermedia</a> and <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="html"><b>Hypertext Markup Language (HTML)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Used to create the <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a> and via <a href="#intranet">intranet</a>s, <b>HTML</b> script is a cross-<a href="#platform">platform</a> presentation language that allows the <a href="#author">author</a> to incorporate into a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> <a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#frame">frame</a>s, <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s, <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a>, <a href="#videorecording">video</a>, and <a href="#link">link</a>s to other documents and <a href="#application">application</a>s.  <a href="#formatting">Formatting</a> is controlled by "tags" embedded in the text.  To see the <b>HTML</b> code in which a Web page is written, click on "View" or its equivalent in the <a href="#toolbar">toolbar</a> of your <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>, then select "Document source" or "Page source."  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#htmleditor">HTML editor</a> and <a href="#sgml">SGML</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hyphen"><b>hyphen</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the shortest <a href="#rule">rule</a> used as <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a>.  Also used to join the parts of a <a href="#compoundname">compound name</a> (Jean-Pierre) or compound word (<a href="#dogeared">dog-eared</a>), and to divide a long word at the end of a line of written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#text">text</a>.  Compare with <a href="#dash">dash</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hyphenation"><b>hyphenation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Use of the <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a> to divide a word (<em>co-opt</em>), to compound two or more words (<em>son-in-law</em>), to give the impression of stuttering or faltering speech (<em>n-n-no</em>), or to indicate that a word is to be spelled out (<em>h-y-p-h-e-n-a-t-e</em>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="hyponym"><b>hyponym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> that can be replaced
without exception by another, without changing the meaning of a
sentence, but not vice versa, for example, <em>azure</em> by <em>blue</em> or <em>sparrow</em> by <em>bird</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#narrowerterm">narrower term</a>.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="I">I</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="iatul1"><b>IATUL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#iatul"><b>I</b>nternational <b>A</b>ssociation of <b>T</b>echnological <b>U</b>niversity <b>L</b>ibraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ibid"><b>ibid.</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin <em>ibidem</em> meaning "in the same place" used with a <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a> (or numbers) in <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s, <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>s, and <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a> to indicate a <a href="#source">source</a> that has been <a href="#cite">cite</a>d fully in a preceding <a href="#note">note</a> or <a href="#entry">entry</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="icic1"><b>ICIC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#icic"><b>I</b>nternational <b>C</b>opyright <b>I</b>nformation <b>C</b>entre</a>.
<p> 
</p></dd><dt><a name="icon"><b>icon</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> element or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> displayed on a computer screen, which the user can select with a pointing <a href="#device">device</a> such as a <a href="#mouse">mouse</a> to summon a <a href="#menu">menu</a> of <a href="#option">option</a>s, <a href="#access">access</a> a <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>, or initiate a process or operation in an <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> that uses a <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a>, for example, a small image of a trash can or recycle bin to which unwanted <a href="#document">document</a>s can be moved for disposal.
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#picture">picture</a>, image, figure, or
representation. In Eastern Orthodox religious imagery, a picture of
Jesus, Mary, or an apostle or saint. Also spelled <em>ikon</em> or <em>eikon</em>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="iconicdocument"><b>iconic document</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> or other <a href="#document">document</a> in which the <a href="#content">content</a> is presented in predominantly <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> or <a href="#picture">pictorial</a> form.  Examples include <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>es, <a href="#childrensbook">children's</a> <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>s, <a href="#exhibitcatalog">exhibit catalog</a>s, <a href="#visualdictionary">visual dictionaries</a>, <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, <a href="#postcard">postcard</a>s, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="iconography"><b>iconography</b></a>
</dt><dd>The art of <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> or representation by means of <a href="#picture">picture</a>s, <a href="#figure">figure</a>s,
or images, developed to a high degree in the artistic tradition of the
Eastern Orthodox faith. Also refers to the study of the pictorial
representation of objects or people, in <a href="#portrait">portrait</a>s, paintings, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s,
sculpture, coins, etc., and to the result of such study, especially
when it takes the form of detailed lists of representations.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="idealcopy"><b>ideal copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#analyticalbibliog">analytical bibliography</a>, a detailed description of the most perfect copy of the first <a href="#impression">impression</a> of an <a href="#edition">edition</a>, based on close inspection of as many <a href="#copy">copies</a> as possible, to which all other copies of the same impression, and any subsequent impressions, are compared in determining <a href="#issue">issue</a> and <a href="#state">state</a> (adapted from <em>The ALA Glossary of Library and Information Science</em>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="identifier"><b>identifier</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#keywords">keyword</a> or indexable concept assigned to a <a href="#document">document</a> to add depth to <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, not listed in the <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of indexing <a href="#term">term</a>s because it either represents a <a href="#propername">proper name</a> (<a href="#geographicname">geographic name</a>, <a href="#personalname">personal name</a>, test or program name, piece of legislation, etc.) or a concept not yet approved as an authorized <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>.  Identifiers are usually listed in a separate <a href="#field">field</a> of the <a href="#index">index</a> <a href="#entry">entry</a> or <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, immediately following the descriptors.  <a href="#major">Major</a> identifiers may be marked with an <a href="#asterisk">asterisk</a> or distinguished in some other manner.  <a href="#formofentry">Form of entry</a> may be subject to <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>.
In some indexing systems, identifiers are periodically reviewed for
suitability as new descriptors. Not all indexing systems use
identifiers. Compare with <a href="#provisionalterm">provisional term</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ideogram"><b>ideogram</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#picture">picture</a> or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> that represents an object or idea without expressing phonetically the sounds of its name, for example, the <a href="#character">character</a>s
used in Chinese and Japanese writing systems. Also refers to a symbol
that represents an idea, for example, the equal sign = or the plus sign
+. Synonymous with <em>ideograph</em>.  Compare with <a href="#phonogram">phonogram</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ideograph"><b>ideograph</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ideogram">ideogram</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="idiom"><b>idiom</b></a>
</dt><dd>A well-known expression that has a different meaning than the literal interpretation of its words (<em>example</em>:  <b>holy terror</b>).  Idioms are sometimes coined from the <a href="#lexicon">lexicon</a> of a particular occupation or pastime (<em>example</em>:  <b>Monday morning quarterback</b>).  Because idioms are specific to a given <a href="#language">language</a>, they can be difficult to <a href="#translation">translate</a>.  <a href="#dictionary">Dictionaries</a> of idioms are usually shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a characteristic style, particularly in the arts, or to the <a href="#language">language</a> or dialect peculiar to a specific people, geographic region, or social class.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="idyl"><b>idyl</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek word meaning "little picture"--a short <a href="#poetry">poem</a>
describing the simplicity and innocence of rural, pastoral, or domestic
life. The origin of this literary form can be traced to Theocritus, who
described pastoral life in Sicily for readers in Alexandria during the
3rd century BC. An <a href="#eclogue">eclogue</a> is a type of idyl.  Compare with <a href="#idyll">idyll</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="idyll"><b>idyll</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#poetry">poem</a> based on a romantic, <a href="#epic">epic</a>, or <a href="#tragedy">tragic</a> theme, for example, <b><em>Idylls of the King</em></b> (1859) by Alfred, Lord Tennyson, an <a href="#episodic">episodic</a> retelling of the <a href="#fable">fable</a>s of the Holy Grail, Camelot, Round Table, and Morte d'Arthur.  Compare with <a href="#idyl">idyl</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ie"><b><em>i.e.</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin phrase <em>id est</em> meaning "that is."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ifcs1"><b>IFCS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ifcs"><b>I</b>nternational <b>F</b>ederation of <b>C</b>lassification <b>S</b>ocieties</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ifla1"><b>IFLA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ifla"><b>I</b>nternational <b>F</b>ederation of <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociations and Institutions</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ifrt1"><b>IFRT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ifrt"><b>I</b>ntellectual <b>F</b>reedom <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="iii1"><b>III</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#iii"><b>I</b>nnovative <b>I</b>nterfaces <b>I</b>nc</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ilab1"><b>ILAB</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ilab"><b>I</b>nternational <b>L</b>eague of <b>A</b>ntiquarian <b>B</b>ooksellers</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ill"><b>ILL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#interlibrary"><b>i</b>nter<b>l</b>ibrary <b>l</b>oan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="illiteracy"><b>illiteracy</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#literacy">literacy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="illuminate"><b>illuminate</b></a>
</dt><dd>To decorate an <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a> or word in a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> with designs or tracings in bright colors and <a href="#goldleaf">gold</a> or silver, or to decorate a <a href="#border">border</a> or an entire <a href="#page">page</a> with initial <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, hand-painted <a href="#miniature">miniature</a>s, and/or colorful designs highlighted in gold or silver, techniques commonly used in medieval manuscripts and <a href="#incunabula">incunabula</a>.  An artist who decorates <a href="#book">book</a>s by hand is an <em>illuminator</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> and <a href="#rubric">rubric</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="illuminated"><b>illuminated</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>luminaire</em> meaning "to give light."  A <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#incunabula">incunabulum</a> richly decorated by hand with ornamental polychrome <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, designs, and/or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s highlighted in <a href="#goldleaf">gold</a> or silver.  Illumination flourished during the medieval period when <a href="#book">book</a>s were hand-<a href="#copy">copied</a> on <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> and <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>, mainly by Catholic monks who produced <a href="#book">book</a>s for devotional use and for exchange with other monasteries (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.primate.wisc.edu/people/dubois/kells/">Book of Kells</a></em>).  
<p>
Beginning in the 14th century, traveling artists traded on their skill as <em>illuminators</em>, working mainly for wealthy <a href="#patron">patron</a>s who filled their <a href="#privatelib">private libraries</a> with <a href="#finebook">fine book</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://metalab.unc.edu/wm/rh/">Tres Riches Heures du Duc de Berry</a></em>).  The <a href="#pierpont">Pierpont Morgan Library</a> in New York City holds one of the largest <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of illuminated books and manuscripts in the United States.  For an <a href="#online">online</a> collection of manuscript illuminations, please see <em><a href="http://www.bnf.fr/enluminures/aaccueil.htm">The Age of Charles V (1338-1380)</a></em> compliments of the <a href="#bnfrance">Bibliotheque Nationale de France</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>illum</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#chrysography">chrysography</a> and <a href="#rubric">rubric</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="illuminatedinitial"><b>illuminated initial</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a> in a <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> decorated in bright colors and highlighted in <a href="#goldleaf">gold</a> or silver.  Compare with <a href="#rubric">rubric</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#foliateinitial">foliate initial</a>, <a href="#historiated">historiated initial</a>, and <a href="#inhabited">inhabited initial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="illumination"><b>illumination</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="illustration"><b>illustration</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#picture">picture</a>, <a href="#plate">plate</a>, <a href="#diagram">diagram</a>, <a href="#plan">plan</a>, <a href="#chart">chart</a>, <a href="#map">map</a>, design, or other <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> image <a href="#printing">printed</a> with or inserted in the <a href="#text">text</a> of <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> as an embellishment or to complement or elucidate the text.  Also refers to the fine art of creating such visual <a href="#work">work</a>s.  
<p>
The earliest examples of illustrated texts date from the second millennium BC.  Medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s were illustrated with <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#miniature">miniature</a>s.  Early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s were illustrated with <a href="#woodcut">woodcut</a>s or wood <a href="#engraving">engraving</a>s.  In modern books, illustrations are often <a href="#number">number</a>ed and listed by number in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>.  <a href="#photograph">Photograph</a>s or <a href="#plate">plate</a>s may be printed on a different grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a> than the text and added to the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a book in one or more groups.  Maps, <a href="#table">table</a>s, and <a href="#genealogy">genealogies</a> are sometimes printed on the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s.  <a href="#magazine">Magazine</a>s, <a href="#artbook">art book</a>s, and books for young children are usually heavily illustrated.  The use of illustration in <a href="#work">work</a>s of general <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> has declined since the early 20th century.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>ill.</em> or <em>illus.</em>  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#artwork">artwork</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="illustrator"><b>illustrator</b></a>
</dt><dd>An artist who creates drawings, paintings, or designs to elucidate or embellish the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  The illustrator of a <a href="#childrensbook">children's</a> <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a> may receive higher honors than the <a href="#author">author</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, when <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> is added to the text of a <a href="#work">work</a>, <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a> is made under the <a href="#heading">heading</a> appropriate to the text, with an <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> for the illustrator if appropriate.  However, if the <a href="#work">work</a> is the result of a <a href="#collaborator">collaboration</a> between author and illustrator, main entry is under the person named first on the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a> unless greater prominence is given to the other by <a href="#typography">typography</a> or some other means.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#caldecott">Caldecott Medal</a> and <a href="#greenaway">Greenaway Medal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ilmp1"><b>ILMP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#ilmp"><b>I</b>nternational <b>L</b>iterary <b>M</b>arket <b>P</b>lace</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="im"><b>IM</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#instantmessaging"><b>i</b>nstant <b>m</b>essaging</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="imbrication"><b>imbrication</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#bookarts">book arts</a>, a decorative pattern designed to give the impression of overlapping scales, tiles, shingles, leaves, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="imitationbinding"><b>imitation binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A contemporary <a href="#binding">binding</a> executed in a style intended to closely resemble that of an earlier period.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="imitationleather"><b>imitation leather</b></a>
</dt><dd>A synthetic or partly synthetic <a href="#binding">binding</a> material manufactured to resemble <a href="#leather">leather</a>, for example, a fabric base given a textured coating, usually more washable than real <a href="#leather">leather</a>.  Synonymous with <em>artificial leather</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="imls1"><b>IMLS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#imls"><b>I</b>nstitute of <b>M</b>useum and <b>L</b>ibrary <b>S</b>ervices</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="impensis"><b><em>impensis</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for "at the expense of," a word appearing in an <a href="#imprint">imprint</a> or <a href="#colophon">colophon</a> at the end of a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> prior to the end of the 17th century, followed by the name of the person or entity responsible for financing the <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, or a <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> or <a href="#patron">patron</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="imperfect"><b>imperfect</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a <a href="#book">book</a> discovered upon examination to have <a href="#page">page</a>s or <a href="#section">section</a>s missing, duplicated, or <a href="#binding">bound</a> out of order or upside-down.  The <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> will usually exchange or perfect <a href="#copy">copies</a> containing binding errors, and reimburse the purchaser for <a href="#shipping">shipping</a> costs.  Compare with <a href="#imperfections">imperfections</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="imperfections"><b>imperfections</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#printing">Printed</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s rejected in the <a href="#binding">binding</a> process because they contain defects or errors that require replacement sheets. 
<p>
Also refers to <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> that contain printing or <a href="#binding">binding</a> defects, for example, the accidental omission or duplication of a <a href="#signature">signature</a> or <a href="#insert">insert</a>.  The <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> will usually exchange or perfect such copies and reimburse <a href="#shipping">shipping</a> costs when <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s or retail purchasers return them, but only for defective <a href="#makeup">make-up</a>, not the insertion of <a href="#errata">errata</a> slips (corrigenda).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#out">out</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="import"><b>import</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> produced and <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in one country and brought into another for sale in the same unaltered form.  The name of the importer may be <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> in addition to, or in place of, the original <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, or indicated on a <a href="#label">label</a> added to the title page after printing.  Compare with <a href="#copublishing">co-publishing</a>.
<p>
In computing, to read or receive <a href="#data">data</a> from a different <a href="#application">application</a> or computer system, which may require that it be <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> into a compatible <a href="#format">format</a>.  Popular applications are usually equipped to convert a variety of formats.  Compare with <a href="#export">export</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="impression"><b>impression</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> in the same <a href="#pressrun">press run</a> from the same setting of <a href="#type">type</a> or <a href="#plate">plate</a>s.  An <a href="#edition">edition</a> may comprise several impressions in which the <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a> remains unchanged.  Compare with <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#issue">issue</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the result of the transfer of wet <a href="#ink">ink</a> under pressure from <a href="#type">type</a> or <a href="#plate">plate</a>s to the surface of a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> or roll of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, as in printing, <a href="#engraving">engraving</a>, <a href="#etching">etching</a>, etc. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="imprimatur"><b><em>imprimatur</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A Latin <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> meaning "let it be printed."  The license for <a href="#publication">publication</a> granted by an ecclesiastical or secular authority, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>,
indicating the name of the licenser and the date on which it was
granted. Found most often in books printed during the 16th and 17th
centuries, <em>imprimatur</em> is still used in the doctrinal publications of the Roman Catholic Church to indicate official approval (<em>example</em>: <b><em>New Catholic Encyclopedia</em></b>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#cumprivilegio">cum privilegio</a></em> and <em><a href="#nihilobstat">nihil obstat</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="imprint"><b>imprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>The statement in a <a href="#book">book</a> that identifies the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> and/or <a href="#printer">printer</a>.  The <em>publisher's imprint</em> consists of the official name of the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> company and the <a href="#publicationdate">date</a> and <a href="#placeofpublication">place of publication</a>.  It usually appears at the <a href="#foot">foot</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, and more completely on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the title page.  The <em>printer's imprint</em>, indicating the name of the printing company and the place of <a href="#printing">printing</a>, usually appears on the verso of the title page, at the foot of the last <a href="#page">page</a> of <a href="#text">text</a>, or on the page following the text.  Synonymous with <em>biblio</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#colophon">colophon</a>, <a href="#distribimprint">distribution imprint</a>, and <a href="#jointimprint">joint imprint</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, the name of the publisher and/or the publisher's <a href="#device">device</a> stamped at the base of the <a href="#spine">spine</a>, or the name of the <a href="#binder">binder</a> stamped on the inside of the back <a href="#board">board</a> of the <a href="#cover">cover</a>, usually near the bottom.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="imprintdate"><b>imprint date</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inactiverecords"><b>inactive records</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#records">Records</a> no longer required by an <a href="#agency">agency</a> or individual in the daily conduct of business or affairs, which may be placed in <a href="#intermediatestorage">intermediate storage</a>, <a href="#transfer">transfer</a>red to <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#custody">custody</a>, <a href="#destruction">destroyed</a>, or <a href="#disposition">disposed</a> of in some other way without affecting normal operations.  The opposite of <a href="#activerecords">active records</a>.  Synonymous with <em>nonactive records</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#intermediaterecords">intermediate records</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="incipit"><b>incipit</b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for "here begins," a word used to indicate the point at which the <a href="#text">text</a> commences in a medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#incunabula">incunabulum</a> that lacks a <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, usually written or printed in <a href="#majuscule">majuscule</a>s or in a distinguishing color, often including the name of the <a href="#author">author</a> and the <a href="#title">title</a> of the work.  Compare with <a href="#explicit">explicit</a> and <a href="#colophon">colophon</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="incomplete"><b>incomplete</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#completeness">completeness</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="incunabula"><b>incunabula</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin word <em>cunae</em> meaning "cradle."  <a href="#book">Book</a>s, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, <a href="#calendar">calendar</a>s, and indulgences printed in Europe from <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a> prior to 1500 during the earliest years (infancy) of <a href="#printing">printing</a>.  A prime example is the <em><a href="#gutenbergbible">Gutenberg Bible</a></em> believed to have been printed in Mainz before 1456 , Germany by <a href="#gutenberg">Johann Gutenberg</a> who is credited with the invention of printing from movable metal type.  Singular: <em>incunabulum</em>.  Synonymous with <em>cradle books</em> and <em>incunables</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="incutnote"><b>in-cut note</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cutinnote">cut-in note</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="indent"><b>indent</b></a>
</dt><dd>To set back a line of <a href="#type">type</a> or column of figures by one or more <a href="#spacing">spaces</a> from a <a href="#margin">margin</a>, to mark or distinguish it from preceding and succeeding lines or columns, as at the beginning of a new paragraph.  <a href="#indention">Indention</a> is heavily used in <a href="#outline">outline</a>s and subject <a href="#thesaurus">thesauri</a> to indicate logical arrangement and <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic</a> <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchy</a>.  It is also used in typed and <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a>s to designate specific <a href="#area">area</a>s of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="indention"><b>indention</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#spacing">space</a> between the <a href="#margin">margin</a> on a <a href="#page">page</a> and the beginning of a line of <a href="#type">type</a>, as at the beginning of a paragraph of <a href="#text">text</a>.  The points listed in an <a href="#outline">outline</a> are usually indented to indicate the logical structure of the <a href="#content">content</a> covered.  Indention is also used in subject <a href="#thesaurus">thesauri</a> to indicate <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>s, and in typed and <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a>s to designate specific <a href="#area">area</a>s of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  Compare with <a href="#fullmeasure">full measure</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#hangingindention">hanging indention</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="independentpub"><b><em>Independent Publisher</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#tradejournal">trade publication</a>, formerly <a href="#title">title</a>d <b><em>Small Press</em></b>, that provides <a href="#article">article</a>s, announcements of <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s, <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>s, and over 100 <a href="#review">review</a>s of <a href="#smallpress">small press</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s in each <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>.  <b><em>Independent Publisher</em></b> is known for reviewing <a href="#work">work</a>s not reviewed elsewhere. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="index"><b>index</b></a>          
</dt><dd>An <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly arranged list of <a href="#heading">heading</a>s consisting of the <a href="#personalname">personal name</a>s, places, and <a href="#subject">subject</a>s treated in a written <a href="#work">work</a>, with <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s to refer the <a href="#reader">reader</a> to the point in the <a href="#text">text</a> at which <a href="#information">information</a> pertaining to the heading is found.  In single-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s of <a href="#refbook">reference</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>, any indexes appear at the end of the <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>.
In a multi-volume work, they are found at the end of the last volume.
In very large multi-volume reference works, the last volume may be
devoted entirely to indexes. Works of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> are rarely indexed.  The <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> may provide an index to each volume at the end of the last <a href="#issue">issue</a> of the <a href="#pubyear">publication year</a>.  For best results, <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> should be done by a professional <em>indexer</em>.  Alternate plural:  <em>indices</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#asi">American Society of Indexers</a>.
<p>
Also refers to an <a href="#openendindex">open-end</a> finding guide to the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of an academic <a href="#field">field</a> or <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> (<em>example</em>: <b><em>Philosopher's Index</em></b>), to works of a specific literary form (<b><em>Biography Index</em></b>) or <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a specific <a href="#format">format</a> (<b><em>Newspaper Abstracts</em></b>), or to the analyzed <a href="#contents">contents</a> of a serial <a href="#publication">publication</a> (<b><em>New York Times Index</em></b>).  Indexes of this kind are usually issued in <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> or <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>s, <a href="#cumulativeindex">cumulated</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly.  <a href="#citation">Citation</a>s are usually listed by <a href="#authorindex">author</a> and <a href="#subjectindex">subject</a> in separate sections, or in a single alphabetical sequence under a system of authorized headings collectively known as <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a>, developed over time by the indexing service.  <a href="#indexing">Indexing</a> can be either <a href="#precoordinate">pre-coordinate</a> or <a href="#postcoordinate">post-coordinate</a>.  Compare with <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a> and <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  
</p><p>
<b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#authorindex">author index</a>, <a href="#classifiedindex">classified index</a>, <a href="#crossindex">cross-index</a>, <a href="#geographicindex">geographic index</a>, <a href="#metaindex">meta-index</a>, <a href="#nameindex">name index</a>, <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>, <a href="#subjectindex">subject index</a>, and <a href="#titleindex">title index</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="indexablematter"><b>indexable matter</b></a>
</dt><dd>The parts of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> included when the <a href="#document">document</a> is analyzed for <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, not necessarily limited to the <a href="#text">text</a>.  <a href="#note">Note</a>s, <a href="#appendix">appendices</a>, and other complementary or supplementary material may or may not be <a href="#index">index</a>ed, depending on its usefulness to potential <a href="#reader">reader</a>s, and the policy of the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  <a href="#bibliography">Bibliographies</a> and <a href="#glossary">glossaries</a> are rarely indexed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="index expurg"><b><em>Index Expurgatorius</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#indexlibrorum">Index Librorum Prohibitorum</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="indexing"><b>indexing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of <a href="#compile">compiling</a> one or more <a href="#index">index</a>es for a single <a href="#publication">publication</a>, such as a <a href="#monograph">monograph</a> or multi-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>, or adding <a href="#entry">entries</a> for new <a href="#document">document</a>s to an <a href="#openendindex">open-end index</a> covering a particular publication <a href="#format">format</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s), works of a specific literary form (<a href="#biography">biography</a>, <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#review">review</a>s, etc.), or the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of an academic <a href="#field">field</a>, <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, or group of disciplines.  
<p>
The professionally trained <em>indexer</em> reads or scans the <a href="#text">text</a> of each document to determine its <a href="#content">content</a>, then selects appropriate <a href="#heading">heading</a>s (names, places, <a href="#subject">subject</a>s) to facilitate <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a>.  <a href="#crossref">Cross-reference</a>s are made from <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>s, and the <a href="#entry">entries</a> are <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> in the desired sequence (<a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>, numerical, <a href="#classified">classified</a>, etc.).  In an <a href="#openendindex">open-end index</a>, <a href="#content">content</a> <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s are usually selected from a list of <a href="#preferredterm">preferred term</a>s (<a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a>), developed over time by the indexing service.  Indexing can be <a href="#precoordinate">pre-coordinate</a> or <a href="#postcoordinate">post-coordinate</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#assignmentindexing">assignment indexing</a>, <a href="#automaticindexing">automatic indexing</a>, <a href="#derivativeindexing">derivative indexing</a>, <a href="#machineaided">machine-aided indexing</a>, and <a href="#indexablematter">indexable matter</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="indexinglang"><b>indexing language</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#artificiallang">artificial language</a> consisting of <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#content">content</a> <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s selected to facilitate <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a> by serving as <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#index">index</a>, including any <a href="#leadinvocabulary">lead-in vocabulary</a> and rules governing <a href="#formofentry">form of entry</a>, <a href="#syntax">syntax</a>, etc.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="indexlibrorum"><b><em>Index Librorum Prohibitorum</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An "Index of Forbidden <a href="#book">Book</a>s" prepared in 1558 at the request of Pope Paul IV by a special "Congregation of the Inquisition."  <a href="#publishing">Published</a> in 1559, the list included <a href="#work">work</a>s
which Catholic laypersons were prohibited from owning or reading
because ecclesiastical authorities considered them to be detrimental to
faith and morals, usually because they contained teachings condemned as
heretical. Also known as the <em>Index Expurgatorius</em>, the list was not abolished by the Vatican until 1966.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#imprimatur">imprimatur</a></em> and <em><a href="#nihilobstat">nihil obstat</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="indexmap"><b>index map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> showing the complete extent of the geographic coverage of a <a href="#set">set</a> or <a href="#series">series</a> of more detailed maps, with or without segmentation.  Compare with <a href="#mapindex">map index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="indiapaper"><b>India paper</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#biblepaper">bible paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="indicativeabstract"><b>indicative abstract</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abstract">abstract</a> that describes the type and form of the <a href="#work">work</a> abstracted, indicating the main <a href="#topic">topic</a>s covered and providing a brief description of the <a href="#treatment">treatment</a>, but which does not <a href="#summary">summarize</a> the <a href="#content">content</a> or evaluate quality.  Compare with <a href="#criticalabstract">critical abstract</a> and <a href="#infoabstract">informative abstract</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="indicator"><b>indicator</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of two single-<a href="#character">character</a> positions following the <a href="#tag">tag</a> at the beginning of a <a href="#field">field</a> in a <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>
(except fields 001 to 009) which can be used to specify certain
conditions for the field. The positions nearly always contain a digit
from 0-9, although <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>ic characters are permitted.  The first indicator may be field dependent, for example, in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> (field 300), it can be set to supply the <a href="#text">text</a> label <em>Descript</em> in the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>
display. The second indicator may specify the number of characters to
be ignored in filing or sorting the field, for example, 2 for "a," 3
for "an," or 4 for "the" at the beginning of a <a href="#title">title</a>.
In some fields, the first or second position is used; in others, both
or neither. When one of the positions is not used, the indicator is <em>undefined</em> and the position is left <a href="#blank">blank</a>.  In some fields, the absence of a character in one of the indicator positions has a specific meaning. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inedita"><b>inedita</b></a>
</dt><dd>The plural of the Latin word <em>ineditum</em> meaning "not made known," <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s not <a href="#publishing">published</a>, for example, the <a href="#personalpapers">personal papers</a> of a writer or well-known person.  <a href="#work">Work</a>s of this kind are usually available in the <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a> of the <a href="#library">library</a> that purchased them or received them as a <a href="#gift">gift</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inedited"><b>inedited</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> as submitted by the <a href="#author">author</a>, without editorial changes.  Such works may include passages objectionable to some <a href="#reader">reader</a>s or containing errors of fact, which an <a href="#editor">editor</a> might have altered or omitted.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#editing">editing</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to <a href="#unpublished">unpublished</a> works, especially the <a href="#memoirs">memoirs</a> or <a href="#correspondence">correspondence</a> of a writer who is deceased.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="informatics"><b>informatics</b></a>
</dt><dd>The formal study of <a href="#information">information</a>, including its structure, properties, uses, and functions in society, in particular the <a href="#infotech">technology</a> used to record, organize, store, <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a>, and disseminate it.  For a discussion of the history and current state of informatics, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> by A. E. Cawkell in the <b><em>International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science</em></b> (1997).  <a href="http://www-slis.lib.indiana.edu/CSI/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the Center for Social Informatics at the School of Library and Information Science, Indiana University.  Compare with <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="information"><b>information</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#data">Data</a> presented in readily comprehensible form, to which meaning has been attributed within a <a href="#context">context</a> for its use.  In a more dynamic sense, the message conveyed by the use of a <a href="#medium">medium</a> of communication or expression.  Whether a specific message is <em>informative</em> or not depends in part on the subjective perception of the person receiving it.  
<p>
More concretely, all the facts, conclusions, ideas, and creative <a href="#work">work</a>s
of the human intellect and imagination which have been communicated,
formally or informally, in any form. In his inaugural address of 1801,
Thomas Jefferson listed the "diffusion of information" as one of the
fundamental principles of the republican form of government established
under the Constitution of the United States. Compare with <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="infovalue"><b>informational value</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inforeferral"><b>information and referral (I&amp;R)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A service available at no charge, usually from a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> or other public service <a href="#agency">agency</a>, providing contact <a href="#information">information</a> about <em>other</em> organizations, agencies, and individuals qualified to offer specific information and services, both free and <a href="#feebased">fee-based</a>, usually within a local community. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="informationbroker"><b>information broker</b></a>
</dt><dd>A self-employed professional, skilled in <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a> and delivery, who markets his or her <a href="#research">research</a> services commercially, usually on a <a href="#freelance">freelance</a> basis.  Information brokers are organized in the <a href="#aiip">Association of Independent Information Professionals</a> (AIIP).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="informationdesk"><b>information desk</b></a>
</dt><dd>A desk in a large <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> or <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a>, usually located near the main entrance, <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ed by a nonprofessional trained to screen questions, provide basic <a href="#information">information</a> about <a href="#library">library</a> services and <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, and direct users to the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a> or some other public <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a>, when further assistance is  needed.  The presence of an information desk reduces the <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#directional">directional</a> <a href="#refquestion">question</a>s received by <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a>s, freeing them to focus on the needs of <a href="#patron">patron</a>s who require professional services.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="informationethics"><b>information ethics</b></a>
</dt><dd>The branch of ethics that focuses on the relationship between the creation, organization, dissemination, and use of <a href="#information">information</a>, and the ethical <a href="#standards">standards</a> and moral <a href="#codeofethics">code</a>s governing human conduct in society.  In the United States, the <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/ethics.html">ALA Code of Ethics</a></em> is the leading statement of ethical standards for the <a href="#library">library</a> profession.  Compare with <a href="#informationlaw">information law</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>, <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>, <a href="#intellectualproperty">intellectual property</a>, <a href="#plagiarism">plagiarism</a>, and <a href="#privacy">privacy</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="informationgap"><b>information gap</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#digitaldivide">digital divide</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="informationindustry"><b>information industry</b></a>
</dt><dd>A broad <a href="#term">term</a> covering all the companies and individuals in the business of providing <a href="#information">information</a> and <a href="#access">access</a> to information for a profit, including the mass <a href="#media">media</a>, commercial <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, <a href="#software">software</a> and <a href="#database">database</a> <a href="#producer">producer</a>s and <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s, <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s, and <a href="#freelance">freelance</a> <a href="#informationbroker">information broker</a>s.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a>, <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, and many types of <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>
function outside the information industry because they operate on a
nonprofit basis. Because the industry encompasses such a wide range of
commercial enterprises, it has no single <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="informationlaw"><b>information law</b></a>
</dt><dd>The regulation and control of <a href="#information">information</a> by the state, including laws concerning <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>, <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> and <a href="#intellectualproperty">intellectual property</a>, <a href="#forgery">forgery</a>, <a href="#freedom">freedom of information</a>, <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>, <a href="#privacy">privacy</a>, computer crime, and public funding of information providers, such as <a href="#library">libraries</a> and museums.  Also refers to a <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> branch of legal studies dealing with the regulation of information.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#informationethics">information ethics</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="infoliteracy"><b>information literacy</b></a>
</dt><dd>Skill in finding the <a href="#information">information</a> one needs, including an understanding of how <a href="#library">libraries</a> are organized, familiarity with the resources they provide (including information <a href="#format">format</a>s and automated <a href="#search">search</a> tools), and <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> of commonly used <a href="#research">research</a> techniques.  The concept also includes the skills required to critcally evaluate information <a href="#content">content</a>,
and an understanding of the technological infrastructure on which
information transmission is based, including its social, political, and
cultural <a href="#context">context</a> and impact.  <a href="http://www.csusm.edu/acrl/il/ilacrl/ilacrl.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#website">Web site</a> on information literacy maintained by the <a href="#acrl">Association of College and Research Libraries</a> (ACRL).  Compare with <a href="#computerliteracy">computer literacy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="infomanagement"><b>information management</b></a>
