</dt><dd>The skillful exercise of control over the acquisition, organization, storage, <a href="#security">security</a>, <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a>, and dissemination of the <a href="#information">information</a> resources essential to the successful operation of a business, <a href="#agency">agency</a>, organization, or institution, including <a href="#documentation">documentation</a>, <a href="#recordsmanagement">records management</a>, and technical <a href="#infrastructure">infrastructure</a>.  For a detailed discussion of information management as a <a href="#field">field</a>, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> by T. D. Wilson in the <b><em>International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science</em></b> (1997).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#aslib">Association for Information Management</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="infoneed"><b>information need</b></a>
</dt><dd>A gap in a person's <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> which, when experienced at the conscious level as a question, gives rise to a <a href="#search">search</a> for an answer.  If the need is urgent, the search may be pursued with diligence until the desire is fulfilled.  Persons with <a href="#information">information</a> needs often end up at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> where it is the responsibility of the <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a> to determine the precise nature of the need, usually by conducting an informal <a href="#refinterview">reference interview</a>, as a basis for recommending <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> sources.  In order to to search the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, the need must be expressed in the form of a <a href="#query">query</a>.  
<p>
It is the job of <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s to anticipate the information needs of a library's <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>, sometimes with the aid of <a href="#usersurvey">survey</a> <a href="#research">research</a>, in order to <a href="#selection">select</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> to meet those needs.  <a href="#patron">Patron</a>s with questions that cannot be answered using the resources of the library may be <a href="#inforeferral">referred</a> to other information providers in the local community, or elsewhere.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="infooverload"><b>information overload</b></a>
</dt><dd>A condition in which too much <a href="#information">information</a> is available on a <a href="#topic">topic</a>, a common occurrence in <a href="#online">online</a> searching, particularly when the <a href="#query">query</a> is expressed in <a href="#term">term</a>s
that are too broad. Systems that facilitate the retrieval of
high-quality resources, sifting out the chaff, are badly needed. In the
meantime, consumers of information must develop their own analytical
and critical skills. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="infopolicy"><b>information policy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A governing principle, plan, or course of action concerning <a href="#information">information</a> resources and <a href="#infotech">technology</a>,
adopted by a company, organization, institution, or government, for
example, the political decision to use public funds to subsidize <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#access">access</a> for schools and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.  In the United States, Congress and the President are advised by the <a href="#nclis">National Commission on Library and Information Science</a> (NCLIS) on decisions concerning national <a href="#library">library</a> and information policy.  For a detailed discussion of information policy, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> by Charles Oppenheim and Noreen MacMorrow in the <b><em>International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science</em></b> (1997).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inforetrieval"><b>information retrieval (IR)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process, methods, and procedures used to selectively recall recorded <a href="#information">information</a> from a <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#data">data</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#archives">archives</a>, <a href="#search">search</a>es are typically for a <a href="#knownitem">known item</a> or for information on a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a>, and the file is usually a human-readable <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#index">index</a>, or a computer-based <a href="#isar">information storage and retrieval</a> system, such as an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>.  In the design of such systems, a balance must be attained between speed, <a href="#accuracy">accuracy</a>, cost, and effectiveness.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="infoscience"><b>information science</b></a>
</dt><dd>The systematic study and analysis of the sources, development,
collection, organization, dissemination, evaluation, use, and
management of <a href="#information">information</a> in all its forms, including the channels (formal and informal) and <a href="#it">technology</a> used in its communication.  Compare with <a href="#informatics">informatics</a> and <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#informationtheory">information theory</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isa"><b><em>Information Science Abstracts (ISA)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a> established in 1966 that provides <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>s of <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#conference">conference</a> <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a>, and <a href="#article">article</a>s from over 450 <a href="#journal">journal</a>s and trade <a href="#publication">publication</a>s in <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>, <b><em>ISA</em></b> covers abstracting and indexing, <a href="#bibliometrics">bibliometrics</a>, <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, <a href="#classification">classification</a>, <a href="#electronicpub">electronic publishing</a>, <a href="#infomanagement">information management</a>, the information industry, <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>s, and <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>.  <a href="#publishing">Published</a> nine times per year in <a href="#print">print</a> by Information Today Inc., <b><em>ISA</em></b> provides <a href="#author">author</a> and <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#index">index</a>es in the last <a href="#issue">issue</a> of each <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a>.  The service is also available online from <a href="#dialog">DIALOG</a>.  <a href="http://www.infotoday.com/ISA/default.htm">Click here</a> to learn more about <b><em>ISA</em></b>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isar"><b>information storage and retrieval (ISAR)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Operations performed by the <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> and <a href="#software">software</a> used in <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> and <a href="#storage">storing</a> a <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s, whenever a user <a href="#query">queries</a> the system for <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> to a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a>.  For records to be <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a>, the <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a> must be expressed in <a href="#syntax">syntax</a> that is executable by the computer.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="infotech"><b>information technology (IT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A very broad term encompassing all aspects of the management and processing of <a href="#information">information</a> by computer, including the <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> and <a href="#software">software</a> required to <a href="#access">access</a> it.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="informationtheory"><b>information theory</b></a>
</dt><dd>The systematic statement of principles concerning the phenomenon of <a href="#information">information</a> and its transmission, based on the collection and analysis of quantitative and qualitative <a href="#data">data</a> as a means of testing hypotheses about its nature and properties.  Compare with <a href="#informatics">informatics</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="infoabstract"><b>informative abstract</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abstract">abstract</a> that <a href="#summary">summarizes</a> as much of the essential <a href="#content">content</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> as possible, within the limitations of a single paragraph.  Compare with <a href="#criticalabstract">critical abstract</a> and <a href="#indicativeabstract">indicative abstract</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="infrastructure"><b>infrastructure</b></a>
</dt><dd>A collective <a href="#term">term</a> borrowed from military
parlance, encompassing all the components that support a particular
activity, especially the permanent systems and structures that
constitute its foundation. In modern <a href="#infotech">information technology</a>, all the <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> and <a href="#software">software</a>
developed and maintained to keep a communication system (large or
small) operating smoothly. The state of a society's infrastructure
represents its commitment to investing in the future. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="infringement"><b>infringement</b></a>
</dt><dd>The use without <a href="#permission">permission</a> of material protected by <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> or <a href="#patent">patent</a>, in a manner reserved under law to the holder of <a href="#rights">rights</a> in the <a href="#work">work</a>.  Such use may be subject to legal action at the discretion of the copyright owner.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#allrights">all rights reserved</a> and <a href="#fairuse">fair use</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ingram"><b>Ingram</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#jobber">wholesaler</a> of <a href="#tradeedition">trade book</a>s, <a href="#bookontape">books-on-tape</a>, and <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s to <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, and specialty retailers, <b>Ingram</b> passes on economies of scale to its customers in the form of a substantial <a href="#discount">discount</a> off the <a href="#listprice">list price</a>.  <a href="http://www.ingrambookgroup.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Ingram</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inhabited"><b>inhabited initial</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a> in an <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> containing within its contours decorative figures of human, animal, or imaginary beings, not necessarily related to the <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a>, often depicted fancifully.  Compare with <a href="#figureinitial">figure initial</a> and <a href="#historiated">historiated initial</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#foliateinitial">foliate initial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inherentvice"><b>inherent vice</b></a>
</dt><dd>A weakness in the chemical or physical composition of a <a href="#document">document</a> or other object that causes it to <a href="#deterioration">deteriorate</a> from within over time, for example, <a href="#acidic">acid</a> in the <a href="#lignin">lignin</a> contained in <a href="#acidpaper">paper</a>s made from untreated wood <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>, or the chemical instability of cellulose <a href="#nitratefilm">nitrate film</a>.  If <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> measures fail, <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> may require <a href="#reformat">reformat</a>ting.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inhouse"><b>in-house</b></a>
</dt><dd>Refers to something accomplished on the premises, usually by <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a>, rather than outside the <a href="#library">library</a> by an independent contractor, for example, <a href="#binding">binding</a> done in the library, rather than sent to an offsite commercial <a href="#bindery">bindery</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#inhouseuse">in-house use</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inhousearchives"><b>in-house archives</b></a>
</dt><dd>The unit within a company, <a href="#agency">agency</a>, or institution responsible for retaining the <a href="#noncurrent">noncurrent</a> <a href="#records">records</a> of the parent organization, and sometimes those of other <a href="#corporatebody">corporate bodies</a> and individuals with which it is closely associated, as opposed to an outside <a href="#repository">repository</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inhouseuse"><b>in-house use</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#number">number</a> of times an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is used within the walls of a <a href="#library">library</a> during a given period of time (usually a month or year), as opposed to the number of times it is <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>.  In-house use is tracked by counting the number of times an item is left lying on a table, <a href="#carrel">carrel</a>, or <a href="#reshelvingcart">reshelving cart</a> in a public area of the library, to be <a href="#reshelving">reshelved</a> by a member of the <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a>.  Although this method is never completely accurate (some <a href="#patron">patron</a>s return <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> to the shelf after using them), statistics on in-house use can be helpful in <a href="#collecdevel">developing</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> and <a href="#refcollection">reference</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#circstats">circulation statistics</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#usage">usage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="initialarticle"><b>initial article</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#article">article</a> appearing in first-word position in a <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#corporatename">corporate name</a> (usually <em>a</em>, <em>an</em>, or <em>the</em>, or the equivalent in another <a href="#language">language</a>), ignored in <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>.  In the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>, the second <a href="#indicator">indicator</a> position following a <a href="#tag">tag</a> indicates how many <a href="#character">character</a>s are to be ignored when the title or name in the <a href="#field">field</a> is sorted or filed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="initialism"><b>initialism</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened form of a <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> or compound <a href="#term">term</a>, composed of the initial <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of its words or parts spoken <em>letter-by-letter</em>, rather than pronounced as a word (<em>example</em>:  <b>IPO</b> for <b>i</b>nitial <b>p</b>ublic <b>o</b>ffering or <b>ADA</b> for <b>A</b>mericans with <b>D</b>isabilities <b>A</b>ct).  Compare with <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> and <a href="#acronym">acronym</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="initialize"><b>initialize</b></a>
</dt><dd>To start a computer system, <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>, or <a href="#disk">disk</a> anew, an operation that usually requires erasing all or part of the <a href="#data">data</a> stored in <a href="#memory">memory</a>.  In Apple Macintosh computers, initializing a disk <a href="#format">format</a>s it.  In computer programming, a variable is <em>initialized</em> when it is given its first value. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="initialletter"><b>initial letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a> at the beginning of the first word of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or paragraph.  In medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, initial <a href="#letter">letter</a>s are often ornamented and <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a>.  In <a href="#incunabula">incunabula</a>, a <a href="#rubric">rubric</a>ator inserted them in spaces left <a href="#blank">blank</a> when the <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s were <a href="#printing">printed</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dropinitial">drop initial</a>, <a href="#facetedinitial">faceted initial</a>, <a href="#figureinitial">figure initial</a>, <a href="#foliateinitial">foliate initial</a>, <a href="#historiated">historiated intitial</a>, <a href="#inhabited">inhabited initial</a>, and <a href="#raisedcapital">raised capital</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ink"><b>ink</b></a>
</dt><dd>A colored liquid used for writing and in <a href="#printing">printing</a> to create an <a href="#impression">impression</a> on a flat surface, usually a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> or roll of <a href="#paper">paper</a>.
Up to the late 19th century, printing ink was traditionally made from
lampblack (pure carbon) mixed with a linseed oil base. To create
colors, lampblack was replaced with other substances, such as
vermillion to produce red. The quality of printing ink depended on the
quality of the oil base, which varied because prior to the mid-19th
century most <a href="#printer">printer</a>s made their own ink
according to recipes handed down from master to apprentice. Although
lampblack remains the basic ingredient of black printing ink, the
complex formulas used today are the product of chemical technology. The
<a href="#typography">typographer</a> must carefully match choice of ink to grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a> in planning a print job.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#permanentink">permanent ink</a> and <a href="#showthrough">show through</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inkball"><b>ink ball</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large round pad made of buckskin or sheepskin firmly stuffed
with a wad of cotton or wool and fastened to a short wooden handle,
used by the pressman in hand <a href="#printing">printing</a> to apply <a href="#ink">ink</a> to <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#typesetting">set</a> in wooden <a href="#forme">forme</a>s.  Most pressmen worked two-handed with an ink ball in each hand.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inlay"><b>inlay</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#picture">picture</a> or decorative element of contrasting color, set into the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually in <a href="#leather">leather</a> with or without <a href="#tooling">tooling</a>.  Also, an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> set into a <a href="#border">border</a> or frame of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, the overlapping edges shaved thin to make the resulting sheet uniform in thickness.  Compare with <a href="#onlay">onlay</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, the strip of heavy-weight paper between the inner edges of the <a href="#board">board</a>s, that adds stiffness to the <a href="#spine">spine</a> when the <a href="#case">case</a> is covered in <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>, <a href="#paper">paper</a>, or some other protective material.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#backstrip">backstrip</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inline"><b>inline</b></a>
</dt><dd>An elegant <a href="#displaytype">display</a> <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> in which each broad stroke has a white line down its center.  Compare with <a href="#outlineletter">outline letter</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="iii"><b>Innovative Interfaces Inc. (III)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1978 by Jerry Kline and Steve Silberstein, <b>Innovative Interfaces</b> has become one of the leading <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s of <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> <a href="#software">software</a> and automation support for <a href="#library">libraries</a> worldwide.  A significant number of library <a href="#consortium">consortia</a> in the United States prefer <b>III</b> software (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.ohiolink.edu/">OhioLINK</a>).  Also known as <em>Triple I</em>.  <a href="http://www.iii.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>III</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inpress"><b>in press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> in the process of being <a href="#printing">printed</a>, usually listed in <em><a href="#forthcomingbooks">Forthcoming Books</a></em> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inprint"><b>in print</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> currently available from the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, either as a <a href="#frontlist">frontlist</a> or <a href="#backlist">backlist</a> <a href="#title">title</a>, as opposed to a title no longer available.  Books currently in print in the United States are listed <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly in <em><a href="#bip">Books in Print</a></em>, <em><a href="#cbip">Children's Books in Print</a></em>, and <em><a href="#elhitextbooks">El-Hi Textbooks &amp; Serials in Print</a></em>.  The opposite of <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inprocess"><b>in process</b></a>
</dt><dd>Newly ordered <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> <a href="#shipping">shipped</a> by the vendor and received by the <a href="#library">library</a>, but not yet ready for <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> because <a href="#technical">technical processing</a> has not been completed.  In some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s, the <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> "in process" is added in the temporary <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> to indicate the <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> of a new <a href="#bibitem">item</a> that has arrived but is not ready to be <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>.  Most libraries will expedite processing at the request of a registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#arrears">arrears</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inprogress"><b>in progress</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used by <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s to indicate that a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> or <a href="#set">set</a> is incomplete, usually because <a href="#part">part</a>s or <a href="#volume">volume</a>s remain to be <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  Compare with <a href="#workinprogress">work in progress</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#checklist">checklist</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="input"><b>input</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#data">Data</a> transferred to or entered into a computer system for processing, as opposed to the <em>results</em> of processing, known as <a href="#output">output</a>.  The most commonly used <em>input devices</em> in personal computing are the <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> and <a href="#mouse">mouse</a>.  <a href="#scanner">Scanner</a>s are also becoming more widespread and significant advancements have recently been made in <a href="#voicerecognition">voice recognition</a> technology.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inputstandards"><b>input standards</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> has established the following set of <a href="#standards">standards</a> for entering bibliographic <a href="#data">data</a> into its <a href="#onlinecatalog">online</a> <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a>:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>SS</b> - <a href="#systemsupplied">System-supplied</a> - data generated by the <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> system which cannot be altered by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>.
</dd><dd><b>M</b> - <a href="#mandatory">Mandatory</a> - data the cataloger must enter to meet the designated standard for a specific <a href="#encodinglevel">encoding level</a>.
</dd><dd><b>R</b> - <a href="#requiredif">Required if applicable or readily available</a> - must be entered if appropriate under <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em> and available on the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> or from other <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s. 
</dd><dd><b>O</b> - <a href="#optional">Optional</a> - cataloger may decide whether to enter.
</dd><dd><b>C</b> - From copy only - data entered from <a href="#copycataloging">cataloging copy</a>, usually provided by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>, <a href="#nlm">National Library of Medicine</a>, etc.
</dd><dd><b>X</b> - Obsolete - not used (older records may contain data <a href="#element">element</a>s no longer used).</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inquires"><b>in quires</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#insheets">in sheets</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inscribed"><b>inscribed copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> that bears, as a presentation <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>, the name of the recipient and sometimes an appropriate comment or remark, followed by the <a href="#signature">signature</a> of the donor, who may be the <a href="#author">author</a>.  The inscription is usually written on the <a href="#flyleaf">flyleaf</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>insc</em>.  Compare with <a href="#presentationcopy">presentation copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inscription"><b>inscription</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief, informal <a href="#dedication">dedication</a> written inside a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually on the <a href="#flyleaf">flyleaf</a>.
Also, words engraved in stone or on some other hard surface, usually as
a greeting or to commemorate an important event or person (<em>example</em>:  the <a href="#rosetta">Rosetta Stone</a>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#inscribed">inscribed copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="insert"><b>insert</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any <a href="#printing">printed</a> material, such as <a href="#map">map</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> blank, advertising supplement, etc., slipped <a href="#loose">loose</a> (<a href="#unbound">unbound</a>) into a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, which is not an <a href="#integral">integral</a> part of the <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  Synonymous with <em>loose insert</em> and <em>throw-in</em>.
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, sentence, or paragraph added to the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#proof">proof</a> and included in the revised or final proof before the <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#gonetopress">goes to press</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inservice"><b>in-service training</b></a>
</dt><dd>Formal instruction provided by a company, <a href="#agency">agency</a>,
organization, or institution at its own expense to enable its employees
to become more proficient or qualified, especially in a new skill or
set of skills. The sessions may be designed in-house and conducted on
the premises by employees with the necessary expertise, presented by a
vendor's traveling representative, or conducted by an outside training
firm hired specifically for the purpose. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#profdevel">professional development</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inset"><b>inset</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a <a href="#section">section</a> of two or more <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> placed within another section in such a way that the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a>s of both are <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> in the same pass of the <a href="#thread">thread</a>.
The inset section can wrap around the outside of the main section
("outsert"), or be placed in its center or at some intermediate
location within it. Insetting is used to include <a href="#plate">plate</a>s without having to go through the time-consuming process of <a href="#tippedin">tipping them in</a>.  Also refers to a small <a href="#diagram">diagram</a>, <a href="#map">map</a>, or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> within the area of a larger illustration, usually enclosed in a <a href="#border">border</a> of <a href="#rule">rule</a>d lines.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#insetmap">inset map</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="insetmap"><b>inset map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#map">map</a> drawn or <a href="#printing">printed</a> within the <a href="#border">border</a>
of a larger map, usually showing in greater detail a specific feature
or portion of the larger one, for example, a major metropolitan area
within the borders of a map of a state or province. The same purpose
may be served by an <em>ancillary map</em> printed on the same <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> or <a href="#page">page</a> outside the borders of the main map.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="insheets"><b>in sheets</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> in flat or folded <a href="#unbound">unbound</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s, before the <a href="#section">section</a>s have been <a href="#gathering">gathered</a>.  Synonymous with <em>in quires</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inspectioncopy"><b>inspection copy</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#deskcopy">desk copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="installment"><b>installment</b></a>
</dt><dd>One portion of a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> divided into parts for <a href="#publication">publication</a> in consecutive <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, or one <a href="#part">part</a> or <a href="#fascicle">fascicle</a> of such a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#separatelypub">published separately</a>, usually at <a href="#regular">regular</a> intervals.  During the 19th century, <a href="#novel">novel</a>s were often published in this fashion.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#originalparts">original parts</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="installmentsale"><b>installment sale</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sale in which the purchaser pays for an item in two or more
payments, usually at regular intervals of a month or more. Under this
arrangement, the item is <a href="#shipping">shipped</a> when the order is received, without waiting for final payment.  In the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, this practice is usually limited to very expensive multi-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="instantbook"><b>instant book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> within weeks of an important event to capitalize on popular interest in the <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  Because careful <a href="#research">research</a> usually requires considerable time and effort, <a href="#work">work</a>s prepared in haste may contain errors of fact and lack depth of <a href="#treatment">treatment</a>.  An experienced <a href="#review">review</a>er will note such deficiencies.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="instantmessaging"><b>instant messaging (IM)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#realtime">real time</a> computer conferencing system that enables two or more persons to "<a href="#chat">chat</a>" <a href="#online">online</a> via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, <b>IM</b> allows the user to add the name of another person to a messaging list and be instantly notified whenever the person <a href="#logon">logs on</a>.  A chat session is initiated by typing a message in a designated <a href="#window">window</a> or "chat room" generated by the <b>IM</b> <a href="#software">software</a>.
The message is displayed almost instantaneously on the screen of each
person on the list, and the recipient(s) may respond quickly by typing
a message. Most <b>IM</b> systems are designed to emit an auditory
signal whenever a message is transmitted or received. Some systems
allow the user to exchange <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s, synchronize <a href="#www">Web</a> <a href="#webbrowser">browsing</a>, send images and video, and play computer games.  Instant messaging is used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> to deliver <a href="#electronicref">electronic reference</a> services to remote users and to persons who prefer to communicate online. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isi"><b>Institute for Scientific Information</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established by Eugene Garfield in 1958, <b>ISI</b> is a commercial company providing <a href="#citationindex">citation index</a>ing, <a href="#currentcontents">current contents</a> services, and <a href="#infomanagement">information management</a> tools in the sciences, social sciences, and arts and humanities.  <a href="http://www.isinet.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ISI</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="imls"><b>Institute of Museum and Library Services</b></a>
</dt><dd>An independent federal <a href="#grant">grant</a>-making <a href="#govtagency">agency</a> created under the Museum and Library Services Act of 1996 to foster leadership, innovation, and <a href="#lifelong">lifelong learning</a> by supporting museums, <a href="#archives">archives</a>, and <a href="#library">libraries</a> of all types, and encouraging partnerships among them.  <b>IMLS</b> administers four <a href="#grantinaid">grant-in-aid</a> programs for libraries, including <a href="#lsta">LSTA</a> grants to <a href="#statelibrary">state library</a> agencies.  <b>IMLS</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> <a href="#email">e-mail</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em><a href="http://www.imls.gov/">Primary Source</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.imls.gov/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>IMLS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="instock"><b>in stock</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#bibitem">item</a> for which a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>, or <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> has a sufficient number of <a href="#copy">copies</a> in <a href="#inventory">inventory</a> to fill an order at the time it is placed.  Compare with <a href="#outofstock">out of stock</a> and <a href="#tos"> temporarily out of stock</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="instructionlab"><b>instruction lab</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bi">library instruction</a> classroom equipped with computer <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>s (<a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a>s or <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>s) for the <a href="#handson">hands-on</a> use of students, usually with an instructor station connected to an <a href="#lcd">LCD</a> projector for the demonstration of <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#search">search</a> techniques. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="intaglio"><b>intaglio</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printing</a> technique used mainly for <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> purposes in which the areas to be printed are <a href="#engraving">engraved</a> or <a href="#etching">etched</a> below the surface level of a <a href="#plate">plate</a>.  The plate is <a href="#ink">ink</a>ed and then the surface is wiped clean, leaving a residue only in the engraved portions, which is transferred to a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> or other printing surface under pressure, usually on a rolling <a href="#printingpress">press</a>.  The only intaglio printing process still in commercial use is <a href="#photogravure">photogravure</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="integral"><b>integral</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> or <a href="#page">page</a> <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> or <a href="#binding">bound</a> into a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a> when the <a href="#publication">publication</a> was first <a href="#printing">printed</a>.  Compare with <a href="#insert">insert</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="integratedaccess"><b>integrated access</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a> system that allows users to <a href="#search">search</a> for <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s, and electronic resources such as computer <a href="#file">file</a>s and <a href="#website">Web site</a>s, in one operation using a single <a href="#interface">interface</a>, instead of searching <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, and <a href="#www">Web</a> <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>s separately.  Seamless <a href="#access">access</a> is a goal yet to be realized in most <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="intellectualfreedom"><b>intellectual freedom</b></a>
</dt><dd>The right under the <a href="#firstamendment">First Amendment</a>
to the U.S. Constitution of any person to read or express views that
may be unpopular or offensive to some people, within certain
limitations (<a href="#libel">libel</a>, slander, etc.).  Legal cases concerning free speech issues are heard by the U.S. Supreme Court.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>Office for Intellectual Freedom</b> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  Compare with <a href="#freedom">freedom of information</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#banned">banned book</a>, <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>, <a href="#challenge">challenge</a>, <a href="#filtering">filtering</a>, <em><a href="#ftrs">Freedom to Read Statement</a></em>, and <em><a href="#lbor">Library Bill of Rights</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ifrt"><b>Intellectual Freedom Round Table (IFRT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1973 as a permanent <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>IFRT</b> advocates freedom of <a href="#access">access</a> and expression in <a href="#library">libraries</a>, and provides support to <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and other library employees who become embroiled in controversies involving <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>.  <b>IFRT</b> also serves as a forum for the discussion of <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>
issues at the state and local levels, and monitors developments in
intellectual freedom that affect libraries, including legislation and
court decisions. <b>IFRT</b> is affiliated with the <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/">Office for Intellectual Freedom</a> of the ALA which <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <em><a href="#lbor">Library Bill of Rights</a></em>, the <em><a href="#ftrs">Freedom to Read Statement</a></em>, and <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/policies.html">other ALA policies</a> concerning the freedom to read.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/ifrt_inf.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>IFRT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ftrf">Freedom to Read Foundation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="intellectualproperty"><b>intellectual property</b></a>
</dt><dd>Tangible products of the human mind and intelligence, entitled to the legal status of personal property, especially <a href="#work">work</a>s protected by <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, inventions which have been <a href="#patent">patent</a>ed, and registered <a href="#trademark">trademark</a>s.  An idea is considered the intellectual property of its creator only after it has been <a href="#record">record</a>ed or made manifest in specific form.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#informationlaw">information law</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="interactive"><b>interactive</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#interface">interface</a> designed to respond to <a href="#input">input</a> from a human being, usually in the form of commands and/or <a href="#data">data</a>.  A back-and-forth <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> between a <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a> and its human user is an <em>interactive session</em>.
Highly interactive systems, such as computer games, are designed to
anticipate the user's needs, instead of responding in a prescribed way.
Once started, a program that is <em>not</em> interactive proceeds without further human input.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#expertsystem">expert system</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="interactivemap"><b>interactive map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, designed to allow the user to view a portion of its surface on another <a href="#scale">scale</a> or gain access to additional <a href="#information">information</a>, usually by selecting a <a href="#hotspot">hot spot</a> on its surface with a pointing <a href="#device">device</a> such as a <a href="#mouse">mouse</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.mapquest.com/">Mapquest</a></em>).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="interdisciplinary"><b>interdisciplinary</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#research">Research</a> or course work requiring the resources of more than one academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, for example, a <a href="#topic">topic</a> in <em>American studies</em>, a <a href="#field">field</a> that overlaps American history, politics, literature, art, music, popular culture, etc.  Although most <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s limit their <a href="#scope">scope</a> to a specific discipline (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Psychological Abstracts</em></b>) or field (<b><em>Child Development Abstracts &amp; Bibliography</em></b>), pertinent <a href="#literature">literature</a> from allied disciplines may also be included.  Also refers to a <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#work">work</a> on a <a href="#subject">subject</a> that overlaps two or more disciplines (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Encyclopedia of Violence, Peace, and Conflict</em></b>).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="interdiscipnumber"><b>interdisciplinary number</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, used for <a href="#work">work</a>s that cover a <a href="#subject">subject</a> from the point of view of two or more <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s, for example, <b>305.231</b> in <em>sociology</em>, reserved for <a href="#interdisciplinary">interdisciplinary</a> works on <em>child development</em>.  In the <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a>s, such works are identified by an <em>interdisciplinary works note</em>.  They are to be used only when the <a href="#author">author</a> devotes a significant amount of <a href="#content">content</a> to the discipline in which the number is found.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="interestprofile"><b>interest profile</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s selected from a <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a>, representing <a href="#topic">topic</a>s of interest to the user of a <a href="#currentawareness">current awareness service</a>.  As part of the service, regular <a href="#search">search</a>es are performed on the <a href="#term">term</a>s.  Based on the results, the user is notified of the existence of new <a href="#publication">publication</a>s as soon as they are <a href="#indexing">indexed</a>, and <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#information">information</a> is forwarded on the desired topic(s).  Synonymous with <em>user profile</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="interface"><b>interface</b></a>
</dt><dd>The point or process that joins two components of a <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a> system, for example, the screen display that functions as an intermediary between a <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> and its human users.  Some interfaces are more <a href="#userfriendly">user-friendly</a> than others.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a> and <a href="#usability">usability</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="interleaving"><b>interleaving</b></a>
</dt><dd>In fine <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, a protective <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#tissue">tissue</a> or <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> pasted or <a href="#insert">inserted</a> <a href="#loose">loose</a> between a <a href="#plate">plate</a> and a <a href="#page">page</a> of <a href="#text">text</a> to prevent rubbing.  Interleaving is sometimes done with <a href="#bufferedpaper">buffered paper</a> between <a href="#acidpaper">acid materials</a> to prevent <a href="#acidmigration">acid migration</a>.  Also refers to <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> that are sometimes <a href="#binding">bound</a> between the <a href="#printing">printed</a> pages of a <a href="#book">book</a> for use in note-taking.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="interlibrary"><b>interlibrary loan (ILL)</b></a>   
</dt><dd>When a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> needed by a registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> is <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>, unavailable for some other reason, or not owned by the <a href="#library">library</a>, a <a href="#patron">patron</a> may request that it be borrowed from another library by filling out a <a href="#printing">printed</a> interlibrary loan request form at a service desk, or electronically via the library's <a href="#website">Web site</a>.  Some libraries also accept ILL requests via <a href="#email">e-mail</a> or by telephone, usually under exceptional circumstances.  <a href="#libmaterials">Materials</a> borrowed on interlibrary loan may usually be <a href="#renew">renew</a>ed on or before the <a href="#duedate">due date</a>.  Interlibrary loan is a form of <a href="#resourcesharing">resource sharing</a> that depends on the maintenance of <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a>s.  The largest interlibrary loan <a href="#network">network</a> in the world is maintained by <a href="#oclcill">OCLC</a> which uses the <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em> <a href="#database">database</a> as its union catalog.  Compare with <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery service</a> and <a href="#intralibrary">intralibrary loan</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#ariel">Ariel</a></em>, <a href="#borrowinglibrary">borrowing library</a>, <a href="#lendinglibrary">lending library</a>, and <a href="#reciprocalagreement">reciprocal agreement</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="interlinear"><b>interlinear</b></a>
</dt><dd>Explanatory <a href="#note">note</a>s or <a href="#translation">translation</a> handwritten or <a href="#printing">printed</a> between the lines of a <a href="#text">text</a>, usually in small <a href="#lettering">lettering</a> or <a href="#type">type</a>.  Compare with <a href="#gloss">gloss</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="intermediary"><b>intermediary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person or <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> that functions <em>between</em> the <a href="#enduser">end-user</a> and an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibretrieval">bibliographic retrieval</a> system to assist in <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> selection, establish <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> connections, formulate useful <a href="#query">queries</a> in correct <a href="#syntax">syntax</a>, and evaluate the <a href="#relevance">relevance</a> of <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a>.  <a href="#mediated">Mediated search</a>ing is provided on request in most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> by a <a href="#publicservices">public services</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> specially trained in online <a href="#search">search</a>ing.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="intermediaterecords"><b>intermediate records</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#records">Records</a> used so infrequently by an <a href="#agency">agency</a> or individual in the conduct of business or affairs that normal operations are not hampered by their <a href="#transfer">transfer</a> to a storage area less <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> than the location where <a href="#activerecords">active records</a> are housed.  Synonymous with <em>semicurrent records</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#inactiverecords">inactive records</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="intermediatestorage"><b>intermediate storage</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, a separate area where <a href="#inactiverecords">inactive</a> or <a href="#intermediaterecords">intermediate records</a> are stored temporarily prior to final <a href="#disposition">disposition</a>, often less <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> than the location where <a href="#activerecords">active records</a> are housed.  Synonymous with <em>secondary storage</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="intern"><b>intern</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#internship">internship</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="internaldocument"><b>internal document</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#document">document</a>, such as a memorandum or <a href="#report">report</a>, intended for distribution <em>within</em> an organization, rather than for wider <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  Sensitive internal documents may be <a href="#classified">classified</a> to restrict <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#authorization">authorized</a> personnel.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="iatul"><b>International Association of Technological University Libraries (IATUL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in Germany in 1955, <b>IATUL</b> provides an international forum for the exchange of ideas pertinent to <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>
in technological universities, and the discussion of opportunities for
collaboration in the solution of common problems. Its member <a href="#library">libraries</a> are represented by their <a href="#librarydirector">director</a>s and senior managers.  <b>IATUL</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em><a href="http://www.iatul.org/newsletter/index.html">IATUL News</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.iatul.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>IATUL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="internationalcopyright"><b>international copyright</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#copyright">Copyright</a> protection extended to <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> outside a country's borders, currently governed by international copyright law and international agreements, most notably the <em><a href="#berne">Berne Convention</a></em> and the <em><a href="#universalcopyright">Universal Copyright Convention</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="icic"><b>International Copyright Information Centre</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#clearinghouse">clearinghouse</a> with headquarters in Paris, established by UNESCO in 1971 to offer assistance to <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s from developing countries in securing <a href="#rights">rights</a> to <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s protected by <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> in other countries.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ccc">Copyright Clearance Center</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ifcs"><b>International Federation of Classification Societies (IFCS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1985, <b>IFCS</b> is a federation of national, regional, and linguistically-based <a href="#classification">classification</a> <a href="#society">societies</a> devoted to promoting <a href="#research">research</a> in classification.  The <b>IFCS</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <em><a href="http://www.classification-society.org/newsletter.html">IFCS Newsletter</a></em> and supports the <em><a href="http://www.pitt.edu/%7Ecsna/joc.html">Journal of Classification</a></em> published by the <a href="#csna">Classification Society of North America</a>.  <a href="http://www.classification-society.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>IFCS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="fiaf"><b>International Federation of Film Archives (FIAF)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in Paris in 1938, <b>FIAF</b> has an international membership of the world's leading museums and <a href="#filmarchives">film archives</a>.  Its goals are to preserve the moving image in all its forms, facilitate <a href="#research">research</a> on the history of <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, encourage the collection of <a href="#document">document</a>s on cinema history and <a href="#film">film</a> <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, foster the <a href="#accessibility">accessibility</a> and exchange of films and cinema-related material, and help create new film <a href="#archives">archives</a> around the world.  <b>FIAF</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#biannual">biannual</a> <em><a href="http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/fiaf/english/jour.html">Journal of Film Preservation</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/fiaf/english/default.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>FIAF</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nfpb">National Film Preservation Board</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ifla"><b>International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions (IFLA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An independent international nongovernmental <a href="#association">association</a> of <a href="#libassociation">library association</a>s, libraries and related institutions, sponsors, and individuals, <b>IFLA</b>
was founded in 1927 by fifteen countries as the International Library
and Bibliographical Committee to promote global cooperation,
communication, and <a href="#research">research</a> in <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a> and <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>.  With association and institutional members in over 130 countries, <b>IFLA</b>
has a democratic structure in which a general assembly of members (the
Council), is the highest governing organ. The organization maintains a
Secretariat headed by a Secretary-General in The Hague and sponsors an
annual <a href="#conference">conference</a> in a different member country each year.  <a href="http://www.ifla.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>IFLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ilab"><b>International League of Antiquarian Booksellers (ILAB)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization encompassing twenty national <a href="#association">association</a>s representing <a href="#antiquarian">antiquarian bookseller</a>s in 30 countries, <b>ILAB</b> was founded in Amsterdam in 1947 to uphold and improve professional <a href="#standards">standards</a> in the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, promote honorable conduct in business, and contribute to a broader appreciation of the <a href="#bookarts">art</a> and <a href="#bookhistory">history of the book</a>.  <a href="http://www.ilab-lila.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ILAB</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ilmp"><b><em>International Literary Market Place (ILMP)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#directory">directory</a> of the international <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> industry <a href="#issue">issue</a>d <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, <b><em>ILMP</em></b> provides <a href="#information">information</a> on <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, <a href="#literaryagent">literary agent</a>s, book manufacturing, <a href="#bookclub">book club</a>s and <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>s, major <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#libassociation">library association</a>s, and literary <a href="#association">association</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, and <a href="#literaryaward">award</a>s for over 180 countries.  the directory also includes an industry <a href="#yellowpages">yellow pages</a>.  The most recent <a href="#edition">edition</a> of <b><em>ILMP</em></b> is usually shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most large <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="iso"><b>International Organization for Standardization (ISO)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A name derived from the Greek word <em>isos</em> meaning "equal."  Founded in London in 1947 with headquarters in Geneva, <b>ISO</b> is a nongovernmental federation of national <a href="#standardization">standardization</a> organizations in 130 countries, dedicated to establishing international <a href="#standards">standards</a> to facilitate commerce and cooperation in scientific, technical, and economic endeavors.  The United States is represented in <b>ISO</b> by the <a href="#ansi">American National Standards Institute</a> (ANSI).  <b>ISO</b>
operates through approximately 160 technical committees and 2,300
subcommittees which recommend standards and standardization policy to
its national members. <a href="http://www.iso.ch/iso/en/ISOOnline.frontpage">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ISO</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="irrt"><b>International Relations Round Table (IRRT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> created in 1949, <b>IRRT</b> develops the interests of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s in activities and problems related to international <a href="#library">library</a>
relations by providing hospitality to visitors to the United States
from the library community abroad and by facilitating communication
between the International Relations Committee of the ALA and individual
ALA members. <a href="http://www.ala.org/irrt/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>IRRT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isds"><b>International Serials Data System (ISDS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An intergovernmental network established under the auspices of UNESCO to develop and maintain an international <a href="#registry">registry</a> of <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s containing the <a href="#information">information</a> necessary for identification and <a href="#bibcontrol">bibliographic control</a>, including the <a href="#issn">International Standard Serial Number</a> (ISSN) and <a href="#keytitle">key title</a>.  The ISSN center for the United States is the <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/issn/">National Serials Data Program</a> (NSDP) administered by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  <a href="http://www.issn.org/">Click here </a> to connect to the International Centre for <b>ISDS</b>, located in Paris.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isbd"><b>International Standard Bibliographic Description (ISBD)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of <a href="#standards">standards</a> adopted in 1971 by the <a href="#ifla">International Federation of Library Associations</a> (IFLA), governing the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#libcollec">collected</a> by <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  The general standard ISBD(G) serves as a guide for describing <em>all</em> types of <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a>.  Standards have also been developed for specific <a href="#format">format</a>s:  ISBD(CM) for <a href="#cartographic">cartographic material</a>s, ISBD(PM) for <a href="#printing">printed</a> music, ISBD(S) for <a href="#serial">serial</a>s, etc.  ISBDs have been integrated into several <a href="#catalogcode">catalog code</a>s around the world, including <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isbn"><b>International Standard Book Number (ISBN)</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>I</b>nternational <b>S</b>tandard <b>B</b>ook <b>N</b>umber, a unique ten-digit <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s code assigned for purposes of identification to a specific <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>ic <a href="#work">work</a> prior to publication, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> and on the back of the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> of a book in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>, or at the foot of the back <a href="#cover">cover</a> in a <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> edition.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the ISBN is given in the <a href="#standardnumberandterms">standard number and terms of availability</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>.
<p>
The ISBN is divided into four parts separated by <a href="#spacing">space</a>s or <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a>s.  In the example <b>0-340-65267-5</b>, the first part (zero) identifies the national, <a href="#language">language</a>, geographic, or other area in which the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is published; the second part (<b>340</b>) identifies the publisher; the third part (<b>65267</b>) identifies the <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#volume">volume</a>, or edition of the <a href="#work">work</a>; and the last part is a <a href="#checkdigit">check digit</a> that allows any errors in the preceding sequence to be detected.  The <a href="#letter">letter</a> X may be used as a check digit, but in the other three parts, only the <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s 0-9 may be used.  In the United States, ISBNs are assigned by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.  ISBN prefixes for publishers are listed in the <b><em>Publishers' International ISBN Directory</em></b> available from Bowker.  Compare with <a href="#issn">ISSN</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#standardnumber">standard number</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="issn"><b>International Standard Serial Number (ISSN)</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>I</b>nternational <b>S</b>tandard <b>S</b>erial <b>N</b>umber, a unique eight-digit <a href="#standardnumber">standard number</a> assigned by the <a href="#isds">International Serials Data System</a> (ISDS) to identify a specific <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>0363-0277</b> for <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em>).  The ISSN is usually given in the <a href="#masthead">masthead</a> of each <a href="#issue">issue</a>.  When a serial undergoes a <a href="#changedtitle">title change</a>, a new ISSN is assigned.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the ISSN is given in the <a href="#standardnumberandterms">standard number and terms of availability</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>.  Compare with <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="internet"><b>Internet</b></a>
</dt><dd>The high-speed <a href="#opticalfiber">fiber-optic</a> <a href="#network">network</a> of networks that uses <a href="#tcpip">TCP/IP</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a>s to interconnect computer networks around the world, enabling users to communicate via <a href="#email">e-mail</a>, transfer <a href="#data">data</a> and <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s via <a href="#ftp">FTP</a>, find <a href="#information">information</a> on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>, and <a href="#access">access</a> remote computer systems such as <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and electronic <a href="#database">database</a>s easily and effortlessly, using an innovative technique called <a href="#packet">packet switching</a>.  The Internet began in 1969 as <a href="#arpanet">ARPAnet</a>, a project of the U.S. Department of Defense.  It now has hundreds of millions of regular users worldwide.  <a href="http://www.isoc.org/internet/history/brief.shtml">Click here</a> to read <em>A Brief History of the Internet</em> courtesy of the <a href="http://www.isoc.org/">Internet Society</a>.  Synonymous with <em>Net</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#backbone">backbone</a> and <a href="#domainname">domain name</a>.  
<p>
Broadly speaking, an "internet" is any group of interconnected, but logically independent networks.  Compare with <a href="#intranet">intranet</a> and <a href="#extranet">extranet</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="internetaddress"><b>Internet address</b></a>
</dt><dd>The unique code assigned to a specific computer connected to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> to identify it as a sender and/or receiver in the transmission of <a href="#data">data</a> or <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> files.  Two categories of addresses are used:  <a href="#email">e-mail</a> addresses of specific individuals (<em>example</em>:  <b>presleyelvis@aol.com</b>) and the <a href="#url">URL</a>s of <a href="#ftp">FTP</a> sites, <a href="#telnet">Telnet</a> sites, and <a href="#website">Web site</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b>www.aol.com</b>).  The form of Internet addresses is governed by the <a href="#domainnamesystem">Domain Name System</a> (DNS).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ipaddress">IP address</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="internetcafe"><b>Internet cafe</b></a>
</dt><dd>A retail business that sells coffee, snacks, and light meals, and provides computer equipment and <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#access">access</a> to customers while they dine, at no charge or for a reasonable <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  Some large <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> have installed such facilities on their premises to allow <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to read their <a href="#email">e-mail</a> without monopolizing equipment needed in other locations for <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#research">research</a>.  <a href="http://dir.yahoo.com/Business_and_Economy/Shopping_and_Services/Communication_and_Information_Management/Internet_and_World_Wide_Web/Internet_Cafes/By_Region/">Click here</a> to see the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> <a href="#index">index</a> of <a href="#link">link</a>s to Internet cafes by country and region.  Synonymous with <em>cybercafe</em> and <em>netcafe</em>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="internetexplorer"><b><em>Internet Explorer</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="internetresource"><b>Internet resource</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#document">document</a> (<a href="#webpage">Web page</a>, <a href="#ftp">FTP</a> file, <a href="#email">e-mail</a> message, etc.) that can be <a href="#download">download</a>ed from a <a href="#remoteaccess">remote</a> <a href="#server">server</a> over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  Rules for <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> Internet resources are available <a href="#online">online</a> from <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> in <em><a href="http://www.oclc.org/oclc/man/9256cat/toc.htm">Cataloging Internet Resources:  A Manual and Practical Guide</a></em> <a href="#editing">edited</a> by Nancy Olson.  Most writing <a href="#stylemanual">style manual</a>s have been <a href="#updated">updated</a> to include a section on <a href="#citation">citing</a> electronic sources (<a href="#electronicstyle">electronic style</a>).   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="internetservice"><b>Internet service provider (ISP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A company in the business of providing <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#access">access</a> to computer users who do not have a direct connection, usually via a <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> channel in exchange for payment of a modest monthly <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  The <b>ISP</b> with the largest number of <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s is <a href="#aol">America Online</a> (AOL).  Most <b>ISP</b>s also provide <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> <a href="#software">software</a> to facilitate use of the Internet.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dialaccess">dial-up access</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="internettv"><b>Internet TV</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#webtv">WebTV</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="internship"><b>internship</b></a>
</dt><dd>A limited period of supervised training in a <a href="#library">library</a> or other <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#agency">agency</a>,
intended to facilitate the application of theory to practice following
completion of formal course work toward a master's degree in <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>.  An <em>intern</em> may be paid and/or receive graduate credits based on the number of hours worked.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mls">M.L.S.</a> and <a href="#mlis">M.L.I.S.</a>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="interoperability"><b>interoperability</b></a>
</dt><dd>The capability of a computer <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> or <a href="#software">software</a> system to communicate and work effectively with another system in the exchange of <a href="#data">data</a>, usually a system of a different type, designed and produced by a different vendor.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="interpolation"><b>interpolation</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#information">Information</a> added to the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>, not explicitly stated in or on the item, for example, the number of <a href="#page">page</a>s in a <a href="#book">book</a> without <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s, or a <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> not given in the item but believed on the basis of investigation to be correct.  In the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, interpolations are made inside <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s (<em>examples</em>:  [32] p. and [1974?]). Compare with <a href="#extrapolation">extrapolation</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the insertion of a new <a href="#subject">subject</a> at any point in an existing <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#hospitality">hospitality</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="intralibrary"><b>intralibrary loan</b></a>
</dt><dd>The loan of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a> to another library within the same <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, or directly to a <a href="#patron">patron</a> of another library in the same system, on request, usually faster than <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> if the system has its own delivery service.  In some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s, the user may initiate this type of transaction without <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> assistance.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="intranet"><b>intranet</b></a>
</dt><dd>An in-house <a href="#website">Web site</a> designed to be
used only by the staff or employees of an organization, institution, or
commercial enterprise. Intranets use the same <a href="#tcpip">TCP/IP</a> and <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a>s as the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, but <a href="#access">access</a> by un<a href="#authorization">authorized</a> users is usually blocked by a <a href="#firewall">firewall</a>.  Also used in a more general sense to refer to any in-house <a href="#localarea">LAN</a> or <a href="#clientserver">client-server</a> system.  Compare with <a href="#extranet">extranet</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="intrinsicvalue"><b>intrinsic value</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="introduction"><b>introduction</b></a>
</dt><dd>The part of a <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#subject">subject</a> and purpose of the <a href="#work">work</a> are briefly stated, and the <a href="#reader">reader</a> prepared for the <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> of the subject that follows in the <a href="#text">text</a>, usually written by the <a href="#author">author</a> or by a recognized authority in the <a href="#field">field</a>.  The introduction normally appears in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>, following the <a href="#preface">preface</a> or <a href="#foreword">foreword</a>, but may sometimes take the form of the first <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>.  In either case, it is considered an integral part of the work and is not necessarily changed in subsequent <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, as is the preface.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>introd</em>.  Compare with <a href="#prologue">prologue</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a book written for persons unfamiliar with its <a href="#subject">subject</a>, to provide <a href="#information">information</a> at an elementary level, the <a href="#title">title</a> often beginning with the words <em>Introduction to...</em> or ending in the <a href="#subtitle">subtitle</a> <em>: An Introduction</em>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="introductoryoffer"><b>introductory offer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A promotional tool used by <a href="#bookclub">book club</a>s to attract new <a href="#subscription">subscriber</a>s by allowing the customer to select a certain number of <a href="#book">book</a>s at a very low price (sometimes at no charge), usually from a list of popular <a href="#title">title</a>s,
in exchange for a commitment to purchase a minimum number of additional
titles within a designated period of time, usually one year.
<p>
In <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, a similar promotional device in which a heavily <a href="#discount">discount</a>ed
price is offered to new subscribers, usually for a one- or two-year
subscription, after which the subscriber is billed at the normal rate. </p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="introprice"><b>introductory price</b></a>
</dt><dd>A lower price offered by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> prior to the announced <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, or for a limited period before <em>and</em> after publication, to encourage advance sales, after which the item is sold at <a href="#listprice">list price</a>.  The period during which an introductory price is offered may be extended if <a href="#advanceorder">advance order</a>s warrant, in contrast to a <a href="#prepubprice">prepublication price</a> that expires on a specific date designated by the publisher.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="introductorytitle"><b>introductory title</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#leadintitle">lead-in title</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inventory"><b>inventory</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of checking all the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s on a <a href="#library">library</a>'s shelves against a list of <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> to identify for <a href="#replacement">replacement</a> or <a href="#deselection">deselection</a> those <a href="#missing">missing</a> and not <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>.  A similar procedure is used to check other library property such as furniture and <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>
against an authority list to identify missing items. Also refers to the
list itself, which may include descriptions, quantities, prices paid,
etc. <p>
In the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, the total stock of materials available from a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, or <a href="#dealer">dealer</a> at a particular point in time.  In the United States, publishers strive to keep the size of a <a href="#printing">printing</a> as close as possible to estimated demand to avoid paying inventory tax, a practice that has caused <a href="#book">book</a>s to go <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a> more rapidly than they did before inventories were taxed.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#outofstock">out of stock</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="invertedheading"><b>inverted heading</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, a multiword <a href="#heading">heading</a> in which conventional word order is transposed to bring the most significant word into first-word position, for example, the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject heading</a> <b>Combustion, Spontaneous human</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="invertedtitle"><b>inverted title</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#title">title</a> divided by a bibliographer or
indexer into two parts and transposed to bring a significant word into
first-word position, for use as an <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> or as a <a href="#heading">heading</a> in an <a href="#index">index</a> (<em>example</em>: <b><em>Language and Linguistics, Dictionary of</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="invoice"><b>invoice</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#document">document</a> or form sent to a purchaser by a <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> indicating the order number, description, quantity, <a href="#price">price</a>, terms of sale, method of delivery, cost of <a href="#shipping">shipping</a>, and total amount owed for <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s shipped and/or services rendered.  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> require an invoice before payment can be authorized.  Compare with <a href="#purchaseorder">purchase order</a>.
<p>
Symbols and <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a>s commonly used on <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s invoices:
</p><p>
</p><dl><dt>
</dt><dd><a href="#backorder">BO</a> - back order
</dd><dd>CWO - cash required with order
</dd><dd><a href="#nep">NEP</a> or NE - new <a href="#edition">edition</a> pending
</dd><dd><a href="#nop">NOP</a> - not our <a href="#publication">publication</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#nr">NR</a> - nonreturnable (no <a href="#returns">returns</a> allowed)
</dd><dd><a href="#nyp">NYP</a> - not yet <a href="#publishing">published</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#oc">OC</a> - order <a href="#canceled">canceled</a> 
</dd><dd><a href="#outofprint">OP</a> - out of print
</dd><dd><a href="#opp">OPP</a> - out of print at present
</dd><dd><a href="#outofstock">OS</a> - out of stock
</dd><dd>OSC - out of stock, <a href="#canceled">canceled</a>
</dd><dd>OSI - out of stock indefinitely
</dd><dd><a href="#top">TOP</a> - temporarily out of print
</dd><dd><a href="#tos">TOS</a> - temporarily out of stock
</dd><dd><a href="#returns">XR</a> - nonreturnable
</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="inovicesymbol"><b>invoice symbol</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#invoice">invoice</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ipaddress"><b>IP address</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>IP</b> stands for <b>I</b>nternet <b>P</b>rotocol, the physical address of a <a href="#client">client</a> or <a href="#server">server</a> computer attached to a <a href="#network">network</a> governed by the <a href="#tcpip">TCP/IP</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a>, written as four sets of <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s separated by <a href="#dot">dot</a>s (<em>example</em>: <b>123.456.78.9</b>).
