Each IP address has an associated <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a> <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a> in the <a href="#domainnamesystem">Domain Name System</a> (DNS), which is easier to remember.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ipm"><b>IPM</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of "<b>i</b>ntegrated <b>p</b>est <b>m</b>anagement."  <b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#pestmanagement">pest management</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ips"><b>ips</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of "<b>i</b>nches <b>p</b>er <b>s</b>econd."  <b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#playingspeed">playing speed</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ir1"><b>IR</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#inforetrieval"><b>i</b>nformation <b>r</b>etrieval</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="irregular"><b>irregular</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#frequency">frequency</a> of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d at intervals of uneven length which do not follow an established rule.  The opposite of <a href="#regular">regular</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="irreversible"><b>irreversible</b></a>
</dt><dd>A change in the chemical or physical state of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, which cannot be undone, for example, an <a href="#embossed">embossed</a> or <a href="#perforating">perforated</a> <a href="#ownershipmark">ownership mark</a> or <a href="#worming">worming</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a>.  In <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>, <a href="#reversibility">reversibility</a> is a priority in the <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> for which the original <a href="#condition">condition</a> is of evidential or historical <a href="#archivalvalue">value</a>.

<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="irrt1"><b>IRRT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#irrt"><b>I</b>nternational <b>R</b>elations <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isa1"><b><em>ISA</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#isa"><b>I</b>nformation <b>S</b>cience <b>A</b>bstracts</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isar1"><b>ISAR</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#isar"><b>I</b>nformation <b>S</b>torage <b>a</b>nd <b>R</b>etrieval</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isbd1"><b>ISBD</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#isbd"><b>I</b>nternational <b>S</b>tandard <b>B</b>ibliographic <b>D</b>escription</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isbn1"><b>ISBN</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#isbn"><b>I</b>nternational <b>S</b>tandard <b>B</b>ook <b>N</b>umber</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isds1"><b>ISDS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#isds"><b>I</b>nternational <b>S</b>erials <b>D</b>ata <b>S</b>ystem</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isi1"><b>ISI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#isi"><b>I</b>nstitute for <b>S</b>cientific <b>I</b>nformation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="iso1"><b>ISO</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#iso"><b>I</b>nternational <b>O</b>rganization for <b>S</b>tandardization</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isogram"><b>isogram</b></a>
</dt><dd>A line on a <a href="#graph">graph</a> or <a href="#map">map</a> connecting points of equal or corresponding average value for a specific variable.  <em>Isorithms</em> show amount, for example, temperature (<em>isotherms</em>), barometric pressure (<em>isobars</em>), sunshine (<em>isohels</em>), etc.  <em>Isopleths</em> show frequency (hurricanes, marriages, power plants, etc.).  Synonymous with <em>isoline</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#choropleth">choropleth map</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isopleth"><b>isopleth</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#isogram">isogram</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isorithm"><b>isorithm</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#isogram">isogram</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="isp"><b>ISP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#internetservice"><b>I</b>nternet <b>s</b>ervice <b>p</b>rovider</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="issn1"><b>ISSN</b></a>           
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#issn"><b>I</b>nternational <b>S</b>tandard <b>S</b>erial <b>N</b>umber</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="issue"><b>issue</b></a>          
</dt><dd>To produce <a href="#book">book</a>s or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> materials for public sale or distribution.  
<p>
Also, all the <a href="#copy">copies</a> of an <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a book printed from the same <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> of <a href="#type">type</a> as the first <a href="#impression">impression</a>, which may include minor variations or revisions such as a new <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, an additional <a href="#appendix">appendix</a>, an updated <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, or a slightly different <a href="#format">format</a>.  Also used synonymously with <a href="#state">state</a> to refer to the priority of copies within a <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>.  Compare with <a href="#variant">variant</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#asissued">as issued</a> and <a href="#reissue">reissue</a>.  
</p><p>
Also refers to all the copies of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> on the same date, bearing the same <a href="#issuenumber">issue number</a>.  Purchase of a <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> entitles the subscriber to receive one copy of each successive issue for a prescribed period of time.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, all the issues for the same <a href="#pubyear">publication year</a> may be <a href="#binding">bound</a> in one or more physical <a href="#volume">volume</a>s, with the bibliographic <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a> stamped on the <a href="#spine">spine</a>(s), to create a <a href="#backfile">back file</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#backissue">back issue</a>, <a href="#conventionissue">convention issue</a>, <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>, <a href="#firstissue">first issue</a>, <a href="#sampleissue">sample issue</a>, and <a href="#specialissue">special issue</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="issuedate"><b>issue date</b></a>
</dt><dd>The specific date or period (spring, summer, fall, winter) by which a particular <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> is identified, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the front <a href="#cover">cover</a> and on each <a href="#page">page</a> as a <a href="#runningfoot">running foot</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b> <a href="#issuenumber">issue number</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="issuenumber"><b>issue number</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#number">number</a> assigned by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to a separately <a href="#issue">issue</a>d part of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>
to distinguish it from other parts published at different times. Issue
numbers are assigned consecutively, starting with the first issue of
each <a href="#pubyear">publication period</a>.  When a serial is <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#volume">volume</a>s, issue numbers recommence with each volume.  
<p>
When an <a href="#article">article</a> published in a numbered issue of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> is <a href="#cite">cite</a>d, the issue number is usually given in the <a href="#citation">citation</a> following a colon preceded by the <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a>.  In the following example, the article appeared on <a href="#page">page</a>s 116-123 in the <em>third</em> issue of volume 9 of the <a href="#journal">journal</a> <b><em>Research Strategies</em></b>, published in the summer of 1991:
</p><p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>:
<dl><dt></dt><dd>O'Hanlon, Nancy. "Begin at the End: A Model for Research Skills Instruction." <b><em>Research Strategies</em></b> 9:3 (Summer 1991), 116-123.</dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="it"><b>IT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#infotech"><b>i</b>nformation <b>t</b>echnology</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="italic"><b>italic</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#cursive">cursive</a> form of <a href="#type">type</a>, first used in an Italian <a href="#edition">edition</a> of Virgil, which slants heavily to the right, used in combination with <a href="#roman">roman</a> type for <em>emphasis</em> and to indicate foreign words or phrases in a <a href="#text">text</a>.  In the preceding sentence, the word "emphasis" is in italic, and in the following sentence, the <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#title">title</a> appears in <a href="#boldface">boldface</a> italic.  Warren Chappell states in <b><em>A Short History of the Printed Word</em></b> (1970) that italic is rooted in a variety of <a href="#humanistic">humanistic script</a> known as <em>cancellaresca</em> or "chancery" that reached its highest state of development in 16th century Italy when rounded <a href="#letterform">letterform</a>s were elongated to become elliptical.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>Ital.</em> or <em>It.</em>
<b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> and <a href="#recorditem">record item</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="item"><b>item</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> and <a href="#recorditem">record item</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="itemrecord"><b>item record</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a record attached to the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> to track a single <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a one-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#work">work</a>, or a single copy of one volume of a work <a href="#publishing">published</a> in more than one separately <a href="#binding">bound</a> volume, after the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> has been <a href="#acquisitions">acquired</a> and <a href="#technical">processed</a> by the <a href="#library">library</a>.  The item record usually indicates <a href="#itemtype">item type</a>, <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a>, <a href="#copynumber">copy number</a>, <a href="#barcode">barcode</a>, <a href="#locationsymbol">location</a>, <a href="#price">price</a>, <a href="#status">status</a>, applicable <a href="#loanrule">loan rule</a>, and <a href="#information">information</a> about borrowing transactions, such as <a href="#patronid">patron ID</a>, <a href="#duedate">due date</a>, year-to-date <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>, etc.  When item records are used in <a href="#serial">serial</a>s cataloging, each record usually represents a single serial <a href="#title">title</a>, and a separate <a href="#checkinrecord">check-in record</a> is created to track individual <a href="#issue">issue</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#orderrecord">order record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="itemtype"><b>item type</b></a>
</dt><dd>A code in the <a href="#itemrecord">item record</a> for a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> which, in conjunction with <a href="#patrontype">patron type</a>, determines the <a href="#loanrule">loan rule</a> applied when the item is <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> by a specific <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>.  Each <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> develops and maintains its own set of item types based on the nature of its collection(s).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="iterative"><b>iterative search</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#search">search</a> for <a href="#information">information</a> in which the <a href="#researcher">researcher</a> or investigator repeatedly poses questions until an answer or solution is found.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>

| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="JK">JK</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="jacket"><b>jacket</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> and <a href="#sleeve">sleeve</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jacketcover"><b>jacket cover</b></a>
</dt><dd>A removable covering made of thin, transparent, flexible plastic, designed to fit over the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>, to extend the life of the <a href="#binding">binding</a> and enhance the visual appeal of the jacket design, available from <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s in a range of sizes.  Used more extensively in <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#schoollibrary">school libraries</a> than in <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>,
it allows the outside surface of a book to be easily cleaned with a
damp rag or paper towel and disinfectant cleaning solution. The ends
should be securely fastened to the <a href="#cover">cover</a> with <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> tape of a type that can be removed without damage.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="japanesestyle"><b>Japanese style</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#chinesestyle">Chinese style</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jargon"><b>jargon</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a> and <a href="#idiom">idiom</a>s of a group of people engaged in the same activity or line of work, for example, the <a href="#marcese">MARCese</a> used by <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s in reference to the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> and its component <a href="#field">field</a>s.  In a more general sense, speech that is unintelligible or incoherent.  Compare with <a href="#slang">slang</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="java"><b><em>Java</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A high-level <a href="#proglang">programming language</a> widely used for writing <a href="#clientserver">client-server</a> <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#software">software</a> for the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>.  Introduced in 1995 by Sun Microsystems, <b><em>Java</em></b> enables <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s to run on a Java-enabled <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> regardless of <a href="#platform">platform</a> (<a href="#windows">Windows</a>, <a href="#macintosh">Macintosh</a>, or <a href="#unix">UNIX</a>), eliminating the need to write platform-specific versions of the same program.  <a href="#netscape">Netscape</a> developed the <b><em>JavaScript</em></b> language to make programming in <b><em>Java</em></b> easier, especially in the design of <a href="#interactive">interactive</a> <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s, but it is less powerful and limits the designer to the <a href="#html">HTML</a> <a href="#interface">interface</a>.  <a href="http://java.sun.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>Java</em></b> page at Sun Microsystems, or try <em><a href="http://www.javaworld.com/">JavaWorld</a></em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#applet">applet</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="javascript"><b><em>JavaScript</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#java">Java</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jeremiad"><b>jeremiad</b></a>
</dt><dd>A fierce denunciation of a particular evil, or the evils of
society in general, in which current misfortunes are considered a just
penalty for past misdeeds, and repentance extolled as the only road to
a happier, more secure future. The term is derived from the <em>Lamentations of Jeremiah</em>
in the Old Testament. The sermons of Puritan preachers in colonial New
England provide abundant examples of this literary form. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jestbook"><b>jestbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A collection of jokes, witty anecdotes, <a href="#epigram">epigram</a>s, <a href="#exemplum">exempla</a>, and ribald <a href="#tale">tale</a>s,
usually with didactic endings. Introduced into Europe from the Muslim
world during the 8th century, jestbooks enjoyed greatest popularity
during the 16th and 17th centuries. Because of their <a href="#ephemera">ephemeral</a> nature, few early examples survive.  Also spelled <em>jest book</em>.  Synonymous with <em>facetiae</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jewelledbinding"><b>jewelled binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the <a href="#board">board</a>s
are covered in designs done in gold or silver inset with ivory and
precious or semi-precious stones, usually with a similarly decorated <a href="#clasp">clasp</a> to keep the <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of the <a href="#body">body</a> pressed firmly together (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Heures Francoises et Latines pour Madame L. Gallois</em></b>).  During the medieval period, this style was used for devotional <a href="#book">book</a>s
commissioned by the Catholic Church and members of the nobility from
the 6th century onwards. The lavish use of costly materials was
considered an act of religious piety, rather than ostentation, and the
colors of the gems often had <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ic meaning.  Extremely valuable, the <a href="#rarity">rare</a> survivals are sold by the world's most prestigious <a href="#bookauction">auction</a> houses. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jobber"><b>jobber</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the United States, a wholesaler that stocks large quantities of <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s and <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> materials (<a href="#bookontape">audiobook</a>s, <a href="#videotape">videotape</a>s, music <a href="#compactdisc">CD</a>s, etc.) <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by various <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, and supplies them to <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s and <a href="#library">libraries</a> on order, usually at a substantial <a href="#discount">discount</a> (10-40%).  <a href="#title">Title</a>s <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>
from the publisher may still be available in limited quantity from a
book jobber. Large jobbers also offer customized services such as <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>s, <a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a>s, <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, <a href="#technical">technical processing</a>, etc.  Using a jobber allows a library to operate more efficiently by consolidating <a href="#book">book</a> ordering.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> on book wholesalers is available in the <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>.  Synonymous in the UK with <em>library supplier</em>.  Compare with <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#baker&amp;taylor">Baker &amp; Taylor</a> and <a href="#ingram">Ingram</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jobdescrip"><b>job description</b></a>
</dt><dd>A detailed description of the duties and responsibilities associated with a specific <a href="#position">position</a> in an organization, used in training, <a href="#performanceeval">performance evaluation</a>, and the allocation of <a href="#workload">workload</a>.  Compare with <a href="#positiondescrip">position description</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="joblot"><b>job lot</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#copy">Copies</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> offered by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> at lower than <a href="#listprice">list price</a> to a wholesale <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> known as a <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, usually to reduce or close out stock of a particular <a href="#title">title</a>.  Compare with <a href="#remainders">remainders</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="joint"><b>joint</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the narrow portion of covering material affixed directly to the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a> along the groove separating the <a href="#board">board</a> from the <a href="#inlay">inlay</a> over the <a href="#spine">spine</a>, forming the <a href="#hinge">hinge</a> that allows the <a href="#cover">cover</a> to open and close like a door.  A <a href="#book">book</a> has a <em>front joint</em> connecting the front board to the spine, and a <em>back joint</em> connecting the back board to the spine.  On the inside, the hinge is formed by the fold in the endpaper, reinforced in some <a href="#edition">edition</a>s with a <a href="#clothjoint">cloth strip</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jointauthor"><b>joint author</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, a person who collaborates with one or more others to produce a <a href="#work">work</a> in which all who contribute perform the same function.  The contributions of the individual <a href="#collaborator">collaborator</a>s may not be indicated and are usually not separable.  In <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a> is made under the name of the <a href="#author">author</a> listed first on the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a> (the <a href="#primaryauthor">primary author</a>), with <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a> for the other authors, unless the primary responsibility clearly rests with one author.  <a href="#bibliography">Bibliographic</a> <a href="#stylemanual">style manual</a>s differ in the maximum <a href="#number">number</a> of joint authors named in a <a href="#citation">citation</a>.  Synonymous with <em>coauthor</em>.  Compare with <a href="#compositework">composite work</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#shared">shared responsibility</a> and <em><a href="#etal">et al.</a></em>   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jointimprint"><b>joint imprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#imprint">imprint</a> of two or more <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, appearing on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of the same <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>.  In most instances, the <a href="#copublishing">co-publisher</a>s market and <a href="#distributor">distribute</a> the work in different countries or regions of the world.  For a recent example, see <b><em>The Great Libraries:  From Antiquity to the Renaissance</em></b>, <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 2000 by Oak Knoll Press and The British Library, assigned separate <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>s for the US and UK.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jointpseudonym"><b>joint pseudonym</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jointpub"><b>joint publication</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publication">Publication</a> (by prior agreement) of the same <a href="#work">work</a> by two different <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s in separate <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, often in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> by a <a href="#universitypress">university press</a> and in <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> by a <a href="#tradepublisher">trade publisher</a>.  Compare with <a href="#coedition">co-edition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#simultaneouspub">simultaneous publication</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jointuse"><b>joint use</b></a>
</dt><dd>A cooperative arrangement between a <a href="#library">library</a>
and another institution, such as a school, community college, or
university, in which both institutions share the same facility and/or <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s
for example, the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library in San Jose,
California, a partnership between the City of San Jose and San Jose
State University in which the San Jose Public Library and the
University library share the same building and collections.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="journal"><b>journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> devoted to disseminating original <a href="#research">research</a> and <a href="#commentary">commentary</a> on <a href="#currency">current</a> developments within a specific <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, subdiscipline, or <a href="#field">field</a> of study (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Journal of Clinical Epidemiology</em></b>), usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a>, <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a>, or <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>s sold by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>.  Journal <a href="#article">article</a>s are usually written by the person (or persons) who conducted the research.  Longer than most <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> articles, they almost always include a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> or list of <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#citation">cited</a> at the end.  In journals in the sciences and social sciences, an <a href="#abstract">abstract</a> usually precedes the <a href="#text">text</a> of the article, <a href="#summary">summarizing</a> its <a href="#content">content</a>.  Most scholarly journals are <a href="#peerreviewed">peer-reviewed</a>.  Scholars often use a <a href="#currentcontents">current contents</a> service to keep abreast of the journal <a href="#literature">literature</a> in their <a href="#field">field</a>s of interest and <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>.  
<p>
A <a href="#library">library</a> usually <a href="#binding">bind</a>s the all the issues for a given <a href="#pubyear">publication year</a> in one or more <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a>s, or converts its <a href="#print">print</a> issues to <a href="#microform">microform</a>.  Articles from some journals are available in <a href="#digital">digital</a> format in <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, usually by <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a>.  Some journal <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s also provide an electronic version accessible via the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>jour</em>.  Compare with <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> and <a href="#journalofcomment">journal of commentary</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#archivaljournal">archival journal</a>, <a href="#commercialjournal">commercial journal</a>, <a href="#corejournal">core journal</a>, <a href="#electronicjournal">electronic journal</a>, <a href="#hybridjournal">hybrid journal</a>, <a href="#libjournal">library journal</a>, <a href="#synoptic">synoptic journal</a>, <a href="#technicaljournal">technical journal</a>, and <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a>. 
</p><p>
Also refers to a <a href="#record">record</a> of events,
experiences, thoughts, and observations kept on a regular basis by an
individual for personal use. Writers often keep a daily journal to
record ideas and material that may subsequently be incorporated into
their <a href="#work">work</a>s.  Synonymous in this sense with <a href="#diary">diary</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="journalese"><b>journalese</b></a>
</dt><dd>The rather trite style of writing used by some <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> and <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> journalists, who rely on cliches and hackneyed expressions to pitch a story to the widest possible <a href="#audience">audience</a> ("rattlesnake roundup rattles rights groups"), avoided in serious <a href="#journalism">journalism</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="journalism"><b>journalism</b></a>
</dt><dd>The art of gathering news, writing and <a href="#editing">editing</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a>, or directing the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, or <a href="#journal">journal</a>.  A person who turns news into copy is a <em>journalist</em> (also refers to the person who keeps a journal or <a href="#diary">diary</a>).  A <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>er who <a href="#specialization">specializes</a> in capturing news on camera is a <em>photojournalist</em>.  In the United States, <a href="#pulitzer">Pulitzer Prize</a>s are awarded annually for distinguished public service in journalism, and for reporting in a variety of categories (<a href="#feature">feature</a> writing, <a href="#commentary">commentary</a>, <a href="#criticism">criticism</a>, <a href="#editorial">editorial</a> writing, <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>ing, and <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>y).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="journalist"><b>journalist</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#journalism">journalism</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="journalofcomment"><b>journal of commentary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> that <a href="#specialization">specializes</a> in the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of news analysis and discussion of political, social, and cultural issues, usually from an <a href="#editorial">editorial</a> position somewhere on the political spectrum, for example, the <b><em>National Review</em></b> on the right or <b><em>The Progressive</em></b> on the left.  Journals of <a href="#commentary">commentary</a> are usually <a href="#issue">issue</a>d <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> and sold at news stands, in <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s, and by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>.  Compare with <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> and <a href="#journal">journal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="journalpagination"><b>journal pagination</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s often begin with the first <a href="#page">page</a> of the first <a href="#issue">issue</a> in a <a href="#volume">volume</a>, and continue in a single numeric sequence through the last page of the last issue in the volume.  This means that the <a href="#pagination">pagination</a> in each issue (except the first) begins where the previous issue ended.  Since most journals are published <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> and <a href="#binding">bound</a> into <a href="#annual">annual</a> volumes, <a href="#continuouspagination">continuous pagination</a> makes it easier for the user to find a specific <a href="#article">article</a> by page number in the appropriate volume.  Compare with <a href="#magazinepagination">magazine pagination</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="journalsconsortium"><b>journals consortium</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization that handles the production and distribution of a number of <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, but does not necessarily exercise <a href="#editor">editor</a>ial
control over them if they are owned by other organizations. In the
United States, perhaps the best-known example is the journals <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> division of the <a href="http://www.press.jhu.edu/press/journals/">Johns Hopkins University Press</a> which provides <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#access">access</a> through <em><a href="#projectmuse">Project MUSE</a></em> to the <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> of its own journals, plus sixty <a href="#title">title</a>s from other scholarly <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jpeg"><b>JPEG</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> which stands for <b>J</b>oint <b>P</b>hotographic <b>E</b>xperts <b>G</b>roup, a <a href="#standards">standard</a> for compressing still images in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a> at ratios of 100:1 and higher.  <a href="#datacompression">Data compression</a> is accomplished by dividing the image into small blocks of <a href="#pixel">pixel</a>s, halved again and again until the desired ratio is reached.  <a href="#data">Data</a> is lost each time the compression ratio increases.  Pronounced "jay-peg."  Compare with <a href="#mpeg">MPEG</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#gif">GIF</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jstor"><b><em>JSTOR</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonprofit organization that began as a <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#text">text</a> initiative of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, <b><em>JSTOR</em></b> provides <a href="#search">search</a>able <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s containing the complete <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s of <a href="#corejournal">core</a> scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a>s in a wide range of <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s, <a href="#currency">current</a> to within 2-5 years.  <a href="http://www.jstor.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>JSTOR</em></b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#projectmuse">Project MUSE</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jukebox"><b>jukebox</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cdromchanger">CD-ROM changer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jumbofile"><b>jumbo file</b></a>
</dt><dd>A collection of <a href="#print">print</a>s, <a href="#picture">picture</a>s, and/or <a href="#document">document</a>s of unusually large size, organized for ease of <a href="#access">access</a> in a <a href="#folder">folder</a>, <a href="#portfolio">portfolio</a>, or other container of a size sufficient to accommodate them.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="jumppage"><b>jump page</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#page">page</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, or other <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> on which a story or <a href="#article">article</a> that begins on the first page (or near the front of the <a href="#issue">issue</a>) is continued, usually indicated by the references "Continued on page..." and "Continued from page..." at the break in the <a href="#text">text</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="junkmail"><b>junk mail</b></a>
</dt><dd>Unwanted <a href="#email">e-mail</a> messages, usually advertising not solicited by the recipient.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#spam">spam</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="justification"><b>justification</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a>, the equal and exact <a href="#spacing">spacing</a> of words and <a href="#letter">letter</a>s in a line of <a href="#type">type</a> to make the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> appear even vertically at the right- and/or left-hand <a href="#margin">margin</a>s.  Type aligned with the left margin is said to be <em>left-justified</em>.  Aligned with the right-hand margin, it is said to be <em>right-justified</em>.  Type can also be <em>centered</em> on a <a href="#page">page</a>, as in <a href="#heading">heading</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#alignment">alignment</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ragged">ragged</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="justified"><b>justified</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#justification">justification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="juvenile"><b>juvenile collection</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#childrensbook">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> intended specifically for children under 12-13 years of age, shelved separately from the <a href="#adult">adult</a> and <a href="#youngadult">young adult</a> collections, sometimes in a <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a> with separate sections for juvenile <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>, <a href="#beginningreader">beginning reader</a>s and <a href="#easybook">easy book</a>s, <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>s, and books for very young children (<a href="#alphabetbook">alphabet book</a>s, <a href="#countingbook">counting book</a>s, <a href="#boardbook">board book</a>s, <a href="#clothbook">cloth book</a>s, etc.).  Juvenile collections are usually managed by a <a href="#childrenslibrarian">librarian</a> with <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> training in <a href="#childrensservices">children's services</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#alsc">Association for Library Services to Children</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="juvenilia"><b>juvenilia</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#work">Work</a>s produced during the childhood or
youth of an artist or writer, which may reveal literary or artistic
immaturity, but often compensate with an abundance of youthful
enthusiasm and a style or approach that is highly innovative. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kanji"><b>kanji</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#subset">subset</a> of approximately 5,000 Chinese <a href="#ideogram">ideogram</a>s borrowed or adapted by the Japanese for use in their own written <a href="#language">language</a>.  In 1946, the Japanese government selected a smaller subset of 1,850 for use in official <a href="#publication">publication</a>s and in <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>/<a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>.  Also refers to any one of these <a href="#loancharacter">loan character</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="keepdown"><b>keep down</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a>, an instruction to the typesetter to use <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a>s sparingly in the <a href="#title">title</a>s of <a href="#work">work</a>s mentioned in the <a href="#text">text</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#keepup">keep up</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="keepsake"><b>keepsake</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#giftbook">giftbook</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="keepup"><b>keep up</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a>, an instruction to the typesetter to use <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a>s at the beginning of each word of the <a href="#title">title</a> of any <a href="#work">work</a> mentioned in the <a href="#text">text</a>.  Prepositions, conjunctions, and initial <a href="#article">article</a>s are usually <em>kept down</em>, making "The Adventures of the Huckleberry Finn" an <em>all up</em>
setting. In modern British practice, only the first word and proper
names are capitalized ("The adventures of Huckleberry Finn"). In
French, only the first word following the initial article and proper
names are capitalized. In Italian, only the initial article is
capitalized. In German, all nouns are capitalized. The opposite of <a href="#keepdown">keep down</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kelmscott"><b>Kelmscott Press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#privatepress">private press</a> founded in 1891 by the architect, designer, writer, <a href="#calligraphy">calligrapher</a>, and <a href="#typography">typographer</a> William Morris (1834-1896) who sought to revive, in modern <a href="#book">book</a> production, the aesthetic of the medieval period and early <a href="#printing">printing</a>.  Although the <a href="#press">press</a> survived only until 1894, the 53 books it <a href="#issue">issue</a>d set a very high <a href="#standard">standard</a> of beauty and craftsmanship.  For more <a href="#information">information</a> about the Kelmscott Press, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> in <b><em>A Dictionary of Book History</em></b> (1986) by John Feather.  For images of <a href="#work">work</a>s produced by the Press, see the <a href="#exhibitcatalog">exhibit catalog</a> <b><em>William Morris and the Art of the Book</em></b> (1976) <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the <a href="#pierpont">Pierpont Morgan Library</a>, or <a href="http://special.lib.gla.ac.uk/teach/privatepress/kelmscott.html">click here</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kerf"><b>kerf</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shallow groove cut into the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a>, perpendicular to the <a href="#spine">spine</a> near the <a href="#head">head</a> and <a href="#tail">tail</a> of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a>, to allow the <a href="#kettle">kettle stitch</a>ing to be recessed.  Also spelled <em>cerf</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kermit"><b>Kermit</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#asynchronous">asynchronous</a> communication <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> developed and maintained by the Kermit Project at Columbia University, which enables <a href="#file">file</a>s to be transferred from one computer system to another.  Accurate, flexible, and customizable, Kermit includes <a href="#emulation">terminal emulation</a> and can be installed on almost any <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>.  Although it is not in the <a href="#publicdomain">public domain</a>, Columbia University allows Kermit to be used as <a href="#shareware">shareware</a>, but encourages users to purchase the product in support of the Project.  <a href="http://www.columbia.edu/kermit/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of The Kermit Project at Columbia.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kern"><b>kern</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portion of the <a href="#face">face</a> of a unit of <a href="#type">type</a> that extends beyond the edge of its body to overlap an adjacent <a href="#character">character</a> (<em>example</em>: the <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#italic">italic</a> <em>f</em> in many <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>s).  <em>Kerning</em> is also refers to the practice in <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a> of backspacing to tuck one character into another to avoid the appearance of irregular <a href="#spacing">spacing</a> in a line.  Pairs of <a href="#letter">letter</a>s close-fitted in this way include AT, AV, Ta, Wa, etc.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used in typesetting for the practice of reducing the space between characters to make <a href="#copy">copy</a> fit a given line length.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kettle"><b>kettle stitch</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a>, a special end stitch taken near the <a href="#head">head</a> and <a href="#foot">foot</a> of each <a href="#section">section</a> to lock the <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> <a href="#thread">thread</a> after it passes down the <a href="#backfold">fold</a>, linking adjacent sections through their folds and producing two rows of kettle stitches perpendicular to the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a>, one near the top and the other at the bottom of the <a href="#spine">spine</a>.  In some <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, a shallow groove called a <a href="#kerf">kerf</a> is cut into the binding edge at each end of the spine to recess the kettle stitching.  Synonymous with <em>catch stitch</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="keyboard"><b>keyboard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thin flat <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> device that allows a computer user to enter <a href="#input">input</a> by manually depressing keys marked with <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s, and special <a href="#character">character</a>s.
The keys can be arranged in a single set of parallel rows, or split
into two sets of rows (fixed or adjustable) to make them more <a href="#ergonomics">ergonomic</a>.  A computer keyboard can be built-in, as in a <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>, or a separate piece of equipment, as in most desktop <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="keycontrol"><b>key control</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of establishing and maintaining the list of persons authorized to access keys to the door locks and lockable <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a>, as a means of <a href="#security">securing</a>
the facility's locking system. A full survey of all locks and lock
locations must first be conducted and an inventory made of all existing
keys. Then key distribution is carefully <a href="#record">record</a>ed,
including keys retrieved from employees who leave library employment.
Access to master keys is limited to essential personnel, using a
two-key system in areas where security is especially important (<a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s, <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>,
computer equipment rooms, etc.). When not in use, keys are stored in a
secure cabinet, with a log for recording name of borrower, date of
issue, and date of return. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="keypad"><b>keypad</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small hand-held infrared device used in large-screen demonstrations of <a href="#online">online</a>
systems to enable the instructor to control electronic equipment
installed on the demonstration console. Also, the part of a full-size
computer <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> consisting of a set of programmable numeric keys, usually arranged in four rows on the far right-hand side.

<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#security">security</a> device consisting of a small set of numeric keys, usually mounted on a wall near a door, to allow the automatic <a href="#securitysystem">alarm</a> system to be deactivated and reactivated by a person typing a valid <a href="#authorization">authorization</a> code.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="keytitle"><b>key title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The unique name assigned to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, linked to the <a href="#issn">International Standard Serial Number</a> (ISSN) under the <a href="#isds">International Serials Data System</a> (ISDS), usually (but not always) the same as the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the key title is given immediately following the ISSN in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>.  If there is no ISSN, the key title is not added.  Also spelled <em>key-title</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="keywordindex"><b>keyword index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#index">index</a> in which significant words, usually from the <a href="#title">title</a>s of the <a href="#work">work</a>s indexed, are used as <a href="#heading">heading</a>s.  When a string of keywords is rotated, such an index is said to be <a href="#permutedindex">permuted</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#kwac">KWAC</a>, <a href="#kwic">KWIC</a>, and <a href="#kwoc">KWOC</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="keywords"><b>keyword(s)</b></a>     
</dt><dd>A significant word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> in the <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s (<a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s), <a href="#contentsnote">contents note</a>, <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>, or <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> in an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> which can be used as a <a href="#searchterm">search term</a> in a <a href="#freetextsearch">free-text search</a> to <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> all the records containing it.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#stopword">stopword</a>.
<p>
Most online catalogs and bibliographic databases include an <a href="#option">option</a> that allows the user to type words that describe the <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#topic">topic</a> (in any order) and retrieve records containing the search <a href="#term">term</a>s in the <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#field">field</a>s the system is designed to <a href="#search">search</a> whenever the keywords option is selected.  One disadvantage of a keywords search is that it does not take into account the <em>meaning</em> of the words used as <a href="#input">input</a>, so if a term has more than one meaning, <a href="#relevance">irrelevant</a> records (<a href="#falsedrop">false drop</a>s) may be retrieved.  Keywords are also used as <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s in <a href="#kwac">KWAC</a>, <a href="#kwic">KWIC</a>, and <a href="#kwoc">KWOC</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>.  <em><b>See also</b></em>:  <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> and <a href="#truncation">truncation</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kilobyte"><b>kilobyte</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#byte">byte</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kinescope"><b>kinescope</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> made by <a href="#film">film</a>ing the images displayed on a television <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kiosk"><b>kiosk</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small circular pavilion, usually located near the entrance to a <a href="#library">library</a>, used for displaying announcements, <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>s removed from <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s, <a href="#readinglist">reading list</a>s, comments and suggestions from library users (sometimes with responses from <a href="#libadmin">library administration</a>), and other <a href="#information">information</a> concerning library operations and programs.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bulletinboard">bulletin board</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a free-standing furnishing equipped with a multimedia computer to allow users to <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> <a href="#information">information</a> "on the run" via a <a href="#touchscreen">touch screen</a>, used in airports and other public locations to provide directions, scheduling information, etc.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kit"><b>kit</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of related instructional materials in more than one <a href="#medium">medium</a>, designed to be used as a unit with no single medium predominating, usually in the classroom or in a <a href="#schoollibrary">school library</a>.  Kits are often stored in a <a href="#container">container</a> to keep the parts together.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, they are usually shelved in the <a href="#curriculumroom">curriculum room</a>.  Synonymous with <em>multimedia item</em>.
<p>
In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, this category also includes <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s consisting of a single-medium package of <a href="#text">text</a>ual material, such as a set of activity cards.  Compare with <a href="#game">game</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="knowledge"><b>knowledge</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#information">Information</a> that has been
comprehended and evaluated in the light of experience, and incorporated
into the knower's intellectual understanding of its <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#epistemology">epistemology</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="knownitem"><b>known-item search</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#search">search</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> for a specific <a href="#work">work</a>, as opposed to a search for <em>any</em> work by a known <a href="#author">author</a> or for works on a particular <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  If the <a href="#title">title</a> of the work is known, the easiest way to locate a <a href="#copy">copy</a> is to search a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> by title.  When the user is uncertain of the precise wording of the title, the best strategy may be to search by <a href="#author">author</a>'s name.  If at least 2-3 significant words in the title are known with certainty, a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> search may retrieve an <a href="#entry">entry</a> for the work.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kochel"><b>Kochel number</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#opusnumber">opus number</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kraftpaper"><b>kraft paper</b></a>
</dt><dd>A heavy, unbleached grade of coarse <a href="#paper">paper</a>, usually mocha brown in color, used for paper bags and wrapping paper.  In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, kraft paper is used for the outer <a href="#wrapper">wrapper</a> on <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s to protect the <a href="#glossy">glossy</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> from damage in mailing.  In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, a narrow strip of kraft paper may be used as a second <a href="#lining">lining</a> to reinforce the layer of thin fabric called <a href="#crash">crash</a> (or <em>super</em>) affixed to the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s as the first lining to hold them firmly together.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kunstlerroman"><b>Kunstlerroman</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the German word <em>Kunstler</em> ("artist") and the French word <em>roman</em> ("novel"), a <a href="#novel">novel</a>
that traces the growth of a writer's creative genius from childhood to
maturity, with particular attention to major trials and obstacles, and
their influence on the development of the artist's character and <a href="#work">work</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man</em></b> by James Joyce).  Compare with <a href="#bildungsroman">Bildungsroman</a>.        
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kwac"><b>KWAC</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <em><b>K</b>ey<b>w</b>ord <b>a</b>nd <b>C</b>ontext</em> (also known as <em><b>K</b>eyword <b>a</b>longside <b>C</b>ontext</em>), an <a href="#algorithm">algorithm</a>ically generated <a href="#index">index</a> in which <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> from the <a href="#title">title</a> (and sometimes the <a href="#text">text</a>) of a <a href="#document">document</a> are <a href="#printing">printed</a> as <a href="#heading">heading</a>s along the left-hand <a href="#margin">margin</a> of the <a href="#page">page</a>, with the portion of the title or text following each keyword <a href="#indention">indented</a> under the heading, followed by the portion of the title or text preceding the word.  Unlike <a href="#kwoc">KWOC</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, this method preserves multiword <a href="#term">term</a>s and <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s in the <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a> sequence of headings.  Compare with <a href="#kwic">KWIC</a>. 
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>:
<dl><dt></dt><dd>academic
<dl><dt></dt><dd>support systems for distance learning. Libraries and</dd></dl>
</dd><dd>distance
<dl><dt></dt><dd>learning. Libraries and academic support systems for</dd></dl>
</dd><dd>learning
<dl><dt></dt><dd>Libraries and academic support systems for distance</dd></dl>
</dd><dd>libraries
<dl><dt></dt><dd>and academic support systems for distance learning</dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="kwic"><b>KWIC</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <em><b>K</b>ey<b>w</b>ord <b>i</b>n <b>C</b>ontext</em>, a type of <a href="#permutedindex">permuted index</a> in which the <a href="#title">title</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a> (and sometimes the <a href="#text">text</a>) is used to illustrate the meaning of a <a href="#keywords">keyword</a> used as an <a href="#entry">entry</a>.  Tagged by hand or extracted from the document <a href="#algorithm">algorithm</a>ically, keywords are <a href="#printing">printed</a> in <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>
order at a fixed position in a line of fixed length (usually at the
center), so that they appear in a column, with as much of the <a href="#context">context</a> as can be accommodated preceding and following each word.  The keywords in the column may be distinguished <a href="#typography">typographically</a> to make them easier to read.  Keyword and context are usually coded to identify the document <a href="#indexing">indexed</a>.  Compare with <a href="#kwac">KWAC</a> and <a href="#kwoc">KWOC</a>.
<p>
<em>Example</em>:
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><table>
<tbody><tr align="left"><td width="125">Libraries and </td><td width="475"> <b>ACADEMIC</b> support systems for distance learning.</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="125">ort systems for </td><td width="475"> <b>DISTANCE</b> learning. Libraries and academic supp</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="125">ems for distance </td><td width="475"><b>LEARNING</b>. Libraries and academic support syst</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="125">stance learning.</td><td width="475"><b>LIBRARIES</b> and academic support systems for di</td></tr>
</tbody></table></dd></dl>
<p> 
</p></dd><dt><a name="kwoc"><b>KWOC</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <em><b>K</b>ey<b>w</b>ord <b>o</b>ut of <b>C</b>ontext</em>, a variation on the <a href="#kwic">KWIC</a> (Keyword in Context) <a href="#index">index</a>, in which <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> extracted <a href="#algorithm">algorithm</a>ically from the <a href="#title">title</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a> (and sometimes the <a href="#text">text</a>) are <a href="#printing">printed</a> as <a href="#heading">heading</a>s along the left-hand <a href="#margin">margin</a> of the <a href="#page">page</a>, with the titles or portions of text containing each keyword <a href="#indention">indented</a> under the corresponding heading.  A symbol may be substituted for the keyword in the string of text.  Unlike <a href="#kwac">KWAC</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, this method does <em>not</em> preserve multiword <a href="#term">term</a>s and <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s in the <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a> sequence of headings.
<p>
<em>Example</em>:
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd>libraries
<dl><dt></dt><dd>academic support systems for distance learning. <b>Libraries</b> and
</dd><dd>distance learning. <b>Libraries</b> and academic support systems for
</dd><dd>learning. <b>Libraries</b> and academic support systems for distance
</dd><dd>support systems for distance learning. <b>Libraries</b> and academic
</dd><dd>systems for distance learning. <b>Libraries</b> and academic support
</dd></dl></dd></dl>
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>
<center>| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> | <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a>
| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="L">L</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="la1"><b>LA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#la"><b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a> (UK).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lab"><b>lab</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#instructionlab">instruction lab</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="label"><b>label</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#paper">paper</a> form on which <a href="#information">information</a> can be written, typed, or <a href="#printing">printed</a>, designed to be affixed to the surface of an item such as a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually for purposes of identification or <a href="#classification">classification</a>.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> use labels extensively in <a href="#technical">technical processing</a>.  They are available precut from library <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s in various colors, shapes, and sizes, either <a href="#blank">blank</a> or preprinted, with or without <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> backing.  Labeling tape is also available for making customized labels mechanically.  When labels are used in <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, they should be <a href="#acidfree">acid-free</a>.
In a broader sense, any identifying mark attached to a thing to set it
apart or provide information to those using or viewing it (<em>see</em> <a href="#labeling">labeling</a>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#spinelabel">spine label</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="labeling"><b>labeling</b></a>
</dt><dd>The controversial practice of affixing a warning mark or <a href="#label">label</a> to <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> considered unsuitable for young children or that contain <a href="#language">language</a> or images which some <a href="#reader">reader</a>s or viewers might find offensive or distressing.  The practice is followed by some <a href="#pubtv">public television</a> stations in the United States when programs containing adult language or graphic images of sex and/or violence are <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> at times when children are likely to be watching.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="labmanual"><b>lab manual</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> of exercises that includes
instructions for laboratory experiments to be carried out, usually
under the supervision of an instructor, by a student enrolled in a
course in the sciences, often <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> in conjunction with a <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lacuna"><b>lacuna</b></a>
</dt><dd>A gap in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, usually in the <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> on a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> or by a particular <a href="#author">author</a>, which the <a href="#library">library</a> seeks to fill in order to meet the needs of its users.  Also refers to a missing portion of a <a href="#page">page</a>, or missing pages, in a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#text">text</a>, especially when caused by damage or normal wear and tear.  Plural:  <em>lacunae</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lai"><b>lai</b></a>
</dt><dd>In medieval French <a href="#literature">literature</a> of the late 12th to 13th century, a short <a href="#poetry">poem</a>
composed in octasyllabic couplets. Provencal lais were love poems
composed to be sung to music. Marie de France, who wrote in old French
at the court of Henry II (Plantagenet), is famous for her short
romantic <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>s on themes drawn from Arthurian and other Celtic <a href="#legend">legend</a>s.  <a href="http://www.people.vcu.edu/%7Ecmarecha/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the International Marie de France Society which provides the <a href="#text">text</a> of some of her lais.  
<p>
The term <em>lay</em> was also used by English poets of the 18th
and 19th centuries in reference to a song or relatively short narrative
poem with romance or adventure as its central theme (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Lay of the Last Minstrel</em></b> by Sir Walter Scott).      
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="laidin"><b>laid in</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> <a href="#insert">insert</a>ed but not glued into a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  Compare with <a href="#integral">integral</a>.
<p>
Also used in a <a href="#note">note</a> in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> <a href="#entry">entry</a> to indicate a <a href="#leaflet">leaflet</a> or <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a> included in a <a href="#phonograph">record</a> <a href="#album">album</a> or musical <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually containing <a href="#information">information</a> about the <a href="#contents">contents</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="laidpaper"><b>laid paper</b></a>
</dt><dd>Handmade <a href="#paper">paper</a> which, when held up to a
light source, reveals a pattern of fine, faintly translucent parallel
lines intersecting at right angles in a grid made by the wires of the <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a> frame.  The same effect is achieved in machine-made paper by the <a href="#dandyroll">dandy roll</a>, a cylinder that smooths the surface and impresses designs such as the <a href="#watermark">watermark</a> and <a href="#countermark">countermark</a>.  Compare with <a href="#wovepaper">wove paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lama1"><b>LAMA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lama"><b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>dministration and <b>M</b>anagement <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lambda"><b><em>Lambda Book Report</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the Lambda Literary Foundation, a nonprofit organization supporting gay and lesbian <a href="#literature">literature</a>.  The Foundation also sponsors the annual Lamda Literary Awards and Behind Our Masks, an annual writers <a href="#conference">conference</a>.  <a href="http://www.lambdalit.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the Lambda Literary Foundation.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lamination"><b>lamination</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of preserving old and fragile <a href="#document">document</a>s in which a layer of thin transparent plastic film is adhered to one or both sides of a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#board">board</a> by means of heat and/or pressure, sealing it against dust and atmospheric conditions.  Processes of <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> inherent in the object are not arrested by lamination.  <a href="#encapsulation">Encapsulation</a> is preferred in <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> work because it is <a href="#reversibility">reversible</a>.  Lamination is also used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> to protect and enhance the appearance of <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>s on <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and the <a href="#cover">cover</a>s of <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  Available in rolls from library <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s, <em>laminate</em> is applied by hand or on a machine called a <em>laminator</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lampoon"><b>lampoon</b></a>
</dt><dd>A  biting <a href="#satire">satire</a> written in <a href="#prose">prose</a> or <a href="#verse">verse</a>,
usually directed against an individual in public life or an institution
that has become the object of public scrutiny. Lampoons written in
verse were popular in England during the 18th century. The form was
given new life in 20th century by <a href="#publication">publication</a>s such as the <em>Harvard Lampoon</em> and its close relative, the <em>National Lampoon</em>.  Because this form of humor exposes its <a href="#subject">subject</a>(s) to public ridicule, <a href="#libel">libel</a> laws impose restraint.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#caricature">caricature</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lan"><b>LAN</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#localarea"><b>l</b>ocal <b>a</b>rea <b>n</b>etwork</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="landmarkbuilding"><b>landmark building</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> facility preserved because it has architectural and historical significance, for example, the <a href="#nypl">New York Public Library</a> building at 5th Avenue and 42nd Street in Manhattan which houses the humanities and social sciences <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.
Designed in the beaux-arts style by John Merven Carrere and Thomas
Hastings, and constructed on the site of the old Croton Reservoir, the
building opened in the spring of 1911.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="language"><b>language</b></a>
</dt><dd>The system of conventional sounds and <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s developed over time by a specific human population as a means of expressing and exchanging thoughts, feelings, <a href="#information">information</a>, and <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>.  A language consists of a <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a> and rules of grammar, <a href="#syntax">syntax</a>, and <a href="#orthography">orthography</a>.  A <em>national language</em> is the official language of a specific country, used in its <a href="#govdocs">government publications</a>
and educational institutions. Some countries have more than one
national language, for example, Canada where both English and French
are officially recognized.
<p>
In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the language in which a <a href="#work">work</a> is written or spoken.  A <a href="#note">note</a> is made in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> only when the language of the <a href="#text">text</a> is not apparent from the rest of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, as in the case of a <a href="#film">film</a> <a href="#subtitle">subtitle</a>d in a language different from that of the <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> or <a href="#narration">narration</a>.  In some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, it is possible to <a href="#limiting">limit</a> <a href="#search">search</a> results by language.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/marc/languages/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em>MARC Code List for Languages</em>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>lang</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#artificiallang">artificial language</a>, <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>, and <a href="#naturallang">natural language</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="languagedictionary"><b>language dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> that lists the words of one <a href="#language">language</a>, in <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> order, with <a href="#definition">definition</a>s
in another. Some language dictionaries are divided into two parts,
first listing the words of a language with definitions in another, and
then vice versa. <a href="http://www.yourdictionary.com/">Click here</a> to connect to a list of <a href="#link">link</a>s to <a href="#online">online</a> language dictionaries maintained by <em>YourDictionary.com</em>.  Compare with <a href="#polyglotdictionary">polyglot dictionary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lapsitservices"><b>lapsit services</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#library">Library</a> services and programs designed for very young children (12-24 months old) in conjunction with their <a href="#adult">adult</a> caregivers, including <a href="#nurseryrhyme">nursery rhyme</a>s, songs, finger plays, and <a href="#storytelling">storytelling</a>, often with the aid of a <a href="#flannelboard">flannel board</a> or <a href="#puppetry">puppets</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="laptop"><b>laptop</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small portable battery-operated <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a>, usually equipped with a built-in <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> and <a href="#mouse">mouse</a>, and a <a href="#flatpanel">flat panel</a> <a href="#monitor">monitor</a> that folds over the keyboard to form a cover.  Modern <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> are <a href="#retrofit">retrofit</a>ting study areas to provide <a href="#network">network</a> connectivity for <a href="#patron">patron</a>s who use laptops, and some <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> are installing them in classrooms used for <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>.  Synonymous with <em>notebook</em>.  Compare with <a href="#pda">personal digital assistant (PDA)</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dockingstation">docking station</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="largepaperedition"><b>large paper edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> in which the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> are larger in size than the <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a> (and usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on better quality <a href="#paper">paper</a>) making the <a href="#margin">margin</a>s wider than normal.  <a href="#limitededition">Limited</a> and <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a>s are often printed in this way.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="largeprint"><b>large print (LP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any <a href="#typesize">type size</a> larger than 16-<a href="#point">point</a>.  Also refers to <a href="#book">book</a>s <a href="#printing">printed</a> in <a href="#type">type</a> larger than the 9-, 10-, or 11-point size normally used for <a href="#text">text</a>, mostly <a href="#publication">publication</a>s for visually impaired, elderly, and young <a href="#reader">reader</a>s (<a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>s, <a href="#beginningreader">beginning reader</a>s, etc.).  The <a href="http://www.navh.org/">National Association for Visually Handicapped</a> has established <a href="#standards">standards</a> for LP materials.  English-<a href="#language">language</a> LP materials currently <a href="#inprint">in print</a> (and <a href="#forthcoming">forthcoming</a>) are listed in <b><em>The Complete Directory of Large Print Books and Serials</em></b>, a <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, arranged by <a href="#subject">subject</a>, with <a href="#authorindex">author</a> and <a href="#title">title index</a>es, and printed in 14-point type to facilitate use by sight-impaired readers.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="laserdisk"><b>laser disk</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#opticaldisk">optical disk</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="laserpointer"><b>laser pointer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small battery-operated metal wand about the size of a
fountain pen, designed to project a narrow laser beam of intense red
light onto a wall screen or other display surface, in daylight or a
darkened room, from a distance of over 100 yards, used for emphasis by
speakers during presentations including <a href="#visualaid">visual aid</a>s.  Most models include a pocket clip or come with a carrying case. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="laserprinter"><b>laser printer</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#output">output</a> <a href="#device">device</a> introduced by IBM in 1975 that uses a laser beam and electrostatic imaging to <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#text">text</a> and/or image(s) by transferring and fusing toner to the surface of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, one <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> at a time.  <a href="#resolution">Resolution</a> is determined by the spot size of the laser.  Print quality is superior to that of dot-matrix and ink-jet <a href="#printer">printer</a>s.
Hewlett-Packard is currently the major manufacturer of personal laser
printers, from low-end desktop models capable of printing 4-8 <a href="#page">page</a>s per minute, to large office units capable of printing up to 32 pages per minute.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="latin"><b>latin</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general term used in <a href="#typography">typography</a> to refer to all <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>s that have their origin in the Latin <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>, as opposed to those that do not (Arabic, Chinese, Greek, Hebrew, etc.).  Also refers to typefaces that have <a href="#wedgeserif">wedge-serif</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="laubachliteracy"><b>Laubach Literacy (LL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonprofit educational corporation dedicated to helping <a href="#adult">adult</a>s of all ages improve their lives and communities by learning essential <a href="#literacy">literacy</a> skills (reading, writing, math, and problem-solving).  Its <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> division, New Readers Press, distributes over 500 <a href="#title">title</a>s to literacy programs, <a href="#library">libraries</a>, schools, prisons, and religious organizations in the United States.  <b>LL</b> is an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  <a href="http://www.laubach.org/home.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Laubach Literacy</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lawbinding"><b>law binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A style of <a href="#binding">binding</a> used for law <a href="#book">book</a>s in which the <a href="#board">board</a>s are covered in <a href="#leather">leather</a> or <a href="#imitationleather">imitation leather</a> of a medium to light color, with two contrasting bands of a darker color on the <a href="#spine">spine</a> (usually dark red, green, or blue).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lawlibrary"><b>law library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a> with a <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> consisting primarily of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> for legal <a href="#research">research</a> and study, including case law, federal and state statutes, international legal agreements, <a href="#treatise">treatise</a>s, <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s, legal <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, and electronic <a href="#search">search</a> tools.  A law library maintained by a court, law school, or legal firm is normally managed by a <em>law librarian</em> who may hold a J.D. degree in addition to the <a href="#mls">M.L.S.</a> or <a href="#mlis">M.L.I.S.</a>  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#aall">American Association of Law Libraries</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lay"><b>lay</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lai">lai</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="layout"><b>layout</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typography">typography</a>, the overall plan of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> showing the placement of <a href="#textblock">text block</a>s, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#caption">caption</a>s, <a href="#runninghead">running head</a>s, etc., and indicating <a href="#font">font</a>s and font sizes, intended to be followed by the <a href="#printer">printer</a>.  Also refers to the process of preparing <a href="#copy">copy</a> for <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a>,
and to the preliminary rough sketch and eventually to the more precise
drawing called a "comprehensive" showing the general appearance of a
printed <a href="#page">page</a>, usually done on special <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#rule">rule</a>d in 12-<a href="#point">point</a> squares.  Compare with <a href="#makeup">make-up</a>.
<p>
Also, the manner in which components of an <a href="#interface">interface</a> or <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#document">document</a>, such as a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>, are arranged by the designer for viewing on the user's computer screen.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lbi1"><b>LBI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lbi"><b>L</b>ibrary <b>B</b>inding <b>I</b>nstitute</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="loc"><b>LC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lc"><b>L</b>ibrary of <b>C</b>ongress</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lcc"><b>LCC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lcclassification"><b>L</b>ibrary of <b>C</b>ongress <b>C</b>lassification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lccn1"><b>LCCN</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lccn"><b>L</b>ibrary of <b>C</b>ongress <b>C</b>ontrol <b>N</b>umber</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lcd"><b>LCD</b></a>
</dt><dd><em><b>L</b>iquid <b>c</b>rystal <b>d</b>isplay</em>, a technology used in display panels and projectors that enables the <a href="#output">output</a> from a computer or other <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#device">device</a> to be projected onto a large screen. <b>LCD</b> technology is used in <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>s because it requires less power than a conventional light-emitting <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>
and occupies less space, allowing a flat panel to be used as the
display unit; however, an external light source is required (ambient
