light is usually sufficient).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lcri1"><b><em>LCRI</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#lcri"><b>L</b>ibrary of <b>C</b>ongress <b>R</b>ule <b>I</b>nterpretations</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leader"><b>leader</b></a>
</dt><dd>The first <a href="#field">field</a> of a <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>, consisting of 24 <a href="#character">character</a> positions, each of which <a href="#encoding">encode</a>s <a href="#data">data</a> of a specific type, mostly <a href="#information">information</a> of use to <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s, such as record status (new, corrected or revised, deleted, etc.) and <a href="#descripcatalog">descriptive cataloging</a> form (<em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, <a href="#isbd">ISBD</a>, etc.), or codes to facilitate record retrieval (character coding scheme, base address of data, etc.).  <a href="#cataloging">Cataloging</a> <a href="#software">software</a> usually provides <a href="#prompt">prompt</a>s or <a href="#window">window</a>s to assist catalogers as they enter information in the leader.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fixedfield">fixed field</a>.   
<p>
Also refers to the strip of <a href="#film">film</a> without images at the beginning of a <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, or <a href="#roll">roll</a> of unexposed film, used to thread the projector, processing machine, or camera.  Compare with <a href="#trailer">trailer</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leaders"><b>leaders</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a>, a line of dots or <a href="#dash">dash</a>es intended to direct the <a href="#reader">reader</a>'s eye across the <a href="#page">page</a>, as from a <a href="#chaptertitle">chapter title</a> listed in a <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a> to the appropriate <a href="#locator">locator</a> (usually a <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>) in the right-hand column.  Also, a <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> term for the most important <a href="#title">title</a>s on a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#frontlist">frontlist</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leading"><b>leading</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the amount of vertical space allowed by the <a href="#typesetting">typesetter</a> between lines of <a href="#type">type</a> in a <a href="#column">column</a> or on a <a href="#page">page</a>.  Pronounced "ledding."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leadintitle"><b>lead-in title</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#backlist">Backlist</a>ed <a href="#title">title</a>s offered  in a <a href="#bookclub">book club</a> mail advertising campaign at very low prices or no charge, as an inducement to potential <a href="#subscription">subscriber</a>s, or as bonuses or dividends to existing members.  Synonymous with <em>introductory title</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leadinvocabulary"><b>lead-in vocabulary</b></a>
</dt><dd>In a <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of the <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a> used in <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of an academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> (or group of disciplines), <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s are included to direct or "lead" the user from <a href="#synonym">synonyms</a> and <a href="#quasisynonym">quasi-synonym</a>s to the authorized <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>, usually by means of an instruction to <em><a href="#see">see</a></em> or <a href="#use">USE</a> the <a href="#preferredterm">preferred term</a>.  A thesaurus containing such cross-references is said to have <a href="#syndetic">syndetic structure</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leadstory"><b>lead story</b></a>
</dt><dd>The most important item of news reported in an <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> or <a href="#newsmagazine">news magazine</a>, or in a television news <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#frontpage">front page</a>, featured on the front <a href="#cover">cover</a>,
or introduced in the opening minutes of the program. The lead story is
usually longer and more detailed than the other stories <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the same issue or broadcast on the same program. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leadterm"><b>lead term</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, the first word in a <a href="#heading">heading</a> or <a href="#content">content</a> <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>, which determines the position of the heading when it is listed or filed in <a href="#alphanumeric">alphanumeric</a> sequence.  In headings of two or more words, conventional word order is sometimes <a href="#invertedheading">inverted</a> to bring the most significant word into first-word position (<em>example</em>:  <b>Law, Spartan</b> as opposed to <b>Spartan Law</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leaf"><b>leaf</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#book">book</a> production, a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> or half-sheet of <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> when folded in half forms two <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, each of single thickness with two <a href="#page">page</a>s, one on each side, either <a href="#blank">blank</a> or <a href="#printing">printed</a>.  In early books, the leaves were consecutively numbered only on the <a href="#recto">recto</a> or right-hand page of an <a href="#opening">opening</a> (<a href="#foliation">foliation</a>), but in modern book production, the recto usually bears an <em>odd</em> page number and the <a href="#verso">verso</a> or left-hand page an <em>even</em> number (<a href="#pagination">pagination</a>), sometimes reversed in <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doubleleaf">double leaf</a> and <a href="#folio">folio</a>.
<p>
Also refers to very thin sheets of silver or <a href="#goldleaf">gold</a>, used to highlight <a href="#lettering">lettering</a> or ornamentation stamped on a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>, or applied to one or more of the <a href="#giltedges">edges</a> of a <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a> to give the appearance of luxury.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#burnish">burnish</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leaflet"><b>leaflet</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> of two to four <a href="#page">page</a>s, un<a href="#saddle">stitched</a> and <a href="#unbound">unbound</a>, usually folded or stapled together, as in the <a href="#programnotes">program notes</a> distributed to attendees at a performance.  Also refers to a thin <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a> of comparatively small size.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leak"><b>leak</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#information">information</a> systems, the loss of <a href="#confidentiality">confidentiality</a> that results when <a href="#security">security</a>
precautions are breached. When sensitive information falls into
unauthorized hands, the consequences can be devastating for those who
have a stake in maintaining secrecy, but leaks can also be intentional
(to divert attention, pre-empt criticism, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leanmatter"><b>lean matter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printer">printer</a>'s <a href="#term">term</a> for <a href="#copy">copy</a> that takes longer than usual to <a href="#typesetting">set</a> because it does not contain much <a href="#whitespace">white space</a>, for example, a scholarly <a href="#essay">essay</a> or <a href="#treatise">treatise</a>, as opposed to <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> or <a href="#poetry">poetry</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#fatmatter">fat matter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="learningcurve"><b>learning curve</b></a>
</dt><dd>A graphical representation of the rate at which learning occurs, particularly in a new environment or <a href="#subject">subject</a> area.  A learning curve may be <em>steep</em>, <em>moderate</em>, or <em>gentle</em> depending on the amount of new <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> to be acquired, its complexity, and the time available to complete the task.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="learningresources"><b>learning resources center (LRC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Synonymous in the United States with <a href="#schoollibrary">school library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="learningstyle"><b>learning style</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cognitivestyle">cognitive style</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leasedline"><b>leased line</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dedicatedline">dedicated line</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leasingplan"><b>leasing plan</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#booklease">book lease plan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leather"><b>leather</b></a>
</dt><dd>The skin of an animal (<a href="#calf">calf</a>, sheep, <a href="#goatskin">goat</a>, <a href="#pigskin">pig</a>, seal, etc.), processed for use in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>.  Often dyed an attractive color, the leather used on <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s may also be embellished with <a href="#inlay">inlay</a> and/or <a href="#tooling">tooling</a>, <a href="#blind">blind</a> or highlighted in <a href="#goldleaf">gold</a> or silver.  <a href="#leatherbound">Leather-bound</a> books were common up to the mid-19th century.  Today, <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>, <a href="#paper">paper</a>, or synthetic material is used to cover the <a href="#board">board</a>s of <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>.  Real leather is used only in <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a>.  Compare with <a href="#imitationleather">imitation leather</a> and  <a href="#leatherette">leatherette</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#oozeleather">ooze leather</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leatherbound"><b>leather-bound</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a>, fully or partially, in the processed skin of an animal, with the back of the <a href="#spine">spine</a> always in <a href="#leather">leather</a>.  Medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and early <a href="#printing">printed</a> books were bound in wooden <a href="#board">board</a>s <a href="#cover">cover</a>ed in leather or <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>.  In modern book production, leather is used  mainly in <a href="#handbinding">hand-bound</a> books of <a href="#finebook">fine</a> quality.  Leather bindings can be plain or <a href="#tooling">tooled</a>, with any tooling left <a href="#blind">blind</a> or <a href="#goldleaf">gilt</a>.  Compare with <a href="#imitationleather">imitation leather</a> and <a href="#leatherette">leatherette</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#calf">calf</a>, <a href="#goatskin">goatskin</a>, <a href="#morocco">morocco</a>, <a href="#pigskin">pigskin</a>, and <a href="#oozeleather">ooze leather</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="leatherette"><b>leatherette</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#durability">durable</a> <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> material available in various colors, made from strong machine-glazed <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#embossed">embossed</a> to give the appearance of a <a href="#leather">leather</a> surface.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lectern"><b>lectern</b></a>
</dt><dd>A reading desk in a Christian church, especially one from which portions of the <a href="#scripture">Scripture</a>s are read aloud during services.  In a more general sense, any sloping desk or stand, usually with a narrow ledge called a <a href="#bookstop">book stop</a> along the bottom edge to support an open <a href="#book">book</a> or sheaf of <a href="#papers">papers</a>, and to allow the <a href="#reader">reader</a> free use of the hands.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lectionary"><b>lectionary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A liturgical <a href="#book">book</a> containing selections
from the Christian Scriptures, indicating the sequence in which they
are to be read by a congregation during services throughout the year. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="legalvalue"><b>legal value</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="legend"><b>legend</b></a>
</dt><dd>A visual aid that explains to the <a href="#reader">reader</a> the <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s used on a <a href="#map">map</a> or in a <a href="#diagram">diagram</a>.  Also refers to the <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#caption">caption</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> below an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, or on a coin or medal.  
<p>
Also, a traditional story of a well-known event, sometimes concerning the life of a national folk hero, which may contain <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>al or supernatural elements, but is considered to have some basis in historical fact (<em>example</em>:  Paul Bunyan).  Compare with <a href="#folktale">folktale</a> and <a href="#myth">myth</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="legibility"><b>legibility</b></a>
</dt><dd>The cumulative visual effect of the physical appearance of written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#text">text</a>, which depends on the size, shape, and darkness of the <a href="#character">character</a>s, their distance from each other, length of line, and the amount of <a href="#spacing">spacing</a> between words and between lines.  Other factors that determine legibility are the color and <a href="#finish">finish</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, available illumination, and the experience and skill of the <a href="#reader">reader</a>.  In printing, the legibility of text is enhanced by no more than thirteen words per line, adequate <a href="#typesize">type size</a> (9- to 12-<a href="#point">point</a>), <a href="#margin">margin</a>s of sufficient width and balance, clarity of <a href="#type">type</a>, density of <a href="#ink">ink</a>, and a paper finish that reduces glare (<a href="#matte">matte</a> rather than smooth). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="legible"><b>legible</b></a>
</dt><dd>Writing or <a href="#printing">printing</a> that can be easily read or deciphered by the human eye, the opposite of <em>illegible</em>.  <a href="#legibility">Legibility</a> is an important consideration in the design of printed material.  Compare with <a href="#readable">readable</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="legishist"><b>legislative history</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#chronological">chronological</a> account of the steps involved in the passage of a <a href="#bill">bill</a> into law, including events leading up to the first <a href="#draft">draft</a>, committee <a href="#hearings">hearings</a>,
lobbying efforts, floor debates, compromises, final vote, enactment,
and any subsequent history, such as a presidential veto or court test. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#legislative">legislative reference service</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="legislative"><b>legislative reference service</b></a>
</dt><dd>An agency or unit of government that provides <a href="#research">research</a> assistance to legislatures and other <a href="#govtagency">government agencies</a> on issues related to proposed legislation.  This function may include assistance in <a href="#draft">draft</a>ing and <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> bills.  At the federal level, legislative <a href="#refservices">reference service</a> is provided by <em>Congressional Research Services</em>, a division of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#legishist">legislative history</a> and <em><a href="#thomas">THOMAS</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lenderstring"><b>lender string</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>, a list of the <a href="#oclcsymbol">OCLC symbol</a>s of up to five <a href="#library">libraries</a>, selected by the <a href="#borrowinglibrary">borrowing library</a> from the <a href="#holdingsdisplay">holdings display</a> in the <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em> <a href="#database">database</a> as potential <a href="#lendinglibrary">lender</a>s for an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> requested by a library <a href="#patron">patron</a>.
OCLC queries the first prospective lender on the list and if the
request is not filled, the second is automatically queried, and so on.
Should the request remain <em>unfilled</em> after the first five
libraries have been contacted, the borrowing library has the option of
selecting a second string of five new OCLC symbols from the holdings
list and repeating the process. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lendinglibrary"><b>lending library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> or other institution that sends <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> on request to another library, usually via <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>.  Compare with <a href="#borrowinglibrary">borrowing library</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#netlender">net lender</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="letter"><b>letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>In writing and <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#character">character</a> or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> used to represent a speech sound.  All the letters of a written <a href="#language">language</a> constitute its <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>.  The Latin alphabet used to write the English language contains 26 letters, each with an <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> and <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> form.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#lettering">lettering</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a handwritten, typewritten, or printed personal or
business message of one or more persons, usually enclosed in an
envelope and delivered to the addressee by post or courier. Compare
with <a href="#correspondence">correspondence</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#coverletter">cover letter</a>, <a href="#epistle">epistle</a>, <a href="#lettereditor">letter to the editor</a>, and <a href="#missive">missive</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="letterbyletter"><b>letter-by-letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#alphabetization">alphabetization</a> in which any <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a> marks and divisions are ignored in a <a href="#heading">heading</a> consisting of two or more words, and the heading treated as a single word ("newt" appearing before "New Testament").  <b><em>The Chicago Manual of Style</em></b> recommends a modification in which the method is followed only to the first comma or <a href="#parenthesis">parenthesis</a>, to keep identically spelled <a href="#surname">surname</a>s together.  Most <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a> are alphabetized in this fashion.  Synonymous with <em>all through</em> and <em>follow through</em>.  Compare with <a href="#wordbyword">word-by-word</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lettered"><b>lettered</b></a>
</dt><dd>Inscribed with <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>, especially the <a href="#title">title</a> on the <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually done in letters of contrasting color or <a href="#goldleaf">gilt</a>.  Also refers to a person who is educated or <a href="#literacy">literate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="letterform"><b>letterform</b></a>
</dt><dd>The shape of the <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> and <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the Latin <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>, especially with reference to their evolution in <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphy</a> and their design in <a href="#typography">typography</a>.  Also spelled <em>letter form</em>.  For a brief but informative <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> of the history of letterforms, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> on "Letters" in Geoffrey Glaister's <b><em>Encyclopedia of the Book</em></b> (Oak Knoll/British Library, 1996). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lettering"><b>lettering</b></a>
</dt><dd>The act of making <a href="#letter">letter</a>s or of <a href="#inscription">inscribing</a> with letters, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s, and special <a href="#character">character</a>s, especially by hand-<a href="#printing">printing</a>, painting, or <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphy</a>.  In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, the process of marking the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#volume">volume</a> with the <a href="#title">title</a>, name of <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a>, etc.  To remain sharp and <a href="#legible">legible</a>, lettering on the outside of a <a href="#book">book</a> should be applied with sufficient pressure, temperature, and <a href="#dwell">dwell</a> to ensure permanent adhesion of the stamping foil to the covering material.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="letterpress"><b>letterpress</b></a>
</dt><dd>The original <a href="#printing">printing</a> process invented by <a href="#gutenberg">Johann Gutenberg</a> in which the raised surface of metal <a href="#type">type</a>, or an image on a block or <a href="#plate">plate</a>, is coated with <a href="#ink">ink</a> transferred directly to <a href="#paper">paper</a> (or some other printing surface) by the application of pressure.  After a <a href="#pressrun">press run</a>,
type may be left standing for subsequent reuse, or broken up and used
for another job. In modern printing, letterpress had been largely
replaced by <a href="#offset">offset</a>.  Also spelled <em>letter-press</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#intaglio">intaglio</a> and <a href="#lithography">lithography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="letters"><b>letters</b></a>
</dt><dd>The handwritten, typewritten, or <a href="#printing">printed</a>
personal or business messages of one or more persons. A letter is
usually enclosed in an envelope and sent to the addressee by post or
courier. In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the <a href="#collection">collected</a> letters of a single person are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under the name of the writer, with an <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> for the <a href="#editor">editor</a> or <a href="#compiler">compiler</a>.
If the letters are addressed to the same person, an added entry is also
made under the name of the addressee. The collected letters of several
writers are cataloged under the name of the editor or compiler. Compare
with <a href="#correspondence">correspondence</a>.
<p>
Also refers to learning or <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> in a general sense (as in the <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> "arts and letters") and to the profession of the writer, with reference to <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="letterspatent"><b>letters patent</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written <a href="#document">document</a> of <a href="#record">record</a>, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by a government or monarch to confer a right, privilege, <a href="#title">title</a>, office, or property on a person or corporate entity, in a manner that is open for inspection. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lettereditor"><b>letter to the editor</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#letter">letter</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the discretion of the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> on the <a href="#editorial">editorial page</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> or <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, in which a <a href="#reader">reader</a> expresses his or her views on the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of a previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#article">article</a> or editorial, or on the editorial policy of the <a href="#publication">publication</a> in general, sometimes followed by a brief response from the <a href="#editor">editor</a>(s).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="levant"><b>levant</b></a>
</dt><dd>A high-quality open-grained <a href="#morocco">morocco</a> <a href="#leather">leather</a> made from the skin of the Angora goat, used in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> to achieve an elegant, highly polished look.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="levelofdescrip"><b>level of description</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the amount of detail given in a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, indicated by the number of <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>s included in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  <em><a href="#anglo">Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</a></em> specify three distinct levels of description:  <a href="#fulllevel">full level</a>, <a href="#corelevel">core level</a>, and <a href="#minimallevel">minimal level</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lexicography"><b>lexicography</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of writing and <a href="#compile">compiling</a> a <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> or <a href="#glossary">glossary</a>, including the selection of <a href="#term">term</a>s and the preparation of an <a href="#entry">entry</a> for each word, giving the correct <a href="#orthography">spelling</a>, pronunciation, <a href="#etymology">derivation</a>, one or more <a href="#definition">definition</a>s, and sometimes <a href="#antonym">antonym</a>s and examples of <a href="#usage">usage</a>.   The person who writes or compiles such a work is a <em>lexicographer</em>.  Compare with <a href="#lexicology">lexicology</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lexicology"><b>lexicology</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#field">field</a> of study devoted to the origins, form, and meaning of words in any <a href="#language">language</a>.  Compare with <a href="#lexicography">lexicography</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#etymology">etymology</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lexicon"><b>lexicon</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, a <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> of Greek, Hebrew, Arabic, or some other literary <a href="#language">language</a>.  In modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, a <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> dictionary or <a href="#glossary">glossary</a> of the words of a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#field">field</a> of study.  In linguistics, a list of all the lexical items (lexemes) in a given language.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lhrt1"><b>LHRT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lhrt"><b>L</b>ibrary <b>H</b>istory <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="liaison"><b>liaison</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s are often assigned one or more academic departments for which they serve as intermediary between the teaching faculty and the <a href="#library">library</a>.  Liaison responsibilities may include <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>, <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> (including <a href="#refbook">reference</a> and electronic resources), <a href="#currentawareness">current awareness</a>,
and faculty training in the use of library resources. Most liaison
librarians have academic preparation or at least some level of
expertise in the <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s they serve.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libdex"><b><em>LibDex: The Library Index</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#searchable">searchable</a> worldwide <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#directory">directory</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>s, <a href="#www">Web</a>-based <a href="#opac">OPAC</a>s, <a href="#friends">Friends of the Library</a> homepages, and library e-commerce affiliates, maintained by Peter Scott of the University of Saskatchewan Library.  <a href="http://www.libdex.com/">Click here</a> to connect to <b><em>LibDex</em></b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#libweb">Libweb</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libel"><b>libel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> statement or
representation intended to expose a person, group of persons, or
corporate entity to public ridicule or contempt, or to damage in some
other way the reputation of its <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  Also refers to the act of <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>
such a statement. Burden of proof is on the plaintiff to show that
actual damage occurred. In the United States, the constitutional
guarantee of freedom of speech and press provides no protection to
libelous statements. <em>Slander</em> is defamatory words spoken but not published in writing or in print.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="liber"><b>LIBER</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ligue"><b>L</b>igue des <b>B</b>ibliotheques <b>E</b>uropeennes de <b>R</b>echerche</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarian"><b>librarian</b></a>
</dt><dd>A professionally trained person responsible for the care of a <a href="#library">library</a> and its contents, including the <a href="#selection">selection</a>, <a href="#technical">processing</a>, and organization of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> and the delivery of <a href="#information">information</a>, <a href="#libraryinstruction">instruction</a>, and loan services to meet the needs of its users.  In an <a href="#online">online</a> environment, the role of the librarian is to manage and mediate <a href="#access">access</a> to information which may exist only in electronic form.  
<p>
In the United States the <a href="#title">title</a> is reserved for persons who have been awarded the <a href="#mls">M.L.S.</a> or <a href="#mlis">M.L.I.S.</a> degree or <a href="#certification">certified</a> as professionals by a state <a href="#govtagency">agency</a>.  Also refers to the person responsible for the overall <a href="#libadmin">administration</a> of a library or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, synonymous in this sense with <a href="#librarydirector">library director</a>.  Classified by functional <a href="#specialization">specialization</a> (<a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> librarian, <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>, <a href="#bi">instruction</a> librarian, <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a>, <a href="#serial">serial</a>s librarian, <a href="#systemslibrarian">systems librarian</a>, etc.), librarians in the United States are organized in the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> (ALA) and its <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#supportstaff">support staff</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#solo">solo librarian</a> and <a href="#librariancongress">Librarian of Congress</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librariana"><b>librariana</b></a>
</dt><dd>A catch-all term for the body of <a href="#information">information</a>, <a href="#work">work</a>s, and <a href="#memorabilia">memorabilia</a> that has accumulated on the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, and related <a href="#topic">topic</a>s, particularly items of historical interest.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#-ana">-ana or -iana</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librariancongress"><b>Librarian of Congress</b></a>
</dt><dd>An office created in 1802, two years after the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>
was established, for which no qualifications were specified. The
position is filled by presidential appointment for no fixed term. In
1897, the Senate acquired the power to approve the President's
nomination, and the <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a> of Congress was given the authority to appoint the <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>
of the Library of Congress and to establish its rules and regulations.
In the 20th century, a precedent was established for appointing the
Librarian of Congress for life. <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/loc/legacy/librs.html">Click here</a> for <a href="#biography">biographical</a> <a href="#information">information</a> about the Americans who have served as Librarian of Congress since the office was created. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarianship"><b>librarianship</b></a>
</dt><dd>The profession devoted to applying <a href="#informationtheory">theory</a> and <a href="#infotech">technology</a> to the creation, <a href="#selection">selection</a>, organization, management, <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, dissemination, and utilization of <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of <a href="#information">information</a> in all <a href="#format">format</a>s.  In the United States, often used synonymously with <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a>.  A person formally trained or certified to perform such services is a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#comparativelib">comparative librarianship</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lu"><b>Libraries Unlimited (LU)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1964 by Bohdan S. Wynar, <b>Libraries Unlimited</b> serves the needs of the <a href="#library">library</a> profession through the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a> and <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s, <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a> <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s, <a href="#infoscience">information science</a> materials, and practical <a href="#handbook">handbook</a>s, <a href="#manual">manual</a>s, and <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>s for <a href="#libraryeducation">library educator</a>s, practicing <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#mediaspecialist">media specialist</a>s, and teachers.  In July 2001, <b>LU</b> joined the Greenwood Publishing Group Inc., a division of Elsevier.  <a href="http://www.lu.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>LU</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="library"><b>library</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>liber</em> meaning "book" (in Greek and the Romance <a href="#language">language</a>s the corresponding <a href="#term">term</a> is <em>bibliotheca</em>).  A <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> or group of collections of <a href="#book">book</a>s and/or other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> organized and maintained for use (reading, consultation, study, <a href="#research">research</a>, etc.).  Institutional libraries, organized to facilitate <a href="#access">access</a> by a specific <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>, are <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ed by <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s
and other personnel trained to provide services to meet user needs. By
extension, the room, building, or facility that houses such a
collection, usually but not necessarily built for that purpose. <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> on libraries is available <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by country in <b><em>World Guide to Libraries</em></b>, a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by K. G. Saur.  Two <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> worldwide <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#directory">directories</a> of library <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>s are <em><a href="http://www.libdex.com/">LibDex</a></em> and <em><a href="http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/Libweb/">Libweb</a></em>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>lib</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a>, <a href="#govtlibrary">government library</a>, <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>, and <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a>.   
<p>
Also, a collective noun used by <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, particularly during the Victorian period, for certain <a href="#book">book</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#series">series</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Everyman's Library</em></b>). 
</p><p>
Also refers to a collection of <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a>s or <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s, or a set of ready-made reusable <a href="#routine">routine</a>s, sometimes called <em>modules</em>,
that can be linked to a program at the time it is compiled, relieving
the programmer of the necessity to repeat the code each time the
routine is used in a program.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libadmin"><b>library administration</b></a>
</dt><dd>The control and <a href="#supervision">supervision</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, including <a href="#strategicplanning">planning</a>, <a href="#budget">budget</a>ing, policy-making, personnel management, <a href="#publicrelations">public relations</a>,
and program assessment, with responsibility for results. Also refers
collectively to the persons responsible for managing a library, usually
a board of <a href="#librarytrustee">trustee</a>s or dean, <a href="#librarydirector">library director</a>, and his or her immediate staff.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#lama">Library Administration and Management Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lama"><b>Library Administration and Management Association (LAMA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> founded in 1957, <b>LAMA</b> has a membership consisting of <a href="#librarydirector">library director</a>s and persons with an interest in improving the quality of <a href="#libadmin">administration</a> and management in <a href="#library">libraries</a> of all types.  <b>LAMA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/lama/">Library Administration &amp; Management (LA&amp;M)</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/lama/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>LAMA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryadvocate"><b>library advocate</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who appreciates <a href="#library">libraries</a> and their role in society, to the extent of speaking and acting publicly in their support, especially when funding and the <a href="#ftrs">freedom to read</a> are at stake.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#friends">Friends of the Library</a> and <a href="#librarytrustee">library trustee</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lisa"><b><em>Library and Information Science Abstracts (LISA)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a> devoted to the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>, <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> from 1950-1968 under the <a href="#title">title</a> <em>Library Science Abstracts</em>, and <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> since 1969 under the current title by the <a href="#la">Library Association</a> of Great Britain (<a href="#issn">ISSN</a> 0024-2179).  Available <a href="#online">online</a> from <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, <b><em>LISA</em></b> provides <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>s of <a href="#article">article</a>s from over 550 <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s published in over 68 countries worldwide and <a href="#paper">paper</a>s from major English-<a href="#language">language</a> <a href="#conference">conference</a> <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a>, <a href="#update">update</a>d <a href="#biweekly">biweekly</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#librarylit">Library Literature &amp; Information Science</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lita"><b>Library and Information Science Technology Association (LITA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> since in 1966, <b>LITA</b> has a membership consisting of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and other information professionals concerned with all aspects of the acquisition, organization, <a href="#storage">storage</a>, <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a>, and dissemination of <a href="#information">information</a> in electronic <a href="#format">format</a>s, including <a href="#digitallibrary">digital libraries</a>, <a href="#metadata">metadata</a>, <a href="#authorization">authorization</a> and <a href="#authentication">authentication</a>, <a href="#electronicjournal">electronic journal</a>s and <a href="#electronicpub">electronic publishing</a>, <a href="#telecommunications">telecommunications</a>, <a href="#network">network</a>s, computer <a href="#security">security</a> and <a href="#intellectualproperty">intellectual property</a> rights, technical <a href="#standards">standards</a>, <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, optical information systems, desktop <a href="#application">application</a>s, <a href="#software">software</a> engineering, etc.  <b>LITA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em><a href="http://www.lita.org/">Information Technology and Libraries (ITAL)</a></em> and also the <em><a href="http://www.lita.org/newslett/index.html">LITA Newsletter</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.lita.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>LITA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libassociation"><b>library association</b></a>
</dt><dd>A membership organization consisting of a group of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#librarydirector">library director</a>s, and other persons involved with <a href="#library">libraries</a>, who meet periodically to discuss matters of professional interest.  Library <a href="#association">association</a>s elect officers, sponsor <a href="#libconference">conference</a>s, select committees to address specific issues, <a href="#publishing">publish</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a>s and professional <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, and charge <a href="#dues">dues</a> to support the organization's activities.  The largest library association in the United States is the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> (ALA).  Its counterparts in Canada and Great Britain are the <a href="#canadianla">Canadian Library Association</a> (CLA) and the <a href="#cilip">Chartered Institute of Library and Information Professionals</a> (CILIP).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#asist">ASIST</a> and <a href="#sla">SLA</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="la"><b>Library Association (LA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1877, <b>LA</b> is the leading <a href="#libassociation">library association</a> in the United Kingdom, with a membership of 25,000 <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and other <a href="#information">information</a>
professionals, approximately 5.5% of whom are employed overseas.
Divided into twelve geographic branches and over twenty special
interest groups with headquarters in London, <b>LA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>Library Association Record</em>.  Its publishing arm, Library Association Publishing Limited (LAPL), <a href="#issue">issue</a>s approximately thirty <a href="#newbook">new title</a>s each year and maintained a <a href="#backlist">backlist</a> of over 200 <a href="#title">title</a>s.  In April 2002, <b>LA</b> merged with the Institute of Information Scientists (IIS) to form the <a href="#cilip">Chartered Institute of Library and Information Professionals</a> (CILIP).  <a href="http://www.cilip.org.uk/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>CILIP</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryaward"><b>library award</b></a>
</dt><dd>Special honor and recognition given to an individual for outstanding <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a> and/or service to the <a href="#library">library</a> profession.  If an award includes a monetary prize, it is usually funded by an individual or corporate donor, or by a <a href="#libassociation">library association</a>.  Recipients of library awards and scholarships are listed <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly in the <b><em>Bowker Annual Library and Book Trade Almanac</em></b>.  A less extensive list is provided in the <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <em><a href="#ald">American Library Directory</a></em>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lap"><b>Library Awareness Program</b></a>
</dt><dd>An attempt by the FBI to recruit <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s in the United States as "cold warriors" during the 1970s and 1980s, by suggesting that they <a href="#restricted">restrict</a> public <a href="#access">access</a> to un<a href="#classified">classified</a> scientific <a href="#research">research</a>, particularly <a href="#information">information</a> available from the <a href="#ntis">National Technical Information Service</a>
(NTIS). Librarians were asked to report on individuals requesting
certain categories of scientific information, especially foreign
nationals from countries in the Soviet Union. The FBI had the support
of the <a href="#nclis">National Commission on Libraries and Information Science</a> (NCLIS) in this effort, which undermined the <a href="#confidentiality">confidentiality</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> lending <a href="#records">records</a> and open access to library resources.  
<p>
In <b><em>Free Expression and Censorship in America:  An Encyclopedia</em></b>
(Greenwood: 1997), Herbert Foerstel writes that the FBI conducted a
16-month investigation of librarians who openly opposed the <b>Library Awareness Program</b>, even accusing them of being dupes of the Soviet Union.  The program was also opposed by the <a href="#aaup">American Association of University Professors</a>,
the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), and other organizations. In
response to public indignation, many state legislatures passed statutes
making it illegal for any librarian to reveal library records or <a href="#patron">patron</a> requests without a court order. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lbor"><b><em>Library Bill of Rights</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal statement adopted by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> in 1948 and amended in 1961, 1990, and 1996, affirming the right of <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States to provide, to all members of the communities they serve, <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> expressing diverse points of view, and to remain free of <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>.  Implementation of the <b><em>Library Bill of Rights</em></b> is the work of the <a href="http://www.ala.org/oif.html">Office for Intellectual Freedom</a> of the ALA.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/work/freedom/lbr.html">Click here</a> to read the entire <a href="#text">text</a> of the statement.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#ftrs">Freedom to Read Statement</a></em> and <a href="#ifrt">Intellectual Freedom Round Table</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libbinder"><b>library binder</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial <a href="#binder">binder</a> that <a href="#specialization">specializes</a> in serving the needs of <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  Most libraries regularly send their <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s to a library binder to be <a href="#binding">bound</a> into <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a>s.  Special binding may also be needed for heavily used <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s and <a href="#tradepaperback">trade paperback</a>s.  Library binders are organized in the <a href="#lbi">Library Binding Institute</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarybinding"><b>library binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>An especially strong, <a href="#durability">durable</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a> used for <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s and for <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a> worn <a href="#volume">volume</a>s and new <a href="#paperback">paperbound</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s for which <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> is expected to remain high over a comparatively long period of time.  Includes <a href="#prelibrary">pre-library binding</a>.  
<p>
The <a href="#ansi">ANSI</a> <a href="#standard">standard</a> for <a href="#library">library</a> binding, established by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> and the <a href="#lbi">Library Binding Institute</a>, requires that a <a href="#book">book</a> have a <a href="#spine">spine</a> <a href="#gluingoff">glued</a> with <a href="#polyvinylacetate">polyvinyl acetate</a> <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a>, strong <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s, reinforced <a href="#hinge">hinge</a>s, and <a href="#board">board</a>s <a href="#cover">cover</a>ed in <a href="#buckram">buckram</a> coated or impregnated with nonmigratory resin.  Library binding is usually more expensive than the standard <a href="#publishersbinding">publisher's binding</a>.  Compare with <a href="#libraryedition">library edition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#oversewing">oversewing</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lbi"><b>Library Binding Institute (LBI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a> of commercial <a href="#libbinder">library binder</a>s doing business in the United States, Canada, and the U.K., <b>LBI</b> was established in 1935 to create and maintain <a href="#standards">standards</a> for library <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a> and <a href="#prelibrary">prebinding</a>, improve <a href="#binding">binding</a> methods, and facilitate cooperation between <a href="#library">library</a>
binders and between binders and their customers. Membership is also
open to suppliers of library binders and organizations with an interest
in the <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> of <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s.  <b>LBI</b> developed the <a href="#ansi">ANSI</a> standard for <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a> in cooperation with the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  The Institute <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <em>The New Library Scene</em> and technical <a href="#paper">paper</a>s on binding and related <a href="#topic">topic</a>s. <a href="http://www.lbibinders.org/">Click here</a> connect to the <b>LBI</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarybond"><b>library bond</b></a>
</dt><dd>An interest-bearing or discounted security issued by a <a href="#librarydistrict">library district</a>, or by the government entity of which a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> is a part, usually to finance the <a href="#newconstruc">construction</a> and/or <a href="#renovation">renovation</a> of facilities, or some other major <a href="#capitalexp">capital project</a>.
A bond places the library district under a general obligation to pay
the bondholder (investor) a specified amount of interest, usually at
regular intervals, and to repay the principal amount of the loan within
a designated period of time. The bond is backed by a majority of voters
in the district, who consent to be taxed at a slightly higher rate to
raise sufficient revenue to pay the interest and principal on the loan.
Bond measures pass more easily in times of prosperity than in economic
recession.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarycard"><b>library card</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#paper">paper</a> or plastic card issued by a <a href="#library">library</a> to a registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>, which must be presented at the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> in order to <a href="#checkedout">check out</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> from its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  Identification is usually required of new applicants.  In most libraries in the United States, library cards are <a href="#barcode">barcode</a>d for electronic <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>.  Periodic <a href="#renew">renewal</a> may be required to verify current street address and telephone number.  Synonymous with <em>borrower card</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#patronid">patron ID</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryclosure"><b>library closure</b></a>
</dt><dd>The closing of a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#branchlibrary">branch</a> in a <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, temporarily or permanently, usually due to <a href="#budget">budget</a>ary constraints or demographic changes in the area served.  Library closings are announced in the news section of <em><a href="#americanlibraries">American Libraries</a></em>, the <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libcollec"><b>library collection</b></a>
</dt><dd>The total accumulation of <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> owned by a <a href="#library">library</a>, <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> and arranged for ease of <a href="#access">access</a>, which often consists of several smaller collections (<a href="#refcollection">reference</a>, <a href="#circulating">circulating</a> books, <a href="#serial">serials</a>, <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a>, <a href="#rarebook">rare books</a>, <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>, etc.).  The process of building a library collection over time is called <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>.  Synonymous with <a href="#holdings">holdings</a>.  Compare with <a href="#collection">collection</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#electroniccollec">electronic collection</a>, <a href="#highriskcollec">high-risk collection</a>, <a href="#rentalcollec">rental collection</a>, <a href="#subjectcollec">subject collection</a>, and <a href="#testcollec">test collection</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libconference"><b>library conference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal gathering of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#librarydirector">library director</a>s, and others associated with <a href="#library">libraries</a>,
for the purpose of meeting colleagues, discussing issues and events,
and learning about new products, services, technologies, and recent
developments in the <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a> profession.  Most <a href="#libassociation">library association</a>s sponsor regular <a href="#conference">conference</a>s at which officers are elected, committees and <a href="#taskforce">task force</a>s formed, policies formulated, <a href="#libraryaward">award</a>s announced, etc.  <em>Conferees</em> are generally charged a registration fee based on the sections of the conference they plan to attend.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#preconference">preconference</a> and <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a>. 
<p>
The <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> sponsors two
national conferences each year, one during the summer in a different
city each year, and the other at mid-winter in Chicago. The state
chapters of the ALA, and some of its major divisions, sponsor their own
conferences, as does the <a href="#sla">Special Libraries Association</a> and <a href="#asist">ASIST</a>.  The permanent <a href="#roundtable">round table</a>s of the ALA convene concurrently with the national conferences. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarycoop"><b>library cooperation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Methods by which <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s work together for the mutual benefit of their users, including <a href="#centralizedproc">centralized processing</a>, <a href="#cooperativecat">cooperative cataloging</a>, international exchange of bibliographic <a href="#information">information</a>, <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a>s, <a href="#resourcesharing">resource sharing</a>, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarydirector"><b>library director</b></a>
</dt><dd>The person who has overall responsibility for supervising the operations of a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, including <a href="#strategicplanning">planning</a>, <a href="#budget">budget</a>ing, policy-making, personnel management, and program <a href="#assessment">assessment</a>.  In <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, the library director is usually subject to the oversight of a <a href="#board">board</a> of <a href="#librarytrustee">trustee</a>s; in <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, by a dean of academic affairs or provost.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#libadmin">library administration</a> and <a href="#lama">Library Administration and Management Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarydiscount"><b>library discount</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#discount">discount</a> off the <a href="#listprice">list price</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, given by most <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s and <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>s on purchases made by an institutional <a href="#library">library</a>.
Most publishers offer a flat rate, usually 5-10%. Jobbers may link the
discount rate to size of order or volume of purchasing. As a general
rule, <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s are given a <a href="#shortdiscount">shorter discount</a> than <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a>s, or not discounted at all because of their limited sales potential. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarydistrict"><b>library district</b></a>
</dt><dd>An officially delineated geographic area in which the residents decide by popular vote whether to provide tax support for a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>,
or one of the geographical areas into which a state is divided for the
purpose of administering libraries in accordance with a comprehensive
state-wide tax plan. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#servicearea">service area</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryedition"><b>library edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a <a href="#binding">binding</a> stronger and more <a href="#durability">durable</a> than the usual <a href="#publishersbinding">publisher's binding</a>, for marketing specifically to <a href="#library">libraries</a>, usually more expensive than the <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a> of the same <a href="#title">title</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a> and <a href="#prelibrary">pre-library bound</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryeducation"><b>library education</b></a>
</dt><dd>Educational programs designed to prepare students for the post-baccalaureate degree of <a href="#mls">M.L.S.</a> or <a href="#mlis">M.L.I.S.</a>, taught by the faculty of a university department known as a <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> (or school of <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>).  Modern library education began in 1887 when <a href="#deweymelvil">Melvil Dewey</a> founded the first school for training professional <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s at Columbia University.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#alise">Association for Library &amp; Information Science Education</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryequipment"><b>library equipment</b></a>
</dt><dd>Mechanical and electronic devices purchased by a <a href="#library">library</a> for <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> use, or to facilitate <a href="#patron">patron</a> use of its services and <a href="#collection">collection</a>s, including <a href="#photocopier">photocopy machine</a>s, <a href="#microform">microform</a> <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a>s, <a href="#videocassette">video</a> and <a href="#compactdisc">CD</a> players, projection equipment, computers and computer <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a>s, <a href="#securitysystem">security</a> devices, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryextension"><b>library extension</b></a>
</dt><dd>Programs and activities that enable a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> to deliver traditional services outside the physical walls of its facilities, including <a href="#bookmobile">bookmobile</a>s, <a href="#booksbymail">books-by-mail</a>, and <a href="#directdelivery">direct delivery</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">library material</a>s to <a href="#patron">patron</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#outreach">library outreach</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryfaculty"><b>library faculty</b></a>
</dt><dd>The professionally trained <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s employed at an academic institution that grants <a href="#facultystatus">faculty status</a> to librarians.  One of the advantages of faculty status is the right to participate in <a href="#governance">governance</a>.  At some institutions, library faculty are members of the same <a href="#collectivebargaining">collective bargaining unit</a> as the teaching faculty.  Whether they are eligible for <a href="#tenure">tenure</a> and <a href="#promotion">promotion</a> to the same <a href="#rank">rank</a>s as the teaching faculty depends on the <a href="#contract">contract</a> governing employment.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#acadstatus">academic status</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryhand"><b>library hand</b></a>
</dt><dd>A highly <a href="#legibility">legible</a>, uniform style of handwriting traditionally used by <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s for making <a href="#entry">entries</a> in <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s before the typewriter came into widespread use.  With the <a href="#dataconversion">conversion</a> of <a href="#cardcatalog">card catalog</a>s into <a href="#file">file</a>s of <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s, <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a>s have fallen into disuse and handwritten catalog entries are rarely seen. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryhistorian"><b>library historian</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#researcher">researcher</a> who writes about the history of <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>, from ancient to modern times.  <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s with an interest in library history are organized in the <a href="#lhrt">Library History Round Table</a> (LHRT) of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lhrt"><b>Library History Round Table (LHRT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> dedicated to facilitating communication among scholars and students of <a href="#library">library</a> history, supporting <a href="#research">research</a> in library history, and addressing current issues of concern to <a href="#libraryhistorian">library historian</a>s, such as <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> and <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>.  <b>LHRT</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> <em>LHRT Newsletter</em>.  <a href="http://www.spertus.edu/library-history/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>LHRT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryhours"><b>library hours</b></a>
</dt><dd>The hours during which a <a href="#library">library</a> is open to its users, and any days when it is <em>not</em> open, usually posted near the entrance or at the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a>.  Libraries also make their hours available by telephone and via their <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s.  Because staffing is required to keep a library facility open, hours often reflect <a href="#budget">budget</a>ary constraints.  Most libraries are equipped with a <a href="#bookdrop">book drop</a> for returning <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s when the facility is closed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryhumor"><b>library humor</b></a>
</dt><dd>Jokes, <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>s, anecdotes, unusual <a href="#refquestion">reference question</a>s, witticisms, <a href="#satire">satire</a>, occupational folklore, etc., having to do with <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>.  <a href="http://mel.lib.mi.us/libraries/LIBS-humor.html">Click Here</a> to connect to a list of <a href="#website">Web site</a>s on "Humor and Culture in Libraries" compliments of the Michigan Electronic Library.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryinstruction"><b>library instruction</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lirt"><b>Library Instruction Round Table (LIRT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> dedicated to promoting formal and informal <a href="#bi">library instruction</a> in all types of <a href="#library">libraries</a>, as a means of helping library users acquire the <a href="#infoliteracy">information literacy</a> skills essential for <a href="#lifelong">lifelong learning</a>.  <a href="http://www3.baylor.edu/LIRT/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>LIRT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libjournal"><b>library journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A professional <a href="#journal">journal</a> devoted to the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of <a href="#article">article</a>s about <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>, <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>, and related <a href="#topic">topic</a>s.  Most library journals also <a href="#publishing">publish</a> <a href="#review">review</a>s of new <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, including <a href="#book">book</a>s of professional interest to <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s.  <a href="http://www.yahoo.com/Reference/Libraries/Library_and_Information_Science/Journals/">Click here</a> to see the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of <a href="#online">online</a> library journals. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryjournal"><b><em>Library Journal (LJ)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1876, <b><em>Library Journal</em></b> is a combination <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a>/<a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 20 <a href="#issue">issue</a>s per year by Cahner Business Information, a division of Elsevier.  <b><em>LJ</em></b> publishes news and announcements of interest to <a href="#library">library</a> professionals, feature <a href="#article">article</a>s, commentary, analysis of trends, regular <a href="#column">column</a>s, and approximately 7,500 <a href="#review">review</a>s per year of <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, <a href="#database">database</a>s and <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>s, <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>s, and <a href="#bookontape">books-on-tape</a> suitable for general <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s aimed at <a href="#adult">adult</a> <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.  The reviews are short but evaluative, written by and for <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s.  <a href="#libmaterials">Materials</a> published for <a href="#childrensbook">children</a> and <a href="#youngadult">young adult</a>s are reviewed in <em><a href="#slj">School Library Journal</a></em>.  <a href="http://libraryjournal.reviewsnews.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> version of <b><em>Library Journal</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarylaw"><b>library law</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#liblegislation">library legislation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="liblegislation"><b>library legislation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Laws passed by a federal or state legislative body, pertaining to or affecting the interests of <a href="#library">libraries</a> and related institutions (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="#dmca">Digital Millennium Copyright Act</a></em> of 1998).  Through their professional <a href="#libassociation">association</a>s, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and <a href="#libraryadvocate">library advocate</a>s seek to influence legislative decision-making in ways that will benefit libraries and their users.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/work/legislation.html">Click here</a> to explore the legislative priorities and activities of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  Synonymous with <em>library law</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="liblit"><b><em>Library Literature</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#librarylit">Library Literature &amp; Information Science</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarylit"><b><em>Library Literature &amp; Information Science (LLIS)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publishing">Published</a> since 1934 by <a href="#hwwilson">H. W. Wilson</a>, <b><em>Library Literature &amp; Information Science</em></b> is an <a href="#author">author</a> and <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#index">index</a> to the English-<a href="#language">language</a> <a href="#literature">literature</a> of <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>, covering <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, and <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> <a href="#thesis">theses</a>, with book <a href="#review">review</a>s listed in a separate section at the end of each <a href="#volume">volume</a>.  Published from 1934-1998 under the <a href="#title">title</a> <em>Library Literature</em>, <b><em>LLIS</em></b> is available in <a href="#print">print</a> in <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>s <a href="#cumulativeindex">cumulated</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly.  It is also available as an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> directly from the Wilson Company or via <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#firstsearch">FirstSearch</a></em> (1980 to the present).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#lisa">Library and Information Science Abstracts (LISA)</a></em>.      
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libmanagement"><b>library management</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#libadmin">library administration</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarymarket"><b>library market</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portion of the market for <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s generated by sales to <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s, and related organizations such as museums, <a href="#archives">archives</a>, and <a href="#research">research</a> institutions.  The library market is segmented by type of library (<a href="#publiclibrary">public</a>, <a href="#academiclib">academic</a>, <a href="#schoollibrary">school</a>, <a href="#speciallibrary">special</a>, etc.).  <a href="#publisher">Publisher</a>s and <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>s market their products to libraries by <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ing at <a href="#libconference">library conference</a>s, advertising in library <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a>s and <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>s, offering special library <a href="#librarydiscount">discount</a>s and <a href="#prepubprice">prepublication price</a>s, and direct mail advertising (<a href="#tradecatalog">trade catalog</a>s and <a href="#brochure">brochure</a>s).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libmaterials"><b>library materials</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s purchased by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> to satisfy the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of its users, including <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, <a href="#refbook">reference materials</a>, music <a href="#score">score</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#microform">microform</a>s, and <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#media">media</a>, as distinct from <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a> and <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a>.  Some libraries include <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s to electronic resources in the materials <a href="#budget">budget</a>, others fund them separately.  Except for <a href="#gift">gift</a>s and special <a href="#endowment">endowment</a>s, the <a href="#acquisitions">acquisition</a> of library materials is normally funded through the <a href="#operatingbudget">operating budget</a>.  The rapid escalation of <a href="#journal">journal</a> subscription prices over the past decade has forced many <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> to cancel periodical subscriptions to maintain balance between expenditures for books and <a href="#serial">serial</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lc"><b>Library of Congress (LC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established by Congress in 1800 to function as a <a href="#researchlib">research library</a> for the legislative branch of the federal government, the <b>Library of Congress</b> eventually became the unofficial <a href="#nationallib">national library</a> of the United States.  Located in Washington D.C., <b>LC</b> houses a collection of over 120 million <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s and administers the U.S. <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> system, serving as the nation's copyright <a href="#depository">depository</a>.  <b>LC</b> is also the primary source of <a href="#originalcataloging">original cataloging</a> in the United States.  The <a href="#machinecat">machine-readable cataloging</a> (MARC) and <a href="#cip">cataloging-in-publication</a> (CIP) programs originated at the Library of Congress.  <a href="http://www.loc.gov/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>LC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  Compare with <a href="#nara">NARA</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#librariancongress">Librarian of Congress</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lccatnumber"><b>Library of Congress Catalog Number</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lccn">Library of Congress Control Number (LCCN)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lcclassification"><b>Library of Congress Classification (LCC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A system of <a href="#classificationsys">classifying</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> developed and maintained over the last 200 years by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> in Washington, D.C.  In <b>LCC</b>, human <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> is divided into 20 broad categories indicated by single <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the roman <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>, with major subdivisions indicated by a second letter, and narrower subdivisions by <a href="#decimalpoint">decimal</a> <a href="#number">number</a>s and further alphabetic <a href="#notation">notation</a>.  
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>LC call number:</em>  <b>PE 3727.N4 M34 1994</b></dd></dl>
<p>
In the example given above, assigned to the book <em>Juba to Jive: A Dictionary of African-American Slang</em> <a href="#edited">edited</a> by Clarence Major, <b>P</b> represents the <a href="#mainclass">main class</a> "Language and literature," <b>PE</b> the <a href="#class">class</a> "English language," <b>3727</b> the <a href="#subclass">subclass</a> "English slang," and <b>N4</b> African-Americans as a special group.  <b>M34</b> is the <a href="#cutternumber">Cutter number</a> for the <a href="#editor">editor</a>'s <a href="#surname">surname</a> and <b>1994</b> the <a href="#publicationdate">year of publication</a>.
</p><p>
In the United States, most <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> use <b>LCC</b>, while most <a href="#schoollibrary">school libraries</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> use <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/lcco/lcco.html">Click here</a> to see an <a href="#outline">outline</a> of LC Classification and <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/cpso.html#subjects">here</a> for the <em>LC Classification Weekley Lists</em>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lccn"><b>Library of Congress Control Number (LCCN)</b></a>
</dt><dd>When the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> began <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a>s in 1898 and distributing them in 1901, a unique Library of Congress Card Number was assigned to each <a href="#bibitem">item</a> for identification and <a href="#bibcontrol">control</a>.  With the development of <a href="#machinecat">machine-readable</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> in the late 1960s, <b>LCCN</b> became the Library of Congress Control Number.  It is used in <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s and also in <a href="#authorityrecord">authority</a> and <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> records.  The <b>LCCN</b> is assigned to a <a href="#publication">publication</a> after the <a href="#depositcopy">deposit copy</a> is received by the <a href="#usco">U.S. Copyright Office</a>, or in advance of the <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> if a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> requests <a href="#cip">cataloging-in-publication</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#accessionnumber">accession number</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lcri"><b><em>Library of Congress Rule Interpretations (LCRI)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> service that provides <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#information">information</a> on recent decisions of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> concerning the interpretation of the most recent revision of <em><a href="#anglo">Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</a></em> (<em>AACR2</em>).  <b><em>LCRI</em></b> is <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#print">print</a> and as part of <em><a href="#catalogersdesktop">Cataloger's Desktop</a></em> available on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lcsh"><b>Library of Congress subject heading (LCSH)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A descriptive word or phrase selected by a <a href="#subjectspecialist">subject specialist</a> at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> from the list of <b><em>Library of Congress Subject Headings</em></b> and assigned to a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> when first <a href="#publishing">published</a> to indicate its <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  Multiple <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s are assigned when necessary or desirable.  The complete list of LC subject headings is published <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly in a multi-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#set">set</a> known to <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s as "the big red books," usually available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most large <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, and in the <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> department of smaller libraries.
