Compare with <a href="#sears">Sears subject heading</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="liborientation"><b>library orientation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryportal"><b>library portal</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#software">Software</a> that allows a computer user to customize <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of <a href="#information">information</a> resources by creating a list of <a href="#internet">Internet</a> connections, much like a personalized <a href="#directory">directory</a> of street addresses and telephone/FAX numbers (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>MyLibrary</em></b>).  The purpose is to reduce <a href="#infooverload">information overload</a> by allowing <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to select only the resources they wish to display on their personal <a href="#interface">interface</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libpublication"><b>library publication</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> produced and distributed by a <a href="#library">library</a>, for example, a <a href="#brochure">brochure</a> intended for users, describing the library facility, its resources, and the services provided by its <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>.  Most library <a href="#publication">publication</a>s are <a href="#ephemera">ephemeral</a>, but large <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> <a href="#publishing">publish</a> more permanent works.  A recent example:  Alixe Bovey's <b><em>Monsters and Grotesques in Medieval Manuscripts</em></b> published by the British Library in 2002.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryrate"><b>library rate</b></a>
</dt><dd>A significantly lower postal rate charged to <a href="#library">libraries</a> and related nonprofit institutions by the U.S. Postal Service for <a href="#book">book</a>s and other educational materials sent by mail.  The law was amended in 1976 to allow <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s and distributors to use the rate when <a href="#shipping">shipping</a> books and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> to libraries.  The lower rate has allowed <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> to offer <a href="#booksbymail">books-by-mail</a> programs to <a href="#homebound">homebound</a> <a href="#patron">patron</a>s, and has helped keep down the cost of <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> service.  Compare with <a href="#mediarate">media mail</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryrep"><b>library rep</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#libraryrepresentative">library representative</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryrepresentative"><b>library representative</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s sales representative responsible for calling on <a href="#library">libraries</a>, usually within an established territory, to solicit orders for <a href="#title">title</a>s on the publisher's <a href="#list">list</a>.  Contacts are made, usually by telephone or in person, with <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s responsible for <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> and <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>.  Also refers to a <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>'s representative, responsible for soliciting <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s to <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s and <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> resources, usually trained to give demonstrations to library <a href="#selection">selection</a> committees.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>library rep</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryresearch"><b>library research</b></a>
</dt><dd>Systematic study and investigation of some aspect of <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>, in which conclusions are based on the statistical analysis of <a href="#data">data</a> collected in accordance with a pre-established <a href="#research">research</a> design and methodology.  Results are usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a professional <a href="#libjournal">library journal</a>, or presented at a <a href="#libconference">library conference</a> and subsequently published in its <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a>.
Library research helps expand the theoretical base of library and
information science, and also provides data necessary for effective <a href="#libadmin">administrative</a> decision-making and problem-solving.  Research on libraries and <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a> published in the previous year is reported in an <a href="#essay">essay</a> in the <em>Bowker Annual Library and Book Trade Almanac</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#librarysurvey">library survey</a> and <a href="#lrrt">Library Research Round Table</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lrrt"><b>Library Research Round Table (LRRT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1968 as a permanent <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>LRRT</b> is dedicated to fostering <a href="#libraryresearch">library research</a> by providing program opportunities for <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s to describe and disseminate their work, and by informing and educating ALA members about <a href="#research">research</a> techniques and the importance of research as a foundation for effective <a href="#libadmin">administrative</a> decision-making and problem-solving.  <b>LRRT</b> also gives annual <a href="#libraryaward">award</a>s for distinguished <a href="#publishing">published</a> research and excellence in doctoral research.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/lrrt/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>LRRT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryschool"><b>library school</b></a>
</dt><dd>A professional school or department qualified to grant the post-baccalaureate degree of <a href="#mls">M.L.S.</a> or <a href="#mlis">M.L.I.S.</a>,
supported and administered by an institution of higher learning to
prepare graduate students for employment in professional positions in <a href="#library">libraries</a> and as <a href="#information">information</a> service providers.  The first modern library school was established by <a href="#deweymelvil">Melvil Dewey</a> at Columbia University in 1887.  Library schools may be <a href="#accredited">accredited</a> or <a href="#approved">approved</a> (or both).  Length of program varies.  Synonymous with <em>school of librarianship</em>.  Library schools in the United States and Canada are listed by state and province in a section of the <em><a href="#ald">American Library Directory</a></em>, <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.  <a href="http://informationr.net/wl/">Click here</a> to connect to an <a href="#online">online</a> <b><em>World List of Departments and Schools of Information Studies...</em></b>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryscience"><b>library science</b></a>
</dt><dd>The professional <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> and skill with which <a href="#record">record</a>ed <a href="#information">information</a> is <a href="#selection">selected</a>, <a href="#acquisitions">acquired</a>, organized, stored, maintained, retrieved, and disseminated to meet the needs of a specific <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>, usually taught at a professional <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> qualified to grant the post-baccalaureate degree of <a href="#mls">M.L.S.</a> or <a href="#mlis">M.L.I.S.</a>  The <a href="#term">term</a> is used synonymously in the United States with <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>.  Compare with <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lsca"><b><em>Library Services and Construction Act (LSCA)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Passed by Congress in 1956, the Library Services Act (LSA) provided federal funding for the extension of <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> services to the unserved, mainly in rural areas.  In 1964, Congress expanded its scope to permit federal <a href="#grantinaid">grants-in-aid</a> for construction <em>and</em> expansion of <a href="#library">library</a> services in all areas with inadequate services, including urban communities.  Over a period of thirty years, the effect of <b><em>LSCA</em></b> on public library construction was comparable to the earlier era of <a href="#carnegielibrary">Carnegie</a> philanthropy.  In its final phase, <b><em>LSCA</em></b> funding was extended to <a href="#adult">adult</a> <a href="#literacy">literacy</a> programs and <a href="#outreach">outreach</a> services to the children and youth of poor families, homeless persons, and the physically disabled. 
<p>
In 1996, following a proposal by a task force consisting of the Chief Officers of the <a href="#statelibrary">State Libraries</a> (COSLA), the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> (ALA), and the <a href="#ulc">Urban Libraries Council</a> (ULC), Congress passed the <em><a href="#lsta">Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA)</a></em> as part of the <em>Museum and Library Services Act</em>, replacing the eight titles of the <b><em>LSCA</em></b> with two new titles and consolidating the administration of federal library programs under the <a href="#imls">Institute for Museum and Library Services</a> (IMLS).   
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lsta"><b><em>Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A section of the <em>Museum and Library Services Act</em> of 1996, <b><em>LSTA</em></b> promotes <a href="#access">access</a> to learning and to the <a href="#information">information</a> resources provided by all types of <a href="#library">libraries</a>, by distributing federal funds to <a href="#statelibrary">state library</a> <a href="#govtagency">agencies</a>
under a formula based on population. State libraries may use the
appropriations to support state-wide initiatives and services, or
distribute funds to <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a>, <a href="#academiclib">academic</a>, <a href="#researchlib">research</a>, <a href="#schoollibrary">school</a>, and <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a> within their state, through sub-<a href="#grant">grant</a> competitions and cooperative agreements.  In the year 2000, more than $138 million in <b><em>LSTA</em></b> funds was distributed to state library agencies.  <a href="http://www.imls.gov/grants/library/lib_gsla.asp">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#imls">Institute of Museum and Library Services</a> <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> on <b><em>LSTA</em></b> <a href="#grantinaid">grants-in-aid</a>.  For a brief history of the origins of <b><em>LSTA</em></b>, see <em><a href="#lsca">Library Services and Construction Act (LSCA)</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarystaff"><b>library staff</b></a>
</dt><dd>The entire group of paid employees responsible for the operation and management of a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, including its <a href="#librarydirector">director</a>, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#paraprofessional">paraprofessional</a>s, technical assistants, clerical personnel, and <a href="#page">page</a>s or <a href="#studentassistant">student assistant</a>s.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> at institutions that grant librarians <a href="#facultystatus">faculty status</a>,
a distinction is usually made between faculty members and nonfaculty
staff. In other types of libraries, a distinction may be made between
professionally trained librarians and <a href="#supportstaff">support staff</a>.  <a href="#volunteer">Volunteer</a>s are not considered part of the staff because they are unpaid.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libstats"><b>library statistics</b></a>
</dt><dd>Numerical <a href="#data">data</a> assembled, <a href="#classification">classified</a>, and <a href="#table">tabulated</a> to present useful facts and <a href="#information">information</a> about the operation of a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, or about the activities of libraries at the local, state, provincial, or national level, usually in the form of a periodic <a href="#report">report</a>.  <a href="http://libws66.lib.niu.edu/libstats/etst.htm">Click here</a> to connect to the <em>LIBSTATS</em> <a href="#website">Web site</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#circstats">circulation statistics</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarysupplies"><b>library supplies</b></a>
</dt><dd>Expendable materials such as <a href="#label">label</a>s, <a href="#bookcard">book card</a>s and <a href="#bookpocket">pocket</a>s, <a href="#datedueslip">date due slip</a>s, <a href="#rubberstamp">rubber stamp</a>s, <a href="#mending">mending</a> tape, <a href="#magneticstrip">magnetic strip</a>s, plastic <a href="#sleeve">sleeve</a>s, <a href="#lamination">laminate</a>, <a href="#paper">paper</a> for <a href="#printing">printing</a> and <a href="#photocopy">photocopy</a>ing, etc., which a <a href="#library">library</a> must order from a library <a href="#supplier">supplier</a> in order to prepare new <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s for <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>, maintain <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, and provide services.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#brodart">Brodart</a>, <a href="#gaylord">Gaylord</a>, and <a href="#highsmith">Highsmith</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarysurvey"><b>library survey</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written or oral question-and-answer instrument designed to elicit <a href="#feedback">feedback</a> from <a href="#library">library</a> users.  Library surveys are administered by <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>, or by an outside <a href="#agency">agency</a>, to determine how well the library's services, programs, and <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s meet user needs and any <a href="#objective">objective</a>s established by the <a href="#libadmin">library administration</a> and/or governing institution.  They are also used to generate <a href="#data">data</a> in <a href="#libraryresearch">library research</a>.  Also refers to the <a href="#report">report</a> produced as the result of such a study.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarysystem"><b>library system</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of <a href="#library">libraries</a> administered in common, for example, a <a href="#centrallib">central library</a> and its <a href="#branchlibrary">branch</a>es
or auxiliary outlets. Also, a group of independently administered
libraries joined by formal or informal agreement to achieve a common
purpose. Under such an arrangement, each library is considered an <a href="#affiliatedlibrary">affiliate</a>.  Compare with <a href="#consortium">consortium</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarytour"><b>library tour</b></a>
</dt><dd>A guided walk through a <a href="#library">library</a> facility, usually conducted by a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or library assistant, to orient new users to the location of services and resources.  Some libraries have installed <a href="#online">online</a> library tours on their <a href="#website">Web site</a>s, which include clickable <a href="#floorplan">floor plan</a>s <a href="#link">link</a>ed to <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s and descriptive <a href="#text">text</a>.  Not to be confused with <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarytrustee"><b>library trustee</b></a>
</dt><dd>A member of an appointed or elected <a href="#board">board</a> responsible for overseeing the growth and development of a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, including long-range planning and policy-making, <a href="#publicrelations">public relations</a>, and <a href="#fundraising">fund-raising</a>.  Trustees are usually <a href="#libraryadvocate">library advocate</a>s but may sometimes be political appointees.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#alta">Association of Library Trustees and Advocates</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libraryuseonly"><b>library use only</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> code written on or affixed to a physical <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> and entered in the <a href="#itemrecord">item record</a> in the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, indicating that it is <a href="#available">available</a> for use within the walls of the <a href="#library">library</a>, but may not be <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> and removed from the premises except by special arrangement.  The use of <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s, <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es, and in some cases <a href="#binding">bound</a> and/or <a href="#unbound">unbound</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s is generally restricted to the library.  Use of items in <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>, such as <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, may even be restricted to a designated room or area of the library.  Compare with <a href="#noncirculating">noncirculating</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#inhouseuse">in-house use</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="librarywithoutwalls"><b>library without walls</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#virtuallibrary">virtual library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libretto"><b>libretto</b></a>
</dt><dd>The words or <a href="#text">text</a> to which a cantata, oratorio, opera, operetta, or other <a href="#musicalwork">work</a> for the musical stage is set, often <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the form of a small <a href="#pamphlet">booklet</a> for enthusiasts who wish to follow along while attending a performance or listening to a <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>.  The person who writes a libretto is the <em>librettist</em> (<em>example</em>:  Edna St. Vincent Millay for <em>The King's Henchman</em>, an opera <a href="#composer">composed</a> by Deems Taylor).  To find librettos <a href="#online">online</a>, try a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> <a href="#search">search</a> on the <a href="#term">term</a> "librettos" in <em><a href="http://www.yahoo.com/">Yahoo!</a></em>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="libweb"><b><em>Libweb</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A very <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> worldwide <a href="#directory">directory</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>s, <a href="#updated">updated</a> daily on the Berkeley Digital Library <a href="#website">Web site</a>.  <a href="http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/Libweb/">Click here</a> to connect to <b><em>Libweb</em></b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#libdex">LibDex</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="license"><b>license</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="licensedbook"><b>licensed book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#author">author</a> makes use of a <a href="#character">character</a> or product subject to <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> restrictions, for example, a <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a> based on a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>
character (Mickey Mouse) or a commercially successful toy (Barbie). Use
is by permission of the copyright holder under the terms of a <em>licensing agreement</em> handled by the copyright owner's <em>licensing agent</em>.  Although the sales potential of licensed books makes them popular with retail <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, they are as a general rule not purchased for <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="licensing"><b>licensing agreement</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal written contract between a <a href="#library">library</a> and a <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> for the lease of one or more <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> (<a href="#copyright">copyright</a>ed) <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s or <a href="#online">online</a> resources, usually for a fixed period of time in exchange for payment of an <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> <a href="#fee">fee</a> or <a href="#persearch">per-search</a> charge.  Vendors typically charge libraries on a sliding scale based on <a href="#number">number</a> of registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s or <a href="#fte">FTE</a> enrollment, number of institutions or facilities served, and number of <a href="#simultaneous">simultaneous user</a>s.  Most licensing agreements limit <a href="#remoteaccess">remote access</a> to registered users.  For more <a href="#information">information</a> about licensing, see the final <a href="#draft">draft</a> of <em><a href="http://www.arl.org/scomm/licensing/principles.html">Principles for Licensing Electronic Resources</a></em> developed by the <a href="#aall">AALL</a>, <a href="#ala">ALA</a>, <a href="#aahsl">AAHSL</a>, <a href="#arl">ARL</a>, <a href="#medicallibassoc">MLA</a>, and <a href="#sla">SLA</a>.  Compare with <a href="#sitelicense">site license</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lifelong"><b>lifelong learning</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of the goals of <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a> and <a href="#infoliteracy">information literacy</a> programs is to help <a href="#library">library</a> users obtain the skills they need to pursue <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> at any age, independent of a formal educational institution.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> play an important role in meeting this need because they provide <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in a wide range of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s at various <a href="#readinglevel">reading level</a>s, not only for students enrolled in a formal curriculum, but for anyone interested in reading and learning.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ligature"><b>ligature</b></a>
</dt><dd>Two or more <a href="#letter">letter</a>s joined together in <a href="#printing">printing</a>, such as the double <em>ff</em> joined at the cross-stroke in some <a href="#font">font</a>s.  Also refers to the stroke that joins the two letters.  In <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a>, a ligature is cast as a single unit of <a href="#type">type</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lightface"><b>lightface</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> in which the <a href="#character">character</a>s are the same <a href="#typesize">size</a> as <a href="#medium">medium</a>-<a href="#weight">weight</a> and <a href="#boldface">boldface</a> <a href="#type">type</a> of the same <a href="#font">font</a>, but composed of thinner strokes that do not appear as dark on the <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#page">page</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lightpen"><b>light-pen</b></a>
</dt><dd>A metal <a href="#stylus">stylus</a> equipped with a light sensor on one end for <a href="#scanner">scanning</a> <a href="#barcode">barcode</a>s at the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a>.  Some models require an <a href="#externaldecoder">external decoder</a>.  Synonymous with <em>bar code wand</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lignin"><b>lignin</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organic substance contained in wood <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>, considered undesirable in all but the lowest grades of <a href="#paper">paper</a> because it contains <a href="#acidic">acid</a> which weakens the <a href="#cellulose">cellulose</a> in vegetable fiber, causing paper, <a href="#board">board</a>, and cloth to <a href="#yellowing">yellow</a> and become <a href="#brittle">brittle</a>
over time. Lignin is removed in the manufacture of chemical pulp, but
not in the production of groundwood pulp from which inexpensive papers
such as <a href="#newsprint">newsprint</a> are made.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ligue"><b>Ligue des Bibliotheques Europeenes de Recherche (LIBER)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The European version of the  <a href="#arl">Association of Research Libraries</a>, <b>LIBER</b> is a nongovernmental <a href="#association">association</a> of the <a href="#nationallib">national</a>, <a href="#universitylib">university</a>, and <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> of Europe, founded in 1971 by an <a href="#ifla">IFLA</a> steering group under the auspices of the Council of Europe.  Its goal is to assist in establishing a functional <a href="#network">network</a> of <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#library">libraries</a> throughout Europe, improve <a href="#access">access</a> to research <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s and services, facilitate research <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>, and help preserve the European cultural heritage.  <b>LIBER</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> <em>LIBER Quarterly</em> and sponsors a <a href="#conference">conference</a> in a different country each year.  <a href="http://www.kb.dk/liber/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>LIBER</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lilliput"><b>lilliput edition</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#miniatureedition">miniature edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="limerick"><b>limerick</b></a>
</dt><dd>A five-line <a href="#poetry">poem</a> written in light <a href="#verse">verse</a> in which the rhymes (in a/a/b/b/a scheme) are highly original and often irreverent to the point of being <a href="#unprintable">unprintable</a>.  The earliest examples are from the 18th century <a href="#nurseryrhyme">nursery rhyme</a> <a href="#collection">collection</a> <b><em>Mother Goose Melodies for Children</em></b> ("Hickory dickory dock...").  A brief <a href="http://www.wcsu.edu/library/www.cc.emory.edu/ENGLISH/classes/Handbook/limerick.html">discussion of the limerick form</a> is available <a href="#online">online</a> compliments of the English Department at Emory University.  <a href="http://www.yesterdaysisland.com/main_pages/limerick.html">Click here</a> to read a sampling of limericks found in a June 14, 1924 <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a Nantucket <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="limitation"><b>limitation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The statement that certifies the total <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#copy">copies</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> in a <a href="#limitededition">limited edition</a>, usually appearing on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> preceding the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  The statement usually notes any special qualities of the <a href="#edition">edition</a> (<a href="#largepaperedition">large paper</a>, special <a href="#binding">binding</a>, etc.) and provides a <a href="#blank">blank</a> space for the number of each copy to be entered by hand.  Synonymous with <a href="#certificate">certificate of issue</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="limitededition"><b>limited edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> consisting of a predetermined <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#copy">copies</a> (usually 200 to 500, seldom more than 1500) which the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> intends not to <a href="#reprint">reprint</a> in exactly the same form.  If the individual copies are consecutively numbered, each copy usually bears a <a href="#certificate">certificate of issue</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> preceding the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, indicating the size of the edition and copy number.  Individual copies may also be <a href="#autograph">autograph</a>ed by the <a href="#author">author</a>.  If a <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a> of the same <a href="#work">work</a> is also <a href="#issue">issue</a>d, the limited edition is usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on finer <a href="#paper">paper</a>, given a better quality <a href="#binding">binding</a>, and sold at a higher price.  In the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, a copy of a limited edition usually commands a higher price because of its <a href="#rarity">rarity</a>.  Compare with <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#overs">overs</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="limiter"><b>limiter</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#limiting">limiting</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="limiting"><b>limiting</b></a>
</dt><dd>A feature of a well-designed <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> that allows the user to employ various <a href="#parameter">parameter</a>s to restrict the <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a> of <a href="#entry">entries</a> containing the <a href="#term">term</a>s included in the <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>.  Limits may be set <em>before</em> a <a href="#search">search</a> is executed, <em>after</em> results are displayed, or both, depending on the design of the system.  <em>Limiters</em> are not <a href="#standardization">standardized</a> but typically include:  <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, <a href="#materialtype">material type</a>, <a href="#language">language</a>, <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a>, <a href="#peerreviewed">peer-reviewed</a> (<a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s), and locally <a href="#holdings">held</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="limpbinding"><b>limp binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> without <a href="#board">board</a>s in flexible <a href="#leather">leather</a>, <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>, or <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s, lined or unlined, a style used mainly for <a href="#diary">diaries</a>, devotional <a href="#work">work</a>s, and light <a href="#verse">verse</a>.  The <a href="#squares">squares</a> in limp binding often extend further beyond the edges of the <a href="#section">section</a>s than in a normal binding.  Compare with <a href="#flexiblebinding">flexible binding</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#yapp">Yapp binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lineart"><b>line art</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> of <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> quality done in black-and-white, as opposed to a <a href="#halftone">half-tone</a> in which the range of tonal values in the <a href="#original">original</a> is rendered by converting the image into a field of minutely graded dots.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="linedrawing"><b>line drawing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A drawing executed entirely in lines without the use of
shading, hatching, or some other graphic technique to add depth or
volume to the image. <a href="#cartoon">Cartoon</a>s, <a href="#caricature">caricature</a>s, and <a href="#diagram">diagram</a>s are often done in this style.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lineitem"><b>line-item budget</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#budget">budget</a>ing used in some <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s in which anticipated expenditures are divided into discrete functional categories called "lines" (<a href="#salary">salaries</a> and <a href="#wages">wages</a>, <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, etc.) for the purpose of systematically <a href="#allocation">allocating</a> resources and tracking <a href="#operatingbudget">operating expenditures</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lining"><b>lining</b></a>
</dt><dd>Materials applied to the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> with <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a>, following <a href="#rounding">rounding</a> and <a href="#backing">backing</a>, to hold the <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s together securely, usually a piece of thin, loosely woven fabric called <a href="#crash">crash</a> (<em>gauze</em>, <em>mull</em>, <em>super</em>), followed by a strip of <a href="#kraftpaper">kraft paper</a> as a second layer in better quality <a href="#binding">binding</a>s.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>back-lining</em>.  The term is also used synonymously with <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="link"><b>link</b></a>
</dt><dd>A direct connection in a <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#document">document</a> to the <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a> (<a href="#url">URL</a>) of another document, embedded as a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> in the <a href="#text">text</a>, or appearing as a <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>, <a href="#icon">icon</a>, or other <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> element which can be activated by the click of a <a href="#mouse">mouse</a> or some other pointing <a href="#device">device</a>.  Text links usually appear underlined and in blue on the computer screen.  A link is <a href="#brokenlink">broken</a> if it does not take the user to the desired destination when clicked.  <em>Link rot</em> is a colloquial expression for the tendency of links to become broken due to address changes and the removal of <a href="#html">HTML</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s from public <a href="#access">access</a>.  The remedy is regular <a href="#linkchecking">link checking</a>.  Synonymous with <em>hyperlink</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#hotspot">hot spot</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="linkchecking"><b>link checking</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of testing the <a href="#link">link</a>s in an <a href="#html">HTML</a> <a href="#document">document</a>
to determine if they are functioning properly. Software has been
developed to check links automatically. Without regular checking and <a href="#update">updating</a>, <a href="#url">URL</a> changes and dead links may accumulate in a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lirt1"><b>LIRT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lirt"><b>L</b>ibrary <b>I</b>nstruction <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lis"><b>LIS</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of "<b>l</b>ibrary and <b>i</b>nformation <b>s</b>cience."  <b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lisa1"><b><em>LISA</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#lisa"><b>L</b>ibrary and <b>I</b>nformation <b>S</b>cience <b>A</b>bstracts</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="list"><b>list</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#publication">publication</a>s currently available for purchase from a given <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, including the <a href="#frontlist">frontlist</a> and <a href="#backlist">backlist</a>, but not <a href="#forthcoming">forthcoming</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#midlist">midlist</a>.  Also used as a shortened form of <a href="#listprice">list price</a> and <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="listeningroom"><b>listening room</b></a>
</dt><dd>A special soundproof room or area in a <a href="#library">library</a>, equipped with <a href="#playback">playback</a> equipment (players, speakers, headphones, etc.) for listening to <a href="#audiorecording">audiorecording</a>s (<a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>s, <a href="#audiocassette">audiocassette</a>s, <a href="#longplaying">LP</a>s, etc.).  Registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s and sometimes members of the general public are permitted to use the <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, individually or in groups, usually for a limited period of time.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#viewingroom">viewing room</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="listprice"><b>list price</b></a>
</dt><dd>The undiscounted price at which a new <a href="#publication">publication</a> is offered for sale to the public, established by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> at the time the <a href="#edition">edition</a> is <a href="#issue">issue</a>d.  The list price is quoted in the publisher's <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> and <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the front <a href="#flap">flap</a> of the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> editions, and usually on the back cover in <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> editions.  <a href="#discount">Discount</a>s offered to <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, and <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>s are computed as a percentage off the list price.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the list price of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is indicated (when available) in the <a href="#standardnumberandterms">standard number and terms of availability</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> (<a href="#field">field</a> 020 or 022 of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>).  Synonymous with <em>published price</em> and <em>retail price</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#introprice">introductory price</a> and <a href="#prepubprice">prepublication price</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="listserv"><b>LISTSERV</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#mailinglist">Mailing list</a> management <a href="#software">software</a> that runs on a variety of <a href="#platform">platform</a>s, designed to scan incoming <a href="#email">e-mail</a> messages for the words "subscribe," "unsubscribe," and other houskeeping commands, and <a href="#update">update</a> the <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a> list automatically.  Also used as a general <a href="#term">term</a> for any mailing list that runs on LISTSERV software.  Two excellent <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#directory">directories</a> of e-mail discussion lists are <a href="http://www.liszt.com/">LISZT</a> and <a href="http://tile.net/lists/">Tile.Net/Lists</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#majordomo">majordomo</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lita1"><b>LITA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lita"><b>L</b>ibrary and <b>I</b>nformation <b>T</b>echnology <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="literacy"><b>literacy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The ability to read and write with a minimal level of proficiency.  <em>Illiteracy</em> is the <em>in</em>ability to read and write.  The <em>literacy rate</em> of a nation or other geographic area is usually expressed as the percentage of its <a href="#adult">adult</a> citizens who know how to read and write.  In the United States, adult literacy programs have been available for many years and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>
have been heavily involved in promoting literacy. In recent years, such
efforts have focused on adults for whom English is not the first <a href="#language">language</a>.  Compare with <a href="#infoliteracy">information literacy</a> and <a href="#computerliteracy">computer literacy</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#newadultreader">new adult reader</a>, <a href="#laubachliteracy">Laubach Literacy</a>, and <a href="#lva">Literacy Volunteers of America</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lva"><b>Literacy Volunteers of America (LVA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A national <a href="#network">network</a> of over 350 locally based programs that provide professionally trained <a href="#volunteer">volunteer</a> tutors to teach basic <a href="#literacy">literacy</a> and English to speakers of other <a href="#language">language</a>s.  <b>LVA</b> is an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  <a href="http://www.literacyvolunteers.org/home/index.htm">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>LVA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="literal"><b>literal</b></a>
</dt><dd>Following the exact words and ordinary meaning of a <a href="#text">text</a> or speech, without taking into account possible figurative or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ic use of <a href="#language">language</a>, as in a literal interpretation of a passage from the <em>Bible</em>.
The interpretation of words or statements according to their denotation
rather than their connotation. Also refers to an approach that is
prosaic or matter-of-fact, rather than intuitive.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="literaryagent"><b>literary agent</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization or person in the business of offering professional advice to writers on the suitability of <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s for <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  An agent may also provide guidance and/or assistance in locating and selecting a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, negotiating a <a href="#bookcontract">book contract</a>, arranging the sale of <a href="#subsidiaryrights">subsidiary rights</a>, and handling the business of <a href="#authorship">authorship</a> in general, usually in exchange for a commission paid by the <a href="#author">author</a>, or a portion of the proceeds derived from the <a href="#work">work</a>.
A literary agent may also act on behalf of a publisher to find works to
fill a specific need. Not all authors use an agent--some prefer to deal
directly with the publisher. <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> for literary agents is available in the <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a>s <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em> and <em><a href="#writersmarket">Writer's Market</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="literaryaward"><b>literary award</b></a>
</dt><dd>A special honor and/or reward given to an <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a> for creating a specific <a href="#work">work</a>,
or in recognition of a distinguished career, usually based on the
decision of a qualified panel of judges. Most literary awards and
prizes given annually are funded by private individuals or foundations.
Rewards may include a medal, <a href="#grant">grant</a>, and/or cash prize.  Recognition usually boosts the sale of the recipient's works and can mean larger <a href="#advanceonroyalty">advances on royalties</a> from <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#childrensaward">children's book award</a>.  
<p>
The most prestigious literary awards are the <a href="#nobel">Nobel Prize for Literature</a> and in the United States the <a href="#pulitzer">Pulitzer Prize</a>.  <a href="http://library.christchurch.org.nz/Guides/LiteraryPrizes/">Click here</a> to see an <a href="#online">online</a> list of literary prizes and awards maintained by the Christchurch City Libraries in New Zealand.  The <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a>s <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em> and <em><a href="#writersmarket">Writer's Market</a></em> also list literary awards and contests.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="literaryepic"><b>literary epic</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#epic">epic</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="literarymagazine"><b>literary magazine</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#littlemagazine">little magazine</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lmp"><b><em>Literary Market Place (LMP)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Published <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, <b><em>LMP</em></b> is a <a href="#directory">directory</a> of the <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> industry in the United States and Canada, containing an <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetic</a> list of U.S. <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, <a href="#index">index</a>ed by <a href="#subject">subject</a>, type of <a href="#publication">publication</a>, and geographically by state.  It also lists Canadian publishers, <a href="#smallpress">small press</a>es, <a href="#editor">editor</a>ial services, <a href="#literaryagent">literary agent</a>s, <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> <a href="#association">association</a>s, writer's <a href="#conference">conference</a>s and <a href="#workshop">workshop</a>s, <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a>s and prizes, fellowships and <a href="#grant">grant</a>s, and provides a <a href="#calendar">calendar</a> of <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> and promotional events.  The section on advertising, marketing, and <a href="#publicity">publicity</a> lists book <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>s, <a href="#newsservice">news service</a>s, <a href="#bookclub">book club</a>s, book <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>s, etc.  <b><em>LMP</em></b> also includes an industry <a href="#yellowpages">yellow pages</a>, with separate sections for companies and key personnel.  Bowker also publishes the companion <em><a href="#ilmp">International Literary Market Place</a></em>.  The most recent <a href="#edition">edition</a> of <b><em>LMP</em></b> is shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most large and medium-sized <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#writersmarket">Writer's Market</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="literaryprize"><b>literary prize</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="literarywarrant"><b>literary warrant</b></a>
</dt><dd>The quantity of <a href="#work">work</a>s that have been written on a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#topic">topic</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the development of portions of a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> in response to the <a href="#content">content</a> of materials requiring classification. In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, the addition of a <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#content">content</a> <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> to an <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>, based on the frequency of occurrence of the concept it represents in the <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#text">text</a> of <a href="#document">document</a>s <a href="#index">index</a>ed.  Compare with <a href="#userwarrant">user warrant</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="literarywork"><b>literary work</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonsacred <a href="#work">work</a> written in literary form (<a href="#poetry">poem</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>, <a href="#essay">essay</a>, <a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#shortstory">story</a>), recognized and appreciated by educated <a href="#reader">reader</a>s and lovers of <a href="#literature">literature</a> for the superior quality of its style and <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> of an enduring theme.  Compare with <a href="#popularfiction">popular fiction</a> and <a href="#pulpfiction">pulp fiction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="literati"><b>literati</b></a>
</dt><dd>Men of letters.  Scholarly, learned, and/or well-educated people.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="literature"><b>literature</b></a>
</dt><dd>Enduring <a href="#work">work</a>s of <a href="#poetry">poetry</a> or <a href="#prose">prose</a>
that express ideas and emotions of universal human interest in a form
and style embodying excellence. Also refers to the body of works
written and/or produced on a <a href="#subject">subject</a>, in a given <a href="#field">field</a> of inquiry, or in a specific <a href="#language">language</a>, country, period, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="litreview"><b>literature review</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> survey of the <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a <a href="#field">field</a> of study, or related to a particular line of <a href="#research">research</a>, usually in the form of a <a href="#bibessay">bibliographic essay</a> or <a href="#annotation">annotated</a> list of references in which attention is drawn to the most significant works.  An <a href="#annualreview">annual review</a> is a form of <a href="#serial">serial</a> devoted entirely to the publication of literature reviews.  Synonymous with <em>review of the literature</em>.  
<p>
Also, in scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a>s that <a href="#publishing">publish</a> original <a href="#research">research</a> in the physical and social sciences, the first section of each <a href="#article">article</a> is usually devoted to a review of the previously published <a href="#literature">literature</a> on the <a href="#subject">subject</a>, with references in the <a href="#text">text</a> to a list of works <a href="#cite">cite</a>d at the end.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="litsearch"><b>literature search</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#exhaustive">exhaustive</a> search for <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#information">information</a> on a <a href="#subject">subject</a>, conducted systematically using all available bibliographic <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a>s, aimed at locating as much existing material on the <a href="#topic">topic</a> as possible, an important initial step in any serious <a href="#research">research</a> project.  Compare with <a href="#readyreference">ready reference</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lithography"><b>lithography</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of creating <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s or <a href="#print">print</a>s by drawing on a zinc <a href="#plate">plate</a> or the surface of fine-grained limestone with a water-repellent substance to which <a href="#ink">ink</a>
adheres, a technique developed in Germany in the early part of the 19th
century. When the stone is wetted, ink is repelled by the moist areas
and attracted only by the design. An <a href="#impression">impression</a> is made by applying dampened <a href="#paper">paper</a> to the stone under pressure.  In <em>chromolithography</em>, separate stones are used to produce multiple colors.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="litterateur"><b>litterateur</b></a>
</dt><dd>A man of <a href="#letters">letters</a>, especially one who devotes himself to the study and writing of <a href="#literature">literature</a> in the capacity of an amateur or dilettante. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="littlemagazine"><b>little magazine</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> of limited <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>, devoted to experimental or avant-garde <a href="#poetry">poetry</a>, <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, <a href="#essay">essay</a>s, humor, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>y, and art.  Little <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s
flourished in the United States, Britain, and France during the 1920s,
but most disappeared before the beginning of World War II. <a href="#desktop">Desktop publishing</a> has given new life to this form of <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  According to <em><a href="#magazinesfor">Magazines for Libraries</a></em>, over 5,000 little magazines are currently <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the United States, with some available <a href="#online">online</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.pshares.org/">Ploughshares</a></em>).  For <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> is a problem because they fall outside the mainstream <a href="#press">press</a>.  Synonymous with <em>literary magazine</em>.  Compare with <a href="#zine">zine</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="littlepress"><b>little press</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#smallpress">small press</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="liturgicalwork"><b>liturgical work</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> used in the worship services of an organized religion.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, liturgical <a href="#work">work</a>s are entered under the name of the <a href="#corporatebody">body</a> with which they are associated (<em>example</em>:  <b>Catholic Church</b>).  If a well-established <a href="#title">title</a> exists in English, it is used as the <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>Breviary</b>).  If there is no well-known title in English, or the name of the body is given in another <a href="#language">language</a>, a brief title is entered in the language of the liturgy, followed by a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> in <a href="#parenthesis">parentheses</a> indicating the <a href="#variant">variant</a> or special <a href="#text">text</a> (if applicable), for example, <b>Book of hours (Ms. Rohan)</b>.  Compare with <a href="#sacredtext">sacred text</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#antiphonary">antiphonary</a>, <a href="#bookofhours">book of hours</a>, <a href="#breviary">breviary</a>, <a href="#missal">missal</a>, and <a href="#psalter">psalter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lj"><b><em>LJ</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#libraryjournal"><b>L</b>ibrary <b>J</b>ournal</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lmp1"><b><em>LMP</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#lmp"><b>L</b>iterary <b>M</b>arket <b>P</b>lace</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="loancharacter"><b>loan character</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#character">character</a> from one writing system, used in writing another <a href="#character">language</a>, for example, the Chinese characters used by the Japanese to write their own language (<a href="#kanji">kanji</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="loandesk"><b>loan desk</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See </em></b>: <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="loanperiod"><b>loan period</b></a>
</dt><dd>The length of time for which an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in the <a href="#circulating">circulating collection</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> may be <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> by a <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>.  Under normal circumstances, loan period is determined by the <a href="#loanrule">loan rule</a> applied to a specific item, based on <a href="#itemtype">item type</a> and the borrower's <a href="#patrontype">patron type</a>.  In most libraries, circulating items (except <a href="#reserves">reserves</a>) may be <a href="#renew">renew</a>ed for an additional loan period provided no <a href="#hold">hold</a>s have been placed by other borrowers.  Most libraries charge <a href="#fines">fine</a>s for items returned after the <a href="#duedate">due date</a>.  Synonymous with <em>borrowing period</em> and <em>checkout period</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="loanrule"><b>loan rule</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s, the decision governing the prescribed <a href="#loanperiod">period</a> of time for which an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> of a specific <a href="#itemtype">item type</a> may be <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> by a <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>, depending on the <a href="#patrontype">patron type</a>.  The loan rule also determines the form of the notice sent when an item is kept past its <a href="#duedate">due date</a>, and the amount of any <a href="#overdue">overdue</a> <a href="#fines">fine</a> charged to the <a href="#patron">patron</a>.  The cost of <a href="#replacement">replacing</a> a <a href="#lost">lost</a> or <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> item may also be determined in part by the loan rule.  Each <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> establishes and maintains its own set of loan rules for the various categories of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="loanstatus"><b>loan status</b></a>
</dt><dd>The type of loan in effect at a particular time for a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>.  Most items are available for general <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>, but some may be on <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> or <a href="#checkedout">on loan</a> to other <a href="#library">libraries</a> via <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>.  <a href="#noncirculating">Noncirculating</a> items such as <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s are for <a href="#libraryuseonly">library use only</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="localarea"><b>local area network (LAN)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#communications">communications</a> <a href="#network">network</a>
restricted to a relatively small geographic area, often within a single
building or group of adjacent buildings such as a college, university,
or corporate campus, consisting of at least one high-speed <a href="#server">server</a>, <a href="#client">client</a> <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>s, a network <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>, and a <a href="#communications">communications</a> link.  LANs handling communication over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> use <a href="#opticalfiber">optical fiber</a> as a transmission <a href="#medium">medium</a>.  Compare with <a href="#widearea">wide area network (WAN)</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="localbib"><b>local bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> of <a href="#book">book</a>s
and other materials about a specific geographic area smaller than a
country, usually including material about the history, geography,
architecture, and environment of the area, as well as <a href="#work">work</a>s about the people born or residing in it.  Useful in <a href="#genealogy">genealogical</a> <a href="#research">research</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#regionalbook">regional book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="localcollec"><b>local collection</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> of <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#print">print</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> related to a specific geographic area and its inhabitants, usually the community in which the <a href="#library">library</a> is located, useful in historical and <a href="#genealogy">genealogical</a> <a href="#research">research</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#regionalbook">regional book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="locationcode"><b>location code</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#locationsymbol">location symbol</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="locationsymbol"><b>location symbol</b></a>
</dt><dd>A code consisting of a few letters or a word displayed in a <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> or added to an <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, indicating the specific location or <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> in which the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is shelved (<em>example</em>:  <b>Ref</b> for items in the <a href="#refstacks">reference stacks</a>).  In a <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a>, location <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s are used to indicate the <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the <a href="#librarysystem">system</a> or <a href="#consortium">consortium</a> owning at least one <a href="#copy">copy</a> of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  Synonymous with <em>location code</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="locativerelation"><b>locative relation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="locator"><b>locator</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portion of an <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#index">index</a> that gives the location of the unit <a href="#indexing">indexed</a>.  In the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, it is the <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>.  In a <a href="#singleindex">single index</a>, the locator is usually a <a href="#pagenumber">page</a> or paragraph number, or a <a href="#figure">figure</a> or <a href="#table">table</a> number.  In an <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>, the locator is the abstract number under which the full <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a> can be found.  In an <a href="#openendindex">open-end index</a>, the locators may be the bibliographic descriptions themselves. 
<p>
A <em>sequential locator</em> is a pair of locators separated by a <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a>, indicating the first and last <a href="#page">page</a>s, paragraphs, or sections of the <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#document">document</a> in which the indexed <a href="#topic">topic</a> is mentioned.  To avoid ambiguity, it is standard practice to give the second part of a sequential locator in full (<em>example</em>:  396-409 instead of 396-09).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="loccit"><b><em>loc cit.</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin phrase <em>loco citato</em> meaning "in the place cited."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lockedup"><b>locked up</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of assembled <a href="#type">type</a> and <a href="#displaymatter">display matter</a> <a href="#makeup">made up</a> into <a href="#page">page</a>s and imposed in a <a href="#chase">chase</a> once it has been tightly secured by adjusting small expandable wooden or metal boxes called <em>quoins</em> positioned between the imposed type and the sides of the chase.  The resulting <a href="#forme">forme</a> is ready to be placed on the bed of the <a href="#printingpress">press</a> for <a href="#printing">printing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="loex"><b>LOEX</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <b>L</b>ibrary <b>O</b>rientation <b>EX</b>change
(pronounced "low-ex"), a "library outreach" office established in 1971
at Eastern Michigan State University with the aid of a <a href="#grant">grant</a> from the Council on Library Resources (<a href="#clir">CLR</a>) and the <a href="#neh">National Endowment for the Humanities</a> (NEH).  Since its inception, <b>LOEX</b> has sponsored the annual <em>LOEX Conference</em>, attended by <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and other individuals with an interest in <a href="#library">library</a> instruction, and has served as a <a href="#clearinghouse">clearinghouse</a> for bibliographic instruction materials and resources.  <a href="http://www.emich.edu/public/loex/loex.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>LOEX Clearinghouse for Library Instruction</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="logicaldifference"><b>logical difference</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic, the result obtained when the <b>NOT</b> command is used to separate members of a <a href="#set">set</a> of entities from those of another.  It is the <a href="#searchstrategy">search strategy</a> used to determine which <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> contain <a href="#term">term</a> <b>A</b> but not term <b>B</b>.  Synonymous with <em>logical subtraction</em> and <em>negation</em>.  Compare with <a href="#logicalproduct">logical product</a> and <a href="#logicalsum">logical sum</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="logicalproduct"><b>logical product</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic, the result obtained when the <b>AND</b> command is used to find all the members common to two or more <a href="#set">set</a>s of entities.  It is the <a href="#searchstrategy">search strategy</a> used to determine which <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> contain both <a href="#term">term</a> <b>A</b> and term <b>B</b>.  Synonymous with <em>logical multiplication</em> and <em>conjunction</em>.  Compare with <a href="#logicaldifference">logical difference</a> and <a href="#logicalsum">logical sum</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="logicalsum"><b>logical sum</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic, the result obtained when the <b>OR</b> command is used to find all the members of two or more <a href="#set">set</a>s of entities.  It is the <a href="#searchstrategy">search strategy</a> used to determine which <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> contain <a href="#term">term</a> <b>A</b> or term <b>B</b>, or both <b>A</b> and <b>B</b>.  Synonymous with <em>logical addition</em> and <em>union</em>.  Compare with <a href="#logicaldifference">logical difference</a> and <a href="#logicalproduct">logical product</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="logo"><b>logo</b></a>
</dt><dd>An emblem or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> design used in <a href="#publication">publication</a>s and on promotional materials by a company, organization, <a href="#agency">agency</a>, or institution as a <a href="#trademark">trademark</a> or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> of its identity.  <a href="#website">Web site</a>s often include a logo to indicate affiliation with a <a href="#host">host</a> organization, or to suggest the nature of the site's <a href="#content">content</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="logoff1"><b>logoff</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#logoff">log off</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="logoff"><b>log off</b></a>
</dt><dd>The procedure by which a user closes or terminates communication with a remote computer system. The opposite of <a href="#logon">log on</a>.  Also spelled <em>log-off</em> or <em>logoff</em>.  Compare with <a href="#exit">exit</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="logogram"><b>logogram</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> or <a href="#character">character</a> that stands for an entire word, for example, <b>$</b> for <em>dollar</em> and <b>#</b> for <em>number</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="logon1"><b>logon</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#logon">log on</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="logon"><b>log on</b></a>
</dt><dd>The procedure by which a user gains <a href="#access">access</a> to and initiates communication with a remote computer system, usually by typing or entering an <a href="#authorization">authorized</a>  <a href="#username">username</a> and/or <a href="#password">password</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#logoff">log off</a>.  Also spelled <em>log-on</em> and <em>logon</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="longdiscount"><b>long discount</b></a>
</dt><dd>The standard <a href="#discount">discount</a> given by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to a <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> on <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a>s, usually 40%.  Compare with <a href="#shortdiscount">short discount</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="longitudinal"><b>longitudinal study</b></a>
</dt><dd> A <a href="#research">research</a> methodology in which the
same phenomenon is observed continuously or at intervals over an
extended period of time, usually to discern temporal patterns or
identify changes that occur in response to altered conditions. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#usersurvey">user survey</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="longpage"><b>long page</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#page">page</a> containing more lines of <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a> than specified.  In <a href="#book">book</a>s, a <a href="#typesetting">typesetter</a> may add an extra line (or lines) to avoid setting an <a href="#orphan">orphan</a> or <a href="#widow">widow</a>.  Compare with <a href="#shortpage">short page</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="longplaying"><b>long-playing record (LP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a>
in which music or spoken words are recorded in a continuous spiral
groove on the surface of a thin, flat vinyl disk that can be <a href="#playback">played back</a> at 33 <a href="#rpm">rpm</a> using a device called a <em>record player</em> equipped with a <a href="#stylus">stylus</a>, cartridge, and speakers to amplify the sound.  Long-playing records have been <a href="#superseded">superseded</a>, first by <a href="#audiocassette">audiocassette</a>s and then by audio <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>s.  They are retained by <a href="#library">libraries</a> for <a href="#archives">archival</a> purposes.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#monaural">monaural</a>, <a href="#stereophonic">stereophonic</a>, and <a href="#quadraphonic">quadraphonic</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="loose"><b>loose</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#sheet">Sheet</a>s of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, etc., that are <a href="#unbound">unbound</a>, usually filed in a <a href="#folder">folder</a> or <a href="#container">container</a>.  The opposite of <em>bound</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a>.
<p>
Also refers to one or more <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, or all the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a>, which have become partially or completely detached from the <a href="#binding">binding</a> through use.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used to describe the binding on a well-used <a href="#book">book</a> that opens easily and lies flat at any <a href="#page">page</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#tight">tight</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="looseback"><b>loose-back</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#hollowback">hollow back</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="looseleaf"><b>loose-leaf</b></a>
</dt><dd>A rigid or flexible <a href="#mechanical">mechanical binding</a> that can be manually opened and closed by the user to remove or insert, at any location in the sequence of <a href="#page">page</a>s, one or more <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> or <a href="#section">section</a>s with holes or slots punched along the back <a href="#margin">margin</a>.  The most common varieties are <a href="#ringbinding">ring binding</a> and <a href="#postbinding">post binding</a>.  Loose-leaf binding is used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> for <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a>s, <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a>, legal <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, instruction <a href="#manual">manual</a>s, etc., which must be <a href="#update">update</a>d on a regular basis.  Compare with <a href="#combbinding">comb binding</a> and <a href="#spiralbinding">spiral binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lost"><b>lost</b></a>
</dt><dd>A code used in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> to indicate the <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> no longer <a href="#available">available</a> because it was <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> to a previous <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> and never returned.  Most libraries <a href="#billed">bill</a> the <a href="#patron">patron</a> an amount based on the cost of <a href="#replacement">replacement</a> after a <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#overduenotice">overdue notice</a>s
have been sent without result. In some libraries, the charge may be
refundable if the item is found and returned within a reasonable time.
Compare with <a href="#missing">missing</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a creative <a href="#work">work</a> whose existence is known only through <a href="#allusion">allusion</a>s or <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s in the writings of contemporary <a href="#author">author</a>s.  <a href="#literarywork">Literary work</a>s of the classical period (<a href="#poetry">poem</a>s, <a href="#play">play</a>s, etc.) are often known only through fragmentary <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s and references in surviving works.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lot"><b>lot</b></a>
</dt><dd>A regular shipment of <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> material sent by a <a href="#library">library</a> to a <a href="#bindery">bindery</a> for <a href="#binding">binding</a> or <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>.  The phrase "closing the lot" refers to the point in time after which no further <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s are added to a shipment.  Only when the lot is closed can the necessary paperwork be prepared to accompany the shipment. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lowdemand"><b>low-demand</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#demand">demand</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lowercase"><b>lowercase</b></a>
</dt><dd>The small <a href="#letter">letter</a>s as opposed to the <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a>s of a <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#font">font</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a>.  Type <a href="#matter">matter</a> set in lowercase can be read more rapidly than the same <a href="#text">text</a> set in uppercase.  
The words "lowercase" and "uppercase" are derived from the relative positions of the compartments within the wood or metal <a href="#case">case</a> designed to hold elements of <a href="#type">type</a> bearing small letters and capital letters at a typesetter's bench in the days when <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a> was done by hand (<a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a>).  Also spelled <em>lower case</em>.  Compare with <a href="#minuscule">minuscule</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ascender">ascender</a>, <a href="#descender">descender</a>, and <a href="#xheight">x-height</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lp"><b>LP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#largeprint"><b>l</b>arge <b>p</b>rint</a> and <a href="#longplaying"><b>l</b>ong-<b>p</b>laying record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lrc"><b>LRC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#learningresources"><b>l</b>earning <b>r</b>esources <b>c</b>enter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lrrt1"><b>LRRT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lrrt"><b>L</b>ibrary <b>R</b>esearch <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lsca1"><b>LSCA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lsca"><b>L</b>ibrary <b>S</b>ervices and <b>C</b>onstruction <b>A</b>ct</a>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lsta1"><b>LSTA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lsta"><b>L</b>ibrary <b>S</b>ervices and <b>T</b>echnology <b>A</b>ct</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lu1"><b>LU</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lu"><b>L</b>ibraries <b>U</b>nlimited</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lurk"><b>lurk</b></a>
</dt><dd>To receive and read messages posted to an <a href="#online">online</a> discussion forum, or observe the exchanges in a <a href="#chat">chat</a> room, without actively participating in the discussion.  In some <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>s, there may be more <em>lurkers</em> than active correspondents. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lva1"><b>LVA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lva"><b>L</b>iteracy <b>V</b>olunteers of <b>A</b>merica</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lyric"><b>lyric</b></a>
</dt><dd>In classical Greece, a song or <a href="#poetry">poem</a> performed to the accompaniment of a harp-like stringed instrument called a <em>lyre</em>.  In contemporary <a href="#usage">usage</a>, a relatively short poem in which a single speaker expresses a personal emotion or state of mind, as opposed to <a href="#narrative">narrating</a> a sequence of events.  The form includes <a href="#sonnet">sonnet</a>s, <a href="#elegy">elegies</a>, <a href="#ode">ode</a>s, and hymns.  Compare with <a href="#lyrics">lyrics</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lyricist"><b>lyricist</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lyrics">lyrics</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="lyrics"><b>lyrics</b></a>
</dt><dd>The words of a song or musical drama, as opposed to its music.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, songs and musicals are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under the name of the <a href="#composer">composer</a>, with an <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> under the name of the <em>lyricist</em> when the words are written by a person other than the composer (<em>examples</em>:  Lorenz Hart and  Oscar Hammerstein who wrote the words for <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a>s composed by Richard Rodgers).  Compare with <a href="#lyric">lyric</a>.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>
<center>| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> | <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a>
| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="M">M</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="mac"><b>Mac</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#macintosh">Macintosh</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="machineaided"><b>machine-aided indexing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> in which a computer is programmed to select possible <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s from a <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#preferredterm">preferred term</a>s, based on an analysis of words and <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s appearing in the <a href="#title">title</a> and/or <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>.  Each suggestion is evaluated by a human <a href="#index">index</a>er and either accepted or rejected.  The indexer is also free to select additional authorized terms for indexing.  Compare with <a href="#automaticindexing">automatic indexing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="machinereadable"><b>machine-readable</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#data">Data</a> in a form that can be recognized, accepted, and interpreted by a machine, such as a computer or other <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a> device, whether created in such a form or <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> from a <a href="#format">format</a> that a machine cannot read.  Usually refers to <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#storage">stored</a> on <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a>, <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>, or <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="machinecat"><b>MAchine-Readable Cataloging (MARC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An international <a href="#standards">standard</a> <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a> for the description of <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>s, developed by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> during the 1960s to facilitate the creation and dissemination of computerized <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> from <a href="#library">library</a> to library within the same country, and between countries.  By 1971 the <b>MARC</b>
format had become the national standard for dissemination of
bibliographic data, and by 1973 the international standard. Widespread
use of the <b>MARC</b> standard has helped libraries acquire predictable and reliable cataloging <a href="#data">data</a>,
make use of commercially available library automation systems, share
bibliographic resources, avoid duplication of effort, and ensure that
