bibliographic data will be <a href="#compatibility">compatible</a> when one automation system is replaced by another.  
<p>
The <b>MARC</b> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> has three components:
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>Record structure</b> - an implementation of national and international standards, such as the <em>Information Interchange Format</em> <a href="#ansi">ANSI</a> Z39.2 and <em>Format for Information Exchange</em> <a href="#iso">ISO</a> 2709
</dd><dd><b>Content designation</b> - codes and conventions that
explicitly identify and characterize the data elements within a record
to facilitate the manipulation of data
</dd><dd><b>Data Content</b> - defined by external standards such as <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, <em><a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH)</a></em>, etc.</dd></dl>
<p>
In structure, the <b>MARC</b> record is divided into <a href="#field">field</a>s, each containing one or more related <a href="#element">element</a>s of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  A field is preceded by a three-digit <a href="#tag">tag</a> designating the nature of its content.  Tags are organized in hundreds as follows, with <b>XX</b> in the range of <b>00-99</b>, indicating a group of related tags:  
</p><p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>0XX</b> fields - Control <a href="#information">information</a>, <a href="#number">number</a>s, codes
</dd><dd><b>1XX</b> fields - <a href="#mainentry">Main entry</a>
</dd><dd><b>2XX</b> fields - <a href="#title">Title</a>s, <a href="#edition">edition</a>, <a href="#imprint">imprint</a>
</dd><dd><b>3XX</b> fields - <a href="#physicaldescrip">Physical description</a>, etc.
</dd><dd><b>4XX</b> fields - <a href="#seriesstatement">Series statement</a>s (as shown in item) 
</dd><dd><b>5XX</b> fields - <a href="#notearea">Notes</a>
</dd><dd><b>6XX</b> fields - <a href="#subjectheading">Subject</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a>
</dd><dd><b>7XX</b> fields - Added entries other than subject or <a href="#series">series</a>
</dd><dd><b>8XX</b> fields - Series added entries (other authoritative forms)</dd></dl>
<p>
<a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/marc/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>MARC Standards</em></b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> maintained by the MARC Standards Office of the Library of Congress.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#unimarc">UNIMARC</a> and <a href="#marcese">MARCese</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mrdf"><b>machine-readable data file (MRDF)</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#information">Information</a> stored in a form that can be used directly as computer <a href="#input">input</a>, without <a href="#dataconversion">conversion</a> from a <a href="#format">format</a> that is not <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a>, for example, <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s in <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> format as opposed to <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a>s.  <a href="#storage">Storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> varies (<a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a>, magnetic <a href="#disk">disk</a>, etc.).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="machinerecords"><b>machine-readable records</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, <a href="#records">records</a> created and maintained in a <a href="#medium">medium</a> that requires some kind of machine to <a href="#access">access</a> their <a href="#content">content</a> (<a href="#microform">microform</a>s, <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>s, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a> and <a href="#disk">disk</a>s, <a href="#opticaldisk">optical disk</a>s, etc.).  Compare with <a href="#electronicrecords">electronic records</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mrdf">machine-readable data file</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="macintosh"><b>Macintosh</b></a>
</dt><dd>The family of computers introduced by Apple in 1984 which popularized the <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a> (GUI), setting a precedent for the design of <a href="#userfriendly">user-friendly</a> graphical <a href="#application">application</a>s and <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>s that other <a href="#software">software</a>
companies like Microsoft were quick to follow. Although Apple commands
only 5% of the market for desktop computers, the company produces the
largest series of nonIBM-<a href="#compatibility">compatible</a> <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a>s.  "Macs" remain popular in <a href="#desktop">desktop publishing</a> and <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> design because of the <a href="#usability">usability</a> of the <a href="#interface">interface</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, Macs are used mainly in the <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a> and <a href="#curriculumroom">curriculum room</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#windows">Windows</a> and <a href="#unix">UNIX</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="macro"><b>macro</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, a method of customizing user <a href="#input">input</a> in which a series of recorded keystrokes, commands, or <a href="#menu">menu</a> <a href="#option">option</a>s are assigned a brief name or key combination (usually <b>Ctrl</b> or <b>Alt</b> plus a specific <a href="#character">character</a>) to enable the user to execute a pre-determined sequence of steps quickly by simply typing the name or key combination.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="macroform"><b>macroform</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general term for any storage <a href="#medium">medium</a> bearing <a href="#text">text</a> and/or images large enough to be easily read without magnification.  Macroforms can be opaque (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#photocopy">photocopies</a>) or transparent (overhead <a href="#transparency">transparencies</a>).  Compare with <a href="#microform">microform</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="madeupcopy"><b>made-up copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> assembled from parts taken from one or more defective copies of the same <a href="#edition">edition</a>, or a copy in which <a href="#imperfect">imperfect</a>ions are corrected by adding or substituting parts taken from other copies of the same edition.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="magazine"><b>magazine</b></a>
</dt><dd>A popular interest <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> usually containing <a href="#article">article</a>s on a variety of <a href="#topic">topic</a>s, written by various <a href="#author">author</a>s in a nonscholarly style.  Most magazines are heavily <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a>, contain advertising, and are <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#glossy">glossy</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  Articles are usually short (less than five <a href="#page">page</a>s long), frequently <a href="#unsigned">unsigned</a>, and do not include a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> or list of references for <a href="#furtherreading">further reading</a>.  Most magazines are <a href="#issue">issue</a>d <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> or <a href="#weekly">weekly</a> for sale at newsstands, in <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s, and by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>.  English-<a href="#language">language</a> magazines are listed by <a href="#subject">subject</a> in <em><a href="#magazinesfor">Magazines for Libraries</a></em> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>mag</em>.  Compare with <a href="#journal">journal</a> and <a href="#journalofcomment">journal of commentary</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicmagazine">e-zine</a>, <a href="#genintmag">general interest magazine</a>, <a href="#hybridjournal">hybrid journal</a>, <a href="#newsmagazine">news magazine</a>, <a href="#specintmag">special interest magazine</a>, and <a href="#zine">zine</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a rectangular slotted container designed to hold a sequence of <a href="#slide">slide</a>s, <a href="#queue">queue</a>d for use in a slide projector.  Compare with <a href="#carousel">carousel</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="magazinepagination"><b>magazine pagination</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#pagenumber">Number</a>ing the <a href="#page">page</a>s of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, starting with one at the beginning of each <a href="#issue">issue</a>.  <a href="#magazine">Magazine</a>s and <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a>s are usually <a href="#pagination">paginated</a> in this way, making it more difficult to locate a specific <a href="#article">article</a> in a <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a> by <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s, compared with a <a href="#publication">publication</a> that uses <a href="#journalpagination">journal pagination</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="magazinesfor"><b><em>Magazines for Libraries</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publishing">Published</a> <a href="#irregular">irregular</a>ly since 1969 by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, <b><em>Magazines for Libraries</em></b> is a <a href="#subject">subject</a> list (with <a href="#title">title</a> <a href="#index">index</a>) of over 8,000 English-<a href="#language">language</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, selected by the <a href="#editor">editor</a>s from over 170,000 possibilities as the most useful for the average <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a>, <a href="#academiclib">academic</a>, <a href="#govtlibrary">government</a>, <a href="#schoollibrary">school</a>, or <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a>.  Coverage includes <a href="#genintmag">general interest magazine</a>s, <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a>s, <a href="#zine">zine</a>s, and children's periodicals.  Each <a href="#entry">entry</a> includes a basic <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>; an <a href="#annotation">annotation</a> explaining the purpose, <a href="#scope">scope</a>, and <a href="#audience">audience</a> of the <a href="#publication">publication</a>; and a brief evaluation.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> usually place this <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> tool on <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a> and shelve it in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="magert1"><b>MAGERT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#magert"><b>MA</b>p and <b>GE</b>ography <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="magneticdisk"><b>magnetic disk</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#disk">disk</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="magneticstrip"><b>magnetic strip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thin magnetized strip of plastic firmly affixed to a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> at the time it is <a href="#technical">processed</a>, which can be set to trigger a <a href="#securitysystem">security alarm</a> whenever someone attempts to remove the item from the <a href="#library">library</a> without <a href="#checkedout">checking it out</a>.  Synonymous with <em>security strip</em> and <em>tattle-tape</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#desensitization">desensitization</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="magnetictape"><b>magnetic tape</b></a>
</dt><dd>An electronic <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a>
consisting of a thin strip of flexible plastic to which a metallic
coating is applied which can be selectively magnetized to record <a href="#information">information</a> sequentially in linear or helical <a href="#track">track</a>s.  Magnetic tape is mounted on open <a href="#reel">reel</a>s or in cartridges.  To <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> a specific <a href="#record">record</a> or <a href="#file">file</a> on tape, all the records (or partitions) preceding it must be sequentially searched.  Magnetic <a href="#disk">disk</a> storage is faster because it allows <a href="#data">data</a> to be <a href="#access">access</a>ed randomly.  For this reason, <a href="#data">data</a> in <a href="#currency">current</a> use is usually stored on disk, but tape is often used for <a href="#archives">archival</a> storage because it is more economical and has greater capacity.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="magnumopus"><b>magnum opus</b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for "great work."  A <a href="#literarywork">literary</a> or artistic <a href="#work">work</a> considered by discerning critics to be of major importance, usually the crowning achievement of its <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#composer">composer</a>, or creator (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Ulysses</em></b>
by James Joyce). Not all authors and artists produce a work that is
considered superior to their others (William Shakespeare). The opposite
of <a href="#opuscule">opuscule</a>.  Compare with <a href="#masterpiece">masterpiece</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mailinglist"><b>mailing list</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#email">e-mail</a> discussion forum that allows individuals to subscribe and automatically receive messages posted to the list by other <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s.
Participants may also post their own messages and replies for
distribution to the other subscribers to the list. A mailing list may
be <em>moderated</em> or <em>unmoderated</em>.  Synonymous with <em>electronic discussion list</em>.  Compare with <a href="#bbs">bulletin board system</a> and <a href="#distributionlist">distribution list</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#listserv">LISTSERV</a>, <a href="#lurk">lurk</a>, <a href="#majordomo">majordomo</a>, and <a href="#netiquette">netiquette</a>.  
<p>
<a href="http://www.wrlc.org/liblists/">Click here</a> to see a list of <em>Library-Oriented Lists &amp; Electronic Serials</em> maintained by the Washington Research Library Consortium (WRLC).  Two of the most <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> general <a href="#directory">directories</a> of e-mail discussion groups are <a href="http://www.liszt.com/">LISZT</a> and <a href="http://tile.net/lists/">Tile.Net/Lists</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mainclass"><b>main class</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of the highest-level divisions of a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>.  In <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a>, the 20 major <a href="#class">class</a>es are indicated by <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the English <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>:
<p>
</p><center><table>
<tbody><tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>A</b> - General works</td><td width="400"><b>M</b> - Music</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>B</b> - Philosophy, psychology, religion</td><td width="400"><b>N</b> - Fine arts</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>C</b> - Auxiliary sciences of history (archaeology, genealogy, etc.)</td><td width="400"><b>P</b> - Language and literature</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>D</b> - History (except America)</td><td width="400"><b>Q</b> - Science</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>E-F</b> - History: America and United States</td><td width="400"><b>R</b> - Medicine</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>G</b> - Geography and anthropology</td><td width="400"><b>S</b> - Agriculture</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>H</b> - Social sciences</td><td width="400"><b>T</b> - Technology and engineering</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>J</b> - Political science</td><td width="400"><b>U</b> - Military science</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>K</b> - Law</td><td width="400"><b>V</b> - Naval science</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>L</b> - Education</td><td width="400"><b>Z</b> - History of books, library science, bibliography</td></tr>
</tbody></table></center>
<p>
In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the ten main classes are indicated by <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s:
</p><p>
</p><center><table>
<tbody><tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>000</b> - Generalities</td><td width="400"><b>500</b> - Natural sciences and mathematics</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>100</b> - Philosophy, parapsychology and occultism, psychology</td><td width="400"><b>600</b> - Technology (Applied sciences)</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>200</b> - Religion</td><td width="400"><b>700</b> - Arts (Fine and Decorative Arts)</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>300</b> - Social sciences</td><td width="400"><b>800</b> - Literature (Belles-lettres) and rhetoric</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="400"><b>400</b> - Language</td><td width="400"><b>900</b> - Geography, history, and auxiliary disciplines</td></tr>
</tbody></table></center>
<p>
<b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#division">division</a> and <a href="#section">section</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mainentry"><b>main entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> that provides the fullest <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a> of a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>, enabling the <a href="#work">work</a> to be clearly identified and <a href="#citation">cited</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the main entry is the primary <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>.  In the <a href="#cardcatalog">card catalog</a>, it includes all the secondary <a href="#heading">heading</a>s under which the item is <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a>, called <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a>.  For most items, main entry is under name of <a href="#authorentry">author</a>.  When there is no author, main entry is under the <a href="#title">title</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mainframe"><b>mainframe</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large computer system capable of supporting many <a href="#terminal">terminal</a>s that do not have independent <a href="#centralproc">processing</a> capability, used to run complex <a href="#application">application</a>s
that require a considerable amount of computing power. Mainframes are
classified by size (small, medium, and large). Compare with <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a>, <a href="#minicomputer">minicomputer</a>, and <a href="#supercomputer">supercomputer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mainheading"><b>main heading</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#precoordinate">pre-coordinate</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, the first part of a composite <a href="#heading">heading</a> that includes at least one <a href="#subheading">subheading</a>.  In the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject heading</a> <b>Information science--Research--Methodology</b>, the phrase <em>Information science</em> is the main heading, <em>Research</em> is the subheading, and <em>Methodology</em> is the sub-subheading.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#standardsubdivision">standard subdivision</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mainlibrary"><b>main library</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#centrallib">central library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mainschedule"><b>main schedule</b></a>
</dt><dd>The list of <a href="#class">class</a>es used by a <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> or indexer, individually or in combination, to <a href="#classification">classify</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s by <a href="#subject">subject</a> under the rules of a given <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, arranged in the order of their <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ic <a href="#notation">notation</a>.  In a <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical classification</a> system, the logical divisions, subdivisions, etc., of the <a href="#mainclass">main class</a>es are displayed.  Compare with <a href="#auxiliaryschedule">auxiliary schedule</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="maintenancecontract"><b>maintenance contract</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal agreement in which an outside company agrees to check designated <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a> on a regular basis after any <a href="#warranty">warranty</a>
has expired, and to maintain it in good working order, including major
repairs as needed, in exchange for payment of a monthly or annual fee,
an arrangement common in <a href="#library">libraries</a> that own their own <a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a>s, <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a> machines, computer equipment, etc.
<p>
Also refers to an agreement with an outside company to clean and maintain a <a href="#library">library</a> facility on a regular basis, in exchange for payment of a monthly or annual <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  Some libraries and <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s hire their own maintenance personnel, or use the services provided by the parent organization.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="major"><b>major</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> or <a href="#identifier">identifier</a> in an <a href="#index">index</a> <a href="#entry">entry</a> or <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, representing a main focus or <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the <a href="#document">document</a> indexed, usually indicated by an <a href="#asterisk">asterisk</a> or other <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>, or distinguished <a href="#typography">typographically</a>.  <a href="#minor">Minor</a> descriptors and identifiers representing less significant aspects of the <a href="#content">content</a> are left unmarked. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="majordomo"><b>Majordomo</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> designed to run on the <a href="#unix">UNIX</a> <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>.  Compare with <a href="#listserv">LISTSERV</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mola"><b>Major Orchestra Librarians' Association (MOLA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1983 by representatives of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Boston Symphony, and Minnesota Orchestra, <b>MOLA</b> is an international organization devoted to improving communication among performance <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and helping them provide better service to their orchestras.  The <a href="#association">association</a> also presents a unified voice in relations with music <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s.  Its membership includes over 170 <a href="#library">libraries</a> associated with orchestras, opera and ballet companies, military bands, and music conservatories.  <b>MOLA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em>Marcato</em> and hosts the <em>MOLAList</em> electronic <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>.  <a href="http://mola-inc.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>MOLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="majuscule"><b>majuscule</b></a>

</dt><dd>A large <a href="#capitalletter">capital</a> or <a href="#uncial">uncial</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a> used in Greek and Latin <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s of the 4th and 5th centuries A.D., as distinct from a small letter or <a href="#minuscule">minuscule</a>. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="makeready"><b>makeready</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of preparing the <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a> for a <a href="#pressrun">press run</a>, including adjustment of the <a href="#forme">forme</a> or <a href="#plate">plate</a>s to produce a uniform <a href="#impression">impression</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="makeup"><b>make-up</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a> <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the process of removing <a href="#type">type</a> from the <a href="#galley">galley</a>s and arranging it in <a href="#page">page</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, including the positioning of <a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#note">note</a>s, and <a href="#runninghead">running head</a>s in accordance with the <a href="#typography">typographer</a>'s <a href="#layout">layout</a>, done by a worker known as a <a href="#compositor">compositor</a>.  Also spelled <em>makeup</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#remake">remake</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a list of the <a href="#contents">contents</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> in the order in which they are to be <a href="#binding">bound</a>, provided by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to the <a href="#binding">binder</a> to ensure that any <a href="#plate">plate</a>s or other additions not <a href="#printing">printed</a> with the <a href="#text">text</a> are included in correct sequence.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="malapropism"><b>malapropism</b></a>
</dt><dd>The accidental or intentional misuse of words, especially two
words of similar pronunciation but very different meaning. The term is
derived from Mrs. Malaprop, the name of a <a href="#character">character</a> in Sheridan's <a href="#play">play</a> <b><em>The Rivals</em></b>
(1775) who had a habit of using polysyllabic words incorrectly
("...don't attempt to extirpate yourself from the matter"). Earlier
examples can be found in the utterances of the constable Dogberry in
Shakespeare's <b><em>Much Ado About Nothing</em></b>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="managedbook"><b>managed book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> on a <a href="#topic">topic</a> chosen by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, who controls and directs every aspect of its creation.  If a paid staff writer or <a href="#freelance">freelancer</a> is used for the <a href="#text">text</a>, the structure of the <a href="#work">work</a> is usually based on an <a href="#outline">outline</a> provided by the publisher.  In books with a preponderance of <a href="#picture">pictorial</a> <a href="#content">content</a>, the name of the <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#editor">editor</a> may not be given on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  Compare with <a href="#packagedbook">packaged book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mis"><b>management information system (MIS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer-based <a href="#information">information</a> system developed and maintained by a commercial enterprise to integrate <a href="#data">data</a>
from all its departments (product development, production and
inventory, marketing and sales, personnel administration, etc.) to
support managerial and supervisory decision-making with <a href="#realtime">real time</a> analysis.  <b>MIS</b> systems are designed to track progress towards achievement of the company's <a href="#goal">goal</a>s and <a href="#objective">objective</a>s, including the identification of problems or obstacles that must be resolved by upper-level management.  In the plural, the <a href="#term">term</a> refers to the study and teaching of such systems.  Courses on <b>MIS</b> are offered as a major at some business schools in the United States.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mandatory"><b>mandatory (M)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#field">field</a> or <a href="#subfield">subfield</a> of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> in which <a href="#data">data</a> must be entered to meet <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <a href="#inputstandards">input standards</a> for a given <a href="#encodinglevel">encoding level</a>.  Compare with <a href="#optional">optional</a> and <a href="#requiredif">required if applicable or readily available</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="manifestation"><b>manifestation</b></a>
</dt><dd>As defined in <em><a href="#frbr">FRBR</a></em> (<em>Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records</em>), the result of a single act of physical embodiment/production of a specific <a href="#expression">expression</a> of a creative <a href="#work">work</a>, for example, an <a href="#edition">edition</a> of one of the <a href="#variant">variant</a> <a href="#text">text</a>s of a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> (1993 Yale University Press edition of <b><em>Hamlet</em></b>), or a recording of a specific performance of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> (1998 recording of <b><em>West Side Story</em></b> released by Sony/Columbia on <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>).  A manifestation consists of all the physical objects (<a href="#bibitem">item</a>s) possessing the same characteristics with respect to intellectual/artistic <a href="#content">content</a> and physical form, in most instances a set of multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a> produced for commercial distribution.  However, for some expressions there may be only a single <a href="#exemplar">exemplar</a>, as in the case of an <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#oralhistory">oral history</a> recording, an <a href="#author">author</a>'s <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, or a <a href="#oneofakind">one-of-a-kind</a> <a href="#artbook">art book</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="manifesto"><b>manifesto</b></a>
</dt><dd>A public declaration, in writing or in speech, of beliefs,
motives, plans, and/or intentions, made by an individual, group, or
government (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Mein Kampf</em></b> by Adolf Hitler).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="manila"><b>manila</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thick, <a href="#durability">durable</a> buff-colored <a href="#paper">paper</a>, originally manufactured from Manila hemp fiber, used mainly for <a href="#file">file</a> <a href="#folder">folder</a>s and mailing envelopes.  Also spelled <em>manilla</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="manual"><b>manual</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> of compact size, especially one
describing in considerable detail the government of a state or the
structure and functions of a <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The United States Government Manual</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by the U.S. <a href="#gpo">GPO</a>).  
<p>
Also refers to a book or <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>
containing practical instructions, rules, or steps for performing a
task or operation, assembling a manufactured object, or using a system
or piece of equipment (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Manual of Archival Description</em></b> published by Gower).  Used synonymously with <a href="#handbook">handbook</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#stylemanual">style manual</a>.  
</p><p>
Also, any operation or procedure done by hand rather than by machine.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="manufacturer"><b>manufacturer</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#agency">agency</a> responsible for actually making a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>.  In the case of <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, the <a href="#printer">printer</a> is the manufacturer.  Compare with <a href="#producer">producer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="manuscript"><b>manuscript</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> <em>codex manu scriptus</em>.  Strictly speaking, a <a href="#work">work</a> of any kind (<a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>, music <a href="#score">score</a>, <a href="#map">map</a>, etc.) written entirely by hand.  Also refers to the handwritten or <a href="#typescript">typescript</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> of an <a href="#author">author</a>'s work as submitted for <a href="#publication">publication</a>, before <a href="#printing">printing</a>.  In the United States, <a href="#bibcontrol">bibliographic control</a> of manuscript <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s is provided by the <a href="#nucmc">National Union Catalog of Manuscript Collections</a> (NUCMC), a <a href="#cooperativecat">cooperative cataloging</a> program of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, manuscripts are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under the rules for printed <a href="#book">book</a>s.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>ms.</em> and <em>mss.</em> in the plural.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a>, <a href="#manuscriptbook">manuscript book</a>, and <a href="#manuscriptsociety">Manuscript Society</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="manuscriptbook"><b>manuscript book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> written entirely by hand, particularly one produced prior to the invention of <a href="#printing">printing</a> from <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>, usually <a href="#copy">copied</a> by medieval monks or <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>s on <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>, <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#leather">leather</a>-covered wooden <a href="#board">board</a>s.  Medieval manuscript books were often <a href="#rubric">rubric</a>ated, <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a>, and/or embellished with <a href="#miniature">miniature</a>s. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bookofhours">Book of Hours</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="manuscriptsociety"><b>Manuscript Society, The</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1948 as the National Society of Autograph Collectors, <b>The Manuscript Society</b> has since grown to a membership of over 1,800 scholars, <a href="#author">author</a>s, <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>s, private <a href="#bookcollecting">collector</a>s, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#archivist">archivist</a>s, and <a href="#curator">curator</a>s.  Its membership also includes <a href="#historicalsociety">historical societies</a>, museums, <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>, and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> with <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  The Society <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>Manuscripts</em> and the <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em>Manuscript Society News</em>.  <a href="http://www.manuscript.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of <b>The Manuscript Society</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="map"><b>map</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any two-dimensional representation of all or a portion of the
earth's surface, the heavens, or another celestial body, normally done
to <a href="#scale">scale</a> on a flat <a href="#sheetmap">sheet</a>.  Early maps were drawn on <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> stored in <a href="#roll">roll</a>s.  In modern <a href="#library">libraries</a>, maps are usually stored flat or folded in a specially designed <a href="#mapcase">map case</a> with wide, shallow drawers.  Maps are also included as <a href="#insert">insert</a>s or <a href="#pocketpart">pocket part</a>s in <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s.  As <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, they may be <a href="#printing">printed</a> as <a href="#plate">plate</a>s with the <a href="#text">text</a>, or on the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s.  An <a href="#atlas">atlas</a> is a book consisting almost entirely of maps, with the <a href="#content">content</a> usually <a href="#index">index</a>ed in a <a href="#gazetteer">gazetteer</a> at the end.  The largest <a href="#mappingagency">mapping agency</a> in the United States is the <a href="http://www.usgs.gov/">U.S. Geological Survey</a>.  <a href="http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/gmdhtml/gmdhome.html">Click here</a> to connect to an historical map <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> available <a href="#online">online</a>, courtesy of the <em><a href="http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/ammemhome.html">American Memory</a></em> project at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  Compare with <a href="#globe">globe</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cartography">cartography</a>, <a href="#cartouche">cartouche</a>, <a href="#legend">legend</a>, <a href="#mapseries">map series</a>, and <a href="#projection">projection</a>.
<p> 
Maps are categorized by the type of <a href="#content">content</a> and method of presentation.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#aerialmap">aerial map</a>, <a href="#astronomicalmap">astronomical map</a>, <a href="#bathymetricmap">bathymetric map</a>, <a href="#cadastralmap">cadastral map</a>, <a href="#cartogram">cartogram</a>, <a href="#choropleth">choropleth map</a>, <a href="#citymap">city map</a>, <a href="#contourmap">contour map</a>, <a href="#dynamicmap">dynamic map</a>, <a href="#geologicmap">geologic map</a>, <a href="#hydrologicmap">hydrologic map</a>, <a href="#indexmap">index map</a>, <a href="#insetmap">inset map</a>, <a href="#interactivemap">interactive map</a>, <a href="#mentalmap">mental map</a>, <a href="#multimediamap">multimedia map</a>, <a href="#photomap">photomap</a>, <a href="#planimetric">planimetric map</a>, <a href="#politicalmap">political map</a>, <a href="#raremap">rare map</a>, <a href="#reliefmap">relief map</a>, <a href="#roadmap">road map</a>, <a href="#thematicmap">thematic map</a>, and <a href="#topographic">topographic map</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="magert"><b>Map and Geography Round Table (MAGERT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> established in 1980, <b>MAGERT</b> is the world's largest organization devoted to <a href="#map">map</a> and geography <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>.  Membership is open to ALA members who work with or have an interest in map and geography <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s and <a href="#information">information</a> related to maps and mapping.  <b>MAGERT</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>Meridian</em> and the <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em>Base Line</em>.  <a href="http://magert.whoi.edu:8000/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>MAGERT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mapcase"><b>map case</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> furnishing, usually made of wood or metal, containing a <a href="#number">number</a> of wide, shallow drawers in which large <a href="#sheetmap">sheet map</a>s can be stored flat, with a large smooth top on which they can be spread for examination.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mapindex"><b>map index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> list of the <a href="#geographicname">place name</a>s written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a <a href="#map">map</a> or <a href="#mapseries">series of maps</a>, giving the location of each feature, usually as <a href="#grid">grid</a> <a href="#coordinate">coordinate</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#indexmap">index map</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="maplibrary"><b>map library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> or unit within a library which has <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s consisting primarily of <a href="#cartographic">cartographic material</a>s that are of <a href="#currency">current</a> or historic interest, including <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>es, <a href="#gazetteer">gazetteer</a>s, <a href="#chart">chart</a>s, <a href="#globe">globe</a>s, relief <a href="#model">model</a>s, <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#data">data</a>, remotely sensed images, etc., for example, the <a href="http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/index.html">Perry-Castaneda Library Map Collection</a> at the University of Texas.  <em>Map librarians</em> are organized in the <a href="#magert">Map and Geography Round Table</a> (MAGERT) of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mapping"><b>mapping</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#vocabmap">vocabulary mapping</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mappingagency"><b>mapping agency</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization that produces and <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> <a href="#map">map</a>s and other <a href="#cartographic">cartographic</a> <a href="#information">information</a>,
usually under the sponsorship of a national government or its armed
forces. The largest mapping agency in the United States is the <a href="http://www.usgs.gov/">U.S. Geological Survey</a>. In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, name of mapping <a href="#agency">agency</a> is given in the <a href="#statementof">statement of responsibility</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of a cartographic <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mapseries"><b>map series</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#series">series</a> of <a href="#sheetmap">sheet map</a>s, all drawn to the same <a href="#scale">scale</a> and specifications, encompassing a clearly defined geographic area when complete, identified collectively by the <a href="#mappingagency">mapping agency</a> that produced them. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="marbi"><b>MARBI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>MA</b>chine-<b>R</b>eadable <b>B</b>ibliographic <b>I</b>nformation Committee, the body within the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> responsible for developing official ALA <a href="#standards">standards</a> for the representation of bibliographic <a href="#information">information</a> in <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  Its membership includes nine voting members from <a href="#alcts">ALCTS</a>, <a href="#lita">LITA</a>, and <a href="#rusa">RUSA</a>, and three interns.  Members of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> Advisory Committee to the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> also participate in its deliberations, including ex-officio representatives of the <a href="#nationallib">national libraries</a> and <a href="#bibutility">bibliographic utilities</a>,
and several dozen nonvoting liaisons from other units within the ALA
and from non-ALA organizations with an interest in issues related to <a href="#library">library</a> automation standards.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/alcts/organization/div/marbi/marbi.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>MARBI</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="marbling"><b>marbling</b></a>
</dt><dd>A style of decorative <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a> used in hand <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, bearing a design produced by water colors floated on the gummed surface of a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>.
The liquid pigments are swirled with a special comb in a pattern
resembling the surface of cut marble. The technique is also used on
book <a href="#cover">cover</a>s, and to decorate the edges of the <a href="#section">section</a>s
of a book. Developed in the 17th century, probably in France, marbing
was particularly popular during the Victorian period. As a less
expensive alternative, endpapers are sometimes <a href="#printing">printed</a> with a pattern resembling hand-marbled paper.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="marc"><b>MARC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#machinecat"><b>MA</b>chine-<b>R</b>eadable <b>C</b>ataloging</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="marcese"><b>MARCese</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#jargon">jargon</a> used by <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s who work extensively with <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s and fall into the habit of using <a href="#contentdesignator">content designator</a>s (<a href="#tag">tag</a>s, <a href="#indicator">indicator</a>s, and <a href="#subfieldcode">subfield code</a>s) instead of words and <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s to refer to <a href="#area">area</a>s and <a href="#element">element</a>s of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="margin"><b>margin</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any one of the four <a href="#blank">blank</a> borders around the <a href="#matter">matter</a> written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a <a href="#page">page</a> or <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>, known as the <em>top</em> or <em>head</em> margin; the <em>bottom</em>, <em>foot</em>, or <em>tail</em> margin; the <em>outer</em>, <em>outside</em>, or <em><a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a></em> margin; and the <em>inner</em>, <em>inside</em>, <em>back</em>, or <em><a href="#bindingmargin">binding margin</a></em>.  The combined inner margins of facing pages form the <a href="#gutter">gutter</a>.  The relationship of the widths of the four margins is an important factor in the design of a <a href="#legibility">legible</a>,
aesthetically pleasing page. Standard proportions are: bottom margin
double the top and inside margin 1/2 or 2/3 of the outside. <a href="#rebinding">Rebinding</a> may require <a href="#trimmed">trimming</a> the inner margin of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#marginalia">marginalia</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="marginalia"><b>marginalia</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#heading">Heading</a>s or <a href="#note">note</a>s written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#margin">margin</a>s of a <a href="#page">page</a>, usually in writing or <a href="#type">type</a> of a <a href="#typesize">size</a> or style distinct from that of the <a href="#text">text</a>.  Marginalia include <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s, <a href="#sidenote">side note</a>s, and <a href="#shouldernote">shoulder note</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="marginalnote"><b>marginal note</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#sidenote">side note</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="markup"><b>mark up</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, to prepare <a href="#copy">copy</a> for <a href="#printing">printing</a> by specifying details of <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>, <a href="#font">font</a>s, <a href="#layout">layout</a>, etc., in a code comprehensible to the <a href="#compositor">compositor</a> or <a href="#typesetting">typesetter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="masque"><b>masque</b></a>
</dt><dd>A lavish form of court entertainment that originated in
Renaissance Italy and was particularly popular during the reigns of
Elizabeth I, James I, and Charles I of England. Masques combined music,
song, dance, and <a href="#poetry">poetic</a> <a href="#play">drama</a> in a spectacular display of costume and elaborate staging held together by a loose <a href="#allegory">allegorical</a> <a href="#plot">plot</a>, usually based on a <a href="#myth">myth</a>ological theme (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Masque of Blacknesse</em></b> by Ben Jonson).  The name is derived from the face <em>masques</em> worn by the members of court who played the main <a href="#character">character</a>s.  This costly form of royal amusement ended with the Puritan revolution of 1642. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="massdeacid"><b>mass deacidification</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#deacidification">deacidification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="massmarket"><b>mass-market paperback</b></a>
</dt><dd>A new <a href="#work">work</a> or a <a href="#reprint">reprint</a> of a <a href="#title">title</a> previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>, produced and distributed in <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> for sale at newsstands and in supermarkets, drugstores, chain stores, etc., rather than <a href="#tradebookstore">trade bookstore</a>s.  <a href="#copy">Copies</a> are usually of standard rack-size (4 x 7 inches), <a href="#printing">printed</a> on poor quality <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#binding">bound</a> with <a href="#hotmelt">hot melt</a> <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a>, and priced to sell to the widest possible <a href="#audience">audience</a>.  The <a href="#format">format</a> is used extensively for <a href="#popularfiction">popular fiction</a> and <a href="#genre">genre</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> prefer them for <a href="#booksbymail">books-by-mail</a> programs to keep mailing costs down.  In some <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, mass-market paperbacks received as <a href="#gift">gift</a>s are <a href="#circulation">circulated</a> on the honor system.  Compare with <a href="#tradepaperback">trade paperback</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pulpfiction">pulp fiction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="massmedia"><b>mass media</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#media">media</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="master"><b>master</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#reprography">reprography</a>, the <a href="#plate">plate</a>, stencil, <a href="#negative">negative</a>, or <a href="#document">document</a> from which <a href="#copy">copies</a> are made, usually more than once.  The quality of a master copy usually deteriorates with extended use.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#generation">generation</a>, <a href="#masternegative">master negative</a>, and <a href="#printmaster">print master</a>.
<p>
Also refers to an artist, writer, <a href="#composer">composer</a>, or craftsman who consistently creates <a href="#work">work</a>s of the highest quality (<em>example</em>:  Mozart).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#masterpiece">masterpiece</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="masternegative"><b>master negative</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a>, the first <a href="#generation">generation</a> <a href="#negative">negative</a>, developed from the <a href="#film">film</a> used to shoot the image, from which at least one <a href="#printmaster">print master</a> is made, usually stored in a separate location under controlled conditions and used as little as possible.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#servicecopy">service copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="masterpiece"><b>masterpiece</b></a>
</dt><dd>A work of art, craftsmanship, or writing universally recognized as embodying the highest skill of a great <a href="#master">master</a> or group of masters.  An artist, <a href="#composer">composer</a>, or writer may produce a single masterpiece (<em>examples</em>:  Charlotte and Emily Bronte) or more than one masterpiece in a lifetime (Jane Austen).  Synonymous with <em>chef-d'oeuvre</em>.  Compare with <a href="#magnumopus">magnum opus</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="masthead"><b>masthead</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#box">box</a> or <a href="#column">column</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> in each <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, stating the <a href="#title">title</a> of the <a href="#publication">publication</a>, its <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, ownership, <a href="#editor">editor</a>s, <a href="#frequency">frequency</a>, <a href="#issn">ISSN</a>, <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> rates, and giving notice of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, usually with contact <a href="#information">information</a>.  In a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, the mastehead is found on the <a href="#editorial">editorial</a> <a href="#page">page</a> or on <a href="#page">page</a> one.  In <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s and <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, it is usually printed on or near the page bearing the <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a>.  Compare with <em>flag</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dateline">date line</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mat"><b>mat</b></a>
</dt><dd>Two pieces of <a href="#board">board</a>, hinged along one edge for <a href="#mounted">mounting</a> a <a href="#print">print</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>, etc., the bottom piece providing support (backing) and the top piece cut in the shape of a <a href="#window">window</a> through which the image is viewed.  In quality framing, prints are often <em>double-</em> or <em>triple-matted</em> in boards of contrasting color. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="matchinggrant"><b>matching grant</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#grant">grant</a> made by a foundation, <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>,
or individual, contingent on the recipient raising sufficient funds to
match the donor's contribution. Although the ratio of grant funds to
contributions may vary, most are dollar-for-dollar up to a fixed
amount, with a time limit imposed on fund-raising activities. Some
federal <a href="#lsta">LSTA</a> <a href="#grantinaid">grants-in-aid</a> are structured in this way. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="materialsbudget"><b>materials budget</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portion of a <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#operatingbudget">operating budget</a> <a href="#allocation">allocated</a> for the purchase of <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#media">media</a>, <a href="#serial">serial</a>s, and other <a href="#information">information</a> resources for the use of its <a href="#clientele">clientele</a> and <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>, as opposed to expenditures for <a href="#salary">salaries</a> and <a href="#wages">wages</a>, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a>, and services.  Some libraries include <em>electronic resources</em> in the <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> <a href="#budget">budget</a>, others make a separate allocation. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="materialspecific"><b>material specific details (MSD)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic <a href="#term">term</a> for the <a href="#area">area</a> of a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> reserved for <a href="#element">element</a>s of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> specific to certain types of material (<a href="#musicalpresentation">musical presentation</a>, <a href="#mathdata">mathematical data</a>, and <a href="#numericalphabetic">numeric and/or alphabetic, chronological, or other designation</a>) recorded in <a href="#field">field</a> 254 of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> for music, field 255 for <a href="#cartographic">cartographic material</a>s, and field 362 for <a href="#serial">serial</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="materialtype"><b>material type</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#option">option</a> available to users of some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s that allows <a href="#search">search</a> results to be <a href="#limiting">limited</a> to <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> of a specific physical <a href="#format">format</a> (<a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>, <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>, <a href="#map">map</a>, music <a href="#score">score</a>, etc.).  In <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, material type is assigned to the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> from a list established by the local <a href="#library">library</a> (or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>) and is not necessarily the same as the <a href="#itemtype">item type</a> used for <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> purposes.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#gmd">GMD</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mathdata"><b>mathematical data</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#field">field</a> within the <a href="#materialspecific">materials specific details</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> in which mathematical <a href="#element">element</a>s in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of <a href="#cartographic">cartographic materials</a> are entered (<a href="#scale">scale</a>, <a href="#projection">projection</a>, <a href="#coordinate">coordinate</a>s, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="matte"><b>matte</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#paper">Paper</a> that has a dull unreflective <a href="#finish">finish</a>, easier on the eye of the <a href="#reader">reader</a> than <a href="#glossy">glossy</a> finish, but not as visually appealing for <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s.  Also spelled <em>matt</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="matter"><b>matter</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#copy">copy</a> in the process of being <a href="#typesetting">set</a> in <a href="#type">type</a>, or already set (standing).  <em>Live</em> matter has yet to be used in printing; <em>dead</em> matter has been used and is ready to be <em>broken up</em>.  The terms <em>fat matter</em> and <em>lean matter</em> refer to the proportion of <a href="#whitespace">white space</a> or broken lines on a <a href="#page">page</a>.  <a href="#printer">Printer</a>s also differentiate between <a href="#bodymatter">body matter</a> and <a href="#displaymatter">display matter</a>.  Also refers to copy that is to be printed, in <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#typescript">typescript</a> form. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="maximize"><b>maximize</b></a>
</dt><dd>A feature of a <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a> that allows the user to enlarge a <a href="#window">window</a> to its fullest size by clicking on a small button in the upper right-hand corner of the window.  The opposite of <a href="#minimize">minimize</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#multitasking">multitasking</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mazarin"><b><em>Mazarin Bible</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#gutenbergbible">Gutenberg Bible</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mcluhan"><b>McLuhan, Marshall (1911-1980)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The University of Toronto professor of <a href="#literature">literature</a>
and culture who became famous for his innovative theories about how
methods of communication influence society. In 1963, his analysis of
the effect of <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a> on the culture of 15th century Europe (<b><em>The Gutenberg Galaxy: The Making of Typographic Man</em></b>)
won the Governor-General's award for critical writing. In 1964, McLuhan
gained considerable attention in the popular press for <b><em>Understanding Media: The Extensions of Man</em></b> in which he argued that the communication <a href="#media">media</a>
used by humans are extensions of the physical senses which, by their
very nature, introduce changes in the way societies function and in
human consciousness, apart from the <a href="#content">content</a> they convey.  His assertion that "the <a href="#medium">medium</a> is the message" eventually became "the medium is the massage."  For more about his life and work, see <b><em>Marshall McLuhan: The Medium and the Messenger</em></b> (1989) by Philip Marchand.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mcnaughton"><b>McNaughton Plan</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#booklease">book lease plan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="meanline"><b>mean line</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typography">typography</a>, the imaginary horizontal line running along the tops of the <a href="#xheight">x-height</a> <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of a <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#font">font</a> that lack <a href="#ascender">ascender</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>x-line</em>.  Compare with <a href="#capline">cap line</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#baseline">base line</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mechanical"><b>mechanical binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a>
are held together by some type of mechanism, usually metal or plastic
wire or rings threaded or inserted through holes or slots punched along
the back <a href="#margin">margin</a> parallel to the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a>, to allow the <a href="#volume">volume</a> to <a href="#openability">open</a> flat.  The category includes <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> binding, <a href="#combbinding">comb binding</a>, and <a href="#spiralbinding">spiral binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="media"><b>media</b></a>         
</dt><dd>A generic <a href="#term">term</a> for <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> (<a href="#film">film</a>s, <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>s, <a href="#slide">slide</a>s, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, <a href="#audiorecording">audiorecording</a>s, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>s, <a href="#mrdf">machine-readable data file</a>s, computer <a href="#software">software</a>, etc.).  <a href="#microform">Microform</a>s are not considered media because they are <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>s of print <a href="#document">document</a>s.  The person responsible for managing a media <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> and associated equipment is a <a href="#mediaspecialist">media specialist</a>.  <a href="#review">Review</a>s of newly <a href="#publishing">published</a> media <a href="#title">title</a>s are <a href="#index">index</a>ed <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by type of <a href="#medium">medium</a> in <b><em>Media Review Digest</em></b>.  Synonymous with <em>audiovisuals</em>.  In a more general sense, material in <em>any</em> <a href="#format">format</a> that carries and communicates <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#content">content</a>.
<p>
Also refers collectively to all the <a href="#channel">channel</a>s through which information is <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>, including radio, television, cable, and the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  The <em>mass media</em> disseminate public information to the widest possible <a href="#audience">audience</a>
(and some would argue to the lowest common denominator) with a close
eye on the profits to be made from advertising, as in the case of major
commercial television networks. Although the producers of this one-way
flow of information may use polling to reveal the characteristics of
their listeners or viewers, the individuals who receive their message
remain largely anonymous. The <em>news media</em> (<a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, <a href="#newsmagazine">news magazine</a>s, news broadcasts, news <a href="#website">Web site</a>s, etc.) specialize in providing the latest information about current events, with or without <a href="#commentary">commentary</a>, usually without intending to entertain.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> information on print and broadcast media is available in the <b><em>Gale Directory of Publications and Broadcast Media</em></b>, an <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> available in most <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and large <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pubtv">public television</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mediacenter"><b>media center</b></a>
</dt><dd>A facility within an educational institution, responsible for providing a full-range of <a href="#media">media</a> resources, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, and services, staffed to assist students and instructors in utilizing its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, usually supervised by a <a href="#mediaspecialist">media specialist</a>.  A media center can be a separate facility, a separately administered unit located in the same building as a <a href="#library">library</a>, or an integral part of the library.  Synonymous with <em>learning resources center</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#listeningroom">listening room</a> and <a href="#viewingroom">viewing room</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mediarate"><b>media mail</b></a>
</dt><dd>A special rate available from the U.S. Postal Service to businesses and the public for mailing <a href="#book">book</a>s of at least eight <a href="#page">page</a>s, <a href="#film">film</a> (16 mm or narrower), <a href="#printing">printed</a> music, printed test materials, <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>s, <a href="#play">play</a> <a href="#script">script</a>s, printed educational <a href="#chart">chart</a>s, <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> pages and <a href="#binder">binder</a>s containing medical <a href="#information">information</a>,
and computer-readable media, lower than the rate charged for parcels of
comparable weight which do not contain such items. Advertising
restrictions apply. Synonymous with <em>book post</em> and <em>book rate</em>.  Compare with <a href="#libraryrate">library rate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mediaspecialist"><b>media specialist</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or other individual with <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> training in the creation, <a href="#selection">selection</a>, organization, maintenance, and provision of <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#media">media</a> of all kinds, who may also be responsible for supervising a <a href="#mediacenter">media center</a> or the media department of a <a href="#library">library</a>, including <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, and facilities for <a href="#listeningroom">listening</a> and/or <a href="#viewingroom">viewing</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mediated"><b>mediated search</b></a>
</dt><dd>A systematic <a href="#search">search</a> in which a trained <a href="#intermediary">intermediary</a>, such as an <a href="#onlineservices">online services</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or <a href="#informationbroker">information broker</a>, assists the <a href="#enduser">end-user</a> in locating desired <a href="#information">information</a>, by helping to formulate and execute appropriate <a href="#searchstrategy">strategies</a> for searching <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>s, and by using more traditional bibliographic <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#endusersearch">end-user search</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="medicalbook"><b>medical book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#print">print</a> or on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> for the use of medical practitioners, researchers, and/or students (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Physician's Desk Reference</em></b>), or for laypersons with an interest in health care (<b><em>Harvard Medical School Family Health Guide</em></b>).  The category includes <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s, <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s, and <a href="#consumerguide">consumer guide</a>s, often published in successive <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  <a href="#currency">Currency</a> is essential in maintaining medical <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#medicallib">medical library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="medicallib"><b>medical library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a> maintained by a university medical school, hospital, medical <a href="#research">research</a> institute, public health <a href="#govtagency">agency</a>, or medical <a href="#association">association</a> to serve the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of students, <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s, and practitioners in the health sciences (medicine, nursing, dentistry, pharmacy, etc.), with <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s that include <a href="#print">print</a> and <a href="#online">online</a> resources related to medicine and allied health.  The largest medical <a href="#library">library</a> in the United States is the <a href="#nlm">National Library of Medicine</a>, located in Washington, D.C.  Medical <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s are organized in the <a href="#medicallibassoc">Medical Library Association</a>.  Synonymous with <em>health science library</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#hospitallib">hospital library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="medicallibassoc"><b>Medical Library Association (MLA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1898, <b>MLA</b> has a membership of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and other individuals engaged in professional <a href="#library">library</a> or bibliographic work in <a href="#medicallib">medical libraries</a> and allied scientific libraries.  An <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>MLA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em><a href="http://www.mlanet.org/publications/bmla/index.html">Bulletin of the Medical Library Association (BMLA)</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.mlanet.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>MLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="medium"><b>medium</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#isar">information storage and retrieval</a>, the physical substance or material on which <a href="#data">data</a> is recorded (<a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#film">film</a>, <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a> or <a href="#disk">disk</a>, <a href="#opticaldisk">optical disk</a>, etc.) or through which data is transmitted (<a href="#opticalfiber">optical fiber</a>, <a href="#coaxial">coaxial cable</a>, <a href="#twistedpair">twisted pair</a>, etc.).  In a more general sense, the material or technical means by which any creative <a href="#work">work</a> is expressed or communicated, in <a href="#print">print</a> or <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  Plural: <em>media</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mcluhan">McLuhan, Marshall</a>. 
<p>
In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> of intermediate <a href="#weight">weight</a>, as distinct from <a href="#lightface">lightface</a> or <a href="#boldface">boldface</a>.  Medium type is standard for printed <a href="#text">text</a>.  
</p><p>
<b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mediumistic">mediumistic writing</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mediumistic"><b>mediumistic writing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written <a href="#work">work</a> transmitted through a
psychic medium who claims to have received it as a communication from
the spirit of a dead person or entity. In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, such works are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under the name of the medium with an <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> under the name of the purported <a href="#author">author</a>(s).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mediumofperf"><b>medium of performance</b></a>
</dt><dd>The voice(s) and/or instrument(s) for which a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> is <a href="#composer">composed</a>, recorded in the <a href="#notearea">note area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> in the order given on the actual <a href="#bibitem">item</a> (<em>example</em>:  soprano and piano).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="medlars"><b><em>MEDLARS</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <em><b>MED</b>ical <b>L</b>iterature <b>A</b>nalysis and <b>R</b>etrieval <b>S</b>ervice</em>, a collection of <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>s maintained and leased to <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#research">research</a> institutions by the <a href="#nlm">National Library of Medicine</a> (NLM), including <em><a href="#medline">MEDLINE</a></em>, <em>AIDSLINE</em>, <em>TOXLINE</em>, etc.  <a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/databases/databases.html">Click here</a> to see a <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> list of NLM databases and electronic resources. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="medley"><b>medley</b></a>
</dt><dd>A musical <a href="#composition">composition</a> consisting of a string of well-known melodies or passages from various <a href="#piece">piece</a>s which share a common characteristic (<a href="#composer">composed</a> by the same person, during the same period, in the same <a href="#genre">genre</a>, etc.), arranged so that the end of one coincides with the beginning of the next, with no break in continuity.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="medline"><b><em>MEDLINE</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Created and maintained by the <a href="#nlm">National Library of Medicine</a>, <b><em>MEDLINE</em></b> is the largest <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> in the world, indexing the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of the biomedical sciences.  It includes <em>Index Medicus</em>, <em>Index to Dental Literature</em>, and <em>International Nursing</em>.  It also covers allied health, biological and physical sciences, humanities, and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a> as they relate to medicine and health care, communication disorders, population biology, and reproductive biology.  <b><em>MEDLINE</em></b> contains over 11 million <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s representing <a href="#article">article</a>s <a href="#indexing">indexed</a> since 1966 from over 3,900 <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, as well as <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> as the result of biomedical congresses and <a href="#symposium">symposia</a>.  Approximately 67% of the records in <b><em>MEDLINE</em></b> include <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>s.  <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/PubMed/">Click here</a> to connect to <b><em>PubMed</em></b>, the free public version of <b><em>MEDLINE</em></b> sponsored by the <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/">National Center for Biotechnology Information</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="megabook"><b>megabook</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#blockbuster">blockbuster</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="megabyte"><b>megabyte (MB)</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#byte">byte</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="megahertz"><b>MegaHertz (MHz)</b></a>

</dt><dd>A measurement of the transmission speed of electronic devices,
named after the German physicist Heinrich R. Hertz. One MHz equals one
million cycles per second. In computing, a MegaHertz is usually equal
to one million bps (<a href="#bit">bit</a>s per second).  When used in reference to a computer's clock, the number of MHz indicates the speed of the <a href="#cpu">central processing unit</a> (CPU). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="melodrama"><b>melodrama</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek word <em>melos</em> meaning "music."  The <a href="#term">term</a> originally referred to all dramatic <a href="#work">work</a>s that included music, but in 19th-century England it was applied to a <a href="#play">play</a> in which the <a href="#character">character</a>s
are stereotyped (good or bad), the action exaggerated and emotional,
and the plot improbable and/or sensational, interspersed with catchy
songs and orchestral accompaniment, with an invariably happy ending (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Sweeney Todd, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street</em></b>).  Melodrama bears the same relationship to <a href="#tragedy">tragedy</a> as <a href="#farce">farce</a> to <a href="#comedy">comedy</a>.  In contemporary <a href="#usage">usage</a>, the adjective <em>melodramatic</em> is applied to any performance or <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> in which the characters are overdrawn and the action taxes the credulity of <a href="#audience">audience</a> or <a href="#reader">reader</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="memo"><b>memo</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#memorandum">memorandum</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="memoir"><b>memoir</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#record">record</a> or <a href="#report">report</a> of a person's investigations in a <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#field">field</a>, especially one prepared for presentation to members of a scholarly <a href="#society">society</a>.  Also, a record of <a href="#research">research</a> or observation <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by a scholarly society or institution.  Synonymous, in the plural, with <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a> and <a href="#transactions">transactions</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="memoirs"><b>memoirs</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> of events or reminiscences based on the <a href="#author">author</a>'s own observations or personal <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>
of the world in which he (or she) lived, including events witnessed,
people known or observed, places visited, etc. The life need not have
been historically significant, but one which placed the writer in a
position to observe first-hand significant events as they unfolded.
Unlike a private <a href="#diary">diary</a> or <a href="#journal">journal</a>, memoirs are usually written for <a href="#publication">publication</a> long after the occurrence of the events described, and do not necessarily provide a day-to-day account.  Compare with <a href="#autobiography">autobiography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="memorabilia"><b>memorabilia</b></a>
</dt><dd>Materials of sentimental or historical value to the person who created or collected them, including personal <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#papers">papers</a>, <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, sketches, <a href="#correspondence">correspondence</a>, <a href="#diary">diaries</a>, <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, notes, invitations, etc.  Memorabilia are usually added to <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>, in accordance with a <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#collecdevelpolicy">collection development policy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="memorandum"><b>memorandum</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal note distributed internally to one or more persons in a company, <a href="#agency">agency</a>,
organization, or institution, with a header indicating the date it was
sent and stating to whom it is addressed (To:), from whom it is sent
(From:), and the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a> (Re:).  Unlike a <a href="#letters">letter</a>, a <em>memo</em> does not require a full salutation or <a href="#signature">signature</a> at the end of the <a href="#text">text</a>--the sender may simply initial his or her name in the header.  Plural:  <em>memoranda</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="memory"><b>memory</b></a>
</dt><dd>The space available for holding or storing <a href="#data">data</a> on a computer.  <em>External memory</em> consists of permanent <a href="#storage">storage</a> space on <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a>s and <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>s.  <em>Main memory</em> (<a href="#ram">RAM</a>) stores data only during a single work session, which is why <a href="#file">file</a>s must be <a href="#save">save</a>d before ending a session.  Because main memory also allocates space to the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>, the amount of <em>usable memory</em> is usually less than total RAM, which may limit the size of <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s that can be run on a given computer, and the maximum speed at which it can process data. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mending"><b>mending</b></a>
</dt><dd>Minor restoration of a <a href="#book">book</a>'s <a href="#condition">condition</a>, not requiring replacement of material or removal of the <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s from the <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  When mending of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> is done <a href="#inhouse">in-house</a>, the job should be given to a person who is properly trained, to avoid permanent damage to <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in need of attention.  Compare with <a href="#repairing">repairing</a> and <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mendingtape"><b>mending tape</b></a>
