</dt><dd>A generic <a href="#term">term</a> for various kinds of adhesive tape designed specifically for making minor <a href="#repairing">repairs</a> on <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>,  available by the roll from <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s, either single- or double-sided, with <a href="#pressuresensitive">pressure-sensitive</a> or water-based <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a>.  For <a href="#mending">mending</a> tears in <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#acidfree">acid-free</a> tape is preferred.  In <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>, <a href="#reversibility">reversibility</a> may require the use of a tape that can be easily removed without damaging the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mentalmap"><b>mental map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> depicting a geographic area of any
extent according to the subjective perceptions of a particular person
or group of people, rather than in relation to physical reality, for
example, a New Yorker's view of the United States west of New York
City. This category also includes maps in which an area is sized
according to the quantity of the <a href="#subject">subject</a>
involved, for example, human population per square mile, which would,
in a map of the United States, make Texas considerably smaller and New
York much larger than is actually the case. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mentor"><b>mentor</b></a>
</dt><dd>An experienced, trustworthy person who willingly provides
useful advice to a new member of a community, profession, or
organization, to assist the person in achieving success in his or her
new position and environment. Mentoring relationships can either be
established informally by the participants, or under the formal
sponsorship of the organization. Mentoring of recent <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> graduates can be arranged through the <a href="#nmrt">New Members Round Table</a> (NMRT) of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="menu"><b>menu</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computer systems, a display of two or more <a href="#option">option</a>s from which the user may select by typing <a href="#letter">letter</a>s or <a href="#number">number</a>s (or some other combination of keys), or by clicking on a <a href="#link">link</a>, <a href="#icon">icon</a>, text label, etc., with a <a href="#mouse">mouse</a> or other pointing device.  <em>Main menu</em> options often lead to lower-level <em>submenus</em> in a hierarchical display.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#gopher">Gopher</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="menubar"><b>menu bar</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of <a href="#menu">menu</a> names, usually displayed horizontally below the title bar in a <a href="#gui">graphical user interface</a>, with corresponding menu <a href="#option">option</a>s
hidden from view. When the user selects one of the menu names, the
appropriate list of options is displayed in a drop-down, pop-up, or
sidebar menu.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="menudriven"><b>menu-driven</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <a href="#interface">interface</a> that provides a hierarchical sequence of lists of possible choices (<a href="#option">option</a>s)
from which the user must make the appropriate selections to accomplish
the desired result. Menu-driven interfaces are easier for <a href="#novice">novice</a>s to negotiate, but slower and less sophisticated than <a href="#commanddriven">command-driven</a> systems and consequently less attractive to experienced users.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="merge"><b>merge</b></a>
</dt><dd>To combine in logical sequence two or more separate <a href="#file">file</a>s of <a href="#information">information</a>
into one, either manually or by an automated process. When such a
combination includes the recognition and removal of duplicate files,
the process is known as <em>merge/purge</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#deduping">deduping</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="merger"><b>merger</b></a>
</dt><dd>The combination of two or more <a href="#serial">serial</a>s into one.  A <a href="#note">note</a> is included in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for the new serial (<em>Merger of:</em>) indicating the <a href="#title">title</a>s of the <a href="#publication">publication</a>s that merged, and a companion note is added to the record for each of the serials that merged (<em>Merged with: to become:</em>)
indicating the title(s) with which it merged and the title of the
publication created as the result of the merger. The opposite of <a href="#split">split</a>.  Compare with <a href="#absorption">absorption</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mesh"><b><em>MeSH</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <em><b>Me</b>dical <b>S</b>ubject <b>H</b>eadings</em>, the <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a> used by the <a href="#nlm">National Library of Medicine</a> in its <em><a href="#medline">MEDLINE</a></em> <a href="#database">database</a> (available on the <a href="#www">Web</a> as <em><a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/PubMed/">PubMed</a></em>).  The <b><em>MeSH</em></b> headings are <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#print">print</a> by NLM in an <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly arranged <a href="#annotation">annotated</a> list and in <a href="#treestructure">tree structure</a>s.  <a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/mesh/MBrowser.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> <b><em>MeSH Browser</em></b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="metadata"><b>metadata</b></a>
</dt><dd>Strictly speaking, <a href="#data">data</a> about other data.
In a functional sense, structured data about data. More specifically, a
description of a set of data (how and when it was collected, who
collected and organized it, the <a href="#format">format</a> in which it is presented, etc.). In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, any <a href="#database">database</a> or <a href="#mrdf">machine-readable data file</a> used to identify, describe, and locate <a href="#network">network</a>ed electronic resources (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="#askjake">AskJake</a></em>).  At the present time, no <a href="#standardization">standardized</a> <a href="#format">format</a> exists, but the <a href="#dublincore">Dublin Core</a> Metadata Initiative (DCMI) is working to establish an international cross-<a href="#discipline">disciplinary</a> consensus on methods of <a href="#bibcontrol">bibliographic control</a> for electronic resources.  For more <a href="#information">information</a>, <a href="http://www.yahoo.com/Reference/Libraries/Library_and_Information_Science/Metadata/">click here</a> to see the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of <a href="#online">online</a> resources and <a href="#index">index</a>es on the subject of metadata.  Also spelled <em>meta-data</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#metadatabase">metadatabase</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="metadatabase"><b>metadatabase</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#database">database</a> of databases, usually formed by aggregating two or more smaller databases to allow the user to search their <a href="#contents">contents</a> <em>as a whole</em>, instead of repeating the same <a href="#search">search</a> in each separately (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>OneFile</em></b> from <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a> which consolidates the <b><em>InfoTrac</em></b> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s into a single very large <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a>).  The pace of aggregation has accelerated as very large <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s have dominated the market for <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> databases, but however helpful "one-stop searching" may be in <a href="#interdisciplinary">interdisciplinary</a> <a href="#research">research</a> (and to users who lack the skill to select the optimum databases for a <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#topic">topic</a>), segmentation still offers significant advantages for the experienced <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="metaindex"><b>meta-index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#index">index</a> of indexes.  For a meta-index of indexes to <a href="#website">Web site</a>s, see the <a href="http://www.vlib.org/">WWW Virtual Library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="metallicink"><b>metallic ink</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#printing">Printing</a> <a href="#ink">ink</a> to
which finely ground particles of metal (aluminum, bronze, copper, etc.)
have been added to produce a decorative metallic effect.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="metaphor"><b>metaphor</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek word <em>metapherein</em> meaning to "to carry across."  A <a href="#figspeech">figure of speech</a> in which a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>
denoting a specific object, person, idea, etc., is applied to something
with which it is not normally associated, to attribute one or more of
its qualities to the other without using "like" or "as" to make an
explicit comparison. The identification or substitution can be direct
("Oaths are straws, men's faiths are wafer-cakes" <em>Henry V</em> 2.3.51) or merely suggested ("Upon the heat and flame of thy distemper sprinkle cool patience" <em>Hamlet</em> 3.4.123).  
<p>
Metaphor has been used as a literary device since the earliest <a href="#work">work</a>s of <a href="#record">record</a>ed <a href="#literature">literature</a> ("rosy-fingered dawn"), to enable imaginative writers to expand the <a href="#literal">literal</a> meaning(s) of a word or phrase.  When the elements compared are so dissimilar as to be incongruous, the resulting <em>mixed metaphor</em> ("mixaphor") can be amusing ("rusty lips").  A <em>dead metaphor</em>
has become so commonplace as to have lost its impact ("time marches
on"). The history and grammar of metaphor is studied in the <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> of linguistics.  Metaphors are sometimes <a href="#collection">collected</a> and <a href="#index">index</a>ed, usually thematically (<b><em>Metaphors Dictionary</em></b> <a href="#editor">edited</a> by Elyse Sommer and Dorrie Weiss).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="metonymy"><b>metonymy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#figspeech">figure of speech</a> in which the name
of one thing is used for another to which it is related, of which it is
an attribute, with which it is associated, or which it suggests (<em>example</em>:  "White House" for Presidency or "Crown" for King).  <em>Reverse metonymy</em> is the use of the name of a thing to refer to one or more of its attributes. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mhz"><b>MHz</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#megahertz">MegaHertz</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microchip"><b>microchip</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#chip">chip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microclimate"><b>microclimate</b></a>
</dt><dd>The isolated environment (light, temperature, relative <a href="#humidity">humidity</a>, dust, etc.) within a small confined space such as a <a href="#displaycase">display case</a>, enclosed <a href="#bookcase">bookcase</a>, drawer, box, or other storage <a href="#container">container</a>, easier to control than a large storage area when <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> is a high priority.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microcomputer"><b>microcomputer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic <a href="#term">term</a> for a <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>mable computer designed to handle relatively small operations, usually a desk-top machine containing a single-<a href="#chip">chip</a> <a href="#microprocessor">microprocessor</a> on a printed circuit board, which may be part of a larger computer system or connected to a <a href="#network">network</a>.  The <a href="#term">term</a> may have been coined to distinguish <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a>s from more powerful <a href="#minicomputer">minicomputer</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microfiche"><b>microfiche</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small card-shaped sheet of <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic <a href="#film">film</a>, designed to store miniaturized <a href="#text">text</a>
and/or microimages arranged sequentially in a two-dimensional grid.
Microfiche is available in color or black-and-white (negative or
positive). Various formats exist, but <a href="#iso">ISO</a> recommends 75 x 125 mm (48 <a href="#frame">frame</a>s in four rows of twelve) or 105 x 148 mm (60 frames in five rows of twelve).  Although each sheet usually includes a <a href="#title">title</a> and/or <a href="#index">index</a> number in a <a href="#heading">heading</a> across the top that can be read without magnification, the text itself can be read and <a href="#copy">copied</a> only with the aid of a <a href="#microform">microform</a> <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a> machine.  User resistance can be mitigated by keeping equipment in good repair and providing point-of-use assistance.  
<p>
In most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, the <a href="#ericdocument">ERIC document</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> is available on microfiche, filed by the 6-digit ED number assigned to each <a href="#document">document</a>.  <a href="#periodical">Periodical</a> <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s and <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a>
may also be available on microfiche, usually stored in specially
designed metal filing cabinets. The sheets of film may be enclosed in <a href="#microenvelope">microfiche envelope</a>s to prevent abrasion.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>fiche</em>.  Compare with <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#superfiche">superfiche</a> and <a href="#ultrafiche">ultrafiche</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microenvelope"><b>microfiche envelope</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#paper">paper</a> envelope, open at the top and right end, or at the top only,  with a high throat for storing one or more sheets of <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> so that only the <a href="#title">title</a> strip on the first sheet is visible.  <a href="#archivalquality">Archival quality</a> microfiche envelopes are made of <a href="#acidfree">acid</a>- and <a href="#lignin">lignin</a>-free paper.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microfilm"><b>microfilm</b></a>     
</dt><dd>A continuous roll of 16 mm <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic <a href="#film">film</a> used for storing miniaturized <a href="#text">text</a> and/or microimages in a single row (<em>cine</em> <a href="#format">format</a>) or double row (<em>comic</em> format) of <a href="#frame">frame</a>s that can be magnified and copied only with the aid of a specially designed <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a> machine.  Microfilm is available in color or black-and-white (negative or positive).  In some <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s are routinely <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> to microfilm to save space.  <a href="#microform">Microform</a> reader/printers are available in libraries with microfilm <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> for viewing and making <a href="#hardcopy">hard copies</a>.  User resistance can be mitigated by keeping equipment in good repair and by providing point-of-use assistance.  Compare with <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#masternegative">master negative</a>, <a href="#printmaster">print master</a>, and <a href="#servicecopy">service copy</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microform"><b>microform</b></a>     
</dt><dd>A generic term for a highly <a href="#reduction">reduced</a> <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic <a href="#copy">copy</a> of <a href="#text">text</a> and/or images stored on a translucent <a href="#medium">medium</a> (<a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> or <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a>), or on an opaque medium such as card stock (<a href="#microopaque">microopaque</a> or <a href="#aperturecard">aperture card</a>).  Microforms can be <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s or <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>s.  <a href="#readerprinter">Reader-printer</a> machines are required to view and make <a href="#hardcopy">hard copies</a>.  <a href="#digital">Digital</a> <a href="#storage">storage</a> media such as <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a> and <a href="#disk">disk</a>, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, etc., are <a href="#superseded">superseding</a> microforms in <a href="#isar">information storage and retrieval</a> but the transformation is far from complete.  Microforms <a href="#currency">current</a>ly available for purchase are listed by <a href="#author">author</a>/<a href="#title">title</a> and <a href="#subject">subject</a> in the <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> <b><em>Guide to Microforms in Print</em></b>.  Compare with <a href="#macroform">macroform</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#com">computer output microform (COM)</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="micrographics"><b>micrographics</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general term for the techniques used to <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ically <a href="#reduction">reduce</a> <a href="#text">text</a> and/or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> images to a size too small to be read by the human eye without magnification, usually for the purpose of <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> or compact storage, as in the <a href="#dataconversion">conversion</a> of <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s from <a href="#print">print</a> to <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> or <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>.  Micrographic <a href="#format">format</a>s also include <a href="#microopaque">microopaque</a> and <a href="#aperturecard">aperture card</a>.  Compare with <a href="#micrography">micrography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="micrography"><b>micrography</b></a>
</dt><dd>The art and practice of writing in microscopically small <a href="#character">character</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#micrographics">micrographics</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microopaque"><b>microopaque</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sheet of opaque material, such as <a href="#paper">paper</a> or card stock, bearing miniaturized <a href="#text">text</a> and/or microimages arranged in a two-dimensional grid which can be magnified and <a href="#copy">copied</a> only with the aid of special equipment.  <a href="#readerprinter">Reader-printer</a> machines for viewing and making <a href="#hardcopy">hard copies</a> are usually provided in <a href="#library">libraries</a> with microopaque <a href="#holdings">holdings</a>.  Compare with <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microprocessor"><b>microprocessor</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#centralproc">central processing unit</a> (CPU) etched or printed on a single silicon micro<a href="#chip">chip</a>.  To function as a computer, a microprocessor requires a power supply, a clock, and <a href="#memory">memory</a>.  Microprocessors are used in most <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#device">device</a>s (<a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a>s, <a href="#pda">personal digital assistant</a>s, clock radios, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microscopeslide"><b>microscope slide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small piece of transparent material (usually glass) designed
to hold a very small object for viewing through the lens of a
microscope or microprojector. In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, microscope slides are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> according to the rules for three-dimensional <a href="#artifact">artifact</a>s and <a href="#realia">realia</a>.  Compare with <a href="#microslide">microslide</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microscopic"><b>microscopic printing</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#printing">Printing</a> done in a very small <a href="#typesize">type size</a>.  Although the first <a href="#work">work</a>s printed in Europe were in large <a href="#type">type</a>, early <a href="#printer">printer</a>s soon realized that with smaller <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>s, more <a href="#matter">matter</a> fitted on a <a href="#page">page</a>.
By 1825, the French type-founder Henri Didot had cast type that
produced 25 lines to the inch. Because the casting of extremely small
type has physical limitations, most microscopic <a href="#reduction">reduction</a> is now done <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ically.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#miniaturebook">miniature book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="microslide"><b>microslide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#slide">slide</a> consisting of a single <a href="#mounted">mounted</a> <a href="#frame">frame</a> of <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a>.  Compare with <a href="#microscopeslide">microscope slide</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="midlist"><b>midlist</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portion of a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#list">list</a> consisting of <a href="#literarywork">literary</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and serious <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s which are not expected to become <a href="#bestseller">bestseller</a>s, often written by new and emerging <a href="#author">author</a>s.  Studies suggest that although publishers are <a href="#issue">issuing</a> as many new midlist titles as ever, the failure of <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a> chains to market them competitively has resulted in a decline in percentage of total <a href="#book">book</a> sales.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="migration"><b>migration</b></a>
</dt><dd>A move from one <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> <a href="#platform">platform</a> or <a href="#software">software</a> system to another, usually because the purchaser or lessee believes the new system to be superior.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the most common example is from the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> software of one <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> to that of another.  Such a change may or may not require the <a href="#dataconversion">conversion</a> of <a href="#data">data</a> from one <a href="#format">format</a> to another.  Compare with <a href="#upgrade">upgrade</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mildew"><b>mildew</b></a>
</dt><dd>The growth of micro-organisms whose spores remain dormant under cool, dry conditions inside <a href="#library">libraries</a> and other facilities, but are stimulated by warm, moist air to feed on the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> and <a href="#binding">binding</a>s of <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#printing">printed</a> materials.  The growth of mildew produces an acid harmful to <a href="#paper">paper</a>
and materials used in binding. It also produces a characteristic musty
odor that can be prevented in libraries by maintaining good air
circulation, low relative <a href="#humidity">humidity</a>, and adequate lighting.  Once started, an infestation of mildew can be difficult to eradicate.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fumigation">fumigation</a> and <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="militarylibrary"><b>military library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> maintained by a unit of government responsible for national defense, maintaining <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s for the use of military staff, but which may have a broader mandate, including <a href="#accessibility">accessibility</a> to the general public (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.nadn.navy.mil/Library/">Nimitz Library</a> at the U.S. Naval Academy).  <em>Military librarians</em> are organized in the <a href="#faflrt">Federal and Armed Forces Libraries Round Table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="millboard"><b>millboard</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bindersboard">binder's board</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="milling"><b>milling</b></a>
</dt><dd>Cutting away a small portion of the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> (usually less than 1/8 inch) to prepare the <a href="#section">section</a>s for <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive binding</a> or <a href="#oversewing">oversewing</a>, an operation done in a <a href="#bindery">bindery</a> by moving the inner edge of the clamped <a href="#textblock">text block</a> over the rotating blades of a <em>milling machine</em>.  In first-time <a href="#binding">binding</a>, the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a>s of the <a href="#section">section</a>s are cut away, producing <a href="#loose">loose</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>.  In <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>, the old <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a>, <a href="#thread">thread</a>, staples, etc., are cut away along with the folds to prepare the leaves for reattachment.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mime"><b>MIME</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> that stands for <b>M</b>ultipurpose <b>I</b>nternet <b>M</b>ail <b>E</b>xtensions, a specification that allows non-<a href="#ascii">ASCII</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s to be <a href="#format">format</a>ted so that they can be transmitted over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> via <a href="#email">e-mail</a>.  Supported by many e-mail <a href="#clientserver">client</a>s, <b>MIME</b> extends the <a href="#smtp">SMTP</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> to allow the exchange of <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s, <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a>, and <a href="#videorecording">video</a> files, and messages in <a href="#character">character</a>-sets other than ASCII.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="miniature"><b>miniature</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small colorful, often fanciful, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> painted in and/or around an <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a>, or elsewhere on the <a href="#page">page</a> of a medieval <a href="#manuscriptbook">manuscript book</a>, sometimes <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> in <a href="#goldleaf">gold</a> or silver.  Also refers to a small, separate, minutely detailed drawing, painting, or <a href="#portrait">portrait</a>, usually done on ivory or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#document">document</a> conceived on a very small scale, or to a greatly <a href="#reduction">reduced</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a document, designed to be read or <a href="#reproduction">reproduced</a> with the aid of special optical equipment.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#miniaturebook">miniature book</a> and <a href="#miniatureedition">miniature edition</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="miniaturebook"><b>miniature book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> conceived on a very small <a href="#scale">scale</a>, measuring no more than three inches along its greatest dimension (<a href="#height">height</a> or <a href="#width">width</a>), usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> in 6-<a href="#point">point</a> <a href="#type">type</a> or smaller and <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> on the same scale.  Not uncommon, miniature books include Bibles, <a href="#almanac">almanac</a>s, <a href="#poetry">poetry</a>, <a href="#classic">classic</a>s, <a href="#childrensbook">juvenile literature</a>, tokens, etc.  Very tiny books, such as those used in doll houses, are usually produced <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ically.  Of interest to <a href="#collectible">collector</a>s, miniature books have an enthusiastic following in the United States.  For more <a href="#information">information</a>, see the <a href="#website">Web site</a> maintained by the <a href="http://www.mbs.org/">Miniature Book Society</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#miniatureedition">miniature edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="miniatureedition"><b>miniature edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of very small size (three inches or less in <a href="#height">height</a> and <a href="#width">width</a>), usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> in 6-<a href="#point">point</a> <a href="#type">type</a> or smaller, and <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> on the same <a href="#scale">scale</a>.  Synonymous with <em>lilliput edition</em> and <em>microscopic edition</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#miniaturebook">miniature book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="miniaturescore"><b>miniature score</b></a>
</dt><dd>A music <a href="#score">score</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> in small <a href="#type">type</a> to allow the <a href="#page">page</a>s
to be reduced to pocket size. Miniature scores are designed to be used
by music lovers for study and enjoyment, rather than by performers in
their work. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="minicomputer"><b>minicomputer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A medium-sized computer introduced in the 1960's, capable of serving up to several hundred users.  A <a href="#dedicated">dedicated</a> minicomputer is used to run the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> in many <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  Synonymous with <em>midrange computer</em>.  Compare with <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a>, <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a>, and <a href="#supercomputer">supercomputer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="minimallevel"><b>minimal level cataloging (MLC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#encodinglevel">encoding level</a> that allows more severe limitations on the <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a> and <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> (and on the amount of <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>) than in <a href="#corelevel">core level cataloging</a>, resulting in a less than complete <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>.  <b>MLC</b> was designed to provide <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> unavailable due to <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> <a href="#arrears">arrears</a>, as well as items worthy of retention but not considered worth the expense of <a href="#fulllevel">full level cataloging</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="minimize"><b>minimize </b></a>
</dt><dd>A feature of a <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a> that allows the user to reduce a <a href="#window">window</a> to a tab in the <a href="#taskbar">taskbar</a>, or to an <a href="#icon">icon</a> on the desktop, by clicking on a small button in the upper right-hand corner of the window.  The opposite of <a href="#maximize">maximize</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#multitasking">multitasking</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="minor"><b>minor</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> or <a href="#identifier">identifier</a> assigned in a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> to represent one of the <em>less</em> significant aspects of the <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#document">document</a> (form, methodology, etc.).  A minor descriptor or identifier is <em>not</em> marked with an <a href="#asterisk">asterisk</a> or distinguished <a href="#typography">typographically</a> in the list of preferred <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">term</a>s, as is a <a href="#major">major</a> descriptor or identifier representing a primary focus or <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the document.  Some indexing systems do not provide minor descriptors and identifiers. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mint"><b>mint</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, a <a href="#copy">copy</a> in the same immaculate, unaltered <a href="#condition">condition</a> as when it was first <a href="#publishing">published</a>, new and virtually unused--the highest possible grade in any assessment of condition.  <a href="#usedbook">Used book</a>s in mint condition command a higher price than copies showing signs of wear.  Synonymous with <em>as new</em> and <em>pristine</em>.  Compare with <a href="#finecopy">fine copy</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#brightcopy">bright copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="minuscule"><b>minuscule</b></a>
</dt><dd>In medieval <a href="#cursive">cursive</a> handwriting, one of the small <a href="#letter">letter</a>s from which the modern <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> letters of the roman <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> evolved by way of the <a href="#carolingian">Carolingian</a> <a href="#script">script</a> introduced by Alcuin of York in Europe in the late 8th century.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#majuscule">majuscule</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="minutes"><b>minutes</b></a>
</dt><dd>Under parliamentary procedure, a written <a href="#chronological">chronological</a> account of the business conducted at a formal assembly, such as a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#facultystatus">faculty</a> or <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>
meeting, usually written from notes taken by an elected or appointed
secretary, or other designated member, for distribution to all the
other participants in advance of the next meeting for their correction
and approval. The minutes of important meetings may be <a href="#archives">archived</a> as a matter of <a href="#record">record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="miracleplay"><b>miracle play</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of medieval religious <a href="#play">drama</a> performed on a movable wagon from a <a href="#script">script</a> giving an account of a divine miracle, usually one believed to have occurred in the life of a Christian saint or <a href="#character">character</a> from the Bible.  Compare with <a href="#moralityplay">morality play</a>. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mysteryplay">mystery play</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mirror"><b>mirror</b></a>
</dt><dd>An exact <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#website">Web site</a>, installed on a <a href="#server">server</a> other than the one maintained by the official <a href="#host">host</a>, usually to handle demand for the site's <a href="#content">content</a> in another country or region of the world.  When the main server goes <a href="#offline">offline</a>, the <a href="#website">Web site</a>s it normally hosts may still be available at one or more mirror sites.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mis1"><b>MIS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#mis"><b>m</b>anagement <b>i</b>nformation <b>s</b>ystem</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="misbound"><b>misbound</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> in which a <a href="#map">map</a> or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, a number of <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, or a complete <a href="#section">section</a> has been folded incorrectly, <a href="#gathering">gathered</a> in incorrect sequence, <a href="#binding">bound</a> in upside down, or omitted.  The <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> will normally send a replacement if such a <a href="#copy">copy</a> is returned by a <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> or retail customer.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="miscellany"><b>miscellany</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#collection">collection</a> consisting of an assortment of writings on diverse <a href="#subject">subject</a>s.  The term also appears in the <a href="#title">title</a>s of <a href="#book">book</a>s containing <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s of various forms, usually related to a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> (<b><em>A Miscellany of Women's Wisdom</em></b>), person (<b><em>A James Joyce Miscellany</em></b>), place (<b><em>A Handful of Spice: A Miscellany of Maine Literature and History</em></b>), etc.  Compare with <a href="#anthology">anthology</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="misprint"><b>misprint</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#typo">typographical error</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="misquote"><b>misquote</b></a>
</dt><dd>To repeat incorrectly words that another person has spoken or written, inadvertently or by intention.  A <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> made out of <a href="#context">context</a> may be misleading, but it is not necessarily a misquote.  Quotations included in written <a href="#work">work</a>s should be properly <a href="#cite">cited</a> and double-checked for <a href="#accuracy">accuracy</a> before <a href="#publication">publication</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="missal"><b>missal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#liturgicalwork">liturgical work</a> containing all
the prayers used in celebrating the Catholic Mass during the period of
a year. The earliest medieval examples were <a href="#copy">copied</a> by hand on <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> and beautifully <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a>.  In a more general sense, any <a href="#book">book</a> of prayers or daily devotions.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bookofhours">Book of Hours</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="missing"><b>missing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A code used in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> to indicate the <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> not <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>, which cannot be found anywhere in the <a href="#library">library</a>.  If a thorough <a href="#search">search</a> by <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> fails to locate the item within a reasonable time, a <a href="#replacement">replacement</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> may be ordered, provided <a href="#demand">demand</a> persists and an <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a> is still <a href="#inprint">in print</a>.  Compare with <a href="#lost">lost</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="missingcopy"><b>missing copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>Parts of a <a href="#book">book</a>, such as the <a href="#index">index</a> or <a href="#appendix">appendices</a>, which may not be ready when a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> sends the <a href="#typescript">typescript</a> and <a href="#specifications">specifications</a> to the <a href="#printer">printer</a>.  If additional <a href="#copy">copy</a> is to follow, allowance must be made in estimating the cost of <a href="#printing">printing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mission"><b>mission</b></a>
</dt><dd>The basic purpose or role of an organization, expressed
succinctly in abstract terms. A clearly written mission statement is
the basis for formulating achievable <a href="#goal">goal</a>s and <a href="#objective">objective</a>s in <a href="#strategicplanning">strategic planning</a>, and serves as a constant reminder of the organization's primary reason for existing.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="missionary"><b>missionary book</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publisher">Publisher</a>'s <a href="#slang">slang</a> for the first <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> on a <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  To <a href="#cataloging">catalog</a> such a <a href="#work">work</a>, a new <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> and <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> may be required.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="missive"><b>missive</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal or official message, especially a detailed and lengthy one, such as a <a href="#letters">letter</a>
sent by a superior authority conveying a mandate, recommendation,
permission, or invitation to a specific individual or group of persons
concerning an action (or actions) to be undertaken. Also refers to a
legal <a href="#document">document</a> in the form of a letter, exchanged by parties to a contractual agreement.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="miter"><b>miter</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#handbinding">hand</a> <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, to  bring materials together at an angle (usually 45 degrees) along a straight line without overlap, as in folding the <a href="#leather">leather</a> or <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> covering material over the edges of the <a href="#board">board</a>s at the <a href="#corner">corner</a>s toward the inside, and <a href="#pastingdown">pasting it down</a> before the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s
are applied. Also refers to the joint formed by fitting together two
pieces beveled at an angle along a straight line. Also spelled <em>mitre</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mixednotation"><b>mixed notation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> <a href="#notation">notation</a> in which two or more kinds of <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s are used, for example, the <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the English <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> used to indicate the <a href="#mainclass">main class</a>es and first-level <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a>s in <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress classification</a> and the <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s used for further subdivisions (<em>example</em>:  <b>ND2893.A78 2000</b>).  Compare with <a href="#purenotation">pure notation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mixed"><b>mixed responsibility</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, a collaboration in which two or more persons or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate bodies</a> contribute to the <a href="#content">content</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, each performing a different function, for example, the <a href="#author">author</a> responsible for writing the <a href="#text">text</a> of a children's <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a> and the artist who creates the <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#shared">shared responsibility</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mla1"><b>MLA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#medicallibassoc"><b>M</b>edical <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a> and <a href="#musiclibassoc"><b>M</b>usic <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mlastyle"><b>MLA style</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#format">format</a> for typing <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a>s and <a href="#cite">citing</a> <a href="#source">source</a>s in the humanities, developed by the <a href="http://www.mla.org/">Modern Language Association of America</a> and <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the <b><em>MLA Handbook for Writers of Research Papers</em></b>, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#apastyle">APA style</a> and <a href="#electronicstyle">electronic style</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mlc1"><b>MLC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#minimallevel"><b>m</b>inimal <b>l</b>evel <b>c</b>ataloging</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mlis"><b>M.L.I.S.</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the United States, the post-baccalaureate degree of Master of <a href="#libraryscience">Library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">Information Science</a>, granted by a <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> upon completion of a required course of study.  To be considered for a professional <a href="#position">position</a> in most <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> in the United States, a <a href="#candidate">candidate</a> must have earned either an M.L.I.S. or <a href="#mls">M.L.S.</a> degree.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#accredited">accredited library school</a> and <a href="#approved">approved library school</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mls"><b>M.L.S.</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the United States, the post-baccalaureate degree of Master of <a href="#libraryscience">Library Science</a>, granted by a <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> upon completion of a required course of study.  To be considered for a professional <a href="#position">position</a> in most <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> in the United States, a <a href="#candidate">candidate</a> must have earned either an M.L.S. or <a href="#mlis">M.L.I.S.</a> degree.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#accredited">accredited library school</a> and <a href="#approved">approved library school</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mnemonic"><b>mnemonic</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek <em>mnemon</em> meaning "mindful."  A code in which the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a>(s), <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>(s), or formula(s) are easy to remember (<em>example</em>:
DEL for "delete" and REF for "reference"). Also, a word or rhyme
composed by a person to be used as a mental aid in recalling something.
<b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mnemonicnotation">mnemonic notation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mnemonicnotation"><b>mnemonic notation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classification">classification</a> <a href="#notation">notation</a> in which the <a href="#character">character</a>s representing the <a href="#class">class</a>es are directly linked to the name of the class, making it easier for the user to learn and recall the way the <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> is organized.  Most notations used in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> and <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> are <em>not</em> mnemonic. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mobilelibrary"><b>mobile library</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bookmobile">bookmobile</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mockup"><b>mock-up</b></a>
</dt><dd>A rough but accurate physical representation in wood,
cardboard, papier-mache, plastic, canvas, etc., of a device, apparatus,
structure, or process, usually on the same <a href="#scale">scale</a>,
with movable parts that can be manipulated or modified for the purpose
of analysis, testing, demonstration, or instruction. Compare with <a href="#model">model</a> and <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="model"><b>model</b></a>
</dt><dd>An accurate three-dimensional representation, usually on a smaller <a href="#scale">scale</a>, of the physical appearance of a real object of any size, particularly useful in depicting very large objects (<em>e.g.</em>, the solar system).  Compare with <a href="#mockup">mock-up</a> and <a href="#realia">realia</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="modem"><b>modem</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#contraction">contraction</a> of <em><b>mo</b>dulator-<b>dem</b>odulator</em>, originally a <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> <a href="#device">device</a> capable of <a href="#dataconversion">converting</a> <a href="#digital">digital</a> pulses into <a href="#analog">analog</a> frequencies for transmission over <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> lines, and <a href="#data">data</a>
received in analog frequencies into digital pulses for display on, or
processing by, a digital computer. A modem also dials the telephone
line, answers calls, and controls transmission speed. Modem speed is
measured in <a href="#baud">baud</a>.  Although external modems are still available, most new <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a>s come equipped with a built-in modem.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dialaccess">dial-up access</a> and <a href="#webtv">WebTV</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="module"><b>module</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of several parts of an <a href="#onlinetutorial">online tutorial</a>
designed in separate units, to be completed in a certain sequence. Each
unit is sufficiently self-contained that advanced students may skip it
if they are already familiar with its <a href="#content">content</a>,
or complete it out of sequence, although continuity may be lost in
doing so. Some tutorials include a self-quiz at the end of each module.
<p>
Also, a <a href="#library">library</a> furnishing designed to be
used alone or in combination with other units to create a customized
workspace, for example, worktables of various shapes that can be pushed
together to form different configurations, depending on the needs of a
particular work group. Modern furnishings for office spaces and
computer <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>s are often <em>modular</em> in design.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mola1"><b>MOLA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#mola"><b>M</b>ajor <b>O</b>rchestra <b>L</b>ibrarians' <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mold"><b>mold</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of microscopic lower plants whose reproductive spores
are abundant in most environments, but require certain conditions of
temperature and <a href="#humidity">humidity</a> to germinate and grow.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the best way to keep molds from infecting <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>
is to provide good air circulation and keep the relative humidity below
70-80%. Once established, molds can be eliminated by using a fungicide
or by <a href="#fumigation">fumigation</a>.  Also spelled <em>mould</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="monaural"><b>monaural</b></a>
</dt><dd>Sound reproduced from a single channel by an audio <a href="#playback">playback</a> device with one amplifier or speaker.  The result is less realistic than <a href="#stereophonic">stereophonic</a> or <a href="#quadraphonic">quadraphonic</a> <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>.  Synonymous with <em>monophonic</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="monetaryvalue"><b>monetary value</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="monitor"><b>monitor</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#output">output</a> <a href="#device">device</a> consisting of an electronic display screen which, when attached to a computer, enables the user to view <a href="#text">text</a> and/or images.  Computer monitors vary in size, shape, and <a href="#resolution">resolution</a>.  A <em>recessed monitor</em>
is mounted below the surface of a desk or table, usually beneath a
glass panel at an angle to allow the user's line of sight to remain
unobstructed in a classroom equipped with a wall screen and <a href="#lcd">LCD</a> projector.  <a href="#laptop">Laptop</a> computers have a <a href="#flatpanel">flat panel</a> monitor that folds down to cover the <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>.  A <em>television monitor</em> is an <a href="#analog">analog</a> device designed to display signals from a television receiver, or signals prerecorded on <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a> for <a href="#playback">playback</a> using a <a href="#vcr">VCR</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#lcd">LCD</a> and <a href="#pixel">pixel</a>.
<p>
Also, to check on a person or process periodically to make sure work is progressing smoothly.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="monochromeplate"><b>monochrome plate</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> separately from the <a href="#text">text</a> in a <em>single</em> color, usually listed by <a href="#number">number</a> with any other <a href="#plate">plate</a>s in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> of the <a href="#book">book</a>.  Compare with <a href="#duotone">duotone</a> and  <a href="#colorplate">color plate</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="monograph"><b>monograph</b></a>
</dt><dd>A relatively short <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#treatise">treatise</a> on a single <a href="#subject">subject</a>, complete in one physical piece, usually written by a <a href="#specialization">specialist</a> in the <a href="#field">field</a>.  Monographic <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> is detailed and scholarly, but not extensive in <a href="#scope">scope</a>.  The importance of monographs in <a href="#scholarlycommunication">scholarly communication</a> depends on the <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>.  In the humanities, monographs remain the <a href="#format">format</a> of choice for serious scholars, but in the sciences and social sciences where <a href="#currency">currency</a> is essential, <a href="#journal">journal</a>s are usually the preferred means of <a href="#publication">publication</a>. 
<p>
For the purpose of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, any non<a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, either complete in one <a href="#volume">volume</a> or intended to be completed in a finite number of successive <a href="#part">part</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d at <a href="#regular">regular</a> or <a href="#irregular">irregular</a> intervals, consisting of a single <a href="#work">work</a> or <a href="#collection">collection</a> of works.  Monographs are sometimes <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#monographicseries">monographic series</a> and <a href="#subseries">subseries</a>.  Compare with <a href="#book">book</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="monographicseries"><b>monographic series</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#series">series</a> of <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>s, usually <a href="#issue">issue</a>d under a <a href="#collectivetitle">collective title</a> by a <a href="#universitypress">university press</a> or scholarly <a href="#society">society</a>.  Each <a href="#volume">volume</a> in the series may contain more than one monograph, each with its own <a href="#title">title</a> in addition to the <a href="#seriestitle">series title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="monoline"><b>monoline</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> in which the strokes of which the <a href="#character">character</a>s are composed, whether straight or curvilinear, are all of the same thickness, including any <a href="#serif">serif</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#blockletter">block letter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="monologue"><b>monologue</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek <em>monologos</em> meaning "speaking alone."  A <a href="#play">play</a>,
skit, or recitation in which all the lines are spoken by a single
actor, or a long sequence of lines within a play, spoken by one of the <a href="#character">character</a>s alone on the stage.  In drama and <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, an <em>interior monologue</em> reveals a character's private thoughts and feelings.  Compare with <a href="#soliloquy">soliloquy</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the remarks of a person who continues to speak without
interruption for an extended period of time despite cues from listeners
that the conversation is being monopolized.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="montage"><b>montage</b></a>
</dt><dd>A composite image made by juxtaposing two or more images, or parts of images (drawings, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#picture">picture</a>s,
etc.), without separation lines, in a composition that gives new
meaning to the whole but preserves the distinctiveness of the
individual elements, a technique originally developed as an art form
but now used extensively in advertising and <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> design.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#photomontage">photomontage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="monthly"><b>monthly</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d once a month (twelve times per year) with the possible exception of one or two months, usually during the summer.  Many <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s and some <a href="#journal">journal</a>s are <a href="#publishing">published</a> monthly (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Monthly Labor Review</em></b>).  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> issued once a month.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="moralityplay"><b>morality play</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of drama popular during the Middle Ages and Renaissance in which the <a href="#character">character</a>s are engaged in an <a href="#allegory">allegorical</a> struggle over the condition of the human soul.  Unlike <a href="#mysteryplay">mystery play</a>s and <a href="#miracleplay">miracle play</a>s, which were presented on mobile wagons, morality plays were usually performed on a stationary platform.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="morgue"><b>morgue</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> maintained by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, usually consisting of <a href="#backnumber">back issue</a>s, <a href="#refbook">reference materials</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>es and <a href="#database">database</a>s, <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s, notes, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, and other resources needed by reporters and staff to <a href="#research">research</a>, write, and <a href="#editing">edit</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s for <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  The term originally referred to the <a href="#repository">repository</a> of <a href="#biography">biographical</a> materials collected on persons of interest, for the purpose of writing <a href="#obituary">obituaries</a>.  The first newspaper library in the United States was established at the office of the <em>Boston Pilot</em> in 1831.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="morocco"><b>morocco</b></a>
</dt><dd>A fine pebble-grained <a href="#leather">leather</a> made from <a href="#goatskin">goatskin</a> tanned with sumac, believed to have been introduced to Europe by the Moors.  One of the most <a href="#durability">durable</a> leathers used in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, it is strong yet flexible.  Older books <a href="#binding">bound</a> in morocco are often <a href="#rarebook">rare</a> and valuable.  Compare with <a href="#calf">calf</a> and <a href="#pigskin">pigskin</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#levant">levant</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="motif"><b>motif</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> borrowed from art and music (<em>leitmotif</em>) to refer to a <a href="#text">text</a>ual element that <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ically represents a specific theme in a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> by virtue of repetition, usually presented in the opening <a href="#verse">verse</a>, <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>, or paragraphs and subsequently elaborated.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="motionpicture"><b>motion picture</b></a>
</dt><dd>A length of <a href="#film">film</a> from which an unbroken sequence of <a href="#still">still</a> <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s can be projected at speeds of 16 to 24 <a href="#frame">frame</a>s
per second, producing the illusion of continuous motion. Motion
pictures made in color or black-and-white, with or without recorded <a href="#soundtrack">sound</a>, on film 8, 16, 35, or 70 mm wide.  They include <a href="#documentary">documentaries</a>, <a href="#featurefilm">feature film</a>s, and <a href="#shortfilm">short film</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>cinefilm</em>.  Compare with <a href="#cinema">cinema</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#filmclip">film clip</a>, <a href="#filmlibrary">film library</a>, <a href="#filmography">filmography</a>, <a href="#trailer">trailer</a>, and <a href="#fiaf">International Federation of Film Archives</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mottledcalf"><b>mottled calf</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#calf">Calf</a>skin used in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, which has been dabbed or sprinkled with colored dye or tanning acid to give it a decorative spotty appearance.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mounted"><b>mounted</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> or <a href="#photograph">photograph</a> <a href="#tippedin">tipped</a> onto a <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#album">album</a>.  Also, a fragile or <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> <a href="#leaf">leaf</a>, illustration, <a href="#map">map</a>, etc., strengthened with <a href="#backing">backing</a> made of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, card, or thin cloth.
<p>
Also refers to an <a href="#artifact">artifact</a> or <a href="#specimen">specimen</a> placed on a pedestal or inside a case, or a <a href="#print">print</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic image, or <a href="#document">document</a> protected by framing, usually against a backing material.  Loose specimens and unframed prints and <a href="#picture">picture</a>s are <em>unmounted</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mat">mat</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mouse"><b>mouse</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small handheld <a href="#input">input</a> <a href="#device">device</a> which, when rolled across a hard, flat surface, allows the user to direct the motion of a <a href="#cursor">cursor</a> or pointer on a computer screen, and initiate an operation or select an <a href="#option">option</a> displayed in a <a href="#gui">graphical user interface</a> by pressing down on one of its buttons.  Because the button makes a clicking sound when pressed, such <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s are called <em>point-and-click</em> <a href="#application">application</a>s.  In <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s
programs, the mouse can be used like a pen, pencil, or paintbrush. Most
mouse operations can be executed more slowly using the <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>.
Basic models are designed to be used by a right- or left-handed person.
Contoured models are available for either the right or left hand. In <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>s, the mouse is usually built-in.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mousetype"><b>mouse type</b></a>
</dt><dd>Very tiny, barely <a href="#readable">readable</a> <a href="#type">type</a> used for the <a href="#fineprint">fine print</a> in sales contracts, coupons, contest entry forms, etc., to notify the <a href="#reader">reader</a> of legal restrictions, <a href="#expirationdate">expiration date</a>s, and other <a href="#information">information</a> that the seller is required to display but wishes to downplay.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="movabletype"><b>movable type</b></a>
</dt><dd>Metal <a href="#type">type</a> cast as individual units, each bearing a single <a href="#character">character</a>, assembled by a <a href="#typesetting">typesetter</a> into words, lines, and <a href="#page">page</a>s of <a href="#text">text</a>, then disassembled for reuse once a print job is completed.  Although there is evidence that <a href="#printing">printing</a> from <a href="#woodcut">wood block</a>s originated in China, probably during the 11th century, <a href="#gutenberg">Johann Gutenberg</a> is credited with the invention of modern movable type in Germany in the mid-15th century.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="moving"><b>moving</b></a>
</dt><dd>The transfer of all or a portion of the contents of a <a href="#library">library</a> (<a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, furnishings, and personnel) from one facility to another, temporarily or permanently.  Most libraries hire a professional <a href="#movingcompany">moving company</a> with library experience to do the actual work, but advance planning is required for a move to be executed smoothly.  Library <a href="#literature">literature</a> is available on the moving process to assist planners in avoiding common pitfalls.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="movingcompany"><b>moving company</b></a>
</dt><dd>A professional mover hired to transfer the contents of a <a href="#library">library</a>
from one location to another, usually selected in a competitive process
in which the company is given the opportunity to inspect the sites
before submitting a bid. Unless stated otherwise in the bid
specifications, the contractor determines the methods used and provides
both personnel and equipment. Professional movers with experience
moving libraries work very methodically and quickly because, as the
move slows or stops, their costs increase. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mpeg"><b>MPEG</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>M</b>oving <b>P</b>icture <b>E</b>xperts <b>G</b>roup, a <a href="#standards">standard</a> for <a href="#datacompression">compressing</a> <a href="#fullmotion">full-motion video</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  More efficient than <a href="#jpeg">JPEG</a> (the standard for compressing still images), <b>MPEG</b> is used to transmit a wide range of audio-video formats including <a href="#dvd">DVD</a> <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s.  MPEG-2 requires <a href="#bandwidth">bandwidth</a> of 4-15 <a href="#byte">MB</a> per second and an MPEG <a href="#board">board</a> for <a href="#playback">playback</a> in most computers.  Pronounced "em-peg."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mrdf1"><b>MRDF</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#mrdf"><b>m</b>achine-<b>r</b>eadable <b>d</b>ata <b>f</b>ile</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mull"><b>mull</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#crash">crash</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="multicast"><b>multicast</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a>, to transmit <a href="#data">data</a> simultaneously to more than one individual or site connected to the same <a href="#network">network</a>, for example, to all who subscribe to an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>, as opposed to <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>ing messages to all who own the appropriate receiving equipment (radio and television).
<p>

</p></dd><dt><a name="multimedia"><b>multimedia</b></a>
</dt><dd>A combination of two or more <a href="#digital">digital</a> media (<a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s, <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a>, <a href="#animated">animation</a>, <a href="#videorecording">video</a>, etc.) used in a computer <a href="#application">application</a>, such as an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>, computer game, or <a href="#website">Web site</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.a2z4birders.com/cgi-bin/birds">A 2 Z 4 Birders Online Guide</a>).  Multimedia applications are often <a href="#interactive">interactive</a>.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>digital media</em>.  
<p>
In a more general sense, any program, presentation, or computer <a href="#application">application</a> in which two or more communication <a href="#medium">media</a> are used simultaneously or in close association, for example, <a href="#slide">slide</a>s with <a href="#soundrecording">recorded sound</a>.  <a href="#still">Still</a> images accompanying <a href="#text">text</a> are considered <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, rather than multimedia. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="multimediamap"><b>multimedia map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> available electronically that includes <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a>, <a href="#videorecording">video</a>, and/or <a href="#animated">animation</a>, in addition to <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> images and <a href="#text">text</a> (<em>example</em>:  the <em><a href="http://www.nationalgeographic.com/wildworld/">WildWorld</a></em> <a href="#website">Web site</a> maintained by the National Geographic Society).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="multipartvolume"><b>multipart volume</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in two or more physically separate <a href="#part">part</a>s that together constitute a single bibliographic <a href="#volume">volume</a>.  <a href="#refbook">Reference work</a>s too large to be bound as a single volume are published in this manner (<em>example</em>:  some volumes of <b><em>Dictionary of Literary Biography</em></b>).  Compare with <a href="#multivolumework">multivolume work</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="multipleaccess"><b>multiple access</b></a>
</dt><dd>More than one <a href="#accesspoint">point of access</a> to a <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#data">data</a> (<em>example</em>:  a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> <a href="#searchable">searchable</a> by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>, <a href="#keywords">keywords</a>, etc.), as opposed to a resource that has only one point of access (<em>example</em>:  the <a href="#headword">headword</a>s in a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> of the words of a <a href="#language">language</a>).  Compare with <a href="#multipleuser">multiple user access</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="multipleuser"><b>multiple user access</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#data">data</a> that can be used independently by more than one person at the same time, for example, a multi-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a> as opposed to a single-volume <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>.  <a href="#access">Access</a> to <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, and <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> electronic resources by more than one <a href="#simultaneous">simultaneous user</a> may be governed by <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a>.  Compare with <a href="#multipleaccess">multiple access</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="multitasking"><b>multitasking</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> that permits more than one <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> to remain open at the same time, allowing the user to perform multiple operations through shared use of the <a href="#centralproc">central processor</a> (CPU), exchanging <a href="#information">information</a> between applications if necessary.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="multivolumework"><b>multivolume work</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in two or more <a href="#volumenumber">number</a>ed or unnumbered <a href="#volume">volume</a>s under a single <a href="#title">title</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Oxford English Dictionary</em></b>), sometimes over an extended period (<b><em>Dictionary of American Regional English</em></b>).  A multivolume work is <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> as a single entity, with the volumes owned by the <a href="#library">library</a> listed in a <a href="#holdingsnote">holdings note</a>.  Compare with <a href="#multipartvolume">multipart volume</a> and <a href="#series">series</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="museumlib"><b>museum library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a> maintained by a museum or gallery, usually within its walls, but sometimes in a separate location, containing a <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>s, and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> related to its <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>s and <a href="#field">field</a>s of <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>.  <a href="#access">Access</a> may be by appointment only.  <a href="#borrowingprivileges">Borrowing privileges</a> may be <a href="#restricted">restricted</a> to museum staff and members.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="museumpublisher"><b>museum publisher</b></a>
</dt><dd>A museum or historical society that <a href="#issue">issue</a>s <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#exhibitcatalog">exhibit catalog</a>s, and other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s under its own <a href="#imprint">imprint</a> or in cooperation with other <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s,
for example, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. Museum
publications are usually of fine quality, often issued in both <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> and <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s to appeal to collectors and casual buyers.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#exhibitcatalog">exhibit catalog</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="musicalpresentation"><b>musical presentation statement</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#optional">optional</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a>, in which the physical form of the music is described (<a href="#fullscore">full score</a>, <a href="#miniaturescore">miniature score</a>, <a href="#pianoscore">piano score</a>, etc.) as it appears on the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a>.  If such a statement is an integral part of another area of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, and recorded as such, it is not repeated.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="musicalwork"><b>musical work</b></a>
</dt><dd>Three <a href="#definition">definition</a>s are recognized in <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>:  1) a musical <a href="#composition">composition</a> created as a single unit intended by its <a href="#composer">composer</a> to be performed as a whole; 2) a set of musical compositions with a <a href="#collectivetitle">collective title</a>, not necessarily intended for performance as a whole; and 3) a group of musical compositions assigned a single <a href="#opusnumber">opus number</a>.  In <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> musical <a href="#work">work</a>s, <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a> is under the name of the composer, with <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a> for <a href="#arranger">arranger</a>, <a href="#libretto">librettist</a>, major <a href="#performer">performer</a>(s), etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="musiclibrary"><b>music library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> containing a <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> on music and musicians, including <a href="#printing">printed</a> and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> music <a href="#score">score</a>s, music <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, recorded music (<a href="#compactdisc">CD</a>s, <a href="#audiocassette">audiocassette</a>s, <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>s, etc.), <a href="#book">book</a>s about music and musicians, <a href="#programnotes">program notes</a>, <a href="#discography">discographies</a>, and music <a href="#refbook">reference material</a>s. 
<p>
Music collections in <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> are <a href="#selection">selected</a> and maintained for <a href="#lifelong">lifelong learning</a> and leisure pursuits.  <a href="#academiclib">Academic</a> and conservatory libraries provide resources for music study and <a href="#research">research</a>, including <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#source">source</a> materials (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.columbia.edu/cu/lweb/indiv/music/">Columbia University Music and Arts Library</a>).  <a href="#nationallib">National libraries</a> offer unique and often <a href="#rarebook">rare</a> musical heritage collections (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/achtml/achome.html">The Aaron Copland Collection</a> at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>).  <em>Music librarian</em>s are organized in the <a href="#musiclibassoc">Music Library Association</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="musiclibassoc"><b>Music Library Association (MLA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1931, <b>MLA</b> promotes the establishment, growth, and use of <a href="#musiclibrary">music libraries</a> and collections of music, musical instruments, music <a href="#literature">literature</a>, music recordings, and related materials in both <a href="#print">print</a> and <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  An <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, the organization also seeks to advance music <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>, scholarship, and <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>.  <b>MLA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> <em>Music Cataloging Bulletin</em>.  <a href="http://www.musiclibraryassoc.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>MLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="musicscore"><b>music score</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#score">score</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mutilation"><b>mutilation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Damage, defacement, or destruction of <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> inflicted intentionally, rather than accidentally, including tearing <a href="#cover">cover</a>s and <a href="#page">page</a>s; cutting out <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s or passages of <a href="#text">text</a>; marking or writing on <a href="#margin">margin</a>s or text; and removing <a href="#label">label</a>s, <a href="#bookplate">bookplate</a>s, protective covers, <a href="#datedueslip">date due slip</a>s,
etc., all actions that drain library resources. The motives for such
acts range from an attitude of entitlement, to monetary concerns
(libraries generally charge for <a href="#photocopy">photocopying</a>), disapproval of the library's <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> decisions, to outright malice.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#biblioclast">biblioclast</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mystery"><b>mystery</b></a>
</dt><dd>A popular <a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#shortstory">story</a>,
or drama about an unusual event or occurrence, such as a murder or
disappearance, that remains so secret or unexplained as to excite
popular curiosity and interest. The <a href="#plot">plot</a> in mystery <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> often hinges on an attempt by a sleuth to uncover the truth.  The Sherlock Holmes stories of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle are <a href="#classic">classic</a> examples.  <a href="#subgenre">Subgenre</a>s include <a href="#detective">detective fiction</a> and <a href="#suspense">suspense</a>.  <a href="http://www.themysteryreader.com/">Click here</a> to connect to <em>The Mystery Reader</em>, a <a href="#website">Web site</a> devoted to mystery fiction.  Compare with <a href="#truecrime">true crime story</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#gothicnovel">gothic novel</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="mysteryplay"><b>mystery play</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of medieval religious drama, popular from the 14th to the 16th century, usually performed on a mobile wagon from a <a href="#script">script</a> based on a story from the <a href="#scripture">Scripture</a>s
or a sequence of episodes from biblical history. In England, the
performance of mystery plays was often financed by the local trade
guilds in connection with important feast days, such as Corpus Christi.
Compare with <a href="#moralityplay">morality play</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#miracleplay">miracle play</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="myth"><b>myth</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the classical Greek word <em>mythos</em> meaning "story."  A <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>
rooted in the traditions of a specific culture, capable of being
understood and appreciated in its own right, but at the same time part
of a system of stories (<em>mythology</em>) transmitted orally from one
generation to the next to illustrate man's relationship to the cosmos.
In traditional societies, myths often serve as the basis for social
customs and observances. <p>
