Many of the archetypes of classical Greek mythology recur in the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of Western culture and some have been appropriated by <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s outside the arts and humanities (<em>example</em>:
Oedipus complex in psychology). Some scholars have argued that mythic
thinking is integral to human consciousness and that myths are simply a
manifestation of the way culture is created by the human mind. <a href="#dictionary">Dictionaries</a> of mythology are available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>.  Compare with <a href="#folktale">folktale</a> and <a href="#legend">legend</a>.
</p></dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="N">N</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><p>
</p><dt><a name="nagara1"><b>NAGARA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nagara"><b>N</b>ational <b>A</b>ssociation of <b>G</b>overnment <b>A</b>rchives and <b>R</b>ecords <b>A</b>dministrators</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="naics1"><b>NAICS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#naics"><b>N</b>orth <b>A</b>merican <b>I</b>ndustry <b>C</b>lassification <b>S</b>ystem</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nal1"><b>NAL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nal"><b>N</b>ational <b>A</b>gricultural <b>L</b>ibrary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nameauthority"><b>name authority file</b></a>
</dt><dd>An authorized list giving the <a href="#preferredterm">preferred</a> <a href="#formofentry">form of entry</a> for names (<a href="#personalname">personal</a>, <a href="#corporatename">corporate</a>, and <a href="#geographicname">geographic</a>) used as <a href="#heading">heading</a>s in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, and any <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s from variant forms. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nameindex"><b>name index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the <a href="#personalname">personal name</a>s appearing of a <a href="#work">work</a>, arranged <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#surname">surname</a>, with reference to the <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>(s) on which each name can be found in the <a href="#text">text</a>.  Not all <a href="#book">book</a>s have a separate name index--personal names may be included in a general <a href="#index">index</a> or in the <a href="#subjectindex">subject index</a>.  When present in a single-<a href="#volume">volume</a> work, the name index is part of the <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>.  In a a multi-volume work, it is usually found at the end of the last volume.  Compare with <a href="#authorindex">author index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nameplate"><b>nameplate</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#flag">flag</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nametitleadded"><b>name-title added entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, an <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> that gives the name of a person (or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a>) and the <a href="#title">title</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, to identify:  1) a work that is included in or the subject of the work being <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a>; 2) a larger work of which the work being cataloged is <a href="#part">part</a>; or 3) another work to which the work being cataloged is in some way related.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="namtc1"><b>NAMTC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#namtc"><b>N</b>ational <b>A</b>ssociation of <b>M</b>edia &amp; <b>T</b>echnology <b>C</b>enters</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nap1"><b>NAP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nap"><b>n</b>ormal <b>a</b>dministrative <b>p</b>ractice</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nara1"><b>NARA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nara"><b>N</b>ational <b>A</b>rchives and <b>R</b>ecords <b>A</b>dministration</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="narration"><b>narration</b></a>
</dt><dd>The telling of a story or account of events, in speech or writing, usually in the first or third person.  Most <a href="#documentary">documentary</a> <a href="#film">film</a>s and television programs include a <a href="#script">script</a>ed narration, with the name of the <em>narrator</em> given in the <a href="#credit">credit</a>s.  Celebrity narrators may be employed to enhance the appeal of a <a href="#work">work</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="narrative"><b>narrative</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written or spoken <a href="#work">work</a> in the form of a story or account (real or imagined) told by one or more <em>narrators</em> as a continuous, <a href="#episodic">episodic</a>,
or broken series of related events, usually in the first or third
person. Narratives can be short, as in a brief anecdote, or as long as
a full-length <a href="#novel">novel</a>.  A narrative <a href="#poetry">poem</a> is one that relates a story (<a href="#ballad">ballad</a>, <a href="#epic">epic</a>, etc.).  The <em>narrative structure</em> of a work is the sequence and voice in which the <a href="#author">author</a> unfolds events, for example, in a series of flashbacks.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="narrow"><b>narrow</b></a>
</dt><dd>The shape of a <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#width">width</a> of the <a href="#cover">cover</a> is less than two-thirds its <a href="#height">height</a>, a <a href="#format">format</a> commonly used in the design of <a href="#fieldguide">field guide</a>s and <a href="#travelguide">travel guide</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#square">square</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#portrait">portrait</a> and <a href="#oblong">oblong</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="narrowcast"><b>narrowcast</b></a>
</dt><dd>Selective use of communication <a href="#media">media</a> to target a highly <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#audience">audience</a>, in contrast to a <a href="#media">mass media</a> <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> intended to reach as many listeners or viewers as possible.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="narrowerterm"><b>narrower term (NT or N)</b></a>
</dt><dd>In a <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, a <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> representing a <a href="#subclass">subclass</a> of a <a href="#class">class</a> indicated by another <a href="#term">term</a> (<em>example</em>:
"Music librarianship" under "Librarianship"). A subject heading or
descriptor may have more than one narrower term (also "Comparative
librarianship" under "Librarianship"). Compare with <a href="#broaderterm">broader term</a> (BT) and <a href="#relatedterm">related term </a> (RT).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#hyponym">hyponym</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nasig1"><b>NASIG</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nasig"><b>N</b>orth <b>A</b>merican <b>S</b>erials <b>I</b>nterest <b>G</b>roup</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="naslin1"><b>NASLIN</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#naslin"><b>N</b>orth <b>A</b>merican <b>S</b>port <b>L</b>ibrary <b>N</b>etwork</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nal"><b>National Agricultural Library (NAL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established as a <a href="#federallibrary">federal library</a> in 1862 under legislation signed by President Lincoln, <b>NAL</b> is part of the Agricultural Research Service (ARS) of the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA).  With a <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of over 3.3 million <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s, <b>NAL</b> is the primary source of agricultural <a href="#information">information</a> in the United States and the largest agricultural <a href="#library">library</a> in the world.  Located in Beltsville, Maryland, <b>NAL</b> works closely with libraries at land-grant universities to improve <a href="#access">access</a> to, and utilization of, agricultural information by <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s, policy-makers, educators, farmers, consumers of agricultural products, and the general public.  <a href="http://www.nal.usda.gov/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NAL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nationalarchives"><b>national archives</b></a>
</dt><dd>The central <a href="#archives">archives</a> of a nation, charged with collecting and preserving <a href="#document">document</a>s and <a href="#records">records</a>
of historical significance to its citizens and government. The first
national archives was established in France in 1790. In the United
States, the <a href="#nara">National Archives and Records Administration</a> (NARA) has statutory responsibility for the <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> of archival <a href="#information">information</a> of national importance.  Compare with <a href="#nationallib">national library</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nara"><b>National Archives and Records Administration (NARA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#nationalarchives">national archives</a> of the United States, a federal <a href="#govtagency">agency</a> established by Congress in 1934 to oversee the management of all federal <a href="#records">records</a>, including the public's right of <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#document">document</a>s and <a href="#information">information</a> not specifically exempted under the <a href="#freedom">Freedom of Information Act</a>.  <b>NARA</b>'s 33 facilities house approximately 21.5 million cubic feet of original <a href="#text">text</a>ual materials collected from the executive, legislative, and judicial branches.  It also includes <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> materials, such as <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, <a href="#soundrecording">sound</a> and <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s and <a href="#chart">chart</a>s, aerial <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#architecturaldrawing">architectural drawing</a>s, computer <a href="#data">data</a> sets, <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, etc.  <b>NARA</b> is administered by an <a href="#archivist">Archivist</a> of the United States appointed by the President with the approval of Congress, and advised by a National Archives Council.  <a href="http://www.archives.gov/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NARA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nagara">NAGARA</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nagara"><b>National Association of Government Archives and Records Administrators (NAGARA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1984, <b>NAGARA</b> is a nationwide <a href="#association">association</a> of local, state, and federal <a href="#archivist">archivist</a>s and <a href="#records">records</a>
administrators, and individuals with an interest in improving the
management of government records. Its members are local, state, and
federal archival and <a href="#recordsmanagement">records management</a> <a href="#govtagency">agencies</a>.  <b>NAGARA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em><a href="http://www.nagara.org/clearinghouse/clearinghousehome.html">NAGARA Clearinghouse</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.nagara.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NAGARA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nara">NARA</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="namtc"><b>National Association of Media &amp; Technology Centers (NAMTC) </b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonprofit <a href="#association">association</a> devoted to assisting specialists responsible for managing <a href="#mediacenter">media</a> and technology centers, through networking, advocacy, and support activities intended to enhance equitable <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#media">media</a>, technology, and <a href="#information">information</a> services to educational communities.  Membership in <b>NAMTC</b> is open to regional, K-12, and higher education media and technology centers, as well as commercial media <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s.  <a href="http://www.namtc.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NAMTC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nationalbib"><b>national bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>An ongoing list of the <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#printing">printed</a> materials <a href="#publishing">published</a> or <a href="#distributor">distributed</a> in a specific country, especially <a href="#work">work</a>s written about the country and its inhabitants, or in its <a href="#language">national language</a>, for example, the <b><em>British National Bibliography</em></b> which has provided, since 1950, a weekly list of new works published in Great Britain.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nationalbiog"><b>national biography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> containing <a href="#biography">biographical</a> <a href="#information">information</a>
about people of noteworthy accomplishments living in or associated with
a particular country. Most national biographies are multi-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s.  
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>:  <b><em>American National Biography</em></b>, edited by John A. Garraty.  New York: Oxford University Press, 1999.</dd></dl>
<p>
Also refers to the branch of biography devoted to describing and
analyzing the lives of important people living in or associated with a
country. </p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nationalbook"><b>National Book Award</b></a>
</dt><dd>An honor awarded since 1950 by the National Book Foundation, a <a href="#consortium">consortium</a> of <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> groups, to enhance public awareness of exceptional books written by Americans.  <a href="#literaryaward">Award</a>s are given in four categories:  <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>, <a href="#poetry">poetry</a>, and <a href="#childrenslit">children's literature</a>.  Decisions are made by an independent panel of five judges.  The prize in each category is $10,000 and a crystal sculpture.  <a href="http://www.powells.com/prizes/national.html">Click here</a> to see an <a href="#annotation">annotated</a> list of prize-winners past and present compliments of Powells Books.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pulitzer">Pulitzer Prize</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nclis"><b>National Commission on Libraries and Information Science (NCLIS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An independent <a href="#govtagency">agency</a> within the
executive branch of the U.S. federal government, established in 1970 to
advise the President and Congress on national <a href="#library">library</a> and <a href="#infopolicy">information policy</a>, conduct studies of library and <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s, assess the adequacy of current resources and services, promote <a href="#research">research</a>, develop plans for meeting the nation's <a href="#information">information</a> needs, and help coordinate library-related activities at the federal, state, and local levels.  <a href="http://www.nclis.gov/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NCLIS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="neh"><b>National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An independent <a href="#grant">grant</a>-making <a href="#agency">agency</a> established in 1965 by the <em>National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities Act</em>, <b>NEH</b> supports <a href="#research">research</a>,
education, and public programs in the humanities, with attention to the
diverse heritage, traditions, and history of the United States, and the
relevance of the humanities to current conditions and events affecting
American society. Each state has an Humanities Council that establishes
its own guidelines and application deadlines. The state councils
support a variety of projects, including <a href="#library">library</a> reading programs, lectures, <a href="#conference">conference</a>s, seminars and institutes, <a href="#media">media</a> presentations, and museum and library traveling <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ions.  The national office is located in Washington D.C.  <a href="http://www.neh.gov/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NEH</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nfais"><b>National Federation of Abstracting and Information Services (NFAIS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1958 at the instigation of the Director of <b><em>BIOSIS</em></b>, <b>NFAIS</b> has a membership of 55 leading nonprofit, commercial, government, and academic <a href="#producer">producer</a>s and <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>s of <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s and other <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#information">information</a> services for <a href="#research">research</a> and professional use, as well as organizations that provide <a href="#access">access</a> to electronic <a href="#database">database</a>s in a wide range of <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s.  <b>NFAIS</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> <em>NFAIS Newsletter</em>.  <a href="http://www.nfais.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NFAIS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nfpb"><b>National Film Preservation Board (NFPB)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established by the <em>National Film Preservation Act</em> of 1988, <b>NFPB</b> is an advisory board authorized to assist the <a href="#librariancongress">Librarian of Congress</a> in <a href="#preservation">preserving</a> <a href="#archives">archival</a> materials related to 25 <a href="#film">film</a>s selected each year for the <a href="#nfr">National Film Registry</a> as culturally, historically, and aesthetically significant.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/film/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NFPB</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fiaf">International Federation of Film Archives</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nfpf"><b>National Film Preservation Foundation (NFPF)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonprofit organization created by Congress to support nationwide efforts to <a href="#preservation">preserve</a> the <a href="#film">film</a> heritage of the United States and improve <a href="#access">access</a> to film for study, <a href="#research">research</a>, education, and <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ion, <b>NFPF</b> began in 1997 with the support of <a href="#grant">grant</a>s
from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and the Film
Foundation. In 2000, the organization began distributing federal <a href="#matchinggrant">matching grant</a>s to <a href="#filmarchives">film archives</a> to preserve <a href="#endangered">endangered</a> films and <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  <a href="http://www.filmpreservation.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NFPF</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nfr"><b>National Film Registry (NFR)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of up to 25 <a href="#film">film</a>s selected each year by the <a href="#librariancongress">Librarian of Congress</a>, with the assistance of the <a href="#nfpb">National Film Preservation Board</a>, for <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> in the <a href="#archives">archives</a> of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  The films must be at least ten years old, but need not be <a href="#featurefilm">feature-length</a> or have been released to a theater <a href="#audience">audience</a> to be eligible for <a href="#selection">selection</a>.  The <em>National Film Preservation Act</em> of 1988 authorizes the Board to consider the broadest possible range of films in its deliberations.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/film/filmnfr.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NFR</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> which includes a list of Registry films for the current year.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ngs"><b>National Genealogical Society (NGS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1903 with headquarters in Arlington, Virginia, <b>NGS</b> is a service organization devoted to collecting, <a href="#preservation">preserving</a>, and disseminating <a href="#genealogy">genealogical</a> <a href="#information">information</a>, encouraging interest in genealogical <a href="#research">research</a>, fostering careful <a href="#documentation">documentation</a> of genealogical <a href="#data">data</a>, and promoting education and training in the <a href="#field">field</a> of genealogy.  <b>NGS</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <em>NGS Newsmagazine</em> and the <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>NGS Quarterly</em>. <a href="http://www.ngsgenealogy.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NGS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="niso"><b>National Information Standards Organization (NISO)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonprofit <a href="#association">association</a> <a href="#accreditation">accredited</a> by the <a href="#ansi">American National Standards Institute</a> (ANSI) to develop voluntary <a href="#standards">standards</a> in <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a>, <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>, <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, and other <a href="#information">information</a> services, <b>NISO</b> is designated by ANSI to represent U.S. interests to the Technical Committee on Information and Documentation of the <a href="#iso">International Organization for Standardization </a> (ISO).  <a href="http://www.niso.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NISO</b> <a href="#homepage"> homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#z3950">Z39.50</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nationallib"><b>national library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> designated and funded by a national government to serve the nation by maintaining a <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of the <a href="#publishing">published</a> and <a href="#unpublished">unpublished</a> literary output of the nation as a whole, including <a href="#publication">publication</a>s of the government itself.  Most national libraries are also responsible for <a href="#compile">compiling</a> a <a href="#nationalbib">national bibliography</a>, and some serve as the legal <a href="#depositcopy">depository</a> for <a href="#work">work</a>s protected by <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> in their country.  The national library of the United States is the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>, located in Washington D.C.  Three other libraries--the <a href="#nal">National Agricultural Library</a>, the <a href="#nle">National Library of Education</a>, and the <a href="#nlm">National Library of Medicine</a>--contain national collections in specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> areas.  <a href="http://dir.yahoo.com/Reference/Libraries/National_Libraries/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of national libraries of the world.  Compare with <a href="#nationalarchives">national archives</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nlcbnc"><b>National Library of Canada/Bibliotheque nationale du Canada (NLC/BNC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#nationallib">national library</a> of Canada, established by act of Parliament in 1953.  Located in Ottawa, <b>NLC/BNC</b> is charged with <a href="#acquisitions">acquiring</a>, <a href="#preservation">preserving</a>, and promoting the <a href="#publishing">published</a> heritage of Canada for all Canadians.  Its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s are focused primarily on Canadiana (<a href="#work">work</a>s written by, about, or of interest to Canadians, <a href="#publishing">published</a> in Canada or abroad).  <a href="http://www.nlc-bnc.ca/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NLC/BNC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nle"><b>National Library of Education (NLE)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The largest <a href="#library">library</a> in the world devoted solely to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, and effective use of <a href="#research">research</a> and other <a href="#information">information</a> in the <a href="#field">field</a> of education.  Located in Washington D.C., <b>NLE</b>
is funded by the U.S. federal government. It serves the U.S. Department
of Education, Congress, and the Office of the President, as well as the
general public, and is the center of a national <a href="#network">network</a> of libraries, <a href="#archives">archives</a>, and other information providers in education.  <a href="http://www.ed.gov/NLE/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NLE</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nlm"><b>National Library of Medicine (NLM)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The largest <a href="#medicallib">medical library</a> in the United States, administered by the National Institutes of Health (NIH).  Located in Bethesda, Maryland, <b>NLM</b> provides public <a href="#access">access</a> to an <a href="#online">online</a> version of its <em><a href="#medline">MEDLINE</a></em> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> at no charge under the <a href="#title">title</a> <em><a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/PubMed/">PubMed</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NLM</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nls"><b>National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped (NLS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#nationallib">national library</a> program administered by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> that produces and distributes <a href="#braille">Braille</a> and <a href="#soundrecording">recorded</a> <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> at no charge to eligible <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s through a national <a href="#network">network</a> of cooperating <a href="#regionallib">regional</a> and local <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  Established by Congress in 1931 to serve blind <a href="#adult">adult</a>s, <b>NLS</b> was expanded in 1952 to serve <a href="#visuallyimpaired">visually impaired</a>
children, in 1962 to provide music materials, and in 1966 to serve
individuals with other physical impairments that prevent them from
reading <a href="#print">print</a> of standard size.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/nls/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NLS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nlw"><b>National Library Week</b></a>
</dt><dd>Sponsored for the first time in 1958 by the National Book Committee and the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>National Library Week</b> is an officially recognized seven-day period in the spring of each year during which special attention is given to promoting <a href="#library">libraries</a> of all types in the United States.  Most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> celebrate the event by displaying <a href="#poster">poster</a>s and <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>s, issuing <a href="#pressrelease">press release</a>s, and sponsoring <a href="#booktalk">book talk</a>s
and other promotional activities. In the UK, a similar event known as
National Libraries Week is celebrated in the fall of each year. <a href="http://www.ala.org/celebrating/">Click here</a> to connect to the ALA gateway to <em>Celebrating America's Libraries</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nsn"><b>National Storytelling Network (NSN)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Formed in 1998 when the National Storytelling Association
split into the National Storytelling Network and Storytelling
Foundation International, <b>NSN</b> is an organization dedicated to improving the quality of <a href="#storytelling">storytelling</a> wherever it can contribute to the quality of life.  An <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>NSN</b> sponsors the annual National Storytelling Conference in cooperation with its local and regional members.  <b>NSN</b> also <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> <b><em>Storytelling Magazine</em></b> and <a href="#host">host</a>s the <em><a href="http://www.storynet.org/">StoryNet</a></em> <a href="#website">Web site</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nationalsurvey"><b>national survey</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a> that <a href="#specialization">specializes</a> in <a href="#map">map</a>ping, surveying, and providing scientific <a href="#information">information</a> about the topography natural resources of a country.  In the United States, the national surveys are the <a href="http://www.usgs.gov/">U.S. Geological Survey</a> (USGS) and the <a href="http://www.ngs.noaa.gov/">National Geodetic Survey</a> (NGS).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ntis"><b>National Technical Information Service (NTIS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Located on the outskirts of Washington D.C., <b>NTIS</b> is an
agency within the Technology Administration of the U.S. Department of
Commerce that is the largest centralized source of scientific,
technical, engineering, and business <a href="#information">information</a> produced or sponsored by U.S. and international <a href="#govtagency">government agencies</a>.  Its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of over 3 million <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s includes <a href="#technicalreport">technical report</a>s, statistics, business information, <a href="#publication">publication</a>s of the U.S. military, <a href="#multimedia">multimedia</a> training programs, computer <a href="#software">software</a>, and electronic <a href="#database">database</a>s.  <a href="http://www.ntis.gov/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NTIS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nuc"><b>National Union Catalog (NUC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A series of <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>, that began in 1948 as an <a href="#author">author</a> list of printed <a href="#catalogcard">card</a>s and <a href="#title">title</a>s reported as held by other <a href="#library">libraries</a> in North America--a heroic pre-<a href="#digital">digital</a> attempt to create a <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a> of national scope to facilitate <a href="#resourcesharing">resource sharing</a>.  With the development of <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s, the <b>NUC</b>s have been largely <a href="#superseded">superseded</a> by the availability of <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> <a href="#information">information</a> in the large <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s maintained by <a href="#bibutility">utilities</a> such as <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nucmc">National Union Catalog of Manuscript Collections</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nucmc"><b>National Union Catalog of Manuscript Collections (NUCMC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#cooperativecat">cooperative cataloging</a> program sponsored by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> since 1959, <b>NUCMC</b> provides <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> of <a href="#archives">archival</a> and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> materials at no charge to <a href="#repository">repositories</a> in the United States which meet its eligibility guidelines.  <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s are created by <b>NUCMC</b> <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s in the <em><a href="#rlin">RLIN</a></em> national-level <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>, based on cataloging <a href="#data">data</a> supplied by eligible repositories.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/coll/nucmc/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NUCMC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="naturallang"><strong>natural language</strong></a>
</dt><dd>A human <a href="#language">language</a> in which the structure and rules have evolved from <a href="#usage">usage</a>, usually over an extended period time, as opposed to an <a href="#artificiallang">artificial language</a> based on rules prescribed prior to its development and use, as in a computer language.  In <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a> designed to handle <a href="#input">input</a> expressed in natural language, the user may enter the <a href="#query">query</a> in the same form in which it would be spoken or written.  Compare with <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="navigation"><b>navigation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Using the <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#link">link</a>s, <a href="#icon">icon</a>s, and <a href="#menu">menu</a> <a href="#option">option</a>s displayed on a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> to move to other resources available on the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  When the user proceeds in a casual way, the activity is called <a href="#surf">surf</a>ing; when approached purposefully, it is a <a href="#search">search</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#navigationbar">navigation bar</a> and <a href="#searchhistory">search history</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="navigationbar"><b>navigation bar</b></a>
</dt><dd>A series of <a href="#option">option</a>s, usually in the form of clickable buttons, <a href="#icon">icon</a>s, or <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#link">link</a>s arranged in a row across the top or bottom of the screen or <a href="#window">window</a>, or along the right- or left-hand side, indicating the main categories under which the <a href="#information">information</a> contained in the subpages of a <a href="#website">Web site</a> is organized.  In a well-designed site, the <a href="#navigation">navigation</a>
bar is repeated on each subpage to enable the user to select from the
list of main options without having to return to the initial page.
Compare with <a href="#toolbar">toolbar</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nclis1"><b>NCLIS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nclis"><b>N</b>ational <b>C</b>ommission on <b>L</b>ibrary and <b>I</b>nformation <b>S</b>cience</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ndltd"><b>NDLTD</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#etd"><b>e</b>lectronic <b>t</b>heses and <b>d</b>issertations</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ne"><b>NE</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nep"><b>n</b>ew <b>e</b>dition pending</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="neatline"><b>neatline</b></a>
</dt><dd>The line that marks the edges of a <a href="#map">map</a>, separating it from the <a href="#margin">margin</a> (if there is a margin), usually a thin <a href="#rule">rule</a> in black or dark-colored ink.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="needtoknow"><b>need to know</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#security">security</a> systems, the underlying principle restricting <a href="#access">access</a> to sensitive or <a href="#classified">classified</a>
materials to persons who have an essential and justifiable need to be
informed. Under conditions of extreme secrecy, such a need may be
substantiated by various levels of security clearance and the issuance
of identification (badges, <a href="#password">password</a>s, etc.). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="negative"><b>negative</b></a>
</dt><dd>The image that results when negative <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic <a href="#film">film</a> is developed, producing tonal values (black and white) that are the reverse of the original <a href="#subject">subject</a> and of any positive <a href="#print">print</a>
of the same image. Negative color film not only reverses tonal values,
but also the colors of the subject, making them appear as complementary
colors (red as green, blue as yellow, etc.). <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#masternegative">master negative</a> and <a href="#printmaster">print master</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="neh1"><b>NEH</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#neh"><b>N</b>ational <b>E</b>ndowment for the <b>H</b>umanities</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nemethcode"><b>Nemeth code</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#braille">braille</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="neologism"><b>neologism</b></a>
</dt><dd>A new word coined from an existing <a href="#term">term</a> or terms (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#netiquette">netiquette</a> from "network" and "etiquette"), or a new meaning given to an existing word (<em>example</em>:  "quark" from <b><em>Finnegan's Wake</em></b> used in physics as the name of a subatomic particle).  <a href="#acronym">Acronym</a>s are neologisms.  Also refers to the use of this form of new word or meaning.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nep1"><b>NEP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nep"><b>n</b>ew <b>e</b>dition <b>p</b>ending</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nesting"><b>nesting</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> <a href="#search">search</a>ing, the use of <a href="#parenthesis">parentheses</a> to embed a logical operation within another logical operation, as a means of indicating the sequence (<a href="#syntax">syntax</a>)
in which the logical commands are to be executed by the computer. In
the following example, the Boolean "or" command will be executed first,
followed by "not" and then "and."
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Search statement</em>: <b>children and violence and ((television or media) not cartoon*)</b></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="net"><b>net</b></a>
</dt><dd>Terms of sale in which a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> specifies that a <a href="#book">book</a> must be offered at <em>no</em> retail <a href="#discount">discount</a> or reduction in price.  Synonymous with <em>net published price</em>.  Compare with <a href="#nonnet">non-net</a>.  Also used as a shortened form of "<a href="#internet">Internet</a>," usually <a href="#capitalization">capitalized</a> (Net).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="netborrower"><b>net borrower</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> that borrows more <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s via <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> than it lends to other libraries over a designated period of time.  The opposite of <a href="#netlender">net lender</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="netcast"><b>netcast</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#webcast">Webcast</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="netiquette"><b>netiquette</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#neologism">neologism</a> formed by shortening the phrase <em><b>net</b>work et<b>iquette</b></em>.  The rules of civility and good manners that apply to communication via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>,
an environment in which the visual cues available in face-to-face
communication and the auditory cues perceptible in voice communication
are lacking. <a href="http://www.albion.com/netiquette/">Click here</a> to connect to Virginia Shea's <b><em>Netiquette Home Page</em></b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#email">e-mail</a>, <a href="#flame">flame</a>, <a href="#shouting">shouting</a>, and <a href="#smiley">smiley</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="netlender"><b>net lender</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> that lends more <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s via <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> than it borrows from other libraries during a designated period of time.  Net lenders are more likely than <a href="#netborrower">net borrower</a>s to charge a <a href="#fee">fee</a> for interlibrary loan service.  In the <a href="#oclcill">OCLC ILL</a>
system, each time the status of an item requested is updated to
"shipped," a small credit is given per transaction to the lender,
providing some compensation to libraries that are net lenders.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="netprice"><b>net price</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>'s cost for a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#listprice">list price</a> or suggested price, less any <a href="#discount">discount</a>.  The cost of <a href="#shipping">shipping</a> is usually added to the net price. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="netscape"><b><em>Netscape Navigator</em></b></a>      
</dt><dd>A popular <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> designed to facilitate <a href="#browse">browsing</a> for <a href="#information">information</a> available at <a href="#website">site</a>s on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>.  <b><em>Netscape Navigator</em></b> allows the user to <a href="#bookmark">bookmark</a> Web sites for future reference, <a href="#printing">print</a> and <a href="#download">download</a> <a href="#search">search</a> results, and includes many other <a href="#userfriendly">user-friendly</a> features.  Its primary competitor in the <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> market is <b><em>Internet Explorer</em></b> from Microsoft.  <a href="http://www.netscape.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of Netscape Communications Corp. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="netspeak"><b>netspeak</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#argot">argot</a> of <a href="#internet">Internet</a> enthusiasts.  <a href="http://www.yahoo.com/Computers_and_Internet/Dictionaries/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of <a href="#link">link</a>s to Internet <a href="#glossary">glossaries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="network"><b>network</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of physically discrete computers interconnected to allow resources to be shared and <a href="#data">data</a> exchanged, usually by means of <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> links and <a href="#clientserver">client/server</a>
architecture. Most networks are administered by an operations center
that provides assistance to users. The largest "network of networks" in
the world is the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, allowing users of computers of all types and sizes to communicate in <a href="#realtime">real time</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cdromnetwork">CD-ROM network</a>,  <a href="#extranet">extranet</a>, <a href="#intranet">intranet</a>, <a href="#localarea">LAN</a>, and <a href="#widearea">WAN</a>.
<p>
Also, two or more organizations engaged in the exchange of <a href="#information">information</a> through common communication channels, usually for the purpose of accomplishing shared objectives.  When the organizations are <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the arrangement is a <em>library network</em> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.nnlm.nlm.nih.gov/">National Network of Libraries of Medicine</a>).  Compare with <a href="#consortium">consortium</a>.
</p><p>
In <a href="#communications">communications</a> <a href="#media">media</a>, a chain of television or radio <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>ing
stations that share a significant portion of their programming, either
because they are owned by the producer of the programming (the network)
or are independent affiliates compensated by the network for
broadcasting its programs. At one time, the major television networks (<a href="http://abc.abcnews.go.com/">ABC</a>, <a href="http://www.cbs.com/">CBS</a>, and <a href="http://www.nbc.com/">NBC</a>)
had a virtual monopoly of television programming in the United States,
but they have lost market share to the cable networks. <a href="http://dir.yahoo.com/News_and_Media/Television/Networks/">Click here</a> connect to the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of <a href="#link">link</a>s to television network <a href="#website">Web site</a>s. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="networking"><b>networking</b></a>
</dt><dd>The art of developing contacts within a profession and using them to advance one's work and career.  <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s do this by meeting colleagues at <a href="#libconference">library conference</a>s, participating in colloquia and <a href="#roundtable">round table</a>s, volunteering to serve on committees, running for elective office, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newadultreader"><b>new adult reader</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person of mature years who has recently learned to read, usually by enrolling in an <a href="#adult">adult</a> <a href="#literacy">literacy</a> program.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> try to meet the needs of new adult <a href="#reader">reader</a>s by <a href="#selection">selecting</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> appropriate to their <a href="#readinglevel">reading level</a>, and by developing services to acquaint them with available <a href="#information">information</a> resources.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newagebook"><b>new age book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic <a href="#term">term</a> used in <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> to refer to contemporary <a href="#title">title</a>s written on <a href="#subject">subject</a>s
outside mainstream American culture, such as holistic health and
alternative medicine, nontraditional exercise and fitness techniques,
natural foods and alternative diets, self-help psychology, astrology
and numerology, and non-Western spiritual practices (yoga, meditation,
tai chi, etc). New age <a href="#book">book</a>s are <a href="#selection">selected</a> mainly by <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newberrylib"><b>Newberry Library</b></a>
</dt><dd>Located in Chicago, the <b>Newberry Library</b> is a privately funded independent <a href="#researchlib">research library</a> devoted primarily to the humanities.  Free and open to the public, it contains an extensive <a href="#noncirculating">noncirculating</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> related to the civilizations of Western Europe and the Americas.  The <a href="#library">Library</a>
was established in the late 19th century at the bequest of the wealthy
Chicago businessman and philanthropist Walter Loomis Newberry. <a href="http://www.newberry.org/nl/newberryhome.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>Newberry Library</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newberyjohn"><b>Newbery, John (1713-1767)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The English writer, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#printer">printer</a>, and <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> who first recognized the potential commercial market for <a href="#book">book</a>s written specifically for children.  <b>Newbery</b> began <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s for children in 1744 with <em>A Little Pretty Pocket-Book</em>, containing rhyming <a href="#fable">fable</a>s and rules of conduct, followed by the didactic favorites <em>The History of Little Goody Two-Shoes</em> (1765) which may have been written by his friend Oliver Goldsmith.  <a href="#illustration">Illustrated</a> in color, the <a href="#title">title</a>s in his inexpensive <em>Juvenile Library</em> <a href="#series">series</a> were very popular in England.  He also published the first children's <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>, <em>The Circle of the Sciences</em> in seven <a href="#volume">volume</a>s (1745-48), and the first children's <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, <em>The Lilliputian Magazine</em> (1751).  <b>Newbery</b>'s contribution to <a href="#childrenslit">children's literature</a> is commemorated in the <a href="#newbery">Newbery Medal</a>, <a href="#childrensaward">award</a>ed annually since 1922 to the most distinguished <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a> by an American <a href="#author">author</a> published in the United States during the preceding year. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newbery"><b>Newbery Medal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a> given <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly since 1922 under the auspices of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> to the <a href="#author">author</a> of the most distinguished <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a>
in the United States during the preceding year. Sponsored by the family
of Frederic G. Melcher, the medal is named after John Newbery
(1713-1767), the British <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> who first published <a href="#book">book</a>s written specifically for children.  <a href="http://www.acs.ucalgary.ca/%7Edkbrown/awards.html">Click here</a> to see a list of Newbery Medal winners.  Compare with <a href="#caldecott">Caldecott Medal</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#carnegiemedal">Carnegie Medal</a> and <a href="#clabook">CLA Book of the Year for Children</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newbie"><b>newbie</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#slang">slang</a> <a href="#term">term</a> for a person who is a newcomer to <a href="#email">e-mail</a>, electronic <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>s, <a href="#newsgroup">newsgroup</a>s, the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>, or the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> in general, or to any computer <a href="#application">application</a> or system.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#novice">novice</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newbook"><b>new book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A new <a href="#title">title</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d for the first time, usually in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>, <a href="#bookannouncement">announced</a> by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> in <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> <a href="#tradejournal">journal</a>s and <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>s and promoted through <a href="#booksigning">book signing</a>s, <a href="#authorinterview">author interview</a>s, etc.  Recently <a href="#publishing">published</a> titles make up a publisher's <a href="#frontlist">frontlist</a>.  Some new <a href="#book">book</a>s make the <a href="#bestseller">bestseller</a> list.  Compare with <a href="#backlist">backlist</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#missionary">missionary book</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a title recently added to a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> often display the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>s of new books on a <a href="#bulletinboard">bulletin board</a> or <a href="#kiosk">kiosk</a>, or shelve them in a special location for a few weeks, to allow <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to <a href="#browse">browse</a> them separately before they are integrated into the general <a href="#circulating">collection</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newconstruc"><b>new construction</b></a>
</dt><dd>A completely new <a href="#library">library</a> facility, designed from scratch and constructed from the ground up, as opposed to the <a href="#renovation">renovation</a> or <a href="#expansion">expansion</a>
of an existing structure. New construction allows the architect to use
state-of-the-art design concepts and the latest materials, furnishings,
and equipment, within the constraints imposed by the project budget.
The old facility is usually converted to some other purpose once the
library has <a href="#moving">moved</a> to its new location.  New library construction is reported annually in <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em> and the <em>Bowker Annual Library and Book Trade Almanac</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newedition"><b>new edition</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#revisededition">revised edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nep"><b>new edition pending (NE or NEP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A code used on a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#invoice">invoice</a> to indicate that a new <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the <a href="#title">title</a> ordered is in preparation, but has not yet been <a href="#issue">issue</a>d.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nmrt"><b>New Members Round Table (NMRT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1931 as a <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>NMRT</b> assists persons who have been ALA members for under ten years to become active in the Association and in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#professionalism">profession</a> at the national, state, and local levels.  In addition to providing a <a href="#resume">resume</a> review service and a <a href="#mentor">mentor</a>ing program, <b>NMRT</b> sponsors the electronic <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a> <em>NMRT-L</em>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/nmrt/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NMRT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newsgroup"><b>newsgroup</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#internet">Internet</a> message board, usually devoted to a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a>, to which a participant may post comments or <a href="#query">queries</a>,
then view the replies of other participants, responses to the replies,
and so on. A sequence of related postings is called a discussion <a href="#thread">thread</a>.  The most common types are <b><em>Usenet</em></b> and <b><em>NetNews</em></b> which use the Network News Transfer Protocol (NNTP).  Unlike <a href="#email">e-mail</a> <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>s, most newsgroups are unmoderated, so postings are not filtered on the basis of <a href="#content">content</a>, nor are they limited to a list of registered <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s.  The <em><a href="http://www.cyberfiber.com/index.html">CyberFiber Newsgroups Directory</a></em> or the <em><a href="http://groups.google.com/">Google Groups</a></em> <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a> can be used to locate newsgroups on a specific topic.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newsletter"><b>newsletter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> consisting of no more than a few <a href="#page">page</a>s, devoted to news, announcements, and <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#information">information</a> of interest primarily to a <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> group of <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s or members of an <a href="#association">association</a> or organization who receive it as part of their membership, for example, <em><a href="http://www.ntlf.com/">The National Teaching &amp; Learning Forum</a></em>, available in <a href="#print">print</a> and in an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>.  Newsletters are listed in the <b><em>Oxbridge Directory of Newsletters</em></b>, a <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by Oxbridge Communications.  Most <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s do not cover newsletter <a href="#content">content</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicnewsletter">electronic newsletter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newslibrary"><b>news library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a> maintained in the offices of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, or other news agency, which includes in its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> newspaper and <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photo</a> files (sometimes with <a href="#negative">negative</a>s), <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#pamphletfile">pamphlet file</a>s, <a href="#microform">microform</a>s, <a href="#refbook">reference materials</a>s, and <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#database">database</a>s related to news and <a href="#currency">current</a> events.  Most are open to <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s and <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s at the discretion of the <em>news librarian</em>, usually by appointment.  News <a href="#library">libraries</a> are listed in <b><em>The International Directory of News Libraries</em></b>, a <a href="#refserial">serial</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in cooperation with the News Division of the <a href="#sla">Special Libraries Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newsmagazine"><b>news magazine</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general interest <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> devoted to the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of news and <a href="#editorial">editorial</a> comment, usually on a wide range of subjects, from politics to entertainment (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>U.S. News &amp; World Report</em></b> and <b><em>Maclean's</em></b> in Canada).  Most news magazines are <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#weekly">weekly</a> and sold at newsstands, in <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s, and by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>.  Some are available in an <a href="#online">online</a> version (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.newsweek.com/">Newsweek</a></em> or <em><a href="http://www.time.com/">Time</a></em>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newspaper"><b>newspaper</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#newsprint">newsprint</a> and <a href="#issue">issue</a>d <a href="#daily">daily</a>, on certain days of the week, or <a href="#weekly">weekly</a>, containing news, <a href="#editorial">editorial</a> comment, regular <a href="#column">column</a>s, <a href="#lettereditor">letters to the editor</a>, <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>s, advertising, and other items of <a href="#currency">current</a>, often local, interest to a general <a href="#readership">readership</a>.  Some national newspapers are issued <em>twice</em> daily in early and late <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, or in different editions for different regions of the country.  
<p>
According to Warren Chappell, writing in <b><em>A Short History of the Printed Word</em></b> (Boston:  Nonpareil, 1970), the first modern newspaper of <a href="#regular">regular</a> publication was <em>Avisa Relation oder Zeitung</em> <a href="#publishing">published</a>
by Johan Carolus of Strasbourg beginning in 1609. Because they can be
used to influence public opinion, newspapers are subject to <a href="#censorship">censorship</a> in some countries.  In the United States, newspapers once fiercely independent are increasingly owned by mass <a href="#media">media</a> conglomerates.  Under such conditions, <a href="#editor">editor</a>ial decisions may be influenced by commercial priorities.  
</p><p>
In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>s of newspapers are normally available in <a href="#print">print</a>, but the <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s are usually converted to <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> or <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> (or <a href="#digitization">digitized</a>) to conserve space.  Most national and regional newspapers offer at least a portion of their <a href="#content">content</a> <a href="#online">online</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/">New York Times</a></em>).  <a href="#information">Information</a> on local, regional, and national newspapers can be found in the <a href="#annual">annual</a> <b><em>Gale Directory of Publications and Broadcast Media</em></b> available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and large <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.  Compare with <a href="#newsmagazine">news magazine</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#actadiurna">Acta Diurna</a></em>, <a href="#headline">headline</a>, <a href="#masthead">masthead</a>, <a href="#newspaperindex">newspaper index</a>, and <a href="#newslibrary">news library</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newspaperindex"><b>newspaper index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the <a href="#editorialcontent">editorial content</a> (news stories, <a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#editorial">editorial</a>s, and <a href="#column">column</a>s) <a href="#publishing">published</a> in one or more <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, usually <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#subject">subject</a> (including names).  <a href="#index">Index</a>es to major U.S. <a href="#daily">dailies</a> are available in <a href="#print">print</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>New York Times Index</em></b>).  Newspaper indexes are also available <a href="#online">online</a> (<em>examples</em>:  <b><em>DataTimes</em></b> and <b><em>Newspaper Abstracts</em></b> in <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#firstsearch">FirstSearch</a></em>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newspaperlib"><b>newspaper library</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#morgue">morgue</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newspaperrod"><b>newspaper rod</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#stick">stick</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newspeak"><b>newspeak</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#neologism">neologism</a> coined by the <a href="#journalism">journalist</a> and writer George Orwell in his anti-utopian <a href="#novel">novel</a> <b><em>1984</em></b> (<a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1949) to refer to the artificial <a href="#language">language</a> of government slogans, especially authoritarian <a href="#propaganda">propaganda</a>.
The term is also applied to euphemisms used by politicians,
bureaucrats, and military personnel in public pronouncements to evade
public scrutiny and deflect criticism of their actions (<em>incursion</em> instead of "invasion"), and by <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>ers to lull <a href="#audience">audience</a>s into complacency.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newsprint"><b>newsprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>A grade of coarse, absorbent, un<a href="#sizing">sized</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> made primarily from groundwood <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>, used in <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s and <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a>s to keep costs down.  Because it is bulky, <a href="#yellowing">yellows</a> quickly, and becomes <a href="#brittle">brittle</a> with the passage of time, <a href="#library">libraries</a> convert newspaper <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s to <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> or <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>, and provide <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a> machines for <a href="#enlargement">enlarging</a> and making <a href="#hardcopy">hard copies</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newsreel"><b>newsreel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#shortfilm">short film</a>, 10-20 minutes in length, providing brief <a href="#documentary">documentary</a>-style coverage of a series of news events or <a href="#topic">topic</a>s of general interest.  Newsreels preceded the <a href="#featurefilm">feature film</a> in commercial movie theaters until the 1950s when television <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> news replaced them.  In the United States and Europe, the newsreel was an important <a href="#propaganda">propaganda</a> tool during the first and second world wars.  They are <a href="#preservation">preserved</a> in <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#film">film</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newsservice"><b>news service</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of pooling news-gathering resources, first developed in the mid-19th century when six highly competitive New York City <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s
decided to cooperate to lower the expense of collecting and
transmitting international news via telegraph to the United States.
Most wire services operate through overseas bureaus to which news
reporters submit their <a href="#copy">copy</a> and <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s.  <a href="http://www.ap.org/anniversary/nhistory/index.html">Click here</a> to read an <a href="#online">online</a> history of the <b>Associated Press (AP)</b> news service, and <a href="http://dir.yahoo.com/Business_and_Economy/Business_to_Business/News_and_Media/News_Services/">here</a> to view the <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> list of news services.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> for news services is available in <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nypl"><b>New York Public Library (NYPL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The largest <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> in the United States, <b>NYPL</b>
is composed of Research Libraries supported largely by private funds,
and Branch Libraries serving the boroughs of Manhattan, the Bronx, and
Staten Island operated mainly from public funds <a href="#allocation">allocated</a> by the city and state of New York.  <a href="http://www.nypl.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NYPL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="newyorkreview"><b><em>New York Review of Books (NYRB)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publishing">Published</a> since 1963 in 20 <a href="#issue">issue</a>s per year by NYREV, Inc., <b><em>NYRB</em></b> provides in-depth <a href="#commentary">commentary</a> on <a href="#literature">literature</a>, culture, politics, and science in the form of lengthy <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#review">review</a>s written for the educated <a href="#reader">reader</a> by well-known <a href="#author">author</a>s and scholars.  <b><em>NYRB</em></b> also includes <a href="#bookannouncement">announcement</a>s of <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s published by <a href="#tradepublisher">trade</a> and <a href="#universitypress">university press</a>es.  <a href="http://www.nybooks.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> version of <b><em>NYRB</em></b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#nytbr">New York Times Book Review (NYTBR)</a></em> and <em><a href="#tls">Times Literary Supplement (TLS)</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nytbr"><b><em>New York Times Book Review (NYTBR)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>One of the most influential <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>s in the United States, <b><em>NYTBR</em></b> is <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#weekly">weekly</a> as part of the Sunday <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the <em>New York Times</em>.  It is also available by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> as a separate <a href="#section">section</a>.  <a href="#review">Review</a>s are long and scholarly, written for the educated <a href="#reader">reader</a> by well-known writers and scholars.  Some <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s consider it the most important <a href="#medium">medium</a> in the country for advertising new <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a>s.  <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/books/review/">Click here</a> to connect to <b><em>NYTBR</em></b> <a href="#online">online</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#newyorkreview">New York Review of Books (NYRB)</a></em> and <em><a href="#tls">Times Literary Supplement (TLS)</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nfais1"><b>NFAIS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nfais"><b>N</b>ational <b>F</b>ederation of <b>A</b>bstracting and <b>I</b>nformation <b>S</b>ervices</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nfpb1"><b>NFPB</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nfpb"><b>N</b>ational <b>F</b>ilm <b>P</b>reservation <b>B</b>oard</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nfpf1"><b>NFPF</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nfpf"><b>N</b>ational <b>F</b>ilm <b>P</b>reservation <b>F</b>oundation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nfr1"><b>NFR</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nfr"><b>N</b>ational <b>F</b>ilm <b>R</b>egistry</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ngs1"><b>NGS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ngs"><b>N</b>ational <b>G</b>enealogical <b>S</b>ociety</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nichepublishing"><b>niche publishing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The activities of <a href="#smallpress">small press</a>es and divisions within large <a href="#publisher">publishing companies</a> that limit their scope to a relatively narrow <a href="#subject">subject</a> area (<em>example</em>:  auto repair manuals or travel guides) or type of <a href="#literature">literature</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#genre">genre</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>), producing <a href="#publication">publication</a>s intended to meet the needs of a specific market segment.  Some niches are broader than others.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nickname"><b>nickname</b></a>
</dt><dd>A familiar name of a person, usually a diminutive form of the full given name (<em>example</em>:
"Bill" for William). Also, a popular name sometimes given in derision
or to highlight a special attribute of the person ("Wild Bill").
Corporate entities can have nicknames ("Big Apple" for New York City). <a href="#information">Information</a> on nicknames can be found in the latest <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the <b><em>Pseudonyms and Nicknames Dictionary</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>.  Compare with <a href="#conventionalname">conventional name</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nihilobstat"><b><em>nihil obstat</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A Latin <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> meaning "nothing hinders" appearing on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of <a href="#work">work</a>s that have been examined by officials of the Roman Catholic Church and found to contain no offense that merits <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>, still used in books that present official Catholic doctrine (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>New Catholic Encyclopedia</em></b>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#imprimatur">imprimatur</a></em> and <em><a href="#indexlibrorum">Index Librorum Prohibitorum</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nipping"><b>nipping</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the step in which the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> and <a href="#case">case</a> (or <a href="#cover">cover</a>s) are pressed firmly together to expel air from between the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, giving the <a href="#volume">volume</a> its desired shape.  When done after <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> to reduce <a href="#swell">swell</a> before the covers are applied, the process is called <em>smashing</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="niso1"><b>NISO</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#niso"><b>N</b>ational <b>I</b>nformation 
<b>S</b>tandards <b>O</b>rganization</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nitratefilm"><b>nitrate film</b></a>
</dt><dd>A flexible base made of cellulose nitrate, produced by Eastman Kodak from about 1890 until 1950 for use in <a href="#film">film</a> <a href="#negative">negative</a>s and <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> film.  Because it is chemically unstable and highly flammable, organizations such as the <a href="#nfpf">National Film Preservation Foundation</a> provide <a href="#grant">grant</a> assistance to <a href="#filmarchives">film archives</a> to facilitate the <a href="#copy">copy</a>ing of moving image <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s from nitrate film to a more permanent base, such as acetate or <a href="#polyester">polyester</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nle1"><b>NLE</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nle"><b>N</b>ational <b>L</b>ibrary of <b>E</b>ducation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nlm1"><b>NLM</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nlm"><b>N</b>ational <b>L</b>ibrary of <b>M</b>edicine</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nls1"><b>NLS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nls"><b>N</b>ational <b>L</b>ibrary <b>S</b>ervice for the Blind and Physically Handicapped</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nmrt1"><b>NMRT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nmrt"><b>N</b>ew <b>M</b>embers <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nntp"><b>NNTP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#newsgroup">newsgroup</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nobel"><b>Nobel Prize in Literature</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a> established and funded in 1900 by Alfred B. Nobel, who made his fortune from the invention of dynamite.  The <b>Nobel Prize in Literature</b> is given annually by the Swedish Academy in Stockholm to "the person who shall have produced in the <a href="#field">field</a> of <a href="#literature">literature</a> the most distinguished <a href="#work">work</a> of an idealistic tendency."  <a href="http://www.nobel.se/literature/laureates/">Click here</a> to see a list of past prize winners.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nationalbook">National Book Award</a> and <a href="#pulitzer">Pulitzer prize</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nodate"><b>no date</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> <em>n.d.</em>, used in a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> to indicate that the <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> is unknown.  If no <a href="#publication">publication</a> date appears on a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, but the correct date is ascertainable from other sources, it is indicated in the <a href="#edition">edition</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the record, is a <a href="#bracketedinterp">bracketed interpolation</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>[1956]</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="node"><b>node</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>nodus</em> meaning "knot" or "knob."  In botany, the point on the stem of a plant from which a leaf or twig grows.  In <a href="#communications">communications</a>, a junction point in a <a href="#network">network</a>, such as a <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a> connected to a <a href="#localarea">LAN</a> or a <a href="#terminal">terminal</a> connected to a <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a>.  Each node has its own unique network address and the capacity to send, receive, and store messages.  In an <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>, the point in a <a href="#treestructure">tree structure</a> at which two or more lines meet.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nomdeplume"><b>nom de plume</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nomenclature"><b>nomenclature</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#terminology">terminology</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nonbook"><b>nonbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A collective <a href="#term">term</a> for <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> not <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#codex">codex</a> form like a <a href="#book">book</a>, including but not limited to <a href="#map">map</a>s and other <a href="#cartographic">cartographic materials</a> (except <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>es), <a href="#print">print</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#slide">slide</a>s, <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>s, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>s, <a href="#kit">kit</a>s, <a href="#model">model</a>s, <a href="#realia">realia</a>, etc.  Compare with <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="noncirculating"><b>noncirculating</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#libmaterials">Materials</a> which may not be <a href="#charge">charged</a> to a <a href="#borroweraccount">borrower account</a> except by special arrangement, but are usually available for <a href="#libraryuseonly">library use only</a>, including <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s, <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es, and sometimes the <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s themselves.  Whether materials in <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a> are designated <a href="#circulating">circulating</a> or noncirculating depends on the policy of the individual <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, but their use is nearly always <a href="#restricted">restricted</a> to library premises.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="noncurrent"><b>noncurrent</b></a>
</dt><dd>Recurring <a href="#information">information</a>, materials, or <a href="#record">record</a>s that are no longer up-to-date, for example, corporate <a href="#annualreport">annual report</a>s from previous years or earlier <a href="#edition">edition</a>s of a <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a>, often retained in <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#archives">archives</a> for their <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>.  Noncurrent <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> of <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, called <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s, are often converted to <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> or <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> to conserve space.  The opposite of <a href="#currency">current</a>.  Compare with <a href="#outdated">outdated</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nonfiction"><b>nonfiction</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#prose">Prose</a> <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s describing events that actually occurred and <a href="#character">character</a>s or phenomena that actually exist or existed in the past.  In a more general sense, any piece of prose writing in which the <a href="#content">content</a> is not imagined by the <a href="#author">author</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a> that use <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a> or <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, nonfiction is shelved by <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>.  Compare with <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>. <em><b>See also</b></em>: <a href="#documentary">documentary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nongapbreak"><b>nongap break</b></a>
</dt><dd>An indication in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> that a hiatus exists in the <a href="#publication">publication</a> or in the <a href="#issuenumber">number</a>ing of a <a href="#serial">serial</a>, despite the fact that no <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d are missing.  This circumstance can arise when <a href="#ceased">publication ceases</a> and then starts up again under the same or a different <a href="#title">title</a>, sometimes with a change in numeration.  Compare with <a href="#gap">gap</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nonnet"><b>non-net</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#copy">Copies</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> (usually a <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>) which a <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> is permitted by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to sell in bulk quantities to schools for educational use at a discretionary <a href="#discount">discount</a>.  Compare with <a href="#net">net</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nonprint"><b>nonprint</b></a>
