</dt><dd>Materials <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a <a href="#format">format</a> other than writing or <a href="#print">print</a> on <a href="#paper">paper</a>, including <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> and <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a>, <a href="#slide">slide</a>s, <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>s, <a href="#film">film</a>s, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, <a href="#audiorecording">audiorecording</a>s, and <a href="#information">information</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> format such as <a href="#mrdf">machine-readable data file</a>s.  Most nonprint <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> require special <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a> for listening and/or viewing.  Compare with <a href="#nonbook">nonbook</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nonrepeatable"><b>nonrepeatable (NR)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#field">field</a> which may appear only once in the same <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, for example, the <b>250</b> field reserved for the <a href="#editionstatement">edition statement</a> and other <a href="#information">information</a> pertaining to <a href="#edition">edition</a>.  A nonrepeatable <a href="#subfield">subfield</a> may occur only once in a field.  The opposite of <a href="#repeatable">repeatable</a> (R). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nonresidents"><b>nonresident's card</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#librarycard">borrower's card</a> issued to a person who does not reside within the legal boundaries of the <a href="#librarydistrict">district</a> or area served by the <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, usually in exchange for payment of a modest <a href="#fee">fee</a>, <a href="#renew">renew</a>able at regular intervals.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nonretrnable"><b>nonreturnable</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#returns">returns</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nonsorting"><b>nonsorting character</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#character">character</a>, such as the apostrophe, ignored in <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> when it appears in a word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, <a href="#heading">heading</a>, or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nonsupplier"><b>nonsupplier</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> or other participant in the <a href="#oclcill">OCLC Interlibrary Loan</a> <a href="#network">network</a> that does <em>not</em> respond to requests from other <a href="#library">libraries</a> to borrow <a href="#returnable">returnable</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>.  In the <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>, the three-letter <a href="#oclcsymbol">OCLC symbol</a>s of nonsuppliers appear in <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> in the <a href="#holdingsdisplay">holdings display</a> attached to the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, in contrast to the <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s which appear in <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nontrad"><b>nontrad</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nontraditional">nontraditional student</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nontraditional"><b>nontraditional student</b></a>
</dt><dd>A student who enrolls at an institution of higher education
after several years of little or no contact with the system of formal
education. <em>Nontrads</em> are usually older than <em>traditional students</em> who enter college out of high school and complete their undergraduate degree without a break.  Because nontrads often lack the <a href="#library">library</a> skills of their younger classmates, they may require <a href="#bi">instruction</a> and <a href="#refdesk">reference</a> assistance at a more basic level, but once they gain self-confidence, they can be highly motivated.  Compare with <a href="#adultlearner">adult learner</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nop1"><b>NOP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nop"><b>n</b>ot <b>o</b>ur <b>p</b>ublication</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nap"><b>normal administrative practice (NAP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The concept in <a href="#archives">archives</a> that <a href="#records">records</a> such as <a href="#draft">draft</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s, <a href="#duplicate">duplicate</a>s, and multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a> of <a href="#publication">publication</a>s may be routinely <a href="#destruction">destroyed</a> when no longer needed, provided no <a href="#information">information</a> of enduring value to the organization is lost in the process.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="naics"><b>North American Industry Classification System (NAICS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Adopted in 1997 by the Office of Management and Budget as the industry <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> used by statistical <a href="#govtagency">agencies</a> of the U.S. federal government, <b>NAICS</b> (pronounced <em>nakes</em>)
was developed by the Economic Classification Policy Committee of the
OMB, in cooperation with Statistics Canada and the Instituto Nacional
de Estadistica Geografia e Informatica (INEGI) of Mexico to replace the
<a href="#sic">Standard Industrial Classification</a> (SIC) used since the 1930s.
<p>
Based on a new concept that classifies businesses by the processes they use to produce goods and services, <b>NAICS</b>
is designed to reflect expansion of the service and technology sectors,
provide comparable statistics across the three countries covered by the
North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), and be compatible with the
International Industrial Classification System (ISIC) developed by the
United Nations. <a href="http://www.census.gov/epcd/www/naics.html">Click here</a> connect to the <b>NAICS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nasig"><b>North American Serials Interest Group (NASIG)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1985, <b>NASIG</b> is an independent organization that facilitates the sharing of <a href="#information">information</a> and ideas among individuals involved with <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, including serials <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agencies</a>, <a href="#producer">producer</a>s and <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s of <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> <a href="#software">software</a> and <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#periodicalindex"> index</a>es/<a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>s, representatives of <a href="#bibutility">bibliographic utilities</a>, educators, and <a href="#bindery">binder</a>s, mainly in the United States, Canada, and Mexico. <b>NASIG</b> sponsors an annual <a href="#libconference">conference</a>, hosts the electronic <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a> <em>NASIG-L</em> , and <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <em>NASIG Newsletter</em>.  <a href="http://www.nasig.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NASIG</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="naslin"><b>North American Sport Library Network (NASLIN)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1989, <b>NASLIN</b> is dedicated to facilitating communication and <a href="#resourcesharing">resource sharing</a> among sports <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#archives">archives</a>, and information services through <a href="#conference">conference</a>s, educational programs, and other cooperative projects.  Its members are <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#archivist">archivist</a>s, and information specialists involved in the <a href="#publication">publication</a>, <a href="#acquisitions">acquisition</a>, organization, retrieval, and dissemination of <a href="#information">information</a> related to all aspects of sports, physical education, and recreation.  <b>NASLIN</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em><a href="http://www.sportquest.com/naslin/nasnew.html">NASLINE</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.sportquest.com/naslin/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>NASLIN</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="northpointer"><b>north pointer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A standard <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> <a href="#device">device</a> in the form of a small cross or wheel with an arrow pointing north, <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#chart">chart</a>s, <a href="#blueprint">blueprint</a>s, plans, etc., usually in or near the <a href="#legend">legend</a> to indicate compass orientation.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nos"><b>nos</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> "not on shelf," used by <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> to refer to an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> listed as <a href="#available">available</a> in the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, which cannot be located in correct <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> sequence in the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a>.  When this occurs, the <a href="#patron">patron</a> may request that the staff conduct a <a href="#search">search</a> for the item.  If it is not found, the <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> is changed to "<a href="#missing">missing</a>" in the <a href="#itemrecord">item record</a> and a <a href="#replacement">replacement</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> may be ordered or the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> removed from the catalog.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="not"><b>NOT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#logicaldifference">logical difference</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="notation"><b>notation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The set of <a href="#character">character</a>s (usually <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s and/or <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>) used to represent the <a href="#class">class</a>es and <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a>s of a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the class notation assigned to a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> represents its <a href="#subject">subject</a> and is the first element of the <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>, determining its position on the shelf relative to other items of similar <a href="#classification">classificiation</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#baseofnotation">base of notation</a>, <a href="#expressivenotation">expressive notation</a>, <a href="#facetednotation">faceted notation</a>, <a href="#mixednotation">mixed notation</a>, <a href="#mnemonicnotation">mnemonic notation</a>, and <a href="#purenotation">pure notation</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s used to write music, as in a music <a href="#score">score</a>, and to express mathematical concepts.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="notchedbinding"><b>notched binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>In some <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive binding</a>s, shallow parallel grooves are cut into the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> perpendicular to the <a href="#spine">spine</a> to enlarge the surface area exposed to the <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a>.  Although <em>notching</em> strengthens the <a href="#binding">binding</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, the additional adhesive has the disadvantage of restricting <a href="#openability">openability</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="note"><b>note</b></a>
</dt><dd>In writing and <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a statement explaining a point in the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, or giving the <a href="#source">source</a> of a <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> or idea that does not originate with the <a href="#author">author</a>.  Notes are usually numbered consecutively and may be listed as <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s at the bottom of the same <a href="#page">page</a> as the text to which they refer, or as <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>s at the conclusion of an <a href="#article">article</a>, <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>, or <a href="#book">book</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#sidenote">side note</a> and <a href="#shouldernote">shoulder note</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a statement in the <a href="#notearea">note area</a> of a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> giving the <a href="#contents">contents</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a>, its relationship to other works, and any physical characteristics not included elsewhere in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  If there is more than one note, each is given in a separate paragraph.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="notearea"><b>note area</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#area">area</a> following the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> in a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> giving the <a href="#contents">contents</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a>, its relationship to other works, and any physical characteristics not included in preceding areas of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  Each note is given a separate paragraph in <a href="#field">field</a>s 5XX of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="notebook"><b>notebook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> or <a href="#spiralbinding">spiral</a> <a href="#binder">binder</a> with flexible or inflexible <a href="#board">board</a> or plastic <a href="#cover">cover</a>s, usually filled with <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, <a href="#rule">rule</a>d
or unruled, for taking notes. Some notebooks also include a pocket
across the bottom inside the front and/or back cover for holding <a href="#loose">loose</a> papers.  Also used as a synonym for <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="notificationslip"><b>notification slip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> form sent to the <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> department of a <a href="#library">library</a> by an <a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a> <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> to announce a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> that meets the needs profile established by the library.  Under most plans, rejection of the <a href="#title">title</a> by the library within a designated period of time will prevent <a href="#shipping">shipment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nop"><b>not our publication (NOP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used on a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#invoice">invoice</a> to indicate that the <a href="#title">title</a> ordered cannot be supplied because the <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> apparently ordered it from the wrong publisher. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nr"><b>not returnable (NR) </b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used on a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#invoice">invoice</a> to indicate that a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> cannot be <a href="#returns">returned</a> once it has been <a href="#receiving">received</a> by the <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> placing the order. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nyp"><b>not yet published (NYP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used on a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#invoice">invoice</a> to indicate that the <a href="#title">title</a> ordered cannot be immediately supplied because it is in the process of being <a href="#publishing">published</a> and will be <a href="#issue">issue</a>d at some time in the future.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="novel"><b>novel</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Italian <em>novella</em>, meaning "a new little thing."  In most European <a href="#language">language</a>s, the word for novel is <em>roman</em>,
derived from the literary tradition of medieval romance. The origins of
the modern novel can also be traced to the picaresque <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>s of 16th-century Spain, of which Cervantes' <b><em>Don Quixote</em></b> is a well-known example.  
<p>
As a literary form, the novel of incident began in 1719 with the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of Daniel Defoe's <b><em>Robinson Crusoe</em></b>, followed shortly by <b><em>Moll Flanders</em></b>.  The novel of character originated in 1740 with <b><em>Pamela</em></b> by Samuel Richardson.  Since then, the form has evolved into many styles and <a href="#genre">genre</a>s (see <a href="#bildungsroman">Bildungsroman</a>, <a href="#epistolarynovel">epistolary novel</a>, <a href="#gothicnovel">gothic novel</a>, <a href="#kunstlerroman">Kunstlerroman</a>, <a href="#psychologicalnovel">psychological novel</a>, <a href="#romanaclef">roman a clef</a>, and <a href="#sentimental">sentimental novel</a>).
</p><p>
Strictly speaking, a novel is a <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>al <a href="#prose">prose</a> <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> involving people and events that exist in the imagination of the <em>novelist</em>.  This is true even in <a href="#historicalfiction">historical fiction</a>
which is an imaginative attempt to reconstruct events known to have
occurred in the past. There is no upper limit on the length of a novel,
but a fictional narrative of <em>less</em> than 30,000-40,000 words is considered either a <a href="#novelette">novelette</a> or <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>.  Greater length gives the novelist a freer hand in developing <a href="#character">character</a>, <a href="#plot">plot</a>, and <a href="#setting">setting</a>.  Most novels are divided into <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>s,
usually reflecting major divisions in the narrative. Long novels may be
divided into "books" each containing two or more chapters. Compare with
<a href="#novella">novella</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#archetypalnovel">archetypal novel</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="novelette"><b>novelette</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#novel">novel</a> of 30,000-50,000 words (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Billy Budd</em></b> by Herman Melville).  Synonymous with <em>short novel</em>.  Compare with <a href="#novella">novella</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="novelization"><b>novelization</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> converted into a <a href="#novel">novel</a> from the form in which it was originally written (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Wave</em></b> by Morton Rhue based on a <a href="#teleplay">teleplay</a> by Johnny Dawkins based on a <a href="#shortstory">short story</a> by Ron Jones).  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, a novelization is <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under the name of the <em>novelist</em> with <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a> for the <a href="#author">author</a> and <a href="#title">title</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a> on which it is based.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dramatization">dramatization</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="novella"><b>novella</b></a>
</dt><dd>An Italian word meaning "short story" or "tale."  A short <a href="#prose">prose</a> <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> comparable in length to a <a href="#novelette">novelette</a> or long <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>, which often relates a surprising <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>al event (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Old Man and the Sea</em></b> by Ernest Hemingway).  Novellas often have a moral and may be written in a <a href="#satire">satirical</a> style (<b><em>Goodbye, Columbus</em></b> by Philip Roth).  Compare with <a href="#novel">novel</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="novice"><b>novice</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who uses an unfamiliar computer system for the first time, as opposed to an experienced user.  In the design of <a href="#website">Web site</a>s and <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a>s, <a href="#library">libraries</a> and computer <a href="#software">software</a> companies may conduct <a href="#usabilitytesting">usability test</a>s to judge the <a href="#userfriendly">user-friendliness</a> of the new system.  In a more general sense, any <a href="#patron">patron</a> for whom the procedures of a library are new and often confusing.  Special consideration must be shown at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nr1"><b>NR</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nr"><b>n</b>ot <b>r</b>eturnable</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nsn1"><b>NSN</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nsn"><b>N</b>ational <b>S</b>torytelling <b>N</b>etwork</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nt"><b>NT (or N)</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#narrowerterm"><b>n</b>arrower <b>t</b>erm</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ntis1"><b>NTIS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ntis"><b>N</b>ational <b>T</b>echnical <b>I</b>nformation <b>S</b>ervice</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nuc1"><b>NUC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nuc"><b>N</b>ational <b>U</b>nion <b>C</b>atalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nucmc1"><b>NUCMC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nucmc"><b>N</b>ational <b>U</b>nion <b>C</b>atalog of <b>M</b>anuscript <b>C</b>ollections</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="number"><b>number</b></a>
</dt><dd>A quantity that can be counted, represented by a word, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>, or combination of numerals--<em>cardinal</em> numbers indicate how many (1, 2, 3, 14, 154), <em>ordinal</em> numbers indicate relative position in sequence (1st, 2nd, 3rd, 14th, 154th).  In <a href="#text">text</a>,
the numbers zero to nine are usually spelled out, but numbers greater
than nine are given in numerals. Also, to assign a number to each item
in a series, for reference and to indicate sequence. <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>no</em>. 
<p>
Also refers to a single <a href="#issuenumber">number</a>ed or dated <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> or <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, to one of the <a href="#part">part</a>s of a <a href="#work">work</a> issued in <a href="#installment">installment</a>s, or to a numbered <a href="#fascicle">fascicle</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#backissue">back issue</a>, <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>, and <a href="#numberbook">number book</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="numberbook"><b>number book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#book">book</a>, common in the 18th and 19th centuries, <a href="#publishing">published</a> in numbered <a href="#part">part</a>s or <a href="#installment">installment</a>s, usually at <a href="#regular">regular</a> intervals.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#serialized">serialized</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="numberbuilding"><b>number building</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> must construct a <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> when no existing <a href="#class">class</a> in the <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a>s precisely represents the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a>.  This is done by adding to a <a href="#basenumber">base number</a>, <a href="#notation">notation</a> found in the <a href="#table">table</a> of <a href="#standardsubdivision">standard subdivision</a>s (or in one of the other tables), or from another part of the <a href="#mainschedule">main schedule</a>s, according to established rules, for example, the addition of the <a href="#decimalpoint">decimal</a> fraction <b>.5</b> to the base number <b>020</b> to create the class <b>020.5</b> for <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s in the <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="numberedcopy"><b>numbered copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a consecutively numbered <a href="#limitededition">limited edition</a>, bearing a <a href="#copynumber">copy number</a> assigned by hand by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> and an indication of the total number of copies <a href="#printing">printed</a>, usually in the <a href="#colophon">colophon</a> or in a <a href="#certificate">certificate of issue</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> preceding <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#overs">overs</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="numeral"><b>numeral</b></a>
</dt><dd>In writing and <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#character">character</a> or set of characters used to represent a <a href="#number">number</a> (<em>example</em>:  the <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a> <b>9</b> or <a href="#romannumeral">roman numeral</a> <b>IX</b>).  General rules for the use of numerals in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> are given in <em>Appendix C</em> of <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="numericalphabetic"><b>numeric and/or alphabetic, chronological, or other designation</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#materialspecific">material specific details</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> in which the <a href="#pubhistory">publication history</a> of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> is given, usually in the form of an <a href="#openentry">open</a> or <a href="#closedentry">closed entry</a>, as distinct from the <a href="#holdingsnote">holdings note</a> indicating the <a href="#issue">issue</a>s owned by a specific <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nurseryrhyme"><b>nursery rhyme</b></a>
</dt><dd>A short metrical <a href="#verse">verse</a> or ditty
originating in the oral tradition of a specific culture, taught to very
young children to help them learn to speak or count. Some nursery
rhymes are derived from <a href="#adult">adult</a> sayings that had a double meaning in the cultural context in which they originated.  Nursery rhymes are usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#collection">collection</a>s shelved in the <a href="#juvenile">juvenile section</a> of a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>, or in the <a href="#curriculumroom">curriculum room</a> of an <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#limerick">limerick</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nyp1"><b>NYP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nyp"><b>n</b>ot <b>y</b>et <b>p</b>ublished</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nypl1"><b>NYPL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nypl"><b>N</b>ew <b>Y</b>ork <b>P</b>ublic <b>L</b>ibrary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nyrb1"><b><em>NYRB</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#newyorkreview"><b>N</b>ew <b>Y</b>ork <b>R</b>eview of <b>B</b>ooks</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="nytbr1"><b><em>NYTBR</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#nytbr"><b>N</b>ew <b>Y</b>ork <b>T</b>imes <b>B</b>ook <b>R</b>eview</a></em>.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>

| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="O">O</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="oai1"><b>OAI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#oai"><b>O</b>pen <b>A</b>rchives <b>I</b>nitiative</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oakknoll"><b>Oak Knoll</b></a>
</dt><dd>A company located in New Castle, Delaware that <a href="#publisher">publishes</a>, <a href="#distributor">distributes</a>, and sells <a href="#book">book</a>s on <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, <a href="#bookcollecting">book collecting</a>, <a href="#bookhistory">book history</a>, <a href="#bookplate">bookplate</a>s, the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, book design, book <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, <a href="#typography">typography</a>, fine <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#forgery">forgery</a>, and <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>.  Its inventory includes over 12,500 <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s.  <a href="http://www.oakknoll.com/">Click here</a> to learn more about <b>Oak Knoll Books &amp; Oak Knoll Press</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="obiit"><b>obiit</b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for "died," usually <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> <em>ob.</em> before a date to indicate the year of a person's decease (<b><em>ob. 1922</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="obituary"><b>obituary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A notice of a person's death, usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> or <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, which may include a brief <a href="#biography">biographical</a> sketch of the main events in the life of the deceased.  The obituaries of well-known public figures may be <a href="#research">research</a>ed and written long before the person's death, to be ready for <a href="#printing">printing</a> on short notice.  Obituaries are <a href="#index">index</a>ed under the last name of the deceased in <b><em>Biography Index</em></b>, a <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> available in most large <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States and via <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#firstsearch">FirstSearch</a></em>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>obit</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="object"><b>object</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, an object is defined as a three-dimensional <a href="#artifact">artifact</a>, <a href="#replica">replica</a>, or naturally occurring entity.  In the British list of <a href="#gmd">general material designation</a>s, the <a href="#term">term</a> also includes <a href="#diorama">diorama</a>s, <a href="#game">game</a>s, <a href="#microscopeslide">microscope slide</a>s, <a href="#model">model</a>s, and <a href="#realia">realia</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="objective"><b>objective</b></a>
</dt><dd>A specific achievable outcome of actions taken to achieve a stated <a href="#goal">goal</a>,
usually expressed in measurable terms and subject to a time limit.
Although an objective does not address the specific means by which the
outcome is to be achieved, it should be based upon a realistic
assessment of available resources. A good set of achievable objectives
can serve as an inspiration and guide for an organization in <a href="#strategicplanning">planning</a> for the future, <a href="#allocation">allocating</a> resources, evaluating progress, adjusting strategy, and persevering until the desired result is achieved.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oblong"><b>oblong</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#width">wider</a> than it is <a href="#height">high</a>.  Children's <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>s are often oblong in shape to allow the <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a> a wider canvas.  In a more general sense, any <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> on its shorter dimension.  Synonymous in the <a href="#printing">printing</a> trade with <em>landscape</em>.  Compare with <a href="#portrait">portrait</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#narrow">narrow</a> and <a href="#square">square</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="obscenity"><b>obscenity</b></a>
</dt><dd>Speech, writing, or artistic expression considered indecent by conventional <a href="#standards">standards</a> of behavior because it offends the modesty and delicacy of feeling of ordinary people.  Synonymous with <em>smut</em>.  Compare with <a href="#pornography">pornography</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bowdlerize">bowdlerize</a>, <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>, <a href="#expurgated">expurgated</a>, and <a href="#unprintable">unprintable</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oc1"><b>OC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#oc"><b>o</b>rder <b>c</b>ancelled</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="occasional"><b>occasional</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#document">document</a> or <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d on an <a href="#irregular">irregular</a> basis, sometimes numbered sequentially by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Occasional Publications in Archaeology and History</em></b> of the Massachusetts Historical Commission).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oclc1"><b>OCLC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#oclc"><b>O</b>nline <b>C</b>omputer <b>L</b>ibrary <b>C</b>enter, Inc.</a>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oclccontrol"><b>OCLC control number</b></a>
</dt><dd>Whenever the <a href="#bibutility">bibliographic utility</a> <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> enters a new <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> into its <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a> (<em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em>), a unique <a href="#number">number</a> is assigned to the record for the purpose of <a href="#bibcontrol">bibliographic control</a>.  The number appears in the <a href="#leader">leader</a> of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record and is <a href="#systemsupplied">system-supplied</a>.  Compare with <a href="#lccn">LCCN</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#accessionnumber">accession number</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oclcill1"><b>OCLC ILL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#oclcill">OCLC Interlibrary Loan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oclcill"><b>OCLC Interlibrary Loan (ILL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> service of <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a>, a <a href="#network">network</a> that facilitates the borrowing and lending of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> between <a href="#library">libraries</a> and other institutions that are OCLC members and participants in <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em>, the largest <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a> in the world.  <a href="http://www.oclc.org/oclc/menu/ill.htm">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>OCLC ILL</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oluc"><b><em>OCLC Online Union Catalog (OLUC)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>The former name of <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em>, an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a> containing over 46 million <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s representing <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#holdings">held</a> by over 6,700 <a href="#library">libraries</a> and other institutions that are members and participants in <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a>, the largest <a href="#bibutility">bibliographic utility</a> in the world. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oclcsymbol"><b>OCLC symbol</b></a>
</dt><dd>A unique three-letter code assigned by <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> to identify a <a href="#library">library</a> or other institution that is a member or participant in its <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> and <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> <a href="#network">network</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>DLC</b> for <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>).  Institutions with more than one library may have a different <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> for each library.  
<p>
OCLC symbols are used in <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s to indicate <a href="#catsource">cataloging source</a> (<a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#field">field</a> 040) and in <a href="#holdingsdisplay">holdings display</a>s in the OCLC <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> to identify libraries that have used a record for cataloging purposes.  Symbols of interlibrary loan <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s are displayed in <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a>, those of <a href="#nonsupplier">nonsupplier</a>s in <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a>.  OCLC <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> two <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly arranged <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#directory">directories</a> under the <a href="#title">title</a> <em>OCLC Participating Institutions</em>, one arranged by OCLC symbol and the other by name of institution.  The list is also available on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a> in <a href="#searchable">searchable</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, <a href="#update">update</a>d <a href="#weekly">weekly</a> (<a href="http://purl.org/oclc/pi">purl.org/oclc/pi</a>).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ocr"><b>OCR</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#opticalcharacter"><b>o</b>ptical <b>c</b>haracter <b>r</b>ecognition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="octavo"><b>octavo (8vo)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> approximately 6 x 9 inches in size, made by folding a full <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of book <a href="#paper">paper</a> in three right-angle folds, producing <a href="#signature">signature</a>s of eight <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> (sixteen <a href="#page">page</a>s).  If a 32-page <a href="#section">section</a> is desired, as in most children's <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>s, double size sheets are folded four times.  The precise size of each leaf in an octavo <a href="#edition">edition</a> depends on the size of the original sheet.  In modern <a href="#printing">printing</a>, octavo is the most commonly used size for books <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>.  Compare with <a href="#folio">folio</a>, <a href="#quarto">quarto</a>, <a href="#duodecimo">duodecimo</a>, and <a href="#sextodecimo">sextodecimo</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ode"><b>ode</b></a>
</dt><dd>A relatively long <a href="#lyric">lyric</a> <a href="#poetry">poem</a> of elaborate structure derived from songs performed by the <em>chorus</em> in ancient Greek dramatic performances, written to <a href="#eulogy">eulogize</a> a hero (or heroes).  In English <a href="#literature">literature</a>, the object of praise may be a person or category of person (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Ode to the Confederate Dead</em></b> by Allen Tate), an abstraction (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Ode to Beauty</em></b> by Ralph Waldo Emerson), or an inner state expressed <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ically (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Ode on a Grecian Urn</em></b> by John Keats). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oed1"><b><em>OED</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#oed"><b>O</b>xford <b>E</b>nglish <b>D</b>ictionary</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="offduty"><b>off-duty</b></a>
</dt><dd>Time when an employee is 1) scheduled but not working (usually
on a break or lunch hour), 2) not scheduled on a shift, or 3) not
working if employed <a href="#parttime">part-time</a>.  Off-duty <a href="#publicservices">public services</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s are sometimes recognized as <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> when passing through a public area of the <a href="#library">library</a> and approached by <a href="#patron">patron</a>s in need of assistance.  The opposite of <a href="#onduty">on-duty</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="officeofrecord"><b>office of record</b></a>
</dt><dd>The unit within an organization, responsible for systematically <a href="#documentation">documenting</a> an activity and preserving the resulting <a href="#records">records</a>
for the normal period for which they are needed to conduct business or
affairs, for example, a personnel office in the case current employment
records. Synonymous with <em>agency of record</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="officialname"><b>official name</b></a>
</dt><dd>The legal name of a company, <a href="#agency">agency</a>, organization, institution, etc., which may differ from the form of name used in its <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, or in <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> them for a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>.  Compare with <a href="#corporatename">corporate name</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="officialpub"><b>official publication</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a> by an official body, such as a <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a> or intergovernmental organization, under its legal name, often retained by <a href="#library">libraries</a> for <a href="#refservices">reference</a> purposes (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Budget of the United States Government</em></b> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by the Office of Management and Budget).  U.S. federal <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> fall into this category.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="officialrecords"><b>official records</b></a>
</dt><dd>The formal written <a href="#document">document</a>s in which the ongoing activities of a company, government, organization, or institution are <a href="#record">record</a>ed, usually retained in <a href="#archives">archives</a> for their evidential, legal, <a href="#information">information</a>al, or historical value, in accordance with instructions contained in a <a href="#dispositionschedule">disposition schedule</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Congressional Record</em></b>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#officeofrecord">office of record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="officialtitle"><b>official title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The full <a href="#title">title</a> appearing on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, used by <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s in <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#titleproper"> title proper</a> and <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="offline"><b>offline</b></a>
</dt><dd>An automated service not connected to a <a href="#network">network</a>, for example, a <a href="#standalone">stand-alone</a> <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a> running <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> or an <a href="#intranet">intranet</a> not connected to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  Also refers to computer accessories or <a href="#device">device</a>s not connected to or installed on the <a href="#centralproc">central processing unit</a> (CPU), or physically connected but not turned on or standing ready for use, for example, a <a href="#printer">printer</a> or <a href="#scanner">scanner</a> that is turned off.
<p>
Also used as a <a href="#slang">slang</a> expression for a person who is uninformed about something of which those around him are aware.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>out of the loop</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="offprint"><b>offprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of an <a href="#article">article</a>, <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>, or portion of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>ed from the same <a href="#plate">plate</a>s, usually at the same time as the <a href="#original">original</a>, but <a href="#issue">issue</a>d separately, with or without a <a href="#cover">cover</a>, usually for the <a href="#author">author</a>'s personal use.  <a href="#contributor">Contributor</a>s to scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a>s often receive a limited number of copies of their articles from the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, sometimes as a form of compensation.  An offprint may or may not include a <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, but retains the original <a href="#pagination">pagination</a>.  The sale of offprints provides an important source of revenue for some journal publishers.  Also spelled <em>off-print</em>.  Synonymous with <em>overprint</em>, <em>run-on</em>, and <em>separate</em>.  Compare with <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="offset"><b>offset</b></a>
</dt><dd>A rotary <a href="#printing">printing</a> process in which <a href="#ink">ink</a> is applied to a thin <a href="#plate">plate</a> wrapped around a rotating cylinder, which transfers the image to a second rubber-coated cylinder from which an <a href="#impression">impression</a> is made on a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> or roll of printing <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  Offset is faster, less expensive, and capable of printing much finer detail than <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dd>Also refers to faint traces of ink unintentionally transferred from a freshly printed <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#page">page</a> or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> to the facing page, usually when a <a href="#publication">publication</a> is <a href="#binding">bound</a> before the ink has dried, a problem averted in some <a href="#edition">edition</a>s by inserting sheets of <a href="#tissue">tissue</a> between the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, a procedure called <a href="#interleaving">interleaving</a>.  Also refers to the image transferred.  Synonymous with <em>setoff</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="offsitestorage"><b>off-site storage</b></a>
</dt><dd>Temporary or permanent storage of <a href="#archives">archival</a> or <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>
at a location outside the walls of the main facility, usually
necessitated by a shortage of space. Stored materials may be
temporarily unavailable or retrievable by <a href="#courier">courier</a> upon request during certain hours.  The most common criterion used in selecting <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s for off-site storage is low <a href="#usage">usage</a>.  Items may be shelved by a method that maximizes storage capacity, instead of in a <a href="#classification">classified</a> <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#annex">annex</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="offtherecord"><b>off the record</b></a>
</dt><dd>A statement or comment that the speaker does not wish <a href="#record">record</a>ed or made publicly known.  At meetings, such remarks are not included in the <a href="#minutes">minutes</a> and may not be expressed if the proceedings are <a href="#audiotape">tape</a>-recorded.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="olla"><b>olla</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of writing material made in southern India and Sri
Lanka from young leaves, especially of the palmyra palm, soaked in
water and pressed flat, then cut into strips approximately three inches
wide and one to three feet in length. Holes are made in one end of each
strip through which they can be attached by a cord to wooden <a href="#board">board</a>s to form a <a href="#book">book</a>.  The mixture of charcoal and oil rubbed into writing incised on the surface with a metal <a href="#stylus">stylus</a> may have helped <a href="#preservation">preserve</a> the earliest pre-Christian examples.  According to <em>Harrod's Librarians' Glossary</em> (Gower: 1990), this type of book is still made by Buddhist monks in Sri Lanka.  The term also applies to <a href="#document">document</a>s of this form and material.  Also spelled <em>ola</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oluc1"><b><em>OLUC</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#oluc">OCLC <b>O</b>n<b>l</b>ine <b>U</b>nion <b>C</b>atalog</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="omnibus"><b>omnibus book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large single-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#reprint">reprint</a> of two or more <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a> <a href="#novel">novel</a>s or other <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s, usually by the same <a href="#author">author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="omnibusref"><b>omnibus reference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a> directing the user from a single <a href="#heading">heading</a> to multiple headings in an <a href="#index">index</a>, as in the following example from the <em><a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress Subject Heading</a></em> list:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>:  
<dl><dt></dt><dd>Bibliographical cooperation <em>see</em> Bibliography, International; Cataloging, Cooperative; International cooperation; Union catalogs</dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="omnibusreview"><b>omnibus review</b></a>
</dt><dd>An evaluative <a href="#article">article</a> in which a <a href="#reviewer">reviewer</a> discusses and in some cases compares two or more <a href="#book">book</a>s or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s of a certain type, on a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a>, in a particular <a href="#field">field</a> of study, or which have some other characteristic in common.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onapproval"><b>on approval</b></a>
</dt><dd>An arrangement with a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#jobber">jobber</a> that allows a prospective buyer, such as a <a href="#library">library</a>, to examine newly <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s before deciding to purchase.  <a href="#libmaterials">Materials</a> sent for inspection must be returned within a designated period of time if the recipient does not intend to purchase.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ondemand"><b>on-demand publishing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The production of single <a href="#copy">copies</a> or small quantities of <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s in response to orders from customers, as opposed to supply from inventory.  An example of such a service is <em><a href="http://www.umi.com/hp/Products/DisExpress.html">Dissertation Express</a></em> which provides single copies of Ph.D. <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a>s on <a href="#demand">demand</a> for a fixed <a href="#fee">fee</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onduty"><b>on-duty </b></a>
</dt><dd>Time when an employee is expected to be at work, particularly the hours of a scheduled shift at a public <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a>, such as the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> or <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#offduty">off-duty</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oneactplay"><b>one-act play</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of modern drama in which all the action occurs in a single <a href="#act">act</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Aria da Capo</em></b>
by Edna St. Vincent Millay). Established as a literary form by the
experimental theater movement that began in the late 19th century, the
one-act <a href="#play">play</a> is usually short (20-50 minites performed), with a limited number of <a href="#character">character</a>s, no breaks in the action, and little if any change of scene, analogous to the <a href="#shortstory">short story</a> in <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oneofakind"><b>one-of-a-kind book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> created in a single <a href="#copy">copy</a>, as opposed to a production book <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in multiple copies.  <a href="#artbook">Art book</a>s created for display are usually of this type.  Compare with <a href="#limitededition">limited edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oneonone"><b>one-on-one</b></a>
</dt><dd>Services provided by a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or other <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> member working alone with a single <a href="#patron">patron</a>, usually involving a high degree of interaction, as in most transactions at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>.  Synonymous with <em>one-to-one</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oneperson"><b>one-person library (OPL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#information">information</a> service operated and managed by a single individual, usually with minimal assistance, more common in <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a> than in other types of libraries.  In <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s, small <a href="#branchlibrary">branch libraries</a> are sometimes run by a <a href="#solo">solo librarian</a> or <a href="#paraprofessional">paraprofessional</a>, often with the help of <a href="#volunteer">volunteer</a>s from the community.  <a href="#bookmobile">Bookmobile</a>s are nearly always operated by a single person.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oneshot"><b>one-shot</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> for which only a single <a href="#issue">issue</a> was <a href="#publishing">published</a>.  Also refers to a <a href="#reprint">reprint</a> of the entire <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or of an <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>, <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a single issue of a periodical, as distinct from a <a href="#serialized">serialized</a> reprint.
<p> 
In <a href="#perfectbinding">perfect binding</a>, the <a href="#hotmelt">hot melt</a> <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> used to <a href="#binding">bind</a> a book in a single application.  Also, a <a href="#slang">slang</a> <a href="#term">term</a> used by <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s to refer to formal instruction given in a <em>single</em> session, as opposed to instruction extended over two or more sessions. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onionskin"><b>onionskin</b></a>
</dt><dd>A very thin, tough, light-weight, translucent <a href="#paper">paper</a> with a smooth glazed or <a href="#cockle">cockle</a> <a href="#finish">finish</a>, used for airmail stationery, tracing paper, etc.  Also spelled <em>onion skin</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onlay"><b>onlay</b></a>
</dt><dd>One or more decorative <a href="#panel">panel</a>s or thin pieces of <a href="#leather">leather</a> or <a href="#paper">paper</a>, often of more than one color, mounted on the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> in relief, usually <a href="#tooling">tooled</a> around the edges to secure them to the surface and for decorative effect.  Compare with  <a href="#inlay">inlay</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="online"><b>online</b></a>        
</dt><dd>A computer connected to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, an <a href="#intranet">intranet</a>, or some other <a href="#network">network</a>, via <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> links, as opposed to a <a href="#standalone">stand-alone</a> system.  Also refers to computer accessories or <a href="#device">device</a>s physically separate from, but directly connected to and under the control of, a <a href="#centralproc">central processing unit</a> (CPU) and ready for <a href="#interactive">interactive</a> use in <a href="#realtime">real time</a>.  Sometimes used <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>ously in <a href="#library">libraries</a> with <em>automated</em>, <em>computerized</em>, and <em>electronic</em>.  Compare with <a href="#offline">offline</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#onlinebookstore">online bookstore</a>, <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>, <a href="#onlineservices">online services</a>, and <a href="#onlinetutorial">online tutorial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onlinemag"><b><em>ONLINE</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> providing <a href="#feature">feature</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s, product <a href="#review">review</a>s, <a href="#casestudy">case studies</a>, and informed opinion to assist <a href="#information">information</a> professionals in <a href="#selection">selecting</a>, using, and managing electronic information products, including <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#database">database</a>s, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>s, and <a href="#internet">Internet</a> resources, <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> by Information Today, Inc.  <a href="http://www.onlinemag.net/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>ONLINE</em></b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onlinebookstore"><b>online bookstore</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial enterprise that electronically markets and sells <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#media">media</a> (<a href="#videorecording">video</a>s, <a href="#compactdisc">CD</a>s, <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>s, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>s, etc.) mail order over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  Some online <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s have retail outlets (<em>example</em>: <a href="http://www.barnesandnoble.com/">barnesandnoble.com</a>), others do not (<a href="http://www.amazon.com/">amazon.com</a>).  <a href="http://www.lights.com/publisher/bookstores.html">Click here</a> to connect to a list of <a href="#link">link</a>s to online <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s, maintained by Peter Scott of the University of Saskatchewan Library.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onlinecatalog"><b>online catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> consisting of a collection of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s in <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, maintained on a <a href="#dedicated">dedicated</a> computer that provides uninterrupted <a href="#interactive">interactive</a> <a href="#access">access</a> via <a href="#terminal">terminal</a>s or <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>s in direct, continuous communication with the central computer.  Most <a href="#online">online</a> catalogs are <a href="#searchable">searchable</a> by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>, and <a href="#keywords">keywords</a>.  The <a href="#software">software</a> used in online catalogs is <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> and not <a href="#standardization">standardized</a>.  Synonymous with <a href="#opac">OPAC</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oclc"><b>Online Computer Library Center (OCLC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The largest <a href="#bibutility">bibliographic utility</a> in the world, providing <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> and <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> services, <a href="#serial">serial</a>s and <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> control, <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> support, and <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#database">database</a>s.  <b>OCLC</b>
began as the Ohio College Library Center in 1967, changed its name in
1981 to reflect wider membership, and has since become a major source
of <a href="#cooperativecat">cooperative cataloging</a> <a href="#data">data</a> for <a href="#library">libraries</a> around the world, <b>OCLC</b> maintains <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em>, the  largest <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> in the world, containing over 46 million <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s.  <a href="http://www.oclc.org/home/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>OCLC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onlineref"><b>online reference</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicref">electronic reference</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onlineservices"><b>online services</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the branch of <a href="#publicservices">public services</a> concerned with <a href="#selection">selecting</a> and providing <a href="#access">access</a> to electronic resources, such as <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, including <a href="#mediated">mediated searching</a>, usually done by an <em>online services librarian</em>.  Compare with <a href="#systemslibrarian">systems librarian</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onlinetutorial"><b>online tutorial</b></a>
</dt><dd>An instructional tool in electronic <a href="#format">format</a>, usually available via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, designed to teach <a href="#library">library</a> users, in a step-by-step and sometimes <a href="#interactive">interactive</a> process, how to use a specific resource (usually an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>), or all the services and resources needed to <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#topic">topic</a>s in a specific <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or <a href="#subject">subject</a> area.  Particularly helpful to students enrolled in <a href="#distancelearning">distance education</a> courses who may be unable to come to the library for <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>, <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#tutorial">tutorial</a>s are often <a href="#module">modular</a> in design, with a self-quiz at the end of each unit to give users the opportunity to assess their mastery of the <a href="#content">content</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://tilt.lib.utsystem.edu/">TILT</a></em>, provided by the University of Texas System Digital Library).  Compare with <a href="#pathfinder">pathfinder</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onlineunioncat"><b><em>Online Union catalog (OLUC)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#oluc">OCLC Online Union Catalog</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onloan"><b>on loan</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onorder"><b>on order</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> to describe an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> ordered from a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, or <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>, but not yet received by the <a href="#library">library</a>.  After the item has been received and completely <a href="#technical">processed</a>, the <a href="#orderrecord">order record</a> created by the library at the time the order was placed is eventually purged.  In some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s, the status of an item on order is indicated in a temporary <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#backorder">back order</a> and <a href="#canceled">canceled</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onreserve"><b>on reserve</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#reserves">reserves</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onsale"><b>on sale or return</b></a>
</dt><dd>Terms given by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to a <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> allowing the <a href="#returns">return</a> for <a href="#credit">credit</a> of <a href="#copy">copies</a> that remain unsold.  The bookseller's account is normally charged for the sale, but payment is not expected until the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s have sold or a designated time limit has expired.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#overstock">overstock</a> and <a href="#remainders">remainders</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="onthejob"><b>on-the-job</b></a>
</dt><dd>Occurring in the course of one's employment, for example, <em>on-the-job training</em> as opposed to instruction that takes place outside the normal work routine.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oozeleather"><b>ooze leather</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#calf">Calf</a> or split sheepskin given a soft velvet or suede finish on the flesh side, used mainly in <a href="#binding">binding</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a>s of <a href="#poetry">poetry</a>, <a href="#belleslettres">belles lettres</a>, etc.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="op1"><b>OP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#outofprint"><b>o</b>ut of <b>p</b>rint</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opac"><b>OPAC</b></a>          
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <b>O</b>nline <b>P</b>ublic <b>A</b>ccess <b>C</b>atalog, a computer <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> of the <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> owned by a <a href="#library">library</a>.  In most libraries, the largest concentration of <b>OPAC</b> <a href="#terminal">terminal</a>s or <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>s is located near the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a> to make it easier for <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a>s to provide assistance.  Synonymous with <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>.  Compare with <a href="#webpac">WebPac</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opacity"><b>opacity</b></a>
</dt><dd>The quality of nontransparency in <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a>s, determined by amount of air space between the fibers, apparent from the extent to which light passes through a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>.  If too thin a paper is used in printing, <a href="#text">text</a> and/or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s may <a href="#showthrough">show through</a> on the opposite side of the sheet or <a href="#page">page</a>.  As a general rule, bright white papers are less <em>opaque</em> than off-white or creamy papers, and <a href="#matte">matte</a> <a href="#finish">finish</a> has greater opacity than glazed finish.  
<p>
Also refers to the degree to which <a href="#ink">ink</a> obscures the color of the surface on which it is printed. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opcit"><b>op. cit.</b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for <em>opere citato</em> meaning "in the work previously cited."  An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> used in <a href="#note">note</a>s and <a href="#bibliography">bibliographic</a> <a href="#citation">citation</a>s that allows a <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> or idea from the <a href="#work">work</a> previously <a href="#cite">cite</a>d to be referenced simply by giving the new <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>(s).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="openability"><b>openability</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binder">binder</a>'s <a href="#term">term</a> for the ease with which the <a href="#binding">binding</a> on a <a href="#book">book</a> can be opened at any <a href="#page">page</a>.  In <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> bindings, a <a href="#volume">volume</a> with a <a href="#hollowback">hollow back</a> can be opened more easily than one with a <a href="#tightback">tight back</a>.  In <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive binding</a>s, an <a href="#otabind">Otabind</a> binding opens flat more easily than a <a href="#perfectbinding">perfect binding</a>.  In perfect bindings, an unnotched binding is easier to open than a <a href="#notchedbinding">notched binding</a>.  Most <a href="#mechanical">mechanical binding</a>s are designed to open flat.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oai"><b>Open Archives Initiative (OAI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Supported by the <a href="#dlf">Digital Library Federation</a>, the <a href="#cni">Coalition for Networked Information</a>, and a <a href="#grant">grant</a> from the National Science Foundation (NSF), <b>OAI</b> develops and promotes interoperability <a href="#standards">standards</a> to facilitate the exchange of <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#content">content</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>s.  The program had its origins in the desire to facilitate <a href="#scholarlycommunication">scholarly communication</a> by improving <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#digitalarchives">digital archives</a>.  <a href="http://www.openarchives.org/">Click here</a> to learn more about <b>OAI</b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#sparc">SPARC</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="openback"><b>open back</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#hollowback">hollow back</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opencatalog"><b>open catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> in which there are no restrictions on the addition of new <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s, and existing records are revised and corrected as the need arises.  Compare with <a href="#closedcatalog">closed catalog</a> and <a href="#frozencatalog">frozen catalog</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opened"><b>opened</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a <a href="#book">book</a> left <a href="#uncut">uncut</a> in <a href="#binding">binding</a>, whose <a href="#page">page</a>s have to be slit by hand with a <a href="#paper">paper</a>-knife, usually by the person who purchases the <a href="#volume">volume</a> or receives it as a gift.  Compare with <a href="#unopened">unopened</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="openendindex"><b>open-end index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An ongoing <a href="#index">index</a> covering a single <a href="#publication">publication</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>New York Times Index</em></b>), <a href="#work">work</a>s of a particular form (<b><em>Biography Index</em></b>), or the <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#literature">literature</a> of a specific <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> (<b><em>Art Index</em></b>) or group of related disciplines (<em><a href="#medline">MEDLINE</a></em>), <a href="#update">update</a>d continuously or at fixed intervals.  Compare with <a href="#closedendindex">closed-end index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="openentry"><b>open entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, <a href="#holdingsnote">holdings note</a>, or <a href="#entry">entry</a> in an <a href="#index">index</a> or <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> that allows further <a href="#information">information</a> concerning the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> to be added, used in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> to describe <a href="#serial">serial</a>s for which the <a href="#library">library</a> does not own all the <a href="#issue">issue</a>s or <a href="#part">part</a>s. Open entries are indicated by a <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a> and a space following the first <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a> and/or year owned (<em>example</em>: <b>v.1-  , 1936- </b>).  Compare with <a href="#closedentry">closed entry</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opening"><b>opening</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any two facing <a href="#page">page</a>s in an open <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  The right-hand page is called the <a href="#recto">recto</a>; the left-hand page the <a href="#verso">verso</a>.  Compare with <a href="#conjointleaves">conjoint leaves</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doublespread">double spread</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dd>Also refers to the procedures followed by <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> at the beginning of each working day to ready a <a href="#library">library</a> facility for use by its <a href="#patron">patron</a>s, such as turning on lights and <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, checking the <a href="#paper">paper</a> supply in <a href="#printer">printer</a>s and <a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a>s, checking the <a href="#bookdrop">book drop</a> for <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> returned after the previous day's <a href="#closing">closing</a>, deactivating the <a href="#securitysystem">security system</a>, unlocking the entrance door(s), etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="openorder"><b>open order</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, an order for <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> that remains active because it could not be completely filled by the seller at the time it was received.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#backorder">back order</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="openreserve"><b>open reserve</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> shelved in an <a href="#openstacks">open stack</a> to afford <a href="#library">library</a> users un<a href="#restricted">restricted access</a>.  Compare with <a href="#closedreserve">closed reserve</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opensource"><b>open source</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a> for which the source code is made available without charge by the owner or licenser, usually via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, to encourage the rapid development of a more useful and <a href="#bug">bug</a>-free product through open <a href="#peerreview">peer review</a>.  The practice also allows the product to be customized by its users to suit local needs (<em>example</em>:  Linux <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>).  To be certified "open source" under the Open Source Initiative (OSI), <a href="#software">software</a> must meet certain established criteria which include no <a href="#restricted">restriction</a>s on <a href="#access">access</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="openstacks"><b>open stacks</b></a>
</dt><dd>Shelving in a <a href="#library">library</a> to which users have un<a href="#restricted">restricted access</a>.  Synonymous with <em>open access</em>.  The opposite of <a href="#closedstacks">closed stacks</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="osi"><b>Open System Interconnection (OSI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#iso">ISO</a> <a href="#standards">standard</a> for <a href="#network">network</a> <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a>
developed during the 1980's to allow direct communication between
computers of all types and sizes by defining a general framework for
implementing communication <a href="#protocol">protocol</a>s in seven layers.  Although most network systems follow the <b>OSI</b> model, some have compressed two or three of the <b>OSI</b> layers into one.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#z3950">Z39.50</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="operatingbudget"><b>operating budget</b></a>
</dt><dd>Funds <a href="#allocation">allocated</a>, usually on an <a href="#annual">annual</a> or <a href="#biennial">biennial</a> basis, to cover the ongoing expenses incurred in running a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, including the payment of <a href="#wages">wages</a> and <a href="#salary">salaries</a>, and the purchase of <a href="#materialsbudget">materials</a>, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a>, and services.  Compare with <a href="#capitalexp">capital expenditure</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="operatingsys"><b>operating system (OS)</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#software">Software</a> designed to control the basic operation of a computer and the exchange of <a href="#data">data</a> between the <a href="#cpu">central processing unit</a> and any <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> equipment, mainly <a href="#input">input</a> and <a href="#output">output</a> <a href="#device">device</a>s.  Loaded whenever the computer is started, the <b>OS</b> controls the running of all other <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s, including any <a href="#security">security</a> systems designed to prevent un<a href="#authorization">authorized</a> use.  Commonly used <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a> operating systems include <a href="#dos">DOS</a>, <a href="#windows">Windows</a>, <a href="#macintosh">Macintosh</a>, and <a href="#unix">UNIX</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="operational"><b>operational</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of equipment and/or systems that are running in good working order.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="operations"><b>operations</b></a>
</dt><dd>A management <a href="#term">term</a> encompassing all the activities and details involved in running a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>
on a day-to-day basis, as opposed to functions requiring a long-range
view of the institution's direction and priorities, such as <a href="#strategicplanning">planning</a> and <a href="#budget">budget</a>ing, policy-making, <a href="#fundraising">fund-raising</a>, and <a href="#publicrelations">public relations</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opl"><b>OPL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#oneperson"> <b>o</b>ne-<b>p</b>erson <b>l</b>ibrary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opp1"><b>OPP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#opp"><b>o</b>ut of <b>p</b>rint at <b>p</b>resent</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opticalcenter"><b>optical center</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the point slightly above the mathematical center of a <a href="#page">page</a> which the human eye perceives as the center.  In page <a href="#layout">layout</a>, the <a href="#typography">typographer</a> fools the eye by designing around the optical center, rather than the mathematical center.  The same rule applies in <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> design for computer screens.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opticalcharacter"><b>optical character recognition (OCR)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A process by which <a href="#character">character</a>s typed or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a <a href="#page">page</a> are electronically <a href="#scanner">scanned</a>, analyzed, and if found recognizable on the basis of appearance, <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> into a <a href="#digital">digital</a> character code capable of being <a href="#dataprocessing">processed</a> by a computer.  <b>OCR</b> eliminates the time-consuming process of re-keying <a href="#information">information</a> available in <a href="#print">print</a>, but results can be unpredictable if the scanned <a href="#copy">copy</a> is imperfect or contains <a href="#diacriticalmark">diacritical mark</a>s or unrecognizable characters.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opticaldisk"><b>optical disk</b></a>
</dt><dd>A high-density <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> consisting of a specially coated <a href="#disk">disk</a> on which <a href="#data">data</a> can be <a href="#encoding">encoded</a> in a pattern of tiny pits burned into the surface with a laser, read by a <a href="#device">device</a> that reflects a laser beam off the pitted surface, and decoded by a <a href="#microprocessor">microprocessor</a> into <a href="#digital">digital</a> or <a href="#analog">analog</a> signals.  Includes <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>s, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>s, and <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>laser disk</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opticalfiber"><b>optical fiber</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thin, flexible cable containing a bundle of very fine,
highly transparent, tubular glass fibers made of pure silicon dioxide,
designed to transmit <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#encoding">encoded</a> in pulses of laser light at very high speed (billions of <a href="#bit">bit</a>s per second) by means of internal reflection.  Telephone companies are rapidly upgrading their transmission <a href="#infrastructure">infrastructure</a> from copper wire to fiber-optic cable.
