The advantages of optical fiber over <a href="#coaxial">coaxial</a> and <a href="#twistedpair">twisted-pair</a> cable are high <a href="#bandwidth">bandwith</a>s, less attenuation of signal, and lighter weight, making it possible to transmit <a href="#data">data</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a> at very high-speed from one computer to another over a <a href="#network">network</a> such as the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opticalscanner"><b>optical scanner</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#scanner">scanner</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opticalspacing"><b>optical spacing</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a>, the technique of adjusting the distance between the individual <a href="#letter">letter</a>s in a line of <a href="#capitalletter">capital</a>s to create the optical illusion of even <a href="#spacing">spacing</a>, which requires placing some letter combinations closer together than others.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="option"><b>option</b></a>
</dt><dd>The privilege of purchasing the <a href="#rights">rights</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> from the <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> holder for a specific purpose (<em>example</em>:  the right to <a href="#adaptation">adapt</a> a <a href="#novel">novel</a> or <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>
for performance on stage or screen), usually granted for a fixed period
of time designated in a legally binding agreement, in exchange for some
form of compensation. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#subsidiaryrights">subsidiary rights</a>.
<p>
In computing, a choice available to the user in the form of a <a href="#menu">menu</a> item, button, or <a href="#icon">icon</a> appearing in the <a href="#toolbar">toolbar</a> or <a href="#window">window</a> of a <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a>, or as a <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#link">link</a> embedded in a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="optional"><b>optional (O)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#field">field</a> or <a href="#subfield">subfield</a> of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> in which <a href="#data">data</a> may be entered at the discretion of the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>, but is not required to meet <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <a href="#inputstandards">input standards</a> for a given <a href="#cataloginglevel">cataloging level</a>.  Compare with <a href="#mandatory">mandatory</a> and <a href="#requiredif">required if applicable or readily available</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opus"><b>opus</b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for "a work."  In the most general sense, any creative <a href="#work">work</a> or <a href="#composition">composition</a>.  In music, the term is usually followed by an <a href="#opusnumber">opus number</a> assigned by the <a href="#composer">composer</a> or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to one of several works, or a collection of works related in form or <a href="#medium">medium</a>, to indicate its place in the sequence in which they were composed or <a href="#issue">issue</a>d.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>op.</em>  Plural: <em>opera</em> or <em>opuses</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#magnumopus">magnum opus</a> and <a href="#opuscule">opuscule</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opuscule"><b>opuscule</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#treatise">treatise</a> of small size.  Also refers to a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> or <a href="#literarywork">literary</a> <a href="#composition">composition</a> of little significance.  Compare in this sense with <a href="#magnumopus">magnum opus</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#opus">opus</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opusnumber"><b>opus number</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#number">number</a> assigned by the <a href="#composer">composer</a> or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to one of several <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a>s, or a set of <a href="#work">work</a>s related in form or <a href="#medium">medium</a>, to indicate its place in the sequence in which they were composed or <a href="#issue">issue</a>d, usually included in the <a href="#title">title</a> following the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> <em>op.</em> (<em>example</em>:  Beethoven's <b><em>Concerto for Violin, op. 61, D major</em></b>).  Special numbering exists for certain composers whose works were unnumbered when first <a href="#publishing">published</a>, for example, the universally accepted <em>Kochel numbers</em> devised by the 19th century Austrian botanist Ludwig von Kochel in his <a href="#chronological">chronological</a> thematic <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> of the works of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="or"><b>OR</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#logicalsum">logical sum</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oralhistory"><b>oral history</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a> or <a href="#transcribe">transcription</a> of an interview with a person whose memories and perceptions of historical events are considered worth preserving as an aural <a href="#record">record</a> for future <a href="#research">research</a>.  Also refers to an historical <a href="#work">work</a> based on <a href="#data">data</a> collected orally, often <a href="#preservation">preserved</a> in <a href="#archives">archives</a> and <a href="#specialcollections">special collection</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Hard Times: An Oral History of the Great Depression</em></b> by Studs Terkel).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="orchestralscore"><b>orchestral score</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#fullscore">full score</a> of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> <a href="#composer">composed</a> for orchestra, giving the parts for all the instruments.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oc"><b>order canceled (OC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used on an <a href="#invoice">invoice</a> to indicate that the order for a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> has been canceled by the seller, usually because <a href="#copy">copies</a> are no longer available.  Compare with <a href="#backorder">back order</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="orderprecedence"><b>order of precedence</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#precedence">precedence order</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="orderrecord"><b>order record</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, a record created and attached to the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> at the time it is ordered, containing <a href="#information">information</a> needed to process the order (name of <a href="#selection">selector</a>, <a href="#budget">budget</a>ary fund, <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>, order date, estimated <a href="#price">price</a>, <a href="#purchaseorder">purchase order</a> number, date <a href="#receiving">received</a>, special handling notes, date <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a>, and pertinent characteristics of the item).  After the item is received and <a href="#technical">processed</a>, the order record is eventually purged.  Compare with <a href="#itemrecord">item record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="orgculture"><b>organizational culture</b></a>
</dt><dd>The prevailing values, expectations, and conventions within an
organization or institution, often unspoken and persistent. Advancement
may depend on sensitivity to such norms. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="original"><b>original</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#literature">literature</a>, a <a href="#work">work</a> as written by the <a href="#author">author</a> or in the author's own words.  In art, a finished work as completed by the artist and ready for <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>.  In science, a study that produces results never before reported, in some cases through the use of a new methodology or <a href="#research">research</a> design.  In <a href="#reprography">reprography</a>, the <a href="#sourcedocument">source document</a> from which the first <a href="#copy">copy</a>
is made or in some cases the first copy itself. In a more general
sense, something new and fresh, not copied or based on a pre-existing
model. <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>orig</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="originalbinding"><b>original binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> to indicate that a <a href="#book">book</a> retains the <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which it was first <a href="#issue">issue</a>d, which may show definite signs of wear if the <a href="#volume">volume</a> is an old one.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="originalcataloging"><b>original cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd>Preparation of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> <em>without</em> the aid of a pre-existing <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> for the same <a href="#edition">edition</a>, more time-consuming for the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> than <a href="#copycataloging">copy cataloging</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="originalorder"><b>original order</b></a>
</dt><dd>The principle in <a href="#archives">archives</a> that <a href="#records">records</a> should remain in the sequence in which they were maintained when in <a href="#activerecords">active</a>
use, unless the method of accumulation is determined upon inspection to
have been so unsystematic as to render retrieval difficult, if not
impossible. Existing relationships are preserved when <a href="#document">document</a>s remain as originally <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a>, making it easier to prepare <a href="#findingaid">finding aid</a>s.  Original order also has <a href="#archivalvalue">evidential value</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="originalparts"><b>original parts</b></a>
</dt><dd>A descriptive term used in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> to indicate that a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> first <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#installment">installment</a>s has survived in its original form without having been <a href="#rebinding">rebound</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="orihon"><b>orihon</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#document">document</a> in the form of a continuous length of <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a>, <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>, or <a href="#paper">paper</a>, folded backwards and forwards accordion-style between the <a href="#column">column</a>s of <a href="#text">text</a> to divide the <a href="#work">work</a> into <a href="#page">page</a>s which are usually fastened with a cord threaded through holes pierced in the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a>, with or without laced-on <a href="#cover">cover</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#zigzag">zig-zag book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ornament"><b>ornament</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#printersornament">printer's ornament</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="orphan"><b>orphan</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, an incomplete line of <a href="#type">type</a>, such as a <a href="#heading">heading</a> or the first line of a paragraph, when it appears at the <a href="#foot">foot</a> of a <a href="#page">page</a> or <a href="#column">column</a> of <a href="#text">text</a>.  Skilled <a href="#typography">typographer</a>s consider such lines awkward and avoid <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> them if possible, just as they avoid setting <a href="#widow">widow</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#clubline">club line</a>.  
<p>
In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, a <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> or <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> that has no <a href="#semanticrelation">relation</a>, <a href="#hierarchicrelation">hierarchic</a> or <a href="#associative">associative</a>, to any other <a href="#term">term</a> in the <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>Chank</b>, the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject heading</a> for a type of seashell used in Indian folklore and religion).  Orphans are rare in indexing.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#sibling">sibling</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="orthography"><b>orthography</b></a>
</dt><dd>Correct spelling of a written <a href="#language">language</a>, usually given in a standard <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>.  British spelling differs slightly from American spelling of certain words (<em>colour</em>/<em>color</em>, <em>grey</em>/<em>gray</em>, <em>theatre</em>/<em>theater</em>, etc.). Also refers to any style or method of spelling, and to the study of spelling and its conventions.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="os1"><b>OS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#outofstock"><b>o</b>ut of <b>s</b>tock</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="osi1"><b>OSI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#osi"><b>O</b>pen <b>S</b>ystem <b>I</b>nterconnection</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="otabind"><b>Otabind</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#tradename">trade name</a> for a relatively new type of <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive binding</a> that opens flat without any resistance and has the internal characteristics of a <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> through the <a href="#backfold">fold</a> <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Two different cold <a href="#emulsion">emulsion</a> <a href="#polyvinylacetate">polyvinyl acetate</a> (PVA) <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a>s are applied separately to the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a>, providing maximum strength and flexibility when allowed to dry naturally.  The <a href="#cover">cover</a> is attached with <a href="#hotmelt">hot-melt</a> adhesive, not to the <a href="#spine">spine</a> but to the sides of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a>, leaving a <a href="#hollowback">hollow back</a>.  
<p>
The hot-melt adhesives used in <a href="#perfectbinding">perfect binding</a> have a clamping effect which hampers <a href="#openability">openability</a>.  They also have low <a href="#coldcrack">cold-crack</a>
resistance which makes them unsuitable for use in countries that
experience extreme winter temperatures. The impetus for the development
of an enhanced softcover binding came from the Finnish <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> Otava.  Otabind International was founded in 1986 by the Dutch <a href="#binder">binder</a>
Gerard Hexspoor in cooperation with Muller Martini, a Swiss
manufacturer of binding equipment. The method was introduced in the
United States and Canada in 1988 and is especially suitable for <a href="#volume">volume</a>s that must open flat (instruction <a href="#manual">manual</a>s, music books, <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s, <a href="#travelguide">travel guide</a>s, <a href="#cookbook">cookbook</a>s, etc.).  Its <a href="#durability">durability</a> is several times that of conventional perfect binding.    
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="out"><b>out</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#copy">copy</a> accidentally omitted in <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a>.  When a <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> or retail purchaser discovers a defect of this kind, the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> will normally send a replacement copy at no charge.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#imperfections">imperfections</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="outdated"><b>outdated</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#information">Information</a> that is no longer <a href="#currency">current</a>.  <a href="#publication">Publication</a>s containing such information may be misleading, as in the case of a <a href="#superseded">superseded</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#manual">manual</a> of medical diagnosis or prescription drugs.  <a href="#book">Book</a>s are usually <a href="#update">update</a>d in <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>s and <a href="#revisededition"> revised edition</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="outlay"><b>outlay</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sum of money spent, especially in the initial phase of a
project, on the expectation that the investment will eventually produce
a tangible or intangible return, or some other desired result. <a href="#publicrelations">Public relations</a> expenditures usually fall into this category. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="outline"><b>outline</b></a>
</dt><dd>A popular <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> of an extensive <a href="#subject">subject</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Outline of History</em></b> by H. G. Wells).  Also refers to a <a href="#summary">summary</a> of the main aspects of a <a href="#topic">topic</a>, or a systematic list of the most important points of a speech or written <a href="#work">work</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a line or thin edge drawn around a <a href="#picture">picture</a> or image, as a form of decoration or to establish its visual limits.  Compare with <a href="#neatline">neatline</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#outlineletter">outline letter</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="outlineletter"><b>outline letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#letter">letter</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> from a unit of <a href="#type">type</a>
from which the inside of each stroke has been removed, leaving a black
line around the edges enclosing white space in the interior. Synonymous
with <em>open letter</em>.  Compare with <a href="#inline">inline</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#shadedletter">shaded letter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="outofcirculation"><b>out of circulation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Not <a href="#available">available</a> to be <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> or used for <a href="#refbook">reference</a>, for example, <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in the process of being <a href="#mending">mended</a>, <a href="#repairing">repaired</a>, <a href="#rebinding">rebound</a>, <a href="#recataloging">recataloged</a>, etc.  The opposite of <em>in circulation</em>.  Compare with <a href="#noncirculating">noncirculating</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="outofprint"><b>out of print (OP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> no longer obtainable through regular market channels because the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#inventory">inventory</a> is exhausted and there is no prospect of another <a href="#printing">printing</a> in the foreseeable future.  OP <a href="#book">book</a>s can sometimes be found in <a href="#usedbookstore">used bookstore</a>s.  <a href="#searchservice">Search service</a>s, <a href="#antiquarian">antiquarian bookseller</a>s, and <a href="#bookscout">book scout</a>s <a href="#specialization">specialize</a> in tracking down out of print <a href="#edition">edition</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.alibris.com/">Alibris</a>).  An out of print book may eventually be reissued (the <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a> <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em> includes a special "Classic Returns" section devoted to recent <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>s).  Books that have gone out of print since 1979 are <a href="#index">index</a>ed in <b><em>Books Out-of-Print</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, which includes <a href="#information">information</a> on <a href="#remainders">remainder</a> <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>s and <a href="#ondemand">on-demand</a> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s.  Also <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> <em>o.p.</em>  Compare with <a href="#top">temporarily out of print</a> and <a href="#opp">out of print at present</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#outofstock">out of stock</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="opp"><b>out of print at present (OPP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used on a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#invoice">invoice</a> to indicate that a <a href="#publication">publication</a> cannot be supplied because current <a href="#inventory">inventory</a> is exhausted, but additional <a href="#copy">copies</a> may be <a href="#printing">printed</a> at some unspecified time in the future.  Compare with <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a> and <a href="#top">temporarily out of print</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="outofseries"><b>out of series</b></a>
</dt><dd>The unnumbered <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> in excess of a <a href="#limitededition">limited edition</a>, usually <a href="#binding">bound</a> as <a href="#overs">overs</a> for use in promotion and for distribution as <a href="#reviewcopy">review copies</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="outofstock"><b>out of stock (OS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used on a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#invoice">invoice</a> to indicate that a <a href="#publication">publication</a> cannot be supplied at the time the order is received because it is not in <a href="#inventory">inventory</a>.  Also <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> <em>o.s.</em>  The opposite of <a href="#instock">in stock</a>.  Compare with <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#tos">temporarily out of stock</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="output"><b>output</b></a>
</dt><dd>The end result of <a href="#centralproc">processing</a> by computer, as opposed to <a href="#data">data</a> entered into or transferred to a computer system for processing (<a href="#input">input</a>).  Output may be sent to a peripheral <a href="#device">device</a> for <a href="#storage">storage</a> or display.  Also refers to the signal that emanates from a <a href="#videorecording">video</a> or <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a> player, as opposed to the signal fed into it.
<p>
Also, the total amount of work produced by a person, team,
organization, machine, etc., usually during a fixed period of time
(hour, day, week, or month), for example, the number of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> by a <a href="#technicalservices">technical services</a> department in a given amount of time.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="outreach"><b>outreach</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#library">Library</a> programs and services designed to meet the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of users who are unserved or <a href="#underserved">underserved</a>, for example, those who are <a href="#visuallyimpaired">visually impaired</a>, institutionalized, not fluent in the national <a href="#language">language</a>, <a href="#literacy">illiterate</a>, or marginalized in some other way.  Large <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> often have an <em>outreach librarian</em> responsible for providing such services.  Compare with <a href="#libraryextension">library extension</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="outsourcing"><b>outsourcing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The contracting of <a href="#library">library</a> services formerly performed in-house to an outside service provider, usually a for-profit enterprise.  Part of a recent <a href="#trend">trend</a> in the United States in the direction of <a href="#privatization">privatizing</a> government services, outsourcing has affected <a href="#technicalservices">technical services</a> to a greater extent than <a href="#publicservices">public services</a>
in libraries. Cost-effectiveness is the justification most often heard
for this controversial management practice. One disadvantage is that in
decisions requiring judgment, an outside contractor may lack
familiarity with local conditions and practices. <p>
Outsourcing has generated the <em>least</em> amount of controversy in <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> and <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> (particularly <a href="#binding">binding</a> and <a href="#reformat">reformat</a>ting), purchasing <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>s in <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> form, <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> plans (<a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a>s, <a href="#blanketorder">blanket order</a> plans, <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agent</a>s, etc.), <a href="#physicalprocessing">physical processing</a>, <a href="#retrocon">retrospective conversion</a>, and library automation systems.  However, proposals to outsource <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> and <a href="#selection">selection</a>, and to privatize <a href="#federallibrary">federal</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> have met greater resistance.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overdue"><b>overdue</b></a>
</dt><dd>Refers to a <a href="#circulating">circulating</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> by a <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> and kept past its <a href="#duedate">due date</a>.  Most <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s are designed to automatically generate an <a href="#overduenotice">overdue notice</a> requesting prompt return of the item.  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> charge <a href="#fines">fines</a> for overdue <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>.  A <a href="#borroweraccount">borrower account</a> may be <a href="#blocked">blocked</a> if fines accumulate beyond a maximum amount determined by the library.  Accounts long overdue may be sent to a <a href="#collecagency">collection agency</a>.  Overdue charges can be avoided by <a href="#renew">renew</a>ing an item on or before its due date.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#grace">grace period</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overduenotice"><b>overdue notice</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> or handwritten notice sent to a <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>'s street address requesting the prompt return of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s kept past their <a href="#duedate">due date</a>.  The first notice may be followed by a second notice, then a final notice, depending on the policy of the individual <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fines">fines</a> and <a href="#renew">renew</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overhang"><b>overhang</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the portion of covering material that extends beyond the edges of the <a href="#board">board</a>s, before it is <a href="#turnin">turned in</a> and the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s <a href="#pastingdown">pasted down</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overheadprojector"><b>overhead projector</b></a>
</dt><dd>A table-top platform device used in presentations and <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a> to project clear <a href="#transparency">transparencies</a> onto a wall screen or other light-colored surface.  <a href="#documentcamera">Document camera</a>s are <a href="#superseded">superseding</a> overhead projectors in well-equipped <a href="#library">library</a> instruction classrooms and <a href="#instructionlab">lab</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overheadtransparency"><b>overhead transparency</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#transparency">transparency</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overlay"><b>overlay</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of transparent material bearing <a href="#text">text</a>
and/or images, aligned in such a way that the appearance of any matter
on which it is superimposed is altered, for example, the transparent
sheets used to <a href="#illustration">illustrate</a> the various components of human anatomy (skeleton, internal organs, circulatory system, etc.) in some medical <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s and <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#transparency">transparency</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overprint"><b>overprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>To print over <a href="#matter">matter</a> that has already been printed, sometimes in a space or <a href="#box">box</a> left <a href="#blank">blank</a> for the purpose.  Also refers to the <a href="#printing">printing</a> of more <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> than are ordered or needed by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  Unsold copies may be <a href="#remainders">remainder</a>ed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overrun"><b>overrun</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#sheet">Sheet</a>s or <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> printed in excess of the quantity ordered by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to allow for normal <a href="#spoilage">spoilage</a> in <a href="#printing">printing</a> and <a href="#binding">binding</a>, and for distribution as <a href="#presentationcopy">presentation</a> and <a href="#reviewcopy">review copies</a>.  Synonymous with <em>overs</em>.  The opposite of <a href="#underrun">underrun</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#outofseries">out of series</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overs"><b>overs</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#overrun">overrrun</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oversewing"><b>oversewing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of extra-strength <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a>s are removed from the <a href="#section">section</a>s by <a href="#milling">milling</a> and the resulting <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> through the back <a href="#margin">margin</a> in thin groups, one to another in succession, with the needle held perpendicular to the <a href="#paper">paper</a> surface in hand sewing or positioned at an oblique angle in machine sewing.  Oversewing is also used in some <a href="#foldsewn">fold sewn</a> bindings to reinforce the first and last sections.  The <a href="#swell">swell</a> added by oversewing may limit a <a href="#volume">volume</a>'s <a href="#openability">openability</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oversize"><b>oversize</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> too <a href="#height">tall</a> or too <a href="#width">wide</a> to be shelved with <a href="#volume">volume</a>s of smaller size in normal <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> sequence, for example, large <a href="#artbook">art book</a>s and <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>es.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> often shelve oversize <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in a separate location, indicated by a special code or <a href="#locationsymbol">location symbol</a> displayed in the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> and on the <a href="#spinelabel">spine label</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overstaffed"><b>overstaffed</b></a>
</dt><dd>Having more than enough employees to accomplish the necessary work, a situation that is usually remedied by reassigning <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> to other duties and responsibilities, or in extreme cases by laying off personnel.  The opposite of <a href="#understaffed">understaffed</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overstock"><b>overstock</b></a>
</dt><dd>Excess quantities of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> held in stock, for which <a href="#demand">demand</a> has dropped to a low level or ceased, usually the result of over-estimating the sales potential of the <a href="#work">work</a> or a <a href="#returns">returns</a> policy that encourages <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s to over-order to secure a more favorable <a href="#discount">discount</a>.  To avoid paying tax on inventory, the publisher may dispose of overstock by <a href="#remainders">remaindering</a>.  Compare with <a href="#outofstock">out of stock</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#onsale">on sale or return</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dd>Also refers to <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> <a href="#holdings">held</a> in excess of what is needed to serve the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of a <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overthetransom"><b>over the transom</b></a>
</dt><dd>An unsolicited <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#bookproposal">book proposal</a> received by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> without prior notification, usually directly from the <a href="#author">author</a> without the assistance of a <a href="#literaryagent">literary agent</a>.  A very high proportion of such <a href="#work">work</a>s receive <a href="#rejectionslip">rejection slip</a>s, but occasionally a work of exceptional quality is submitted in this manner, launching a successful writing career.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="overtime"><b>overtime</b></a>
</dt><dd>Time worked in excess of the maximum <a href="#number">number</a>
of regular hours per day, week, or month specified under the terms of
employment, for which an employee is normally compensated at a higher
rate. <a href="#library">Libraries</a> pay their <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> overtime only under very exceptional circumstances.  Compare with <a href="#flextime">flextime</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ownershipmark"><b>ownership mark</b></a>
</dt><dd>A mark in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> indicating the name of the <a href="#library">library</a> that owns it, usually in the form of a <a href="#label">label</a>, <a href="#embossed">embossment</a>, <a href="#perforating">perforation</a>, or <a href="#rubberstamp">stamp</a> (usually in <a href="#permanentink">permanent ink</a>).
An ownership mark is normally placed where it can be easily located,
but usually not in a position of prominence or where it might cause
confusion or disfigure the item. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#exlibrary">ex-library copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="oed"><b><em>Oxford English Dictionary (OED)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>The most complete collection of words and their <a href="#definition">definition</a>s in the English <a href="#language">language</a> as spoken throughout the world, the <em><b>O</b>xford <b>E</b>nglish <a href="#dictionary"><b>D</b>ictionary</a></em> is also the leading authority on <a href="#etymology">word origins</a> and the evolution of the English <a href="#language">language</a> over the past 1,000 years.  <a href="#publishing">Published</a> in twenty <a href="#volume">volume</a>s by Oxford University Press, the <b><em>OED</em></b> is currently in its second <a href="#edition">edition</a>, with a third edition in preparation.  It is available in <a href="#print">print</a>, on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, and <a href="#online">online</a>, <a href="#update">update</a>d <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a>.  <a href="http://dictionary.oed.com/">Click here</a> to learn more about the <b><em>OED</em></b>.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>

| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>

| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="P">P</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="packagedbook"><b>packaged book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> produced wholly or in part by a <a href="#freelance">freelancer</a> or <a href="#agency">agency</a> in the business of assembling books for <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  The extent of the <em>packager</em>'s role is determined by the agreement with the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, which may include writing, <a href="#editor">editing</a>, designing, <a href="#illustration">illustrating</a>, <a href="#printing">printing</a>, and even <a href="#binding">binding</a> the final product.  Portions of the production process may be subcontracted out to specialists.  Compare with <a href="#managedbook">managed book</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="packet"><b>packet switching</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#network">Network</a> technology that breaks a message in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a> into tiny parcels of no more than 128 <a href="#character">character</a>s, each with the same destination <a href="#internetaddress">address</a>,
then routes them separately as transmission circuits become available.
When the packets reach their destination, they are checked to ensure
that no <a href="#data">data</a> was lost in transmission, then
reassembled in original sequence. Packet switching enables the
transmission capability of a computer network to be used with maximum
speed and efficiency, reducing costs and enhancing productivity.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="packingslip"><b>packing slip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> list sent with a <a href="#shipping">shipment</a> of goods to confirm that the items included have been checked against the customer's order, not to be confused with an <a href="#invoice">invoice</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paddedenvelope"><b>padded envelope</b></a>
</dt><dd>A flexible wrapper made of heavy-duty <a href="#kraftpaper">kraft</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> and lined with soft fiber or air bubbles to protect <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in <a href="#shipping">shipment</a>.  Used extensively in <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>, padded envelopes are available from <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s in various sizes and are reusable if opened carefully.  Synonymous with <em>padded mailer</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="page"><b>page</b></a>
</dt><dd>One side of a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> in a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, <a href="#number">number</a>ed or unnumbered.  The right-hand page in an <a href="#opening">opening</a> is the <a href="#recto">recto</a>, the left-hand page the <a href="#verso">verso</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>p.</em> and <em>pp.</em> (plural).  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#folio">folio</a> and <a href="#jumppage">jump page</a>.  Also, a shortened form of the term <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>.
<p>  
Also refers to a <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> member responsible for delivering <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> from <a href="#closedstacks">closed stacks</a> and assigned the routine task of general <a href="#stackmaintenance">stack maintenance</a> (<a href="#reshelving">reshelving</a>, <a href="#shelfreading">shelf reading</a>, etc.).  Also, to call a person by name over a <a href="#publicaddress">public address system</a> in a large facility, a practice avoided in <a href="#library">libraries</a> to minimize distraction.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pagebreak"><b>page break</b></a>
</dt><dd>The point in a <a href="#text">text</a> at which one <a href="#page">page</a> ends and the next page begins, indicated in most <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#software">software</a> by a horizontal broken line across the screen.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#widow">widow</a> and <a href="#orphan">orphan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pagehead"><b>page head</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#headline">headline</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pagenumber"><b>page number</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#number">number</a> assigned in sequence to a <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, etc., to facilitate reference.  Page numbers are written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> in the <a href="#head">head</a> or <a href="#tail">tail</a> <a href="#margin">margin</a>, usually centered or in the outer corner.  <a href="#frontmatter">Front matter</a> is usually <a href="#pagination">paginated</a> in <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#romannumeral">roman numeral</a>s, <a href="#text">text</a> and <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a> in consecutive <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#foliation">foliation</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#blindpage">blind page</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pagepreview"><b>page preview</b></a>
</dt><dd>A feature of most <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#software">software</a> that allows the <a href="#format">format</a> of a <a href="#page">page</a> of <a href="#text">text</a> to be viewed on the screen exactly as it will appear when <a href="#printing">printed</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#wysiwyg">WYSIWYG</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pageproof"><b>page proof</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, an <a href="#impression">impression</a> made from <a href="#type">type</a> that has been <a href="#makeup">made-up</a> into <a href="#page">page</a>s after the <a href="#galley">galley proof</a>s have been inspected and any errors corrected, ready for final checking before the <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#gonetopress">goes to press</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pagination"><b>pagination</b></a>
</dt><dd>The practice of marking the <a href="#page">page</a>s of a written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#document">document</a> with consecutive <a href="#number">number</a>s to indicate their sequence.  <a href="#frontmatter">Front matter</a> is usually numbered in <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#romannumeral">roman numeral</a>s, <a href="#text">text</a> and <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a> in <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s.  Rare in <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and documents printed prior to 1500 A.D., pagination did not become common practice until about 1550 when it replaced <a href="#foliation">foliation</a>.  The <a href="#recto">recto</a> traditionally bears an odd page number and the <a href="#verso">verso</a> an even number.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#blindpage">blind page</a>, <a href="#continuouspagination">continuous pagination</a>, <a href="#duplicatepaging">duplicate paging</a>, <a href="#journalpagination">journal pagination</a>, <a href="#magazinepagination">magazine pagination</a>, <a href="#repaginated">repaginated</a>, <a href="#separately">separately paginated</a>, and <a href="#unpaginated">unpaginated</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the portion of the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> (<a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#field">field</a> 300) of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> that indicates the number of pages and/or <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> in a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pagingsystem"><b>paging system</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#publicaddress">public address system</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paleography"><b>paleography</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek <em>palaios</em> ("ancient") and <em>graphien</em> ("writing").  The study of early forms of handwriting, for example, <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>s carved on ancient monuments and the  various <a href="#script">script</a>s used in classical and medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s.  Also refers to the study of the origins of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>s and <a href="#letterform">letterform</a>s used in writing the world's <a href="#language">language</a>s, including the Latin alphabet.  British spelling is <em>palaeography</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#rosetta">Rosetta Stone</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="palimpsest"><b>palimpsest</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> written on <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>
on which earlier writings, only partially or imperfectly erased, are
still faintly visible. It was common practice, prior to the invention
of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, to reuse parchment and vellum because good quality writing material was comparatively expensive and often in short supply.  A <em>double palimpsest</em> is one that has been erased twice.  The study of palimpsests has enabled <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s to recover portions of <a href="#text">text</a>s, and in some cases entire <a href="#work">work</a>s, otherwise <a href="#lost">lost</a> to history. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="palmtop"><b>palmtop</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#pda">personal digital assistant (PDA)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pamphlet"><b>pamphlet</b></a>
</dt><dd>A non<a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> consisting of at least five but no more than 48 <a href="#page">page</a>s, stapled or <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> but not <a href="#binding">bound</a>, usually enclosed in a <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  Pamphlets were first <a href="#publishing">published</a> in England to disseminate the <a href="#polemic">polemic</a>al writings of 16th century reformers, but are now used mainly for material too <a href="#ephemera">ephemeral</a> or too brief (500 to 10,000 words) to be <a href="#printing">printed</a> in <a href="#book">book</a> form.  Synonymous with <em>booklet</em>.  Compare with <a href="#brochure">brochure</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pamphletbinding">pamphlet binding</a> and <a href="#pamphletfile">pamphlet file</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pamphletbinding"><b>pamphlet binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#selfcover">self-cover</a> or <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#publishersbinding">publisher's binding</a> in which the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> or <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a> are wire-stitched or stapled, rather than <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> or <a href="#glue">glue</a>d.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pamphletfile"><b>pamphlet file</b></a>
</dt><dd>A cardboard, plastic, or metal box or frame designed for storing, in an upright position, items such as <a href="#pamphlet">brochures</a>s, <a href="#report">report</a>s, loose <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, and other materials (<a href="#unbound">unbound</a> or <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s), usually with a blank space on the front for a <a href="#label">label</a> listing the contents.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="panel"><b>panel</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, a square or rectangular compartment on the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, impressed below the surface or enclosed in a <a href="#border">border</a> or <a href="#frame">frame</a>, often stamped with the <a href="#title">title</a> or displaying a <a href="#picture">picture</a> or design.  Also, a similar space on the <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a book, usually between the <a href="#raisedbands">raised bands</a> of a <a href="#handbinding">hand-bound</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a "list of works by the same <a href="#author">author</a>" appearing in some books on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> immediately preceding the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, which may include titles <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a> or even <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by other <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s.  
</p><p>
Also, one of a series of drawings in a <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a> created as a sequence of related images.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="panelback"><b>panel back</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#handbinding">hand-bound</a> <a href="#book">book</a> on which the space between two or more of the <a href="#bands">bands</a> has been enclosed in decorative <a href="#tooling">tooling</a>, <a href="#blind">blind</a> or <a href="#goldleaf">gilt</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="panorama"><b>panorama</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> in which the angle of view is
oblique, rather than from a position directly above, creating a visible
horizon, used to depict towns, cities, and popular recreational areas
(mountain ranges, canyonlands, etc.). Important geographic features are
sometimes labeled across the top or bottom <a href="#margin">margin</a>.  Panoramas have characteristics of both maps and <a href="#picture">picture</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paper"><b>paper</b></a>
</dt><dd>A flat fibrous writing or <a href="#printing">printing</a> surface made by breaking down vegetable fiber, such as wood or <a href="#ragpaper">rag</a>, into <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>
to which a filler is added in water suspension. As the water is drained
away on a wire screen, the moist fibers bond with each other at points
of contact, forming a dense mat that stiffens as it dries. Paper is
graded by content and intended use, and by such properties as color,
brightness, <a href="#opacity">opacity</a>, <a href="#finish">finish</a>, strength, density, <a href="#weight">weight</a>, and chemical stability.  It can be <a href="#coated">coated</a> or uncoated, <a href="#sized">sized</a> or unsized, handmade or machine-made.  The <a href="#acidpaper">acid</a> content of the paper used in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> is an issue in <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>.  Compare with <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, <a href="#biblepaper">bible paper</a>, <a href="#bookpaper">book paper</a>, <a href="#bufferedpaper">buffered paper</a>, <a href="#coverpaper">cover paper</a>, <a href="#esparto">esparto</a>, <a href="#foolscap">foolscap</a>, <a href="#kraftpaper">kraft paper</a>, <a href="#laidpaper">laid paper</a>, <a href="#manila">manila</a>, <a href="#newsprint">newsprint</a>, <a href="#onionskin">onionskin</a>, <a href="#permanentpaper">permanent paper</a>, and <a href="#wovepaper">wove paper</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a brief <a href="#composition">composition</a>, especially one prepared for presentation by the <a href="#author">author</a> at a <a href="#conference">conference</a> or other professional meeting.  Conference papers may be <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a> or <a href="#transactions">transactions</a>.  They are <a href="#index">index</a>ed in <b><em>PapersFirst</em></b>, an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> available in <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#firstsearch">FirstSearch</a></em>.  Compare with <a href="#article">article</a>.    
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paperback"><b>paperback</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#coverpaper">paper cover</a>s, rather than in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>, usually <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive bound</a>.  The modern paperback first appeared in the 1930s when Sir Allen Lane, founder of Penguin books, published <b><em>Ariel</em></b> by Andre Maurois in <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s.  Paperback <a href="#edition">edition</a>s are normally published <em>after</em> the hardcover edition of the same <a href="#title">title</a> and sold at a lower <a href="#listprice">price</a>, which has made them a staple of the retail market for <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>.  Synonymous with <em>paperbound</em> and <em><a href="#softcover">softcover</a></em>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>pb</em> and <em>ppr</em>.  Compare with <a href="#paperboards">paper boards</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#massmarket">mass-market paperback</a> and <a href="#tradepaperback">trade paperback</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a form of <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which <a href="#hotmelt">hot melt</a> <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> is applied to the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the un<a href="#sewing">sewn</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a>, to secure them directly to a <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  <a href="#durability">Durability</a> depends on the capacity of the adhesive to remain flexible over time.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#otabind">Otabind</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paperboard"><b>paperboard</b></a>
</dt><dd>Fairly rigid <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s of matted fiber, manufactured in the same manner as <a href="#papermaking">paper</a>, but .3 mm (.012 of an inch) or more in thickness.  Compare with <a href="#paperboards">paper boards</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paperboards"><b>paper boards</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> bound in <a href="#board">board</a>s made of <a href="#pasteboard">pasteboard</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>ed in heavy <a href="#paper">paper</a>, usually not as <a href="#durability">durable</a> as <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>  <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Compare with <a href="#paperback">paperback</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paperbound"><b>paperbound</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#paperback">paperback</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paperknife"><b>paper knife</b></a>
</dt><dd>A dull blade made of metal, wood, plastic, or ivory, which has the appearance of a knife but is made for slicing <a href="#paper">paper</a> by hand along a fold, as in opening a sealed envelope or separating the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of an <a href="#uncut">uncut</a> <a href="#book">book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paperless"><b>paperless </b></a>
</dt><dd>An automated office or system that relies primarily on electronic <a href="#medium">media</a> rather than <a href="#paper">paper</a> for <a href="#information">information</a> transmission and <a href="#recordkeeping">recordkeeping</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="papermaking"><b>papermaking</b></a>
</dt><dd>According to Chinese tradition, the process of making <a href="#paper">paper</a>
from native vegetable fibers was invented in 105 A.D. by Ts'ai Lun, an
official employed in one of the workshops of the Emperor Ho-ti. The
technique reached the Islamic world via the trade caravans and was
introduced in Spain in the 11th century, probably by the Moors.
Papermills were in operation in Europe at least 250 years before the
invention of <a href="#printing">printing</a> from <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>, but the use of <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> as a writing and printing surface persisted until well after the <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a> became established.  
<p>
Prior to the mid-19th century, nearly all paper was made from <a href="#ragpaper">rag</a> and cloth fiber reduced to <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>.  Each <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>
was produced by hand-dipping a mold or screen into a large vat
containing pulped fiber in water suspension. Early in the 19th century,
the first commercially successful papermaking machine was introduced in
England, and in 1841 a technique for making paper from wood pulp was
developed in Nova Scotia. Despite these advances, the four basic steps
of papermaking remain the same: 1) preparation of the fiber, 2)
distribution of the resulting "stock" in a thin layer across a part of
the machine called the "web," 3) removal of moisture by various means,
and 4) <a href="#finish">finish</a>ing the surface to give it the desired qualities.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#calender">calender</a>, <a href="#coated">coated</a>, <a href="#dandyroll">dandy roll</a>, and <a href="#sizing">sizing</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="papermark"><b>papermark</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#watermark">watermark</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="papers"><b>papers</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#collection">collection</a> of more than one type of handwritten or typewritten <a href="#document">document</a>.  Also refers to a group of <a href="#composition">composition</a>s, especially those written for presentation by the <a href="#author">author</a> (or authors) at a <a href="#conference">conference</a>, sometimes <a href="#publishing">published</a> as <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a> or <a href="#transactions">transactions</a> by the <a href="#society">society</a> or <a href="#association">association</a> sponsoring the meeting.  
<p>
In <a href="#archives">archives</a> and <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>, a collection of personal and family <a href="#document">document</a>s, as distinct from formal <a href="#records">records</a>, which may include <a href="#correspondence">correspondence</a>, <a href="#diary">diaries</a>, notes, etc.  <a href="#personalpapers">Personal papers</a> are often donated to a <a href="#library">library</a> by the <a href="#author">author</a> or a member of the family after the author's death.  In the United States, the trend has been for presidential papers to be <a href="#archives">archived</a> in a special <a href="#presidentiallib">presidential library</a> located in or near place of birth or residence prior to election.  
</p><p>
Also refers to an individual's official <a href="#document">document</a>s (birth certificate, identity card, passport, etc.).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paperwork"><b>paperwork</b></a>
</dt><dd>Routine tasks having to do with matters that must be committed to <a href="#paper">paper</a> (<a href="#report">report</a>s, <a href="#letters">letters</a>, <a href="#memorandum">memoranda</a>, etc.), as opposed to work that is more creative or involves other forms of communication.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#procrastination">procrastination</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="papiermache"><b>papier mache binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A 19th century molded <a href="#binding">binding</a> made from a mixture of <a href="#paper">paper</a>
fiber, plaster of Paris, and possibly antimony, formed in a rigid frame
usually made of metal. The designs, mainly in black and sometimes in
lattice-work over a red or metallic underlay, reflected the Victorian
revival of Gothic style in the decorative arts. Patented by the British
firm Jackson &amp; Sons, the method required a <a href="#leatherbound">leather</a> <a href="#spine">spine</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#relievobinding">relievo binding</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="papyrus"><b>papyrus</b></a>
</dt><dd>A tall marsh reed (<em>Cyperus papyrus</em>) native to North
Africa, from which the ancient Egyptians made a material used as a
writing and painting surface in the Mediterranean region from the 3rd
millnnium B.C. until about the 10th century A.D. Although the word
"paper" is derived from <em>papyrus</em>, the latter is not technically speaking a <a href="#paper">paper</a>,
since it is not made from pulped and processed fiber, but from the pith
of the plant laid crosswise in layers and pressed into sheets which
were polished and attached one to another in long rolls wound around a
stick which the ancient Romans called the <a href="#umbilicus">umbilicus</a>.  Because papyrus is fragile and does not withstand damp conditions, very little survives of the magnificent <a href="#library">libraries</a> of antiquity.  As a writing surface, it was <a href="#superseded">superseded</a> in the early Christian era by <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> and <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>.  Also refers to <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s written on papyrus, mainly in the form of <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>s.  <em>Papyrology</em> is the study of ancient <a href="#text">text</a>s written on papyrus.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="parable"><b>parable</b></a>
</dt><dd>A short simple story, usually written in the form of an <a href="#allegory">allegory</a>, intended to convey an explicit moral lesson (the Prodigal Son) or religious principle (the parables of Jesus).  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#fable">fable</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paradigm"><b>paradigm</b></a>
</dt><dd>A model, pattern, or example, especially one that revolutionizes the standard approach to a <a href="#subject">subject</a> or conventional modes of thinking in a profession or <a href="#field">field</a> of study.  In <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a>, paradigm shifts are increasingly driven by <a href="#infotech">technological</a> innovation.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="parallelcontent"><b>parallel content</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>, the same digits are assigned across <a href="#field">field</a>s in the second and third <a href="#character">character</a> positions of the <a href="#tag">tag</a> to indicate <a href="#data">data</a> of the same type, for example, the digits <b>10</b> for <a href="#corporatename">corporate name</a>s, making <b>110</b> the <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a> corporate name field, <b>410</b> the <a href="#seriesstatement">series statement</a> corporate name field, <b>610</b> the <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> corporate name field, <b>710</b> the <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> corporate name field, and so on.  Parallel content designation can be summarized as follows, with <b>X</b> in the range of <b>1-9</b>:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>X00</b> - <a href="#personalname">personal name</a>s
</dd><dd><b>X10</b> - corporate names
</dd><dd><b>X11</b> - meeting names
</dd><dd><b>X30</b> - <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a>s
</dd><dd><b>X40</b> - bibliographic titles
</dd><dd><b>X50</b> - <a href="#topic">topic</a>al <a href="#term">term</a>s
</dd><dd><b>X51</b> - <a href="#geographicname">geographic name</a>s</dd></dl>  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paralleledition"><b>parallel edition</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#paralleltexts">parallel texts</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="parallelpublishing"><b>parallel publishing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#publication">publication</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> at the same time in both <a href="#printing">print</a> and electronic <a href="#format">format</a>.  Compare with <a href="#simultaneouspub">simultaneous publication</a> 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paralleltexts"><b>parallel texts</b></a>
</dt><dd>Different <a href="#text">text</a>s of the same <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> side-by-side on the same <a href="#page">page</a> or on facing pages of a <a href="#book">book</a>, for example, two versions of the Bible, or a text in <a href="#translation">translation</a> and in the original <a href="#language">language</a>.  Such works are <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <em>parallel edition</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#duplicatepaging">duplicate paging</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paralleltitle"><b>parallel title</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> of an <a href="#edition">edition</a>, in a <a href="#language">language</a> or <a href="#script">script</a> other than that of the original <a href="#title">title</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, parallel <a href="#title">title</a>s are entered in the <a href="#titleand">title and statement of responsibility</a> <a href="#area">area</a> (<a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#field">field</a> 245) of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, in the same order as in the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a>, separated by an equal sign preceded and followed by a space.  The <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> records all parallel titles if the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in the United States.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="parameter"><b>parameter</b></a>
</dt><dd>An established <a href="#limiting">limit</a> whose value affects the execution or result of a process or operation, for example, a <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> <a href="#daterange">range</a> specified by the user to limit the results of a <a href="#search">search</a> in an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#database">bibliographic database</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paraph"><b>paraph</b></a>
</dt><dd>An elaborate ornamental <a href="#flourish">flourish</a> at the end of an <a href="#autograph">autograph</a> <a href="#signature">signature</a>, added, especially by notaries, to protect official <a href="#document">document</a>s from <a href="#forgery">forgery</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paraphrase"><b>paraphrase</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek <em>para</em> ("beyond") and phrasis ("to tell").  A <em>re</em>wording of the thought expressed in a previously spoken statement or written <a href="#work">work</a>, usually to make the meaning clearer by substituting shorter, simpler words for difficult <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a>.  Also, the use of rewording as a literary device or educational technique.  Compare with <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#plagiarism">plagiarism</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paraprofessional"><b>paraprofessional</b></a>
</dt><dd>A member of the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#supportstaff">support staff</a>,
usually someone who holds at least a baccalaureat degree, trained to
understand specific procedures and apply them according to
pre-established rules under normal circumstances without exercising
professional judgment. Library paraprofessionals are usually assigned
high-level technical support duties, for example, <a href="#copycataloging">copy cataloging</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s control.  In smaller <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> <a href="#librarysystem">system</a>s in the United States, <a href="#branchlibrary">branch</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s are sometimes paraprofessionals.  <a href="http://flightline.highline.ctc.edu/lssrc/orgs/indexmap.htm">Click here</a> to connect to a <a href="#directory">directory</a> of <b><em>State and Regional Library Paraprofessional Associations</em></b> in the United States.  Synonymous with <em>library technician</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ssirt">Support Staff Interests Round Table</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="parchment"><b>parchment</b></a>
</dt><dd>The split skin of an animal (sheep, goat, or calf) after it has been bleached, stretched, scraped, and prepared for use in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>
or as a writing or painting surface. Parchment was used in Europe from
about the 2nd century A.D. until well after the invention of <a href="#printing">printing</a> from <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>.  The original form of the word, <em>pergamenum</em>, is derived from the name <a href="#pergamum">Pergamum</a>, an ancient city on the west coast of Asia Minor where King Eumenes II founded a <a href="#library">library</a> to rival the great center of scholarship at <a href="#alexandrian">Alexandria</a> in Egypt.  
<p>
Although costly to produce, parchment was more <a href="#durability">durable</a> than <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a> which it gradually replaced.  Throughout the Middle Ages, it was used to make the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of hand-<a href="#copy">copied</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, one of the reasons books of that period were so thick.  Modern <a href="#paper">paper</a>
was invented in China in the 2nd century A.D. and introduced in Spain
in the 11th century, but did not replace parchment in book production
until the <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a> became well established.  Also refers to a <a href="#document">document</a> written or printed on parchment, such as a <a href="#map">map</a> or diploma.  Compare with <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="parenthesis"><b>parenthesis</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, a word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, or sentence enclosed in a pair of curved brackets <b>( )</b>
to indicate that it has been added for the sake of explanation or
clarification, but is not essential to the overall meaning of the <a href="#text">text</a>.  The use of <em>parentheses</em> has declined since the 19th century, replaced by commas in modern writing style.  Also used in reference to the <em>parenthetical expression</em> inside the brackets.  
<p>
Parentheses are used in <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject heading</a>s to add <a href="#parenthetical">parenthetical qualifier</a>s, and in <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>s to indicate <a href="#syntax">syntax</a>, a technique called <a href="#nesting">nesting</a>.  Compare with <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="parenthetical"><b>parenthetical qualifier</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> added in <a href="#parenthesis">parentheses</a> at the end of a <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> to:  
<p>
</p><ul>
<li>indicate a specific <a href="#definition">definition</a> of the term, as in <b>Nutcracker (Ballet)</b></li>
<li>give the <a href="#context">context</a> of an obscure word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, as in <b>Obatala (Yoruba deity)</b></li>
<li>give the location of a <a href="#geographicname">geographic name</a> that is not well-known, as in <b>Kymi River (Finland)</b></li>
<li>specify the academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> in which a <a href="#subject">subject</a> is studied, as in <b>Extinction (Psychology)</b></li>
<li>indicate <a href="#language">language</a>, as in <b>Sudanese fiction (English)</b></li>
<li>indicate that a proper name is imaginary, as in <b>Ophelia (Fictitious character)</b></li><li>  
</li><li>indicate instrumentation in music, as in <b>Suites (Bassoon and flute)</b></li>
<li>eliminate ambiguity, as in <b>AIDS (Disease)</b></li>
</ul>
<p>
Compare with <a href="#scopenote">scope note</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paris"><b><em>Paris Principles</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>The <em>Statement of Principles</em> adopted in 1961 at the International Conference of Cataloging Principles (ICCP), which laid the foundation for the <em><a href="#anglo">Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</a></em> and <a href="#catalogcode">catalog code</a>s used in countries other than the United States, Great Britain, and Canada.  Organized by <a href="#ifla">IFLA</a> to address international <a href="#standardization">standardization</a> in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the conference was held in Paris, France.  The <em>Statement</em> lists twelve basic principles which remain the foundation of <a href="#author">author</a>/<a href="#title">title</a> <a href="#entry">entry</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paritybit"><b>parity bit</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, a <a href="#bit">bit</a> included in a unit of <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#data">data</a> to detect errors in transmission, for example, the eighth bit in a <a href="#byte">byte</a> representing an <a href="#ascii">ASCII</a> <a href="#character">character</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="parody"><b>parody</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#satire">satirical</a> imitation in which the style of a serious artistic or <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> is ridiculed by applying the same style to an inappropriate or trivial <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or by treating the original subject in a nonsensical or irreverent manner.  One of the earliest examples is <b><em>The Frogs</em></b>, a <a href="#play">play</a> by Aristophanes believed to parody <a href="#work">work</a>s by Aeschylus and Euripides.  In a more recent example, Jane Austen parodied the <a href="#gothicnovel">gothic novel</a>s popular in early 19th century England in <b><em>Northanger Abbey</em></b>.  Parody can also be used as a form of political or social criticism (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Wind Done Gone</em></b>, Alice Randall's African-American perspective on the <a href="#novel">novel</a> <b><em>Gone With the Wind</em></b> by Margaret Mitchell).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#burlesque">burlesque</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="part"><b>part</b></a>
</dt><dd>One portion of a <a href="#work">work</a> divided by the <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, or <a href="#manufacturer">manufacturer</a> into two or more subordinate units which may be <a href="#issue">issue</a>d at intervals as the work is completed.  The intervals may be <a href="#regular">regular</a> or <a href="#irregular">irregular</a>, depending on the nature of the work.  In printed <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>s, a part is usually equivalent to a <a href="#volume">volume</a>.  A part is distinguished from a <a href="#fascicle">fascicle</a> by being a permanent component, rather than a temporary division of the work.  As used in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, the <a href="#term">term</a> refers to one of two or more bibliographic units intended to be <a href="#binding">bound</a> together, more than one to a volume (<em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>).  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>pt</em>.  Compare with <a href="#piece">piece</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#multipartvolume">multipart volume</a>, <a href="#originalparts">original parts</a>, and <a href="#serialized">serialized</a>.
<p>
In music, one of the voices or instruments for which an <a href="#ensemblework">ensemble work</a> is <a href="#composer">composed</a>.  Also, a written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> of the <a href="#notation">notation</a> in which the music for a voice or instrument is recorded, for the use of the performer.  In the <a href="#fullscore">full score</a> of an ensemble work, each part appears on a separate <a href="#stave">stave</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#condensedscore">condensed score</a>.   
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="partialremainders"><b>partial remainders</b></a>
</dt><dd>A quantity of <a href="#book">book</a>s offered by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> at lower than <a href="#listprice">list price</a> to selected <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s who are permitted to sell <a href="#copy">copies</a> retail at less than the <a href="#publishedprice">published price</a>, even though the books are still considered <a href="#net">net</a>.  This practice is condemned by publishers' and booksellers' <a href="#association">association</a>s because it gives some booksellers an unfair competitive advantage over others in the same market.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="partialtitle"><b>partial title</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#catchtitle">catch title</a> consisting of part of the <a href="#title">title</a> as it appears on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  It may be a secondary part (<a href="#subtitle">subtitle</a> or <a href="#alternativetitle">alternative title</a>) or the title with the less significant words omitted.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="partitiverelation"><b>partitive relation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="partsofabook"><b>parts of a book</b></a>
</dt><dd>Although order of appearance varies slightly from one <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to the next, the parts of a <a href="#book">book</a> in order of <a href="#gathering">gathering</a> are normally the <a href="#halftitle">half-title</a>, <a href="#seriestitle">series title</a> or <a href="#frontispiece">frontispiece</a>, <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, printer's <a href="#imprint">imprint</a> and notice of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, <a href="#dedication">dedication</a>, <a href="#epigraph">epigraph</a>, <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a>, list of <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, list of <a href="#table">table</a>s, <a href="#foreword">foreword</a> or <a href="#preface">preface</a>, <a href="#acknowledgments">acknowledgments</a>, other <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> (list of <a href="#contributor">contributor</a>s, list of <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a>s, <a href="#chronology">chronology</a>, <a href="#translation">translator</a>'s note, etc.), <a href="#introduction">introduction</a>, <a href="#errata">errata</a>, <a href="#halftitle">half-title</a>, <a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#appendix">appendices</a>, <a href="#note">note</a>s, <a href="#glossary">glossary</a>, <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>(es), <a href="#colophon">colophon</a>, and <a href="#cip">CIP</a> (if not on <a href="#verso">verso</a> of title page).  In some <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, the preface and acknowledgments may appear before the table of contents, and the contributors are sometimes listed in the <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="parttime"><b>part-time</b></a>
</dt><dd>Employment limited to a portion of normal working hours.
Part-time employees who work less than a certain number of hours per
week or month may not be entitled to full <a href="#benefits">benefits</a>.  In academic institutions, the ratio of <a href="#fulltime">full-time</a> to part-time (<a href="#adjunct">adjunct</a>) faculty, including <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, may be governed by a <a href="#collectivebargaining">collective bargaining agreement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="passalong"><b>pass-along</b></a>
</dt><dd>The likelihood that a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of an <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> will be read by more individuals than the person who actually purchases it at a news stand or by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>.  Some <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s use this as a justification for charging <a href="#library">libraries</a> a substantially higher subscription price than the rate paid by individual <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s, a practice known as <a href="#differential">differential pricing</a>.  Although pass-along is difficult to quantify, when combined with <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> it gives an approximate indication of total <a href="#readership">readership</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="passim"><b><em>passim</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for "here and there" or "in various places," <a href="#printing">printed</a> after a <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> in an <a href="#index">index</a>, or in a <a href="#footnote">footnote</a> or <a href="#endnote">endnote</a> following the <a href="#title">title</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> or the <a href="#author">author</a>'s name, to indicate that a phrase or reference to a concept or idea is scattered throughout the <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or entire <a href="#work">work</a>, too briefly or too abundantly for individual <a href="#page">page</a> references to be given.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>pass.</em>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="passiverelation"><b>passive relation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>.
<p>
