</p></dd><dt><a name="password"><b>password</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#authorization">authorized</a> word or sequence of <a href="#character">character</a>s which a user must enter as <a href="#input">input</a> in order to <a href="#logon">log on</a> to a computer system and gain <a href="#access">access</a> to desired resources.  Passwords are usually managed by the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> or a <a href="#dbmanagement">database management system</a> (DBMS).  Because system <a href="#software">software</a> is only capable of verifying the legitimacy of a password, not the identity of the person using it, passwords should remain <a href="#confidentiality">confidential</a>.  In a well-designed system, passwords must be changed periodically by the user to maintain <a href="#security">security</a>.  By contrast, the <a href="#username">username</a> is usually permanent.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paste"><b>paste</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> used to stick together light-weight materials such as <a href="#paper">paper</a> and <a href="#goldleaf">gold leaf</a>,
made from the starch contained in a cereal grain such as wheat or rice,
combined over heat with water (and sometimes alum or resin), then
allowed to cool. Compare with <a href="#glue">glue</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pasteboard"><b>pasteboard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A rigid, relatively light-weight <a href="#binding">binding</a> material made from layer upon layer of <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#paste">paste</a>d together, or from thin layers of <a href="#pulp">pulp</a> bonded together, introduced in the 15th century to replace wooden <a href="#board">board</a>s in small to medium-sized <a href="#book">book</a>s.  In modern <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a heavy grade of pasteboard called <a href="#bindersboard">binder's board</a> is used extensively in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pastedown"><b>paste-down</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the half of a double-<a href="#leaf">leaf</a> <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a> firmly affixed to the inside of one of the <a href="#board">board</a>s of the <a href="#case">case</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a>, over the <a href="#turnin">turn-in</a>.  Also spelled <em>pastedown</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pastein"><b>paste-in</b></a>
</dt><dd>A correction or addition, supplied after the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> has been <a href="#printing">printed</a>, to be <a href="#tippedin">tipped in</a> opposite to or on the <a href="#page">page</a> containing the line or passage to which it refers.  Compare with <a href="#errata">errata</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pasteup"><b>paste-up</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the arrangement on a large <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> of the <a href="#pageproof">page proof</a>s of several pages, to enable the <a href="#typography">typographer</a> to position the <a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, <a href="#caption">caption</a>s, and other elements of the finished <a href="#publication">publication</a> in a design that meets the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#specifications">specifications</a>.  Compare with <a href="#layout">layout</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pastingdown"><b>pasting down</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the process of securely affixing one half of a double-<a href="#leaf">leaf</a> <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a> to the inside of each of the <a href="#board">board</a>s of the <a href="#cover">cover</a>, over the <a href="#turnin">turn-in</a>.  In <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a>, this step is a finishing touch, the <a href="#body">body</a> of the book having been laced to the cover, but in <a href="#casebinding">case binding</a>, the endpapers attach the body to the <a href="#case">case</a>.  Compare with <a href="#gluingoff">gluing off</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="patent"><b>patent</b></a>
</dt><dd>A legal <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d
by the United States government, or the government of another country
in response to a formal application process, in which the inventor or
originator of a new product or process is granted the exclusive right
to manufacture, use, and sell it for a designated period of time. The
document is assigned a <em>patent number</em> by the patent office for future reference.  Most large engineering <a href="#library">libraries</a> provide patent <a href="#search">search</a> <a href="#database">database</a>s and services.  Compare with <a href="#trademark">trademark</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ptdl">patent and trademark depository library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ptdl"><b>patent and trademark depository library (PTL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> designated by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (PTO) to receive and store <a href="#copy">copies</a> of U.S. <a href="#patent">patent</a>s and patent/<a href="#trademark">trademark</a> materials, make them freely available to the public, and disseminate general <a href="#information">information</a> about patents and trademarks.  Created by federal statute in 1871, the <a href="http://www.uspto.gov/go/ptdl/">Patent and Trademark Depository Library Program</a> (PTDLP) has grown to include more than 80 libraries, half of which are <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, with nearly as many <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, one <a href="#statelibrary">state library</a>, and a <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a> devoted to <a href="#research">research</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ptdla">Patent and Trademark Depository Library Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ptdla"><b>Patent and Trademark Depository Library Association (PTDLA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>PTDLA</b> is dedicated to advising the United States <a href="#patent">Patent</a> and <a href="#trademark">Trademark</a> Office (PTO) on the interests, needs, opinions, and goals of <a href="#ptdl">patent and trademark depository libraries</a> (PTLs) and their users, and to assisting the PTO in planning and implementing appropriate services. <a href="http://www.rice.edu/fondren/gov/ptdla/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>PTDLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="patentfile"><b>patent file</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#collection">collection</a> of drawings and <a href="#specifications">specifications</a> for <a href="#patent">patent</a>s, <a href="#index">index</a>ed by country and patent number, name of <em>patentee</em>, or <a href="#subject">subject</a>, usually maintained in a <a href="#ptdl">patent and trademark depository library</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="patentnumber"><b>patent number</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#patent">patent</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pathfinder"><b>pathfinder</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#subjectbib">subject bibliography</a> designed to lead the user through the process of <a href="#research">research</a>ing a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a>, or any topic in a given <a href="#field">field</a> or <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, usually in a systematic, step-by-step way, making use of the best <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a>s the <a href="#library">library</a> has to offer.  Pathfinders may be <a href="#print">print</a>ed or available <a href="#online">online</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#topicalguide">topical guide</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="patron"><b>patron</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any person who uses the resources and services of a <a href="#library">library</a>, not necessarily a registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>.  Synonymous with <em>user</em>.  Compare with <a href="#client">client</a>. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#patronid">patron ID</a>, <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a>, <a href="#patrontype">patron type</a>, and <a href="#problempatron">problem patron</a>.
<p>
Also, a person who helps sponsor the creation, <a href="#copy">copy</a>ing, or <a href="#printing">printing</a> of an <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#work">work</a>.  During the 16th and 17th centuries, when returns from the fees paid by <a href="#printer">printer</a>/<a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s were meager, many writers could not have flourished without the <em>patronage</em> of wealthy individuals and institutions.  It was not unusual for a sponsored work to be formally <a href="#dedication">dedicated</a>
to the benefactor, in gratitude and hope of further financial
assistance. In a more general sense, any person or group that
encourages or supports an activity or project, especially by providing
necessary funds.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="patronid"><b>patron ID</b></a>
</dt><dd>The means by which <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> at the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> ascertain that a <a href="#patron">patron</a> is a registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>, usually the person's <a href="#librarycard">library card</a>, student ID card, <a href="#security">security</a> badge, or a substitute.  Also refers to the number used in most library <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s to identify the borrower.  Sometimes it is the library card number, but in <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> it may be the student ID number or the social security number.  In <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>, patron ID may be linked to the employee identification system used by the parent organization.  Each library or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> adopts its own method of patron identification.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="patronrecord"><b>patron record</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#confidentiality">confidential</a> record in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>, containing <a href="#data">data</a> pertaining to a <a href="#borroweraccount">borrower account</a> (full name, street address, telephone number, <a href="#patronid">patron ID</a>, <a href="#patrontype">patron type</a>, items on loan, <a href="#hold">hold</a>s, unpaid <a href="#fines">fines</a>, etc.).  In electronic circulation systems, an <a href="#authorization">authorized</a> member of the <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> is permitted to <a href="#access">access</a> the <a href="#patron">patron</a> record by <a href="#scanner">scanning</a> the <a href="#barcode">barcode</a> on the <a href="#librarycard">library card</a>, or by using a <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> to enter the patron's name or library card number as <a href="#input">input</a>.  Some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s allow registered borrowers to view thir own patron records with proper <a href="#authorization">authorization</a>.  Synonymous with <em>circulation record</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#blocked">blocked</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="patrontype"><b>patron type</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s, a code entered in the <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a> to indicate a specific category of <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>, which in conjunction with <a href="#itemtype">item type</a> determines the <a href="#loanrule">loan rule</a> applied when an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>.  <a href="#academiclib">Academic libraries</a> usually differentiate faculty, student, alumni, and staff by patron type.  Most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> distinguish between nonresidents and <a href="#patron">patron</a>s who reside in the service area, and between <a href="#adult">adult</a> and juvenile users.  In <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>, patron type may reflect hierarchical rank within the parent organization, levels of <a href="#security">security</a> clearance, etc.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="patronymic"><b>patronymic</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> derived from the <a href="#firstname">given name</a>
of the father or a more distant paternal ancestor, usually by the
addition of a prefix (ben Jacob, MacArthur, O'Brien) or suffix
(Donaldson, Petrovich).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="paymentdate"><b>payment date</b></a>
</dt><dd>The date by which an outstanding bill for goods and/or services must be paid, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the seller's <a href="#invoice">invoice</a>, after which the account is delinquent.  A penalty may be charged for late payment. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="payout"><b>pay-out</b></a>
</dt><dd>In marketing, an expenditure of funds that produces a return
greater than the investment. When return equals investment, the result
is known as <em>break-even</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="payperiod"><b>pay period</b></a>
</dt><dd>The interval at which an employee is paid, usually weekly, biweekly, or monthly, depending on the <a href="#payroll">payroll</a> system of the employer.  Hours worked are usually reported to the <a href="#payroll">payroll</a> department on a timesheet signed by the employee.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="payphone"><b>payphone</b></a>
</dt><dd>A telephone located in a public area from which anyone may make calls in exchange for payment in cash or by calling card.  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> that open their doors to the public provide at least one payphone as a courtesy to their users. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="payroll"><b>payroll</b></a>
</dt><dd>The list of employees who are paid <a href="#salary">salaries</a> and <a href="#wages">wages</a> by an employer, usually by check or direct deposit on a weekly, biweekly, or monthly basis.  <a href="#library">Library</a> employees may be required to sign a <em>timesheet</em> for each <a href="#payperiod">pay period</a>, stating the hours they worked.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pbs"><b>PBS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#pubtv">public television</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pc"><b>PC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#personalcomputer"><b>p</b>ersonal <b>c</b>omputer</a> and <a href="#politcorrect"><b>p</b>olitical <b>c</b>orrectness</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pcc1"><b>PCC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#pcc"><b>P</b>rogram for <b>C</b>ooperatrive <b>C</b>ataloging</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pda1"><b>PDA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#pda"><b>p</b>ersonal <b>d</b>igitial <b>a</b>ssistant</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pdf1"><b>PDF</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#pdf"><b>P</b>ortable <b>D</b>ocument <b>F</b>ormat</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="peakuse"><b>peak use</b></a>
</dt><dd>The period(s) in a day, week, month, and year during which the services and resources of a <a href="#library">library</a> or computer system are most heavily used.  <a href="#transactionlog">Transaction log</a>s, <a href="#circstats">circulation statistics</a>, and <a href="#gatecount">gate count</a>s can be compiled and analyzed to reveal recurrent periods of peak use.  The results are useful in establishing <a href="#libraryhours">library hour</a>s, anticipating <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ing needs, scheduling maintenance, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="peerevaluation"><b>peer evaluation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process in which the job performance of a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or other <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> member is assessed by the individual's colleagues and a recommendation made concerning contract renewal or <a href="#promotion">promotion</a>.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> at institutions that grant librarians <a href="#facultystatus">faculty status</a>, <a href="#tenure">tenure</a> decisions may also be based on peer evaluation.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a> in which employment is governed by a <a href="#collectivebargaining">collective bargaining agreement</a>, the method of peer evaluation may be determined by <a href="#contract">contract</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="peerreview"><b>peer review</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process in which the <a href="#author">author</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#article">article</a>, <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>, etc., submits his or her <a href="#work">work</a> to experts in the <a href="#field">field</a> for critical evaluation, usually prior to <a href="#publication">publication</a>, a standard procedure in scholarly <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>.  In <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a>ming, source code may be certified by its owner or licenser as <a href="#opensource">open source</a> to encourage development through peer review.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="peerreviewed"><b>peer-reviewed</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a> that requires an <a href="#article">article</a> to be submitted to a process of critical evaluation by one or more experts on the <a href="#subject">subject</a>, known as <a href="#referee">referee</a>s, responsible for determining if the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the article falls within the <a href="#scope">scope</a> of the <a href="#publication">publication</a>, and for evaluating originality, quality of research, clarity of presentation, etc.  Changes may be suggested to the <a href="#author">author</a>(s) before an article is finally accepted for publication.  In evaluation for <a href="#tenure">tenure</a> and <a href="#promotion">promotion</a>, <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s may be given <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> credit only for articles accepted by peer-reviewed journals.  Some <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s allow <a href="#search">search</a> results to be <a href="#limiting">limited</a> to <a href="#peerreview">peer-review</a>ed <a href="#journal">journal</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>juried</em> and <em>refereed</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pendant"><b>pendant</b></a>
</dt><dd>An additional <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>, statement, or <a href="#composition">composition</a> that completes or complements another <a href="#work">work</a>, but is independent of it, for example, an <a href="#essay">essay</a> illuminating the historical basis of a <a href="#satire">satirical</a> work. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pendingfile"><b>pending file</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#paper">paper</a> or electronic <a href="#file">file</a> in which <a href="#document">document</a>s
pertaining to matters that cannot be immediately resolved are allowed
to accumulate until circumstances are more favorable for their
disposition. A rapidly growing pending file may be a sign of overwork
or a bottleneck in <a href="#workflow">workflow</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pendingrequest"><b>pending request</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#oclcill">OCLC Interlibrary Loan</a> system, a loan request sent by a <a href="#borrowinglibrary">borrowing library</a> that appears in the message file of a potential <a href="#lendinglibrary">lending library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="penname"><b>pen name</b></a>
</dt><dd>A name used by an <a href="#author">author</a> other than his or her real name, usually adopted to conceal identity.  A pen name can be an <a href="#allonym">allonym</a> (name of an actual person other than the author), a fictitious <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>Avi</b> for Edward Irving Wortis), a pseudonym based on the author's real name (<b>Dr. Seuss</b> for Theodor Seuss Geisel), or a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> that is not a <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> (<b>Spy</b>
for Sir Leslie Ward). Pen names were used more commonly during the 19th
century when writing was not as respectable as it is today and
therefore considered an unsuitable occupation for women. Some authors
write under more than one pen name, adopting a different name when
writing in a new <a href="#genre">genre</a> or introducing a new lead <a href="#character">character</a> (or set of characters) in a <a href="#series">series</a>.  <a href="http://www.trussel.com/books/pseudo.htm">Click here</a> to connect to <b><em>a.k.a.</em></b>,  an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> of pseudonyms and pen names.  Synonymous with <em>nom de plume</em>.  Compare with <a href="#autonym">autonym</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#eponym">eponym</a> and <a href="#pseudandry">pseudandry</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pennydreadful"><b>penny dreadful</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sensational <a href="#melodrama">melodrama</a> in the form of a <a href="#novel">novel</a> or <a href="#novelette">novelette</a> of <a href="#mystery">mystery</a>, crime, or adventure, <a href="#printing">printed</a> in cheap <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>, the equivalent in England of the <a href="#dimenovel">dime novel</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="perdiem"><b>per diem</b></a>
</dt><dd>The rate at which a product or service is billed on a daily
basis. Also refers to the maximum amount allowed by an employer for
travel expenses (meals, lodging, etc.), usually calculated on the basis
of average cost for a given geographic area.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="perfectbinding"><b>perfect binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A quick and comparatively inexpensive method of <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive binding</a> in which the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> is <a href="#milling">milled</a> to produce a block of <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> and then roughened.  Fast-drying <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> is applied to the uneven surface and the <a href="#case">case</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a> attached without <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> and <a href="#backing">backing</a>.  Nearly all <a href="#book">book</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> are bound by this method, which is also used for some <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#specialedition">special edition</a>s, for example, <a href="#bookclub">book club</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  <a href="#durability">Durability</a>
depends on the strength of the adhesive and its capacity to remain
flexible over time, usually not as long-lasting as a sewn or <a href="#sidestitching">stitched</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Compare with <a href="#otabind">Otabind</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doublefan">double-fan adhesive binding</a>, <a href="#hotmelt">hot-melt</a>, and <a href="#notchedbinding">notched binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="perfecting"><b>perfecting</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of <a href="#printing">printing</a> the second side of a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>.  On a <em>perfecting press</em>, both sides are printed in a single pass.  Synonymous with <em>backing up</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#register">register</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="perforating"><b>perforating stamp</b></a>
</dt><dd>A mechanical device designed to produce a permanent mark on a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> by punching a pattern of tiny holes in the fibers, once used by <a href="#library">libraries</a> to mark <a href="#ownershipmark">ownership</a>, but now largely replaced by the <a href="#rubberstamp">rubber stamp</a>.  Notaries still use this tool to validate their <a href="#signature">signature</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="perforation"><b>perforation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Cutting or punching a line of small, closely-spaced holes or slits along the inner <a href="#margin">margin</a> of a <a href="#page">page</a>, or around <a href="#matter">matter</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>, to make a page or portion of a page easier to tear out or off.  Also refers to the line of holes produced for that purpose.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#perforating">perforating stamp</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="performanceeval"><b>performance evaluation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of judging the competence with which an employee has performed the duties and responsibilities associated with the <a href="#position">position</a> for which the person was hired by a company or organization, usually for the purpose of contract renewal or <a href="#promotion">promotion</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, job performance may be evaluated entirely by management or in a process of <a href="#peerevaluation">peer evaluation</a>.  Synonymous with <em>performance measurement</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#accountability">accountability</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="performanceindicator"><b>performance indicator</b></a>
</dt><dd>A measure of how well an employee, department, organization, or institution is meeting its <a href="#goal">goal</a>s and <a href="#objective">objective</a>s, for example, the percentage of borrowing requests received by the <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> department of a <a href="#library">library</a> that are successfully filled within a given period of time.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="perfmeasurement"><b>performance measurement</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>Sede</em></b>:  <a href="#performanceeval">performance evaluation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="performer"><b>performer</b></a>
</dt><dd>An individual who plays a visible part in a <a href="#work">work</a> created for a <a href="#medium">medium</a> of performance (<a href="#play">play</a>, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, musical <a href="#composition">composition</a>, dance, etc.).  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the names of leading performers may be included as <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a> (<a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#field">field</a> 700) in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of a recorded performance (<a href="#film">film</a>, <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>, <a href="#audiocassette">audiocassette</a>, <a href="#compactdisc">CD</a>, etc.).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#composer">composer</a> and <a href="#director">director</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pergamum"><b>Pergamum</b></a>
</dt><dd>An ancient city on the west coast of Asia Minor near the modern town of Bergama, Turkey, the location of a magnificent royal <a href="#library">library</a> and museum built during the Hellenistic period by Eumenes II of the Attalid dynasty to rival the great center of learning at <a href="#alexandrian">Alexandria</a> in Egypt.  The use of <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> as a writing surface is believed to have originated at Pergamum.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="period"><b>period</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a> mark that indicates the end of an ordinary sentence, also used as a mark of <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a>.  Synonymous with <a href="#fullpoint">full point</a> and <a href="#fullstop">full stop</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dot">dot</a>.
<p>
In history and <a href="#literature">literature</a>, an interval
of time, usually of indefinite beginning and/or ending date(s),
characterized by certain events, conditions, or characteristics of
style, such as the Romantic period (early 19th century in Europe), or
the Victorian period (late 19th century in Britain). </p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="periodbib"><b>period bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> limited to <a href="#work">work</a>s covering a specific period of time, for example, American history of the <em>colonial period</em> or the <em>progressive era</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="periodical"><b>periodical</b></a>    
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> with its own distinctive <a href="#title">title</a>, containing <a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#shortstory">stories</a>, or other short <a href="#work">work</a>s usually written by different <a href="#contributor">contributor</a>s, issued in <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> more than once, usually at <a href="#regular">regular</a> stated intervals without prior decision as to when the final <a href="#issue">issue</a> will appear.  Although each issue is complete in itself, its relationship to preceding issues is indicated by an <a href="#issuenumber">issue number</a> and <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the front <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  <a href="#editorialcontent">Content</a> is controlled by an <a href="#editor">editor</a> or <a href="#editorialboard">editorial board</a>.  The category includes <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a>s, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, and <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, sold at newsstands and by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>.  Libraries usually <a href="#binding">bind</a> all the issues <a href="#publishing">published</a> during a specific <a href="#pubyear">publication year</a> in one or more physical <a href="#volume">volume</a>s, with the bibliographic volumes <a href="#volumenumber">number</a>ed consecutively, starting with number one for the first year in which the periodical was issued.  Compare with <a href="#serial">serial</a>.
<p>
Periodicals are published by scholarly <a href="#society">societies</a>, <a href="#universitypress">university press</a>es, <a href="#govtagency">government agencies</a>, commercial <a href="#publisher">publishing house</a>s, private corporations, trade and professional <a href="#association">association</a>s, and nonprofit organizations.  The most <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> periodical <a href="#directory">directories</a> are <em><a href="#ulrichs">Ulrich's International Periodicals Directory</a></em> published by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a> and <em><a href="#serialsdirectory">The Serials Directory</a></em> published by <a href="#ebsco">EBSCO</a>, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of large <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States.  The content of periodicals is <a href="#indexing">indexed</a> in <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a>s called <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s, usually by <a href="#subject">subject</a> and <a href="#author">author</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dd>Periodicals are usually shelved <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by title in a separate section of the library <a href="#stacks">stacks</a>.  In some libraries, <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>s are shelved in a different location than <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s, which may be converted to <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> or <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> to conserve space.  <a href="#microform">Microform</a> <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a> machines are provided for viewing and making <a href="#hardcopy">hard copies</a>.  Periodicals published by the U.S. federal government may be shelved by <a href="#sudocs">SuDocs number</a> in a separate section of the stacks reserved for <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#frequency">frequency</a>, <a href="#holdingsnote">holdings note</a>, <a href="#oneshot">one shot</a>, and <a href="#periodicalstand">periodical stand</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="periodicalindex"><b>periodical index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#cumulativeindex">cumulative</a> list of <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s in which the <a href="#citation">citation</a>s are entered by <a href="#subject">subject</a> (or in <a href="#classified">classified</a> arrangement) and sometimes under the <a href="#author">author</a>'s last name, separately or in a single <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetic</a> sequence.  Periodical indexes may be general (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Reader's Guide to Periodical Literature</em></b>), devoted to a specific academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> (<b><em>Education Index</em></b>) or group of disciplines (<b><em>Humanities Index</em></b>), or limited to a particular type of <a href="#publication">publication</a> (<b><em>Alternative Press Index</em></b>).  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, periodical indexes are available in <a href="#printing">print</a> and as <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, <a href="#online">online</a> or on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a> and <a href="#hwwilson">H. W. Wilson</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="periodicalstand"><b>periodical stand</b></a>
</dt><dd>A piece of display furniture with sloping shelves, used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> to display <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>s of <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s <a href="#faceout">face out</a>, not as compact as conventional shelving, but more <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> to <a href="#browser">browser</a>s.  The sloping shelf may be hinged to allow a limited <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#backissue">back issue</a>s to be stored on a flat shelf behind it.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="periodprinting"><b>period printing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The production of <a href="#book">book</a>s or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s in a style appropriate to the period of time in which the material was originally <a href="#issue">issue</a>d.  Compare with <a href="#facsimile">facsimile</a>.
<p>
Also, the production of a book in a style resembling that of an earlier period, although the <a href="#text">text</a> may have been written by a contemporary <a href="#author">author</a>, usually conceived by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> as a <a href="#promotion">promotion</a>al device.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="periodsubdivision"><b>period subdivision</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a> added to a <a href="#class">class</a> or <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> to limit its application to a specific period of time (<em>example</em>:  <b>American poetry--20th century</b> or <b>France--History--1789-1815</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="peripheral"><b>peripheral</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#device">device</a> used in conjunction with a computer, which is not an indispensable or inseparable part of it.  <a href="#microcomputer">Microcomputer</a> peripherals are used for <a href="#input">input</a> (<a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>, <a href="#mouse">mouse</a>, <a href="#scanner">scanner</a>), <a href="#output">output</a> (<a href="#printer">printer</a>, <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>, audio speakers), <a href="#storage">storage</a> (<a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>), and communication (<a href="#modem">modem</a>).  The trend has been to build peripherals into <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a>s, especially <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>auxiliary equipment</em>. <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#centralproc">CPU</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="periphrasis"><b>periphrasis</b></a>
</dt><dd>Saying something in a less direct, more roundabout way.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>circumlocution</em>.
Also refers to speech or writing that uses an excess of words to convey
an idea or concept that could be expressed more succinctly. Compare
with <a href="#paraphrase">paraphrase</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="perk"><b>perk</b></a>
</dt><dd>An advantage enjoyed by an employee over and above the normal <a href="#benefits">benefits</a> to which the <a href="#position">position</a> is entitled, for example, exemption from <a href="#overdue">overdue</a> <a href="#fines">fine</a>s for the <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> of some <a href="#library">libraries</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="permanence"><b>permanence</b></a>
</dt><dd>The quality of <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> designed to last indefinitely without significant <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a>, defined by <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s as a change of one percent or less in 100 years.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#permanentpaper">permanent paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="permanentink"><b>permanent ink</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of visible <a href="#ink">ink</a> used in applying <a href="#ownershipmark">ownership mark</a>s to <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> because it cannot be easily removed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="permanentpaper"><b>permanent paper</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#paper">Paper</a> manufactured to resist chemical <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> that occurs as a result of aging.  The most important factor in <a href="#permanence">permanence</a> is a minimum <a href="#ph">pH</a> of 7.0 (neutral).  <a href="#acidfree">Acid-free</a> paper is preferred in <a href="#library">library</a> and <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> because it contains low levels of <a href="#lignin">lignin</a>, an <a href="#acidic">acidic</a> substance that causes <a href="#document">document</a>s made of paper to <a href="#yellowing">yellow</a> and become <a href="#brittle">brittle</a> over time.  The <a href="#acidpaper">acid paper</a> used to <a href="#printing">print</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s in the 19th and early 20th centuries has created a major <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> imperative for <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> and <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>.  Some permanent papers are <a href="#bufferedpaper">buffered</a> with an <a href="#alkaline">alkaline</a> substance to counteract acids that develop after manufacture or are introduced from an outside source.  
<p>
<a href="#ansi">ANSI</a> and <a href="#niso">NISO</a> have established a set of <a href="#standards">standards</a> (Z39.48) for the <a href="#permanence">permanence</a> of paper used in materials for libraries and archives.  Degrees of permanence for paper are based on <a href="#specifications">specifications</a> for acidity, <a href="#fibercontent">fiber content</a>,
fold endurance, and the residual amount of certain substances used in
manufacture (rosin, chlorine, etc.). Under normal use and storage
conditions, paper that meets ANSI criteria should last for several
hundred years without significant deterioration. Synonymous with <em>acid-free paper</em>, <em>durable paper</em>, and <em>non-acidic paper</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="permission"><b>permission</b></a>
</dt><dd>Authorization, usually granted in writing by the <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> holder, to <a href="#quotation">quote</a> or <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a> passages of <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#reproduction">reproduce</a> <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s from a <a href="#work">work</a> legally protected by copyright.  Failure to obtain permission may constitute <a href="#infringement">infringement</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ccc">Copyright Clearance Center</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="permissionscopy"><b>permissions copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> containing <a href="#quotation">quoted</a> or <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>ed material, sent to the <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> holder at first <a href="#publication">publication</a> to confirm that passages were used in accordance with the <a href="#permission">permission</a>s granted.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="permutedindex"><b>permuted index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#subjectindex">subject index</a> in which a string of significant words or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s, usually extracted from the <a href="#title">title</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> or assigned as <a href="#content">content</a> <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s by an indexer, are rotated to bring each word or phrase into first-word position in the <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> sequence of <a href="#entry">entries</a>.  For example, in the <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#index">index</a> to <b><em>America: History and Life</em></b>, the string of descriptors assigned to the <a href="#article">article</a> <a href="#title">title</a>d "Library Services and the African-American Intelligentsia before 1960" (<em>Libraries &amp; Culture</em> 33: 91-97) is rotated to produce the following index entries:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>Blacks.</b> Higher Education. Intellectuals. Libraries. 1900-1960.
</dd><dd><b>Higher education.</b> Intellectuals. Libraries. Blacks. 1900-1960.
</dd><dd><b>Intellectuals.</b> Libraries. Blacks. Higher education. 1900-1960.
</dd><dd><b>Libraries.</b> Blacks. Higher education. Intellectuals. 1900-1960.</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="persearch"><b>per search</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#database">database</a> for which <a href="#access">access</a> is billed by the <a href="#search">search</a>, rather than by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>.  The charge may be a fixed amount per search as in <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#firstsearch">FirstSearch</a></em>, or based on <a href="#connecttime">connect time</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="personalarchives"><b>personal archives</b></a>
</dt><dd>A category of <a href="#collectingarchives">collecting archives</a> devoted to <a href="#preservation">preserving</a> the <a href="#personalpapers">personal papers</a> and <a href="#memorabilia">memorabilia</a> of one or more persons, or of a family or group of families.  In the United States, the <a href="#presidentiallib">presidential libraries</a> function as <a href="#archives">archives</a> for the <a href="#papers">papers</a> of the Presidents.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="personalauthor"><b>personal author</b></a>
</dt><dd>The person primarily responsible for the literary, musical, artistic, or intellectual <a href="#content">content</a> of a creative <a href="#work">work</a>, whose full <a href="#personalname">name</a> is entered in the <a href="#statementof">statement of responsibility</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> when the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>ed.  Compare with <a href="#corporateauthor">corporate author</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#jointauthor">joint author</a> and <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="personalcomputer"><b>personal computer (PC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> designed for individual use, usually in a personal workspace, consisting of a <a href="#centralproc">CPU</a> and associated <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> <a href="#device">device</a>s.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is often restricted to IBM-<a href="#compatibility">compatible</a> microcomputers in which the <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> is controlled by Intel and the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> by Microsoft.  A <b>PC</b> may function as a <a href="#standalone">stand-alone</a> <a href="#workstation">workstation</a> or be connected to a <a href="#network">network</a>.  In a <a href="#localarea">LAN</a>, <b>PC</b>s may function as <a href="#client">client</a> workstations or as <a href="#file">file</a> <a href="#server">server</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pda"><b>personal digital assistant (PDA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer small enough to fit in the palm of the hand or in a small pocket.  Some models accept handwritten <a href="#input">input</a>, others are equipped with a small <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>.  Because of their small size, most PDAs do not include a <a href="#diskdrive">disk drive</a>.
Their capabilities are therefore limited to scheduling, note-taking,
simple calculations, and storing addresses and phone numbers, but some
models include slots into which disk drives, <a href="#modem">modem</a>s, and other <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> <a href="#device">device</a>s can be inserted to allow users to exchange <a href="#email">e-mail</a> and <a href="#access">access</a> <a href="#information">information</a> on the <a href="#www">Web</a>.  Synonymous with <em>handheld computer</em>, <em>palmtop</em>, and <em>pocket computer</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="personalname"><b>personal name</b></a>
</dt><dd>The name given to an animate being, real or imaginary.  In the case of a human being, usually a <a href="#forename">forename</a> and <a href="#surname">surname</a> or family name, but sometimes a single name (Moses, Socrates, etc.), used as the <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a> when <a href="#work">work</a>s by the person are listed in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  In a <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>, the name may be followed by a <a href="#parenthetical">parenthetical qualifier</a> for clarification, as in <b>Tarzan (Fictitious character)</b>.  A qualifier is also added to the personal name of a nonhuman being to indicate species, as in <b>Dolly (Sheep)</b>.  Compare with <a href="#corporatename">corporate name</a> and <a href="#geographicname">geographic name</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nickname">nickname</a> and <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="personalpapers"><b>personal papers</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the private <a href="#document">document</a>s and related materials accumulated by an individual in the course of a lifetime (<a href="#letters">letters</a>, <a href="#diary">diaries</a>, legal <a href="#document">document</a>s,
etc.). Personal papers are subject to the owner's disposition, in
contrast to official papers which may be subject to the disposition of
an employer or government. <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#papers">papers</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="personalweb"><b>personal Web page</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> maintained by or for an individual for the purpose of acquainting other <a href="#internet">Internet</a> users with the views, activities, or <a href="#work">work</a>s of the person whose name is identified with it, sometimes installed at the <a href="#author">author</a>'s expense on a <a href="#server">server</a> maintained by a commercial <a href="#internetservice">Internet service provider</a> (ISP).  Synonymous with <em>personal homepage</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="personnel"><b>personnel</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#humanresources">human resources</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pertinence"><b>pertinence</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, the extent to which a <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a> in response to a <a href="#query">query</a> actually satisfies the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>, based on the user's current state of <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>--a narrower concept than <a href="#relevance">relevance</a>.  Although a document may be relevant to the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the <a href="#search">search</a>, it may already be known to the searcher, written in a <a href="#language">language</a> the user does not read, or available in a <a href="#format">format</a> the user is unable or unwilling to use.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pestmanagement"><b>pest management</b></a>
</dt><dd>Physical and chemical methods employed by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#archive">archive</a> to control or eliminate living organisms that infest <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s (<a href="#mildew">mildew</a>, <a href="#mold">mold</a>, insects, rodents, etc.), for example, freezing or <a href="#fumigation">fumigation</a>.  <em>Integrated pest management</em>
(IPM) strategies begin with careful identification of the nature and
habits of the offender(s), then rely on nonchemical preventive methods
as the first line of defense (control of climate, entry points, food
sources, etc.). Chemical <a href="#treatment">treatment</a>s are usually reserved for infestations of crisis proportions and pests that do not succumb to less toxic alternatives.  <a href="http://palimpsest.stanford.edu/bytopic/pest/">Click here</a> to connect to the pest management section of the <em>Conservation OnLine (CoOL)</em> <a href="#website">Web site</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ph"><b>pH</b></a>
</dt><dd>A chemical <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> representing the concentration of hydrogen ions in a given substance in aqueous solution, a standard measure of its <a href="#acidic">acidity</a> or <a href="#alkaline">alkalinity</a> (basicity) on a scale of 0-14, with 0=strongly acidic and 14=strongly alkaline, used in <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> to detect <a href="#acidpaper">acid paper</a>, <a href="#board">board</a>,
etc. Since pH is a logarithmic measure, each unit on the scale
represents a factor of 10, with 7.0 (the pH of pure water) the neutral
point.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pharmacopoeia"><b>pharmacopoeia</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#online">online</a> resource that lists drugs, chemical compounds, and biological substances, providing <a href="#information">information</a>
on molecular structure and properties, therapeutic uses, derivatives,
and sometimes formulas for manufacture, and tests for establishing
identity, purity, strength, etc. (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Merck Index</em></b> or <b><em>PDR: Physicians' Desk Reference</em></b>).  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> keep the <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> of at least one modern pharmacopoeia in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="philateliclib"><b>philatelic library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> devoted to the history of postage stamps and stamp collecting, with a <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> consisting of <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s on <a href="#philately">philately</a>, auction <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a>, <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s, etc., for example, the <a href="http://www.stamps.org/TheLibrary/lib_AbouttheAPRL.htm">American Philatelic Research Library</a> in State College, Pennsylvania.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="philately"><b>philately</b></a>
</dt><dd>The collection and study of postage stamps and related materials, usually as a hobby.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#philateliclib">philatelic library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="phonebook"><b>phone book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#telephonedirectory">telephone directory</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="phonogram"><b>phonogram</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written sign, <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>, or <a href="#character">character</a> that represents a sound, syllable, or word spoken in a <a href="#language">language</a>, as opposed to an <a href="#ideogram">ideogram</a> that represents an object, idea, or concept without phonetically expressing the sound of its name.  The Latin <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> is a set of phonograms.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="phonograph"><b>phonograph record</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thin, flat disk, usually made of vinyl, impressed on one or
both sides with a continuous spiral groove in which audible sounds are
recorded. As the disk revolves on a <a href="#playback">playback</a> machine, called a <em>record player</em>, the groove causes a <a href="#stylus">stylus</a> to vibrate, producing electrical impulses in a cartridge, which can be amplified as sound.  The most common <a href="#playingspeed">playing speed</a> is 33 <a href="#rpm">rpm</a> (<a href="#longplaying">long-playing</a>), but 78, 45, and 66 2/3 rpm disks were also manufactured.  Audio <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>s have <a href="#superseded">superseded</a> phonograph records in the retail market for <a href="#soundrecording">sounds recording</a>s, but there is still a market for second-hand records, some of which have become <a href="#collectible">collectible</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, "vinyl" is <a href="#preservation">preserved</a> primarily for its <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the <a href="#term">term</a> "sound disc" is used in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for a phonograph record, with "<a href="#analog">analog</a>" given as <a href="#typerecording">type of recording</a>.  Synonymous with <em>audiodisc</em> and <em>gramophone record</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="photocopier"><b>photocopier</b></a>
</dt><dd>A machine available in most <a href="#library">libraries</a> for making <a href="#xerography">xerographic</a> <a href="#copy">copies</a> of <a href="#document">document</a>s, usually in black-and-white.  Some photocopiers are capable of <a href="#enlargement">enlarging</a> or <a href="#reduction">reducing</a> the size of the <a href="#original">original</a>.  Most copiers are coin-operated, with payment by the <a href="#page">page</a> in cash or by debit card (<a href="#fee">fee</a> varies).  Sophisticated <a href="#photocopy">photocopy</a> machines available in commercial copy shops are capable of color copying and handling large jobs that require <a href="#collation">collating</a> and stapling.  Compare with <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#copycard">copy card</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="photocopy"><b>photocopy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#macroform">macroform</a> <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> of <a href="#printing">printed</a> or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> material produced directly on a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> or other copying surface in black-and-white or color, usually by a process called <a href="#xerography">xerography</a>.  <a href="#photocopier">Photocopy machine</a>s are available in most <a href="#library">libraries</a> for making <a href="#hardcopy">hard copies</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> that may not be removed from the premises (<a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s, <a href="#closedreserve">closed reserve</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s,  etc.).  Photocopying is subject to the <a href="#fairuse">fair use</a> provisions of U.S. <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#presphotocopy">preservation photocopy</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a photographic <a href="#copy">copy</a> of an existing photograph, as opposed to a duplicate <a href="#print">print</a> made from the same <a href="#negative">negative</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="photograph"><b>photograph</b></a>
</dt><dd>The unique <a href="#negative">negative</a> image produced on chemically sensitized <a href="#film">film</a>
when it is exposed to light through a focusing lens. Also, the
repeatable positive image printed in any size on light-sensitive <a href="#paper">paper</a> after exposed film has been developed.  <em>Photography</em>
is the science, technology, and art of producing photographic images.
Photographs were originally produced in black-and-white, with or
without subsequent tinting, but color film is used in modern
photography. Synonymous with <em>still</em>.  Compare with <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#photomap">photomap</a>, <a href="#photomontage">photomontage</a>, and <a href="#photomosaic">photomosaic</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, photographs are <a href="#libcollec">collected</a> as original <a href="#print">print</a>s and <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>s.  They are also <a href="#publishing">published</a> as <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s in <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s.  Still photographs are also <a href="#digitization">digitized</a> for use as illustrations in <a href="#document">document</a>s available <a href="#online">online</a> and on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#stockphotograph">stock photograph</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="photogravure"><b>photogravure</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> or <a href="#print">print</a> made from an image <a href="#etching">etched</a> or <a href="#engraving">engraved</a> on a metal <a href="#plate">plate</a> or cylinder by any one of several <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic processes.  Also refers to the <a href="#intaglio">intaglio</a> technique used to <a href="#printing">print</a> such images.  Synonymous with <em>gravure</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="photomap"><b>photomap</b></a>
</dt><dd>An aerial <a href="#photograph">photograph</a> on which <a href="#cartography">cartographic</a> <a href="#information">information</a> is superimposed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="photomontage"><b>photomontage</b></a>
</dt><dd>A creative <a href="#work">work</a> in which several <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, or portions of photographs, are combined to form a single composite image (<a href="#montage">montage</a>).
The effect can be achieved by cutting and pasting together the
component parts, by exposing the same negative several times, or by
combining several negatives in the developing process to produce a
single composite <a href="#print">print</a>.  Compare with <a href="#photomosaic">photomosaic</a>.  
<p>
In <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, a similar effect
is achieved in time, rather than space, by showing a selection of
images in such rapid succession that in the mind of the viewer, they
are associated in a way that gives them meaning not apparent when
viewed separately or at a slower pace. </p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="photomosaic"><b>photomosaic</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#aerialmap">aerial map</a> made by combining several aerial <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s,
or portions of them, in a way that covers a specific area of the
surface of the earth or another celestial body. Compare with <a href="#photomontage">photomontage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="phrase"><b>phrase</b></a>
</dt><dd>In grammar, two or more words that convey a single concept or
thought, or constitute a part of a sentence that does not contain a
subject or predicate. An <em>adjectival phrase</em> is a noun modified by one or more adjectives (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#digitalarchives">digital archives</a> or <a href="#smallpress">small press</a>).  In a <em>prepositional phras</em>e, two words are joined by a preposition (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#gonetopress">gone to press</a> or <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="phylactery"><b>phylactery</b></a>
</dt><dd>A narrow banner or ribbon extending from the mouth or held in the hand of a human figure drawn in a medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, inscribed with the individual's name or words spoken by the person depicted.  This technique of combining <a href="#text">text</a> with <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s survives in contemporary <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>s in the <a href="#balloon">balloon</a>s used to convey speech or thought. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="physicalcarrier"><b>physical carrier</b></a>
</dt><dd>The physical <a href="#medium">medium</a> used to store <a href="#data">data</a>, sound, images, etc., for example, <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a> or <a href="#disk">disk</a> bearing <a href="#information">information</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  The medium may be permanently encased in a protective covering integral to the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, as in a <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a> or <a href="#zipdisk">Zip disk</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="physicaldescrip"><b>physical description</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> (<a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#field">field</a> 300) in which the extent of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is recorded.  For <a href="#book">book</a>s, extent of item includes the number of <a href="#volume">volume</a>s, <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> or <a href="#page">page</a>s, <a href="#column">column</a>s, <a href="#plate">plate</a>s, and the presence of <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, and/or <a href="#accompanying">accompanying material</a>.  The physical description also gives the <a href="#dimensions">dimensions</a> and <a href="#format">format</a> of the item.  In most cases, the physical description of a book (<em>example</em>:  xiv, 508 p. : ill. ; 22 cm.) is shorter than that of a <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> item (<em>example</em>: 3 filmstrips : col.; 35 mm. + 3 sound cassettes + 3 guides).  Synonymous with <a href="#collation">collation</a>.

<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="physicalprocessing"><b>physical processing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The activities carried out by the <a href="#technical">technical processing</a> department of a <a href="#library">library</a> to prepare <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s for use by <a href="#patron">patron</a>s.  The specific techniques used in physical processing depend on the <a href="#format">format</a> of the item.  A <a href="#book">book</a> is usually stamped with at least one <a href="#ownershipmark">ownership mark</a>, <a href="#label">label</a>ed, <a href="#dustjacket">jacketed</a>, and <a href="#barcode">barcoded</a>.  A <a href="#magneticstrip">magnetic strip</a> may also be applied to the item to prevent <a href="#theft">theft</a>.  Physical processing also includes <a href="#mending">mending</a>, <a href="#repairing">repairing</a>, and <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a> in libraries that have an in-house <a href="#bindery">bindery</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#preprocessing">preprocessing</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pianoscore"><b>piano score</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> for solo piano of a vocal, instrumental, or orchestral <a href="#work">work</a>, written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on two <a href="#stave">stave</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pianopart"><b>piano [violin, etc.] conductor part</b></a>
</dt><dd>A performance <a href="#part">part</a> for a specific instrument in an <a href="#ensemblework">ensemble work</a>.  Cues for the other instruments enable the <a href="#performer">performer</a> to conduct while performing.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pica"><b>pica</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typography">typography</a>, a <a href="#standards">standard</a> measurement based on a unit of <a href="#type">type</a> 12 <a href="#point">point</a>s in size (about 4.2 mm or 1/6 inch wide), used to indicate line length and <a href="#spacing">spacing</a>.  On the old-fashioned typewriter, pica was the most common <a href="#typesize">type size</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pickuplocation"><b>pick-up location</b></a>
</dt><dd>The place to which an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> requested on interlibrary, intercampus, or intra-campus loan is delivered and stored until the <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> responds to notification of its arrival, usually the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> or <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> office of the <a href="#library">library</a> from which it was requested.  <a href="#onlinecatalog">Online catalog</a>s that provide an electronic request <a href="#option">option</a> may permit the borrower to specify pick-up location in the initial request.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pictogram"><b>pictogram</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#pictograph">pictograph</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pictograph"><b>pictograph</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sign in the form of a <a href="#picture">picture</a> representing or suggesting the thing signified, for example, a street sign bearing a <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> of a person reading a <a href="#book">book</a> to indicate that a <a href="#library">library</a>
is located in the vicinity. Also refers to a prehistoric drawing made
on a rock surface, such as the side of a cliff or the wall of a cave,
one of the earliest forms of human communication. Synonymous with <em>pictogram</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pictorial"><b>pictorial</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> to refer to a <a href="#book">book</a> with a <a href="#picture">picture</a> on its <a href="#cover">cover</a>, in addition to the one on the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> (if a dust jacket is provided).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pictorialdictionary"><b>pictorial dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#visualdictionary">visual dictionary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pictorialmap"><b>pictorial map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> on which small drawings or <a href="#pictograph">pictograph</a>s
are used to indicate the geographic distribution and/or concentration
of physical features, economic resources, demographic characteristics,
etc. The meaning of the <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s representing the variables is given in the <a href="#legend">legend</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="picture"><b>picture</b></a>
</dt><dd>A two-dimensional visual representation or image large enough
to be easily viewed without magnification, usually rendered in
black-and-white or color on a flat, opaque surface. The <a href="#term">term</a> includes paintings, drawings, art <a href="#print">print</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>s, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s of pictorial matter, etc., and is often used in a generic sense when a more specific word is inappropriate.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>, <a href="#picturefile">picture file</a>, and <a href="#picturelibrary">picture library</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="picturebook"><b>picture book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> consisting mainly of visual <a href="#content">content</a>, with little or no <a href="#text">text</a>, intended mainly for children of preschool age, but sometimes of interest to <a href="#adult">adult</a>s because of the artistic quality of the <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s and/or the originality of the text, often used by children's <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s in <a href="#storytelling">storytelling</a>.  <a href="#publishing">Published</a> in large <a href="#format">format</a>, <a href="#picture">picture</a> books are frequently <a href="#oblong">oblong</a> in shape to give the artist a broader canvas.  Compare with <a href="#picturestorybook">picture storybook</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ameliafrances">Amelia Frances Howard-Gibbon Illustrator's Award</a>, <a href="#caldecott">Caldecott Medal</a>, and <a href="#greenaway">Greenaway Medal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="picturecollec"><b>picture collection</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#picturelibrary">picture library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="picturedictionary"><b>picture dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#visualdictionary">visual dictionary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="picturefile"><b>picture file</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#mounted">mounted</a> or unmounted <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, art <a href="#print">print</a>s, <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s, and other images, usually small enough to be filed in <a href="#folder">folder</a>s and stored in a filing cabinet.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the <a href="#file">file</a>s may be arranged by <a href="#subject">subject</a>, theme, name of artist, or some other characteristic.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#jumbofile">jumbo file</a> and <a href="#verticalfile">vertical file</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="picturelibrary"><b>picture library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> consisting primarily of visual <a href="#document">document</a>s (<a href="#print">print</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, <a href="#postcard">postcard</a>s, <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s, etc.), <a href="#mounted">mounted</a> or unmounted.  The largest collections are maintained by <a href="#nationallib">national libraries</a> and museums.  <a href="#indexing">Indexing</a> is usually limited to a specific collection.  <a href="#digitization">Digitization</a> has made <a href="#picture">picture</a> collections more <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a>.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/rr/print/">Click here</a> to connect to the Prints &amp; Photographs Reading Room at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="picturestorybook"><b>picture storybook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A short <a href="#book">book</a> containing one or more simple <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>s accompanied by <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s coordinated with the <a href="#text">text</a>, intended for children of at least third grade <a href="#readinglevel">reading level</a>.  Compare with <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a> and <a href="#storybook">storybook</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="piece"><b>piece</b></a>
</dt><dd>A fragment or portion of a <a href="#document">document</a> in any <a href="#format">format</a>
that has become detached from the whole by cutting, tearing, breaking,
or some other physical means, accidental or intentional, or as a result
of normal wear and tear. Compare with <a href="#part">part</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the most basic unit of description and <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> that can be retrieved from a <a href="#repository">repository</a> as a separate and distinct entity under its own reference, regardless of <a href="#format">format</a>.  If a file of <a href="#document">document</a>s
is described as a single unit, a document within that file would not be
considered a piece; however, a single document once part of a file,
such as a <a href="#letters">letter</a> or <a href="#memorandum">memorandum</a>, might be a piece provided the file as a whole is not made a unit of description.  
</p><p>
Synonymous in music with a single <a href="#composition">composition</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="piechart"><b>pie chart</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#graph">graph</a>ical representation of statistical <a href="#data">data</a>
in the form of a circle divided into pie-shaped slices, the relative
size of each piece indicating percentage of the whole, a technique used
to show the relative proportions of <a href="#budget">budget</a> <a href="#allocation">allocation</a>s, funding by source, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pierpont"><b>Pierpont Morgan Library</b></a>
</dt><dd>Assembled by the wealthy financier Pierpont Morgan and expanded by his son J. P. Morgan who in 1924 appointed six <a href="#librarytrustee">trustee</a>s to administer it as a <a href="#refcollection">reference</a> <a href="#library">library</a> for scholars, the <b>Pierpont Morgan Library</b> includes approximately 55,000 <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s as well as a priceless <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#cuneiform">cuneiform</a> <a href="#claytablet">clay tablet</a>s, old master drawings and <a href="#print">print</a>s,
coins, and medals. The Library was subsequently incorporated by the
State of New York and dedicated to the use of "learned men of all
countries." <p>
Between 1902 and 1906, the elder Morgan had an Italian
Renaissance-style building constructed adjacent to his residence in New
York City to house the collection. In 1928, an Annex was added and in
1991 the facility doubled in size with the acquisition of the Morgan
townhouse and construction of a garden court to connect the various
parts. <a href="#bibitem">Item</a>s from its collections are selectively <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ed in a small museum associated with the Library.  <a href="http://www.morganlibrary.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>Pierpont Morgan Library</b>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pigskin"><b>pigskin</b></a>
</dt><dd>A tough <a href="#leather">leather</a> made from the skin of a pig, used to <a href="#binding">bind</a> large, heavy <a href="#book">book</a>s because of its strength and <a href="#durability">durability</a>.  The distinctive <a href="#grain">grain</a> of pigskin can be distinguished from <a href="#morocco">morocco</a> by the small, widely-spaced punctures where the bristles were once attached.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pilot"><b>pilot</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small-scale experimental study conducted in advance of a full-scale <a href="#research">research</a>
project to test an initial hypothesis, research design, or methodology,
or to determine whether a large-scale study is necessary. Also, a
preliminary test of a system or solution to determine the feasibility
of implementation on a larger scale.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pin"><b>PIN</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <b>P</b>ersonal <b>I</b>dentification <b>N</b>umber, a code used in automated systems to identify <a href="#authorization">authorized</a> users.  Whether the <b>PIN</b> is created by or issued to the user depends on the policy governing <a href="#access">access</a> to the system.  The practice originated in the banking industry and is used in some <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s to verify that a <a href="#patron">patron</a> is registered to use electronic resources <a href="#restricted">restricted</a> by <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pinyin"><b>pinyin (PY)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A system of writing the Chinese <a href="#language">language</a> in the roman <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>, used by the news <a href="#media">media</a>, by the United States government, and throughout the world.  In 1997, the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> announced its intention to begin converting <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s created in the older Wade-Giles (WG) system to the new pinyin <a href="#standards">standard</a> for <a href="#romanization">romanizing</a> Chinese, a decision that will affect millions of <a href="#authorityrecord">authority record</a>s and is expected to facilitate the international exchange of bibliographic <a href="#data">data</a>.  <a href="http://www.loc.gov/catdir/pinyin/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <em>Library of Congress Pinyin Conversion Project</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="piperoll"><b>pipe roll</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#roll">roll</a> of <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>
used to record the annual audit at exchequer of the King's revenues and
expenses. Of interest primarily to historians, the pipe rolls are the
oldest and longest series of public <a href="#records">records</a> in England, continuing without significant interruption from 1156-1832. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="piracy"><b>piracy</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#copyrightpiracy">copyright piracy</a> and <a href="#pirated">pirated edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pirated"><b>pirated edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in violation of existing <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law, without <a href="#permission">permission</a> of the <a href="#author">author</a> or copyright holder, usually outside the country in which it was originally <a href="#publishing">published</a> to avoid the legal consequences of <a href="#infringement">infringement</a>.  Compare with <a href="#authorizededition">authorized edition</a> and <a href="#unauthorized">unauthorized edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pixel"><b>pixel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#neologism">neologism</a> coined from the <a href="#term">term</a>
"picture element," any one of the tiny dots of uniform illumination
that in the aggregate comprise the image on a television screen or
computer <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>.  Pixels may be <a href="#binary">binary</a>
(black and white) or multivalued to display colors or gradations of a
gray-scale. A pixel on a color screen is a combination of three
dots--blue, green, and red. To see the pixels on your computer monitor,
try wiping the surface of the screen with a clean, damp cloth or
tissue. Synonymous with <em>pel</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bitmap">bitmap</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pla1"><b>PLA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#pla"><b>P</b>ublic <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="placard"><b>placard</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#poster">poster</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="placeindex"><b>place index</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#geographicindex">geographic index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="placename"><b>place name</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#geographicname">geographic name</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="placeofpublication"><b>place of publication</b></a>
</dt><dd>The geographic location in which an <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> is <a href="#issue">issue</a>d, usually given on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> as the city (or city and state) of a <a href="#book">book</a> and sometimes more completely on the <a href="#verso">verso</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, place of publication is one of the <a href="#element">element</a>s recorded in the <a href="#publicationarea">publication, distribution, etc.</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="placesubdivision"><b>place subdivision</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#geographic">geographic subdivision</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="plagiarism"><b>plagiarism</b></a>
