</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>plagiarius</em> meaning "kidnapper."  <a href="#copy">Copy</a>ing or closely imitating the <a href="#work">work</a> of another writer or <a href="#composer">composer</a> with the intention of passing the results off as <a href="#original">original</a>
work. In most colleges and universities, instructors impose serious
penalties on students who plagiarize the works of others. To avoid
plagiarism, it is best to express an idea in one's own words. When it
is necessary to <a href="#paraphrase">paraphrase</a> closely or <a href="#quotation">quote</a>, the <a href="#source">source</a> should be <a href="#cite">cite</a>d in a <a href="#footnote">footnote</a> or <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>.  Submission of a term paper purchased ready-made from an <a href="#online">online</a>
term paper mill is considered plagiarism at most colleges and
universities, and astute professors keep abreast of the latest
techniques for detecting this form of cheating. Compare with <a href="#forgery">forgery</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="plagiary"><b>plagiary</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#work">Work</a> offered as <a href="#original">original</a> which has, in fact, been <a href="#copy">copied</a> (<a href="#plagiarism">plagiarized</a>) from another source, usually without <a href="#permission">permission</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="plan"><b>plan</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large-<a href="#scale">scale</a> (1:5,000 or greater) <a href="#map">map</a>,
usually of a relatively small area such as a university campus, garden,
small park, battlefield, or site on which a building or complex of
buildings stands. An <em>architectural plan</em> shows a building, such as a <a href="#library">library</a>, rather than the ground on which it is situated.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#floorplan">floor plan</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="planimetric"><b>planimetric map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> showing locations and distances on a horizontal plane, with no indication of elevation, as distinct from a <a href="#reliefmap">relief map</a> showing height and/or depth of surface (relative to sea level if the subject is a portion of the surface of the earth).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="plaquette"><b>plaquette</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the French word for a small, thin plate or slab. A small
circular or oval tablet with a design in relief cast in bronze or lead
from a wax mold, originally used during the Renaissance to decorate
boxes and other personal items. According to Geoffrey Glaister, writing
in the <b><em>Encyclopedia of the Book</em></b> (Oak Knoll: 1996), metal dies for casting plaquettes were sometimes used in Italian <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> of the 16th century to stamp designs in relief on <a href="#leather">leather</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>s, which were subsequently hand-painted.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cameobinding">cameo binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="plat"><b>plat</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#diagram">diagram</a> or <a href="#map">map</a> drawn to <a href="#scale">scale</a>, showing boundaries, subdivisions, and other important <a href="#data">data</a> for a relatively small piece of land, established by survey, usually for legal purposes.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="plate"><b>plate</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#illustration">Illustrative</a> matter in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> of different quality <a href="#paper">paper</a> than the <a href="#text">text</a>, with the reverse often <a href="#blank">blank</a> or bearing a descriptive <a href="#legend">legend</a>.  Plates are usually <a href="#insert">insert</a>ed in the <a href="#section">section</a>s after <a href="#gathering">gathering</a>,
distributed throughout the text or in one or more groups. Because they
are not integral to the gathering, plates are excluded from the <a href="#pagination">pagination</a>; however, they are usually numbered in <a href="#romannumeral">roman</a> or <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s and listed in order of appearance in a separate part of the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>.  In the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> created to represent an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, the number of leaves or pages of plates is indicated in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a>, following extent of text.  Compare with <a href="#cut">cut</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#colorplate">color plate</a>, <a href="#doubleplate">double plate</a>, <a href="#interleaving">interleaving</a>, and <a href="#monochromeplate">monochrome plate</a>.
<p>
Originally, a flat piece of wood or sheet of metal used to print, <a href="#embossed">emboss</a>, or <a href="#engraving">engrave</a> a design, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, or image on <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>, or some other <a href="#printing">printing</a> surface.  In modern printing, photomechanical plates are used to print both text and illustrations. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="platform"><b>platform</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally referred to a specific type of computer <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> architecture, but the <a href="#term">term</a> now includes both the hardware and <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> installed on the <a href="#centralproc">CPU</a>, usually for a model or entire family of computers (<em>examples</em>:  <a href="#windows">Windows</a>, <a href="#macintosh">Macintosh</a>, <a href="#unix">UNIX</a>).  <em>Cross-platform</em> refers to <a href="#device">device</a>s, <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s, and <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#format">format</a>s designed to function on more than one type of computer system.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="play"><b>play</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> in <a href="#prose">prose</a> or <a href="#verse">verse</a> that presents a <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>
in words and action intended for live performance on a stage by a cast
of players. In the earliest known dramas, performed at religious
festivals in ancient Greece, a clear distinction was maintained between
<a href="#comedy">comedy</a> and <a href="#tragedy">tragedy</a>.  Plays are written for <a href="#adult">adult</a>s or children by a <em>playwright</em>, usually in one or more major divisions called <a href="#act">act</a>s.  When <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#collection">collection</a>s, they are <a href="#index">index</a>ed by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>, and dramatic style in <b><em>Play Index</em></b> published by <a href="#hwwilson">H. W. Wilson</a>.  Compare with <a href="#screenplay">screenplay</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#actingedition">acting edition</a>, <a href="#closetdrama">closet drama</a>, <a href="#masque">masque</a>, <a href="#melodrama">melodrama</a>, <a href="#miracleplay">miracle play</a>, <a href="#moralityplay">morality play</a>, <a href="#mysteryplay">mystery play</a>, <a href="#oneactplay">one-act play</a>, <a href="#teleplay">teleplay</a>, <a href="#thesisplay">thesis play</a>, and <a href="#script">script</a>.  
<p>
In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the emphasis or attention given a news story or <a href="#article">article</a> by virtue of its position in the <a href="#publication">publication</a> (front or back), placement on the <a href="#page">page</a> (top or bottom), or <a href="#typography">typographical</a> treatment (<em>played up</em> or <em>played down</em>).  Also, to operate any <a href="#device">device</a> designed to receive <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> signals (radio or television) or reproduce <a href="#soundrecording">sound recorded</a> on any <a href="#medium">medium</a> (<a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>, <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a>, <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>, <a href="#videotape">videotape</a>, etc.).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#playback">playback</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="playback"><b>playback</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any recording heard or viewed as soon as it is produced,
usually to enable the performers, producers, etc., to evaluate its
quality and select the version to be used for manufacture and
distribution. In a more general sense, the reproduction of sounds
and/or images from the <a href="#medium">medium</a> on which they are recorded (<a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>, <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a>, <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>, <a href="#videotape">videotape</a>, <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>, etc.).  A <em>playback device</em> is capable of reproducing audio and/or video, but is not designed for recording.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="playingspeed"><b>playing speed</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>, the speed at which the carrier of a message recorded in a specific <a href="#medium">medium</a> must be operated to reproduce the sound intended by the manufacturer, for example, 33 1/3 <a href="#rpm">rpm</a> for a <a href="#longplaying">long-playing</a> <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>, or 1 7/8 <a href="#ips">ips</a> for an <a href="#analog">analog</a> <a href="#audiocassette">audiocassette</a>.  Compare with <a href="#projectionspeed">projection speed</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="playingtime"><b>playing time</b></a>
</dt><dd>The duration of a <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#media">media</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> that requires equipment for <a href="#playback">playback</a> (<a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>, <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>, etc.).  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, playing time is given under <a href="#extentofitem">extent of item</a> in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, as stated on the item.  If not readily ascertainable, an approximate length is given.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="playwright"><b>playwright</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#author">author</a> of a dramatic <a href="#work">work</a> written to be read (<a href="#closetdrama">closet drama</a>) or performed live on a stage, whose name is entered in the <a href="#statementof">statement of responsibility</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of an <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the work.  The best-known example is William Shakespeare, whose <a href="#play">play</a>s are still performed and <a href="#adaptation">adapted</a> around the world, more than 400 years after he wrote them.  Synonymous with <em>dramatist</em>.  Compare with <a href="#screenwriter">screenwriter</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#director">director</a> and <a href="#performer">performer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="plot"><b>plot</b></a>
</dt><dd>The organization of incidents or episodes in a <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#work">work</a> (<a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>) in a sequence that unfolds to the <a href="#reader">reader</a> or viewer the relationship between <a href="#character">character</a> and events.  Most literary plots present a struggle between opposing forces leading to a conclusion or <em>denouement</em> in which the <a href="#author">author</a> employs an element of suspense to heighten dramatic effect.  Complicated plots may include one or more <a href="#subplot">subplot</a>s.  To encourage <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to read the <a href="#original">original</a> work, <a href="#library">libraries</a> do not as a rule purchase resources that provide <a href="#synopsis">synopses</a> or <a href="#plotsummary">plot summaries</a> of <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#setting">setting</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="plotsummary"><b>plot summary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A concise account of the sequence of events or incidents in a fairly long <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#work">work</a> (<a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>, <a href="#epic">epic</a> <a href="#poetry">poem</a>, etc.).  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> do not, as a matter of <a href="#collecdevelpolicy">policy</a>, <a href="#selection">select</a> <a href="#series">series</a> such as <b><em>Cliff Notes</em></b> and <b><em>Masterplots</em></b> which provide <a href="#plot">plot</a> <a href="#summary">summaries</a> of <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s, because they are too easily used by students to avoid reading assignments.  Synonymous with <em>synopsis</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="plr"><b>PLR</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#publiclending"><b>P</b>ublic <b>L</b>ending <b>R</b>ight</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="plug"><b>plug</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#slang">slang</a> term used in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> to refer to a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> that does not sell.  To "plug" a <a href="#book">book</a> is to attempt to boost sales and <a href="#readership">readership</a> by praising its strengths and ignoring or downplaying its weaknesses.  Such an endorsement may be unsolicited by the <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#puff">puff</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="plugin"><b>plug-in</b></a>
</dt><dd>An easy-to-install supplementary <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> that extends the capability of a major <a href="#software">software</a> package, for example, an <a href="#application">application</a> added to a <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> to enable it to support a specific form of <a href="#content">content</a> (<a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s and animation, <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a>, <a href="#videorecording">video</a>, etc.).  Although they are integrated into the main <a href="#html">HTML</a> <a href="#file">file</a>, browser plug-ins require a separate <a href="#window">window</a>.  <a href="http://wp.netscape.com/plugins/index.html">Click here</a> to view the <em><a href="#netscape">Netscape</a></em> list of browser plug-ins.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ply"><b>ply</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single thickness or layer of <a href="#paper">paper</a> or fiber, laminated or pressed together to build up heavier sheets, as in certain types of <a href="#fiberboard">board</a>.
Thickness is normally indicated by the number of layers (2-ply, 3-ply,
etc.). Also refers to one of the twisted strands that make up the <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> <a href="#thread">thread</a> used in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pochoir"><b>pochoir</b></a> 
</dt><dd>From the French word meaning "stencil."  A method of hand <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> used primarily in <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a>s in which color is applied by dabbing <a href="#ink">ink</a> or paint on a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>,
metal, or celluloid from which a design has been cut, to produce an
uneven hand-crafted effect. The same technique can be used to add color
to a preprinted design. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pocket"><b>pocket</b></a>
</dt><dd>A receptacle for loose <a href="#pocketpart">part</a>s (<a href="#supplement">supplement</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, music parts, etc.) made from a piece of stiff <a href="#paper">paper</a> or fabric pasted inside the front or back <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bookpocket">book pocket</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pocketcomputer"><b>pocket computer</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#pda">personal digital assistant (PDA)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pocketdictionary"><b>pocket dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> of the words of a <a href="#language">language</a>, <a href="#publishing">published</a> in inexpensive <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>.
Most contain no more than 30,000 to 55,000 words and are small enough
to be carried conveniently in a pocket. Some include a <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Pocket Oxford Dictionary and Thesaurus</em></b>).  Foreign <a href="#languagedictionary">language dictionaries</a> are often published in small <a href="#format">format</a> for the convenience of students and travelers.  Compare with <a href="#deskdictionary">desk dictionary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pocketedition"><b>pocket edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small, inexpensive portable <a href="#octavo">octavo</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>, usually no larger than 6 3/4 x 4 1/4 inches in size, called a <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> when <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pocketpart"><b>pocket part</b></a>
</dt><dd>A separately <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#supplement">supplement</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#limpbinding">limp</a> or <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s for insertion in a <a href="#pocket">pocket</a> inside the front or back cover of a previously published <a href="#book">book</a>.  Pocket parts are used mainly to update law books and other <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s.  Also refers to separately <a href="#printing">printed</a> material, such as a <a href="#map">map</a> or music <a href="#score">score</a>, or to <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> material (usually a <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a> or <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>), inserted in a pocket inside the cover of a book by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the presence of a pocket part is indicated in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pocketvolume"><b>pocket volume</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binder">binder</a>'s <a href="#term">term</a> for a <a href="#book">book</a> that has a <a href="#cover">cover</a> made with an inside <a href="#pocket">pocket</a> to hold one or more <a href="#unbound">unbound</a> <a href="#pocketpart">pocket part</a>s, such as a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>, <a href="#map">map</a>, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="poeticlicense"><b>poetic license</b></a>
</dt><dd>The freedom of a writer of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> to alter historical facts in the interest of producing a more interesting or compelling <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>,
for example, Shakespeare's use of the Holinshed account of the murder
of an earlier King Duff by Donwald as source material for the murder of
Duncan in <b><em>Macbeth</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="poetlaureate"><b>poet laureate</b></a>
</dt><dd>Literally, a poet "crowned with laurel." An honorific <a href="#title">title</a> and stipend, usually bestowed by a university or head of state on an eminent poet who is expected to compose <a href="#poetry">poems</a> commemorating dates and occasions of national importance, and is called upon to read or recite from his or her own <a href="#work">work</a>s, and from the works of other poets, on special occasions.  
<p>
Poet laureates were originally appointed for life as officers of the
royal household in England where they were expected to compose poems
for state occasions, but the post is now conferred mainly as a mark of
distinction. In the United States, the <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/poetry/laureate.html">Poet Laureate Consultant in Poetry</a> is appointed annually by the <a href="#librariancongress">Librarian of Congress</a> and receives a stipend.  <a href="http://www.cftech.com/BrainBank/OTHERREFERENCE/LITERATURE/PoetLaurt.html">Click here</a> to view a list of English and American poet laureates.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="poetry"><b>poetry</b></a>
</dt><dd>A spoken or written <a href="#work">work</a> consciously created in metrical form by a speaker or writer who has a gift for imaginative and <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ic use of <a href="#language">language</a>.  Also, the art of metrical <a href="#composition">composition</a>,
intended to express sublime thought and emotion, and give aesthetic
pleasure through the ingenious combination of well-chosen words and
rhythmic phrases (sound and sense). Poetry is classified by form (<a href="#ballad">ballad</a>, <a href="#eclogue">eclogue</a>, <a href="#elegy">elegy</a>, <a href="#epic">epic</a>, <a href="#idyl">idyl</a>, <a href="#idyll">idyll</a>, <a href="#lai">lai</a>, <a href="#limerick">limerick</a>, <a href="#lyric">lyric</a>, <a href="#ode">ode</a>, <a href="#sonnet">sonnet</a>, etc.) and often <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#anthology">anthology</a>.  Poems in <a href="#collection">collection</a>s are <a href="#index">index</a>ed by <a href="#firstline">first-line</a>, last-line, and <a href="#title">title</a> in <b><em>The Columbia Granger's Index to Poetry in Anthologies</em></b>.  <a href="http://www.loc.gov/poetry/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em>Poetry &amp; Literature Center</em> at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  Compare with <a href="#prose">prose</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#poetlaureate">poet laureate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="point"><b>point</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a unit of measurement
created in 1737 by the French typographer Pierre Fournier, revised by
Firmin-Didot in 1770, and formalized in the United States in the 1870's
for indicating the body size (height and width) of <a href="#type">type</a> and other elements used in <a href="#typography">typography</a> (<a href="#rule">rule</a>s, <a href="#border">border</a>s,
etc.). One point equals approximately 1/72 or 0.013837 of an inch and
one inch equals 72.25433 points. Before the point system was developed,
descriptive terms were used for the various <a href="#typesize">type size</a>s:  nonpareil (6-point), brevier (8-point), <a href="#pica">pica</a> (12-point), etc.  Also, a unit for measuring the thickness of <a href="#paper">paper</a> and <a href="#board">board</a>, one point equal to one-thousandth (1/1000) of an inch.
<p>
In <a href="#analyticalbibliog">historical bibliography</a> and <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, a specific characteristic or peculiarity of <a href="#printing">printing</a> or <a href="#binding">binding</a> (usually a minor defect or error) by which <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a> can be distinguished, or priority of <a href="#issue">issue</a> established within an <a href="#edition">edition</a> that has undergone multiple <a href="#printing">printing</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fingerprint">fingerprint</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pointille"><b>pointille</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the French verb <em>pointiller</em> meaning "to mark with dots."  In hand <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a form of <a href="#tooling">tooling</a> used in <a href="#leatherbound">leather-bound</a> <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a>s to produce delicate designs composed of tiny, closely spaced dots, usually highlighted in <a href="#goldleaf">gold</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pointofaccess"><b>point of access</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pointofservice"><b>point of service</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pointofuse"><b>point-of-use instruction</b></a>
</dt><dd>An explanation of how to use a specific resource or <a href="#research">research</a> tool (<a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, etc.), provided to a <a href="#library">library</a> user orally, <a href="#online">online</a>, or in <a href="#print">print</a> at the time and place assistance is needed, usually by a <a href="#publicservices">public services</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or other trained expert.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#helpscreen">help screen</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="polaire"><b>polaire</b></a>
</dt><dd>The sturdily-made leather sachel or case used by monks, <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>s, and other literate persons of the medieval period for transporting <a href="#manuscriptbook">manuscript book</a>s.
Most were plain, but those custom-made for persons of wealth or
prominence sometimes bore an ensignia or other distinctive design
stamped in relief.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="polarity"><b>polarity</b></a>
</dt><dd>The relationship of the colors or tones of a <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic image to those of the actual object or scene captured on <a href="#film">film</a>--<em>positive</em> if the image reflects the original, <em>negative</em> if the colors/tones are reversed.  A <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> composed of more than one photographic image may have <em>mixed polarity</em>.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used in <a href="#reprography">reprography</a> to describe the reversal of tones from positive to negative, or vice versa. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="polemic"><b>polemic</b></a>
</dt><dd>An argument or debate on a controversial subject. Also refers
to a person inclined to argument or debate. A skilled debater or writer
of polemical <a href="#work">work</a>s is a <em>polemicist</em>.  The art or practice of disputation is called <em>polemics</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="politcorrect"><b>political correctness (PC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> that came into widespread use
during the early 1990's to describe the influence of liberal political
views on American culture, particularly speech and other forms of
social behavior, for example, the replacement of the title "chairman"
with "chairperson" to avoid the appearance of gender discrimination
(this particular problem has not arisen in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#professionalism">profession</a> because the <a href="#term">term</a>
"librarian" is gender-neutral). In literary studies, the debate
centered around whether to abolish the traditional canon, dominated by <a href="#literarywork">work</a>s
written primarily by males of European descent. Some universities have
side-stepped this dilemma by making the debate over political
correctness part of the curriculum. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="politicalmap"><b>political map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> showing the political boundaries of
nations and states, the political affiliations (formal or informal) of
people living within a given geographic area, official names of capital
cities, voting districts, etc. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="politicalname"><b>political name</b></a>
</dt><dd>The legally designated name of a geographic feature, location, area, or public entity, which may change as governments change (<em>example</em>:  St. Petersburg to Petrograd to Leningrad to St. Petersburg).  Compare with <a href="#geographicname">geographic name</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="poll"><b>poll</b></a>
</dt><dd>Statistical <a href="#data">data</a> produced by surveying
selected individuals on their opinions concerning an issue or event,
usually reported by the institution that conducted or commissioned the <a href="#survey">survey</a>, for example, the <a href="#annual">annual</a> <b><em>Gallup Poll</em></b> of American public opinion, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of large <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and  <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>.  Sampling methods can influence results.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="polyester"><b>polyester</b></a>
</dt><dd>A clear, flexible plastic, used as a base in <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic <a href="#film">film</a>, for <a href="#encapsulation">encapsulation</a>, and to protect <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s.  Polyester is chemically stable, has high tensile strength, and is very resistant to moisture and other chemicals.  <a href="#tradename">Trade name</a>s are Mylar and Melinex.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="polyethylene"><b>polyethylene</b></a>
</dt><dd>A chemically stable, somewhat flexible, translucent waxy plastic with a low melting point, used in <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> to protect <a href="#brittle">brittle</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> because it is resistant to <a href="#acidic">acid</a>.  Also used as a <a href="#coated">coating</a> in <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a> to provide <a href="#finish">finish</a> and add strength.  Less expensive than <a href="#polyester">polyester</a>.  Non-biodegradable.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="polyglot"><b>polyglot</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#series">series</a> of books containing the same <a href="#text">text</a> in several <a href="#language">language</a>s, sometimes arranged in <a href="#paralleltexts">parallel</a> <a href="#column">column</a>s across facing <a href="#page">page</a>s.  The polyglot Bibles first <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the 16th century are a prime example.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#paralleltitle">parallel title</a> and <a href="#polyglotdictionary">polyglot dictionary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="polyglotdictionary"><b>polyglot dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the words of a <a href="#language">language</a> with a <a href="#translation">translation</a> of each word into two or more other languages (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Multilingual Dictionary of Printing and Publishing</em></b> edited by Alan Isaacs).  Polyglot dictionaries are usually shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>.  Compare with <a href="#languagedictionary">language dictionary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="polypropylene"><b>polypropylene</b></a>
</dt><dd>A stiff, hard, heat-resistant, chemically stable plastic that can be extruded and cast.  It has better clarity than <a href="#polyethylene">polyethylene</a> and less static charge than <a href="#polyester">polyester</a>.  Polypropylene self-<a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> protective <a href="#book">book</a> covers can be ordered from <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s, pre-shaped, with peel-off <a href="#paper">paper</a> backing.  Also used as an additive in <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>.  Non-biodegradable.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="polysemy"><b>polysemy</b></a>
</dt><dd>Having multiple meanings, some of which may overlap.  By way of example, the <em><a href="#oed">Oxford English Dictionary</a></em> gives fourteen <a href="#definition">definition</a>s of the word "power."  In <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> and <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, a <a href="#parenthetical">parenthetical qualifier</a> is usually added to a polysemic <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> for <a href="#semantics">semantic</a> clarification, as in the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject heading</a>s <b>Power (Electronics)</b> and  <b>Power (Social sciences)</b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#homograph">homograph</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="polyvinylacetate"><b>polyvinyl acetate (PVA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A transparent, water-based chemical <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> used in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>
to produce a very strong bond. Applied cold, it is allowed to dry
naturally for maximum strength and flexibility. PVA is not as strong as
<a href="#hotmelt">hot-melt</a> adhesive, but it is more flexible, longer-lasting, and more resistant to <a href="#coldcrack">cold-crack</a>.  For these reasons, it is used in <a href="#otabind">Otabind</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="polyvinylchloride"><b>polyvinyl chloride (PVC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of plastic that has high chemical resistance but is not chemically stable.  Because it emits hydrochloric <a href="#acidic">acid</a> as it ages, it has very limited application in the <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> of <a href="#document">document</a>s made of <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  The volatile plasticizers that make it flexible are hazardous to humans. Non-biodegradable.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>vinyl</em>.  Compare with <a href="#polyester">polyester</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="popularedition"><b>popular edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on poorer quality <a href="#paper">paper</a> than the <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>, sometimes without <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s and in a less sturdy <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> or <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>, usually sold at a lower price.  Some <a href="#bookclubedition">book club edition</a>s fall into this category.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="popularfiction"><b>popular fiction</b></a>
</dt><dd>Serious <a href="#work">work</a>s of <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, widely read when first <a href="#publishing">published</a> and superior in quality to <a href="#pulpfiction">pulp fiction</a>, but not as enduring as literary fiction (<em>example</em>:  the <a href="#novel">novel</a>s of Catherine Cookson).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bestseller">bestseller</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="popularname"><b>popular name</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened or simplified form of the official name by which a company, <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>, or other <a href="#corporatebody">corporate entity</a> is known (<em>example</em>:  "the Fed" for Federal Reserve Board).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="popularpress"><b>popular press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publisher">publishing house</a> that <a href="#issue">issue</a>s <a href="#publication">publication</a>s for the mass market, sold at news stands and in supermarkets and chain stores.  Compare with <a href="#tradepublisher">trade publisher</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#massmarket">mass-market paperback</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="poprefbook"><b>popular reference book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#refbook">reference book</a> intended primarily for the general <a href="#reader">reader</a>, as opposed to one <a href="#publishing">published</a> mainly for use in <a href="#library">libraries</a> and related institutions.  Unlike specialized reference <a href="#work">work</a>s which must be ordered from the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, popular reference <a href="#title">title</a>s are sold retail in <a href="#tradebookstore">trade bookstore</a>s.  The category includes <a href="#almanac">almanac</a>s, <a href="#deskdictionary">desk dictionaries</a> and <a href="#thesaurus">thesauri</a>, foreign <a href="#languagedictionary">language dictionaries</a>, <a href="#worldatlas">world atlas</a>es, <a href="#roadatlas">road atlas</a>es, medical guides and <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s, <a href="#fieldguide">field guide</a>s, income tax guides, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="popupbook"><b>pop-up book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of novelty <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a> containing cut-out <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s ingeniously folded so that they spring up in three dimensions from the surface of the <a href="#page">page</a> when the <a href="#book">book</a> is opened, and fold back down when the page is turned or the <a href="#cover">cover</a>s are closed.  Because they require special assembly, pop-up books are usually more expensive than standard children's <a href="#picture">picture book</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pornography"><b>pornography</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the ancient Greek <em>porne</em> ("prostitute") and <em>graphos</em> ("writing").  <a href="#work">Work</a>s of no artistic value in which sexuality is depicted with the conscious intent to arouse sexual desire.  The terms <em>soft core</em> and <em>hard core</em> indicate degree of licentiousness.  Ownership is limited to <a href="#privatelib">private</a> and <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>.  Compare with <a href="#erotica">erotica</a> and <a href="#obscenity">obscenity</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#banned">banned book</a>, <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>, and <a href="#expurgated">expurgated</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="port"><b>port</b></a>
</dt><dd>A physical connection on a computer or <a href="#network">network</a> <a href="#device">device</a>, usually in the form of a socket, that allows <a href="#data">data</a> to be received from and transmitted to an external device.  The number of available ports may determine the number of <a href="#simultaneous">simultaneous user</a>s who may <a href="#access">access</a> a system such as an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>.  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> reserve a fixed number of ports for local use.  Any remaining ports are made available for <a href="#remoteaccess">remote access</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="portability"><b>portability</b></a>
</dt><dd>The capacity of an <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>, <a href="#proglang">programming language</a>, or <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> to operate independently of a specific <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> <a href="#platform">platform</a>,
usually achieved by designing a different version for each platform, or
by building in mechanisms for switching between platforms or converting
from one type of machine to another. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pdf"><b>Portable Document Format (PDF)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#format">format</a> used for <a href="#page">page</a> description in the <em><a href="#adobeacrobat">Adobe Acrobat</a></em> <a href="#document">document</a> exchange <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>.  In <em>Acrobat</em>, the <em>PDF Writer</em> converts most <a href="#dos">DOS</a>, <a href="#windows">Windows</a>, <a href="#unix">UNIX</a>, and <a href="#macintosh">Macintosh</a> <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s into PDF format.  Since the original <a href="#font">font</a>s are embedded in the PDF file, there is no need to install them on the receiving machine.  With <em>Adobe Acrobat Reader</em> installed at the receiving end, PDF files can be displayed and <a href="#printing">printed</a> in original format.
<p>
In <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, a "native PDF" <a href="#file">file</a> is received in a <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a> from the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, reproducing the appearance of the original <a href="#text">text</a> and images with a high degree of clarity.  A "scanned PDF" file is created by running a <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> of the text through a high-quality <a href="#scanner">scanner</a>.  The result is then examined closely for <a href="#legibility">legibility</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="portal"><b>portal</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, a general purpose <a href="#website">Web site</a>, offering a wide variety of resources and services, such as news, weather, <a href="#directory">directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a>, <a href="#www">Web</a> searching, free <a href="#email">e-mail</a> accounts, <a href="#chat">chat</a> groups, <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>s, <a href="#online">online</a> shopping, and <a href="#link">link</a>s to other Web sites (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#aol">America Online</a>).
However, the term is increasingly applied to Web sites that offer such
services only within a particular industry, occupation, or <a href="#field">field</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://acqweb.library.vanderbilt.edu/">AcqWeb</a>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#libraryportal">library portal</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="portfolio"><b>portfolio</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#container">container</a> designed to hold <a href="#loose">loose</a> papers, such as drawings, <a href="#print">print</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#diagram">diagram</a>s, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, etc., consisting of two rigid <a href="#board">board</a>s joined at the <a href="#spine">spine</a> by a wide band of cloth, with ties attached to the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> and sometimes to the other edges to prevent <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s from sliding out.  Also refers to the <a href="#contents">contents</a> of such a case.
<p>
In art, a collection of the <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s of an artist, usually selected to illustrate range of talent.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used in reference to the entire body of an artist's work.
</p><p>
In business, a <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> list
of all the securities (stocks, bonds, etc.) owned by an investor or
financial institution. Publicly held corporations are required by law
to disclose such holdings.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="portrait"><b>portrait</b></a>
</dt><dd>The representational likeness of a person (especially the face), <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ed or drawn, painted, or sculpted from life.  Most full-length <a href="#biography">biographies</a> and some biographical <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s include at least one portrait of the <em>biographee</em>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>port.</em>  Compare with <a href="#caricature">caricature</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#authorportrait">author portrait</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, <a href="#leaf">leaf</a>, or <a href="#book">book</a> of a <a href="#height">height</a> approximately 25% greater than its <a href="#width">width</a>, the norm in <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>long way</em>.  Compare with <a href="#oblong">oblong</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#narrow">narrow</a> and <a href="#square">square</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="position"><b>position</b></a>
</dt><dd>The duties for which an employee is responsible in an organization, usually described in detail in the <a href="#positiondescrip">position description</a> used in the hiring process, along with the minimum <a href="#qualification">qualification</a>s considered necessary for satisfactory performance.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, a position usually corresponds to a specific function or group of related functions (<em>cataloger</em>, <em>instruction librarian</em>, <em>interlibrary loan assistant</em>,
etc.) and is associated with a specific rate or range of compensation.
As functional needs change, so do the duties and responsibilities
required of a specific position. <em>Digital services librarian</em> is an example of a comparatively new position.  Compare with <a href="#rank">rank</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="positiondescrip"><b>position description</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written statement providing a general description of the duties and responsibilities associated with a specific <a href="#position">position</a> in an organization, the minimum <a href="#qualification">qualification</a>s considered necessary for satisfactory performance, and the <a href="#rank">rank</a>, compensation, and <a href="#benefits">benefits</a> which the prospective employer is prepared to offer, for use in hiring.  Compare with <a href="#jobdescrip">job description</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="positiontitle"><b>position title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The official name associated with a set of duties and
responsibilities within an organization, assigned to an employee at the
time of hiring. Each <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> develops its own set of titles for professional <a href="#position">position</a>s, which typically include: <a href="#accessservices">access services</a> or <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> librarian, <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> librarian, <a href="#archivist">archivist</a>, <a href="#bibliographer">bibliographer</a>, <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>, children's librarian, <a href="#collecmanagement">collection mangement</a> specialist, <a href="#digital">digital</a> or <a href="#onlineservices">online services</a> librarian, <a href="#bi">instruction</a> librarian, <a href="#mediaspecialist">media specialist</a>, <a href="#outreach">outreach</a> services librarian, <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a>, <a href="#serial">serials</a> librarian, <a href="#systemslibrarian">systems librarian</a>, <a href="#yaservices">young adult services</a> librarian, <a href="#librarydirector">library director</a>,
etc. As functions are added and dropped, a position title may be
changed to reflect current conditions, usually at the time a new person
is hired to fill the position.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="postbinding"><b>post binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of expandable <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> <a href="#binder">binder</a> in which screw posts, usually made of metal or plastic, are inserted through holes pre-punched in the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> to allow them to be individually added or removed.  Often used for materials that require regular <a href="#update">updating</a>.  Post bindings do not <a href="#openability">open flat</a> as do <a href="#ringbinding">ring binding</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="postcard"><b>postcard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#picture">picture</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>, or collage of images, with or without accompanying <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#caption">caption</a>, <a href="#printing">printed</a>
on card stock and intended for delivery by post, usually with space on
the back for the sender to fill in the name and street address of the
recipient and add a brief message. Postcards are usually of standard
size (4 x 6 inches in the U.S. and most other countries) but panoramic
landscapes may require a larger <a href="#format">format</a>.  Considered <a href="#ephemera">ephemera</a>, postcards are sometimes <a href="#archives">archived</a> with the <a href="#memorabilia">memorabilia</a> of important individuals.  Very old or <a href="#rarity">rare</a> postcards, and those commemorating important historical events, may be of value to <a href="#collectible">collectors</a>.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> <a href="#cataloging">catalog</a> postcards as <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> materials.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="postcoordinate"><b>post-coordinate indexing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> in which the <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s assigned to <a href="#document">document</a>s represent simple concepts which the user must combine at the time of <a href="#search">search</a>ing to <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> <a href="#information">information</a> on a complex <a href="#subject">subject</a> (<em>example</em>:  "Annotation" + "Bibliography" for "Annotated bibliography").  Synonymous with <em>coordinate indexing</em> and <em>post-coordination</em>.  Compare with <a href="#precoordinate">pre-coordinate indexing</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#syntax">syntax</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="postdated"><b>postdated</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#bibitem">item</a> bearing a <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> <em>later</em> than the actual date of publication.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR</a></em>, the date given on the item is used in <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> even if it is known to be incorrect, and the correct date is added in <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b>1959 [1958]</b>), with an explanatory <a href="#note">note</a> if necessary.  The opposite of <em>antedated</em>.  Also spelled <em>post-dated</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="poster"><b>poster</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large single <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of heavy <a href="#paper">paper</a> or cardboard, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on one side only, with or without <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, to advertise a product/service or <a href="#publicity">publicize</a> a forthcoming event (meeting, concert, dramatic performance, etc.), intended for display on a <a href="#bulletinboard">bulletin board</a>, <a href="#kiosk">kiosk</a>, wall, or other suitable surface.  Poster design is a branch of the <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> arts made famous by the 19th century French artist Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec and his contemporaries.  Synonymous with <em>placard</em>.  Compare with <a href="#handbill">handbill</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ephemera">ephemera</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="posthumous"><b>posthumous</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> for the first time after the death of the <a href="#author">author</a>.  Works left <a href="#unfinished">unfinished</a> at the time of an author's death may be <a href="#continuation">continued</a> by another writer, for example, the completion of Dorothy L. Sayers' unfinished <a href="#detective">detective</a> <a href="#novel">novel</a> <b><em>Thrones, Dominations</em></b> by Jill Paton Walsh (1998).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#redaction">redaction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="posting"><b>posting</b></a>
</dt><dd>The assignment in <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> of a <a href="#heading">heading</a> to an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, or a <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> to a <a href="#document">document</a> in <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, based on its <a href="#content">content</a>, form, or other distinguishing feature.  In some <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#thesaurus">thesauri</a>, the number of times an authorized <a href="#term">term</a> has been assigned is indicated in a <a href="#postingsnote">postings note</a> included in the <a href="#entry">entry</a> for the term.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="postingsnote"><b>postings note</b></a>
</dt><dd>A note added in the <a href="#entry">entry</a> for a <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> in a <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">term</a>s, indicating the <a href="#number">number</a> of times the <a href="#term">term</a> has been assigned as a <a href="#major">major</a> or <a href="#minor">minor</a> descriptor to <a href="#document">document</a>s <a href="#index">index</a>ed, usually since its addition to the authorized list.  The note gives the user some idea of the <a href="#number">number</a> of entries a <a href="#search">search</a> for the term is likely to <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a>.  A small number of postings might suggest a <a href="#searchstrategy">search strategy</a> that includes <a href="#relatedterm">related term</a>s or even <a href="#broaderterm">broader term</a>s; a large number might suggest the substitution of one or more <a href="#narrowerterm">narrower term</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="postliminary"><b>postliminary matter</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="postscript"><b>postscript</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sentence or paragraph following the <a href="#signature">signature</a> at the end of a <a href="#letter">letter</a>, or a note written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the close of a <a href="#composition">composition</a>, conveying a further thought or additional <a href="#information">information</a>.  In a letter, the postscript usually follows the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> <em>PS</em>.  In a more general sense, any comment or remark appended as an afterthought in speech or writing.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="posttest"><b>post-test</b></a>
</dt><dd>A quiz or test administered to students following <a href="#bi">instruction</a> in a specific <a href="#library">library</a> skill, to assess the effectiveness of pedagogical methods.  Ideally, it is administered in conjunction with a <a href="#pretest">pretest</a> for purposes of comparison.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="potboiler"><b>potboiler</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> written primarily to earn money for the <a href="#author">author</a> and <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>
("to keep the pot boiling"). Such works are usually of little or no
artistic merit, but financial pressures are rarely absent from the
consideration of writers who have no other source of income,
particularly in the early stages of a literary career. The problem with
<a href="#publishing">publishing</a> such works at the beginning of a
career is that once the author earns a reputation for producing popular
works, any future attempt at serious writing is likely to be met with
skepticism by <a href="#review">review</a>ers, unless a <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a> is used.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pouncing"><b>pouncing</b></a>
</dt><dd>Smoothing a new piece of <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>
with a pumice stone to prepare the surface for writing, or using the
same abrasive technique to remove writing from a previously used piece
of parchment, so that another <a href="#text">text</a> can be written on it. The result of the erasure is called a <a href="#palimpsest">palimpsest</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="powerdown"><b>power down</b></a>
</dt><dd>To turn a computer off at the power switch.  Because <a href="#ram">RAM</a> <a href="#chip">chip</a>s require electrical power, <a href="#data">data</a> will be lost when a computer is powered down unless it is <a href="#save">save</a>d to a <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> (<a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a>, <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>, etc.).
<p>

</p></dd><dt><a name="practicum"><b>practicum</b></a>
</dt><dd>A limited period of hands-on work in a <a href="#library">library</a> or other <a href="#information">information</a> service <a href="#agency">agency</a>, structured to provide an opportunity for a <a href="#novice">novice</a> to relate theory to practical experience, usually in the student's <a href="#field">field</a>(s) of <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>.  Compare with <a href="#internship">internship</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="praeses"><b>praeses</b></a>
</dt><dd>The faculty moderator in a formal academic disputation, responsible for proposing the <a href="#thesis">thesis</a> which the degree <a href="#candidate">candidate</a> (<a href="#respondent">respondent</a>) must defend or oppose.  The praeses is expected to participate with a panel of other faculty members in the ensuing debate.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preamble"><b>preamble</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>prae</em> ("before") and <em>ambulare</em> ("to go").  An introductory statement or <a href="#preface">preface</a> to a written <a href="#document">document</a>, especially a statute or constitution, stating its purpose.  One of the best-known examples is the <em>Preamble to the United States Constitution</em> which establishes the basic principles on which American government is based.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prebinding"><b>prebinding</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#prelibrary">pre-library binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="precedence"><b>precedence order</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the order indicating which one of two or more numbers is to be chosen when the numbers represent different <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>s of a <a href="#subject">subject</a> that cannot be shown in full by <a href="#numberbuilding">number building</a>.  A note (sometimes containing a <a href="#table">table</a> of precedence) always indicates which characteristic is to be selected for <a href="#work">work</a>s covering more than one characteristic.  When the <a href="#notation">notation</a> can be synthesized to show two or more characteristics, it is a matter of <a href="#citationorder">citation order</a> (<em>DDC</em>).  Synonymous with <em>order of precedence</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="precis"><b>precis</b></a>
</dt><dd>A concise <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a> or <a href="#summary">summary</a> that captures the essential thought(s) or idea(s) expressed in a longer <a href="#work">work</a>, and retains something of the original tone and spirit.
<p>
<b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#preserved"><b>PRE</b>served <b>C</b>ontext <b>I</b>ndexing <b>S</b>ystem (PRECIS)</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="precision"><b>precision</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, a measure of <a href="#search">search</a> effectiveness, expressed as the ratio of <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> <a href="#record">record</a>s or <a href="#document">document</a>s retrieved from a <a href="#database">database</a> to the total number retrieved in response to the <a href="#query">query</a>, for example, in a database containing 100 records relevent to the <a href="#topic">topic</a>
"book history," a search retrieving 50 records, 25 of which are
relevant to the topic, would have 50% precision (25/50). Synonymous
with <em>relevance ratio</em>. Compare with  <a href="#recall">recall</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preconference"><b>preconference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A mini-conference scheduled in advance of a longer <a href="#libconference">conference</a>,
usually on the preceding day (or days) for attendees who wish to spend
additional time meeting with colleagues. Most preconferences are
organized around a central theme which may or may not be related to
that of the main conference. The theme is usually addressed by a panel,
rather than a keynote speaker, with break-out sessions on related <a href="#topic">topic</a>s.  <em>Preconferees</em> are normally charged an additional <a href="#fee">fee</a> at registration.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="precoordinate"><b>pre-coordinate indexing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> in which multiple concepts are combined by the indexer to form <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s assigned to <a href="#document">document</a>s to facilitate the <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a> of <a href="#information">information</a> on complex <a href="#subject">subject</a>s (<em>example</em>:
"Libraries and the blind--United States--Directories" instead of
"Libraries" + "Blind" + "United States" + "Directories"). Synonymous
with <em>pre-coordination</em>.  Compare with <a href="#postcoordinate">post-coordinate indexing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="predominantname"><b>predominant name</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#authoritywork">authority work</a>, when a person or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a> is known by more than one name, <a href="#entry">entry</a> is made under the most commonly known name, whether it is the real name or a <a href="#nickname">nickname</a>, <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a>, shortened name, or other form.  Under this rule, the <a href="#work">work</a>s of Samuel Langhorne Clemens are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under <b>Twain, Mark</b>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the predominant name is that which occurs most frequently in a person's works or the works <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by a corporate body, or in <a href="#refbook">reference source</a>s, in that order of preference.  If no predominance is found, the latest form is used.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preface"><b>preface</b></a>
</dt><dd>A preliminary statement at the beginning of a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually written by the <a href="#author">author</a>, stating the origin, <a href="#scope">scope</a>, purpose, plan, and intended <a href="#audience">audience</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a>, and including any afterthoughts and <a href="#acknowledgments">acknowledgments</a> of assistance, usually in the final paragraphs.  When written by a person <em>other</em> than the author, the preliminary statement is called a <a href="#foreword">foreword</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>pref</em>. 
<p>
The preface or foreword is distinct from the <a href="#introduction">introduction</a> which addresses the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the work and prepares the <a href="#reader">reader</a> for the <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> to follow.  When a new <a href="#edition">edition</a> is <a href="#publishing">published</a>, the preface may be rewritten to alert the reader to the extent of additions or changes in the <a href="#text">text</a>, but the introduction usually remains unchanged.  The preface or foreword normally follows the <a href="#dedication">dedication</a> and precedes the introduction in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> of a book. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preferredterm"><b>preferred term</b></a>
</dt><dd>In an <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>, a descriptive word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> selected as an authorized <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> to represent a discrete <a href="#subject">subject</a> or concept.  For the convenience of the user, <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s to the preferred form are made from <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>s and closely related terms, making materials on the same subject <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> at a single <a href="#accesspoint">point</a> in the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>.  Preferred terms and cross-references are usually listed in a <a href="#printing">printed</a> or <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> to assist users in planning <a href="#searchstrategy">search strategy</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prefix"><b>prefix</b></a>
</dt><dd>The code at the beginning of an <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a> that indicates the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> of the resource located at the address.  There are <em>six</em> main prefixes: 
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>ftp://</b> - <a href="#ftp">FTP</a> <a href="#directory">directory</a> of <a href="#download">download</a>able <a href="#data">data</a> or <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s
</dd><dd><b>gopher://</b> - <a href="#gopher">Gopher</a> <a href="#server">server</a>
</dd><dd><b>http://</b> - <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a> <a href="#webpage">page</a>
</dd><dd><b>mailto:</b> - Electronic mail (<a href="#email">e-mail</a>)
</dd><dd><b>news:</b> - Usenet <a href="#newsgroup">newsgroup</a>
</dd><dd><b>telnet://</b> - <a href="#application">Application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> running on a <a href="#remoteaccess">remote</a> <a href="#host">host</a></dd></dl>
<p>
In a more general sense, any syllable or group of syllables which,
added at the beginning of a word, changes its meaning or creates a new
word. In the word <em>prefix</em>, "pre" is a Latin prefix meaning "before."
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prelibrary"><b>prelibrary binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#binding">binding</a> of <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s to meet a higher <a href="#standard">standard</a> of <a href="#durability">durability</a> than the normal <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#publishersbinding">publisher's binding</a>.  A <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> design similar to that of the original binding is usually preserved on the front <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  In <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, <em>prebinding</em> is used extensively for <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>s which must withstand heavy wear.  <a href="#standards">Standards</a> for prebinding, issued by the <a href="#lbi">Library Binding Institute</a>, include <a href="#oversewing">oversewn</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s, a <a href="#rounding">rounded</a> and <a href="#backing">backed</a> <a href="#spine">spine</a>, and <a href="#hinge">hinge</a>s made of cloth instead of <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> on prebinders is available in the <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>.  Compare with <a href="#libraryedition">library edition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#btsb">Bound To Stay Bound</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preliminaries"><b>preliminaries</b></a>
</dt><dd>A shortened form of <em>preliminary matter</em>.  <b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preliminaryedition"><b>preliminary edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> prior to the final edition, sometimes to allow time for <a href="#criticism">criticism</a> of the <a href="#text">text</a> before the final version is <a href="#publishing">published</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the <a href="#title">title</a> and <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> of a preliminary edition are given in the <a href="#note">note</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of the final edition.  Synonymous with <em>provisional edition</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prelims"><b>prelims</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of <em>preliminaries</em>, a shortened form of <em>preliminary matter</em>.  <b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="premiumbook"><b>premium book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> given as a reward for action taken by the recipient, such as becoming a member of a <a href="#bookclub">book club</a>.  Also refers to a book or other item offered as an inducement, for example, to order a certain volume of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>.  <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s apply the same <a href="#selectioncriteria">selection criteria</a> used in evaluating materials for purchase.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preorder"><b>pre-order searching</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, work done by a bibliographic searcher prior to ordering an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, including a <a href="#search">search</a> of the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> for <a href="#duplicate">duplicate</a> and related <a href="#title">title</a>s; <a href="#verification">verifying</a> the name of the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> and/or <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>, <a href="#listprice">price</a>, availability, and <a href="#standardnumber">standard number</a>; and locating other pertinent <a href="#information">information</a> (terms of <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a>, restrictions on use, etc.).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prepaid"><b>prepaid</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#prepayment">prepayment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prepayment"><b>prepayment</b></a>
</dt><dd>In purchasing, an order for which full payment must be made in advance of <a href="#shipping">shipment</a>, usually with the <a href="#purchaseorder">purchase order</a> rather than in response to an <a href="#invoice">invoice</a>.  If the order is <a href="#canceled">canceled</a> or the merchandise is returned in compliance with the seller's <a href="#returnpolicy">return policy</a>, a <a href="#credit">credit</a> may be issued.  Small independent <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s and electronic retailers are more likely to require prepayment than large <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s and <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>s.  Most <a href="#journal">journal</a> publishers require prepayment before beginning a new <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prepaymentdiscount"><b>prepayment discount</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#discount">discount</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preprint"><b>preprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>A portion of a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> and distributed for a special purpose in advance of the <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> announced for the whole, for example, an <a href="#article">article</a> to be <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> or a <a href="#work">work</a> selected for inclusion in an <a href="#anthology">anthology</a> or <a href="#collection">collection</a>.  Also, a <a href="#paper">paper</a> preapred for presentation at a <a href="#conference">conference</a>, printed in multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a> in advance of the conference date, usually for distribution to participants and other interested persons.  In some academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s, preprints are an important medium of <a href="#scholarlycommunication">scholarly communication</a>.  Also refers to a few copies of an <a href="#author">author</a>'s <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> produced by a method such as <a href="#xerography">xerography</a> for circulation within the office of the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, usually to facilitate reading, evaluation, and <a href="#editor">editing</a>.
<p>
Also refers to an advertising <a href="#insert">insert</a> printed by a manufacturer to be included in a periodical, sometimes designed to accommodate local <a href="#copy">copy</a>, such as the names and addresses of sales outlets located in the area of <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preprocessing"><b>preprocessing</b></a>
</dt><dd>One or more steps in <a href="#physicalprocessing">physical processing</a>, completed before a new <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> is <a href="#shipping">shipped</a> by the seller to the ordering <a href="#library">library</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prepub"><b>prepub</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#prepublication">prepublication</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prepublication"><b>prepublication</b></a>
</dt><dd>An adjective referring to activities that occur <em>before</em> a <a href="#work">work</a> is <a href="#publishing">published</a>, for example, an offer by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of a <a href="#prepubprice">prepublication price</a> on <a href="#advanceorder">advance order</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prepubdiscount"><b>prepublication discount</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#discount">discount</a> or reduction in the <a href="#listprice">list price</a> of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, offered by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> on orders placed before the <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, to encourage <a href="#advanceorder">advance order</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#prepubprice">prepublication price</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prepubprice"><b>prepublication price</b></a>
</dt><dd>The price at which a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> is sold if ordered before a specified date in <a href="#advanceorder">advance</a> of the <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, after which it is sold at the higher <a href="#listprice">list price</a>.  Expensive multi-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#set">set</a>s may be offered to <a href="#library">libraries</a> by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> at a substantially lower price several months before the publication date as an inducement to order.  Compare with <a href="#introprice">introductory price</a> and <a href="#prepubdiscount">prepublication discount</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#expirationdate">expiration date</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prequel"><b>prequel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> (usually a <a href="#novel">novel</a>) complete in itself, which extends the <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> back in time from the beginning of a previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> work, retaining at least some of the same <a href="#character">character</a>s, although the action may occur in a different <a href="#setting">setting</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Mossflower</em></b>, prequel to <b><em>Redwall</em></b> by Brian Jacques).  A prequel may be written by a person other than the <a href="#author">author</a> of the work on which it is based (<b><em>Gertrude and Claudius</em></b> by John Updike).  In a more general sense, anything that precedes, especially a preceding sequence of events.  The opposite of <a href="#sequel">sequel</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prerecordedmessage"><b>prerecorded message</b></a>
</dt><dd>A telephone message recorded in advance for automatic <a href="#playback">playback</a> when no one is present or able to answer a call.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> often use a prerecorded message when the facility is closed to inform callers of <a href="#libraryhours">library hours</a>, and sometimes when open to direct calls to the appropriate <a href="#servicepoint">service desk</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="presentationcopy"><b>presentation copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> bearing a presentation <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>, usually written spontaneously by the <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a> on the <a href="#flyleaf">flyleaf</a>.  When the inscription is requested by the recipient, the book is an <a href="#inscribed">inscribed copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="presentationsoftware"><b>presentation software</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#application">Application</a> <a href="#software">software</a> designed to assist a presenter in preparing <a href="#text">text</a> and/or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s for visual display via a computer attached to an <a href="#lcd">LCD</a> projector (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>PowerPoint</em></b>).  The graphic quality of such presentations is usually superior to overhead <a href="#transparency">transparencies</a>, but a well-prepared speaker brings <a href="#backup">backup</a> to use in the event of machine or <a href="#network">network</a> failure.  Presentation software is becoming more common in <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>, particularly in <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> as instruction <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s become proficient users.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preservation"><b>preservation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Prolonging the existence of <a href="#library">library</a> and <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> by maintaining them in a <a href="#condition">condition</a> suitable for use, either in their <a href="#original">original</a> form or in a form that is more <a href="#durability">durable</a>, through retention under proper <a href="#environcontrol">environmental condition</a>s and actions taken after a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> has been <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> to prevent further <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a>.  Single <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s may be <a href="#encapsulation">encapsulated</a> or <a href="#lamination">laminated</a> for protection.  Materials <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#acidpaper">acid paper</a> may be <a href="#deacidification">deacidified</a>
if their value warrants the expense; however, when the original has
deteriorated beyond the point of salvation, conversion to a different <a href="#format">format</a> may be necessary.  <a href="#publication">Publication</a>s with soiled or <a href="#foxing">foxed</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> are sometimes <a href="#washing">washed</a> in <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>.  Materials infected with <a href="#mildew">mildew</a> or <a href="#mold">mold</a> require <a href="#fumigation">fumigation</a>.  <a href="#rarebook">Rare book</a>s and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s are usually stored in a darkened room in which temperature and <a href="#humidity">humidity</a> are strictly controlled.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/preserv/">Click here</a> to learn more about preservation at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  <em><a href="http://www.nedcc.org/plam3/manhome.htm">Preservation of Library &amp; Archival Materials: A Manual</a></em> (1999) by Sherelyn Ogden is available <a href="#online">online</a> from the <a href="http://www.nedcc.org/">Northeast Document Conservation Center</a>.  Compare with <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#digitalpreservation">digital preservation</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="presphotocopy"><b>preservation photocopy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#facsimile">facsimile</a> of a written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#document">document</a>, <a href="#reprography">reproduced</a> on a high-end <a href="#photocopier">photocopy machine</a> according to strict criteria, usually when the <a href="#condition">condition</a> of the <a href="#original">original</a> has <a href="#deterioration">deteriorated</a> and the <a href="#content">content</a> is worth <a href="#preservation">preserving</a> in the same form.  The <a href="#paper">paper</a> on which such a <a href="#copy">copy</a> is made must meet <a href="#ansi">ANSI</a> <a href="#standards">standards</a> for <a href="#permanentpaper">permanence</a> and <a href="#durability">durability</a> (Z39.48).  If the document is a <a href="#book">book</a>, the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> should be bound according to ANSI standards for <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a> (Z39.78).  The facsimile should bear a statement clearly identifying the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> as a copy.
