If the original is of "poor quality," its <a href="#condition">condition</a> may also be noted.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/preserv/care/photocpy.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> <a href="#webpage">webpage</a> on preservation <a href="#photocopy">photocopy</a>ing, adapted from the <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alcts/publications/guidelines/photocopying.html">ALA Guidelines for Preservation Photocopying of Replacement Pages</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preserved"><b>Preserved Context Indexing System (PRECIS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer-assisted <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> system developed and used since 1971 in the <em>British National Bibliography (BNB)</em>, <b>PRECIS</b> is also used by <a href="#library">library</a> services in Canada and in the <em>Australian National Bibliography</em>.  In contrast to the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject headings</a> used by libraries in the United States, <b>PRECIS</b> attempts <a href="#coextensive">coextensive entry</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="presidentiallib"><b>presidential library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a> housing the <a href="#papers">papers</a> of a former president of the United States (since Herbert Hoover) and <a href="#document">document</a>s
pertaining to his term of office, usually located in or near the
president's place of birth or residence prior to election. Although
funds for the construction of presidential <a href="#library">library</a> facilities are provided by private donors, the <a href="#nara">National Archives and Records Administration</a> operates and maintains them as <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a>.  <a href="http://www.archives.gov/presidential_libraries/addresses/addresses.html">Click here</a> to connect to the NARA list of presidential libraries with <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="press"><b>press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general term for the news media that traditionally included only <a href="#print">print</a> sources (<a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s and <a href="#newsmagazine">news magazine</a>s) but has expanded to include <a href="#newsservice">news service</a>s and radio and television <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>ing.  A <em>press corps</em> is a body of reporters who cover breaking news, usually from a particular location (<em>example</em>:  the White House).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pressrelease">press release</a>.  
<p>
Also used in the same sense as "<a href="#publisher">publisher</a>" (<em>example</em>:  <b>Oxford University Press</b>), to refer to the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> industry in general (<em>example</em>:  popular press), and as a shortened form of the <a href="#term">term</a> <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a>.
</p><p>
Also refers to the initial response of <a href="#reviewer">reviewer</a>s to a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> or creative <a href="#work">work</a>, which may have an effect on public <a href="#demand">demand</a> in <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s, <a href="#library">libraries</a>, theaters, etc.  Press can be "bad" (panned), "good" (well-received), or "excellent" (laudatory). 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pressboard"><b>pressboard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A highly glazed form of paperboard, used when strength and rigidity are required of comparatively thin <a href="#board">board</a> because it is very dense and tough.  Made from <a href="#ragpaper">rag</a> or chemical wood <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>, it is less <a href="#acidic">acidic</a> than board made from mechanical wood pulp. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pressclipping"><b>press clipping service</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization in the business of collecting <a href="#copy">copies</a> of <a href="#review">review</a>s, <a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#column">column</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s,  etc., <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s and <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s about <a href="#author">author</a>s, prominent people, news events, or other <a href="#topic">topic</a>s of interest to clients who pay a <a href="#fee">fee</a> to receive them on a regular basis.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pressconference"><b>press conference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal meeting to which members of the <a href="#press">press</a> are invited to hear an announcement or statement concerning an important event, project, <a href="#topic">topic</a>, or development which the sponsors of the meeting wish to see <a href="#publicity">publicized</a> in the <a href="#media">media</a>.  The attendees are usually given the opportunity to question the spokesperson(s) closely.  <a href="#libassociation">Library association</a>s and large <a href="#library">libraries</a> sometimes schedule press conferences to publicize major initiatives.  Compare with <a href="#pressrelease">press release</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pressrelease"><b>press release</b></a>
</dt><dd>An official or <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> statement of news or other <a href="#information">information</a>, intended for <a href="#publication">publication</a> in a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> or news <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>, or for dissemination via some other news medium, usually written and issued by a press secretary or <a href="#publicrelations">public relations</a> office, giving the point of view of a person, company, or organization on a <a href="#currency">current</a> event or situation.  Synonymous with <em>news release</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pressconference">press conference</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pressrun"><b>press run</b></a>
</dt><dd>The number of <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> that are to be <a href="#printing">printed</a> at any one time, usually more than the <a href="#binding">binding</a> order calls for, to allow for <a href="#spoilage">spoilage</a>.  Also spelled <em>pressrun</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#overrun">overrun</a> and <a href="#underrun">underrun</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pressuregroup"><b>pressure group</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organized group that attempts to influence a <a href="#library">library</a>'s policies or practices, usually to secure the removal of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s considered objectionable by its members, or the addition to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> that advocate or substantiate its point of view on a controversial political or social issue.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> in the United States are frequent targets because they are supported by public funds and serve a <a href="#diversity">diverse</a> <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>.  A carefully worded <a href="#collecdevelpolicy">collection development policy</a> is a library's best defense against threats to  <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pressuresensitive"><b>pressure-sensitive</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> designed to work by means
of gentle compression, which may or may not allow the material to be
easily removed from a surface once it has adhered.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pretest"><b>pretest</b></a>
</dt><dd>A quiz or test administered to students prior to receiving <a href="#bi">instruction</a> in the use of the <a href="#library">library</a>, to assess their entry-level <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> and identify deficiencies that need to be addressed.  Ideally, a pretest is administered in conjunction with a <a href="#posttest">post-test</a>, for the purpose of comparison.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preventivemaint"><b>preventive maintenance</b></a>
</dt><dd>The cost-effective practice of regularly checking <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a> and making minor repairs as needed to prevent more serious problems from developing.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="preview"><b>preview</b></a>
</dt><dd>A private showing of a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> or <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ion to a limited <a href="#audience">audience</a> in advance of the official public <a href="#release">release</a>
or opening date. Also refers to a brief sequence of scenes taken from a
motion picture, to be shown in a movie theater, on television, or on <a href="#videotape">videotape</a>, <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>, etc., to advertise the <a href="#work">work</a> as a coming attraction.  Also spelled <em>prevue</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#trailer">trailer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="price"><b>price</b></a>
</dt><dd>The amount actually paid by a <a href="#library">library</a> for a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a> after any <a href="#discount">discount</a> is deducted, as stated on the <a href="#invoice">invoice</a>, not including the cost of <a href="#shipping">shipping</a>.  Price is entered in the <a href="#orderrecord">order record</a>, and also in the <a href="#itemrecord">item record</a> to facilitate <a href="#billed">billing</a> if the item is <a href="#lost">lost</a> or <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> beyond repair after the order record has been purged.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#averageprice">average price</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="priceclipped"><b>price clipped</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#book">book</a> from which the <a href="#listprice">list price</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the front <a href="#flap">flap</a> of the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> has been snipped off.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="priceguide"><b>price guide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> that gives <a href="#currency">current</a> prices of <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, as well as <a href="#book">book</a>s that are comparatively scarce, usually because they are <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>.  The <a href="#information">information</a> is usually based on  prices paid at <a href="#bookauction">book auction</a>s (<b><em>American Book Prices Current</em></b>) or asked in <a href="#dealer">dealer</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s (<b><em>Bookman's Price Index</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="priceresistance"><b>price resistance</b></a>
</dt><dd>The point at which the value of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a>
is perceived by prospective buyers to be lower than the stated price.
Under normal conditions, the customer will decide not to purchase, or
postpone purchase until the price comes down. <a href="#library">Library</a> <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>s and <a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a>s may state a maximum price not to be exceeded for a specific category of item.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="primaryauthor"><b>primary author</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#author">author</a> whose name appears first on the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a> in the case of a <a href="#work">work</a> by two or more <a href="#jointauthor">joint author</a>s, in whose name the <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a> is made in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>.  <a href="#addedentry">Added entries</a> are made under the names of each of the other authors.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="primaryjournal"><b>primary journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a> devoted to disseminating the results of original <a href="#research">research</a> in the <a href="#field">field</a>(s) or <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>(s) it covers (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Journal of Experimental Psychology</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="primaryletter"><b>primary letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#letter">letter</a> of the roman <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> that does not have an <a href="#ascender">ascender</a> or <a href="#descender">descender</a> (<b>a</b>, <b>c</b>, <b>e</b>, <b>m</b>, <b>n</b>, <b>o</b>, <b>r</b>, <b>s</b>, <b>u</b>, <b>v</b>, <b>w</b>, <b>x</b>, and <b>z</b>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#xheight">x-height</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="primarysource"><b>primary source</b></a>
</dt><dd>In scholarship, a <a href="#document">document</a> or <a href="#record">record</a> containing first-hand <a href="#information">information</a> or <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#data">data</a> on a <a href="#topic">topic</a>, used in preparing a <a href="#derivativework">derivative work</a>.  Primary sources include original <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s reporting original <a href="#research">research</a> or thought, <a href="#diary">diaries</a>, <a href="#memoirs">memoirs</a>, <a href="#letters">letters</a>, <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, drawings, <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, <a href="#film">film</a> <a href="#footage">footage</a>, <a href="#sheetmusic">sheet music</a>, songs, interviews, <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a>, public <a href="#records">records</a>, eyewitness accounts, <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s, etc.  Compare with <a href="#secondarysource">secondary source</a> and <a href="#tertiarysource">tertiary source</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="primaryvalues"><b>primary values</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the <a href="#archivalvalue">values</a> of <a href="#record">record</a>s for the purpose(s) and activities for which they were created.  Compare with <a href="#secondaryvalues">secondary values</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="primer"><b>primer</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, a prayer <a href="#book">book</a>.  Later, a book for written for young children to teach them how to read and spell.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>Dick and Jane book</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#abecedarium">abecedarium</a>, <a href="#battledore">battledore</a>, and <a href="#hornbook">horn book</a>.
<p>
In a more general sense, any book that gives the first principles of a <a href="#subject">subject</a> or basic instruction for beginners.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="princeps"><b>princeps edition</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="print"><b>print</b></a>
</dt><dd>To transfer an <a href="#ink">ink</a>ed image or <a href="#text">text</a> from blocks, <a href="#type">type</a>, or <a href="#plate">plate</a>s onto a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> or roll of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, or onto some other <a href="#printing">printing</a> surface, by the application of pressure.  Also refers to the result of such a process, whether it be a string of <a href="#character">character</a>s on a <a href="#page">page</a>, or an entire page of text and/or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>.  Also used as a generic term for the <a href="#medium">medium</a> of print, as opposed to <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#media">media</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#offprint">offprint</a> and <a href="#preprint">preprint</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#picture">picture</a> (<a href="#mounted">mounted</a> or unmounted) made by any printing process.  An <em>art print</em> is an <a href="#original">original</a> drawing, <a href="#woodcut">woodcut</a>, <a href="#etching">etching</a>, <a href="#engraving">engraving</a>, <a href="#lithography">lithograph</a>, or <a href="#photograph">photograph</a> transferred to the <a href="#medium">medium</a> of print from a plate cut by the artist.  Prints made from the same plate may vary in quality.  In photography, a copy of a <a href="#photograph">photograph</a> made on <a href="#paper">paper</a> from a <a href="#negative">negative</a>.  In cinematography, a copy on <a href="#film">film</a> of a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="printer"><b>printer</b></a>
</dt><dd>The person or firm that <a href="#printing">prints</a> a <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, or other <a href="#document">document</a>, as distinct from the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> who <a href="#issue">issue</a>s the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> and the <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>
who offers it for sale. In early printed books, the printer and
publisher were often the same, but in modern book production, the two
functions are almost always performed by separate establishments. <p>
Also refers to a mechanical or electronic device that produces printed <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a document, including computer <a href="#peripheral">peripherals</a> designed to produce <a href="#hardcopy">hard copy</a> <a href="#output">output</a>.  The most common types are <a href="#laserprinter">laser printer</a>s, dot-matrix printers, and ink-jet printers.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="printerscopy"><b>printer's copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> version of a <a href="#work">work</a>, used as the model for <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> the <a href="#type">type</a> used in a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>.  Survival of such <a href="#copy">copies</a> is rare, but when properly <a href="#authentication">authenticated</a>, they can be of considerable interest to scholars engaged in <a href="#text">text</a>ual <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> and <a href="#criticism">criticism</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="printersflower"><b>printer's flower</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> <a href="#printersornament">printer's ornament</a> in the form of a flower or piece of foliage, which can be repeated to form a decorative <a href="#border">border</a> on a <a href="#page">page</a> or <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>.  Synonymous with <em>fleuron</em> and <em>floret</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="printersornament"><b>printer's ornament</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#type">Type</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a> used by a <a href="#printer">printer</a> to add touches of embellishment to a <a href="#text">text</a>, including <a href="#arabesque">arabesque</a>s, <a href="#border">border</a>s (plain and fancy), <a href="#printersflower">flower</a>s, <a href="#headpiece">headpiece</a>s, <a href="#rule">rule</a>s, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="printing"><b>printing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The production of identical <a href="#copy">copies</a> of written or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> material by means of a <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a> or other mechanical device.  Printing began in Germany in the mid-15th century with the invention by <a href="#gutenberg">Johann Gutenberg</a> of <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a> and spread rapidly throughout Europe, replacing <a href="#manuscriptbook">manuscript book</a>s as the primary <a href="#medium">medium</a> of written communication.  Compare with <a href="#reprography">reprography</a> and <a href="#xerography">xerography</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a>, <a href="#offset">offset</a>, <a href="#typography">typography</a>, and <a href="#apha">American Printing History Association</a>.
<p>
Also refers to all the <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> printed at one time in the same <a href="#pressrun">pressrun</a>.  A copy of the first printing of the first <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> is usually of greater value to <a href="#bookcollecting">book collector</a>s than a copy of a subsequent printing, in comparable <a href="#condition">condition</a>.  Also refers to the art of hand-<a href="#lettering">lettering</a> made to look like printed <a href="#letter">letter</a>s.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="printingpress"><b>printing press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A machine designed to make <a href="#impression">impression</a>s from an <a href="#ink">ink</a>ed <a href="#plate">plate</a> or block, or from <a href="#type">type</a>, on <a href="#paper">paper</a> or some other <a href="#printing">printing</a> surface.  The modern printing press was invented at Mainz, Germany in about 1456 by <a href="#gutenberg">Johann Gutenberg</a> whose first <a href="#publication">publication</a> was a 42-line Bible known as the <em><a href="#gutenbergbible">Gutenberg Bible</a></em>.
The invention spread rapidly throughout Continental Europe and to the
British Isles, becoming well-established by the 1480's. It put
ownership of <a href="#book">book</a>s withing the reach of people who had previously been unable to afford hand-<a href="#copy">copied</a> reading material.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#chase">chase</a>, <a href="#forme">forme</a>, <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a>, and <a href="#offset">offset</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="printmaster"><b>print master</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a>, a second <a href="#generation">generation</a> <a href="#negative">negative</a> made directly from the <a href="#masternegative">master negative</a>, used to make <a href="#servicecopy">service copies</a>.  The print <a href="#master">master</a> is usually stored under controlled conditions in a separate location.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="printout"><b>printout</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#text">Text</a>, images, or other <a href="#data">data</a> from a computer <a href="#file">file</a>, printed as <a href="#output">output</a> on <a href="#paper">paper</a> or some other <a href="#printing">printing</a> surface, using a <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> <a href="#device">device</a> called a <a href="#printer">printer</a>.  Compare with <a href="#hardcopy">hard copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="priorpub"><b>prior publication</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> submitted to a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> after it has already been <a href="#publishing">published</a>, usually in a different form, for example, an <a href="#article">article</a> initially published in a <a href="#journal">journal</a>, later submitted by the <a href="#author">author</a> as a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a>.  Whether <a href="#etd">electronic theses and dissertation</a>s constitute prior <a href="#publication">publication</a>
is an issue currently in debate. The policy of a publishing company
with regard to prior publication is usually stated in its guidelines
for <a href="#contributor">contributor</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prisonlib"><b>prison library</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#correctional">correctional library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="privacy"><b>privacy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The right of an individual (or group) to keep <a href="#information">information</a>
about personal and professional life from disclosure, especially to
government and commercial enterprises, and to remain free from
surveillance except as authorized under provisions of law. In the <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/ethics.html">ALA Code of Ethics</a></em>, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> are encouraged to "protect each library user's right to privacy and <a href="#confidentiality">confidentiality</a> with respect to information sought or received and resources consulted, borrowed, acquired or transmitted."  Many <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States have decided as a matter of policy not to retain <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> records for <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> returned by the user, to prevent misuse of such information.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#informationlaw">information law</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="privatelib"><b>private library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> of any size which is not
supported by public funds, especially one owned by an individual or
family for personal enjoyment, or by a private club, corporation, or
foundation. Historically, large private <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s have been the nucleus of many <a href="#academiclib">academic</a>, <a href="#researchlib">research</a>, and <a href="#nationallib">national libraries</a>.  Examples include the private collection of Thomas Jefferson acquired by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> and the personal library of financier Pierpont Morgan, founder of the <a href="#pierpont">Pierpont Morgan Library</a> in New York City. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="privately"><b>privately printed</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#printing">printed</a> but not offered for sale to the general public, usually intended solely for private distribution.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also applied to <a href="#publication">publication</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by a <a href="#privatepress">private press</a>.  Such works normally come to public attention when they are offered for sale in a <a href="#bookauction">book auction</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="privatepress"><b>private press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#printing">printing</a> establishment, often operated by a single person, offering <a href="#limitededition">limited edition</a>s
at the discretion of the owner. The results are usually of fine quality
and, when offered for sale, may not be distributed through regular
market channels. A prime example is the <a href="#kelmscott">Kelmscott Press</a>
founded in England in 1891 by William Morris, leader of the
19th-century English revival of the art and craft of bookmaking.
Compare with <a href="#vanitypublisher">vanity publisher</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="privatization"><b>privatization</b></a>
</dt><dd>The contracting out of <a href="#library">library</a> services under an agreement that transfers control over policy decisions and management of <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s and services from the public to the private sector, usually to an external <a href="#agency">agency</a> that operates on a for-profit basis.  Compare with <a href="#outsourcing">outsourcing</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="problempatron"><b>problem patron</b></a>
</dt><dd>A user whose behavior disrupts the normal functioning of a <a href="#library">library</a>,
for example, a person whose actions annoy others (staring, harassment,
talking on cell phones), who exhibits aberrant behavior (mental and
emotional disturbances, influence of drugs or alcohol, etc.), who
engages in illegal activities (<a href="#vandalism">vandalism</a>, <a href="#theft">theft</a>,
sex offenses, or who uses the library for purposes other than reading
and study (socializing, soliciting, sleeping, bathing). Most larger
libraries in the United States have installed <a href="#securitysystem">security system</a>s to prevent theft.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> plagued with persistent problem patrons may hire a <a href="#securityguard">security guard</a> to police the premises during <a href="#libraryhours">hours</a> when the library is open.  <a href="#academiclib">Academic libraries</a> usually call upon the campus police if necessary.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pyropatron">pyro-patron</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proceduremanual"><b>procedure manual</b></a>
</dt><dd>A systematic list documenting the tasks involved in a specific
job, sometimes including a description of the manner in which they are
to be performed, given in sufficient detail that after careful reading,
someone unfamiliar with the job is able to perform basic functions with
a minimal amount of assistance. Procedure <a href="#manual">manual</a>s are often maintained in <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> <a href="#format">format</a> to facilitate revision.  Compare with <a href="#employeehandbook">employee handbook</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proceedings"><b>proceedings</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#record">record</a> of a <a href="#conference">conference</a>, congress, symposium, or other meeting sponsored by a <a href="#society">society</a> or <a href="#association">association</a>, usually but not necessarily including <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>s or <a href="#report">report</a>s of <a href="#paper">paper</a>s presented by the participants.  When the entire <a href="#text">text</a> of the papers presented is included, the result is called <a href="#transactions">transactions</a>.  Conference proceedings are <a href="#index">index</a>ed worldwide in <b><em>ProceedingsFirst</em></b>, an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> available in <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#firstsearch">FirstSearch</a></em>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>proc</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="processing"><b>processing</b></a>
</dt><dd>Everything done to a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> after it is acquired by a <a href="#library">library</a>, before it is placed on the shelf, including <a href="#accession">accession</a>ing, <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, <a href="#propertystamp">stamping</a>, <a href="#spinelabel">label</a>ing, <a href="#number">number</a>ing, <a href="#dustjacket">jacket</a>ing, etc.  In some libraries, items <a href="#inprocess">in process</a> are identified as such in the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>.  The user may request that processing be expedited if an item is urgently needed.  Compare with <a href="#technical">technical processing</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="processingcenter"><b>processing center</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#centralizedproc">centralized processing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="procrastination"><b>procrastination</b></a>
</dt><dd>Putting off until tomorrow work that can and should be done
today, sometimes with serious or vexing consequences for oneself and
others. Persons overloaded with <a href="#paperwork">paperwork</a> are particularly prone to this affliction.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="producer"><b>producer</b></a>
</dt><dd>The person(s), company, or <a href="#agency">agency</a> primarily responsible for determining the form and <a href="#content">content</a> of a <a href="#media">media</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> such as a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> or television program, usually listed in the <a href="#credit">credit</a>s at the beginning or end of the <a href="#work">work</a>.  The producer is also responsible for financing and making arrangements for the <a href="#manufacturer">manufacture</a> of the final product, and for promoting it in the market place.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>production company</em>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>prod</em>.  Compare with <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>.  
<p>
Also, the organization responsible for creating the content of a <a href="#mrdf">machine-readable data file</a> such as a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, usually indicated on the <a href="#welcomescreen">welcome screen</a>, not necessarily the same as the <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> that markets and provides <a href="#access">access</a> to the product.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="productioncompany"><b>production company</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#producer">producer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="professionalbook"><b>professional book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> intended to be used by members of a profession in the course of their work or in continuing education (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Countdown to a New Library:  Managing the Building Project</em></b> by Jeannette A. Woodward).  Books for the <a href="#library">library</a> profession are <a href="#review">review</a>ed in a separate <a href="#section">section</a> of <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em> and <em><a href="#booklist">Booklist</a></em>.  Because professional books appeal to a  limited <a href="#audience">audience</a>, <a href="#pressrun">press run</a>s tend to be small and they are sold at a <a href="#shortdiscount">short discount</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="profdevel"><b>professional development</b></a>
</dt><dd>Further study undertaken during employment by a person trained
and educated in a profession, sometimes at the initiative of the
employer, but also through voluntary attendance at <a href="#conference">conference</a>s, <a href="#workshop">workshop</a>s, seminars, or enrollment in post-graduate courses, particularly important in professions that have a rapidly changing <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> base.  Compare with <a href="#inservice">in-service training</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="professionalism"><b>professionalism</b></a>
</dt><dd>Exercise of a high <a href="#standard">standard</a> of trained judgment in meeting the needs of the clients or users of a service.  In most countries, professional <a href="#qualification">qualification</a>s are awarded by the leading professional <a href="#association">association</a>, on the expectation that competencies will be maintained through continuing <a href="#profdevel">development</a> of <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> and skills.  In most professions, standards are reinforced by government licensing and by a professional <a href="#codeofethics">code of ethics</a>.  The <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> established its <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/alaorg/oif/ethics.html">Code of Ethics</a></em> in 1939.  Adherence has brought some <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s into conflict with members of the local community and with persons of power and influence, particularly over issues of <a href="#censorship">censorship</a> and <a href="#privacy">privacy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="profile"><b>profile</b></a>
</dt><dd>A demographic study of the community served by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, or of its registered users or <a href="#usergroup">user group</a>, for the purpose of measuring economic, social, and educational variables pertinent to the <a href="#collecdevel">development</a> of <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, services, and programs, and to the design of new facilities.  A profile is usually conducted with the aid of a <a href="#survey">survey</a> instrument, but may also include <a href="#data">data</a> compiled from other sources.
<p>
Also refers to the list of needs established by a library with a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#jobber">wholesaler</a> that supplies <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> <a href="#onapproval">on approval</a> or <a href="#blanketorder">blanket order</a>, which may include <a href="#subject">subject</a> areas, levels of <a href="#specialization">specialization</a> and/or difficulty, <a href="#language">language</a>s, <a href="#series">series</a>, <a href="#format">format</a>s, maximum <a href="#listprice">price</a>s, etc.
</p><p>
Also, the degree to which the activities of an individual,
organization, or institution are known in its community. Libraries
typically emerge from their <em>low-profile</em> role in society when faced with the necessity of persuading their <a href="#constituency">constituency</a> to approve a funding measure.  Library policy can also become <em>high-profile</em> when a <a href="#challenge">challenge</a> sparks a conflict over <a href="#censorship">censorship</a> or <a href="#privacy">privacy</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pcc"><b>Program for Cooperative Cataloging (PCC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An international program coordinated by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> and participants from other countries, aimed at expanding access to <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s by providing useful, timely, and cost-effective <a href="#cooperativecat">cooperative cataloging</a> that meets the mutually-accepted <a href="#standards">standards</a> of <a href="#library">libraries</a> around the world.  <b>PCC</b> has four components:  NACO (name <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority</a> program), SACO (subject authority program), BIBCO (<a href="#monograph">monograph</a>ic <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> program), and <a href="#conser">CONSER</a> (cooperative <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#serial">serial</a>s program), guided by a policy committee that includes as permanent representatives the <a href="#britishlib">British Library</a>, Library of Congress, <a href="#nlcbnc">National Library of Canada</a>, <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a>, and <a href="#rlg">Research Libraries Group</a>.  <a href="http://www.loc.gov/catdir/pcc/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>PCC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="programmedtext"><b>programmed text</b></a>
</dt><dd>An instructional <a href="#book">book</a> presented as a sequence of self-paced units that require the student to demonstrate understanding of the <a href="#content">content</a>
by responding appropriately at various steps along the way. If the
correct answer is given, the lesson continues; if the student answers
incorrectly, additional instruction and practice is provided until the
unit is mastered. Programmed instruction is suitable only for material
of limited complexity that can be learned in a step-by-step process.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proglang"><b>programming language</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s with its own <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a>, grammar, and <a href="#syntax">syntax</a>, in which a person called a <em>programmer</em> writes statements instructing a computer to accomplish a specific task by executing a sequence of logical operations (<em>examples</em>:  BASIC, C, C++, COBOL, FORTRAN, etc.).  The instructions, known as <em>source code</em>, are translated into the machine-language specific to each type of <a href="#centralproc">CPU</a> by special <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s called <em>assemblers</em>, <em>compilers</em>, and <em>interpreters</em>.  <a href="#standards">Standards</a> for programming languages are set by the <a href="#ansi">American National Standards Institute</a> (ANSI).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="programnotes"><b>program notes</b></a>
</dt><dd>Explanatory notes accompanying a <a href="#printing">printed</a> list of the <a href="#work">work</a>s
performed in a concert or theater, usually distributed by an usher to
attendees upon entering the hall. Intended to be read before the
curtain rises and during intermission, program notes usually contain <a href="#information">information</a> about the <a href="#composition">composition</a>s to be performed and the people involved (<a href="#composer">composer</a> or <a href="#playwright">playwright</a>, conductor or <a href="#director">director</a>, <a href="#performer">performer</a>s,
etc.), usually written by a knowledgeable person. Of particular
interest to music historians, program notes are classified by <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s as <a href="#ephemera">ephemera</a> and can therefore be difficult to locate, with the exception of performances given in major venues that maintain their own <a href="#archives">archives</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="projection"><b>projection</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#cartography">cartography</a>, the result produced when the spherical surface of a <a href="#globe">globe</a>
is placed in a position relative to a light source from which an image
of its surface can be projected onto a plane, or onto a curved surface
such as a cone or cylinder that can be cut and laid flat. The normal
orientation for a <em>planar projection</em> is polar; for a <em>conical projection</em>, oblique; and for a <em>cylindrical projection</em>, equatorial.  All projections involve some degree of distortion.  The type of projection used in making a <a href="#map">map</a> of the earth or another celestial body is usually indicated in the <a href="#legend">legend</a>, with the <em>Mercator projection</em> being the most common.  When a map is <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a>, the <em>statement of projection</em> is given in the <a href="#mathdata">mathematical data</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a future need or condition that can be forecast from a known set of <a href="#data">data</a>, for example, the amount of <a href="#expansion">expansion</a> space needed in the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>, based on average annual <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> growth.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="projectionspeed"><b>projection speed</b></a>
</dt><dd>The rate at which images on <a href="#film">film</a> are made to appear on a screen, using a machine called a <em>film projector</em>, the standard being 24 fps (<a href="#frame">frame</a>s per second) for sound film and 16 fps for <a href="#silentfilm">silent film</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, projection speed is given in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> only if it is not <a href="#standard">standard</a> for the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  Compare with <a href="#playingspeed">playing speed</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="projectmuse"><b><em>Project MUSE</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#grant">grant</a>-funded joint project of Johns Hopkins University Press and the Milton S. Eisenhower Library at Johns Hopkins University, <b><em>Project MUSE</em></b> began by offering <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#access">access</a> by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> to the <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> of its own <a href="#journal">journal</a>s.  In 2000, the Project added 60 journals from other scholarly <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, bringing the total <a href="#coverage">coverage</a> of the <a href="#database">database</a> to over 100 <a href="#title">title</a>s, mostly in the arts, humanities, and social sciences.  <a href="http://muse.jhu.edu/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>Project MUSE</em></b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#jstor">JSTOR</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prolegomenon"><b>prolegomenon</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#prologue">prologue</a> or preliminary <a href="#essay">essay</a>, especially one that is long and scholarly.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is often seen in the <a href="#title">title</a>s of <a href="#thesis">theses</a> and <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>A Prolegomenon on Moderation in Plato's Republic</em></b> by Stephen John Lange).  Plural:  <em>prolegomena</em>   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prologue"><b>prologue</b></a>
</dt><dd>An introduction to a <a href="#play">play</a>, <a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#poetry">poem</a>, or other <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> placed by the <a href="#author">author</a> at the opening of the <a href="#text">text</a>, rather than in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em>Wife of Bath's Prologue</em> in Chaucer's <b><em>Canterbury Tales</em></b>).
Also refers to introductory lines spoken by a member of the cast before
the beginning of the first act of a dramatic performance, to prepare
the <a href="#audience">audience</a> for the theme to be developed, or state the moral embodied in the action that follows.  Compare with <a href="#epilogue">epilogue</a>.  In a broader sense, preliminary events leading to more weighty consequences.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="promotion"><b>promotion</b></a>
</dt><dd>Advancement of a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or other <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> member to a higher <a href="#rank">rank</a> within the same <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, usually on the basis of favorable <a href="#performanceeval">performance evaluation</a> and accompanied by an increase in <a href="#salary">salary</a> or <a href="#wages">wages</a>.  A change of <a href="#position">position</a> can be a promotion if it involves more responsibility and authority.  In libraries in which employment is governed by a <a href="#collectivebargaining">collective bargaining agreement</a>, eligibility for promotion and method of evaluation may be determined by <a href="#contract">contract</a>.  Compare with <a href="#tenure">tenure</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#peerevaluation">peer evaluation</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the activity of marketing a product, service, or institution to people in a position to buy, use, or support it.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="promobook"><b>promotional book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A profusely <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> <a href="#book">book</a> on a popular <a href="#subject">subject</a>, usually an <a href="#outofprint">out-of-print</a> <a href="#tradebook">trade title</a> <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>ed in a less expensive <a href="#edition">edition</a> specifically for sale as a bargain <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in <a href="#tradebookstore">trade bookstore</a>s.  Art, travel, cooking, gardening, and natural history are favorite subjects.  In <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, a promotional book received in good <a href="#condition">condition</a> as a <a href="#gift">gift</a> may be added to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> if <a href="#demand">demand</a> exists for the subject.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>promo book</em>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prompt"><b>prompt</b></a>
</dt><dd>A message at a point on a computer screen, usually in the form of a small blinking <a href="#cursor">cursor</a> (with or without explanatory <a href="#text">text</a>), indicating that <a href="#data">data</a> is to be entered or an operation initiated by the user.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="promptbook"><b>promptbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>The version of the <a href="#script">script</a> of a <a href="#play">play</a>
used during a performance by the person responsible for jogging the
memory of the actors and stage hands when they forget their lines or
miss their cues. A promptbook indicates the lines, action, cues, props,
costumes, lighting, etc., at each point in the production. Synonymous
with <em>prompt copy</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proof"><b>proof</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a trial <a href="#impression">impression</a> made from metal <a href="#type">type</a>, <a href="#plate">plate</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic <a href="#film">film</a>, or <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a> or <a href="#disk">disk</a>, for inspection and correction at the various stages of <a href="#composition">composition</a>.  Proofs of <a href="#text">text</a>ual matter are known as <em>proof sheets</em>.  In <a href="#book">book</a>
production, a different kind of proof is made at each stage of the
printing process. Designated by form, purpose, or destination, proofs
are taken in the following sequence:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b><em>first proof</em></b> - a preliminary <a href="#galleyproof">galley proof</a>, corrected by the <a href="#printer">printer</a>'s <a href="#reader">reader</a> for return to the <a href="#typesetting">typesetter</a>
</dd><dd><b><em>galley</em> or <em>slip proof</em></b> - taken before <a href="#matter">matter</a> is <a href="#makeup">made-up</a> into <a href="#page">page</a>s, checked by the printer's reader and sent to <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> for <a href="#author">author</a> corrections
</dd><dd><b><em>page proof</em></b> - taken after the author's corrections are made and the type is made-up into pages, sent to the author for final corrections
</dd><dd><b><em>marked proof</em></b> - includes the author's corrections, checked by the printer's reader for conformity with <a href="#housestyle">house style</a>
</dd><dd><b><em>show revise</em></b> - the reader requires a further proof
</dd><dd><b><em>clean proof</em></b> - a statement by the reader that the <a href="#copy">copy</a> is completely corrected
</dd><dd><b><em>press</em></b> - final instruction from the publisher that the <a href="#work">work</a> is ready to <a href="#gonetopress">go to press</a></dd></dl> 
<p>
<b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#proofprint">proof print</a> and <a href="#proofreading">proofreading</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proofimpression"><b>proof impression</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#proofprint">proof print</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proofprint"><b>proof print</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, an <a href="#impression">impression</a> of an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> made from the final <a href="#plate">plate</a> before the regular impression is <a href="#publishing">published</a>, usually prior to the addition of <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#caption">caption</a>.  Synonymous with <em>proof impression</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proofreading"><b>proofreading</b></a>
</dt><dd>The step in the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> process in which the <a href="#printer">printer</a>'s <a href="#proof">proof</a> is meticulously read and compared with the <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#typescript">typescript</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> to detect errors in <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a>.  Corrections are noted on the proof by the <em>proofreader</em> and sent back to the printer.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#typo">typographical error</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="propaganda"><b>propaganda</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally referred to the activities of a committee of cardinals called the <em>congregatio de propaganda fide</em>
(Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith), established in the
17th century by the Roman Catholic Church to oversee the training of
priests for foreign missions. <p>
In modern usage, the organized dissemination of <a href="#information">information</a>,
doctrines, or practices by a person, group, organization, or government
with intent to manipulate or control public opinion in support of a
specific political, social, economic, or religious agenda. In
democratic societies, the <a href="#term">term</a> has acquired a pejorative connotation.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#intellectualfreedom">intellectual freedom</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="propername"><b>proper name</b></a>
</dt><dd>An appelation identifying a specific <a href="#personalname">person</a>, <a href="#corporatename">corporate body</a>, <a href="#geographicname">place</a>, event, or entity.  Each part of a proper name is <a href="#capitalization">capitalized</a> (<em>examples</em>:  <a href="#gutenberg">Johann Gutenberg</a>, Catholic Church, Salt Lake City, American Revolution, Statue of Liberty)   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="propertystamp"><b>property stamp</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#rubberstamp">rubber stamp</a> used to <a href="#ownershipmark">mark ownership</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in <a href="#ink">ink</a>, usually on the inside of the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, on one of the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>(s), on one or more of the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, or across the top, bottom, or <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of the <a href="#section">section</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proposal"><b>proposal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A plan for a project involving <a href="#research">research</a>, scholarship, or creative endeavor, usually written as part of an application for <a href="#grant">grant</a>
funding by the person or group who conceived the idea with the
intention of pursuing it to fruition. A proposal typically includes a
brief <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>, a detailed <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> description, a statement of <a href="#goal">goal</a>s and <a href="#objective">objective</a>s, a realistic timetable, a list of resources (human and material), an itemized <a href="#budget">budget</a>, criteria for evaluating success, a commitment to specific reporting procedures, and <a href="#letters">letters</a> of support affirming the value of the project.  <a href="#manual">Manual</a>s on proposal writing are available in most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proprietary"><b>proprietary</b></a>
</dt><dd>Something that is privately owned and controlled, usually by a
person or commercial company. The term implies that the specifications
or authority needed to reproduce the thing are withheld from public
knowledge or protected by law (<a href="#copyright">copyright</a> or <a href="#patent">patent</a>).  In computing, a system, <a href="#interface">interface</a>, <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>, or <a href="#file">file</a> available only by permission of the owner or <a href="#author">author</a>, as opposed to one available for use without restrictions.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proprietarylib"><b>proprietary library</b></a>
</dt><dd>An early form of <a href="#library">library</a> in which the
capital (property) was held in a common fund as joint stock owned by
the members in shares that could be sold or transferred independently.
Proprietors were required to pay an annual assessment on their shares,
and non-proprietors were allowed use of the library only upon payment
of an annual <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  Compare with <a href="#subscriptionlib">subscription library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proquest"><b>ProQuest</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#information">information</a> service that provides <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> of <a href="#article">article</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in thousands of <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, including the <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> of a significant <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#title">title</a>s.  One of the three leading <a href="#aggregator">aggregator</a>s of <a href="#journal">journal</a>s available in electronic <a href="#format">format</a>, <b>ProQuest</b> relies on the extensive UMI <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> collection to expand its <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s.  <a href="http://www.proquest.com/">Click here</a> to connect the the <b>ProQuest</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ebsco">EBSCO</a> and <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prose"><b>prose</b></a>
</dt><dd>Spoken and written <a href="#language">language</a> in its ordinary everyday form, as distinct from <a href="#poetry">poetic</a>
language consciously given metric structure. Samuel Taylor Coleridge
defined prose as "words in their best order" and poetry as "the best
words in the best order." <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#purpleprose">purple prose</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="prospectus"><b>prospectus</b></a>
</dt><dd>A separately <a href="#printing">printed</a> advertisement, usually in the form of a <a href="#leaflet">leaflet</a> distributed by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to prospective purchasers, describing or sketching the plan of a <a href="#forthcoming">forthcoming</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> for the purpose of soliciting <a href="#advanceorder">advance order</a>s, sometimes with the added inducement of a <a href="#prepubprice">prepublication price</a> or <a href="#prepubdiscount">discount</a>.  Usually includes a sample <a href="#page">page</a> and <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a>, list of <a href="#contributor">contributor</a>s, and <a href="#information">information</a> about <a href="#listprice">price</a> and estimated <a href="#publicationdate">date of publication</a>.  Used for major <a href="#work">work</a>s, such as <a href="#serial">serial</a>s and expensive <a href="#multivolumework">multivolume</a> <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#set">set</a>s, to provide more detailed <a href="#information">information</a> than a <a href="#selection">selector</a> can normally obtain from reading <a href="#review">review</a>s and <a href="#bookannouncement">book announcement</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="protocol"><b>protocol</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of formal conventions for the exchange of <a href="#data">data</a> between <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>s connected to a computer <a href="#network">network</a>, including the rules governing data <a href="#format">format</a> and control of <a href="#input">input</a>, transmission, and <a href="#output">output</a>.  Data transmission over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> is governed by the <a href="#tcpip">TCP/IP</a> protocol implemented in 1982, which allows users of different types of computers to communicate seamlessly.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#osi">Open System Interconnection (OSI)</a>. 
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#signature">signed</a> diplomatic <a href="#document">document</a> recording points of agreement reached at a <a href="#conference">conference</a> between two or more nations, preliminary to negotiating a formal <a href="#treaty">treaty</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="provenance"><b>provenance</b></a>
</dt><dd>A record of the origin and history of ownership or <a href="#custodian">custodian</a>ship of a <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, or other object of value.  <a href="#bookplate">Bookplate</a>s, <a href="#ownershipmark">ownership mark</a>s, <a href="#inscribed">inscription</a>s, <a href="#insert">insert</a>ed matter, a special <a href="#binding">binding</a>, and notes written in or on an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> often provide evidence of provenance, which can be important in establishing the value of <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s and manuscripts.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#exlibrary">ex-library copy</a>. 
<p>
In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the succession of <a href="#custody">custodian</a>s responsible for creating, receiving, or accumulating a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#records">records</a> or <a href="#personalpapers">personal papers</a>.  <a href="#authentication">Authentication</a> of archival materials requires that provenance be determined with certainty.  The related principle of <a href="#respectdesfonds">respect des fonds</a> requires that records known to have originated from a given source be <a href="#documentation">documented</a> and retained separately from those of other <a href="#agency">agencies</a> or persons, and in their <a href="#originalorder">original order</a> and organizational context, whenever possible. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proverb"><b>proverb</b></a>
</dt><dd>A short memorable saying of unknown origin, but in common use,
expressing in simple yet vivid language an obvious truth, familiar
experience, or piece of sage advice, often <a href="#metaphor">metaphor</a>ical or alliterative (<em>example</em>: <b>look before you leap</b>).  Proverbs are <a href="#collection">collected</a> and <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a>, usually shelved in the <a href="#refstacks">reference section</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="provisionaledition"><b>provisional edition</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#preliminaryedition">preliminary edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="provisionalserial"><b>provisional serial</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> as a <a href="#serial">serial</a> while in the process of being <a href="#publishing">published</a>, but as a nonserial when complete, usually because the period of publication is lengthy and/or the <a href="#number">number</a>ing of <a href="#issue">issue</a>s complicated.  Compare with <a href="#pseudoserial">pseudo-serial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="provisionalterm"><b>provisional term</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> or <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> added temporarily to an <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>, subject to future evaluation, often representing a new concept in a <a href="#field">field</a> whose <a href="#terminology">terminology</a> is still growing.  Compare with <a href="#identifier">identifier</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proximity"><b>proximity</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a> of some <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s allows a <em>proximity operator</em> to be used in <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>s to specify that a <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> will be <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a> only if the <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> typed as <a href="#searchterm">search term</a>s appear within a designated <a href="#number">number</a> of words of each other, or within the same sentence or paragraph. The proximity operator is not <a href="#standardization">standardized</a> (in some <a href="#database">database</a>s it is "adj" for <em>adjacent to</em>, in others it is "w" for <em>with</em>).  
<p> 
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>: <b>publication adj1 date</b> or <b>publication w1 date</b></dd></dl>
<p> 
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd>In the example given above, the <a href="#query">query</a> will retrieve records in which the word "publication" appears within one word of "date," for example, records containing the <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> <em>date of publication</em> or <em>publication date</em> (or both) and also <em>date for publication</em>, <em>publication and date</em>, <em>publication to date</em>, etc.</dd></dl>  
<p>
If proximity searching is available in a specific database, instructions concerning its use can usually be found in the <a href="#helpscreen">help screen</a>(s).  Synonymous with <em>adjacency</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="proxyserver"><b>proxy server</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> that operates <em>between</em> a <a href="#client">client</a> and <a href="#server">server</a> on a computer <a href="#network">network</a>, usually installed as a <a href="#firewall">firewall</a> to provide <a href="#security">security</a> or to increase speed of <a href="#access">access</a> by performing some of the <a href="#housekeeping">housekeeping</a> tasks that would normally be handled by the server itself, such as checking <a href="#authentication">authentication</a> or validating user requests.  Also called a <em>proxy</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#daemon">daemon</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="psalter"><b>psalter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> containing a <a href="#version">version</a> of the psalms of the <em>Bible</em>, separately <a href="#printing">printed</a> for <a href="#liturgicalwork">liturgical</a> or devotional use.  Medieval psalters were often beautifully <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pseudandry"><b>pseudandry</b></a>
</dt><dd>A female <a href="#author">author</a> writing under a masculine <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a>, common literary practice during the 18th and 19th centuries when writing was considered an unsuitable occupation for a woman (<em>example</em>:  <b>George Eliot</b> whose real name was Mary Ann Evans Cross).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pseudepigrapha"><b>pseudepigrapha</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#text">Text</a>s falsely ascribed to <a href="#character">character</a>s
in the Old Testament, subsequently found to have been written by Jews
and Christians between 300 BC and 200 AD. In a general sense, any text
falsely <a href="#attributed">attributed</a> to a major <a href="#author">author</a>.  Some scholars have argued that all the <a href="#work">work</a>s of William Shakespeare fall into this category.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pseudonym"><b>pseudonym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#fiction">fictitious</a> name, especially one assumed by an <a href="#author">author</a> to conceal or obscure identity.  The classic example in American <a href="#literature">literature</a>
is Mark Twain whose real name was Samuel Langhorne Clemens. The writer
Francois Marie Arouet (Voltaire) probably holds the record for the most
pseudonyms, with Daniel Foe (Defoe) a close second. Prior to the
mid-19th century, women writers often used male pseudonyms (<a href="#pseudandry">pseudandry</a>) to get their <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> and to attract <a href="#readership">readership</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>George Sand</b>
whose real name was Amandine-Aurore-Lucile Dupin Dudevant), although
there were notable exceptions (Jane Austen and the Bronte sisters). A <em>joint pseudonym</em> is one shared by two or more <a href="#collaborator">collaborator</a>s in a work (<b>Stone, Rosetta</b> by by Dr. Seuss and the <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a> Michael K. Frith).  <a href="#information">Information</a> on pseudonyms can be found in the latest <a href="#edition">edition</a> of <b><em>Pseudonyms and Nicknames Dictionary</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>.  <a href="http://www.trussel.com/books/pseudo.htm">Click here</a> to connect to <b><em>a.k.a.</em></b>, an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> of pseudonyms.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>pseud.</em>  Compare with <a href="#allonym">allonym</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#penname">pen name</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pseudoserial"><b>pseudo-serial</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> treated by a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> as a <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>ic <a href="#work">work</a> when first <a href="#publishing">published</a>, but subsequently as a <a href="#serial">serial</a>, usually after having been repeatedly <a href="#revisededition">revised</a> and <a href="#reissue">reissue</a>d (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Guide to Reference Books</em></b> published by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>).  Compare with <a href="#provisionalserial">provisional serial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="psp"><b>PSP</b></a>
</dt><dd>The professional and scholarly <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> division of the <a href="#aap">Association of American Publishers</a> which includes in its membership <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s of <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> materials, computer <a href="#software">software</a>, <a href="#database">database</a>s, and <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>s
in technology, science, medicine, law, business, the social and
behavioral sciences, and the humanities. A book published by such a
company is known in the <a href="#booktrade">trade</a> as a <em>PSP book</em>.  <a href="http://www.pspcentral.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>PSP</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#professionalbook">professional book</a> and <a href="#stm">STM</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="psychologicalnovel"><b>psychological novel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#novel">novel</a> in which the <a href="#plot">plot</a> and <a href="#setting">setting</a> are secondary to the <a href="#author">author</a>'s exploration of the mind and motives of the principal <a href="#character">character</a>s in the <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Crime and Punishment</em></b> by Fyodor Dostoyevsky).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ptdla1"><b>PTDLA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ptdla"><b>P</b>atent and <b>T</b>rademark <b>D</b>epository <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publicaddress"><b>public address system</b></a>
</dt><dd>A voice amplification system installed in a large facility, used for paging <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> when their presence is required, and for informing <a href="#patron">patron</a>s of <a href="#closing">closing</a> time, emergencies, etc.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the microphone is usually installed behind the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> and used only when necessary, to minimize distraction.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publication"><b>publication</b></a>
</dt><dd>Under U.S. <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law, the act of distributing <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a creative <a href="#work">work</a> to the public by sale, lease, rental, or lending.  Also refers to a work capable of being read or otherwise perceived (<a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#audiorecording">audiorecording</a>, <a href="#videorecording">videocrecording</a>, <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, etc.), <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> for sale to the general public, usually in multiple copies and sometimes in multiple <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#privately">privately printed</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#libpublication">library publication</a>, <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, and <a href="#pubhistory">publication history</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publicationdate"><b>publication date</b></a>
</dt><dd>The date on which <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a creative <a href="#work">work</a> are officially offered for sale to the public.  For <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a>s, the date is announced by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> in advance and promotional activities are coordinated with it.  In <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s, the publication date is given as the year, usually on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  When date of first publication differs from date of current <a href="#edition">edition</a>, first and subsequent dates are indicated.  In older books, publication date may be given in the <a href="#colophon">colophon</a>.  In <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, it is the day and month, or just the month or period of <a href="#issue">issue</a> (spring, summer, fall, winter), usually printed on the front <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  For <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, <a href="#releasedate">release date</a> is used.  For a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>, it is usually the date of last <a href="#update">update</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, publication date is <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>ed as one of the <a href="#element">element</a>s in the <a href="#publicationarea">publication, distribution, etc.</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>pub date</em>.  Synonymous with <em>imprint date</em>.  Compare with <a href="#copyrightdate">copyright date</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#daterange">date range</a>, <a href="#falsedate">false date</a>, <a href="#nodate">no date</a>, and <a href="#postdated">postdated</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publicationarea"><b>publication, distribution, etc.</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#area">area</a> of <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a> in a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> reserved for <a href="#information">information</a> about the act of <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, <a href="#distributor">distributing</a>, <a href="#releasedate">releasing</a>, and <a href="#issue">issuing</a> a specific <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> (<a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#field">field</a> 260), including <a href="#placeofpublication">place of publication</a>, name of <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, and <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pubhistory"><b>publication history</b></a>
</dt><dd>For <a href="#book">book</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in one or more <a href="#volume">volume</a>s, the sequence of <a href="#printing">printing</a>s and <a href="#edition">edition</a>s of a <a href="#work">work</a>, especially any changes in the <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  For <a href="#serial">serial</a>s, the sequence of volumes, <a href="#part">part</a>s, or <a href="#number">number</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d, including any <a href="#nongapbreak">break</a>s, <a href="#changedtitle">title change</a>s, or changes in publisher.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, details of publication are given for a serial in the <a href="#numericalphabetic">numeric and/or alphabetic, chronological, or other designation</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, in an <a href="#openentry">open</a> or <a href="#closedentry">closed entry</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publicschedule"><b>publication schedule</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, a timetable established by the managing <a href="#editor">editor</a> for the process of <a href="#editing">editing</a>, <a href="#printing">printing</a>, and <a href="#binding">binding</a> a new <a href="#publication">publication</a> (or new <a href="#edition">edition</a> of an existing one) to ensure that it will be ready for distribution by the projected <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publicationtype"><b>publication type</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#materialtype">material type</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pubyear"><b>publication year</b></a>
</dt><dd>The twelve-month period during which all the <a href="#issue">issue</a>s or <a href="#part">part</a>s of a <a href="#volume">volume</a> of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> are issued, which may not coincide with the <a href="#calendaryear">calendar year</a>, for example, for some of the <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#hwwilson">H. W. Wilson</a>, the <a href="#publication">publication</a> year begins with a month other than January (<em>Art Index</em>, <em>Education Index</em>, <em>Social Sciences Index</em>, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publicdomain"><b>public domain</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#work">Work</a>s <em>not</em> protected by <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, or for which copyright has expired, which may be <a href="#printing">printed</a> for distribution and sale, <a href="#quotation">quoted</a>, <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>ed, <a href="#reproduction">reproduced</a>, and made available <a href="#online">online</a> to the public without <a href="#infringement">infringement</a>, for example, a <a href="#govdocs">government document</a> over which a <a href="#govtagency">state agency</a> decides not to exercise copyright in order to make its <a href="#content">content</a> widely known.  The <a href="#term">term</a> also applies to computer <a href="#software">software</a> (<a href="#freeware">freeware</a> and <a href="#shareware">shareware</a>) which the designers make available at no charge as a public service.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publicity"><b>publicity</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#information">Information</a> publicly distributed in a variety of forms (announcements, advertisements, <a href="#pressrelease">press release</a>s, <a href="#flier">flier</a>s, <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, etc.) with the intention of making something widely known.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> sponsor special events, especially during <a href="#nlw">National Library Week</a>, to <em>publicize</em> their services and programs.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#publicrelations">public relations</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publiclending"><b>Public Lending Right (PLR)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Under programs funded by the national governments of Britain, Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, <a href="#author">author</a>s of <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#circulation">circulated</a> by <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> are entitled to receive a subsidy based on the <a href="#number">number</a> of times a <a href="#book">book</a> is borrowed.  In Britain, living authors and <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>s named on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> may register to receive compensation, provided they are UK residents.  <a href="#periodical">Periodical</a>s, <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s, and <a href="#conference">conference</a> <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a> are excluded, as are works of less than 32 <a href="#page">page</a>s (24 pages for <a href="#poetry">poetry</a> and <a href="#play">drama</a>).  For a more detailed discussion of <b>PLR</b>, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> by John Sumsion in the <b><em>International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science</em></b> (New York: Routledge, 1997). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publiclibrary"><b>public library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> that provides unrestricted <a href="#access">access</a> to library resources and services free-of-charge to <em>all</em>
the residents of a given community, district, or geographic region,
supported wholly or in part by public funds. Because public libraries
have a broader mandate than <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> and most <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>, they must <a href="#collecdevel">develop</a> their <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s to reflect <a href="#diversity">diversity</a>.  The largest public library system in the United States is the <a href="#nypl">New York Public Library</a>.  <a href="http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/Libweb/Public_main.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>Libweb</em></b> directory of U.S. public libraries.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pla">Public Library Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pla"><b>Public Library Association (PLA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> since 1944, <b>PLA</b> has a membership consisting of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#librarytrustee">library trustee</a>s, and <a href="#friends">friends</a> interested in the general improvement and expansion of <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> services for <a href="#reader">reader</a>s of all ages.  <b>PLA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <em><a href="http://www.pla.org/mag-index.html">Public Libraries</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.pla.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>PLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publicrelations"><b>public relations</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publicity">Publicity</a> designed to create favorable public opinion and boost awareness of the benefits of <a href="#library">library</a> services, resources, and programs, and promote the interests of libraries in society.
