Large <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> <a href="#librarysystem">system</a>s usually employ at least one <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> member <a href="#specialization">specializing</a> in public relations.  The <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> actively promotes libraries, especially during <a href="#nlw">National Library Week</a>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/celebrating/">Click here</a> to connect to the ALA's <em>Celebrating America's Libraries</em> <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#friends">Friends of the Library</a> and <a href="#fundraising">fund-raising</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publicservices"><b>public services</b></a>
</dt><dd>Activities and operations of a <a href="#library">library</a> that bring the <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> into regular direct contact with its users, including <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>, <a href="#refdesk">reference</a>, <a href="#onlineservices">online services</a>, <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>, <a href="#serialsdesk">serials</a> assistance, <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a>, and <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>/<a href="#docdeliv">document delivery</a>, as opposed to <a href="#technicalservices">technical services</a> which are performed behind-the-scenes, out of contact with library users.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pubtv"><b>public television</b></a>
</dt><dd>Television <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> stations supported by foundation <a href="#grant">grant</a>s,
government subsidies, and contributions from viewers, commercial
companies, and other benefactors, providing cultural, educational, and
recreational programming for <a href="#adult">adult</a>s and children.
Public television stations do not rely on ratings so the quality of
their programming is not dictated by the need to cater to the widest
possible viewing <a href="#audience">audience</a>.  In the United States, the public broadcasting system is <a href="http://www.pbs.org/">PBS</a>.  In Great Britain, it is the <a href="#bbc">BBC</a> and in Canada, <a href="http://www.cbc.ca/">CBC</a>.  Compare with <a href="#comtv">commercial televison</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#readingrainbow">Reading Rainbow</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publishedprice"><b>published price</b></a>
</dt><dd>The retail price at which a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> offers a <a href="#book">book</a> for sale at the time of <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the inside <a href="#flap">flap</a> of the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> editions and on the back <a href="#cover">cover</a> in <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  Under certain conditions, a <a href="#discount">discount</a> may be given on specific <a href="#title">title</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>list price</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#prepubprice">prepublication price</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publisher"><b>publisher</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate entity</a> that prepares and <a href="#issue">issue</a>s <a href="#printing">printed</a> materials for public sale or distribution, normally on the basis of a legal <a href="#bookcontract">contract</a> in which the publisher is granted certain exclusive rights in exchange for assuming the financial risk of <a href="#publication">publication</a>, and agrees to compensate the <a href="#author">author</a>, usually with a share of the profits.  In older <a href="#book">book</a>s, the publisher and <a href="#printer">printer</a> are often the same, but in modern <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the two functions are performed by separate entities.  The name of the publisher is usually printed at the <a href="#foot">foot</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, and on the <a href="#verso">verso</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, name of publisher is entered in the <a href="#publicationarea">publication, distribution, etc.</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  Compare with <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#device">device</a>.  
<p>
In the United States, the <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a> of the publishing industry is the <a href="http://www.publishers.org/index.htm">Association of American Publishers</a> (AAP).  An international <a href="http://www.library.vanderbilt.edu/law/acqs/pubr.html">Directory of Publishers and Vendors</a> is available <a href="#online">online</a> from <a href="http://acqweb.library.vanderbilt.edu/">AcqWeb</a>, a <a href="#website">Website</a> created and maintained especially for <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> and <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s.  One of the <a href="#volume">volume</a>s of <em><a href="#bip">Books in Print</a> (BIP)</em> is a print <a href="#directory">directory</a> of U.S. publishers, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#commercialpublisher">commercial publisher</a>, <a href="#foreignsub">foreign subsidiary</a>, <a href="#museumpublisher">museum publisher</a>, <a href="#popularpress">popular press</a>, <a href="#privatepress">private press</a>, <a href="#smallpress">small press</a>, <a href="#tradepublisher">trade publisher</a>, <a href="#universitypress">university press</a>, and <a href="#vanitypublisher">vanity publisher</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publishersagreement"><b>publisher's agreement</b></a>
</dt><dd>A contract between a writer and <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> stating the terms under which the <a href="#author">author</a>'s <a href="#work">work</a>(s) will be <a href="#publishing">published</a> and sold.  The publisher is granted certain exclusive rights in exchange for assuming the financial risk of <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  Under most agreements, the author is compensated in one of four ways:  <a href="#royalties">royalties</a> based on a percentage of sales, profit-sharing, commission, or outright sale of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>.  Synonymous with <a href="#bookcontract">book contract</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publishersbinding"><b>publisher's binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#binding">binding</a> on a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> as originally <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, intended for sale in <a href="#tradebookstore">trade bookstore</a>s, usually a <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> <a href="#casebinding">case binding</a>.  Not all <a href="#copy">copies</a> of an <a href="#edition">edition</a> are cased at the same time, or even by the same <a href="#bindery">bindery</a>, which may lead to slight variations in <a href="#state">state</a> within the same edition.  Synonymous with <em>edition binding</em> and <em>trade binding</em>.  Compare with <a href="#popularedition">popular edition</a> and <a href="#prelibrary">prelibrary binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publisherscatalog"><b>publisher's catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A free advertising <a href="#brochure">brochure</a> sent by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, and other prospective customers, describing <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s (<a href="#frontlist">frontlist</a>) and listing <a href="#title">title</a>s on the <a href="#backlist">backlist</a>, usually <a href="#index">index</a>ed by <a href="#author">author</a> and title, with an order form in the back.  Publisher's <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s are <a href="#issue">issue</a>d <a href="#season">season</a>ally, usually in the spring and fall of each year.  <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s <a href="#selection">select</a> on the basis of <a href="#review">review</a>s, but may use publisher's <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s to verify <a href="#information">information</a> prior to ordering.  <a href="http://www.lights.com/publisher/">Click here</a> to connect to a seachable <a href="#database">database</a> of <em>Publishers' Catalogues</em> maintained by Peter Scott of the University of Saskatchewan Library.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#blurb">blurb</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publishersreader"><b>publisher's reader</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#reader">reader</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publishersweekly"><b><em>Publishers Weekly (PW)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#weekly">weekly</a> <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> of the American <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> industry since 1872, <b><em>Publishers Weekly</em></b> includes news and announcements, <a href="#authorinterview">author interview</a>s, advance <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#review">review</a>s, <a href="#article">article</a>s about book production, and analysis of trends of interest to <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, and others involved in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>. <b><em>PW</em></b> is published by Cahners Business Information, a division of Elsevier.  <a href="http://publishersweekly.reviewsnews.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> version of <b><em>PW</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publishing"><b>publishing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The business of <a href="#issue">issuing</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s, music, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, and other <a href="#printing">printed</a> materials for sale to the public, which includes negotiating <a href="#bookcontract">contract</a>s with <a href="#author">author</a>s and their <a href="#literaryagent">literary agent</a>s, <a href="#editing">editing</a> the author's <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, designing the physical <a href="#bibitem">item</a> (<a href="#typography">typography</a>, <a href="#layout">layout</a>, etc.), producing the finished product (<a href="#printing">printing</a>, <a href="#binding">binding</a> etc.), marketing the <a href="#work">work</a>, and making arrangements for its distribution through regular market channels.  In the United States, the <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a> of the publishing industry is the <a href="http://www.publishers.org/index.htm">American Association of Publishers</a> (AAP).  The industry's <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> is <em><a href="#publishersweekly">Publishers Weekly</a></em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#copublishing">co-publishing</a>, <a href="#desktop">desktop publishing</a>, <a href="#electronicpub">electronic publishing</a>, and <a href="#nichepublishing">niche publishing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="publishingseason"><b>publishing season</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#season">season</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pubmed"><b><em>PubMed</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#medline">MEDLINE</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="puff"><b>puff</b></a>
</dt><dd>A pejorative term used since the 17th century to refer to immoderate praise of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other creative <a href="#work">work</a>, usually in the form of a <a href="#review">review</a> or advertisement written by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#author">author</a>, or a <a href="#copy">copy</a> writer, intended to influence opinion and promote sales.  In <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, a puff is usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> or included in an advertisement in a <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>.  A <em>preliminary puff</em> is written prior to <a href="#publication">publication</a> for the use of traveling sales representatives.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#blurb">blurb</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="puffery"><b>puffery</b></a>
</dt><dd>Biased literary <a href="#criticism">criticism</a> emanating from a small clique or coterie, usually individuals who have a vested interest in promoting the <a href="#work">work</a>, either because they stand to gain financially from its success, are indebted to the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> for some reason, or are personal friends of the <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pugillaria"><b>pugillaria</b></a>
</dt><dd>In ancient Rome, a <a href="#book">book</a> small enough to be held in the hand, consisting of two to eight <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> made of wood, ivory, or metal, covered on one side with wax on which <a href="#character">character</a>s were incised with a sharp writing implement called a <a href="#stylus">stylus</a>.  <a href="#cover">Cover</a>ed in <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> or <a href="#leather">leather</a>, the tablets were held together by leather cords or rings.  Synonymous with <em>tablet book</em>.  Compare with <a href="#diptych">diptych</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#codex">codex</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pulitzer"><b>Pulitzer Prize</b></a>
</dt><dd>Named after the Hungarian-American journalist and philanthropist Joseph Pulitzer who initially endowed them, the <b>Pulitzer Prizes</b> have been awarded <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by Columbia University since 1917 for exemplary achievements in American <a href="#journalism">journalism</a>, <a href="#letters">letters</a>, <a href="#play">drama</a>, and music.  Fourteen prizes are given in journalism, including a gold medal for public service.  The prizes in <a href="#letters">letters</a> are for <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, history, <a href="#poetry">poetry</a>, <a href="#biography">biography</a> or <a href="#autobiography">autobiography</a>, and general <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>.  Each prize includes $5,000 paid by the Pulitzer <a href="#endowment">endowment</a>s.  <a href="http://www.pulitzer.org/index.html">Click here</a> to see a list of <b>Pulitzer Prize</b> winners.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nationalbook">National Book Award</a> and <a href="#nobel">Nobel Prize in Literature</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pullcase"><b>pull-case</b></a>
</dt><dd>A telescoping box in two separable parts, designed as a <a href="#container">container</a> for a <a href="#book">book</a> (or <a href="#set">set</a> of books), <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> material.  Compare with <a href="#slipcase">slipcase</a> and <a href="#solander">solander</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pulling"><b>pulling</b></a>
</dt><dd>Disassembling a <a href="#book">book</a> to prepare it for <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>, a process that requires the removal of <a href="#case">case</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a>, <a href="#board">board</a>s, <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s, <a href="#tapes">tapes</a>, and <a href="#lining">lining</a>.  The <a href="#section">section</a>s are then freed by stripping the <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> from the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> and cutting the <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> <a href="#thread">thread</a>s.  Synonymous with <a href="#takedown">take down</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pullout"><b>pull-out</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#throwout">throw-out</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pulp"><b>pulp</b></a>
</dt><dd>Vegetable material reduced to a liquid fibrous mass by mechanical and/or chemical means for use in <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>.  Most pulp is manufactured from wood, but <a href="#permanentpaper">permanent paper</a> usually contains a percentage of cotton and/or linen <a href="#ragpaper">rag</a>.  <em>Chemical wood pulp</em> is treated in manufacture to remove <a href="#lignin">lignin</a>, an <a href="#acidic">acidic</a> substance that causes the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> and <a href="#binding">binding</a>s of <a href="#book">book</a>s to <a href="#deterioration">deteriorate</a> over time.  Untreated <em>mechanical wood paper</em> is used for low-grade <a href="#paper">paper</a>s such as <a href="#newsprint">newsprint</a> when <a href="#permanence">permanence</a> is not essential.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fibercontent">fiber content</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pulpfiction"><b>pulp fiction</b></a>
</dt><dd>Sensational <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> of no enduring
literary value, popular from the 1920s through the 1940s. Written for
the mass market, usually according to formula, pulp fiction was <a href="#printing">printed</a> on poor-quality <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#softcover">softcover</a>, and easily recognized by the lurid design on the front <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  Popular <a href="#genre">genre</a>s include <a href="#romance">romance</a>, adventure, <a href="#western">western</a>s, etc.  Compare with <a href="#popularfiction">popular fiction</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#massmarket">mass-market paperback</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pulpmagazine"><b>pulp magazine</b></a>
</dt><dd>An inexpensive popular <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> of the early 20th century, devoted to sensational stories of love, adventure, <a href="#mystery">mystery</a>, or intrigue, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#newsprint">newsprint</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ephemera">ephemera</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="punctuation"><b>punctuation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The use of standard <a href="#character">character</a>s in writing and <a href="#printing">printing</a> to separate words, clauses, parenthetical <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s, sentences, etc., and to indicate meaning or tone.  In the English <a href="#language">language</a>, the most frequently used <em>punctuation marks</em> are the <a href="#period">period</a> (.), comma (,), colon (:), semicolon (;), question mark(?), exclamation point (!), apostrophe ('), <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> marks (" "), <a href="#parenthesis">parentheses</a> ( ), <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a> (-), <a href="#dash">dash</a> (--), and <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s [ ].  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, precise rules for the use of punctuation in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>s are given in the instructions for each <a href="#area">area</a> of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#spacing">spacing</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="puppetry"><b>puppetry</b></a>
</dt><dd>A technique used in <a href="#storytelling">storytelling</a> in which each <a href="#character">character</a> in the <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>
is represented by a doll with movable parts operated with wire,
strings, and/or sticks, or in the form of a cloth mitten or glove
designed to fit over the hand of the <em>puppeteer</em>, who synchronizes the movements of the doll with <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> and action in the <a href="#text">text</a>.  A small portable stage may be used as a backdrop.  Some <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> include <a href="#circulating">circulating</a> <em>puppets</em> in the <a href="#juvenile">juvenile collection</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="purchaseorder"><b>purchase order (PO)</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, the official <a href="#record">record</a> of an order placed by a <a href="#library">library</a>, authorizing a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>, or <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>
to deliver materials or services at a fixed price. A PO becomes a
contract once it is accepted by the seller. Most purchase orders
include the purchase order number, name and address of seller, name and
address of ordering <a href="#agency">agency</a>, description and quantity of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s ordered, <a href="#price">price</a> per item (with totals), <a href="#discount">discount</a> or <a href="#credit">credit</a> terms, fund to be charged, time for completion, <a href="#shipping">shipping</a> terms, and delivery address and instructions.  Compare with <a href="#invoice">invoice</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#acquisitionnumber">acquisition number</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="purenotation"><b>pure notation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> <a href="#notation">notation</a> in which only one kind of <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> is used, usually <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s <em>or</em> <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> but not both, for example, the <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s used to indicate <a href="#classnumber">class number</a>s in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>.  Compare with <a href="#mixednotation">mixed notation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="purpleprose"><b>purple prose</b></a>
</dt><dd>A pejorative term for a passage or entire <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> written in a <a href="#prose">prose</a> style so extravagantly overdone as to tax the <a href="#reader">reader</a> with its incongruity.  Synonymous with <em>purple patch</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pva"><b>PVA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#polyvinylacetate"><b>p</b>oly<b>v</b>inyl <b>a</b>cetate</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pvc"><b>PVC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#polyvinylchloride"><b>p</b>oly<b>v</b>inyl <b>c</b>hloride</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pw"><b><em>PW</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#publishersweekly"><b>P</b>ublishers <b>W</b>eekly</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="pyropatron"><b>pyro-patron</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#patron">patron</a>
who is 1) showing signs of combustability, 2) in imminent danger of
igniting, or 3) already on fire, usually a test of civility and
self-control for the <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a>.  For possible responses, please see:  John Herbert, "Pyro-Patron Policy" in <em>The Unabashed Librarian</em> (1998).  Synonymous with <em>flaming patron</em> and <em>conflagrated patron</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#problempatron">problem patron</a>.  
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="Q">Q</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><p>
</p><dt><a name="quad"><b>quad</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#quadrangle">quadrangle</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quadrangle"><b>quadrangle</b></a>
</dt><dd>A four-sided area of the earth's surface, bounded by parallels of latitude and meridians of longitude, used as a unit in <a href="#map">map</a>ping.  The dimensions of a <em>quad</em> are not necessarily the same in both directions.  The 1:24,000 7.5-minute <a href="#topographic">topographic</a> quadrangle is the <a href="#basemap">base map</a> used by the <a href="#nationalsurvey">U.S. Geological Survey</a>, the largest <a href="#mappingagency">mapping agency</a> in the United States.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quadraphonic"><b>quadraphonic</b></a>
</dt><dd>Sound reproduced by an audio device simultaneously from four
separate channels with four amplifiers or speakers. Quadraphonic sound
separation produces a more realistic result than <a href="#monaural">monaural</a> or <a href="#stereophonic">stereophonic</a> <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quadrennial"><b>quadrennial</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d every four years.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> issued every four years.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#annual">annual</a>, <a href="#biennial">biennial</a>, <a href="#triennial">triennial</a>, <a href="#quinquennial">quinquennial</a>, <a href="#sexennial">sexennial</a>, <a href="#septennial">septennial</a>, and <a href="#decennial">decennial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="qualification"><b>qualification</b></a>
</dt><dd>Evidence that a person applying for employment has passed the
requisite examinations, or acquired the education, experience, and
skills necessary to meet the requirements stated in the <a href="#positiondescrip">position description</a>.  Usually used in the plural:  <em>qualifications</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="qualifier"><b>qualifier</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#parenthetical">parenthetical qualifier</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="qualityofservice"><b>quality of service</b></a>
</dt><dd>The degree to which the services provided by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> meet the needs of its users and the <a href="#standards">standards</a> established by the profession, usually <a href="#assessment">assessed</a> statisticcally and on the basis of qualitative <a href="#feedback">feedback</a> (<a href="#usersurvey">user survey</a>s, <a href="#suggestionbox">suggestion box</a>, etc.).  Quality of service is affected by <a href="#budget">budget</a>ary constraints, management policies, design and condition of facilities, personnel decisions, and employee morale.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>QoS</em>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="qualitypaperback"><b>quality paperback</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#tradepaperback">trade paperback</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quanititydiscount"><b>quantity discount</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#discount">discount</a> offered by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#jobber">jobber</a> to <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s and <a href="#library">libraries</a> on orders for a minimum <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#copy">copies</a> of the same <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, or a minimum number of assorted <a href="#title">title</a>s.  Large libraries are usually in a better position than small libraries to take advantage of such offers.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quarterbinding"><b>quarter binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A style of <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> in which the <a href="#spine">spine</a> is bound in a different material than the sides, usually a more <a href="#durability">durable</a> covering such as <a href="#leather">leather</a>, often in a contrasting color, extending no more than one-eighth of the width of the <a href="#board">board</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#fullbinding">full binding</a>, <a href="#halfbinding">half binding</a>, and <a href="#threequarter">three-quarter binding</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#quarterleather">quarter leather</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quarterleather"><b>quarter leather</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#spine">spine</a> is <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#leather">leather</a> and the rest <a href="#cover">cover</a>ed in some other material, such as <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>, often in a contrasting color.  Compare with <a href="#halfleather">half leather</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quarterly"><b>quarterly</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d four times a year.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d every three months, usually in spring, summer, fall, and winter.  Most scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a>s are <a href="#publishing">published</a> quarterly (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Shakespeare Quarterly</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quarto"><b>quarto (4to)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a>, approximately 13 inches in <a href="#height">height</a>, made by folding a full <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of book <a href="#paper">paper</a> in two right-angle folds, producing <a href="#signature">signature</a>s of four <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> (eight <a href="#page">page</a>s).  The precise size of each leaf in a quarto <a href="#edition">edition</a> depends on the size of the original sheet.  Some early editions are known by the <a href="#number">number</a> of leaves in their sections, for example, the <em>Quarto Edition</em> of Shakespeare's <a href="#play">play</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#folio">folio</a>, <a href="#octavo">octavo</a>, <a href="#duodecimo">duodecimo</a>, and <a href="#sextodecimo">sextodecimo</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quasisynonym"><b>quasi-synonym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> not precisely the same in meaning as another <a href="#term">term</a>, which is nevertheless treated as <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>ous in a given <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>, for example, the term "Library science" <a href="#usedfor">used for</a> (UF) "Librarianship" in the <em><a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress Subject Headings</a></em> list.  Synonymous with <em>near-synonym</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quaternbook"><b>quatern book</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a>, the <a href="#binder">binder</a> traditionally bound the thirteenth book at no charge, presumably as an incentive to place larger <a href="#binding">binding</a> orders, but by the early 19th century, this custom was restricted in England to all the <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a single <a href="#title">title</a> delivered to the <a href="#bindery">bindery</a> at the same time, and was not carried over into machine-binding.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quaternion"><b>quaternion</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a <a href="#gathering">gathering</a> consisting of four <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> folded once to create eight <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, used in assembling some <a href="#manuscriptbook">manuscript book</a>s and early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ternion">ternion</a>, <a href="#quinternion">quinternion</a>, and <a href="#sextern">sextern</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="query"><b>query</b></a>
</dt><dd>A request submitted as <a href="#input">input</a> in a <a href="#search">search</a> of an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, to <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s or <a href="#document">document</a>s <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> to the user's <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>(s).  Some <a href="#isar">information storage and retrieval</a> systems allow queries to be submitted in <a href="#naturallang">natural language</a>, but most systems require the user to formulate <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>s in the <a href="#artificiallang">artificial language</a> used for <a href="#indexinglang">indexing</a>, and in <a href="#syntax">syntax</a> acceptable to the <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a>.  The query is an approximation of the information need that gives rise to the search.  
<p>
Also refers to the symbol <b>?</b> used by the printer's <a href="#reader">reader</a> in the <a href="#margin">margin</a>s of a <a href="#proof">proof</a> to indicate to the <a href="#author">author</a> the need for clarification of a detail in the <a href="#text">text</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="questionnaire"><b>questionnaire</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of written questions, carefully formulated to be administered to a selected group of people for the purpose of gathering <a href="#information">information</a> (<a href="#feedback">feedback</a>) in <a href="#survey">survey</a> <a href="#research">research</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#patron">patron</a>s may be asked to fill out questionnaires designed to <a href="#assessment">assess</a> the perceived quality and usefulness of services and resources.  The results are then compiled and analyzed for use in <a href="#strategicplanning">planning</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="queue"><b>queue</b></a>
</dt><dd>A temporary storage location in a computer, reserved for <a href="#data">data</a> awaiting <a href="#dataprocessing">processing</a>, usually organized <a href="#chronological">chronological</a>ly
(first-in-first-out) or according to some other pre-established
priority. Also refers to a line of people waiting to be served or a
series of tasks waiting to be executed, usually in the order in which
they arrived or were received. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quillandquire"><b><em>Quill &amp; Quire</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in Toronto that provides news and <a href="#review">review</a>s of <a href="#book">book</a>s published in Canada.  The June and December <a href="#issue">issue</a>s include the <em>Canadian Publishers Directory</em> as a free <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>.  <a href="http://www.quillandquire.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> version of <b><em>Q&amp;Q</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quinquennial"><b>quinquennial</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d very five years.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> issued every five years (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Biography and Genealogy Master Index</em></b>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#annual">annual</a>, <a href="#biennial">biennial</a>, <a href="#triennial">triennial</a>, <a href="#quadrennial">quadrennial</a>, <a href="#sexennial">sexennial</a>, <a href="#septennial">septennial</a>, and <a href="#decennial">decennial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quinternion"><b>quinternion</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a <a href="#gathering">gathering</a> consisting of five <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> folded once to create ten <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, used in assembling some <a href="#manuscriptbook">manuscript book</a>s and early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ternion">ternion</a>, <a href="#quaternion">quaternion</a>, and <a href="#sextern">sextern</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quire"><b>quire</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally referred to a <a href="#gathering">gathering</a> of four <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s of <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a>, forming eight <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> or sixteen <a href="#page">page</a>s, convenient for hand-<a href="#sewing">sewn</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s in which the leaves were made of <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>.  When paper came into widespread use after the invention of <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>, the fact that it was thinner meant more sheets could be included in a gathering.  In modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, the word <em>quire</em> is synonymous with <em>gathering</em>, <em><a href="#section">section</a></em>, and <em><a href="#signature">signature</a></em>, particularly when unfolded.  Also refers to one-twentieth of a <a href="#ream">ream</a>, equal to 24 <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s of handmade paper or 25 sheets of machine-made paper.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quorum"><b>quorum</b></a>
</dt><dd>The minimum number of members who must be present for business
to be conducted at a meeting governed by the rules of parliamentary
procedure. When a quorum is not present, a meeting may proceed without
formally transacting business.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="quotation"><b>quotation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Words or passages reproduced from a written <a href="#work">work</a> or repeated <a href="#verbatim">verbatim</a> from an oral statement.  Because words and <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s taken out of <a href="#context">context</a> may give a misleading impression of the whole, care must be taken in selecting quotations.  A passage quoted incorrectly is a <em>misquotation</em>.  In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the <a href="#accuracy">accuracy</a> of quotations is checked by the <a href="#editor">editor</a>.  
<p>
In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, brief quotations are set in the <a href="#text">text</a>, enclosed in <em>quotation marks</em>.  Long quotations, called <em>block quotations</em>, are set apart from the main text by <a href="#indention">indention</a>, and are printed in smaller <a href="#typesize">type size</a> without quotation marks, preceded and followed by a <a href="#blank">blank</a> line.  A very long quotation is called an <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>.  To avoid <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> <a href="#infringement">infringement</a>, quotations in a written work should be <a href="#documentation">documented</a> in <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s or <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>s. In an oral statement, the <a href="#source">source</a> should be verbally acknowledged as a courtesy to the original <a href="#author">author</a>.  Synonymous with <em>quote</em>.  Compare with <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#permission">permission</a>.
</p></dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>

| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

                                                          
<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="R">R</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="radiograph"><b>radiograph</b></a>
</dt><dd>An image produced by exposing a sensitized surface (<a href="#film">film</a> or <a href="#plate">plate</a>) to radiation other than visible light, especially X-rays.  Collected mainly by <a href="#medicallib">medical libraries</a>, radiographs are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> as <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> materials in <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ragbook"><b>rag book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#clothbook">cloth book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ragged"><b>ragged</b></a>
</dt><dd>Refers to a <a href="#page">page</a> of <a href="#type">type</a> with lines of variable length, usually <em>ragged right</em>, <a href="#typesetting">set</a> <a href="#flush">flush</a> (aligned) with the left-hand <a href="#margin">margin</a> but un<a href="#justification">justified</a> on the right, as in the lines of a <a href="#poetry">poem</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ragpaper"><b>rag paper</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#paper">Paper</a> made from cotton and/or linen rags, stronger and more <a href="#permanentpaper">permanent</a>
than paper made from wood or most other fibers, but also more
expensive. Rag content is usually indicated as a percentage. Paper made
from 100% rag fiber is called <em>all-rag</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#biblepaper">bible paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="raisedbands"><b>raised bands</b></a>
</dt><dd>Narrow, slightly elevated ridges visible across the width of the <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#handbinding">hand-bound</a> <a href="#book">book</a>, produced by cords binding the <a href="#section">section</a>s together underneath the material applied as a covering.  When faked on a decorative <a href="#binding">binding</a>, such ridges are called <em>false bands</em>.  The opposite of <a href="#sunkbands">sunk bands</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="raisedcapital"><b>raised capital</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, an <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a>, usually at the beginning of the first paragraph of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>, projecting above the line of <a href="#type">type</a> on which it appears.  Synonymous with <em>cocked-up initial</em>.  Compare with <a href="#dropinitial">drop initial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ram1"><b>RAM</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ram"><b>R</b>andom <b>A</b>ccess <b>M</b>emory</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ramie"><b>ramie</b></a>
</dt><dd>Fiber of the Asiatic plant species <em>Baehmeria nivea</em>, in the nettle family, one of the most <a href="#durability">durable</a> materials for weaving and <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, used in <a href="#printing">printing</a> bank notes.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ragpaper">rag paper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ram"><b>random access memory (RAM)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of high-speed <a href="#memory">memory</a> <a href="#chip">chip</a>s that perform most of the <a href="#centralproc">processing</a> in a computer, allowing users to <a href="#access">access</a> <a href="#byte">byte</a>s of <a href="#data">data</a> in any order, rather than <a href="#sequential">sequential</a>ly.  At startup, the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> and any <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s are routinely loaded from the <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a> into <b>RAM</b> to allow processing to begin.  Any <a href="#data">data</a> in current use is also stored in <b>RAM</b>.  To retain their content, <b>RAM</b> chips must have electric power, which is why users must <a href="#save">save</a> data to a slower <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> (hard disk, <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>, <a href="#zipdisk">Zip disk</a>, etc.) before <a href="#powerdown">powering down</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#buffer">buffer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ranganathan"><b>Ranganathan, S(hiyali) R(amamrita) (1892-1972)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A former mathematics professor who, after receiving an honors certificate in <a href="#libraryscience">library science</a> from the University of London in 1925, served as first <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> of the University of Madras until 1944 where he developed <em><a href="#colonclassification">Colon Classification</a></em> (1933), a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> used in <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> worldwide.  
<p>
Ranganathan's pioneering work in <a href="#libraryeducation">library education</a> established him as the "father" of <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>
in India. He helped found the Indian Library Association in 1933 and
served as its president from 1944 to 1953. From 1948 to 1958 he served
on the Indian national committee for cooperation with UNESCO, focusing
his attention on issues of concern to <a href="#library">libraries</a>, and from 1951 to 1962 he was <em>rapporteur-general</em> for the <a href="#documentation">documentation</a> classification section of the International Federation for Documentation.  
</p><p>
In 1956, Ranganathan gave his life savings to endow a professorship in
library science at the University of Madras, the first such chair
outside the United States. In 1962, he used the <a href="#royalties">royalties</a> from his <a href="#book">book</a>s to establish an <a href="#endowment">endowment</a> for annual lectures given in India by eminent contributors to library science from around the world.  He is famous for his <em>Five Laws of Library Science</em> (1931):
</p><p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd>1. Books are for use.
</dd><dd>2. Every reader his book.
</dd><dd>3. Every book its reader.
</dd><dd>4. Save the time of the reader.
</dd><dd>5. A library is a growing organism.</dd></dl>  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="range"><b>range</b></a>
</dt><dd>A component of a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#stacks">stack</a>, consisting of a row of two or more <a href="#section">section</a>s of single- or double-faced <a href="#fixedshelving">fixed</a> or adjustable shelving, with common uprights or shelf supports between each section.  The row may be <a href="#freestanding">free-standing</a> or assembled against a <a href="#wallshelving">wall</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the difference between the largest value and the smallest in a given set of numerical <a href="#data">data</a>, for example, a <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> range specified by the user in a <a href="#search">search</a> of an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, to <a href="#limiting">limit</a> retrieval to <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> within a certain period. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rangeaisle"><b>range aisle</b></a>
</dt><dd>The narrow corridor or passageway between two <a href="#range">range</a>s of shelves in the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>.  In the United States, the standard minimum aisle width in <a href="#newconstruc">new</a> and <a href="#renovation">renovated</a> facilities is 36 inches.  Some kinds of <a href="#compactshelving">compact shelving</a> allow the distance between ranges to be adjusted as needed.  Synonymous with <em>stack aisle</em>.  Compare with <a href="#crossaisle">cross aisle</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rank"><b>rank</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any one of a number of grades of employment within a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, reflecting the <a href="#qualification">qualification</a>s, experience, skill, and length of tenure of the person occupying the <a href="#position">position</a> to which the rank applies, usually associated with a given rate or range of compensation.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> at institutions that grant <a href="#facultystatus">faculty status</a> to <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, the ranks are usually <em>Instructor</em>, <em>Assistant Librarian</em>, <em>Associate Librarian</em>, and <em>Librarian</em>.  The ranks for <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> who do not hold the <a href="#mls">M.L.S.</a> or <a href="#mlis">M.L.I.S.</a> degree are based on technical skill and experience.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#promotion">promotion</a>.
<p>
Also, to put a series of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s, <a href="#record">record</a>s, <a href="#citation">citation</a>s,
applicants, etc., in sequence based on one or more evaluative criteria
such as relevance, usefulness, merit, etc. The presence of an <a href="#option">option</a> allowing users to rank <a href="#search">search</a> results by <a href="#relevance">relevance</a> is a mark of sophistication in <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a>.  Compare with <a href="#sorting">sorting</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ranking"><b>ranking</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, the presentation of <a href="#search">search</a>
results in a sequence based on one or more criteria which, in some
systems, the user may specify in advance. The most common are <a href="#currency">currency</a> (<a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>) and <a href="#relevance">relevance</a>, usually determined by the <a href="#number">number</a> of occurrences of the <a href="#searchterm">search term</a>s typed as <a href="#input">input</a> and their location in the <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> (in <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s, <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>, or <a href="#text">text</a>).  Compare with <a href="#sorting">sorting</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#weighting">weighting</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rarebook"><b>rare book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A valuable <a href="#book">book</a> so difficult to find that only a few copies are known to <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s.  Those that do exist seldom appear on the market and are consequently coveted.  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> keep their <a href="#rarity">rare</a> books in a <a href="#security">secure</a> location to which <a href="#access">access</a> is <a href="#restricted">restricted</a> (usually in <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>).  Very rare books are sold at <a href="#bookauction">book auction</a>s and by <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>s serving <a href="#bookcollecting">collector</a>s.  <a href="http://www.rbms.nd.edu/yob.html">Click here</a> to read the answers to a list of <a href="#faq">frequently asked questions</a> about rare books, provided by the late Peter Van Wingen of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  For a detailed discussion of the history of rare book <a href="#library">libraries</a>, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> by Daniel Traister in the <b><em>International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science</em></b> (New York: Routledge, 1997).  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#incunabula">incunabula</a>, <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>, <a href="#priceguide">price guide</a>, and <a href="#rbms">Rare Books and Manuscripts Section</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rbms"><b>Rare Books and Manuscripts Section (RBMS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Created in 1948 as a special committee of the <a href="#acrl">Association of College and Research Libraries</a>, <b>RBMS</b> exercises leadership in local, national, and international <a href="#specialcollections">special collection</a>s communities to represent and promote the interests of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#curator">curator</a>s, and other <a href="#specialization">specialist</a>s concerned with the <a href="#acquisitions">acquisition</a>, organization, <a href="#security">security</a>, <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, <a href="#libadmin">administration</a>, and use of special <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, including <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#archives">archives</a>, <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> materials, music, <a href="#ephemera">ephemera</a>, etc.  <b>RBMS</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> <em>RBM: A Journal of Rare Books, Manuscripts, and Cultural Heritage</em> and the semiannual <em>RBMS Newsletter</em>.  <a href="http://www.rbms.nd.edu/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>RBMS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="raremap"><b>rare map</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#rarity">Rarity</a> in <a href="#map">map</a>s depends on the history of the country or region depicted.  As a general rule, any map of the United States <a href="#publishing">published</a>
before 1900 is considered rare, especially if it depicts an area west
of the Rocky Mountains. In Great Britain, a map is considered rare if
published prior to 1825. As historical <a href="#document">document</a>s, rare maps are often of considerable interest to scholars and <a href="#bookcollecting">collector</a>s.  They can also be aesthetically pleasing.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rarity"><b>rarity</b></a>
</dt><dd>The degree to which a <a href="#book">book</a> or other item is scarce or uncommon, which, in combination with its age, <a href="#condition">condition</a>, and aesthetic qualities, helps determine its value in the market place.  In the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, degrees of rarity are classified as follows:
<p>
</p><dl><dt>
</dt><dd><b><em>Scarce</em></b> - comes to the attention of an expert in <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s no more than once in a year
</dd><dd><b><em>Rare</em></b> - comes to the attention of an expert once in a decade
</dd><dd><b><em>Very rare</em></b> - comes to the attention of an expert once in a lifetime
</dd><dd><b><em>Unique</em></b> - one-of-a-kind, no other <a href="#copy">copies</a> known to exist</dd></dl>
<p>
<b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#raremap">rare map</a> and <a href="#rbms">Rare Books and Manuscripts Section</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rbb1"><b><em>RBB</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#rbb"><b>R</b>eference <b>B</b>ooks <b>B</b>ulletin</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rbms1"><b>RBMS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#rbms"><b>R</b>are <b>B</b>ooks and <b>M</b>anuscripts <b>S</b>ection</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readable"><b>readable</b></a>
</dt><dd>Capable of being read.  Also refers to reading material that is interesting and written in a style that makes the <a href="#content">content</a> easy for most <a href="#reader">reader</a>s to comprehend.  Sometimes used synonymously with <a href="#legible">legible</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fogindex">fog index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readathon"><b>read-a-thon</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#contraction">contraction</a> of <em><b>read</b>ing mar<b>athon</b></em>, a school or <a href="#library">library</a> event in which young <a href="#reader">reader</a>s are given an incentive to read a certain <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#page">page</a>s or <a href="#book">book</a>s within a designated period of time.  The event may be tied to <a href="#fundraising">fund-raising</a>, with sponsors pledging to contribute a certain amount to a worthy cause when the reading goal is met.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reader"><b>reader</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who reads silently to himself (or herself) or aloud to others, from a <a href="#book">book</a> other other written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> source, or an electronic <a href="#medium">medium</a> displaying <a href="#text">text</a>.  One of the primary goals of <a href="#library">libraries</a> is to encourage reading and <a href="#literacy">literacy</a>.  <a href="#readingpreference">Reading preference</a>s are of particular interest to <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s who use survey techniques to measure them.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#newadultreader">new adult reader</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, a person asked to read and evaluate for potential <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s submitted by <a href="#author">author</a>s and their <a href="#literaryagent">agent</a>s.  In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a person responsible for reading <a href="#proof">proof</a>s and comparing them with the original <a href="#copy">copy</a> to detect <a href="#typo">typographical error</a>s, a process called <a href="#proofreading">proofreading</a>.  Also, a person who volunteers or is paid to read a book onto <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a> for distribution as a <a href="#bookontape">book-on-tape</a>, sometimes a professionally trained actor or actress.
</p><p>
In <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>, a staff member responsible for scanning <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> to select <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s to be routed to persons within the organization who have requested <a href="#currentawareness">current awareness service</a>, based on their <a href="#interestprofile">interest profile</a>s.
</p><p>
Also refers to a <a href="#textbook">textbook</a> containing reading exercises, especially one intended for young school children.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readerprinter"><b>reader-printer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A machine designed for <a href="#enlargement">enlarging</a>, viewing, and making <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#copy">copies</a> of <a href="#microform">microform</a>s (<a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>, <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a>, <a href="#microopaque">microopaque</a>), usually coin-operated (<a href="#fee">fee</a> varies).  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> with microform <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> usually provide at least one reader-printer for <a href="#patron">patron</a> use.  Compare with <a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#copycard">copy card</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readersadvisory"><b>readers' advisory</b></a>
</dt><dd>Services provided by an experienced <a href="#publicservices">public services</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> who <a href="#specialization">specializes</a> in the reading needs of the <a href="#adult">adult</a> <a href="#patron">patron</a>s of a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>.  A reader's advisor recommends specific <a href="#title">title</a>s and/or <a href="#author">author</a>s, based on <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> of a <a href="#patron">patron</a>'s past <a href="#readingpreference">reading preference</a>s, and may also <a href="#compile">compile</a> lists of recommended titles and serve as liaison to other adult education <a href="#agency">agencies</a> in the community.  The same type of <a href="#information">information</a> is provided by <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s such as <b><em>Reader's Adviser:  A Layman's Guide to Reading</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.  Compare with <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readership"><b>readership</b></a>
</dt><dd>The total <a href="#number">number</a> of people who read, or are estimated to read, a given <a href="#publication">publication</a>, not necessarily equal to the number who purchase or <a href="#subscription">subscribe</a> to it.  In <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, total readership equals base <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> plus <a href="#passalong">pass-along</a>.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used to refer to a particular class of reader, for example, <em>educated readership</em> as opposed to <em>general readership</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readingcopy"><b>reading copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#complimentary">complimentary copy</a> of a <a href="#forthcoming">forthcoming</a> <a href="#book">book</a> sent  at no charge by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to selected <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s in advance of the <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>  to promote sales.  Reading copies may be <a href="#printing">printed</a> as part of the regular <a href="#edition">edition</a> and distributed in the same <a href="#binding">binding</a> as the <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>.  Compare with  <a href="#advancecopy">advance copy</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dd>Also refers to a <a href="#usedbook">used book</a> so worn that it is not considered <a href="#collectible">collectible</a> in the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> unless <a href="#rebinding">rebound</a>, but is suitable for reading because no portion of the <a href="#text">text</a> is missing.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readinggroup"><b>reading group</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organized group, usually sponsored by a <a href="#library">library</a>, school, church, or <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>, whose members meet to talk about <a href="#book">book</a>s they have read.  Most groups coordinate their reading so that everyone has read the same book, or a <a href="#work">work</a> by the same <a href="#author">author</a>,
in advance of meeting. In some groups, a facilitator is selected,
sometimes on a rotating basis, who begins the session with a brief <a href="#booktalk">talk</a> about the author or <a href="#newbook">new book</a>, then opens the floor for discussion.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readinglamp"><b>reading lamp</b></a>
</dt><dd>A man-made light source specifically designed to provide the
optimum amount of illumination for a person sitting and reading in a
chair or at a desk, shaded to direct the light downward onto the <a href="#page">page</a> without glare.  Very small models designed to clip onto the <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> can be purchased for reading in bed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readinglevel"><b>reading level</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of several degrees of proficiency in reading, usually
defined in reference to a specific academic grade level (e.g.,
third-grade level) or stage of reading development, applicable to both <a href="#reader">reader</a> and reading material.  Factors determining reading level include <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a>, sentence structure, length of <a href="#text">text</a>, and difficulty of <a href="#content">content</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readinglist"><b>reading list</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of recommended resources (<a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#website">Web site</a>s, etc.) on a <a href="#topic">topic</a>, usually <a href="#compile">compile</a>d by a teacher or <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> with an interest in or expertise on the <a href="#subject">subject</a>, for distribution to students enrolled in a course of study, or available to <a href="#reader">reader</a>s on a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#displayrack">display rack</a>, <a href="#kiosk">kiosk</a>, or <a href="#bulletinboard">bulletin board</a>, not as <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> or scholarly as a <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>. Compare with <a href="#pathfinder">pathfinder</a> and <a href="#researchguide">research guide</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readingmatter"><b>reading matter</b></a>
</dt><dd>Anything that can be read, from the back of a cereal box to a philosophical <a href="#treatise">treatise</a>.  Reading material need not be written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#paper">paper</a>, merely <a href="#text">text</a>-based (<em>example</em>:  a news <a href="#report">report</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> on a <a href="#website">Web Site</a>).  Choice of reading material reflects a person's interests, tastes, education, and experience.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#readersadvisory">reader's advisory</a> and <a href="#readingpreference">reading preference</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readingpreference"><b>reading preference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#reader">reader</a>'s taste in <a href="#readingmatter">reading matter</a>, as to <a href="#format">format</a> (<a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, <a href="#comicbook">comic books</a>, etc.), <a href="#genre">genre</a> (<a href="#fiction">fiction</a> or <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a>), and subject (<a href="#biography">biography</a>,
crime, travel, etc.). Although reading preferences often change as a
person grows older, studies have shown that in some individuals, they
remain remarkably constant. <a href="#publisher">Publisher</a>s use <a href="#survey">survey</a> <a href="#research">research</a> to study the choices consumers make in purchasing reading material.  <a href="#nichepublishing">Niche publisher</a>s may depend on consumers who have developed specific preferences.  In <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, experienced <a href="#publicservices">public services</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, having learned the reading habits of <a href="#regular">regular</a> <a href="#patron">patron</a>s, may order new <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> with the preferences of specific individuals in mind. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readingrainbow"><b><em>Reading Rainbow</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A television series designed to interest children 4-8 years of age in the pleasures of reading outstanding <a href="#childrensbook">books for children</a>, <b><em>Reading Rainbow</em></b> is broadcast daily (M-F) for one-half hour by 95% of the <a href="#pubtv">public television</a> (PBS) stations in the United States.  Its fast-paced <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>-style <a href="#format">format</a> has garnered over 150 awards since its inception, including 13 <a href="#emmy">Emmy Award</a>s.  <a href="http://gpn.unl.edu/rainbow/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>Reading Rainbow</em></b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readingroom"><b>reading room</b></a>
</dt><dd>A specially designated room in a <a href="#library">library</a>, usually furnished with comfortable chairs, study tables, and <a href="#readinglamp">reading lamp</a>s, where a person can study or read quietly without being disturbed.  Reading rooms may also contain <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> such as <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s.  Some libraries have wired their reading rooms to accommodate <a href="#patron">patron</a>s using <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>s, who require <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#access">access</a>.  Reading rooms in very large libraries, such as the <a href="#nypl">New York Public Library</a> at 5th Avenue and 42nd Street, are often beautifully designed and furnished.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readme"><b>readme</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#file">file</a> containing important instructions on how to use a <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a>, or <a href="#information">information</a> about new developments affecting the user of a <a href="#software">software</a> system, which may not be included in the <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#documentation">documentation</a>.  To avoid computer <a href="#virus">virus</a>es, caution should be exercised when opening a readme file sent as an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> <a href="#attachment">attachment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readonly"><b>read-only</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> capable of being read but not modified or erased, used for <a href="#data">data</a> that is to be retained permanently, for example, <a href="#rom">ROM</a> (read only <a href="#memory">memory</a>) and <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#rewritable">rewritable</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#worm">WORM</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rom"><b>Read Only Memory (ROM)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#memory">memory</a> <a href="#chip">chip</a> containing instructions and/or <a href="#data">data</a> that cannot be changed or erased because the manufacturer created it in unalterable form.  Usually contains the <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s required to start the computer.  Compare with <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="readyreference"><b>ready reference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#refquestion">reference question</a> that can be answered by a <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a> in one or two minutes by providing a fact or piece of <a href="#information">information</a> found in a single <a href="#source">source</a>, a type of question which sometimes turns out to be an opening gambit that develops into a more <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#search">search</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to the <a href="#refbook">reference material</a>s used most often in answering such questions, shelved for convenience in a separate location near the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a> rather than in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> (<em><a href="#bip">Books in Print</a></em>, <em><a href="#encyassoc">Encyclopedia of Associations</a></em>, <em>Statistical Abstract of the U.S.</em>, world <a href="#almanac">almanac</a>s, <a href="#citydirectory">city directories</a>, <em><a href="#ulrichs">Ulrich's Periodicals Directory</a></em>, etc.).  <a href="#shelfdummy">Shelf dummies</a> are used in the <a href="#refstacks">reference stacks</a> to direct users to the correct location.  Some <a href="#library">libraries</a> also provide <a href="#online">online</a> ready reference resources via their <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s.  Selection decisions are usually made by the <a href="#publicservices">public services</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s who work at the reference desk, based on consensus developed over time. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="realia"><b>realia</b></a>
</dt><dd>Three-dimensional <a href="#object">object</a>s from real life such as <a href="#artifact">artifact</a>s, <a href="#specimen">specimen</a>s, samples, and naturally occurring objects, sometimes borrowed or purchased by <a href="#library">libraries</a> for use in classroom instruction.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the <a href="#term">term</a> is added inside <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s [realia] as a <a href="#gmd">general material designation</a> following the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> in the the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  Compare with <a href="#replica">replica</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="realtime"><b>real time</b></a>
</dt><dd>Happening immediately, in the present moment. An electronic
process, operation, or routine that occurs quickly enough to affect or
respond to a related process taking place simultaneously in actual
time. The opposite of <a href="#asynchronous">asynchronous</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ream"><b>ream</b></a>
</dt><dd>As originally used in <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, the <a href="#term">term</a> referred to a unit of measurement consisting of twenty <a href="#quire">quire</a>s or 480 <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s of handmade <a href="#paper">paper</a>, but the <a href="#number">number</a> of sheets in a ream eventually became <a href="#standardization">standardized</a> at 500 sheets of machine-made paper.  More recently, European papermakers have adopted 1,000 sheets as the <a href="#standard">standard</a> number.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rebacked"><b>rebacked</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> given a new <a href="#spine">spine</a> and <a href="#mending">mended</a> <a href="#hinge">hinge</a>s, usually because the spine was <a href="#cracked">cracked</a> or the hinges weakened.  Rebacking is not as extensive as <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a> since some of the original <a href="#binding">binding</a> materials (usually the <a href="#board">board</a>s) are retained.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#backstrip">backstrip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rebinding"><b>rebinding</b></a>
</dt><dd>The complete rehabilitation of a <a href="#book">book</a> too worn to be <a href="#mending">mended</a> or <a href="#repairing">repaired</a>, a process that usually entails removing the <a href="#case">case</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a>, re<a href="#sewing">sewing</a> the <a href="#section">section</a>s, and applying a new cover.  The steps involved in preparing a book for rebinding are collectively known as <a href="#pulling">pulling</a>.  Very large <a href="#library">libraries</a> are often equipped to perform rebinding <a href="#inhouse">in-house</a>, but smaller libraries must rely on the services of a commercial <a href="#bindery">bindery</a>.  Compare with <a href="#recased">recased</a> and <a href="#recover">recover</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#coversboundin">covers bound in</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reboot"><b>reboot</b></a>
</dt><dd>To cause the <a href="#file">file</a>s in the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> of a computer to be re-executed, usually by selecting the <a href="#option">option</a> to "Restart" or "Reset," or by pressing <b>Ctrl</b>+<b>Alt</b>+<b>Del</b> on the <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>.
This procedure is sometimes helpful in getting a computer "unstuck"
after it locks up unexpectedly during processing. If it fails, the user
can <a href="#coldboot">cold boot</a> the system, but <a href="#powerdown">powering down</a> will result in the loss of un<a href="#save">save</a>d <a href="#data">data</a>.  Synonymous with <em>warm boot</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#boot">boot</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rebus"><b>rebus</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of puzzle in which certain words in a sentence are replaced by <a href="#picture">picture</a>s
of objects whose names suggest the meaning or sound of the words they
are intended to represent, for example, a picture of a bed to suggest
"sleep" or of an eye to represent the pronoun "I." According to James
Bettley, <a href="#editor">editor</a> of <b><em>The Art of the Book</em></b> (London: V&amp;A Publications, 2001), the earliest known example appears in a <a href="#treatise">treatise</a> on penmanship by Giovambattista Palatino <a href="#printing">printed</a> in 1540.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recall"><b>recall</b></a>
</dt><dd>A request by a <a href="#library">library</a> to one of its <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s to return a borrowed <a href="#bibitem">item</a> <em>before</em> its <a href="#duedate">due date</a>.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, this occasionally happens when an instructor wishes to place the item on <a href="#reserves">reserve</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, a measure of the effectiveness of a <a href="#search">search</a>, expressed as the ratio of the <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s or <a href="#document">document</a>s retrieved in response to the <a href="#query">query</a>, to the total number of relevant records or documents in the <a href="#database">database</a>, for example, in a database containing 100 records relevant to the <a href="#topic">topic</a>
"book history," a search retrieving 50 records, 25 of which are
relevant to the topic, would have 25% recall (25/100). One of the main
difficulties in using recall as a measure of search effectiveness is
that it can be nearly impossible to determine the total number of
relevant records in all but very small databases. Compare with <a href="#precision">precision</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recased"><b>recased</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> that has come <a href="#loose">loose</a> in or fallen out of its <a href="#case">case</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a> and been reglued into it, a process that usually requires new <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s, but not re<a href="#sewing">sewing</a>.  Compare with <a href="#recover">recover</a> and <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recataloging"><b>recataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of making substantial revisions in <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s for <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s that have already been <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a>, usually in response to changes in the needs or policies of a <a href="#library">library</a>, for example, the addition of <a href="#contentsnote">contents note</a>s in records representing <a href="#anthology">anthologies</a> and other <a href="#collection">collected work</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#reclassification">reclassification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="receiving"><b>receiving</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, the initial processing of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> <a href="#shipping">shipped</a> to the <a href="#library">library</a> by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, or <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>, including verification that the correct item was shipped with all <a href="#part">part</a>s included, routing the <a href="#invoice">invoice</a> to the appropriate accounting office for payment, and updating the <a href="#orderrecord">order record</a>, usually with date received, <a href="#number">number</a> of parts received, and an indication of where the item was sent for the next step in <a href="#processing">processing</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recension"><b>recension</b></a>
</dt><dd>A revision of the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, often a literary <a href="#classic">classic</a>, based on a critical examination of earlier texts and <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> <a href="#source">source</a>s, usually undertaken only after a consensus has developed among scholars concerning the weight of evidence.  Compare with <a href="#redaction">redaction</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#textusreceptus">textus receptus</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recently"><b>recently returned</b></a>
</dt><dd>A code used in <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>s to indicate the <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> returned by a <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> and checked in by <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> so recently that it may still be on a holding shelf or in the process of being <a href="#reshelving">reshelved</a>.  The temporary designation assists staff in tracing the item if it cannot be located by <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> in the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recessedmonitor"><b>recessed monitor</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reciprocalagreement"><b>reciprocal agreement</b></a>
</dt><dd>A mutual understanding between <a href="#library">libraries</a>, usually concerning <a href="#fee">fee</a>s for lending via <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>, typically "we will not charge you, if you do not charge us."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reciprocal"><b>reciprocal borrowing privileges</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#borrowingprivileges">Loan privileges</a> granted by independent cooperating <a href="#library">libraries</a> to members of each other's <a href="#usergroup">user group</a>s, sometimes for a modest <a href="#fee">fee</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reclassification"><b>reclassification</b></a>
</dt><dd>Revision of the <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>s assigned to selected <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s to make their relationship to other items in the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> more consistent, for example, to reflect the merger of two <a href="#class">class</a>es very similar in <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  Also refers to the conversion of a collection (or part of a collection) originally <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under one <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> to another, for example, from <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal classification</a> to <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress classification</a>, or vice versa.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recon"><b>recon</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#retrocon">retrospective conversion</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reconfigure"><b>reconfigure</b></a>
</dt><dd>To change the way <a href="#data">data</a> is structured in a computer system.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="record"><b>record</b></a>
</dt><dd>An account of something, put down in writing, usually as a
means of documenting facts for legal or historical purposes. Also, to
make such an account. In a narrower sense, a formal <a href="#document">document</a> in which the <a href="#content">content</a> is presented in a named set of <a href="#standardization">standardized</a> <a href="#data">data</a> elements treated as a single unit, for example, a certificate, deed, lease, etc.  In <a href="#archives">archives</a>,
a document created or received, and subsequently maintained, by an
institution, organization, or individual in the transaction of official
or personal business, or in the fulfillment of a legal obligation. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> and <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>.
<p>
