In computing, a collection of related <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#field">field</a>s organized and <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> as a single entity.  A <a href="#mrdf">machine-readable data file</a> is a collection of such records.
</p><p>
Also, to use an <a href="#audiorecording">audiorecording</a> device to capture and store audio signals for <a href="#playback">playback</a>.  Also refers to any <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a> made on a vinyl disk, for example, a <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recordedbook"><b>recorded book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bookontape">book-on-tape</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recordgroup"><b>record group</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, an aggregation of all the <a href="#records">records</a> of a particular <a href="#agency">agency</a> or person, or a body of records known to be related on the basis of <a href="#provenance">provenance</a>, usually stored together in their <a href="#originalorder">original order</a> (see <a href="#respectdesfonds">respect des fonds</a>).  A <em>record subgroup</em> consists of records within a record group, related in some way (functionally, <a href="#chronological">chronological</a>ly, geographically, etc.) or produced by a subordinate unit of the agency responsible for <a href="#creator">creating</a>, receiving, or accumulating the group.  Subgroups may be further subdivided. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recorditem"><b>record item</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the smallest separate and distinct unit of recorded material which, when accumulated, constitutes a <a href="#recordseries">record series</a>, for example, a <a href="#file">file</a> in a group of related files.  Compare with <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recordkeeping"><b>recordkeeping system</b></a>
</dt><dd>The methods and procedures used in <a href="#creator">creating</a>, <a href="#arrangement">arranging</a>, and maintaining <a href="#records">records</a> of the activities of an <a href="#agency">agency</a> or individual, usually in some kind of systematic order (<a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>, <a href="#chronological">chronological</a>, <a href="#topic">topic</a>al, functional, etc.) which may appear idiosyncratic to outsiders unfamiliar with the system.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#originalorder">original order</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="records"><b>records</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#document">Document</a>s in any form, created or received by an <a href="#agency">agency</a> or person, accumulated in the normal conduct of business or affairs, and retained as evidence of such activity, usually <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> according to a discernible system of <a href="#recordkeeping">recordkeeping</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#activerecords">active records</a>, <a href="#electronicrecords">electronic records</a>, <a href="#inactiverecords">inactive records</a>, <a href="#intermediaterecords">intermediate records</a>, <a href="#machinerecords">machine-readable records</a>, <a href="#officialrecords">official records</a>, <a href="#temprecords">temporary records</a>, <a href="#timeexpired">time-expired records</a>, <a href="#vitalrecords">vital records</a>, and <a href="#recordsmanagement">records management</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recordseries"><b>record series</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, <a href="#records">records</a> of the same <a href="#provenance">provenance</a>,
determined upon inspection to belong together because they 1) are part
of a recognizable filing system, 2) have been stored together because
they were produced by the same activity, 3) are related to the same
function or activity and are similar in <a href="#format">format</a>, or 4) comprise a set logically grouped in some other way.  A record series is usually identified by a unique <em>series number</em> and may in some cases consist of a single <a href="#recorditem">record item</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recordsmanagement"><b>records management</b></a>
</dt><dd>The field of management devoted to achieving accuracy, efficiency, and economy in the systematic creation, <a href="#retention">retention</a>, <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>, dissemination, use, and <a href="#disposition">disposition</a> of the official <a href="#records">records</a> of a company, <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>, organization, or institution, whether in physical or electronic form, usually undertaken by a professionally trained <em>records manager</em> on the basis of a thorough <a href="#recordssurvey">records survey</a>.  <a href="#security">Security</a> and <a href="#disasterplan">disaster preparedness</a> are essential elements of a good records management program.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recordssurvey"><b>records survey</b></a>
</dt><dd>The systematic process of examining <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#records">records</a> in their administrative context to determine their <a href="#content">content</a>, <a href="#format">format</a>, <a href="#provenance">provenance</a>, <a href="#originalorder">original order</a>, physical quantities and <a href="#condition">condition</a>, rates of accumulation, and other characteristics, before beginning the work of describing and <a href="#arrangement">arranging</a> them.  The <a href="#information">information</a> gained in such a survey is also of use in developing <a href="#dispositionschedule">disposition schedule</a>s, planning <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>, determining <a href="#accesspolicy">access policy</a>, and estimating the amount of space required to store them. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recordstructure"><b>record structure</b></a>
</dt><dd>The pre-established sequence of <a href="#field">field</a>s and <a href="#subfield">subfield</a>s used to describe a single <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, each field containing one or more related <a href="#element">element</a>s of <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a>.  For example, the <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a>, date of <a href="#issue">issue</a>, and <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s in the <a href="#sourcefield">source field</a> of a record representing a journal <a href="#article">article</a> in a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> database.  Most catalogs and databases include <a href="#text">text</a>ual <a href="#fieldlabel">field label</a>s in the record display to help users distinguish the various categories of description.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recover"><b>recover</b></a>
</dt><dd>To apply a new <a href="#cover">cover</a> to a <a href="#volume">volume</a>, without re<a href="#sewing">sewing</a> the <a href="#section">section</a>s.  The process of making the new cover and attaching it to the sections is called <em>recovering</em>.  Compare with <a href="#recased">recased</a> and <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>.
<p>
Also, to get back something that was lost, for example, <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> known to have been stolen or <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> and <a href="#lost">lost</a> by the <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>.  <a href="#fee">Fee</a>s may be refunded, depending on the circumstances.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#replevin">replevin</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recruitment"><b>recruitment</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of attracting <a href="#qualification">qualified</a> personnel to work in a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, by posting a notice and <a href="#positiondescrip">position description</a> in <a href="#libjournal">library journal</a>s and to library-related electronic <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>s, and by publicizing the vacancy at job fairs and word-of-mouth.  Also refers to the efforts of <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a>s and professional <a href="#libassociation">library association</a>s to attract promising students to the career of <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recto"><b>recto</b></a>
</dt><dd>The upper side of a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> of <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>, or <a href="#paper">paper</a>, or the right-hand <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a> when opened, usually assigned an uneven <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#verso">verso</a>.  The <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> and <a href="#dedication">dedication</a>, and the first page of the <a href="#preface">preface</a>, <a href="#introduction">introduction</a>, <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a>, <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>s, <a href="#appendix">appendices</a>, <a href="#index">indexes</a>, and other major <a href="#partsofabook">parts of a book</a> are <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the recto.  Also, the side of a single printed <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> intended to be read first, unless both sides are identically printed.  Also known as the <em>obverse</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="recycledpaper"><b>recycled paper</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#paper">Paper</a> manufactured from reclaimed wastepaper that has been reduced to <a href="#pulp">pulp</a> and processed to remove <a href="#ink">ink</a> and other impurities.  Recycled paper is used in <a href="#printing">printing</a> and as writing paper, to conserve natural resources and reduce the volume of refuse in sanitary landfills.  <a href="#book">Book</a> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s consider the highest grades suitable for printing <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="redaction"><b>redaction</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of <a href="#editing">editing</a>, revising, and/or arranging to <a href="#publishing">publish</a> a <a href="#work">work</a> left incomplete or in a condition not suitable for <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually at the death of the <a href="#author">author</a>, done by a <em>redactor</em>.  Also refers to the result of such an endeavor.  Compare with <a href="#continuation">continuation</a> and <a href="#recension">recension</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="redbook"><b>red book</b></a>
</dt><dd>The popular name given to a <a href="#manual">manual</a>
containing official lists of state employees or other eminent people,
for example, members of the British peerage, known by the color of its <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  Compare with <a href="#bluebook">blue book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reduction"><b>reduction</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> or <a href="#copy">copy</a> produced on a smaller <a href="#scale">scale</a> than the <a href="#original">original</a>,
usually indicated as a percentage of the initial size (a 50% reduction
of an 8 x 10-inch original produces a copy measuring 4 x 5 inches).
Most <a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a>s available in <a href="#library">libraries</a> have reduction capability for the convenience of users.  The opposite of <a href="#enlargement">enlargement</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#micrographics">micrographics</a> and <a href="#reductionratio">reduction ratio</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reductionratio"><b>reduction ratio</b></a>
</dt><dd>In microphotography, an indication of the number of times the size of a <a href="#document">document</a> or other object is reduced to form a <a href="#microform">microimage</a>.  For example, 25X means that the image is 25 times smaller than the linear dimensions of the <a href="#original">original</a>.  <a href="#reduction">Reduction</a> ratios are classified as follows:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd>Low reduction - up to 15X
</dd><dd>Medium reduction - 15X to 30X
</dd><dd>High reduction - 30X to 60X
</dd><dd>Very high reduction - 60X to 90X
</dd><dd>Ultrahigh reduction - above 90X</dd></dl>   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="redundancy"><b>redundancy</b></a>
</dt><dd>In communication, the use of repetition to reinforce a message
and prevent misunderstanding, as in a sign that reads, "This Way to the
<a href="#library">Library</a>" instead of simply "Library" or "To the Library."  In a more general sense, any words or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s not essential to the meaning of a message.
<p>
In computer systems, <a href="#device">device</a>s that stand ready to handle transmission or <a href="#centralproc">processing</a>, if and when the units normally used for the purpose fail or have to be taken <a href="#offline">offline</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reel"><b>reel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A flanged circular holder with a hole running from end-to-end onto which a roll of processed <a href="#film">film</a> is wound, usually designed to be inserted in a projector, reader, <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a>, or other display device.  Open reels were once used for <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a>, but have been largely replaced by cartridges.  Compare with <a href="#spool">spool</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="referee"><b>referee</b></a>
</dt><dd>In scholarly <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, an expert whose areas of <a href="#specialization">specialization</a> include the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of a <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#article">article</a> or <a href="#book">book</a>, usually a professional peer of the <a href="#author">author</a>, to whom the <a href="#editor">editor</a> or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> sends the <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> for critical evaluation before accepting it for <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#peerreviewed">peer-reviewed</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refereed"><b>refereed</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#peerreviewed">peer-reviewed</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reference"><b>reference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A conventional word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> used in a <a href="#work">work</a> to refer the <a href="#reader">reader</a> to another part of the <a href="#text">text</a>  (<em>see above</em> or <em>see below</em>), or a similar word or phrase used in an <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, or <a href="#refbook">reference work</a> to direct the user from one <a href="#heading">heading</a> or <a href="#entry">entry</a> to another (<em><a href="#see">see</a></em> or <em><a href="#seealso">see also</a></em>).  Also refers to any Latin phrase used in <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s, <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>s, and <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a> to refer the reader to works previously <a href="#quotation">quoted</a> or <a href="#citation">cited</a>, for example, <em><a href="#ibid">ibid.</a></em> and <em><a href="#opcit">op. cit.</a></em> Sometimes used synonymously with <a href="#citation">citation</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#letters">letter</a> written in support of a person's <a href="#application">application</a> for employment or housing, usually by someone familiar with the applicant's <a href="#qualification">qualification</a>s or reputation, or to a person who agrees to be contacted for such a recommendation, usually by telephone. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rusa"><b>Reference and User Services Association (RUSA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established as a division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> in 1972, <b>RUSA</b> has a membership consisting of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and other individuals committed to promoting the delivery of <a href="#refquestion">reference</a> and <a href="#informationdesk">information</a> services to all persons, regardless of age, in <a href="#library">libraries</a> of all kinds.  <b>RUSA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/rusa/rusq/">Reference and User Services Quarterly (RUSQ)</a></em> and maintains the <a href="#online">online</a> newscenter <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/rusa/update/index.html">RUSA Update</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/rusa/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>RUSA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refbook"><b>reference book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> designed to be consulted when <a href="#authority">authoritative</a> <a href="#information">information</a> is needed, rather than read <a href="#cover">cover</a>-to-cover.  Reference books often consist of a series of <a href="#signed">signed</a> or <a href="#unsigned">unsigned</a> "<a href="#entry">entries</a>" listed <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly under <a href="#headword">headword</a>s or <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, or in some other <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> (<a href="#classified">classified</a>, numeric, etc.).  The category includes <a href="#almanac">almanac</a>s, <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>es, <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a>, <a href="#biography">biographical</a> sources, <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, <a href="#concordance">concordance</a>s, <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a>, <a href="#directory">directories</a>, <a href="#discography">discographies</a> and <a href="#filmography">filmographies</a>, <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s, <a href="#glossary">glossaries</a>, <a href="#handbook">handbook</a>s, <a href="#index">index</a>es, <a href="#manual">manual</a>s, <a href="#researchguide">research guide</a>s, <a href="#unionlist">union list</a>s, and <a href="#yearbook">yearbook</a>s, whether <a href="#publishing">published</a> commercially or as <a href="#govdocs">government document</a>s.  Long reference <a href="#work">work</a>s may be <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#multivolumework">multivolume</a> <a href="#set">set</a>s, with any indexes in the last volume.  Reference works that require continuous <a href="#update">updating</a> may be published <a href="#refserial">serial</a>ly, sometimes as <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> services. 
<p>
In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, reference books are shelved in a separate section called the <a href="#refstacks">reference stacks</a> and are not allowed to <a href="#circulation">circulate</a> because they are needed to answer questions at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>.  Reference books are <a href="#review">review</a>ed in <em><a href="#arba">American Reference Books Annual</a></em>, <em><a href="#choice">CHOICE</a></em>, <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em>, the <em><a href="#rbb">Reference Books Bulletin</a></em> <a href="#section">section</a> of <em><a href="#booklist">Booklist</a></em>, <em>Reference Services Review</em>, and <em><a href="http://www.ala.org/rusa/rusq/">Reference and User Services Quarterly</a></em> published by <a href="#rusa">RUSA</a>.  The two leading <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a> of English-<a href="#language">language</a> reference materials are <b><em>Guide to Reference Books</em></b> published by the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> and <b><em>Walford's Guide to Reference Materials</em></b> published by the <a href="#la">Library Association</a> (UK).  Compare with <a href="#circbook">circulating book</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#poprefbook">popular reference book</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rbb"><b><em>Reference Books Bulletin (RBB)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A separate <a href="#section">section</a> at the end of the <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a> <em><a href="#booklist">Booklist</a></em>, providing <a href="#review">review</a>s of approximately 500 <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s and electronic reference materials annually.  General <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s and certain types of <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a> are often reviewed together to facilitate comparison.  <b><em>RBB</em></b> has its own editorial board and, unlike <em>Booklist</em>, <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> reviews of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <em>not</em> recommended for purchase.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/booklist/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>RBB</em></b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refcollection"><b>reference collection</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#book">Book</a>s not meant to be read <a href="#cover">cover</a>-to-cover, such as <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a>, <a href="#handbook">handbook</a>s, and <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s, shelved together by <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> in a special section of the <a href="#library">library</a> called the <a href="#refstacks">reference stacks</a>.  <a href="#refbook">Reference book</a>s may not be <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> because they are needed by <a href="#reflibrarian">librarian</a>s to answer <a href="#refquestion">question</a>s at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>.  Their <a href="#locationsymbol">location</a> and <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> is usually indicated by the <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> "R" or "Ref" preceding the call number in the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> and on the <a href="#spinelabel">spine label</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#readyreference">ready reference</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refdesk"><b>reference desk</b></a>     
</dt><dd>When a person has a question about how to find specific <a href="#information">information</a> or how to use <a href="#library">library</a> services and resources, assistance can be obtained by contacting the public <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a> located near the <a href="#refcollection">reference collection</a> of the library (in person, by telephone, or in some libraries via <a href="#email">e-mail</a>).  A professionally trained <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a> scheduled to work at the reference desk will try to provide an answer or <a href="#referral">refer</a> the inquirer to a knowledgeable <a href="#source">source</a>.  In large <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, the reference desk may be <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ed by two <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, especially during periods of <a href="#peakuse">peak use</a>.  Compare with <a href="#informationdesk">information desk</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#refinterview">reference interview</a> and <a href="#roving">roving</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refinterview"><b>reference interview</b></a>
</dt><dd>The interpersonal communication that occurs between a <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a> and a <a href="#library">library</a> user to determine the person's specific <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>(s), which may turn out to be different than the <a href="#refquestion">reference question</a> as initially posed.  Because <a href="#patron">patron</a>s are often reticent, especially in face-to-face interaction, patience and tact may be required on the part of the <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>.  A reference interview may occur in person, by telephone, or electronically (usually via <a href="#email">e-mail</a>)
at the request of the user, but a well-trained reference librarian will
sometimes initiate communication if a hesitant user appears to need
assistance. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#roving">roving</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reflibrarian"><b>reference librarian</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> who works in <a href="#publicservices">public services</a>, answering questions posed by <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#patron">patron</a>s at a <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>, by telephone, or via <a href="#email">e-mail</a>.  A reference librarian may also be called upon to provide <a href="#pointofuse">point-of-use instruction</a> on the use of library resources and <a href="#infotech">information technology</a>.  Most reference librarians also assist in the <a href="#selection">selection</a> of a balanced <a href="#refcollection">collection</a> of <a href="#refbook">reference materials</a> to meet the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of the library's <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#roving">roving</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refmark"><b>reference mark</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printer">printer</a>'s <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> used in <a href="#text">text</a> to refer to material <a href="#printing">printed</a> in a different place, for example, in a <a href="#footnote">footnote</a> or in another passage on the same <a href="#page">page</a>.  When more than one reference is given on a page, the order of symbols is:  <a href="#asterisk">asterisk</a>, <a href="#dagger">dagger</a>, <a href="#doubledagger">double dagger</a>, section mark, parallel mark, and paragraph mark.  <a href="#numeral">Numeral</a>s in <a href="#superscript">superscript</a> are preferred by most <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s to indicate the sequence of multiple references.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refquestion"><b>reference question</b></a>
</dt><dd>A request from a <a href="#library">library</a> user for assistance in locating specific <a href="#information">information</a> or in using library resources in general, made in person, by telephone, or via <a href="#email">e-mail</a>.  In most libraries, reference questions are answered by a professionally trained <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a> during a regularly scheduled shift at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>, but in small libraries this function may be performed by a <a href="#paraprofessional">paraprofessional</a>.  A <a href="#refinterview">reference interview</a> may be required to determine the precise nature of the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>.  Questions are usually recorded for statistical purposes by category (<a href="#directional">directional</a>, informational, instructional, <a href="#inforeferral">referral</a>) in a <a href="#transactionlog">transaction log</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refserial"><b>reference serial</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> used by <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a>s to find <a href="#authority">authoritative</a> <a href="#information">information</a>, which is <a href="#issue">issue</a>d successively at <a href="#regular">regular</a> or <a href="#irregular">irregular</a> intervals with no indication of an ending date.  The category includes <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a> and <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Contemporary Authors</em></b>), <a href="#directory">directories</a> (<b><em>AV Market Place</em></b>), <a href="#annual">annual</a>s (<b><em>Europa World Year Book</em></b>), <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> services (<b><em>Facts on File</em></b>), etc.  Reference <a href="#serial">serial</a>s are normally placed on <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a> and shelved with other reference materials in the <a href="#refstacks">reference stacks</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refservices"><b>reference services</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the functions performed by a trained <a href="#reflibrarian">librarian</a> employed in the reference section of a <a href="#library">library</a> to meet the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of <a href="#patron">patron</a>s (in person, by telephone, or via <a href="#email">e-mail</a>), including but not limited to answering substantive <a href="#refquestion">question</a>s, instructing users in the selection and use of appropriate <a href="#findingtool">tool</a>s and techniques for finding <a href="#information">information</a>, conducting <a href="#search">search</a>es on behalf of the patron, directing users to the location of library resources, assisting in the evaluation of information, <a href="#referral">referring</a> patrons to resources outside the library when appropriate, keeping <a href="#refstatistics">reference statistics</a>, and participating in the <a href="#collecdevel">development</a> of the <a href="#refcollection">reference collection</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refsource"><b>reference source</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any <a href="#publication">publication</a> used by a <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a> to provide <a href="#authority">authoritative</a> <a href="#information">information</a> in response to a <a href="#refquestion">reference question</a>, including but not limited to <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s, <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>s, <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#index">index</a>es and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting services</a>, and <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s.  Individuals and services outside the <a href="#library">library</a> who can be relied upon to provide authoritative information are considered <em>resources</em> for <a href="#referral">referral</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refstacks"><b>reference stacks</b></a>
</dt><dd>The area of a <a href="#library">library</a> in which the <a href="#refcollection">reference collection</a> is shelved in <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> order, usually located near the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>, <a href="#openstacks">open</a> to the public in most <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> in the United States.  <a href="#printing">Printed</a> <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es may be shelved separately from the <a href="#refbook">reference book</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, usually <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#title">title</a> or in a <a href="#classified">classified</a> <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#readyreference">ready reference</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refstatistics"><b>reference statistics</b></a>
</dt><dd>In most <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s who work at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a> keep a daily <a href="#transactionlog">transaction log</a> in which they record <a href="#refquestion">reference question</a>s, usually by hour and type of question (<a href="#information">information</a>al, directional, instructional, <a href="#inforeferral">referral</a>, etc.).  <a href="#compile">Compile</a>d by week, month, and year, the results are analyzed to reveal patterns and trends helpful in anticipating <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ing needs, scheduling the reference desk, <a href="#collecdevel">developing</a> the <a href="#refcollection">reference collection</a>, and planning new services.  The <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> responsible for supervising <a href="#refservices">reference services</a> may also <a href="#cite">cite</a> them in <a href="#report">report</a>s submitted to the <a href="#libadmin">library administration</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="referral"><b>referral</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of reference transaction in which a <a href="#patron">patron</a> with an <a href="#infoneed">information need</a> is directed to a reputable person or <a href="#agency">agency</a> outside the <a href="#library">library</a>, better <a href="#qualification">qualified</a> to provide assistance.  In some <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, a list or <a href="#index">index</a> of referral agencies and resources, with contact <a href="#information">information</a>, is maintained at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a> for this purpose.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#inforeferral">information and referral</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reforma"><b>Reforma</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1971 as an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>Reforma</b> actively promotes the development of Spanish-<a href="#language">language</a> and Latino-oriented <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s, <a href="#recruitment">recruitment</a> of bilingual and multicultural <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and <a href="#supportstaff">support staff</a>, development of <a href="#library">library</a> programs and services for the Latino community, public awareness of library services among Latinos, lobbying on behalf of the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of Latinos, and liaison with other professional organizations.  <a href="http://www.reforma.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Reforma</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reformat"><b>reformat</b></a>
</dt><dd>To convert a <a href="#document">document</a> from one <a href="#format">format</a> to another without changing its <a href="#content">content</a>, for example, a <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#article">article</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#print">print</a> to <a href="#microform">microform</a> for compact storage, or from print to <a href="#ascii">ASCII</a> <a href="#text">text</a> for inclusion in a <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>.  In <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, reformatting is usually undertaken when the long-term survival of a <a href="#document">document</a> in its current format is unlikely, for example, a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> electronically in a <a href="#medium">medium</a> rapidly becoming obsolete, or a document <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#acidpaper">acid paper</a> which is in an advanced state of <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a>.  
<p>
Also, to prepare a <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a> for a new use by completely erasing any <a href="#data">data</a> stored on it.  Normally when a disk is re<a href="#initialize">initialize</a>d, it is also tested to make sure it is still reliable.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="refresh"><b>refresh</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#reload">reload</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="regionalbook"><b>regional book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A term used in the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> industry for a <a href="#book">book</a> written to appeal to <a href="#reader">reader</a>s who live in, or have an interest in, a specific geographic area.  Regional books are often published by <a href="#smallpress">small press</a>es for sale in local bookstores or by mail-order.  They include local histories, <a href="#biography">biographies</a>, <a href="#genealogy">genealogies</a>, <a href="#directory">directories</a>, <a href="#cookbook">cookbook</a>s, <a href="#travelguide">travel guide</a>s, <a href="#fieldguide">field guide</a>s, etc.  Some <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> shelve them in a separate section to make them more <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="regionallib"><b>regional library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> serving the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s
of a group of communities or counties in the United States, supported
by public funds provided by the units of government within its <a href="#servicearea">service area</a> (<em>example</em>:  the King County Library System in the Seattle metropolitan area). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="register"><b>register</b></a>
</dt><dd>The alignment of <a href="#page">page</a>s back-to-back during the <a href="#printing">printing</a> of the second side of a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>, to make the <a href="#text">text</a> blocks coincide exactly.  In multicolor printing, the precise alignment of the <a href="#impression">impression</a> for each color with the one(s) preceding it to produce an image that is <em>in register</em> (sharp), rather than <em>out of register</em> (blurred).  Also refers to the list of <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s by which the <a href="#signature">signature</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> are marked to indicate their sequence in <a href="#binding">binding</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a length of thin ribbon <a href="#glue">glue</a>d to the top of the <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> before <a href="#lining">lining</a>, for use as a <a href="#bookmark">bookmark</a>.
Books used in the services of the Roman Catholic Church sometimes have
several ribbons in different colors for marking more than one <a href="#page">page</a>
in the text. In French bookbinding of the 16th century, a precious
stone or other ornament was sometimes attached to the ribbon.
Synonymous in this sense with <em>signet</em>.
</p><p>
Also refers to a list of names, addresses, events, dates, etc., usually <a href="#compile">compile</a>d in a single <a href="#chronological">chronological</a> or numerical sequence and maintained as an official log or <a href="#record">record</a>.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used for the act of recording <a href="#information">information</a> in such a list.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#registry">registry</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="registry"><b>registry</b></a>
</dt><dd>The office responsible for maintaining one or more official lists or <a href="#register">register</a>s of names, addresses, events, dates, or other <a href="#information">information</a>, usually for legal purposes.  For example, in the United States the official registry for <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>s is the <a href="#usco">U.S. Copyright Office</a> of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is sometimes used for the list or record itself.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#isds">International Serials Data System</a> and <a href="#nfr">National Film Registry</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="regular"><b>regular</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#frequency">frequency</a> of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d
at intervals governed by an established rule, usually of uniform
length, expressed in days, weeks, months, quarters, years, etc. (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> with the exception of August and December).  The opposite of <a href="#irregular">irregular</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a person who attends a certain type of event or uses the same service(s) at fairly predictable intervals.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> often have regular <a href="#patron">patron</a>s whose habits and <a href="#readingpreference">reading preference</a>s become familiar to the <a href="#publicservices">public services</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s who serve them.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reimburse"><b>reimburse</b></a>
</dt><dd>To pay back money spent by another person or compensate
someone for damages or expenses incurred, usually upon presentation of
a receipt verifying the amount. In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, employees may be reimbursed for travel expenses, office supplies purchased out of pocket, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reinforced"><b>reinforced binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publishersbinding">publisher's binding</a> that has been strengthened, usually by adding a strip of cloth to each <a href="#hinge">hinge</a> and using stronger <a href="#thread">thread</a> to <a href="#sewing">sew</a> the <a href="#section">section</a>s, but which does not meet the <a href="#standards">standards</a> for <a href="#prelibrary">prelibrary binding</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reinstate"><b>reinstate</b></a>
</dt><dd>To return something to a former condition, or a person to a <a href="#position">position</a> from which he or she has been removed, sometimes in compliance with the outcome of a <a href="#grievance">grievance</a> procedure or lawsuit.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reissue"><b>reissue</b></a>
</dt><dd>A second or subsequent <a href="#impression">impression</a> of a previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> in which the <a href="#text">text</a> remains substantially the same, but the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> may be redesigned and the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> and <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a> altered.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rejectionslip"><b>rejection slip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> slip sent by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> with a returned <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> to inform the <a href="#author">author</a> that the <a href="#work">work</a> has <em>not</em> been accepted for <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  <b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#overthetransom">over the transom</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="relatedbody"><b>related body</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a> associated with another corporate body, but not functioning under its direct authority, for example, a <a href="#friends">Friends</a> group that supports a <a href="#library">library</a> through <a href="#volunteer">volunteer</a> work, <a href="#fundraising">fund raising</a>, <a href="#libraryadvocate">advocacy</a>, and other activities, but is not a unit within its organizational structure.  Compare with <a href="#subordinatebody">subordinate body</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="relatedterm"><b>related term (RT or R)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> or <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> in a <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, closely related to another <a href="#term">term</a> conceptually, but not <a href="#hierarchicrelation">hierarchically</a> (<em>example</em>:  "Media Specialists" under "School Libraries").  A descriptor or subject heading may have more than one related term (<em>example</em>:  "Children's libraries" under "School Libraries").  Compare with <a href="#broaderterm">broader term</a> (BT) and <a href="#narrowerterm">narrower term</a> (NT).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="relatedwork"><b>related work</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dependentwork">dependent work</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="relationship"><b>relationship</b></a>
</dt><dd>As defined in <em><a href="#frbr">FRBR</a></em> (<em>Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records</em>), the nature of the link between <a href="#entity">entities</a>, for example, between one <a href="#work">work</a> and another (a "<a href="#prequel">prequel</a> to" Shakespeare's <a href="#play">play</a> <b><em>Hamlet</em></b>), between a work and one of its <a href="#expression">expression</a>s (the film version of <b><em>Hamlet</em></b> "adapted and directed by" Kenneth Branagh), between an expression and one of its <a href="#manifestation">manifestation</a>s (Branagh's <a href="#adaptation">adaptation</a> of <b><em>Hamlet</em></b> "embodied in" the <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a> released in 1997 by Columbia TriStar Home Video), or between a manifestation and one of its <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s (a <a href="#set">set</a> of <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>s "exemplifying" the 1997 videorecording of Branagh's interpretation of <b><em>Hamlet</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="relativehumidity"><b>relative humidity</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#humidity">humidity</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="relativeindex"><b>relative index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#subjectindex">subject index</a> to a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, indicating the <a href="#class">class</a>es under which <a href="#subject">subject</a>s are listed, with their <a href="#notation">notation</a>s.  In the <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> <a href="#classificationschedule">schedules</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>s are <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> by <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>.  At the end of the schedules, an <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> <a href="#index">index</a>
of subjects is provided (the Relative Index), indicating the
disciplines in which each subject is found, listed in alphabetical
order and <a href="#indention">indented</a> under the <a href="#heading">heading</a> for each subject, with the corresponding <a href="#classnumber">class number</a>s listed in a <a href="#column">column</a> on the right-hand side of the <a href="#page">page</a>.  For example, the <a href="#entry">entry</a> for the subject "Books" directs the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> to the discipline "Bibliographies" which has the notation <b>011</b>, and also to "Publishing" (<b>070.5</b>), "Sociology" (<b>302.232</b>), and "Technology" (<b>686</b>).   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="release"><b>release</b></a>
</dt><dd>To allow <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a recorded <a href="#work">work</a> to be <a href="#issue">issue</a>d, shown, or sold to the general public for the first time.  In the case of <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s and <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, to permit <a href="#copy">copies</a> to be distributed for public viewing.  In exceptional cases, a motion picture may be <em>rereleased</em> in significantly altered form.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#releasedate">release date</a> is used as the <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pressrelease">press release</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="releasedate"><b>release date</b></a>
</dt><dd>The date on which a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> or <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a> is officially made available for distribution to theaters for public viewing, or to wholesale and retail outlets for sale.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, year of <a href="#release">release</a> is entered in the <a href="#publicationarea">publication distribution, etc.</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  Compare with <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="releaseprint"><b>release print</b></a>
</dt><dd>The final version of a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, intended for distribution to public <a href="#audience">audience</a>s, in some cases shorter than the <a href="#director">director</a> intended.  In some cases, an initial <a href="#print">print</a> found to be too long is <em>rereleased</em> after having been cut (<em>example</em>: Disney's <b><em>Fantasia</em></b>).  On very rare occasions, a motion picture from which important scenes were cut is re<a href="#release">release</a>d after having been restored to its original length (Frank Capra's <b><em>Lost Horizon</em></b>).  When such an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a>, the <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> "original restored version" is added as a <a href="#note">note</a> in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  Synonymous with <em>showprint</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="relevance"><b>relevance</b></a>
</dt><dd>The extent to which <a href="#information">information</a> retrieved in a <a href="#search">search</a> of a <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> or a resource, such as an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, is judged by the user to be "<a href="#aboutness">about</a>" the <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the <a href="#query">query</a>.  Relevance depends on the searcher's subjective perception of the degree to which the <a href="#document">document</a> fulfills the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>, which may or may not have been expressed fully or with precision in the <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>.  Measures of the effectiveness of <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, such as <a href="#precision">precision</a> and <a href="#recall">recall</a>, depend on the relevance of search results.  Compare with <a href="#pertinence">pertinence</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#falsedrop">false drop</a> and <a href="#relevanceranking">relevance ranking</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="relevanceranking"><b>relevance ranking</b></a>
</dt><dd>A feature of some <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a> which <a href="#weighting">weights</a> the <a href="#document">document</a>s or <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a> in a <a href="#search">search</a> according to the degree to which they meet the requirements of the <a href="#query">query</a>.  <a href="#ranking">Ranked</a> results are normally presented in decreasing order of <a href="#relevance">relevance</a>, computed on the basis of the <a href="#number">number</a> of occurrences of each <a href="#searchterm">search term</a> in the document or record, and the weight assigned to the <a href="#field">field</a>(s) in which each term appears (<a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s, <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>, or <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a>). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="relevanceratio"><b>relevance ratio</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#precision">precision</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reliefmap"><b>relief map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#topographic">topographic map</a> showing the elevation of an area of the surface of the earth by means of standard <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> techniques, such as linear <a href="#contourmap">contour</a> lines, <a href="#hachure">hachure</a>s, shading, or tint.  The <a href="http://www.usgs.gov/">U.S. Geological Survey</a> (USGS) <a href="#issue">issue</a>s relief <a href="#map">map</a>s of the fifty states, available in the <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of larger <a href="#depository">depository libraries</a>.  Compare with <a href="#planimetric">planimetric map</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bathymetricmap">bathymetric map</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="relievobinding"><b>relievo binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">binding</a> made from <a href="#leather">leather</a> that is softened, then molded and deeply <a href="#embossed">embossed</a>, a technique used in 19th century England to introduce designs reflecting the Victorian revival of Gothic style.  In Italian, <em>relievo</em> means "relief."  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#papiermache">papier mache binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="religiousbook"><b>religious book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> or <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> in which the main theme is based on a particular religious faith.  Included in the category are <a href="#sacredtext">sacred text</a>s, devotional works, materials for religious professionals, <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s for religious education, and inspirational <a href="#title">title</a>s intended for laypersons.  Some <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s <a href="#specialization">specialize</a> in religious works (<em>examples</em>:   <a href="http://www.zondervan.com/">Zondervan</a>, <a href="http://www.judaicapress.com/">Judaica Press</a>, and <a href="http://www.kazi.org/">Kazi Publications</a>).  Large publishers may have a division devoted to religious <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.randomhouse.com/schocken/home.html">Schocken Books</a> within Random House).  New <a href="#christianfiction">Christian fiction</a> is <a href="#review">review</a>ed regularly in a separate section of <em><a href="#booklist">Booklist</a></em>.  Religious books are sold in religious <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s, through religious <a href="#bookclub">book club</a>s, and increasingly in <a href="#tradebookstore">trade bookstore</a>s.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> select judiciously with an eye toward maintaining a <a href="#balanced">balanced</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reload"><b>reload</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#option">option</a> in the <a href="#toolbar">toolbar</a> of a <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> that causes the currently displayed <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> to be <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a> from its original remote <a href="#url">address</a>, rather than from the <a href="#browsercache">browser cache</a> of the computer used to retrieve it, necessary if the <a href="#data">data</a> available from the <a href="#website">site</a>
is time-sensitive (news, stock quotes, weather reports, current
statistics, etc.). Some Web pages are designed to automatically <em>refresh</em> at regular intervals.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="relocation"><b>relocation</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the editorial decision to shift a <a href="#subject">subject</a> from one <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> to another in a new <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a>s, resulting in more than just a change in length of <a href="#notation">notation</a> (<em>example</em>:  "sociolinguistics" relocated in the 20th edition from <b>401.9</b> to <b>306.44</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="remainderbinding"><b>remainder binding</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#remainders">remainders</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="remaindermark"><b>remainder mark</b></a>
</dt><dd>A mark made by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> on the bottom edge of a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually with a <a href="#rubberstamp">stamp</a>, permanent marking pen, or spray paint to indicate that it has been <a href="#remainders">remaindered</a>, as a means of distinguishing it from <a href="#copy">copies</a> sold at <a href="#listprice">list price</a> or regular <a href="#discount">discount</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="remainders"><b>remainders</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#overstock">overstock</a> (unsold <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a>) purchased by lot by a <em>remainder dealer</em> on the understanding that they may be offered for sale at a substantially reduced price.  <a href="#binding">Bound</a> remainders may be <a href="#remaindermark">mark</a>ed to distinguish them from copies sold at <a href="#listprice">list price</a>.  <a href="#unbound">Unbound</a> remainders may be bound in an inexpensive <em>remainder binding</em> or reduced to <a href="#pulp">pulp</a> if there is no market for them.  
<p>
The fact that a book is <em>remaindered</em> does not necessarily reflect the quality of the <a href="#work">work</a>:  the <a href="#edition">edition</a> may have been too large, the <a href="#publishedprice">published price</a> too high, the <a href="#subject">subject</a> matter esoteric or ephemeral, or the <a href="#content">content</a> revised and <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in a new edition.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>rem</em>.  Compare with <a href="#joblot">job lot</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="remake"><b>remake</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, to rearrange the <a href="#typography">typographic</a> elements on a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#page">page</a> or in an entire <a href="#publication">publication</a>, or to <a href="#repaginated">repaginate</a> a publication (or a portion of it) from beginning to end.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#makeup">make-up</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="remboite"><b>remboite</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the French word <em>remboiter</em> meaning "to fit back into."  A descriptive <a href="#term">term</a> for a <a href="#book">book</a> that has been <a href="#rebinding">rebound</a> in <a href="#cover">cover</a>s removed from another <a href="#volume">volume</a>, usually a <a href="#binding">binding</a> that is in better <a href="#condition">condition</a>, or more valuable or attractive.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="remoteaccess"><b>remote access</b></a>
</dt><dd>Communication with a distant computer system or <a href="#network">network</a> as if one were a local user.  To <a href="#logon">log on</a>, the user may be required to enter an <a href="#authorization">authorized</a> <a href="#username">username</a> and/or <a href="#password">password</a>.  Special <a href="#communications">communications</a> <a href="#software">software</a> and/or <a href="#hardware">hardware</a>, such as a <a href="#modem">modem</a>, may also be necessary.  In most <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, a certain <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#port">port</a>s are reserved for remote <a href="#access">access</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#authentication">authentication</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="removes"><b>removes</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printing</a> term for <a href="#note">note</a>s or <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s set in smaller <a href="#type">type</a> at the <a href="#foot">foot</a> of a <a href="#page">page</a> of <a href="#text">text</a>, for example, a <a href="#book">book</a> set in 12-<a href="#point">point</a> might have <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s or <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>s set in 10-point or smaller type. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="renaissance"><b>renaissance librarian</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> who cultivates a broad and deep understanding and appreciation of, and lively interest in, all aspects of <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>, despite having developed at least one <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="renew"><strong>renew</strong></a>
</dt><dd>To extend the period of time for which a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is loaned by a <a href="#library">library</a>, usually by the length of the normal <a href="#loanperiod">loan period</a>.  Renewal policies vary, but most libraries allow at least one renewal for most types of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>.  To avoid <a href="#fines">fines</a>, items <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> must be renewed by the <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> on or before the <a href="#duedate">due date</a>.
<p>
Also, to extend the period during which a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> is to be delivered, usually by an additional year or period of years, in exchange for payment of a <a href="#renewal">renewal</a> <a href="#fee">fee</a> by the <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>.  A price break may be given to subscribers who renew for more than one year.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#renewalnotice">renewal notice</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="renewal"><b>renewal</b></a>
</dt><dd>An extension of the <a href="#loanperiod">loan period</a> for a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, usually for the length of the normal borrowing period.  Also, the reregistration of a <a href="#borrower">borrower</a> at the end of an established period of <a href="#library">library</a> membership.  Also refers to an extension of the period during which a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> is to be delivered following payment of a <a href="#renew">renew</a>al <a href="#fee">fee</a> by the <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#renewalnotice">renewal notice</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="renewalnotice"><b>renewal notice</b></a>
</dt><dd>A notice sent by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> to inform a <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a> or <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agent</a> that unless a <a href="#renewal">renewal</a> <a href="#fee">fee</a> is paid before a designated <a href="#expirationdate">expiration date</a>, the <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> will end.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="renovation"><b>renovation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A major refurbishing of existing facilities to make them appear new or like new.  In a <a href="#library">library</a>, this can mean anything from repainting, recarpeting, and installing new <a href="#ada">ADA</a>-compliant furnishings and <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, to the complete gutting of an old building and reconstruction to meet current needs and contemporary design <a href="#standards">standards</a>.  Extensive renovation may require <a href="#moving">moving</a> the library to a temporary location until alterations are completed.  Major renovations are reported annually in <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em> and in the <em>Bowker Annual Library and Book Trade Almanac</em>.  Compare with <a href="#expansion">expansion</a> and <a href="#newconstruc">new construction</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#retrofit">retrofit</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rentalcollec"><b>rental collection</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#book">Book</a>s in such high <a href="#demand">demand</a> that they are <a href="#circulation">circulated</a> by a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> for a small <a href="#fee">fee</a>, usually in multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a>.  Not all public <a href="#library">libraries</a> provide rental collections. Some use a waiting list or allow <a href="#hold">hold</a>s to be placed on high-demand <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s.
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#nonbook">nonbook</a> <a href="#collection">collection</a> such as a <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a> or <a href="#filmlibrary">film library</a> for which a rental fee is charged when an item is borrowed, usually to help meet the high cost of <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> and maintenance (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.facets.org/">Facets</a>). 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reorder"><b>reorder</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> and <a href="#bookseller">bookselling</a>, any order for a stock <a href="#bibitem">item</a> placed after the initial order has been received.  Reordering is necessary when the original order is lost or <a href="#canceled">canceled</a> (usually because the item was unavailable when the order was first placed).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="repackaging"><b>repackaging</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#reissue">Reissuing</a> a previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#book">book</a> in a different <a href="#format">format</a> to enhance its appeal to <a href="#reader">reader</a>s outside its primary market, sometimes by making it more affordable, as in a <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>, or easier to read, as in a <a href="#largeprint">large print</a> edition. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="repaginated"><b>repaginated</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> in which the <a href="#pagenumber">number</a>s originally assigned to successive <a href="#page">page</a>s have been changed.  Synonymous with <em>repaged</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#remake">remake</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="repairing"><b>repairing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The partial rehabilitation of a worn <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, including <a href="#restoration">restoration</a> of the <a href="#cover">cover</a> and reinforcement of the <a href="#hinge">hinge</a>s or <a href="#joint">joint</a>s, more extensive than <a href="#mending">mending</a>, but less extensive than <a href="#recased">recasing</a> or <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>.  In most <a href="#library">libraries</a>, repairs are done <a href="#inhouse">in-house</a>.  <a href="http://www.dartmouth.edu/%7Epreserve/repair/repairindex.htm">Click here</a> to connect to <em>A Simple Book Repair Manual</em> maintained by the Preservation Services department of the Dartmouth College Library.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="repeatable"><b>repeatable (R)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#field">field</a> that may occur more than once in the same <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, for example, the <b>600</b> field, reserved for <a href="#personalname">personal name</a>s used as <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a>.  A repeatable <a href="#subfield">subfield</a> may occur more than once in the same field.  The opposite of <a href="#nonrepeatable">nonrepeatable</a> (NR).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="replacement"><b>replacement</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> purchased by a <a href="#library">library</a> to take the place of a <a href="#lost">lost</a>, <a href="#damaged">damaged</a>, or worn-out <a href="#copy">copy</a> of the same <a href="#title">title</a>, not necessarily of the same <a href="#edition">edition</a> if the original edition is <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>.  Also, a copy sent by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#jobber">jobber</a> as a substitute for one found by a library or other purchaser to contain <a href="#imperfections">imperfections</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="replevin"><b>replevin</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#recover">recover</a>y of <a href="#archives">archive</a>d property (<a href="#records">records</a>, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#document">document</a>s,
etc.) by an organization or institution claiming ownership. Also refers
to the writ or legal action by which such property is recovered.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="replica"><b>replica</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> or <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> of art, especially one made by the artist who created the <a href="#original">original</a>,
or produced under the artist's supervision. In a more general sense,
any very close reproduction or copy of an object, especially one made
on a smaller <a href="#scale">scale</a> than the original.  Synonymous with <em>doublette</em>.  Compare with <a href="#facsimile">facsimile</a> and <a href="#realia">realia</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="report"><b>report</b></a>
</dt><dd>A separately <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#record">record</a> of <a href="#research">research</a> findings, research still in progress, or other technical findings, usually bearing a <em>report number</em> and sometimes a <em>grant number</em> assigned by the funding <a href="#agency">agency</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ericdocument">ERIC document</a>.  
<p>
Also, an official record of the activities of a committee or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate entity</a>, the proceedings of a government body, or an investigation by an agency, whether published or private, usually <a href="#archives">archived</a> or submitted to a higher authority voluntarily or under mandate.  In a more general sense, any formal account of facts or <a href="#information">information</a> related to a specific event or phenomenon, sometimes given at <a href="#regular">regular</a> intervals.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>rept</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#annualreport">annual report</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="repository"><b>repository</b></a>
</dt><dd>The physical space (building, room, area) reserved for the permanent or <a href="#intermediatestorage">intermediate storage</a> of <a href="#archives">archival</a> materials (<a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s, <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a>, <a href="#papers">papers</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, etc.).  To <a href="#preservation">preserve</a> and protect archival collections, modern repositories are equipped to meet current <a href="#standards">standards</a> of environmental control and <a href="#security">security</a>.
Whether a repository is open or closed to the public depends on the
policy of the parent institution. Sometimes used synonymously with <a href="#depository">depository</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rf"><b>representative fraction (RF)</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#cartography">cartography</a>, the relationship of <a href="#scale">scale</a> between distance on a <a href="#map">map</a> or <a href="#chart">chart</a> and the actual distance on the surface of land or sea represented on the map, given in the <a href="#legend">legend</a> as a ratio understood to be in <a href="#standard">standard</a> units of measurement (<em>example</em>:  1:1,00,000). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reprint"><b>reprint</b></a>
</dt><dd>A new <a href="#impression">impression</a> of an existing <a href="#edition">edition</a>, often made by <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic means, or a new edition made from a new <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> of <a href="#type">type</a> which is a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a previous impression, with no alterations in the <a href="#text">text</a> except perhaps the correction of <a href="#typo">typographical error</a>s.  The <a href="#work">work</a> may also be given a redesigned <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> and <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  The date of <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>ing is usually included in the details of <a href="#publication">publication</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the title page.  The <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a> <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em> includes a "Classic Returns" section in each <a href="#issue">issue</a>, highlighting recent reprints.  Compare with <a href="#reissue">reissue</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#reprintbook">reprint book</a> and <a href="#reprintpublisher">reprint publisher</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a separately issued <a href="#article">article</a>, <a href="#essay">essay</a>, <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>, or other portion of a previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>, whether <a href="#printing">printed</a> from a new <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> of <a href="#type">type</a> or <a href="#reproduction">reproduced</a> by other means.  Compare with <a href="#offprint">offprint</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reprintbook"><b>reprint book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#collection">collection</a> consisting of <a href="#article">article</a>s previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> in one or more <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s or <a href="#journal">journal</a>s.  The articles are used in their original <a href="#format">format</a> as <a href="#cameraready">camera-ready copy</a>, rather than <a href="#typesetting">reset</a> by the <a href="#printer">printer</a> in uniform <a href="#typography">typographic</a> style.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reprintpublisher"><b>reprint publisher</b></a>
</dt><dd>A publishing company that specializes in new <a href="#impression">impression</a>s of previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s which the original <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> has allowed to go <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>, despite continuing <a href="#demand">demand</a>.  Reprint <a href="#rights">rights</a> must be negotiated with the <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> holder.  The <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#copy">copies</a> in a reprint <a href="#edition">edition</a> is usually less than in the original edition.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reproduction"><b>reproduction</b></a>
</dt><dd>A close <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a work of art made mechanically or by hand for the commercial market, for example, a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#poster">poster</a> of a painting or drawing.  Reproductions of large works are usually done on a smaller <a href="#scale">scale</a> than the <a href="#artoriginal">original</a>.  Price usually depends on quality and fidelity to the original.  Also refers to an exact copy of a written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#document">document</a> made by mechanical or electronic means, for example, a <a href="#photocopy">photocopy</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#reprography">reprography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reprography"><b>reprography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general term encompassing the processes of <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> or <a href="#copy">copy</a>ing, by any method except large-scale professional <a href="#printing">printing</a>, including <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>y, microphotography, <a href="#photocopy">photocopy</a>ing, and photoduplication.  For a more detailed overview of the various methods, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> by J. E. Davies in the <b><em>International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science</em></b> (New York: Routledge, 1997).  <a href="http://palimpsest.stanford.edu/bytopic/repro/">Click here</a> to connect to the reprographics section of the <em>Conservation OnLine (CoOL)</em> <a href="#website">Web site</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="republication"><b>republication</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process by which a previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a> is <a href="#reissue">reissue</a>d by a <em>different</em> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, without alteration of the <a href="#text">text</a>.  Sometimes refers to the <a href="#reprint">reprinting</a> of such a work in another country.  Also refers to any <a href="#publication">publication</a> reissued in this manner.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="requiredif"><b>required if applicable and readily available (R)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Under <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <a href="#inputstandards">input standards</a>, a <a href="#field">field</a> or <a href="#subfield">subfield</a> of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> in which <a href="#data">data</a> must be entered if 1) appropriate in <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em> or essential for efficient <a href="#access">access</a> or effective processing, and 2) it is available in or on the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> at hand, from other <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s in the OCLC <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a>, or from OCLC <a href="#authorityfile">authority file</a> records.  Compare with <a href="#mandatory">mandatory</a> and <a href="#optional">optional</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="requisition"><b>requisition</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written request, usually submitted to the <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> department of a <a href="#library">library</a> on a <a href="#standardization">standardized</a> form, for the order of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a>, or services.  Compare with <a href="#purchaseorder">purchase order</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rerun"><b>rerun</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a job redone because the quality of the first <a href="#pressrun">press run</a> was not acceptable.  Also refers to the re<a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> of previously <a href="#release">release</a>d television programming, more common during the summer months than at other times of the year.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="research"><b>research</b></a>
</dt><dd>Systematic, painstaking investigation of a <a href="#topic">topic</a>, or in a <a href="#field">field</a>
of study, often employing techniques of hypothesis and experimentation,
undertaken by a person intent on revealing new facts, theories, or
principles, or determining the current state of <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> of the <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  The results of original research are usually reported in a <a href="#primaryjournal">primary journal</a>, in <a href="#conference">conference</a> <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a>, or in a <a href="#monograph">monograph</a> by the <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>(s) who conducted the study.  In the sciences, methodology is also reported to allow the results to be verified.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#heuristic">heuristic</a> and <a href="#libraryresearch">library research</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="researchcollec"><b>research collection</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> sufficiently <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> to support <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#research">research</a> in an academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or <a href="#field">field</a>.  A good research collection includes <a href="#primarysource">primary source</a>s, <a href="#secondarysource">secondary source</a>s, and the bibliographic <a href="#findingtool">tool</a>s needed to conduct an <a href="#exhaustive">exhaustive</a> <a href="#search">search</a> of the <a href="#literature">literature</a>.  <a href="#collecdevel">Development</a> of such a <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> requires considerable time, and the <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> and experience of one or more <a href="#subjectspecialist">subject specialist</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#researchlib">research library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="researcher"><b>researcher</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who conducts a careful, systematic investigation of a <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or inquiry in a <a href="#field">field</a> of study, to establish facts, reveal underlying principles, and determine the current state of <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#researchlib">research library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="researchguide"><b>research guide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> or <a href="#online">online</a> resource that provides detailed <a href="#information">information</a>, instructions, and advice concerning the best <a href="#searchstrategy">strategies</a>, techniques, and resources for <a href="#research">research</a> in a <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#field">field</a> of study.  <a href="#book">Book</a>-length research guides are usually shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Shakespeare: A Study and Research Guide</em></b> by David M. Bergeron and Geraldo U. de Sousa).  Most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> provide one- or two-page <a href="#handout">handout</a>s on a <a href="#displayrack">display rack</a> near the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>, explaining research techniques and listing <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a>s appropriate to each <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rlg"><b>Research Libraries Group (RLG)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1974, <b>RLG</b> is a <a href="#consortium">consortium</a> of over 160 universities, <a href="#nationallib">national libraries</a>, <a href="#archives">archives</a>, <a href="#historicalsociety">historical societies</a>, museums, and related institutions with substantial <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s for <a href="#research">research</a> and learning.
