Devoted to improving <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#information">information</a> through collaboration, <b>RLG</b> maintains the <em><a href="#rlin">RLIN</a></em> <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> of nearly 88 million <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s and <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> <em><a href="http://www.rlg.org/rlgnews/rlgnews.html">Research Libraries Group News</a></em> in three <a href="#issue">issue</a>s per year.  <a href="http://www.rlg.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>RLG</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#conspectus">conspectus</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rlin"><b><em>Research Libraries Information Network (RLIN)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#information">information</a> management and <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a> system consisting of an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a> of the <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> of members of the <a href="#rlg">Research Libraries Group</a> (RLG) combined with the <em>English Short Title Catalog (ESTC)</em> and <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority file</a>s.  <b><em>RLIN</em></b> contains over 88 million records and is used by hundreds of <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#archives">archives</a>, and museums for <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>, and control of <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> and archival <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  <a href="http://www.rlg.org/rlin.html">Click here</a> to learn more about <b><em>RLIN</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="researchlib"><b>research library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> containing a <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#researchcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in a specific <a href="#field">field</a>, academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, or group of disciplines, including <a href="#primarysource">primary</a> and <a href="#secondarysource">secondary source</a>s, <a href="#selection">selected</a> to meet the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of serious <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#folger">Folger Shakespeare Library</a> in Washington D.C.).  The primary emphasis in research libraries is on the <em>accumulation</em> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> and the provision of <a href="#accessservices">access services</a> to scholars qualified to make use of them.  In most large research libraries, access to collections containing <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s and <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s is <a href="#restricted">restricted</a>. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#arl">Association of Research Libraries</a>, <a href="#crl">Center for Research Libraries</a>, and <a href="#rlg">Research Libraries Group</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="researchpaper"><b>research paper</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written <a href="#composition">composition</a>, usually five or more <a href="#page">page</a>s in length, assigned as an exercise in a formal course of study.  The writer is expected to state a <a href="#thesis">thesis</a> and advance a logical argument based on supporting <a href="#information">information</a> found in a systematic investigation of the <a href="#topic">topic</a>.  The source of <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s, facts, and ideas not those of the <a href="#author">author</a> must be <a href="#documentation">documented</a> in <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s or <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>s, and a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reserves"><b>reserves</b></a>

</dt><dd>In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> given a shorter <a href="#loanperiod">loan period</a>
(one-hour, three-hours, overnight, 3-day, etc.) for a limited period of
time (usually one term or semester) at the request of the instructor,
to ensure that all the students enrolled in a course have an
opportunity to use them. <a href="#bibitem">Item</a>s on <a href="#closedreserve">closed reserve</a> must be used on <a href="#library">library</a> premises.  Instructors sometimes put personal <a href="#copy">copies</a> on reserve, usually at their own risk.  
<p>
<a href="#fines">Fines</a> charged for <a href="#overdue">overdue</a>
reserve items are higher than for materials not on reserve, to
encourage prompt return. In some academic libraries, reserves are
available <a href="#elecreserves">electronic</a>ally, usually as an <a href="#option">option</a> in the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or through <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> via the library's <a href="#website">Web site</a>.  Synonymous with <em>reserve collection</em> and <em>short loan collection</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#openreserve">open reserve</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reshelving"><b>reshelving</b></a>
</dt><dd>The job of returning <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s to the shelves of a <a href="#library">library</a> in correct <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> sequence after they have been used, usually performed by a student assistant in an <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a> or by a <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> member called a <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#reshelvingcart">reshelving cart</a> and <a href="#shelfreading">shelf reading</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reshelvingcart"><b>reshelving cart</b></a>
</dt><dd>A double-sided wheeled cart equipped with 2-3 shelves to hold <a href="#recently">recently returned</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s until they are aready to be transported to the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a> and placed back on the shelf.  If a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a> is listed as available in the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> but is "not on the shelf" (<a href="#nos">nos</a>), it may be on a cart waiting to be <a href="#reshelving">reshelved</a>.  Some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s indicate in the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a> the <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a> of items recently returned.  Synonymous with <a href="#booktruck">book truck</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="residuum"><b>residuum</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portion of an <a href="#author">author</a>'s total body of <a href="#work">work</a>, considered by scholars and critics to be of lasting value.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#classic">classic</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="resignation"><b>resignation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Formal notice of an employee's intention to terminate
employment, usually given to the employer in writing, effective on a
specific date. Most employment <a href="#contract">contract</a>s require 30-60 days notice to allow the employer sufficient time to reallocate <a href="#workload">workload</a> while a <a href="#search">search</a> for a replacement is conducted.  Compare with <a href="#retirement">retirement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="resized"><b>resized</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> or <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> that has been <a href="#washing">washed</a>, usually to remove writing, stains, or acid from the <a href="#paper">paper</a>, and then re<a href="#coated">coated</a> with a <a href="#sizing">sizing</a> compound to add stiffness and provide a protective <a href="#finish">finish</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="resolution"><b>resolution</b></a>
</dt><dd>The amount of fine detail on a computer screen, in a <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>, or on a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#page">page</a>, expressed as the number of <a href="#pixel">pixel</a>s or dots per line, inch, or centimeter.  The more units, the higher the resolution and the sharper the image.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#vga">VGA</a> and <a href="#svga">SVGA</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a formal statement of opinion or intention, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by an assembly, organization, or group.  In the United States, the <a href="#text">text</a> of Congressional resolutions can be found in the federal <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> section of <a href="#depository">depository libraries</a> and <a href="#online">online</a> via the <em><a href="#gpoaccess">GPO Access</a></em> <a href="#website">Web site</a>.
</p><p>
In <a href="#literature">literature</a>, the <a href="#term">term</a> is used <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>ously with <em>denouement</em>, the final phase of a <a href="#work">work</a> of <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> or <a href="#play">drama</a>, in which unanswered questions are resolved and the action brought to a logical conclusion.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="resourcesharing"><b>resource sharing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The activities that result from an agreement, formal or informal, among a group of <a href="#library">libraries</a> (usually a <a href="#consortium">consortium</a> or <a href="#network">network</a>) to share <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, <a href="#data">data</a>, facilities, personnel, etc., for the benefit of their users and to reduce the expense of <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="respectdesfonds"><b>respect des fonds</b></a>
</dt><dd>A French term for the principle of <a href="#provenance">provenance</a> under which the <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#records">records</a> of an <a href="#agency">agency</a>
or individual are maintained separately according to source, rather
than combined or intermingled with those of different origin.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="respondent"><b>respondent</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#candidate">candidate</a> for an academic degree who must defend, against one or more opponents, a <a href="#thesis">thesis</a> proposed by a faculty moderator acting as the <a href="#praeses">praeses</a> in a formal disputation.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="responsetime"><b>response time</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, the amount of time that elapses between the submission of <a href="#input">input</a> (a <a href="#query">query</a>, command, <a href="#data">data</a>, etc.) and the return of results (<a href="#output">output</a>) by the system.  On the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, response time depends on speed of connection and amount of traffic on the <a href="#network">network</a>, which varies with time of day, day of week, etc.  When a <a href="#server">server</a> goes <a href="#offline">offline</a>, response time may be delayed indefinitely.  Compare with <a href="#turnaroundtime">turnaround time</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="restoration"><b>restoration</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>, the physical process of returning a <a href="#damaged">damaged</a>, worn, or otherwise altered <a href="#document">document</a> to its original <a href="#condition">condition</a>, or as close an approximation of the original condition as possible.  Before restoration can begin, <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> must be <a href="#stabilization">stabilized</a> by whatever method is most appropriate.  To preserve the <a href="#archivalvalue">evidential value</a> of an item in its altered condition, care should be taken to make <a href="#repairing">repair</a>s both visible and <a href="#reversibility">reversible</a> (if possible).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="restricted"><b>restricted access</b></a>
</dt><dd>The privilege of using a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> under specific conditions established as a matter of library policy.  In <a href="#archives">archives</a> and <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>, the use of <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, and other unique and valuable <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> may be limited to a particular room or a certain method, or by appointment only.  In the United States, large private <a href="#universitylib">university libraries</a> may limit <a href="#access">access</a> to the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a> to registered students, faculty, and staff, and to outside <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s granted special permission to use specific collections.  The opposite of <em>unrestricted</em>.  Compare with <a href="#controlledaccess">controlled access</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#openstacks">open stacks</a> and <a href="#closedstacks">closed stacks</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="resume"><b>resume</b></a>
</dt><dd>A summing up.  In hiring, a statement of the experience and <a href="#qualification">qualification</a>s an <a href="#applicant">applicant</a> brings to the <a href="#position">position</a>.  <a href="#handbook">Handbook</a>s on resume preparation are available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a> and <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>.  The <a href="#nmrt">New Members Round Table</a> (NMRT) of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> provides a resume review service for recent <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a> graduates.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#cv">curriculum vitae</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="retailprice"><b>retail price</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#listprice">list price</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="retention"><b>retention</b></a>
</dt><dd>Holding or keeping materials in possession, usually in a desired state or <a href="#condition">condition</a>, as opposed to disposing of them.  In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the <a href="#retentionperiod">retention period</a> for <a href="#document">document</a>s is usually indicated in the <a href="#dispositionschedule">disposition schedule</a>.  <a href="#academiclib">Academic</a> and <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> generally purchase <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> with the intention of retaining them indefinitely; <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> <a href="#weeding">weed</a> on the basis of <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>.  Long-term retention of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> may require <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> measures, such as <a href="#reformat">reformat</a>ting.  
<p>Also refers to the extent to which a company, organization, or
institution is able to keep its personnel from accepting employment
elsewhere, and to the capacity of an academic institution to keep
students enrolled through graduation.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="retentionperiod"><b>retention period</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the length of time that <a href="#records">records</a> of a specific category or origin must be <a href="#retention">retained</a> before they are <a href="#transfer">transfer</a>red to <a href="#intermediatestorage">intermediate storage</a> or given some other <a href="#disposition">disposition</a>.  In the absence of statutory or regulatory stipulations, the period is usually determined by current usage and projected need.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="retentionschedule"><b>retention schedule</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dispositionschedule">disposition schedule</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="retirement"><b>retirement</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#resignation">Resignation</a> from a position of employment with the intention of ending a career, a step usually taken at an age when the <em>retiree</em> is in a position to live on other income (pension, retirement savings, social security, etc.).  <em>Early retirement</em>
is resignation before the age at which most employees cease working,
sometimes in response to a special offer of eligibility or compensation
made by management ("golden handshake"). Under a policy of <em>mandatory retirement</em>, employees are not allowed to continue working beyond a certain age. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="retitlededition"><b>retitled edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#reissue">reissue</a>d under a <a href="#title">title</a> that is not the same as the title of the original <a href="#edition">edition</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the original title is entered as a <a href="#note">note</a> in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> when the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#changedtitle">changed title</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="retrofit"><b>retrofit</b></a>
</dt><dd>To adapt an older <a href="#library">library</a> facility to accommodate improvements in <a href="#infotech">information technology</a>, a process that often involves not only the installation of new <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>
and furnishings, but may also require structural alterations,
reallocation of space, changes in lighting and HVAC, additional
electrical and <a href="#telecommunication">telecom</a> wiring, and attention to noise control, traffic patterns, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="retrospective"><b>retrospective</b></a>
</dt><dd>Including <a href="#work">work</a>s created or <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the past, rather than <a href="#currency">current</a> or recently <a href="#issue">issue</a>d materials, as in a <a href="#retrobib">retrospective bibliography</a>.
In a more general sense, anything pertaining to events or activities
that occurred in the past, rather than the present, as in the <a href="#retrocon">retrospective conversion</a> of existing <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s to another <a href="#format">format</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="retrobib"><b>retrospective bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> restricted to <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the past, usually limited to a specific period of time (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Agriculture and the GATT: A Retrospective Bibliography, 1948-1980</em></b> by Wayne K. Olson).  The opposite of <a href="#currentbib">current bibliography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="retrocon"><b>retrospective conversion</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of <a href="#dataconversion">converting</a> existing <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s from manual, human-readable form, such as a <a href="#catalogcard">card</a>s in a <a href="#cardcatalog">card catalog</a>, into <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, usually by matching the old records one-at-a-time to those contained in an <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> of machine-readable records.  Once a match is made, the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> <a href="#download">download</a>s as much of the machine-readable record as the <a href="#library">library</a> needs, usually for a modest <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  In the United States, <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> provides most of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> records used in <a href="#retrospective">retrospective</a> conversion.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>recon</em>.  Compare with <a href="#recataloging">recataloging</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="retrosearch"><b>retrospective search</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#search">search</a> for <a href="#information">information</a> that is no longer <a href="#currency">current</a>.  <a href="#bibdatabase">Bibliographic database</a>s that support this type of searching usually <a href="#index">index</a> information in <a href="#repository">repositories</a> and <a href="#archive">archival</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s in which <a href="#document">document</a>s may be added but are rarely modified or removed.  Some <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a> allows the user to specify a <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a> <a href="#range">range</a>, to exclude current <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="returnable"><b>returnable</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>, <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> that the lending <a href="#library">library</a> expects the borrowing library to return, usually within a designated period of time unless <a href="#renew">renew</a>ed, as opposed to materials, such as <a href="#photocopy">photocopied</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s, provided without expectation of return.
<p>
Also refers to an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> that may be returned by a <a href="#library">library</a> to the seller for <a href="#credit">credit</a>, usually under specific conditions explicitly stated in the seller's <a href="#returnpolicy">return policy</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="returnpolicy"><b>return policy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The conditions established by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> under which <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s ordered, <a href="#shipping">shipped</a>, and delivered may be returned for <a href="#credit">credit</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>.  Items received in <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> <a href="#condition">condition</a>,
not the fault of the receiver, are understood to be returnable. The
return policy for undamaged items is normally stated on the publisher's
<a href="#invoice">invoice</a>, usually in code, <b>NR</b> or <b>XR</b> indicating <em>no returns</em> or <em>nonreturnable</em>.  Items that have been <a href="#processing">processed</a> or specially <a href="#binding">bound</a>
at the request of the purchaser are not returnable unless a major
defect is found within a reasonable time. When an item is returned for
a valid reason, a <a href="#replacement">replacement</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> is usually sent by the publisher.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#returns">returns</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="returns"><b>returns</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#book">Book</a>s or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s sent back to the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> by a <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> who purchased them under terms allowing unsold stock to be returned for <a href="#credit">credit</a>.  Also, items returned to a publisher or <a href="#jobber">jobber</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a> under an <a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a> or <a href="#booklease">book lease plan</a>, or because they were found upon delivery to be <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> or defective.  The conditions under which items may be returned for <a href="#credit">credit</a> are stated in the publisher's <a href="#returnpolicy">return policy</a>.  On the <a href="#invoice">invoice</a>, the symbol <b>NR</b> or <b>XR</b> indicates that returns are <em>not</em> allowed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reversechron"><b>reverse chronological</b></a>
</dt><dd>The arrangement of <a href="#data">data</a>, <a href="#records">records</a>, <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s, <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, <a href="#entry">entries</a>, etc., according to their relation in time, from the most recent to the earliest.  In <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, the <a href="#default">default</a> display of <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a> in a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> <a href="#search">search</a> is often reverse chronological order.  The opposite of <a href="#chronological">chronological</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reversibility"><b>reversibility</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#document">document</a> <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>, the degree to which a procedure can be <em>undone</em> without adversely affecting the <a href="#condition">condition</a> of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.
As a general rule, reversible procedures are preferred because future
research or legal developments may require that the item be restored to
its original condition. However, since complete reversibility may be
difficult to achieve, it must be balanced against other priorities. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#irreversible">irreversible</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="review"><b>review</b></a>
</dt><dd>An evaluative account of a recent artistic performance or <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>, or of a newly <a href="#publishing">published</a> literary or scholarly <a href="#work">work</a>, usually written and <a href="#signed">signed</a> by a qualified person, for <a href="#publication">publication</a> in a <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, or <a href="#journal">journal</a>.  The account can be descriptive, reportorial, comparative, <a href="#criticism">critical</a>, or serve as a vehicle for a lengthy <a href="#essay">essay</a> in which the <a href="#reviewer">reviewer</a> discusses several recently <a href="#publishing">published</a> works (<a href="#omnibusreview">omnibus review</a>) or a broader <a href="#topic">topic</a> for which the works reviewed serve as a springboard.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#selection">selection</a> decisions are based primarily on reviews.  Synonymous with <em>critique</em>.  Compare with <a href="#puff">puff</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#reviewlag">review lag</a>.  
<p>
<a href="#book">Book</a> reviews are <a href="#index">index</a>ed by the year in which they were published and by <a href="#author">author</a> of <a href="#title">title</a> reviewed in <em><b>Book Review Digest</b></em> and <b><em>Book Review Index</em></b>, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and large <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.  <a href="#film">Film</a> reviews are indexed by title of film under the <a href="#heading">heading</a> "Motion picture reviews--Single works" in the <a href="#volume">volume</a> of <b><em>Reader's Guide to Periodical Literature</em></b> corresponding to <a href="#releasedate">date of release</a>.  Reviews can also be located <a href="#online">online</a> in general <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>s by entering <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> from the title of the work reviewed, as <a href="#searchterm">search term</a>s.  For a list of online review sources, please see <b><em>AcqWeb's</em></b> <em><a href="http://www.library.vanderbilt.edu/law/acqs/bookrev.html">Directory of Book Reviews on the Web</a></em>.
</p><p>
Also refers to a periodical devoted primarily to publishing <a href="#article">article</a>s of <a href="#criticism">criticism</a> and appraisal (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Romantic Review</em></b>).  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reviewcopy"><b>review copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#complimentary">complimentary copy</a> of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> or other <a href="#work">work</a> in its final form, sent by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> at no charge to a person who writes <a href="#review">review</a>s, to the <a href="#editor">editor</a>(s) of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> that <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> reviews, to an opinion leader in the <a href="#field">field</a> covered, or to a <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> in the hope of attracting favorable comment, often with a <a href="#reviewslip">review slip</a> <a href="#laidin">laid in</a>.  Synonymous with <em>press copy</em>.  Compare with <a href="#advancecopy">advance copy</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reviewer"><b>reviewer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who writes a brief or extended evaluation of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> or other creative <a href="#work">work</a>, usually at the request of the <a href="#editor">editor</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> that includes <a href="#review">review</a>s.  Scholarly works are usually reviewed by the <a href="#author">author</a>'s <a href="#peerreview">peer</a>s.  Reviews <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>s, such as <em><a href="#choice">CHOICE</a></em>, <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em>, and <em><a href="#booklist">Booklist</a></em>, are written by <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and academic professionals actively engaged in <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>.  In the performing arts, reviews are written by critics whose response can determine the success or failure of a production.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reviewjournal"><b>review journal</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reviewlag"><b>review lag</b></a>
</dt><dd>The interbal of time between the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a>, or the release or first performance of a creative <a href="#work">work</a>, and the appearance of <a href="#review">review</a>s.  For <a href="#popularfiction">popular fiction</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> written by well-known <a href="#author">author</a>s, the delay may be a matter of days or weeks, especially if <a href="#galley">galley</a>s or <a href="#reviewcopy">review copies</a> are distributed by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to prospective <a href="#reviewer">reviewer</a>s in advance of the <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, but for scholarly <a href="#title">title</a>s, the lag may exceed a year. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reviewoflit"><b>review of the literature</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#litreview">literature review</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reviewpub"><b>review publication</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, or <a href="#journal">journal</a> devoted primarily to <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> <a href="#review">review</a>s of <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s and other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s (<a href="#serial">serial</a>s, <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#media">media</a>, etc.).  Some also provide <a href="#feature">feature</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#regular">regular</a> <a href="#column">column</a>s, <a href="#authorinterview">author interview</a>s, <a href="#litreview">literature review</a>s, etc., and most include <a href="#bookannouncement">book announcement</a>s and other advertising.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> for review publications is available in <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>. 
<p>
<em>Examples</em>:
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em><a href="#arba">American Reference Books Annual (ARBA)</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.ala.org/booklist/index.html">Booklist</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.ala.org/acrl/choice/index.html">CHOICE: Current Reviews for Academic Libraries</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="#lambda">Lambda Book Report</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://libraryjournal.reviewsnews.com/">Library Journal (LJ)</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://publishersweekly.reviewsnews.com/">Publisher's Weekly (PW)</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.quillandquire.com/">Quill &amp; Quire</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.nybooks.com/nyrev/index.html">New York Review of Books (NYRB)</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/books/review/">New York Times Book Review (NYTBR)</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.the-tls.co.uk/">Times Literary Supplement (TLS)</a></em></dd></dl>
<p>
<em>Children's literature</em>:
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em><a href="http://www.lis.uiuc.edu/puboff/bccb/">Bulletin of the Center for Children's Books (BCCB)</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="#chlitreview">Children's Literature Review (CLR)</a></em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.hbook.com/mag.shtml">The Horn Book Magazine</a></em>
</dd><dd><em>Kirkus Reviews</em>
</dd><dd><em><a href="http://www.press.jhu.edu/press/journals/titles/uni.html">The Lion and the Unicorn</a></em>
</dd><dd><em>School Library Journal (SLJ)</em></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reviewslip"><b>review slip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief notice or form <a href="#letters">letter</a> sent by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> to a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#review">review</a>er or <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> with a free <a href="#copy">copy</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a>, informing the recipient that the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is a <a href="#reviewcopy">review copy</a> and requesting its consideration. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="reviewsoncards"><b><em>Reviews on Cards (ROC)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#choice">CHOICE</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="revisededition"><b>revised edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> in which the <a href="#text">text</a> of a previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a> is substantially altered by correction, deletion, and/or addition, either by the original <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#editor">editor</a>, or by another writer, usually to expand the <a href="#content">content</a> or bring it <a href="#update">up-to-date</a>.  Some revised editions are not as "revised" as they claim to be (<em>caveat emptor</em>).  The extent of <a href="#revision">revision</a> may be indicated in a new <a href="#foreword">foreword</a> or <a href="#preface">preface</a>.
Frequency of revision usually depends on the amount of new material
available, but may also be linkd to a decline in sales of the preceding
edition. In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> <em>Rev. ed.</em> is given in the <a href="#editionstatement">edition statement</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> to indicate that an edition is revised.  Usually synonymous with <em>second edition</em>.  Compare with <a href="#expandededition">expanded edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="revision"><b>revision</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#text">Text</a> that has been altered by the original <a href="#author">author</a>, or by another writer, usually to correct, amend, <a href="#update">update</a>, or otherwise improve it.  In <a href="#book">book</a>s, the result may be <a href="#publishing">published</a> as a <a href="#revisededition">revised edition</a>.  Compare with <a href="#rewrite">rewrite</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the <a href="#publishing">published</a> result of editorial work that changes the <a href="#text">text</a> of any <a href="#class">class</a> of the <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a>s.  Four degrees of revision are recognized:
</p><p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>Routine revision</b> - <a href="#update">Update</a>s <a href="#terminology">terminology</a>, clarifies notes, provides modest <a href="#expansion">expansion</a>s of existing <a href="#notation">notation</a>
</dd><dd><b>Substantial revision</b> - Major redefinitions and <a href="#relocation">relocation</a>s in a class
</dd><dd><b>Extensive revision</b> - <a href="#subdivision">Subdivision</a>s reworked, but the basic outline of the schedule is left untouched
</dd><dd><b>Complete revision</b> - <a href="#basenumber">Base number</a>s remain the same as in the previous <a href="#edition">edition</a>, but virtually every subdivision is altered</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rewritable"><b>rewritable</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> capable of being written, erased, and rewritten repeatedly, for example, <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a> or <a href="#disk">disk</a>, as opposed to a medium that is <em><a href="#readonly">read only</a></em> or <em>write once, read many</em> (<a href="#worm">WORM</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rewrite"><b>rewrite</b></a>
</dt><dd>To put <a href="#text">text</a> already written into different words or form, making more extensive changes than in a <a href="#revision">revision</a>.  In <a href="#journalism">journalism</a>, to convert news <a href="#copy">copy</a> submitted in rough form by one or more reporters into a version suitable for <a href="#publication">publication</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rf1"><b>RF</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#rf"><b>r</b>epresentative <b>f</b>raction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rhymingdictionary"><b>rhyming dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> in which the words of a <a href="#language">language</a> are listed <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by phonetic ending to assist writers of <a href="#verse">verse</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, rhyming dictionaries are usually shelved in the <a href="#language">language</a> section of the <a href="#refcollection">reference collection</a>. They are also available <a href="#online">online</a> (see <em><a href="http://rhyme.lycos.com/">RhymeZone</a></em> from <b><em>Lycos</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ri"><b>RI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ruleinterpretation"><b>r</b>ule <b>i</b>nterpretation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="riddle"><b>riddle</b></a>
</dt><dd>A puzzle or problem in the form of a misleading statement or
question containing clues expressed in a manner requiring ingenuity and
a sense of humor to arrive at the correct answer or solution (in the
parlor game "Charades" the clues are visual). Exceedingly popular with
young <a href="#reader">reader</a>s, <a href="#collection">collection</a>s of riddles are available in the <a href="#juvenile">juvenile section</a> of most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.  Synonymous with <em>conundrum</em>.
<p>
In a more general sense, any puzzling or enigmatic person, phenomenon, or saying.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rights"><b>rights</b></a>
</dt><dd>The exclusive privilege of receiving the benefits associated
with ownership of a literary property, the most important of which is
the right of first <a href="#publication">publication</a>, protected under <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law in most countries.  In the case of <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#volumerights">volume rights</a> give the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> the exclusive right to <a href="#publishing">publish</a> a <a href="#work">work</a> in <a href="#volume">volume</a> form within a specific geographic territory, including the right to <a href="#reprint">reprint</a> in <a href="#paperback">paperback</a>, <a href="#bookclub">book club</a>, or <a href="#textbook">textbook</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>, and to reprint the work in its entirety in a single <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> or in an <a href="#anthology">anthology</a>.  <a href="#subsidiaryrights">Subsidiary rights</a> include <a href="#serialized">serialization</a>, <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>, <a href="#translation">translation</a>, foreign publication, <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>, <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>, <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a>, commercial exploitation, and <a href="#adaptation">adaptation</a> for performance on stage, as a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, or on radio or television.  Rights may be transferred or sold by the owner to another person or entity.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#infringement">infringement</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ringbinding"><b>ring binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> <a href="#binder">binder</a> consisting of a number of metal rings (usually three) fixed in a metal or hard plastic <a href="#spine">spine</a>.
The rings are designed to open, usually at the center, by means of
pressure tabs at the top and bottom of the spine, allowing prepunched <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> to be individually added or removed, used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> for <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> such as <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a> services that require frequent <a href="#update">updating</a>.  Unlike <a href="#postbinding">post binding</a>s, ring bindings <a href="#openability">open flat</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rlg1"><b>RLG</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#rlg"><b>R</b>esearch <b>L</b>ibraries <b>G</b>roup</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rlin1"><b><em>RLIN</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#rlin"><b>R</b>esearch <b>L</b>ibraries <b>I</b>nformation <b>N</b>etwork</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="roadatlas"><b>road atlas</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> of <a href="#map">map</a>s showing
the roads, highways, towns, and cities in a specific state, province,
region, or country, often with mileage between major destinations (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Rand McNally Road Atlas and Vacation Guide</em></b>).  <a href="#update">Update</a>d <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly for retail sale to motorists and travelers, most include an <a href="#index">index</a> of <a href="#geographicname">place name</a>s (<a href="#gazetteer">gazetteer</a>) at the end, giving the location of cities, towns, and other geographic features by means of <a href="#grid">grid</a> <a href="#coordinate">coordinate</a>s on the <a href="#roadmap">road map</a>s.  For an <a href="#interactive">interactive</a> <a href="#online">online</a> road <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>, see <em><a href="http://www.mapquest.com/">MapQuest</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="roadmap"><b>road map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> showing the location of the roads and
highways passable to motorized vehicles within a given area (county,
state, province, country), for the use of motorists and travelers.
Smaller in <a href="#scale">scale</a> than a <a href="#citymap">city map</a>, a road map usually includes a <a href="#table">table</a> of distances between major towns and cities, a <a href="#gazetteer">gazetteer</a>, one or more larger-scale <a href="#insetmap">inset map</a>s of major metropolitan areas, and <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s indicating service and rest areas, scenic routes, toll roads, major parks and museums, campgrounds, airports, etc.  A <a href="#roadatlas">road atlas</a> is a <a href="#collection">collection</a> of road maps covering a large area, usually <a href="#binding">bound</a> in the form of a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="roan"><b>roan</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thin, soft, flexible sheepskin, usually dyed a dark color, used in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> from the late 18th century as a substitute for <a href="#morocco">morocco</a> which was more elegant, but also more expensive. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="roc"><b><em>ROC</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#choice">CHOICE <b>R</b>eviews <b>o</b>n <b>C</b>ards</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="roll"><b>roll</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> written on a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> or <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, not folded but rolled up for storage on a shelf or in a box or cylindrical receptacle called a <a href="#scrinium">scrinium</a>.  Compare with <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#umbilicus">umbilicus</a>.
Also refers to a list of names, especially the members of an
organization, assembly, or official body, used to "call the roll" in a
roll-call vote. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rom1"><b>ROM</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#rom"><b>R</b>ead <b>O</b>nly <b>M</b>emory</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="roman"><b>roman</b></a>
</dt><dd>The formal Latin <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> consisting of <a href="#minuscule">minuscule</a> (<a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a>) and <a href="#majuscule">majuscule</a> (<a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a>) <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, as distinct from <a href="#gothic">gothic</a> or <em>black letter</em>.  Minuscules were adapted from the non<a href="#cursive">cursive</a> <a href="#bookhand">book hand</a> used in medieval Europe; majuscules evolved from the <a href="#capitalletter">capital</a>s used in the <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>s carved on tombs and other stone monuments by the ancient Romans.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cyrillic">Cyrillic</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#typography">typography</a>, a <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> in which the <a href="#character">character</a>s are not slanted as in <a href="#italic">italic</a>, but stand straight up.  Also used as a generic <a href="#term">term</a> for all typefaces with <a href="#serif">serif</a>s, as opposed to those that are <a href="#sansserif">sans-serif</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="romanaclef"><b>roman a clef</b></a>
</dt><dd>French for "novel with a key."  A form of <a href="#novel">novel</a> in which real people or institutions are given <a href="#fiction">fictitious</a> names, but depicted in such a way that well-informed <a href="#reader">reader</a>s can penetrate the disguise.  Such works are often <a href="#satire">satirical</a>, for example, Robert Penn Warren's thinly veiled characterization of the Louisiana demagogue Huey Long in <b><em>All the King's Men</em></b>.  Compare with  <a href="#historicalfiction">historical fiction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="romanathese"><b>roman a these</b></a>
</dt><dd>French for "novel with a thesis."  A form of <a href="#novel">novel</a> in which the <a href="#author">author</a>
presents a moral dilemma or social problem in order to advance a
specific point of view or programmatic solution, instead of leaving the
resolution to the <a href="#reader">reader</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Grapes of Wrath</em></b> by John Steinbeck).  Synonymous with <em>problem novel</em> and <em>protest novel</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#thesisplay">thesis play</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="romance"><b>romance</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> in which the primary themes are passionate love and adventure, usually depicted in an exotic rather than realistic <a href="#setting">setting</a>, involving <a href="#character">character</a>s that are larger than life stereotypes.  Most contemporary romance is written to appeal to female <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.  The origins of romance as a literary form can be traced to the <a href="#gothicnovel">gothic novel</a> of the 18th century and the earlier tradition of medieval chivalry.  Nineteenth century <em>romanticism</em> revived the romance in <a href="#verse">verse</a> form, and also in the visual arts.  <a href="http://www.theromancereader.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em>The Romance Reader</em>, a <a href="#website">Web site</a> devoted to romance <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pulpfiction">pulp fiction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="romanfleuve"><b>roman-fleuve</b></a>
</dt><dd>A French term for a form of <a href="#novel">novel</a> in which the <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> covers the fortunes of an entire family, sometimes over several generations (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>One Hundred Years of Solitude</em></b> by Gabriel Garcia Marquez).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="romanization"><b>romanization</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#transliteration">transliteration</a> of words, names, <a href="#title">title</a>s, or <a href="#text">text</a> from non-<a href="#roman">roman</a> <a href="#script">script</a> into the letters of the roman <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/roman.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>ALA-LC Romanization Tables</em></b> for over 150 <a href="#language">language</a>s and dialects written in non-roman scripts, published by the <a href="#cds">Cataloging Distribution Service</a> of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pinyin">pinyin</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="romannumeral"><b>roman numeral</b></a>
</dt><dd>A system of <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s developed by the ancient Romans, used throughout Europe prior to the introduction of <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s in the 11th century.  <a href="#capitalletter">Capital letter</a>s of the Latin <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> are used to indicate number, either alone (<b>I</b>=1, <b>V</b>=5, <b>X</b>=10, <b>L</b>=50, <b>C</b>=100, <b>D</b>=500, and <b>M</b>=1,000) or in combination, according to established conventions (<b>IV</b> = 4, <b>VI</b> = 6, <b>IX</b>=9, <b>XI</b>=11, etc.).  In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, roman numerals are used for <a href="#chapterheading">chapter heading</a>s, lists, dates, and in <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> to <a href="#pagination">paginate</a> the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="root"><b>root</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#stem">stem</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rosetta"><b>Rosetta Stone</b></a>
</dt><dd>A smooth slab of black basalt, approximately 2.5 feet wide and 3.75 feet high, bearing the same <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>, a decree honoring Ptolemy V Epiphanes written in 196 BC in two <a href="#language">language</a>s:  Greek and Egyptian.  The Egyptian version of the <a href="#text">text</a> is carved in <a href="#hieroglyphics">hieroglyphs</a> and in the demotic <a href="#cursive">cursive</a> <a href="#script">script</a>.
Discovered in Egypt in 1799 by a party of French soldiers under the
command of Napoleon Bonaparte, the stone was subsequently used by the
British physicist Thomas Young and the French Egyptologist
Jean-Francois Champollion to decipher the meaning of Egyptian
hieroglyphic writing. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rotatedidsplay"><b>rotated display</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly arranged display of all the significant words contained in the <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s listed in a <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">term</a>s,
in which each word is treated as a filing unit. Descriptors are
repeated in the alphabetic sequence under each of their significant
words, single-word descriptors appearing only once. Word order within
terms is not altered. The following example is from the <em>Rotated Descriptor Display</em> in the <b><em>Thesaurus of ERIC Descriptors</em></b>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#permutedindex">permuted index</a>.
<p>
</p><center><table>
<tbody><tr align="right"><td width="200"></td><td width="600" align="left">Literacy</td></tr>
<tr align="right"><td width="200">Adult</td><td width="600" align="left">Literacy</td></tr>
<tr align="right"><td width="200">Child Parent</td><td width="600" align="left">Literacy Use Family Literacy</td></tr>
<tr align="right"><td width="200"></td><td width="600" align="left">Literacy Classes (1966 1980) Use Literacy Education</td></tr>
<tr align="right"><td width="200">Computer</td><td width="600" align="left">Literacy</td></tr>
<tr align="right"><td width="200">Cultural</td><td width="600" align="left">Literacy</td></tr>
<tr align="right"><td width="200">Early</td><td width="600" align="left">Literacy Use Emergent Literacy</td></tr>
<tr align="right"><td width="200"></td><td width="600" align="left">Literacy Education</td></tr>
<tr align="right"><td width="200">Emergent</td><td width="600" align="left">Literacy</td></tr>
<tr align="right"><td width="200">Family</td><td width="600" align="left">Literacy</td></tr>
</tbody></table></center>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rotated"><b>rotated index</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#permutedindex">permuted index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rotatingdisplay"><b>rotating display</b></a>
</dt><dd>A highly compact <a href="#bookcase">bookcase</a> with shelves on four faces, mounted on a cylindrical spindle that allows it to be turned by the person <a href="#browse">browsing</a> its contents, used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> for displaying <a href="#paperback">paperback</a>s and <a href="#media">media</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s (<a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>s, <a href="#compactdisc">CD</a>s, etc.).  Synonymous with <em>rotor display</em> and <em>revolving case</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rotation"><b>rotation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#deskschedule">scheduling</a> <a href="#shift">shift</a>s at a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a> in which a group of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s or other <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> members take turns, usually in predetermined sequence.  Evening and weekend <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a> hours are often scheduled in this manner to distribute <a href="#workload">workload</a> equitably.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rotulus"><b>rotulus</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> in the form of length of <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a>, <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> written on one side only and stored in a hollow roll.  The oldest examples are from ancient Egypt.  Compare with <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rotunda"><b>rotunda</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#gothic">gothic</a> <a href="#script">script</a> developed in Italy and Spain during the Middle Ages.  The broad, round <a href="#letterform">letterform</a>s of rotunda retained some of the features of the earlier <a href="#carolingian">Carolingian script</a>.  Widely used by <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>s for <a href="#copy">copy</a>ing theological, legal, and scholastic <a href="#text">text</a>s, its use eventually spread north of the Alps.  After the invention of <a href="#printing">printing</a> from <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a> in the mid-15th century, it was adapted for use in <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rough"><b>rough</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#calf">Calf</a>skin given a suede-like nap, instead of the usual polished surface, used in <a href="#binding">binding</a> from the 17th century onwards.  Synonymous with <em>reversed calf</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="roughedges"><b>rough edges</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic <a href="#term">term</a> used in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> to refer to the irregular <a href="#deckle">deckle edge</a>s of <a href="#paper">paper</a> left <a href="#uncut">uncut</a> by the <a href="#binder">binder</a> in some <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, more difficult to clean than <a href="#trimming">trimmed</a> edges when <a href="#book">book</a>s are exposed to dust.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rounding"><b>rounding</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a procedure performed after first <a href="#gluingoff">gluing</a>, before the <a href="#lining">lining</a> is applied to the <a href="#back">back</a>.  In rounding, the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s is hammered or otherwise physically manipulated to give the <a href="#spine">spine</a> a convex shape in preparation for <a href="#backing">backing</a>.  The procedure gives the <a href="#book">book</a> a concave <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a>, diminishes <a href="#swell">swell</a>,
and prevents the binding edge from falling forward with extended use,
or from the force of gravity as a result of standing upright for years
on the shelf. Compare with <a href="#flatback">flat back</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="roundtable"><b>round table</b></a>
</dt><dd>In modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, a group established to discuss on an ongoing basis a range of <a href="#topic">topic</a>s
and/or issues of concern to its members, usually within the context of
a larger organization. The original "Round Table" preserved at
Winchester, England is believed to have been the center around which
the King Arthur of medieval <a href="#legend">legend</a> met with his knights, its shape intended to prevent quarrels over pre-eminence.   
<p>
Within the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, each of the following permanent round tables has its own membership:
</p><p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd>
</dd><dd><a href="#ert">Exhibits Round Table (ERT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#faflrt">Federal and Armed Forces Libraries Round Table (FAFLRT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#glbtrt">Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, and Transgendered Round Table (GLBTRT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#godort">Government Documents Round Table (GODORT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#ifrt">Intellectual Freedom Round Table (IFRT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#irrt">International Relations Round Table (IRRT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#lhrt">Library History Round Table (LHRT</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#lirt">Library Instruction Round Table (LIRT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#lrrt">Library Research Round Table (LRRT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#magert">Map and Geography Round Table (MAGERT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#nmrt">New Members Round Table (NMRT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#srrt">Social Responsibilities Round Table (SRRT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#ssirt">Support Staff Interests Round Table (SSIRT)</a>
</dd><dd><a href="#vrt">Video Round Table (VRT)</a></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="router"><b>router</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> <a href="#device">device</a> designed to direct the tiny <a href="#packet">packet</a>s of <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#data">data</a> comprising an electronic message from one <a href="#node">node</a> on a computer <a href="#network">network</a> to another by the most efficient pathway.  Routers also perform other functions in the control of network traffic. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="routine"><b>routine</b></a>
</dt><dd>A component of a <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a>, written to execute a given operation or function under specific conditions, for example, an <em>error routine</em>.  Also refers to an operation or procedure which, if performed regularly in the same manner, increases efficiency.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="routing"><b>routing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The routine circulation of new <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, such as the <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>s of <a href="#libjournal">library journal</a>s, to a list of <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> in accordance with their preferences, to allow them to keep abreast of recent developments in their field(s) of interest and <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>.  
<p>
In <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a>, new publications may be circulated to a list of personnel within the <a href="#hostorg">host organization</a> based on their interests, usually by means of a <a href="#routingslip">routing slip</a> listing the names of the individuals who wish to see each <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#title">title</a>.  When finished, each person crosses his or her name off the list and sends the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> to another person on the list.  When all the names have been crossed off, the item is usually returned to the <a href="#serialsdesk">serials desk</a> or <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> to be <a href="#technical">processing</a> for general <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>.  Also spelled <em>routeing</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="routingslip"><b>routing slip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list attached to the front <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a new <a href="#document">document</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>,
giving the names of the people within a department or organization who
would like to receive it. Each person crosses his or her name off the
list when finished, then sends the item to another on the list. After
the last person has seen the item, it is returned to the person
responsible for <a href="#technical">processing</a>, filing, or disposing of it. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="roving"><b>roving</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the delivery of <a href="#refservices">reference services</a>, the practice of discreetly walking about the reference area of a <a href="#library">library</a> in search of users who need assistance, as opposed to remaining seated at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>, waiting for <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to approach with their <a href="#refquestion">question</a>s.  Experienced <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a>s learn to tell by body language and other nonverbal cues when a user is experiencing difficulty.  They may initiate a <a href="#refinterview">reference interview</a> by politely asking if the person is finding the <a href="#information">information</a>
needed. In large libraries, when two librarians are scheduled on
reference duty at the same time, one may rove while the other remains
at the desk.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="royalties"><b>royalties</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> for the regular payments made by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to the <a href="#author">author</a> or creator of a <a href="#work">work</a> for <a href="#copy">copies</a> sold, based on a percentage of the <a href="#publishedprice">published price</a> (usually 10-15 percent).  Negotiated in advance by the parties or their agents, royalties and <a href="#advanceonroyalty">advance on royalty</a> are stipulated in the <a href="#bookcontract">book contract</a>.
Most publishers have an established policy concerning royalty
percentage, but in the case of books with high sales potential, a
higher percentage may be offered as an inducement to sign.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rpm"><b>rpm</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>R</b>evolutions <b>p</b>er <b>m</b>inute, a unit of measurement indicating the <a href="#playingspeed">playing speed</a> of a <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>.  The most common speed is 33 rpm (<a href="#longplaying">long-playing</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rrbowker"><b>R. R. Bowker</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in New York City in 1872, the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> <b>R. R. Bowker</b> <a href="#specialization">specializes</a> in <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s on <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, <a href="#library">libraries</a>, and the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>.  The company is known for its long-standing <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a>s (<em><a href="#bip">Books in Print</a></em>, <em><a href="#ald">American Library Directory</a></em>, <em>The Bowker Annual Library and Book Trade Almanac</em>, <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>, <em><a href="#magazinesfor">Magazines for Libraries</a></em>, <em><a href="#ulrichs">Ulrich's International Periodicals Directory</a></em>, etc.).  <b>Bowker</b> has also served as the official <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a> <a href="#agency">agency</a> for the United States since 1968.  <a href="http://www.bowker.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>Bowker</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bowkerrr">Bowker, Richard Rogers</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rt"><b>RT (or R)</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#relatedterm"><b>r</b>elated <b>t</b>erm</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rubbed"><b>rubbed</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> that has a visibly chafed <a href="#binding">binding</a>, but is otherwise undamaged.  Compare with <a href="#scuffed">scuffed</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rubberstamp"><b>rubber stamp</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small block of wood or metal covered on one side with a thin layer of rubber into which <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, <a href="#number">number</a>s, and/or a design have been cut in relief.  When <a href="#ink">ink</a>ed and pressed against a smooth, clean surface, the block leaves a mark, used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> to stamp <a href="#ownershipmark">ownership mark</a>s on <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, and to stamp the <a href="#duedate">due date</a> on <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s at the time they are <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>.  Some models are self-inking.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rubric"><b>rubric</b></a>
</dt><dd>An initial <a href="#letter">letter</a>, word, <a href="#chapterheading">chapter heading</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, or other part of a <a href="#work">work</a>, written in red or blue <a href="#ink">ink</a>, in contrast to the <a href="#text">text</a> which is written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> in black, a technique used to embellish hand-<a href="#copy">copied</a> medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s and early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s.  A book decorated in this way is said to be <em>rubricated</em>.  A person who pens such <a href="#letter">letter</a>s is a <em>rubricator</em> or <em>rubrisher</em>.  Compare with <a href="#illuminatedinitial">illuminated initial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rule"><b>rule</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thin metal strip of <a href="#type">type</a>-height, used to <a href="#printing">print</a> continuous lines, or lines of dots or pattern, as in a plain or decorative <a href="#border">border</a> around a <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  Rule-borders on <a href="#binding">binding</a>s can be in <a href="#blind">blind</a> or <a href="#goldleaf">gilt</a>.  Thickness of rule (measured in <a href="#point">point</a>s) determines thickness of line.  A rule may be thicker at the center with tapered ends.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dash">dash</a> and <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a>.
<p>Also refers to a regulation or principle governing acceptable
conduct, usually within a specific social, cultural, or organizational
context. Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> have written rules concerning computer use and unacceptable behavior, usually posted near the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> or <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>, and sometimes on the library's <a href="#website">Web site</a>.
</p><p>
In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a <a href="#standard">standard</a> procedure, usually governed by a <a href="#catalogcode">catalog code</a>, such as the <em><a href="#anglo">Anglo-American Cataloging Rules (AACR)</a></em> or the <em><a href="#alafiling">ALA Filing Rules</a></em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ruleinterpretation"><b>rule interpretation (RI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal explanation, clarification, or expansion of existing <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> <a href="#rule">rule</a>s, usually resulting from a case that raises questions concerning the applicability of established policy and/or procedure.  <b>RI</b>s are <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by the cataloging <a href="#agency">agency</a> responsible for administering the <a href="#catalogcode">catalog code</a>; in the case of <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, by the <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/cds/cdsintro.html">Cataloging Distribution Service</a> of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ruleofapplication"><b>rule of application</b></a>
</dt><dd>The instruction in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> to <a href="#classification">classify</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s about the application of one <a href="#subject">subject</a> to another under the second of the two, for example, the <a href="#classification">classification</a> of a <a href="#monograph">monograph</a> on the literary influence of Ovid on Chaucer with works about Chaucer.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ruleofthree"><b>rule of three</b></a>
</dt><dd>The instruction in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> to <a href="#classification">classify</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s in which equal treatment is given to three or more <a href="#subject">subject</a>s (all <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a>s of a more general subject) under the first higher <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> encompassing them all.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#firstoftwo">first-of-two</a>.
<p>
Also, in the days when most <a href="#library">libraries</a> used the <a href="#cardcatalog">card catalog</a>, an effort was made by <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s to assign no more than three <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s per <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, to limit growth of the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  When libraries began <a href="#retrocon">converting</a> <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a>s to <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s, the number of <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s per item ceased to be an issue because the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> occupies no physical space.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ruleofzero"><b>rule of zero</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, when two or more <a href="#classnumber">class number</a>s are found to be equally suitable for a <a href="#work">work</a>, the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> is instructed to avoid <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a>s beginning with zero if there is a choice between 0 and 1-9 at the same point in the <a href="#notation">notation</a>, and to avoid subdivisions beginning with 00 when there is a choice between 00 and 0.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rums"><b>rums</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#slang">slang</a> expression used by London <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s of the 18th century for a miscellaneous assortment of unsaleable <a href="#book">book</a>s, probably derived from the tell-tale odor imparted by the previous contents of the wooden barrels used to store them.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="run"><b>run</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#impression">impression</a>s taken from a <a href="#plate">plate</a> or <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> of <a href="#type">type</a> at one time.  A completed job is said to have been <em>run-off</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="runaround"><b>run-around</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a reduction in the line width of a <a href="#column">column</a> of <a href="#type">type</a>, on either the left- or right-hand side, to accommodate an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> or <a href="#note">note</a> set into the <a href="#text">text</a>.  Synonymous with <em>set-around</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rune"><b>rune</b></a>
</dt><dd>A letter or <a href="#character">character</a> of the earliest Scandinavian and Anglo-Saxon <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>.
Also refers to the characters carved on metal, wood, or stone by the
ancient Teutonic peoples of northern Europe. In a more general sense,
an <a href="#aphorism">aphorism</a>, <a href="#riddle">riddle</a>, or saying believed to have mystical meaning or magical powers.  <a href="http://www.tarahill.com/runes/">Click here</a> to learn more about runes. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="runners"><b>runners</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sequence of <a href="#number">number</a>s or <a href="#letter">letter</a>s <a href="#printing">printed</a> at regular intervals down one or both side <a href="#margin">margin</a>s in a <a href="#book">book</a> to indicate the position of any line on a <a href="#page">page</a>.  Used in long <a href="#poetry">poems</a>, dramatic <a href="#script">script</a>s, and <a href="#text">text</a> in a foreign <a href="#language">language</a>, to enable the <a href="#reader">reader</a> to reference a specific line (or lines) by <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="runningfoot"><b>running foot</b></a>
</dt><dd>The line of <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> below the <a href="#text">text</a> at the bottom of a <a href="#page">page</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, <a href="#uniformstyle">uniform in style</a> and content, usually giving the same <a href="#information">information</a> as a <a href="#runninghead">running head</a>. Synonymous with <em>footline</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#footer">footer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="runninghead"><b>running head</b></a>
</dt><dd>The line of <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> above the <a href="#text">text</a> at the top of a <a href="#page">page</a>.  In a <a href="#book">book</a>, it usually gives the <a href="#title">title</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> and the <a href="#chaptertitle">chapter title</a> on the <a href="#recto">recto</a>.  In <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, the running head gives the name of the <a href="#publication">publication</a>, <a href="#issue">issue</a> date, and <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>, and may also include the <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a> and <a href="#issuenumber">issue number</a>.  Synonymous with <em>headline</em> and <em>page head</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="runningtime"><b>running time</b></a>
</dt><dd>The duration of a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, including the <a href="#credit">credit</a>s but not any <a href="#trailer">trailer</a>(s) or supplemental material.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, running time is given under <a href="#extentofitem">extent of item</a> in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>.  Compare with <a href="#playingtime">playing time</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="runningtitle"><b>running title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> title of a <a href="#book">book</a>, or section of a book, repeated in <a href="#uniformstyle">uniform style</a> at the <a href="#head">head</a> or <a href="#foot">foot</a> of each <a href="#page">page</a> or <a href="#verso">verso</a>, usually the same as the <a href="#dropdowntitle">drop-down title</a>.  Also known as a <a href="#runninghead">running head</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="runonchapter"><b>run on chapter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> that does not begin on a new <a href="#page">page</a>, but is <a href="#typesetting">set</a> immediately following the end of the <a href="#text">text</a> of the preceding chapter, usually to minimize the amount of <a href="#paper">paper</a> required to print the <a href="#work">work</a>.  In quality <a href="#printing">printing</a>, it is <a href="#standard">standard</a> practice to begin a new chapter on the <a href="#recto">recto</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> following the last page of the preceding chapter.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rurallibrary"><b>rural library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>
that serves a population living primarily on farms and ranches, and in
remote communities, rather than in a town or city. Rural libraries
typically provide <a href="#outreach">outreach</a> services such as <a href="#bookmobile">bookmobile</a>s and <a href="#booksbymail">books-by-mail</a> to  bring library resources and services to users. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rusa1"><b>RUSA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#rusa"><b>R</b>eference and <b>U</b>ser <b>S</b>ervices <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rushorder"><b>rush order</b></a>
</dt><dd>A request made by a <a href="#library">library</a> to a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, or <a href="#dealer">dealer</a> that a specific <a href="#title">title</a> be supplied as quickly as possible, usually because it is needed by a professor for course <a href="#reserves">reserves</a>, to meet heavy <a href="#demand">demand</a>, or to satisfy a <a href="#patron">patron</a> who has requested it.  Compare with <a href="#specialorder">special order</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#rushprocessing">rush processing</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rushprocessing"><b>rush processing</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> sent to <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> to be <a href="#technical">processed</a> as soon as it is <a href="#receiving">received</a>, usually a <a href="#rushorder">rush order</a> or an item for which a <a href="#patron">patron</a> is waiting.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="rusticcapital"><b>rustic capital</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of the lighter and less formal <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a>s used as a <a href="#bookhand">book hand</a> by <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>s from the 1st to the 6th century A.D., in contrast to the heavy <a href="#squarecapital">square capital</a>s used in formal <a href="#document">document</a>s, derived from Roman <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>s.  Vertical strokes were thinned by holding the pen at an acute angle, condensing previously rounded <a href="#letterform">letterform</a>s to allow more <a href="#text">text</a> to be copied on a <a href="#page">page</a>, a distinct advantage when writing material (<a href="#parchment">parchment</a> or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>) was costly and in limited supply.  Latin:  <em>capitalis rustica</em>.  Compare with <a href="#uncial">uncial</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a capital letter with a design engraved on its face,
especially in the form of vines and leaves, or the textured bark of a
tree. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#foliateinitial">foliate initial</a>. 
</p></dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>
<center>| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> | <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a>
| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="S">S</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="saa1"><b>SAA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#saa"><b>S</b>ociety of <b>A</b>merican <b>A</b>rchivists</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sabbatical"><b>sabbatical</b></a>
</dt><dd>A paid leave of absence granted to an academic professional for the purpose of <a href="#research">research</a>
or scholarly endeavor, usually for one semester or a full academic
year, following six or seven years of full-time service, sometimes
involving travel. At many colleges and universities, applications are
evaluated on a competitive basis by a faculty committee, or in some
