other manner determined by institutional <a href="#governance">governance</a>.  <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s employed in <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> may be eligible for sabbatic leave depending on the provisions of the contract governing terms of employment. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sacredtext"><b>sacred text</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written <a href="#work">work</a> revered by people who believe in one of the world's organized religions.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, such <a href="#work">work</a>s are entered under a <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a> (<b><em>Bible</em></b>, <b><em>Talmud</em></b>, <b><em>Koran</em></b>, <b><em>Vedas</em></b>, etc.).  Most libraries in the United States keep at least one English <a href="#translation">translation</a> of the <em>Bible</em> in the <a href="#refcollection">reference collection</a>, usually with <a href="#commentary">commentaries</a>, <a href="#concordance">concordance</a>s, etc.  The sacred <a href="#book">book</a>s of the other major world religions may be available in the <a href="#circulating">circulating</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, especially at universities offering a major or graduate degree in comparative religion.  Compare with <a href="#liturgicalwork">liturgical work</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#scripture">scripture</a>.
 <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="saddle"><b>saddle-stitching</b></a>
</dt><dd>A technique used to <a href="#binding">bind</a> <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s and <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s in which the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> are secured by round wire staples driven completely through the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a> at two or more places, usually by machine.  Unlike <a href="#sidestitching">side-stitching</a>, this method allows the leaves to <a href="#openability">open</a> flat, but its strength is not sufficient to bind <a href="#publication">publication</a>s of more than 100 <a href="#page">page</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>stapling</em> and <em>saddle-wire stitching</em>.  Compare with <a href="#sewing">sewing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="saga"><b>saga</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Old Norse word for "thing said," a lengthy <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> in <a href="#prose">prose</a> or <a href="#verse">verse</a>, telling of adventure and heroic events, usually involving the history of a <a href="#legend">legend</a>ary Norse lineage.  In modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, any long, complicated <a href="#tale">tale</a> in which the <a href="#plot">plot</a> has many unexpected twists and turns, particularly one recounting the fortunes of an extended family (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Forsyte Saga</em></b> by John Galsworthy).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="salary"><b>salary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sum of money paid to an employee on a regular basis (weekly,
biweekly, monthly) for performing a specific job. In the United States,
most <a href="#fulltime">full-time</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and technical <a href="#supportstaff">support staff</a> are salaried.  Statistical <a href="#information">information</a> on salaries for librarians employed in the U.S. and Canada is reported annually in <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em> (usually in the October 15th <a href="#issue">issue</a>) and in the <em>Bowker Annual Library and Book Trade Almanac</em>.  Compare with <a href="#wages">wages</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="salis1"><b>SALIS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#salis"><b>S</b>ubstance <b>A</b>buse <b>L</b>ibrarians and <b>I</b>nformation <b>S</b>pecialists</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="salvage"><b>salvage</b></a>
</dt><dd>Measures taken to recover <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, and furnishings <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> outside of normal use, for example, by water as a result of a major leak or flood.  Salvaged materials may require special <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> procedures such as <a href="#vacuumfreeze">vacuum freeze dry</a>ing or <a href="#fumigation">fumigation</a>.   <a href="#bibitem">Item</a>s not <em>salvageable</em> are usually <a href="#discard">discard</a>ed.  Also refers collectively to the materials recovered.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="samesize"><b>same size</b></a>
</dt><dd>Instructions from the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to the <a href="#printer">printer</a> to <a href="#reproduction">reproduce</a> an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> submitted as <a href="#copy">copy</a> without <a href="#enlargement">enlargement</a> or <a href="#reduction">reduction</a> in size.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sampleissue"><b>sample issue</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, usually the first of an entirely new <a href="#publication">publication</a>, sent at no charge by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to a potential <a href="#subscription">subscriber</a> for inspection.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, such <a href="#copy">copies</a> are usually received and evaluated for <a href="#selection">selection</a> by the <a href="#serial">serial</a>s department.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, they may be routed to the appropriate department of the teaching faculty for evaluation. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sansserif"><b>sans-serif</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#blockletter">block letter</a>.  Also spelled <em>sanserif</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="satire"><b>satire</b></a>
</dt><dd>The use of sarcasm, irony, and wit to expose to ridicule the
weaknesses or foibles of a person, group, or institution, often used to
call public attention to a moral lapse or abuse of public trust, to
damage the reputation of the victim for political or personal reasons,
or as entertainment (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Ideal Husband</em></b>, a <a href="#comedy">comic</a> <a href="#play">drama</a> by Oscar Wilde).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#caricature">caricature</a>, <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>, <a href="#lampoon">lampoon</a>, and <a href="#libel">libel</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="save"><b>save</b></a>
</dt><dd>To preserve a <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a> by <a href="#copy">copy</a>ing it from main <a href="#memory">memory</a> (<a href="#ram">RAM</a>) to a permanent <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a>, such as a <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a> or <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>, at the end of a session on a computer.  Unsaved data may be lost when the <a href="#application">application</a> is closed or the computer <a href="#powerdown">powered down</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scale"><b>scale</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#cartography">cartography</a>, the ratio of distance shown on a <a href="#map">map</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>, or other <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>
representation of a given geographic phenomenon, to its corresponding
dimension on the ground, or to another graphic representation. On maps,
the scale is usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> beneath the <a href="#title">title</a> in the <a href="#legend">legend</a>, in the form of a bar scale or as a <a href="#rf">representative fraction</a> (<em>example</em>:  1:24,000).  When a map is <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> by a <a href="#library">library</a>, the <em>statement of scale</em> is given in the <a href="#mathdata">mathematical data</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  
<p>
Also, the ratio of the size of a <a href="#model">model</a> or <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> to the size of the <a href="#original">original</a> object.  Also refers to the size of an item relative to others of its <a href="#class">class</a>.  Compare with <a href="#reductionratio">reduction ratio</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scanner"><b>scanner</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a>, a <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> <a href="#device">device</a> that reads and <a href="#dataconversion">converts</a> handwritten or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s, or <a href="#barcode">barcode</a>s into <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a> (a <a href="#bitmap">bitmap</a>) for <a href="#centralproc">processing</a> or display on a computer screen, without actually recognizing the <a href="#content">content</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, optical scanners are used to create <a href="#digitalimaging">digital image</a>s of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> for <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>, <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery</a>, and <a href="#elecreserves">electronic reserves</a>, and in <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> to read the barcode on the <a href="#patron">patron</a>'s <a href="#librarycard">library card</a> and on <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  Some barcode scanners require an <a href="#externaldecoder">external decoder</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scatter"><b>scatter</b></a>
</dt><dd>The separation of <a href="#entry">entries</a> on the same <a href="#subject">subject</a> in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#index">index</a>, a condition that occurs when entries are made under 1) both the singular and plural forms of a <a href="#heading">heading</a>, 2) variant forms of a name or <a href="#title">title</a>,
or 3) a broad heading in one instance and a more specific heading in
another. Scatter may also occur when there is inadequate control of <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>s or lack of precision in the assignment of <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s.  Scatter is reduced by <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a> and <a href="#vocabcontrol">vocabulary control</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scattered"><b>scattered</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#completeness">completeness</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scatternote"><b>scatter note</b></a>
</dt><dd>A note in a <a href="#classificationschedule">classification schedule</a> instructing the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> to <a href="#classification">classify</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s in multiple locations.  For example, in <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, <a href="#review">review</a>s of works on a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> are classed with the subject or <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, rather than under a general <a href="#class">class</a> for "Reviews."  
<p>
In a list of <a href="#precoordinate">pre-coordinate</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> terms, a note indicating that a term is used as a <a href="#subheading">subheading</a> under one or more categories of headings, for example, the note in the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress Subject Headings</a> list under "Catalogs, Union" indicating that "Union lists" is used as a <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a> under "<em>types of printed or non-book materials, e.g.</em> Italian imprints--Union lists." 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scenario"><b>scenario</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#outline">outline</a> or <a href="#sketch">sketch</a> of the <a href="#plot">plot</a> of a dramatic <a href="#work">work</a> (<a href="#play">play</a>, opera, ballet, etc.), indicating the order of scenes and the <a href="#character">character</a>s involved in the action.  Compare with <a href="#treatment">treatment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="schedule"><b>schedule</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#classificationschedule">classification schedule</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="schedulereduction"><b>schedule reduction</b></a>
</dt><dd>The elimination of some of the provisions made in a previous <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#classification">classification schedule</a>, resulting in the <a href="#discontinuednumber">discontinuation</a> of certain <a href="#class">class</a>es, usually because the <a href="#literature">literature</a> on the <a href="#subject">subject</a> has dwindled significantly or because the <a href="#class">class</a> represents a distinction no longer recognized in the <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or <a href="#field">field</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="schematic"><b>schematic</b></a>
</dt><dd>A clear, simple <a href="#linedrawing">line drawing</a> or <a href="#diagram">diagram</a> used in <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s and technical <a href="#book">book</a>s to <a href="#illustration">illustrate</a> an operating principle or mechanism (or one of its parts).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scholarlybook"><b>scholarly book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> <a href="#term">term</a> for a <a href="#book">book</a> that is: 1) written in a scholarly style, 2) about a <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#subject">subject</a>,
3) aimed at relatively narrow clearly-defined market segment, 4) sold
primarily within that market, 5) often purchased on the basis of <a href="#imprint">imprint</a>, 6) not <a href="#listprice">price</a>-sensitive, 7) not highly profitable for the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, 8) usually published by a <a href="#universitypress">university press</a> or the publishing arm of a scholarly <a href="#society">society</a>, 9) <a href="#review">review</a>ed mainly in scholarly <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, and 10) <a href="#index">index</a>ed, with a <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> or list of references for <a href="#furtherreading">further reading</a> at the end.  Scholarly books normally generate little income from the sale of <a href="#subsidiaryrights">subsidiary right</a>s, but attract a more sustained <a href="#readership">readership</a> than most <a href="#tradebook">trade title</a>s (adapted from <em>Bodian's Publishing Desk Reference</em>, NY: Oryx Press, 1988).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scholarlycommunication"><b>scholarly communication</b></a>
</dt><dd>The means by which individuals engaged in academic <a href="#research">research</a>
and creative endeavor inform their peers, formally or informally, of
the work they have accomplished. Scholars communicate by writing <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>s and <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s for <a href="#publication">publication</a>, presenting <a href="#conference">conference</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a>s which are subsequently <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a> and <a href="#transactions">transactions</a>, submitting <a href="#report">report</a>s in fulfillment of <a href="#grant">grant</a> requirements, creating and maintaining <a href="#website">Web site</a>s aimed at the academic community, and <a href="#correspondence">corresponding</a> with peers via <a href="#email">e-mail</a> and electronic <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>s.  One of the <a href="#mission">mission</a>s of <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> (and <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s) is to facilitate scholarly communication in all its forms.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#peerreviewed">peer reviewed</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scholarlyjournal"><b>scholarly journal</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#journal">journal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sparc"><b>Scholarly Publishing and Academic Resources Coalition (SPARC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An international alliance of approximately 200 universities, <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a>, and <a href="#libassociation">library association</a>s, <b>SPARC</b> was created in 1998 by several <a href="#arl">Association of Research Libraries</a> (ARL) <a href="#librarydirector">director</a>s to address the pricing practices and policies of scientific, technical, and medical (STM) <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s.  The coalition seeks to educate faculty on academic <a href="#serial">serial</a>s issues, fosters competition in the <a href="#scholarlycommunication">scholarly communication</a> market, and advocates fundamental changes in the system and culture of scholarly communication.  <a href="http://www.arl.org/sparc/home/index.asp">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>SPARC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#oai">Open Archives Initiative</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scholium"><b>scholium</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#sidenote">marginal note</a> explaining, interpreting, or commenting on a <a href="#text">text</a>, especially an <a href="#annotation">annotation</a> added by a classical grammarian on a passage from a <a href="#work">work</a> by Greek or Latin <a href="#author">author</a> of antiquity.  Plural:  <em>scholia</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#exegesis">exegesis</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="schoollibrary"><b>school library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> in a public or private elementary or secondary school that serves the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of its students and the curriculum needs of its teachers and staff, usually managed by a <em>school librarian</em> or <a href="#mediaspecialist">media specialist</a>.  A school <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> usually contains <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, and educational <a href="#media">media</a> suitable for the grade levels served. <a href="http://www.sldirectory.com/index.html">Click here</a> to connect to a worldwide <a href="#directory">directory</a> of <b><em>School Libraries on the Web</em></b>.  Synonymous with <em>learning resources center</em> and <em>school library media center</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#slj">School Library Journal</a></em> and <a href="#aasl">American Association of School Librarians</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slj"><b><em>School Library Journal (SLJ)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publishing">Published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, <b><em>SLJ</em></b> is a <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> and <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a> for <a href="#schoollibrary">school</a>, <a href="#childrensservices">children's</a>, and <a href="#yaservices">young adult</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s.  In addition to <a href="#regular">regular</a> <a href="#column">column</a>s, <a href="#feature">feature</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s, and news of interest to the profession, <b><em>SLJ</em></b> <a href="#review">review</a>s approximately 4,000 general <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a>s for <a href="#childrensbook">children</a> and <a href="#youngadult">young adult</a> <a href="#reader">reader</a>s each year, and over 1,000 educational <a href="#media">media</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s, including <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>s.  The reviews are short but evaluative, written by and for librarians.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="schoollibmedia"><b>school library media center</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#schoollibrary">school library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sciencefiction"><b>science fiction</b></a>
</dt><dd>A highly imaginative form of <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>
based on scientific speculation, usually depicting life and adventure
in the future or on other worlds, not outside the realm of possibility,
sometimes prophetically (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>1984</em></b> by George Orwell) or as a commentary on contemporary conditions (<b><em>Brave New World</em></b> by Aldous Huxley).  Science fiction is so popular that most large cities in the United States have at least one <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a> <a href="#specialization">specializing</a> in the <a href="#genre">genre</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>sci fi</em>.  Compare with <a href="#fantasy">fantasy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scope"><b>scope</b></a>
</dt><dd>The area or field within which a specific activity occurs.
Also, the range or extent of action, observation, meaning, inquiry,
etc. In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the range of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s or <a href="#field">field</a>s covered in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>, etc.  Compare with <a href="#coverage">coverage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#scopenote">scope note (SN)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scopenote"><b>scope note (SN)</b></a>
</dt><dd>One or two sentences of <a href="#text">text</a> added to an <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">term</a>s or list of <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s to indicate the intended use of a <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> or subject heading, including any special rules for assigning it in indexing.  <a href="#scope">Scope</a> notes are usually added to clarify ambiguity or restrict the use of a <a href="#term">term</a> to one of several possible meanings.  Not all terms require a scope note, but if one is given, it normally precedes any <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>s (<a href="#usedfor">UF</a>), <a href="#broaderterm">broader term</a>s (BTs), <a href="#narrowerterm">narrower term</a>s (NTs), or <a href="#relatedterm">related term</a>s (RTs).  Compare with <a href="#parenthetical">parenthetical qualifier</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="score"><b>score</b></a>
</dt><dd>A record of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> in which the <a href="#part">part</a>s to be played or sung are written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> in musical <a href="#notation">notation</a> on separate <a href="#stave">stave</a>s, vertically aligned to enable them to be read at the same time.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#chorusscore">chorus score</a>, <a href="#closescore">close score</a>, <a href="#condensedscore">condensed score</a>, <a href="#fullscore">full score</a>, <a href="#miniaturescore">miniature score</a>, <a href="#pianoscore">piano score</a>, <a href="#shortscore">short score</a>, and <a href="#vocalscore">vocal score</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scoring"><b>scoring</b></a>
</dt><dd>To make a linear indentation on a piece of <a href="#paper">paper</a> or card to allow it to turn or fold more easily without damaging the fibers.  When done with a dull <a href="#rule">rule</a> or disk, the process is called <a href="#creasing">creasing</a>.  When a sharp rule is used, the fibers are partially broken, producing an effect similar to <a href="#perforation">perforation</a>, which allows the paper to tear more cleanly along the fold.  In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, to compress the fibers of a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> in a line along the inner edge to allow the <a href="#volume">volume</a> to open more easily. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scout"><b>scout</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person with experience in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, employed by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to seek out new writers and <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>s whose early <a href="#work">work</a>s show promise, and to explore with them possibilities for <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#bookscout">book scout</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scrapbook"><b>scrapbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#blankbook">blankbook</a>, usually of large-size, containing unprinted <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> for <a href="#mounted">mounting</a> or inserting <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, <a href="#picture">picture</a>s, <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s, <a href="#letters">letters</a>, invitations, and other <a href="#memorabilia">memorabilia</a>, usually to preserve them for sentimental reasons.  Compare with <a href="#album">album</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="screencapture"><b>screen capture</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#screendump">screen dump</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="screendump"><b>screen dump</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of <a href="#save">saving</a> as a <a href="#file">file</a>, or sending to a <a href="#printer">printer</a>, a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of the image displayed on the <a href="#monitor">monitor</a> of a computer, usually to create a <a href="#record">record</a> that can be used to document and/or diagnose a malfunction.  Synonymous with <em>screen capture</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="screenplay"><b>screenplay</b></a>
</dt><dd>A story written in a form suitable for <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> or television production, or <a href="#adaptation">adapted</a> for that purpose from an existing <a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>, or stage <a href="#play">play</a> by a <a href="#screenwriter">screenwriter</a> whose name is given in the <a href="#credit">credit</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#script">script</a> and <a href="#treatment">treatment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="screenprinting"><b>screen printing</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#silkscreen">silk screen</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="screensaver"><b>screen saver</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#utility">utility</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> that blanks out the image displayed on the <a href="#monitor">monitor</a> of a computer, or replaces it with a continuously changing pattern, to prevent <em>ghosting</em>,
the permanent etching of a still image on the monitor. Most screen
savers can be set to commence after a designated period of inactivity
and remain on the screen until the <a href="#mouse">mouse</a> is moved or a key is depressed, restoring the original image.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="screenwriter"><b>screenwriter</b></a>
</dt><dd>The person responsible for writing the <a href="#screenplay">screenplay</a> for a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>, or television program, or the <a href="#script">script</a>ed <a href="#narration">narration</a> for a <a href="#documentary">documentary</a>, whose name is usually given in the <a href="#credit">credit</a>s.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the name of the screenwriter is entered in the <a href="#notearea">note area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scribalcopy"><b>scribal copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> produced by a <a href="#scribe">scribe</a> or <a href="#copy">copy</a>ist, as opposed to the <a href="#original">original</a> manuscript written by the <a href="#author">author</a>, or at the author's dictation.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scribe"><b>scribe</b></a>
</dt><dd>A professional penman who <a href="#copy">copied</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s by hand before the invention of <a href="#printing">printing</a> from <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a>.  During the Middle Ages, most copyists were monks who worked in the <a href="#scriptorium">scriptoria</a> of Roman Catholic religious establishments.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#calligraphy">calligraphy</a> and <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scrinium"><b>scrinium</b></a>
</dt><dd>A container in the shape of a cylinder with a removable top, used by the Romans of antiquity for storing <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s in the form of <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#capsa">capsa</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="script"><b>script</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#play">play</a>, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>, or television or radio program, indicating the lines to be spoken by each <a href="#character">character</a>, with directions for staging the <a href="#work">work</a>.  Compare with <a href="#actingedition">acting edition</a> and <a href="#promptbook">promptbook</a>.  
<p>
Also, a set of <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>ic, syllabic, or <a href="#ideogram">ideograph</a>ic <a href="#character">character</a>s used in writing one or more <a href="#language">language</a>s (see <a href="http://www.ancientscripts.com/">Ancient Scripts of the World</a>).  In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#cursive">cursive</a> <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> designed to imitate handwriting done with brush or pen.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scriptorium"><b>scriptorium</b></a>
</dt><dd>The room in a medieval monastery reserved for the preparation of <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s by <a href="#scribe">scribe</a>s.
In some religious houses it was a single large room; in others, the
space was partitioned into individual cells. To minimize distraction,
absolute silence was maintained while work was in progress. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#armarian">armarian</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scripture"><b>scripture</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, any written <a href="#composition">composition</a>, but the <a href="#term">term</a> is now used mainly for the Old and New Testaments of the Christian <b><em>Bible</em></b>, sometimes in the plural (<em>Holy Scriptures</em>).  In a more general sense, any religious or <a href="#sacredtext">sacred text</a> or <a href="#record">record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scroll"><b>scroll</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> in the form of a length of <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a>, usually rolled around a sturdy wooden rod with knobbed ends called the <a href="#umbilicus">umbilicus</a>, with a tag attached to one end for identification.  In antiquity, <a href="#text">text</a>s were written in <a href="#column">column</a>s on papyrus <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s glued together to form a continuous roll which the Romans called a <a href="#volumen">volumen</a>.  The <a href="#codex">codex</a> (<a href="#book">book</a> with <a href="#page">page</a>s) replaced the scroll after animal skin (<a href="#parchment">parchment</a> and <a href="#vellum">vellum</a>) came into widespread use as a writing surface.  Compare with <a href="#rotulus">rotulus</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#capsa">capsa</a> and <a href="#scrinium">scrinium</a>.
<p>
Also, to cause the <a href="#text">text</a> or images on a computer screen to move vertically or horizontally, by typing strokes on a <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> or by using a pointing <a href="#device">device</a> such as a <a href="#mouse">mouse</a> to manipulate a <em>scroll bar</em> along one side, or across the top or bottom, of a <a href="#window">window</a> or <a href="#frame">frame</a> in a <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="scuffed"><b>scuffed</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> with a <a href="#binding">binding</a> so badly scraped that it has become <a href="#frayed">frayed</a> or roughened in places.  Compare with <a href="#rubbed">rubbed</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sdi1"><b>SDI</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of "<b>s</b>elective <b>d</b>issemination of <b>i</b>nformation."  <b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#currentawareness">current awareness service</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="search"><b>search</b></a>
</dt><dd>A systematic effort on the part of a <a href="#library">library</a> user or <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> to locate desired <a href="#information">information</a> by manual or electronic means, whether successful or not, as opposed to <a href="#browse">browsing</a> a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#collection">collection</a> with no clear intention in mind.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>, <a href="#searchstrategy">search strategy</a>, <a href="#mediated">mediated search</a>, and <a href="#serendipity">serendipity</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to an attempt by a member of the <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> to find an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> listed as available in the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, but not in its correct location on the shelf (<a href="#nos">nos</a>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#missing">missing</a>.
</p><p>
In employment, the formal process of seeking qualified <a href="#candidate">candidate</a>s to fill a vacant <a href="#position">position</a>, usually undertaken by a <a href="#searchcommittee">search committee</a> composed of staff members and/or supervisors who will work closely with the new employee.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, national searches are usually announced in professional <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, such as <em><a href="#americanlibraries">American Libraries</a></em>, <em>College &amp; Research Libraries News</em>, and the <em>Chronicle of Higher Education</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="searchable"><b>searchable</b></a>
</dt><dd>An electronic resource running on <a href="#software">software</a> designed to allow the user to type a word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, or string of words or phrases, as <a href="#input">input</a> to find all the <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s, <a href="#entry">entries</a>, or <a href="#text">text</a> containing the <a href="#searchterm">search term</a>(s).  Most <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s can be <a href="#search">search</a>ed by <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> (<a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>), and <a href="#keywords">keywords</a>.  <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic and <a href="#truncation">truncation</a> are permitted in a keywords search in most <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s and <a href="#database">database</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="searchcommittee"><b>search committee</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of people, usually three or more <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> members, elected or appointed to assist in the process of selecting a <a href="#candidate">candidate</a> (or list of candidates) to fill a vacant <a href="#position">position</a> in the <a href="#library">library</a>.  Their responsibilities may include drafting the <a href="#positiondescrip">position description</a>,
posting the vacancy, evaluating applications, selecting candidates for
interviewing, drafting interview questions, conducting interviews, and
selecting and recommending finalist(s) to <a href="#libadmin">library administration</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="searchengine"><b>search engine</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> <a href="#device">device</a> designed to search a <a href="#text">text</a>-based <a href="#database">database</a> for specific <a href="#character">character</a> strings typed as <a href="#input">input</a> by the user. More recently, computer <a href="#software">software</a> designed to help the user locate <a href="#information">information</a> available at <a href="#website">site</a>s on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>, by selecting categories from a hierarchical <a href="#directory">directory</a> of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em>) or by entering appropriate <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> (<em><a href="http://www.google.com/">Google</a></em>, <em><a href="http://www.hotbot.com/">Hotbot</a></em>, etc.).  Most Web search engines allow the searcher to use <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic and <a href="#truncation">truncation</a> in <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>s.  <a href="http://www.searchengineguide.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em>Search Engine Guide</em> <a href="#website">Web site</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#crawler">crawler</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="searchhistory"><b>search history</b></a>
</dt><dd>A feature of some <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a> systems and <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>s that allows the user to view a consecutive list of all the <a href="#search">search</a>es executed during the current search session, or all the <a href="#website">site</a>s visited in a <a href="#browse">browsing</a> session.  Some systems allow the user to select a previous search from the list and re-execute it, or <a href="#printing">print</a> or <a href="#save">save</a> the search history, if desired.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="searchservice"><b>search service</b></a>
</dt><dd>A business that <a href="#specialization">specializes</a> in locating <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s at the request of <a href="#library">libraries</a> and private <a href="#bookcollecting">collector</a>s.  <a href="#acquisitions">Acquisitions</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s must rely on such services when a <a href="#replacement">replacement</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a> is needed for an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> that is still in <a href="#demand">demand</a> but no longer <a href="#inprint">in print</a>.  Some <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s dealers also offer this service.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#alibris">Alibris</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="searchsoftware"><b>search software</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a> designed to execute a <a href="#search">search</a> for <a href="#information">information</a> when <a href="#query">queried</a> by a user.  <a href="#userfriendly">User-friendly</a> search <a href="#software">software</a> provides both a <a href="#menudriven">menu-driven</a> <a href="#interface">interface</a> for <a href="#novice">novice</a>s and a <a href="#commanddriven">command-driven</a> interface for experienced searchers.  Sophisticated search software permits the use of <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic, <a href="#nesting">nesting</a>, <a href="#truncation">truncation</a>, <a href="#wildcard">wildcard</a>, and <a href="#proximity">proximity</a> operators in <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>s, and allows the user to <a href="#limiting">limit</a> search results by various <a href="#parameter">parameter</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#functionality">functionality</a>.  
<p> 
</p></dd><dt><a name="searchstatement"><b>search statement</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, an <a href="#infoneed">information need</a> or <a href="#query">query</a> entered as <a href="#input">input</a> in a form acceptable to the <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a> used by the retrieval system.  Most <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, and <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>s allow <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic, <a href="#nesting">nesting</a>, <a href="#truncation">truncation</a>, <a href="#wildcard">wildcard</a>, and <a href="#proximity">proximity</a> operators to be used in <a href="#search">search</a> statements, and permit the user to <a href="#limiting">limit</a> search results.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a> and <a href="#naturallang">natural language</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="searchstrategy"><b>search strategy</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, a systematic <em>plan</em> for conducting a <a href="#search">search</a>.  In most cases, the first step is to formulate a clear and concise <a href="#topic">topic</a> statement.  The next step is to identify the main concepts in the topic.  Then the most appropriate <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a>s for the <a href="#subject">subject</a> must be identified and located.  Lists of authorized <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>(s) and <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s in the appropriate <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> systems can then be consulted to find <a href="#preferredterm">preferred term</a>s to represent the main concepts.  
<p>
In computer-based information retrieval, <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> can be combined using <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic to form one or more <a href="#query">queries</a> expressed in <a href="#syntax">syntax</a> acceptable to the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, and <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>s most likely to contain <a href="#information">information</a> on the subject.  If the initial results of a search are unsatisfactory, the user can modify the <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a> by adding <a href="#relatedterm">related term</a>s or substituting <a href="#broaderterm">broader term</a>s to expand retrieval, or by substituting <a href="#narrowerterm">narrower term</a>s to restrict retrieval.  In most systems, <a href="#limiting">limiting</a> can be employed to restrict retrieval to <a href="#entry">entries</a> that meet specific <a href="#parameter">parameter</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#heuristic">heuristic</a>, <a href="#proximity">proximity</a>, and <a href="#truncation">truncation</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="searchterm"><b>search term</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> representing one of the main concepts in a <a href="#research">research</a> <a href="#topic">topic</a> which, when combined with other <a href="#term">term</a>s in a <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>, can be used to query an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> and <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> <a href="#information">information</a>.  Search terms can be authorized <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s selected from a prescribed list (<a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a>), or <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> supplied by the user.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sears"><b>Sears subject heading</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> from a list created by Minnie E. Sears, first <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1923 for use in <a href="#schoollibrary">school libraries</a> and small <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.  Although it is based on <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject heading</a>s, the <b><em>Sears List of Subject Headings</em></b> published by <a href="#hwwilson">H. W. Wilson</a> is narrower in <a href="#scope">scope</a> and its <a href="#heading">heading</a>s are more general.  Small <a href="#library">libraries</a> supplement it with LC headings as needed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="season"><b>season</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of the annual cycles in the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> industry.  When <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s introduce their <a href="#frontlist">frontlist</a> in the spring and fall of each year, the previous year's frontlist <a href="#title">title</a>s move to the <a href="#backlist">backlist</a>.  New and backlisted titles are described in the seasonal <a href="#publisherscatalog">publisher's catalog</a> distributed by mail to <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="seasonalcatalog"><b>seasonal catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#season">season</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="secondarybinding"><b>secondary binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>When potential sales of a new <a href="#book">book</a> are difficult to predict, the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> may decide to bind an <a href="#edition">edition</a> in batches over a period of years.  The color or quality of the <a href="#binding">binding</a> material and the <a href="#lettering">lettering</a> on the <a href="#spine">spine</a> may differ slightly from one batch to another.  To distinguish the <em>primary binding</em> from subsequent bindings, the order in which the batches were bound must be determined, if possible.  Compare with <a href="#remainders">remainder</a> binding.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="secondaryentry"><b>secondary entry</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="secondarysource"><b>secondary source</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any <a href="#publishing">published</a> or <a href="#unpublished">unpublished</a> <a href="#work">work</a>
that is one step removed from the original source, usually describing,
summarizing, analyzing, evaluating, derived from, or based on <a href="#primarysource">primary source</a> materials, for example, a <a href="#review">review</a>, critical analysis, second-person account, or <a href="#biography">biographical</a>
or historical study. Also refers to material other than primary sources
used in the preparation of a written work. Compare with <a href="#tertiarysource">tertiary source</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="secondaryvalues"><b>secondary values</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, the <a href="#archivalvalue">values</a> of <a href="#record">record</a>s for the activities of users other than the <a href="#officeofrecord">office of record</a> or its successors.  Compare with <a href="#primaryvalues">primary values</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="secondhandbook"><b>second-hand book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#usedbook">used book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="secondhandbookstore"><b>second-hand bookstore</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#usedbookstore">used bookstore</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="section"><b>section</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a separately <a href="#publishing">published</a> part of a <a href="#serial">serial</a>, usually representing a <a href="#subject">subject</a> category within the whole, designated by a <a href="#topic">topic</a>al <a href="#heading">heading</a> or an <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>
or numerical code (or both). Also, a similar division within a law
book. Also refers to one of the separately folded parts of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, for example, the <em>Entertainment Section</em>.
<p>
In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a unit of <a href="#paper">paper</a> which when folded, <a href="#gathering">gathered</a>, and <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> or glued together with similar units, constitutes the <a href="#bookblock">book block</a>, usually a single folded <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>, but in some cases one-and-a-half or two sheets, or one sheet with an extra <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> added.  Strictly speaking, a section is a <a href="#signature">signature</a> to which any <a href="#plate">plate</a>s and/or <a href="#insert">insert</a>s have been added.  
</p><p>
In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, the third level of <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a>, represented by a three-digit <a href="#notation">notation</a> not ending in zero (<em>example</em>:  <b>947</b> for <a href="#work">work</a>s
on the history of Russia). There are one thousand sections in DDC (10 x
10 x 10). Further subdivision is indicated by the addition of a <a href="#decimalpoint">decimal</a> fraction (<b>947.084</b> for history of the Russian Revolution).  <a href="http://www.oclc.org/dewey/about/thousands.htm">Click here</a> to see a <a href="#table">table</a> of the sections in DDC.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#division">division</a> and <a href="#mainclass">main class</a>.
</p><p>
In <a href="#cartography">cartography</a>, a <a href="#scale">scale</a>
representation of a vertical plane of intersection, showing both the
surface profile of the ground (and any large bodies of water) and
underlying geological features, for example, rock formations and
sedimentary strata. Also, a unit of subdivision of a township, usually
a <a href="#quadrangle">quadrangle</a> one mile square.
</p><p>
In library shelving, the vertical unit between two uprights in a single or double-faced <a href="#range">range</a>.  In the United States, a standard section is 7 1/2 feet high and 3 feet wide.  Synonymous in Britain with <em>tier</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sectiontitle"><b>section title</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#divisionaltitle">divisional title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="security"><b>security</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, the technology developed to prevent unauthorized persons, particularly <a href="#hacker">hacker</a>s and <a href="#cracker">cracker</a>s, from gaining entry to protected systems and <a href="#file">file</a>s, including <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#encryption">encryption</a>, <a href="#virus">virus</a> detection, <a href="#firewall">firewall</a>s, and the <a href="#authentication">authentication</a> of <a href="#authorization">authorization</a> codes (<a href="#username">username</a>s, <a href="#password">password</a>s, <a href="#pin">PIN</a>s, etc.).  In a more general sense, all the measures taken to prevent unauthorized persons from <a href="#access">access</a>ing <a href="#confidentiality">confidential</a> <a href="#information">information</a>.
<p>
In the operation of <a href="#library">libraries</a> and <a href="#archives">archives</a>, a general term encompassing all the <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, personnel, practices, and procedures used to prevent the <a href="#theft">theft</a> or destruction of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> and <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, and to protect <a href="#patron">patron</a>s and employees from the harmful actions of persons intent on mischief.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#keycontrol">key control</a>, <a href="#securityaudit">security audit</a>, <a href="#securityguard">security guard</a>, and <a href="#securitysystem">security system</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="securityaudit"><b>security audit</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thorough on-site inspection in which a person (or persons) trained and experienced in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#security">security</a> critically examine and analyze all the existing <a href="#securitysystem">security system</a>s
and procedures used in a library, to ascertain current status, identify
deficiencies or excesses, and make recommendations based on findings. A
professional security audit may include the analysis of crime
statistics, an assessment of insurance needs, and discussion of
sensitive topics, such as internal <a href="#theft">theft</a> and personal security issues. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="securitygate"><b>security gate</b></a>
</dt><dd>A device installed near the entrance and/or <a href="#exit">exit</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>,
usually in the form of a swing-arm or pair of uprights positioned in
such a way that persons entering or leaving the premises must pass
through a <a href="#magneticstrip">magnetic detection</a> system designed to trigger an alarm if an attempt is made to remove <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> without <a href="#checkedout">checking them out</a>.  Less obtrusive laser systems are also available.  Some <a href="#security">security</a> gates include a <a href="#gatecount">counter</a> that provides traffic statistics. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="securityguard"><b>security guard</b></a>
</dt><dd>An employee responsible for patrolling the premises of a <a href="#library">library</a> to discourage disruptive behavior and illegal activities, such as <a href="#vandalism">vandalism</a> and the unauthorized removal of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> (<a href="#theft">theft</a>),
and to deal with individuals who do not comply with library policies
and rules. Most security guards wear uniforms and are trained to handle
<a href="#problempatron">problem patron</a>s and various types of <a href="#emergencyplan">emergency</a> situations.  Synonymous with <em>security officer</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="securitystrip"><b>security strip</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#magneticstrip">magnetic strip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="securitysystem"><b>security system</b></a>
</dt><dd>An electronic alarm system installed at the entrance and <a href="#exit">exit</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> facility to detect the unauthorized removal of <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> (<a href="#theft">theft</a>).  Most <a href="#security">security</a> systems use a swing-arm or pair of uprights called a <a href="#securitygate">security gate</a>, activated by a <a href="#magneticstrip">magnetic strip</a> affixed to each <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, which must be <a href="#desensitization">desensitized</a> by <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> at the time an item is <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> to avoid triggering the alarm.  Some security systems include a <a href="#counter">counting device</a> for gathering statistics on traffic patterns.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="see"><b><em>see</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, or <a href="#refbook">reference work</a> directing the user from a <a href="#synonym">synonym</a> (or other equivalent term) to the <a href="#preferredterm">preferred</a> <a href="#heading">heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> for a given name, place, or <a href="#subject">subject</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>Beyle, Marie Henri</b> <em>see</em> <b>Stendahl, 1783-1842</b>).  Synonymous with <em>search under</em>.  Compare with <a href="#use">USE</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="seealso"><b><em>see also</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, or <a href="#refbook">reference work</a> directing the user to a <a href="#heading">heading</a> under which related <a href="#information">information</a> can be found on a given <a href="#subject">subject</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>Treaty of Versailles, 1919</b> <em>see also</em> <b>Paris Peace Conference, 1919</b>).  Synonymous with <em>search also under</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="selection"><b>selection</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of deciding which <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> should be added to a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>.  Selection decisions are usually made on the basis of <a href="#review">review</a>s and standard <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a> tools, by <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s designated as <em>selectors</em> in specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> areas, based on their interests and <a href="#field">field</a>s of <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, selection may also be done by members of the teaching faculty in their <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s.  Very large <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> may use an <a href="#approvalplan">approval plan</a> or <a href="#blanketorder">blanket order plan</a> to assist selectors.  Library <a href="#patron">patron</a>s also recommend <a href="#title">title</a>s for purchase, especially in libraries that provide a <a href="#suggestionbox">suggestion box</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#deselection">deselection</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#selectioncriteria">selection criteria</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="selectioncriteria"><b>selection criteria</b></a>
</dt><dd>The set of <a href="#standards">standards</a> used by <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s to decide whether an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> should be added to the <a href="#collection">collection</a>, which normally include a list of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s or <a href="#field">field</a>s to be covered, levels of <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>, <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, <a href="#currency">currency</a>, <a href="#language">language</a>s, and <a href="#format">format</a>s (<a href="#largeprint">large print</a>, <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a>, <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>s, etc.).  Selection criteria usually reflect the library's <a href="#mission">mission</a> and the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of its <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>, but <a href="#selection">selection</a> decisions are also influenced by <a href="#budget">budget</a>ary constraints and qualitative evaluation in the form of <a href="#review">review</a>s, recommended <a href="#corelist">core list</a>s, and other selection guides.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#collecdevelpolicy">collection development policy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="selective"><b>selective</b></a>
</dt><dd>Chosen in preference to another or others on the basis of a special characteristic or quality.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#research">research</a>, a <a href="#findingtool">finding tool</a> such as an <a href="#index">index</a> or <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> that includes only a portion of the available <a href="#literature">literature</a>, usually limited to sources that meet certain pre-established <a href="#selectioncriteria">criteria</a> (quality, <a href="#currency">currency</a>, <a href="#readinglevel">reading level</a>, degree of <a href="#specialization">specialization</a>, etc.).  Compare with <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="selectivebibliography"><b>selective bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> that includes only a portion of the <a href="#relevance">relevant</a> <a href="#literature">literature</a>, usually based on predetermined <a href="#selectioncriteria">selection criteria</a>, such as the needs of a particular group of users, desire for <a href="#currency">current</a> versus <a href="#retrobib">retrospective</a> material, or an evaluation of quality.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sdi"><b>selective dissemination of information (SDI)</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#currentawareness">current awareness service</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="selfcheckout"><b>self-checkout</b></a>
</dt><dd>An automated <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a> that allows registered <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to <a href="#checkedout">check out</a> <a href="#circulating">circulating</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> without the assistance of <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>, usually by <a href="#scanner">scanning</a> the <a href="#barcode">barcode</a> on the individual's <a href="#librarycard">library card</a> and on each of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>(s) to be borrowed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="selfcitation"><b>self-citation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A reference made in a written <a href="#work">work</a> to one of the <a href="#author">author</a>'s previous <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, an accepted practice in <a href="#scholarlycommunication">scholarly communication</a>, provided important works written on the <a href="#subject">subject</a> by other authors are not neglected or ignored.
<p>

</p></dd><dt><a name="selfcover"><b>self-cover</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a> or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>ed in the same <a href="#paper">paper</a> stock used to <a href="#printing">print</a> the <a href="#text">text</a>, rather than a heavier grade of paper.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="selfend"><b>self end</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, an <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a> that is not separate from the <a href="#text">text</a>, but rather part of the first or last <a href="#section">section</a> and therefore of the same <a href="#paper">paper</a> stock as the text.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="selfhelp"><b>self-help publication</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a>, or <a href="#videotape">videotape</a> intended to assist the <a href="#reader">reader</a>,
listener, or viewer in solving a personal problem, for example, finding
the best treatment for a physical illness or condition, or the answer
to a legal question without having to pay for professional services.
Some <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s specialize in self-help <a href="#publication">publication</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b>Nolo Press</b>, providing legal books for laypersons).  Compare with <a href="#howto">how-to publication</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="selfpublishing"><b>self-publishing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The design, <a href="#printing">printing</a>, and marketing of a <a href="#work">work</a> at the <a href="#author">author</a>'s own expense, without the assistance of a commercial <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, often undertaken out of devotion to the <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  Sophisticated <a href="#desktop">desktop publishing</a> <a href="#software">software</a> and high-quality <a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a>s have made this option easier and less expensive than it once was.  Also refers to the electronic <a href="#publication">publication</a> of a work by its author, usually installed on a <a href="#server">server</a> publicly <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  
<p>
It can be difficult to get self-published works <a href="#review">review</a>ed.  Because <a href="#library">libraries</a> <a href="#selection">select</a> largely on the basis of reviews and order <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> through regular market channels, this type of work is rarely added to <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#vanitypublisher">vanity publisher</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#zine">zine</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="selfservice"><b>self-service</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#library">Library</a> functions that can be initiated, controlled, and/or executed by the <a href="#patron">patron</a> without the assistance of <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a>, including <a href="#automatedcheckout">automated checkout</a>, patron-initiated <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> service, and <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s that allow users to view their own <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a>s, place <a href="#hold">hold</a>s, <a href="#renew">renew</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s on loan, etc.  Synonymous with <em>disintermediated service</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="selfwrapper"><b>self-wrapper</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#wrapper">wrapper</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="semanticfactoring"><b>semantic factoring</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> technique in which a <a href="#compoundsubject">compound heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> is divided into its constituent parts (<em>example</em>:  Annotated bibliography --&gt; Annotation + Bibliography).  In some cases, semantic factoring yields <a href="#falsedrop">false drop</a>s (Library + Research --&gt; "Library research"  and "Research library").  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="semanticrelation"><b>semantic relation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The connection in meaning between two or more concepts, and between the <a href="#term">term</a>s (<a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s) used to represent them in an <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>.  Semantic relations can be classified as follows:
<p>
</p><center><p>
</p><table>
<tbody><tr align="left"><td width="150"><b><em>Relation</em></b></td><td width="450"><b><em>Description</em></b></td><td width="250"><b><em>Example</em></b></td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="150"><b>Active</b></td><td width="450">Action, process, or operation directly performed by one on the other</td><td width="250">Scanner / Barcode</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="150"><b>Associative</b></td><td width="450">Linked conceptually, but not <a href="#hierarchicrelation">hierarchically</a></td><td width="250">Library statistics / Bibliometrics</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="150"><b>Causal</b></td><td width="450">One responsible for occurrence of the other</td><td width="250">Acquisitions / Collection growth</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="150"><b>Generic</b></td><td width="450">Genus to species</td><td width="250">Literature / Poetry</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="150"><b>Hierarchic</b></td><td width="450">One a logical <a href="#subclass">subclass</a> of the other</td><td width="250">Bookbinding / Binding</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="150"><b>Locative</b></td><td width="450">One located at, in, or on a place specified by the other</td><td width="250">Mainz Psalter</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="150"><b>Partitive</b></td><td width="450">Part to whole</td><td width="250">Chapter / Book</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="150"><b>Passive</b></td><td width="450">One influenced by or subjected to the action of the other, with no reciprocal influence</td><td width="250">Library collection / Selection criteria</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="150"><b>Antonymous</b></td><td width="450">Opposite in meaning</td><td width="250">Selection / Deselection</td></tr>
<tr align="left"><td width="150"><b>Syonymous</b></td><td width="450">Having the same or nearly the same meaning</td><td width="250">Booklet / Pamphlet</td></tr>
</tbody></table></center>
<p>

</p></dd><dt><a name="semantics"><b>semantics</b></a>
</dt><dd>The branch of linguistics concerned with the <em>meaning</em> of the words, signs, and <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s that constitute the elements of change and evolution in a spoken or written <a href="#language">language</a>.  Also, the branch of <a href="#semiotics">semiotics</a>
that deals with relationships of meaning between signs and between
signs and their referents within a system of communication. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="semiannual"><b>semiannual</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d at intervals of six months.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> issued every six months.  Synonymous with <em>half yearly</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="semicurrent"><b>semicurrent</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#archives">Archival</a> materials too old to be considered <a href="#currency">current</a>, but still useful and therefore <a href="#retention">retained</a> for a certain period, usually in a location reserved for <a href="#intermediatestorage">intermediate storage</a>, pending final <a href="#disposition">disposition</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="semimonthly"><b>semimonthly</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d twice each month, or every two weeks.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> issued twice a month, with the possible exception of certain issues (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Library Journal</em></b>).  Synonymous with <a href="#biweekly">biweekly</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="seminal"><b>seminal</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin word for "seed."  An idea or <a href="#work">work</a> so <a href="#original">original</a> when first expressed, composed, created, <a href="#release">released</a>, or <a href="#publishing">published</a>
that it has considerable influence on the thought and work of
contemporaries, and on succeeding generations of writers, scholars, or
artists who may give it further development in their own works. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="semiotics"><b>semiotics</b></a>
</dt><dd>The systematic study of the linguistic and nonlinguistic signs and <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s used in both <a href="#naturallang">natural</a> and <a href="#artificiallang">artificial</a>ly-constructed <a href="#language">language</a>s.  The three branches of semiotics are: 1) pragmatics (how signs are used by those who make use of them), 2) <a href="#semantics">semantics</a> (relationships of meaning between signs and their referents), and 3) <a href="#syntax">syntactics</a> (how signs are combined).  Each of the branches has pure (theoretical), descriptive, and applied aspects. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="semipublished"><b>semipublished</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#work">Work</a>s such as <a href="#report">report</a>s, <a href="#internaldocument">internal document</a>s, <a href="#thesis">theses</a>, etc., which are difficult if not impossible to obtain through regular market channels because they were never intended for <a href="#publication">publication</a>, but which may be available via <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>, <a href="#docdeliv">document delivery service</a>, or some other method of retrieval.  Compare with <a href="#unpublished">unpublished</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#grayliterature">gray literature</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="semiweekly"><b>semiweekly</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d twice each week.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> issued twice a week.  Synonymous with <em>twice weekly</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="send"><b>send</b></a>
</dt><dd>To transmit <a href="#data">data</a> from one <a href="#node">node</a> to another on a computer <a href="#network">network</a>, as in the exchange of <a href="#email">e-mail</a> messages or the <a href="#export">export</a> of bibliographic <a href="#data">data</a> from an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> to an e-mail account.  Also refers to the command in a <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a> that initiates such a transmission.  The opposite of <em>receive</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sentencing"><b>sentencing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The application of the appropriate <a href="#dispositionschedule">disposition schedule</a> to a group or <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#archives">archival</a> <a href="#records">records</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sentimental"><b>sentimental novel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> of serious <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, popular in 18th century England and 19th century America, in which the <a href="#author">author</a>
portrays the afflictions of one or more heroes and/or heroines of
unblemished character, to demonstrate the rewards virtuous conduct (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Uncle Tom's Cabin</em></b> by Harriet Beecher Stowe).  Synonymous with <em>domestic novel</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="separately"><b>separately paginated</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#pagenumber">Number</a>ing the <a href="#page">page</a>s of each <a href="#volume">volume</a> or <a href="#part">part</a> of a <a href="#set">set</a>, or of each <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a single volume of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, in a separate sequence, starting with number one.  Compare with <a href="#continuouspagination">continuous pagination</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#magazinepagination">magazine pagination</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="separatelypub"><b>separately published</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#bibitem">item</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#distributor">distributor</a> as an independent entity, usually under its own <a href="#title">title</a> and <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, as opposed to a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a <a href="#collection">collection</a> or as a <a href="#serial">serial</a>.  For example, the individual works in a <a href="#monographicseries">monographic series</a>, each published under a separate title. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="septennial"><b>septennial</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d every seven years.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> issued every seven years.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#annual">annual</a>, <a href="#biennial">biennial</a>, <a href="#triennial">triennial</a>, <a href="#quadrennial">quadrennial</a>, <a href="#quinquennial">quinquennial</a>, <a href="#sexennial">sexennial</a>, and <a href="#decennial">decennial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sequel"><b>sequel</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> of <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, in most instances a <a href="#novel">novel</a>, which although complete in itself, continues a previous work in <a href="#plot">plot</a>, <a href="#setting">setting</a>, and <a href="#character">character</a>s, usually (but not always) beginning where the action in the previous work left off (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Let the Circle Be Unbroken</em></b> by Mildred D. Taylor, sequel to <b><em>Roll of Thunder Hear My Cry</em></b>).  In a more general sense, anything that follows; a subsequent series of events or course of affairs.  The opposite of <a href="#prequel">prequel</a>.  Compare with <a href="#continuation">continuation</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#trilogy">trilogy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sequential"><b>sequential</b></a>
</dt><dd>The arrangement of a series of <a href="#entry">entries</a> or <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in prescribed order based on a predetermined system of priority, for example, <a href="#reversechron">reverse chronological</a> order.  In computing, <em>sequential access</em> refers to <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#storage">stored</a> in a manner that allows pieces of it to be <a href="#access">access</a>ed only in a certain order, as in the <a href="#medium">medium</a> of <a href="#magnetictape">magnetic tape</a>.  Compare with <a href="#ram">random access memory</a> (RAM).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sequentiallocator"><b>sequential locator</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#locator">locator</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serendipity"><b>serendipity</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word first coined by the English writer Horace Walpole in <b><em>The Three Princes of Serendip</em></b> to refer to the knack of making fortunate discoveries unexpectedly, by accident or coincidence.  In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, this usually depends on the ability of the <a href="#browse">browse</a>r to recognize the <a href="#relevance">relevance</a> or utility of <a href="#data">data</a> not actively sought at the time it is encountered.  Flexibility is one of the qualities of a good <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#heuristic">heuristic</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serial"><b>serial</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, a <a href="#publication">publication</a> in any <a href="#format">format</a> issued under the same <a href="#title">title</a> in successively <a href="#number">number</a>ed and/or dated <a href="#part">part</a>s or <a href="#issue">issue</a>s, appearing at <a href="#regular">regular</a> or <a href="#irregular">irregular</a> intervals and intended to be continued indefinitely.  Serials include <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s (<a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a>s, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, and <a href="#journal">journal</a>s) and their electronic counterparts, as well as <a href="#annual">annual</a>s, <a href="#yearbook">yearbook</a>s, <a href="#transactions">transactions</a>, <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a>, and <a href="#monographicseries">monographic series</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> separately.  When serials <a href="#split">split</a>, <a href="#merger">merge</a>, or are <a href="#absorption">absorbed</a>, a <a href="#changedtitle">change of title</a> may result.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#provisionalserial">provisional serial</a>, <a href="#pseudoserial">pseudo-serial</a>, <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a>, <a href="#serialbib">serial bibliography</a>, and <a href="#serialindex">serial index</a>. 
<p>
A specific <a href="#serialtitle">serial title</a> is identified by a unique <a href="#issn">International Standard Serials Number</a> (ISSN) and <a href="#keytitle">key title</a>, assigned and maintained by the <a href="#isds">International Serials Data System</a> (ISDS), a <a href="#network">network</a> of national serials <a href="#data">data</a> centers.  Serials and <a href="#annual">annual</a>s are listed in <em><a href="#ulrichs">Ulrich's International Periodicals Directory</a></em> <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, and in <em><a href="#serialsdirectory">The Serials Directory</a></em> published by <a href="#ebsco">EBSCO</a>.  A <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> of a serial <a href="#title">title</a> are indicated in an <a href="#openentry">open</a> or <a href="#closedentry">closed entry</a> in the <a href="#serialrecord">serial record</a> representing the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in the <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  The <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> responsible for managing a serials <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> is a <em>serials librarian</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>, <a href="#serialsdesk">serials desk</a>, <a href="#conser">CONSER</a>, and <a href="#nasig">NASIG</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialbib"><b>serial bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in successive <a href="#part">part</a>s, at fairly <a href="#regular">regular</a> intervals, usually limited to a <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#field">field</a> of study (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Bibliography of Asian Studies</em></b> published every one or two years). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialcancel"><b>serial cancellation</b></a>
</dt><dd>Notice given to a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agency</a> that a <a href="#library">library</a> no longer wishes to subscribe to a specific <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  In recent years, the relentless increase in <a href="#subscripprice">subscription price</a>s and the inability of <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a> <a href="#budget">budget</a>s to keep pace with inflation have forced <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a> to <a href="#canceled">cancel</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s to maintain balance in the purchase of serials and <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>s.  The scientific <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>s
most affected by such cuts because they are more serial-dependent than
the arts and humanities, and because average subscription price is
highest for scientific <a href="#journal">journal</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#serialsreview">serials review</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialindex"><b>serial index</b></a>
