</dt><dd>An <a href="#index">index</a> to the <a href="#content">content</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> issued in successively numbered <a href="#part">part</a>s, usually a <a href="#cumulativeindex">cumulative</a> <a href="#authorindex">author</a> and/or <a href="#titleindex">title index</a> <a href="#compile">compile</a>d by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, appearing at the end of the last <a href="#issue">issue</a> of the <a href="#pubyear">publication year</a>.  Most <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s (and some <a href="#journal">journal</a>s) do not provide such an index.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialized"><b>serialized</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#installment">installment</a>s, usually at <a href="#regular">regular</a> intervals.  During the 18th and early 19th centuries, <a href="#book">book</a>s were often published in <a href="#serialnumber">number</a>ed <a href="#part">part</a>s or <a href="#fascicle">fascicle</a>s, but by the late 19th century most serialized works appeared in consecutive <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s and <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#numberbook">number book</a> and <a href="#serialrights">serial rights</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialnumber"><b>serial number</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#number">number</a> identifying the place in sequence of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d as part of a <a href="#series">series</a>.  Also refers to a unique identification number assigned to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#title">title</a> for identification purposes, such as the <a href="#issn">International Standard Serial Number</a> (ISSN).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialrecord"><b>serial record</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> created to represent a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, including as <a href="#element">element</a>s of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> the <a href="#serialtitle">title</a>, <a href="#placeofpublication">place of publication</a>, name of <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, publication history, <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a>, <a href="#frequency">frequency</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>ing, <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s, and <a href="#issn">ISSN</a>.  Library <a href="#holdings">holdings</a>, <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> source, payment record, and <a href="#binding">binding</a> history are usually indicated in a separate <a href="#itemrecord">item record</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#serialslist">serials list</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialrights"><b>serial rights</b></a>
</dt><dd>Under <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law, the <a href="#subsidiaryrights">subsidiary rights</a> of an <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to control the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> in <a href="#installment">installment</a>s, usually in a <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> or <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>.  Serial rights can be sold or transferred by the owner.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialsdesk"><b>serials desk</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a>, usually located near the <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s section in a <a href="#library">library</a>, <a href="#librarystaff">staffed</a> by a person trained to assist <a href="#patron">patron</a>s in locating <a href="#serial">serial</a>s and in using <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a> for making <a href="#copy">copies</a> of <a href="#article">article</a>s (<a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a>s, <a href="#microform">microform</a> <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a>s, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialsdirectory"><b><em>Serials Directory, The</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#directory">directory</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#ebsco">EBSCO</a> in <a href="#print">print</a>, <a href="#online">online</a>, and on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, providing <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic</a> <a href="#information">information</a> and <a href="#subscripprice">pricing</a> for a <a href="#classifiedindex">classified</a> list of over 140,000 <a href="#serial">serial</a>s currently <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the U.S. and internationally.  <a href="#index">Index</a>ed <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#serialtitle">serial title</a>, <a href="#cessation">ceased title</a>, <a href="#issn">ISSN</a>, and <a href="#peerreviewed">peer-reviewed</a> title, <b><em>The Serials Directory</em></b> is usually shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of large <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#ulrichs">Ulrich's International Periodicals Directory</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialslist"><b>serials list</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of all the <a href="#serial">serial</a>s held by a <a href="#library">library</a>, including any <a href="#serialtitle">title</a>s that have <a href="#ceased">ceased publication</a> or been <a href="#serialcancel">canceled</a> for which the library retains <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s, usually arranged in <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> order by title, with <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> indicated in <a href="#openentry">open</a> and <a href="#closedentry">closed entries</a>, and <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s to and from <a href="#changedtitle">changed title</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#serialrecord">serial record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialsreview"><b>serials review</b></a>
</dt><dd>A systematic examination of a <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#serialslist">serials list</a> to identify <a href="#serialtitle">title</a>s to be retained and <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s to be <a href="#serialcancel">canceled</a>, usually conducted by a <a href="#serial">serial</a>s <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>
or serials department, ideally with input solicited from persons likely
to be affected by the decisions. Titles suggested for addition or
substitution may also be considered, depending on the amount <a href="#budget">budget</a>ed
for serials expenditures. In some libraries, serials reviews are
scheduled on a regular basis (usually every 1-3 years), but in others,
the process occurs irregularly. Decisions are based on <a href="#usage">usage</a>, <a href="#subscripprice">subscription price</a>, importance to the <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, and availability of <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> in <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serialtitle"><b>serial title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The name of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> issued in successive <a href="#part">part</a>s, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the front <a href="#cover">cover</a> and in the <a href="#masthead">masthead</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a> or on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#monograph">monograph</a>ic <a href="#serial">serial</a>.  In electronic periodicals, the title appears on the <a href="#welcomescreen">welcome screen</a>.  <a href="#changedtitle">Title change</a>s are more frequent in serials than in other types of publications.  In most <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States, periodicals are shelved <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#title">title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="series"><b>series</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s related in <a href="#subject">subject</a> and/or form, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in succession by a single <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>, usually in <a href="#uniformstyle">uniform style</a>, each bearing, in addition to its own <a href="#title">title</a>, a <a href="#collectivetitle">collective</a> or <a href="#seriestitle">series title</a> applied by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to the group as a whole.  The individual <a href="#volume">volume</a>s or <a href="#part">part</a>s may not share the same <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#editor">editor</a>, nor is it necessary for them to be <a href="#publishing">published</a> at <a href="#regular">regular</a> intervals, or <a href="#number">number</a>ed.  The series title is given on a separate <a href="#seriestitlepage">series title page</a>, usually the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> bearing the <a href="#halftitle">half-title</a>.  It also appears at the top of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> or on a <a href="#page">page</a> following the title page.  Some <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s are published in open-ended series (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Contemporary World Issues</em></b> from ABC-CLIO).  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, <a href="#information">information</a> describing series (<a href="#titleproper">title proper</a>, <a href="#statementof">statements of responsibility</a>, <a href="#issn">ISSN</a>, number, etc.) is given in the <a href="#seriesarea">series area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>ser</em>.  Compare with <a href="#serial">serial</a>.   <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>, <a href="#mapseries">map series</a>, <a href="#monographicseries">monographic series</a>, <a href="#recordseries">record series</a>, and <a href="#subseries">subseries</a>.
<p>
Also, a separately numbered sequence of <a href="#volume">volume</a>s <em>within</em> a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> (<em>example</em>: <b><em>Contemporary Authors</em></b>, <em>New Revision Series</em>).
</p><p>
In <a href="#typography">typography</a>, all the <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#font">font</a>s available in a given <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>, usually ranging in <a href="#typesize">size</a> from 5 <a href="#point">point</a>s to 80 points.  Compare with <a href="#typefamily">type family</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="seriesarea"><b>series area</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#area">area</a> of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> reserved in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> for <a href="#information">information</a> about a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a> as one of a group of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s, including the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> of the <a href="#series">series</a>, <a href="#statementof">statements of responsibility</a> concerning the series, <a href="#issn">ISSN</a>, and the <a href="#number">number</a> within the series (if the individual items are numbered).  In the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>, <a href="#seriesstatement">series statement</a>s are entered in the <a href="#field">field</a>s <a href="#tag">tag</a>ged 4XX.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="seriesauthor"><b>series author</b></a>
</dt><dd>A writer of <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#series">series</a> (<em>example</em>:  J. K. Rowling, <a href="#author">author</a> of the Harry Potter <a href="#book">book</a>s for children).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="seriesstatement"><b>series statement</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portion of a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> reserved for <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a> of the group of which the <a href="#publication">publication</a> is a member (if applicable), including the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> of the <a href="#series">series</a>, <a href="#statementof">statements of responsibility</a> concerning the series, <a href="#issn">ISSN</a>, and number within the series (if the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s are numbered).  In the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record, series statements are entered in <a href="#field">field</a>s <a href="#tag">tag</a>ged 4XX.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="seriestitle"><b>series title</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#collectivetitle">collective title</a> applied to a group of <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in succession in <a href="#uniformstyle">uniform style</a> by a single <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>.  In <a href="#book">book</a>s, the <a href="#series">series</a> <a href="#title">title</a> is usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> bearing the <a href="#halftitle">half-title</a>, often with a list of previously published <a href="#work">work</a>s in the same series.  In the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> is given in the <a href="#seriesstatement">series statement</a>s (<a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#field">field</a>s 4XX).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="seriestitlepage"><b>series title page</b></a>
</dt><dd>An added <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> appearing before the main title page in a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d as part of a group of <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, giving the <a href="#seriestitle">title of the series</a> and, in some cases, additional <a href="#information">information</a>, such as a list of previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s in the <a href="#series">series</a>, names of <a href="#author">author</a>s, <a href="#publicationdate">dates of publication</a>, numeric designations, etc.  The series title page is usually the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#page">page</a> bearing the <a href="#halftitle">half-title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serif"><b>serif</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Dutch <em>Schreef</em> meaning "stroke" or "line" in
writing--a fine, short line crossing or projecting as a finishing touch
from the end of one of the main strokes of a <a href="#letter">letter</a> of the Latin <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> in a <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>
that includes such extensions. Warren Chappell describes the serif as
"a terminal device, functionally employed to strengthen lines which
otherwise would tend to fall away optically" (<b><em>A Short History of the Printed Word</em></b>, Boston: Nonpareil Books, 1970).  Serifs enhance the <a href="#legibility">legibility</a> of <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a>.  The opposite of <em>sans-serif</em> and <a href="#blockletter">block letter</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#wedgeserif">wedge-serif</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="serigraphy"><b>serigraphy</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#silkscreen">silk screen</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="server"><b>server</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#host">host</a> computer on a <a href="#network">network</a>, programmed to answer requests to <a href="#download">download</a> <a href="#data">data</a> or <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s, received from <a href="#client">client</a> computers connected to the same network.  Also refers to the <a href="#software">software</a> that makes serving clients possible over a network.  Servers are classified by the functions they perform (<a href="#application">application</a> server, <a href="#database">database</a> server, <a href="#facsimiletrans">FAX</a> server, <a href="#ftp">file server</a>, <a href="#intranet">intranet</a> server, <a href="#email">mail</a> server, <a href="#proxyserver">proxy server</a>, <a href="#terminal">terminal</a> server, <a href="#webserver">Web server</a>, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="servicearea"><b>service area</b></a>
</dt><dd>The geographic area served by a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, from which it derives a major portion if not all of its funding, usually through taxation.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#librarydistrict">library district</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="servicecharge"><b>service charge</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#fee">fee</a> added by some <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>s to orders placed by <a href="#library">libraries</a> for <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> sold by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> at little or no <a href="#discount">discount</a>, or for special services provided by the jobber in filling the order.  Also refers to a fee charged by a <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agency</a> for filling orders for <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s, usually 5-10% of the total annual amount paid by the library for subscriptions.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="servicecontract"><b>service contract</b></a>
</dt><dd>An arrangement in which the <a href="#supplier">supplier</a> (or some other service provider) agrees to regularly maintain and repair one or more pieces of <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a> after any <a href="#warranty">warranties</a> have expired, usually in exchange for payment of an annual or monthly <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> enter into such agreements to keep <a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a>s, <a href="#microform">microform</a> <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a> machines, <a href="#security">security</a> <a href="#device">device</a>s, automation equipment, etc., in working order.  Synonymous with <em>service agreement</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="servicecopy"><b>service copy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A third <a href="#generation">generation</a> <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> <a href="#copy">copy</a>, produced from a <a href="#printmaster">print master</a> to be <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a>, stored, and used as an <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#source">source</a> in a <a href="#library">library</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#masternegative">master negative</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="servicepoint"><b>service point</b></a>
</dt><dd>A fixed location within a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#information">information</a> center, <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ed to provide a specific service or services to users (<em>examples</em>:  <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a>, <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>, <a href="#serialsdesk">serials desk</a>, <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a> office, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="set"><b>set</b></a>
</dt><dd>Two or more related <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>s in any <a href="#format">format</a>, <a href="#publishing">published</a> or <a href="#issue">issue</a>d as a single entity in <a href="#uniformstyle">uniform style</a> and <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> as a unit, for example, a <a href="#multivolumework">multivolume</a> <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> or <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>.  Normally, all the volumes in a set are <a href="#publishing">published</a> at the same time, but there are notable exceptions (<b><em>Dictionary of American Regional English</em></b>).  Compare with <a href="#series">series</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#setdiscount">set discount</a> and <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a>.
<p>
In a more general sense, any group of entities that together constitute a whole.  In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, the group of <a href="#entry">entries</a> or <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s retrieved in response to a <a href="#query">query</a>, containing the <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> or <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">term</a>s specified in the <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a>.  In most <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, retrieval sets can be combined in a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> <a href="#search">search</a> using <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic to produce a <a href="#logicalproduct">logical product</a>, <a href="#logicalsum">logical sum</a>, or <a href="#logicaldifference">logical difference</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#subset">subset</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="setdiscount"><b>set discount</b></a>
</dt><dd>The price charged by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> when all the <a href="#volume">volume</a>s in a <a href="#multivolumework">multivolume</a> <a href="#set">set</a>
are ordered at the same time, as opposed to the higher price charged
per volume when one or more volumes are purchased separately. The price
difference is usually 5-20%.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="setoff"><b>setoff</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#offset">offset</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="setting"><b>setting</b></a>
</dt><dd>The overall locale and historical period in which the action in a <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#work">work</a>
occurs. In a specific scene or episode, the setting consists of the
actual physical surroundings (indoors or out), an element of the <em>atmosphere</em>.  For example, the general setting of the <a href="#play">play</a> <b><em>Hamlet</em></b> by Shakespeare is medieval Denmark, with the duel scene at the end of the <a href="#play">play</a>
set inside the castle at Elsinore. In a theater production, the setting
is the scenery and properties, synonymous with the French term <em>mise-en-scene</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#character">character</a> and <a href="#plot">plot</a>. 
<p>
Also refers to the position of an indicator that controls the operation of a machine, for example, the option on a <a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a> allowing the user to <a href="#enlargement">enlarge</a> or <a href="#reduction">reduce</a> the size of an <a href="#original">original</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sewing"><b>sewing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> are held together with <a href="#thread">thread</a>, usually machine-stitched through the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a> before the <a href="#lining">lining</a> is <a href="#gluingoff">glued</a> to the <a href="#back">back</a>.  In quality binding, the sewn sections are stitched to two or more narrow cotton <a href="#tapes">tapes</a> spaced at intervals across the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a>.  Sewing allows the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> to <a href="#openability">open</a> without pulling <a href="#loose">loose</a>, as they often do in <a href="#adhesivebinding">adhesive binding</a>s.  For a well-<a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> description of the sewing process, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> on "Machine sewing" in Geoffrey Glaister's <em>Encyclopedia of the Book</em> (Oak Knoll/British Library:  1996).  Compare with <a href="#saddle">saddle-stitching</a> and <a href="#sidestitching">side-stitching</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#allalong">all along</a>, <a href="#kettle">kettle stitch</a>, <a href="#oversewing">oversewing</a>, <a href="#sidesewing">side sewing</a>, and <a href="#twoon">two on</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sexennial"><b>sexennial</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d every six years.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> issued every six years.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#annual">annual</a>, <a href="#biennial">biennial</a>, <a href="#triennial">triennial</a>, <a href="#quadrennial">quadrennial</a>, <a href="#quinquennial">quinquennial</a>, <a href="#septennial">septennial</a>, and <a href="#decennial">decennial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sextern"><b>sextern</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a <a href="#gathering">gathering</a> consisting of six <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> folded once to create twelve <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, used in some <a href="#manuscriptbook">manuscript book</a>s and early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ternion">ternion</a>, <a href="#quaternion">quaternion</a>, and <a href="#quinternion">quinternion</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sextodecimo"><b>sextodecimo (16mo)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#book">book</a>, approximately 6 inches in <a href="#height">height</a>, made by folding each <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of book <a href="#paper">paper</a> to form <a href="#signature">signature</a>s of sixteen <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> (thirty-two <a href="#page">page</a>s).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#folio">folio</a>, <a href="#quarto">quarto</a>, <a href="#octavo">octavo</a>, and <a href="#duodecimo">duodecimo</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sexualharassment"><b>sexual harassment</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any unwelcome sexual advance, request for sexual favors
(explicit or implicit), or other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual
nature, when submission to such conduct is made a condition of
employment or used as the basis for employment decisions affecting the
recipient, or when such conduct interferes with an employee's work
performance or creates an intimidating, hostile, or offensive work
environment. <a href="#library">Libraries</a> deal with sexual
harassment by formulating and disseminating clear policies, screening
applicants carefully, providing in-service training, keeping complete
and accurate personnel records, and taking appropriate disciplinary
action. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sgml1"><b>SGML</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#sgml"><b>S</b>tandard <b>G</b>eneralized <b>M</b>arkup <b>L</b>anguage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shadedletter"><b>shaded letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, an <a href="#outlineletter">outline letter</a>
made to appear three-dimensional by the presence of a dark shadow along
the same side of each stroke, used mainly in display work.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shaken"><b>shaken</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> are beginning to come <a href="#loose">loose</a> but are still attached to the <a href="#binding">binding</a>, usually caused by loosening of the <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> <a href="#thread">thread</a>s or wear on the <a href="#hinge">hinge</a>s, a <a href="#condition">condition</a> more advanced than <a href="#started">started</a>, but not yet <a href="#sprung">sprung</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#tight">tight</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sharedcat"><b>shared cataloging</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#cooperativecat">cooperative cataloging</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shared"><b>shared responsibility</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, a <a href="#work">work</a> in which two or more persons or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate bodies</a> collaborate in creating the <a href="#content">content</a>,
each performing the same type of activity, with the contribution of
each participant either distinct or indistinguishable from that of the
others. Synonymous with <em>shared <a href="#authorship">authorship</a></em>.  Compare with <a href="#mixed">mixed responsibility</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#jointauthor">joint author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shareware"><b>shareware</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#software">Software</a> available over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> which the user may <a href="#download">download</a> and try on the "honor system" before deciding to purchase.  Payment of a nominal registration <a href="#fee">fee</a> is expected following a reasonable trial period, entitling the user to receive <a href="#documentation">documentation</a>, technical support, and <a href="#updated">updated</a> <a href="#version">version</a>s as they become available.  <a href="http://www.shareware.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the CNet collection of shareware.  Compare with <a href="#freeware">freeware</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sharingviolation"><b>sharing violation</b></a>
</dt><dd>An attempt by a computer user to open a <a href="#data">data</a> or <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> <a href="#file">file</a> currently in use in another <a href="#application">application</a>,
an action that generates a message on the screen saying the file must
be "closed" before it can be used in the other application.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sharp1"><b>SHARP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#sharp"><b>S</b>ociety for the <b>H</b>istory of <b>A</b>uthorship, <b>R</b>eading and <b>P</b>ublishing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shaved"><b>shaved</b></a>
</dt><dd>Said of a <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#page">page</a>s have been <a href="#trimming">trimmed</a> so closely in <a href="#binding">binding</a> that the <a href="#text">text</a> is touched but not cut into.  Compare with <a href="#cropped">cropped</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sheet"><b>sheet</b></a>
</dt><dd>As used to <a href="#bibdescrip">describe</a> an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> under <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, a single whole piece of thin, flat <a href="#opacity">opaque</a> or transparent material other than a <a href="#broadside">broadside</a>, bearing <a href="#printing">printed</a> and/or handwritten <a href="#matter">matter</a> on one or both sides.  In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a unit of <a href="#paper">paper</a> as manufactured, whether printed or <a href="#blank">blank</a>.  In hand <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>, a unit of paper the same size as the physical mold used to make it.  In <a href="#microform">microform</a>s, a single piece of fiche (<a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>, <a href="#superfiche">superfiche</a>, <a href="#ultrafiche">ultrafiche</a>), usually 4 x 6 inches in size.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#sheetmap">sheet map</a> and <a href="#sheetmusic">sheet music</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sheetmap"><b>sheet map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on one side of a single <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, with or without explanatory matter printed on the reverse side.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, sheet maps are usually stored flat or folded in a <a href="#mapcase">map case</a> with wide shallow drawers.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sheetmusic"><b>sheet music</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on one or more <a href="#unbound">unbound</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s of <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> usually place sheet music inside a protective <a href="#folder">folder</a> or <a href="#binder">binder</a> in <a href="#physicalprocessing">physical processing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelfback"><b>shelf back</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#spine">spine</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelfcapacity"><b>shelf capacity</b></a>
</dt><dd>The average number of <a href="#volume">volume</a>s that will fit on a book shelf, depending on the <a href="#width">width</a> of the shelf from upright to upright, the average <a href="#depth">depth</a> (thickness) per volume, and the portion of each shelf left empty to facilitate <a href="#reshelving">reshelving</a>.  Total <a href="#stackcapacity">stack capacity</a> can be computed by multiplying shelf capacity by the number of available shelves in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#stacks">stacks</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cubook">cubook</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelfcocked"><b>shelf-cocked</b></a>
</dt><dd>A permanent deformation in the <a href="#binding">binding</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> that develops when it is allowed to lean at an angle against a shelf upright or nearby <a href="#volume">volume</a> over a prolonged period of time.  The <a href="#condition">condition</a> is caused by the force of gravity and can be prevented by using a sturdy <a href="#bookend">bookend</a> at the end of each row on shelves that are not full.  Also known as <em>spine lean</em>  Compare with <a href="#cocked">cocked</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelfdummy"><b>shelf dummy</b></a>

</dt><dd>A piece of wood, cardboard, or plastic in the shape of a <a href="#book">book</a>, placed on a shelf in a <a href="#library">library</a>, with a <a href="#spinelabel">spine label</a> directing the user to the location of a <a href="#title">title</a> shelved out of normal sequence.  Shelf dummies are often used in <a href="#refcollection">reference stacks</a> to indicate the location of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s shelved in <a href="#readyreference">ready reference</a>, and in <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#stacks">stacks</a> to indicate that <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s are located elsewhere, for example, in <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> or <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> cabinets.  Compare with <a href="#dummy">dummy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelfguide"><b>shelf guide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sign or <a href="#label">label</a> attached to the end or edge of a shelf in a <a href="#library">library</a> indicating its contents, usually by <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>, or <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#title">title</a> (<a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s) or last name of <a href="#author">author</a> (<a href="#fiction">fiction</a>).  Synonymous with <em>shelf label</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelfheight"><b>shelf height</b></a>
</dt><dd>The vertical distance between two shelves.  Adjustable shelving allows the distance to be altered to accommodate <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s of varying <a href="#height">height</a>.  Average shelf height is one of the factors determining <a href="#stackcapacity">stack capacity</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#oversize">oversize</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelflife"><b>shelf life</b></a>
</dt><dd>The average length of time an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> owned by a <a href="#library">library</a>, such as a <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#audiocassette">audiocassette</a>, <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>, or <a href="#compactdisc">CD</a>, is likely to remain in usable <a href="#condition">condition</a> before it must be <a href="#replacement">replaced</a> due to normal wear.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelflist"><b>shelflist</b></a>
</dt><dd>A nonpublic <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> of a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, containing a single <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for each <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, filed in the order in which the items are arranged on the shelf (usually by <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>), used for <a href="#inventory">inventory</a> because it contains the most current <a href="#information">information</a> on <a href="#copy">copy</a> and <a href="#volume">volume</a> <a href="#holdings">holdings</a>.  Card shelflists are being phased out by <a href="#library">libraries</a> that have <a href="#retrocon">converted</a> their public catalogs to <a href="#machinerecords">machine-readable records</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelfreading"><b>shelf reading</b></a>
</dt><dd>Periodic examination of the arrangement of <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> to ensure that <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s are in correct <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> sequence on the shelf, usually performed by a student assistant or <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> member called a <a href="#page">page</a>, during slack periods.  An item shelved out of order may be lost to users until the shelves are read.  Synonymous with <em>shelf checking</em>.  Compare with <a href="#inventory">inventory</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelfsitter"><b>shelf-sitter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#slang">slang</a> <a href="#term">term</a> used by <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s for an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in the <a href="#circulating">circulating</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> that is seldom if ever <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a>, or a <a href="#refbook">reference book</a> that is rarely used.  In <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> with limited shelf space, items with low <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> are eventually <a href="#weeding">weeded</a>, but in the collections of <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> and <a href="#researchlib">research libraries</a>, they may be <a href="#retention">retained</a> indefinitely.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelfworn"><b>shelf-worn</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> that shows visible signs of having been repeatedly removed and replaced on the shelf, usually along the edges of the <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the most shelf-worn <a href="#volume">volume</a>s are often well-loved <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>s, standard <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a>, general <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s, and other heavily used <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s.  <a href="#librarybinding">Library binding</a> increases the <a href="#shelflife">shelf life</a> of a book.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shelvingbysize"><b>shelving by size</b></a>
</dt><dd>Storing <a href="#book">book</a>s by height rather than by <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#classification">classification</a>, usually in four or more groups ranging from the smallest to the largest.  This method increases <a href="#shelfcapacity">shelf capacity</a> by up to 25%, but when subject <a href="#access">access</a> is sacrificed, <a href="#browse">browsing</a> capability is diminished.  For this reason, shelving by size is used mainly in storage locations inaccessible to the public.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doubleshelving">double shelving</a>, <a href="#flatshelving">flat shelving</a>, and <a href="#foreedgeshelving">fore-edge shelving</a>.     
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shift"><b>shift</b></a>
</dt><dd>The length of time spent working at one job in any 24-hour period, no more than eight hours for <a href="#fulltime">full-time</a>
employment in most workplaces. Also refers to the length of time a
person performs a particular task before being relieved by the next
person scheduled to do the same work. <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s scheduled at a <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a> such as the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a> may <a href="#rotation">rotate</a> shifts, especially in the evening and on weekends.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shifting"><b>shifting</b></a>
</dt><dd>The laborious process of moving an entire <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, or sections of a collection, from one location to another in the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>, usually to create shelf space in <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a>s that have become overcrowded.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shipping"><b>shipping</b></a>
</dt><dd>The delivery of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, or <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a> ordered from a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>, or <a href="#supplier">supplier</a> to a <a href="#library">library</a> by post or some other method.  Also refers to the charge for delivery, usually included as a separate amount on the <a href="#invoice">invoice</a>.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> for shipping services is available in <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#consolidated">consolidated shipment</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shoe"><b>shoe</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of a set of four metal sheaths custom-fitted to the <a href="#corner">corner</a>s of a large <a href="#handbinding">hand-bound</a> <a href="#book">book</a> to protect the <a href="#leather">leather</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a>, usually made of brass or silver, plain or decorated.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="short"><b>short</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#shortfilm">short film</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortcut"><b>shortcut</b></a>
</dt><dd>Some <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>s allow the user to create an <a href="#icon">icon</a> or pointer on the desktop which can be double-clicked to directly <a href="#access">access</a> a <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> or <a href="#document">document</a>, without having to click the <b>Start</b> button and select the <a href="#application">application</a> or <a href="#filename">filename</a> from a <a href="#menu">menu</a> or <a href="#directory">directory</a> system.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortdiscount"><b>short discount</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, a <a href="#discount">discount</a> less than the one normally allowed by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>, or <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>, usually 5-35%.  Professional books, <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s, and <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s are normally sold at short discount, as are items on <a href="#specialorder">special order</a>.  Compare with <a href="#longdiscount">long discount</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortfilm"><b>short film</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> with a <a href="#runningtime">running time</a> of less than 30 minutes (three reels or less).  The category includes <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>s, <a href="#newsreel">newsreel</a>s, <a href="#documentary">documentaries</a>, and experimental <a href="#film">film</a>s.  The once common practice of showing one or more <em>shorts</em> before a <a href="#featurefilm">feature film</a> has ceased in commercial movie theaters.  Short films are now shown mainly at film festivals.  Synonymous with <em>short subject</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortlist"><b>short list</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small group of <a href="#candidate">candidate</a>s chosen from a larger group, from which the final selection is made when filling a vacant <a href="#position">position</a>, awarding a prize, or determining the winner of a competition. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortloan"><b>short loan</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#reserves">reserves</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortnovel"><b>short novel</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#novelette">novelette</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortpage"><b>short page</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a <a href="#page">page</a> with fewer lines of <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a> than the specified number, as at the end of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>.  In contemporary <a href="#book">book</a>s, the unfilled space is usually left <a href="#blank">blank</a>, but in older <a href="#edition">edition</a>s it was sometimes adorned with a <a href="#printersornament">printer's ornament</a>.  Compare with <a href="#longpage">long page</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shorts"><b>shorts</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#shortshipment">short shipment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortscore"><b>short score</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sketch of an <a href="#ensemblework">ensemble work</a> in which the <a href="#composer">composer</a> sets forth on a few <a href="#stave">stave</a>s its main elements, with the intention of elaborating on the themes at some time in the future.  Compare with <a href="#closescore">close score</a> and <a href="#condensedscore">condensed score</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortshipment"><b>short shipment</b></a>
</dt><dd>An order <a href="#shipping">shipped</a> with one or more <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s lacking, usually because they were <a href="#outofstock">out of stock</a> at the time the order was filled.  The absent <a href="#title">title</a>s, known as <em>shorts</em>, are usually placed on <a href="#backorder">back order</a> to be shipped as soon as they become available.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortshort"><b>short short story</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>al <a href="#prose">prose</a> <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> of 500 to 1,500 words, containing all the elements of a <a href="#shortstory">short story</a> in very concise form (<em>example</em>:  "The Mad Woman" by Guy de Maupassant).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#conte">conte</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortstory"><b>short story</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> of short <a href="#fiction">fiction</a>, usually 2,000-10,000 words in length, in which the <a href="#author">author</a> limits the <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> to a single <a href="#character">character</a> (or group of characters) acting in a limited <a href="#setting">setting</a>, usually at a single point in time, to achieve a unified effect.  Short fiction is <a href="#publishing">published</a> in literary <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s and <a href="#collection">collection</a>s.  Stories considered outstanding by <a href="#editor">editor</a>s and critics may be <a href="#anthology">anthologized</a> following initial <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  Short stories published in <a href="#collection">collection</a>s are <a href="#index">index</a>ed in <b><em>Short Story Index</em></b> published <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#hwwilson">H. W. Wilson</a>.  Compare with <a href="#novelette">novelette</a> and <a href="#shortshort">short short story</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#conte">conte</a>, <a href="#fable">fable</a>, and <a href="#tale">tale</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shortsubject"><b>short subject</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#shortfilm">short film</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shorttitle"><b>short title</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> <a href="#title">title</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually enough of the full title to enable the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> to be identified in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, or on a price list or order form.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#estc">English Short-Title Catalogue</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shoulder"><b>shoulder</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the ridge along the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a>, made to accommodate the <a href="#board">board</a>s of the <a href="#cover">cover</a> by bending the backs of the <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s from the center toward the front and back, a process called <a href="#backing">backing</a>, done in with a hammer in <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a>, and by machine in commercial binding, after the <a href="#back">back</a> has been <a href="#rounding">rounded</a>, and before the <a href="#lining">lining</a> is applied.  Also called an <em>abutment</em>, <em>flange</em>, <em>groove</em>, or <em> ledge</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shouldernote"><b>shoulder note</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#note">note</a> written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the outer corner of the <a href="#head">head</a> <a href="#margin">margin</a> of a <a href="#page">page</a>, usually in handwriting or a <a href="#typesize">type size</a> (or style) that distinguishes it from the <a href="#text">text</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="shouting"><b>shouting</b></a>
</dt><dd>When specific words within an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> message (or its entire <a href="#text">text</a>) are typed in <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a>, THE TONE MAY BE INTERPRETED AS RUDE by its recipient(s).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#flame">flame</a> and <a href="#netiquette">netiquette</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="showthrough"><b>show through</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printing</a> defect in which <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> printed on one side of a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> is visible through the <a href="#paper">paper</a> from the other side, usually the result of a mismatch between paper stock and <a href="#ink">ink</a>, on the part of the <a href="#typography">typographer</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#opacity">opacity</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sibling"><b>sibling</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, a <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> or <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> that shares a <a href="#broaderterm">broader term</a> (one level up in <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchy</a>) with one or more other descriptors in the same <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>.  The meanings of sibling <a href="#term">term</a>s may overlap (<em>example</em>:  "Children's librarians" and "School librarians" under the broader term "Librarians").  Compare with <a href="#orphan">orphan</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sic1"><b>sic</b></a>
</dt><dd>The Latin word for "thus" written inside brackets [<em>sic</em>] or parentheses (<em>sic</em>) after a <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> to indicate that a misspelled word or grammatical error has been reproduced <a href="#verbatim">verbatim</a>.  In continental Europe, the exclamation mark (<b>!</b>) is used for the same purpose.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sicode"><b>SIC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#sic"><b>S</b>tandard <b>I</b>ndustrial <b>C</b>lassification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sidebar"><b>sidebar</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#information">Information</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> alongside a <a href="#text">text</a> and set apart visually, usually inside a <a href="#box">box</a> or by shading.  Sidebars are used in <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s, popular <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s, <a href="#howto">how-to book</a>s, etc., to present related or supplementary material which the author does not wish to include in the text.  Compare with <a href="#sidenote">side note</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sidenote"><b>side note</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#note">note</a> written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on one of the side <a href="#margin">margin</a>s of a <a href="#page">page</a>, opposite the passage of <a href="#text">text</a> to which it refers, usually in writing or <a href="#type">type</a> that distinguishes it from the text.  A <em>cut-in side note</em> is set in from the left- or right-hand margin, with text surrounding it on three sides.  Synonymous with <em>marginal note</em>.  Compare with <a href="#gloss">gloss</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#scholium">scholium</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sidesewing"><b>side sewing</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, to fasten <a href="#section">section</a>s or <a href="#loose">loose</a> <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> together by <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> the entire <a href="#textblock">text block</a> through the side along the <a href="#bindingmargin">binding margin</a> in a single pass, a method that considerably restricts <a href="#openability">openability</a>.  The <a href="#ansi">ANSI</a> <a href="#standard">standard</a> for <a href="#librarybinding">library binding</a>
specifies that a lock-stitch be used in side sewing, and does not
recommend the method for text blocks over 1/2-inch thick or when the
binding margin is less than 3/4-inches wide. Compare with <a href="#foldsewn">fold sewn</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sidestitching"><b>side-stitching</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which flat wire staples are driven by machine through the entire thickness of the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#publication">publication</a>, parallel with the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a>, close to the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a>.  Used primarily for <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s and <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of more than one section, the method is stronger than <a href="#saddle">saddle-stitching</a>, but does not allow the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> to <a href="#openability">open</a> easily.  For this reason, side-stitched publications must have a wide <a href="#gutter">gutter</a> <a href="#margin">margin</a>.  Synonymous with <em>side-wire stitching</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#sewing">sewing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sidetitle"><b>side title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> impressed on the outside of the front <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, sometimes a shortened version of the title <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#binderstitle">binder's title</a> and <a href="#covertitle">cover title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="signage"><b>signage</b></a>
</dt><dd>A collective <a href="#term">term</a> for all the static visual <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s and devices posted in a <a href="#library">library</a> to direct <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to specific resources, services, and facilities, and to inform them of <a href="#libraryhours">library hours</a>,
policies, programs, and events, including their size, design, and
placement. Signs which are clear, concise, consistent, courteous, and
appropriately placed can significantly reduce the number of <a href="#directional">directional</a> <a href="#refquestion">question</a>s received at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a> and make using the library less stressful, especially for inexperienced <a href="#patron">patron</a>s.  
<p>
To comply with <a href="#ada">ADA</a> requirements, many libraries in the United States have added <a href="#braille">Braille</a> to signs posted within reach of patrons.  In libraries that serve a significant <a href="#number">number</a> of non-English speaking users, signs may be provided in more than one <a href="#language">language</a>.  An effort is made in <a href="#newconstruc">new construction</a> and major <a href="#renovation">renovation</a>s to avoid a piecemeal approach by incorporating the style and placement of signs into the overall interior design.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="signatory"><b>signatory</b></a>
</dt><dd>A government or <a href="#agency">agency</a> that has the legal right to sign an official <a href="#document">document</a>, such as a <a href="#treaty">treaty</a> or trade agreement.  Also refers to a person whose <a href="#signature">signature</a> appears on such a document.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="signature"><b>signature</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a single <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> folded one or more times to become, with the addition of any <a href="#plate">plate</a>s or other <a href="#insert">insert</a>s, one <a href="#section">section</a> in a <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  In modern <a href="#book">book</a> production, signatures are usually in multiples of 8 <a href="#page">page</a>s, with 32 the norm.  A signature mark called a <a href="#register">register</a> is applied by the <a href="#printer">printer</a> to alert the <a href="#binding">binder</a> to the order in which the folded sheets are to be <a href="#gathering">gathered</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a  person's name, written in his or her own hand, usually appearing at the end of an original <a href="#document">document</a>, such as a <a href="#letters">letter</a> or legal instrument.  Handwriting analysis can be useful in verifying the <a href="#authenticity">authenticity</a> of a signature.  <em><b>See also</b></em>:  <a href="#forgery">forgery</a> and <a href="#signatory">signatory</a>.  
</p><p>
In <a href="#email">e-mail</a> messages, a standard ending that usually includes the sender's full name, <a href="#position">position</a>, affiliation, contact <a href="#information">information</a>, and sometimes a brief <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> or favorite saying.  Synonymous in this sense with <a href="#footer">footer</a>. 
</p><p>
In written music, a <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> or symbols appearing at the beginning of a staff to indicate key and/or time.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="signed"><b>signed</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>, or <a href="#article">article</a> in a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, in which the name of the <a href="#author">author</a> (or authors) is given, usually at the beginning or end of the <a href="#text">text</a>.  In a more general sense, any written <a href="#document">document</a> that indicates the identity of the person who wrote it, such as a <a href="#letters">letter</a> or legal instrument bearing the author's <a href="#signature">signature</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#unsigned">unsigned</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#byline">byline</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="signet"><b>signet</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#register">register</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="silentfilm"><b>silent film</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> produced
without sound, usually from the period before "talkies" were introduced
(1895 until about 1927). Also refers to the entire body of motion
pictures produced during this early period. <a href="#classic">Classic</a> American examples include the early <a href="#film">film</a>s of comedians Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton, and the <a href="#work">work</a>s of D. W. Griffith.  When early silent films were shown to live <a href="#audience">audience</a>s, the movie theater usually hired an orchestra or pianist to provide musical accompaniment.  <a href="#projectionspeed">Projection speed</a> for silent films is usually 16 fps (<a href="#frame">frame</a>s per second).  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, lack of <a href="#soundtrack">sound track</a> is indicated by the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> <em>si.</em> in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for a film.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="silking"><b>silking</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of affixing chiffon silk, or some other gossamer material, to one or both sides of a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, or to a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a>, to <a href="#repairing">repair</a> or <a href="#preservation">preserve</a> it.  The result is said to have been <em>silked</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="silkscreen"><b>silk screen</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of stencil <a href="#printing">printing</a> in which
the areas of a design to be left unprinted are masked on the underside
of a screen made of fabric, plastic, or woven metal stretched on a
frame. <a href="#ink">Ink</a> or paint is forced through the unmasked
areas onto the printing surface by hand or by machine. Each color must
be applied separately using a different stencil. Screen printing is
used for <a href="#signage">sign</a>s and <a href="#poster">poster</a>s, and for printing on surfaces such as glass, metal, plastic, wood, etc.  Synonymous with <em>serigraphy</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="silverplatter"><b>SilverPlatter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A commercial <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> that provides <a href="#access">access</a> to a wide range of <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic</a> and <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> electronic <a href="#database">database</a>s to <a href="#library">libraries</a> of all kinds via a <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> <a href="#interface">interface</a>.  <a href="http://www.silverplatter.com/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>SilverPlatter</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="simplex"><b>simplex</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#communications">communications</a>, a channel that has the capacity to transmit signals in one direction but not in the other.  Compare with <a href="#duplex">duplex</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="simplifiededition"><b>simplified edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#adaptation">adaptation</a> that makes the <a href="#text">text</a> of a previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a> easier to read, usually for a specific age group or category of <a href="#reader">reader</a>, by substituting less difficult words, shortening the <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>, and adding a <a href="#glossary">glossary</a>, commonly used in ESL (English as a second <a href="#language">language</a>) instruction.  Compare with <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="simultaneouspub"><b>simultaneous publication</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#publication">Publication</a> of the <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> and <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> at the same time.  Normally, the <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> edition is <a href="#publishing">published</a> months or even years after the <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> edition.  Compare with <a href="#parallelpublishing">parallel publishing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="simultsubmission"><b>simultaneous submission</b></a>
</dt><dd>Submission of a completed <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> by the <a href="#author">author</a> or the author's <a href="#literaryagent">agent</a> to more than one <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> at the same time.  A <a href="#journal">journal</a> publisher's policy concerning simultaneous submission is usually stated in its guidelines for <a href="#contributor">contributor</a>s. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="simultaneous"><b>simultaneous user</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who <a href="#access">access</a>es a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> or other <a href="#online">online</a> resource at the same time as other users.  <a href="#licensing">Licensing agreement</a>s usually specify the maximum number of users who may <a href="#logon">log on</a> simultaneously at a given <a href="#subscription">subscription rate</a>.  Most <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s have designed their <a href="#proprietary">proprietary</a> <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a> to deny access when the limit is exceeded.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sineloco"><b><em>sine loco</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A Latin <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> meaning "without place."  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> <em>s.l.</em> is used inside <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s [s.l.] in the <a href="#publicationarea">publication, distribution, etc.</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> to indicate that there is no known <a href="#placeofpublication">place of publication</a>.  Compare with <em><a href="#sinenomine">sine nomine</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sinenomine"><b><em>sine nomine</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A Latin <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> meaning "without name."  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> <em>s.n.</em> is used inside <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s [s.n.] in the <a href="#publicationarea">publication, distribution, etc.</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> to indicate that the name of the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#distributor">distributor</a> is unknown.  Compare with <em><a href="#sineloco">sine loco</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="singleindex"><b>single index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#index">index</a> <a href="#compile">compile</a>d all at one time, to facilitate <a href="#access">access</a> to the <a href="#content">content</a> of a single <a href="#publication">publication</a>, for example, an index at the back of a <a href="#book">book</a> or at the end of the last <a href="#volume">volume</a> of a <a href="#multivolumework">multivolume</a> <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>.  Compare with <a href="#cumulativeindex">cumulative index</a> and <a href="#openendindex">open-end index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sinkage"><b>sinkage</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the amount of <a href="#spacing">space</a> left <a href="#blank">blank</a> above the first line of <a href="#type">type</a> at the top of a <a href="#page">page</a> of <a href="#text">text</a>, for example, at the beginning of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or other major division of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#headpiece">headpiece</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sitelicense"><b>site license</b></a>
</dt><dd>Official permission granted to a company, <a href="#agency">agency</a>, organization, or institution by a <a href="#software">software</a> <a href="#producer">producer</a> or <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> to use a software product under specified conditions on all the computers at a designated <a href="#ipaddress">IP address</a>, or range of IP addresses, usually in exchange for payment by the <em>licensee</em> of an annual <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  Compare with <a href="#softwarelicense">software license</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sized"><b>sized</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#paper">Paper</a> treated in manufacture with a
substance that makes its surface less porous, reducing its capacity to
absorb moisture. Blotting paper is left unsized. Also refers to <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> treated with a stiffener.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#resized">resized</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sizing"><b>sizing</b></a>
</dt><dd>Substances such as resin or gelatin added to <a href="#paper">paper</a> stock in manufacture to promote the bonding of <a href="#cellulose">cellulose</a> fibers, or as a <a href="#coated">coating</a> to fill pores in the surface after <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s have been formed.  Sizing makes paper less permeable to water, preventing the <a href="#ink">ink</a> used in <a href="#printing">printing</a> from bleeding.  Sizing also gives <a href="#definition">definition</a> to the <a href="#printing">printed</a> image.  Some sizings are <a href="#acidic">acidic</a> and contribute to the <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> of paper.  
<p>
Also refers to the process of sorting a number of <a href="#book">book</a>s into batches of similar <a href="#booksize">size</a> in preparation for some kind of <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> or <a href="#technical">processing</a>, such as the application of clear plastic <a href="#jacketcover">jacket cover</a>s.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="skeletonstaff"><b>skeleton staff</b></a>
</dt><dd>The minimum number of employees required to operate a <a href="#library">library</a>, usually those necessary to <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> essential <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a>s and maintain <a href="#security">security</a>.  Libraries chronically <a href="#understaffed">under-staffed</a> may be forced to operate with minimal staff in the evening and on weekends, or remain closed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sketch"><b>sketch</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief <a href="#essay">essay</a>, <a href="#shortstory">story</a>, or <a href="#play">play</a>, developed in less detail than a more complete <a href="#work">work</a> of the same literary form.  A <em>character sketch</em> captures the essence of one or more individuals, with little or no <a href="#plot">plot</a>.  Also refers to a drawing that provides a rough outline of its <a href="#subject">subject</a> without adding much detail, usually done rapidly, in a single sitting, sometimes as a study for a more elaborate <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> of the same <a href="#subject">subject</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="skyline"><b>skyline</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, any <a href="#headline">headline</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> across the top of the first <a href="#page">page</a> above the <a href="#flag">flag</a>.  Compare with <a href="#banner">banner</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="s.l."><b><em>s.l.</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#sineloco">sine loco</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sla1"><b>SLA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#sla"><b>S</b>pecial <b>L</b>ibraries <b>A</b>ssociation</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slander"><b>slander</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#libel">libel</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slang"><b>slang</b></a>
</dt><dd>An informal or colloquial expression peculiar to a specific
group, often unintelligible to outsiders but sometimes decipherable
from its <a href="#context">context</a>.  Slang expressions are subject to linguistic fashion.  Most serious <a href="#author">author</a>s use slang <a href="#term">term</a>s only in <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> or when writing informally.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a> of slang are available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>A Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English</em></b> by Eric Partridge).  Compare with <a href="#argot">argot</a>, <a href="#jargon">jargon</a>, and <a href="#idiom">idiom</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slash"><b>slash</b></a>
</dt><dd>In writing, <a href="#printing">printing</a>, and computing, a <a href="#character">character</a> in the form of a line slanting diagonally from upper right to lower left, used to indicate division, fractions, and ratios (<b>miles/hour</b>); to combine dates (<b>1905/06</b>); to indicate alternatives (<b>and/or</b>); and to separate the parts of an <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a> (<b>http://www.myuniversity.edu/library</b>).  Synonymous with <em>forward slash</em>, <em>solidus</em>, and <em>virgule</em>.  Compare with <a href="#backslash">backslash</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sleeper"><b>sleeper</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the retail <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, a <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a> that sells slowly when first <a href="#publishing">published</a>, but develops a strong, steady market over a period of months or even years.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> that <a href="#circulation">circulates</a> slowly when first added to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, but in time attracts a strong, steady <a href="#readership">readership</a>.  In the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian book</a> trade, a valuable <a href="#bibitem">item</a> priced well below its market value in a <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>'s <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> or on the shelf because the seller is unaware of its actual worth.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sleeve"><b>sleeve</b></a>
</dt><dd>A transparent plastic covering designed to fit snugly over the <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> of a <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#book">book</a>.  Applied by a <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> member during <a href="#physicalprocessing">physical processing</a>, plastic sleeves are used in <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a> to a greater extent than in other types of <a href="#library">libraries</a>, to protect book <a href="#cover">cover</a>s and enhance their visual appeal.  
<p>
Also, the <a href="#paper">paper</a> envelope provided by the <a href="#manufacturer">manufacturer</a> of a <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>, to protect the disc from dust and abrasion as it is removed from and replaced in the jacket or <a href="#album">album</a>, sometimes with a wide circle cut from the center or replaced with transparent material, to allow the record <a href="#label">label</a> to remain visible.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slick"><b>slick</b></a>
</dt><dd>A term used in <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> to describe a heavily <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> consumer <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> of high <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>, printed in color on <a href="#glossy">glossy</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a>, for sale at newsstands, in <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a>s and supermarkets, and by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Cosmopolitan</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slide"><b>slide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small transparent, positive image in color or black-and-white, produced on <a href="#film">film</a> or glass, usually <a href="#slidemount">mounted</a> in a rigid cardboard or plastic <a href="#frame">frame</a> of standard size (2 x 2 inches), designed to be projected one-at-a-time on a large screen using a <em>slide projector</em>, with or without <a href="#soundrecording">recorded sound</a>.  Modern slide projectors are designed to hold <a href="#carousel">carousel</a>s for <a href="#queue">queuing</a>
dozens of slides. Most models have an automatic advance that can be
activated remotely by the presenter. Models designed for professional
use include a <a href="#microprocessor">microprocessor</a> that enables slides to be accessed randomly.  Slides may also be viewed in a <em>slide viewer</em>,
a smaller device with built-in rear-screen projection. Some models have
audio and automatic advance capability similar to slide projectors.
Compare with <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#microslide">microslide</a> and <a href="#microscopeslide">microscope slide</a>.  
<p>
In computing, one of a <a href="#number">number</a>ed sequence of screens created using <a href="#presentationsoftware">presentation software</a>, such as <b><em>PowerPoint</em></b>, for display with the aid of an <a href="#lcd">LCD</a> projector, as part of an oral presentation. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slidemount"><b>slide mount</b></a>
</dt><dd>A rigid cardboard or plastic <a href="#frame">frame</a>, usually of standard size (2 x 2"), designed to hold a single <a href="#slide">slide</a> to protect it from damage and make it easier to label, store, and handle. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slideprojector"><b>slide projector</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#slide">slide</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slideviewer"><b>slide viewer</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#slide">slide</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slipcase"><b>slipcase</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sturdy cardboard box, covered in <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>, or <a href="#leather">leather</a>, designed to snugly contain a single <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#set">set</a> of books, with an open front to expose the <a href="#spine">spine</a>s, allowing the <a href="#title">title</a>(s) remain visible.  Intended to keep volumes together and protect them from damage, slipcases are more common in <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a>s and <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a> sets than in <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  Also spelled <em>slip-case</em>.  Compare with <a href="#pullcase">pull-case</a> and <a href="#solander">solander</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slipproof"><b>slip proof</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#galley">galley proof</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="slj1"><b><em>SLJ</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#slj"><b>S</b>chool <b>L</b>ibrary <b>J</b>ournal</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="smallcapital"><b>small capital</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a> of x-height, about 2/3 as large as the full-size capital of the same <a href="#typesize">type size</a>, used for emphasis in <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#text">text</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>small cap</em>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>s.c.</em>  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> and <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="smallpress"><b>small press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of comparatively limited resources, functioning independently of the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> "establishment" and consequently more likely to <a href="#issue">issue</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s outside the cultural mainstream.  Most small <a href="#press">press</a>es employ fewer than a dozen people and publish no more than 20-30 <a href="#newbook">new title</a>s per year.  Synonymous with <em>little press</em>. 
<p>
<b><em>Small Press</em></b>, the <a href="#tradejournal">trade publication</a> of small publishers, provides approximately 100 <a href="#review">review</a>s of small press <a href="#book">book</a>s in each <a href="#bimonthly">bimonthly</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> on small presses is available in <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em> and <em><a href="#writersmarket">Writer's Market</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.smallpress.org/index.htm">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>
of the Small Press Center, a nonprofit cultural and educational
institution dedicated to promoting awareness of small independent
publishers and their contributions to society. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nichepublishing">niche publishing</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="smartboard"><b>smartboard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general <a href="#term">term</a> for several types of electronic <a href="#whiteboard">whiteboard</a>, the most sophisticated of which can be synchronized with a computer to function like an oversize <a href="#touchscreen">touch screen</a>, allowing users to interact directly with the display, instead of using a <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>, <a href="#mouse">mouse</a>, or other <a href="#input">input</a> <a href="#device">device</a>.  Smartboards are used for <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a> in very well-equipped <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>.  Also spelled <em>smart board</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="smashing"><b>smashing</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#nipping">nipping</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="smiley"><b>smiley</b></a>
