</dt><dd>A whimsical sequence of <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a> marks and special <a href="#character">character</a>s, arranged to suggest the expression on a human face, used in <a href="#email">e-mail</a> messages to <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ically communicate emotion or humor.  Frequently used examples include:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>:-)</b>  Smiling
</dd><dd><b>;-)</b>  Ironic smile
</dd><dd><b>:-(</b>  Not amused
</dd><dd><b>&gt;:(</b>  Very angry
</dd><dd><b>:O</b>  Yelling
</dd><dd><b>:D</b>  Laughing</dd></dl> 
<p>
For more smileys, please see the <em><a href="http://paul.merton.ox.ac.uk/ascii/smileys.html">Unofficial Smiley Dictionary</a></em>.  Synonymous with <em>emoticon</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="smtp"><b>SMTP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>S</b>imple <b>M</b>ail <b>T</b>ransfer <b>P</b>rotocol, the standard <a href="#tcpip">TCP/IP</a> <a href="#email">e-mail</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> used on the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>, originally designed for <a href="#ascii">ASCII</a> <a href="#text">text</a> but subsequently enhanced to permit the <a href="#attachment">attachment</a> of other <a href="#filetype">file type</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mime">MIME</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="s.n."><b><em>s.n.</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#sinenomine">sine nomine</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sn"><b>SN</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#scopenote"><b>s</b>cope <b>n</b>ote</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sobriquet"><b>sobriquet</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#nickname">nickname</a>, assumed name, or other imaginative appellation applied to a person (<em>example</em>:  Sachmo), group (Copperheads), place (Dixie), thing (Old Ironsides), or institution (Uncle Sam).  An <a href="#author">author</a> is occasionally known by such a name (The Bard).  Compare with <a href="#pseudonym">pseudonym</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="srrt"><b>Social Responsibilities Round Table (SRRT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established over 25 years ago as a permanent <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> to make the organization more democratic and to establish progressive priorities for the <a href="#library">library</a> profession, <b>SRRT</b> has been particularly active on issues involving civil and economic rights.  <b>SRRT</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em>SRRT Newsletter</em> and is affiliated with the <a href="http://www.altpress.org/">Alternative Press Center</a> (APC) which <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> of the <b><em>Alternative Press Index</em></b>.  <a href="http://libr.org/SRRT/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>SRRT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="society"><b>society</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#corporatebody">corporate entity</a> consisting of
a group of people who meet periodically to share a common interest,
especially one that is academic or professional. The most <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#directory">directory</a> of such organizations is the <em><a href="#encyassoc">Encyclopedia of Associations</a></em>, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States.  <a href="http://www.lib.uwaterloo.ca/society/subjects_soc.html">Click here</a> to connect to an <a href="#online">online</a> directory of scholarly societies in North America, maintained by the University of Waterloo Library.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>soc</em>.  Synonymous with <em>association</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dues">dues</a>, <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a>, and <a href="#transactions">transactions</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ssp"><b>Society for Scholarly Publishing (SSP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization that grew out of the Association of Scientific
Journals (ASJ) and the Innovation Guide project of the National Science
Foundation during the 1970s, <b>SSP</b> is devoted to advancing <a href="#scholarlycommunication">scholarly communication</a> and <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, and the <a href="#profdevel">professional development</a> of its members through education, collaboration, and <a href="#networking">networking</a>.  Its members include <a href="#scholarlybook">scholarly book</a> and <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, manufacturers, <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, and <a href="#www">Web</a> <a href="#editor">editor</a>s.  <a href="http://www.sspnet.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>SSP</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sharp"><b>Society for the History of Authorship, Reading and Publishing (SHARP) </b></a>
</dt><dd>Created in 1991, <b>SHARP</b> provides a global network for <a href="#bookhistory">book historian</a>s.  Its membership includes <a href="#literature">literature</a> professors, historians, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> professionals, sociologists, <a href="#bibliophile">bibliophile</a>s, <a href="#classics">classicists</a>, <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, art historians, reading instructors, and independent scholars from over 20 countries.  <b>SHARP</b> sponsors an annual <a href="#conference">conference</a>, maintains an <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#mailinglist">discussion forum</a>, and <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em><a href="http://www.pmpc.napier.ac.uk/scob/sharpnews.html">SHARP News</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.sharpweb.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>SHARP</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="saa"><b>Society of American Archivists (SAA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1934, <b>SAA</b> is the oldest professional organization of <a href="#archives">archivist</a>s in North America, dedicated to promoting the identification, <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, and use of <a href="#records">records</a> of historical value.  <b>SAA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em><a href="http://www.archivists.org/periodicals/index.html">Archival Outlook</a></em> and the <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em><a href="http://www.archivists.org/periodicals/index.html">American Archivist</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.archivists.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>SAA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="softcover"><b>softcover</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#cover">cover</a>s that are not rigid, usually a <a href="#paperback">paperback</a>, but the term also includes <a href="#limpbinding">limp</a> and <a href="#flexiblebinding">flexible binding</a>s.  Most <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s are <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in softcover.  In <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a>s, the softcover <a href="#edition">edition</a> is <a href="#publishing">published</a> separately from the <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> edition, usually at a later date, and is sold at a lower <a href="#listprice">price</a>.  Synonymous with <em>paperbound</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="software"><b>software</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic term for <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a>s and their associated <a href="#documentation">documentation</a>, as opposed to <a href="#data">data</a> used as <a href="#input">input</a> and generated as <a href="#output">output</a>.
In computing, data is "processed"--software "runs." A software product
consists of a set of instructions written by a programmer, distinct
from the manufactured <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> used to run it.  The <a href="#term">term</a> includes systems programs such as <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>s (OS), <a href="#dbmanagement">database management system</a>s (DBMS), <a href="#utility">utilities</a> that control the operation of the computer itself, and <a href="#application">application</a> programs designed to process <a href="#data">data</a> and accomplish specific tasks for the user.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a> and <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="softwarelicense"><b>software license</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal agreement between the <a href="#producer">producer</a> and purchaser of a <a href="#software">software</a> product concerning permissible use, especially with regard to sharing and making <a href="#copy">copies</a>.  <em>Software piracy</em> is the unauthorized copying of licensed software, usually for sale in a country other than the one in which it is <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>ed.  Compare with <a href="#sitelicense">site license</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="solander"><b>solander</b></a>
</dt><dd>A box in the shape of a <a href="#book">book</a>, wide enough to stand upright, used for storing books, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, <a href="#plate">plate</a>s, <a href="#papers">papers</a>,
etc., designed in two parts with a slide-on top, or hinged to open at
the front or side, with a clasp or spring catch. Named after Daniel C.
Solander, the 18th century Swedish botanist who designed it for storing
<a href="#specimen">specimen</a>s at the British Museum.  Compare with <a href="#pullcase">pull-case</a> and <a href="#slipcase">slipcase</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="solidus"><b>solidus</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#slash">slash</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="soliloquy"><b>soliloquy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A long sequence of lines addressed by an actor or actress, not to the other players on stage, but directly to the <a href="#audience">audience</a>, revealing private thoughts, feelings, or intentions.  Perhaps the best known example is the "To Be or Not to Be" speech in <b><em>Hamlet</em></b>
in which the protagonist expresses the personal dilemma posed by the
unexpected allegation of murder made by his father's ghost. A shorter
speech intended to be inaudible to the other <a href="#character">character</a>s in a scene is an <em>aside</em>.  Compare with <a href="#monologue">monologue</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="solo"><b>solo librarian</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> solely responsible for managing a small <a href="#library">library</a>, without the assistance of other paid <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>.  Solo <a href="#publiclibrary">public librarian</a>s often rely on the assistance of <a href="#volunteer">volunteer</a>s
from the community served. Running even a small library single-handedly
requires energy, initiative, versatility, and self-sufficiency. Solo
librarians are organized in the <em>Solo Librarians Division</em> of the <a href="#sla">Special Libraries Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="songster"><b>songster</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#broadside">broadside</a> or <a href="#chapbook">chapbook</a> popular during the 18th and 19th centuries, containing <a href="#poetry">poems</a> and <a href="#ballad">ballad</a>s sung to popular tunes.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sonnet"><b>sonnet</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#lyric">lyric</a> <a href="#poetry">poem</a> of fourteen lines, written in iambic pentameter.  A <em>sonnet sequence</em>
is a group of sonnets written by a single poet, usually on a common
theme. The form originated in Italy in the 13th century. The most
common rhyme schemes were developed by Petrarch and Shakespeare. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sorting"><b>sorting</b></a>
</dt><dd>In a <a href="#search">search</a> of a <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, the <a href="#default">default</a> display is normally <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> order by <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#title">title</a>, or <a href="#reversechron">reverse chronological</a> order by <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>.  However, in some online <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s and <a href="#database">database</a>s, the user may select the sequence in which results will be displayed, usually from a list of <a href="#option">option</a>s, either before or after the search is executed.  Compare with <a href="#ranking">ranking</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="soundarchives"><b>sound archives</b></a>
</dt><dd>A permanent <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>s, <a href="#preservation">preserved</a> for <a href="#research">research</a> purposes (<em>example</em>: <a href="http://www-sul.stanford.edu/depts/ars/ars.html">Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound</a>).  <a href="#libmaterials">Materials</a> collected include wax cylinders, shellac and vinyl <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>s, <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a>, <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>s, etc.  One of the earliest <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#archives">archives</a> of sound recordings was established in the early 20th century by the <a href="#bbc">British Broadcasting Corporation</a> (BBC). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sounddisc"><b>sound disc</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a> and <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="soundrecording"><b>sound recording</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic term for sounds that have been mechanically, electromagnetically, or <a href="#digital">digital</a>ly recorded onto a <a href="#medium">medium</a> designed for <a href="#playback">playback</a> with the aid of audio equipment.  The category includes <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>s, <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a>s, <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>s, and the <a href="#soundtrack">sound track</a> on <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>s, etc.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> collect sound recordings of music and human speech (<a href="#poetry">poetry</a>, <a href="#play">drama</a>, speeches, interviews, <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>s, <a href="#bookontape">books-on-tape</a>, etc.).  The proceedings of meetings and <a href="#conference">conference</a>s are sometimes recorded for <a href="#archives">archival</a> purposes.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/rr/record/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the Recorded Sound Reference Center at the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  Synonymous with <a href="#audiorecording">audiorecording</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#soundarchives">sound archives</a>, <a href="#typerecording">type of recording</a>,  and <a href="#anscr">ANSCR</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="soundtrack"><b>sound track</b></a>
</dt><dd>The sound component of a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> or <a href="#videorecording">video</a>, usually recorded along one or both edges of the <a href="#film">film</a> or <a href="#videotape">tape</a>, on a magnetically coated <a href="#stripe">stripe</a>, synchronizing sound with image.  Also refers to the music <a href="#score">score</a> of a motion picture, released separately on <a href="#audiocassette">audiocassette</a> or <a href="#compactdisc">compact disc</a>, sometimes under a slightly different <a href="#title">title</a>.  <a href="#silentfilm">Silent film</a>s have no sound track.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="source"><b>source</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any <a href="#document">document</a> that provides <a href="#information">information</a> sought by a writer, <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>, <a href="#library">library</a> user, or person <a href="#search">search</a>ing an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>.  Also refers to a document that provides information <a href="#copy">copied</a> or <a href="#reproduction">reproduced</a> in another document, for example, a <a href="#quotation">quotation</a> or <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>.  In <a href="#literature">literature</a>, the story, <a href="#legend">legend</a>, or <a href="#work">work</a> that inspires or provides elements of <a href="#plot">plot</a> or <a href="#character">character</a>ization for another <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>, for example, the <a href="#chronicle">chronicle</a>s of English history on which Shakespeare based some of his history <a href="#play">play</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#primarysource">primary source</a>, <a href="#secondarysource">secondary source</a>, and <a href="#tertiarysource">tertiary source</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#acquisitions">acquisitions</a>, the seller or donor from whom an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is obtained, usually indicated in the <a href="#accessionrecord">accession record</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sourcedocument"><b>source document</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#reprography">reprography</a>, the original <a href="#document">document</a> from which <a href="#copy">copies</a> are made, usually containing <a href="#text">text</a> and/or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> material that can be read by the human eye without magnification.  Compare with <a href="#master">master</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cameramicrofilm">camera microfilm</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sourcefield"><b>source field</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#recordstructure">record structure</a> of most <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, the <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#field">field</a> containing the <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a>, date of <a href="#issue">issue</a>, and <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#article">article</a>; the <a href="#book">book</a> title, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, and page numbers for an <a href="#essay">essay</a> in a <a href="#collection">collection</a>; or the title, publisher, and publication date for a book or book <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>.  In the <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> display, the <a href="#fieldlabel">field label</a> may be <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> <em>SO:</em>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sourcelanguage"><b>source language</b></a>
</dt><dd>The original <a href="#language">language</a> of a <a href="#text">text</a> that has been <a href="#translation">translated</a> into one or more other languages.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the language of the original <a href="#work">work</a> is indicated in a <a href="#paralleltitle">parallel title</a> or <em>Translation of:</em> <a href="#note">note</a> in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spacing"><b>spacing</b></a>
</dt><dd>The use of one or more <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#character">character</a>s to separate words in <a href="#printing">printing</a> and typing.  Also refers to one or more lines left blank at the beginning of <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a>, or between lines of type, for example, the three lines left blank at the top of a typed or printed <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a>, or the double space before the first <a href="#note">note</a> and before the <a href="#tracings">tracings</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the use of spacing in <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>s is governed by the general rules for <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a>, and by the specific rules for punctuation in each <a href="#area">area</a> of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#whiteline">white line</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spam"><b>spam</b></a>
</dt><dd>Unsolicited <a href="#email">e-mail</a> messages mass-mailed to large numbers of <a href="#newsgroup">newsgroup</a>s and/or <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>s with little concern for the burden such activity places on <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s.  Spamming is considered one of the worst violations of <a href="#netiquette">netiquette</a> because it forces <a href="#internet">Internet</a> users to waste valuable time scanning and deleting unwanted messages.  The person who sends such messages is a <em>spammer</em>.  For more <a href="#information">information</a> on this nuisance, please see:  <a href="http://spam.abuse.net/">spam.abuse.net</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sparc1"><b>SPARC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#sparc"><b>S</b>cholarly <b>P</b>ublishing and <b>A</b>cademic <b>R</b>esources <b>C</b>oalition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specialcollections"><b>special collections</b></a>
</dt><dd>Some <a href="#library">libraries</a> segregate from the general <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> <a href="#rarebook">rare book</a>s, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#papers">papers</a>, and other <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s which are 1) of a certain form, 2) on a certain <a href="#subject">subject</a>, 3) of a certain time period or geographic area, 4) in fragile or poor <a href="#condition">condition</a>, or 5) especially valuable.  Such <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> are not allowed to <a href="#circulating">circulate</a> and <a href="#access">access</a> to them may be <a href="#restricted">restricted</a>.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/spcoll/">Click here</a> to connect to an <a href="#online">online</a> guide to the special <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s in the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>, and <a href="http://www.exlib.org/">here</a> to connect to the ExLibris <a href="#directory">directory</a> of special collections that support <a href="#digitization">digitization</a>.  Compare with <a href="#archives">archives</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#rbms">Rare Books and Manuscripts Section</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specialedition"><b>special edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> or <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> (or works) produced in a <a href="#format">format</a> that differs from previous editions, usually for a special purpose and sometimes under a distinctive <a href="#title">title</a>, with a new <a href="#introduction">introduction</a> and sometimes additional <a href="#note">note</a>s, <a href="#appendix">appendices</a>, or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used synonymously with <a href="#libraryedition">library edition</a>.
<p>
Also, a special issue of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, usually devoted wholly or in large part to a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> or occasion, for example, in commemoration of a national event.  Synonymous with <em>special number</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specintmag"><b>special interest magazine</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> devoted to a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a> of interest to a fairly narrow, well-defined <a href="#audience">audience</a>, for example, golfing enthusiasts (<b><em>Golf Digest</em></b>) or yoga teachers and practitioners (<b><em>Yoga Journal</em></b>).  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> usually <a href="#subscription">subscribe</a> to special interest <a href="#title">title</a>s on the basis of <a href="#demand">demand</a>, as indicated by <a href="#patron">patron</a> requests and <a href="#usage">usage</a> statistics for related <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#genintmag">general interest magazine</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specialissue"><b>special issue</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> devoted wholly or substantially to a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> or occasion.  When <a href="#publishing">published</a> more than once on the same <a href="#topic">topic</a>, a special issue usually appears at the same time in consecutive years, for example, the <a href="#annual">annual</a> swimsuit issue of <b><em>Sports Illustrated</em></b>, a high-<a href="#demand">demand</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#conventionissue">convention issue</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specialization"><b>specialization</b></a>
</dt><dd>Concentration on a limited aspect of a <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, often to the exclusion of related areas of study or inquiry.  The breadth of <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a> is so great that most <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s decide to focus on one or two aspects of the profession.  In <a href="#libraryschool">library school</a>, students usually select a functional specialization (<a href="#publicservices">public services</a>, <a href="#technicalservices">technical services</a>, automated <a href="#systems">systems</a>, etc.).  Each of these tracks is divided into narrower branches, for example, <a href="#subjectanalysis">subject analysis</a> within technical services, or <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a> within public services.  In <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, librarians specialize in services for <a href="#adultservices">adults</a>, <a href="#yaservices">young adult</a>s, or <a href="#childrensservices">children</a>.  Librarians employed in <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a> focus on a particular <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#field">field</a> (art, business, engineering, law, medicine), type of material (<a href="#govdocs">government documents</a>, <a href="#film">film</a> and <a href="#videorecording">video</a>), type of institution (<a href="#correctional">correctional</a>, <a href="#militarylibrary">military</a>, <a href="#museumlib">museum</a>), or type of collection (<a href="#archives">archives</a>, <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>).  The professional organizations and <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#literature">literature</a> of librarianship reflect these divisions.   
<p>
Also refers to the level of detail or difficulty of the <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>, which depends the <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#mission">mission</a> and the <a href="#clientele">clientele</a> served, for example, a public library may provide a selection of the <a href="#novel">novel</a>s of Thomas Hardy in at least one <a href="#edition">edition</a>, but not his <a href="#poetry">poetry</a> or the literary <a href="#criticism">criticism</a> and multiple editions one would expect to find in the <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> of an <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a> at a university offering advanced degrees in English <a href="#language">language</a> and <a href="#literature">literature</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sla"><b>Special Libraries Association (SLA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1909, <b>SLA</b> has an international membership of <a href="#information">information</a> professionals employed in <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a> serving business, <a href="#research">research</a>, governments, universities, <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, museums, and institutions that use or produce <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> information.  <b>SLA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> <em><a href="http://www.sla.org/pubs/serial/io/index.shtml">Information Outlook</a></em>.  <a href="http://www.sla.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>SLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dana">Dana, John Cotton</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="speciallibrary"><b>special library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> established and funded by a commercial firm, private <a href="#association">association</a>, <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>, nonprofit organization, or special interest group to meet the <a href="#infoneed">information need</a>s of its employees, members, or staff in accordance with the organization's <a href="#mission">mission</a> and <a href="#goal">goal</a>s.  The <a href="#scope">scope</a> of the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> is usually limited to the interests of its <a href="#hostorg">host organization</a>.  Special <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s are organized in the <a href="#sla">Special Libraries Association</a>.  <a href="#information">Information</a> on special libraries in the United States and Canada is available in the <b><em>Directory of Special Libraries and Information Centers</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#corporationlib">corporation library</a>, <a href="#correctional">correctional library</a>, <a href="#medicallib">medical library</a>, <a href="#museumlib">museum library</a>, and <a href="#newslibrary">news library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specialoffer"><b>special offer</b></a>
</dt><dd>An offer by a <a href="#supplier">supplier</a> or <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> to sell goods and/or services at a lower price, usually for a limited period of time, or to provide a <a href="#trial">trial</a> period, <a href="#premiumbook">premium</a>, or other inducement to purchase or <a href="#subscription">subscribe</a>.  Other restrictions, such as minimum purchase amount, may apply.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specialorder"><b>special order</b></a>
</dt><dd>An order for a single <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a>, requiring special handling, usually because the item is not <a href="#instock">in stock</a>.  Special orders are generally sold at a <a href="#shortdiscount">short discount</a> or no <a href="#discount">discount</a>, and a modest service charge may be added to compensate the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> for extra effort.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specifications"><b>specifications</b></a>
</dt><dd>The instructions sent by a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to a <a href="#printer">printer</a> with the <a href="#typescript">typescript</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> regarding its characteristics as a prospective <a href="#publication">publication</a>, including its dimensions, <a href="#paper">paper</a> stock, <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>, quantity of <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, extent of <a href="#frontmatter">front</a> and <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>, etc., from which the printer creates a <em>specimen page</em> to indicate the proposed style of <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a>.  Cost of production is determined by <em>specs</em> and size of <a href="#edition">edition</a>.
In a more general sense, detailed instructions concerning work to be
done, products or services to be supplied, etc., especially when a
contract is to be signed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specificentry"><b>specific entry</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#subjectanalysis">subject analysis</a>, the principle that a <a href="#work">work</a> is listed in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> under the most specific <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>(s) or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>(s) that fully describe its <a href="#content">content</a>.  For example, a <a href="#book">book</a>
about poets would be entered under "Poets" not "Writers" and a work
about French poets under "French poets" or "Poets, French" rather than
"Poets." Compare with <a href="#coextensive">coextensive entry</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specificity"><b>specificity</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, the degree to which the meaning of a <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> or <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> matches the <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#document">document</a> to which it is assigned.  For example, although the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject heading</a> "Gardening" applies to a <a href="#book">book</a>
about gardening inside the house, the heading "Indoor gardening"
describes the content more precisely. Specificity in this sense is
relative to the <a href="#work">work</a> described.  An indexing <a href="#term">term</a> may be specific, whether broad or narrow, as long as it matches closely an important <a href="#subject">subject</a> of the work.  
<p>
In an <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>, the specificity of a descriptor or subject heading depends on its relationship to other authorized <a href="#term">term</a>s broader or narrower in meaning, usually indicated in a <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> or headings list by <a href="#indention">indention</a>, or by the codes <b>BT</b> (<a href="#broaderterm">broader term</a>) or <b>NT</b> (<a href="#narrowerterm">narrower term</a>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#topterm">top term</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specificmaterial"><b>specific material designation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The most specific designation of the type of material to which an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> belongs, given under <a href="#extentofitem">extent of item</a> in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, for example, "<a href="#videodisc">videodisc</a>" under the <a href="#gmd">general material designation</a> "<a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specimen"><b>specimen</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single individual or member of a group or <a href="#class">class</a>, selected as an example or sample of the whole, for example, an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> of a specific type selected to represent a group of items, or an entire <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>, in a <a href="#library">library</a> display or <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>.  Compare with <a href="#artifact">artifact</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#specimencase">specimen case</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specimencase"><b>specimen case</b></a>
</dt><dd>A wide flat storage container, usually with a transparent top,
divided into compartments usually backed with soft material, used for
for <a href="#mounted">mounting</a> and storing <a href="#specimen">specimen</a>s
in rows to facilitate comparison. Some models are lockable. In museums,
specimen cases may be built to specific dimensions to allow them to be
stored, one atop another inside a specially designed cabinet. <p>
Also refers to a sample <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>, submitted by an <a href="#edition">edition</a> <a href="#binder">binder</a> to the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> for approval, showing the proposed size, <a href="#board">board</a>s, covering, <a href="#lettering">lettering</a>, and <a href="#squares">squares</a> of a <a href="#casebinding">case binding</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specimenpage"><b>specimen page</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of several sample <a href="#page">page</a>s submitted by the <a href="#printer">printer</a> to the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> to show the proposed <a href="#typography">typographic</a> style for a prospective <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually <em>four</em> in number, including the first page of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> and at least one <a href="#subhead">subhead</a> to show <a href="#displaytype">display type</a>.  Also refers to a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a page from a <a href="#book">book</a> or other publication, <a href="#reproduction">reproduced</a> on any <a href="#scale">scale</a> for use by the publisher in marketing.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="specs"><b>specs</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#specifications">specifications</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="speechrecognition"><b>speech recognition</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#voicerecognition">voice recognition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spellchecker"><b>spell checker</b></a>
</dt><dd>A feature of most <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#software">software</a> that automatically checks the spelling of words typed in a <a href="#document">document</a> against a built-in <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>, alerting the user to any misspelled words and even correcting <a href="#typo">typo</a>s
on the fly. Spell-checkers are not infallible. A misspelling will not
be flagged if it is itself a word ("their" for "there"). The <a href="#option">option</a> can usually be turned "off" by the user if not desired.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spider"><b>spider</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#crawler">crawler</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spine"><b>spine</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#rounding">rounded</a> or flat part of the <a href="#binding">binding</a> on a <a href="#book">book</a>, connecting the front and back <a href="#cover">cover</a>s and protecting the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a>, the only part of the cover visible when the <a href="#volume">volume</a> is placed alongside others on the shelf.  It usually bears the <a href="#spinetitle">spine title</a> or an <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> title, and the last name or full name of the <a href="#author">author</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, a <a href="#spinelabel">label</a> bearing the <a href="#locationsymbol">location symbol</a> and <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> is affixed to the lower spine of each <a href="#volume">volume</a> to facilitate retrieval and <a href="#reshelving">reshelving</a>.  In some bindings, the spine is covered in a different material than the <a href="#board">board</a>s (see:  <a href="#halfbinding">half-binding</a>, <a href="#quarterbinding">quarter binding</a>, and <a href="#threequarter">three-quarter binding</a>).  Synonymous with <em>backbone</em> and <em>shelf back</em>.  Compare with <a href="#back">back</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cocked">cocked</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spinelabel"><b>spine label</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small typed or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#label">label</a> affixed to the lower <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> at the time it is <a href="#technical">processed</a>, displaying its <a href="#locationsymbol">location symbol</a> and <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>, for use in <a href="#reshelving">reshelving</a> and to assist the user in retrieving the item from the shelf once its call number has been found in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spineout"><b>spine-out</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#book">Book</a>s displayed on a shelf with their <a href="#spine">spine</a>s facing the front, usually one alongside the other with a <a href="#bookend">bookend</a> at the end of the row to keep them upright--the shelving method used in the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a> of most <a href="#library">libraries</a> because it allows the <a href="#spinetitle">spine title</a> and <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> on each <a href="#volume">volume</a> to be seen at a glance.  Compare with <a href="#faceout">face out</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spinetitle"><b>spine title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> appearing on the <a href="#spine">spine</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, sometimes shorter than the title impressed on the <a href="#cover">cover</a> or <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  Synonymous with <em>back title</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#binderstitle">binder's title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spinoff"><b>spin-off</b></a>
</dt><dd>An independently <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#set">set</a> of books containing material selected from a longer <a href="#work">work</a> published by the same company, for example, the three-<a href="#volume">volume</a> <b><em>New Grove Dictionary of Musical Instruments</em></b> containing <a href="#entry">entries</a> that are nearly identical to those in the much longer <b><em>New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians</em></b>.  Compare with <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#journal">journal</a> that became a separate <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> after having been part of a more <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, for example, <em><a href="#slj">School Library Journal</a></em>, once part of <em><a href="#libraryjournal">Library Journal</a></em>.  The proliferation of scholarly publications into increasingly <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#field">field</a>s and subfields has been called <em>twigging</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spiralbinding"><b>spiral binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#mechanical">mechanical binding</a> in which a continuous coil of <a href="#wirecoil">wire</a> or hard plastic is drawn through small holes or slots punched in the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#cover">cover</a>s and <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#publication">publication</a> to hold them together, used mainly for <a href="#report">report</a>s, <a href="#manual">manual</a>s, <a href="#workbook">workbook</a>s, and <a href="#notebook">notebook</a>s containing <a href="#blank">blank</a> or <a href="#rule">rule</a>d <a href="#page">page</a>s.  Spiral bindings <a href="#openability">open</a> flat.  Synonymous with <em>coil binding</em>.  Compare with <a href="#combbinding">comb binding</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#looseleaf">loose-leaf</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="split"><b>split</b></a>
</dt><dd>The permanent division of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> into two or more parts.  The <a href="#note">note</a> <em>Continues in part:</em> is included in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> for each of the parts to indicate the <a href="#title">title</a> of the <a href="#publication">publication</a> that split, and the corresponding note <em>Split into:</em>
is added in the record for the serial that split to indicate the titles
of the publications created by the division. The opposite of <a href="#merger">merger</a>
<p>
Also, to divide an animal hide into two or more layers for use in <a href="#book">book</a> production.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used for one of the layers produced by such a division (or the <a href="#leather">leather</a> made from it), usually an underlayer rather than the <a href="#grain">grain</a> layer.  In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, to cut a <a href="#signature">signature</a> thicker than 3/4" through the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a> in preparation for <a href="#doublefan">fan gluing</a> or <a href="#oversewing">oversewing</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="splitcatalog"><b>split catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#dividedcatalog">divided catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spoilage"><b>spoilage</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#book">book</a> production, printed <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s or  entire <a href="#copy">copies</a> discarded because they contain <a href="#imperfections">imperfections</a> or were damaged in <a href="#printing">printing</a> or <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Allowance for spoilage is included in the size of printing and binding orders. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sponsor"><b>sponsor</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate entity</a> that
subsidizes or provides encouragement, funding, or some other form of
practical assistance in the production of a radio or television
program, <a href="#website">Web site</a>, or other creative <a href="#work">work</a>, usually in exchange for some form of <a href="#publicity">publicity</a>.  Compare with <a href="#patron">patron</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sponsoredbook"><b>sponsored book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by an established commercial <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> for which the cost of <a href="#publication">publication</a> is subsidized by an organization or company with an interest in seeing it <a href="#publishing">published</a>.
The subsidy may be a direct payment to the publisher to cover losses in
the event of disappointing sales, or an agreement to purchase enough <a href="#copy">copies</a> at an established price to make the publication profitable.  Compare with <a href="#vanitypublisher">vanity publisher</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spool"><b>spool</b></a>
</dt><dd>A cylindrical flanged wheel with a hole running from end-to-end onto which a roll of unprocessed <a href="#film">film</a> is wound, designed to be inserted in a camera or processing machine.  Compare with <a href="#reel">reel</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spread"><b>spread</b></a>
</dt><dd>The full expanse of facing <a href="#page">page</a>s in an <a href="#opening">opening</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  The page on the right-hand side is the <a href="#recto">recto</a>; the one on the left is the <a href="#verso">verso</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doublespread"> double spread</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spreadsheet"><b>spreadsheet</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#application">Application</a> <a href="#software">software</a> that allows <a href="#text">text</a>ual <a href="#information">information</a> and numeric <a href="#data">data</a> to be displayed and computed in two-dimensional <a href="#table">tabular</a> <a href="#format">format</a> (rows and columns), widely used in <a href="#budget">budget</a>ing and statistical analysis.  Also refers to the result of using such a <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>, in <a href="#print">print</a> or electronic <a href="#format">format</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sprinkled"><b>sprinkled</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, a <a href="#book">book</a> on which the cut edges of the <a href="#section">section</a>s have been irregularly sprayed or spattered with flecks of color as a decoration, a technique used mainly on large <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a> and expensive <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#set">set</a>s.  The visual effect makes dust and any natural discoloration less noticeable.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sprung"><b>sprung</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> has separated from its <a href="#cover">cover</a>, either in the process of <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a> or through wear on the <a href="#hinge">hinge</a>s.  <a href="#mending">Mending</a> may require new <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#shaken">shaken</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="spurious"><b>spurious work</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written <a href="#work">work</a> known to be counterfeit (not genuine), usually one uncritically ascribed to a known <a href="#author">author</a> and subsequently discovered to be of unknown or uncertain <a href="#authorship">authorship</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#apocryphal">apocryphal</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="square"><b>square</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#width">width</a> of the <a href="#cover">cover</a> is more than three-quarters (but not greater than) its <a href="#height">height</a>, a shape often used in <a href="#artbook">art book</a>s and <a href="#childrensbook">children's</a> <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#narrow">narrow</a> and <a href="#oblong">oblong</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#portrait">portrait</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="squarebracket"><b>square bracket</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of a pair of angled lines [ ] enclosing a word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, or numeric figure in <a href="#text">text</a>, usually to indicate insertion.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, square brackets are used to indicate an <a href="#bracketedinterp">interpolation</a> made by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> (<em>example</em>:  [48] p.) and around the <a href="#gmd">general material designation</a> following the <a href="#title">title</a> in a <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing a <a href="#nonbook">nonbook</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> (<em>example</em>:  [sound recording]).  Compare with <a href="#parenthesis">parenthesis</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="squarecapital"><b>square capital</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#letter">letter</a> of the Latin <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> used in Europe as a <a href="#bookhand">book hand</a> from the 3rd to the 5th century, adapted from the lapidary <a href="#capitalletter">capital</a>s used in antiquity to carve <a href="#inscription">inscription</a>s on monuments.  The pointed <a href="#serif">serif</a>s
incised in stone were replaced with wider square serifs, easier to
execute with a reed or quill pen, and the contrast between thick and
thin strokes was greater in square capitals. Even so, the difficulty of
writing square capitals led to the use of <a href="#rusticcapital">rustic capital</a>s during the same period.  Latin:  <em>capitales quadrata</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="squares"><b>squares</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the edges of the <a href="#board">board</a>s of a <a href="#cover">cover</a>, extending beyond the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> at the <a href="#head">head</a>, <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a>, and <a href="#tail">tail</a> to protect the <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s from damage.  <a href="#casebinding">Cased</a> books have equal margins of cover around the edges, usually 1/8 to 3/16 of an inch.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used for the part of the cover that is <a href="#turnin">turned in</a> on the inside, but not covered by the <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s after they have been <a href="#pastingdown">pasted down</a>.  Compare with <a href="#cutflush">cut flush</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="srrt1"><b>SRRT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#srrt"><b>S</b>ocial <b>R</b>esponsibilities <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ssirt1"><b>SSIRT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ssirt"><b>S</b>upport <b>S</b>taff <b>I</b>nterests <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ssp1"><b>SSP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ssp"><b>S</b>ociety for <b>S</b>cholarly <b>P</b>ublishing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stabilization"><b>stabilization</b></a>
</dt><dd>Chemical or physical methods applied in <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> to maintain the integrity of a <a href="#document">document</a> by arresting <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> already in progress, for example, the neutralization of <a href="#acidpaper">acid</a> in the <a href="#paper">paper</a> used for <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#publication">publication</a>s.  The <em>stability</em> of a document is its ability to resist changes of physical state when exposed to normal use and <a href="#storage">storage</a> conditions.  Compare with <a href="#restoration">restoration</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#permanence">permanence</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stackaisle"><b>stack aisle</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#rangeaisle">range aisle</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stackcapacity"><b>stack capacity</b></a>
</dt><dd>The amount of <a href="#libmaterials">material</a> that can be contained in the <a href="#stacks">stack</a> area of a <a href="#library">library</a>, expressed as the total linear or square feet of available shelving, or the maximum number of <a href="#volume">volume</a>s or other physical units that can be accommodated, sometimes computed by means of a formula.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cubook">cubook</a> and <a href="#shelfheight">shelf height</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stackedadvertising"><b>stacked advertising</b></a>
</dt><dd>Advertising that appears only in the front or back, or in the front <em>and</em> back, of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> and nowhere else in the <a href="#issue">issue</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>National Geographic</em></b>).  In custom <a href="#binding">binding</a> of periodicals, <a href="#unpaginated">unpaginated</a> advertisements appearing in the front and/or back of each issue may be removed to reduce <a href="#bulk">bulk</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stackmaintenance"><b>stack maintenance</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the duties involved in keeping the <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> stored in the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> in good order, including <a href="#reshelving">reshelving</a>, <a href="#shelfreading">shelf reading</a>, <a href="#shifting">shifting</a> the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> when certain <a href="#class">class</a>ifications become overcrowded, and relabeling shelf <a href="#range">range</a>s to indicate their contents.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stacks"><b>stacks</b></a>
</dt><dd>The shelving areas in a <a href="#library">library</a> where <a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> are stored when not in use.  In some libraries, the stacks are <a href="#closedstacks">closed</a> to the public, but most libraries in the United States allow <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to <a href="#browse">browse</a> all or part of their primary <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s in <a href="#openstacks">open stacks</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#stackcapacity">stack capacity</a> and <a href="#stackmaintenance">stack maintenance</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="staffretreat"><b>staff retreat</b></a>
</dt><dd>An opportunity provided by the <a href="#libadmin">administration</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> for the professional, technical, and administrative <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>
to meet in a comfortable location away from the workplace, usually once
or twice a year for at least a full or half day, to discuss issues
affecting the library and the <a href="#clientele">clientele</a> it serves.  To avoid distraction, <a href="#strategicplanning">strategic planning</a> is often conducted in such a setting.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="staffroom"><b>staff room</b></a>
</dt><dd>A room in a <a href="#library">library</a>, usually equipped with comfortable furniture and a kitchenette, where <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> members can go when they are not <a href="#onduty">on-duty</a> to eat, relax on a break, or meet informally.  Synonymous with <em>staff lounge</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stamping"><b>stamping</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#blocking">blocking</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standalone"><b>stand-alone</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer <em>not</em> connected to a <a href="#network">network</a>, which functions independently of other computers and systems.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> may be installed on a stand-alone <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a> <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>, especially when <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a>s restrict usage to one <a href="#simultaneous">simultaneous user</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standard"><b>standard</b></a>
</dt><dd>An acceptable level or criterion according to which something
is compared, measured, or judged. Also refers to an amount, extent,
quality, pattern, criterion, etc., fixed by usage or convention, or
established as the norm by prevailing authority, as in the standard
size of a <a href="#catalogcard">catalog card</a> used by <a href="#library">libraries</a> prior to the development of <a href="#machinecat">machine-readable</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>.  A <em>de facto standard</em> is one that becomes generally accepted without the formal endorsement of a standard-setting organization.  Compare with <a href="#benchmark">benchmark</a>.  
<p>
Also, any object, such as a flag or banner, used to <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>ize a nation, people, military unit, etc.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#standards">standards</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standardauthor"><b>standard author</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#author">author</a> whose <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s have earned such a respected place in the national <a href="#literature">literature</a> of a country that they are frequently taught in literature courses and included in <a href="#anthology">anthologies</a> (<em>examples</em>:  William Faulkner, Jane Austen, Gustave Flaubert, Henrik Ibsen, Anton Chekhov, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standarddeviation"><b>standard deviation</b></a>
</dt><dd>In statistical analysis, a quantitative measure of how far a
variable differs from the norm, calculated as the square root of the
variance.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standardformat"><b>standard format</b></a>
</dt><dd>The most common form of a specific type of <a href="#document">document</a>, for example, the sequence in which the  parts of a <a href="#journal">journal</a> <a href="#article">article</a> reporting the results of <a href="#original">original</a> scientific <a href="#research">research</a> are presented (review of existing <a href="#literature">literature</a>, <a href="#research">research</a>
methodology, results or findings, discussion or analysis of results,
conclusions, suggestions for further research, and list of <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#cite">cite</a>d).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sgml"><b>Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1986, <b>SGML</b> is an <a href="#iso">ISO</a> <a href="#standards">standard</a> governing the rules for defining <a href="#tag">tag</a> sets that determine how <a href="#machinereadable">machine-readable</a> <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s are <a href="#formatting">formatted</a>.  Not dependent on a specific computer system or type of <a href="#software">software</a>, <b>SGML</b> is widely used in preparing machine-readable text <a href="#archives">archives</a>.  The <a href="#html">HTML</a> code used to create <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s is an <b>SGML</b> language that uses a fixed set of predefined tags.  <a href="#xml">XML</a> is a subset of <b>SGML</b> in which the tags are unlimited and not predefined.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sic"><b>Standard Industrial Classification (SIC)</b></a>  
</dt><dd>A system of four-digit product codes developed in the 1930s by
the Statistical Policy Division of the U.S. Office of Management and
Budget to represent categories of products and services sold by
commercial companies, for the purpose of <a href="#compile">compiling</a> economic statistics.  In 1997, the OMB adopted the <a href="#naics">North American Industry Classification System</a> (NAICS) to replace the <b>SIC</b>, a change that has affected some business <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standardization"><b>standardization</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of establishing uniform procedures and <a href="#standards">standards</a>
in a specific field of endeavor, usually to facilitate exchange and
cooperation, and to assure quality and enhance productivity. In <a href="#librarianship">librarianship</a>, standards are established by professional <a href="#association">association</a>s, <a href="#accreditation">accrediting</a> bodies, and <a href="#govtagency">government agencies</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#niso">National Information Standards Organization (NISO)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standardlist"><b>standard list</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of <a href="#title">title</a>s recommended for any <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> of a particular type and size, usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> under the auspices of a <a href="#libassociation">library association</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Books for College Libraries</em></b>).  Standard lists are difficult to keep <a href="#currency">current</a>.  Synonymous with <em>selection guide</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#corecollection">core collection</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standardnumber"><b>standard number</b></a>
</dt><dd>The unique identification <a href="#number">number</a> assigned to an <a href="#edition">edition</a> at the time of first <a href="#publication">publication</a>, in accordance with an internationally <a href="#standardization">standardized</a> identification system, usually appearing somewhere on the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  In <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s, the International Standard Books Number (<a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>) is <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> and usually on the front <a href="#flap">flap</a> of the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>.  In <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s, it appears on the verso of the title page and on the back <a href="#cover">cover</a> (usually in the lower right-hand corner).  In <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, the International Standard Serial Number (<a href="#issn">ISSN</a>) is included in the <a href="#masthead">masthead</a> or with the <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the standard number is given in the <a href="#standardnumberandterms">standard number and terms of availability</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standardnumberandterms"><b>standard number and terms of availability</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the <a href="#area">area</a> of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> in which the <a href="#standardnumber">standard number</a> (<a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>, <a href="#issn">ISSN</a>, etc.), <a href="#listprice">list price</a>, and any other terms under which the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is available are entered (<a href="#field">field</a> 020 or 022 of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standards"><b>standards</b></a>
</dt><dd>Criteria established by professional <a href="#libassociation">association</a>s, <a href="#accreditation">accrediting</a> bodies, or <a href="#govtagency">agencies of government</a> for measuring and evaluating <a href="#library">library</a> services, <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, and programs (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Information Literacy Competency Standards for Higher Education</em></b> published in 2000 by the <a href="#acrl">Association of College and Research Libraries</a>).  Also refers to any code of rules or procedures established by national and international library organizations to govern <a href="#bibcontrol">bibliographic control</a>, such as the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> <a href="#format">format</a>, <a href="#cip">CIP</a>, and the <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>/<a href="#issn">ISSN</a> adopted by the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> industry.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/standards/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> on standards.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#competencies">competencies</a>.  
<p>
In a more general sense, any criteria established by law, agreement, or
custom, according to which values, quantities, procedures, performance,
etc., are measured or evaluated, and to which manufacturers,
practitioners, <a href="#research">research</a>ers, etc., seek to conform in order to ensure quality and/or uniformity of results.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ansi">American National Standards Institute (ANSI)</a> and <a href="#niso">National Information Standards Organization (NISO)</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standardsubdivision"><b>standard subdivision</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <em><a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress Subject Headings</a></em> list, a <a href="#subheading">subheading</a> applied uniformly to one or more categories of <a href="#mainheading">main heading</a>, for example, the subheading "Influence" under <a href="#heading">heading</a>s for <a href="#personalname">personal name</a>s, <a href="#corporatebody">corporate bodies</a>, <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a>s of <a href="#sacredtext">sacred text</a>s, religions, wars, types of organizations, and forms and movements in the arts (<em>example</em>:  <b>Hardy, Thomas, 1840-1928--Influence</b>). <a href="http://infoshare1.princeton.edu/katmandu/subj/subd.html">Click here</a> to see a list of standard LC subject <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>free-floating subdivision</em>.  
<p>
In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, a <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a> that <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>s may add to a <a href="#class">class</a> listed in the <a href="#mainschedule">main schedule</a>s to indicate form, historical period, category of person, etc., which is never used alone.  In the <a href="#notation">notation</a>, it is indicated by adding a <a href="#decimalpoint">decimal</a> fraction to the <a href="#classnumber">class number</a>.  Standard subdivisions are listed in Table 1.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standardtitle"><b>standard title</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standardwork"><b>standard work</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> widely recognized as a model of excellence in its <a href="#field">field</a>, which <a href="#library">libraries</a> may order in multiple <a href="#copy">copies</a> or <a href="#edition">edition</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Elements of Style</em></b> by William Strunk, Jr.).  A standard <a href="#refbook">reference work</a> is usually <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#revisededition">revised edition</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Columbia Granger's Index to Poetry in Anthologies</em></b>).  Compare with <a href="#classic">classic</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standingcom"><b>standing committee</b></a>
</dt><dd>A permanent committee appointed by management or selected
according to established procedures to handle specific ongoing
responsibilities, usually in support of an organization's <a href="#mission">mission</a> and <a href="#goal">goal</a>s, as opposed to an <em>ad hoc committee</em> established to address a particular issue or accomplish a specific task, then dissolved once its goals and <a href="#objective">objective</a>s have been met.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standingorder"><b>standing order</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="standingroom"><b>standing room</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a>s, <a href="#topic">topic</a>s considerably less extensive in scope than the <a href="#subject">subject</a>(s) represented by the <a href="#class">class</a>, usually given immediately following the <a href="#notation">notation</a> and <a href="#heading">heading</a>,
in a note that begins with "Including," "Contains," "Example(s)," or
"Common names." Standing room provides a location for topics for which
the <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s is limited, but expected to grow, possibly to the point of <a href="#literarywarrant">warrant</a>ing a separate <a href="#classnumber">class number</a>.  <a href="#cataloger">Cataloger</a>s are not permitted to add <a href="#standardsubdivision">standard subdivision</a>s to such topics, nor are other <a href="#numberbuilding">number building</a> techniques allowed (adapted from <em>DDC</em>).  Compare with <a href="#approximatewhole">approximate the whole</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stapling"><b>stapling</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#saddle">saddle-stitching</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="starmap"><b>star map</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#astronomicalmap">astronomical map</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="start"><b>start</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">binding</a> defect in which one of the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> projects beyond the others at the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> because it has not been properly secured at the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a>.  Also refers to a crack between sections at the binding edge, usually the result of forcing the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> open while they are held down, instead of pressing gently along the inner <a href="#margin">margin</a> to form a fold at the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="started"><b>started</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> in which a portion of the <a href="#body">body</a> is so <a href="#loose">loose</a> in the <a href="#binding">binding</a> that it protrudes beyond the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> but remains attached, a <a href="#condition">condition</a> not as advanced as <a href="#shaken">shaken</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="state"><b>state</b></a>
</dt><dd>Part of an <a href="#edition">edition</a> that differs from other <a href="#copy">copies</a> of the same edition by virtue of minor changes in the <a href="#makeup">make-up</a> or <a href="#typesetting">typesetting</a> made during <a href="#printing">printing</a> or <a href="#binding">binding</a>,
usually additions, deletions, corrections, and transpositions. In the
16th and 17th centuries, variations in state were often the result of
allowing the <a href="#author">author</a> to visit the <a href="#printingpress">press</a> room while <a href="#printing">printing</a> was in progress.  They are used in <a href="#analyticalbibliog">historical bibliography</a> and the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> to determine priority of <a href="#issue">issue</a>.  In this sense, state has no relation to <a href="#condition">condition</a>.  Compare with <a href="#variant">variant</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#idealcopy">ideal copy</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a preliminary <a href="#impression">impression</a> taken of a <a href="#print">print</a> by the artist as a test prior to completion of the <a href="#plate">plate</a> or perfection of <a href="#ink">ink</a>ing.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="statelibrary"><b>state library</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the United States, a <a href="#library">library</a> supported by state funds for the use of state employees and citizens, usually located in the state capital, containing a <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of the state's official <a href="#document">document</a>s, <a href="#book">book</a>s written by <a href="#author">author</a>s living in the state, and <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in the state.  The first state library was established in Pennsylvania in 1816.  <a href="http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/Libweb/usa-state.html">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>Libweb</em></b> directory of U.S. State Libraries.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ascla">Association of Specialized and  Cooperative Library Agencies</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="statemanual"><b>state manual</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly or <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a>ly by a state government, usually containing the <a href="#text">text</a> of the state <a href="#charter">charter</a> and/or constitution, election statistics, and <a href="#information">information</a>
about government structure, elected and appointed officials, voting
districts, and the towns or boroughs, cities, and counties within the
state. Also known as a <a href="#bluebook">blue book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="statementof"><b>statement of responsibility</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the portion of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> indicating the person(s) or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a> responsible for creating the intellectual or artistic <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, for example, the <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#editor">editor</a>, or <a href="#compiler">compiler</a> of a written <a href="#work">work</a>, or the <a href="#composer">composer</a> or <a href="#arranger">arranger</a> of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a>.  In most cases, the statement of responsibility is <a href="#transcribe">transcribe</a>d from the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a> in or on the item.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>,
when more than one kind of responsibility is indicated (multiple
statements of responsibility), the names are transcribed in the order
in which they appear on the chief source of <a href="#information">information</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stateoftheart"><b>state-of-the-art</b></a>
</dt><dd>A product, system, or design that represents the most advanced degree of technical achievement in its <a href="#field">field</a> at the present time.  In the construction of <a href="#newconstruc">new facilities</a>, <a href="#library">libraries</a> typically strive for state-of-the-art design and technology, but must often settle for what is financially feasible. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stationer"><b>stationer</b></a>
</dt><dd>In Europe, the earliest nonmonastic producer and lender of <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s for profit.  <em>Stationarii</em> (Latin) were licensed by medieval universities to oversee the <a href="#copy">copy</a>ing, <a href="#binding">binding</a>, distribution, and <a href="#repairing">repair</a> of officially approved <a href="#text">text</a>s.  In England, the earliest commercial <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, who sold their wares from market stalls, were known as stationers.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#exemplar">exemplar</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="statisticalbib"><b>statistical bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bibliometrics">bibliometrics</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="status"><b>status</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#borrowerstatus">borrower status</a>, <a href="#circstatus">circulation status</a>, and <a href="#loanstatus">loan status</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="statutorycopy"><b>statutory copy</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#depositcopy">deposit copy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stave"><b>stave</b></a>
</dt><dd>The set of five parallel horizontal lines on which <a href="#musicalwork">musical</a> <a href="#notation">notation</a> is  written or <a href="#printing">printed</a>.  In the <a href="#fullscore">full score</a> of an <a href="#ensemblework">ensemble work</a>, each <a href="#part">part</a> is written on a separate stave.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="steadystate"><b>steady state</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> in which the <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s <a href="#weeding">weeded</a> equals the number <a href="#acquisitions">acquired</a> over time.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> with a limited amount of shelf space and no prospect of expansion must maintain a constant collection size.  Synonymous with <em>no growth</em> or <em>zero growth</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="steering"><b>steering committee</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of people appointed or elected to take charge of a complex project, for example, the task of planning the <a href="#renovation">renovation</a> of an existing <a href="#library">library</a> or organizing a <a href="#moving">move</a>
into a new library facility. Their responsibilities include setting
priorities and establishing the sequence in which various stages of the
work are to proceed. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stem"><b>stem</b></a>
</dt><dd>The root of a word used as a <a href="#searchterm">search term</a> in a <a href="#query">query</a> entered as <a href="#input">input</a> in <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, to which one or more <a href="#truncation">truncation</a> <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s are added to <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> variant forms (<em>example</em>:  <b>*witch*</b> to retrieve <em>bewitch</em>, <em>bewitched</em>, <em>bewitching</em>, <em>witch</em>, <em>witches</em>, <em>witchery</em>, <em>witchcraft</em>, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stemming"><b>stemming</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#truncation">truncation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stepindex"><b>step index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A series of shallow indentations resembling a staircase, cut into the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, bearing a sequence of <a href="#character">character</a>s or <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, sometimes <a href="#printing">printed</a> against a dark ground to facilitate reference.  Synonymous with <em>cut-in index</em>.  Compare with <a href="#tabindex">tab index</a> and <a href="#thumbindex">thumb index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stereograph"><b>stereograph</b></a>
</dt><dd>A visual <a href="#medium">medium</a> in which a transparent
or opaque image, or two slightly different images of the same scene
arranged side-by-side, appear three-dimensional when seen through the
lenses of a binocular instrument called a <em>stereoscope</em>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, stereographs are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> as <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> materials.  Synonymous with <em>stereogram</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stereophonic"><b>stereophonic</b></a>
</dt><dd>Sound reproduced by an audio device simultaneously from two
separate channels with two amplifiers or speakers. Stereophonic sound
separation produces a more realistic effect than earlier <a href="#monaural">monaural</a> <a href="#soundrecording">recording</a>, but not as realistic as <a href="#quadraphonic">quadraphonic</a> sound.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stereotype"><b>stereotype</b></a>
</dt><dd>A fixed impression which may have little basis in fact, but is
nevertheless perpetuated by persons unwilling to look more deeply into
