the matter. <a href="#librarian">Librarian</a>s are often cast in a mold by the mass <a href="#media">media</a> because few people outside the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#professionalism">profession</a> understand what librarians do when they are not shushing people.  <a href="#libraryhumor">Library humor</a> often makes light of the absurdities inherent in the notion of the "typical librarian."  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stick"><b>stick</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sturdy hardwood rod about three feet long, divided
lengthwise down the center, usually into four thin shafts, with a
handle on one end and a rubber ring at the other to hold the most
recent <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> securely along the fold.  When not in use, the rods are designed to rest horizontally in a rack high enough to allow the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> to hang freely without touching the floor.  Synonymous with <em>newspaper rod</em>.
<p>
Also refers to a hand-held adjustable wood or metal frame used to hold in sequence the individual units of <a href="#type">type</a> as they are <a href="#composition">composed</a> in <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a>, each unit bearing a single <a href="#character">character</a>,
arranged in reverse order from right to left and upside down. The frame
is usually calibrated to allow line-length to be fixed. After several
lines of type have been assembled, the <a href="#typesetting">typesetter</a> transfers them to a holding tray called a <a href="#galley">galley</a> to await <a href="#makeup">make-up</a> into <a href="#page">page</a> form.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sticker"><b>sticker</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small preprinted <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> <a href="#label">label</a> placed inside a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#import">import</a>ed from another country, usually on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> to indicate the name of the domestic <a href="#distributor">distributor</a>.  Stickers are also used by <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s and <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s to indicate price changes.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="still"><b>still</b></a>
</dt><dd>A single <a href="#frame">frame</a> from a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> or <a href="#videotape">videotape</a>, often used for promotional purposes.  Also refers to a single <a href="#photograph">photograph</a> taken with a conventional camera, especially one in which the <a href="#subject">subject</a> is a performer, for use in <a href="#publicity">publicity</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stipple"><b>stipple</b></a>
</dt><dd>A pattern of small dots of varying color and/or density, used in drawing, painting, or <a href="#printing">printing</a> to create the impression of gradations of light and shadow in an image.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#stippleengraving">stipple engraving</a>.  Also refers to an uneven, pebble-grained <a href="#finish">finish</a> on certain grades of <a href="#paper">paper</a>.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stippleengraving"><b>stipple engraving</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> technique that combines <a href="#etching">etching</a> and <a href="#engraving">engraving</a>
to produce designs in which outlines are etched by hand and shading is
produced by a pattern of small dots of varying size and density, cut
into the same <a href="#plate">plate</a> with a graver.  Also refers to a <a href="#print">print</a> made by this technique.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stitching"><b>stitching</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#saddle">saddle-stitching</a> and <a href="#sidestitching">side-stitching</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stm"><b>STM</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> used in the <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> trade for the scientific, technical, and medical segment of the market for <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, <a href="#book">book</a>s, and other forms of <a href="#scholarlycommunication">scholarly communication</a>.  Leading <b>STM</b> publishers include <a href="http://www.elsevier.com/">Elsevier Science</a> and <a href="http://www.springer.de/">Springer-Verlag</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#psp">PSP</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stockphotograph"><b>stock photograph</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#photograph">photograph</a> taken in the past, kept on <a href="#file">file</a> for use when no <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#picture">picture</a> is available, in contrast to one taken specifically for the purpose at hand.  <a href="#newspaper">Newspaper</a>s usually maintain a file of stock photographs, especially <a href="#portrait">portrait</a>s of well-known individuals, pictures of landmarks, etc., for use as the occasion arises.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> for stock photo <a href="#agency">agencies</a> is available in <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>.  <a href="#copyright">Copyright</a> law applies.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stoplist"><b>stop list</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#stopword">stopword</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stopword"><b>stopword</b></a>
</dt><dd>A frequently used word--usually an <a href="#article">article</a>, conjunction, or preposition with little <a href="#semantics">semantic</a> <a href="#content">content</a>--ignored when a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> <a href="#search">search</a> is executed because it adds little value to the <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a> and is not helpful for <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a> (common examples:  <b>a, an, as, at, by, for, from, of, on, the, to</b>).  Some systems have a predetermined list of stopwords, which may be given in the <a href="#helpscreen">help screen</a>(s).  In some systems, a stopword may be <a href="#context">context</a>-dependent, for example, the word "education" in a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> providing <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> on education, but not in a <a href="#database">database</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s or <a href="#genintmag">general interest</a> <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s.  Also spelled <em>stop word</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stop"><b>stop word</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#stopword">stopword</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="storage"><b>storage</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, <em>external</em> <a href="#memory">memory</a> used to store <a href="#data">data</a> for an indefinite period of time (usually on <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a> or <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>), as opposed to <em>main</em> memory or <a href="#ram">RAM</a> used to store data only during a work session.  Storage capacity is measured in <a href="#byte">byte</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#save">save</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="storagearea"><b>storage area</b></a>
</dt><dd>A location within a <a href="#library">library</a> building or outside its walls where infrequently used <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> and <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a> are housed until needed.  In some libraries, <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in storage may be retrieved by <a href="#courier">courier</a> at the user's request.  The status of items in a <em>storage collection</em> may be indicated in the <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="storyboard"><b>storyboard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A series of <a href="#picture">picture</a>s or rough <a href="#sketch">sketch</a>es with accompanying <a href="#text">text</a>, used in the production of an <a href="#audiovisual">audiovisual</a> or <a href="#multimedia">multimedia</a> <a href="#work">work</a> to help the creators visualize the sequence of its parts.  Also spelled <em>story board</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="storybook"><b>storybook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> of stories for children, often an <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> <a href="#collection">collection</a> of well-known <a href="#fable">fable</a>s, <a href="#fairytale">fairy tale</a>s, <a href="#nurseryrhyme">nursery rhyme</a>s, and <a href="#poetry">poem</a>s, sometimes devoted to a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a> or theme (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Japanese Children's Storybook on the Bombing of Hiroshima</em></b> by Toshi and Iri Maruki).  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also seen in the <a href="#title">title</a>s of collections of Bible stories written for children. Compare with <a href="#picturestorybook">picture storybook</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="storyhour"><b>story hour</b></a>
</dt><dd>A period of time set aside for reading and telling stories to the youngest members of a <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>, a regularly scheduled event in some <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>.  The storyteller is usually a trained <a href="#childrenslibrarian">children's librarian</a>, but <a href="#storytelling">storytelling</a> may also be done by a particularly talented or experienced assistant or <a href="#volunteer">volunteer</a>.  In some public libraries, the <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a> includes a special room or corner with soft furniture, designed to put young listeners at ease.  Also spelled <em>storyhour</em>.  Synonymous with <em>storytime</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="storytelling"><b>storytelling</b></a>
</dt><dd>The art of telling and reading stories to young children, for pleasure and to interest them in <a href="#book">book</a>s and reading.  The practice was first introduced in <a href="#library">libraries</a> by Caroline Hewins at the Hartford <a href="#publiclibrary">Public Library</a> in Connecticut in 1882.  Storytelling is sometimes done with the aid of a <a href="#flannelboard">flannel board</a> or <a href="#puppetry">puppet</a>s.  In <a href="#bookontape">audiobook</a>s for children, the story is sometimes told by a celebrity <a href="#narration">narrator</a> whose voice is easily recognized.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#storyhour">story hour</a> and <a href="#nsn">National Storytelling Network</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="storytime"><b>storytime</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#storyhour">story hour</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="strategicalliance"><b>strategic alliance</b></a>
</dt><dd>A collaborative partnership between a <a href="#library">library</a> and one or more external departments, <a href="#agency">agencies</a>, organizations, etc., for the mutual benefit of all the participants.  Examples include <a href="#mentor">mentor</a>ing relationships between <a href="#undergradlib">undergraduate libraries</a> and athletics programs; <a href="#digitization">digitization</a> projects involving libraries, <a href="#archives">archives</a>, museums, and <a href="#historicalsociety">historical societies</a>; and library events involving <a href="#author">author</a>s, sponsored in conjunction with local <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="strategicplanning"><b>strategic planning</b></a>
</dt><dd>The systematic process by which a company, organization, or institution (or one of its units) formulates achievable policy <a href="#objective">objective</a>s for future growth and development over a period of years, based on its <a href="#mission">mission</a> and <a href="#goal">goal</a>s,
and on a realistic assessment of the resources, human and material,
available to implement the plan. The process may require the collection
and analysis of <a href="#data">data</a> on current operations and user preferences in order to evaluate competing options.  A well-developed <em>strategic plan</em> is the basis for effective <a href="#performanceeval">performance evaluation</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="strawboard"><b>strawboard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A coarse <a href="#board">board</a> used in <a href="#casebinding">case binding</a>, made from unbleached straw and re<a href="#pulp">pulp</a>ed waste fiber.  <a href="#bindersboard">Binder's board</a> is preferred in <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="streamingvideo"><b>streaming video</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of sending a sequence of <a href="#datacompression">compressed</a> moving images one-way over a <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#network">network</a>, at the user's request or <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> at a fixed time, which allows viewing to begin before the entire <a href="#file">file</a> has been transmitted.  To counteract any delays caused by <a href="#packet">packet switching</a> and maintain the impression of continuous motion, a <a href="#buffer">buffer</a> on the <a href="#client">client</a> computer is used to store a few seconds of <a href="#videotape">video</a> before it is displayed on the screen.  Unlike video that is <a href="#download">download</a>ed for subsequent <a href="#playback">playback</a>, streaming video is stored as a <em>temporary</em> file and deleted when the <a href="#application">application</a> used to view it is closed.  <a href="#videoconference">Videoconferencing</a> differs from streaming video in providing two-way transmission in <a href="#realtime">real time</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stripe"><b>stripe</b></a>
</dt><dd>A narrow band of magnetic material applied as a coating along one or both edges of a length of <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> <a href="#film">film</a>, on which the <a href="#soundtrack">sound track</a> is recorded. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stub"><b>stub</b></a>
</dt><dd>The narrow strip of <a href="#paper">paper</a> remaining along the inner edge when a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> is sliced cleanly out of a <a href="#book">book</a>, used to <a href="#tippedin">tip in</a> another <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> when a replacement is required.  Also refers to a narrow strip of cloth or paper sewn between the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a book to attach a folded <a href="#map">map</a> or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, or bound into the front or back to secure a <a href="#pocketpart">pocket</a>.  In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, the process of adding such strips to a <a href="#textblock">text block</a> is called <em>stubbing</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="studentassistant"><b>student assistant</b></a>
</dt><dd>A part-time employee in an <a href="#academiclib">academic library</a>, <a href="#schoollibrary">school library</a>, or <a href="#mediacenter">media center</a>, enrolled as a student at the institution served by the <a href="#library">library</a>.  Student assistants are usually paid an hourly wage for performing routine tasks such as <a href="#stackmaintenance">stack maintenance</a> and checking <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in and out at the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stylemanual"><b>style manual</b></a>
</dt><dd>A guide to a prescribed set of rules for typing <a href="#researchpaper">research paper</a>s and <a href="#thesis">theses</a>, usually written for a specific academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or group of related disciplines, covering the mechanics of writing (<a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a>, <a href="#capitalization">capitalization</a>, <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s, <a href="#plagiarism">plagiarism</a>, etc.), <a href="#format">format</a> (<a href="#spacing">spacing</a>, <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, <a href="#table">table</a>s and <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, etc.), and correct form of <a href="#documentation">documentation</a> (<a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s, <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>s, and <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a>), usually including pertinent examples.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, the latest <a href="#edition">edition</a>s of leading style manuals are available on <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> or in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a>.  For <a href="#electronicstyle">electronic style</a>, see the <a href="http://www.yahoo.com/Social_Science/Linguistics_and_Human_Languages/Languages/Specific_Languages/English/Grammar__Usage__and_Style/Style_Guides/">Style Guides</a> section of <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em>  Compare with <a href="#stylesheet">style sheet</a>.
<p>  
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Examples:</em>
<dl><dt></dt><dd><b><em>Chicago Manual of Style</em></b>
</dd><dd><b><em>Complete Guide to Citing Government Documents</em></b> (American Library Association)
</dd><dd><b><em>A Manual for Writers of Term Papers, Theses, and Dissertations</em></b> (Kate Turabian)
</dd><dd><b><em>MLA Handbook for Writers of Research Papers</em></b>
</dd><dd><b><em>Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association</em></b></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stylesheet"><b>style sheet</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the rules of spelling, <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a>, <a href="#usage">usage</a>, and <a href="#citation">citation</a> employed by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, to which an <a href="#author">author</a> who submits a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> for <a href="#publication">publication</a> is expected to conform.  In <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, adherence to <a href="#housestyle">house style</a> is usually checked by the <a href="#copyeditor">copy editor</a> in the process of <a href="#markup">marking up</a> a manuscript for the <a href="#printer">printer</a>.  Compare with <a href="#stylemanual">style manual</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="stylus"><b>stylus</b></a>
</dt><dd>The earliest known writing implement, consisting of a sharp,
pointed stick made of wood, bone, metal, or reed, usually with a small
flat spatula on the nonwriting end for making erasures, used in ancient
Mesopotamia to cut or impress straight, wedge-shaped <a href="#pictograph">pictograph</a>ic <a href="#character">character</a>s into the surface of <a href="#claytablet">clay tablet</a>s, and later by the ancient Greeks and Romans to write on wax tablets.  As clay gave way to <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a>, <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, and <a href="#paper">paper</a> as a writing surface, the stylus was replaced by brush, quill, and pen.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cuneiform">cuneiform</a>.
<p>
Also, a small electronic pen-shaped <a href="#device">device</a> used on <a href="#touchscreen">touch screen</a>s and in computer <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s <a href="#application">application</a>s to direct the <a href="#cursor">cursor</a>.  Also refers to the needle of a record player, which transmits mechanical vibrations from the surface of a <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a> to the cartridge where they are converted into electrical impulses amplified as audible sound.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subclass"><b>subclass</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#classification">classification</a>, a <a href="#class">class</a> of which each and every member is a member of another, usually more encompassing, class (<em>example</em>:  Periodical / Publication).  In <a href="#closeclassification">close classification</a>, subclasses are subdivided into sub-subclasses (Magazine / Periodical) and so on (News magazine / Magazine).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#crossclass">cross-classification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subcommittee"><b>subcommittee</b></a>
</dt><dd>Two or more members of a larger committee, elected or
appointed to address one or more specific issues or needs on behalf of
the larger group and report back in a timely manner. A subcommittee
that begins <em><a href="#adhoc">ad hoc</a></em> may eventually become permanent or develop into an independent committee. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subdirectory"><b>subdirectory</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#directory">directory</a>.

<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subdivision"><b>subdivision</b></a>
</dt><dd>A more <a href="#specificity">specific</a> aspect of a <a href="#class">class</a> or <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>, indicated by additional <a href="#notation">notation</a> or by a <a href="#subheading">subheading</a> following a <a href="#dash">dash</a> or some other mark of <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>History</em></b> in the <a href="#heading">heading</a> <b>Libraries--History</b>).  The most common varieties are <a href="#formsubdivision">form subdivision</a>s (<b>Libraries--Directories</b>), <a href="#geographic">geographic subdivision</a>s (<b>Libraries--United States</b>), and <a href="#periodsubdivision">period subdivision</a>s (<b>Libraries--United States--History--19th century</b>) .  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dividelike">divide-like note</a> and <a href="#standardsubdivision">standard subdivision</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subfield"><b>subfield</b></a>
</dt><dd>Because most <a href="#variablefield">variable field</a>s in the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> contain two or more related pieces of <a href="#information">information</a>, they are subdivided to allow each <a href="#element">element</a> of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> to be recorded separately.  A subfield contains the smallest logical unit of descriptive <a href="#data">data</a> pertaining to a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>.  Each subfield is preceded by a <a href="#delimiter">delimiter</a> (<b>$</b> for <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> or <a href="#doubledagger">double dagger</a> for <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a>) followed by a <a href="#subfieldcode">subfield code</a>, usually a <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>ic <a href="#character">character</a> although <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s are permitted.  For example, subfield <b>$c</b> of the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> (<a href="#field">field</a> 300) is reserved for the <a href="#dimensions">dimensions</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  Since the first subfield is <em>implicit</em> at the beginning of each field, the subfield code <b>$a</b> is not displayed. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subfieldcode"><b>subfield code</b></a>
</dt><dd>A one-<a href="#character">character</a> code used in the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> to indicate the portion of a <a href="#variablefield">variable field</a> reserved for a single <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a>, usually a <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>ic character (although <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s are permitted), preceded by a <a href="#delimiter">delimiter</a> sign, for example, <b>$c</b> to indicate <a href="#publicationdate">date of publication</a> in the <a href="#publicationarea">publication, distribution, etc.</a> <a href="#area">area</a> (<a href="#field">field</a> 260) of a <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> record.  Because the first <a href="#subfield">subfield</a> is <em>implicit</em> at the beginning of each field, the subfield code <b>$a</b> is not displayed.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subgenre"><b>subgenre</b></a>
</dt><dd>A subcategory of an existing class of <a href="#literature">literature</a> or art, which has its own distinguishing characteristics, for example, <a href="#detective">detective fiction</a> within the <a href="#mystery">mystery</a> <a href="#genre">genre</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subgroup"><b>subgroup</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#recordgroup">record group</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subhead"><b>subhead</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any secondary heading in a written <a href="#work">work</a>, intended to subdivide the <a href="#text">text</a> of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or other major division, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> in a smaller size of the <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> used for the main <a href="#heading">heading</a>.  In <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s and long <a href="#entry">entries</a> in <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s, subheads may be further subdivided into sub-subheads indicated by an even smaller <a href="#typesize">type size</a>.
Also spelled <em>sub-head</em>.  Compare with <a href="#subheading">subheading</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subheading"><b>subheading</b></a>
</dt><dd>A secondary <a href="#heading">heading</a> added to a main <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> in a <a href="#precoordinate">pre-coordinate indexing</a> system, usually following a <a href="#dash">dash</a> or some other mark of <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a>, to allow <a href="#document">document</a>s to be <a href="#indexing">indexed</a> more specifically.  Subheadings may be further <a href="#subdivision">subdivided</a>.  For example, in the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject heading</a> <b>United States--History--Civil War 1861-1864</b>, <em>United States</em> is the <a href="#mainheading">main heading</a>, <em>History</em> is the subheading, and <em>Civil War 1861 1864</em> the <em>sub-subheading</em>.  In a <a href="#printing">printed</a> list of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> terms, subheadings and sub-subheadings are <a href="#indention">indented</a> to visually represent the <a href="#hierarchicrelation">hierarchic relation</a>s between <a href="#term">term</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#subhead">subhead</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#formsubdivision">form subdivision</a>, <a href="#geographic">geographic subdivision</a>, <a href="#periodsubdivision">period subdivision</a>, and <a href="#standardsubdivision">standard subdivision</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subject"><b>subject</b></a>
</dt><dd>Any one of the <a href="#topic">topic</a>s or themes of a <a href="#work">work</a>, stated explicitly in the <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#title">title</a>, or implicit in its message.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is assigned one or more <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s as <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s, to assist users in locating its <a href="#content">content</a> by <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s, and in <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, the headings assigned to represent the content of a <a href="#document">document</a> are called <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s.  In a more general sense, any topic of study or discussion, or theme expressed in writing, painting, etc.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>subj</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#aboutness">aboutness</a> and <a href="#subjectanalysis">subject analysis</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the line in the <a href="#header">header</a> of an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> message consisting of a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>
provided by the sender to inform the addressee of its content. The
subject line appears, with the name of the sender, in the recipient's
list of incoming mail.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subjectanalysis"><b>subject analysis</b></a>
</dt><dd>Examination of a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> by a trained <a href="#subjectspecialist">subject specialist</a> to determine the most specific <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>(s) or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>(s) that fully describe its <a href="#content">content</a>, to serve in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> as <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s in a <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#search">search</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>, or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>.  When no applicable subject heading can be found in the existing headings list or <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">term</a>s, a new one must be created.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subjectbib"><b>subject bibliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of resources (<a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#report">report</a>s, etc.) on a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a>, usually <a href="#compile">compile</a>d by a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or <a href="#researcher">researcher</a> with <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> of the <a href="#subject">subject</a>, to acquaint other researchers with the existing <a href="#literature">literature</a>.  A <a href="#retrospective">retrospective</a> subject <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> may be <a href="#selective">selective</a> or <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> within a designated <a href="#publication">publication</a> period.  A <a href="#currency">current</a> subject bibliography quickly becomes <a href="#outdated">outdated</a> unless <a href="#updated">updated</a>, usually in <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>s.  <a href="#book">Book</a>-length subject bibliographies may be shelved in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of the <a href="#library">library</a>.  Compare with <a href="#readinglist">reading list</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#webliography">webliography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subjectcollec"><b>subject collection </b></a>
</dt><dd>An extensive <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> related to a particular <a href="#subject">subject</a> or group of closely related subjects, for example, the South Asia collection at the UC Berkeley Library or the collection on <a href="#printing">printing</a> history at the <a href="#newberrylib">Newberry Library</a> in Chicago.  Special <a href="#security">security</a> precautions may be taken to protect subject collections if they contain <a href="#rarity">rare</a> and/or valuable <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s.  For a list of subject emphases, as reported by <a href="#universitylib">university</a>, <a href="#collegelibrary">college</a>, <a href="#publiclibrary">public</a>, and <a href="#speciallibrary">special libraries</a> and museums in the United States and Canada, please see <b><em>Subject Collections</em></b>, a <a href="#directory">directory</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>.  Compare with <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subjectencyclopedia"><b>subject encyclopedia</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a> in one or more <a href="#volume">volume</a>s devoted to a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a>, <a href="#field">field</a> of study, or academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, as opposed to a <a href="#generalencyclopedia">general encyclopedia</a> containing <a href="#information">information</a> on a broad range of subjects.  <a href="#entry">Entries</a> in a subject encyclopedia are usually written and <a href="#signed">signed</a> by an expert on the topic and may include a brief <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>.  
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Examples</em>: 
<dl><dt></dt><dd><b><em>Encyclopedia of the Holocaust</em></b>
</dd><dd><b><em>Encyclopedia of U.S. Foreign Relations</em></b>
</dd><dd><b><em>Encyclopedia of Psychology</em></b>
</dd></dl></dd></dl> 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subjectheading"><b>subject heading</b></a>
</dt><dd>The most specific word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> that describes the <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or one of the subjects, of a <a href="#work">work</a>, selected from a list of <a href="#preferredterm">preferred term</a>s (<a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a> and assigned as an <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> to serve as an <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a> in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>.  A subject heading may be <a href="#subdivision">subdivided</a> by the addition of <a href="#subheading">subheading</a>s and sub-subheadings (<em>example</em>:  <b>Libraries--History--20th century</b>).  The use of <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s to indicate <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>s between subject headings is called <a href="#syndetic">syndetic structure</a>.   The process of examining the <a href="#content">content</a> of new <a href="#publication">publication</a>s and assigning appropriate subject headings is <a href="#subjectanalysis">subject analysis</a>.  In the United States, most libraries use <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject headings</a> (LCSH), but small libraries may use <a href="#sears">Sears subject heading</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#aboutness">aboutness</a> and <a href="#summarization">summarization</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subjectindex"><b>subject index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly arranged list of <a href="#heading">heading</a>s selected by an <a href="#indexing">indexer</a> to represent the <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#content">content</a> of one or more <a href="#work">work</a>s, with <a href="#locator">locator</a>s (usually <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s) to direct the user to the appropriate point in the <a href="#text">text</a>.  Names are usually included in the subject index, but in some <a href="#publication">publication</a>s there is a separate <a href="#nameindex">name index</a>, and possibly even a separate <a href="#geographicindex">geographic index</a> of place names.  The subject index is sometimes combined with the <a href="#authorindex">author index</a> in a single <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetic</a> sequence.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#titleindex">title index</a>.
<p>
Also refers to an <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly <a href="#arrangement">arranged</a> index to the <a href="#schedule">schedule</a>s of a <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, also called a <a href="#relativeindex">relative index</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subjectspecialist"><b>subject specialist</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> qualified by virtue of <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> and experience to <a href="#selection">select</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> and provide <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a> and <a href="#refservices">reference services</a> to users in a specific <a href="#subject">subject</a> area or academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> (or subdiscipline).  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, subject specialists often hold a second master's degree in their <a href="#field">field</a> of specialization.  Also refers to a librarian trained in <a href="#subjectanalysis">subject analysis</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="submeu"><b>submenu</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#menu">menu</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subordinatebody"><b>subordinate body</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a> integrally
related to a larger corporate entity on which it depends for its
existence and identity, for example, a subsidiary of a large commercial
corporation, or a <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  Compare with <a href="#relatedbody">related body</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subpage"><b>subpage</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> designed as part of a <a href="#website">Web site</a>, <a href="#link">link</a>ed to the site's <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> directly, or through one or more layers of pages linked to the main page.  In the <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a> (<a href="#url">URL</a>) <b>www.myuniversity.edu/library/hours.html</b>, the <a href="#directory">subdirectory</a> <b>/library</b> is added to the <a href="#internetaddress">address</a> of the main page (<b>www.myuniversity.edu</b>) to direct users to the subpage of the <a href="#universitylib">university library</a>, and the <a href="#filename">filename</a> <b>/hours.html</b> takes the user to the sub-subpage displaying <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#hours">hours</a>.  For convenience, a well-designed subpage should include a direct link back to the main page. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subplot"><b>subplot</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#literature">literature</a>, a second complete story with the main action of a <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#work">work</a>, sometimes involving the same or a related set of <a href="#character">character</a>s (<em>example</em>:  the Laertes subplot in Shakespeare's <b><em>Hamlet</em></b>).  More common in <a href="#comedy">comedy</a> than in <a href="#tragedy">tragedy</a>, a subplot may be used to reinforce the main <a href="#plot">plot</a> or as a counterpoint to it.  Complex <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s may have more than one subplot, intertwined for dramatic effect.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscriber"><b>subscriber</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person entitled to receive successive <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> for a prescribed period of time in exchange for payment of a <a href="#subscripprice">subscription fee</a>, payable in advance.  Also refers to a paying member of a <a href="#bookclub">book club</a> or <a href="#rentalcollec">rental library</a>, and to a person who receives <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#access">access</a> from an <a href="#internetservice">Internet service provider</a> (ISP).  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> that pay for <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#licensing">license</a>d <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s and individuals who sign on to receive <a href="#email">e-mail</a> messages from an electronic <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a> are also subscribers.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#subscribersedition">subscriber's edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscribersedition"><b>subscriber's edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of uncertain sales potential, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d only after a sufficient <a href="#number">number</a> of customers agree to purchase a <a href="#copy">copy</a>, usually in response to an announcement by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  The <a href="#work">work</a> may be <a href="#printing">printed</a> on a better grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a> and <a href="#binding">bound</a> more attractively than the <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>, with a list of <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s included.  Synonymous with <em>subscription work</em>.  Compare with <a href="#limitededition">limited edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscript"><b>subscript</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#character">character</a> written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> slightly below the line, usually a <a href="#numeral">numeral</a> or figure, as in a chemical formula.  Also refers to anything written or printed at the bottom of a <a href="#document">document</a>, such as a <a href="#signature">signature</a>.  Compare with <a href="#superscript">superscript</a>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscription"><b>subscription</b></a>
</dt><dd>The right to receive a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> for a designated period of time (or prescribed number of successive <a href="#issue">issue</a>s), upon payment of a subscription <a href="#fee">fee</a> payable in advance to the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> or <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agent</a>.  For <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, the period is usually one <a href="#calendaryear">calendar year</a> (January through December); for <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s and <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, it is one year from the date of the first issue received.  First-time <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s may be offered a heavily <a href="#discount">discount</a>ed <a href="#subscripprice">subscription price</a> as an inducement to subscribe.  Most subscriptions are delivered by post and <a href="#renew">renew</a>ed <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#differential">differential pricing</a>, <a href="#expirationdate">expiration date</a>, <a href="#fulfillmentyear">fulfillment year</a>, and <a href="#subscripcycle">subscription cycle</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the right of a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> to provide <a href="#access">access</a> to a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>, or other <a href="#online">online</a> resource, to its <a href="#patron">patron</a>s under <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a> with a <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>, upon payment of an annual <a href="#subscripprice">subscription price</a>, subject to <a href="#renewal">renewal</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscripagency"><b>subscription agency</b></a>
</dt><dd>A company in the business of providing centralized <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> services, to relieve <a href="#library">libraries</a> of the time-consuming task of dealing with <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s individually.  Customers are required to pay a <a href="#servicecharge">service charge</a>, usually 5-10% of total annual subscription cost.  Some subscription <a href="#agency">agencies</a> also provide <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic</a> and <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> <a href="#database">database</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ebsco">EBSCO</a> and <a href="#faxon">FAXON</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscripagent"><b>subscription agent</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agency</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscripcycle"><b>subscription cycle</b></a>
</dt><dd>The period of time for which a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> is sold, for <a href="#journal">journal</a>s usually one <a href="#calendaryear">calendar year</a>, beginning January 1 and ending December 31.  For <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s and <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, the period is usually one year from the date of the first <a href="#issue">issue</a> received.  <a href="#subscriber">Subscriber</a>s who <a href="#renew">renew</a> for more than one year may received a price break.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fulfillmentyear">fulfillment year</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscriptionlib"><b>subscription library</b></a>
</dt><dd>An early type of <a href="#library">library</a> first conceived by London <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s in the early 18th century, whose members paid annual <a href="#dues">dues</a> or a <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> <a href="#fee">fee</a> in exchange for the privilege of using <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a>
and services. Ownership was by the members acting as a single corporate
entity, not individually in shares. For a brief history of subscription
libraries, please see the <a href="#entry">entry</a> by Peter Hoare in the <b><em>International Encyclopedia of Information and Library Science</em></b> (New York:  Routledge, 1997).  Compare with <a href="#proprietarylib">proprietary library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscripprice"><b>subscription price</b></a>
</dt><dd>The amount charged by the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, or by a <a href="#subscripagency">subscription agent</a>, for the right to receive successive <a href="#issue">issue</a>s
for a prescribed period of time, usually one year. A financial
incentive may be offered to subscribe for two or more years. Some <a href="#journal">journal</a> publishers charge <a href="#library">libraries</a> a substantially higher price than the rate paid by individual <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s (see <a href="#differential">differential pricing</a>).  In recent years, relentless price increases for journal <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>s have forced <a href="#serialcancel">cancellation</a>s on most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>.  Also refers to the annual amount charged by a <a href="#vendor">vendor</a> for <a href="#access">access</a> to an electronic <a href="#database">database</a>, usually based on size of <a href="#library">library</a>, <a href="#fte">FTE</a>, and/or <a href="#number">number</a> of <a href="#simultaneous">simultaneous user</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>subscription rate</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscriprate"><b>subscription rate</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#subscripprice">subscription price</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscriptionterms"><b>subscription terms</b></a>
</dt><dd>Terms under which a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> offers a <a href="#discount">discount</a> of up to 35% on the <a href="#publishedprice">published price</a> of general interest <a href="#title">title</a>s ordered prior to first <a href="#publication">publication</a>, to compensate for the risk taken by the <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a> in purchasing stock before sales potential has been adequately tested in the market place.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subscriptionwork"><b>subscription work</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#subscribersedition">subscriber's edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subseries"><b>subseries</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#series">series</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in conjunction with another series (usually more encompassing), under a <a href="#series">series title</a> which may or may not be independent of the title of the more <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> series. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subset"><b>subset</b></a>
</dt><dd>In logic, a <a href="#set">set</a> in which each and every entity is also an entity of another, usually more encompassing, set (<em>example</em>:  Magazine / Periodical).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subsidiaries"><b>subsidiaries</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subsidiaryrights"><b>subsidiary rights</b></a>
</dt><dd>Under <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law, the <a href="#rights">rights</a> to <a href="#publishing">publish</a> a <a href="#work">work</a> in a form other than the <a href="#original">original</a>, for example, in <a href="#installment">installment</a>s in a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>; as a work included in a <a href="#collection">collection</a> or  <a href="#anthology">anthology</a>; as an <a href="#adaptation">adaptation</a> for performance as a <a href="#play">play</a>, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, or television program; or as an <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>, <a href="#digest">digest</a>, <a href="#translation">translation</a>, <a href="#excerpt">excerpt</a>, or <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>.  Subsidiary rights also include control over commercial exploitation and <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> not covered under <a href="#fairuse">fair use</a>.  Subject to formal agreement between <a href="#author">author</a> and <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, they can be sold or transferred by the person or corporate entity owning them.  Compare with <a href="#volumerights">volume rights</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="salis"><b>Substance Abuse Librarians &amp; Information Specialists (SALIS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Created in 1978 with assistance from the U.S. National
Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) and the National Institute on Alcohol
Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA), <b>SALIS</b> is an international <a href="#association">association</a> of individuals and organizations interested in the exchange and dissemination of objective, accurate <a href="#information">information</a> about the abuse of alcohol, tobacco, and other drugs.  In 1986, <b>SALIS</b>
merged with its Canadian counterpart, Librarians and Information
Specialists in Addictions (LISA), and in 1989 the organization became
an affiliate of the International Council on Alcohol and Addictions
(ICAA). <a href="http://www.salis.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>SALIS</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subtext"><b>subtext</b></a>
</dt><dd>In a <a href="#work">work</a> of <a href="#literature">literature</a>, an implicit meaning or significance, usually on another level of understanding than the explicit meaning of the <a href="#text">text</a>.  In contemporary dramatic performance, an actor's interpretation of the inner motives and emotional state of a <a href="#character">character</a>, evident from the implied meaning of the lines spoken.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="subtitle"><b>subtitle</b></a>
</dt><dd>A secondary portion of the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, consisting of an explanatory or limiting <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> following a colon or semicolon, often beginning with "a" or "an."  In the title <b><em>New York:  A Documentary Film</em></b>, the phrase <em>A Documentary Film</em> is the subtitle.  On the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, the subtitle is usually <a href="#typesetting">set</a> in smaller <a href="#type">type</a> than the first part of the <a href="#title">title</a>.  The subtitle is often omitted from the <a href="#spinetitle">spine title</a>.  Compare with <a href="#alternativetitle">alternative title</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#partialtitle">partial title</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a line of <a href="#text">text</a> along the bottom of a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> or television screen giving the <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a> or <a href="#narration">narration</a> in a <a href="#language">language</a> other than that of the <a href="#soundtrack">sound track</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sudocs"><b>SuDocs</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for the <em><b>Su</b>perintendent of <b>Doc</b>ument<b>s</b></em> <a href="#classification">classification</a>.  <a href="#publication">Publication</a>s of the U.S. federal government are assigned <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>s based on a unique <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> developed between 1893 and 1903 by GPO <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> Adeliade Hasse, currently maintained by the <a href="#superintendent">Superintendent of Documents</a> at the <a href="#gpo">U.S. Government Printing Office</a>.  <b>SuDocs</b> call numbers begin with <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of the roman <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>.  
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example:</em>  <b>J 29.9/6:998</b> assigned to the 1998 <a href="#edition">edition</a> of <em>Sourcebook of Criminal Justice Statistics</em></dd></dl>
<p>
<a href="#library">Libraries</a> that use <b>SuDocs</b> numbers shelve <a href="#govdocs">government document</a>s in a separate location.  Those that use <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress Classification</a> or <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> for govdocs usually shelve them in <a href="#refcollection">reference</a> or with the general <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="suggestionbox"><b>suggestion box</b></a>
</dt><dd>Some <a href="#library">libraries</a> in the United States provide a means for <a href="#patron">patron</a>s to suggest improvements in services, request the purchase of a specific <a href="#bibitem">item</a>,
or comment on library policies and practices in writing on a slip of
paper deposited it in a small box provided for the purpose near the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a>, <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>, or main entrance.  Some <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and library <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s allow users to post suggestions and comments electronically.  The responses of <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> and <a href="#libadmin">administration</a> may be posted on a public <a href="#bulletinboard">bulletin board</a> or <a href="#kiosk">kiosk</a>, or in a special section of the library <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="summarization"><b>summarization</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, a brief statement of the overall <a href="#subject">subject</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, that serves as the the basis for assigning one or more <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s as <a href="#accesspoint">access point</a>s in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, to facilitate <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieval</a> by subject.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#aboutness">aboutness</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="summary"><b>summary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A brief statement expressing the general substance or overall idea of a <a href="#work">work</a> (or a portion of it), recapitulating its main points, findings, and conclusions, usually given at the end.  Compare with <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#synopsis">synopsis</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a brief statement added as a <a href="#note">note</a> in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> to describe the <a href="#content">content</a> of a <a href="#nonbook">nonbook</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> produced in a <a href="#format">format</a> difficult to <a href="#browse">browse</a>. 
</p><p>
In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, a list of the main <a href="#subdivision">subdivision</a>s of a <a href="#class">class</a>, <a href="#printing">printed</a> in the <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a>s immediately following the entry for the class.  Summaries for the entire Classification (<a href="#mainclass">main class</a>es, <a href="#division">division</a>s, and <a href="#section">section</a>s) are given at the beginning of the schedules.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="summerreading"><b>summer reading program</b></a>
</dt><dd>A program offered during the summer months by the <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> of the <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a> of most <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>
in the United States, to keep children reading during the long
vacation. Usually organized around a theme, summer reading programs
sometimes include special events such as contests and <a href="#readathon">read-a-thon</a>s to encourage young <a href="#reader">reader</a>s to practice their reading skills.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#readingrainbow">Reading Rainbow</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sundaysupplement"><b>Sunday supplement</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> of <a href="#tabloid">tabloid</a> size <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#regular">regular</a>ly as part of a Sunday <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, usually in color (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Parade</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sunkbands"><b>sunk bands</b></a>
</dt><dd>On a <a href="#handbinding">hand-bound</a> <a href="#book">book</a>, cords or <a href="#bands">bands</a> recessed by the <a href="#binder">binder</a> in grooves cut across the <a href="#back">back</a> of the <a href="#section">section</a>s to eliminate the ridges produced by <a href="#raisedbands">raised bands</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="sunned"><b>sunned</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> that has a <a href="#cover">cover</a>, <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>, or <a href="#page">page</a>s faded or discolored from prolonged exposure to direct sunlight or some other strong light source, a <a href="#condition">condition</a> that affects its value in the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> and <a href="#usedbook">used book</a> market.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="super"><b>super</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#crash">crash</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="supercomputer"><b>supercomputer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A very large, fast computer capable of executing millions of instructions per second, used mainly by <a href="#govtagency">government agencies</a>, such as the U.S. Department of Defense, and major <a href="#research">research</a> centers at large universities that <a href="#dataprocessing">process</a> large quantities of <a href="#data">data</a>.  Compare with <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a>, <a href="#minicomputer">minicomputer</a>, and <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="superfiche"><b>superfiche</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of transparent <a href="#microform">microform</a> in the shape of a card, with a <a href="#reductionratio">reduction ratio</a> greater than standard <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> (up to 400 images per 4 x 6-inch <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>, instead of the usual 48-60 images) but less than <a href="#ultrafiche">ultrafiche</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="superimposition"><b>superimposition</b></a>
</dt><dd>The principle in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> that when new rules are introduced, only <a href="#entry">entries</a> made <em>after</em> the rules take effect will conform to the changes, making it unnecessary to <a href="#recataloging">recatalog</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> <a href="#technical">processed</a> under the old rules.  Following <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> practice, the principle was adopted by libraries throughout the United States in 1967 when the <em><a href="#anglo">Anglo-American Cataloging Rules</a></em> were adopted as the national <a href="#catalogcode">catalog code</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="superintendent"><b>Superintendent of Documents</b></a>
</dt><dd>The official at the <a href="#gpo">U.S. Government Printing Office</a> responsible for the distribution of federal government <a href="#information">information</a> to the American public, in both <a href="#print">print</a> and <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fdlp">Federal Depository Library Program</a> and <em><a href="#gpoaccess">GPO Access</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="superiornumeral"><b>superior numeral</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#superscript">superscript</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="supers"><b>supers</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> and television production, any <a href="#lettering">lettering</a> or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s superimposed on existing <a href="#footage">footage</a> (<a href="#credit">credit</a>s, <a href="#subtitle">subtitle</a>s, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="superscript"><b>superscript</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#character">character</a> written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> slightly above the line, for example, a superior <a href="#numeral">numeral</a> used to indicate a <a href="#footnote">footnote</a> or <a href="#endnote">endnote</a>.  Compare with <a href="#subscript">subscript</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#refmark">reference mark</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="superscription"><b>superscription</b></a>
</dt><dd>Something written, <a href="#printing">printed</a>, or
engraved at the top or on the outside surface of an object, especially
a name and/or address on the outside of an envelope or parcel.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="superseded"><b>superseded</b></a>
</dt><dd>Something old or <a href="#outdated">outdated</a>, replaced by something more modern or <a href="#currency">current</a>.  In <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s, superseded <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s may be <a href="#retention">retained</a> if they have historical value, for example, older <a href="#edition">edition</a>s of <a href="#almanac">almanac</a>s and statistical <a href="#publication">publication</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="supervision"><b>supervision</b></a>
</dt><dd>Responsibility for overseeing the performance of one or more
persons or machines to ensure that work assignments are properly and
efficiently completed. A person with the authority to <em>supervise</em> is called a <em>supervisor</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="supplement"><b>supplement</b></a>
</dt><dd>Additional <a href="#matter">matter</a>, more extensive than an <a href="#addendum">addendum</a>, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d under separate <a href="#cover">cover</a> and <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, for the stated purpose of complementing a previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#work">work</a>, usually to clarify, continue, expand, or <a href="#update">update</a> it, or to add a special feature not previously included (<a href="#map">map</a>s, statistics, <a href="#directory">directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a>, etc.), usually written by the original <a href="#author">author</a> and published under the same <a href="#title">title</a>.  When available as part of the original purchase price, supplements are usually sent automatically.  In a subsequent <a href="#edition">edition</a>, supplementary material may be included immediately following the original <a href="#text">text</a> or as an <a href="#appendix">appendix</a>.  Most <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es are updated in <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> or <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#paperback">paperbound</a> supplements, <a href="#cumulativeindex">cumulated</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>supp</em>.  Compare with <a href="#continuation">continuation</a>. 
<p>
In <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, an extra <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>, <a href="#section">section</a>, or entire <a href="#issue">issue</a> in addition to the regular issue, usually containing special items of interest to <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#colorsupplement">color supplement</a> and <a href="#sundaysupplement">Sunday supplement</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="suppliedtitle"><b>supplied title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> provided by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> lacking a <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> on the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a> (<a href="#titlepage">title page</a> or a substitute).  A supplied title may be 1) a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> found elsewhere in or on the item, 2) taken from a <a href="#reference">reference</a> to the <a href="#work">work</a> found in another <a href="#source">source</a>, or 3) composed by the cataloger based on an assessment of the <a href="#scope">scope</a> and <a href="#content">content</a> of the work. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="supplier"><b>supplier</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> or other participant in the <a href="#oclcill">OCLC Interlibrary Loan</a> <a href="#network">network</a> that responds to <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> requests from other libraries to borrow <a href="#returnable">returnable</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>.  In the OCLC <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>, the three-<a href="#letter">letter</a> <a href="#oclcsymbol">OCLC symbol</a>s of suppliers appear in <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a> in the <a href="#holdingsdisplay">holdings display</a> attached to the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  If the symbol is preceded by a <b>$</b>, the institution may charge for the loan of certain types of materials.  Compare with <a href="#nonsupplier">nonsupplier</a>. 
<p>
Also refers to a commercial enterprise in the business of selling <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, furnishings, and/or <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a> to libraries and related institutions.  Some supply companies provide other services in support of <a href="#technical">technical processing</a>.  Compare with <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>.  <a href="http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/Libweb/comp.html">Click here</a> to view the <em><a href="#libweb">Libweb</a></em> list of <a href="#link">link</a>s to library-related companies in the United States.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="supportstaff"><b>support staff</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#librarystaff">Library staff</a> members not trained as <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, who have acquired a technical understanding of <a href="#library">library</a> practices and procedures, and contribute on a daily basis to the smooth <a href="#operations">operation</a> of a library, but are not <a href="#qualification">qualified</a> to make policy decisions or participate in other activities of a professional nature.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#paraprofessional">paraprofessional</a> and <a href="#ssirt">Support Staff Interests Round Table</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ssirt"><b>Support Staff Interests Round Table (SSIRT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A permanent <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>SSIRT</b> provides a forum for addressing issues of concern to <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#supportstaff">support staff</a> such as training and <a href="#continuinged">continuing education</a>, career development, job responsibilities, and compensation. <a href="http://www.ala.org/ssirt/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>SSIRT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#paraprofessional">paraprofessional</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="supposedauthor"><b>supposed author</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#attributedauthor">attributed author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="suppositious"><b>suppositious author</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person whose name is substituted for that of the real <a href="#author">author</a>, with intent to deceive others concerning responsibility for the <a href="#work">work</a>.  Compare with <a href="#attributedauthor">attributed author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="suppressed"><b>suppressed</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> or part of a work withheld or withdrawn from <a href="#publication">publication</a> or circulation by the <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>,
by an ecclesiastic or government authority, or by court action, usually
because it contains material considered objectionable by those with the
authority to prevent public distribution. <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#banned">banned book</a> and <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> <a href="#cancel">cancel</a>led from a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> due to an error or for some other technical reason. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="surf"><b>surf</b></a>
</dt><dd>To <a href="#navigation">navigate</a> the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a> in an exploratory manner, moving from one <a href="#document">document</a> to another, using <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>s, <a href="#webindex">Web index</a>es, <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#link">link</a>s, <a href="#navigationbar">navigation bar</a>s, <a href="#icon">icon</a>s, etc., with no definite purpose in mind.  A person who navigates in such a way is called a <em>surfer</em>.  Compare with <a href="#browse">browse</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="surname"><b>surname </b></a>
</dt><dd>A shared name that identifies members of the same family (<em>example</em>:  <b>Patterson</b>), as distinct from a <a href="#givenname">given name</a> (<em>example</em>: <b>Samantha</b>)
which may be the same as that of a close or distant relative, but is
also likely to be shared with persons outside the family. In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#entry">entries</a> begin with the surname, and form of name is subject to <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>.  Synonymous with <em>last name</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#compoundsurname">compound surname</a> and <a href="#patronymic">patronymic</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="surrogate"><b>surrogate</b></a>
</dt><dd>A substitute used in place of an <a href="#original">original</a> item, for example, a <a href="#facsimile">facsimile</a> or <a href="#photocopy">photocopy</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a> too <a href="#rarity">rare</a> or fragile to be handled by <a href="#library">library</a> users, or an <a href="#abstract">abstract</a> or <a href="#summary">summary</a> that provides desired <a href="#information">information</a> without requiring the <a href="#reader">reader</a> to examine the entire <a href="#document">document</a>.  In <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, a surrogate is usually made in more <a href="#durability">durable</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a>.  In a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, the <a href="#bibdescrip">description</a> provided in the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> serves as a surrogate for the actual physical <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="survey"><b>survey</b></a> 
</dt><dd>A scientifically conducted study, or account of a study, in which <a href="#data">data</a>
is systematically collected from a selected group of sources or
informants, usually concerning general conditions, practices, habits,
preferences, etc. (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Survey of Academic Libraries</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 2002 by the Primary Research Group).  The statistical results of survey <a href="#research">research</a> are usually presented in <a href="#graph">graph</a>ic, <a href="#table">tabular</a>, or <a href="#summary">summary</a> form.  Also refers to a brief overview of the main aspects of a <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#field">field</a> of study (<b><em>The Death Penalty: A Historical and Theological Survey</em></b> by James Megivern).  Compare with <a href="#questionnaire">questionnaire</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#usersurvey">user survey</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="suspense"><b>suspense</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#literature">literature</a> and <a href="#film">film</a>, a <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> that keeps its <a href="#reader">reader</a>, viewer, or listener in a state of heightened mental and emotional uncertainty about the outcome (<em>example</em>:  the French film <b><em>Diabolique</em></b>), or about how one or more <a href="#character">character</a>s will respond to the discovery of a fact known only to the reader or <a href="#audience">audience</a>.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>thriller</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#espionage">espionage</a> and <a href="#mystery">mystery</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="svga"><b>SVGA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>S</b>uper <b>V</b>ideo <b>G</b>raphics <b>A</b>rray, an enhancement of the standard 640 x 480 <a href="#vga">VGA</a> <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s display system, capable of producing screen <a href="#resolution">resolution</a>s of 800 x 600 <a href="#pixel">pixel</a>s with up to 16 million colors.  A further enhancement called XVGA increases resolution to 1024 x 768 pixels. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="swashletter"><b>swash letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>An ornamental <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a> written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> in <a href="#italic">italic</a> with at least one long tail or <a href="#flourish">flourish</a> added for dramatic effect, used mainly in display work.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="swell"><b>swell</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, unwanted <a href="#bulk">bulk</a> at the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> caused by the accumulation of <a href="#thread">thread</a> used in <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> or by excessive <a href="#guard">guard</a>ing.  Although some swell is desirable to facilitate <a href="#rounding">rounding</a> and <a href="#backing">backing</a>, in <a href="#book">book</a>s composed of numerous thin sections, additional thickness may impede subsequent <a href="#binding">binding</a> procedures.  If the <a href="#paper">paper</a> used to <a href="#printing">print</a> the text block is soft, the <a href="#spine">spine</a> can normally be compacted by smashing or <a href="#nipping">nipping</a>,
an operation that embeds the sewing threads in the paper, but with hard
papers, pressure on the threads may cut the paper. Swell can be reduced
in <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a> by sewing the sections <a href="#twoon">two-on</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="syllabication"><b>syllabication</b></a>
</dt><dd>The division of a word into units of pronunciation (syllables), indicated in standard <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a> by a centered <a href="#period">period</a> or a <a href="#hyphen">hyphen</a> to help writers, <a href="#editor">editor</a>s, and secretaries divide words at the end of a line.  Most <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#software">software</a> has a feature that accomplishes this automatically.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="syllabus"><b>syllabus</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#outline">outline</a> of the <a href="#topic">topic</a>s
to be covered in a formal course of study, given in the order in which
they are to be discussed in class, with any assignments and related
readings also indicated. Some college and university faculty make their
<em>syllabi</em> available <a href="#online">online</a>, usually on the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>, or place <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#copy">copies</a> on <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> at the <a href="#academiclib">library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="symbol"><b>symbol</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#character">character</a>, image, mark, shape, or
thing used to represent or denote something else by association,
convention, or unintended resemblance, especially an intangible quality
or abstraction (<em>example</em>: the heart or rose for "love" or the
skull-and-crossbones for "death"). When words are used to create such
an image, the result is <em>symbolic <a href="#language">language</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="symposium"><b>symposium</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of experts gathered together to discuss a <a href="#topic">topic</a> (or topics) of mutual interest, often of a theoretical or philosophical nature, as in Plato's <em>Symposium</em>.
In ancient Greece, music and drinking were traditional accompaniments
at such gatherings, which were restricted to males of the household.
Plural: <em>symposia</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="syndeticindex"><b>syndetic index</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#syndetic">syndetic structure</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="syndetic"><b>syndetic structure</b></a>
</dt><dd>The web of interconnected and reciprocal <em><a href="#see">see</a></em> and <em><a href="#seealso">see also</a></em> <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s indicating the <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>s between <a href="#heading">heading</a>s used in a <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, or <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>, or between <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s used in an <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>.  This <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> has syndetic structure.  The opposite of <a href="#asyndetic">asyndetic</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="syndicate"><b>syndicate</b></a>
</dt><dd>A company in the business of distributing <a href="#column">column</a>s, <a href="#cartoon">cartoon</a>s, and <a href="#feature">feature</a> <a href="#article">article</a>s to <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a>s, <a href="#newsservice">news service</a>s, and <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> <a href="#media">media</a>.  A <a href="#columnist">columnist</a> whose <a href="#work">work</a> is marketed in this way is known as a <em>syndicated columnist</em>.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> for syndicates is available in the <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a>s <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em> and <em><a href="#writersmarket">Writer's Market</a></em>, available in most large <a href="#library">libraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="synonym"><b>synonym</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> that has the same (or very nearly the same) meaning as another <a href="#term">term</a> in the same <a href="#language">language</a> (<em>example</em>:  "book jacket" and "dust jacket").  Synonyms in a language are collected in a <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a>, available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  In the <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>s used in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s, <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es, <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting services</a>, and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, synonyms are <a href="#controlled">controlled</a> by establishing an authorized list of <a href="#preferredterm">preferred</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">term</a>s (<a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s).  In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, the <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> <b>OR</b> command is used to expand the results of a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> <a href="#search">search</a> by including synonyms and closely <a href="#relatedterm">related term</a>s.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>syn</em>.  The opposite of <a href="#antonym">antonym</a>.  Compare with <a href="#quasisynonym">quasi-synonym</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#homonym">homonym</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="synopsis"><b>synopsis</b></a>
</dt><dd>A concise written description of the <a href="#plot">plot</a> of a long <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#work">work</a> (<a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>, opera, <a href="#epic">epic</a> <a href="#poetry">poem</a>, etc.), giving a quick, orderly overview of the whole, usually prepared by a person other than the <a href="#author">author</a>.  As a general rule, <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> do not purchase <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s that specialize in providing <em>synopses</em> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Masterplots</em></b>) because they are too easily used by students to avoid reading assignments.
