Synonymous with <em>plot summary</em>.  Compare with <a href="#abstract">abstract</a> and <a href="#summary">summary</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="synoptic"><b>synoptic journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#journal">journal</a> that <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> brief <a href="#report">report</a>s of <a href="#research">research</a> findings and <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>s of <a href="#article">article</a>s for which the entire <a href="#text">text</a> is available on request, usually from a <a href="#databank">data bank</a> or in a <a href="#microform">microform</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the <a href="#publication">publication</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="syntax"><b>syntax</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <em>order</em> in which <a href="#searchterm">search term</a>s and <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> operators in a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a> are typed, determining the sequence in which a computer-based <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a> system executes the <a href="#search">search</a>.  In most <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, commands are executed from left to right unless <a href="#parenthesis">parentheses</a> are used to indicate otherwise (a technique called <a href="#nesting">nesting</a>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#proximity">proximity</a> and <a href="#truncation">truncation</a>.
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>: <b>children and television and (violence or aggression)</b>
<dl><dt></dt><dd>In this search statement, the Boolean "or" command will be performed before the "and."</dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, the rules that determine how <a href="#heading">heading</a>s are constructed and how <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>s among <a href="#term">term</a>s are indicated in an <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>, for example, the conditions under which a <a href="#parenthetical">parenthetical qualifier</a> is added to a heading, or an <a href="#invertedheading">inverted heading</a> is used instead of conventional word order.
</p><p>
Also refers to the grammar and sentence structure of a <a href="#language">language</a>, and to the branch of linguistics devoted to its study.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="syntheticclass"><b>synthetic classification</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> in which the <a href="#class">class</a>es are formed by combining <a href="#characteristic">characteristic</a>s or <a href="#facet">facet</a>s of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s according to a pre-established set of rules (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#colonclassification">Colon Classification</a> developed by <a href="#ranganathan">S. R. Ranganathan</a>).  Compare with <a href="#enumerativeclass">enumerative classification</a> and <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical classification</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="systems"><b>systems</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the computer <a href="#hardware">hardware</a>, <a href="#software">software</a>, and electronic resources on which a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> depends in its daily <a href="#operations">operations</a>, including the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> and <a href="#circulationsystem">circulation system</a>, <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, networked and <a href="#standalone">stand-alone</a> <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a>s, <a href="#webserver">Web server</a>(s), <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s, etc.  It is the responsibility of the <a href="#systemslibrarian">systems librarian</a> to keep the various components running smoothly, including any connections to outside <a href="#network">network</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="systemslibrarian"><b>systems librarian</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> whose primary responsibility is the development and maintenance of the <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> and <a href="#software">software</a> systems used in a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, especially the <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> and <a href="#access">access</a> to any <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s and other electronic resources.  In some libraries, the systems librarian may also serve as <a href="#webmaster">Webmaster</a> and be responsible for training <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> members in the use of library <a href="#systems">systems</a>.  Systems librarians are organized in the <a href="#lita">Library and Information Technology Association</a> (LITA), a division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="systemsupplied"><b>system-supplied (SS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Under <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <a href="#inputstandards">input standards</a>, <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> <a href="#data">data</a> generated by the cataloging system itself, which cannot be altered by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>, for example, the <a href="#oclccontrol">OCLC control number</a> and the date a <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> is entered into the system, <a href="#element">element</a>s of the <a href="#leader">leader</a> in the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>
<center>| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> | <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a>
| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="T">T</a></font></h1>
<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="t1"><b>T1</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> introduced by AT&amp;T to refer to a <a href="#dedicatedline">dedicated</a> <a href="#digital">digital</a> circuit provided by the telephone companies, capable of transmitting <a href="#data">data</a> point-to-point at the rate of 1.544 Mbps (mega<a href="#bit">bit</a>s
per second), containing 24 individual channels, each capable of
transmitting voice or data at the rate of 64 Kbps (kilobits per
second). Individuals may purchase one of these channels in an
arrangement known as <em>fractional T1</em> <a href="#access">access</a>.  Businesses and academic institutions lease T1 lines to connect to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> and may also use them for <a href="#localarea">local area network</a>s.  The monthly charge is usually determined by distance.  T1 lines are also used by <a href="#internetservice">Internet service provider</a>s to provide Internet <a href="#access">access</a> to individuals and small businesses.  The Internet <a href="#backbone">backbone</a> is constructed of higher speed <a href="#t3">T3</a> lines.  Synonymous with <em>DS1</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bandwidth">bandwidth</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="t3"><b>T3</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> introduced by AT&amp;T to refer to a <a href="#dedicatedline">dedicated</a> <a href="#digital">digital</a> circuit provided by the telephone companies, capable of transmitting <a href="#data">data</a> point-to-point at the rate of 44.736 Mbps (mega<a href="#bit">bit</a>s per second), used mainly by <a href="#internetservice">Internet service provider</a>s to connect to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#backbone">backbone</a>
and for the backbone itself. A T3 line contains 672 individual
channels, each capable of transmitting 64 Kbps (kilobits per second).
Synonymous with <em>DS3</em>.  Compare with <a href="#t1">T1</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bandwidth">bandwidth</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tab"><b>tab</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> a small piece of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, card, or fabric attached to the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, stamped or <a href="#printing">printed</a> with <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, words, <a href="#number">number</a>s, or other <a href="#character">character</a>s indicating the <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetic</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>, numeric, or other arrangement of the <a href="#text">text</a>, to facilitate reference.  Also refers to a projecting part of a card, <a href="#folder">folder</a>, divider, etc., large enough to bear a <a href="#label">label</a> concerning contents, used in filing and retrieval.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tabindex"><b>tab index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of small projections called <a href="#tab">tab</a>s extending from the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> like a series of steps, bearing a sequence of <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, <a href="#number">number</a>s, or other <a href="#character">character</a>s, sometimes <a href="#printing">printed</a> against a dark background, to show the <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetic</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>, numeric, or other arrangement of the <a href="#text">text</a> for rapid reference.  Compare with <a href="#stepindex">step index</a> and <a href="#thumbindex">thumb index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="table"><b>table</b></a>
</dt><dd>A compact, systematic list of <a href="#data">data</a>, as in a <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a> listing the <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>s or major divisions of a <a href="#book">book</a>.  Also refers to the compact arrangement of facts, figures, or other <a href="#data">data</a> in vertical rows and columns to facilitate comparison, usually with a title across the top or an explanatory <a href="#caption">caption</a> or <a href="#note">note</a> written or <a href="#printing">printed</a> underneath.  In books containing <a href="#information">information</a> in tabular <a href="#format">format</a>, a list of tables is usually provided in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> with <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s as <a href="#locator">locator</a>s.  Some statistical <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s consist entirely of tables (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Statistical Abstract of the United States</em></b>).
<p>
In <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a>, one of seven <a href="#auxiliaryschedule">auxiliary schedule</a>s containing numbers representing geographic concepts, literary forms, <a href="#language">language</a>s, ethnic and other groups, and <a href="#standardsubdivision">standard subdivision</a>s which may be added in <a href="#numberbuilding">number building</a> to other <a href="#notation">notation</a> in the <a href="#classificationschedule">schedule</a>s to form a <a href="#classnumber">class number</a> appropriate to the <a href="#content">content</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>.  Also, one of the small sets of tabulated numbers included in <a href="#addnote">add note</a>s under specific <a href="#class">class</a> numbers throughout the <a href="#mainschedule">main schedule</a>s of DDC.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tablebook"><b>table book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A luxurious <a href="#edition">edition</a>, usually <a href="#cover">cover</a>ed
in silk or velvet, intended for display in the private drawing rooms of
wealthy people of the 19th century. Its modern counterpart is the <a href="#coffee">coffee table book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tableofcontents"><b>table of contents (TOC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the <a href="#contents">contents</a> of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> in the order of their appearance, usually with <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s as <a href="#locator">locator</a>s.  In a <a href="#book">book</a>, the TOC lists the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>, <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>s or other major divisions of the <a href="#work">work</a>, and the <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>.  In an <a href="#anthology">anthology</a> or <a href="#collection">collection</a>, the TOC lists the <a href="#title">title</a>s of the <a href="#work">work</a>s included by the <a href="#editor">editor</a>(s) (<a href="#shortstory">stories</a>, <a href="#poetry">poems</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>s, <a href="#essay">essay</a>s, etc.), in order of appearance.  In books, the TOC is <a href="#printing">printed</a> in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> on the first <a href="#recto">recto</a> following the <a href="#dedication">dedication</a> or <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.  In <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s, the TOC appears near the front of each <a href="#issue">issue</a> or on the back <a href="#cover">cover</a>, listing the <a href="#editorialcontent">editorial content</a> (<a href="#article">article</a>s, <a href="#column">column</a>s, <a href="#review">review</a>s, etc.), but not any advertising.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#currentcontents">current contents</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tabloid"><b>tabloid</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> in a <a href="#format">format</a> half the size of an ordinary <a href="#broadsheet">broadsheet</a> newspaper, containing short news stories of a highly sensational and improbable nature, abundantly <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> (usually with <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s), sold mainly at newsstands and in supermarkets.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#yellowpress">yellow press</a>.
<p>
Also refers to an advertising <a href="#preprint">preprint</a> of 4 or more <a href="#page">page</a>s, normally one-half the size of the <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> into which it is <a href="#insert">insert</a>ed.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tactilematerials"><b>tactile materials</b></a>
</dt><dd>Reading materials in which the <a href="#text">text</a> is provided as a series of raised <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s, as in <a href="#braille">braille</a>, or in surfaces of different texture, for the use of visually impaired persons.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nls">National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tag"><b>tag</b></a>
</dt><dd>A three-<a href="#character">character</a> numeric code in the range of 0XX-9XX with XX=01-99, used in the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> record to identify the kind of <a href="#data">data</a> contained in a <a href="#field">field</a>.  The <a href="#number">number</a>ing system allows fields to be <a href="#taggroup">group</a>ed by function in hundreds.  In fields requiring <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>, the second and third character positions in the tag indicate <a href="#parallelcontent">parallel content</a>.  According to Betty Furrie, approximately ten percent of all MARC tags are used in most <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s; the other ninety percent are used infrequently (<em><a href="http://www.loc.gov/marc/umb/">Understanding MARC Bibliographic Machine-Readable Cataloging</a></em>).  For <a href="#book">book</a>s, the most frequently used tags are:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>010 tag</b> - <a href="#lccn">Library of Congress Control Number</a> (LCCN)
</dd><dd><b>020 tag</b> - <a href="#isbn">International Standard Book Number</a> (ISBN) and <a href="#termsof">terms of availability</a>
</dd><dd><b>040 tag</b> - <a href="#catsource">cataloging source</a>
</dd><dd><b>050 tag</b> - <a href="#lcclassification">Library of Congress</a> <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>
</dd><dd><b>100 tag</b> - <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#mainentry">main  entry</a> (<a href="#primaryauthor">primary author</a>)
</dd><dd><b>130 tag</b> - <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a> <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a>
</dd><dd><b>240 tag</b> - <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a>
</dd><dd><b>245 tag</b> - <a href="#titleand">title and statement of responsibility</a> (<a href="#titleproper">title proper</a>, name of <a href="#part">part</a>/section of <a href="#work">work</a>, remainder of title, etc.)
</dd><dd><b>246 tag</b> - varying form of <a href="#title">title</a> (<a href="#covertitle">cover title</a>, <a href="#paralleltitle">parallel title</a>, <a href="#spinetitle">spine title</a>, portion of title)
</dd><dd><b>250 tag</b> - <a href="#edition">edition</a> (<a href="#editionstatement">edition statement</a>, other <a href="#information">information</a> about edition)
</dd><dd><b>260 tag</b> - <a href="#publicationarea">publication, distribution, etc.</a> (<a href="#imprint">imprint</a>)
</dd><dd><b>300 tag</b> - <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> (<a href="#collation">collation</a>)
</dd><dd><b>440 tag</b> - <a href="#seriesstatement">series statement</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> (title) 
</dd><dd><b>500 tag</b> - general <a href="#note">note</a>
</dd><dd><b>504 tag</b> - <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a> <a href="#note">note</a>
</dd><dd><b>505 tag</b> - formatted <a href="#contentsnote">contents note</a>
</dd><dd><b>520 tag</b> - <a href="#annotation">annotation</a> or <a href="#summary">summary</a> <a href="#note">note</a>
</dd><dd><b>600 tag</b> - <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a>
</dd><dd><b>610 tag</b> - <a href="#corporatename">corporate name</a> <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a>
</dd><dd><b>650 tag</b> - <a href="#topic">topic</a>al <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>
</dd><dd><b>651 tag</b> - <a href="#geographicname">geographic name</a> <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a>
</dd><dd><b>700 tag</b> - <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> (<a href="#jointauthor">joint author</a>, <a href="#editor">editor</a>, <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>)
</dd><dd><b>710 tag</b> - <a href="#corporatename">corporate name</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> (other than subject or series)
</dd><dd><b>800 tag</b> - <a href="#series">series</a> <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a> 
</dd><dd><b>830 tag</b> - <a href="#series">series</a> <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entry</a></dd></dl>  
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#character">character</a> string attached to a portion of <a href="#text">text</a> in an <a href="#html">HTML</a> <a href="#document">document</a>, usually at the beginning and end, to identify elements of the <a href="#file">file</a>, specify <a href="#formatting">formatting</a>, or establish a <a href="#link">link</a>.  To see the tags in this <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>, click on "View" or its equivalent in your <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> and then select the <a href="#option">option</a> "Page Source" or "View Source." 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="taggroup"><b>tag group</b></a>
</dt><dd>The three-digit <a href="#contentdesignator">content designator</a>s (called <a href="#tag">tag</a>s), used to identify <a href="#field">field</a>s in the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>, are grouped by function in hundreds as follows, with XX in the range of 00-99:  
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>0XX tags</b> - <a href="#bibcontrol">Bibliographic control</a> numbers and coded <a href="#information">information</a>
</dd><dd><b>1XX tags</b> - <a href="#mainentry">Main entries</a> 
</dd><dd><b>2XX tags</b> - <a href="#title">Title</a>s, <a href="#edition">edition</a>, <a href="#imprint">imprint</a> 
</dd><dd><b>3XX tags</b> - <a href="#physicaldescrip">Physical description</a>, etc. 
</dd><dd><b>4XX tags</b> - <a href="#seriesstatement">Series statement</a>s 
</dd><dd><b>5XX tags</b> - <a href="#notearea">Note</a>s 
</dd><dd><b>6XX tags</b> - <a href="#subjectheading">Subject</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a> 
</dd><dd><b>7XX tags</b> - <a href="#addedentry">Added entries</a> other than <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a> or <a href="#series">series</a>; linking fields 
</dd><dd><b>8XX tags</b> - <a href="#series">Series</a> <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a> and <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> 
</dd><dd><b>9XX tags</b> - Fields for local use</dd></dl>
<p>
<b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#parallelcontent">parallel content</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tail"><b>tail</b></a>
</dt><dd>The bottom edge of a <a href="#book">book</a>, on which it rests when shelved in an upright position.  Also refers to the <a href="#margin">margin</a> at the <a href="#foot">foot</a> of a <a href="#page">page</a>, as opposed to the margin at the <a href="#head">head</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tailband"><b>tailband</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#headband">headband</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tailcap"><b>tailcap</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#headcap">headcap</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tailpiece"><b>tailpiece</b></a>
</dt><dd>A decoration <a href="#printing">printed</a> in the <a href="#blank">blank</a> space at the end of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> or other division of a <a href="#book">book</a>, usually a <a href="#printersornament">printer's ornament</a> or a small <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> done by a professional <a href="#illustrator">illustrator</a>.  Also spelled <em>tail-piece</em>.  Synonymous with <em>tail ornament</em>.  Compare with <a href="#headpiece">headpiece</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#frontispiece">frontispiece</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="takedown"><b>take down</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of preparing a <a href="#book">book</a> for <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a> by removing its <a href="#cover">cover</a>, <a href="#board">board</a>s, <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s, <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> <a href="#thread">thread</a>s, and <a href="#lining">lining</a>, including any cleaning or <a href="#repairing">repair</a>.  When a <a href="#volume">volume</a> has been reduced to its original <a href="#section">section</a>s, it is said to have been <em>taken down</em>.  Synonymous with <em>pulling</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="takeover"><b>take-over</b></a>
</dt><dd>The acquisition of exclusive <a href="#rights">rights</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#work">work</a> by a new <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, following initial <a href="#publication">publication</a> by another company. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tale"><b>tale</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> account of a real, imaginary, or <a href="#legend">legend</a>ary incident, usually told in the first person in a rambling style, with more attention to <a href="#plot">plot</a> and <a href="#setting">setting</a> than to <a href="#character">character</a> development.  Most tales are works of short <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> (<em>example</em>: "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow" by Washington Irving), but the term has also been applied to <a href="#novel">novel</a>s (<b><em>Tale of Two Cities</em></b> by Charles Dickens).  In a <em>tall tale</em>, the <a href="#plot">plot</a> is deliberately far-fetched, usually for comic effect ("Cannibalism in the Cars" by Mark Twain).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="talkingbook"><b>talking book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#bookontape">book-on-tape</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="taperecording"><b>tape recording</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tapes"><b>tapes</b></a>
</dt><dd>Narrow strips of tightly woven cotton material to which the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> are <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> in quality <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Two half-inch wide strips spaced at intervals across the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> are the norm, but in larger <a href="#volume">volume</a>s, as many as five may be used.  Tapes are no longer used in most <a href="#publishersbinding">trade binding</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#bands">bands</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="targetaudience"><b>target audience</b></a>
</dt><dd>The group or category of person for which a literary or artistic <a href="#work">work</a> is written or produced, or for which a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> is <a href="#collecdevel">developed</a> (students, professionals, recreational <a href="#reader">reader</a>s, a particular age or interest group, etc.).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="taskbar"><b>taskbar</b></a>
</dt><dd>A row of tabs in a <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a>, usually located across the bottom of the screen, with <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#label">label</a>s indicating the <a href="#application">application</a>s and <a href="#file">file</a>s currently open.  In <a href="#multitasking">multitasking</a>, a tab can be clicked by the user to bring the corresponding <a href="#window">window</a> to the foreground or to restore it to its original size after it has been <a href="#minimize">minimize</a>d.  In the <a href="#windows">Windows</a> <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>, the <b>Start</b> button is also located in the taskbar, which may contain other <a href="#information">information</a> such as date and time. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="taskforce"><b>task force</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of individuals drawn from various units within an organization, charged with accomplishing a specific <a href="#objective">objective</a>
or set of objectives. Once the task is completed, the group is
disbanded and its members return to their former units. Compare with <a href="#adhoc">ad hoc committee</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tattletape"><b>tattle-tape</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#magneticstrip">magnetic strip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="taxonomy"><b>taxonomy</b></a>
</dt><dd>The science of <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a>, including the general principles by which objects and phenomena are divided into <a href="#class">class</a>es which are subdivided into <a href="#subclass">subclass</a>es, then into sub-subclasses, and so on.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tcpip"><b>TCP/IP</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialism">initialism</a> for <b>T</b>ransmission <b>C</b>ontrol <b>P</b>rotocol/<b>I</b>nternet <b>P</b>rotocol, a set of <a href="#communications">communications</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a>s developed by the U.S. Department of Defense and implemented in 1982 to allow the users of <a href="#host">host</a> computers of different types and sizes to communicate with each other and exchange <a href="#data">data</a> via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> and other <a href="#network">network</a>s (<a href="#intranet">intranet</a>s and <a href="#extranet">extranet</a>s).  Supported on most <a href="#platform">platform</a>s, <b>TCP/IP</b> has become <em>the</em> protocol of the Internet.  <b>TCP</b> ensures that the total amount of data (<a href="#byte">byte</a>s) sent is received correctly, and <b>IP</b> provides the mechanism for <a href="#router">routing</a> the <a href="#packet">packets</a> of data comprising a message to the destination <a href="#internetaddress">address</a> as efficiently as possible.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="teachersmanual"><b>teacher's manual</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#pamphlet">booklet</a> or <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in conjunction with a <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>, to assist instructors in using the text to teach their classes.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the presence of a teacher's manual is recorded as <a href="#accompanying">accompanying material</a> in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> representing the textbook. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tearsheet"><b>tear sheet</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#page">page</a> of <a href="#editorialcontent">editorial content</a> or advertising torn from a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> for use as a <a href="#press">press</a> <a href="#clipping">clipping</a> or <a href="#filecopy">file copy</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="teartest"><b>tear test</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#grain">grain</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="teaser"><b>teaser</b></a>
</dt><dd>Advertising <a href="#copy">copy</a> supplied by the marketing department of a <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> company, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> of a <a href="#newbook">new book</a> to entice the <a href="#reader">reader</a> to open the <a href="#cover">cover</a> and sample the <a href="#text">text</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="techie"><b>techie</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#technician">technician</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="technicaljournal"><b>technical journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#journal">journal</a> devoted to a particular branch of engineering or technology, providing <a href="#information">information</a> for technicians in the <a href="#field">field</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Computing in Science and Engineering</em></b>).  <a href="#article">Article</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in technical journals are <a href="#indexing">indexed</a> in <b><em>Applied Science and Technology Index</em></b>, <b><em>Compendex</em></b>, <b><em>INSPEC</em></b>, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="technicallibrary"><b>technical library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> that supports one or more of the applied sciences, such as engineering or computer science.  A technical library can be a <a href="#branchlibrary">branch library</a> in a large university, a major <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> within a large <a href="#academiclib">academic</a> or <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>, or a <a href="#speciallibrary">special library</a> maintained by a private corporation or <a href="#govtagency">government agency</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ntis">National Technical Information Service</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="technical"><b>technical processing</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the activities and processes concerned with <a href="#acquisitions">acquiring</a>, organizing, preparing, and maintaining <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s, including <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> and <a href="#physicalprocessing">physical processing</a>, usually accomplished "behind-the-scenes" by the <a href="#technicalservices">technical services</a> department of a <a href="#library">library</a>.  When the department is <a href="#understaffed">understaffed</a>, <a href="#arrears">arrears</a> may accumulate.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#centralizedproc">centralized processing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="technicalreport"><b>technical report</b></a>
</dt><dd>A scientific <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#article">article</a> describing <a href="#research">research</a> or other significant developments in a <a href="#field">field</a> of the applied sciences.  When submitted to a military <a href="#govtagency">agency</a>, such a <a href="#report">report</a> may be "<a href="#classified">classified</a>" or subject to other <a href="#access">access</a> restrictions.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ntis">National Technical Information Service</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="technicalservices"><b>technical services (TS)</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#library">Library</a> <a href="#operations">operations</a> concerned with the <a href="#acquisitions">acquisition</a>, organization (<a href="#bibcontrol">bibliographic control</a>), <a href="#physicalprocessing">physical processing</a>, and maintenance of <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s, as opposed to the delivery of <a href="#publicservices">public services</a>.  <a href="#technical">Technical processing</a> is performed "behind-the-scenes," usually in a <em>technical services department</em>.  <a href="http://tpot.ucsd.edu/TSU/">Click here</a> to connect to the <em>Technical Services Unlimited</em> <a href="#website">Web Site</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#alcts">ALCTS</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="technician"><b>technician</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who has special expertise in the maintenance of high-tech machines, particularly computer and scientific equipment.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> with automated <a href="#systems">systems</a> require the services of a "techie" to keep <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> and <a href="#software">software</a> running smoothly.  Compare with <a href="#systemslibrarian">systems librarian</a>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tei1"><b>TEI</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#tei"><b>T</b>ext <b>E</b>ncoding <b>I</b>nitiative</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="telecommunication"><b>telecommunication</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of sending and receiving signals or messages at a
distance via telegraph, telephone, radio, television, cable, microwave,
or any other electromagnetic method on which modern <a href="#infotech">information technology</a> depends.  Also, any transmission, emission, or reception of signals by such means.  Compare with <a href="#telecommunications">telecommunications</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="telecommunications"><b>telecommunications</b></a>
</dt><dd>The individual messages transmitted and/or received via
telegraph, telephone, radio, television, cable, microwave, or other
electromagnetic means. Sometimes used synonymously with <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="telecommute"><b>telecommute</b></a>
</dt><dd>To work from home using a computer and <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> links, instead of traveling to an office to conduct business.  Some <a href="#library">library</a> functions, such as the design and maintenance of <a href="#website">Web site</a>s can be accomplished at a distance, but most library personnel work on-site.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="teleconference"><b>teleconference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A live, two-way <a href="#conference">conference</a> of two or more people using <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a> and <a href="#videorecording">video</a> transmission technology that enables the participants to see and hear each other in <a href="#realtime">real time</a> without having to meet in the same physical location.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="telephonedirectory"><b>telephone directory</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large <a href="#format">format</a> <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> distributed <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by a telephone company at no charge to its customers, containing an <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetic</a>
list of the names, telephone numbers, and street addresses of people
served in a given city, town, or geographic area in a section called
the <a href="#whitepages">white pages</a>, and an alphabetic list of businesses with phone numbers and addresses in the <a href="#yellowpages">yellow pages</a> at the back.  For very large cities, the white pages and yellow pages may be <a href="#publishing">published</a> in separate <a href="#volume">volume</a>s.  
<p>
<a href="#libcollec">Library collection</a>s of <a href="#print">print</a> phone <a href="#book">book</a>s have been largely replaced by <a href="#directory">directories</a> available <a href="#online">online</a> at no charge via the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.switchboard.com/">Switchboard.com</a>).  Most libraries continue to provide print phone books only for the major towns and cities in their state.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="teleplay"><b>teleplay</b></a>
</dt><dd>A drama written to be recorded in a studio and <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> on television, rather than for live performance on stage or to be filmed as a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>.  Synonymous with <em>television drama</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="teletext"><b>teletext</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of one-way <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>ing service that allows <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#information">information</a> provided by a television station, such as <a href="#closedcaption">closed caption</a>s or continuously <a href="#updated">updated</a> news, to be displayed on a television receiver specifically adapted to allow <a href="#text">text</a> and <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s to be superimposed over regular programming, usually in frames.  Compare with <a href="#videotex">videotex</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="telnet"><b>Telnet</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#terminal">Terminal</a> emulation <a href="#software">software</a> governed by the <a href="#tcpip">TCP/IP</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a>, which allows the user to <a href="#logon">log on</a> to a remote computer or <a href="#terminal">terminal</a> and use its systems as if on-site.  Designed to transmit <a href="#ascii">ASCII text</a>, Telnet was once widely used in <a href="#library">libraries</a> to provide <a href="#remoteaccess">remote</a> <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s, but has been largely <a href="#superseded">superseded</a> by graphical <a href="#www">Web</a>-based access to electronic resources. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="top"><b>temporarily out of print (TOP)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used on a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#invoice">invoice</a> to indicate that the <a href="#title">title</a> ordered cannot be supplied because the last <a href="#printing">printing</a> is sold out, and to inform prospective purchasers that additional <a href="#copy">copies</a> are expected from the <a href="#printer">printer</a> in the near future.  Compare with <a href="#opp">out of print at present</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tos"><b>temporarily out of stock (TOS)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used on a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#invoice">invoice</a> to indicate that the <a href="#title">title</a> ordered cannot be supplied because current <a href="#inventory">inventory</a> is exhausted, but additional <a href="#copy">copies</a> are expected, usually from the <a href="#bindery">binder</a> or <a href="#manufacturer">manufacturer</a>.  Compare with <a href="#outofstock">out of stock</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#instock">in stock</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="temprecords"><b>temporary records</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#document">Document</a>s intended by their <a href="#creator">creator</a> to remain useful for a short time only, which have no <a href="#archivalvalue">archival value</a> and can be discarded or <a href="#destruction">destroyed</a> when no longer needed without loss to the individual or organization (<em>example</em>:  <a href="#draft">draft</a> versions not required to document a process). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="temporarystorage"><b>temporary storage</b></a>
</dt><dd>A space within an <a href="#archive">archive</a> or <a href="#library">library</a> facility, or located <a href="#offsitestorage">off-site</a>, where <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a>, <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a>, or <a href="#librarysupplies">supplies</a> are kept for a short time until they can be <a href="#technical">processed</a>, installed, distributed, transferred to a permanent location, or disposed of in some other way (<em>example</em>:  a large <a href="#gift">gift</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> awaiting examination by <a href="#selection">selector</a>s). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tenure"><b>tenure</b></a>
</dt><dd>The guarantee of permanent employment, granted by an academic
institution to a faculty member for satisfactory performance upon
completion of a specified number of years of service. A <a href="#position">position</a> for which tenure is granted is classifed as <em>tenure-track</em>.  Academic <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s who have <a href="#facultystatus">faculty status</a> are eligible for tenure; those with <a href="#acadstatus">academic status</a>
usually are not. In a more general sense, the length of time a person
has been employed, or may be expected to be employed, by a company, <a href="#agency">agency</a>, organization, or institution.  Compare with <a href="#promotion">promotion</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="term"><b>term</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>, especially one used to represent, in a <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a>, <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, <a href="#index">index</a>, or <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>, a <a href="#subject">subject</a> or other feature of a <a href="#work">work</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#searchterm">search term</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="termfreq"><b>term frequency (TF)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#number">number</a> of times a <a href="#searchterm">search term</a> occurs in a <a href="#record">record</a> or <a href="#document">document</a> included in a <a href="#database">database</a>, one of the variables used in assigning a <a href="#weighting">weight</a> to the record or document in relation to others <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a> in the same <a href="#search">search</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="terminal"><b>terminal</b></a>
</dt><dd>An electronic <a href="#device">device</a> consisting of a computer <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> and screen or optical <a href="#scanner">scanner</a>, which can be used to enter <a href="#data">data</a> (<a href="#input">input</a>) and display <a href="#output">output</a> from a central computer (usually a <a href="#minicomputer">minicomputer</a> or <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a>), but is not capable of independent <a href="#centralproc">processing</a>.  Synonymous with <em>dumb terminal</em> and <em>visual display terminal (VDT)</em>.  Compare with <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a> and <a href="#thinclient">thin client</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dedicated">dedicated</a>, <a href="#emulation">emulation</a>, and <a href="#vt100">VT100</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="terminalemulation"><b>terminal emulation</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#emulation">emulation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="terminology"><b>terminology</b></a>
</dt><dd>Words, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s, and <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s representing the concepts and <a href="#subject">subject</a>s used in a specific field of <a href="#research">research</a>,
study, or activity, for which the meaning (established by convention or
explicit agreement among its practitioners) is clearly <a href="#definition">defined</a>, sometimes in a <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#glossary">glossary</a> or <a href="#lexicon">lexicon</a>.  Synonymous with <em>nomenclature</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="termsof"><b>terms of availability</b></a>
</dt><dd>The conditions under which a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> is available for sale in the market place, usually the <a href="#listprice">list price</a>, entered in <a href="#field">field</a> 020 or 022 of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ternion"><b>ternion</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, a <a href="#gathering">gathering</a> consisting of three <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#parchment">parchment</a>, or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> folded once to create six <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>, used in some <a href="#manuscriptbook">manuscript book</a>s and early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#quaternion">quaternion</a>, <a href="#quinternion">quinternion</a>, and <a href="#sextern">sextern</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tertiarysource"><b>tertiary source</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written <a href="#work">work</a>, such as a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> in a <a href="#textbook">textbook</a> or <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>, based entirely on <a href="#secondarysource">secondary source</a>s, rather than on original <a href="#research">research</a> involving <a href="#primarysource">primary</a> <a href="#document">document</a>s.  Whether a <a href="#source">source</a> is secondary or tertiary can be determined by examining the <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>
(if one is provided). Another clue is that secondary sources are almost
always written by experts, but tertiary sources may be written by staff
writers who have an interest in the <a href="#topic">topic</a>, but are not scholars on the <a href="#subject">subject</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="testcollec"><b>test collection</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> consisting of assessment instruments used by <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>s and practitioners in education, psychology, counseling, and allied fields.  <a href="#information">Information</a> on test collections is available in the <b><em>Directory of Test Collections in Academic, Professional, and Research Libraries</em></b> (2002) <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the <a href="#acrl">Association of College &amp; Research Libraries</a>.  Tests are <a href="#review">review</a>ed in the <b><em>Mental Measurements Yearbook</em></b> published by the Buros Institute of Mental Measurements. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tetebeche"><b>tete-beche</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the <a href="#text">text</a> of one <a href="#work">work</a> begins at the "front" of the <a href="#book">book</a> and the text of a second work at the "back," inverted (upside-down) with respect to the other so that their last <a href="#page">page</a>s meet somewhere in the middle of the <a href="#section">section</a>s.  Also, a <a href="#volume">volume</a> bound in the same manner, which contains different versions of the same text.  Compare with <a href="#dosados">dos-a-dos</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tetrology"><b>tetrology</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#trilogy">trilogy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="text"><b>text</b></a>
</dt><dd>In a written, <a href="#printing">printed</a>, or <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#work">work</a>, the words or (in the absence of words) signs or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s used to express the <a href="#author">author</a>'s thoughts, feelings, and ideas.  Compare with <a href="#wordless">wordless</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#subtext">subtext</a> and <a href="#textualcriticism">textual criticism</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the body of a <a href="#book">book</a>, excluding the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>, <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>, and any <a href="#note">note</a>s, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#caption">caption</a>s, <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, or other <a href="#displaymatter">display matter</a>.  Also used as a shortened form of the <a href="#term">term</a> <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#textblock">text block</a>.
</p><p>
In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#gmd">general material designation</a>
for printed material which can be read by the human eye without the aid
of magnification. Also, the words of a song, cycle of songs, or <a href="#collection">collection</a> of songs (<em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>).   
</p><p>
In <a href="#email">e-mail</a>, the body of a message, as distinct from its <a href="#header">header</a> and <a href="#footer">footer</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="textblock"><b>text block</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#gathering">gathered</a> <a href="#signature">signature</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a>, <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> or <a href="#adhesive">adhered</a> in a single unit and <a href="#trimming">trimmed</a> before attachment to the <a href="#case">case</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a>, not including any <a href="#paper">paper</a> added by the <a href="#binder">binder</a>, such as <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s or <a href="#doublure">doublure</a>s.  Compare in this sense with <a href="#bookblock">book block</a>. 
<p>
Also used in a narrower sense to refer to the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a book that bear the actual <a href="#text">text</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a>, as opposed to the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>, <a href="#backmatter">back matter</a>, and any <a href="#plate">plate</a>s <a href="#printing">printed</a> separately (usually on a different <a href="#paper">paper</a> stock) to be added in <a href="#binding">binding</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="textbook"><b>textbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> specifically intended for the use of students enrolled in a course of study or in preparing for an examination on a <a href="#subject">subject</a> or in an academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, as distinct from the <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a> of the same <a href="#title">title</a>, sometimes <a href="#publishing">published</a> in conjunction with a <a href="#workbook">workbook</a>, <a href="#labmanual">lab manual</a>, and/or <a href="#teachersmanual">teacher's manual</a>.  Also refers to the <a href="#standardwork">standard work</a> used for a specific course of study, whether published in special edition or not.
<p>
Textbooks are usually ordered by <a href="#collegebookstore">college bookstore</a>s in quantity, based on projected course enrollment.  The standard <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#discount">discount</a> on textbook orders is 20%.  <a href="#usedbook">Used</a> <a href="#copy">copies</a> in good <a href="#condition">condition</a> may be sold back to the <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a> for resale at a lower price than new copies.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#textbookedition">textbook edition</a> and <em><a href="#elhitextbooks">El-Hi Textbooks &amp; Serials in Print</a></em>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="textbookedition"><b>textbook edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in a separate <a href="#edition">edition</a> specifically for the use of students enrolled in a course of study.  The <a href="#format">format</a> may be altered to make it more useful, for example, by the addition of study questions and <a href="#bibliography">bibliographies</a> at the end of each section or <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>.  <a href="#textbook">Textbook</a> editions are sold at <a href="#shortdiscount">short discount</a>, usually 20% when ordered in quantity.  Synonymous with <em>text edition</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tei"><b>Text Encoding Initiative (TEI)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Introduced in 1987, <b>TEI</b> is an international <a href="#interdisciplinary">interdisciplinary</a> <a href="#standard">standard</a> intended to assist <a href="#library">libraries</a>, museums, <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, and scholars in representing literary and linguistic <a href="#text">text</a>s in <a href="#digital">digital</a> form, to facilitate <a href="#research">research</a> and teaching.  The <a href="#encoding">encoding</a> scheme is designed to maximize expressivity and minimize obsolescence.  <b>TEI</b> began as a research project organized cooperatively by the <a href="http://www.ach.org/">Association for Computers and the Humanities</a>, the <a href="http://www.cs.columbia.edu/%7Eacl/home.html">Association for Computational Linguistics</a>, and the Association for Literary and Linguistic Computing, funded by research <a href="#grant">grant</a>s from the <a href="#neh">National Endowment for the Humanities</a>, the European Union, the Canadian Social Science Research Council, the <a href="http://www.mellon.org/">Mellon Foundation</a>, and others.  <a href="http://www.tei-c.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>TEI</b> <a href="#website">Web site</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="textilebinding"><b>textile binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A style of <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> popular in Europe from the 12th-15th century in which the <a href="#board">board</a>s were <a href="#cover">cover</a>ed in velvet and/or silk brocade, usually adorned with gold or silver <a href="#clasp">clasp</a>s.  In the 16th and 17th centuries, embroidered velvet and silk bindings were popular.  Because luxury fabrics are fragile and <a href="#deterioration">deteriorate</a> with age, few examples survive in good <a href="#condition">condition</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="texttype"><b>text type</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#type">Type</a> used to <a href="#printing">print</a> reading material, for example, the body of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, as opposed to the <a href="#displaytype">display type</a> used to print <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, <a href="#runningtitle">running title</a>s, etc., or the <a href="#extracttype">extract type</a> used to print <a href="#note">note</a>s and long <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>body type</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#typesize">type size</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="textualcriticism"><b>textual criticism</b></a>
</dt><dd>Close study and comparison of the various <a href="#text">text</a>s of a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> to determine the version that reflects most faithfully the writer's intentions, particularly important in the case of older <a href="#work">work</a>s for which the original <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> is missing or incomplete, or for which multiple <a href="#version">version</a>s exist. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#recension">recension</a> and <a href="#textusreceptus">textus receptus</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="textura"><b>textura</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the most formal of the <a href="#gothic">gothic</a> or black <a href="#letter">letter</a> <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#font">font</a>s, used in early <a href="#edition">edition</a>s of the <em>Bible</em> and <a href="#liturgicalwork">liturgical work</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="textusreceptus"><b><em>textus receptus</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for "received text."  The <a href="#version">version</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> which, in the absence of indisputable proof to the contrary, is considered by scholars to represent the <a href="#author">author</a>'s intentions to a greater degree than other versions known to exist.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#recension">recension</a> and <a href="#textualcriticism">textual criticism</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tf"><b>TF</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#termfreq"><b>t</b>erm <b>f</b>requency</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tgn1"><b><em>TGN</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#tgn">Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tla"><b>Theatre Library Association (TLA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Established in 1937, <b>TLA</b> has an international membership consisting of <a href="#curator">curator</a>s, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s, <a href="#archives">archivist</a>s, writers, historians, stage designers, actors, <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, <a href="#bookcollecting">collector</a>s, and other individuals with an interest <a href="#research">research</a> in the performing arts, and in the collection, <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>, and use of performing arts materials.  Based in New York City, <b>TLA</b> is an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  Its <a href="#publication">publication</a>s include the <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>Performing Arts Resources</em> and the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#newsletter">newsletter</a> <em>Broadside</em>.  <a href="http://tla.library.unt.edu/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>TLA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="theft"><b>theft</b></a>
</dt><dd>The unauthorized removal of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> from <a href="#library">library</a> premises, a persistent problem controlled by restricting <a href="#access">access</a> to the <a href="#technicalservices">technical services</a> department and installing a <a href="#securitygate">security gate</a> at the public exit with an alarm automatically activated by a <a href="#magneticstrip">magnetic strip</a> affixed to the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, which must be <a href="#desensitization">desensitized</a> by <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> at <a href="#checkedout">checkout</a>.
Unfortunately, determined thieves learn to locate and remove the strips
to avoid detection. In most states in the U.S., theft and <a href="#vandalism">vandalism</a> of library materials is punishable as a misdemeanor.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#crime">crime in the library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thematicatlas"><b>thematic atlas</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> of <a href="#map">map</a>s devoted to a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or theme, usually including <a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, and other <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> material explaining their meaning and significance (<em>examples</em>:  <b><em>The Atlas of Endangered Species</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thematiccatalog"><b>thematic catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the <a href="#musicalwork">work</a>s of a <a href="#composer">composer</a>, arranged <a href="#chronological">chronological</a>ly or by category, in which the major theme is given for each <a href="#composition">composition</a>, or section of a long composition, usually in a few bars.  Some thematic <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s are devoted to musical works of a particular form and period, usually arranged <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by name of composer.  Compare with <a href="#thematicindex">thematic index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thematicindex"><b>thematic index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the major themes in a musical <a href="#composition">composition</a>, or group of compositions, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> in the front or back of the <a href="#score">score</a>, with references to the <a href="#work">work</a>(s) in which they appear.  For short <a href="#piece">piece</a>s, the theme is usually given as the first few bars.  Compare with <a href="#thematiccatalog">thematic catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thematicmap"><b>thematic map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> showing one or more features or
aspects of a given area of the surface of the earth or of another
celestial body. Thematic maps can be <em>quantitative</em>, illustrating statistical <a href="#data">data</a>, such as average annual precipitation, or <em>qualitative</em>, indicating the distribution of characteristics such as predominant <a href="#language">language</a>, ethnic group, religious affiliation, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thesaurus"><b>thesaurus</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> of <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>s and near-synonyms in a written <a href="#language">language</a>, usually arranged conceptually, although <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> arrangement is not uncommon.  The first thesaurus of the English language, <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1852, was <a href="#compile">compile</a>d by Peter Mark Roget.  For an <a href="#online">online</a> thesaurus of the English language, please see <em><a href="http://www.m-w.com/netdict.htm">Merriam-Webster Online</a></em>.  
<p>
Also refers to an <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly arranged <a href="#lexicon">lexicon</a> of <a href="#term">term</a>s comprising the <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#vocabulary">vocabulary</a> of an academic <a href="#discipline">discipline</a> or <a href="#field">field</a> of study, showing the logical and <a href="#semanticrelation">semantic relation</a>s among terms, particularly a list of <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s used as <a href="#preferredterm">preferred term</a>s in <a href="#indexinglang">indexing</a> the <a href="#literature">literature</a> of the field.  In <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a>, a thesaurus can be used to locate <a href="#broaderterm">broader term</a>s and <a href="#relatedterm">related term</a>s if the user wishes to expand retrieval, or <a href="#narrowerterm">narrower term</a>s to make a <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a> more specific.  A well-designed thesaurus also enables the indexer to maintain <a href="#consistency">consistency</a> in the assignment of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> terms to <a href="#document">document</a>s.  Plural:  <em>thesauri</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a> and <a href="#leadinvocabulary">lead-in vocabulary</a>.
</p><p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Examples</em>:
<dl><dt></dt><dd><b><em>Art &amp; Architecture Thesaurus (AAT)</em></b>
</dd><dd><b><em>Thesaurus of ERIC Descriptors</em></b>
</dd><dd><b><em>Thesaurus of Psychological Index Terms</em></b>
</dd><dd><b><em>Thesaurus of Sociological Indexing Terms</em></b></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tgn2"><b><em>Thesaurus of Geographic Names</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#tgn">Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names (TGN)</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thesis"><b>thesis</b></a>
</dt><dd>A proposition advanced and defended in a formal disputation, especially by a <a href="#candidate">candidate</a> in partial fulfillment of university requirements for a master's degree.  Master's theses are <a href="#index">index</a>ed <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly by <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>, and <a href="#author">author</a> in <b><em>Master's Theses Directories</em></b> and in <em><a href="#dai">Disseration Abstracts International</a></em>.  They can also be located in the <em><a href="#worldcat">WorldCat</a></em> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a> via <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#firstsearch">FirstSearch</a></em>.  Compare with <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#praeses">praeses</a> and <a href="#respondent">respondent</a>.
<p>
In a more general sense, any proposition advanced and defended in
expository speech or writing, usually given in the opening lines or
paragraph(s).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thesisplay"><b>thesis play</b></a>
</dt><dd>A dramatic <a href="#work">work</a> in which the <a href="#playwright">playwright</a> consciously attempts to illustrate a social problem and suggest to the <a href="#reader">reader</a> or <a href="#audience">audience</a> a possible solution (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Mrs. Warren's Profession</em></b> by George Bernard Shaw).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#romanathese">roman a these</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thinclient"><b>thin client</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer connected to a <a href="#clientserver">client-server</a> <a href="#network">network</a>, which does very little independent <a href="#centralproc">processing</a>, all or most of the <a href="#application">application</a> processing being done on the <a href="#server">server</a>.  Also refers to a <a href="#client">client</a> computer capable of <a href="#download">download</a>ing a <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> from a server and processing <a href="#data">data</a> like a <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a>, but which does not <a href="#storage">store</a> data locally.  Compare with <a href="#terminal">terminal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thomas"><b><em>THOMAS</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Named in honor of Thomas Jefferson, <b><em>THOMAS</em></b> is a <a href="#database">database</a> designed and maintained since 1995 by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a> to make legislative <a href="#information">information</a>, such as the <em>Congressional Record</em>, more <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> to the public.  Available on the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> 24 hours a day free-of-charge, <b><em>THOMAS</em></b> also provides answers to <a href="#faq">FAQ</a>s, <a href="#link">link</a>s to the <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> of historical <a href="#document">document</a>s such as the <em>Declaration of Independence</em> and the <em>Constitution of the United States</em>, and a section on bills recently in the news.  <a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b><em>THOMAS</em></b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thread"><b>thread</b></a>
</dt><dd>A theme or <a href="#topic">topic</a> that generates an ongoing <a href="#email">e-mail</a> discussion among the participants in an <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#newsgroup">newsgroup</a> or <a href="#mailinglist">mailing list</a>, usually repeated in the <a href="#header">header</a> of each message posted on the <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  In <a href="#literature">literature</a>, an idea or theme that connects the various parts of a <a href="#narrative">narrative</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the strand (or strands) of spun fiber used in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> to <a href="#sewing">sew</a> the <a href="#section">section</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> together, usually made of cotton or linen in machine-sewn <a href="#binding">binding</a>s.  Silk or linen thread may be used in hand-sewing.  <a href="#swell">Swell</a> caused by the accumulation of sewing thread is reduced by <a href="#nipping">smashing</a> in the binding procedure called <a href="#rounding">rounding</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="threedecker"><b>three-decker</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#novel">novel</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in three <a href="#octavo">octavo</a> <a href="#volume">volume</a>s.  First <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#paper">paper</a>-<a href="#cover">cover</a>ed <a href="#board">board</a>s without <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, and later in <a href="#cloth">cloth</a>-covered <a href="#board">board</a>s, three-deckers became the standard <a href="#format">format</a> for <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in England between about 1850 and 1870.  According to Geoffrey Glaister, <a href="#circulatinglib">circulating libraries</a> kept this type of <a href="#publication">publication</a> going until inexpensive <a href="#reprint">reprint</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s became widely available (<b><em>Encyclopedia of the Book</em></b>, Oak Knoll/British Library: 1996). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="threeon"><b>three on</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#twoon">two on</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="threequarter"><b>three-quarter binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A style of <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a> in which the <a href="#spine">spine</a> and <a href="#corner">corner</a>s are <a href="#binding">bound</a> in a different material than the sides, usually a more <a href="#durability">durable</a> covering such as <a href="#leather">leather</a>.  Similar to <a href="#halfbinding">half binding</a> except that the corners are larger and the material covering the spine extends up to half the width of the <a href="#board">board</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#fullbinding">full binding</a> and <a href="#quarterbinding">quarter binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="threequarterborder"><b>three-quarter border</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#fullpageborder">full-page border</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thriller"><b>thriller</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#play">play</a>, or <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> that produces feelings of intense excitement in the <a href="#reader">reader</a> or <a href="#audience">audience</a> by depicting dangerous action (crime, <a href="#espionage">espionage</a>, etc.), usually culminating in a narrow escape in which a high level of suspense is maintained up to the final <em>denouement</em> (<em>example</em>:  Alfred Hitchcock's <a href="#film">film</a> <b><em>North by Northwest</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="throwout"><b>throw-out</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> wider than normal, usually bearing a <a href="#map">map</a>, <a href="#table">table</a>, <a href="#diagram">diagram</a>, wide-angle <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>, or other <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> <a href="#mounted">mounted</a> and folded so that it can be opened out for reference while the corresponding <a href="#text">text</a> is read.  Also spelled <em>throwout</em>.  Synonymous with <em>fold-out</em> and <em>pull-out</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#gatefold">gatefold</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thumbbook"><b>thumb book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#bibelot">bibelot</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thumbindex"><b>thumb index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A series of semicircular thumb-sized notches cut into the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, bearing a sequence of <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, words, <a href="#number">number</a>s, or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> against a dark background to show the <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetic</a>, <a href="#subject">subject</a>, numeric, or other arrangement of the <a href="#text">text</a> and facilitate reference, seen most often in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s of <a href="#language">language</a> <a href="#dictionary">dictionaries</a> and <a href="#handbook">handbook</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#stepindex">step index</a> and <a href="#tabindex">tab index</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="thumbnail"><b>thumbnail</b></a>
</dt><dd>A very small image of a <a href="#page">page</a> of <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> element, used in a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> as a <a href="#link">link</a> to the same image in larger <a href="#format">format</a>.  Since thumbnail graphics take less time to load, they are often used in Web pages to provide the <a href="#option">option</a> of enlarging an image without significantly increasing the time required to transmit the <a href="#document">document</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tier"><b>tier</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of two or more distinct levels, as of shelves in a <a href="#section">section</a> of <a href="#library">library</a> shelving, priorities for resource <a href="#allocation">allocation</a> or acquisition, payment or benefit options in a health care plan, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tiff"><b>TIFF</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for <em><b>T</b>agged <b>I</b>mage <b>F</b>ile <b>F</b>ormat</em>, a widely supported <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#format">format</a> developed by Aldus and Microsoft for storing black-and-white, gray-scale, or color <a href="#bitmap">bitmap</a>ped images on a <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a>.  Files in <b>TIFF</b> format are <a href="#datacompression">compressed</a> and usually have the <a href="#extension">extension</a> <em>.tif</em> or <em>.tiff</em> added to the <a href="#filename">filename</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#jpeg">JPEG</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tight"><b>tight </b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> so tightly bound that the <a href="#spine">spine</a> is inflexible, preventing the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> from opening and staying open at a particular <a href="#page">page</a>.  As <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s are used, their <a href="#binding">binding</a>s gradually <a href="#loose">loose</a>n allowing them to <a href="#openability">open flat</a> at any page.  <a href="#librarybinding">Library binding</a>s are usually tighter than <a href="#publishersbinding">trade binding</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#tightback">tight back</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tightback"><b>tight back</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#binding">binding</a> in which the <a href="#back">back</a> of a <a href="#volume">volume</a> is glued to the <a href="#cover">cover</a>, leaving no <a href="#hollow">hollow</a> to allow the binding to flex as it is <a href="#openability">opened</a>.  <a href="#book">Book</a>s bound by this method do not open flat.  Another disadvantage is that the <a href="#lettering">lettering</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#spine">spine</a> tends to crack with extended use.  For these reasons, <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s are nearly always bound with a <a href="#hollowback">hollow back</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tilde"><b>tilde</b></a>
</dt><dd>A mark in the form of a horizontal inverted "s" used as a <a href="#diacriticalmark">diacritical mark</a> over certain letters in the Spanish and Portuguese <a href="#language">language</a>s to indicate pronunciation, as a <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> in logic and mathematics to indicate negation, and in <a href="#url">URL</a>s, usually followed by the name of the person responsible for creating and/or maintaining the <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="timeexpired"><b>time-expired records</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#archives">archives</a>, <a href="#temprecords">temporary records</a> assigned a specific date for <a href="#destruction">destruction</a> that has passed without the occurrence of appropriate action, usually due to a backlog in processing. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="timeout"><b>timeout</b></a>
</dt><dd>In computing, a <a href="#routine">routine</a> that automatically terminates a period of waiting when a screen requiring user <a href="#input">input</a> receives no response within a designated time, for example, an <a href="#interface">interface</a> that <a href="#logoff">logs off</a> whenever a predetermined period of inactivity occurs during an <a href="#online">online</a> session.  The term is also used in <a href="#communications">communications</a> to refer to the automatic termination of a waiting period when no response is received.  Also spelled <em>time out</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="timesheet"><b>timesheet</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#payroll">payroll</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tls"><b><em>Times Literary Supplement (TLS)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>First <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1902, <b><em>TLS</em></b> is one of the most influential <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#reviewpub">review publication</a>s in the UK.  Published <a href="#weekly">weekly</a> in <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> format, it provides in-depth <a href="#review">review</a>s of <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> on a wide range of <a href="#subject">subject</a>s, as well as reviews of contemporary theater, opera, and <a href="#film">film</a>.  Like its American counterparts, the <em><a href="#newyorkreview">New York Review of Books</a></em> and the <em><a href="#nytbr">New York Times Book Review</a></em>, <b><em>TLS</em></b> is noted for its coverage of <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s.  It also carries announcements of <a href="#newbook">new book</a>s published by <a href="#scholarlybook">scholarly</a> and <a href="#universitypress">university press</a>es.  <a href="http://www.the-tls.co.uk/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#online">online</a> version of <b><em>TLS</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tintype"><b>tintype</b></a>
</dt><dd>A positive <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>ic image made with a wet collodion <a href="#emulsion">emulsion</a> on a thin iron plate darkened with black lacquer.  As in a <a href="#daguerrotype">daguerrotype</a>, the image is reversed laterally.  Inexpensive and fast, the process was widely used for <a href="#portrait">portrait</a>ure
from the 1850s to the end of the 19th century, bringing photographic
images within reach of the masses. In the 1880s, the wet emulsion was
replaced by a dry gelatin. Synonymous with <em>ferrotype</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tipin"><b>tip in</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#tippedin">tipped in</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tippedin"><b>tipped in</b></a>

</dt><dd>A single <a href="#leaf">leaf</a>, <a href="#errata">errata</a> slip, or separately <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#map">map</a> or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> <a href="#trimming">trimmed</a> to <a href="#page">page</a> size and glued into a <a href="#book">book</a> against the following page without using a <a href="#guard">guard</a>, after the <a href="#text">text</a> has been printed and <a href="#binding">bound</a>, usually by applying a thin line of <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a> along the inner <a href="#margin">margin</a>, near the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a>.  A tipped in leaf (called a "paste in") may be somewhat restricted in its <a href="#openability">openability</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tissue"><b>tissue</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of very thin <a href="#paper">paper</a> inserted <a href="#loose">loose</a> between the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or affixed to the inner <a href="#margin">margin</a>, usually to protect the surface of a <a href="#plate">plate</a> or prevent the <a href="#offset">offset</a> of fresh <a href="#ink">ink</a> onto the facing <a href="#page">page</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="title"><b>title</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, sentence, <a href="#character">character</a>, or characters appearing on an <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, naming the <a href="#work">work</a> (or works) for identification and reference.  Choice of title usually reflects the <a href="#content">content</a> of the work, distinguishing it from others of similar subject.  A <a href="#subtitle">subtitle</a> may be included following a colon or semicolon.  <a href="#translation">Translation</a>s may have a <a href="#paralleltitle">parallel title</a> in the original <a href="#language">language</a>.  The full title is usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or at the beginning of an <a href="#article">article</a> or <a href="#essay">essay</a> published in a book or <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>.
