The title given on the title page may differ from the one printed or impressed on the <a href="#spinetitle">spine</a> or <a href="#covertitle">cover</a>.  In a <a href="#film">film</a> or <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>, the title is usually given in the first few <a href="#frame">frame</a>s. 
<p>
In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> is entered in the <a href="#titleand">title and statement of responsibility</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> as it appears on the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a>.  A work <a href="#publishing">published</a> under more than one title is cataloged under a <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em><b>Bible</b></em>).  Also used in a less precise way to refer to any <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> that has a <a href="#title">title</a>, as in the <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> "list of titles ordered."  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#alternativetitle">alternative title</a>, <a href="#binderstitle">binder's title</a>, <a href="#catchwordtitle">catchword title</a>, <a href="#changedtitle">changed title</a>, <a href="#chaptertitle">chapter title</a>, <a href="#divisionaltitle">divisional title</a>, <a href="#halftitle">half title</a>, <a href="#partialtitle">partial title</a>, <a href="#runningtitle">running title</a>, <a href="#seriestitle">series title</a>, <a href="#shorttitle">short title</a>, <a href="#sidetitle">side title</a>, <a href="#spinetitle">spine title</a>, <a href="#suppliedtitle">supplied title</a>, and <a href="#workingtitle">working title</a>. 
</p><p>
Also refers to a formal name or appellation given to an individual or
family in recognition of privilege, distinction, office, or profession,
for example: baron, saint, president, doctor, etc. In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, titles of nobility are included in the <a href="#personalname">personal name</a> <a href="#heading">heading</a>
when used to refer to the individual, titles indicating high office are
given in English whenever possible, and titles of address (Miss, Mr.,
Mrs., etc.) are omitted from the heading, as are minor ecclesiastical
titles, military titles, academic and professional titles, and
government titles below the highest rank. </p><p>
In employment, the official name assigned to a specific <a href="#position">position</a> within the organization, for example, <em>Instruction Librarian</em>.  Usually based on function, <a href="#library">library</a> position titles vary from one institution to another (<em>Instructional Services Librarian</em>).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="titleand"><b>title and statement of responsibility</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#area">area</a> of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> in which the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> and <a href="#information">information</a> concerning <a href="#authorship">authorship</a> (<a href="#statementof">statement of responsibility</a>) are recorded (<a href="#field">field</a> 245 of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="titlechange"><b>title change</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#changedtitle">changed title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="titleframe"><b>title frame</b></a>
</dt><dd>One or more <a href="#frame">frame</a>s usually found at the beginning of a <a href="#work">work</a> produced on <a href="#film">film</a> (<a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>, etc.), containing <a href="#text">text</a>ual <a href="#information">information</a> distinct from the <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#content">content</a>, used as the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a> in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> when the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> is created to <a href="#bibdescrip">describe</a> the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  Compare with <a href="#titlescreen">title screen</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="titleindex"><b>title index</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly arranged list of the <a href="#title">title</a>s of the <a href="#work">work</a>s covered in a <a href="#serial">serial</a> or nonserial <a href="#work">work</a> (<em>example</em>:  the <em>Book and Film Title Index</em> in <b><em>America: History and Life</em></b>).  Title and <a href="#authorindex">author index</a>es are sometimes combined.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#subjectindex">subject index</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="titleleaf"><b>title leaf</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> bearing the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> on the <a href="#recto">recto</a> and the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#imprint">imprint</a>, notice of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, <a href="#cip">cataloging-in-publication</a> (CIP), <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>, and <a href="#printing">printing</a> history on the <a href="#verso">verso</a>.  In the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a> of a book, the title leaf follows the <a href="#halftitle">half-title</a> and precedes the <a href="#dedication">dedication</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="titlepage"><b>title page</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#page">page</a> at the beginning of a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>, <a href="#book">book</a>, or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> (usually the <a href="#recto">recto</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaf</a> following the <a href="#halftitle">half-title</a>) bearing the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a> and usually (but not necessarily) the names of the <a href="#author">author</a>(s), <a href="#editor">editor</a>(s), <a href="#translation">translator</a>(s), and <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  The title page may also indicate the <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a> (if applicable) and the date and <a href="#placeofpublication">place</a> publication.  The <a href="#verso">verso</a> of the <a href="#titleleaf">title leaf</a> usually gives the notice of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, publisher's <a href="#imprint">imprint</a>, <a href="#cip">CIP</a>, <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>, and in some cases the <a href="#printer">printer</a>'s
imprint. According to Geoffrey Glaister, the first complete title pages
appeared in early printed books around 1500. By the late 16th century
the decorative possibilities of the title page had been fully realized (<b><em>Encyclopedia of the Book</em></b>, Oak Knoll/British Library: 1996).  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>tp</em>.  Also spelled <em>title-page</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#addedtitlepage">added title page</a> and <a href="#seriestitlepage">series title page</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="titleproper"><b>title proper</b></a>
</dt><dd>The primary name of a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>, usually found on the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a>, including any <a href="#alternativetitle">alternative title</a>, but not <a href="#paralleltitle">parallel title</a>s or any additional <a href="#title">title</a> <a href="#information">information</a>.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the title proper is entered in the <a href="#titleand">title and statement of responsibility</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> (<a href="#field">field</a> 245 of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#uniformtitle">uniform title</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="titlescreen"><b>title screen</b></a>
</dt><dd>In a <a href="#mrdf">machine-readable data file</a> such as a <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> or <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>, a screen display of <a href="#text">text</a> giving the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> of the <a href="#work">work</a> and in most cases the name of the <a href="#author">author</a>(s) or <a href="#editor">editor</a>(s), and details of its <a href="#publication">publication</a>, used in <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>ing as the <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a> in creating the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> of the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  Compare with <a href="#titleframe">title frame</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="titlestatement"><b>title statement</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, plus the optional <a href="#gmd">general material designation</a> and remainder of the <a href="#title">title</a> (if applicable), given in the <a href="#titleand">title and statement of responsibility</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> (<a href="#field">field</a> 245 of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>).  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the wording, order, and spelling of the title proper is followed exactly as it appears in or on the <a href="#bibitem">item</a>, but <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a> and <a href="#capitalization">capitalization</a> may be changed by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="titulus"><b>titulus</b></a>
</dt><dd>Introductory words added in <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a>s by a <a href="#rubric">rubrisher</a> in red or blue <a href="#ink">ink</a> in a space left <a href="#blank">blank</a> at the beginning of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> when the <a href="#text">text</a> of a medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> was hand-<a href="#copy">copied</a>, often filling several lines.  <a href="#goldleaf">Gold leaf</a> was used in more important works.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tla1"><b>TLA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#tla"><b>T</b>heatre <b>L</b>ibrary <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tls1"><b><em>TLS</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#tls"><b>T</b>imes <b>L</b>iterary <b>S</b>upplement</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="toc"><b>TOC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#tableofcontents"><b>t</b>able <b>o</b>f <b>c</b>ontents</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tome"><b>tome</b></a>
</dt><dd>Originally, any <a href="#volume">volume</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> in more than one volume.  In modern <a href="#usage">usage</a>, a <a href="#book">book</a> of very large size, also weighty in <a href="#subject">subject</a> or <a href="#treatment">treatment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="toolbar"><b>toolbar</b></a>
</dt><dd>A narrow band along one side or across the top or bottom of a <a href="#window">window</a> or <a href="#frame">frame</a> in the <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a> of a <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> <a href="#application">application</a>, displaying a row of buttons or <a href="#icon">icon</a>s that can be clicked with a pointing <a href="#device">device</a> such as a <a href="#mouse">mouse</a> to <a href="#access">access</a> <a href="#menu">menu</a>s and open other <a href="#window">window</a>s, allowing the user to select <a href="#option">option</a>s, set <a href="#parameter">parameter</a>s, and perform functions.  Compare with <a href="#navigationbar">navigation bar</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tooling"><b>tooling</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#finishing">finishing</a>, decorative designs hand-stamped with a heated brass tool on the surface of the material covering the <a href="#board">board</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> (usually <a href="#cloth">cloth</a> or <a href="#leather">leather</a>).  Tooling can be <a href="#blind">blind</a> or highlighted in <a href="#ink">ink</a>, or in <a href="#goldleaf">gold leaf</a> or <a href="#goldfoil">foil</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="toolkit"><b>toolkit</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> or <a href="#online">online</a> guide that brings together in one place practical <a href="#information">information</a> for accomplishing a <a href="#goal">goal</a> or beginning a project, including but not limited to <a href="#casestudy">case studies</a>, action plans, policies, learning <a href="#module">module</a>s, resource lists, useful terminology, important contacts, etc. (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Ethnographer's Toolkit</em></b>, edited by Jean Schensul and Margaret LeCompte).  Also spelled <em>tool kit</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="toolkit1"><b>tool kit</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#toolkit">toolkit</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="top1"><b>TOP</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#top"><b>t</b>emporarily <b>o</b>ut of <b>p</b>rint</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="topic"><b>topic</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#subject">subject</a> for <a href="#research">research</a> or discussion.  The first step in a <a href="#library">library</a> research project is the formulation of a workable topic statement.  As a <a href="#litsearch">literature search</a> progresses, the topic may require refinement (change of <a href="#specificity">specificity</a> or focus), depending on the amount of <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#information">information</a> available and the time constraints of the <a href="#researcher">researcher</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#searchstrategy">search strategy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="topicalguide"><b>topical guide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> or <a href="#online">online</a> list or description of the best bibliographic <a href="#findingtool">tool</a>s and resources available to a <a href="#researcher">researcher</a> for conducting a <a href="#litsearch">literature search</a> on a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a>, presented in the sequence in which they would optimally be used.  Also known as a <a href="#pathfinder">pathfinder</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#searchstrategy">search strategy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="topo"><b>topo</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#topographic">topographic map</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="topographic"><b>topographic map</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#map">map</a> on any <a href="#scale">scale</a>
showing in relief the geographic features of a given area of the
surface of the earth (or another celestial body), usually by means of <a href="#contourmap">contour</a> lines.  When <a href="#unbound">unbound</a>, such a map is called a <em>topographic sheet</em>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>topo</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="toposeries"><b>topographic series</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of <a href="#topographic">topographic</a> <a href="#sheetmap">sheet map</a>s showing the geographic features of the surface of a country at <a href="#scale">scale</a>s of 1:10,000 to 1:250,000, usually <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by an <a href="#agency">agency</a> of civilian or military government, such as a <a href="#nationalsurvey">national survey</a>
or mapping division of a defense department. Topographic series are
also issued internationally at scales of 1:1,000,000 to 1:5,000,000. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#basemap">base map</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="topterm"><b>top term (TT)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The most general term in a <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, indicated by the <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> <b>TT</b> in the <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">term</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>INSPEC Thesaurus</em></b>) or by the narrowest <a href="#indention">indention</a> under the <a href="#heading">heading</a> to which it applies.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#broaderterm">BT</a>, <a href="#narrowerterm">NT</a>, and <a href="#relatedterm">RT</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tos1"><b>TOS</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#tos"><b>t</b>emporarily <b>o</b>ut of <b>s</b>tock</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="totalcirc"><b>total circulation</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#publishing">publishing</a>, the entire distribution of any <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, including <a href="#copy">copies</a> sent to paid <a href="#subscriber">subscriber</a>s, single-copy retail sales, in-house use, and <a href="#complimentary">complimentary copies</a> distributed for <a href="#promotion">promotion</a>al purposes.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="totalpublication"><b>total publication</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#publishersagreement">agreement</a> between an <a href="#author">author</a> and <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> in which a <a href="#work">work</a> is <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> and also in a <a href="#massmarket">mass market paperback</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> under the publisher's separate <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#imprint">imprint</a>, as opposed to leasing the paperback <a href="#rights">rights</a> to an independent publisher for which the author is usually paid a higher <a href="#royalties">royalty</a>.  The term does <em>not</em> apply to <a href="#simultaneouspub">simultaneous publication</a> under a single imprint of hardcover and <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>s, or to the subsequent issuance of a <a href="#tradepaperback">trade paperback</a> edition in which the <a href="#text">text</a> and <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s remain the same as in the hardcover edition.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="touchpad"><b>touchpad</b></a>
</dt><dd>An electronic pointing <a href="#device">device</a> consisting
of a small flat surface connected to a computer, which the user can
activate with the touch of a finger, instead of depressing the keys on
a <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> or moving a <a href="#mouse">mouse</a>.  Synonymous with <em>touch panel</em>.  Compare with <a href="#touchscreen">touch screen</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="touchscreen"><b>touch screen</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer screen covered with a clear touch-sensitive panel that enables the user to make selections from a <a href="#menu">menu</a> of <a href="#option">option</a>s or initiate specific operations by touching the part of the screen that displays the appropriate word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>, <a href="#icon">icon</a>, or button.  Pressure-sensitive cells in the panel transmit <a href="#data">data</a> to the screen <a href="#software">software</a>, activating the selection.  Also spelled <em>touchscreen</em>.  Compare with <a href="#touchpad">touchpad</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#mouse">mouse</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="toybook"><b>toy book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small, <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a> <a href="#book">book</a> for young children, <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 19th century England and America, usually consisting of eight <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of vivid, hand-colored <a href="#picture">picture</a>s with very little <a href="#text">text</a> (<a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a>s and simple <a href="#tale">tale</a>s were popular).  Originally <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a>s, later variations included <a href="#clothbook">cloth book</a>s printed on sturdy fabric, <a href="#popupbook">pop-up book</a>s, and <a href="#flickerbook">flicker book</a>s.  Toy books were often published in <a href="#series">series</a> to encourage gift buying and <a href="#bookcollecting">collecting</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="toycollection"><b>toy collection</b></a>
</dt><dd>A collection of toys, <a href="#puppetry">puppet</a>s, games, etc., sometimes available for loan in the <a href="#childrensroom">children's room</a> of a <a href="#publiclibrary">public library</a>, especially helpful in serving families in low-income communities.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tracings"><b>tracings</b></a>
</dt><dd>A record of the additional <a href="#heading">heading</a>s under which a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> is listed in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, usually associated with the <a href="#mainentry">main entry</a>.  Also, a list in an <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority file</a> of all the <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s made to and from a <a href="#heading">heading</a> used in a file of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s, to enable the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> to "trace" all the <a href="#entry">entries</a> referring to the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> whenever a change or correction is necessary, or when the item is <a href="#withdrawal">withdrawn</a> from the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="track"><b>track</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#isar">information storage and retrieval</a>, one of the concentric rings or spirals on the surface of a magnetic <a href="#disk">disk</a>, on which <a href="#data">data</a> is recorded.  A standard <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a> has either 80 tracks (double-density) or 160 tracks (high-density).  In <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>, one or more optical or magnetic bands running parallel with the long dimension of an <a href="#audiotape">audiotape</a>, <a href="#videotape">videotape</a>, or <a href="#film">film</a> on which signals are recorded for <a href="#playback">playback</a> as synchronized sound.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tract"><b>tract</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a> containing a <a href="#treatise">treatise</a> or discourse on a political, social, or religious <a href="#topic">topic</a>, usually <a href="#issue">issue</a>d as <a href="#propaganda">propaganda</a> or for doctrinal purposes.  Also refers to a pamphlet made from a single <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#printing">printing</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a> folded one or more times to create <a href="#leaf">leaves</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradeassociation"><b>trade association</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization dedicated to promoting a specific line of business, such as the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a>, for example, the <a href="#aap">Association of American Publishers</a> or the <a href="#aba">American Booksellers Association</a>.  Most trade <a href="#association">association</a>s <a href="#publishing">publish</a> a <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a> to keep members informed of new products and developments affecting their interests.  <a href="#directory">Directory</a> <a href="#information">information</a> on book trade associations is available in the <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradebinding"><b>trade binding</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#publishersbinding">publisher's binding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradebook"><b>trade book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A general <a href="#term">term</a> encompassing quality <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> and <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> for <a href="#adult">adult</a>s, <a href="#tradepaperback">trade paperback</a>s, and <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> for the general public, as distinct from <a href="#massmarket">mass market paperback</a>s sold at newsstands and <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s, <a href="#scholarlybook">scholarly</a> books, and <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s intended for a narrow segment of the market.  The standard <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#discount">discount</a> on trade <a href="#book">book</a>s is 40%.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#tradebookstore">trade bookstore</a> and <a href="#tradepublisher">trade publisher</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradebookstore"><b>trade bookstore</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a> that sells <a href="#book">book</a>s of good quality, <a href="#publishing">published</a> for the general public rather than for a narrow segment of the market.  Large chains may also sell <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, <a href="#genintmag">general interest magazine</a>s, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>s, music <a href="#compactdisc">CD</a>s, <a href="#roadmap">road map</a>s, <a href="#calendar">calendar</a>s, greeting cards, etc. (<em>examples</em>: <a href="http://www.barnesandnoble.com/">Barnes and Noble</a> and <a href="http://www.bordersstores.com/index.jsp">Borders Books &amp; Music</a>).  Trade bookstores normally do not stock expensive <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s, <a href="#scholarlybook">scholarly</a> and technical books, and <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>s.  <a href="#massmarket">Mass market paperback</a>s are stocked selectively, based on reputation of <a href="#author">author</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradecatalog"><b>trade catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of all the <a href="#book">book</a>s (currently <a href="#inprint">in print</a>), <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a specific country or in <em>other</em> countries for which domestic <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s act as agents (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="#bip">Books in Print</a></em>).  Also, any <a href="#publication">publication</a> that lists and describes the products manufactured and sold by a commercial company, with prices, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, and <a href="#information">information</a> on how to order, for use in sales.  The <a href="#publisherscatalog">publisher's catalog</a>s sent by post to <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s and <a href="#library">libraries</a> are a prime example.  Some booksellers also publish their own trade <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s for distribution to potential retail customers, or make catalog information available on the <a href="#www">Web</a> (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.amazon.com/">Amazon.com</a>).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradedirectory"><b>trade directory</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually <a href="#issue">issue</a>d <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly,
listing the companies and organizations engaged in buying, selling, or
exchanging a specific category of goods and services. <a href="#entry">Entries</a> include the official name, mailing address, phone/FAX numbers, key personnel, and other important <a href="#information">information</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="#abtd">American Book Trade Directory</a></em> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradeedition"><b>trade edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> produced by a <a href="#tradepublisher">trade publisher</a> in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> and/or <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> <a href="#publishersbinding">publisher's binding</a> for sale to quality <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s and <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  Trade editions are <a href="#publishing">published</a> for the general <a href="#reader">reader</a>, rather than a specific segment of the market.  Compare with <a href="#massmarket">mass-market paperback</a>, <a href="#scholarlybook">scholarly book</a>, and <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradejournal"><b>trade journal</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> devoted to disseminating news and <a href="#information">information</a> of interest to a specific category of business or industry, often <a href="#publishing">published</a> by a <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a>.   Some trade journals are available in an <a href="#online">online</a> version, as well as in <a href="#print">print</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://publishersweekly.reviewsnews.com/">Publishers Weekly</a></em>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradelist"><b>trade list</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#tradecatalog">trade catalog</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="trademark"><b>trademark</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#letter">letter</a>, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>, word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, <a href="#logo">logo</a>, device, design, sound, or <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>
(or combination of these) used in connection with a product or service
to signify, directly or by association, the identity of the owner,
usually a commercial enterprise that has reserved to itself the use of
the distinctive mark by registering it with the U.S. <a href="#patent">Patent</a>
and Trademark Office. Trademarks of successful products and services
are jealously guarded by their owners to prevent competitors from
imitating them. Registration, indicated by an "R" enclosed in a small
circle following the name ("TM" if registration is pending), gives the
owner the right to legal redress in case of <a href="#infringement">infringement</a>.  Also spelled <em>trade mark</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#infringement">infringement</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradename"><b>trade name</b></a>
</dt><dd>The name used to designate a specific business enterprise and the reputation it has acquired in the market place (<em>example</em>:  Microsoft), as distinct from any <a href="#trademark">trademark</a> associated with the firm's products (<em>Windows</em>).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#brandname">brand name</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradepaperback"><b>trade paperback</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#softcover">softcover</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by a <a href="#universitypress">university press</a> or <a href="#tradepublisher">trade publisher</a>, in larger <a href="#format">format</a> and better quality <a href="#binding">binding</a> than a <a href="#massmarket">mass-market paperback</a>, for retail sale in <a href="#collegebookstore">college</a> and <a href="#tradebookstore">trade bookstore</a>s.  Most <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>s are published first in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>, then <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>ed in <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> from the same <a href="#plate">plate</a>s after sales potential in hardcover has been realized.  In some instances, paperback <a href="#rights">rights</a> are sold by the original publisher to a trade paperback publisher.  Synonymous with <em>quality paperback</em>.  Compare with <a href="#massmarket">mass-market paperback</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tradepublisher"><b>trade publisher</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> house that <a href="#issue">issue</a>s <a href="#book">book</a>s of interest to the educated <a href="#reader">reader</a>, for sale in college and quality retail bookstores (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.fsgbooks.com/">Farrar, Straus and Giroux</a> or <a href="http://www.stmartins.com/">St. Martin's Press</a>).  Few large trade <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s remain independent.  A case in point is Alfred A. Knopf, now owned by <a href="http://www.randomhouse.com/">Random House</a>, which is in turn owned by the international publishing and entertainment conglomerate <a href="http://www.bertelsmann.de/">Bertelsmann AG</a>.  Compare with <a href="#popularpress">popular press</a> and <a href="#universitypress">university press</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#tradebook">trade book</a> and <a href="#tradeedition">trade edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tragedy"><b>tragedy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a> in <a href="#prose">prose</a> or <a href="#verse">verse</a> in which a catastrophe or sudden reversal of fortune befalls the protagonist, usually due to uncontrollable circumstances (<em>example</em>:  Arthur Miller's <b><em>Death of a Salesman</em></b>) or as a result of an error of judgment or serious flaw in character (<b><em>Macbeth</em></b>).  In classical Greek drama, the weakness that brings about the downfall of the tragic hero (or heroine) is typically <em>hubris</em> (pride).  Compare with <a href="#comedy">comedy</a> and <a href="#tragicomedy">tragicomedy</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tragicomedy"><b>tragicomedy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of drama that originated in Elizabethan and Jacobean England, combining the forms and conventions of <a href="#tragedy">tragedy</a> <em>and</em> <a href="#comedy">comedy</a>, usually by including <a href="#character">character</a>s of both high and low social position, and by unfolding unfortunate events that unexpectedly result in a happy ending (<em>example</em>:  Shakespeare's <b><em>Merchant of Venice</em></b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="trailer"><b>trailer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A very short <a href="#film">film</a> used primarily for advertising purposes, consisting of carefully selected <a href="#extract">extract</a>s from a longer <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> to be shown at a later date.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#term">term</a> is added inside <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s [trailer] following the <a href="#titleproper">title proper</a> in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> to indicate material type.  Compare with <a href="#filmclip">film clip</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#preview">preview</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the short strip of <a href="#film">film</a> without images at the end of a <a href="#filmstrip">filmstrip</a>, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, or unexposed roll of film, added to allow the item to be handled without damage.  Compare with <a href="#leader">leader</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="training"><b>training</b></a>
</dt><dd>Instruction designed to teach a person or group of people (<em>trainees</em>) a specific skill or set of skills, for example, how to check <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> in and out at the <a href="#circulationdesk">circulation desk</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>, or how to <a href="#reshelving">reshelve</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in correct <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> sequence.  <a href="#inservice">In-service training</a> occurs in the workplace during normal working hours, sometimes in the context in which the skill(s) will be used.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="transactionlog"><b>transaction log</b></a>
</dt><dd>A continuous record of the operations initiated by users of an
automated system during a designated period of time (week, month,
year). In <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, the "transactions" are usually <a href="#search">search</a>es recorded by type (<a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#subjectheading">subject</a>, <a href="#keywords">keywords</a>, etc.) which can be analyzed to reveal usage patterns and longitudinal changes in search behavior.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#peakuse">peak use</a>.
<p>
Also refers to a <a href="#record">record</a> kept for statistical purposes of the number of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#patron">patron</a>s who receive assistance from <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> at a <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a>, for example, the number of <a href="#refquestion">question</a>s answered by <a href="#reflibrarian">librarian</a>s at the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>, usually broken down by type of question (<a href="#directional">directional</a>, <a href="#information">information</a>al, <a href="#bi">instruction</a>al, <a href="#inforeferral">referral</a>).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="transactions"><b>transactions</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#papers">papers</a> or <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>s of papers presented at a <a href="#conference">conference</a> or meeting of a <a href="#society">society</a> or  <a href="#association">association</a>, usually including a <a href="#record">record</a> of what transpired.  Compare with <a href="#proceedings">proceedings</a>.
<p>

</p></dd><dt><a name="transcribe"><b>transcribe</b></a>
</dt><dd>To make a written or typewritten <a href="#copy">copy</a>, usually of a speech, <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>, <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>, or other oral presentation, or a copy of notes taken on the <a href="#content">content</a> of such a presentation.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#transcript">transcript</a>.  
<p>
Also, to <a href="#adaptation">adapt</a> or <a href="#arrangement">arrange</a> a <a href="#piece">piece</a> of music for a voice, instrument, or ensemble different from that for which the <a href="#work">work</a> was originally intended.  In computing, to copy a <a href="#data">data</a> or <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> <a href="#file">file</a> from one external <a href="#storage">storage</a> <a href="#medium">medium</a> to another without altering its <a href="#content">content</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="transcript"><b>transcript</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of an <a href="#original">original</a>, usually made by hand or typewritten, particularly a legal <a href="#document">document</a> or official <a href="#record">record</a>.  Also refers to the written record of words spoken in court proceedings or in a speech, interview, <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>, or <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#transcribe">transcribe</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="transfer"><b>transfer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A change in the physical <a href="#custody">custody</a> of <a href="#archives">archival</a> materials from one location or <a href="#agency">agency</a> to another, usually without a corresponding change of legal ownership and responsibility, for example, the relocation of <a href="#records">records</a> no longer <a href="#currency">current</a> to <a href="#temporarystorage">temporary storage</a> to await final <a href="#disposition">disposition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="translation"><b>translation</b></a>
</dt><dd>A passage from a speech or written <a href="#work">work</a>, or an entire speech or work, put into the words of another <a href="#language">language</a>
(English into Spanish), or into a more modern form of the same language
(Old English or Middle English into contemporary English), usually to
make the <a href="#text">text</a> more accessible to individuals who
are unable to read it in the original language. Translations differ in
the degree to which they follow the <a href="#original">original</a>.  The name of the <em>translator</em> usually appears on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a>, following the name of the <a href="#author">author</a>.  A translation may have a <a href="#paralleltitle">parallel title</a> in the <a href="#sourcelanguage">source language</a>.  In <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the <a href="#note">note</a> <em>Translation of:</em> is added in the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, giving the <a href="#title">title</a> in the original language.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>trans</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="transliteration"><b>transliteration</b></a>
</dt><dd>Rendering the <a href="#character">character</a>s of one <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> in characters representing the same sound (or sounds) in another alphabet (<em>example</em>:  Greek or Cyrillic into Roman).  Each character is treated independently of the others.  Compare with <a href="#romanization">romanization</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="transparency"><b>transparency</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sheet of transparent <a href="#film">film</a>, usually 8 1/2 x 11" in size, bearing <a href="#text">text</a> and/or images in color or black-and-white, designed to be projected on a large screen using an <a href="#overheadprojector">overhead projector</a> or <a href="#documentcamera">document camera</a>.  <a href="#presentationsoftware">Presentation software</a> has <a href="#superseded">superseded</a> overhead transparencies, but a well-prepared presenter brings them to use as <a href="#backup">backup</a> in case of <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a> or <a href="#network">network</a> failure.  Synonymous with <em>overhead transparency</em>.  Compare with <a href="#overlay">overlay</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="travelguide"><b>travel guide</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#handbook">handbook</a> designed for persons
interested in touring a foreign country, or an unfamiliar city, state,
province, or region of their own country. In addition to describing
major attractions, most travel guides include <a href="#map">map</a>s and directions, <a href="#information">information</a>
about dining and overnight accommodations, and advice about currency
exchange, immunizations, personal safety, and communication with the
local inhabitants. Some guides specialize in a particular type of
travel, such as bicycle touring or ecotourism. <p>
In <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraires</a>, travel guides are usually shelved by <a href="#callnumber">call number</a> in the <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> section.  Some <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> keep current <a href="#edition">edition</a>s in <a href="#refcollection">reference</a>.  Because <a href="#currency">currency</a> is important, travel guides may be placed on <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a>.  Synonymous with <em>tour guide</em> and <em>travel book</em>.  Compare with <a href="#guidebook">guidebook</a>.   
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="treasurehunt"><b>treasure hunt</b></a>
</dt><dd>An exercise in which students are required by their instructor to use the resources of the <a href="#library">library</a>
to find answers to a list of very specific and often unrelated
questions, sometimes as a contest. This type of assignment usually puts
a temporary strain on the <a href="#refdesk">reference desk</a>, especially when a large <a href="#number">number</a> of students converge on the library, all needing the same <a href="#information">information</a> at the same time.  For this reason, it is one of the "pet peeves" of <a href="#reflibrarian">reference librarian</a>s who believe library skills are best learned in the context of a more meaningful <a href="#research">research</a> assignment.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="treatise"><b>treatise</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or long formal <a href="#essay">essay</a>, usually on an abstruse or complex <a href="#subject">subject</a>, especially a systematic well-<a href="#documentation">documented</a> presentation of facts or evidence, and the principles or conclusions drawn from them.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is sometimes used in a pejorative sense to refer to a written <a href="#work">work</a> in which the <a href="#treatment">treatment</a> is dry and scholarly or unnecessarily thorough or detailed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="treatment"><b>treatment</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> account of the <a href="#screenplay">screenplay</a> for a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> or television <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>, including a detailed description of <a href="#character">character</a>s, scenes, sets, camerawork, etc., but without the <a href="#dialogue">dialogue</a>.  Compare with <a href="#scenario">scenario</a>.
<p>
In a more general sense, the manner in which a <a href="#subject">subject</a> or theme is handled stylistically in a <a href="#literarywork">literary</a> or artistic <a href="#work">work</a> (<a href="#comedy">comically</a>, <a href="#tragedy">tragically</a>, <a href="#satire">satirically</a>, etc.).
</p><p>
In <a href="#conservation">conservation</a>, use of a specific technique or set of procedures to deliberately alter the chemical or physical <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#document">document</a> or other object for the purpose of prolonging its existence, including <a href="#stabilization">stabilization</a> and possible <a href="#restoration">restoration</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#treatmenthistory">treatment history</a>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="treatmenthistory"><b>treatment history</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#record">record</a> of the <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> procedures applied to an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> (<a href="#deacidification">deacidification</a>, <a href="#fumigation">fumigation</a>, <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>, <a href="#restoration">restoration</a>,
etc.), usually including date of application and any details concerning
the treatment process which might be of future use to conservators,
particularly in cases requiring <a href="#reversibility">reversal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="treaty"><b>treaty</b></a>
</dt><dd>A formal written agreement between two or more governments
concerning peace, military alliance, trade relations, economic
assistance, etc., often the result of protracted negotiations. Also
refers to the <a href="#signed">signed</a> <a href="#document">document</a> serving as the official <a href="#record">record</a> of such an agreement.  The <a href="#text">text</a>s of important treaties are available in the <a href="#govdocs">government documents</a> or <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of large <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  The originals are usually housed in national <a href="#archives">archives</a> or in the <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a> of <a href="#nationallib">national libraries</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="treestructure"><b>tree structure</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#classified">classified</a> display in a <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#indexinglang">indexing term</a>s showing the complete <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchy</a> of <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s, from the broadest to the most <a href="#specificity">specific</a>, usually by <a href="#indention">indention</a>, sometimes with a tree number indicating the location of the heading in the tree, as in the <b><em>Medical Subject Headings. Tree Structures</em></b> developed and maintained by the <a href="#nlm">National Library of Medicine</a>:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>:</dd></dl>
<center><table>
<tbody><tr align="left"><td width="500"><ul>Diagnosis<ul>Diagnosis, Cardiovascular<ul>Angiography<ul>Angiocardiography<br>Angiography, Digital subtraction<br>Aortography<br>Cerebral angiography<br>Cineangiography</ul>Angioscopy</ul></ul></ul></td><td width="200">E1<br>E1.145<br>E1.145.77<br>E1.145.102<br>E1.145.141<br>E1.145.181<br>E1.145.300<br>E1.145.385<br>E1.145.90</td></tr>
</tbody></table></center>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="trend"><b>trend</b></a>
</dt><dd>Movement in the development of a phenomenon, usually in a
certain direction, sometimes measured statistically. Organizations use <em>trend analysis</em> to anticipate future developments that might affect their interests.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used in the more general sense of "current fashion."  In large <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>, a recent trend has been to include, in plans for <a href="#renovation">renovation</a> and  <a href="#newconstruc">new construction</a>, a giftshop operated by the <a href="#friends">Friends of the Library</a>.  <a href="#academiclib">Academic libraries</a> are more inclined to provide a <a href="#cybercafe">cybercafe</a> on the premises.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="trial"><b>trial</b></a>
</dt><dd>A test conducted for a limited period of time to determine the suitability of a new person in a <a href="#position">position</a>, or the quality or feasibility of a new system, product, or service. <a href="#bibdatabase">Database</a> <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>s usually offer a free 30-day trial to <a href="#library">libraries</a> as an inducement to <a href="#subscription">subscribe</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="trialuser"><b>trial user</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person or organization asked to use a new service or
computer system, usually for a limited period of time, to test its
usefulness and effectiveness, and to help identify problems that need
to be corrected before the final version is released for general use.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="triennial"><b>triennial</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d every three years.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> issued every three years.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#annual">annual</a>, <a href="#biennial">biennial</a>, <a href="#quadrennial">quadrennial</a>, <a href="#quinquennial">quinquennial</a>, <a href="#sexennial">sexennial</a>, <a href="#septennial">septennial</a>, and <a href="#decennial">decennial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="trilogy"><b>trilogy</b></a>
</dt><dd>A set of three <a href="#narrative">narrative</a> <a href="#work">work</a>s related in theme or <a href="#plot">plot</a>, which together form a larger work (<em>example</em>:  the <b><em>Oresteia</em></b> of Aeschylus).  Four similarly related works are called a <em>tetrology</em> (<b><em>The Alexandria Quartet</em></b> by Lawrence Durrell).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#prequel">prequel</a> and <a href="#sequel">sequel</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="trimmed"><b>trimmed</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in the <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> to indicate that the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> have been cut down to a size smaller than the <a href="#publication">publication</a> as originally <a href="#issue">issue</a>d.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#trimming">trimming</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="trimming"><b>trimming</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the process of slicing approximately 1/8 of an inch from the <a href="#head">head</a>, <a href="#tail">tail</a>, and <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> of the <a href="#body">body</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> to remove the folds of its <a href="#signature">signature</a>s, done on a machine called a <a href="#guillotine">guillotine</a>.  In <a href="#paperback">paperback</a> books, the <a href="#cover">cover</a> is usually <a href="#cutflush">cut flush</a> or even with the <a href="#section">section</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#uncut">uncut</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#shaved">shaved</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="trimsize"><b>trim size</b></a>
</dt><dd>The finished dimensions of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> or <a href="#publication">publication</a> after waste has been <a href="#trimming">trimmed</a> away to prepare it for <a href="#binding">binding</a>, usually indicated in the <a href="#specifications">specifications</a> for the print job.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="triptych"><b>triptych</b></a>
</dt><dd><em><b>See</b></em>:  <a href="#diptych">diptych</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="truecrime"><b>true crime story</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#nonfiction">nonfiction</a> <a href="#genre">genre</a> in which the <a href="#subject">subject</a>
is an actual crime or event (disappearance, kidnapping, murder, etc.)
so bizarre or inexplicable that it excites popular interest and
curiosity (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Small Sacrifices:  A True Story of Passion and Murder</em></b> by Ann Rule).  Compare with <a href="#mystery">mystery</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="truncation"><b>truncation</b></a>
</dt><dd>The addition of a <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> at the beginning or end of a word <a href="#stem">stem</a> in a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> <a href="#search">search</a> to <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> <a href="#variant">variant</a>s containing the root.  Truncation is particularly useful in retrieving both the <em>singular</em> and the <em>plural</em> forms of a word in the same search. 
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>:  
<dl><dt></dt><dd><b>*librar*</b> to retrieve records containing "interlibrary," "intralibrary," "librarian," "librariana," "librarianship," "libraries," etc.</dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
In most <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a>s and <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, the end truncation symbol is the <b>*</b> (<a href="#asterisk">asterisk</a>), but since the truncation symbol is not <a href="#standardization">standardized</a>, other symbols may be used (?, $, #, +).  In some <a href="#database">database</a>s, the user may add a <a href="#number">number</a> after the symbol to specify how many <a href="#character">character</a>s the symbol may represent (<em>example</em>:  <b>facet?1</b>
to retrieve "facets" but not "faceted" or "facetiae"). As a general
rule, it is unwise to truncate fewer than four characters (<em>example</em>:  <b>art*</b>
retrieves "artist," "artistic," "artistry," and "artwork," but also
"artichoke," "artillery," etc.). Some databases are designed to
truncate automatically. Users are advised to read carefully any <a href="#helpscreen">help screen</a>s before truncating in an unfamiliar database.  Synonymous with <em>character masking</em>.  <em><strong>See also</strong></em>:  <a href="#wildcard">wildcard</a>.  
</p><p>    
</p></dd><dt><a name="trustee"><b>trustee</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#librarytrustee">library trustee</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tt"><b>TT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#topterm">top term</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="turnaroundtime"><b>turnaround time</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#dataprocessing">data processing</a>, the amount of time that elapses between the initiation of a process or operation and its completion.  Compare with <a href="#responsetime">response time</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="turnin"><b>turn-in</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>, the portion of the covering of a <a href="#book">book</a> folded over the outer edges of the <a href="#board">board</a>s, from outside to inside, <a href="#miter">miter</a>ed at the <a href="#corner">corner</a>s, and covered to within 1/8-3/16" of the edge by the <a href="#pastedown">paste-down</a>.  On library corners, the turn-in is folded; on Dutch corners, it is cut. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="turnover"><b>turnover</b></a>
</dt><dd>The rate at which employees leave a company, organization, or institution and are replaced.  A high <em>turnover rate</em> may be a sign of difficult working conditions, inadequate compensation, poor management, <a href="#burnout">burnout</a>, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="tutorial"><b>tutorial</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> or <a href="#online">online</a> instructional tool designed to teach <a href="#novice">novice</a>s
how to use a computer system or electronic resource, usually in a
self-paced step-by-step manner, often with questions at the end for
testing proficiency. <a href="#onlinetutorial">Online tutorial</a>s have been developed by <a href="#bi">instruction</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s to accommodate <a href="#distancelearning">distance learners</a> and students who prefer <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#library">library</a> instruction.  Compare with <a href="#helpscreen">help screen</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="twiceweekly"><b>twice weekly</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#semiweekly">semiweekly</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="twistedpair"><b>twisted pair</b></a>
</dt><dd>A cable of relatively low <a href="#bandwidth">bandwidth</a> used in older telephone networks and less costly <a href="#localarea">LAN</a>s,
consisting of two separately insulated thin-diameter wires twisted
around each other, one to carry the signal and the other grounded to
absorb interference. Most computer <a href="#network">network</a>s use <a href="#coaxial">coaxial cable</a> and/or <a href="#opticalfiber">optical fiber</a> which provide the higher bandwidth required for high-speed <a href="#data">data</a> transmission.  Telephone companies in the United States are upgrading their <a href="#infrastructure">infrastructure</a> to coax and fiber-optic cable.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="twodoublefold"><b>two-double fold test</b></a>
</dt><dd>A simple trial used by <a href="#conservation">conservator</a>s to detect <a href="#brittle">brittle</a> <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  One corner of a <a href="#leaf">leaf</a>
is gently folded diagonally forward and back twice about 1/2-inch in
from the point where the edges meet. Paper is found to be brittle if
the corner breaks off or detaches with a slight pull after the fourth
fold. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="twoon"><b>two on</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#sewing">sewing</a> method used in <a href="#handbinding">hand-binding</a> in which two <a href="#section">section</a>s are sewn along the fold with a single length of <a href="#thread">thread</a>, alternating between the sections from <a href="#kettle">kettle stitch</a> to kettle stitch.  Today, the technique is used mainly in <a href="#finebook">fine</a> <a href="#binding">binding</a> to minimize <a href="#swell">swell</a> (most <a href="#publishersbinding">trade binding</a>s are sewn <a href="#allalong">all along</a>).  Hand sewing three sections together in similar fashion is known as <em>three on</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="type"><b>type</b></a>
</dt><dd>Small, separately cast rectangular metal units, each bearing on its <a href="#face">face</a> a single <a href="#character">character</a> cut in relief.  In <a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a> <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the units are assembled by a <a href="#typesetting">typesetter</a> into <a href="#page">page</a>s of <a href="#text">text</a>, locked in a <a href="#chase">chase</a> and transferred to the bed of a <a href="#printingpress">printing press</a>, where they are <a href="#ink">ink</a>ed and an <a href="#impression">impression</a> of the type <a href="#matter">matter</a> made under pressure on a printing surface such as <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  After the print job is completed, the units are disassembled for reuse.  <a href="#gutenberg">Johann Gutenberg</a> is credited with inventing <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a> in Germany in or around the year 1456.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#displaytype">display type</a>, <a href="#extracttype">extract type</a>, <a href="#mousetype">mouse type</a>, <a href="#texttype">text type</a>, <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>, <a href="#typefamily">type family</a>, and <a href="#typesize">type size</a>. 
<p>
Also, to manually key <a href="#input">input</a> into a computer system via a <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>, for example, a <a href="#searchstatement">search statement</a> to <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> <a href="#information">information</a> from an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="typeface"><b>typeface</b></a>

</dt><dd>The upper surface of a unit of <a href="#type">type</a>, bearing in relief the <a href="#character">character</a> to be <a href="#printing">printed</a>.  Also refers to the general design or style of the <a href="#character">character</a>s of a <a href="#font">font</a> of <a href="#type">type</a>, including all the <a href="#typesize">size</a>s and <a href="#weight">weight</a>s in which the font is made.  Designing a new typeface is a major undertaking, even for an experienced <a href="#typography">typographer</a>.  It is therefore not unusual for a typeface to be named after the person who designed it (<em>example</em>:  <b>Garamond</b>).  There does not appear to be universal agreement on the <a href="#classification">classification</a> of typefaces.  Also spelled <em>type face</em>.  Sometimes <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviated</a> <em>face</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#cameo">cameo</a>, <a href="#condensed">condensed</a>, <a href="#expanded">expanded</a>, <a href="#fatface">fat face</a>, <a href="#glyphic">glyphic</a>, <a href="#gothic">gothic</a>, <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>, <a href="#inline">inline</a>, <a href="#italic">italic</a>, <a href="#monoline">monoline</a>, and <a href="#outlineletter">outline</a>, <a href="#roman">roman</a>, and <a href="#script">script</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="typefacsimile"><b>type facsimile</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#reprint">reprint</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a> made from a new <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> of <a href="#type">type</a> in which every detail of the appearance of <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a> in the <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> is <a href="#copy">copied</a> as precisely as possible.  Synonymous with <em>facsimile reprint</em>.  Compare with <a href="#facsimile">facsimile edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="typefamily"><b>type family</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, all the variants of the same basic <a href="#type">type</a> design, including <a href="#uppercase">uppercase</a>, <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a>, and <a href="#smallcapital">small capital</a>s in both <a href="#roman">roman</a> and <a href="#italic">italic</a> in all <a href="#typesize">size</a>s and <a href="#weight">weight</a>s (<a href="#lightface">lightface</a>, <a href="#medium">medium</a>, semi-bold, <a href="#boldface">boldface</a>, <a href="#condensed">condensed</a>, <a href="#expanded">expanded</a>).  Compare with <a href="#font">font</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="typerecording"><b>type of recording</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the method used to encode sound on a <a href="#disc">disc</a> or tape (<a href="#analog">analog</a>, <a href="#digital">digital</a>, magnetic, or optical) is given in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> created to represent the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> in the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>, as in the following examples:
<p>
</p><dl><dt>
</dt><dd>5 sound discs : analog, 331/3 <a href="#rpm">rpm</a>, <a href="#stereophonic">stereo</a>, ; 12 min
</dd><dd>1 sound disc (59 min.) : digital, stereo. ; 4 3/4 in
</dd><dd>2 sound cassettes (129 min.) : analog, 1 7/8 <a href="#ips">ips</a>., stereo
</dd><dd>1 sound cassette (60 min.) : digital
</dd><dd>1 sound track film reel (10 min.) : magnetic, 24 <a href="#fps">fps</a> 
</dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="typepage"><b>type page</b></a>
</dt><dd>The area or part of a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#page">page</a> that is printed upon, excluding the <a href="#margin">margin</a>s, <a href="#runninghead">headline</a>s, <a href="#runningfoot">footline</a>s, and <a href="#pagination">page numbers</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="typescript"><b>typescript</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#author">author</a>'s <a href="#original">original</a> typewritten <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, in the form in which it is submitted for <a href="#publication">publication</a>, or a typewritten copy of the original commissioned by the author or <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, as opposed to a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> written by hand.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>ts</em>. and <em>tss</em>. (plural).    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="typesetting"><b>typesetting</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, the setting of <a href="#type">type</a> from <a href="#copy">copy</a>, either by hand or by machine, done by a person called a <em>typesetter</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#typography">typography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="typesize"><b>type size</b></a>
</dt><dd>The dimensions (height and width) of the body size of a <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#font">font</a>, usually given in <a href="#point">point</a>s.  Most <a href="#book">book</a>s are <a href="#printing">printed</a> in type sizes ranging from 5-point to 22-point.  Larger types sizes are used mainly for <a href="#displaymatter">display matter</a>.  On the old-fashioned typewriter, <a href="#pica">pica</a> was the most common type size.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#extracttype">extract type</a> and <a href="#texttype">text type</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="typicallibrarian"><b>typical librarian</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#stereotype">stereotype</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="#typo1"><b>typo</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#typo">typographical error</a>.
<p>

</p></dd><dt><a name="typo"><b>typographical error</b></a>
</dt><dd>A mistake in a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#work">work</a> made by the <a href="#typesetting">typesetter</a>.  Also refers to a similar error made by a person using a <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> to <a href="#type">type</a> a <a href="#text">text</a>.  Most <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#software">software</a> includes an automatic <a href="#spellchecker">spell checker</a> to alert writers to such errors.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>typo</em>.  Synonymous with <em>misprint</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#proofreading">proofreading</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="typography"><b>typography</b></a>
</dt><dd>The art and craft of <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> and arranging <a href="#type">type</a>, and making <a href="#impression">impression</a>s from the result, which began with the invention of <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a> by <a href="#gutenberg">Johann Gutenberg</a> in Germany in the mid-15th century.  Also refers to the general style, arrangement, and appearance of a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> from type, and to the skill involved in selecting a suitable <a href="#ink">ink</a> and grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, choosing an appropriate <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> and <a href="#typesize">type size</a>, determining <a href="#page">page</a> <a href="#layout">layout</a>, etc.  The person responsible for the final appearance of a printed <a href="#publication">publication</a> is the <em>typographer</em>.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>
<center>| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> | <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a>
| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="U">U</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="ubcim"><b><em>UBCIM</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialism">initialism</a> that stands for <b>U</b>niversal <b>B</b>ibliographic <b>C</b>ontrol and <b>I</b>nternational <b>M</b>ARC Core Activity.  <b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#unimarc">Universal Machine-Readable Cataloging (UNIMARC)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ucc"><b><em>UCC</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <em><a href="#universalcopyright"><b>U</b>niversal <b>C</b>opyright <b>C</b>onvention</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="udc"><b>UDC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#universaldecimal"><b>U</b>niversal <b>D</b>ecimal <b>C</b>lassification</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="uf"><b>UF</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#usedfor"><b>u</b>sed <b>f</b>or</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ulc1"><b>ULC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ulc"><b>U</b>rban <b>L</b>ibraries <b>C</b>ouncil</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ulrichs"><b><em>Ulrich's International Periodicals Directory</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> since 1932 by <a href="#rrbowker">R. R. Bowker</a>, <b><em>Ulrich's International Periodicals Directory</em></b> provides bibliographic <a href="#information">information</a> and <a href="#subscripprice">pricing</a> for a <a href="#classified">classified</a> list of over 164,000 regularly and <a href="#irregular">irregular</a>ly <a href="#issue">issue</a>d <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s <a href="#currency">current</a>ly published in the U.S. and internationally, including <a href="#title">title</a>s available electronically.  The <a href="#directory">directory</a> is <a href="#index">index</a>ed by <a href="#title">title</a> and <a href="#issn">ISSN</a>, with separate sections for <a href="#cessation">cessation</a>s, <a href="#changedtitle">title change</a>s, <a href="#referee">referee</a>d <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, and titles available in various <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>s.  <b><em>Ulrich's</em></b> is also available on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a> and <a href="#online">online</a> by <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#serialsdirectory">The Serials Directory</a></em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ultrafiche"><b>ultrafiche</b></a>
</dt><dd>A card-shaped transparent <a href="#microform">microform</a> with a <a href="#reductionratio">reduction ratio</a> considerably greater than that of standard <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a> or <a href="#superfiche">superfiche</a> (up to 3,000 <a href="#frame">frame</a>s per 4 x 6-inch <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>).  A special ultrafiche <a href="#readerprinter">reader-printer</a> machine is required to view and make <a href="#hardcopy">hard copies</a> of <a href="#document">document</a>s stored in this <a href="#medium">medium</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ultraviolet"><b>ultraviolet (UV)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Electromagnetic radiation beyond the spectrum visible to
humans as light, shorter in wavelength than violet light but longer
than X-rays. The sun is the chief source of natural ultraviolet
radiation. Because UV radiation can damage <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s and accelerate the <a href="#deterioration">deterioration</a> of certain grades of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, prolonged exposure of <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> to direct sunlight should be avoided and incandescent lighting installed when possible in storage areas where <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> is a high priority.  UV filters can be used to reduce exposure. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="umbilicus"><b>umbilicus</b></a>
</dt><dd>In antiquity, a knobbed wooden rod attached to one end of a <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a> <a href="#scroll">scroll</a> around which a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> was rolled when not in use.  A <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> tag was usually attached to one end, bearing a note indicating the <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#contents">contents</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unabridged"><b>unabridged</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#version">version</a> of a written <a href="#work">work</a> that has not been shortened and is therefore considered to be complete.  The fact that an <a href="#edition">edition</a> is unabridged is sometimes indicated on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of long <a href="#work">work</a>s <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in <a href="#paperback">paperback</a>, but unless otherwise stated, a <a href="#publishing">published</a> work is assumed to be unabridged.  An <a href="#unabridgeddict">unabridged dictionary</a> is the version containing the most words (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Webster's Third New International Dictionary</em></b>).  Compare with <a href="#abridgment">abridgment</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unabridgeddict"><b>unabridged dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> that attempts to include <em>all</em> the words of a <a href="#language">language</a>.  For the English language, there are only three, <b><em>Webster's Third New International Dictionary</em></b> (1961), <b><em>Random House Unabridged Dictionary</em></b> (1993), and the <b><em>Oxford English Dictionary</em></b> (1989), the latter concerned more with <a href="#etymology">etymology</a> than with <a href="#definition">definition</a>.  First <a href="#publishing">published</a> in 1909, <em>Webster's Third</em> has about 450,000 <a href="#entry">entries</a> (down from 600,000 in the second <a href="#edition">edition</a>).  The <em>Random House Unabridged Dictionary</em> has fewer words, but more <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#deskdictionary">desk dictionary</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unauthorizedbiog"><b>unauthorized biography</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#biography">biographical</a> <a href="#work">work</a> written without the consent of its <a href="#subject">subject</a> or the subject's family if the <em>biographee</em> is deceased, sometimes more objective in its analysis than an <a href="#authorizedbiog">authorized biography</a> because the <em>biographer</em> does not have to make concessions to gain <a href="#access">access</a> to confidential <a href="#source">source</a>s.  However, an unauthorized biography may be less detailed or complete if the <a href="#author">author</a> was denied important <a href="#information">information</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unauthorized"><b>unauthorized edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> without the consent of the <a href="#author">author</a>, the author's legal representative, or the original <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, but not in violation of existing <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law.  Compare with <a href="#authorizededition">authorized edition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pirated">pirated edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unbacked"><b>unbacked</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#printing">Printed</a> on only one side of a <a href="#blank">blank</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, as in a <a href="#poster">poster</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unbound"><b>unbound</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d without a <a href="#binding">binding</a> or <a href="#cover">cover</a>, or with its cover removed.  Prior to the 19th century, <a href="#book">book</a>s were sold in the form of <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#section">section</a>s, to be bound to the purchaser's specifications.  Also refers to an issue of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> or <a href="#part">part</a> of a <a href="#serial">serial</a> that will eventually be bound, usually with others, to form a <a href="#volume">volume</a>.  Compare with <a href="#disbound">disbound</a> and <a href="#loose">loose</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="uncial"><b>uncial</b></a>
</dt><dd>From Latin <em>uncialis</em> meaning "of an inch" or "inch-high."  A large, full <a href="#majuscule">majuscule</a> <a href="#script">script</a> used in the earliest Biblical <a href="#codex">codices</a> and as a <a href="#bookhand">book hand</a> in <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s written and <a href="#copy">copied</a> from about 300-700 A.D., in which <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a>s were rounded and modified in ways suggestive of later <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a>s, probably to increase writing speed.  <a href="#halfuncial">Half uncial</a> gradually replaced uncial as a <a href="#book">book</a> hand after the 6th century.  Also refers to manuscripts written in this script.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="uncut"><b>uncut</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#volume">volume</a> in which the <a href="#bolt">bolt</a>s are not <a href="#trimming">trimmed</a> to uniform size in <a href="#binding">binding</a>, leaving the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> to be separated by hand by the owner of the <a href="#book">book</a>, with a <a href="#paperknife">paper knife</a> or other thin-edged instrument.  Synonymous with <a href="#unopened">unopened</a> and <em>untrimmed</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="underfunded"><b>underfunded</b></a>
</dt><dd>An organization, institution, or project allocated insufficient monies to accomplish its <a href="#goal">goal</a>s and <a href="#objective">objective</a>s.  Chronic underfunding can lead to a decline in <a href="#qualityofservice">quality of service</a> and is demoralizing for <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> and <a href="#libadmin">management</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="undergradlib"><b>undergraduate library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A separate <a href="#library">library</a> established, supported, and maintained by a university to serve the <a href="#information">information</a> and <a href="#research">research</a>
needs of its undergraduate students and the instructional requirements
of the undergraduate curriculum. Sometimes administered as a <a href="#branchlibrary">branch library</a>.  Compare with <a href="#gradlib">graduate library</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#collegelibrary">college library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="underground"><b>underground press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> that <a href="#issue">issue</a>s <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s
unofficially or clandestinely, usually to members of a group or
organization that opposes the policies of an established government or
other authority, more common during periods of civil unrest than in
times of peace and prosperity. Eventually, most underground presses
either disband or become "above ground" publishing houses.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="underlining"><b>underlining</b></a>
</dt><dd>Words, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s, or passages of <a href="#text">text</a> underscored in pencil or <a href="#ink">ink</a> by a previous <a href="#reader">reader</a>, usually for future reference.  As a general rule, <a href="#library">libraries</a> do not add heavily underlined <a href="#gift">gift</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s to the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  Also refers to a <a href="#format">format</a>ting option available in <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#software">software</a> that can be used to place a line beneath a single <a href="#character">character</a>, word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, line, or entire passage of <a href="#text">text</a>.  Compare with <a href="#highlighting">highlighting</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="underrun"><b>underrun</b></a>
