</dt><dd>A <a href="#pressrun">press run</a> that produces fewer <a href="#copy">copies</a> than the number ordered, sometimes causing a shortage of <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>'s <a href="#inventory">inventory</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#overrun">overrun</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="underserved"><b>underserved</b></a>
</dt><dd>Persons within the geographic area or <a href="#clientele">clientele</a> served by a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>
who use its services infrequently for a variety of reasons, including
limited awareness of available resources and services, lack of
familiarity with the national <a href="#language">language</a>, <a href="#literacy">illiteracy</a>, poor health, lack of transportation, etc.  <a href="#outreach">Outreach</a> programs help bridge these gaps.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="understaffed"><b>understaffed</b></a>
</dt><dd>Having an insufficient number of employees to do the work required.  Signs of overwork (fatigue, <a href="#absenteeism">absenteeism</a>, <a href="#arrears">arrears</a>, etc.) can be the result of understaffing.  Synonymous with <em>short-staffed</em> and <em>short-handed</em>.  The opposite of <a href="#overstaffed">overstaffed</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#skeletonstaff">skeleton staff</a> and <a href="#underfunded">underfunded</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="underutilized"><b>underutilized</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> service, resource, or <a href="#bibitem">item</a> used less often than it ought to be, usually because its usefulness is not widely appreciated, or because it is not as <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> as other alternatives, for example, <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of <a href="#thesis">theses</a> and <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a>s in some <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="undocumented"><b>undocumented</b></a>
</dt><dd>Lacking official <a href="#paper">paper</a>s or other tangible evidence in support of existence, identity, validity, <a href="#authenticity">authenticity</a>, <a href="#provenance">provenance</a>, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unexpurgated"><b>unexpurgated</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#text">text</a> or <a href="#edition">edition</a> that includes passages omitted from other <a href="#version">version</a>s or editions, usually because they were considered offensive to some <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#expurgated">expurgated</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#bowdlerize">bowdlerize</a> and <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unfinished"><b>unfinished</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> left incomplete at the death of the <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#composer">composer</a>, or creator.  Unfinished <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>s are sometimes <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#posthumous">posthumous</a>ly (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Last Tycoon</em></b> by F. Scott Fitzgerald).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#continuation">continuation</a> and <a href="#redaction">redaction</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="uniformedition"><b>uniform edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>Two or more <a href="#book">book</a>s <a href="#printing">printed</a>, <a href="#binding">bound</a>, and <a href="#dustjacket">jacket</a>ed in the same style to show that they constitute a single entity, such as a <a href="#multivolumework">multivolume</a> <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>, or that they are related to each other in some other way, for example, the individual <a href="#title">title</a>s in a <a href="#monographicseries">monographic series</a> or the <a href="#collectededition">collected work</a>s of an <a href="#author">author</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="url"><b><b>U</b>niform <b>R</b>esource <b>L</b>ocator (URL)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The unique <a href="#internetaddress">address</a> identifying a resource on the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> for <a href="#router">routing</a> purposes.
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Example</em>:  <b>http://www.myuniversity.edu/library/hours.html</b></dd></dl>
<p>
The first part of the URL is a <a href="#prefix">prefix</a> indicating the <a href="#tcpip">TCP/IP</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> of the address.  In the example given above, the prefix <a href="#http">http://</a> indicates that the resource is a <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#document">document</a> (in most <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>s, the <a href="#default">default</a> setting in the "Open" or "Location" field is <b>http://</b> so there is no need to type the prefix in opening a new address).  The second part of the URL (<b>www</b>) indicates the communication language used in the address.  The third part (<b>myuniversity</b>) indicates the <a href="#host">host</a>.  The fourth part (<b>edu</b>) is the high-level <a href="#domain">domain</a> code indicating category of host.  The last part (<b>/library/hours.html</b>) gives the <a href="#directory">directory</a> and <a href="#filename">filename</a> of the <a href="#file">file</a> to be <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a>, in this case a document written in <a href="#html">HTML</a> script.  URLs are <a href="#casesensitive">case sensitive</a> and the parts must be separated by either a <a href="#fullstop">full stop</a> (<a href="#dot">dot</a>) or <a href="#slash">slash</a>.
</p><p>
Six main prefixes are used in URLs:
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><b>ftp://</b> - <a href="#ftp">FTP</a> <a href="#directory">directory</a> of <a href="#download">download</a>able files
</dd><dd><b>gopher://</b> - Gopher <a href="#server">server</a>
</dd><dd><b>http://</b> - <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a> <a href="#webpage">page</a>
</dd><dd><b>mailto:</b> - Electronic mail (<a href="#email">e-mail</a>)
</dd><dd><b>news:</b> - Usenet <a href="#newsgroup">newsgroup</a>
</dd><dd><b>telnet://</b> - <a href="#application">Application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> running on a remote host</dd></dl>
<p>
Most <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>s allow the user to omit the prefix when entering the address of an Internet resource.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="uniformstyle"><b>uniform style</b></a>
</dt><dd>The appearance of <a href="#publication">publication</a>s <a href="#printing">printed</a> in the same <a href="#typography">typographical</a> style on the same grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#issue">issue</a>d in a <a href="#binding">binding</a> of the same size and design.  <a href="#volume">Volume</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> as a <a href="#set">set</a> or <a href="#series">series</a> are usually produced in this fashion.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#uniformedition">uniform edition</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to the appearance of any element of a printed <a href="#work">work</a> that is repeated in the same style throughout the <a href="#text">text</a>, such as the <a href="#chapterheading">chapter heading</a>s, <a href="#runningtitle">running title</a>s, <a href="#headpiece">headpiece</a>s or <a href="#tailpiece">tailpiece</a>s, etc. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="uniformtitle"><b>uniform title</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>, the distinctive <a href="#title">title</a> selected for <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> purposes to represent a <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d under more than one title, usually in more than one <a href="#expression">expression</a> or <a href="#manifestation">manifestation</a>.  Uniform titles are commonly used to catalog <a href="#sacredtext">sacred text</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Bible</em></b>) and <a href="#liturgicalwork">liturgical</a> and <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a>s.  
<p>
Also refers to the <a href="#collectivetitle">collective title</a> used by convention to bring together <a href="#publication">publication</a>s of an <a href="#author">author</a>, <a href="#composer">composer</a>, or <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a> in a single <a href="#volume">volume</a> or <a href="#set">set</a> of volumes containing two or more complete <a href="#work">work</a>s, or <a href="#extract">extract</a>s from several works, usually of a particular literary or musical form (<em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>).  Synonymous with <em>filing title</em> and <em>standard title</em>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unimarc1"><b>UNIMARC</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#unimarc"><b>UNI</b>versal <b>MA</b>chine-<b>R</b>eadable <b>C</b>ataloging</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unioncatalog"><b>union catalog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A list of the <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> of all the <a href="#library">libraries</a> in a <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>, or of all or a portion of the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of a group of independent libraries, indicating by name and/or <a href="#locationsymbol">location symbol</a> which libraries own at least one <a href="#copy">copy</a> of each <a href="#bibitem">item</a>.  When the main purpose of a union <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> is to indicate location, the <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a> provided in each <a href="#entry">entry</a> may be reduced to a minimum, but when it also serves other purposes, description is more complete.  The <a href="#arrangement">arrangement</a> of a union catalog is normally <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> by <a href="#author">author</a> or <a href="#title">title</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#nuc">National Union Catalog</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unionlist"><b>union list</b></a>
</dt><dd>A complete list of the <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> of a group of <a href="#library">libraries</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> 1) of a specific type, 2) on a certain <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or 3) in a particular <a href="#field">field</a>, usually <a href="#compilation">compiled</a> for the purpose of <a href="#resourcesharing">resource sharing</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Union List of Serials in the Libraries of the United States and Canada</em></b> and its <a href="#continuation">continuation</a> <b><em>New Serial Titles</em></b> <a href="#issue">issue</a>d by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>).  The <a href="#entry">entry</a> for each <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> includes a list of codes representing the libraries owning at least one <a href="#copy">copy</a>.  Union lists are usually <a href="#printing">printed</a>, but some have been <a href="#dataconversion">converted</a> into <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unitaryterm"><b>unitary term</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#heading">heading</a> or <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> <a href="#term">term</a> composed of two or more nouns joined by the conjunction "and," treated as a single <a href="#subject">subject</a> because their meanings overlap to such an extent that the <a href="#literature">literature</a> about them is not clearly separated.  Each part is seen as <a href="#approximatewhole">approximating the whole</a>, as in the <a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress subject heading</a> <b>Forests and forestry</b>.  Not all headings of this form are unitary (<em>example</em>:  <b>Forestry and community</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="universalcopyright"><b><em>Universal Copyright Convention (UCC)</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#internationalcopyright">international copyright</a>
convention drafted in 1952 under the auspices of UNESCO, revised in
1971 and ratified by over sixty-five countries, including the United
States. Under its terms, each <a href="#signatory">signatory</a> nation extends to foreign <a href="#work">work</a>s the same <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> protection it gives to works <a href="#publishing">published</a> within its territory by one of its own citizens.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#berne">Berne Convention</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="universaldecimal"><b>Universal Decimal Classification (UDC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An elaborate expansion of <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> in which <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s are used, in addition to <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s, to create longer <a href="#notation">notation</a>s used in <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#classification">classification</a>, making it more flexible than DDC and particularly suitable for <a href="#specialization">specialized</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s.  Developed by Henri La Fontaine and Paul Otlet of the Institut Internationale de Bibliographie, <b>UDC</b> was first <a href="#publishing">published</a> in a French <a href="#edition">edition</a> in 1905.  Adopted by the <a href="#iso">International Organization for Standardization</a> (ISO), it has been <a href="#translation">translated</a> into many <a href="#language">language</a>s, is revised regularly by an international group, and has become the most widely used <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> in the world.  <a href="http://www.udcc.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#website">Web site</a> maintained by the UDC <a href="#consortium">Consortium</a>.  
<p> 
</p></dd><dt><a name="unimarc"><b>Universal Machine-Readable Cataloging (UNIMARC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>The most <a href="#comprehensive">comprehensive</a> version of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> format for <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a>s, <b>UNIMARC</b> was first published in 1977 and is currently developed under the sponsorship of the <a href="#ifla">IFLA</a> Universal <a href="#bibcontrol">Bibliographic Control</a> and International MARC Core Activity (UBCIM) program to facilitate the international exchange of <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>s between national bibliographic <a href="#agency">agencies</a>.  <a href="http://www.ifla.org/VI/3/ubcim.htm">Click here</a> to learn more about the <a href="#currency">current</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a> of <b>UNIMARC</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="universitylib"><b>university library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> established, administered, and funded by a university, to meet the <a href="#information">information</a>, <a href="#research">research</a>, and curriculum needs of its students, faculty, and staff.  Some large universities maintain separate <a href="#undergradlib">undergraduate</a> and <a href="#gradlib">graduate libraries</a>.  Compare with <a href="#collegelibrary">college library</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#departmentallib">departmental library</a> and <a href="#acrl">Association of College and Research Libraries</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="universitypress"><b>university press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publisher">publishing house</a> associated with a university or other scholarly institution, <a href="#specialization">specializing</a> in the <a href="#publication">publication</a> of <a href="#scholarlybook">scholarly book</a>s and <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, particularly <a href="#work">work</a>s written by its faculty (<em>example</em>:  <a href="http://www.press.jhu.edu/press/index.htm">Johns Hopkins University Press</a>).  Most university presses operate on a nonprofit basis, relying on a committee of senior faculty members to select <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s for publication.  The <a href="#tradeassociation">trade association</a> of university presses in North America is the <a href="#aaupress">Association of American University Presses</a> (AAUP).  Compare with <a href="#popularpress">popular press</a> and <a href="#tradepublisher">trade publisher</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unix"><b>UNIX</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> developed at Bell Labs in 1969, <b>UNIX</b> supports multiple users and <a href="#multitasking">multitasking</a>, and has gone through many <a href="#version">version</a>s.  It runs on a variety of <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> <a href="#platform">platform</a>s
and remains popular at academic and scientific institutions,
particularly those that received it free-of-charge from AT&amp;T in the
early stages of its development. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#windows">Windows</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unknownauth"><b>unknown authorship</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> for which the <a href="#author">author</a> (or authors) are unknown or cannot be identified with certainty, including works emanating from a <a href="#corporatebody">corporate body</a> that is unknown or lacks a name.  <a href="#library">Libraries</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> such works under the <a href="#title">title</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Chanson de Roland</em></b>).  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, if the work is <a href="#attributed">attributed</a> to one or more persons or corporate bodies, <a href="#addedentry">added entries</a> are made under their names.  Synonymous with <a href="#anonymous">anonymous</a>.  Compare with <a href="#diffuse">diffuse authorship</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unlettered"><b>unlettered</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#binding">binding</a> that has neither the <a href="#title">title</a> nor the <a href="#author">author</a>'s name is displayed on the <a href="#spine">spine</a>, making its <a href="#content">content</a> difficult to identify when placed upright alongside other <a href="#volume">volume</a>s on the shelf.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unmounted"><b>unmounted</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#mounted">mounted</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unopened"><b>unopened</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> in which the <a href="#bolt">bolt</a>s are left <a href="#uncut">uncut</a> in <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Once the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> have been slit by hand with a <a href="#paperknife">paper knife</a> or other thin-edged implement, the <a href="#volume">volume</a> is said to have been <a href="#opened">opened</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unpaged"><b>unpaged</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#page">Page</a>s of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> not assigned individual <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>s, usually found in the <a href="#frontmatter">front matter</a>.  The <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> records the <a href="#number">number</a> of such pages in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a>, as an <a href="#interpolation">interpolation</a> inside <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s (<em>example</em>: [15] p.).  Compare with <a href="#unpaginated">unpaginated</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unpaginated"><b>unpaginated</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> in which the <a href="#page">page</a>s of the <a href="#text">text</a> are not <a href="#pagenumber">number</a>ed or sequentially marked.  The total <a href="#number">number</a> of pages in an unpaginated <a href="#work">work</a> is noted by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> as an <a href="#interpolation">interpolation</a> inside <a href="#squarebracket">square bracket</a>s in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> (<em>example</em>: [118] p.).  The opposite of <a href="#pagination">paginated</a>.  Compare with <a href="#unpaged">unpaged</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unprintable"><b>unprintable</b></a>
</dt><dd>A word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> considered unfit to be <a href="#printing">printed</a>, usually for reasons of <a href="#obscenity">obscenity</a>, sometimes indicated in <a href="#text">text</a> by the first <a href="#letter">letter</a> followed by an <a href="#asterisk">asterisk</a> substituted for each of the remaining letters (<b>h***</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unprotected"><b>unprotected</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#data">Data</a> <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> to modification or deletion by un<a href="#authorization">authorized</a> persons because it is stored in a <a href="#file">file</a> or on a <a href="#disk">disk</a> that is not <a href="#security">secured</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unpublished"><b>unpublished</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> in the process of <a href="#publication">publication</a> that has yet to be <a href="#issue">issue</a>d.  Also, a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#typescript">typescript</a> never <a href="#publishing">published</a>, either because it was not intended for publication or because the <a href="#author">author</a> was unable to find a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>.  Compare with <a href="#semipublished">semipublished</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unsigned"><b>unsigned</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written <a href="#work">work</a>, such as an <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#refbook">reference book</a> or <a href="#article">article</a> in a <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, that does not include the name of the <a href="#author">author</a>, usually an indication that the piece was written by a paid staff writer.  In a more general sense, any written <a href="#document">document</a> that does not indicate the identity of the author, especially a <a href="#letters">letter</a> or legal instrument lacking a <a href="#signature">signature</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#signed">signed</a>. Compare with <a href="#anonymous">anonymous</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="untouched"><b>untouched</b></a>
</dt><dd>A term describing early <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s (<a href="#incunabula">incunabula</a>) that have been neither <a href="#rubric">rubric</a>ated nor <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="untrimmed"><b>untrimmed</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#uncut">uncut</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="unzip"><b>unzip</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#zip">zip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="update"><b>update</b></a>
</dt><dd>To make a news story, <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>, <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>, or other <a href="#information">information</a> source <a href="#currency">current</a>, usually by revising existing <a href="#content">content</a> or substituting new material.  <a href="#bibdatabase">Bibliographic database</a>s are updated on a <a href="#regular">regular</a> basis by adding <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s representing newly <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s.  Frequency of update is usually given in the <a href="#database">database</a> description.  <a href="#printing">Printed</a> <a href="#index">index</a>es and <a href="#abstractingservice">abstracting service</a>s are updated in <a href="#monthly">monthly</a> or <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <a href="#paperback">paperbound</a> <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>s, usually <a href="#cumulativeindex">cumulated</a> <a href="#annual">annual</a>ly.  Legal <a href="#publication">publication</a>s (statutes, case law, etc.) may also be updated in supplements, but most <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s are revised and republished in a new <a href="#edition">edition</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="updated"><b>updated</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#work">work</a> from which <a href="#outdated">outdated</a> <a href="#information">information</a> has been removed and <a href="#currency">current</a> information substituted, or to which more recent information has been added.  <a href="#printing">Printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s may be updated in <a href="#supplement">supplement</a>s (<em>example</em>:  legal statutes and case law) or <a href="#revision">revised</a> and republished in a new <a href="#edition">edition</a>.  The <a href="#currency">currency</a> of information provided on a <a href="#website">Web site</a> is indicated in the note "Last updated on [date]" usually found near the bottom of the <a href="#welcomescreen">welcome screen</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#expandededition">expanded edition</a> and <a href="#revisededition">revised edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="upgrade"><b>upgrade</b></a>
</dt><dd>To improve existing <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> or <a href="#software">software</a>
by replacing it with a model or version that has new features and/or
additional capabilities. Software upgrades are usually indicated
sequentially by a <a href="#decimalpoint">decimal</a> <a href="#number">number</a> added to the name of the <a href="#application">application</a>.  Compare with <a href="#migration">migration</a>.  
<p>
In employment, to reclassify a job at a higher grade, usually moving it to a higher pay scale.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="upload"><b>upload</b></a>
</dt><dd>To transmit a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of one or more <a href="#file">file</a>s from a local computer to the <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a> of another (usually more remote) computer, such as a <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a> or <a href="#network">network</a> <a href="#server">server</a>, a process that may require <a href="#terminal">terminal</a> <a href="#emulation">emulation</a> <a href="#software">software</a>.  The opposite of <a href="#download">download</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="uppercase"><b>uppercase</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#capitalletter">Capital letter</a>s, as opposed to the small or <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of a <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#font">font</a>.  The terms <em>uppercase</em> and <em>lowercase</em> are derived from the relative positions of the compartments in the wood or metal <a href="#case">case</a> containing elements of type bearing capital letters and small letters at a <a href="#typesetting">typesetter</a>'s bench in the days when type was set by hand (<a href="#letterpress">letterpress</a>).  Also spelled <em>upper case</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#majuscule">majuscule</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ulc"><b>Urban Libraries Council (ULC)</b></a>
</dt><dd>Founded in 1971, <b>ULC</b> is an <a href="#libassociation">association</a> of approximately 150 <a href="#publiclibrary">public libraries</a>
located in metropolitan areas of the United States with 50,000 or more
inhabitants, and the corporations that serve them, organized to solve
common problems, take advantage of new opportunities, and foster
applied <a href="#research">research</a> to improve professional practice.  <b>ULC</b> is an <a href="#affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>.  <a href="http://www.urbanlibraries.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>ULC</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="url1"><b>URL</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#url"><b>U</b>niform <b>R</b>esource <b>L</b>ocator</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="usability"><b>usability</b></a>
</dt><dd>The ease with which a computer <a href="#interface">interface</a> can be efficiently and effectively used, especially by a <a href="#novice">novice</a>.  The first priority in designing for usability is to provide clear, consistent <a href="#navigation">navigation</a> of <a href="#content">content</a>.  Some <a href="#library">libraries</a> employ <a href="#usabilitytesting">usability testing</a> to evaluate the <a href="#userfriendly">user-friendliness</a> of their <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#helpscreen">help screen</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="usabilitytesting"><b>usability testing</b></a>
</dt><dd>Quantifiable methods used to determine the ease with which the design of a computer <a href="#interface">interface</a>, such as an <a href="#onlinecatalog">online catalog</a> or <a href="#website">Web site</a>, meets the <a href="#infoneed">need</a>s of its users, including direct observation of actual <a href="#search">search</a> behavior, interviewing, <a href="#survey">survey</a>s, and exploratory activities in which volunteers are asked to organize categories of <a href="#information">information</a> according to their own preferences.  Without <a href="#usability">usability</a> testing, <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s
tend to design systems from a trained perspective, based on assumptions
about information-seeking behavior that do not necessarily reflect the
experiences of actual users. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="usage"><b>usage</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#number">number</a> of times a <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> is used by <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#patron">patron</a>s during a given period of time, including the number of times it is <a href="#checkedout">checked out</a> and any <a href="#inhouseuse">in-house use</a> measured by the number of times it is picked up from a desk or table in a public area for <a href="#reshelving">reshelving</a>.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, <em>high-use</em> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> may be given a shorter <a href="#loanperiod">loan period</a>, or placed on <a href="#reserves">reserve</a> or in the <a href="#refstacks">reference section</a>.  In some libraries, <em>low-use</em> items may be candidates for <a href="#weeding">weeding</a>.  Usage statistics are also helpful in <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the generally accepted way in which a word, <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, or <a href="#language">language</a> is used to express an idea in speech or writing, which may or may not be grammatically correct.  <a href="#handbook">Handbook</a>s of English usage are available in the <a href="#refcollection">reference section</a> of most <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The New Fowler's Modern English Usage</em></b>).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="usco"><b>U.S. Copyright Office</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#govtagency">agency</a> of the U.S. federal government responsible for administering <a href="#copyright">copyright</a> law, a unit of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.
Although the first federal copyright law was passed in 1790, copyright
functions were not centralized under the Library of Congress until 1870
and the <b>Copyright Office</b> did not become a separate department
of the Library of Congress until 1897. In addition to administering
federal law protecting the <a href="#intellectualproperty">intellectual property</a> <a href="#rights">rights</a> of American citizens, the <b>Copyright Office</b>
also provides expertise to Congress on matters related to intellectual
property, advises and assists Congress in drafting proposed changes in
U.S. copyright law, advises Congress on compliance with international
copyright agreements, serves as a <a href="#copyrightdepository">depository</a> for <a href="#work">work</a>s registered under U.S. copyright law, and furnishes <a href="#information">information</a> to the general public on copyright law and registration.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/copyright/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a> of the <b>U.S. Copyright Office</b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="use"><b>USE</b></a>
</dt><dd>An instruction used in an <a href="#entry">entry</a> in a <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>s list or <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a> to direct the user from a <a href="#synonym">synonym</a> or <a href="#quasisynonym">quasi-synonym</a> to the <a href="#preferredterm">preferred term</a> under which <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s on the <a href="#topic">topic</a> are <a href="#cataloging">cataloged</a> or <a href="#indexing">indexed</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b>Reading Therapy</b> USE <b>Bibliotherapy</b> in the <em>Thesaurus of <a href="#eric">ERIC</a> <a href="#descriptor">Descriptor</a>s</em>).  Compare with <em><a href="#see">see</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="usedbook"><b>used book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> that has had at least one previous owner.  The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of the <a href="#cover">cover</a> and <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> is an indication of the amount of use a <a href="#volume">volume</a> has received.  Sometimes  used books are found upon <a href="#appraisal">appraisal</a> to be <a href="#rarity">rare</a> and valuable, especially <a href="#copy">copies</a> of a <a href="#firstedition">first edition</a>.  Synonymous with <em>secondhand book</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#exlibrary">ex-library copy</a> and <a href="#usedbookstore">used bookstore</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="usedbookstore"><b>used bookstore</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bookstore">bookstore</a> that <a href="#specialization">specializes</a> in <a href="#book">book</a>s that have had at least one previous owner, sometimes limited to a particular <a href="#genre">genre</a>, such as <a href="#mystery">mystery</a> or <a href="#sciencefiction">science fiction</a>.  Unless a used book is <a href="#rarebook">rare</a> or <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a>, it is usually priced on the basis of <a href="#condition">condition</a>, lower than the <a href="#listprice">list price</a> of a new <a href="#copy">copy</a>.  Some bookstores sell both <a href="#newbook">new</a> <em>and</em> used books.  Synonymous with <em>secondhand bookstore</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="usedfor"><b>used for (UF)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> indicating <a href="#term">term</a>s synonymous with an authorized <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>, <em>not</em> used in <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> or <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> to avoid <a href="#scatter">scatter</a>.  In a subject headings list or <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> of <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a>, <a href="#synonym">synonym</a>s are given immediately following the official heading.  In the <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> list of indexing terms, they are included as <a href="#leadinvocabulary">lead-in vocabulary</a> followed by a <em><a href="#see">see</a></em> or <a href="#use">USE</a> <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a> directing the user to the correct heading.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#syndetic">syndetic structure</a>. 
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd><em>Examples</em>:
<dl><dt></dt><dd><em><a href="#lcsh">Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH)</a></em>:  
<dl><dt></dt><dd>Domestic violence 
<dl><dt></dt><dd>USE Family violence</dd></dl> 
</dd><dd>Family violence
<dl><dt></dt><dd>UF Domestic violence</dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
</p></dd><dd><dl><dt></dt><dd><em><a href="#eric">Thesaurus of ERIC Descriptors</a></em>:
<dl><dt></dt><dd>Physical Disabilities
<dl><dt></dt><dd>UF Physical Handicaps</dd></dl>
</dd><dd>Physical Handicaps
<dl><dt></dt><dd>USE Physical Disabilities</dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="uselife"><b>use life</b></a>
</dt><dd>The length of time or <a href="#number">number</a> of times an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> can be used before it becomes so worn that it is no longer fit for use and has to be discarded.  For <a href="#book">book</a>s, use life depends on quality of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, strength of <a href="#binding">binding</a>, and actions taken to protect the <a href="#cover">cover</a>, such as enclosing the <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> in a washable plastic <a href="#sleeve">sleeve</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="user"><b>user</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#patron">patron</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="userarea"><b>user area</b></a>
</dt><dd>The amount of floor space in a <a href="#library">library</a> that can be assigned for use by <a href="#patron">patron</a>s, as opposed to the area required for the use of <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>, <a href="#closedstacks">closed stacks</a>, automation and HVAC equipment, maintenance, storage, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="usereducation"><b>user education</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the activities involved in teaching users how to make the best possible use of <a href="#library">library</a> resources, services, and facilities, including formal and informal instruction delivered by a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> or other <a href="#librarystaff">staff</a> member <a href="#oneonone">one-on-one</a> or in a group.  Also includes <a href="#onlinetutorial">online tutorial</a>s, <a href="#audiovisual">audiovisual</a> materials, and <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#guide">guide</a>s and <a href="#pathfinder">pathfinder</a>s.  A broader <a href="#term">term</a> than <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="userfriendly"><b>user-friendly</b></a>
</dt><dd>Computer <a href="#software">software</a> or <a href="#hardware">hardware</a> designed to be easy to use or operate, even by a complete <a href="#novice">novice</a>.  Most user-friendly systems include <a href="#pointofuse">point-of-use instruction</a> and readily <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> <a href="#helpscreen">help screen</a>s, written in <a href="#language">language</a> that is clear and easy to comprehend.  User-friendliness was a prime consideration in the design of the <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a> (GUI) that made the  <a href="#windows">Windows</a> and <a href="#macintosh">Macintosh</a> <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>s a commercial success.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#usabilitytesting">usability testing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="usergroup"><b>user group</b></a>
</dt><dd>The individuals within the population served by a <a href="#library">library</a> who actually make use of its services and <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s on a fairly regular basis.  Synonymous with <a href="#clientele">clientele</a>.  Compare with <a href="#constituency">constituency</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a group of users of a service or <a href="#software">software</a>/<a href="#hardware">hardware</a> product (or brand of products) who meet periodically and keep in contact, usually via <a href="#email">e-mail</a>, to enhance their understanding of the product(s), discuss problems they experience, and suggest improvements to the <a href="#vendor">vendor</a>.  <a href="#systemslibrarian">Systems librarian</a>s often participate in the user group for their <a href="#library">library</a>'s <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> software.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="userid"><b>user ID</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#username">username</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="username"><b>username</b></a>
</dt><dd>A permanent code which an <a href="#authorization">authorized</a> user must enter into a computer system to <a href="#logon">logon</a> and gain <a href="#access">access</a> to its resources, usually consisting of the full name (<b>john.wilson</b>), or the <a href="#surname">surname</a> plus the initial(s) of the given name(s) (<b>wilsonj</b>) or one or more <a href="#arabicnumeral">arabic numeral</a>s (<b>wilson001</b>).  Synonymous with <em>user ID</em>. <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#password">password</a> and <a href="#pin">PIN</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="userprofile"><b>user profile</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#interestprofile">interest profile</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="usersurvey"><b>user survey</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#questionnaire">questionnaire</a> administered to <a href="#usergroup">users</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>
to find out what brings them to the library, how they normally use the
resources and services it provides, their subjective evaluation of the
quality of their experiences, and any suggestions for improvement (<a href="#feedback">feedback</a>).  In a <a href="#longitudinal">longitudinal study</a>, the same or a similar <a href="#survey">survey</a>
instrument is administered more than once, after a suitable interval of
time has elapsed, to measure changes in usage patterns, attitudes, etc.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="userwarrant"><b>user warrant</b></a>
</dt><dd>The addition of a <a href="#term">term</a> to an <a href="#indexinglang">indexing language</a>, or the assignment of an existing <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> to <a href="#document">document</a>s by an <a href="#indexing">indexer</a>, based on the frequency with which it is requested or included in the <a href="#search">search statement</a>s entered as <a href="#input">input</a> by the users of an <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a> system.  Compare with <a href="#literarywarrant">literary warrant</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="usgpo"><b>U.S. Government Printing Office</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#gpo">GPO</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="utility"><b>utility</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#computerprogram">program</a> that expands the capability of a computer's <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> by enabling it to perform an additional task, usually something as routine as managing a <a href="#diskdrive">disk drive</a>, <a href="#printer">printer</a>, <a href="#scanner">scanner</a>, or other <a href="#peripheral">peripheral</a> <a href="#device">device</a>.  Unlike the basic operating system, utilities can be added and removed as needed.  A utility differs from an <a href="#application">application</a> program in being less complex, usually limited to a single function.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="utopia"><b>utopia</b></a>
</dt><dd>A term coined by Thomas More from the Greek <em>ou</em> ("no" or "not") and <em>topos</em> ("place").  A <a href="#literarywork">literary</a> or artistic <a href="#work">work</a> in which the setting is an ideal society, usually one existing in a future time or imaginary place (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Looking Backward</em></b> by Edward Bellamy).  Utopias are created by <a href="#author">author</a>s
who feel nostalgia for an idealized past, or who wish to call attention
to the need to reform existing social, political, or economic
institutions. The opposite of <em>dystopia</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fantasy">fantasy</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="uv"><b>UV</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#ultraviolet">ultraviolet</a>.
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>
<center>| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> | <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a>
| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>

| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="V">V</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="vacuumfreeze"><b>vacuum freeze dry</b></a>
</dt><dd>An expensive <a href="#conservation">conservation</a> procedure in which wet <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> are frozen, then placed in a chamber from which the air is extracted, causing the water (in the form of ice) to vaporize.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vademecum"><b>vade mecum</b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for "go with me."  A small <a href="#book">book</a>, such as a <a href="#guidebook">guidebook</a>, <a href="#handbook">handbook</a>, or <a href="#manual">manual</a>,
meant to be carried about and used for quick reference. In a more
general sense, any item that is regularly carried by a person. Also
spelled <em>vade-mecum</em>.  Plural:  <em>vade mecums</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vandalism"><b>vandalism</b></a>
</dt><dd>Damage to <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a>s,
furnishings, or facilities which is intentional rather than accidental,
usually motivated by anger or malice on the part of the perpetrator.
Vandalism detracts from the physical appearance of a <a href="#library">library</a> and its resources.  The cost of repair or replacement puts an unwelcome burden on the <a href="#budget">budget</a>.  To avoid detection, most acts of vandalism are committed in un<a href="#librarystaff">staff</a>ed locations or after <a href="#libraryhours">hours</a>.  Some libraries employ a <a href="#securityguard">security guard</a> to keep an eye on areas not visible from at least one public <a href="#servicepoint">service point</a> when the library is open.    
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vanillatext"><b>vanilla text</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#text">Text</a> written on a computer, usually with the aid of a text editor or <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#software">software</a>, in a standard <a href="#font">font</a> with no <a href="#formatting">formatting</a> (<a href="#boldface">boldface</a>, <a href="#italic">italic</a>s, etc.), usually with a <a href="#filename">filename</a> ending in <b>.txt</b>.  Synonymous with <em>plaintext</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#ascii">ASCII</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vanitypress"><b>vanity press</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#vanitypublisher">vanity publisher</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vanitypublisher"><b>vanity publisher</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, more common in the United States than in other countries, that <a href="#specialization">specializes</a> in producing <a href="#book">book</a>s at the <a href="#author">author</a>'s expense, used mainly by writers whose <a href="#work">work</a>s have been <a href="#rejectionslip">rejected</a>
by commercial publishers, and by individuals of private means who are
convinced they have an important message to impart to the world. In
England, vanity publishing is used primarily for <a href="#poetry">poetry</a>.   Books <a href="#publishing">published</a> by vanity publishers are avoided by <a href="#review">review</a>ers and rarely purchased by retail <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s and <a href="#library">libraries</a>.  Synonymous with <em>vanity press</em>.  Compare with <a href="#privatepress">private press</a> and <a href="#selfpublishing">self-publishing</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#sponsoredbook">sponsored book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="variablecontrol"><b>variable control field</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#variablefield">variable field</a> of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> (<a href="#tag">tag</a>ged 00X with X in the range of 1-9) containing neither <a href="#indicator">indicator</a>s nor <a href="#subfieldcode">subfields code</a>s, reserved for a single <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#element">element</a> or series of fixed-length data elements identified by the relative position of <a href="#character">character</a>s.  For example, <a href="#field">field</a> 008 containing 40 <a href="#character">character</a>s of <a href="#encoding">encoded</a> <a href="#information">information</a> about the record as a whole, such as the date it was entered into the <a href="#bibdatabase">database</a>, <a href="#frequency">frequency</a> of <a href="#publication">publication</a>, etc.  Compare with <a href="#variabledata">variable data field</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="variabledata"><b>variable data field</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#variablefield">variable field</a> of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> (<a href="#tag">tag</a>ged 1XX-9XX with XX in the range of 00-99) that has two <a href="#indicator">indicator</a> positions following the tag and usually contains <a href="#text">text</a>ual rather than coded <a href="#information">information</a>, consisting of one or more <a href="#element">element</a>s of <a href="#bibdescrip">bibliographic description</a>, each recorded in a separate <a href="#subfield">subfield</a> preceded by a two-<a href="#character">character</a> <a href="#subfieldcode">subfield code</a>.  Compare with <a href="#variablecontrol">variable control field</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="variablefield"><b>variable field</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#field">field</a> of the <a href="#machinecat">MARC</a> <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> that varies in length, containing either coded <a href="#data">data</a> or <a href="#text">text</a>, subdivided into logical <a href="#element">element</a>s recorded in separate <a href="#subfield">subfield</a>s.  All the fields in the MARC record are variable except the 24-<a href="#character">character</a> <a href="#leader">leader</a> and the 005, 007, and 008 fields which are of <a href="#fixedfield">fixed length</a>.  Variable fields are of two types:  <a href="#variablecontrol">variable control field</a>s (<a href="#tag">tag</a>ged 00X) which include neither <a href="#indicator">indicator</a>s nor <a href="#subfieldcode">subfield code</a>s, and <a href="#variabledata">variable data field</a>s
(tagged 1XX-9XX with XX in the range of 00-99) which include two
indicator positions following the tag and a subfield code at the
beginning of each data <a href="#element">element</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="variant"><b>variant</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#copy">copy</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> that differs slightly in one or more <a href="#point">point</a>s from others of the same <a href="#impression">impression</a>, or from a previous <a href="#printing">printing</a> of the same <a href="#edition">edition</a>.  The differences may occur in the <a href="#section">section</a>s, <a href="#binding">binding</a>, or both.  Once priority of <a href="#publication">publication</a> has been conclusively established, such variations are referred to as <a href="#issue">issue</a>s and <a href="#state">state</a>s.  Also refers to one of two or more slightly different early <a href="#text">text</a>s of a <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>, for example, the <a href="#play">play</a>s of Shakespeare that survive in multiple <a href="#version">version</a>s.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>var</em>. 
<p>
Also, one of several forms of a word <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a> when the <a href="#truncation">truncated</a> stem of a word is used as a <a href="#searchterm">search term</a> in a <a href="#keywords">keywords</a> <a href="#search">search</a>, for example, the <a href="#term">term</a>s <em>videocassette</em>, <em>videodisc</em>, <em>videorecording</em>, and <em>videotape</em> retrieved by truncating the root "video" (<b>video*</b> or <b>video$</b>).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="variantedition"><b>variant edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#edition">edition</a> that includes changes made in the <a href="#work">work</a> by the <a href="#author">author</a>, sometimes ranging from first <a href="#composition">composition</a> all the way to <a href="#publication">publication</a> in a <a href="#definitive">definitive edition</a>, allowing the <a href="#reader">reader</a> to see the evolution of the <a href="#text">text</a>.  Compare with <a href="#variorumedition">variorum edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="variorumedition"><b>variorum edition</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> <em>cum notis variorum</em> meaning "with notes from various persons."  An <a href="#edition">edition</a> based on scholarly comparison and interpretation of several previously <a href="#publishing">published</a> <a href="#version">version</a>s of the <a href="#text">text</a>, which also includes <a href="#commentary">commentary</a> written by various <a href="#editor">editor</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#variantedition">variant edition</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#definitive">definitive edition</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="variousdates"><b>various dates (v.d.)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A phrase used to indicate that a <a href="#set">set</a> or <a href="#series">series</a> of <a href="#volume">volume</a>s contains <a href="#work">work</a>s that have different <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="varnish"><b>varnish</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#glossy">glossy</a> <a href="#coated">coating</a> applied to the <a href="#printing">printed</a> surface of the <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> or <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a> on a <a href="#newbook">new book</a>, for protection and to enhance its visual appeal.  Varnish can be expensive when applied in a separate <a href="#pressrun">press run</a>.  A second pass is not required when varnish is added to <a href="#glossink">gloss ink</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vaticanlibrary"><b>Vatican Library</b></a>
</dt><dd>Although the Catholic popes always had <a href="#privatelib">private libraries</a>, in the 15th century Pope Nicholas V created a <a href="#library">library</a>
specifically for the clerics and scholars who lived and worked in and
around the papal palace. A suite of rooms was set aside, and he began <a href="#bookcollecting">collecting</a> the most beautiful <a href="#manuscriptbook">manuscript book</a>s of the time.  Pope Sixtus IV continued the work, and the library's <a href="#holdings">holdings</a> grew rapidly from about 1,200 <a href="#book">book</a>s in 1455 to 3,500 in 1481 when the first handwritten <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> was made by the <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> Platina.  
<p>
From the beginning, the library included not only Bibles and <a href="#work">work</a>s on theology and canon law, but also secular works, particularly the Greek and Latin <a href="#classics">classics</a> which the popes collected in <a href="#text">text</a>s as close to the <a href="#original">original</a> as they could find. During the Renaissance, the <b>Vatican Library</b>
became a center of classical culture in Europe and its librarians were
often distinguished scholars. It continues to be one of the great
libraries of the Western world, attracting scholars of all
nationalities to its <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s of important historical <a href="#document">document</a>s and <a href="#rarebook">rare</a> and <a href="#finebook">fine book</a>s.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/exhibits/vatican/toc.html">Click here</a> to see the <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a> <b><em>Rome Reborn: The Vatican Library &amp; Renaissance Culture</em></b> sponsored by the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vchip"><b>V-chip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#chip">microchip</a> installed in a television set, designed to allow parents to block <a href="#access">access</a> to programs containing <a href="#content">content</a>
considered unsuitable for children (violence, explicit sex, adult
language, etc.). In 1996, Congress passed legislation requiring
manufacturers of television receivers to install the V-chip in sets
sold in the United States (13-inch or larger). However, according to
the <em>Christian Science Monitor</em>, a survey released in July,
2001 found that only 7% of parents with children 2-17 years old use the
V-chip in their television set, either because they own an older set,
do not know if their set has a V-chip, or find it difficult to use. 56%
said they use the rating displayed on the screen before a program
begins to make decisions about their children's viewing. <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vcr"><b>VCR</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialism">initialism</a> for <em><b>v</b>ideo <b>c</b>assette <b>r</b>ecorder</em>, an electronic device designed to record onto <a href="#videotape">videotape</a> (in <a href="#vhs">VHS</a> <a href="#format">format</a>) signals received by a standard television receiver, for <a href="#playback">playback</a> on a television <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>.  <b>VCR</b>s are also used to play prerecorded <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>s (<a href="#featurefilm">feature film</a>s, <a href="#documentary">documentaries</a>, etc.).  Although <b>VCR</b>s are <a href="#analog">analog</a> machines, adapters are available that enable <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#data">data</a> to be stored on videotape as computer <a href="#backup">backup</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vd"><b>v.d.</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of <a href="#variousdates"><b>v</b>arious <b>d</b>ates</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vdt"><b>VDT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#terminal">terminal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vellum"><b>vellum</b></a>
</dt><dd>A thin, fine <a href="#parchment">parchment</a> made from the
polished skin of a newly born lamb, kid, or calf, dressed and polished
with alum for use as a writing surface before <a href="#paper">paper</a> came into widespread use in Europe, and also in <a href="#bookbinding">bookbinding</a>.  Also refers to a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> written on fine parchment, and to a fine-quality off-white paper made to resemble the animal membrane. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vendingmachine"><b>vending machine</b></a>
</dt><dd>A machine designed to automatically dispense goods when the
correct amount of money, or a credit or debit card, is inserted and a
selection made. In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, <a href="#copycard">copy card</a>s are often dispensed in this way.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vendor"><b>vendor</b></a>
</dt><dd>A company in the business of providing <a href="#access">access</a> to a selection of <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s, <a href="#online">online</a> or on <a href="#cdrom">CD-ROM</a>, by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a> (<em>examples</em>:  <a href="#ebsco">EBSCO</a>, <a href="#proquest">ProQuest</a>, <a href="#gale">Gale Group</a>, <a href="#silverplatter">SilverPlatter</a>) or on a <a href="#persearch">per search</a> basis (<a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <em><a href="#firstsearch">FirstSearch</a></em> and <a href="#dialog">DIALOG</a>), usually under <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a>.  Providers of <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#media">media</a> are also commonly referred to as vendors.  
<p>
In a more general sense, any company or <a href="#agency">agency</a> that provides products or services to a <a href="#library">library</a> or <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a> for a <a href="#fee">fee</a>.  <a href="http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/Libweb/comp.html">Click here</a> to view the <em><a href="#libweb">Libweb</a></em> list of <a href="#link">link</a>s to <a href="#library">library</a>-related companies in the United States.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="venn"><b>Venn diagram</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>al device in which closed circles (or ovals) are used to <a href="#illustration">illustrate</a> the logical relationship between sets of <a href="#data">data</a>:  nonintersecting circles for <a href="#set">set</a>s with <em>no</em> elements in common; overlapping circles for sets with <em>some</em> but not all elements in common; and a circle within a circle for a set that is <a href="#subset">subset</a>
of another. Invented by Johann Sturm in 1661 and named after the
English logician John Venn (1834-1923) who used them from 1880 onwards,
Venn diagrams are used in <a href="#bi">bibliographic instruction</a> to help students visualize the results of <a href="#boolean">Boolean</a> logic in <a href="#keywords">keyword</a> <a href="#search">search</a>ing. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="verbatim"><b>verbatim</b></a>
</dt><dd>In exactly the same words as the <a href="#original">original</a> <a href="#source">source</a> or <a href="#text">text</a>, word for word, as in a direct <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="verbatimetliteratim"><b>verbatim et literatim</b></a>
</dt><dd>A Latin <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> meaning "word for word and letter for letter," precisely as written or <a href="#printing">printed</a>.  More loosely, a <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>, <a href="#transcribe">transcription</a>, or <a href="#translation">translation</a> that is faithful to the <a href="#original">original</a>.  Also refers to a literal translation.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="verification"><b>verification</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of using bibliographic <a href="#source">source</a>s to ascertain that an <a href="#author">author</a> actually exists, or to determine the proper form of a name or the correct <a href="#title">title</a> of a <a href="#work">work</a>, usually prior to ordering or <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> the <a href="#bibitem">item</a> for a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>.  Compare with <a href="#preorder">pre-order searching</a>.  In a more general sense, checking the truth or accuracy of any fact or statement, usually by consulting an <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> source of  <a href="#information">information</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vernacular"><b>vernacular</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>vernaculus</em> meaning "native."  In <a href="#literature">literature</a>, <a href="#work">work</a>s written in the daily <a href="#language">language</a>
of a group of people, particularly the inhabitants of a specific
geographic region, as distinct from the official language of the same
population or area, for example, the language of the <a href="#novel">novel</a>s of Thomas Hardy, in which English country folk speak and act in a manner appropriate to their rural origins.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#vernacularname">vernacular name</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vernacularname"><b>vernacular name</b></a>
</dt><dd>The form of a person's name used in <a href="#refbook">reference source</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> in his or her country of birth or permanent residence.  In <em><a href="#anglo">AACR2</a></em>, the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> is instructed to use the form of the name that has become well-established in English-<a href="#language">language</a> reference sources, and to make appropriate references from other forms (<em>example</em>: <b>'Umar Khayyam</b> <em>see</em> <b>Omar Khayyam</b>).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="versal"><b>versal</b></a>
</dt><dd>In medieval <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, a large ornamental <a href="#capitalletter">capital letter</a> written on the inner <a href="#margin">margin</a> or extending partly into the <a href="#text">text</a>, to indicate the beginning of a paragraph, <a href="#verse">verse</a>, or important passage.  The earliest examples were outlined in dots, ornamented with flourishes, or written in <a href="#ink">ink</a> of contrasting color, but by the 15th century versals had developed into elaborately <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a>s.  The larger size meant that a versal occupied several lines, with its top usually aligned with the <a href="#minuscule">minuscule</a>s of the word to which it belonged.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="verse"><b>verse</b></a>
</dt><dd>A sequence of words arranged in accordance with established rules of metrical <a href="#composition">composition</a>, rhyme, etc.  Also, a set of lines comprising one unit in the overall pattern of a metrical composition (song, <a href="#ballad">ballad</a>, etc.) written in several sections of similar form, aside from any refrain.  Synonymous in this sense with <em>stanza</em>.  Also used as a general term for light <a href="#poetry">poetry</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#doggerel">doggerel</a> and <a href="#limerick">limerick</a>.  
<p>
In a <a href="#sacredtext">sacred text</a>, such as the <em>Bible</em>, one or more sentences forming a division of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>, usually <a href="#number">number</a>ed for reference. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="versification"><b>versification</b></a>
</dt><dd>The transformation of a <a href="#prose">prose</a> <a href="#work">work</a> into <a href="#poetry">poetic</a> or metrical <a href="#language">language</a>.  Also, the overall structure or style in which a poetic work is composed.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="version"><b>version</b></a>
</dt><dd>One of several variations of an intellectual <a href="#work">work</a>, possibly created for a purpose or use other than the one originally intended.  Also, a variant form of a work of <a href="#unknownauth">unknown</a> or uncertain <a href="#authorship">authorship</a>, such as a <a href="#fairytale">fairy tale</a> or <a href="#legend">legend</a>.  Also refers to a specific <a href="#translation">translation</a> of the <em>Bible</em>, or any of its parts (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>King James Version</em></b>).  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>vers</em>.  Compare with <a href="#adaptation">adaptation</a> and <a href="#edition">edition</a>.
<p>
In computer <a href="#software">software</a>, a specific <a href="#upgrade">upgrade</a> of an <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> or <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>, usually indicated by a <a href="#decimalpoint">decimal</a> <a href="#number">number</a> following the <a href="#title">title</a>, for example, <b>5.0</b> to indicate a significant upgrade, <b>5.1</b> a modification containing routine enhancements, and <b>5.11</b> a follow-up, perhaps to correct a minor <a href="#bug">bug</a> in the previous version.  As a general rule, there is greater risk in purchasing version 1.0 of a <a href="#software">software</a> program than in purchasing subsequent versions.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="verso"><b>verso</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> <em>verso <a href="#folio">folio</a></em> meaning "with the page turned."  The back side of a <a href="#book">book</a> or the left-hand <a href="#page">page</a> of an <a href="#opening">opening</a> in a book or other <a href="#publication">publication</a>, usually assigned an even <a href="#pagenumber">page number</a>.  <a href="#publisher">Publisher</a>'s <a href="#imprint">imprint</a>, <a href="#publicationdate">publication date</a>, notice of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, <a href="#isbn">ISBN</a>, and <a href="#cip">CIP</a> are usually given on the verso of the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a> of a book.  Also refers to the reverse side of a single <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>, the side intended by the <a href="#printer">printer</a> to be read second.  The opposite of <a href="#recto">recto</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="verticalfile"><b>vertical file</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#collection">collection</a> of <a href="#loose">loose</a> <a href="#clipping">clipping</a>s, <a href="#picture">picture</a>s, <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>s, or other materials of an <a href="#ephemera">ephemeral</a> nature which, because of size and <a href="#format">format</a>, are filed on edge in drawers or in a box, usually organized in <a href="#folder">folder</a>s by <a href="#subject">subject</a> or some other <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a> to facilitate retrieval.  Also refers to the filing cabinet in which such materials are stored.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vga"><b>VGA</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialism">initialism</a> for <b>V</b>ideo <b>G</b>raphics <b>A</b>rray, a <a href="#standard">standard</a> <a href="#videorecording">video</a> adapter in an IBM <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a>, capable of producing <a href="#resolution">resolution</a>s of 640 x 480 <a href="#pixel">pixel</a>s in up to 256 colors.  Superseded by <a href="#svga">SVGA</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vhs"><b>VHS</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialism">initialism</a> for <b>V</b>ideo <b>H</b>ome <b>S</b>ystem, a <a href="#videorecording">video</a> recording and <a href="#playback">playback</a> <a href="#format">format</a> consisting of hard plastic <a href="#videocassette">cassette</a>s containing half-inch <a href="#videotape">videotape</a>.  Introduced by JVC in 1976 to compete with Sony's Beta format, <b>VHS</b> has since become the industry <a href="#standard">standard</a> for both home and commercial use.  SVHS (Super VHS) was developed to improve <a href="#resolution">resolution</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#vcr">VCR</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vide"><b><em>vide</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>The imperative form of the Latin verb <em>videre</em>, "to see." Used in the sense of "refer to" in <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s to direct the <a href="#reader">reader</a>'s attention to a specific passage, <a href="#page">page</a>, <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>, or <a href="#work">work</a>.  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>v.</em> or <em>vid.</em>
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="videocassette"><b>videocassette</b></a>
</dt><dd>A recorded <a href="#videotape">videotape</a> permanently enclosed in a hard plastic case containing two take-up <a href="#reel">reel</a>s to which the ends of the tape are permanently attached for <a href="#playback">playback</a> and rewinding. In the United States, the <a href="#standard">standard</a> <a href="#format">format</a> for videotapes is <a href="#vhs">VHS</a>.  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> shelve videocassettes in a separate section, but in some libraries they are integrated into the <a href="#circulating">circulating collection</a> by <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>.  To satisfy <a href="#demand">demand</a> and encourage prompt return, the <a href="#loanperiod">loan period</a> for videocassettes may be shorter and the <a href="#overdue">overdue</a> <a href="#fines">fine</a> higher than for <a href="#book">book</a>s.  Compare with <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="videoclip"><b>video clip</b></a>
</dt><dd>A short section of a longer <a href="#work">work</a> produced on <a href="#videotape">videotape</a>, used in a <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a> or incorporated into another work such as a <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>, usually for <a href="#promotion">promotion</a>al purposes or to give the viewer a brief impression of the whole.  Compare with <a href="#filmclip">film clip</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="videoconference"><b>videoconference</b></a>
</dt><dd>A meeting of two or more participants, conducted in <a href="#realtime">real time</a> at a distance using a <a href="#videotape">video</a> camera, microphone, and large television <a href="#monitor">monitor</a> or computer screen installed at each location, linked by satellite or <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#network">network</a>.  <em>Videoconferencing</em> can save time and travel expense, especially in <a href="#distancelearning">distance learning</a> and in organizations with geographically separate units.  Also spelled <em>video conference</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="videodisc"><b>videodisc</b></a>
</dt><dd>A large <a href="#opticaldisk">optical disk</a>, usually made
of plastic with a reflective metal coating, on which visual images and
associated audio signals are recorded for subsequent <a href="#playback">playback</a> on a <em>videodisc player</em> attached to a television receiver and <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>.  Compare with <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>.  Synonymous with <em>optical digital disk</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="videorecording"><b>videorecording</b></a>
</dt><dd>A generic term for an electronic <a href="#medium">medium</a> in which visual images, usually in motion and accompanied by synchronized sound, are recorded for <a href="#playback">playback</a> by means of a television receiver and <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>.  The category includes <a href="#videotape">videotape</a> and <a href="#videodisc">videodisc</a>.  Videorecordings are listed by <a href="#title">title</a> and <a href="#index">index</a>ed by <a href="#subject">subject</a>, <a href="#credit">credit</a>s, awards, and special formats in <b><em>Video Source Book</em></b>, an <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by the National Video Clearinghouse.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fullmotion">full-motion video</a> and <a href="#vrt">Video Round Table</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vrt"><b>Video Round Table (VRT) </b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#roundtable">round table</a> of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a>, <b>VRT</b> provides leadership on issues related to <a href="#videorecording">video</a> <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s, programs, and services in all types of <a href="#library">libraries</a>, including <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, pricing, <a href="#censorship">censorship</a>, and <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>.  <b>VRT</b> also forms alliances with the <a href="#film">film</a> and video <a href="#producer">production</a> and <a href="#distributor">distribution</a> industry to promote diverse, high-quality video production.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/vrt/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>VRT</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="videotape"><b>videotape</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#magnetictape">Magnetic tape</a> on which visual images and accompanying sound are recorded for subsequent <a href="#playback">playback</a> via a television receiver and <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>, usually sold in the form of a <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>.  The industry <a href="#standard">standard</a> is one-half inch wide tape (<a href="#vhs">VHS</a>).  Compare with <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#educationalvideo">educational videotape</a> and <a href="#streamingvideo">streaming video</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="videotex"><b>videotex</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#interactive">interactive</a> (two-way) <a href="#telecommunication">telecommunication</a> system in which a television receiver is adapted to enable computer <a href="#database">database</a>s to be searched over a telephone line or cable, using a <a href="#menu">menu</a>-system or <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> for <a href="#input">input</a>.  <a href="#search">Search</a> results are displayed on the television screen.  Synonymous in Britain with <em>viewdata</em>.  Compare with <a href="#teletext">teletext</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="view"><b>view</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#cartography">cartography</a>, a representation of
a landscape from a perspective that makes details appear as if
projected on an oblique plane, for example, a bird's-eye view,
panorama, or worm's-eye view, sometimes used for comic effect.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="viewingroom"><b>viewing room</b></a>
</dt><dd>A special room in a <a href="#library">library</a>, equipped with projection equipment for viewing <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, or <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>s, individually or in a group.  Viewing equipment may include a film projector and screen, and a <a href="#vcr">VCR</a> and/or DVD player attached to a large-screen television <a href="#monitor">monitor</a> or <a href="#lcd">LCD</a> projector.  Use of the equipment is usually limited to registered <a href="#borrower">borrower</a>s and may be by appointment only.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#listeningroom">listening room</a> 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vignette"><b>vignette</b></a>
</dt><dd>A small <a href="#illustration">illustration</a> or decoration appearing on or before a <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>, or at the beginning or end of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a> in a <a href="#book">book</a>.  In <a href="#illuminated">illuminated</a> <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, a small design, usually circular or oval in shape, consisting of vine leaves and tendrils, used to decorate an <a href="#initialletter">initial letter</a>, <a href="#border">border</a>, or <a href="#miniature">miniature</a>.  
<p>
Also refers to a circular image without a <a href="#border">border</a>, and edges that gradually shade into the <a href="#blank">blank</a> space of the <a href="#page">page</a>, used for <a href="#portrait">portrait</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, and <a href="#engraving">engraving</a>s in 18th- and 19th-century <a href="#publication">publication</a>s.  
</p><p>
In <a href="#literature">literature</a>, a <a href="#sketch">sketch</a> characterized by conciseness of style and delicacy of feeling, which gives a brief but poignant impression of a scene, <a href="#character">character</a>, or situation, without elements of <a href="#plot">plot</a>.  A vignette can be part of a longer <a href="#work">work</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vinyl"><b>vinyl</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#phonograph">phonograph record</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="virgule"><b>virgule</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#slash">slash</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="virtual"><b>virtual</b></a>
</dt><dd>An adjective referring to activities, objects, beings, and
places that have no actual physical reality because they exist only in <a href="#digital">digital</a> form (in <a href="#cyberspace">cyberspace</a>), for example, an <a href="#email">e-mail</a> "box" or an electronic "shopping cart."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="virtuallibrary"><b>virtual library</b></a>
</dt><dd>A "<a href="#library">library</a> without walls" in which the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s do not exist on <a href="#paper">paper</a>, <a href="#microform">microform</a>, or in any tangible form, but are electronically <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.  Such libraries exist only on a very limited scale, but in most traditional print-based libraries in the United States, <a href="#catalog">catalog</a>s and <a href="#periodicalindex">periodical index</a>es are available <a href="#online">online</a>, and the <a href="#fulltext">full-text</a> of some <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s and <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s may also be available electronically.  Some libraries and <a href="#librarysystem">library system</a>s call themselves "virtual" because they offer <a href="#online">online</a> services (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.aclin.org/">Colorado Virtual Library</a></em>).  
<p>
The term <a href="#digitallibrary">digital library</a> is more appropriate because the term <em>virtual</em> (borrowed from "<a href="#virtualreality">virtual reality</a>")
suggests that the experience of using such a library is not the same as
the "real" thing, when in fact, the experience of reading or viewing a <a href="#document">document</a> on a computer screen may be qualitatively different from reading the same <a href="#publication">publication</a> in <a href="#print">print</a>, but the <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#content">content</a> is the same regardless of format.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="virtualreality"><b>virtual reality</b></a>
