</dt><dd>An electronic environment created especially for computer users, through the use of <a href="#software">software</a>
that simulates the visual appearance of three-dimensional reality, but
lacks physical substance, used mainly for training purposes and popular
entertainment. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="virtualtour"><b>virtual tour</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#librarytour">tour</a> of a <a href="#library">library</a>'s facilities, usually available over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  Formats vary, but some include clickable <a href="#floorplan">floor plan</a>s <a href="#link">link</a>ed to <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s with accompanying <a href="#text">text</a> describing the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a>s and services available at each location. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="virus"><b>virus</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#software">Software</a> intended to harm the computers connected to a <a href="#network">network</a>,
usually disseminated with malicious or hostile intent by persons who
try to conceal their identity to avoid detection and prosecution. Most
viruses are designed to attach to <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s or parts of the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>, where they replicate with destructive effect.  To prevent this type of damage, <a href="#localarea">LAN</a> administrators install <a href="#antivirus">anti-virus software</a>
that automatically checks for viruses and eliminates them whenever
possible. Anti-virus software can also be purchased by individual
computer users who wish to protect their <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#security">security</a> and <a href="#worm1">worm</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="visualaid"><b>visual aid</b></a>
</dt><dd>An item, such as a <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, <a href="#videocassette">videocassette</a>, <a href="#slide">slide</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>, <a href="#map">map</a>, <a href="#chart">chart</a>, <a href="#model">model</a>, <a href="#specimen">specimen</a>,
etc., used by an instructor or pressenter to allow the audience to view
an example or representation of what is being taught. <a href="#bi">Instruction</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s sometimes bring to the classroom <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>s containing <a href="#information">information</a> pertinent to course <a href="#content">content</a>, to enable students to recognize them by sight.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="visualdictionary"><b>visual dictionary</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#dictionary">dictionary</a> in which words and <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s (grouped by <a href="#subject">subject</a>, theme, or activity) are <a href="#illustration">illustrated</a>, usually in a <a href="#linedrawing">line drawing</a> on the same or the opposite <a href="#page">page</a>, with each <a href="#term">term</a> keyed to the corresponding feature of the <a href="#diagram">diagram</a> by a thin line or small reference number <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the illustration.  Dorling Kindersley has made a specialty of <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> this type of <a href="#book">book</a> for children.  The <a href="#format">format</a> is also used in <a href="#languagedictionary">language dictionaries</a> in which the terms corresponding to the illustrations are given in two <a href="#language">language</a>s.  Synonymous with <em>pictorial dictionary</em> and <em>picture dictionary</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="visualdisplay"><b>visual display terminal (VDT)</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#terminal">terminal</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="visuallyimpaired"><b>visually impaired</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person whose sight makes using <a href="#libmaterials">library materials</a> in conventional <a href="#format">format</a>s difficult, if not impossible.  <a href="#library">Library</a> services designed to meet the <a href="#infoneed">need</a>s of visually-impaired persons include <a href="#braille">Braille</a>, <a href="#largeprint">large print</a>, <a href="#bookontape">books-on-tape</a> and other recorded <a href="#media">media</a>, and radio reading service.  In the United States, these services are available through the federally-funded <a href="#nls">National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped</a> (NLS).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vra"><b>Visual Resources Association (VRA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>An international organization established in 1982 to advance <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a>, <a href="#research">research</a>, and education in the field of visual <a href="#information">information</a> resources, <b>VRA</b> has a membership consisting of information <a href="#media">media</a> professionals, including <a href="#digitalimaging">digital image</a> specialists; art, architecture, <a href="#film">film</a>, and <a href="#videorecording">video</a> <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s and museum <a href="#curator">curator</a>s; <a href="#slide">slide</a>, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>, <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a>, and <a href="#digitalarchives">digital archivist</a>s; architectural firms; museums and galleries; <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s and image system vendors; <a href="#copyright">rights</a> and <a href="#reproduction">reproduction</a> officials; photographers and artists; art historians; and scientists.  <b>VRA</b> sponsors an annual <a href="#conference">conference</a> and <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#quarterly">quarterly</a> <em>VRA Bulletin</em>.  <a href="http://www.vraweb.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>VRA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vitalrecords"><b>vital records</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#records">Records</a> essential to an <a href="#agency">agency</a> in the ongoing conduct of its business or affairs, without which it would cease to function effectively (<em>example</em>:  the <a href="#file">file</a> of <a href="#patronrecord">patron record</a>s used by a <a href="#library">library</a> in <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> transactions).  For <a href="#archivist">archivist</a>s, identifying and protecting vital records under every conceivable circumstance is a primary concern in <a href="#recordsmanagement">records management</a> and <a href="#disasterplan">disaster plan</a>ning.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="viz"><b><em>viz.</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of the Latin <em>videlicet</em> meaning "namely," "that is to say," or "to wit," used in <a href="#text">text</a> and <a href="#footnote">footnote</a>s to introduce a word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a> added to explain more completely or precisely a previous word, phrase, or statement.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vocabulary"><b>vocabulary</b></a>
</dt><dd>All the words used in a <a href="#language">language</a>.  Also, all the words and <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>s used by a particular person, group, or profession.  Also refers to a list of words in a <a href="#textbook">textbook</a> for students learning a foreign language, usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> at the end of the <a href="#text">text</a> containing them, or at the end of each <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>. Compare with <a href="#glossary">glossary</a> and <a href="#lexicon">lexicon</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a> and <a href="#vocabcontrol">vocabulary control</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vocabcontrol"><b>vocabulary control</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#indexing">indexing</a>, the process of creating and maintaining a list of <a href="#preferredterm">preferred term</a>s to indicate 1) which of two or more equivalent terms will represent a concept as the authorized <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a> or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a> in the <a href="#classificationsys">classification system</a>, and 2) the relations of <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchy</a> (<a href="#broaderterm">broader</a> and <a href="#narrowerterm">narrower term</a>s) and <a href="#associative">association</a> (<a href="#relatedterm">related term</a>s) among <a href="#heading">heading</a>s once they have been selected.   <a href="#controlled">Controlled vocabulary</a> is recorded in a subject headings list or <a href="#thesaurus">thesaurus</a> <a href="#updated">updated</a> as new concepts emerge and older <a href="#terminology">terminology</a> becomes obsolete.  Compare with <a href="#authoritycontrol">authority control</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vocabmap"><b>vocabulary mapping</b></a>
</dt><dd>A function built into the <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a> of some <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s that allows the user to relate a specific <a href="#searchterm">search term</a> to the appropriate <a href="#subjectheading">subject heading</a>(s) or <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>(s), read a <a href="#scopenote">scope note</a> explaining how each heading is used, view the <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> <a href="#treestructure">tree</a> of headings to which it belongs, and select <a href="#broaderterm">broader heading</a>s or <a href="#narrowerterm">narrower term</a>s or <a href="#subheading">subheading</a>s to include in the <a href="#search">search</a>.  <a href="#vocabulary">Vocabulary</a> mapping is available in large <a href="#database">database</a>s, such as <em><a href="#medline">MEDLINE</a></em> and <em>PsycINFO</em>, which have a well-developed <a href="#controlled">controlled vocabulary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vocalscore"><b>vocal score</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#score">score</a> of a <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a> <a href="#composer">composed</a> for voice (opera, oratorio, cantata, etc.) in which <em>all</em> the <a href="#part">part</a>s are shown in normal size on separate <a href="#stave">stave</a>s,
with any accompaniment (ordinarily written for orchestra) reduced to
two staves for performance on a keyboard instrument. Compare with <a href="#chorusscore">chorus score</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="voicemail"><b>voice mail</b></a>
</dt><dd>A messaging system that allows a person to send, receive, and
store audio messages using a standard telephone receiver. Also spelled <em>voicemail</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#email">e-mail</a> and <a href="#facsimiletrans">FAX</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="voiceover"><b>voice-over</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>s, <a href="#videorecording">video</a>, and television, a <a href="#narration">narration</a>, <a href="#commentary">commentary</a>, or prepared <a href="#text">text</a> spoken by a person who is not seen on the screen, a technique widely used in advertising.  In <a href="#documentary">documentaries</a>, the name of the narrator is usually given in the <a href="#credit">credit</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="voicerecognition"><b>voice recognition</b></a>
</dt><dd>Technology capable of recognizing the sounds of human speech and converting them into <a href="#digitization">digital</a> signals for <a href="#centralproc">processing</a> as <a href="#input">input</a> by a computer, used mainly in <a href="#communications">communications</a>.  In computing, command systems capable of recognizing a few hundred words eliminate the need for a <a href="#mouse">mouse</a> or <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>
in repetitive operations. Discrete systems, used in dictation, require
the speaker to pause between words. Continuous recognition handles <a href="#naturallang">natural language</a> at normal speed, but requires considerably more processing capability.  Systems capable of understanding large <a href="#vocabulary">vocabularies</a> spoken at any speed are anticipated in the foreseeable future.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#artificial">artificial intelligence</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="volume"><b>volume</b></a>
</dt><dd>In the bibliographic sense, a major division of a <a href="#work">work</a>, distinguished from other major divisions of the same work by having its own <a href="#chiefsource">chief source of information</a> and, in most cases, independent <a href="#pagination">pagination</a>, <a href="#foliation">foliation</a>, or <a href="#signature">signature</a>s, even when not <a href="#binding">bound</a> in a separate <a href="#cover">cover</a>.  In a <a href="#set">set</a>, the individual volumes are usually <a href="#number">number</a>ed, with any <a href="#index">index</a>es at the end of the last volume.  For a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>, all the <a href="#issue">issue</a>s <a href="#publishing">published</a> during a given publishing period (usually a <a href="#calendaryear">calendar year</a>), bound or <a href="#unbound">unbound</a>.  The <a href="#volumenumber">volume number</a> is usually <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the front <a href="#cover">cover</a> of each issue, and on the same <a href="#page">page</a> as the <a href="#tableofcontents">table of contents</a>.  In bound periodicals, it is impressed on the <a href="#spine">spine</a>.
<p>
In the physical sense, all the written or printed <a href="#matter">matter</a> contained in a single <a href="#binding">binding</a>.  Volume as material entity does not necessarily correspond with volume as bibliographic entity (see <a href="#multipartvolume">multipart volume</a>).  <a href="#abbreviation">Abbreviated</a> <em>v.</em> or <em>vol.</em>
</p><p>
Also refers to the loudness of the sound(s) produced by a receiver (radio or television) or an electronic <a href="#playback">playback</a> machine (<a href="#phonograph">phonograph</a>, <a href="#audiocassette">audiocassette</a> or <a href="#compactdisc">CD</a> player, <a href="#vcr">VCR</a>, etc.), usually regulated by a <em>volume control</em> device that can be manipulated by the listener. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="volumen"><b>volumen</b></a>
</dt><dd>Latin for "a thing rolled up."  A writing surface used in antiquity, consisting of <a href="#papyrus">papyrus</a> or <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s attached end-to-end, with <a href="#text">text</a> handwritten in <a href="#column">column</a>s
on one side only, the lines running parallel with the edges of the
roll. The last sheet was attached to a straight stick with knobbed ends
called an <a href="#umbilicus">umbilicus</a> around which the <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> was rolled.  The rolls were stored in a box called a <a href="#capsa">capsa</a> or on deep shelves with a <a href="#vellum">vellum</a> <a href="#label">label</a> or ticket attached to one end for identification by <a href="#title">title</a> or <a href="#contents">contents</a>.  Synonymous with <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#scrinium">scrinium</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="volumenumber"><b>volume number</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#number">number</a> assigned to all the <a href="#issue">issue</a>s of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> during a given publication period (usually a <a href="#calendaryear">calendar year</a>), beginning with number one for the period (year) in which the <a href="#title">title</a> was first issued.  If the issues are <a href="#binding">bound</a> in one or more physical <a href="#volume">volume</a>s, the number is printed or impressed on the <a href="#spine">spine</a>(s).  In a <a href="#multivolumework">multivolume</a> <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>, such as an <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>, the volume number appears on the spine and on the <a href="#titlepage">title page</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="volumerights"><b>volume rights</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#rights">rights</a>, usually negotiated with a <a href="#publisher">publisher</a> by the <a href="#author">author</a> or author's <a href="#literaryagent">agent</a>, to <a href="#publishing">publish</a> a <a href="#work">work</a> in <a href="#volume">volume</a> form, including <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a>, <a href="#paperback">paperback</a>, <a href="#bookclub">book club</a>, and <a href="#textbook">textbook</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.   Volume rights also include <a href="#publication">publication</a> of the work in its entirety in a single <a href="#issue">issue</a> of a <a href="#periodical">periodical</a> and <a href="#reprint">reprint</a>ing, in full or in part, in an <a href="#anthology">anthology</a>.  Compare with <a href="#subsidiaryrights">subsidiary rights</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="volunteer"><b>volunteer</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who works for a <a href="#library">library</a> or
other organization without material recompense. Library volunteers are
often retirees who wish to make a contribution by remaining actively
engaged in their community. They perform a variety of tasks, depending
on their skills and talents, including <a href="#reshelving">reshelving</a>, <a href="#physicalprocessing">physical processing</a>, <a href="#mending">mending</a>, <a href="#storytelling">storytelling</a>, landscape maintenance, etc.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#friends">Friends of the Library</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vp"><b>v.p.</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of "<b>v</b>arious <a href="#publisher"><b>p</b>ublisher</a>s" or "<b>v</b>arious <b>p</b>laces."
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vra1"><b>VRA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#vra"><b>V</b>isual <b>R</b>esources <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vrt1"><b>VRT</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#vrt"><b>V</b>ideo <b>R</b>ound <b>T</b>able</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vt100"><b>VT100</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of <a href="#mainframe">mainframe</a> <a href="#terminal">terminal</a> developed by Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC) which became the <em>de facto</em> industry <a href="#standard">standard</a>, creating an environment in which other types of computers are required to use <a href="#software">software</a> that <a href="#emulation">emulates</a> VT100 in order to <a href="#logon">log on</a> via <a href="#telnet">Telnet</a> to a mainframe.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vulgate"><b>Vulgate</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Latin <em>vulgata</em> meaning "popular."  A Latin <a href="#translation">translation</a> of the <em>Bible</em> prepared in the 4th century by St. Jerome, which remained for centuries the <a href="#version">version</a>
authorized by the Roman Catholic Church. In 1546, the Council of Trent,
after considering all extant Latin translations, reaffirmed the Vulgate
as the official version. The first <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> in Europe, the <em><a href="#gutenbergbible">Gutenberg Bible</a></em>, was an <a href="#edition">edition</a> of the Vulgate. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="vy"><b>v.y.</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of "<b>v</b>arious <b>y</b>ears."
</dd></dl><p>

</p><hr>
<center>| <a href="#A">A</a> | <a href="#B">B</a> | <a href="#C">C</a> | <a href="#D">D</a> | <a href="#E">E</a>
| <a href="#F">F</a> | <a href="#G">G</a> | <a href="#H">H</a> | <a href="#I">I</a> | <a href="#JK">JK</a>
| <a href="#L">L</a> | <a href="#M">M</a> | <a href="#N">N</a> | <a href="#O">O</a>
| <a href="#P">P</a> | <a href="#Q">Q</a> | <a href="#R">R</a> | <a href="#S">S</a> | <a href="#T">T</a>
| <a href="#U">U</a> | <a href="#V">V</a> | <a href="#W">W</a> | <a href="#XYZ">XYZ</a> |</center>
<hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="W">W</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="waf"><b>w.a.f.</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of "<a href="#withallfaults"><b>w</b>ith <b>a</b>ll <b>f</b>aults</a>," used in the <a href="#antiquarianbook">antiquarian</a> <a href="#booktrade">book trade</a> to refer to the <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> offered for sale <em>as is</em>, not returnable if found to be defective.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wages"><b>wages</b></a>
</dt><dd>Money paid to an employee for the total <a href="#number">number</a> of hours worked in a given period (weekly, biweekly, monthly), computed at an hourly rate.  <a href="#librarystaff">Library staff</a> employed <a href="#parttime">part-time</a> are usually paid by the hour.  Compare with <a href="#salary">salary</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wallpaper"><b>wallpaper</b></a>
</dt><dd>The decorative background pattern or image against which <a href="#window">window</a>s, <a href="#menu">menu</a>s, <a href="#icon">icon</a>s, and other visual elements are displayed and manipulated in a <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a> (GUI), usually created in <a href="#jpeg">JPEG</a> or <a href="#gif">GIF</a> <a href="#file">file</a> <a href="#format">format</a>.
Some systems allow the user to select a wallpaper from a variety of
different designs. Files of wallpaper designs are also available <a href="#online">online</a> from third-parties.  Wallpapers can be custom-designed to display a distinctive element, such as a <a href="#logo">logo</a>, <a href="#trademark">trademark</a>, or other <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> of institutional identity.  Compare with <a href="#screensaver">screen saver</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wallshelving"><b>wall shelving</b></a>
</dt><dd>Single-sided shelving placed against a wall and sometimes attached to it, as opposed to <a href="#freestanding">free-standing shelving</a>
(usually double-sided) designed to stand on its own away from a wall or
other support. Shelving of both types is manufactured in <a href="#section">section</a>s to allow <a href="#library">libraries</a> to assemble <a href="#range">range</a>s of varying length.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wan"><b>WAN</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#widearea"><b>w</b>ide <b>a</b>rea <b>n</b>etwork</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wand"><b>wand</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#lightpen">light-pen</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="warmboot"><b>warm boot</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#reboot">reboot</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="warping"><b>warping</b></a>
</dt><dd>A twist or bend in a <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> that occurs after <a href="#binding">binding</a> or <a href="#casebinding">casing</a>, severe enough to prevent the <a href="#volume">volume</a> from lying flat, usually caused by dampness.  In newly bound books, the <a href="#condition">condition</a> may be caused by differences in the expansion and/or contraction of the materials used in the <a href="#case">case</a> or cover.  Warping can be minimized in binding by using well-dried <a href="#board">board</a>s, <a href="#endpaper">endpaper</a>s with the <a href="#grain">grain</a> running from <a href="#head">head</a> to <a href="#foot">foot</a>, and <a href="#adhesive">adhesive</a>s of low water content, and by proper pressing.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, it is controlled by storing books in a dry, well-ventilated place.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="warranty"><b>warranty</b></a>
</dt><dd>A fixed period of time, specified in the sales agreement, during which the seller is required to repair or replace a piece of <a href="#libraryequipment">equipment</a> that does not function properly.  Once the warranty period has expired, the purchaser must pay for repairs unless a <a href="#maintenancecontract">maintenance contract</a> has been signed.  As a general rule, length of warranty is an indication of the manufacturer's confidence in the product. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="washing"><b>washing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A labor-intensive <a href="#preservation">preservation</a> technique in which an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#paper">paper</a>, such as a <a href="#map">map</a> or <a href="#print">print</a>, is treated with a mild chemical solution to remove stains, writing, <a href="#foxing">foxing</a>, or <a href="#acidpaper">acid</a>, then pressed and <a href="#resized">resized</a>.  For <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s, the process usually necessitates <a href="#rebinding">rebinding</a>.
<p>
In <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>y, immersion of a <a href="#print">print</a>
in clean running water during the developing process to remove
fixatives. Improperly washed photographic prints eventually discolor
and <a href="#deterioration">deteriorate</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="waterdamaged"><b>water-damaged</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#libmaterials">Library materials</a> that have been exposed to wet or damp conditions, usually as a result of leakage, flooding, or accident.  Exposure of <a href="#print">print</a> materials to moisture can cause swelling, <a href="#warping">warping</a>, <a href="#waterstained">staining</a>, and contamination with <a href="#mildew">mildew</a> and <a href="#mold">mold</a>.  Water-damage can be very difficult to <a href="#repairing">repair</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#preservation">preservation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="watermark"><b>watermark</b></a>
</dt><dd>A faintly translucent papermaker's mark, consisting of <a href="#lettering">lettering</a> and/or a design that can be seen faintly in a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of quality <a href="#paper">paper</a> when it is held up to a light source.  In hand <a href="#papermaking">papermaking</a>,
the design is made by sewing or soldering twisted wire to the mold,
causing the layer of moist fiber to be thinner over the wire. In
mechanized papermaking, the wire is impressed on the moist fiber by a
cylinder called the <a href="#dandyroll">dandy roll</a>.  
<p>
Watermarks were originally intended to identify and date the source of
production, but in time came to designate paper size. Modern watermarks
are sometimes used to provide security against <a href="#forgery">forgery</a>.  The paper used in a <a href="#deluxeedit">deluxe edition</a> may be watermarked to indicate that it was made especially for the edition.  Synonymous with <em>papermark</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#countermark">countermark</a>.
</p><p>
In <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a>, a design or lettering <a href="#printing">printed</a> in a shade of gray across a <a href="#page">page</a>, over which the <a href="#text">text</a> appears to be superimposed, for example, the word "<a href="#draft">Draft</a>" to indicate that the text is not the final <a href="#version">version</a>.  A <em><a href="#digital">digital</a> watermark</em> is a sequence of <a href="#bit">bit</a>s skillfully embedded in a <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>, such as an audio <a href="#compactdisc">CD</a> or <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> on <a href="#dvd">DVD</a>, to help identify the source of <a href="#copy">copies</a> manufactured or distributed in violation of <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="waterstained"><b>waterstained</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> which has <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> or <a href="#binding">binding</a> discolored by contact with water.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#waterdamaged">water-damaged</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="watertear"><b>water tear</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#paper">Paper</a> separated along a moistened line to
give the tear a soft, uneven, feathered edge as the fibers gently pull
apart without breaking, a technique is used in making delicate <a href="#paste">paste</a> <a href="#repairing">repairs</a> in <a href="#book">book</a>s and other <a href="#print">print</a> materials. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="web"><b>Web</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#www">World Wide Web (WWW)</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webaddress"><b>Web address</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#url">URL</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webbrowser"><b>Web browser</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#clientserver">Client</a> <a href="#software">software</a> that interprets the <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> (<a href="#html">HTML</a>) code in which <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s are written and allows <a href="#document">document</a>s and other <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s available over the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> to be viewed in <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>al, as opposed to <a href="#text">text</a>-only <a href="#format">format</a>.  In the United States, the most widely used <a href="#www">Web</a> browsers are <em><a href="#netscape">Netscape Navigator</a></em> and Microsoft <b><em>Internet Explorer</em></b>.  The appearance of a Web page may vary slightly depending on the type and <a href="#version">version</a> of browser used to view it.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webcast"><b>Webcast</b></a>
</dt><dd>Simultaneous transmission of live or delayed <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a> or <a href="#videorecording">video</a> programming over the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a> to all who own the equipment needed to receive it, the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> counterpart of <a href="#broadcast">broadcast</a>ing via radio or television.  In a narrower sense, to send the same Web-based <a href="#content">content</a> (audio, video, <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s, <a href="#text">text</a>) to a group of Internet users, based on their individual needs or interests.  Synonymous with <em>netcast</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webdewey"><b><em>WebDewey</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>An enhanced version of the full <a href="#dewey">Dewey Decimal Classification</a> <a href="#database">database</a> available to full members and partial users of <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> in conjunction with the <a href="#corc">CORC</a> <a href="#onlinecatalog">online</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> project, <b><em>WebDewey</em></b> can be used to generate proposed Dewey <a href="#classnumber">class number</a>s for <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s and other electronic resources.  <a href="http://www.oclc.org/dewey/products/webdewey/about.htm">Click here</a> to learn more about <b><em>WebDewey</em></b>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webindex"><b>Web index</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a> that organizes <a href="#website">Web site</a>s by <a href="#subject">subject</a> <a href="#content">content</a> in a hierarchy of <a href="#subject">subject</a> categories, from the most general to the most <a href="#specificity">specific</a>.  For example, links to Web sites for "library and information science organizations" are listed in <em><a href="#yahoo">Yahoo!</a></em> under:
<p>
</p><dl><dt></dt><dd>Reference
<dl><dt></dt><dd>Libraries
<dl><dt></dt><dd>Library and Information Science
<dl><dt></dt><dd>Organizations</dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>
The <a href="#url">URL</a> in a Web <a href="#index">index</a> may reflect the hierarchical arrangement (dir.yahoo.com/Reference/Libraries/Library_and_Information_Science/Organizations/).
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webliography"><b>webliography</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#enumerative">enumerative</a> list of <a href="#digital">digital</a> resources on a specific <a href="#topic">topic</a> or <a href="#subject">subject</a>, available in <a href="#print">print</a> or on the <a href="#www">Web</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.centerx.gseis.ucla.edu/weblio/ellison.html">Ralph Ellison Webliography</a></em> by Claude H. Pott).  Typically, the <a href="#url">URL</a>s of any <a href="#website">Web site</a>s included in the resource list are embedded in the <a href="#html">HTML</a> <a href="#document">document</a>, enabling users to connect to the site by clicking on its <a href="#hypertext">hypertext</a> <a href="#link">link</a>.  The <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> <a href="#corc">CORC</a> project is creating a <a href="#database">database</a> of electronic <a href="#pathfinder">pathfinder</a>s to assist <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s in integrating and organizing their <a href="#print">print</a> and <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#topic">topic</a>-specific resource <a href="#guide">guide</a>s.  Also known as a <em>subject gateway</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="weblog"><b>Weblog</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> providing a list of <a href="#link">link</a>s and/or comments related to a <a href="#topic">topic</a> or <a href="#subject">subject</a> (broad or narrow in <a href="#scope">scope</a>), arranged in <a href="#reversechron">reverse chronological</a> order, the most recently added piece of <a href="#information">information</a> appearing first.  An example in the field of <a href="#libraryscience">library</a> and <a href="#infoscience">information science</a> is <em><a href="http://www.lisnews.com/">LISNews.com</a></em> which accepts postings from its <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.  A list of <a href="#library">library</a> Weblog <a href="#website">site</a>s is maintained by Peter Scott on <em><a href="http://www.libdex.com/weblogs.html">LibDex</a></em>.  Scott also manages the Weblog <em><a href="http://www.lights.com/scott/">Library News Daily</a></em>.  Synonymous with <em>blog</em>.  The process of maintaining a Weblog is known as <em>blogging</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webmaster"><b>Webmaster</b></a>
</dt><dd>The individual responsible for managing and maintaining a <a href="#website">Web site</a>, often the person who designed it, whose name usually appears near the bottom of the main page or <a href="#welcomescreen">welcome screen</a>, usually with a contact <a href="#link">link</a>.  In <a href="#library">libraries</a>, the Webmaster may be the <a href="#systemslibrarian">systems librarian</a>, a "<a href="#technician">techie</a>," or a person who has acquired a <a href="#knowledge">knowledge</a> of <a href="#html">HTML</a> and <a href="#webserver">Web server</a>s.  <a href="http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/Web4Lib/RefCenter/">Click here</a> to connect to <em>The Library Web Manager's Reference Center</em>, a <a href="#website">Web site</a> maintained by the UC Berkeley Digital Library.  Synonymous with <em>Web manager</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webpac"><b>WebPac</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#online">online</a> public <a href="#access">access</a> <a href="#onlinecatalog">catalog</a> (<a href="#opac">OPAC</a>) that uses a <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a> (GUI) <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> via the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>, as opposed to a <a href="#text">text</a>-based <a href="#interface">interface</a> accessible via <a href="#telnet">Telnet</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webpage"><b>Web page</b></a>
</dt><dd>An electronic <a href="#document">document</a> written in <a href="#html">HTML</a> script, stored on a <a href="#webserver">Web server</a> and <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> using <a href="#browser">Web browser</a> <a href="#software">software</a> at a unique <a href="#internetaddress">Internet address</a> called a <a href="#url">URL</a>, usually one of a group of related, inter<a href="#link">link</a>ed <a href="#file">file</a>s that together comprise a <a href="#website">Web site</a>.  A <a href="#www">Web</a> page may include <a href="#formatting">formatted</a> <a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#graphic">graphic</a> material, <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a> and/or <a href="#videorecording">video</a> elements, and links to other files on the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#personalweb">personal Web page</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webserver"><b>Web server</b></a>
</dt><dd>A computer capable of providing <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#www">Web</a>-based resources and services in response to requests from <a href="#client">client</a> computers on which <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a> <a href="#software">software</a> is installed.  A Web server includes the necessary <a href="#hardware">hardware</a>, and also the <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>, <a href="#tcpip">TCP/IP</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a>s, <a href="#server">server</a> <a href="#software">software</a>, and <a href="#information">information</a> <a href="#content">content</a> of the <a href="#website">Web site</a>s installed on it.  Web server software is designed to accept requests from users to <a href="#download">download</a> <a href="#html">HTML</a> <a href="#text">text</a>, <a href="#digitalimaging">image</a>, and <a href="#audiorecording">audio</a> <a href="#file">file</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#clientserver">client-server</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="website"><b>Web site</b></a>
</dt><dd>A group of related, inter<a href="#link">link</a>ed <a href="#webpage">Web page</a>s installed on a <a href="#webserver">Web server</a> and <a href="#accessibility">accessible</a> 24 hours a day to <a href="#internet">Internet</a> users equipped with <a href="#browser">browser</a> <a href="#software">software</a>.  Most Web sites are created to represent the <a href="#online">online</a> presence of a company, organization, or institution, or are the work of a group or individual.  The main page or <a href="#welcomescreen">welcome screen</a>, called the <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>, usually displays the <a href="#title">title</a> of the site, the name of the person (or persons) responsible for creating and maintaining it, and date of last <a href="#update">update</a>.  Also spelled <em>Website</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webtv"><b>WebTV</b></a>
</dt><dd>A Microsoft <a href="#trademark">trademark</a> applied to technology that enables the user to search the <a href="#www">Web</a> via television, rather than a <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a>.  A set-top box is installed containing an <a href="#analog">analog</a> <a href="#modem">modem</a> designed to make the connection to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> via a telephone line and <a href="#dataconversion">convert</a> <a href="#data">data</a> to a <a href="#format">format</a> that can be displayed on the television <a href="#monitor">monitor</a>, with <a href="#navigation">navigation</a> by hand-held remote control <a href="#device">device</a> or optional <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a>.  To gain <a href="#access">access</a>, the user must establish an account with an <a href="#internetservice">Internet service provider</a>.  Synonymous with <em>Internet TV</em>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="webzine"><b>Webzine</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#electronicmagazine">electronic magazine</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wedgeserif"><b>wedge-serif</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> with <a href="#serif">serif</a>s that are triangular in shape, also known as <a href="#latin">latin</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="weeding"><b>weeding</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of examining <a href="#bibitem">item</a>s in a <a href="#libcollec">library collection</a> <a href="#title">title</a>-by-title to identify for permanent <a href="#withdrawal">withdrawal</a> those that are <a href="#outdated">outdated</a>, in worn <a href="#condition">condition</a>, or no longer circulating, especially when space in the <a href="#stacks">stacks</a> is limited.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> usually weed routinely on the basis of <a href="#circulation">circulation</a>.  In <a href="#academiclib">academic libraries</a>, weeding is done less frequently, usually only when the shelves become overcrowded, in anticipation of a <a href="#moving">move</a>,
or when a significant change occurs in curriculum, such as the
elimination of a major. Weeding should be undertaken judiciously
because <a href="#outofprint">out of print</a> <a href="#title">title</a>s can be difficult to <a href="#replacement">replace</a>.  Compare with <a href="#deselection">deselection</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#exchange">exchange</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="weekly"><b>weekly</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#issue">Issue</a>d once a week.  Also refers to a <a href="#serial">serial</a> issued once a week (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="#publishersweekly">Publishers Weekly</a></em>).  Most <a href="#newsmagazine">news magazine</a>s and some <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s are <a href="#publishing">published</a> weekly (<b><em>Newsweek</em></b> and <b><em>Barron's</em></b>).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="weight"><b>weight</b></a>
</dt><dd>The relative thickness of a <a href="#typeface">typeface</a>, which determines how dark it will appear on a <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#page">page</a>, indicated in <a href="#typography">typography</a> by gradation (extra-light, <a href="#lightface">light</a>, semi-light, <a href="#medium">medium</a>, semi-bold, <a href="#boldface">bold</a>, extra-bold, and ultra-bold).  In selecting an appropriate weight of <a href="#type">type</a> for a proposed <a href="#publication">publication</a>, the typographer must consider grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, type of <a href="#ink">ink</a>, and method of printing.  Most <a href="#book">book</a>s are printed in medium type, with bold or semi-bold used for <a href="#heading">heading</a>s and emphasis.
<p>
Also refers to the basis on which a unit of <a href="#paper">paper</a>, such as a <a href="#ream">ream</a>, is sold in the market place.  The <em>M-weight</em> of a given size of paper is the weight of 1,000 <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>s, measured in pounds.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="weighting"><b>weighting</b></a>
</dt><dd>Use of an <a href="#algorithm">algorithm</a> to predict the <a href="#relevance">relevance</a> of <a href="#document">document</a>s <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieved</a> in a <a href="#search">search</a>, usually based on the <a href="#termfreq">frequency</a> of <a href="#searchterm">search term</a>s and their location in the <a href="#bibrecord">record</a> (in <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#descriptor">descriptor</a>s, <a href="#abstract">abstract</a>, or <a href="#text">text</a>).  Weighting allows records to be scored and presented to the user in <a href="#ranking">ranked</a> order.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="welcomescreen"><b>welcome screen</b></a>
</dt><dd>The first screen a user encounters upon <a href="#logon">logging on</a> to a <a href="#database">database</a>, <a href="#website">Web site</a>, or <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>.  A well-designed welcome screen gives the <a href="#title">title</a>, <a href="#scope">scope</a> and <a href="#coverage">coverage</a>, name of <a href="#author">author</a> and/or <a href="#producer">producer</a>, <a href="#host">host</a>, and a basic set of <a href="#option">option</a>s, with instructions for using the system and a link to a more detailed <a href="#helpscreen">help screen</a> if needed.  A well-designed <a href="#interface">interface</a> includes a direct <a href="#link">link</a> back to the welcome screen on all the subordinate screens.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="western"><b>western</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#shortstory">short story</a>, <a href="#novel">novel</a>, <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a>, or television program (or series) in which the <a href="#setting">setting</a> is the 19th century American West and the <a href="#character">character</a>s are cowboys, frontiersmen, "outlaws," settlers, and  indigenous people.  Also refers to the <a href="#fiction">fiction</a> <a href="#genre">genre</a> comprising such <a href="#work">work</a>s.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="whiteboard"><b>whiteboard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A modern version of the erasable chalkboard, with a surface
that is white, rather than the traditional black or green, made of a
smooth material that can be written upon with <em>dry-erase</em>
marking pens in various colors, easy to erase and not as messy as
chalk. However, the plastic pens cannot be refilled and become
nonbiodegradable waste. Whiteboards are available from <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#supplier">supplier</a>s
in reversible freestanding and single-sided wall-mountable models.
Porcelain steel models are available for use with magnets. Synonymous
with <em>markerboard</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#smartboard">smartboard</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="whiteletter"><b>white letter</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used in early <a href="#printing">printing</a> for <a href="#roman">roman</a> <a href="#type">type</a>, as opposed to <a href="#gothic">gothic</a> or <em>black letter</em>. 

<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="whiteline"><b>white line</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, a line of <a href="#spacing">spacing</a> equal in depth to a line of printed <a href="#matter">matter</a>, used before and after <a href="#heading">heading</a>s, long <a href="#quotation">quotation</a>s, etc., to set them apart from the <a href="#text">text</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="whitepages"><b>white pages</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portion of a <a href="#telephonedirectory">telephone directory</a>
in which the names, phone numbers, and street addresses of individuals
residing in a specific city, town, or geographic area are listed <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#surname">surname</a>, usually preceding the <a href="#classified">classified</a> section (<a href="#yellowpages">yellow pages</a>) listing similar <a href="#information">information</a> for businesses and other organizations.  White <a href="#page">page</a>s available on the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> sometimes include <a href="#email">e-mail</a> addresses (see <em><a href="http://www.whowhere.lycos.com/">WhoWhere?</a></em> from Lycos).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="whitepaper"><b>white paper</b></a>
</dt><dd>An official government <a href="#report">report</a> on any <a href="#subject">subject</a>,
especially one summarizing the results of an investigation or important
policy decision of the British Parliament. Compare in this sense with <a href="#greenpaper">green paper</a>.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also used to refer to an <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> <a href="#report">report</a> on a <a href="#topic">topic</a> in technology, such as a new line of product development, sometimes available <a href="#online">online</a>, usually written by a person employed by a <a href="#research">research</a> company or vendor, or by an independent <a href="#consultant">consultant</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="whitespace"><b>white space</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#printing">printing</a>, any area of a <a href="#page">page</a> (other than the <a href="#margin">margin</a>s) not occupied by <a href="#type">type</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a> or <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>, for example, the unfilled space at the end of each line of a <a href="#poetry">poem</a> or at the end of a <a href="#chapter">chapter</a>.  Compare with <a href="#blank">blank</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#fatmatter">fat matter</a> and <a href="#leanmatter">lean matter</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wholesaler"><b>wholesaler</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>: <a href="#jobber">jobber</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="whoswho"><b><em>Who's Who</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#refbook">reference book</a> or <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> providing brief <a href="#biography">biographical</a> <a href="#information">information</a> about well-known people who are still living.  <b><em>Who Was Who</em></b> covers the lives of <em>deceased</em> persons of prominence.  <a href="#title">Title</a>s beginning <b><em>Who's Who in...</em></b> cover the lives of important persons in a given <a href="#field">field</a> or profession.  Those beginning <b><em>Who's Who of...</em></b> are usually devoted to individuals of a specific gender, nationality, or ethnic origin.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="widearea"><b>wide area network (WAN)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A communication <a href="#network">network</a> covering an extensive geographic area, such as a country, region, province, or state.  Compare with <a href="#localarea">LAN</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="widow"><b>widow</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#typography">typography</a>, a single word or <a href="#phrase">phrase</a>, or a line shorter than one-third the specified line length, at the end of a paragraph, when it appears at the <a href="#head">head</a> of a <a href="#column">column</a> or <a href="#page">page</a> of <a href="#text">text</a> <a href="#matter">matter</a>.  Skilled typographers consider fewer than three lines in this position awkward and avoid <a href="#typesetting">setting</a> them if possible.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#orphan">orphan</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="width"><b>width</b></a>
</dt><dd>The dimension of a <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#binding">bound</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> from <a href="#spine">spine</a> to <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a>, usually less than its <a href="#height">height</a>, the exception being <a href="#volume">volume</a>s <a href="#square">square</a> or <a href="#oblong">oblong</a> in shape.  In the <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a>, the height of a book is given in the <a href="#physicaldescrip">physical description</a> <a href="#area">area</a> of the <a href="#bibrecord">bibliographic record</a> in centimeters, but not the width.  Also refers to the horizontal dimension of a <a href="#section">section</a> of single- or double-sided shelving.  Most library shelving is sold in sections 36 inches wide.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#depth">depth</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wildcard"><b>wildcard</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#searchsoftware">search software</a> used in some <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a>s allows a special <a href="#character">character</a> to be inserted in the middle of a <a href="#searchterm">search term</a> in <a href="#keywords">keyword</a> <a href="#search">search</a>ing to <a href="#inforetrieval">retrieve</a> words containing <em>any</em> character or <em>no</em> character in the position, useful in retrieving irregular plurals and variant spellings of a word.  The wildcard <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> is not <a href="#standardization">standardized</a>.  Users are advised to read the <a href="#helpscreen">help screen</a>(s) in an unfamiliar <a href="#database">database</a> to see if wildcard is available and if so, what <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> is used.  <b><em>See also</em></b>: <a href="#truncation">truncation</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dd><em>Examples</em>:  
<dl><dt></dt><dd><b>wom#n</b> or <b>wom?n</b> to retrieve records containing both <em>woman</em> and <em>women</em> 
</dd><dd><b>colo#r</b> or <b>colo?r</b> to retrieve records containing both <em>color</em> and <em>colour</em></dd></dl>
<p>
In computing, a <a href="#symbol">symbol</a> (usually the asterisk) available in most <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a>s and <a href="#application">application</a> <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s, which can be used in a <a href="#filename">filename</a> to identify multiple <a href="#file">file</a>s and <a href="#directory">directories</a>, for example, <em>letter*.doc</em> to retrieve all the files with names ending in "doc" that begin with "letter."  Most <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> applications also allow the user to employ wildcard in <a href="#text">text</a> searches. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wilson"><b>Wilson</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#hwwilson">H. W. Wilson</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wimps"><b>WIMPS</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#acronym">acronym</a> for "<a href="#window"><b>w</b>indow</a>s, <a href="#icon"><b>i</b>con</a>s, <a href="#mouse"><b>m</b>ouse</a>, <b>p</b>ull-down <a href="#menu">menu</a><b>s</b>."  Synonymous with <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface (GUI)</a>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="window"><b>window</b></a>
</dt><dd>A rectangular, <a href="#scroll">scroll</a>able viewing area in the <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a> of a <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> <a href="#application">application</a> that can be opened by the user, overwriting the entire screen or a portion of it.  Windows can be <a href="#resized">resized</a>, minimized to an <a href="#icon">icon</a> when not needed, selected for editing and reference, or closed by the user at any time to facilitate <a href="#multitasking">multitasking</a> (the use of two or more <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>s at the same time).  Compare with <a href="#frame">frame</a>.
<p>
Also refers to the opening cut out of the center of a <a href="#mat">mat</a>, through which a <a href="#mounted">mounted</a> <a href="#print">print</a> is viewed, or out of the center of a card through which a mounted <a href="#slide">slide</a> or <a href="#frame">frame</a> of <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> is viewed.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="windows"><b>Windows</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#userfriendly">user-friendly</a> <a href="#operatingsys">operating system</a> developed in 1985 by Microsoft for <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a>s running on <a href="#dos">DOS</a>, progressively <a href="#upgrade">upgrade</a>d to its current <a href="#version">version</a>.  <b>Windows</b> got its start by emulating the <a href="#graphicaluser">graphical user interface</a> (GUI) developed by Apple and has since become the industry <a href="#standard">standard</a> for desktop <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a>s.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#macintosh">Macintosh</a> and <a href="#unix">UNIX</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wipo1"><b>WIPO</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#wipo"><b>W</b>orld <b>I</b>ntellectual <b>P</b>roperty <b>O</b>rganization</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wirecoil"><b>wire coil</b></a>
</dt><dd>A continuous length of metal wire threaded through holes punched along the <a href="#bindingedge">binding edge</a> of the <a href="#leaf">leaves</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#notebook">notebook</a> in <a href="#spiralbinding">spiral binding</a>.  Flexible hard plastic is also used for this purpose.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wireless"><b>wireless</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of connecting to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a> via electromagnetic airwaves, rather than wire or cable.  <a href="#telecommunication">Telecommunication</a> charges are eliminated, but an <a href="#internetservice">Internet service provider</a> is still required to gain <a href="#access">access</a> to the <a href="#internet">Internet</a>.  Wireless technology enables the ISP to offer greater <a href="#bandwidth">bandwidth</a>
without the expense of adding cable to its own connection. However, in
most wireless systems "line of sight" is required, which means that the
radio antenna installed at a <a href="#library">library</a> must have an unobstructed path to the antenna maintained by the ISP.  Each client antenna can serve 50-100 <a href="#workstation">workstation</a>s at <a href="#t1">T1</a> speed.  Wireless technology is also be used <em>internally</em> by libraries with a direct connection to the Internet, for example, to <a href="#network">network</a> an <a href="#instructionlab">instruction lab</a> equipped with <a href="#personalcomputer">PC</a>s or <a href="#laptop">laptop</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wireservice"><b>wire service</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#newsservice">news service</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="withallfaults"><b>with all faults (w.a.f.)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#term">term</a> used by <a href="#bookseller">bookseller</a>s, <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#dealer">dealer</a>s, and <a href="#bookauction">auction</a>eers to inform prospective buyers that an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> is offered for sale <em>as is</em> and may not be <a href="#returns">returned</a> if found to be defective. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="withdrawal"><b>withdrawal</b></a>
</dt><dd>The process of deleting all references in a <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#catalog">catalog</a> to an <a href="#bibitem">item</a> that has been permanently removed from the <a href="#libcollec">collection</a> without being <a href="#replacement">replaced</a> by another <a href="#copy">copy</a> of the same <a href="#edition">edition</a>.  The item is usually <a href="#rubberstamp">stamp</a>ed "withdrawn" to avoid confusion in the <a href="#disposition">disposition</a> process.  Also refers to the item <em>withdrawn</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#tracings">tracings</a> and <a href="#weeding">weeding</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="witness"><b>witness</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#bibliography">bibliography</a>, the version of a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#incunabula">incunabulum</a> accepted as <a href="#authoritative">authoritative</a> by most scholars qualified to speak on the <a href="#subject">subject</a>.  In <a href="#binding">binding</a>, a <a href="#book">book</a> with the <a href="#foreedge">fore-edge</a> so slightly <a href="#trimming">trimmed</a> that some <a href="#page">page</a>s are left <a href="#roughedges">rough</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wizard"><b>wizard</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#contextsensitive">context-sensitive</a> <a href="#dialogbox">dialog box</a> that <em>automatically</em> appears in some computer <a href="#application">application</a>s to ask the user if help is needed at a particular point in the <a href="#computerprogram">program</a>, as distinct from a <a href="#helpscreen">help</a> <a href="#menu">menu</a> that can be selected by the user as needed.  Wizards can usually be turned "off" if the user finds them intrusive.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="woodcut"><b>woodcut</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#printing">printing</a> from an <a href="#ink">ink</a>ed block of medium-soft wood (usually pear or cherry) from which an artist has excised all but an <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>,
working by hand with knife and gouge in the same direction as the grain
of a plank cut lengthwise from the tree. The design may be drawn
directly on the plank (usually in pencil), or transferred by rubbing a
tracing made on <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  Also refers to the block itself and to the <a href="#print">print</a> made from it.  By contrast, <em>wood engraving</em> is done with a tool called a burin or graver across the grain of a block of hardwood cut in cross-section.    
<p>
The earliest known example of a woodcut is a <a href="#copy">copy</a> of the <b><em>Diamond Sutra</em></b> printed in China in the 9th century AD.  In early printing in Europe, woodblocks were locked with <a href="#movabletype">movable type</a> to allow <a href="#text">text</a> and illustration to be inked together.  To produce colored prints, separate blocks were cut for each color and successive <a href="#impression">impression</a>s made on the same <a href="#sheet">sheet</a>.  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wordbyword"><b>word-by-word</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of <a href="#alphabetization">alphabetization</a> in which <a href="#heading">heading</a>s that begin with the same word are arranged in <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a> order by the next word, and so on, with <a href="#punctuation">punctuation</a> marks treated as spaces ("New Testament" filed before "New, William" before "newt").  Also known as <em>nothing before something</em>.  Compare with <a href="#letterbyletter">letter-by-letter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wordless"><b>wordless</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> or other <a href="#publication">publication</a> without words, in which the story is told in a sequence of <a href="#illustration">illustration</a>s, a <a href="#format">format</a> used mainly in children's <a href="#picturebook">picture book</a>s (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Clown</em></b>  (1995) by Quentin Blake).  Without <a href="#text">text</a>, the "reader" must interpret the meaning of the story from the visual images.  Each <a href="#reader">reader</a> may perceive a slightly different meaning in the <a href="#picture">picture</a>s.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wordprocessing"><b>word processing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A method of converting <a href="#information">information</a> into readable <a href="#text">text</a>
in which personnel, procedures, and equipment are organized for maximum
efficiency and effectiveness. Word processing systems usually include a
<a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> with a <a href="#keyboard">keyboard</a> for typing <a href="#input">input</a>, a <a href="#monitor">monitor</a> for the display of <a href="#text">text</a>, and a <a href="#laserprinter">laser printer</a> for producing high-quality <a href="#output">output</a>.  An <a href="#interface">interface</a> with a photosetting machine allows <a href="#offset">offset</a> <a href="#plate">plate</a>s to be produced for <a href="#printing">printing</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="work"><b>work</b></a>
</dt><dd>An expression of human thought or emotion in <a href="#language">language</a>, signs, <a href="#symbol">symbol</a>s, <a href="#numeral">numeral</a>s, images, or other <a href="#medium">medium</a> for purposes of communication and <a href="#record">record</a>.  When such an expression is <a href="#issue">issue</a>d to the public, it is a <a href="#publishing">published</a> work.  If the original <a href="#author">author</a> or creator is unknown, the work is <a href="#anonymous">anonymous</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#literarywork">literary work</a>, <a href="#musicalwork">musical work</a>, and <a href="#workinprogress">work in progress</a>.
<p>
As defined in <em><a href="#frbr">FRBR</a></em> (<em>Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records</em>), a distinct intellectual or artistic creation, independent of any concrete realization or <a href="#expression">expression</a> of its <a href="#content">content</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Beowulf</em></b> as opposed to a specific <a href="#text">text</a> of the <a href="#epic">epic</a>).  The concept is abstract in specifying only the content which the various expressions of a work have in common.  Under this <a href="#definition">definition</a>,
the boundaries of a work may be culturally determined. When
modification of a work entails considerable independent intellectual or
artistic endeavor, the result is treated as a new work (<em>example</em>:  an <a href="#adaptation">adaptation</a> of <b><em>Beowulf</em></b> intended for juvenile <a href="#reader">reader</a>s).  
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workaholic"><b>workaholic</b></a>
</dt><dd>A person who fails to balance work with activities that
provide rest and relaxation. When chronic, this condition can
eventually lead to <a href="#burnout">burnout</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workbook"><b>workbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#separatelypub">separately published</a> learning
resource containing exercises, sample problems, worksheets, review
questions, and other practice materials, usually with <a href="#blank">blank</a> space for recording answers.  When <a href="#publishing">published</a> in conjunction with a <a href="#textbook">textbook</a>, a workbook is usually <a href="#binding">bound</a> in <a href="#softcover">softcover</a>, sometimes in a <a href="#spiralbinding">spiral</a> or <a href="#combbinding">comb binding</a> to allow it to <a href="#openability">open flat</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workflow"><b>workflow</b></a>
</dt><dd>The manner in which work is passed from one member of a
department to another, or from one department to another within a
company, organization, or institution, to allow the steps necessary for
completion to be executed in proper sequence. Efficiencies can
sometimes be achieved by systematic analysis of workflow.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workform"><b>work form</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#technical">technical processing</a>, a card or <a href="#paper">paper</a> <a href="#form">form</a> that accompanies a newly <a href="#acquisitions">acquired</a> <a href="#bibitem">item</a> from the beginning of <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> to the point at which it is ready to be placed on the shelf, with space for <a href="#librarystaff">library staff</a> to note any special instructions and <a href="#data">data</a> necessary to prepare <a href="#catalogrecord">catalog record</a>s, add <a href="#crossref">cross-reference</a>s, and <a href="#physicalprocessing">physically prepare</a> the item for use.  Synonymous with <em>worksheet</em>.  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workingconditions"><b>working conditions</b></a>
</dt><dd>The surroundings in which work is accomplished, including
factors affecting health and safety (lighting, sanitation,
heating/cooling, noise, air quality, etc.) and comfort (parking, break
time, child care, etc.). Companies, organizations, and institutions
that employ large numbers of people often have a formal procedure or <a href="#standingcom">standing committee</a> for handling complaints and suggestions concerning working conditions.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workingtitle"><b>working title</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#title">title</a> provided by the <a href="#author">author</a> at the time a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> is submitted to the <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>, used during the <a href="#editing">editorial process</a>, but sometimes altered slightly or changed completely before final <a href="#publication">publication</a> to reflect the <a href="#content">content</a> more accurately or make the <a href="#work">work</a> more marketable.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workinprogress"><b>work in progress</b></a>
</dt><dd>A written or artistic <a href="#work">work</a> <a href="#publishing">published</a> or <a href="#exhibit">exhibit</a>ed in incomplete form, sometimes in <a href="#part">part</a>s, to be continued or completed by the <a href="#author">author</a> or creator at a later date.  Large <a href="#refbook">reference work</a>s requiring many years of painstaking <a href="#research">research</a> are sometimes published as the work progresses (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Dictionary of American Regional English</em></b>). 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workload"><b>workload</b></a>
</dt><dd>The amount of work to be completed in a given time by an
employee or group of employees. How much is actually accomplished
depends on speed, skill, motivation, <a href="#workingconditions">working conditions</a>, etc. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workmark"><b>work mark</b></a>
</dt><dd>One or two <a href="#letter">letter</a>s added by the <a href="#cataloger">cataloger</a> to the <a href="#authormark">author mark</a> at the end of a <a href="#callnumber">call number</a>, consisting of the first letter or two of the first word of the <a href="#title">title</a> (initial articles excluded), to distinguish <a href="#work">work</a>s by the same <a href="#author">author</a> which have the same <a href="#classificationsys">classification</a> (<em>example</em>:  the <b>d</b> in the <a href="#booknumber">book number</a> <b>D548d</b> to identify <em>David Copperfield</em> by Charles Dickens), or to subarrange <a href="#edition">edition</a>s of the same <a href="#work">work</a>.  Synonymous with <em>work number</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="worknumber"><b>work number</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#workmark">work mark</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workroom"><b>workroom</b></a>
</dt><dd>A room closed to the public, where technical processes and routine tasks are carried out in the <a href="#library">library</a>, for example, the receiving area of the <a href="#serial">serial</a>s department, where <a href="#currentissue">current issue</a>s of <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s are checked in and prepared for use, and <a href="#backissue">back issue</a>s are boxed to be <a href="#shipping">shipped</a> to the <a href="#bindery">bindery</a> or <a href="#discard">discard</a>ed. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="worksheet"><b>worksheet</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#workform">work form</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workshop"><b>workshop</b></a>
</dt><dd>A meeting of people interested in learning more about a <a href="#subject">subject</a>, or who wish to gain practical experience in the use of a technique, system, or resource, usually for the purpose of <a href="#training">training</a> or <a href="#profdevel">professional development</a>.  A workshop differs from a <a href="#conference">conference</a>
in being task-oriented and of shorter duration (usually one day or
less), and may be open to attendees who do not necessarily share
membership in a voluntary organization. <p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="workstation"><b>workstation</b></a>
</dt><dd>An area within a workplace, equipped with a <a href="#personalcomputer">personal computer</a> and high-<a href="#resolution">resolution</a> <a href="#monitor">monitor</a> for accomplishing tasks that require the use of <a href="#information">information</a> in <a href="#digital">digital</a> <a href="#format">format</a> (especially <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s), usually furnished with a desk, chair, and specially designed table to accommodate the PC and any <a href="#peripheral">peripheral equipment</a>.  If the <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> is <a href="#network">network</a>ed, special wiring may be required.  Also refers to a PC functioning as a <a href="#clientserver">client</a> in a network.  In this sense, compare with <a href="#server">server</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="worldatlas"><b>world atlas</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#refbook">reference book</a>, usually of large size, containing <a href="#map">map</a>s of all the countries and regions of the world, <a href="#printing">printed</a> in color, sometimes accompanied by explanatory <a href="#text">text</a> and statistical <a href="#information">information</a>, with an <a href="#index">index</a> of <a href="#geographicname">place name</a>s (<a href="#gazetteer">gazetteer</a>) in the back (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>The Times Atlas of the World</em></b>).  <a href="http://www.atlapedia.com/">Click here</a> to connect to <b><em>Atlapedia</em></b>, an <a href="#online">online</a> world <a href="#atlas">atlas</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="worldcat"><b><em>WorldCat</em></b></a>
</dt><dd>Formerly known as <em><a href="#oluc">OLUC</a></em>, <b><em>WorldCat</em></b> is the <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#unioncatalog">union catalog</a> of <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> cataloged by <a href="#oclc">OCLC</a> member <a href="#library">libraries</a> and institutions, a rapidly growing <a href="#bibdatabase">bibliographic database</a> containing over 48 million <a href="#bibrecord">record</a>s representing materials <a href="#publishing">published</a> since 1000 BC in over 400 <a href="#language">language</a>s in a variety of <a href="#format">format</a>s (<a href="#book">book</a>s, <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a>s, <a href="#map">map</a>s, music <a href="#score">score</a>s, <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s, <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, <a href="#journal">journal</a>s, <a href="#thesis">theses</a> and <a href="#dissertation">dissertation</a>s, <a href="#soundrecording">sound recording</a>s, <a href="#film">film</a>s, <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a>s, <a href="#computerprogram">computer program</a>s, <a href="#mrdf">machine-readable data file</a>s, etc.). <a href="#updated">Updated</a> <a href="#daily">daily</a>, <b><em>WorldCat</em></b> is used by OCLC members and participants for <a href="#cataloging">cataloging</a> and <a href="#interlibrary">interlibrary loan</a>, and is available for general use by <a href="#licensing">licensing agreement</a> through OCLC <em><a href="#firstsearch">FirstSearch</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wipo"><b>World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A specialized <a href="#agency">agency</a> of the United Nations with headquarters in Geneva, <b>WIPO</b> is responsible for administering 21 international <a href="#treaty">treaties</a> concerning the protection of <a href="#intellectualproperty">intellectual property</a> through <a href="#copyright">copyright</a>, <a href="#patent">patent</a>, and <a href="#trademark">trademark</a> law, for the benefit of its 177 member nations.  <a href="http://www.wipo.org/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>WIPO</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="www"><b>World Wide Web (WWW)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A global <a href="#network">network</a> of <a href="#internet">Internet</a> <a href="#webserver">server</a>s providing <a href="#access">access</a> to <a href="#document">document</a>s written in a script called <a href="#html">Hyper Text Markup Language</a> (HTML) that allows <a href="#content">content</a> to be inter<a href="#link">link</a>ed, locally and remotely.  The "Web" was designed in 1989 by <a href="#bernerslee">Tim Berners-Lee</a>,
working at the CERN high-energy physics lab in Geneva. Mark Andreeson,
a student a the University of Illinois, later devised a simple
point-and-click system called <b><em>Mosaic</em></b> that subsequently evolved into the <em><a href="#netscape">Netscape</a></em> <a href="#webbrowser">Web browser</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> and <a href="#website">Web site</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="worm1"><b>worm</b></a>
</dt><dd>A type of computer <a href="#virus">virus</a> that incapacitates a system by replicating itself through <a href="#harddisk">hard disk</a> and <a href="#memory">memory</a>, consuming space and resources without attaching itself to other <a href="#computerprogram">programs</a>.  <a href="#antivirus">Anti-virus software</a> is available to detect and eliminate known computer viruses before damage occurs.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#bookworm">bookworm</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="worm"><b>WORM</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#initialism">initialism</a> that stands for <em><b>W</b>rite <b>O</b>nce, <b>R</b>ead <b>M</b>any</em>.  <a href="#digital">Digital</a> <a href="#storage">storage</a> technology that allows <a href="#data">data</a> to be written once and read an unlimited <a href="#number">number</a> of times but not erased, used mainly to prevent <a href="#archives">archival</a> data from being accidentally lost.  WORM <a href="#device">device</a>s use double-sided <a href="#opticaldisk">optical disk</a>s that range in size from 5.25 to 14 inches wide, capable of storing 140 <a href="#byte">MB</a> to 3 <a href="#byte">GB</a> on each side.  Acceptance in the market place has been hampered by the fact that WORM disks are not <a href="#standardization">standardized</a>, making them readable <em>only</em> on the type of <a href="#diskdrive">drive</a> used to write them.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#readonly">read-only</a> and <a href="#rewritable">rewritable</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="worming"><b>worming</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#condition">condition</a> of a <a href="#book">book</a> in which small insects called <a href="#bookworm">bookworm</a>s have bored holes through the <a href="#textblock">text block</a> or <a href="#binding">binding</a>, or left other visible traces of their unwelcome presence.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wovepaper"><b>wove paper</b></a>
</dt><dd>Handmade <a href="#paper">paper</a> that reveals a faintly
translucent, fine mesh pattern when held up to a light source, the
result of wires woven evenly like cloth in the paper mold. The same
effect is achieved in machine-made paper by the pressure of the <a href="#dandyroll">dandy roll</a>.  Compare with <a href="#laidpaper">laid paper</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wraparound"><b>wrap-around</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> <a href="#term">term</a> for a <a href="#cover">cover</a> design extending all the way from the front edge of a <a href="#book">book</a> over the <a href="#spine">spine</a> and across the back <a href="#board">board</a>, usually seen in <a href="#volume">volume</a>s containing a large proportion of <a href="#picture">pictorial</a> <a href="#content">content</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pictorial">pictorial</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wrapper"><b>wrapper</b></a>
</dt><dd>The printed or unprinted <a href="#cover">cover</a> of a <a href="#paperback">paperbound</a> <a href="#book">book</a> or <a href="#pamphlet">pamphlet</a>, usually of a heavier grade of <a href="#paper">paper</a> than the <a href="#text">text</a> and therefore not part of the <a href="#printing">printing</a> that produced the <a href="#publication">publication</a>.  When made from the same paper as the text, it is known as a <em>self-wrapper</em>.  Also refers to the outer covering on a <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>, usually made of <a href="#kraftpaper">kraft paper</a>, added to protect the <a href="#glossy">glossy</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> from damage in the post.  Compare with <a href="#dustjacket">dust jacket</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="writ"><b>writ</b></a>
</dt><dd>Historically, a command written in <a href="#epistle">epistolary</a>
form, addressed to one or more officials under the seal of an English
king, indicating that a specific action is to be performed or is
prohibited. In a more general sense, any formal written <a href="#document">document</a>
issued by a court or other judicial authority in the name of a
sovereign or state, forbidding or ordering the person(s) to whom it is
directed to perform a specific action (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Writ of Habeas Corpus</em></b>, known as the "Great Writ" in English common law).
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="writeoff"><b>write-off</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#bibitem">bibliographic item</a> or other piece of <a href="#library">library</a> property so badly <a href="#damaged">damaged</a> that it cannot be repaired, for which the cost of replacement cannot be <a href="#recover">recover</a>ed.  Also refers to a debt that cannot be recovered, for example, an <a href="#overdue">overdue</a> <a href="#fines">fine</a> that remains unpaid for so long that the library must clear it from the <a href="#circulation">circulation</a> record.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="writeonce"><b>write once</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#worm">WORM</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="writersmarket"><b><em>Writer's Market</em></b></a>
