</dt><dd>An <a href="#annual">annual</a> <a href="#refbook">reference</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a> that provides <a href="#directory">directory</a> listings for <a href="#literaryagent">literary agent</a>s, <a href="#book">book</a> <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s, <a href="#smallpress">small press</a>es, book producers, consumer <a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, <a href="#tradejournal">trade journal</a>s, <a href="#script">script</a>writing, <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> <a href="#syndicate">syndicate</a>s, writing contests and <a href="#literaryaward">literary award</a>s, and other resources for writers.  <a href="http://www.writersmarket.com/">Click here</a> to connect to <em>WritersMarket.com</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <em><a href="#lmp">Literary Market Place</a></em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="www1"><strong>WWW</strong></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#www"><b>W</b>orld <b>W</b>ide <b>W</b>eb</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="wysiwyg"><b>WYSIWYG</b></a>
</dt><dd><b>W</b>hat <b>Y</b>ou <b>S</b>ee <b>I</b>s <b>W</b>hat <b>Y</b>ou <b>G</b>et (pronounced "wizzy-wig"), an exact correspondence between <a href="#text">text</a> and/or <a href="#graphic">graphic</a>s as displayed on a computer screen and its appearance when <a href="#printing">printed</a>, difficult to achieve in reality because the <a href="#resolution">resolution</a> of <a href="#monitor">monitor</a> and printer rarely match.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#pagepreview">page preview</a>.
</dd></dl><p>
</p><hr>

<p>
</p><h1><font color="#000066" face="arial"><a name="XYZ">XYZ</a></font></h1>

<p>
</p><dl><dt><a name="xerography"><b>xerography</b></a>
</dt><dd>From the Greek <em>xeros</em> and <em>graphos</em>, meaning "dry writing."  A method of <a href="#reproduction">reproducing</a> <a href="#text">text</a> and/or images in which dry resinous toner transferred from an electrostatically charged plate is thermally adhered to a <a href="#sheet">sheet</a> of <a href="#paper">paper</a> or some other <a href="#copy">copy</a>ing surface inside a <a href="#photocopier">photocopier</a> (originally called a <em>xerox machine</em>).  The result is a <a href="#photocopy">photocopy</a> or <em>xerox copy</em>.  Xerography is a form of <a href="#reprography">reprography</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="xheight"><b>x-height</b></a>
</dt><dd>The mean height of the <a href="#lowercase">lowercase</a> <a href="#letter">letter</a>s of a <a href="#typeface">typeface</a> that have neither <a href="#ascender">ascender</a>s nor <a href="#descender">descender</a>s, sometimes used instead of <a href="#point">point</a> size as an indication of <a href="#typesize">type size</a>.  The x-height letters of the roman <a href="#alphabet">alphabet</a> are:  <b>a</b>, <b>c</b>, <b>e</b>, <b>m</b>, <b>n</b>, <b>o</b>, <b>r</b>, <b>s</b>, <b>u</b>, <b>v</b>, <b>w</b>, <b>x</b>, and <b>z</b>.  The tops and bottoms of some letters such as the "c" and "o" may extend slightly above the <a href="#meanline">mean line</a> and below the <a href="#baseline">base line</a>.  Also spelled <em>ex-height</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#primaryletter">primary letter</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="xml1"><b>XML</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#xml">E<b>X</b>tensible <b>M</b>arkup <b>L</b>anguage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="xr"><b>XR</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#returns">returns</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="xrated"><b>x-rated</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#motionpicture">motion picture</a> or <a href="#videorecording">videorecording</a> containing material considered suitable for <a href="#adult">adult</a>s only, usually because it contains material considered <a href="#pornography">pornographic</a>.  The <a href="#term">term</a> is also applied to <a href="#print">print</a> <a href="#publication">publication</a>s containing adult material (<a href="#magazine">magazine</a>s, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, etc.).  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#unexpurgated">unexpurgated</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="xref"><b>x-ref</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#crossref"> cross-reference</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="xvga"><b>XVGA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#svga">SVGA</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="xylography"><b>xylography</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#printing">Printing</a> done from blocks of wood, especially by the early process of wood <a href="#engraving">engraving</a>.  The results are known as <em>xylographica</em>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#blockbook">block book</a> and <a href="#woodcut">woodcut</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="ya"><b>YA</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#abbreviation">abbreviation</a> of <em>young adult</em>, an adolescent aged 12-18, usually in the ninth to twelfth grade.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#youngadult">young adult book</a> and <a href="#yaservices">young adult services</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="yabook"><b>YA book</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#youngadult">young adult book</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="yahoo"><b><em>Yahoo!</em></b></a>
</dt><dd><em><b>Y</b>et <b>a</b>nother <b>h</b>ierarchically <b>o</b>fficious <b>o</b>racle</em>, a worldwide <a href="#directory">directory</a> of <a href="#website">Web site</a>s developed in 1994 by two Stanford University engineering students to organize <a href="#www">Web</a> <a href="#content">content</a> in a <a href="#hierarchicalclass">hierarchical</a> system of <a href="#subject">subject</a> categories.  <b><em>Yahoo!</em></b> also provides other <a href="#www">Web</a>-based services (news, weather, travel service, <a href="#email">e-mail</a>, shopping, games, etc.).  It uses a smaller <a href="#database">database</a> than most other Web <a href="#searchengine">search engine</a>s, but <a href="#search">search</a>es in <b><em>Yahoo!</em></b> usually have higher <a href="#precision">precision</a> because the Web sites it lists are selected by human beings, rather than robot <a href="#software">software</a>.  <a href="http://www.yahoo.com/">Click here</a> to connect to <b><em>Yahoo!</em></b>  
<p>
Originally coined by Jonathan Swift in <b><em>Gulliver's Travels</em></b> (1726) to refer to an imaginary race of coarse, brutish creatures in human form, the <a href="#term">term</a> was later applied by Mark Twain to any boorish person.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="yalsa1"><b>YALSA</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#yalsa"><b>Y</b>oung <b>A</b>dult <b>L</b>ibrary <b>S</b>ervices <b>A</b>ssociation</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="yapp"><b>Yapp binding</b></a>
</dt><dd>A form of <a href="#limpbinding">limp</a> <a href="#leatherbound">leather binding</a> with rounded <a href="#corner">corner</a>s and <a href="#squares">squares</a> that overlap the edges of the <a href="#section">section</a>s, sometimes by as much as half the thickness of the <a href="#textblock">text block</a>, named after William Yapp who used it on pocket Bibles sold in England in the mid-19th century.  Geoffrey A. Glaister notes in <b><em>Encyclopedia of the Book</em></b> (Oak Knoll/British LIbrary, 1996) that a similar style of <a href="#binding">binding</a> with <a href="#tooling">tooled</a> edges was used during the 16th century.  Synonymous with <em>circuit edges</em>, <em>divinity circuit edges</em>, and <em>divinity edges</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="yearbook"><b>yearbook</b></a>
</dt><dd>An <a href="#annual">annual</a> documentary, historical, or memorial <a href="#compendium">compendium</a> of facts, <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, statistics, etc., about the events of the preceding year, often limited to a specific country, institution, <a href="#discipline">discipline</a>, or <a href="#subject">subject</a> (<em>example</em>:  <b><em>Supreme Court Yearbook</em></b> <a href="#publishing">published</a> by Congressional Quarterly).  Optional yearbooks are offered by some <a href="#publisher">publisher</a>s of general <a href="#encyclopedia">encyclopedia</a>s.  Most <a href="#library">libraries</a> place yearbooks on <a href="#continuationorder">continuation order</a> and shelve them in the <a href="#refcollection">reference collection</a>.  Yearbooks of historical significance may be stored in <a href="#archives">archives</a> or <a href="#specialcollections">special collections</a>.  Also spelled <em>year book</em>.  Compare with <a href="#annual">annual</a>.
<p>
Also refers to an annual high school or college <a href="#publication">publication</a> commemorating a particular school year or graduating class in <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>s, usually sold in <a href="#hardcover">hardcover</a> to seniors by advance <a href="#specialorder">special order</a> at the end of the school year.
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="yellowback"><b>yellowback</b></a>
</dt><dd>An inexpensive popular <a href="#novel">novel</a> <a href="#binding">bound</a> in a shiny yellow <a href="#paper">paper</a> or <a href="#board">board</a> <a href="#cover">cover</a> with a <a href="#picture">picture</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on the front, usually a <a href="#woodcut">woodcut</a> in three colors, a type of <a href="#publication">publication</a> that originated in England in the 1850's and was used until the end of the century for inexpensive <a href="#reprint">reprint</a> <a href="#edition">edition</a>s.  Also spelled <em>yellow back</em>.  Compare with <a href="#dimenovel">dime novel</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="yellowing"><b>yellowing</b></a>
</dt><dd>A color change that occurs in the <a href="#condition">condition</a> of certain grades of <a href="#paper">paper</a> with age, particularly those made from unbleached or groundwood <a href="#pulp">pulp</a>, one of the reasons most <a href="#library">libraries</a> convert <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a> <a href="#backfile">back file</a>s to <a href="#microfilm">microfilm</a> or <a href="#microfiche">microfiche</a>.  The problem can be averted in <a href="#library">libraries</a> by purchasing <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> <a href="#printing">printed</a> on <a href="#acidfree">acid-free</a> <a href="#permanentpaper">permanent paper</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#brittle">brittle</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="yellowpages"><b>yellow pages</b></a>
</dt><dd>The portion of a <a href="#telephonedirectory">telephone directory</a> or <a href="#tradedirectory">trade directory</a> following the <a href="#whitepages">white pages</a> in which the names, phone numbers, and mailing addresses of commercial enterprises are listed, usually <a href="#alphabetical">alphabetical</a>ly by <a href="#subject">subject</a> or in a <a href="#classified">classified</a> arrangement, so named because the section is <a href="#printing">printed</a> on yellow <a href="#paper">paper</a>.  Yellow pages are also available <a href="#online">online</a> (<em>example</em>:  <em><a href="http://www.superpages.com/">SuperPages.com</a></em> from Verizon) and for specific professions (<em><a href="http://www.librariansyellowpages.com/">Librarian's Yellow Pages</a></em>).  
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="yellowpress"><b>yellow press</b></a>
</dt><dd>A popular name for <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>s and <a href="#periodical">periodical</a>s of the early 20th century that <a href="#publishing">published</a> news stories of a vulgarly sensational nature, comparable to the modern <a href="#tabloid">tabloid</a>.  Synonymous with <a href="#gutterpress">gutter press</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="youngadult"><b>young adult book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> intended to be read and enjoyed by adolescents 12 to 18 years of age.  Also refers to a book intended for <a href="#adult">adult</a>s, but considered suitable by <a href="#review">review</a>ers and <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s for mature ninth to twelfth grade <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> usually maintain a separate section of young adult literature managed by a librarian who specializes in <a href="#yaservices">YA services</a>, including <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>.  Compare with <a href="#childrensbook">children's book</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#yalsa">Young Adult Library Services Association</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="yalsa"><b>Young Adult Library Services Association (YALSA)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A division of the <a href="#ala">American Library Association</a> founded in 1930, <b>YALSA</b> has a membership of <a href="#librarian">librarian</a>s responsible for evaluating and <a href="#selection">selecting</a> <a href="#book">book</a>s and <a href="#nonprint">nonprint</a> <a href="#libmaterials">materials</a> for <a href="#youngadult">young adult</a>s (age 12 to 18) and for promoting and strengthening <a href="#library">library</a> <a href="#yaservices">services</a> for young adult <a href="#reader">reader</a>s.  <b>YALSA</b> <a href="#publishing">publishes</a> the <a href="#semiannual">semiannual</a> <a href="#journal">journal</a> <em>Young Adult Library Services</em>.  <a href="http://www.ala.org/yalsa/">Click here</a> to connect to the <b>YALSA</b> <a href="#homepage">homepage</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="yaservices"><b>young adult services</b></a>
</dt><dd><a href="#library">Library</a> services intended specifically for adolescent <a href="#patron">patron</a>s (ninth through twelfth graders), including <a href="#collecdevel">collection development</a>, programming, and <a href="#readersadvisory">readers' advisory</a>.  <a href="#publiclibrary">Public libraries</a> usually have a room or section devoted specifically to <a href="#youngadult">young adult material</a>s, managed by a <a href="#librarian">librarian</a> who <a href="#specialization">specializes</a> in providing services for this age group.  Compare with <a href="#adultservices">adult services</a> and <a href="#childrensservices">children's services</a>.  <b><em>See also</em></b>:  <a href="#yalsa">Young Adult Library Services Association</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="z3950"><b>Z39.50</b></a>
</dt><dd>The <a href="#osi">OSI</a> <a href="#clientserver">client-server</a> <a href="#protocol">protocol</a> established as a <a href="#standards">standard</a> by the <a href="#niso">National Information Standards Organization</a> (NISO), which allows computer users to <a href="#query">query</a> a remote <a href="#inforetrieval">information retrieval</a> system using the <a href="#software">software</a> of their local system and receive results in the <a href="#format">format</a> of the local system.  <a href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/z3950/agency/">Click here</a> to connect to the <a href="#webpage">Web page</a> on <b>Z39.50</b> maintained by the Network Development and MARC Standards Office of the <a href="#lc">Library of Congress</a>.   
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="zbb"><b>zero-base budget (ZBB)</b></a>
</dt><dd>A financial plan that starts from zero at the beginning of each new <a href="#budget">budget</a>
cycle, with no assumptions carried over from previous experience. Under
this budgeting method, every expense must be justified.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="zerogrowth"><b>zero growth</b></a>
</dt><dd><b><em>See</em></b>:  <a href="#steadystate">steady state</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="zigzag"><b>zig-zag book</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#book">book</a> made by folding a continuous strip of <a href="#paper">paper</a> backward and forward accordion-style.  When the <a href="#page">page</a>s are <a href="#sewing">sewn</a> at the <a href="#backfold">back fold</a>, the strip is <a href="#printing">printed</a> on one side only.  When both sides are printed, the folds are left unsewn to allow the <a href="#volume">volume</a> to be opened to its full length.  This form of book is called an <a href="#orihon">orihon</a> when made from a <a href="#manuscript">manuscript</a> or <a href="#printing">printed</a> <a href="#document">document</a> originally produced as a <a href="#roll">roll</a>.  Compare with <a href="#concertina">concertina</a>. 
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="zine"><b>zine</b></a>
</dt><dd>Derived from "fanzine" (a <a href="#contraction">contraction</a> of "fan magazine"), pronounced "zeen."  The <a href="#term">term</a> came into use during the 1980s to refer to a small, low-<a href="#circulation">circulation</a> <a href="#magazine">magazine</a> or <a href="#newspaper">newspaper</a>, <a href="#selfpublishing">self-published</a> out of passion for the <a href="#subject">subject</a> rather than for personal gain, usually produced with the aid of <a href="#desktop">desktop publishing</a> <a href="#software">software</a> and high-quality <a href="#photocopier">photocopy machine</a>s.  
<p>
Zines represent the convergence of amateur <a href="#publishing">publishing</a> hobbyists, high school <a href="#underground">underground</a> newspapers, the literary <a href="#smallpress">small press</a>, political radicalism, and do-it-yourself popular culture.  They are usually not available by <a href="#subscription">subscription</a>, often appear <a href="#irregular">irregular</a>ly or infrequently, and may have a lifetime of only one or two <a href="#issue">issue</a>s.  Some are available <a href="#online">online</a> via the <a href="#www">World Wide Web</a>.  Selected zines are evaluated in the <a href="#refserial">reference serial</a> <em><a href="#magazinesfor">Magazines for Libraries</a></em>.  The Minneapolis Community and Technical College Library provides <a href="#online">online</a> <a href="#indexing">indexing</a> of zines in its <em><a href="http://db.mctc.mnscu.edu/zines/">MCTC Zines Catalog</a></em>. 
</p><p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="zip"><b>zip</b></a>
</dt><dd>To compress a <a href="#data">data</a> <a href="#file">file</a> using PKZIP <a href="#software">software</a> or some other <a href="#utility">utility</a> capable of <a href="#datacompression">compressing data</a> into PKZIP <a href="#format">format</a>.  When such a file is restored to an uncompressed format, it is said to have been <em>unzipped</em>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="zipdisk"><b>Zip disk</b></a>
</dt><dd>A 3.5-inch removable <a href="#disk">disk</a> cartridge developed by Iomega, capable of storing 100<a href="#byte">MB</a> or more of <a href="#data">data</a> (much more than a standard <a href="#floppydisk">floppy disk</a>) at relatively low cost.  A special <a href="#zipdrive">Zip drive</a> must be installed on a <a href="#microcomputer">microcomputer</a> to allow a Zip <a href="#disk">disk</a> to be used.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="zipdrive"><b>Zip drive</b></a>
</dt><dd>A <a href="#diskdrive">disk drive</a> developed by Iomega that uses a 3.5-inch removable <a href="#zipdisk">Zip disk</a> capable of storing 100<a href="#byte">MB</a> or more of <a href="#data">data</a> at relatively low cost, used for storing very large <a href="#file">file</a>s and collections of files.  The drive usually comes with <a href="#software">software</a> that catalogs the <a href="#contents">contents</a> of the <a href="#disk">disk</a> and provides file <a href="#security">security</a>.
<p>
</p></dd><dt><a name="zoom"><b>zoom</b></a>
</dt><dd>In <a href="#photograph">photograph</a>y, to alter the size of an image from a stationary camera position without changing perspective by using a <em>zoom lens</em> to increase or decrease the focal length.  In cinematography, this type of lens appears to make the camera advance toward the <a href="#subject">subject</a> when <em>zooming in</em>, or retreat from it when <em>zooming out</em>.  
<p>
In <a href="#wordprocessing">word processing</a> <a href="#software">software</a>, a feature that allows the user to <a href="#enlargement">enlarge</a> or <a href="#reduction">reduce</a> the size of a <a href="#page">page</a> displayed on the screen, usually by a fixed percentage, or in small increments.  Also, a feature on some <a href="#photocopier">photocopy machine</a>s that allows the user to specifiy the extent to which an <a href="#original">original</a> will be <a href="#enlargement">enlarged</a> or <a href="#reduction">reduced</a> in size.
</p></dd></dl><p>
